James flinches, vividly remembering the feel of the wolf under his feet.

‚ÄúHow long until he gets out?‚Äù Sirius asks, when James can‚Äôt quite manage to get his tongue working again.

‚ÄúAt least not until tonight‚ÄîI‚Äôd like to keep him until tomorrow morning but I think he might bite my head off if I suggest it.‚Äù There‚Äôs a beat of silence before she breaks it by nodding toward his bed. ‚ÄúGo on, see if you can get him to eat something. But be gentle with him this morning.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes m‚Äôam,‚Äù Sirius gives her a salute, but the grin on his face feels forced.

James is only a little surprised when they pull back the curtain and find Remus sitting upright in bed, an expectant look on his face. Clearly he‚Äôd been waiting for them‚Äîno doubt pretending to be asleep so Pomfrey wouldn‚Äôt fuss.

He looks pale and young in his blue pyjamas. There are dark rings under his eyes, and new scrapes across his face.

‚ÄúHey Remus,‚Äù Peter manages to sound casual as he pulls up a chair. James does the same on his other side while Sirius sits at the foot of the bed.

‚ÄúGot all your favourites,‚Äù Sirius lowers the plate onto Remus‚Äôs lap but he barely looks at it.

‚ÄúNot hungry,‚Äù he mumbles, putting onto the bedside table. The three of them exchange a quick glance.

‚ÄúCome on Remus,‚Äù Peter nudges, gripping his own plate a little too tightly. ‚ÄúNot even the bacon?‚Äù

Remus only shakes his head‚Äîthe gesture is sharp, pointed. He turns to James. ‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù

James looks back at him and then down at his plate, pushing his eggs around for a moment, just to buy him some time. ‚ÄúNothing really‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJames.‚Äù

James grimaces, forcing himself to look up again. ‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶‚Äù he starts, swallowing, his throat suddenly feels like sandpaper. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not really sure, to be honest.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour hands,‚Äù Remus is practically whispering now, eyes the size of James‚Äôs plate. ‚ÄúYour hands were covered in blood. So I need you to tell me what happened. I need you to tell me the truth. And I need you to tell me now.‚Äù There is no arguing with that tone of voice.

James nods, exhaling tightly. ‚ÄúYeah, okay Moony,‚Äù he puts his own breakfast aside, running a hand through his hair‚Äînervous tick. ‚ÄúListen, it‚Äôs like Pete said. You‚Äîyou got a bit angry.‚Äù

Remus visibly swallows. ‚ÄúAngry,‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúYou said I didn‚Äôt hurt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt,‚Äù he can‚Äôt think of any way to make this better. To keep Remus from bleeding over this. ‚ÄúYou‚Äîit‚Äî‚Äú his eyes flick nervously to Sirius and then back. That‚Äôs enough for Remus though. He should have known better.

Remus whips his head around, somehow growing paler. ‚ÄúI hurt you?‚Äù

Sirius smiles. Too big and too bright, but god James loves him for trying. ‚ÄúBarely. No offence Moony, but you‚Äôre a bit of a shit werewolf.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo be fair, he does have a disadvantage,‚Äù James chimes in.

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúHow d‚Äôyou figure that?‚Äù

‚ÄúHard to be afraid of a bloke once you know how he folds his pants.‚Äù

Sirius barks so loud that James half expects him to turn back into Padfoot. ‚ÄúQuite right,‚Äù he wheezes.

‚ÄúI hurt you?‚Äù Remus‚Äôs voice cuts through the room like a sharp knife. All brevity sucked out of the air. The look of horror hasn‚Äôt left his face, his eyes pleading.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù Sirius says eventually, surprisingly soft. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm alright, look,‚Äù he spreads his arms out wide, managing a grin.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú but the words don‚Äôt quite make it out of Remus‚Äôs mouth, he opens it and closes it several times before giving up.

James can see the small hitches in his shoulders, like his breath is getting caught in his throat. It reminds him of the way he gets before his skin splits open and the wolf slides out.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Sirius moves so that he‚Äôs right in front of him, hands on his shoulders. ‚ÄúRemus‚ÄîRemus? Look at me okay? Breathe with me, in and out.‚Äù Sirius inhales slowly, counts to three and then exhales. ‚ÄúCome on Moons,‚Äù his eyes are intent, never wavering. ‚ÄúWith me okay? In,‚Äù one, two three. ‚ÄúOut,‚Äù one two three. Slowly, Remus‚Äôs breaths get longer, until eventually he matches Sirius exactly. None of them speak for a while, just listening to each other breathe.

‚ÄúYou alright?‚Äù Sirius asks eventually, breaking them all out of whatever trance they‚Äôd fallen into, hands still on Remus‚Äôs shoulders.

Remus nods. ‚ÄúFuck Sirius, I‚Äôm so‚ÄîI‚Äôm so sorry. I don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Sirius holds up one of his hands to stop him. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to apologize. Really, I mean it, cross my heart and hope James dies.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù

Sirius smirks at him over Remus‚Äôs head as the blond boy lets out a breath that might be close to a laugh.

‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù

But Remus doesn‚Äôt answer right away, and James sees his hands fisted in the sheets, nails digging into his palms.

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI mean it, I‚Äôm fine. Aren‚Äôt I Prongs?‚Äù

‚ÄúBit of a prat, but other than that, yeah, tip-top,‚Äù James grins in a way that he hopes betrays none of the anxiety still swirling in his chest.

‚ÄúSee?‚Äù Sirius says emphatically. ‚ÄúPeter agrees too, don‚Äôt you Pete?‚Äù

Peter nods vigorously. ‚ÄúYup. Uh-huh. Definitely a prat.‚Äù

Sirius reaches over to swot his head, but Peter is too fast, snickering as he ducks out of the way.

Remus is shaking his head, scrubbing at his face with his hands. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre all idiots,‚Äù but his voice sounds thick and not nearly as biting as he, no doubt, intends it to.

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt argue with that,‚Äù Sirius says.

‚ÄúIt is a very accurate assessment,‚Äù James agrees.

Remus drops his hands, sniffling a little even though his eyes are dry. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù

Remus just nods, looking incredibly tired as he drops back against his pillows.

‚ÄúExcellent,‚Äù Sirius beams, trying too hard. James hopes that Remus is too tired to notice, but he doubts it. ‚ÄúNow we can get back to breakfast!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm really not‚Äî‚Äú but the plate of food has already been levitated from the bedside table back to Remus‚Äôs lap. He rolls his eyes but doesn‚Äôt bother fighting it, picking rather unenthusiastically at a piece of toast.

The pause in conversation allows James to realize how tired he himself is, nearly choking on his eggs as he tries to swallow and yawn at the same time. Judging by the light coming in through the windows they haven‚Äôt got much time before transfiguration and James thinks again about skipping.

‚ÄúDo you reckon it was maybe because of our little tiff in the dorm room?‚Äù Sirius says suddenly, causing everyone to start.

He isn‚Äôt looking at them, eyes very determinedly on his breakfast, tone very determinedly casual. James groans internally. He really wants to do this now? Now? They only just managed to get Remus to let up on himself.

‚ÄúDo I‚Äîwhat?‚Äù Remus stutters, dropping the piece of bacon that had been on its way to his mouth.

Sirius shrugs, chewing thoughtfully. ‚ÄúI just wondered, y‚Äôknow, if maybe you were hacked off at me in Moony form cause you were hacked off at me in Remus form?‚Äù

Remus blinks and James fights the urge to smack the back of Sirius‚Äôs head.

‚ÄúI‚ÄîI‚Äôm not mad at you Sirius,‚Äù Remus says finally, carefully.

‚ÄúBut you were a bit, yeah? About me being too protective or whatever,‚Äù he waves his hands about flippantly. ‚ÄúI just wonder if that‚Äôs why Moony was pissed at me too?‚Äù

Something flickers across Remus‚Äôs face for just a second before he shuts it down. He‚Äôs good at that, bottling things up. James probably would have missed it except he‚Äôs seen him make that exact expression before‚Äîin the common room, before they‚Äôd walked down to the infirmary. Just...unbearable sadness.

It takes James‚Äôs brain a second.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus says slowly. ‚ÄúYeah maybe.‚Äù

But then‚Ä¶

‚ÄúYou reckon?‚Äù

Remus nods. ‚ÄúYeah, must be. But I‚Äôm not‚ÄîI wasn‚Äôt really‚Äî‚Äú

James looks between his two friends.

Remus sighs, pinching the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúWhat I‚Äôm trying to say, is I‚Äôm not mad. Not anymore, okay?‚Äù

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúGood. That‚Äôs good.‚Äù

It makes sense, James thinks pityingly, as he watches his friend turn back to his breakfast, unsure of how he didn‚Äôt see it before. Of course, Remus was angry.

He fancies Mary.

Chapter End Notes

Hey-o! Thank you guys so much for the commented recs on the last chapter, it was very much appreciated!

I wish I was the type of person who could be like "This fic will update on __ day" but I would be lying to you all because I keep no schedules. But hopefully frequently, I have plans!

A lot happens in this chapter so I'd love to know what you think!

Chapter 3

Chapter Summary

James is just trying his best - an accurate summary of this whole fic if I'm being honest.

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

James feels like he knows what muggles mean when they say the word ‚Äúmagic.‚Äù They don‚Äôt mean spells or wands or cauldrons‚Äîwell, okay, yes, sometimes they do. But in those moments when the word slips out of them, all quiet and reverent, like they can‚Äôt help it, that‚Äôs something different. James knows that, because it‚Äôs how he feels when he‚Äôs flying.

Magic.

The sun is only just rising above the horizon, and even in his leather playing gloves James‚Äôs hands are still half-frozen to his broom. The warm dawn light reaches across the Great Lake towards him like fingers, the air crisp and sweet the way it only gets in the fall.

‚ÄúMother fuc‚Äî‚Äú

James misses the rest of the curse as he snatches the quaffle out of Macdonald‚Äôs hands and zips off down the pitch towards the opposite goal. Prewett and Abbott put up a good defence but James is in top form this morning. They can barely touch him.

He grins as he watches the ball sail through the middle hoop, out of breath in the best way.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre obsessed, you know that?‚Äù

James pulls his broom around to meet Sirius who‚Äôs floating lazily behind him, beaters‚Äôs club across his shoulders, arms resting on top‚Äîlike he can‚Äôt be bothered.

‚ÄúPlease, you love it as much as I do,‚Äù James tries and fails to push the sweaty hair out of his face.

‚ÄúNot at seven in the morning I don‚Äôt, we don‚Äôt even have anyone to impress,‚Äù he nods towards the empty stands.

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúLike you aren‚Äôt showing off for Macdonald.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll have you know Mary and my‚Äôs relationship has far surpassed such childish games.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh huh.‚Äù

Sirius smirks. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry Jamie, one day you‚Äôll meet a girl with eyesight as bad as yours and then you‚Äôll know what I‚Äôm talking about.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù he tries to punch Sirius's shoulder but the prat swerves out of the way, cackling. ‚ÄúFor your information there are plenty of girls who think I'm well fit.‚Äú

"Really?" Sirius asks, amused. "You'll have to introduce me to them sometime."

"Okay, you know what-"

‚ÄúBLACK, POTTER, STOP FLIRTING AND GET YOUR ASSES DOWN HERE!‚Äù

They both peer over their brooms at the ground where a very small, and very angry looking Frank Longbottom is glaring up at them. Well, they assume he‚Äôs glaring, the details of his face are a little blurry at this height.

‚ÄúYou think he wants use to go down there?‚Äù Sirius asks lightly.

‚ÄúHard to tell,‚Äù James muses, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs not being very clear.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo obtuse, our Frank.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlways speaking in riddles.‚Äù

‚ÄúThough,‚Äù Sirius adds thoughtfully, looking around. ‚ÄúIt does appear that everyone else has gone.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd if they all jumped off a cliff would you do it too?‚Äù James does his best impression of his mother and is glad to see Sirius struggling to hold it together.

‚ÄúMight,‚Äù he shrugs, ‚Äúdepends on the day, really.‚Äù

‚ÄúI WILL KICK YOU BOTH OFF THIS TEAM SO HELP ME GOD.‚Äù

Sirius lets out a dramatic sigh. ‚ÄúThat really can‚Äôt be good for him.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd he has such a lovely singing voice,‚Äù James agrees. ‚ÄúI suppose we could go down.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor his sake.‚Äù

James nods in agreement, meeting Sirius‚Äôs eye and grinning. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre nothing if not considerate.‚Äù

Frank makes a point of not looking or speaking to either of them when they finally land down on the pitch, choosing, instead, to aggressively gather the rest of the straying team back together. They form a rather grumbly half-circle around him.

‚ÄúPrewett‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJust call me Alice, Frank. Honestly, we‚Äôve been dating for two years.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot on the pitch Prewett.‚Äù

Alice arches her brow. ‚ÄúOh really? If memory serves, we were dating on the pitch last Friday night.‚Äù

Sirius snorts, earning him a pointed glare from a very red faced Frank. ‚ÄúRight. Fine. Pre‚ÄîAlice.‚Äù

She smiles brightly at him.

‚ÄúYour defence is weak, you and Abbott are leaving the centre wide open. Stop making the first move, you gotta play hard to get with your chasers. And communicate with each other.‚Äù

‚ÄúAye aye captain, no more fucking the chasers on the first date.‚Äù

Frank looks in danger of exploding.

‚ÄúGod,‚Äù Sirius whispers to James. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm in love.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs taken Black,‚Äù Frank snaps at him, running a hand over his very flustered face. ‚ÄúSo don‚Äôt even think about it.‚Äù

Alice winks at Sirius across the circle and Sirius fake swoons into James‚Äôs arms. "Ugh, you're heavy," James huffs, pushing a laughing Sirius back to his feet.

‚ÄúMacdonald,‚Äù Frank redirects his focus, very determinedly not looking at either Sirius or Alice, ‚Äúyou've gotta make sure not to get too cocky. You thought you were home free and you stopped watching your sides. Potter snatched that quaffle off of you practically mid-goal.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, yeah, I‚Äôd like to see him try it when I‚Äôm not half-asleep on my broom.‚Äù

‚ÄúName the time and place Macdonald,‚Äù James grins, earning him a rude hand gesture in return.

‚ÄúMcKinnon, Black, that was a good practice, but Sirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOh, he gets a first name,‚Äù Alice says, mockingly.

‚ÄúYeah well, you should have seen the things we did on the pitch last Friday,‚Äù Sirius waggles his eyebrows suggestively and Alice looks like someone‚Äôs just told her it‚Äôs Christmas morning.

‚ÄúEnough,‚Äù Frank interjects quickly, holding his hands out like he can shove the innuendos back down their throats. The pair of them are far too pleased with themselves. ‚ÄúBlack,‚Äù Frank says through clenched teeth, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt drop your club, I want you in a prepared position at all times, understood?‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it captain, no more fucking the chasers on the first date,‚Äù he winks at Mary.

Frank truly looks like he‚Äôs on the verge of some kind of breakdown. ‚ÄúForget it, I give up, you lot are a bunch of heathens.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw, but Frank,‚Äù Marlene says cutely, batting her lashes and swinging her shoulders, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre your heathens.‚Äù

He gives her a flat stare. ‚ÄúGet out of here. All of you. But be back tomorrow, and be on bloody time!‚Äù This last comment is directed specifically at Sirius who gives Frank a salute as James pulls him towards the changerooms before he can get himself murdered.

¬†

Twenty minutes, and several towel whippings later, James and Sirius are making their way back up to the castle, Mary and Marlene promising to catch up with them later. They always take ages getting ready after practice, but Sirius isn't much better. James reckons he‚Äôd still be standing in front of the mirror coiffing his hair if it weren‚Äôt for him.

‚ÄúMerlin, did you swallow a wild animal or something?‚Äù Sirius laughs, as James‚Äôs stomach lets out a particularly obscene growl.

‚ÄúListen, it‚Äôs not my fault Frank has us running drills before the house elves are up.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry," Sirius looks far too amused, "is James Fleamont Potter actually complaining about quidditch practice?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo I'm not, you twat," giving Sirius a shove which only seems to delight him more. There's no winning with him. There really isn't. "But I am saying that we need to remember to raid the kitchens tonight so I can have some fuel in the morning.‚Äù

Sirius makes an exaggerated retching noise. ‚ÄúFuel? Did you just call food FUEL? Mate, you‚Äôve been spending too much time with Frank. You little quidditch psycho.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh shut it,‚Äù James knocks his shoulder into Sirius who laughs, the noise echoing around them as they walk into the still sleepy castle.

‚ÄúListen, I‚Äôll catch up with you later, yeah?‚Äù Sirius claps him on the back as he starts to pull away.

‚ÄúCatch up with me later? What are you ditching me to shag Macdonald already? It‚Äôs not even noon!‚Äù

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúI want you to know, that if Mary was up for it, I one hundred percent would do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo bloody loyalty,‚Äù James grumbles, only half joking.

‚ÄúBut, as it happens,‚Äù Sirius talks over his complaining. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm actually posting a letter.‚Äù

That catches James‚Äôs attention. With all the marauders at Hogwarts and Sirius‚Äôs family being‚Ä¶well, his family, Sirius doesn‚Äôt get much post.

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù James asks, desperate to pry but doing his best not to.

Sirius rolls his eyes, still smiling. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs to my uncle you nosey bugger.‚Äù That clarifies exactly nothing, and Sirius must realize it because after a brief pause he pushes on, a little more sincere now. ‚ÄúMy uncle Alphard, he wrote me first week back. I guess he heard through the family gossip network about my‚Ä¶departure.‚Äù

James nods slowly, not entirely clear on what kind of story this is going to turn out to be. Besides, years of knowing Sirius has taught him when to push and when to wait.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve only met him a few times, nice guy, quiet,‚Äù he trails off for a moment, fingers fiddling with the sleeve of his robes. ‚ÄúAnyway he‚Äîhe said he wanted to reach out. Make sure I was okay, said he was proud of me.‚Äù Sirius ducks his head a bit, embarrassed. He can boast and brag all day, but give him a genuine compliment and he has no idea how to handle it.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Ä¶‚Äù James searches for the words, ‚Äúnice and‚Ä¶unexpected.‚Äù

Sirius laughs, hand rubbing at the back of his neck. ‚ÄúYeah, tell me about it. Anyway, I‚Äôve kinda been writing to him a bit. It‚Äînot that I minded, cutting them off, I didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù James says quickly, trying to soothe the defensive tone in Sirius‚Äôs voice.

His friend nods, expression thoughtful, eyes not quite meeting James‚Äôs stare. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äîit‚Äôs comforting I guess, knowing not every member of my family wants me dead,‚Äù he tries for brevity and fails, but James offers him a weak smile anyway.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good Pads, I‚Äôm happy for you.‚Äù

Sirius looks up finally. ‚ÄúYeah‚Äîit‚Äîyeah, thanks. He‚Äôs got wicked taste in music too, for an old man. Says he‚Äôs gonna send me some muggle records.‚Äù

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúYour uncle listens to muggle music?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know right? What a trip. I think he‚Äôs secretly a bit of a rebel.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo shit.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment of awkward silence before Sirius nods, seemingly to himself. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm gonna‚Ä¶‚Äù he starts walking away backwards, gesturing in the direction of the owlery.

‚ÄúYeah, right, see you later then.‚Äù

He watches his best friend disappear up the stairs, feeling a little dazed by the whole conversation. He‚Äôs happy for Sirius, he is. But he‚Äôs also‚Ä¶worried. The Blacks are, well, unpredictable at the best of times. And Sirius barely even knows this guy. What if he turns out to be as bad as the rest of them? What if he‚Äôs worse?

They‚Äôre not all bad, says the annoying voice in the back of his head, Regulus is‚Äî

He stops that thought in its tracks, a little irritated with himself for having it in the first place. One moderately okay conversation doesn‚Äôt change anything. Doesn‚Äôt all of a sudden make Regulus a good person.

But what did he do to make you think he was so bad in the first place?

That‚Äôs it.

James has had enough of talking to himself. He does not have to engage with the stupid thoughts in his stupid head if he doesn‚Äôt want to. He starts walking determinedly in the direction of the great hall. After all, nothing shuts up introspection quite like bacon.

¬†

‚ÄúJesus do they have to‚Äî‚Äú Remus cuts himself off, grumbling something else that James doesn‚Äôt quite catch.

He looks up, first at Moony, who is currently staring down at the parchment in front of him like it just insulted his mother, and then over at the stacks where Sirius is devouring Mary‚Äôs face.

James squints, tilting his head slightly. ‚ÄúD'you think they can breathe like that?‚Äù

Remus makes an indignant noise that reminds James of why he stopped doing his Ancient Ruins readings in the first place. He looks back at his friend pityingly. Typical of Sirius to go for the bird Remus fancies and then insist on snogging her in front of him on a near daily basis.

‚ÄúListen, Moony,‚Äù he pauses, checking to make sure there‚Äôs no one around and then lowering his voice. ‚ÄúIf you just tell Sirius that, you know, if you tell him how you feel‚Äî‚Äú

Remus‚Äôs head pops up so quickly that James quite literally chokes on his words.

‚ÄúW-what did you just say?‚Äù Remus‚Äôs eyes are big with the kind of fear that usually only makes an appearance around the full moon.

‚ÄúWoah, calm down. It‚Äôs not a big deal,‚Äù for whatever reason this does not seem to help matters. ‚ÄúI was just saying‚ÄîI just think, if you tell him, you know, the truth, he‚Äôll quit shoving it down your throat.‚Äù

He knows that Remus is a private person but this, this seems‚ÄîI mean, James knows he‚Äôs a bloody werewolf for fuck's sake. Why is he getting so jumpy about a crush?

‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt mind Moons, honestly, it‚Äôs not like you can help it. Besides, Pads and Mary are about the two most casual people I know, it‚Äôs not like this means you‚Äôre never going to get a chance to shoot your shot‚Ä¶‚Äù James trails off as it becomes apparent that nothing he is saying is doing anything to dampen the fear in Remus‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúH-how do you, how do you know?‚Äù

James blinks, thoroughly regretting this entire conversation. ‚ÄúUh‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know, just the way you looked, in the common room.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn the common room?‚Äù Remus repeats, voice fragile.

‚ÄúYeah, on the full moon.‚Äù

Remus winces, that night is still a sore subject. Remus has mentioned once or twice that he thinks the marauders should sit out the next one, just to be safe. This idea has been unanimously shot down, of course.

‚ÄúRemus, it‚Äôs really not‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù his voice is strained and instantly shuts James up. ‚ÄúPlease, please don‚Äôt tell him.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm asking you as my friend, just‚Äîjust please, please, please, please.‚Äù

It hurts, Remus‚Äôs voice hurts, and James has no idea why. This isn‚Äôt at all how he thought this conversation would go. Part of him aches that this is how Remus feels about this‚Äîhow Remus feels full stop. In the dark. On his own. Always hiding. And he wants him to know that he doesn‚Äôt have to, that he‚Äôs been told his whole life to keep things behind closed doors but it doesn‚Äôt have to be that way.

But Remus just keeps looking at him like he‚Äôs getting ready to bolt and even James has the good sense to know that this is not the time for that conversation.

‚ÄúYeah Remus, I promise, of course.‚Äù

Remus swallows with difficulty, his next exhale shaky. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt look at James, instead he starts packing up his books.

‚ÄúHey wait, Moons, you don‚Äôt have to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù he says, stuffing parchment messily into the canvas bag over his shoulder. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just tired,‚Äù he turns away, nearly bulldozing into Marlene in his rush to escape.

James sighs, leaning back in his chair and passing a hand over his face. ‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses under his breath.

‚ÄúHe was sure in a rush,‚Äù Marlene slides into Remus‚Äôs now vacant seat across from him.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James says, shooting a weary look at the door. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs possible I just said the wrong thing.‚Äù

Marlene gasps. ‚ÄúWhat? You? James Potter, the king of tact?‚Äù

‚ÄúHar, har, har. Hilarious.‚Äù

She smiles. ‚ÄúI am, thanks for noticing.‚Äù

James lets out a breath that‚Äôs almost a laugh, dropping his gaze back down to his Ruins homework. He feels like he ought to go after Remus but he‚Äôs not entirely sure that he knows how to make this better. Or even that he knows what happened in the first place.

‚ÄúGosh, they‚Äôre really going at it aren‚Äôt they?‚Äù

James looks up. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äîoh,‚Äù he follows her gaze to the still very much entangled Mary and Sirius. ‚ÄúYeah well, you know them. Are they really here if no one‚Äôs watching?‚Äù

Marlene snorts. ‚ÄúTrue,‚Äù her gaze comes back to him and it looks like all kinds of trouble. ‚ÄúSpeaking of embarrassing displays of affection.‚Äù

‚ÄúUm, is that what we were talking about?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve noticed you‚Äôve quit making a spectacle out of yourself in front of Lily recently.‚Äù

James lets out an irritated huff, scowling at her across the table. ‚ÄúI wish people would stop bringing that up, it‚Äôs not a big deal.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs kind of a big deal.‚Äù

‚ÄúBesides,‚Äù James presses on, ‚Äúit‚Äôs no ones business.‚Äù

Marlene laughs. ‚ÄúOh come on James, you‚Äôve made this everyone's business.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave not.‚Äù

She sends him a flat look but he doesn‚Äôt budge, leaning back in his chair and crossing his arms over his chest.

‚ÄúReally? What about in third year when you charmed all the pumpkins at the Halloween feast to sing love ballads to her?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was‚ÄîI‚Äîokay, maybe that was a little public. But I only did it once.‚Äù

She raises a disbelieving eyebrow. ‚ÄúThere was also second year, when you made a pink cloud follow her around all Valentine's Day raining petals.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAnd last year, when you filled the Gryffindor common room with about a thousand lilies before serenading her in front of everyone.‚Äù

James bites down on the inside of his cheek as he feels the heat rising in his face.

‚ÄúOr in‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYes okay, I get it, thank you!‚Äù James cuts her off, shoving an aggravated hand through his hair. Marlene looks at him smugly from across the table.

‚ÄúI was a right git.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she nods, too amused for James‚Äôs liking, ‚Äúyou were.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to be‚Äî‚Äú he struggles for a minute, ‚Äúbetter.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good,‚Äù a moment passes before she leans forward across the table, ‚ÄúSo who is she then?‚Äù

James blinks. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs who?‚Äù

Marlene rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúThe girl that‚Äôs distracted you from Lily.‚Äù

James is genuinely at a loss for words‚Äîwhich rarely happens. He splutters for a moment, gawking at her. ‚ÄúI‚Äîthere‚Äôs no girl,‚Äù and then, realizing what he‚Äôs just said, back pedals. ‚ÄúI mean, there have been girls, obviously.‚Äù

‚ÄúObviously,‚Äù Marlene repeats mockingly. James chooses to ignore her.

‚ÄúBut there‚Äôs no other girl,‚Äù he sighs, collapsing a little. ‚ÄúJust Evans.‚Äù There will always be Lily Evans.

Marlene eyes him curiously for a minute before shaking her head. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt buy it.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt buy what?‚Äù

She waves her hand. ‚ÄúYou, James Potter, are a romantic. There is no way you would just give up on Lily without someone else to expend your woo-ing energy on.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, first off, who said anything about giving up on Lily? I have not given up. Secondly, woo-ing energy?" James wrinkles his nose. "Really McKinnon?‚Äù

She laughs, it‚Äôs a nice sound, Marlene‚Äôs laugh, bright and warm. The kind that makes you feel like you‚Äôre exactly where you‚Äôre supposed to be. ‚ÄúAlright, alright not my best, but the point still stands.‚Äù

James looks at her flatly. ‚ÄúOh sorry, you had a point?‚Äù

But the mischief hasn‚Äôt left her eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll figure it out, you know.‚Äù

James sighs dramatically. ‚ÄúYeah well, when you do let me know. I‚Äôd really like to be aware of who I‚Äôm wooing.‚Äù

She opens her mouth to speak when another voice cuts her off:

‚ÄúMar?‚Äù

James feels his heart flip. He always does when she‚Äôs close, has since he was eleven. You‚Äôd think he‚Äôd get used to it at some point, or build up some kind of immunity. But it‚Äôs always the same‚Äîalways feels like the first time‚Äîlike he‚Äôs never going to remember how to breathe again.

‚ÄúReady to go?‚Äù Lily stops beside Marlene‚Äôs chair, barely looking at James.

Which is okay. Completely fine. James bites down on his tongue and forces himself to turn back to his coursework, holding in the numerous desperate and embarrassing things he wants to say.

Like, you‚Äôre beautiful.

So beautiful I can‚Äôt stand it.

You make me feel too big for my skin.

Like staring into the sun.

You‚Äôre melting my wings.

He has no desire to see what Marlene‚Äôs expression is doing right now. Some mate she is, couldn‚Äôt even give him a heads up that she was waiting for Lily.

‚ÄúPotter?‚Äù

James blinks at the sound of his name being spoken by Lily‚Äôs voice.

Carefully, he looks up.

‚ÄúShe asked how you are James,‚Äù Marlene says after a few more seconds of silence pass.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù James says, which is a ridiculous response, so his brain quickly tries to remedy the situation by adding: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing Ruins readings.‚Äù

Marlene looks like holding in her laughter is physically painful, while Lily just looks confused.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîright‚ÄîMarlene, should we g‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWhat about‚Äîhow‚Äîyou?‚Äù Fuck. Fuck. Fuck. ‚ÄúI mean‚Ä¶alright, Evans?‚Äù

The confusion on Lily‚Äôs face does not dissipate and James prays to the soul of Godric Gryffindor for the floor to open up and swallow him whole.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine,‚Äù she says wearily, before sending a pointed look at Marlene. ‚ÄúLets go?‚Äù

Marlene nods, shoulders shaking with laughter. ‚ÄúSee you at practice James?‚Äù

James does his best to channel Sirius when he glares back at her. ‚ÄúYup. You sure will.‚Äù

She at least has the good grace to look frightened by that.

He watches them leave‚Äîpathetically. He watches Lily‚Äôs hair, so long now it‚Äôs nearly passed her waist, watches the way her mouth flicks into a sharp grin. Her eyes bright and trained on Marlene, giving her the attention James would kill for.

And just as they cross the threshold, moving out of sight, he hears her say: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs his problem anyway?‚Äù

¬†

He hasn‚Äôt been sleeping well since the full moon. He closes his eyes and he‚Äôs back in the forest. He can‚Äôt see, but he hears Sirius screaming. He fumbles around in the dark until his hands touch something warm and sticky that smells like iron. Then he wakes up.

Every time he feels like something in his chest is caving in, his hands and legs shaking as he resists the urge to rip back the curtains around Sirius‚Äôs bed and make sure he‚Äôs okay. Make sure Moony didn‚Äôt turn him inside out. That he got there in time.

It‚Äôs stupid.

He‚Äôs too old for nightmares.

With a huff James turns onto his side, the steady breathing of his roommates letting him know they‚Äôre all asleep. He punches his pillow, lays back down, stares up at the canopy over his head. He counts centaurs like he used to do when he was little. He recites the ingredients to the Alihosty Draught they learned in potions this week. He imagines he‚Äôs flying. None of it works.

Eventually he gives up, pulling his legs over the side of the bed and scrubbing at his face. He could go down to the common room and try and get some work done, or maybe sneak into the kitchens - do they ward off the quidditch pitch after curfew? James reaches carefully into the drawer of his bedside table and pulls out the map. Maybe once he figures out where Filch is patrolling he‚Äôll have a better idea of what to do.

Except Filch‚Äôs name isn‚Äôt the one that catches his eye.

The map unfolds in his lap and almost instantly he sees it‚Äîall alone in the Astronomy Tower. Regulus Black. James blinks, double checking that he isn‚Äôt making it up.

‚ÄúNutter,‚Äù he mutters under his breath, but he doesn‚Äôt take his eyes off the name. He‚Äôs probably up there yelling at the sky again, though why he‚Äôs doing it at two-thirty in the morning James can‚Äôt fathom.

A few more minutes pass before he sighs. ‚ÄúFuck it.‚Äù

He shoves his feet into his trainers, not bothering with the invisibility cloak as he throws a grey jumper over his bare torso. He checks the map periodically as he moves through the halls but Filch is on the otherside of the castle and Mrs. Norris appears to be outside doing who-knows-what. He takes the stairs to the top of the Astronomy Tower two at a time, tapping the map closed when he reaches the door at the top.

For a second he wavers, wondering if this is really the best idea. But then, that‚Äôs never stopped him before. He shoves the map into the waistband of his trousers and gently opens the door.

Regulus is standing in front of his telescope just like he had been the last time. Engrossed enough that he somehow doesn‚Äôt hear the door. Alastor Moody invades James‚Äôs thoughts long enough to shout ‚ÄúCONSTANT VIGILANCE‚Äù at the back of Regulus‚Äôs head. He bites the inside of this mouth to keep from laughing.

Unlike James, Regulus is not in his pyjamas, but instead a pair of formal looking trousers and a button down, his robes discarded in a pile by his feet. James leans back against the wall behind him and watches as Regulus‚Äôs fingers meticulously work the knobs of the lens.

‚ÄúOkay I give up, what are you doing?‚Äù

Regulus whips around, drawing his wand without a second thought and pointing it right at the centre of James‚Äôs chest. Maybe him and Moody would get along after all.

James raises his hands in surrender. ‚ÄúOn edge much?‚Äù

Regulus only glares. ‚ÄúWhat the fuck are you doing here?‚Äù

‚ÄúCouldn‚Äôt sleep.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you came to the Astronomy Tower?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou sound awfully judge-y for someone who is also in the Astronomy Tower.‚Äù

The glaring intensifies.

James nods at Regulus‚Äôs wand. ‚ÄúYou going to lower that thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúHaven‚Äôt decided,‚Äù the younger boy bites out.

‚ÄúWell, let me know when you do, yeah?‚Äù James steps around him and up to the neglected telescope, completely ignoring Regulus‚Äôs raised wand. He bends down, shutting one of his eyes and peering through the lens. A grouping of stars blink back at him. For some reason he thought he would understand better, once he saw what Regulus was looking at. But he doesn‚Äôt. He‚Äôs always been crap at astronomy.

‚ÄúBit late for star gazing ‚Äòinnit?‚Äù he says as he straightens up.

Regulus is still standing behind him, tense and sharp looking, but his wand has been put away so James counts that as a win. He really didn‚Äôt fancy getting hexed tonight.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, is there something I can help you with?‚Äù

The words are icy and James can‚Äôt help but remember himself saying them not too long ago, in a cramped train compartment.

‚ÄúNot really,‚Äù he tries to shrug off the weird feeling that memory casts over him. ‚ÄúTold you, can‚Äôt sleep.‚Äù He moves towards the railing, sitting down on the ledge and facing Regulus. ‚ÄúSo what‚Äôs with the telescope?‚Äù

He can see Regulus grinding his teeth, hands in fists at his sides. ‚ÄúListen Potter, I‚Äôm not sure if our little conversation the other day gave you the wrong impression, but you and I are not friends.‚Äù

James leans back, draping his arms over the railing. ‚ÄúNever said we were.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen what,‚Äú he waves his hand pointedly in James‚Äôs direction, ‚Äúare you doing?‚Äù

James arches his brow, holding back a smirk. ‚ÄúPretty sure I asked you first.‚Äù

Regulus just stares at him for a solid minute before shaking his head. ‚ÄúSalazar, you‚Äôre just like him, you know that? Fucking arrogant assholes‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWoah, woah,‚Äù James interrupts, laughing because he can only assume that the ‚Äúhe‚Äù being referred to, is Sirius. ‚ÄúAll I did was ask what you were up to.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, you came out here, into my space‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPretty sure this is public property,‚Äù but Regulus ignores him.

‚Äú‚Äîand decided that you have the right to pry‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize astronomy was such a touchy subject for you.‚Äù

Regulus lets out a frustrated growl and James half expects him to reach for his wand again. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt just get to go around doing whatever you like‚Äîtaking whatever you like. You don‚Äôt have a right to everything just because you‚Äôre James bloody Potter.‚Äù

James blinks, watching as Regulus‚Äôs chest heaves under his shirt. He‚Äôs sitting up straight again, taking Regulus in properly. He looks...tired.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James says, eventually.

Regulus stares at him. ‚ÄúI‚Äîokay?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right, I don‚Äôt have a right to everything.‚Äù

The younger boy continues to eye him wearily, like he‚Äôs waiting for the punchline. When none comes he seems to deflate, and after another prolonged stretch of silence that has James itching to move, Regulus walks over and sits down next to him on the ledge.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he says finally, the word stiff. Uncomfortable. He stares ahead the whole time, not looking at James once. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a‚Ä¶bad day,‚Äù the last words are quiet.

James‚Äôs eyes run him over‚Äîhis shoulders pulled too far back, hands clutching at his knees.

‚ÄúReg has it‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOh don‚Äôt you dare,‚Äù he cuts him off. ‚ÄúRegulus was bad enough, lets not be so gauche as to resort to nicknames.‚Äù

James has to bite the inside of his cheek to keep from laughing, Regulus‚Äôs posh accent coming out in full force. There is something mildly charming about the way that he embraces it. James, on the other hand, has spent years meticulously trying to train the good breeding out of his voice.

‚ÄúHas it occurred to you,‚Äù James pushes on, despite the interruption, ‚Äúthat I‚Äôm not actually trying to take anything from you?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

The answer comes so quickly and so decisively that James finds he‚Äôs actually startled by it.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

There's a moment of silence before Regulus finally turns to face him. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that what people do? Isn‚Äôt that what we do?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe?‚Äù James repeats, feeling a little off kilter.

Regulus must see it because he rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúNot you and I specifically. But our‚Äîour sides.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not on anyone‚Äôs side,‚Äù it‚Äôs such an automatic response, James doesn‚Äôt even think about it, but once he hears the words outloud he realizes that they aren‚Äôt true. That they can‚Äôt be, not anymore.

Regulus gives him a piteous once over. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such a child.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù James says indignantly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm older than you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, pathetic isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù but there‚Äôs the sliver of a smile somewhere in his mouth that takes the edge off. James likes it. Likes when he gets that armour to crack. It reminds him a bit of Remus if he‚Äôs honest‚Äîthe way he was when they were younger. The way he still is sometimes.

‚ÄúHey Reg?‚Äù he says after a brief pause.

Regulus lets out a huff, dropping his face into his hands. ‚ÄúI swear to all that is holy Potter, if you start calling me that in public I will end you.‚Äù

This time James can‚Äôt stop the laughter from spilling out of his mouth. ‚ÄúNoted.‚Äù

Regulus waits a beat before dropping his hands and sending him a pointed look. ‚ÄúWell? Your inflection suggested there was a question to follow?‚Äù

James nods, still smiling. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing up here, at two in the morning with a telescope?‚Äù

‚ÄúIs there something else I should be up here with?‚Äù

‚ÄúA girl‚Äôd make more sense.‚Äù

Something flashes across Regulus‚Äôs face that James can‚Äôt quite catch, and all of a sudden he‚Äôs looking away again. ‚ÄúDid you not listen to anything I said five minutes ago?‚Äù he asks, voice tight.

‚ÄúI did,‚Äù James says slowly. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt owe me an answer, but I want you to know that I‚Äôm asking because I‚Äôm interested, not because I want something to hold over your head.‚Äù

That seems to surprise Regulus, though he does his best not to show it. James waits, which really, he thinks is impressive. He‚Äôs usually quite impatient. But there‚Äôs something about Regulus‚Ä¶something‚Ä¶delicate. And James finds himself wanting desperately not to break whatever it is that‚Äôs keeping him here. Still. Next to him.

Regulus lets out a breath like he‚Äôs been holding it in for days.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all there,‚Äù he says finally, still not looking at James. He wants so badly to ask him to explain but he doesn‚Äôt. He keeps waiting. After several painful minutes Regulus goes on: ‚ÄúMe, Sirius, my father‚Äîwe‚Äôre all there, together, holding up the night sky,‚Äù he shakes his head, picking apart his fingers in his lap. ‚ÄúI started coming up here in second year, when Sirius stopped talking to me. Up there we‚Äôre still‚Ä¶whole. I don‚Äôt know. It makes me think that maybe in a different time, a different world, there‚Äôs an us that‚Äôs still‚Äîthere‚Äôs a place that‚Äôs not like this.‚Äù

Oh.

How does he respond to that? How does he even begin to hold all those feelings? He remembers third year, remembers Sirius showing up to school covered in bruises he didn‚Äôt yet know how to erase. James hadn‚Äôt thought about Regulus, about whether or not he deserved to be lumped in with the rest of them, about whether or not he had his own bruises. He'd just wanted to take Sirius away. To shield him. Keep him to himself.

When James takes too long to say something Regulus laughs, burying the heels of his hands into his eyes. ‚ÄúThat sounds ridiculous now that I say it out loud.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah‚Äîno, it doesn‚Äôt,‚Äù James says quickly, glad his voice doesn‚Äôt sound as shaky as he feels. ‚ÄúIt‚Äî‚Äù he swallows, picking through all the words in his head, trying to find the right ones. ‚ÄúI think Sirius does it too.‚Äù

That causes Regulus to look back at him, grey eyes bright in the moonlight.

‚ÄúI catch him sometimes,‚Äù James explains, ‚Äúlooking out the dorm room window at night, I didn‚Äôt really think about it before but‚Ä¶‚Äù James doesn‚Äôt know what to make of the expression on Regulus‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúCourse,‚Äù he goes on, smiling a bit, ‚Äúyou didn‚Äôt hear that from me.‚Äù

Regulus lets out a breath that might be a laugh. ‚ÄúNo, of course not.‚Äù

They sit in silence, but it's not uncomfortable. Not the kind that makes your skin itch. And James almost misses it, when Regulus starts to pull away.

‚ÄúI should go,‚Äù he says, getting to his feet. ‚ÄúQuidditch practice tomorrow.‚Äù

James feels himself grin. ‚ÄúBig match against Hufflepuff coming up.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes, waving his wand and shrinking the telescope back down so that he can slip it into his pocket. ‚ÄúHardly.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou ready?‚Äù James asks, resisting the sudden urge to pull Regulus back down beside him.

Regulus sends him a sly look. ‚ÄúAlways.‚Äù He‚Äôs at the door, one hand on the handle, but he pauses, standing there for long enough that James starts to wonder if he‚Äôs having some kind of stroke.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not my brother,‚Äù Regulus says eventually, eyes darting up to meet James‚Äôs.

Surprised by the sudden change in topic, it takes James a minute to respond. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust, if that‚Äôs why‚Äîif that‚Äôs what‚Äî‚Äú he stops, face scrunching in frustration as he attempts to get his thoughts in order. ‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs why you‚Äôre doing this, if you think you can‚Ä¶save me, the way you did him. You should know that you can‚Äôt.‚Äù

James feels his thoughts go in a million different directions at those words, unsure of what to address first.

‚ÄúDo you need to be saved Reg?‚Äù he manages finally.

He isn‚Äôt sure what he‚Äôs expecting, but it‚Äôs certainly not the sad smile that peeks out of the corner of Regulus‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúGoodnight, Potter.‚Äù

James watches the door close behind him.

Chapter End Notes

Thanks again for all of your lovely comments on the last chapter truly appreciate it!

Chapter 4

Chapter Summary

TW: Panic attack

This starts soft and fluffy and then gets less so...but, it's gonna be okay...well...I mean...as okay as James and Regulus can be...

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

He‚Äôs not sure how it starts exactly. It‚Äôs an accident, he‚Äôs almost certain, a coincidence, that he finds himself heading up to the astronomy tower almost every night after his friends have gone to sleep. Another coincidence, that Regulus is always there. It‚Äôs strange how quickly he starts to know Regulus. The different ways he smiles without using his mouth. Or how he tugs at his fingers when he gets nervous. James doesn‚Äôt know what it means that he notices these things. He doesn‚Äôt try to figure it out. Maybe he doesn‚Äôt want to.

¬†

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre telling me you‚Äôve been at this school for four years,‚Äù James is lying on his back, arms thrown behind his head, ‚Äúand you‚Äôve never stepped foot in the Forbidden Forest?‚Äù

‚ÄúExcuse me for taking the ‚ÄòForbidden‚Äô part of the name seriously,‚Äù Regulus says, sitting with one knee pulled up, chin resting on top.

James snorts. ‚ÄúRight little rule follower, aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI just happen to be in possession of something called common sense, you might want to try it.‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù James says dismissively, ‚Äúsounds dead boring.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, well, you would think so.‚Äù

James pushes himself up onto his elbows so that he can look at Regulus properly. He seems different like this, curled up, shirt untucked. Soft, James‚Äôs brain supplies, he looks soft.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll take you,‚Äù he‚Äôs says finally.

Regulus arches his brow. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll take me where?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe forest, obviously.‚Äù

Regulus makes a disapproving noise. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going in there.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw, come on,‚Äù James knocks his foot against Regulus‚Äôs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll love it, I promise.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomehow, I doubt that.‚Äù

‚ÄúListen, if you‚Äôre scared‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not scared,‚Äù Regulus interrupts sharply, and James does his best not to laugh. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not scared,‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm smart. There‚Äôs a difference.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you say so,‚Äù James knocks his foot again, this time staying there, pressed to Regulus‚Äôs ankle. ‚ÄúBut my point was, that if you did happen to be scared,‚Äù James holds up his hands the minute he sees Regulus open his mouth, ‚Äúwhich you aren‚Äôt, obviously. But if you were, you should know that you‚Äôd have a distinct advantage going in there with me.‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúAnd why‚Äôs that?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause,‚Äù James grins. ‚ÄúGryffindors are contractually obligated to sacrifice themselves. So you‚Äôll have a decent head start while whatever terrible monster we run into feasts on my flesh.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence before Regulus drops his face into his knees, shoulders shaking with laughter.

Making regulus laugh is new. Good new. Really good new. It feels like scoring a goal in a quidditch match. Like scoring the winning goal.

¬†

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you stole a snitch,‚Äù Regulus says, batting the ball in question away from his face.

James smiles, catching it easily in his hand as it starts zooming over the edge of the tower. ‚ÄúReally? You can‚Äôt believe it?‚Äù Regulus rolls his eyes, but James can tell he‚Äôs trying not to smile. ‚ÄúBesides,‚Äù he goes on, feeling smug. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not stealing, just‚Ä¶borrowing.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course, you are.‚Äù

James tosses the snitch up and down a few times before he notices Regulus watching him. The younger boy quickly turning back to his telescope.

¬†

‚ÄúThe Catapults are your favourite quidditch team?‚Äù Regulus repeats in shock. They‚Äôre sitting on the ground, leaning against the castle, James‚Äôs most recent haul from Honeydukes piled between them.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why you‚Äôre so surprised,‚Äù James says, biting off the end of his jelly wand.

‚ÄúThe Catapults?‚Äù is all Regulus has to say in return.

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúThey're badass. I mean, the award for riskiest play is named after one of their players, doesn't get much cooler than that.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause he was eaten by a chimera,‚Äù Regulus says flatly. ‚ÄúNot because he did anything particularly impressive on the pitch.‚Äù

‚ÄúCorrection,‚Äù James waves around his half-eaten gummy to emphasize his point. ‚ÄúHe was eaten by a chimera AND he was impressive on the pitch. Can‚Äôt ask for a better legacy than that.‚Äù

Regulus stares blankly at him. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell if you‚Äôre joking right now or if you‚Äôre genuinely this ridiculous.‚Äù

James grins. ‚ÄúPart of my charm, that.‚Äù

¬†

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs trying to collect them all?‚Äù Regulus asks incredulously, passing his chocolate frog card to James.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs absurd.‚Äù

James laughs, ‚ÄúYup,‚Äù he slips the card into the pocket of his hoodie, ‚Äúbut you gotta respect his commitment.‚Äù

Regulus arches his brow in a manner that suggests he does not think that you actually do have to respect it, but he doesn‚Äôt say anything. Instead he turns his head and stares out over the grounds, closing his eyes for a moment and breathing in.

‚ÄúBad day?‚Äù James asks eventually, when the silence drags on too long.

Regulus sighs. ‚ÄúMaybe, I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

James watches him, waiting for him to keep going. He‚Äôs learned in these moments that Regulus needs to feel like he‚Äôs in control.

‚ÄúI got a letter from home.‚Äù

James feels himself stiffen. They don‚Äôt talk about his family. James isn‚Äôt sure that he wants to ‚Äî that he can.

‚ÄúIt‚Äîmy dad,‚Äù his voice is clipped, words barely making it out. He struggles to keep going. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs‚Ä¶sick.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Regulus leans back against the pillar behind him, head tilted up towards the sky. ‚ÄúI thought Sirius might have told you‚Ä¶‚Äù he lets that hang there between them while James tries to collect himself.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he can hear the hurt in his voice and he hates it. ‚ÄúNo, he didn‚Äôt say. Has it been‚Ä¶has your dad been sick awhile?‚Äù

Regulus nods, not dropping his eyes from the sky.

‚ÄúAnd the healers can‚Äôt do anything?‚Äù

A dry laugh, James is learning to hate those, they‚Äôre nothing like his real laugh which is full and strong.

‚ÄúNo, blood curse or something. Hereditary. Purebloods, you know, all that inbreeding.‚Äù

James does know, he has the vague memory of his mum telling him about an aunt who died from something similar.

‚ÄúDoes that mean‚Ä¶‚Äù a sentence he can‚Äôt bring himself to finish.

Finally, Regulus‚Äôs eyes come back to him. ‚ÄúThat Sirius has it?‚Äù he shrugs. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know‚Äîwon‚Äôt, not until it happens.‚Äù

James feels a little light headed for a moment, fingers digging into the stone building underneath him. The pain helps, it keeps him grounded. We figured out how to turn ourselves into animagi for Remus, he thinks to himself, trying to get his stomach muscles to unclench. We‚Äôll figure this out too if we have to.

It takes a moment before he realizes that Regulus is watching him, a curious expression on his face. ‚ÄúYou really care about him, don‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù James answers without question. And then: ‚ÄúNot just him, though.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs expression flickers and then quickly goes out. He looks down at his lap, picking some lint off his pants in a poor attempt to appear indifferent. ‚ÄúAnyway,‚Äù he presses on, voice carefully held. Guarded. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard, hearing from him, when I can‚Äôt‚Ä¶do anything. To help.‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt sure what to say. He realizes, suddenly, that he doesn‚Äôt know much about Mr. Black. Most of Sirius‚Äôs stories centre around Walburga‚Äîher rules and her bigotry and her sharp magic. Magic that liked to slice into him any chance it got, sometimes lashing out unconsciously, his mother‚Äôs anger bleeding out of her and leaving him broken. If Sirius spoke of his father, it was as the shadowy figure in the background, who said and did nothing.

‚ÄúHe works at the Ministry right?‚Äù James says finally, pulling out the one piece of information he thinks he can remember.

‚ÄúHe did. But it‚Äîhe‚Äôs gotten worse recently. He can‚Äôt really use his magic anymore. Too bad, he used to be brilliant.‚Äù

James recognizes that tone, knows that that‚Äôs how he sounds when he talks about his own dad. He tries not to feel angry at Regulus, really he does, but he can‚Äôt get the images of Sirius alone on his doorstep out of his head. Or showing up to the Hogwarts Express every year held together by tape and glue.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre nice to you?‚Äù James finds himself asking.

Regulus doesn‚Äôt seem surprised by the question. ‚ÄúI love them.‚Äù

James bites back the automatic responses of how? and why? Because he knows they won‚Äôt get him anywhere. Knows they‚Äôll just shut Regulus down.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not the same thing,‚Äù he says finally.

Regulus smiles dryly. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he concedes, ‚Äúbut it‚Äôs the thing that matters.‚Äù

¬†

James has started sleeping better, which is ridiculous considering how much less time he‚Äôs spending in bed. But it helps, for some reason, talking to Regulus. There‚Äôs something‚Ä¶steadying, about the other boy. Now when he closes his eyes, the darkness is full of stars.

¬†

‚ÄúOi, you lot! Hurry up, we‚Äôre going be late,‚Äù James is walking backwards down the hill towards the pitch, desperately trying to corral the majority of the fifth year Gryffindors. Mary and Sirius are messing about in some strange mating ritual that‚Äôs halfway between wrestling and dancing, and not moving them any closer to the Quidditch pitch. Marlene and Dorcas are making bets on the match with a group of Hufflepuffs and Peter is having an adamant argument with Giffard Abbott about whose chocolate is better: Honeydukes or Cadbury, which for some reason has effected their ability to walk at a reasonable pace.

James sighs, running a hand over his face before looking at the lone figure beside him. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my favourite Moony, have I ever told you that?‚Äù

Remus snorts, watching the chaos unfolding behind them with mild amusement. ‚ÄúUh huh.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait,‚Äù James eyes the bag hanging off of Remus‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúDid you‚Äîdid you bring textbooks with you?!‚Äù

Remus clutches at the bag like he's worried James is about to rip it away from him, sending his friend a sheepish look. ‚ÄúUh‚Ä¶might have, yeah.‚Äù

James throws his hands up over his head. ‚ÄúForget it, I take it back, I hate all of you equally.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh please!‚Äù comes Sirius‚Äôs voice as he starts making his way towards them, Mary now on his back. ‚ÄúYou love us.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd love you more if you could get your asses moving,‚Äù James says as they start walking again, throngs of other students in yellow and green moving with them.

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why you‚Äôre so interested in this game, we all know Hufflepuff‚Äôs got it in the bag.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that a bet I hear Black?‚Äù Marlene calls from behind them.

Sirius laughs. ‚ÄúNot a chance McKinnon, I‚Äôve learned my lesson. You cleaned me out last time.‚Äù

‚ÄúHufflepuff does not have it in the bag,‚Äù James says resolutely.

‚ÄúDo you wanna‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo Marlene,‚Äù James cuts her off. He thinks he hears her mumble ‚Äòcowards‚Äô but he can‚Äôt be sure.

‚ÄúWow, I never would have expected the marauders to be so cautious with their money,‚Äù Mary says, dropping her face down and planting a kiss on Sirius‚Äôs cheek.

James shoots a quick glance at Moony, but he‚Äôs staring straight ahead, hands wrapped tightly around the strap of his bag. They haven‚Äôt talked about‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶anything, since the library. James has gotten the distinct impression that Remus has been going out of his way to avoid being alone with him, which he personally thinks is a bit dramatic. If Remus doesn‚Äôt want to talk about it that‚Äôs fine with James, but that doesn‚Äôt mean he‚Äôs gonna let his friend suffer.

‚ÄúOi, you two, lets keep it decent yeah? There are children present.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd by children do you mean yourself?‚Äù Mary asks, eyebrow raised.

‚ÄúMary, don‚Äôt be ridiculous,‚Äù James holds a hand to his chest as though deeply offended. ‚ÄúI meant Peter.‚Äù

She laughs, sliding off of Sirius‚Äôs back.

‚ÄúI heard that!‚Äù Peter calls out.

‚ÄúInside voice sweetie!‚Äù James shouts over his shoulder, causing general laughter to bubble up from the surrounding group.

‚ÄúWe are literally outside!‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt make me get your father young man!‚Äù

Mary raises her brow as Peter mumbles a myriad of curses behind them. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not the father?‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúObviously not, Sirius is the father, clearly. Never gives you his a approval, emotionally distant, can‚Äôt be relied on‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúTwat,‚Äù Sirius laughs, punching him in the arm before turning to Mary. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs right though, I am clearly the father.‚Äù

Remus makes an exasperated noise. ‚ÄúThe amount of bollocks you two talk is truly astounding.‚Äù

James grins, opening his mouth to speak before Mary beats him to it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd have thought Remus would be the mother.‚Äù

Remus groans, ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt encourage them, they‚Äôre insufferable enough as it is.‚Äù

‚ÄúSee,‚Äù she says, gesturing to the unimpressed blond.

Both James and Sirius look back at her unconvinced.

‚ÄúWhat exactly about dry acerbic wit screams ‚Äúmother‚Äù to you?‚Äù Sirius asks.

‚ÄúYeah, Moony‚Äôs really more of an angsty teenager,‚Äù James agrees.

‚ÄúFor Christ‚Äôs sake,‚Äù Remus mutters beside him, prompting James to swing his arm around his friend, pulling him into a hug.

‚ÄúBut we love him anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúOur wittle moody Moony,‚Äù Sirius uses a baby voice that has James cackling.

Remus eventually manages to shove James off, attempting to glare, though his eyes are a bit too bright to make it believable. The truth is, Remus can take a joke better than most people.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Mary says finally, squinting at Remus like he‚Äôs a painting she‚Äôs trying to work out. ‚ÄúI guess I can see your point.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrust me,‚Äù Sirius pulls Mary in and kisses the top of her head. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve thought about this.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt miss the way Remus looks away.

¬†

The crowd gets thicker as they enter the stadium, the noise suddenly so big you can feel it in your chest. A group of Hufflepuffs in the middle of the stands have started a chant:

Hufflepuffs are just and loyal
unafraid of any toil
But don‚Äôt cross yellow and black
We will always get you back

Which quickly devolves into the simpler refrain of:

Yellow and black
On the attack!
Yellow and black
On the attack!

James smiles. He loves this. He thought his heart was going to explode the first time he stepped onto the Hogwarts quidditch pitch. The Potters have a sprawling backyard and some play hoops set up, but it‚Äôs nothing like this. He never gets less excited no matter how many games he watches. Already he can feel his skin buzzing with anticipation.

The group of them push their way through the throngs of other students, looking for a group of seats together; which wouldn‚Äôt have been a problem, James thinks bitterly, if his friends could walk in a straight-bloody-line. In the end, Peter and Abbott find seats together so they can continue the great chocolate debate of ‚Äô75 and Dorcas and Marlene break off to sit with Lily and Alice. James very determinedly does not look at Evans.

‚ÄúThese seats aren‚Äôt bad,‚Äù Sirius says, as they finally settle, far closer to the ground than James would like. He only grumbles in response.

‚ÄúOh, don‚Äôt sulk.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, he‚Äôs not wrong,‚Äù Mary leans over the railing, peering at the grass below. ‚ÄúThese seats are rubbish.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you Macdonald,‚Äù James says, feeling deeply validated.

Remus is the only one sitting, textbook already open on his lap. It physically pains James to see it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna wear you down one of these days, you know,‚Äù he says, nudging at him playfully.

Remus smiles without looking up. ‚ÄúSure you will, James.‚Äù

James snorts, turning back to the pitch. It‚Äôs late afternoon, slightly overcast in that way the weather always seems to be in the fall. Somehow it makes all the colours more saturated‚Äîthe greens and yellows. James starts drumming his fingers against the railing, bouncing on the balls of his feet, impatient for the game to start.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm telling you,‚Äù Sirius says, leaning in next to him. ‚ÄúHufflepuff has this one in the bag. Morrow is the best seeker at this school.‚Äù

‚ÄúBetter not let Marlene hear you say that,‚Äù Mary says in a sing-song voice.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not all about the snitch,‚Äù James argues, because it isn‚Äôt. Everyone always thinks about that 150 points, but quidditch is so much more than that. The best teams have deep talent - all the positions, all the moving parts, they matter. He wishes more people understood that. Which is what he should say. What he normally would say. And then Sirius would roll his eyes and tease him about being a dork and they would all move on. Unfortunately, for reasons James can't comprehend, what comes out of his mouth is: ‚ÄúBesides, you‚Äôre underestimating Regulus.‚Äù

He feels, more than he sees, Sirius stiffen. That comment even catching Remus‚Äôs attention, causing him to look up from his reading.

‚ÄúAm I?‚Äù there is something far too careful about Sirius‚Äôs voice‚Äîtoo controlled.

James grimaces. Fuck .‚ÄúSorry mate, I didn‚Äôt think‚Äîjust quidditch brain, you know? I wasn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

But Sirius cuts him off with the wave of his hand. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. You‚Äôre right, he‚Äôs not bad, Reg,‚Äù but there‚Äôs still an edge of bitterness to his tone that doesn‚Äôt feel right. ‚ÄúHelps that he has the newest broom model as well, hard for Morrow to compete with that on his three-year-old Cleansweep.‚Äù

James has to bite down on his tongue to keep from telling Sirius that he doesn‚Äôt think that that‚Äôs, strictly speaking, entirely fair. Even if part of him knows that Sirius has a point. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù is all he ends up saying.

James feels himself let out a sigh of relief when Madam Hooch steps onto the pitch, distracting them from the newly uncomfortable silence that‚Äôs settled around them. The announcer calls out the names of the Hufflepuff players as they file out, waving to the crowd and inspiring a new round of ‚ÄúYellow and black, on the attack!‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt really thinking about how watching Regulus play might be different now that he knows him. Their conversations in the astronomy tower are so disconnected from everything else that James hasn‚Äôt really tried to‚Ä¶make sense of them. To make them fit. Sure, he sees Regulus every once in a while in the great hall or the corridors between classes, but they‚Äôre only glimpses. Nothing has changed really.

So he isn‚Äôt expecting to feel anything when Regulus walks out onto the pitch in his tight white quidditch pants and green kit. Isn‚Äôt expecting his stomach to drop into the soles of his shoes beating at about a mile a minute. An exhale shooting out of him like he‚Äôs just been punched in the gut. Sirius sends him a questioning look.

James doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happening. He doesn‚Äôt know what the hell this feeling is. Nerves? Is he nervous? Nervous that Sirius might notice? Might figure it out? Might be mad? Well, okay, that last one isn‚Äôt a might, he knows that Sirius will be mad. He keeps meaning to tell him‚Äîhe‚Äôs been meaning to tell him since the first time with Snape. He doesn‚Äôt know why he hasn‚Äôt. Mostly, he imagines, it's because he doesn't know what to say.

But oh‚Äîoh Regulus is mounting his broom and James‚Äôs heart gives another lurch.

‚ÄúYou alright there?‚Äù Sirius asks.

‚ÄúYup,‚Äù James‚Äôs voice is clipped, hands gripping the railing so tightly his knuckles have gone white.

‚ÄúYou look like you‚Äôre gonna be sick?‚Äù Sirius sounds genuinely concerned.

James is too, if he‚Äôs being honest. Maybe it‚Äôs something he ate? Maybe he's sick?

‚ÄúWell, if you‚Äôre gonna be sick make sure to do it on your other side,‚Äù Mary says, without taking her eyes off the pitch. The snitch has been released, the players are in the air, and James is making a concerted effort not to look at anyone.

‚ÄúOi! Not on my book you better not,‚Äù Remus says, but his eyes linger on James too. ‚ÄúProngs? You really do look a bit‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine,‚Äù he bites out, putting on a smile that he knows isn't exactly reassuring. ‚ÄúJust‚Ä¶headache. It‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you wanna go back?‚Äù Remus asks, a little too excited if James is being honest.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not missing the match!‚Äù

Sirius lets out a laugh from his other side, shaking his head as he mutters to himself: ‚ÄúObsessed.‚Äù

"You're sure?" Remus pushes. "Because I really wouldn't mind-"

"I'm sure, Remus. Very, very sure." Remus lets out a disappointed sigh, returning, reluctantly, to his reading, and allowing James to continue to panic in peace.

It‚Äôs okay. This is okay. It‚Äôs quidditch. James loves quidditch. He watches the keepers closest, since they‚Äôre who he needs to know best. Distracting himself from whatever is going on with him by breaking down their saves and misses, picking apart the gaps in their training. Focus on the game, he tells himself, just focus on the game. Slowly, his breathing evens out, his grip on the railing relaxing.

‚ÄúFucking foul!‚Äù Mary shouts, as a Slytherin Beater nearly knocks the Hufflepuff player he's chasing off her broom with his club.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôll get back up,‚Äù James says confidently, watching as the girl‚Äîwho is currently hanging onto her broom with one hand‚Äîstarts to swing, gaining momentum and then beautifully throwing her leg back over the handle.

‚ÄúIt's still a fucking foul,‚Äù Mary mutters.

‚ÄúYou reckon Slughorn‚Äôs paying Hooch off?‚Äù Sirius asks, Hufflepuff scoring another goal despite the dirty play.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that‚Äîthirty to ten?‚Äù James asks, not taking his eyes off the game. ‚ÄúAnd no, bastard's too cheap for bribery.‚Äù

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúTouch√©.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe she does it for the slug club invite,‚Äù Mary smirks.

Sirius and James make nearly identical noises of disgust.

‚ÄúNot fans?‚Äù she asks innocently.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt think of anything worse than a dinner party with that toad and a bunch of swots,‚Äù Sirius says, shivering at the very thought.

‚ÄúWell fuck you very much,‚Äù comes Remus‚Äôs dry tone.

‚ÄúOh come on Moony, you know I didn‚Äôt mean you,‚Äù Sirius leans around James so he can shoot Remus a smile, ‚ÄúBesides, you only went the once. Barely counts.‚Äù

‚ÄúWasn‚Äôt worth the heckling I got,‚Äù Remus says flatly.

Mary laughs, ‚ÄúJeez, you lot really are arseholes aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù James and Sirius say at the same time that Remus says: ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúThough,‚Äù Remus goes on, ‚Äúto be fair, it was a bloody insufferable dinner party.‚Äù

‚ÄúAha!‚Äù Sirius exclaims happily. ‚ÄúSee, exactly, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm saying.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd there‚Äôs Slytherin with their second goal of the game!‚Äù comes the announcers magnified voice.

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù James whips his head back to the game. ‚ÄúI missed it. You two,‚Äù he gestures between Remus and Sirius, ‚Äúno more bickering until the game is over.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShhh,‚Äù James waves his hand in Sirius‚Äôs face, not daring to take his eyes off the game again. The Hufflepuff keeper is new and James really wants to figure out his strategy before they play against each other.

And that‚Äôs when something small and green catches his attention. He‚Äôd been doing a good job of not looking at the seekers‚Äînot particularly hard considering they‚Äôre usually on the fringes of the game anyway. But this‚ÄîRegulus has done a straight dive for the ground, moving almost impossibly fast. For the third time this game James feels something weird pull at his chest. Be careful, he thinks before he can help it. Be careful, be careful, be careful.

‚ÄúHas he seen the snitch?‚Äù Mary demands, her upper body halfway over the railing. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see anything. James?‚Äù

He tears his eyes away from the speeding figure to look around him. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says slowly, ‚ÄúNo I don‚Äôt see it either.‚Äù

‚ÄúMorrow‚Äôs going now,‚Äù Sirius says, though James thinks he hears a new anxiety in his friend‚Äôs voice as they watch his younger brother hurtle towards the earth.

Be careful.

Be careful.

Be careful.

‚ÄúHoly shit!‚Äù Mary says, all of a sudden.

James is about to ask her what she‚Äôs on about when Regulus abruptly pulls up‚Äîit‚Äôs truly an incredible show of broom work. Morrow doesn‚Äôt stand a chance, realizing too late what‚Äôs happening and trying desperately to pull himself out of the dive. He doesn‚Äôt manage it, not completely anyway, slowing down enough that he doesn‚Äôt crash, but not enough that he can avoid the ground completely, rolling off of his broom as he hits the grass.

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù booms the commentator‚Äôs voice through the stadium. ‚ÄúWe just witnessed one of the best Wronski Feint‚Äôs I‚Äôve ever seen!‚Äù

James grins, heart beating out of control as the adrenaline buzzes under his skin. He watches Regulus flying in smooth circles above the game, the Slytherin‚Äôs going absolutely mental.

‚ÄúMagic,‚Äù James breathes, happy that Sirius is distracted by an excited Mary.

‚ÄúAnd there‚Äôs Hufflepuff with another goal, bringing the score to forty - twenty,‚Äù the announcer calls out, another goal James missed. Distracted again.

Now that he‚Äôs found Regulus he can‚Äôt seem to look anywhere else, watching helplessly as Regulus cooly maneuvers through the game, tracking Morrow, waiting. Seekers require absolute control, self-restraint‚Äîthe ability to sit back and observe. Regulus was practically born for this.

Hufflepuff gets another two goals.

Sirius elbows him. ‚ÄúTold you,‚Äù he says smugly.

‚ÄúNo, you said Morrow would get the snitch. Which he hasn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúI said Hufflepuff would win.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause Morrow was going to catch the snitch.‚Äù

‚ÄúJeez, you‚Äôre as anal as Marlene with her bets.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll take that as a compliment.‚Äù

The Hufflepuffs get another goal‚Äîthe crowd is going wild, students holding up their wands and shooting off alternating yellow and black sparks.

‚ÄúDamn,‚Äù Mary says, sounding impressed, ‚Äúthey‚Äôre really kicking ass this game.‚Äù

James hums noncommittally, eyes bouncing around the field from player to player.

‚ÄúWhat are they doing?‚Äù

All three of them turn to look at Remus, who shades his eyes with his hand as he stares up at the sky. After a moment he seems to notice the rest of them staring at him. ‚ÄúYes?‚Äù

‚ÄúMoony,‚Äù Sirius says slowly, sounding slightly awestruck, ‚Äúare you‚Ä¶watching the match?‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúI looked up for a second and‚Äîbut then I saw‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶that,‚Äù he jabs his finger at the sky and they follow it to Regulus, currently floating next to the Hufflepuff seeker‚Ä¶talking?

‚ÄúAre they having a date in the middle of a quidditch match?‚Äù Mary demands, half-amused and half-indignant.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú and then James stops. Because‚Äîbecause he sees it. The tiny fleck of gold just by Morrow‚Äôs ear.

Regulus is apparently laying on the charm because Morrow is suddenly laughing, his entire attention on Regulus and completely oblivious to the snitch currently behind his head. James blinks, rubs his eyes, blinks again. But no. No it‚Äôs really happening. Regulus Black is going to flirt his way into winning this quidditch match.

‚ÄúThe Hufflepuff‚Äôs are in possession again,‚Äù the announcer calls out, as oblivious as everyone else. ‚ÄúJohnson speeding down the pitch‚Äîooh, nice bludger dodge mate. The badgers really are on fire today. Avery trying to make a save and‚ÄîOh my god, oh my god he‚Äôs got it, Black has caught the snitch! Where the hell did that come from?!‚Äù

A horn blares out signalling the end of the match, Morrow looking dazed and confused as Regulus glides down on to the pitch still holding the snitch in his hand, his team tackling him almost as soon as his feet touch the ground. All the Slytherins in the stands are on their feet, stamping and shouting and throwing green scarves around.

‚ÄúHow did that just happen?‚Äù Sirius asks, dumbfounded.

‚ÄúGod, I feel bad for Morrow,‚Äù Mary adds, ‚Äúno one‚Äôs going to let him forget this.‚Äù

James means to respond but he‚Äôs working too hard on controlling his face, on not smiling as broadly, and madly, as he currently wants to, watching as Regulus is hoisted up onto his teammates‚Äô shoulders. Even now, Regulus doesn‚Äôt smile with his whole mouth, his happiness hiding in the corners, the golden snitch sparkling in his hand as he holds it up. It makes James breathless.

¬†

James doesn‚Äôt expect him to come‚Äînot after the first win of the season. But he goes up to the astronomy tower anyway, brings a book and the map. His whole body feels like it‚Äôs still buzzing from the match, and he can‚Äôt help running over the plays in his mind again and again. He gives up on homework eventually and starts scribbling down strategies to run by Frank at practice tomorrow. There‚Äôs a cool breeze drifting in off the grounds. It‚Äôs halfway through October now and the weather is always crisp and sharp. Goosebumps pepper James‚Äôs skin, but he doesn‚Äôt mind it.

His head snaps up when he hears the door open, blinking as Regulus stumbles in, still in his quidditch kit.

Oh.

James blinks.

Regulus‚Äôs hair is mussed in a way it never is, his pale cheeks pink and eyes wide and glassy.

‚ÄúWell look who it is,‚Äù James can‚Äôt help but smile, placing his parchment and quill down beside him and turning to face Regulus head on.

¬†‚ÄúHere I am,‚Äù his words come out overly articulated‚Äîlike he‚Äôs thinking hard about each one.

‚ÄúFigured you‚Äôd be busy celebrating that win,‚Äù James goes on when Regulus continues to stand there.

‚ÄúBut you came anyway?‚Äù

James shrugs, not sure he knows what to say to that. Not sure he could explain it to himself even.

‚ÄúYou gonna sit down or‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Regulus nods to himself. ‚ÄúRight. Yeah.‚Äù

He moves the same way he spoke‚Äîwith too much thought, one foot placed cautiously in front of the other every step of the way until he‚Äôs collapsing next to James on the ledge. He smells like quidditch and firewhisky.

‚ÄúGood party?‚Äù James asks, watching Regulus pull his legs up, crossing them on the ledge. It makes him look painfully sweet, especially when he runs a hand through his messy dark curls.

‚ÄúParty? ‚ÄîOh, yeah. Yeah, you know.‚Äù

James arches his brow, ‚ÄúYou really are sloshed aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Regulus tries and fails not to smile. ‚ÄúI think I may have had an entire bottle of firewhisky,‚Äù he admits, a little shyly. ‚ÄúAlso, someone made Jelly shots.‚Äù

And that‚Äôs just too much. James throws his head back and laughs. ‚ÄúOh my god, I cannot imagine you doing Jelly shots.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure if I should be insulted by that or not?‚Äù Regulus says, scrunching his face up. He‚Äôs so much more expressive when he‚Äôs drunk. James likes it.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just, not very dignified are they? Tell me, did you raise your pinky finger when you did them?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, fuck off.‚Äù

‚ÄúWere they served on a silver platter?‚Äù

At that Regulus‚Äôs eyes go wide before quickly looking away.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James practically gasps. ‚ÄúNo they weren‚Äôt! Merlin, you absolute wankers.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey! I had nothing to do with the placement of the refreshments,‚Äù Regulus says indignantly.

‚ÄúOh no, you don‚Äôt get to call Jelly shots refreshments.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don't see why not, that's what they are after all,‚Äù Regulus retorts, putting a level of haughtiness behind his words that has James barely able to contain himself.

‚ÄúThere is nothing refreshing about Jelly shots.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe you‚Äôve just never had very good ones.‚Äù

James throws his hands up in the air. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you,‚Äù he says through a smile. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôre you managing to be a snob about this? You pretentious little pri‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúEnough, enough,‚Äù Regulus giggles‚Äîactually giggles‚Äîas he ungracefully reaches forward to cover James‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúSo much talking.‚Äù

The move causes Regulus to fall forward, the hand not currently covering James's mouth being used to hold him up in a crawl position. James feels his breath hitch, Regulus‚Äôs eyes big, and bright, and so close.

They freeze for a moment‚Äînot speaking, not moving‚ÄîRegulus is drunk, but James has no idea what his excuse is. Eventually, Regulus drops his hand away from James‚Äôs face, but he doesn‚Äôt move back.

‚ÄúYou were brilliant today,‚Äù James breathes, he doesn‚Äôt know why, he just suddenly feels the need to tell him. Needs him to know.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù Regulus asks softly.

‚ÄúThat feint? It was beautiful Reg, I mean it. I‚ÄîGod, watching you I just‚Äîhow did I never notice before? How did I never notice what a fucking star you are?‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúLiterally.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James says, without the sarcasm. ‚ÄúYeah, but you are though.‚Äù

Something shifts in Regulus‚Äôs expression that James doesn‚Äôt understand. They‚Äôre still so close, he can practically feel his breath.

‚ÄúGuess you weren‚Äôt looking,‚Äù Regulus says eventually.

It takes a moment for James to realize what he‚Äôs saying. ‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù he answers finally, ‚Äúbut I‚Äôm looking now.‚Äù

In retrospect, he should have seen it coming. He didn‚Äôt. But he should have.

The first thought he has, when Regulus pushes forward, pressing their mouths together, half-crawling into James‚Äôs lap, is that he‚Äôs so warm. His mouth. His hands. For a boy who walks around like he‚Äôs made of stone, Regulus touches like the sun.

After that his brain sort of‚Äîshort circuits.

He can‚Äôt think.

He can‚Äôt move.

He knows he should have seen this coming. But he didn‚Äôt. He didn‚Äôt. And for some reason that keeps him frozen. Everything overpowered by it.

I didn‚Äôt know.

I didn‚Äôt know this was what we were doing.

I didn‚Äôt know this was who I was.

How could I not know?

How could I not know?

And then the heat is gone. James is shaking and dazed and staring up at Regulus who has jumped so far back he‚Äôs on his feet, face broken open in horror as he looks down at James.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù it‚Äôs a word wrapped in all sorts of pain. ‚ÄúFuck, fuck, I‚Äôm sorry I didn‚Äôt‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt mean it.‚Äù He‚Äôs backing up towards the door, the pink flush gone from his cheeks. ‚ÄúI swear I didn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú he chokes, he chokes and his voice hitches and James wants to make it better. Wants to fix this. Wants Regulus to never look like that ever again.

But he can‚Äôt.

He can‚Äôt.

How could he not know?

He flinches when the door slams and now that he‚Äôs on his own he realizes that he isn‚Äôt breathing right‚Äîtoo fast and too short. He‚Äôs seen Moony like this before, like his body‚Äôs forgotten how to breathe. James squeezes his eyes shut. Trying to get himself under control.

Breathe, he commands himself.

Breathe you idiot.

In and out.

In and out.

Fuck, something aches in his chest and he doesn‚Äôt know what it‚Äôs from but it hurts.

Breathe.

In and out.

In and out.

It‚Äôs okay. This is okay. This can be okay.

It‚Äôs just a kiss.

Except it isn‚Äôt.

It‚Äôs Sirius‚Äôs brother.

It‚Äôs Regulus Black.

It‚Äôs a boy.

Breathe.

In and out.

In and out.

A boy who touches like the sun.

In and out.

In and

In and

In and

In‚Äî

Chapter End Notes

Yikes, that was intense

Have faith in James though, he'll get there.

Thanks as always for all the comments you guys are so kind, I love reading them all!

Chapter 5

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

He doesn‚Äôt go back to the astronomy tower the next night. Or the night after that. Neither does Regulus, James checks. That‚Äôs how he spends his free time now. Watching Regulus‚Äôs name move around the map. It is absolutely and utterly pathetic. But that doesn‚Äôt stop him.

‚ÄúHey, earth to Prongs?‚Äù Sirius snaps his fingers impatiently in James‚Äôs direction.

James looks up from the fireplace to find his three friends staring at him.

A beat passes.

‚ÄúSorry‚Äîwhat?‚Äù

Sirius huffs. ‚ÄúHalloween party planning, care to contribute?‚Äù
