‚ÄúWow, bold words from someone who was too afraid to come in here.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt afraid.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure you‚Äî‚Äú

There‚Äôs another howl, James‚Äôs head snapping in the direction of the noise, once again seeing nothing but trees and shadows. It hits him, suddenly, why he‚Äôs usually in the forest at night.

‚ÄúReg, you have to‚Äî‚Äú

But when he turns back Regulus is gone and Sirius is in his place.

‚ÄúDid you just call me Reg?‚Äù his best friend asks.

James is finding it hard to keep a grip on what‚Äôs happening, eyes bounding around looking for Regulus, not sure where he is but knowing he shouldn‚Äôt be out here alone, not if Moony‚Äî

‚ÄúJames? Hello? Why the fuck were you talking to my little brother?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú his brain feels fuzzy, everywhere he looks everything looks the same, it‚Äôs not just that they‚Äôre surrounded by trees, but they‚Äôre the same trees. He feels dizzy.

‚ÄúDid you see him,‚Äù he asks finally, ignoring Sirius‚Äôs questions. ‚ÄúDid you see where he went? We have to get him and then we have to get out of here. Something isn‚Äôt right, why aren‚Äôt we‚Äî‚Äú

And then there‚Äôs screaming. Sirius is gone and someone is screaming. He can‚Äôt tell which one of them. He can‚Äôt tell if it‚Äôs both. He starts running, barely dodging the trees as he shoots through them, the voices getting louder.

This is my fault, he thinks.

This is my fault.

I brought them here.

He doesn‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs true but it feels true and suddenly every part of him is shaking. The screaming growing worse and worse‚Äîlike their voices are being ripped apart, made into something barely human.

I‚Äôm not going to make it, he thinks frantically as the noises strangle him from the inside out. I‚Äôm not going to make it. I‚Äôm not going to make it. I‚Äôm not going to‚Äî

¬†

James‚Äôs eyes fly open as he wakes with a jolt. His chest is heaving, fingers gripping the bed as he tries to figure what‚Äôs happened. Where he is.

‚ÄúProngs?‚Äù

James flinches until he sees it‚Äôs Sirius and then he almost cries.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay,‚Äù he wheezes, voice thin. Peter and Remus come into focus on either side of him. He‚Äôs in the infirmary. Of course he is. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay,‚Äù James repeats, collapsing back down onto his pillows but reaching out for Sirius anyway, hand wrapping around his wrist, making sure he‚Äôs real.

‚ÄúYeah, yeah ‚Äòcourse I am,‚Äù Sirius says confused, though he doesn‚Äôt pull away from James‚Äôs touch. ‚ÄúJesus, it‚Äôs you who‚Äôs not okay.‚Äù

James‚Äôs eyes have fluttered closed because it hurts more when they‚Äôre open. ‚ÄúMe?‚Äù he asks drearily.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Remus says his name tentatively and James reluctantly opens his eyes again, meeting his friend‚Äôs concerned stare. ‚ÄúDo you‚Ä¶remember what happened?‚Äù

I remember being alone in the woods, he thinks.

I remember screaming.

‚ÄúNo, I‚Äî‚Äú his head gives a sudden bone grinding ache, the pain running through his whole body, ‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses under his breath, squeezing Sirius‚Äôs wrist.

‚ÄúProngs?‚Äù Sirius asks nervously, stepping forward.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he grits his teeth, ‚Äújust‚Ä¶hurts.‚Äù

‚ÄúShould I get Pomfrey?‚Äù He hears Peter ask, no longer able to see properly as a dozen black spots suddenly fill up his vision.

‚ÄúYeah, you better.‚Äù

He hears the sound of the curtain being drawn back and Peter‚Äôs quick steps on the stone floor. James breathes in deep, trying to get his thoughts in order.

‚ÄúSomeone remind me how I got here,‚Äù he says eventually, eyes still closed.

He doesn‚Äôt need to look to know Sirius and Remus are trading glances back and forth. The four of them barely need to use words most of the time.

‚ÄúQuidditch,‚Äù Remus says finally, ‚Äúyou were in the middle of the game, doing well, really well actually we think that‚Äôs why‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúFucking Bones,‚Äù Sirius cuts in, voice cold, ‚Äúaimed the bludger right at your head.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I get for showing off then.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou remember?‚Äù

He starts to nod and then instantly regrets it. ‚ÄúFuck‚Äîyeah, you‚Äôve jogged my memory. Game against Ravenclaw, hundred-and-ten Gryffindor, thirty Ravenclaw, Mary had the quaffle.‚Äù

Another thought strikes him and his eyes fly open‚Äîa mistake, but he pushes through. ‚ÄúWe won right?‚Äù he looks at Sirius. ‚ÄúRight?‚Äù

But Sirius won‚Äôt meet his eye.

‚ÄúWhat! Oh come on, how? We were crushing them.‚Äù

Another look is traded between Sirius and Remus.

‚ÄúWell, neither of us saw it but‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWait,‚Äù James is look at Sirius again. ‚ÄúWhat does he mean you didn‚Äôt see it?‚Äù

Sirius makes an irritated scoffing noise. ‚ÄúOh come on, you really think I was going to watch you have your head nearly knocked off and then keep playing a stupid fucking game?‚Äù

James blinks, silencing the part of him that wants to say‚Äîyes, obviously, it‚Äôs quidditch.

A few tense moments pass before Sirius speaks again, still not looking at him. ‚ÄúI thought‚ÄîI‚Äôve never seen a hit like that James, for a moment it really looked like‚Ä¶‚Äù

He hears Remus let out a shaky breath from his other side. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs kicked off the team, Bones is.‚Äù

James tries to let that sink in, eyes still on Sirius and his unnaturally pale face.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he pulls on the arm he‚Äôs still holding, causing Sirius to stumble forward‚Äîto make eye contact with him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù he smiles despite the blinding headache currently raging in his skull.

A pained look ripples across Sirius‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúJames,‚Äù he whispers, ‚ÄúJames I‚Äôm so sorry I didn‚Äôt see it.‚Äù

For a moment James is genuinely confused. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù and then. ‚ÄúOh Jesus, Pads, this is not your fault. Of course you didn‚Äôt, I didn‚Äôt even have the quaffle, there was no reason to think that thing was going to be coming for me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI should have been paying more attention.‚Äù

James lets out an exasperated sigh, turning to Remus for help.

‚ÄúOh don‚Äôt look at me,‚Äù Remus says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been trying to get him to stop blaming himself for hours.‚Äù

‚ÄúHours?‚Äù James‚Äôs brow raises. ‚ÄúHow long have I been out?‚Äù

Sirius looks like he‚Äôs going to answer when the curtains are pulled back again and Pomfrey and Peter file in.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù the older woman says, giving him a once over. ‚ÄúStill remember how to talk then?‚Äù

‚ÄúWas there a possibility I wouldn‚Äôt?‚Äù James asks, as she starts waving her wand over him, silently casting, what James assumes, are diagnostic charms.

‚ÄúYou never know with brain injuries,‚Äù she says, far too casually in James‚Äôs opinion. ‚ÄúNo memory troubles? Name? Location? Year?‚Äù

‚ÄúJames, Hogwarts, 1975. I‚Äôm fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe had trouble remembering what happened right before the injury,‚Äù Remus pipes up, earning him a scowl from James.

‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm not walking out of here just to have you have some kind of brain bleed or something.‚Äù

Sirius sends him a look from across the bed. ‚ÄúBrain bleed? Have you been watching muggle soaps again?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see how that‚Äôs relevant,‚Äù Remus huffs, cheeks pinking.

‚ÄúI heard of one bloke who hit is head and remembered everything except the name of his wife,‚Äù Peter adds.

James laughs and then quickly clutches his head. ‚ÄúOwe, Pete, no jokes, please.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a joke, just a fact,‚Äù but Peter is smiling anyway.

‚ÄúAlright Mr. Potter,‚Äù Pomfrey interrupts, slipping her wand back into the front pocket of her apron. ‚ÄúIt looks like everything is healing nicely, you‚Äôll have to stay here for tonight and tomorrow, then we can reassess.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, come on Poppy,‚Äù James whines, earning him a pointed stare. ‚ÄúI mean, Madam Pomfrey. I‚Äôm good, really just a little‚Äî‚Äú he tries to sit up and instantly feels a shockwave of pain wash over his whole body.

His vision goes white for a minute and the next thing he knows, Sirius‚Äôs hands are on his shoulders, helping to ease him back down.

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù Pomfrey says from the end of his bed, arms crossed over her chest. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in no fit state to be going anywhere. And I‚Äôll have to talk to Minerva as well.‚Äù

‚ÄúMcgonagall?‚Äù James manages to say, voice more a groan than anything else.

‚ÄúYes, you won‚Äôt be able to fly for at least three weeks‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWHAT!‚Äù

James goes to move again but this time Remus holds him back, Sirius and Peter both looking at Pomfrey with similar expressions of horror.

‚ÄúYou must be joking,‚Äù Sirius says, and James finds himself incredibly grateful for the shared outrage.

‚ÄúYeah, that seems really long,‚Äù Peter adds.

Pomfrey looks frankly unimpressed with the lot of them. ‚ÄúThat boy just had his skull fused back together.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait‚ÄîI what?‚Äù

‚ÄúDespite what you might think,‚Äù she goes on. ‚Äúthe brain is a very delicate organ, so until he is completely healed he will not be throwing himself into the sky, am I clear?‚Äù

‚ÄúBut‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMr Black,‚Äù she says harshly, eyes blazing as they zero in on Sirius. ‚ÄúI would strongly suggest you agree with me.‚Äù

After a few minutes of struggling Sirius eventually gets out a sulky; ‚ÄúYes m‚Äôam.‚Äù

Pomfrey nods, satisfied. ‚ÄúGood, you have fifteen minutes and then you are to return to your dormitory.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh come on!‚Äù

‚ÄúFifteen!‚Äù

She holds up her hand, shoving the protests back down their throats. ‚ÄúI do not know what mislead you into thinking this was a democracy but I assure you it is not. Fifteen minutes and then I start docking points.‚Äù

No on argues, and after another sharp look at all off them she parts the curtains again.

‚ÄúShit James,‚Äù Peter whistles, ‚Äúthree weeks‚Äîowe!‚Äù he glares at Sirius who has just smacked the back of his head.

‚ÄúNot helping Pete.‚Äù

James sighs, bringing his hands up to his face, they‚Äôre cold and for a moment it feels nice.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to talk about,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll loose it if I talk about it and my head already feels like it‚Äôs splitting open.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, way too soon for that joke mate.‚Äù

James snorts, opening his eyes to meet Sirius‚Äôs ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou need us to get you anything James?‚Äù Remus asks.

He starts to shake his head but then thinks better of it. ‚ÄúNah, I don‚Äôt think so. Besides, I doubt Pomfrey would let you guys back in.‚Äù

Sirius makes an indignant ‚ÄúHrrmph‚Äù noise.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre Marauders, no one lets us do anything,‚Äù Peter says with a shy grin.

James finds himself smiling back. ‚ÄúFair enough. I am fine though.‚Äù

Remus nods.

‚ÄúFIVE MINUTES!‚Äù Pomfrey shouts from the other side of the room.

‚ÄúMerlin, that woman,‚Äù Sirius curses under his breath.

‚ÄúWe should go, you need to sleep,‚Äù Remus says, picking up the coat he‚Äôd thrown over the back of his chair. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be back tomorrow though, first thing.‚Äù

Remus looks at Sirius, a question in his eyes, but Sirius waves him off. ‚ÄúGimme a minute yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure, Pete?‚Äù

Peter nods, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do that again, okay Prongs? It was bloody scary.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll do my best Pete.‚Äù

They slip through the slit in the curtains, leaving James and Sirius alone. James arches his brow.

‚ÄúJames I‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI swear if you apologize one more time I‚Äôm going to explode.‚Äù

‚ÄúExplode?‚Äù

James sighs, pinching the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúYeah, I know, it‚Äôs the only thing I could think of‚ÄîI just got my head split by a bludger, cut me some slack okay?‚Äù

When he doesn‚Äôt get a reply he drops his hand, looking up again.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù his name shakes in Sirius‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm supposed to have your back.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you do.‚Äù

‚ÄúI should have seen it‚ÄîI should have stopped it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù he says with as much emphasis as he can muster. ‚ÄúThings happen, and despite what your mother may have told you, they are not all your fault.‚Äù

Sirius makes a strangled noise. ‚ÄúDick move bringing my mum into this,‚Äù but he doesn‚Äôt sound like he means it.

‚ÄúI just think sometimes you need to be reminded that that voice in your head is her‚Äôs, so you can tell it to fuck off.‚Äù

Sirius laughs weakly, scrubbing at his eyes. ‚ÄúJesus, alright, you sound like Moony.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin, I hope so, he‚Äôs the only one of us with any sense.‚Äù

‚ÄúAin‚Äôt that the truth.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius Black you better not still be in my infirmary!‚Äù comes Madam Pomfrey‚Äôs voice.

Sirius rolls his eyes, ‚ÄúI guess that my cue.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo, you know Moony‚Äôll have made Pete wait for you and he‚Äôs probably started winging by now.‚Äù

Sirius nods, but seems reluctant to go, nervous eyes still running James over.

‚ÄúWhen you‚Äîbefore you woke up‚Ä¶‚Äù he stops, lips tugging to the side like they‚Äôre fighting with themselves. ‚ÄúI thought‚Äîit sounded like you said Reg?‚Äù

James feels his heart stop. Suddenly he‚Äôs back in the forest, staring at his best friend.

Why the fuck were you talking to my little brother.

Sirius seems to take his silence as something else. ‚ÄúI know it sounds mental,‚Äù he huffs. ‚ÄúAnd Remus and Pete didn‚Äôt even hear it but‚Ä¶It just, I don‚Äôt know I‚Äî‚Äú he shakes his head. ‚ÄúForget it, it‚Äôs dumb. It was probably just my brain playing tricks on me, yeah?‚Äù

He looks at James, clearly hoping for validation, worried he‚Äôs upset him. James wants to tell him the truth. He does. Desperately.

‚ÄúYeah, probably, can‚Äôt imagine why else‚Äîunless I was dreaming about quidditch or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, maybe that was it.‚Äù

James is well aware that people lie all the time. He does, certainly, to his mother, to his professors, to Frank. But Sirius‚Ä¶what is it he said? I‚Äôm supposed to have your back. That‚Äôs it, that‚Äôs them. They have each other‚Äôs backs, always. It‚Äôs‚Ä¶important to James. Sirius is important to James.

‚ÄúHey?‚Äù Sirius looks concerned, stepping towards the bed again. ‚ÄúShould I get Pomfrey? You look‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù James says quickly, offering him a tight smile. ‚ÄúReally,‚Äù he repeats, when Sirius keeps standing there unconvinced.

‚ÄúAlright, alright,‚Äù Sirius exhales passing a hand over his face. ‚ÄúMerlin, don‚Äôt do this again.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúGet hit in the head with a bludger? Wasn‚Äôt planning to.‚Äù

‚ÄúBludger, fist, badger‚Äîif I ever see you bleed again it‚Äôll be too soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going soft Black,‚Äù he laughs, nudging Sirius with his foot. The other boy smiles and it feels good to see.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go spreading that around, it‚Äôll be bad for my rep. As far as anyone knows I‚Äôm a selfish heartless gorgeous bastard.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs going on your tombstone.‚Äù

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúIt better be.‚Äù

‚ÄúMR. BLACK‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYes I‚Äôm going!‚Äù he shouts back sending James an exasperated look. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be back first thing yeah? Whether the old bat likes it or not.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs long as you bring food with you.‚Äù

Sirius scoffs indignantly. ‚ÄúWell obviously, we‚Äôre not savages,‚Äù he tosses James a cheeky wink before slipping through the curtains.

James leans back against his pillows, closing his eyes and trying not to think about the fact that Sirius heard him call out Reg‚Äôs name. About how close that was. About how he wishes it was closer.

He doesn‚Äôt want to go to sleep, partially because he‚Äôs only just getting his bearings back and partially because he‚Äôs not at all excited about what awaits him on the insides of his eyelids. The wolf, the dog, the blood. Over and over agin he sees it. Hears it. He hopes it won‚Äôt be this bad for Sirius, hopes he doesn‚Äôt start dreaming about phantom quidditch games. He doesn‚Äôt remember screaming, but then, he doesn‚Äôt remember much.

He knows there was blood.

His eyes open at the sound of footsteps and ruffling fabric and he finds Pomfrey at his bedside. She smiles at him, and he realizes suddenly that the lights have been put out, the space lit now only by her wand.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm leaving these here for you if you need them,‚Äù she points to two vials on the table beside his bed ‚ÄúThis one is a pain potion, and this one is dreamless sleep. There‚Äôs one dose of each measured out here so drink the whole thing. If you need me just tap your wand twice. Now, is there anything else I can get you?‚Äù she looks at him expectantly, a formidable, but not unkind, expression of her face.

‚ÄúThree weeks?‚Äù

She huffs, rolling her eyes. ‚ÄúYes, more if you keep bugging me,‚Äù and then, pausing to send him a look that is all mother. ‚ÄúYour body needs time James, quidditch will still be there when you‚Äôre ready.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot if we keep losing,‚Äù he grumbles.

‚ÄúAnything else?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

He can see her trying not to smile at his pouting, moving towards the curtains again but stopping before going all the way through.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre lucky James.‚Äù

He blinks at the sudden seriousness of her voice.

‚ÄúThat was a bad hit and it could have gone very differently.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James swallows. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

She sighs after a moment, ‚Äúfor all that boy‚Äôs apologizing, you‚Äôd think he‚Äôd mention that he‚Äôs the one who caught you.‚Äù

That takes James by surprise and he has to stop himself from sitting up again. ‚ÄúSirius? Sirius caught me?‚Äù

She looks back at him over her shoulder, expression soft. ‚ÄúMinerva was slowing you down already of course, I‚Äôm not sure if he could see that. Still, Mr. Black made sure you never hit the ground. I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôve ever seen anyone fly so fast.‚Äù

James‚Äôs chest suddenly feels too tight. Idiot, he thinks, because catching someone is exactly what you‚Äôre not supposed to do‚Äîit‚Äôs dangerous, it can throw you both off, you wait for the referees. You wait for the professors. You don‚Äôt put yourself in danger too. Unless your Sirius Black of course, and then that‚Äôs exactly what you do. The self-sacrificing asshole. He‚Äôs pretty sure Sirius is the most Gryffindor person he‚Äôs ever met.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù he manages finally, wanting desperately to be back in his room with his boys. ‚ÄúThanks for telling me that, he never would have.‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúFigured as much,‚Äù and then, with a pointed look. ‚ÄúSleep now James, okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, alright Poppy.‚Äù

She rolls her eyes, pulling the curtain back and walking off towards her office.

¬†

He‚Äôs able to hold off for all of five minutes before he starts guzzling the pain potion like it‚Äôs water. He‚Äôs not thrilled at the idea of being anymore fuzzy and muddled than he already is but the headache is getting unbearable.

It takes a moment for the potion to set in, leaking through his body, warm and soft. It feels good. Like really, really good. James sighs, smiling into his pillow. The weight in his head lightens, taking with it the pain and dulling everything else‚Äîthe fear, the anxiety, the stress. It feels like floating.

He doesn‚Äôt remember closing his eyes but he must have. He‚Äôs not asleep though, just drifting, which is why the first indication he has that anyone has entered the infirmary is the soft feeling of fingers carding through his hair.

In the grey light of the windows he can make out Regulus standing at his bedside, hand caressing him‚Äîcarefully, delicately‚Äîlike he‚Äôs something to be cherished. That thought makes James warm inside.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell if this is a dream or not,‚Äù he says finally, causing Regulus to jump back in surprise.

James whines. ‚ÄúNooo‚Äîcome back, that felt nice.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, eyes going to the bedside table and then back to James. ‚ÄúPain potion?‚Äù

James hums, holding out his hands and beckoning for Regulus to continue his ministrations. But the other boy doesn‚Äôt move.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay then?‚Äù

‚ÄúMmhm,‚Äù James says, still reaching for Regulus. ‚ÄúRight now I am veeeerrryyyyyy okay.‚Äù

Regulus makes a noise somewhere between a scoff and a laugh before finally moving closer again. Once he‚Äôs near enough James grabs hold of his hand and places it back in his hair.

‚ÄúYou are a child, you know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure, sure, more stroking.‚Äù

Regulus snorts, but dutifully starts moving his hand again. It takes James much longer than it normally would to come to the obvious question. He cracks his eyes open, looking at the boy standing over him.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre here?‚Äù he says dumbly.

‚ÄúAstute as ever Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúUgh,‚Äù James makes a disgusted noise. ‚ÄúNo‚Äîno more Potter-ing please.‚Äù

Regulus bites back a smile. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your name.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy name is James. You call me James all the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll call you James occasionally.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, do it more.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre awfully bossy when you‚Äôre high, did you know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, I‚Äôm bossy all the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù his hand stills in James‚Äôs hair and he‚Äôs about to start complaining when the hand slides down to cup his face, the touch so light James is barely sure it‚Äôs even there. Regulus lets out a shaky breath.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay,‚Äù he whispers, more to himself than to James. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay, you‚Äôre okay, you‚Äôre okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù James says, pulling on Reg‚Äôs sleeve. ‚ÄúI am you know, you don‚Äôt have to sound so‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt,‚Äù and even James‚Äôs drug addled brain is struck by the way that word comes out. ‚ÄúJust‚Äî‚Äú and he can see him struggling the way he always does when the part of him that wants to keep everything sealed off fights with the rest of him.

James waits for Regulus to say more but he doesn‚Äôt, instead he leans down and presses into James‚Äôs mouth. He doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs ever been kissed like this before, soft and desperate at the same time.

It goes on for a while before Regulus pulls away, resting his forehead against James‚Äôs. ‚ÄúI hate you, you know that,‚Äù he says breathlessly.

‚ÄúYeah, tastes like it.‚Äù

Regulus snorts.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù James goes on, ‚Äúyou distracted me.‚Äù

‚ÄúDistracted you from what?‚Äù

James makes an annoyed noise as though it ought to be obvious what he means. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre here.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve established that.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYeah, but how‚ÄîPomfrey‚Äôs like right there,‚Äù he gestures beyond the curtains.

Regulus looks a little smug. ‚ÄúYou think you and my brother are the only people who know how to sneak around?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo but‚Äî‚Äú he snaps his mouth shut, unsure of whether or not he should tell Regulus about the map or the cloak or if that would just be another betrayal of Sirius somehow. To share their secrets.

Eventually Regulus shrugs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good at disillusionment charms.‚Äù

"Of course you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat does that mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know‚Äîc‚Äômere,‚Äù he pulls hard on Regulus arm, forcing him to have to brace himself on the bed, one hand by James‚Äôs shoulder, one knee on the edge of the mattress.

‚ÄúMerlin, James will you‚Äîbe‚Äîcareful. You just had your skull‚Äîcracked‚Äîopen‚Äîstop pulling on me!‚Äù

James only smiles tugging Regulus further onto the bed.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJust lie with me for a bit, that‚Äôs it Reg.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh that‚Äôs it Reg,‚Äù the other boy grumbles, practically on all fours now, hovering over James. ‚ÄúPomfrey could come by anytime.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah but you‚Äôre good at disillusionment charms.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes, letting out a huff. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt make myself bloody invisible.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll distract her,‚Äù James says casually. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very distracting.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve noticed.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave you?‚Äù far too pleased with himself.

When Regulus continues to hold himself apart James drops his hands, worry breaking through the potion. ‚ÄúIs this okay?‚Äù he asks, the world is so fuzzy right now that he‚Äôs not sure that he can read Regulus as well as he usually does.

The younger boy huffs before carefully fitting himself beside James.

‚ÄúReg‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay James,‚Äù he says quietly. ‚ÄúStupid and reckless, but okay.‚Äù

Smiling, James wraps his arm around him, pulling him into his chest, bury his nose in his hair. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you came,‚Äù he murmurs.

He feels Regulus exhale against his chest, ‚Äúgo to sleep James.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hello lovelies!

I don't know about you guys but I'm a little obsessed with the Regulus / James interactions in this chapter (am I allowed to say that if I wrote them? Idk but it's true),

Also Sirius and Lily being hilarious friends is one of my favourite things so prepare yourself for more of that

Your comments are so sweet, I hope you're all having a good day!

Chapter 8

Chapter Summary

No one is having a good time.

Chapter Notes

This gets mildly spicy - so consider this your mild spice warning (by spice I mean sex)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

James is allowed to go back to the dorm after two days, but not without some conditions.

‚ÄúYou are to stay in bed until I say so, do you understand?‚Äù Pomfrey fixes him with a sharp look.

‚ÄúPerfectly.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù there‚Äôs warning in her tone.

‚ÄúListen, I am famously very good at doing what I‚Äôm told.‚Äù

Her eyes narrow. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm friends with the portraits‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry Poppy, this is a judgement free zone, though you may want to try getting out a bit more.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Äîif you move,‚Äù she presses on, though James can see her fighting a smile. ‚ÄúI will know. So if you ever want to get on a broomstick again I suggest you listen to me.‚Äù

Which James thinks is entirely unfair and certainly an abuse of power but since neither McGonagall nor Dumbledore agree with him, he finds himself confined to his bedroom. Which is made infinitely worse when Remus starts bringing him his coursework.

‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm injured!‚Äù he whines. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm supposed to be resting. Isn‚Äôt that what you all keep saying? How am I supposed to rest AND write an essay on the seven uses of unicorn hair? Those two activities are completely incompatible. What, is Slughorn trying to kill me?

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Remus sighs, collapsing onto his bed. ‚ÄúI will literally pay you to shut-up.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJames.‚Äù

He huffs, glaring at Remus and then glaring at his coursework. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe Pomfrey won‚Äôt let me leave this fucking room but she‚Äôs still going to make me‚Äî‚Äú

His rant is cut short by the pillow that collides with his face. Which, if Remus thinks is going to shut him up, he has another thing coming, because now James has a whole new rant about respecting the delicacy of his newly mended head.

Except, when he looks over Remus has curled onto his side, burying his face in his blankets.

‚ÄúUh‚ÄîMoony? You okay over there?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a long pause before Remus speaks, words muffled by the bedding. ‚ÄúJust having a bad day.‚Äù

James‚Äôs eyes automatically go to the window even though he knows the full moon is still two weeks off.

‚ÄúYou wanna talk about?‚Äù James asks.

Remus makes a noise that might be some kind of sad pathetic laugh but it‚Äôs hard to tell from his current position. ‚ÄúNo. I just want to wallow if that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure Moons,‚Äù James nods even though he knows Remus can‚Äôt see him. ‚ÄúWhatever you want.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt emerge until it‚Äôs time for him to go down to the great hall for supper. James, of course, doesn‚Äôt get to go to the great hall for his meals but instead has to have them brought to him via house elf.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù he calls to his friend as he‚Äôs halfway out the door.

‚ÄúMmm?‚Äù

James fidgets with the words in his mouth. ‚ÄúIf you want to talk, at some point, any point, I‚Äôm here.‚Äù

Remus, James realizes for the first time, looks exhausted. ‚ÄúSure Prongs, thanks.‚Äù He gives James a weak smile before disappearing down the stairs.

That‚Äôs the first time that James notices something is wrong.

¬†

The second time is when Sirius is doing his homework.

It‚Äôs not that Sirius doesn‚Äôt do his work. He does. Just usually he does it in a rush moments before it‚Äôs due. James once watched him pen out a four page paper on the mating habits of the Hodag in the fifteen minutes it took them to walk to class. He‚Äôs good enough that he passes, even with his illegible handwriting. Sirius‚Äôs greatest strength has always been his ability to improvise.

So it‚Äôs strange to watch him sit on the floor of their bedroom, books open in front of him, silently scribbling notes in a timely fashion.

‚ÄúEverything alright?‚Äù James asks when he can‚Äôt take the silence anymore.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Sirius doesn‚Äôt look up from the papers in front of him.

‚ÄúYou seem a little‚Ä¶tense?‚Äù

He can see Sirius‚Äôs eyes still, no longer skating across the pages of text.

‚ÄúNah, I‚Äôm good,‚Äù he says eventually.

James watches him, expression stern, shoulders inching up his neck as he starts writing again.

‚ÄúOkay Mate,‚Äù he says eventually, forcing himself to focus on his own work.

¬†

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just wondering if you‚Äôve noticed anything?‚Äù James asks impatiently as he watches Peter scramble around the room, desperately trying to find his wand. He misplaces it at least once a day.

‚ÄúLike what?‚Äù Peter grunts as he gets on his hands and knees and starts rooting around under his bed.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù James huffs, ‚Äújust‚Äîare they fighting? I feel like maybe they‚Äôre fighting?‚Äù

‚ÄúMore than usual?‚Äù Peter wipes the sweat off his forehead as he stands back up, still wand-less. ‚ÄúI swear I just had it,‚Äù he mutters to himself.

James rolls his eyes, picking up his own wand; ‚ÄúAccio Peter‚Äôs wand,‚Äù he mutters. Theres‚Äôs the sound of rattling and then persistent banging as both boys turn towards the closed bathroom door.

‚ÄúI swear I checked there!‚Äù Peter grumbles to himself as he walks over and opens the door, grabbing the wand out of the air on its way to James.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean ‚Äúmore than usual?‚Äù

Peter looks back at him. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

James‚Äôs patience these days is at an all time low. It‚Äôs the captivity, it‚Äôs no good for him. So it takes an incredible amount of effort not to snap at Peter. But he knows that wouldn‚Äôt end well. When he gets snippy with Remus or Sirius they give it right back but Peter‚ÄîPeter just shuts down.

‚ÄúRemus and Sirius, I asked you if they were fighting and you asked ‚Äúmore than usual.‚Äù What does that mean?‚Äù he gestures impatiently.

Peter shrugs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, they fight, we all fight.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù James demands, feeling slightly offended for some reason. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt fight.‚Äù

Peter looks at him curiously for a minute before shaking his head. ‚ÄúSometimes I feel like we‚Äôre in completely different friend groups.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is that supposed to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLook, I gotta go, if I‚Äôm late for transfiguration again McGonagall is going to turn me into a chicken,‚Äù Peter shivers at the thought, shoving his wand in his back pocket and grabbing the books off his bed.

‚ÄúBut what‚ÄîPete! Damn it,‚Äù James sighs, collapsing back onto his bed as the door closes behind his friend. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt fight,‚Äù he grumbles to himself.

¬†

James is pacing in front of the window when Marlene walks in, both of them stopping dead in their tracks. Staring.

‚ÄúBrought these for you,‚Äù she breaks the silence, holding up a stack of parchment that can only be more homework. James groans.

‚ÄúHow did you even get up here?‚Äù he grabs the work from her sulkily and chucks it onto his bed with the half a dozen other assignments he‚Äôs currently ignoring.

Marlene arches her brow. ‚ÄúI walked.‚Äù

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt there like an enchantment or something,‚Äù James waves his hand about. ‚ÄúY‚Äôknow, keeping us out of each others dorms?‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly on the girls, protect our virtue or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell what about MY virtue?‚Äù James demands indignantly, making Marlene laugh.

‚ÄúGuess the founders figured it was a loss cause.‚Äù

‚ÄúPresumptuous bastards.‚Äù

Marlene smirks. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you didn‚Äôt know this, aren‚Äôt you guys supposed to know all the castle‚Äôs secrets, isn‚Äôt that like, your whole thing?‚Äù she gestures around the room.

‚ÄúOur thing?‚Äù James raises his eyebrow. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize we had a ‚Äúthing.‚Äù Also, how would we know this?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could read Hogwarts a History?‚Äù

James looks at her flatly. ‚ÄúI repeat, how would we know this?‚Äù

She snorts. ‚ÄúOkay, okay, fair point. I mean, you‚Äôre telling me you‚Äôve never tried to sneak a girl up‚Äî‚Äú she cuts herself off, eyes going wide. ‚ÄúOr‚Äîshit, never mind that was‚Äî‚Äú

James rolls his eyes, waving off her words and leaning against the wall next to the window. ‚ÄúBelieve it or not, the idea of hooking up with a girl while my three mates listen in has never sounded that appealing to me.‚Äù

Marlene blinks at him a few times before pulling herself back together. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre telling me Sirius Black has never brought a girl back to his room?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre broom cupboard men us,‚Äù he shoots her a grin.

‚ÄúClassy.‚Äù

James nods looking out the window, trying to work through the nagging feeling now taking up space in his gut.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú he stops, shooting her a sidelong look, pulse suddenly hammering against his ribs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only him really.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, James‚Äôs eyes following the tiny students rushing towards the green house below them to distract himself from the buzzing in his ears. Eventually, Marlene moves forward and leans on the wall across from him.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she says softly.

He looks over at her. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah James, of course.‚Äù

He exhales a breath he didn‚Äôt know he was holding, eyes going back to the window.

‚ÄúThey still don‚Äôt know I gather?‚Äù she asks, gesturing to the room behind them.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt want anyone to know.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd what do you want?‚Äù

James lets out a dry laugh, passing a hand over his face. ‚ÄúI have no idea honestly. Even if I could I don‚Äôt know that I‚Ä¶‚Äù he trails off, eyes going unconsciously over his shoulder to Sirius‚Äôs bed.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Marlene goes on carefully, pulling his attention back to her. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure Remus would be okay with it.‚Äù

James can feel the confusion on his face. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

She looks at him expectantly but when she continues to get nothing in return she sighs, laughing a little. ‚ÄúHonestly, you lot are a mess aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúOi! We do alright.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt appreciate the judgemental tone McKinnon.‚Äù

She laughs, blonde hair falling in her eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying, I think if you did‚Äîif you told them,‚Äù she shrugs, ‚Äúit‚Äôd be alright.‚Äù

James‚Äôs chest squeezes. ‚ÄúRemus maybe, Pete, honestly I couldn‚Äôt tell you, but Sirius‚Ä¶‚Äù James swallows. ‚ÄúSirius will never forgive me for this, and I‚ÄîFuck Mar,‚Äù he runs a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I can bare that. Him hating me.‚Äù

She reaches out, squeezing his arm. ‚ÄúJames, you should have seen him, after you got hit.‚Äù

Something in her voice makes him look up.

‚ÄúHe‚ÄîI mean, I knew you two were close but‚Äîhe was wrecked James. I‚Äôm pretty sure if me and Alice hadn‚Äôt held him back he would‚Äôve killed Bones.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd have done the same if it was him,‚Äù James says, because it‚Äôs true.

Marlene nods. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he could ever hate you.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs‚Äîit‚Äôs not just‚Äîhe‚Äôs not just a boy,‚Äù James fights the way saying that out loud makes part of him squirm, want to shy way from it. He isn‚Äôt ashamed, he won‚Äôt be. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs his brother.‚Äù

Marlene grimaces. ‚ÄúYeah, I have to admit, that parts throwing me off a bit too.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúAn asshole?‚Äù

James snorts, restlessly fidgeting against the wall, crossing and uncrossing his arms. ‚ÄúYou know, until a week ago one of your best mates thought I was an asshole.‚Äù

Marlene rolls her eyes, ‚ÄúYeah, it‚Äôs not the same.‚Äù

He looks over at her. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

And suddenly she‚Äôs too serious for James‚Äôs liking. ‚ÄúThere are different levels of bad James. You‚Äôve been obnoxious, sure, you‚Äôve lacked self-awareness, but you‚Äôve never been cruel.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus isn‚Äôt cruel,‚Äù there‚Äôs no room for questioning in his voice, but Marlene looks back at him unconvinced‚Äîpitying even.

‚ÄúListen, I‚Äôve had this conversation too many times with Lily about Snape, I don‚Äôt want to do it again, I‚Äôm just saying,‚Äù she sighs, sounding weary. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying that just because someone can be good sometimes, to some people, doesn‚Äôt mean that they‚Äôre a good person.‚Äù

James feels like someone‚Äôs just slapped him. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt‚ÄîReg is not Snape‚Äîhe‚Äôs nothing like Snape,‚Äù the very idea makes bile crawl up the back of his throat.

He can see Marlene chewing on the inside of her cheek. ‚ÄúMaybe, I don‚Äôt really know him. But do you think Snape can‚Äôt be redeemable when he wants to be? That Lily would have held on to him for so long if he couldn‚Äôt sometimes be a decent human being?‚Äù

‚ÄúMarlene,‚Äù James puts as much emphasis on her name as he can. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm telling you, they‚Äôre different. They are.‚Äù Even as he says it he can see Regulus sitting with Rossier and Crouch, cold eyes and sharp mouth. Can see him sneering at first years in the corridor. Can see Sirius alone on his doorstep.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre really into him huh?‚Äù Marlene‚Äôs words pull him out of his thoughts.

He can‚Äôt look at her, feeling sick for the first time since leaving the infirmary. When he doesn‚Äôt answer he hears Marlene exhale, shifting a little against the wall.

‚ÄúStupid question that, since when is anything ever casual with you.‚Äù

James lets out a weak laugh even though it feels like his chest has started to cave in on itself. ‚ÄúRegulus isn‚Äôt Snape,‚Äù he repeats again. He needs her to know, to understand. ‚ÄúI can see how maybe it looks that way from the outside, but it isn‚Äôt the same,‚Äù it can‚Äôt be, whispers the voice in his head. It can‚Äôt be because I‚Äôm absolutely mad for him, this boy. He makes it feel like the sun rises in my chest.

Marlene nods, ‚ÄúOkay, I believe you. You‚Äôd know better than me,‚Äù and then a small smile pulls at her mouth. ‚ÄúIt means something, you know, that he has you. Maybe it‚Äôll make a difference, like with Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt,‚Äù his voice is scratchy and he coughs, trying to get his words back. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do anything for Sirius.‚Äù

She shakes her head, bemused expression on her face. ‚ÄúYeah James, yeah you did. You gave him a way out.‚Äù

James thinks about Regulus, back on that first night in the tower.

I‚Äôm not my brother, he‚Äôd said.

You can‚Äôt save me.

James feels those words more now than he did the first time.

They bruise.

¬†

Due to the mandatory bedrest and also his tendency to get dizzy when he‚Äôs on his feet for too long, James hasn‚Äôt seen Regulus since the infirmary. Which, if he‚Äôs being honest, is having more of an effect on him than he would have thought. Besides the fact that he‚Äôs found himself watching Regulus‚Äôs name on the map almost constantly‚Äîwhich he can freely admit to himself is both creepy and pathetic‚Äîhe‚Äôs been‚Ä¶dreaming about him.

Sometimes they‚Äôre nightmares. In the woods. In the dark. But sometimes they‚Äôre something else‚Äîsomething with hands and mouthes and a heat that whips through James like nothing he‚Äôs ever felt before. He wakes up hot and panting and wanting. These days he feels like that‚Äôs all he does‚Äîwant.

He hasn‚Äôt forgotten his conversation with Sirius in the infirmary. Hasn‚Äôt forgotten what Sirius heard. These days he casts a Quietus charm over his bed before he goes to sleep.

There‚Äôs a new fidgety energy that sits under his skin. He can‚Äôt sit still, he paces, he plays with his snitch, he throws crumpled balls of paper across the room. He thinks and thinks and thinks. He thinks so much he‚Äôs certain he‚Äôs going mad.

Mostly he thinks about grey eyes and thick dark hair and a mouth that says ‚ÄúI bite.‚Äù And he wants.

¬†

It‚Äôs a few days after his talk with Marlene that Remus walks into their room to find James and Sirius sitting in the window and then promptly walks back out. At which point, James decides that he can‚Äôt ignore the situation anymore.

‚ÄúOkay, what did you do to Moony?‚Äù he demands.

Sirius didn‚Äôt look up when the door opened or closed, eyes trained on the overcast skies, sporadic rain drops splattering the glass.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not making any sense Prongs, think maybe that bludger messed you up a bit,‚Äù his voice is lacking its normal teasing edge, words falling flat.

James watches him for a minute, the picture of melancholy, before reaching over and punching him hard in the arm.

‚ÄúOwe, what the hell!‚Äù Sirius clutches his arm and kicks James in retaliation.

‚ÄúHey! I‚Äôm injured.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt start fights you can‚Äôt finish Potter,‚Äù he says, kicking him once more for good measure.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on with you and Remus,‚Äù James kicks back.

‚ÄúNothing.‚Äù

‚ÄúBullshit.‚Äù

Sirius sighs, throwing his hands in the air. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, he‚Äôs pissed at me, he‚Äôs always pissed at me. I don‚Äôt know what his problem is.‚Äù

James‚Äôs narrows his eyes. ‚ÄúWow, you‚Äôre a really shit liar, you know that?‚Äù

Sirius glares, getting up dramatically and moving to his bed, crossing his arms over his chest as he sits against the headboard.

‚ÄúAre you sulking now?‚Äù James demands.

‚ÄúMaybe, is that a problem for you?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. I tried to leave it alone‚Äî‚Äú Sirius lets out a disbelieving scoff that James chooses to ignore, ‚Äúbut it‚Äôs been days now and the two of you are both in crap moods and won‚Äôt even be in the same room as each other. So since you‚Äôre clearly incapable of pulling your head out of your ass you‚Äôre going to tell me what happened so I can fix it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt fix everything James,‚Äù Sirius snaps back, harsher than James is expecting.

‚ÄúWatch me.‚Äù

When Sirius does nothing but sit there glaring James gets up and moves to his bedside, picking up Peter‚Äôs pillow as he goes. Sirius‚Äôs eyes widen.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you fucking dare James.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen tell me what‚Äôs happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúPut that down or I swear I will crucio your ass.‚Äù

‚ÄúHa! You wish.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

Sirius scrambles to the other side of the bed as James swings for his head.

‚ÄúYou wanker,‚Äù Sirius grumbles, rolling onto the floor. He grabs hold of his own pillow and hurls it at James.

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt have to be if you would stop lying to me,‚Äù James lunges across the bed at the same time that Sirius makes a run for the other side so they end up chasing one another in a circle, with James ending up on Sirius‚Äôs side and Sirius on James‚Äôs.

‚ÄúBit rich coming from you,‚Äù Sirius says, snatching the pillow off of Remus‚Äôs bed and launching it across the room. James ducks.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he says when he comes back up

‚ÄúWhere do you go every night James?‚Äù Sirius demands, causing a cold chill to run along James‚Äôs spine. ‚ÄúHuh? You take the map, so there‚Äôs no way to check, you disappear for bloody hours. What the hell are doing?‚Äù

James stands there, pillow forgotten in his hand.

‚ÄúOh come on,‚Äù Sirius says, tone verging on mean. ‚ÄúDid you really think we would‚Äôt notice?‚Äù

James‚Äôs body has gone so stiff that he feels like he might crack open, a horrible foreboding feeling washing over him. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt say‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMoony thought we should leave it alone, that you‚Äôd come to us if you needed to,‚Äù he‚Äôs sneering but James thinks he can just make out the hurt on the ends of his words. He thinks about how he felt, finding out about Sirius‚Äôs father from Regulus.

‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs been weeks now,‚Äù Sirius goes on. ‚ÄúSo what is it James? What are you hiding from us?‚Äù

James swallows. ‚ÄúNothing‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHa!‚Äù the noise is angry when he forces it out of his mouth. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs the fucking liar now?‚Äù

Shit, is all James can think.

‚ÄúI asked you first,‚Äù he says pathetically.

A look passes over Sirius‚Äôs face that he‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôs ever seen before, or if he has, its never been directed at him.

‚ÄúWhen did you stop trusting me?‚Äù Sirius says finally, and the room feels too quiet and too hot and James doesn‚Äôt know how they got here but he hates it.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not fair‚Äîthat‚Äôs not‚Äîthat‚Äôs not what‚Äôs happening here,‚Äù he struggles with his words.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why you lie James, you lie because you don‚Äôt trust someone with the truth.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a fight for him not to flinch, those words carving their way through his skin. Because that‚Äôs the truth isn‚Äôt? When all is said and done, he doesn‚Äôt trust Sirius with this.

‚ÄúIs that why you lie to me?‚Äù he asks instead of answering.

Sirius makes a dismissive noise. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt trust anyone, it‚Äôs not the same.‚Äù

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

But Sirius shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo, because you trust everyone. You always have. So when did you stop trusting ME.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt have an answer for that. Or maybe he just doesn‚Äôt want to.

‚ÄúI trust you Sirius,‚Äù he says finally, quietly. ‚ÄúI trust you with everything.‚Äù The ‚Äúelse‚Äù that they both know exists on the end of that sentence hangs between them. I trust you with everything else.

‚ÄúBut not this?‚Äù Sirius asks even though it was never said.

James fights everything that swells up inside of him at the way those words sound in Sirius‚Äôs mouth.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no this. I can‚Äôt sleep, I wander around the castle,‚Äù he shrugs, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs it.‚Äù

Sirius looks at him meaningfully before an empty laugh bubbles out of him.

‚ÄúRight, well,‚Äù he runs a hand through his hair, ‚Äúyou go for late night walks, me and Moony are completely fine. That‚Äôs how we‚Äôre playing this?‚Äù

James shrugs helplessly.

‚ÄúGreat. Excellent. Glad we had this talk. Feel loads better now, cheers.‚Äù

Sirius throws the door open with so much force that it bangs into the wall and James flinches when it closes behind him.

¬†

Pomfrey officially takes him off of bedrest.

‚ÄúNo quidditch,‚Äù she says sharply. ‚ÄúNot for another two weeks at least.‚Äù

James grumbles unhappily but doesn‚Äôt bother trying to fight her.

¬†

Sirius and Remus start warming up to each other again‚Äîor, at least they can be in the same room now, which James supposes is an improvement. They don‚Äôt really talk though. In fact, none of them really talk. There‚Äôs no attempt by him or Sirius to bring up the fight they had. They just‚Ä¶move on. That‚Äôs how they‚Äôve always dealt with things or‚Ä¶not dealt with things, depending on your perspective. It feels different this time though. Like there‚Äôs something heavy sitting on James‚Äôs chest every time he thinks about it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou can just say all you want, you‚Äôre still wrong,‚Äù James says confidently.

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúThe Cleansweeps are lighter, more aerodynamic.‚Äù

‚ÄúAerodynamic?‚Äù James snorts. ‚ÄúPlease, I‚Äôd take the oldest Nimbus model over the newest Cleansweep any day.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs because you‚Äôve been completely brainwashed.‚Äù

James laughs. ‚ÄúOh have I?‚Äù

‚ÄúMindless brand loyalty.‚Äù

James knocks their shoulders together. ‚ÄúYeah, whatever you say.‚Äù

It‚Äôs late in the day, the sun is warm but getting low in the sky, James swears it‚Äôs dark by supper these days.

‚ÄúHey, do you have the notes from muggle studies?‚Äù Sirius asks.

‚ÄúYou know I don‚Äôt, I‚Äôm just going to nick them off of Moony.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs expression tightens but he nods his head. ‚ÄúRight, good plan.‚Äù

They‚Äôre walking back from potions. Slughorn kept them late in an attempt to once again woo them into joining his dinner parties. They, of course, refused, but it means the corridors are mostly empty, everyone else already done with classes for the day.

‚ÄúMerlin, I can‚Äôt believe you just called the Cleansweeps aerodynamic,‚Äù James laughs to himself.

‚ÄúOh whatever, you snob. You just like the Nimbus line cause it‚Äôs posher.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope you appreciate the irony of you calling anyone posh mr I-took-ballet-until-I-was-nine.‚Äù
Sirius sends him a flat stare. ‚ÄúIt was ballroom actually.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh well,‚Äù James can‚Äôt help but snicker, ‚Äúin that case, that‚Äôs well rough.‚Äù

Sirius tries to trip him but only partially succeeds, which mostly ends up with the pair of them jostling down the hallway.

‚ÄúLike you‚Äôre any different,‚Äù Sirius says when they eventually push away from each other, both grinning. ‚ÄúYou know most people don‚Äôt have a whole bloody quidditch pitch in their back garden right?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a full quidditch pitch, it‚Äôs only‚Äî‚Äú

They round the corner and James feels his words suck themselves back down his throat as he comes face to face with a pair of wide grey eyes.

Of course, the shock on Regulus‚Äôs face only lasts for about a second before he slides his mask of casual dislike into place. Gaze quickly shifting from James to Sirius.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù he says coldly.

‚ÄúRegulus.‚Äù

James says nothing, he figures that‚Äôs probably what‚Äôs expected of him. Which is good, because his pulse has rammed itself so far up his throat he‚Äôs not sure he could manage speaking right now.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Sirius says after several more seconds of tense silence, ‚Äúas fun as this is, we‚Äôve gotta go so,‚Äù Sirius looks at James who nods as they start walking again, Sirius making a bit of a show of walking around Regulus who is still standing there. All and all James thinks it‚Äôs not so bad, a little awkward but it could‚Äôve been‚Äî

‚ÄúHe asks about you, you know?‚Äù

Sirius freezes.

James looks over at him and silently begs him to just walk away. But Sirius‚Äôs eyes have gone dark and James knows, even before his friend starts to turn around, that there‚Äôs no getting out of this now.

Fuck.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs interesting,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs voice is so falsely casual it makes James cringe, ‚Äúsince he never seemed to care much about me when I was around.‚Äù

Their father, James thinks, looking between the two brothers. They‚Äôre talking about their father.
‚ÄúNobody does the right thing all the time Sirius, people make mistakes.‚Äù

And that makes Sirius laugh‚Äîcold and sharp.

‚ÄúMistakes? Is that what you think they‚Äôre making? Come on little brother, you‚Äôre smarter than that,‚Äù Sirius leers, stepping closer, James follows behind incase he has to stop them from killing each other. Both of them burn cold‚Äîwhen they get angry they don‚Äôt yell or bluster. They turn their smiles into knives and carve you into pieces. It fucking terrifying to watch.

‚ÄúIn order for something to be a mistake you have to feel guilty about it,‚Äù Sirius goes on, him and Reg have eyes only for each other.

‚ÄúYou know that he‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúBeing sick doesn‚Äôt make you a good person.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes narrow. ‚ÄúThere are no ‚Äúgood‚Äù people,‚Äù he says flatly. ‚ÄúThere are just people. That‚Äôs it. This isn‚Äôt a fairytale.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that how you do it? How you live with yourself?‚Äù Sirius asks darkly, now far too close for James‚Äôs comfort. Regulus doesn‚Äôt respond, hands curled in fists at his sides but at least he‚Äôs not reaching for his wand.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right Reg,‚Äù Sirius goes on, neither of them looking away, not for a second. ‚ÄúNobody can do the right thing all the time. But the problem with you lot,‚Äù his eyes trail over his brother in mild disgust, ‚Äúis you don‚Äôt even try.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause before Regulus lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúWhat exactly makes you think you‚Äôre any different? What great injustice are you righting Sirius? All you‚Äôve done is runaway, like a coward,‚Äù he spits the last word out of his mouth and now James does step forward, hand taking hold of Sirius‚Äôs arm to keep him from lunging.

‚ÄúYou think you‚Äôre some kind of hero? You think you accomplished something the night you left? Because to me it just looks like you‚Äôre doing what you‚Äôve always done, which is look out for your fucking self.‚Äù

Sirius jolts forward, James yanking him back as Regulus pulls out his wand.

‚ÄúHey, enough!‚Äù James shouts, pinning both of Sirius‚Äôs arms behind his back to keep him from reaching for his own wand.

Regulus isn‚Äôt looking at James, eyes intent on his brother.

‚ÄúI said enough!‚Äù Sirius is struggling against his grip, trying to throw his elbows back into James‚Äôs stomach so he can get himself free. James grunts as Sirius lands a well aimed kick to his shin, feeling his grip start to slip. ‚ÄúFuck‚ÄîRegulus‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou really want to call me a coward Reg?‚Äù Sirius asks. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd let her use you as a fucking rug if you thought it would make her love you. It‚Äôs pathetic!‚Äù

James sees it, just barely, the switch in Reg‚Äôs grip, the look in his eyes. He throws them against the wall just as the curse shoots silently out of Regulus wand.

‚ÄúYou fucking psycho‚Äî‚Äú Sirius is yelling, James barely keeping his grip as he holds him against the wall.

‚ÄúREGULUS PUT THE FUCKING WAND DOWN.‚Äù

Regulus looks at James for the first time and James feels the air empty out of his lungs. He doesn‚Äôt know that face. He doesn‚Äôt know those eyes. They certainly aren‚Äôt the same ones that snuck to his bedside in the infirmary and held him like it meant something.

It takes a few more seconds before Regulus puts his wand back in his pocket, eyes returning to his still struggling brother. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a disgrace,‚Äù he says coldly, picking up the books he dropped in the scuffle and turning his back on them.

‚ÄúOh, fuck you Reg!‚Äù Sirius shouts after him as he turns the corner.

James‚Äôs mouth feels dry.

‚ÄúProngs‚ÄîJesus‚Äîlet me go you prick!‚Äù

‚ÄúShit, sorry,‚Äù Sirius stumbles forward out of his grasp, both of them breathing heavy. Sirius glares at the place where his brother disappeared, James doing his best to get the look on Regulus‚Äôs face out of his head.

Finally, Sirius rounds on him, ‚ÄúWhat the hell was that?‚Äù he demands.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù James feels off balance, like he can‚Äôt quite get a grip on the world around him.

Sirius gestures emphatically at the spot where Regulus had been standing. ‚ÄúSince when do you protect him?‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt protect him,‚Äù James says automatically, which he thinks might actually be true but doesn‚Äôt make him feel any better.

‚ÄúYou held me back!‚Äù

‚ÄúHe had his fucking wand out, if you took a swing he was going to hex your bloody arms off.‚Äù

‚ÄúI would have drawn mine first if you hadn‚Äôt already been pulling me away!‚Äù

James lets out an exasperated sigh, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúSo what, Sirius? I was supposed to just stand back and watch you kill each other?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he fumes. ‚ÄúYou were supposed to fucking help me! You were supposed to have my back!‚Äù

‚ÄúTwo against one‚Äôs not exactly fair.‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing is fair‚Äîwhat about any of this seems fair to you?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell now you sound just like him!‚Äù

That catches Sirius off guard, catches James off guard too if he‚Äôs being honest. Sirius physically steps back and James feels his stomach lurch. He expects more shouting but there isn‚Äôt any, after a few minutes Sirius brings his hands up to his face. The hallway feels too big all of the sudden. Too quiet.

‚ÄúHe just makes me so fucking angry sometimes,‚Äù Sirius says eventually. ‚ÄúI hate that he‚Äôs like that‚Äîthat he defends them, that he plays their games. And I used to feel like I knew that he didn‚Äôt really think it was okay, any of the stuff they say or‚Äî‚Äù Sirius lets out a breath looking down at the floor for a moment, ‚Äúbut fuck, I don‚Äôt know anymore, maybe he does. Because he won‚Äôt fight it. Won‚Äôt stand up for himself. Won‚Äôt stand up for anything. It drives me nuts.‚Äù

James feels suddenly exhausted, head swimming in a way he decides to blame on the bludger instead of Reg. He‚Äôs not sure what to say, what to do.

‚ÄúListen don‚Äôt‚Äîdon‚Äôt bite my head off for this yeah?‚Äù James starts, which gets a snort out of Sirius.

‚ÄúStrong start.‚Äù

James grimaces. ‚ÄúHave you tried‚Ä¶talking to him? I mean, actually talking to him? Not just shouting insults at each other or whatever that was,‚Äù he waves vaguely at the empty hallway around them. ‚ÄúTalking to him outside of that house?‚Äù Sirius stiffens at the mention of Grimmauld place.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt talk to him,‚Äù Sirius says simply. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a wall. It‚Äôs all family and duty and when I try and ask him what he actually thinks he just shrugs me off. Like it‚Äôs not important,‚Äù Sirius laughs dryly, digging the heels of his palms into his eyes. ‚ÄúLike thinking isn‚Äôt important. Which is what they want you know, fucking mindless zombies who‚Äôll do whatever they say. I could never do that‚Äîcould never hollow myself out the way he could.‚Äù

It takes a lot of work for James to hold himself still, to keep from flinching. He thinks of Regulus up in the tower, talking about having to hide parts of himself away. How it made things easier. And he wonders how much of himself he puts in boxes.

‚ÄúMaybe if he knew he had somewhere he could go‚Ä¶‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes snap up and James tries to look casual.

‚ÄúMy mum, this summer, she said something‚Äîwell, she said she was going to try and get him out of there‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù Sirius demands, surprised.

‚ÄúYou know her,‚Äù fighting to keep his voice level. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs gotta save everyone.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a moment before Sirius nods. ‚ÄúYeah. You‚Äôre like her that way.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt know why that aches. ‚ÄúBloody annoying I expect,‚Äù he offers Sirius a weak smile that his friend returns.

‚ÄúYeah, it is, but‚Ä¶you know, saved me so‚Ä¶can‚Äôt really complain.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù he says around the lump in throat, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre Sirius Black, you saved yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh fuck off James, stop trying to make me cry in the middle of the bloody corridor,‚Äù he laughs as he punches James in the arm.

‚ÄúTold you Black, you‚Äôre going soft.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, yeah, like you aren‚Äôt a bleeding fucking heart.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù James says as they start walking slowly in the direction of the common room, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre turning into Hufflepuffs.‚Äù

Sirius gives him a look of outrage. ‚ÄúBite your tongue.‚Äù

This time James laughs big.

¬†

He doesn‚Äôt know whether to go to the tower or not. After what happened. After finding out that the others know. He lays in his bed, staring up at the canopy, tapping his fingers anxiously on his stomach. But eventually he gets up. Of course he does. Taking the map and looking nervously at Sirius‚Äôs bed before slipping out the door.

He‚Äôa more cautious this time, constantly checking his surroundings, not for Filch, but for his friends. It‚Äôs only a matter of time really, Sirius wont be able to let this go forever. Honestly he‚Äôs kind of impressed Sirius hasn‚Äôt already tried to follow him. If It‚Äôd been the other way around James is pretty sure he‚Äôd have done it the second night. He expects he has Moony to thank for Sirius‚Äôs restraint.

‚ÄúAnd your parents told you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI told you not to try and save me James.‚Äù

‚ÄúGod, you and your brother are so melodramatic,‚Äù James stands up now too, levelling Regulus with a look. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not a loss cause Regulus, you‚Äôre not.‚Äù

That seems to take the younger boy by surprise and James watches him fight with himself, watches him chew up the words as they try to escape his mouth.

‚ÄúNot everyone can be a hero,‚Äù he says eventually.

‚ÄúThere aren‚Äôt any heroes, remember? You said that. No heroes, no villains, just people.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a hero Reg.‚Äù

Part of James‚Äôs brain‚Äîthe loud part‚Äîscreams

Yes.

Yes this.

Please.

More.

Careful.

Be careful.

Be careful with him.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll stop eventually.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs expression goes from surprised to annoyed in no time. ‚ÄúWhat way?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre we?‚Äù

Regulus laughs, passing a hand over his face. ‚ÄúI really should, but it‚Äôs nice that you don‚Äôt think so.‚Äù

‚ÄúI told you that I didn‚Äôt want to take anything from you,‚Äù he looks right into Regulus‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúI meant that Reg. I mean that.‚Äù

James lets himself smile a little. ‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs fucked me up yet, or at least that‚Äôs what I‚Äôve been told.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not.‚Äù

James shrugs. ‚ÄúMaybe, but, you know, I have a lot to give. More than most people I think. You can take it if you want. I‚Äôll let you have whatever you want Reg.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe right thing?‚Äù James manages to ask.

Regulus looks at him sadly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to let you go James, not until you make me. Not until you tell me you don‚Äôt want me. I should, I never should have let this start. Somehow those words hurt and feel good all at the same time, tangling up inside of James like the rest of it.

‚ÄúI want you,‚Äù he says a breathlessly. ‚ÄúI want you Reg.‚Äù

The other boy‚Äôs eyes close briefly before he steps forward, slow, careful, and James lets him. It‚Äôs not like it was before, it‚Äôs careful, breakable. And James thinks, this is what they mean, when they say love is falling.

Because he doesn‚Äôt know where the floor is.

Because he knows it‚Äôs going to hurt when they hit the ground.

Chapter End Notes

Hello lovelies!

This chapter was really hard to write for some reason so hopefully it turned out okay - I really struggled to get that ending right.

Honestly, I say it every time, but getting to read the comments on this story has been really nice so THANK YOU.

Chapter 9

Chapter Summary

Surprise it's Christmas (almost)!

Chapter Notes

I just wanted to real quick address something I know has been talked about in the fandom recently (and also is just important):

The characters in this story are minors, now, I still have some sexual content because a) teenagers do have sex and b) I want them to have conversations about consent and boundaries and (eventually) trauma because it's relevant (I think) to the characters BUT I try to do it in a way that isn't too explicit or graphic because, again, minors.

Hopefully I manage not to cross any boundaries but if any of you feel like I do, give me a shout, I'm always happy to make changes if something makes someone feel uncomfortable

Okay, I'm done now, thank you for coming to my TedTalk!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

‚ÄúIt just doesn‚Äôt make any sense!‚Äù

There‚Äôs a collective groan from the room.

‚ÄúIt makes perfect sense,‚Äù James says indignantly, cheeks flushed from the firewhiskey.

‚ÄúLily, it‚Äôs a lost cause,‚Äù Remus sends her sympathetic look. ‚ÄúBelieve me, I‚Äôve tried. It‚Äôs like a cult.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll sports are cults, but at least muggle ones don‚Äôt have a ball worth a hundred-and-fifty points that automatically ends the game,‚Äù she tilts the drink she‚Äôs holding back into her mouth, fiery red hair piled in a messy bun on top of her head.

‚ÄúOr have a ball that‚Äôs trying to kill you,‚Äù Remus adds.

She gestures to him emphatically with her bottle. ‚ÄúExactly!‚Äù

It‚Äôs the night before Christmas Holidays and nearly all of the Gryffindor upper years are sitting around the common room drinking.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù James says solemnly. ‚ÄúI hope you know that you‚Äôre breaking my heart.‚Äù

The other boy rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll get over it.‚Äù

‚ÄúCome on James,‚Äù Lily pushes, ‚Äúyou must see how mad it is‚Äîyou nearly got beheaded in your last game.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat,‚Äù Frank cuts in emphatically, ‚Äúwas Bones‚Äôs fault, not quidditch‚Äôs. It was a bad play.‚Äù

‚ÄúHere, here,‚Äù Mary lifts her drink in the air and Marlene giggles.

‚ÄúI mean, it was kind of quidditch‚Äôs fault.‚Äù

‚ÄúDue to the aforementioned murder balls,‚Äù Remus backs Lily up.

‚ÄúExactly,‚Äù she says again, laughing a bit. ‚ÄúHow do they not see it?‚Äù

‚ÄúCult, this is what I‚Äôm saying.‚Äù

‚ÄúA safe reasonable room,‚Äù Lily corrects.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think anyone was talking about boners darling,‚Äù Alice sing-songs from her spot next to Frank.

That gets a laugh from everyone but Remus, who looks very determinedly at the fireplace. It‚Äôs been weeks but James still catches them avoiding eye contact, or not standing too close. The older boy rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúAs if you need me to Potter. Doesn‚Äôt your family have a private box at the stadium outside of London?‚Äù

James glares at him. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt eat caviar at quidditch matches.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, do you eat caviar at other times?‚Äù Lily asks, a little bemused.

‚ÄúCome now Evans,‚Äù Sirius pulls back his shoulders and tilts up his nose, speaking in his haughtiest voice. ‚ÄúWhat do you expect us to eat? Fish sticks? Crisps? Our aristocratic constitutions simply would not stand for it. No, give me caviar or give me death!‚Äù

‚ÄúGive me caviar or give me death,‚Äù Marlene laughs. ‚ÄúI need that on a t-shirt.‚Äù Which makes Sirius look far too pleased with himself.

‚ÄúOh they‚Äôll have you,‚Äù Alice squeezes his arm. ‚ÄúYou and me both.‚Äù

If she‚Äôs offended by the looks of surprise she doesn‚Äôt show it, flashing Peter a toothy grin. ‚ÄúWell, someone‚Äôs gotta protect you lot from the baddies, don‚Äôt they?‚Äù
