Snape‚Äôs voice manages to weasel its way unwelcome into James‚Äôs thoughts;

This is all irrelevant Potter, all so insignificant compared to what‚Äôs coming. And it‚Äôs not going to be long now, I can wait. I can be so patient.

‚ÄúI have an idea,‚Äù Mary says suddenly, causing them all to start. She sits forward on the sofa, absentmindedly running her fingers through Marlene‚Äôs hair.

‚ÄúWhy does that sound like a threat when you say it?‚Äù Lily asks, unable to keep the amusement out of her voice.

‚ÄúCouldn‚Äôt tell you dear, now, what do you lot say to a round of spin the bottle?‚Äù

Both Marlene and Lily groan.

‚ÄúOooh, yes,‚Äù Alice claps her hands, ‚ÄúI am very into that!‚Äù

‚ÄúI like the way your brain works Macdonald,‚Äù Sirius seconds, earning him a wink from Mary that has James wondering, not for the first time, how it is that they didn‚Äôt make it work. The two of them are so bloody similar.

‚ÄúOh because that doesn‚Äôt sound awkward at all,‚Äù Remus says flatly.

James lifts his glass to him. ‚ÄúI agree with Moony.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you just go join him and Evans in their reasonable-boner-killing-no-fun-room then,‚Äù it‚Äôs Sirius‚Äôs turn to kick James, nearly spilling his drink.

‚ÄúOi, watch it you heathen!‚Äù

Mary reaches over and ruffles Peter‚Äôs hair. ‚ÄúWhat about you Pete? What do you say?‚Äù she gives him a smile that James thinks is thoroughly unfair.

Peter‚Äôs cheeks go red. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîuh‚Äîyeah, yeah sure. Why not, could be‚Äîuh‚Äîfun.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúMerlin Peter.‚Äù

Mary sits back looking quite pleased with herself. ‚ÄúExcellent,‚Äù she claps her hands together. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the majority then, so we‚Äôre playing.‚Äù

‚ÄúFirst of all, no it isn‚Äôt,‚Äù Remus says. ‚ÄúAnd second of all, I don‚Äôt remember agreeing to be part of a democracy.‚Äù

Mary turns her big brown eyes on him, batting her lashes in a way that makes even James‚Äôs stomach swoop, but Remus only gives her a flat look.

‚ÄúYeah, not gonna work on me Macdonald.‚Äù

Marlene snorts.

‚ÄúRemus, I love you, I ever tell you that?‚Äù James says, smiling.

‚ÄúAlmost constantly James, it‚Äôs getting a bit much if I‚Äôm being honest.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust waiting for the day you say it back babe.‚Äù

Sirius reaches his arm impatiently towards the sofa. ‚ÄúMacdonald, bottle?‚Äù sounding suddenly irritated for some reason. James sends him a questioning look but Sirius very determinedly ignores him.

Mary reaches over to the coffee table beside her, grabbing one of her empties and passing it down to Sirius who places it firmly in the middle of the carpet.

‚ÄúYour game Macdonald, you start.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt mind if I do,‚Äù she leans over Marlene, giving the bottle a practiced twist.

James feels warm as he looks out at his friends, all gathered in the holly covered common room, muggle Christmas lights, that Mary insisted on hanging-up, draped over the fireplace, casting everything in a rainbow glow.

‚ÄúOh boy,‚Äù Sirius gives Peter a slap on the back as the bottle slows right in front of him. Peter‚Äôs eyes grow to about twice their normal size, staring at the bottle like he‚Äôs never seen one before.

‚ÄúI think he‚Äôs going to combust,‚Äù Lily murmurs beside James, who can‚Äôt help but snort.

‚ÄúYeah, in his pants.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin, James,‚Äù she reaches over and punches his arm even though they‚Äôre both laughing.

‚ÄúAlright Petey,‚Äù Mary is clearly enjoying the effect that she‚Äôs having on Peter. ‚ÄúC‚Äômere,‚Äù

‚ÄúOh no,‚Äù Marlene crawls out from between Mary‚Äôs legs and moves towards Lily. ‚ÄúYou are not kissing overtop of me.‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúPrude.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeter?‚Äù Remus leans forward, waving his hand in front of Peter‚Äôs face, which appears to be frozen, along with the rest of him. ‚ÄúI think we might have broken him.‚Äù

Mary sighs, blowing a strand of curly brown hair out of her face. ‚ÄúOh honestly,‚Äù she pushes off of the sofa, taking Peter‚Äôs face very purposefully between her hands and bringing them together with an almost comical ‚Äúsmack.‚Äù

‚ÄúGodric‚Äôs sake Mary don‚Äôt hurt the boy,‚Äù Alice laughs, burying her face in Franks‚Äôs shoulder.

After several seconds the two Gryffindors part, Peter‚Äôs eyes somehow even wider.

‚ÄúAdequate,‚Äù Mary judges, before smiling and kissing the top of his head.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù he says, slightly dazed, and James doesn‚Äôt have the heart to tell him that ‚Äúadequate‚Äù is not exactly a compliment.

‚ÄúAw, look out our wittle Pwete, he‚Äôs a man now,‚Äù Sirius pinches his cheeks, and it‚Äôs a testament to how blissed out Peter is that he doesn‚Äôt even try to swat him away.

‚ÄúOkay Mckinnon,‚Äù Mary slides back into her spot on the sofa, ‚Äúyour turn.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt help but feel I‚Äôll be a disappointment after that,‚Äù Marlene says dryly, reaching for the bottle. It skids in a pathetic circle on the carpet, stopping rather inexactly between James and the empty armchair.

‚ÄúIs it a wash?‚Äù Lily asks, looking around.

‚ÄúNuh-uh,‚Äù Mary grins. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs you Potter.‚Äù

In all honesty, if it had to be anyone, he‚Äôs rather pleased it‚Äôs Marlene. James places his drink down and raises an eyebrow at her, as if to say; ‚Äúshall we?‚Äù

With a laugh she crawls across the circle to meet James halfway, her eyes bright and blue in the dim light of the room.

It‚Äôs a quick kiss, mouthes closed, lips both sticky from the alcohol. But it‚Äôs nice. Her hand holds his shoulder, his cups her face. It feels familiar. When they break apart she smiles at him.

‚ÄúAdequate.‚Äù

James can‚Äôt stop himself from laughing, ‚ÄúPlease McKinnon, I rocked your world.‚Äù

She sticks out her tongue at him.

He doesn‚Äôt miss the very pointed looks that Sirius sends him, the ‚Äúsee, what did I tell you?‚Äù looks. He does ignore them though.

‚ÄúRemus, your up,‚Äù Marlene passes the bottle to him as she leans back against the sofa, Mary‚Äôs hand in her hair again.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt remember agreeing to this,‚Äù he takes the bottle with great trepidation.

‚ÄúLupin,‚Äù Mary sends him a pointed stare, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt make me fight you, because I will.‚Äù

Remus makes an exaggerated show of placing the bottle back in the middle of the floor. ‚ÄúI want it known that I‚Äôm only doing this because I one-hundred-percent believe you.‚Äù

Mary smiles. ‚ÄúNoted.‚Äù

With the air of the long suffering, Remus spins the bottle.

It hadn‚Äôt quite occurred to James just how awkward this game could get. He had been against it, of course, very aware of the red-head sitting next to him and the history he didn‚Äôt want to bring up with a kiss. Or of Sirius‚Äôs maybe-not-so-fake crush on Alice who was currently sitting with her boyfriend, who was also their captain, and who might not appreciate the two of them snogging in front of him. But he hadn‚Äôt considered what would happen if, say, Remus, spun the bottle and it landed on‚Äî

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù Mary lets out a half-laugh half-gasp as the bottle comes to a stop.

The ensuing silence is deafening.

Remus looks as though he wants the ground to swallow him whole, face suddenly pale as he stares very determinedly at his hands, Sirius gone rigid on the other side of Peter.

‚ÄúRe-spin?‚Äù Frank suggests, which elicits outraged noises from both Alice and Mary.

‚ÄúThat is not how the game works Frankfurt,‚Äù Mary says resolutely.

‚ÄúYeah, that‚Äôs not my na‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just re-spin because you didn‚Äôt get the person you wanted.‚Äù

‚ÄúHonestly, no need to be weird about it,‚Äù Alice adds, ‚ÄúJames would kiss Remus in a heartbeat, wouldn‚Äôt you Jamie?‚Äù

James does his best not to choke, wishing very much to be left out of it. ‚ÄúUh‚Äîyeah,‚Äù he manages eventually, not looking at anyone. ‚ÄúSure, ‚Äòcourse I would.‚Äù He hopes they can‚Äôt hear the strain in his voice.

‚ÄúI mean, it is a bit‚Ä¶‚Äù Pete starts, causing James‚Äôs heart to clench.

‚ÄúBit what?‚Äù Marlene‚Äôs voice is sharp as she turns to him.

‚ÄúI just meant‚Ä¶you know‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt actually,‚Äù Lily chimes in, causing James to look over at her, surprised and oddly relieved all at once. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean Peter?‚Äù

Peter‚Äôs eyes widen as he realizes the hole he‚Äôs dug himself into. ‚ÄúNo‚Äîno‚ÄîI just, I‚Äôm just saying that it would be weird to‚Ä¶you know‚Ä¶kiss a mate. That‚Äôs all.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou kissed me,‚Äù Mary says calmly. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt seem like you found it that weird.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo‚ÄîI mean‚Äîyes, but that‚Äîthat‚Äôs different.‚Äù

‚ÄúDifferent how?‚Äù Alice asks, leaning across Frank‚Äôs lap as she does so.

Peter is sweating now, eyes darting to James for help but finding none.

‚ÄúNo‚Äînever mind‚Äîforget I said anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell okay then,‚Äù Mary looks back to Sirius and Remus who have not moved or spoken since the bottle stopped spinning. ‚ÄúLets go boys.‚Äù

There are a few more moments of stillness before Remus reaches jerkily for the bottle, hand shaking as he passes it off to Lily, who takes it with a startled expression on her face.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not playing,‚Äù Remus says, still not looking at anyone.

Mary opens her mouth to object but James quickly cuts her off. ‚ÄúOkay Evans,‚Äù he says loudly, overly so, in the new silence that‚Äôs fallen around the group, ‚Äúlets see what you‚Äôve got.‚Äù

Lily, thankfully, seems to catch on quick. Smiling and spinning the bottle without question, effectively silencing Mary when it lands on Frank, earning a ‚Äúwoop-woop‚Äù from Alice and generally dissolving the tension.

James can‚Äôt quite get rid of the aching in his chest though, even while watching the spectacle that is Evans and Longbottom‚Äôs kiss. He had thought‚Äîhe had at least thought that Remus‚Ä¶but if this is how they react just to the idea of kissing‚Ä¶James tries to cover up his grimace by taking a swig of his drink.

He meets Marlene‚Äôs gaze only once, and finds exactly what he‚Äôs expecting.

Pity.

¬†

The game never quite recovers its momentum and after a few more spins the group breaks up, all yawns and sleepy goodnights and promises to say goodbye tomorrow before the train.

When James heads upstairs Remus and Sirius are the only ones left in the common room. He debates whether or not he should stay, but decides against it. Maybe it‚Äôll help‚Äîthe two of them being alone together‚Äîtalking.

Exhausted, he drags himself to their room, saying goodnight to Peter before drawing the curtains around his bed and waiting, all the while trying not to think about the sick look that had crossed Sirius‚Äôs face. Or Remus‚Äôs for that matter. About how it would feel to have them look at him that way.

Some weak part of him tries to find comfort in the fact that they don‚Äôt have to know. But it doesn‚Äôt work. Because in the end he‚Äôll still know, and besides, he doesn‚Äôt want it to be like this forever. To love always in the dark.

After a while he starts to hear Peter snore and pulls out the map. Regulus‚Äôs name hovers in the astronomy tower, the sight making James smile even while his chest aches. His eyes travel next to his two friends, still in the common room. He sighs, setting the map down and managing to stay still for a whole ten minutes longer before he can‚Äôt stand it anymore.

He grabs the invisibility cloak, slipping the map into the waistband of his pants and carefully opening the door so as to not wake Peter.

He‚Äôs about halfway down the stairs when he hears Remus and Sirius, not the words exactly, but the humming of their whispered voices. He slows his pace, making sure to be quiet. He‚Äôs not exactly certain how he‚Äôs planning to get through the portrait without them noticing, but he‚Äôs hoping an opportunity will present itself.

‚ÄúI miss you.‚Äù

James falters on the last step, the break in Sirius‚Äôs voice making him freeze. They‚Äôre still sitting in the same spots they were when he left, a good deal of distance between them. James can see Sirius‚Äôs face but Remus has his back to him.

‚ÄúGod, don‚Äôt,‚Äù Remus leans forward, dropping his head into his hands.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just the truth Remus,‚Äù when the silence stretches on he sighs, eyes like bleeding wounds, and James is struck by the pain that seems to sit in the room. He‚Äôd known they were fighting but he hadn‚Äôt thought‚Äî

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how to handle this.‚Äù

Remus laughs wetly. ‚ÄúMe, you mean?‚Äù

Sirius makes a pained noise. ‚ÄúNo‚Äîno I mean‚ÄîMerlin, I don‚Äôt‚ÄîI can‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú his hand runs angrily through his hair. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt Remus,‚Äù his words are shaky.

‚ÄúRight. Fine. You‚Äôve said. I understand.‚Äù

‚ÄúI doubt that.‚Äù

James swears that Remus actually growls. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt say that unless you‚Äôre going to explain yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry, okay, sorry,‚Äù Sirius grimaces but doesn‚Äôt offer any further explanation, his words followed by more silence.

James wonders how much talking they‚Äôve actually done since he went upstairs. It doesn‚Äôt feel like much.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm tired,‚Äù Remus exhales finally. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to bed.‚Äù

James quickly moves off the stairs and out of the way as he watches Remus get to his feet.

‚ÄúWait‚ÄîMoons, please just‚Äî‚Äú Sirius‚Äôs voice is wrecked and Remus must hear it too because he turns back, watching Sirius fight with himself.

‚ÄúYou‚Äîyou have to understand,‚Äù Sirius breathes with difficulty. ‚ÄúYou, James, Peter, you‚Äôre the only things that matter to me, in the whole world.‚Äù

Remus nods stiffly. ‚ÄúI get it Pads, we‚Äôre just friends. I do understand.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, that‚Äôs,‚Äù Sirius gets to his feet too now, closing the distance between them but not touching. ‚ÄúYou are important to me,‚Äù he says desperately, looking right into Remus‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúYou are so important and I‚Äôm scared I‚Äôm going to lose you‚Äîscared I‚Äôm already losing you and I can‚Äôt handle that Remus, I can‚Äôt. It‚Äôll break me. I just don‚Äôt know what to do here‚Äîwhat to do with‚Äîwith whatever it is that‚Äôs happened‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou kissed me, that‚Äôs what happened.‚Äù

James steps back, running right into the wall behind him and biting down on his lip so hard he draws blood just to keep himself quiet.

Holy shit.

Holy shit.

Holy.

Shit.

Sirius looks like he‚Äôs just been slapped, eyes going to the stairwell. At first James is worried he‚Äôs made some sort of noise but then Remus scoffs.

‚ÄúNo one can hear me Sirius, they‚Äôre all asleep, Merlin.‚Äù

Sirius keeps staring though, as though expecting someone to come after him. His mum, James realizes, recognizing that look, the fear that only Walburga can bring out in him.

‚ÄúRemus, please,‚Äù Sirius is whispering now, and James isn‚Äôt sure what it is he‚Äôs begging for.

Remus sounds defeated. ‚ÄúYou told me not to say anything and I won‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut I didn‚Äôt want‚Äî‚Äú Sirius swallows with some difficulty. ‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt even look at me.‚Äù

James is well aware that he shouldn‚Äôt be here. Shouldn‚Äôt be hearing any of this. But he can‚Äôt very well walk out of the portrait hole now and he‚Äôs pretty sure that if Sirius hears the door upstairs he‚Äôll freak. Also, if he‚Äôs being honest with himself, he wants to hear this.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù Remus says finally, the name soft in his mouth. ‚ÄúI just‚Äîit‚Äôs hard, that‚Äôs all.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

Remus reaches out but drops his hand before it gets to him, sighing as he pinches the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt know what you want from me. You were so scared and then it was like, every time I came near you, I could feel that fear and I‚ÄîI hate the idea that I make you feel like that. So I just thought‚Ä¶it‚Äôd be easier for you‚Äîfor both of us‚Äîto‚Ä¶stay away. For a bit.‚Äù

Sirius shakes his head, eyes big, looking so young it startles James. ‚ÄúI need you Moony,‚Äù he begs. ‚ÄúI always need you. I know this is‚Äîmy fault‚Äîthat I messed it all up‚Äî‚Äù

Remus cuts him off. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what this is about.‚Äù

And James wonders if Sirius understands what that means because he surely doesn‚Äôt. There‚Äôs a moment of tense stillness before Sirius finally manages to speak.

‚ÄúThen what‚Äôs it about Moony?‚Äù

Remus shakes his head turning away from Sirius and therefor towards James, which is strange. Strange to have him staring nearly straight at him with that heartbroken look on his face.

‚ÄúWhy did you kiss me Sirius?‚Äù

The other boy looks lost. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

Lie, James thinks, but he can‚Äôt tell if Remus spots it as easily.

Remus nods, resigned. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what this is about.‚Äù

Several minutes pass in which Sirius opens and closes his mouth but no sound makes it out. Eventually, Remus looks back at him, putting him out of his misery.

‚ÄúWhen you figure it out let me know, yeah? Until then‚Ä¶you haven‚Äôt lost me, I just can‚Äôt‚ÄîI can‚Äôt be there all the time. It‚Äôs too hard.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs voice is something broken. ‚ÄúI never wanted to make life harder for you.‚Äù

Remus bites down on his lower lip, trying and failing to keep back the wounded noise that rips out of him. Sirius steps forward but Remus waves him off.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to bed,‚Äù he says, choked, not waiting for a reply before he blows past James and up the stairs.

James watches Sirius sit alone on the sofa, head in his hands, for a long time.

¬†

‚ÄúI was beginning to give up on you,‚Äù Regulus says when James bursts through the door to the astronomy tower. He‚Äôs over by the railing, looking out at the view. The grounds are beautiful right now, blanketed in a snow that sparkles under the moonlight. Regulus‚Äôs warming charm is barely able to keep the cold out.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù James says breathlessly, ‚Äúthanks for waiting I‚Äî‚Äú he steps closer, holding his hands out, desperate to touch him. ‚ÄúCan I?‚Äù

Regulus looks at him curiously. James knows how he sounds‚Äîheartbroken. It‚Äôs how he feels.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

He pulls him in immediately, pressing Regulus‚Äôs body against his own. Regulus lets him‚Äîlets him open his mouth, lets him inside; warm and desperate.

Eventually they part, breathing heavy, Regulus‚Äôs hands coming up to circle his wrists. ‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù he asks, searching James‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happened?‚Äù

James shakes his head, brushing their foreheads against one another. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry for how I was, the first time you kissed me.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes widen. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúJames, I was drunk and I pounced on you,‚Äù James snorts but Regulus ignores him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I could have expected anything else‚ÄîI certainly could have expected worse.‚Äù

And James hates that. The image of Remus‚Äôs face‚ÄîSirius‚Äôs‚Äîinvading his thoughts.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm still sorry, I know that must have felt‚Äî‚Äú but he doesn‚Äôt have the words to finish that thought, so instead he leans forward and kisses him again, slow and sweet.

They stay there, pressed together like that, in comfortable silence, until eventually Regulus‚Äôs hand comes up and tugs on his collar. ‚ÄúCome,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI have something to show you.‚Äù

James arches his brow as Regulus pulls away, moving towards the door. ‚ÄúYou have something to show me?‚Äù he repeats.

Regulus nods, mistaking James‚Äôs stillness for worry. ‚ÄúI doubt anyone will be around at this hour, Filch is usually asleep in his office by now and the Prefects will be long done their rounds.‚Äù

‚ÄúWow, very knowledgeable about sneaking about after dark aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù James muses as he follows him into the stairwell, his eyes darting momentarily to the spot outside the door where he stashed the invisibility cloak. He‚Äôll just have to come back for it latter.

‚ÄúLike I‚Äôve said before, you and my brother are not the only ones who break the rules.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll have to excuse me if your ironed pants and perfectly coiffed hair don‚Äôt scream rebel,‚Äù he lowers his voice as they slip into the corridor, Regulus lighting his wand but keeping it low.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I must have misplaced my leather jacket and Doc Martens,‚Äù Regulus quips back and it‚Äôs work for James to hold his laughter in.

He has a vague idea of where they are in the castle‚Äîsomewhere on the seventh floor‚Äîbut after a few turns it‚Äôs easy to get lost and he feels his hands itching to pull out the map.

‚ÄúReg, where are you taking me?‚Äù

‚ÄúShh,‚Äù he hushes, ‚Äúyou‚Äôll see.‚Äù

James can‚Äôt help but smile, feeling some of the weight in his chest lighten.

They walk for another ten minutes or so before Regulus stops in front of an empty wall.

‚ÄúWell, this is fascinating,‚Äù James says dryly, earning him an elbow to the side.

‚ÄúJust wait,‚Äù Regulus steps forward and starts pacing back and forth in front of the wall, muttering to himself. Which, James has to admit, is mildly concerning. He‚Äôs about to step in when suddenly the wall trembles, lines distorting as a door pulls itself out of the stone.

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù James gasps.

Regulus, who has stopped his pacing, shoots him a grin over his shoulder. ‚ÄúShall we?‚Äù

James‚Äôs mouth is fully open, like some kind of cartoon character, looking from Regulus to the door and back again. ‚ÄúReg, did you just magic a room into existence?‚Äù

His grin widens. ‚ÄúMight‚Äôve,‚Äù he pushes through the door, James stumbling after him.

The room inside is warm‚Äîactually, it reminds James a lot of the Gryffindor common room‚Äîthere‚Äôs an ornate fireplace, dark oak walls covered in tapestries, comfortable looking chairs and sofas everywhere. The one noticeable difference, would be the bed.

James walks into the centre looking around, the ceiling, he notices, has been painted. He‚Äôs seen murals like this in older wizarding homes, but never at Hogwarts. There are people he doesn‚Äôt recognize who don‚Äôt move or appear to be wearing robes, and, in the centre, a man holding a pale body.

‚ÄúWhat is this place?‚Äù James drops his gaze back down to Regulus who has put his wand away and is currently leaning against the wall looking smug.

‚ÄúThe house elves call it the Come and Go Room, it appears when someone needs it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äî‚Äú James struggles to get his thoughts in order. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs bloody brilliant!‚Äù He turns about himself again, taking it all in.

‚ÄúI figured it was getting a little cold for the tower, besides, as long as we‚Äôre in here, no one else can find us unless we want them to.‚Äù

Those words drift through James‚Äôs head as he walks forward, running his hand along the soft upholstery on the sofa. No one can find them. ‚ÄúThe map,‚Äù he breathes, ‚Äúit‚Äôs not on the map.‚Äù They hadn‚Äôt known about it, so it‚Äôs not plotted, which means that, as long as they‚Äôre here, the marauders won‚Äôt be able to see them.

‚ÄúMap?‚Äù he hears Regulus ask behind him.

Oh.

Right.

James turns around to find Regulus looking at him curiously. He knows he could lie, it wouldn‚Äôt be that hard. But he doesn‚Äôt want to.

‚ÄúI have something to show you too,‚Äù he says finally, pulling out the parchment from his waistband. Regulus raises his brow, stepping forward. He hands it over to Reg, who, if anything, looks even more confused.

‚ÄúJames, this is just‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWait,‚Äù he pulls out his wand and taps the centre. ‚ÄúI solemnly swear that I am up to no good.‚Äù

He always feels a little jolt of pleasure when the map springs to life, their finely penned names coming into focus before the panels fold out, revealing the castle. Honestly, it might be the most impressive thing they‚Äôve ever done.

For a moment Regulus says nothing, staring down at the map in awe. ‚ÄúIs this‚Äîis this showing the entire school?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd everyone in it?‚Äù

James grins. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúMerlin that‚Äôs‚Äîthat‚Äôs incredible.‚Äù

James preens, feeling thoroughly pleased with himself.

‚ÄúYou made this?‚Äù he looks back up at James who shrugs.

‚ÄúMoo‚ÄîRemus did most of the heavy lifting, me and Sirius were mostly moral support.‚Äù

Regulus squints at him before turning back to the map. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre being modest,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúYour magic is all over this.‚Äù

That surprises James. ‚ÄúYou can feel my magic?‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hello Lovelies!

Gosh, they're so cute! I should warn you, that things are maybe going to be much less cute in the next chapter so, brace yourselves.

Also, if you're interested, this is the painting they're talking about: https://www.nationalgalleries.org/art-and-artists/5009/achilles-lamenting-death-patroclus

As always, your comments are sunshine and rainbows, thanks so much!

Chapter 10

Chapter Summary

Welcome to the Noble and Most Ancient House of Black.

Chapter Notes

TW: Sexual assault (not graphically described)
TW: Child Abuse (Mostly magical, mostly psychological, a little physical)
TW: Trauma/PTSD/Anxiety/Panic Attack
TW: Threatened forced outing (Idk if this is a TW but, like, just incase)

OKAY as you can tell this is heavy, hopefully done in a way that is respectful of all these experiences

Last thing: the purpose of this is to understand Regulus, it's not to excuse him, or any of the bad things he may or may not do in this or any future chapters

Alright sorry I'm done, I promise to stop ranting at the top of these chapters

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Regulus was eleven the first time he fell in love with James Potter. It was really rather inconvenient, since he had already decided to hate him. Not for any of the obvious reasons‚Äîthe tension between their families, the impending war‚Äîbut because, until Sirius went to Hogwarts, Regulus had been his best friend. They would make forts, and read stories, and go for adventures in the back garden. When Regulus had a nightmare Sirius was there. When their mother was angry Sirius was there. When their father got sick Sirius was there.

But the summer after his first year at Hogwarts all Sirius could talk about was James Potter. James Potter this and James Potter that and oh wasn‚Äôt he so fantastic. Regulus quickly grew to despise him. A feeling his mother seemed to share. It wasn‚Äôt that her and Sirius had ever gotten along particularly well, Sirius had never been very good at being quiet or sitting still or keeping his clothes clean. But they didn‚Äôt start hating each other until Sirius went to Hogwarts. Until James Potter came along.

So when he boarded the train the following September, with his mother whispering viscously in his ear about all the things she would do to him if he was to find himself sorted into Gryffindor like his brother, Regulus already hated James Potter. Sirius had dragged him into the compartment with his friends, and Lupin had been kind and Pettigrew a little jumpy and Potter‚ÄîPotter barely looked at him. They rarely interact except when forced and besides, Regulus was a first year, a little kid. It had never mattered to Sirius before that he was younger but‚Äînow he had Potter. So Regulus didn‚Äôt see his brother much. Or his brother‚Äôs friends. And mostly, he felt lost. He drifted through his classes, quiet and reserved, not wanting to draw too much attention to himself. Not wanting to be noticed. That was how he had always survived at Grimmauld Place. He assumed it would work at Hogwarts too.

He was wrong.

A few weeks into school Severus Snape found him kissing a boy. Or‚Äîperhaps more accurately‚Äîfound a boy kissing Regulus. At eleven, Regulus didn‚Äôt much fancy kissing anyone, he found the whole thing rather unbecoming if he was being honest. It had not occurred to eleven year old Regulus that Severus Snape, who barely had the strength in his lanky limbs to lift his own wand, was not going to out Roger Flint to the entire school. All he knew was that he didn‚Äôt want Sirius to know.

Oh how little things change.

So he did as Snape asked: ‚ÄúMy homework Black‚Äù ‚ÄúMy Laundry Black‚Äù ‚ÄúPush that Hufflepuff down the stairs Black.‚Äù Regulus did all of it. Unlike Sirius, he had always been good at doing what he was told.

A few months later, he watched James Potter punch Severus Snape in the face outside of the great hall. And, well, it was hard not to fall in love with him after that.

¬†

Regulus takes these memories and puts them in a box. And then he buries it. He digs deep inside himself, for the darkest, lowest corner, and he puts it there. He puts all of James there. You do not walk into Grimmauld Place with your walls down.

¬†

‚ÄúMistress Black is out for the afternoon but she tells Kreacher to inform his Young Master Regulus that she will be returning for supper at six o‚Äôclock sharp.‚Äù

Regulus nods, standing awkwardly in the middle of his bedroom, feeling like a ghost. A stranger.

‚ÄúKreacher is making Master Regulus‚Äôs favourite, roast pheasant.‚Äù

Regulus looks down at the elf and forces himself to smile. ‚ÄúThank you Kreacher, I really appreciate it.‚Äù

The elf preens. ‚ÄúOf course Master, Kreacher wants always to be a good help to the noble house of Black.‚Äù

Regulus swallows. ‚ÄúYou are. Always.‚Äù

He needs to get himself more under control, he knows that, he‚Äôs letting it all get to him. The grey walls, the heavy smell of the air, the missing photos on the walls. He can‚Äôt be full of cracks the first time he sees her.

‚ÄúIs‚Äîis my father up?‚Äù he asks finally.

Kreacher nods. ‚ÄúYes sir, he is very, very excited to be seeing Master Regulus Sir,‚Äù the elf does his best attempt at a smile, the sight oddly endearing despite all the teeth. ‚ÄúHe will be taking his tea now Sir, in his bed.‚Äù

Regulus nods. ‚ÄúExcellent, thank Kreacher, that‚Äôs all for now.‚Äù

Kreacher gives him a bow apparating out of the room before his head is raised.

Regulus closes his eyes, feeling the walls as much as he sees them. The weight of them, the pressure. There‚Äôs never any air in this fucking house. He breathes in deep, trying to calm the anxious tremors running up and down his bones. He exhales. All of these feelings are useless and he needs to be done with them. There‚Äôs no point in being afraid here. Better to wrap himself in a layer of apathy, of disinterest.

Nothing matters. If nothing matters than nothing hurts.

He opens his eyes, blinking the dim room back into focus and feeling the beginning of a familiar numbness spread through him. Good, he thinks, flexing his fingers, releasing some of the tension from his muscles.

There is no privacy in Grimmauld Place. The walls are covered in the shadowy silhouettes of the Blacks of yore. They whisper and scowl and scurry about. And all of them belong to his mother. Bend to her will. He feels their eyes on him now as he walks stiffly down to the floor below, their gazes making his skin itch.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters.

He pauses at his father‚Äôs open door, his parents don‚Äôt share a bedroom of course, they haven‚Äôt since Regulus was young. Since before his father got sick. In his memories, his father is a towering figure, with big warm hands and a domineering presence. He never spoke much, even back then, always quiet. Regulus knows that he takes after his father, just as he knows that Sirius takes after their mother. He‚Äôs sure they‚Äôve both ached over that truth.

Now his father is sitting in a chair by the window, flannel housecoat wrapped around him, dark hair shot through with white, the curls, once so like Regulus‚Äôs, gone limp.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters.

‚ÄúPapa?‚Äù

The older man‚Äôs head snaps to the doorway, on edge, suspicious, before he finds Regulus‚Äôs face and then he smiles. For a moment, it almost doesn‚Äôt look like he‚Äôs dying.

‚ÄúReggie!‚Äù he makes to stand but falters, his strength gone. Regulus has no doubt that Kreacher is the one who helped him into that chair in the first place. He crosses the room quickly so that his father won‚Äôt try again, bending down so that he can wrap his arms around him.

‚ÄúLook at you,‚Äù his father gushes as keeps his hands on Regulus‚Äôs shoulders even as he straightens up. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve grown.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been three months.‚Äù

But his father only grins. ‚ÄúAh, not up but in, mon chou, your eyes are far wiser than they were this summer.‚Äù

Regulus feels the twinge of something in his chest but quickly smothers it. It will not serve him to remember everything that has changed since the summer. Not here. Not now.

‚ÄúViens,‚Äù his father gestures to the chair across from him, ‚Äúasseyez-vous, asseyez-vous. Parle √† ton p√®re pendant un moment, parle-moi de ta vie, je deviens fou coinc√© dans cette pi√®ce.‚Äù His french is rapid, one word blending into the next. Orion spent most of his childhood growing up in the french countryside, so when he‚Äôs tired, or drunk, or sick, it‚Äôs the language that spills out of him. Regulus has always loved the way his father speaks French, the deep way his voice wraps around the vowels and hugs the end of each word. Slow and smooth, in a way English never can be.

His mother hates it, but it‚Äôs only because she‚Äôs not very good at it. Expensive tutors are no substitute for the real thing, and Walburga cannot stand to be outdone in anything.

‚ÄúOkay, okay,‚Äù Regulus takes a seat. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs really not that much to say‚ÄîI study, I play quidditch, that‚Äôs it,‚Äù he shrugs.

His father makes a scoffing noise, leaning slightly forward in his chair. ‚ÄúMore than play, you think you could pull of a Wronski Feint and Horace wouldn‚Äôt tell me, huh?‚Äù

Regulus feels himself blush. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt that impressive.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, I hear the scouts are already talking about you. You never know, you might be the youngest player to sign with a major team in quidditch history huh? On ne sait jamais.‚Äù

Don‚Äôt we? Regulus almost says. Because they both know that even if he was approached by a team‚Äînext year, two years from now‚ÄîWalburga would never allow it. He is needed for the cause. Everything else is dust.

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù he answers instead, looking out the window, the sky is nearly as grey as the wallpaper. ‚ÄúThey really keep you coup‚Äôd up in here all the time?‚Äù

His father makes irritated grumble. ‚ÄúBloody healers. Won‚Äôt let me do anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre only trying to help.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs certainly what they say.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes, turning back to his father who instantly holds his hands up in surrender. ‚ÄúMerde Reggie, don‚Äôt look at me like that. I‚Äôm following orders, doing what they say, I swear mon petit.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou better be.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am, I am, why do you think I‚Äôm so miserable huh?‚Äù he shoots Regulus a playful grin that the younger boy does his best to return.

‚ÄúOkay then.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay then,‚Äù his father mockingly repeats.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt sound like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou absolutely do mon chou.‚Äù

Instead of responding Regulus reaches for one of the biscuits on the untouched plate in front of him, eyeing his father‚Äôs thin frame as he takes his first bite.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not eating,‚Äù he says after he swallows. It‚Äôs not a question. His father is a shell of what he once was, shoulders slumped, skin hanging off his bones in unnatural ways.

‚ÄúI eat,‚Äù his father says dismissively, but Regulus only scowls, shoving the rest of his cookie in his mouth.

‚ÄúNot enough.‚Äù

Orion laughs. ‚ÄúJeez, who is the parent here?‚Äù

I don‚Äôt know, Regulus thinks, you tell me. But for the second time he holds his tongue.

His father pauses then, eyes flicking nervously towards the door.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not here,‚Äù Regulus says, answering the question that wasn‚Äôt asked.

Orion nods. ‚ÄúHave you spoken to your brother?‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs heart drops. Sirius is a dangerous topic in this household and he‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôs up for the task of walking through that minefield right now.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says slowly, not sure what else he can say, not when his father is looking at him like that. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs‚Ä¶well.‚Äù

His father smiles softly. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good.‚Äù

Regulus only nods, looking back out the window.

¬†

There was a wedge, between him and Sirius, the moment his brother could escape. The moment he didn‚Äôt have to rely on Regulus‚Äôs company alone anymore. But it wasn‚Äôt until last summer that Regulus thinks his brother really lost faith in him. It wasn‚Äôt the night he left‚Äînothing so explosive and obvious. It was a quiet moment, Regulus leaning against the doorway of Sirius‚Äôs bedroom, Sirius ignoring him.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you want me to do Sirius,‚Äù he‚Äôd asked, feeling equal parts annoyed and apologetic.

Sirius had sighed, rubbing his eyes like talking with Regulus was exhausting. Maybe it was.

‚ÄúI want you to fight back,‚Äù Sirius had said finally, the first words he‚Äôd spoken to Regulus all day. ‚ÄúFight back.‚Äù

Regulus answered before he could think better of it, before he could remember who he was speaking to;

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the point?‚Äù

Sirius had looked at him then, looked at him like he had never seen him before. Like he had no idea who he was. And maybe he didn‚Äôt.

¬†

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

He‚Äôs on his feet instantly, arms stiff at his sides as his mother opens the door to his room. She is a slight woman, dark hair pulled back tightly, dark robes pooling at her feet when she stands. She has Sirius‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúMaman,‚Äù he says stiffly, unsure which of her faces intends to show itself today.

Her eyes run him over before stepping forward, taking his chin sharply between her index finger and thumb. ‚ÄúYou look thin.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know what to say to that so he says nothing, remaining compliant and silent as she looks him over.

‚ÄúAnd your hair too long.‚Äù

He sometimes envies muggles, who have to put so much energy and intent behind all their actions, who have to walk everywhere, and pick everything up, and wait for things to finish. It all means so much less to wizards. It‚Äôs all too easy. Too quick. The words are barely out of his mother‚Äôs mouth before he feels the icy fingers of her magic. Curls falling lifeless at his feet. He looks down for a moment, mournful.

‚ÄúBetter,‚Äù his mother steps back, admiring her handiwork. ‚ÄúYour grades are good?‚Äù she asks sharply, the change in topic sudden but not surprising. Walburga is rarely wasteful with her words when it comes to her children.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúCome down, supper is ready. Tomorrow your cousins will be here.‚Äù

Regulus feels his stomach clench as she walks towards the door.

‚ÄúWhen are they coming?‚Äù he hopes she doesn‚Äôt hear the tension in his voice.

‚ÄúNoon,‚Äù Walburga tosses over her shoulder, already in the hall.

Regulus lets out a shaky breath, then lifts his hand to his newly cut hair. Well, cut is a bit generous. The hair is short and prickly and close to the scalp. Not completely gone, but about as short as it is possible to go. It shouldn‚Äôt ache. He‚Äôs not sure why it does.

He vanishes the hair on the floor on his way out the door.

¬†

He wants to fly but there‚Äôs no room. Not here in the city. Hidden behind layers and layers of secrecy charms. So he goes for a run instead.

The air is crisp, the pavement freshly cleared of snow. Regulus can see his breath freeze outside his lips as he forces it out of his lungs again and again. He‚Äôs not sure how long he‚Äôs been gone for, a while, if the aching in his muscles is anything to go by. Still, it‚Äôs not enough, still he can‚Äôt get himself to still, to quiet down. So he keeps going. Block after block. The sun is now fully in the sky, a bright day for December, though it has no warmth.

He doesn‚Äôt allow himself to think about anything except taking the next step, except fighting the weakness in his legs. He blocks out the world beyond London. Beyond Grimmauld. He doesn‚Äôt think about Hogwarts. Or about anything that transpired within it. And whenever those thoughts or feelings try to drag themselves to the surface he gets a new box. He digs a new hole. He buries himself deeper and deeper.

He can barely stand when he gets home.

¬†

‚ÄúMaster Regulus has missed his breakfast,‚Äù Kreacher says unhappily as Regulus drags himself into the kitchen, showered and clothed and light headed.

‚ÄúSorry Kreacher,‚Äù he says as he sits down at the work table, watching the elf rush about, preparing for lunch.

‚ÄúKreacher is told by Mistress that he cannot feed Regulus now, that he will have to wait for his cousins.‚Äù

Regulus nods slowly, resting his chin on his folded arms, and taking in a deep breath. It smells of caramelized onions and roast beef. His stomach responds accordingly.

Kreacher shoots him a look over his shoulder, but Regulus doesn‚Äôt move.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll wait,‚Äù he says, reassuring the elf.

But Kreacher only shakes his head. ‚ÄúI cannot be feeding Master Regulus, you understand? I have been told so, so I will not,‚Äù Regulus is opening his mouth to once again affirm that he understands when a plate of bread and cheeses appears in front of him.

‚ÄúHe would like to help Master Regulus very much but he simply cannot go against his Mistresses wishes.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, lifting his head up off his arms, a small smile pulling at his mouth.

‚ÄúThanks Kreacher,‚Äù he reaches for the food, that much hungrier now that it was in front of him.

‚ÄúDo not be thanking me, I am doing nothing,‚Äù but he swears he sees the elf wink.

Regulus has always liked the kitchen the best, maybe because it‚Äôs the the warmest place in the house, or because Kreacher always gives him some of what he‚Äôs cooking. Probably, he imagines, it‚Äôs because the rest of his family never really come in here. Not even Sirius, when he was still around. It‚Äôs a nice escape. A place where he can breathe a little easier.

It‚Äôs partially underground, the window above the sink level with the grass in the garden, the walls made of an untreated stone, the fireplace enormous and deep‚Äîallowing for all manner of cooking and brewing. The floor and table are unvarnished wood‚Äîeverything in this space is soft and natural and lacking the artifice that is strewn throughout the rest of the house. There are no portraits, no gaudy embellishments, nothing is covered in gold or ivory. Regulus imagines that this is what a real home is meant to feel like.

He forces himself to relax as he eats, forces his shoulders down from his neck, forces his muscles to let go.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters.

He‚Äôs okay. This is okay. He‚Äôs done it a dozen times before, there‚Äôs no reason for it to be any different now.

The feeling, when it comes, is like falling into to a frozen lake but slowly. It starts at his head and trickles through his body, his hands freezing on their way to his mouth and then suddenly dropping back to the table.

Stand up.

And he does. Before he can think about the fact that the voice isn‚Äôt his own or that an unnatural calm has suddenly settled around his bones.

Turn around.

Bellatrix is grinning at him, wild brown curls cascading down her back as Rodolphus throws himself into the chair beside Regulus, looking entirely bored by the situation.

‚ÄúOh wittle Wegulus,‚Äùshe presses the tip of her wand to his forehead and he wants to move, he does, wants to knock it away, but he can‚Äôt. He can‚Äôt move. He can barely think.

‚ÄúYou never learn do you?‚Äù She draws the wand down his nose, his lips, flicking it off the edge of his chin.

On your knees, says the voice in his head.

His body drops with a painful crack onto the hard stone floor. He can feel himself tremble, hear the laboured breath in his ears. She‚Äôs in his head. In his skin.

‚ÄúWhat trick should he do next?‚Äù she stalks around him, hand running over his shaved head. Rodolphus leans forward, elbows on his knees, face coming into view. Regulus can‚Äôt turn his head, can‚Äôt follow his cousin‚Äôs path, can‚Äôt look away from her husband‚Äôs empty eyes.

‚ÄúBark,‚Äù he says, an ugly smile stretching his face.

Bellatrix laughs.

Bark, commands the voice.

Bark, bark, bark.

And he does. On his knees, he barks.

‚ÄúEnough enough,‚Äù Bellatrix stops in front of him, still laughing.

Stop.

He goes quiet, throat raw, struggling to push back against her presence inside his head and failing. He fails every time.

Bellatrix sticks out her foot, sleek black leather pushing into the centre of his chest. He barely notices. His ribs already feel too tight. His lungs barely able to breathe.

‚ÄúKiss it,‚Äù she says, amusement clear in her voice, Rodolphus snorting in the background.

Kiss it.

He tries. Really. Tries to pull his will power out from behind the veil of the spell. But it‚Äôs nothing but a distant yell. A muffled voice. So he does as he‚Äôs told. Doesn‚Äôt he always?

‚ÄúOh here you are,‚Äù it‚Äôs his mother, he can‚Äôt see her because Bellatrix hasn‚Äôt ordered him to look, hasn‚Äôt allowed him to take his mouth off her shoe. But he doesn‚Äôt need to. He would know her voice anywhere.

There‚Äôs a brief pause, he isn‚Äôt sure what her face is doing, what she thinks about the scene in front of her.

‚ÄúCome, lunch is ready, Narcissa and Lucius are in the dinning room,‚Äù and then, almost as an after thought; ‚Äúhonestly Regulus, you must learn to strengthen your mind. We practiced this.‚Äù

They did.

Over and over again.

By the end of the summer Regulus had felt raw with it, like his body had been turned inside out.

He hears the sounds of his mother‚Äôs shoes as she walks away.

‚ÄúPity,‚Äù Bellatrix throws him off her foot, ‚Äúlooks like play time‚Äôs over.‚Äù

He gasps as the spell lets go, as he comes crashing back down into his body, catching himself on his hands as they tremble along with the rest of him.

‚ÄúCome now little cousin, we don‚Äôt want to keep your maman waiting.‚Äù

He can‚Äôt lift his head, it‚Äôs too heavy, the room spinning. He watches their feet‚ÄîRodolphus getting out of his chair, the pair of them sauntering into the hallway.

Inhale. Exhale.

His skin is clammy, drenched in a cold sweat.

Inhale. Exhale.

He barely has time to turn his head before he‚Äôs retching all over the kitchen floor. He doesn‚Äôt know how their can be so much when he‚Äôs barely eaten. You‚Äôd think after all this time he‚Äôd be used to this feeling, but it never gets easier. Being invaded. It never gets easier and he never gets stronger.

Regulus collapses onto his back, chest heaving as he tries to focus on the soothing feeling of the cold floor on his skin. It‚Äôs only a few moments before Kreacher‚Äôs worried face appears above him.

‚ÄúMaster Regulus must be getting up now,‚Äù he says, placing a small hand on Regulus‚Äôs back and helping him peel himself off the ground. With the snap of his fingers there‚Äôs a glass of water being pressed to Regulus‚Äôs lips. He drinks, gratefully.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he croaks. ‚ÄúSorry about the‚Äî‚Äú he gestures to the puddle of sick beside them but Kreacher only shakes his head, snapping his fingers again, leaving behind a clean floor.

‚ÄúWhat is mess to a house elf?‚Äù

Regulus almost smiles.

‚ÄúRegulus!‚Äù his mother‚Äôs voice rings out. She doesn‚Äôt scream, she commands. There is a difference.

He winces as he hands the water back to Kreacher and gets unsteadily to his feet. For a second the room sways.

Inhale. Exhale.

‚ÄúMaster Regulus?‚Äù

Reg tries to force a smile. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine Kreacher. Just have to make it to the table right?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt have to see his face to know how pale he must look. How weak.

‚ÄúKreacher will send in soup‚Äî‚Äú

But Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo, best not to change anything. You know how they are.‚Äù

Kreacher only stares back at him helplessly.

Regulus keeps his hand pressed to the wall all the way down the hallway to steady himself, only taking it off the minute he comes into view.

The dinning room is largely taken up by a long black table. His mother is at the head, of course, his father nowhere to be seen‚Äîin bed Regulus supposes‚ÄîBellatrix and Rodolphus on one side, Narcissa and Lucious on the other.

‚ÄúThere he is,‚Äù Narcissa smiles at him, hair charmed blond to match her fianc√©‚Äôs. She gets out of her chair and pulls him into a hug that Regulus does his best not to flinch away from. He does not want to be touched. Not right now.

‚ÄúMerlin you‚Äôre so big, I can‚Äôt believe it most of the time.‚Äù

He smiles stiffly as she pulls him into the seat next to her. Lucius nods his head in acknowledgement and Regulus does the same, even though it makes his stomach roil.

There are appetizers on the table, but Regulus isn‚Äôt sure he can trust himself not to throw them back up just yet so he chooses to focus on his plate. Eyes following the pattern, hands clenched in his lap.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters.

‚ÄúYou were saying Rodolphus,‚Äù his mother gives him a detached once over before returning her attention to her nieces‚Äôs husband.

‚ÄúMinchum has agreed to put more Dementors around Azkaban, he‚Äôll announce it next week, new security measures. Put all the troublesome Death Eaters in their place.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes rise at that, at the bubbling laugh that comes out of Bellatrix‚Äôs mouth.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt know then?‚Äù Walburga asks mildly.

‚ÄúMinchum? Not a clue. He‚Äôs quite happy with Lucius and I for suggesting it, isn‚Äôt he Lu?‚Äù Rodolphus rips into one of the buns on the table, gesturing to the man across from him.

‚ÄúAppreciates our no nonsense approach,‚Äù Lucius says dryly, eliciting more laughter from Bellatrix.

‚ÄúAnd the dementors, we can rely on them?‚Äù his mother goes on.

Rodolphus shrugs. ‚ÄúSure, for what we need,‚Äù he speaks with his mouth still half-full, chewing lazily. ‚ÄúThe Ministry‚Äôs never done anything for them, and our Lord can be so very convincing. Whether or not they‚Äôll fight with us I can‚Äôt say, but I can promise they won‚Äôt fight against us.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôll let the prisoners go then?‚Äù Narcissa asks, leaning forward slightly.

Rodolphus nods, swallowing. ‚ÄúWe go get ‚Äòem, the Dementors will let them walk. No question.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù his mother says, as Regulus feels something start to scratch at the inside of his skin. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll make it harder for them to slow us down.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot that they were able to do much of that anyway,‚Äù Lucius says dryly, smug looks and low chuckles exchanged around the table.

There‚Äôs a ‚Äòwoosh‚Äô of air, and suddenly steaming pots and dishes appear before them.

‚ÄúAh, excellent,‚Äù his mother sits up straighter, ‚Äúeveryone, lunch is served.‚Äù

¬†

Several hours later they‚Äôre still talking. Meals never last a reasonable time with them, drifting into the late afternoon and early evening. Once a sufficient number of brandies and wine glasses have been had Regulus slips away.

It‚Äôs a relief, the quiet darkness of his room. For a moment he leans his forehead against the wall and exhales.

Nothing matters.

Nothing matters.

Nothing matters.

He thinks about visiting his father but he‚Äôs worried he‚Äôll wake him up‚Äîor that they‚Äôd hear him downstairs. That they‚Äôd realize he‚Äôd left. No, better to stay here. Quiet.

It wasn‚Äôt until last summer that he realized what a shield Sirius had been for him. It was easy to disappear when his brother was around. Pathetic, he knew, but Sirius always handled it so well. Got up from every hit like he couldn‚Äôt even feel it. Nothing seemed to touch him. Meanwhile to Regulus everything feels like water in his lungs.

The door opens and Regulus whips around, Lucius knocking the wand out of his hand with the flick of his own.

Fuck.

‚ÄúHiding are you?‚Äù the older man smiles, crowding him against the wall. His breath smells of alcohol.

‚ÄúGo away Lucius.‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt look at his face, but somewhere off his left shoulder, safer that way.

‚ÄúTisk, tisk, not very nice of you,‚Äù he grabs hold of Regulus‚Äôs jaw, pulling it forward with a grip that will no doubt bruise. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve talked about that mouth of yours.‚Äù

For the second time that day Regulus feels like he‚Äôs going to be sick. Lucius is too close‚Äîtoo fucking close and he can‚Äôt‚Äîhe can‚Äôt breathe. He can‚Äôt stand all these hands on him. It makes something deep inside him ache.

He would speak, but Lucius‚Äôs grip is too tight.

His mouth too suffocating, pressing into him.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters. If nothing matters than nothing hurts.

Regulus brings his knee to meet Lucius‚Äôs stomach, taking the older man by surprise, which is enough to let Regulus throw him off, making a dive for his wand which sits on the floor by the door. His fingers have only just wrapped around the handle when he feels a sharp pain shoot through him, Lucius‚Äôs pointed dress shoe ramming itself into his side. He isn‚Äôt fast enough, he never is. Suddenly he finds himself on his back, Lucius‚Äôs foot pressing down on his chest.

‚ÄúWhat the hell was that you little brat,‚Äù he spits, wand aimed at Regulus‚Äôs face. His chest struggles against Lucius‚Äôs weight.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not doing this Lucius‚ÄîI‚Äôm not doing this anymore.‚Äù

Lucius arches his eyebrow, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not doing this anymore?‚Äù he repeats icily, pushing down on Regulus for emphasis, forcing a gasp out of him as the air rips from his body.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôll notice you‚Äôve gone,‚Äù he‚Äôs feeling desperate now, hand groping around on the floor for his wand, not sure where it went after he got kicked.

A sickening leer carves itself into Lucius‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúYou think they‚Äôll care?‚Äù

Regulus swallows with great difficulty. ‚ÄúNarcissa will care,‚Äù he manages to force out. ‚ÄúSo if you want her to pump out your pureblood pups you‚Äôll get the fuck out of my room before I start screaming.‚Äù

Regulus never knows what Sirius would do in these situations. Though he imagines he probably doesn‚Äôt find himself in them very often. Nobody looks at Sirius and thinks ‚Äúweak.‚Äù

Lucius‚Äôs eyes are intense as he bends forward, bringing their faces closer together and tilting his to the side. Like Regulus is an exhibit he‚Äôs trying to puzzle out. And then he smiles.

‚ÄúOh Regulus, have you found yourself a boy?‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth, feeling the box rattle down inside him. But he keeps it closed. He keeps it buried, keeps his thoughts empty of faces and voices and hands that never ask for more than he can give.

‚ÄúDoes he know that this is what you‚Äôre really like?‚Äù Lucius lets out a cruel laugh. ‚ÄúA worm? Pathetic and grovelling and used?‚Äù

It shouldn‚Äôt hurt. He doesn‚Äôt know why it does.

A few moments of tense silence pass before Lucius straightens up, taking his foot off of Regulus and smoothing out his robes.

‚ÄúHave it your way,‚Äù he says loftily, Regulus gasping on the floor below him, ‚Äúbut you know,‚Äù he goes on as he pauses by the door, the light from the hallway cutting brutally through the dark room, ‚Äúhe‚Äôll figure it out eventually. What a sad little thing you are. And I can‚Äôt imagine he‚Äôll want you after that.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt move until he‚Äôs alone again. Sitting up against the wall and pulling his knees in, resting his head on top of them.

Inhale. Exhale.

Inhale. Exhale.

Inhale. Exhale.

He wonders, absentmindedly, if other people have to remind themselves to breathe, or if that‚Äôs just him?

You see, Roger Flint was the first boy who didn‚Äôt care what Regulus wanted. But he wasn‚Äôt the last.

¬†

I want you to fight back. That‚Äôs what Sirius had said. The truth is, Regulus doesn‚Äôt stay because he feels very strongly about his family‚Äôs cause. About the supremacy of purebloods. He supposes maybe they have a point sometimes, he isn‚Äôt sure. But really, Regulus stays because he doesn‚Äôt think Sirius‚Äôs side can win. That they stand any chance at all. His parents, their friends, they have so much power. So much money and influence. I want you to fight back, Sirius had said. But what‚Äôs the point? What‚Äôs the point of fighting for a lost cause?

¬†

Regulus spends Christmas morning with his father. Kreacher helps him bring him down to the living room, where the fire is lit and the tree is sparkling and his father makes him open all his gifts like he‚Äôs still a little kid. They drink hot chocolate and eat pancakes.

His father starts singing a terribly off-key version of jingle bells and when Regulus can‚Äôt get him to stop he joins in.

His mother is out. She has meetings. According to his father she has a lot of those these days, though he‚Äôs rather vague about who they‚Äôre with or what they‚Äôre about. Regulus doesn‚Äôt push the matter. He doesn‚Äôt really want to know.

‚ÄúDo you remember when you were six‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI already don‚Äôt like where this is going,‚Äù Regulus laughs from the floor, he‚Äôs resting on his hand, legs stretched out in front of him as he looks up at his father. He‚Äôs still in his pyjama‚Äôs even though it‚Äôs nearly one, his father too, though these days he‚Äôs rarely in anything else. In the background Celestina Warbeck‚Äôs Christmas record is on.

‚ÄúNo, no, this is a good one,‚Äù his father grins.

‚ÄúUh-huh, I‚Äôm not sure our definitions of good are the same but go on.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh il pense qu'il est si dr√¥le‚Äîa little respect wouldn‚Äôt kill you huh?‚Äù he winks at Regulus who rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou were barely up to here,‚Äù he holds his hand out at waist height. ‚ÄúAnd you followed Sirius everywhere he went, you two were absolutely inseparable.‚Äù

I followed him everywhere until the day he got on that train, Regulus thinks but doesn‚Äôt say. His father is rarely in so good a mood, and he doesn‚Äôt want to ruin it.

‚ÄúAnd it had snowed all night, the hills were practically up to my neck‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre exaggerating.‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft, I am not, there‚Äôll be pictures somewhere I‚Äôm sure. Anyway, we turned our backs on you for two seconds, I swear, we were‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚Äîcleaning up the kitchen or something. And then you were gone, poof!‚Äù

‚ÄúWe were six and seven, I find it hard to believe we were quite that stealthy.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh but you were, we searched the whole house, calling out your names, your mother was absolutely beside herself, and then, I looked out the window and I saw a little red shirt tied to a stick on top of snowbank.‚Äù

Regulus actually does remember this. Remembers how badly his hands stung from digging in the snow, remembers how pleased he was when Sirius told him he was doing a good job.

‚ÄúSo we go outside only to see that you two have turned the entire back garden into a snow fort and Sirius comes wandering out and informs us, quite formally, that we are on his property.‚Äù

Regulus remembers that too, remembers staying behind, inside their little snow tunnels, watching Sirius face their parents, alone. Always alone.

‚ÄúSaid he was going to be living in his fort and that since he was no longer under our roof, he no longer had to follow our rules.‚Äù His father starts to laugh, no longer the big boisterous sound it once was but quiet, rough. Ending in a cough.

‚ÄúAre you okay papa?‚Äù Regulus moves forward, placing his hand on his father‚Äôs back.

‚ÄúOui, oui, I‚Äôm fine Reggie, I‚Äôm fine,‚Äù he exhales, leaning back in his chair. ‚ÄúYou two were such a pair,‚Äù smiles to himself. ‚ÄúYou still speak yes, at school?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes papa,‚Äù he lies again. ‚ÄúYes, all the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood, that‚Äôs good,‚Äù his eyes drift closed, breath still hitching in his chest. It doesn‚Äôt take much these days, to wear him out. ‚ÄúLa famille est importante ma cher, ton fr√®re par-dessus tout, il s'en remettra‚Ä¶He‚Äôll come back,‚Äù his English and French blend together.

No, Regulus doesn‚Äôt have the heart to tell him, no I don‚Äôt think he will.

‚ÄúPerhaps it be time to be returning Master Black to his bed?‚Äù

Regulus starts at Kreacher‚Äôs sudden appearance, hand tightening protectively over his father before he forces himself to relax.

‚ÄúYeah, yeah, that‚Äôs a good idea,‚Äù he looks back down. ‚ÄúCome on dad, lets get you upstairs okay?‚Äù

His father grumbles, but doesn‚Äôt put up nearly the fight Regulus expects him to.

‚ÄúJoyeux No√´l mon fils,‚Äù he mumbles as Regulus helps him into bed, pulling the blankets all the way up to his shoulders. He‚Äôs asleep almost as soon as he puts his head on his pillow.

‚ÄúJoyeux No√´l Papa.‚Äù

He pauses for a moment, remembering that day in the snow. Sirius had been so excited. This is ours, he‚Äôd told Regulus, it‚Äôll be just us here, they can‚Äôt come in.

Walburga took his voice for that. One flick of her wand and Sirius couldn‚Äôt speak for three days. That, of course, was not part of their father‚Äôs story. It never was.

¬†

Regulus makes it all the way to the hall outside his bedroom before he stops, looking across the way to the other door. He hasn‚Äôt seen it open since last summer. Since he left. It‚Äôs foolish really, stupid, but he finds himself moving towards it anyway, finds his hand turning the doorknob.

It even still smells like Sirius‚Äîhair products and leather boots. The walls are covered in red and gold, lions roaring overhead. For days last summer their mother had sat in this room trying to peel them off, but whatever spell Sirius used was strong because not a single poster came down.

He hadn‚Äôt had time to take anything, the night he left, so his room remains unchanged. Like any minute he might walk back in. Regulus takes a tentative step forward, towards the familiar bed, hands trailing along the walls and dressers, like he‚Äôs trying to make sure they‚Äôre really there. He used to spend a lot of time in this room. Reading, playing, hiding from monsters.

It feels different from the rest of the house. Even when he‚Äôs gone Sirius still has so much presence. He bleeds out of every corner. Undeniable. A force. Regulus sits down on the side of the bed, eyes roaming over the room, catching on a picture on the bedside table. Shaking, his hand reaches out for it, framed in a clunky plastic thing. It‚Äôs of Sirius and his friends, somewhere in Hogwarts, maybe third year. James is caught in a laugh, smile spread big across his face as he throws his head back. Regulus knows that laugh, he knows what it sounds like and feels like and tastes like.

The box strains inside him, begging him to open it up, to think all the things he can‚Äôt afford to right now. Not while he‚Äôs in this house that is so hungry to tear things apart. Still, he slips off the back of the frame and slides the photo into his pocket. Stupid.

He lets out a breath, eyes sweeping over the room one last time before he gets up and heads back into the corridor.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù

He freezes with his hand on the doorknob.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù his mother says stiffly from the top of the stairs. ‚ÄúWhat were you doing in there?‚Äù

He almost laughs. Because of course. Of course she comes home now.

‚ÄúI wanted to see if his quidditch gear fit,‚Äù he says flatly, a voice he‚Äôs perfected over the years. It works on most people.

‚ÄúAre you lying to me?‚Äù she asks, stepping nearer, and Regulus tries to get his pulse under control, the hair raising on the back of his neck as her dark eyes zero in on him.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

But, of course, it‚Äôs too late. He knows what‚Äôs going to happen even before she raises her wand. Before she whispers the spell.

It burns when she forces her way into his thoughts, flipping through them like the pages of a book. They whip before his mind‚Äôs eye at breakneck speed, making him feel dizzy. But he was careful. He was ready. He‚Äôs put all the things that could hurt him away, he‚Äôs buried them deep. She won‚Äôt find them, she won‚Äôt‚Äî

Except for the picture. She grabs hold of it, focusing in on the moving faces of the young boys. No, Regulus thinks pathetically, hoping she doesn‚Äôt hear, trying to quite his own thoughts, but they persist. No, leave them alone. Leave him alone.

He gasps as she pulls back.

‚ÄúGive it to me,‚Äù she says coldly.

He stares at her, unsure of why this feels like such a betrayal.

‚ÄúRegulus. Now.‚Äù

Slowly he reaches for the photograph, barely getting it out of his pocket before she‚Äôs ripping it away from him, eyes never leaving his face even when she sets it on fire, letting it drop to the floor and curl in on itself. Turning to ash.

‚ÄúHe is not your brother,‚Äù and Regulus almost sighs with relief that she couldn‚Äôt tell who he was focusing on. ‚ÄúDo you understand?‚Äù

‚ÄúOui maman.‚Äù

Her shrewd eyes run him up and down, sending shivers along his spine. ‚ÄúThis summer. You will take the mark.‚Äù

He blinks. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs past time. Things are happening Regulus, you need to take your place.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs place you mean‚Äîbut he doesn‚Äôt say it out loud.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not finished school,‚Äù knowing, of course, that it won‚Äôt matter.

‚ÄúAnd you needn‚Äôt be, as if they teach you anything of quality anyway. I only allowed you to return this year because your father insisted.‚Äù

He says nothing. He has nothing to say. Nothing that won‚Äôt end with him in pain anyway.

‚ÄúThings are changing Regulus,‚Äù she walks away, the picture a cold pile of ash on the floor, ‚Äúand nothing will be the same once we‚Äôre done.‚Äù

He wonders if she means for it to sound like a threat. He imagines she probably does.

It was Sirius who taught him the trick with the box. Taught him how to hide things in his own head. He wonders if his brother still does it sometimes. Still hides parts of himself away. Or if now that he‚Äôs free of this place he doesn‚Äôt need to. If he gets to remember without fear. He‚Äôd like to ask him. He‚Äôs sure he never will.

¬†

He has Kreacher drop him off in London. He‚Äôs two hours early for the train but he can‚Äôt stand being in that house any more. He doesn‚Äôt go to Diagon Alley like he said he would, or to platform 9 3/4. Instead he finds a bench in the muggle train station and sits, leaning back and closing his eyes, listening to the crowds rushing around him, trains arriving and departing, the voice over the loudspeaker buzzing in his ears every five seconds. He feels‚Ä¶delicate. A nervous shaking inside his skin that promises it won‚Äôt take much to pull him apart.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

He starts, eyes flying open, heart jolting against his ribs. His wand is in a holster on the inside of his arm but he doesn‚Äôt dare pull it out here.

A middle-aged woman stands over him, she has dark brown hair with a single white streak at the front that has been braided down her back. Her face is kind.

She smiles softly at him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Euphemia Potter,‚Äù she holds out her hand.

Regulus feels something shoot through his chest, something pull at his gut. He blinks up at her and then down at her hand.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú he shakes himself. ‚ÄúSorry, Mrs. Potter, it‚Äôs nice to meet you,‚Äù he reaches out and takes her hand, her grip warm and strong. Now that she‚Äôs said it he can‚Äôt not see it‚Äîthe similarities between her and her son. The box rattles again, with all the feelings and thoughts he still doesn‚Äôt feel strong enough to face. Not now. Not yet. It‚Äôll be too much.

‚ÄúCan I sit with you?‚Äù she nods to the empty spot beside him.

‚ÄúOh‚Äîyes, of course.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know what to do with his hands, eventually finding them fidgeting in his lap, his eyes unable to meet her gaze.

‚ÄúI see you‚Äôre an early bird too huh?‚Äù she says kindly. ‚ÄúThe boys have gone to Diagon, but I‚Äôve always liked this station, excellent place for people watching.‚Äù

The boys.

He‚Äôs not sure he can manage this conversation right now, he already feels on the verge of coming apart.

‚ÄúAre you excited for the new term? I hear you have a quidditch game soon?‚Äù

That gets him to look up, meeting her stare head on, he has experience in holding stares but her‚Äôs is different. A different kind of intense.

‚ÄúHave you?‚Äù is all he manages to get out, and her smile becomes a bit more mischievous.

‚ÄúOh yes, I‚Äôve heard about the feint you pulled so many times I feel like I was there myself.‚Äù

He swallows with difficulty, unsure of what to do with the knowledge that he‚Äôs been a topic of conversation in the Potter household.

‚ÄúYou know, my son is a bit of an open book,‚Äù she goes on. Regulus does know. He‚Äôs obsessed with it. He‚Äôs afraid of it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm never sure if that means I‚Äôve done something right as a mother or something wrong but it‚Äôs too late now either way I suppose.‚Äù Her eyes drift out calmly over the rushing people in front of them. ‚ÄúBut gosh, did he ever light up when he talked about you.‚Äù

She looks back at him and suddenly his chest feels too tight. Please stop, he wants to tell her, but he‚Äôs not sure he means it. Part of him is greedy. Is hungry. Is desperate for more.

‚ÄúRegulus, I want you to know,‚Äù she goes on softly. ‚ÄúThat our door is always open okay? If you ever need it.‚Äù

It‚Äôs all a bit too much if he‚Äôs being honest. He‚Äôs had too many people in his head recently, too many hands on his skin. There is nothing stable about him‚Äîhe is all weak foundations and cracking beams. His body ready to cave in on itself.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú he coughs, trying to clear the weakness out of his throat. ‚ÄúI should go, the train.‚Äù Even though they both know he has plenty of time. Still, she nods her head, smiling all the same.

‚ÄúOf course, don‚Äôt let me keep you.‚Äù

He gets up shakily, hoping he can make it through the barrier in this state.

‚ÄúIt was nice to meet you, Mrs. Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúEffie, please.‚Äù

He nods though he knows he will never call her that. He wonders if Sirius does. Or if he just calls her mum. It‚Äôs a title that suits her, far more than it ever has his own mother.

His body feels awkward and out of place as he walks away from her, through the crowd. None of his limbs moving the right way.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters.

¬†

He sleeps for most of the train ride, Evan and Barty bickering with one another in the seats across from him. He makes a point of not looking at anyone on the platform when they arrive, or in the great hall at dinner.

Hours later he finds himself sitting alone in the Slytherin common room. Unable to concentrate on his readings, or do any of the coursework he neglected over the break. He stares into the fire and wonders if he shouldn‚Äôt just go to bed. If he shouldn‚Äôt just let this whole thing die. Of course, he‚Äôs thought that before. Thought it nearly every time. It‚Äôs not really a question, when the answer is so obvious. He should. Of course he should. Especially in the state he‚Äôs in.

His foot taps nervously on the floor, eyes flicking up from the fire to the clock on the mantle. He should just go to bed. It would be better for the both of them. He should. He should. He should. He doesn‚Äôt. Of course. But he should.

¬†

He wonders how James will know to come now that he won‚Äôt be able to see Regulus on the map. He wonders if he‚Äôll remember how to get in. He wonders if the room would keep him out if Regulus asked it to. He doesn‚Äôt‚Äîask it to, that is‚Äîbut he thinks about it.

He makes a concerted effort not to look at the bed, not to remember the last time he was in this room, the box still closed, though cracks have started to splinter it. Have started to let things leak through. He isn‚Äôt at all sure he can handle this. Isn‚Äôt at all sure how to. It‚Äôs never been this bad. He‚Äôs never felt this broken apart. It was too quiet in that house, too cold, and now all of the sudden there are so many people and voices and so much heat that he feels like he‚Äôs burning up.

‚ÄúYou cut your hair.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs head snaps up, he doesn‚Äôt know how he missed the sound of the door opening.

And oh.

Oh.

Oh shit.

Something yanks at his chest. Yanks hard. This was a bad idea. He knew this was a bad idea.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says, because it feels like James is waiting for some kind of response and that‚Äôs all he has. Truthfully, he‚Äôd forgotten about his hair. He‚Äôs been avoiding mirrors lately, avoiding being confronted with his own face. It‚Äôs easier that way.

‚ÄúI like it,‚Äù James smiles, he‚Äôs being nice, Regulus knows what he looks like‚Äîsevere, cold, bare. James steps forward, Regulus having positioned himself at the back wall, across from the door.

‚ÄúCan I‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù The word is out of Regulus so fast he can barely believe he‚Äôs said it, and instantly James stops. Hands dropping to his sides. He looks like he always does‚Äîperfect. Hair a mess, glasses smudged. Perfect.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James says, clearly trying to recover. This is no doubt not the reunion he thought he was going to be getting. Regulus knows that he‚Äôs hurting him. Knows he shouldn‚Äôt have come.

James leans against the back of the sofa. ‚ÄúYou have a good Christmas?‚Äù he asks tentatively.

Regulus wants to laugh. He doesn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúSure, it was fine. Yours?‚Äù

It‚Äôs hard to concentrate, its been hard to concentrate all day. Maybe longer than that. It‚Äôs always a bit of a culture shock returning to school after being at Grimmauld Place, but this, this is next level.

You had to hide too much of yourself this time, says the voice in his head. He thinks it‚Äôs probably right.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù

The last time I saw you I was happy.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

The last time I saw you my mother was trying to rip you out of my head.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù James repeats his name for a third time, louder now, and afraid. It‚Äôs clear that he‚Äôs been speaking and Regulus hasn‚Äôt heard a word of it.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù the shaking has started and it‚Äôs work to keep it out of his voice. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not feeling well.‚Äù

He can see how desperately James wants to close the space between them but he doesn‚Äôt. Doesn‚Äôt take a single step.

‚ÄúDo you want me to take you to the infirmary?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt take me to the infirmary,‚Äù because someone might see us, he lets remain unsaid, his voice verging on cruel. He hates it. But he doesn‚Äôt stop it.

‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs going to see us at this hour.‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know that, besides, I don‚Äôt want to go to the infirmary anyway. I just want to go back to my room. I just want to sleep.‚Äù

Pain, imperfectly suppressed by James Potter‚Äôs beautiful face.

I‚Äôve been in love with you since I was eleven years old, he thinks.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James says eventually. ‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs what you want.‚Äù

Regulus nods, letting them stay in tense silence only a minute longer before he somehow manages to force his legs to move. He doesn‚Äôt look at James.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù

Part of him doesn‚Äôt want to stop. He‚Äôs so close, so close to being out of here. So close to being free of the growing ache in his chest. Of the cracking in his bones.

But he does stop, looking behind him to find James unmoved, face broken open.

‚ÄúI missed you,‚Äù he gives him a weak smile and Regulus feels his hand tighten around the doorknob in front of him in an attempt to stay standing.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you tomorrow,‚Äù is all he says, not waiting to see what effect those words have on James before he throws himself into the hallway.

He just needs to get back to his room. He just needs to close his eyes. He just needs to not be awake for a little bit.

Regulus shoves his hands in his pockets as he moves through the hallways, steps determined, focused.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters. If nothing matter than nothing hurts.

‚ÄúBlack, fancy seeing you here.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs steps stutter but don‚Äôt stop. He knows that voice, knows it without even looking for it.

‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs not very polite,‚Äù Severus Snape falls into step beside him.

‚ÄúFollowing me now are you?‚Äù Regulus demands through clenched teeth, eyes very determinedly forward as he makes a conscious effort to keep his breath at a reasonable pace.

‚ÄúActually, I had other business to attend to, but, two birds one stone. This seemed like an excellent opportunity to remind you of that favour you still owe me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt owe you shit,‚Äù Regulus growls, too tired for this, too broken for this.

‚ÄúAh-ah-ah, I think you‚Äôll find that that‚Äôs not true. Unless you want a certain rumour going around‚Ä¶‚Äù

Regulus sighs. ‚ÄúPlease, enough with the empty threats. You‚Äôre not going to tell anyone anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt be so sure.‚Äù

Regulus stops so abruptly that Snape nearly trips over himself trying to do the same. ‚ÄúYou want in Snape, huh? You want in on the cause? You want to run around with Mulciber and Avery and call yourself a Death Eater? Then I would watch your fucking mouth around me.‚Äù

Snape looks back at him, clearly taken off guard, and Regulus sneers in a way he knows makes him look like his mother.

‚ÄúYou are no one,‚Äù Regulus pushes, feeling the anger and the fear and the pain of the last two weeks straining against his skin. ‚ÄúYour mother is no one. Your muggle father is no one. You think that they‚Äôll let you join without the help of people like me?‚Äù he laughs and doesn‚Äôt recognize the sound of his own voice. ‚ÄúWhen you have blood thicker than that mudblood you can‚Äôt get to fuck you?‚Äù

It happens fast.

One minute they‚Äôre facing each other and the next Snape has him pressed up against the wall. Whatever was holding Regulus together snaps then. Like a dam it all comes crashing forth, everything he‚Äôd been trying to keep controlled, keep buried. And he can‚Äôt breathe. He can‚Äôt breathe. He tries, he tries but nothing is working.

Inhale.

Inhale.

Come on, inhale.

But he‚Äôs eleven years old and Roger Flint is crushing him.

Inhale.

Inhale.

Inhale.

He‚Äôs trapped in his bedroom, Lucius Malfoy‚Äôs foot on his chest.

Inhale.

Inhale.

Inhale.

He knows that Snape is talking, spitting venom in his face, but Regulus can‚Äôt hear him. He wonders if anyone has ever died like this before? Because their heart just gave up.

‚ÄúOi! Get the fuck off him.‚Äù

The second that Snape‚Äôs grip is pried from his shoulders he collapses, legs unable to support him. But nothing changes. The horrible feelings clawing at his skin, the pain‚Äîthe pain that hurts so much more now‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt go away.

Inhale.

Inhale.

Inhale.

Bellatrix is in his head. He can‚Äôt move. He can‚Äôt blink. His mother is flipping through his memories. His brother is walking out the door.

Inhale.

Inhale.

Inhale.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on here?‚Äù

He is vaguely aware of the third voice. Vaguely aware that something has been going on around him‚Äîbodies, spells, feet shuffling on the stone floor.

He‚Äôs rocking back and forth, nails digging into his knees.

Does he know that this is what you‚Äôre really like? Lucius asks. A worm? Pathetic and grovelling and used?

Inhale.

Inhale.

Inhale.

He‚Äôll figure it out eventually. What a sad little thing you are. And I can‚Äôt imagine he‚Äôll want you after that.

Inhale.

Inhale.

Inhale.

There‚Äôs talking, voices, he knows there is. Doesn‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre saying though. Doesn‚Äôt think it matters. What can they do to him? What else can they do?

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

James comes into view, kneeling in front of him, hands held out but not touching. He can feel his magic, he can always feel his magic. Sweet and warm, it curls around him but doesn‚Äôt squeeze. Regulus tries to hold on to that, tries to use it as a rope to pull himself out of whatever hole he‚Äôs fallen into, but it doesn‚Äôt work.

‚ÄúRegulus, I need you to breathe okay?‚Äù his eyes are pleading, and it‚Äôs not until that moment that Regulus realizes that he‚Äôs been hearing James Potter‚Äôs voice in his head the whole time.

Inhale. Exhale.

He opens his mouth to speak but he can‚Äôt, so he just shakes his head. Squeezing his eyes shut.

‚ÄúOkay, it‚Äôs okay, you‚Äôre okay.‚Äù

And Regulus wonders how he manages to say it without choking.

‚ÄúSo, it turns out my mum knows about Patroclus and Achilles,‚Äù James goes on, his voice low, calm. Just talking, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt ask me how, she‚Äôs a bit mad like that, I‚Äôm pretty sure she knows everything honestly. Anyway, I started reading the Iliad, which I thought was going to me a bit more, you know, soppy, but it‚Äôs mostly a bunch of guys killing each other. Not that I‚Äôm complaining.‚Äù

Something comes out of Regulus that‚Äôs almost a laugh. He doesn‚Äôt know if he‚Äôs crying. He hopes that he‚Äôs not.
