‚ÄúI might fight him,‚Äù Sirius calls from behind James.

Remus raises his eyebrow but James waves his concerns away. ‚ÄúIf he really wants to throw a punch I can take it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs comforting,‚Äù Remus says dryly. He looks between them one more time before shaking his head. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon Pete, lets go,‚Äù he disappears back into the corridor, door closing behind him.

James exhales, gearing himself up for whatever the hell is coming next because, to be honest, he doesn‚Äôt really have a plan.

Sirius glares at him. ‚ÄúSo,‚Äù he spits, ‚Äúare we going to discuss your favourite routes?‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Äîthe sights you see along the way? I hear the grounds are great for bird watching, maybe that‚Äôs what you‚Äôve been doing with your time‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSirius.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Äîcourse, probably not the best time for bird watching, the middle of the night, star gazing then? Shall we discuss our favourite constellations? Mine, personally, is Alpha Canis Majoris, but you can see why I might be slightly bias‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been seeing someone.‚Äù

Sirius shuts his mouth, the tirade of words coming to an end, leaving them just standing there, staring at one another. The silence feels deafening.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius says finally, some of the energy gone out of him but none of the anger, that still simmers under his words, ‚Äúno shit.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt exactly know what to say to that.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been lying about it for months. Poorly, sure, but still lying. To me.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James refrains from pointing out that Sirius has also been lying‚Äîor at the very least neglecting to mention that he snogged one of their best mates. He can‚Äôt quite see that accusation going over well right now.

Sirius stares at him expectantly, clearly waiting for some kind of explanation.

He takes a deep breath. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a bloke.‚Äù

Sirius blinks, his entire body going rigid. It‚Äôs such a sudden change that James can spot it even from across the room.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe person I‚Äôve been seeing, he‚Äôs a boy. He doesn‚Äôt want anyone to know. That‚Äôs why I didn‚Äôt tell you, I‚Äôm sorry. Really.‚Äù He says it quickly because he knows if he takes his time he won‚Äôt get it out. That the words will get stuck in his throat. It‚Äôs not the whole truth, he knows that, but it‚Äôs as close as he can get right now.

The silence is stretching on too long and James can feel himself growing anxious. He hopes that this wasn‚Äôt a mistake. He wanted to make things better, he wanted to get rid of the wall that‚Äôs been slowly building itself between him and Sirius these past few months. He wanted his friend back.

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt tell me because he asked you not to,‚Äù Sirius says finally, ‚Äúor you didn‚Äôt tell me because you were afraid of how I‚Äôd react?‚Äù

James sighs, passing a hand over his face and meeting Sirius‚Äôs eye. ‚ÄúDoes it matter?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. To me. It matters.‚Äù

He‚Äôs not sure what the right answer is here. If there is a right answer. ‚ÄúBoth,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúIt was both.‚Äù

He can‚Äôt read the expression on Sirius‚Äôs face, has no idea what he‚Äôs feeling. James just wants him to tell him it‚Äôs okay. That they‚Äôre okay. He opens his mouth to say as much when Sirius suddenly starts forward.

He‚Äôs leaving, James thinks, feeling his heart clench.

Fuck.

Fuck.

But then Sirius wraps his arms around him, pulling him close, and in his shock it takes James a few minutes to respond‚Äîto hold him back.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Sirius says, squeezing him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry for whatever I did that made you think you couldn‚Äôt tell me.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs ever been so relieved in his life, a shaking breath escaping his lungs as he drops his head against his friend‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúGod, I‚Äôm so glad that you‚Äî‚Äú but his voice cuts out on him, an unexpected wave of emotion closing his throat.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my brother James, my family, there‚Äôs nothing‚Äî‚Äú Sirius pulls back so that they can look at each other. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing bigger than that okay? Not ever.‚Äù

James feels ridiculous, getting choked up over this, but he‚Äôd been so worried. ‚ÄúI feel the same,‚Äù he coughs, clearing his throat, trying to get rid some of the tightness, ‚Äúobviously.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow who‚Äôs gone soft eh?‚Äù Sirius grins and James shoves him. It feels good. It feels like he can breathe again.

He still doesn‚Äôt know it‚Äôs Regulus but James pushes that thought away, not willing to deal with it right now.

‚ÄúListen,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs expression is sincere again, ‚ÄúI need to‚Äîthere‚Äôs something I need to tell‚Äî‚Äú

But at that moment Albus Dumbledore‚Äôs voice fills up the room, so loud that James has to cover his ears.

‚ÄúAll students are to go to the Great Hall immediately. I repeat, all students are to go to the Great Hall immediately.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat the hell was that?‚Äù Sirius demands, looking around like he‚Äôs expecting to find the headmaster standing behind him.

James shakes his head, hands dropping away from his ears. ‚ÄúNo idea, never heard him do that before.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Sirius says suddenly. ‚ÄúYou reckon they caught the people who put up the mark?‚Äù

James shrugs. ‚ÄúYou think they‚Äôd call a school assembly for that? Usually they make us wait to get the news from the Prophet like everyone else.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, but these are extreme circumstances.‚Äù

And while James is still skeptical, he can‚Äôt say that Sirius doesn‚Äôt have a point. ‚ÄúGod, who knows, maybe.‚Äù He can already hear the sounds of students outside the door.

‚ÄúI hope they did, I can‚Äôt wait see those bastards crumble in front of the Wizengamot.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think they will?‚Äù James asks as they push their way outside. The halls are a mess, confused students looking around, making their way uncertainly towards the great hall.

‚ÄúCourse, you know they‚Äôre all Slytherin‚Äôs‚Äîbig and bad until McGonagall has them in her sights and then it‚Äôs all ‚Äòplease professor‚Äô ‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt mean it professor‚Äô ‚Äòplease don‚Äôt be mean to me professor'.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúSounds like you‚Äôre doing an impression of Peter.‚Äù

Sirius barks out a laugh so loud the people in front of them turn back in alarm.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt tell him I said that.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôm definitely going to.‚Äù

‚ÄúCome on, you know he‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHere‚ÄîJames! Sirius!‚Äù James looks ahead to see Remus waving at them through the chaos that is the Great Hall. James waves back, grabbing hold of Sirius and dragging him through the sea of students to where their friends are sitting at the Gryffindor table.

‚ÄúAny idea what‚Äôs going on?‚Äù James asks as they sit down.

Remus shakes his head. ‚ÄúNot a clue.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe just got here and then the food disappeared,‚Äù Peter adds, looking mournfully at the empty table.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Remus says a bit quitter, nudging James, ‚Äúyou two work it out?‚Äù he nods to Sirius whose eyes are trained on the Professors at the head table.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James gives him a smile. ‚ÄúYeah we worked it out.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood.‚Äù

‚ÄúEVERYONE,‚Äù all heads snap towards the front of the room where Dumbledore stands at the podium, wand pointed at his throat. ‚ÄúQUIET.‚Äù

The reaction is instant, couldn‚Äôt have been faster if it‚Äôd been enforced by magic. James looks over at the Slytherin table but he can‚Äôt spot Regulus amongst the crowd of green and silver.

‚ÄúBetter,‚Äù Dumbledore smiles kindly, lowering his wand. Behind him all the teachers are assembled, but none of them are sitting, which feels a bit ominous if James is being honest.

‚ÄúNow,‚Äù the headmaster goes on, ‚Äúas I am sure you are all aware, a few months ago a mark was cast over London, one that has been associated with a group of witches and wizards who call themselves Death Eaters,‚Äù he pauses, eyes running over the body of students before him, James isn‚Äôt sure he‚Äôs ever heard the great hall so quiet. Everything is still, it feels like even the enchanted sky above them has frozen.

‚ÄúIt is now believed that this was a warning, foreshadowing an attack that took place today in Diagon Alley.‚Äù

James feels the air rush out of his lungs, frightened whispers growing up around him. Dumbledore raises his hand and without even having to say a word all mouthes shut.

‚ÄúAs of right now,‚Äù he licks his lips, ‚Äúthirteen people have been pronounced dead. Five are in critical care at St. Mungos.‚Äù

Nothing can keep the silence after that.

‚ÄúThirteen,‚Äù he hears Remus hiss beside him. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Äîthat‚Äôs never happened before has it?‚Äù he looks at James as if he knows. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs never been that many‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt is believed,‚Äù Dumbledore continues, speaking over all the other voices, ‚Äúthat the victims were specifically targeted. We do not, at this time, have confirmation on the names of the victims, but classes have been cancelled for the rest of the afternoon and students will be summoned one at a time by their heads of house to contact their families,‚Äù he gives them another sweeping look. ‚ÄúIn this hour of tragedy our friends are our greatest resource. Our strength. Be there for one another, and we will make it through this. Thank you, you‚Äôre dismissed.‚Äù

There‚Äôs shuffling, feet on the floor, benches being pushed back from the table, but James can‚Äôt move. An icy sensation dripping down his bones.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Remus asks, but he barely registers it, his name floating passed him, unable to permeate the new bubble of panic slowly surrounding him.

‚ÄúHey, Prongs,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs hand comes down, warm and steadying on his shoulder, and James blinks up at him. ‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù

James swallows. ‚ÄúMy mum,‚Äù his voice breaks, ‚Äúshe said‚Äîshe said she was going to Diagon Alley.‚Äù

¬†

They end up outside on the lawn. James grabs his snitch‚Äîsomething to do, something to keep his hands busy. He wanted to fly but Flitwick saw him with his broom and quickly put an stop to that plan. Apparently, all students are to remain on the ground for the foreseeable future.

He begged McGonagall to let him floo his parents.

‚ÄúAlphabetical order Potter,‚Äù she said, already sweeping past him with the first student. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

So here he is, sitting with his friends on the lawn, throwing a snitch up and down and trying not to think about the fact his mum might be‚Äîwell.

There are other students around, though most groups are like them‚Äîtense, quiet. It feels weird, their fear out of place under the sun. The world does not look tragic, and somehow that makes it all the more unnerving.

Remus lets out a sharp hissing noise and James looks down in time to catch him grimacing at his potions textbook.

‚ÄúYou okay Moony?‚Äù

He nods stiffly. ‚ÄúYeah, sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt apologize.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou need me to grab you a pain potion?‚Äù Sirius asks, propping himself up on his elbows.

But Remus shakes his head again. ‚ÄúNah, it‚Äôs not so bad this month.‚Äù

The full moon is tomorrow. James had almost forgotten. He runs his friend over one more time‚Äîpale, purple bags under his eyes, shivering slightly.

‚ÄúYou let us know if you wanna go back up to the room okay?‚Äù James says, even though he doesn‚Äôt think he could stand sitting in that quiet. At least out here there are things to distract himself with. At least out here he doesn‚Äôt feel trapped.

‚ÄúThanks, but I‚Äôm fine, really.‚Äù

Remus has already been called up to MacGonagall‚Äôs office. His mother was there, his father at work, both fine. It‚Äôs good, Remus doesn‚Äôt need anymore tragedy in his life. James tries not to let the other thoughts in, the ones that say that that makes it just a little bit more likely that his mum is one of the victims. Lyall Lupin would make sense as a target, he‚Äôs already been one once after all. James hates himself for thinking that, hates himself for wanting it‚Äîeven for a second.

This time, when he catches the snitch, his hand wraps around it a little more tightly.

Just not my mum, he thinks over and over again. Not my mum. Anyone but my mum. Which, again, is a shitty thing to want, especially as he looks at the other kids around him. There aren‚Äôt that many wizards and witches in the world, really there aren‚Äôt. That thirteen were killed today. Thirteen‚Äî

Just not my mum.

Please not my mum.

Anyone but my mum.

He can‚Äôt remember the last time he told her he loved her. He thinks of the pitiful letters he‚Äôs been sending home, once every three weeks at most, barely a paragraph long. How could he be so callous?

He loves his dad. Really, he does. But his home is his mum. Without her‚Äîwithout her he‚Äî

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù

His head snaps up at the feel of Sirius‚Äôs hand on his arm. James tries to breathe.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs going to be okay,‚Äù Sirius says, voice firm, no hint of doubt. His eyes demand James stay still, just for a moment, demand he hear what‚Äôs being said to him. ‚ÄúI promise.‚Äù

And he wants to tell him that he can‚Äôt‚Äîcan‚Äôt possibly promise that. Except that the brilliant thing about Sirius Black, his best mate, is that he makes you believe that he can.

James nods stiffly. ‚ÄúThanks.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Äòcourse.‚Äù

Sirius has only just pulled back when the sound of smug laughter cuts across the lawn. James looks up and sees Snape and Mulciber coming out of the castle and they‚Äôre‚Äîfucking‚Äîlaughing. He sees Regulus pushed against a wall. Sees him struggling to breathe. Sees Snape looming over him, not giving a shit.

I just hope I‚Äôm there to see it, Snape had said to him.

See what?

See them break you.

It happens so fast, like a switch has been flicked in his brain and suddenly all his fear and regret and pain turns to anger. It hits him so hard he shakes with it.

He‚Äôs on his feet before he can think about what he‚Äôs doing, someone calls his name‚ÄîRemus, he thinks‚Äîbut he doesn‚Äôt turn away. His wand is already out by the time Snape sees him coming. He doesn‚Äôt care that they‚Äôre in the open, surrounded by people, that he will definitely be punished for this. Good, he thinks, let them watch.

‚ÄúLevicorpus,‚Äù James snaps, dragging Snape up into the air by his ankles.

He sees Mulciber raise his wand but it‚Äôs knocked out of his hand in the same moment as Sirius comes up beside him.

‚ÄúThanks Pads.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnytime Prongs.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat the fuck Potter!‚Äù Snape shouts, voice loud in the somber afternoon. There is something dangerous in the air. Something that snaps and crackles and threatens to ignite. And James is glad for it. Because someone might have hurt his mum, and that makes him want to burn the world to the ground.

‚ÄúHey Pads?‚Äù he says, loud enough that everyone watching can hear. He fully intends to make a show of this. ‚ÄúWhat colour do you reckon Snivellus‚Äôs pants are?‚Äù

‚ÄúUgh, Prongs,‚Äù Sirius responds in the same showman-like tone, and honestly, it feels good. The two of them, doing what they do best. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna make me sick-up my lunch.‚Äù

He hears snickering from some of their audience and feels a nasty smirk curling his lips.

‚ÄúYou think he washes them as much as he washes his hair?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou mean never?‚Äù

More laughter.

‚ÄúFuck. You.‚Äù Snape punches out, struggling though James can‚Äôt imagine why. It‚Äôs his spell, he ought to know better than anyone that there‚Äôs no way he‚Äôs getting down until James puts him down.

‚ÄúWanna bet on it? I say they‚Äôre green.‚Äù

Sirius smirks. ‚ÄúMy money‚Äôs on grey‚Äîor brown‚Äîthe creep has no style.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want to do the ho‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWhat the hell are you doing?‚Äù her voice cuts across the lawn like a knife. James feels it against his skin, the anger in her voice that hasn‚Äôt been direct at him in a long time.

‚ÄúAh, Evans, here to see the show?‚Äù

She comes up beside him but he doesn‚Äôt take his eyes off Snape, doesn‚Äôt want to look at her face.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she says more quietly, almost desperately. ‚ÄúJames, I know you‚Äôre worried‚Äîbut this‚ÄîI thought you were trying to better than this?‚Äù

And that irks him. Maybe because it‚Äôs true. Maybe because she‚Äôs still defending Snape. Even now. Even after everything that‚Äôs happened today and everything that she knows that he is.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs one of them,‚Äù he says through gritted teeth.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know that.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure I do.‚Äù

She makes an exasperated noise. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt punish him just because you feel bad. It won‚Äôt change anything. It‚Äôll just make it worse.‚Äù

And oh. Oh that‚Äôs just bang out of order. Because that isn‚Äôt what he‚Äôs doing. He isn‚Äôt making this up just to‚Äîto feel better.

‚ÄúI thought you were done with him, huh? You told me that, you said it‚Äîyou don‚Äôt like him anymore,‚Äù his voice has started getting louder again. ‚ÄúWas that all talk Lily? Just bullshit?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she grits out. ‚ÄúBut none of that makes what you‚Äôre doing okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh and who made you the moral authority? What makes you so good?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is ridiculous‚Äîput him down.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù And this time James does look at her, looks her dead in the eye. ‚ÄúNow shut up or go away.‚Äù

Just not my mum.

Please not my mum.

Anyone but my mum.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù he says, turning back to Snape, ‚Äútake off his trousers.‚Äù

And to his credit, Sirius doesn‚Äôt hesitate.

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt do that if I were you Black,‚Äù Lily‚Äôs voice is cold. ‚ÄúUnless you want your friend to get stupefied at close range.‚Äù

James almost laughs, looking over at her raised wand.

‚ÄúYou gonna hex me Evans?‚Äù

She doesn‚Äôt even blink. ‚ÄúAbsolutely. Now put him down.‚Äù

He holds her gaze, unwavering green eyes boring into his. Part of him wants to push her, too see if she really means it. But then, one look at her is all he needs to know that she does.

‚ÄúWell, Snivellus, aren‚Äôt you lucky the pretty girl came to your rescue,‚Äù he announces coldly, a smile on his face that feels sharp. ‚ÄúEver the gentleman, always letting a woman to fight your battles for you,‚Äù there‚Äôs more snickering from the surrounding crowd.

He watches Snape‚Äôs face contort with rage and embarrassment and he thinks that this might actually be better than taking his trousers off.

And then.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need a filthy mudblood to defend me.‚Äù

He‚Äôs not entirely certain what happens next. Everything goes a bit hazy. He knows he drops his wand, and Snape along with it, and then he‚Äôs on top of him, driving his fist into his ugly face. He‚Äôs not thinking. Not really. It‚Äôs all feeling. Pouring out of him and into Snape‚Äôs bleeding mouth. The violence feels good. All that anxiety and fear finally finding the outlet its been craving. For a moment he can‚Äôt remember why he ever wanted to be better than this.

And then he‚Äôs thrown back‚Äîmagic. He lands on his back a few paces away, the air knocked from his lungs. He sits up, trying to get on his feet again, but finds a wand in is face.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt,‚Äù Lily says through clenched teeth.

‚ÄúYou heard what he said‚Äîwhat he called you,‚Äù James says indignantly.

But Lily only shakes her head. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you dare use me as an excuse James Potter,‚Äù it‚Äôs the break in her voice that catches his attention, and suddenly he can see the wetness in her eyes. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you fucking dare.‚Äù

She waits a moment longer before sliding her wand back up her sleeve and turning away, James sees Mary and Marlene hovering in the background, concerned looks on their faces as she walks right by them. Snape, of course, is gone. James suddenly feels exhausted.

‚ÄúChrist, Prongs, are you alright?‚Äù Sirius comes up beside him and James lets out a breath that might be a laugh, bringing his hands up to his face. Needing a minute.

He tries to think of this morning‚Äîto remember how it had felt, to hear Regulus laugh, to see him smiling in the sun, the warmth of his hands, his mouth. And suddenly he wants him. Just to feel his touch, to hear his voice. He could tell Reg, he thinks, all the terrible thoughts he‚Äôs had. The weak thoughts. And he‚Äôd understand.

Just not my mum.

Please not my mum.

Anyone but my mum.

Regulus doesn‚Äôt need him to be better. To be stronger. He doesn‚Äôt know why that suddenly makes his chest feel too tight. He just wants to be back in their room. Just wants to lie next to him in bed and listen to him talk about gods and mortals and a love that can‚Äôt be stopped by violence and war and death.

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPotter?‚Äù

James‚Äôs head snaps up as Frank walks towards them, he falters for a moment, taking in the state of James and seemingly deciding not to comment. He nods his head back towards the castle. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your turn.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh thank god,‚Äù James breathes, scrambling to his feet. He‚Äôs barely taken five steps before something pulls him back.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù his friend is still kneeling in the grass. ‚ÄúComing?‚Äù

He sees it‚Äîthe surprise, followed quickly by gratitude. Sirius nods, quickly jogging up to him and causing Frank to arch his brow.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs supposed to just be family.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe is family,‚Äù James says, in a voice that has Frank raising his hands in surrender.

‚ÄúHey, don‚Äôt shoot the messenger.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt bother responding, walking so fast he‚Äôs practically running into the building.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs going to be okay,‚Äù Sirius murmurs bedside him. James only nods, no longer able to muster a response.

He feels like his insides are tearing themselves apart. He thinks about the letter he sent this morning, about how inadequate it was. All the things he needs to tell her. Needs her to know.

‚ÄúMr. Potter,‚Äù McGonagall barely even blinks when he storms into her office, Sirius at his side. ‚ÄúMr. Black.‚Äù

She‚Äôs sitting at her desk, the fire burning next to her and he sees‚Äî

‚ÄúDad,‚Äù his voice catches in his throat. It‚Äôs just him.

No.

No. no. no.

He feels Sirius wrap his hand around his arm and squeeze.

‚ÄúDad where‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJames!‚Äù his mother is pushing into view, sounding slightly breathless. ‚ÄúSorry, I just went to turn the kettle off,‚Äù she smiles and he feels his legs almost give out, thank merlin for Sirius who is probably the only reason he doesn‚Äôt collapse right then and there.

‚ÄúMum,‚Äù his voice is weak as they stumble forward, both of them getting on their hands and knees by the fire. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay.‚Äù

She looks confused. ‚ÄúI am, of course I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said‚Äîin your letter‚Äîyou said you were going to Diagon Alley.‚Äù

And suddenly her eyes grow wide. ‚ÄúOh darling, no‚Äînot‚Äînot today.‚Äù

James is feeling so many things right now that all that comes out of him is a wet sounding laugh.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúMerlin that must have been terrible for you.‚Äù

He shakes his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just glad you‚Äôre okay. I love you. I love you both so much. I‚Äôm sorry I don‚Äôt say that enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúGosh James,‚Äù his dad says, running a hand through his hair in a way that is nearly identical to his son. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt make me cry in front of Minerva, she‚Äôll lose all respect for me.‚Äù

‚ÄúNever Fleamont,‚Äù comes McGonagall‚Äôs voice from behind them.

‚ÄúSirius? You alright honey?‚Äù

James looks beside himself to find his best friend with wet eyes.

‚ÄúYeah, yeah I‚Äôm just glad you guys are okay.‚Äù

James realizes for the first time how scared Sirius has been, and how he buried it so that he could be strong for James. He swears his heart swells so much it nearly breaks his ribs.

‚ÄúOh well, now you‚Äôve gone and done it,‚Äù Fleamont says as he pulls off his glasses to wipe his eyes.

‚ÄúOi! How come he‚Äôs the one who makes you cry?‚Äù James demands.

‚ÄúI like him better than you.‚Äù

And that has them all laughing. James feels himself take a proper breath for the first time since he heard Dumbledore‚Äôs booming voice. Looking at the people he loves, smiling and crying and safe, he thinks;

Okay.

Okay.

Maybe we‚Äôll be okay.

Maybe we‚Äôll make it through this.

Chapter End Notes

1) "I'm afraid of hurting you. Because I love you. I think I always will."

2) "I don't deserve it."

3) "I don't deserve you."

Hello beautiful people!

Does this chapter work? I sure hope so, but it's becoming one of those things where I feel like I've been looking at it for so long that I don't even know what it is anymore.

Your comments are cupcakes and sunshine! Thank you!

Chapter 13

Chapter Summary

Uh-oh.

That's it. That's the whole chapter.

Chapter Notes

TW violence (it isn't graphic or anything but I feel like there's just more than usual in this chapter)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Classes are still cancelled the next day. Some students don‚Äôt come back from their calls with their parents, and even though the names of the victims haven‚Äôt been released, everyone knows what that means.

‚ÄúMoony, I swear to God‚Äîget back in bed,‚Äù Sirius stands at the door, arms crossed over his chest as he stares down a haggard looking Remus.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just going to get breakfast.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll get you breakfast you loon. You look like shite, get back in bed.‚Äù

In a turn of events that surprised no one, Remus had actually been rather downplaying how bad he was feeling yesterday and proceeded to spend much of the night, and morning, being sick.

‚ÄúMoons, he‚Äôs got a point,‚Äù James finishes tying his trainers and stands up. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no class, no assignments due, give yourself a break for once, yeah?‚Äù

Remus shoots him a sharp look. ‚ÄúEt tu, Brute?‚Äù

He says it with such conviction that James can‚Äôt help laughing. ‚ÄúJesus, you‚Äôre really out for blood today, huh?‚Äù

Remus only grumbles, turning his glare back on Sirius.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not moving,‚Äù Sirius leans back against the door, one leg crossing over the other. ‚ÄúNot until you get in that bloody bed, now go on.‚Äù

It is a face off for the ages, two of the most stubborn people James knows going head to head. Neither of them wavering‚Äîhe‚Äôs not even sure they blink.

‚ÄúOkay, but guys, I‚Äôm hungry,‚Äù Peter says, looking longingly at the door. James‚Äôs stomach grumbles in agreement.

This does not appear to matter to Sirius or Remus, both of whom maintain their positions like they‚Äôre the Royal bleeding Guard.

Peter starts inching towards the door. ‚ÄúMaybe I could just sneak by?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot happening Pettigrew,‚Äù Sirius doesn‚Äôt take his eyes off of Remus. ‚ÄúNo one gets to leave until Moony gets back in bed.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrying to turn the room against me?‚Äù

Sirius grins, flashing his teeth. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already against you my friend.‚Äù

‚ÄúLie down and put us out of our misery Moons,‚Äù James calls out, which earns him a very rude hand gesture from Remus.

‚ÄúMy goodness,‚Äù he clutches his chest dramatically. ‚ÄúHardly appropriate behaviour for a prefect.‚Äù

Remus crosses his arms over his chest, seemingly doubling down on his position. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how many times I have to tell you, I‚Äôm not an invalid.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe know,‚Äù Sirius says. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôve got a fever and you can‚Äôt go five minutes without being sick, ergo, bed.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe does make a compelling argument.‚Äù

‚ÄúShut up James,‚Äù Remus snaps.

James rolls his eyes, holding his hands up in surrender, leading to several moments of tense silence.

‚ÄúMoony,‚Äù Sirius says eventually, ducking his head in a move that James has seen him pull many times, just never with one of them. He stares up through his lashes, all bashful and pouty. Girls fall all over themselves for that look. ‚ÄúFor me?‚Äù Sirius goes on. ‚ÄúPlease?‚Äù

Personally, James thinks this is the weakest of his arguments, but apparently Remus disagrees.

He exhales, hands scrubbing at his face before he eventually allows himself to look at Sirius again. ‚ÄúFine. FINE. I‚Äôll stay.‚Äù

Sirius beams, practically bouncing around him to pull back the covers on his bed.

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúEager much?‚Äù

‚ÄúTo get you into bed? Always,‚Äù Sirius gives him a wink that has Remus blushing something fierce and James turns to Peter to see if he‚Äôs noticed any of this but Peter is already halfway out the door.

‚ÄúJeez Pete, in a rush?‚Äù he half-laughs, following after him.

‚ÄúYou know how I am about breakfast,‚Äù and to be fair, James does know. By the time he gets to the door Peter is already at the bottom of the stairs.

‚ÄúWait for Padfoot, would you? Honestly, the Great Hall will still be there in five minutes, Si‚Äî‚Äú James turns back to the room to see where Sirius‚Äôs is only to find him perched on Remus‚Äôs bed. The two of them are whispering, and then James sees Sirius run his knuckle softly along the side of Remus‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Padfoot?‚Äù Peter demands as James jogs down the stairs into the common room.

‚ÄúHe said he‚Äôll meet us there. C‚Äômon, lets go before your stomach starts eating itself yeah?‚Äù he smiles at Peter, mussing his hair as he swings through the portrait and into the corridor beyond.

James feels something warm in his chest as he thinks about the way Remus and Sirius were looking at one another. He‚Äôs never seen Sirius so soft. Maybe he finally worked it out, the tosser.

‚ÄúWhy are you smiling?‚Äù Peter asks, looking a little unnerved.

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúJust thinking about how much bacon I‚Äôm gonna shove in my face when we get down there.‚Äù

Peter makes a longing noise. ‚ÄúMe too.‚Äù

¬†

James‚Äôs high spirits decrease slightly as they walk into the Great Hall. The weight of everything that happened yesterday is unavoidable. It‚Äôs in the faces of the students around them and in the empty spaces along the tables.

They pass by Marlene, Mary and Lily. Peter waves, while James refuses to make eye contact. He hasn‚Äôt quite figured out how he wants to handle that situation yet.

‚ÄúAre you two back to hating each other, then?‚Äù Peter asks as they sit down at the opposite end of the table.

James frowns. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt hate each other‚Äîwe‚Äôve never hated each other.‚Äù

Peter shoots him a skeptical look as he loads an extraordinary amount of scrambled eggs onto his plate.

‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt!‚Äù James says indignantly, suddenly feeling defensive.

‚ÄúI mean, maybe you never hated her, but‚Ä¶‚Äù Peter shrugs, moving on to the sausage.

James crosses his arms over his chest, slouching slightly in his chair. ‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt hate me, she just‚Ä¶didn‚Äôt‚Ä¶like me very much.‚Äù Which he has to admit, sounds weak even to his own ears.

‚ÄúMhm,‚Äù Peter takes a bite out of his toast, ‚Äúwhatever you say mate.‚Äù

James keeps pouting for another few minutes before his stomach makes a noise that reminds him that Peter isn‚Äôt the only one who‚Äôs hungry. He‚Äôs halfway through his first serving before he speaks again.

‚ÄúHey, I forgot to ask yesterday, with everything that happened,‚Äù James swallows the mouthful he‚Äôd been chewing, ‚Äúbut how did it go with your mum?‚Äù

‚ÄúUgh,‚Äù Peter moans. ‚ÄúShe wanted me to come home‚Äîtook me ages to convince her I didn‚Äôt need to.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? Why would she want you home?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know how she is,‚Äù Peter waves around his third piece of toast. ‚ÄúShe thinks I‚Äôm in danger, she has a bad feeling, being so far away from home isn‚Äôt safe,‚Äù Peter clears his throat, adjusting his posture, ‚ÄúYou know Peter,‚Äù he says, in a high-pitched voice that does sound strikingly like his mother. ‚ÄúI was homeschooled until I was seventeen and I can do magic just as well as anyone who went to Hogwarts, ask your father. There‚Äôs no need for you to be so far away from me, it‚Äôs not natural, surrounded by strangers. Who knows what kind of families they come from.‚Äù

Peter rolls his eyes, leaning back in his chair and taking another massive bite of his breakfast.

‚ÄúDid she really say all that?‚Äù James asks.

Peter nods, exhaling through his nose. ‚ÄúI love her, I do, but sometimes I think that woman has completely lost the plot.‚Äù

But something nags at James. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd she mean‚Äîwho knows what kind of families they come from?‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù Peter looks up, ketchup staining the corner of his mouth. ‚ÄúOh, I don‚Äôt know. Doesn‚Äôt want me hanging out with people whose parents didn‚Äôt teach them manners or something. Y‚Äôknow, trouble makers.‚Äù

James can‚Äôt help laughing at that, biting down on the inside of his cheek to keep from being too loud. ‚ÄúShe must be thrilled you hang around with us then.‚Äù

Peter smiles a little shyly. ‚ÄúYou she doesn‚Äôt mind so much, she likes your parents, think that helps. Sirius though?‚Äù he lets out a low whistle. ‚ÄúOne look at his hair and I heard about it for a week. Said there‚Äôd be no long-haired hippies in her house and I better remember that.‚Äù

‚ÄúLong-haired hippy,‚Äù James is in near tears he‚Äôs holding his laughter back so hard. ‚ÄúYou have to tell him she said that, he‚Äôll hate it.‚Äù

Peter snorts, shovelling egg into his mouth, ‚ÄúYeah, no thank you,‚Äù words slightly muffled by the food.‚ÄúThe last thing I want to do is have to sit there and listen to him go on a tirade about what punk is.‚Äù

James smirks. ‚ÄúGood point‚Äîah, speak of the devil,‚Äù he says as Sirius strolls up.

‚ÄúAw, were you talking about me? James, really, you do need to get yourself a new hobby, this obsession is getting a bit sad.‚Äù

James swats at him as he sits down but Sirius ducks out of the way, pulling two plates towards him.

‚ÄúDoing one up for Remus?‚Äù James asks, trying to sound casual.

Sirius nods. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt bother bringing him much, not like he can keep it down, but he‚Äôs gotta eat something. Toast you reckon?‚Äù

James nods, turning back to his own neglected breakfast.

‚ÄúAnd porridge,‚Äù Peter pipes up. ‚ÄúHe likes the porridge, especially with raisins and brown sugar.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood call Wormy,‚Äù Sirius says, standing up to reach towards the breakfast foods in question.

There‚Äôs a noise from above and they all look up to see the owls arriving with the morning post.

‚ÄúFinally,‚Äù James mutters, fingers itching to get his hands on a copy of the Daily Prophet, and by the looks on the faces around him, he‚Äôs not the only one.

‚ÄúYou reckon they‚Äôll know anything we don‚Äôt?‚Äù Sirius asks, watching the ceiling along with James.

He shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo idea, hope so.‚Äù

James‚Äôs owl drops down beside them in a flurry of dark, brown wings. His name is Hoot, which James thought was hilarious when he was eleven, but it doesn‚Äôt suit him at all. He‚Äôs a very dignified owl, always holding his head up, keeping his feathers clean.

‚ÄúThanks Hoot,‚Äù James takes the rolled up paper out of his beak before tossing the owl a piece of bacon. He looks down like he‚Äôs too good for it, but James doesn‚Äôt miss the way he scoops it up when he flies off.

‚ÄúWell?‚Äù Sirius asks, still somewhat preoccupied filling his two plates. ‚ÄúAnything?‚Äù

‚ÄúBlimey, give me a minute would you?‚Äù James unfolds the paper and feels his stomach drop. There, on the front page, is a black and white photo of Diagon Alley. It‚Äôs the emptiest James has ever seen it, the hanging shop signs the only things moving, and on the road, surrounded by broken glass and rubbish, are several bodies covered with white sheets.

‚ÄúJesus, that‚Äôs grim,‚Äù Sirius hisses, looking over his shoulder before turning back to the task at hand.

James swallows, throat suddenly tight. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he flips the paper open to the article inside.

‚ÄúOh shit.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey have the names of the victims,‚Äù James says, eyeing the single column in front of him. They look so small written out like this. So insignificant. A whole life reduced to a line of text.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Peter asks from across the table, sounding slightly concerned. ‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù

James shakes his head, trying to get himself together. ‚ÄúYeah‚Äîyeah sorry, must still be half asleep.‚Äù

His eyes run down the names. He has no reason to be nervous, everyone he cares about is here or accounted for, but that doesn‚Äôt seem to stop his insides from twisting themselves into knots. Most of the names he recognizes only in a distant way‚Äîa family he‚Äôs heard mentioned once or twice. Someone‚Äôs third cousin on their mother‚Äôs side.

Until.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù the noise comes out of James involuntarily. He feels his friends turn to him but doesn‚Äôt see it, eyes still stuck on the page in front of him.

No, is all he can think.

No.

That isn‚Äôt fair.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Sirius prods, food forgotten. James has his full attention now, and he does his best not to crack under it.

He forces himself to turn, to hold Sirius‚Äôs questioning stare. No one‚Äôs ever told him how to do this. He doesn‚Äôt know if there‚Äôs a right way, but he‚Äôs almost certain there‚Äôs a wrong one.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù he manages eventually, voice strained. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

For a moment the confusion remains, Sirius not able to make sense of what he‚Äôs just heard. And then he‚Äôs ripping the newspaper out of James‚Äôs hands.

‚ÄúWho‚Äî‚Äú Peter starts, but James cuts him off with one quick hand motion, watching as his best friend runs down the list of names. Watching him stop. He doesn‚Äôt know what to say. He should, at this point he should know, but words seem to have abandoned him.

Sirius‚Äôs hands are shaking when he puts the paper back down, elbows resting on the table as he drops his head. Eventually he laughs and it‚Äôs wet and sad and James feels his heart squeeze.

‚ÄúI should have known better than to think‚Äîto think that I could‚Äî‚Äú James hears the sob creeping up Sirius‚Äôs throat, hears him cut it off before it can escape.

Peter grabs the paper from the other side of the table, eyes scanning down until they inevitably fall on Alphard Black. Third from the bottom. One of the last bodies found.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my fault,‚Äù Sirius says suddenly, voice all wrapped around itself, twisting and pulling and ripping apart.

‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt,‚Äù James says automatically. ‚ÄúSirius, this is not your fault.‚Äù

But Sirius only shakes his head, turning to look at James. ‚ÄúIt is‚Äîthey said the attacks were targeted. He‚Äôd never done anything‚Äînothing except try to help me. They killed him for it. Fuck,‚Äù he leans back in his chair, pressing the heels of his hands into his eyes like he can force the tears back.

‚ÄúYou have no idea why they targeted those people, no one does. How would anyone have even found out that he was writing to you?‚Äù

Sirius lets out a shaky breath. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he drops his hands. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

The only warning is his sudden stillness. A second ago he couldn‚Äôt sit still, grief pulling at his skin, and now, suddenly, stillness.

‚ÄúSiriu‚Äî‚Äú

But he‚Äôs out of his chair, storming toward the doors like he‚Äôs being chased.

‚ÄúWhere is he going?‚Äù Peter asks.

James only shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo ide‚Äî‚Äú and then he sees the back of Regulus‚Äôs head disappearing into the corridor and he realizes what‚Äôs about to happen.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù it‚Äôs his turn to jolt out of his seat, jogging down the length of the Great Hall.

‚Äú‚Äîyou did,‚Äù he hears Sirius say as he bursts into the foyer, turning about himself, looking for the source of the noise. ‚ÄúI know you did.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre being irrational,‚Äù Regulus says, voice flat.

They‚Äôre only a few paces down the hall, facing one another like they‚Äôre about to duel. For the first time Regulus isn‚Äôt the one with his wand out.

‚ÄúI bet you couldn‚Äôt wait to tell her,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs voice has teeth.

Regulus sighs. ‚ÄúI told you, I didn‚Äôt know you were writing to Uncle Alphard, but even if I had, I wouldn‚Äôt have said anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell that sounds like your problem not mine.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou selfish, spineless‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James steps in, grabbing hold of Sirius‚Äôs arm as he steps towards his brother whose wand, James can now see, has been expelliarmus-ed down the hall, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs enough, Sirius, lets go.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was him,‚Äù he pulls against James‚Äôs grip. ‚ÄúI fucking know it was. You always were such a little snitch. Tell me, did she reward you? How much was our Uncle‚Äôs life worth? A new broom? New robes? What‚Äôd you get on your knees for this time Regulus?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt react to his brother‚Äôs words, his expression completely unmoved.

‚ÄúIs this how its going to be Sirius?‚Äù he asks eventually, voice flat, emptied of feeling. It makes James ache. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just going to blame me for everything that goes wrong in your life?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not innocent Reg, you know that right? Just because you don‚Äôt cast the spells doesn‚Äôt mean you aren‚Äôt every bit as guilty as them. You stand there and you watch and you let it happen.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd what‚Äôs the alternative?‚Äù Regulus asks coldly.

‚ÄúRegulus‚Äî‚Äú James warns as the younger boy steps forward, Sirius barely restrained by James‚Äôs grip. Neither of them are paying much attention to him, of course. They never can see anything but each other when they‚Äôre together.

‚ÄúShould I be like you?‚Äù the younger boy asks coldly. ‚ÄúRisk everything just so I can watch everyone I love die?‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck you Reg,‚Äù Sirius doesn‚Äôt quite manage it without his voice breaking. James can feel the pain caused by Regulus‚Äôs words running through him, like they were a physical hit. He stares pleadingly at the boy he loves, willing him to look back, to stop, but his eyes are locked on his brother‚Äôs.

‚ÄúYou chose this Sirius.‚Äù

Something primal rips itself out of Sirius‚Äôs throat as he tries to raise his wand again, tries to get free of James‚Äôs grip. And honestly, James doesn‚Äôt blame him.

‚ÄúWell, well, well, what do we have here?‚Äù comes a snide voice from over James‚Äôs shoulder.

‚ÄúChrist,‚Äù he mutters under his breath, ‚Äúcould we catch a fucking break here?‚Äù

Rosier and Crouch saunter towards them, taking their places at Regulus‚Äôs side. Though, Reg looks like he‚Äôs no happier to see them than James is.

‚ÄúYou wouldn‚Äôt be trying to come for our Reggie now would you?‚Äù Crouch asks, dark eyed and pointy-faced, sneering down at them as he twirls his wand between his fingers. James already feels the overwhelming desire to punch him in the face.

‚ÄúLeave it,‚Äù Regulus says, stepping back, ‚Äúlets go.‚Äù

But Rosier and Crouch are sharks, and they can smell the blood in the water.

‚ÄúAw, are you upset?‚Äù Rosier says in a baby voice. ‚ÄúDid one of your muggle-loving friends get their heads blown off?‚Äù

Crouch snickers off to the side and James slowly lets Sirius go, no longer sure he isn‚Äôt about to whip out his own wand.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd quit while you‚Äôre ahead Rosier,‚Äù James growls, but the two Slytherin‚Äôs only seem to find this more amusing.

‚ÄúYou lot are going to have to get used to this you know, especially if this is the best your side has to offer,‚Äù he gives them a derisive once over.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù Crouch says, before James can open his mouth again, ‚ÄúI hear some of them begged,‚Äù there‚Äôs a nasty glint in his eyes. ‚ÄúCan you imagine? Begging? Fucking pathetic.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what happens when you mix with non-magical folk. Makes you soft,‚Äù Rosier chuckles. ‚ÄúSee, you lot? You lot are going to go one-by-one, and you want to know why?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre going to tell us,‚Äù James replies flatly, feeling Sirius buzzing beside him, ready to go off.

Rosier steps up close. Too close, really. His ugly sneer getting right in James‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúBecause you have no fucking claws.‚Äù

James does punch Rosier in the face then, at the same moment that Sirius sends Crouch flying down the corridor.

‚ÄúYou sure about that Rosy?‚Äù James asks as he gets Rosier on the ground before driving his foot into his stomach. ‚ÄúWhat do you reckon Padfoot?‚Äù

‚ÄúI feel pretty fucking sharp Prongs,‚Äù he spells Crouch into the air before letting him drop back down again, he lets out a high pitched screeching noise as he crumples to the floor.

‚ÄúEnough,‚Äù Regulus snaps, at the same time that Rosier scrambles to his feet and pulls out his wand. James already has his aimed. ‚ÄúEvan, I said enough!‚Äù he growls when Rosier‚Äôs wand doesn‚Äôt drop.

‚ÄúRegulus‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThis is not the time,‚Äù Regulus bites out, Crouch only just managing to peel himself off the floor.

James can‚Äôt quite believe that they‚Äôre going to listen to him, certainly doesn‚Äôt believe it enough to lower his own wand. But, to his surprise, Rosier steps back.

‚ÄúThis is a mistake,‚Äù he hisses at Regulus.

‚ÄúYour opinion has been noted, take Barty back to the common room.‚Äù

At first Rosier doesn‚Äôt move, glaring menacingly at James who honestly has no idea what‚Äôs happening anymore.

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù he spits the word out of his mouth, dragging his eyes up and down James‚Äôs body one more time before he goes to help Crouch off the wall.

‚ÄúWell done Reg,‚Äù Sirius says coldly, and James wonders if they‚Äôre going to have to do this all over again, but when he looks beside him he sees that Sirius has lowered his wand. ‚ÄúReally putting the Black name to good use I see. Is it bribery? Or have they just met Walburga?‚Äù

Regulus stares at him for a beat longer before shaking his head and turning away. Fire and ice they are. Sirius can‚Äôt keep his feelings in and Regulus can‚Äôt let his out. Either way they‚Äôll destroy themselves if they keep going.

James watches Regulus disappear down the hall, trying to swallow the tempest of emotions currently warring inside him.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù he says eventually, nudging Sirius lightly. ‚ÄúLets go, yeah?

But Sirius doesn‚Äôt respond, instead he turns away and walks very determinedly toward the front doors.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù James calls after him, moving to follow.

‚ÄúJust‚Äîleave me alone James,‚Äù he snaps over his shoulder. ‚ÄúI just want to be alone.‚Äù

James pulls up short, watching Sirius storm out of the castle. He knows that he means it. When all is said and done, Sirius really isn‚Äôt that hard to read. Still. James struggles to fight the urge to start moving again, to follow him anyway. Which isn‚Äôt fair. If Sirius wants to be alone, he should be allowed to be. It‚Äôs just that James‚Äôs wishes that wasn‚Äôt what he wanted.

¬†

‚ÄúMaybe you should go check on him?‚Äù Remus says for the hundredth time.

James is lying on his bed, arm flung over his eyes. ‚ÄúIs he still by the lake?‚Äù

He hears the sound of shuffling‚ÄîRemus has been pacing back and forth in front of the window for what feels like hours. James has given up trying to get him to relax and is counting it as a win that Remus isn‚Äôt trying to go after Sirius himself.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù there‚Äôs the unmistakable sound of the map unfolding. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs wandering around the third floor now.‚Äù

James nods, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs fine. He‚Äôll come get us when he needs us.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut I won‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú Remus shuts his mouth, frustrated.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll be here when it matters,‚Äù James stretches, pulling himself up to sitting and seeing that the sun has almost set, ‚ÄúSpeaking of which, what time is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know, I lost track,‚Äù Remus says guiltily, causing James to arch his brow. ‚ÄúYes, yes, I know.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs eight,‚Äù Peter supplies helpfully.

‚ÄúWell thank merlin someone is paying attention,‚Äù James groans as he gets to his feet. ‚Äúc‚Äômon Moons, I‚Äôll walk you to the infirmary.‚Äù

Remus scowls. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need you to chaperone me James.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, but I‚Äôm obsessed with you remember?‚Äù he grins as he holds the door open.

Remus looks down at the map again, worrying his bottom lip between his teeth.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù James says softly, and eventually the other boy lifts his head, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre going to take care of him, I promise. But right now, we have to take care of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt fair to him, he needs you guys, you should stay here tonight. Don‚Äôt worry about me, I‚Äôve done it alone before.‚Äù

Peter snorts from behind the Witch Weekly he‚Äôs currently reading ‚Äúironically‚Äù on his bed. ‚ÄúFat chance.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm with Pete,‚Äù James cuts in before Remus can. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to be there, ALL of us, and then afterwards we‚Äôll deal with the rest okay? Now come on.‚Äù

Reluctantly, Remus does.

The common room is almost empty tonight, no one feels much like socializing at the moment. Everything is just slightly‚Ä¶off. Nothing fits right. Nothing sounds right. As much as James is trying to hide it from Remus, it kills him that Sirius hasn‚Äôt come back yet. That he‚Äôs stayed away this long. Maybe he should have gone after him.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù he says after a long stretch of silence. Remus looks over at him, their steps loud in the empty corridor. ‚ÄúLily.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Remus almost smiles. ‚ÄúI was wondering when she‚Äôd come up.‚Äù

James nods, shoving his hands in his pockets and not saying anything else for a bit. ‚ÄúDo you think I should apologize?‚Äù

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúI mean, you did beat the shit out of her best mate.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, but in my defence, her best mate is Snape.‚Äù

Remus actually laughs at that, though it quickly turns into a cough that‚Äôs bad enough that they have to stop walking.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Remus croaks.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be. You okay to keep going?‚Äù

He pauses, breathing in and out a couple times before nodding his head.

‚ÄúListen,‚Äù Remus carries on eventually, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to stand here and pretend that I don‚Äôt think Snape had it coming or that it wasn‚Äôt satisfying to watch you deck him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI knew we‚Äôd corrupt you,‚Äù James grins, causing Remus to roll his eyes.

‚ÄúBut that doesn‚Äôt mean that you weren‚Äôt still acting like a brat.‚Äù

James scrunches his face. ‚ÄúLets go back to the part where you liked that I decked him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Remus snorts, ‚Äúbut you know it‚Äôs true.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe called her‚Äî‚Äú but James can‚Äôt finish it, feeling the anger boil up in him so fast he thinks he‚Äôs going to choke on it.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Remus says soberly. ‚ÄúLook, give her some space, then go talk to her. You don‚Äôt have to apologize for not liking Snape, but it might help if you at least admitted that trying to pants him in front of the whole school was a dick move.‚Äù

James lets out a melodramatic sigh as they come to a stop in front of the infirmary. ‚ÄúFine, I‚Äôll consider it.‚Äù

Remus tries to hide his smile. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs all I ask.‚Äù

James smiles back. ‚ÄúWell, guess I‚Äôll see you on the other side huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, guess,‚Äù Remus turns to go but pauses before he makes it inside. ‚ÄúJames?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf Sirius doesn‚Äôt want to come tonight‚Äîor if he doesn‚Äôt show up in time‚Äîdon‚Äôt give him shit for it, okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus, he‚Äôs going to be there.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù the other boy allows. ‚ÄúBut if he isn‚Äôt? I‚Äôm telling you now that that‚Äôs okay. He gets to have tonight if he needs it, and I don‚Äôt want you to make him feel guilty for that.‚Äù

James huffs. ‚ÄúYes, okay mum. I won‚Äôt nag him if he doesn‚Äôt want to, but I‚Äôm telling you, he will.‚Äù

Remus nods. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course Moons, whatever you want.‚Äù

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúWhatever I want, huh? In that case, I want you to fold all the‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOh no? What‚Äôs that? I can‚Äôt hear you? I think we‚Äôre breaking up,‚Äù James makes a loud static noise as he starts slowly walking backwards.

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I thought. See you James.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlways a pleasure Remus.‚Äù

He watches the door close and feels something heavy start to grow in the pit of his stomach. Whatever Remus says, Sirius needs to be there tonight. It‚Äôs a promise they‚Äôve made to each other‚Äîto Remus‚Äîto be there every time. Every moon. It‚Äôll feel like a betrayal if Sirius doesn‚Äôt show up now.

But Sirius knows that. Understands it the same way James does. All that time they spent getting Remus to trust them, to let them in. This was part of it. Being there when it‚Äôs the hardest. Not looking away from the scary bits. Not like his parents. The full moon isn‚Äôt optional for Remus. Bad day. Good day. He has to go through it. And so do they‚Äîthe three of them. It‚Äôs their job to be there, to prove to him that it isn‚Äôt optional for them either. To prove to him that he‚Äôs seen. Completely and utterly. And that all of him is wanted.

Sirius knows that.

¬†

An hour later James is feeling less certain.

‚ÄúProngs‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI know, I know,‚Äù James is standing by the window, invisibility cloak in one hand, foot tapping impatiently on the floor. ‚ÄúJust give him another five minutes yeah?‚Äù

He should have gone after him. He should have known better than to let Sirius stew on his own for this long. He should have dragged him out of that hallway before him and Regulus even got going.

James sighs, passing a hand over his face and tearing his eyes away from the quickly materializing moon, ‚ÄúOkay, I guess he‚Äî‚Äú

The door swings open and Sirius waltzes in, not angry, not flustered, he might even be‚Ä¶happy? James has neither the energy nor the time to make sense of that.

‚ÄúGents,‚Äù he nods to them.

‚ÄúThank merlin,‚Äù James says, ‚Äúthought you weren‚Äôt going to make it. C‚Äômon we gotta‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôd give it a few minutes if I were you,‚Äù and there‚Äôs something off about his voice, an empty sort of cheerfulness that makes the hair on the back of James‚Äôs neck stand on end.

‚ÄúGive it a few minutes?‚Äù he looks at Peter who shakes his head, just as lost, wand at the ready to turn into Wormtail.

‚ÄúSirius, we‚Äôre late,‚Äù he says slowly, ‚Äúwe have to go‚Äîwe should have gone twenty minutes ago.‚Äù

But instead of grasping the urgency of the situation, Sirius drops onto his bed, crossing his arms behind his head and looking infuriatingly calm.

‚ÄúNah, trust me, we‚Äôre going to be right on time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú James really has no idea what‚Äôs going on, and after floundering about for a few seconds finally manages to speak again; ‚ÄúListen, if you don‚Äôt want to come tonight Moony says it‚Äôs okay, but I really think‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI ran into Snape just now, on my way back,‚Äù Sirius interrupts, completely derailing James‚Äôs train of thought.

‚ÄúI‚Äîer‚Äîokay?‚Äù

It feels like it did. That time in the woods. When Moony went haywire.

Wrong, James‚Äôs brain keeps saying. Somethings is wrong. The way Sirius is talking, lying‚Äîin control and out of control all at the same time.

‚ÄúBrilliant it was, like fate, and I just saw it‚Äîsaw how we would prove them wrong,‚Äù he laughs and the noise finds its way between James‚Äôs ribs and pulls at his lungs.

‚ÄúProve them wrong? Prove who wrong?‚Äù James shakes his head. ‚ÄúNever mind, tell me later yeah? We have to go.‚Äù

But Sirius just smiles, it‚Äôs an expression too sharp to be joyful. ‚ÄúGod, it‚Äôs so fucking funny‚Äîso fucking ironic. Don‚Äôt you see?‚Äù he turns his head, looking at James properly for the first time.

‚ÄúSee what Pads?‚Äù he asks nervously.

‚ÄúThey said we don‚Äôt have claws,‚Äù still with that same smile on his face, ‚Äúbut we have a fucking werewolf.‚Äù

The world stops. James swears the literal rotation of the earth freezes on those words. Cold dripping down his spine.

Wrong.

Wrong.

Wrong.

‚ÄúWe‚Äîyou‚Äîdid you tell Snape about Remus?‚Äù a question he never thought he‚Äôd have to ask and somehow Sirius is still smiling.

‚ÄúBetter than that,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI told him how to get past the tree.‚Äù

¬†

James is running. No invisibility cloak. No secret passageways. He runs, feet slamming into the stone floors, chest heaving with the effort. He‚Äôs never moved so fast in his life. Never felt so scared‚Äîso scared that he‚Äôs not even sure this is real, that he hasn‚Äôt just fallen into one of his nightmares. Wake up, he thinks, wake up. Wake up. Wake up. Please wake up.

I told him how to get past the tree.

It must have rained at some point because James slips on the grass as he hurtles himself across the lawn, lungs stinging with the cold air. There‚Äôs always the chance that Snape didn‚Äôt take the bait‚Äîthat he saw it for the trap that it is. That he just minded his own fucking business for once in his miserable life. But as the willow comes into view James knows that‚Äôs not what happened. Knows it from the strange way the branches are holding themselves. Someone‚Äôs pressed the knot. Recently.

I told him how to get past the tree.

James doesn‚Äôt stop, doesn‚Äôt slow down, throwing himself into the passage and towards the shrieking shack, barely breathing. It‚Äôs late. They were already running late. He has no time. He doesn‚Äôt know what he‚Äôs going to do if he gets there and Moony has already transformed. If he gets there and he‚Äôs‚Äîhe‚Äôs‚Äîfuck.

He bursts into the shack, breathing heavy, pulse loud in his ears as he takes the steps two at a time.

‚ÄúGet out! GET OUT!‚Äù Remus‚Äôs voice is stripped bare with fear.

‚ÄúWhat the hell are you playing at Lupin? What is this place?‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, please, Snape I‚Äôm begging you, leave. Just leave,‚Äù he sounds close to tears.

James throws open the door to the bedroom with such force that it slams into the wall behind it. Remus has backed himself up as far away from Snape as he can get‚Äîhe doesn‚Äôt have his wand, of course, completely defenceless, meanwhile Snape has his drawn and pointed right at him.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Remus says weakly, ‚ÄúJames he‚Äôs here, he‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú Remus doubles over, an agonizing groan ripping out of him.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck is going on?‚Äù Snape turns on him, pointing his wand in James‚Äôs direction but he ignores it, walking right passed him and over to Remus‚Äôs side.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs now,‚Äù he trembles, ‚ÄúJames, James, James,‚Äù his voice skips like a scratched record, like he‚Äôs losing control of it. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs happening now‚Äîyou have to‚Äî-he‚Äîhe can‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSh, sh, it‚Äôs okay, it‚Äôs going to be okay, I promise. I‚Äôm going to take care of it,‚Äù he wraps his arm around him as gently as he can but Remus still flinches as James guides him back to the mattress.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck is wrong with him?‚Äù Snape demands.

Remus is hyperventilating, dropping his head between his knees the minute he‚Äôs sitting down again, his whole body shaking.

‚ÄúYou have to get‚Äî‚Äú but his voice disappears and instead he screams. James wonders if one day that sound will stop feeling like broken glass.

With a shaky breath he turns to Snape, ‚ÄúWe have to go. Now.‚Äù

Snape only glares, attempting to lean around James so he can get a better look at Remus. ‚ÄúIs he mental‚Äîhave they let a fucking psycho into Hogwarts?‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, you‚Äôre going to move or I‚Äôm going to‚Äî‚Äú James reaches into his back pocket for his wand. And keeps reaching.

And reaching.

But there‚Äôs nothing there.

He forgot his wand.

He. Forgot. His. Wand.

At that moment he hears the unmistakable noise of bones breaking. He doesn‚Äôt need to turn around. He‚Äôs seen it before. He knows what‚Äôs happening.

And if the new expression of horror on Snape‚Äôs face is anything to go by, he does too.

‚ÄúMove, you idiot. Now. We‚Äôre going now.‚Äù

James steps forward to grab him but Snape jabs the tip of his wand into his chest.

‚ÄúA werewolf?‚Äù he demands. ‚ÄúThe freak is a werewolf?‚Äù

‚ÄúMOVE.‚Äù

Some horrendous noise rips itself from Remus‚Äôs throat and James sees it happen‚Äîsees the wand move from his chest to the boy behind him, sees Snape open his mouth.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you dare!‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt think, he just launches himself forward, tackling Snape before he can get out whatever spell he‚Äôs trying to. They crash to the floor, landing hard on his shoulder.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong with you!‚Äù Snape‚Äôs voice is high as they roll around, dust getting into James‚Äôs eyes and mouth‚Äîan elbow to the face, a knee to the gut‚Äîhe still ends up on top. At some point in the scuffle Snape‚Äôs wand is lost. He doesn‚Äôt know where it goes.

‚ÄúGet off of me! Get off! Get off! That thing is a fucking monster‚Äîdo people know? There‚Äôs going to be a fucking inquiry. They‚Äôll throw you all in Azkaban‚ÄîGET OFF OF ME!‚Äù

‚ÄúI would shut your mouth unless you want a repeat of yesterday, asshole. Lily‚Äôs not here to rescue you this time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú but suddenly Snape goes still, eyes growing to nearly twice their normal size.

James nearly asks what‚Äôs wrong with him when‚Äî

Oh.

Oh no.

The screaming‚Äôs stopped.

James looks over his shoulder and is met with a pair of glowing, yellow eyes. He tries sometimes, to look for Remus in them. He hasn‚Äôt found him yet.

He rolls off of Snape just as the wolf launches itself forward, Snape scrambling out after him. They‚Äôre nearly out of the room when Snape jerks to a stop.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck are you doing?‚Äù James demands.

‚ÄúMy wand‚Äî‚Äú

James doesn‚Äôt wait, grabbing Snape by the front of his shirt and throwing him down the hall towards the stairs.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll buy you a new fucking wand, now move‚Äî‚Äú

He hears Moony howl behind them, the noise is loud, shaking the shack, scraping along his bones.

They make it to the top of the stairs before James feels a set of sharp claws sink into his back, throwing him into Snape. They all go careening down the stairs. James manages to knock Moony off but can‚Äôt stop himself from falling the rest of the way to the bottom.

Everything shakes. His hands. His head. He‚Äôs pretty sure the floor underneath him is shaking. There‚Äôs blood. His face maybe? Definitely his back. Somehow he manages to push himself back onto his hands and knees.

Snape is lying beside him. Face down.

‚ÄúSnape,‚Äù he shakes him, and then sees the blood by his forehead. ‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù fear cuts through him like a knife. ‚ÄúSnape? Snape? Severus‚Äîfuck.‚Äù

A growl from above draws his attention and he looks back to see Moony standing at the top of the landing, seeming so much bigger than he ever has before, lips pulled back over his teeth.

James‚Äôs eyes dart around, looking for something‚Äîanything‚Äîto fight with. They land on the stair bannister. He hears the noise of claws on wood as he reaches for one of the posts and starts pulling.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù he hisses, feeling the rotten wood give. Feeling the stairs creak as Moony gets closer. ‚ÄúCome. On.‚Äù It pulls off and James spins around, wielding it like a bat.

Moony is nearly on him, launching off the last step as James swings. A clean shot. Right at the face. Moony lets out a whine pulling away but not far and James feels his panic rising. What exactly is his plan here? How is he gonna fight a werewolf with a piece of wood? How is he going to fight Moony?

The wolf‚Äôs hackles are up, back arched as he turns to James again‚Äîexcept‚Äîexcept his eyes are on the post in his hands.

‚ÄúOh you have got to be kidding me,‚Äù James breathes, giving the wood an experimental wave and watching Moony‚Äôs eyes follow it.

Admittedly, if this doesn‚Äôt work, James will once again find himself defenceless in front of a werewolf. But hey, what‚Äôs life without a little risk?

‚ÄúOkay Moony,‚Äù he waves the post around a little more. ‚ÄúOkay, okay, you want the stick? Huh? You want the stick big guy?‚Äù

Praying with every fibre of his being that this works.

‚ÄúGo get it then!‚Äù he chucks the post up onto the floor above them and by some absolute miracle, Moony follows.

James doesn‚Äôt hesitate, bending down and grabbing Snape by the arms, dragging him towards the door. He can taste blood in his mouth.

It feels like seconds. Maybe less, before a snarl brings his attention back to the stairs. Moony glares at him for a moment, before spitting the post out from between his teeth.

‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù

James tries to move faster, the door to the passage just behind him, but Moony is moving fast now too.

‚ÄúFuck, fuck, fuck.‚Äù

He pushes through the door, yellow eyes coming right for him. He lets Snape drop as he scrambles for the handle, slamming the door shut and sliding the metal bolt across the top. There‚Äôs barely a second before he hears Moony colliding with it on the other side.

He stays with his back pressed against it, breathing so heavy it hurts, sweat covering his skin. Moony growls, pawing at the door, but the lock holds. James tries to exhale, tries to get some kind of control over his heart, his eyes trailing down to the body at his feet.

Snape still hasn‚Äôt moved.

‚ÄúI swear to God if you‚Äôre dead,‚Äù James murmurs, stumbling beside him, his limbs not quite working properly. He can‚Äôt tell if it‚Äôs from the adrenaline or the stairs, but his whole body feels numb. Which is probably a blessing.

He rolls Snape onto his back, pressing his ear to his chest, trying to hear past his own thundering heartbeat.

‚ÄúCome on you bastard,‚Äù he hisses.

He feels more than he hears Snape take his next breath, his chest rising and falling under James‚Äôs ear. He pulls back, looking down at the nasty gash on his forehead that slips up into his black hair, covering half his face with blood.

James brings his hands to his own face, sussing out the damage. Behind him Moony starts howling.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù he drops his hands, getting Snape‚Äôs arm over his shoulder and hauling him onto his back. ‚ÄúMerlin you‚Äôre heavy,‚Äù he mutters, as he starts to walk.

It‚Äôs hard, and takes longer than it should. James is pretty sure he‚Äôs got some nasty bruises along his ribs and shoulder because every time Snape shifts on his back he feels a burning pain down his side. He prays to Godric the wanker doesn‚Äôt wake up. The last thing he needs is to have to deal with a hysterical Snape making things difficult.

By the time he drags himself out of the whomping willow he‚Äôs sweating and shaking and only just makes it past the tree branches before dropping Snape onto the grass. Hissing at the sharp pain that shoots through his shoulder.

‚ÄúHoly shit‚Äî‚Äú

He looks up and sees Peter and Sirius coming towards him across the lawn. Even in the near pitch black he can tell that Sirius isn‚Äôt smiling anymore.

‚ÄúHoly shit, Prongs,‚Äù Peter repeats.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôs Remus? What happened?‚Äù Sirius asks beside him, sounding nervous.

James ignores him, looking only at Peter. ‚ÄúI need you to go calm him down, he‚Äôs right by the door so you‚Äôll have to transform before you go.‚Äù

Peter has only barely opened his mouth to respond when Sirius steps forward.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll go‚ÄîI‚Äôll‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThe hell you will,‚Äù with everything left in him James shoves Sirius back. ‚ÄúYou stay the fuck away from him.‚Äù

Sirius blinks, eyes big and swimming in moonlight. He looks lost. And for once in his life James doesn‚Äôt care.

‚ÄúPeter. Go.‚Äù

‚ÄúBy myself?‚Äù Peter squeaks.

James gives him a look that is apparently enough of an answer because he doesn‚Äôt bother arguing again, transforming into a rat and running towards the tree with his wand in his mouth.

The quiet is heavy, Sirius and James just staring at one another, James still breathing hard. He doesn‚Äôt know what he looks like‚Äîhe imagines not good.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Sirius says weakly‚Äîpleadingly. And it makes James angry.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck is wrong with you?‚Äù he snaps. ‚ÄúHow could you do that? How could‚Äîhow could you be so fucking selfish?‚Äù he watches Sirius flinch, curling in on himself.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he whispers.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know?‚Äù he‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôs ever heard himself sound so cold. ‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs brilliant Sirius, really. Just thought it‚Äôd be funny eh? A good laugh? Another one of your spontaneous pranks?‚Äù

Sirius isn‚Äôt looking at him anymore, eyes on the ground. ‚ÄúDoes he‚Äîdid he see?‚Äù he asks eventually, nodding to Snape.

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that what you wanted?‚Äù

Sirius grimaces but doesn‚Äôt move his gaze from Snape‚Äôs motionless form. Like he‚Äôs trying to convince himself it‚Äôs really there.

‚ÄúWe could wipe his memory.‚Äù

‚ÄúWipe his memory,‚Äù James repeats slowly, feeling cracked open. ‚ÄúYou know how to do that do you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI could figure it out,‚Äù he looks up at James, hopeful. ‚ÄúI know I could.‚Äù

James lets out an empty laugh, the noise bouncing around them in the dark. ‚ÄúAnd then what? It‚Äôll be like it never happened? You going to wipe Remus‚Äôs memory too? Mine? Pete‚Äôs?‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes go wide, his mouth opening helplessly without any sound coming out. Suddenly James is exhausted. He doesn‚Äôt want to deal with this. Doesn‚Äôt know how.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs illegal,‚Äù he says finally, bending down to pick Snape up again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to Azkaban just so you don‚Äôt have to deal with what a shitty person you are,‚Äù he brushes past him and towards the castle.

‚ÄúWhere you taking him?‚Äù Sirius asks, jogging up beside him.

‚ÄúInfirmary.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames he‚Äôll talk, you know he will, and then Remus‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYES. I KNOW.‚Äù

James has to stop again, struggling to keep himself contained, to keep himself from falling out of the holes torn in his skin. Sirius is looking at him with shocked eyes. James has never yelled at him like that before. He‚Äôs not sure that he‚Äôs ever yelled at anyone like that.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to talk to Dumbledore,‚Äù his voice trembles with the effort to remain steady. ‚ÄúHe went through all the trouble of letting Remus in, he‚Äôs not going to let Snape ruin that,‚Äù he starts walking again. He can feel Snape‚Äôs blood soaking into his shoulder.

‚ÄúOkay‚Äîyeah, you might be right. I‚Äôll come with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, maybe I wasn‚Äôt clear earlier. When I said stay the fuck away from him, I also meant stay the fuck away from me.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames please, please I‚ÄîI just wasn‚Äôt thinking. I‚Äôm sorry. I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou just weren‚Äôt thinking?‚Äù James demands. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre unbelievable‚Äîyou know it‚Äôs going to break his heart right?‚Äù he stops again, turning to face Sirius fully. ‚ÄúI mean, it would have if it was any of us but that it was you‚Äîyou,‚Äù James‚Äôs voice breaks and he grits his teeth in frustration. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to destroy him when he finds out.‚Äù

For a minute Sirius just stands there, looking small. And then; ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why it matters that it was me,‚Äù he says thinly.

James drops his head, letting out a long exhale. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says dryly, looking up again, ‚Äúsure you don‚Äôt.‚Äù He turns around and keeps walking. He hears his name one more time but doesn‚Äôt stop.

¬†

Poppy Pomfrey stands in front of him in a housecoat and slippers, hair braided down her back. Her wand currently providing the only light in the room.

‚ÄúJames Potter you better have a good reason for waking me up at‚Äî‚Äú she pauses, squinting, ‚Äúis that blood?‚Äù with one flick of her wand all the lamps in her office light and she steps forward, bringing her hands to his face, inspecting the damage.

‚ÄúIs it bad? I haven‚Äôt seen it yet?‚Äù

‚ÄúJames what happened?‚Äù apparently, in her shock, last names have gone out the window.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a long story, listen,‚Äù he steps gently out of her grasp. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine, it‚Äôs‚Äîit‚Äôs Snape you need to look at.‚Äù

She blinks. ‚ÄúSnape? Severus Snape?‚Äù

James nods, leading her back out into the infirmary where he left Snape on one of the empty beds.

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù she hisses under her breath, moving quickly to his side. ‚ÄúJames what on earth happened to you?‚Äù her eyes are on the body in front of her, wand running up and down, casting so quickly James can‚Äôt keep track.

He sighs, sitting on the chair next to the bed and wiping at his bleeding nose. ‚ÄúHe got in.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot in?‚Äù she asks distractedly, muttering something over Snape‚Äôs head. He watches her wearily, hoping it looks worse than it is. That it‚Äôll be an easy fix. Remus will never forgive himself otherwise.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James croaks. ‚ÄúYeah, he got into the shack.‚Äù

Her hands still. Her whole body stills really, eyes flicking up to meet his for the first time. ‚ÄúThe shack?‚Äù she repeats.

James nods.

‚ÄúHe‚ÄîRemus did this?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot on purpose, but, yeah.‚Äù

He sees the fear in her eyes as they bounce back and forth between him and Snape, reassessing their injuries.

‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt bite us.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúThis was the stairs mostly,‚Äù he motions to himself.

‚ÄúAnd Remus?‚Äù he knows that she cares for him. Maybe almost as much as James does.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs still there, locked in. He‚Äôll be okay‚Äîor, well‚Äîhe‚Äôs not hurt too bad anyway, I don‚Äôt think. We didn‚Äôt have our wands.‚Äù James feels his stomach squirm but he pushes all thoughts of how very not okay Remus is going to be out of his head. There are still hours until sunrise and if he thinks about it too much he‚Äôll lose it.

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt have your wands,‚Äù she repeats slowly, face paling, she just stares at him for a moment before eventually shaking her head. ‚ÄúI have to get the Headmaster and your Heads of House,‚Äù she looks at him and then quickly waves her wand, James feels the tingling sensation of her diagnostic charms.

‚ÄúYou should be okay to wait, nothing severe,‚Äù she starts moving away when James calls her back.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôll be alright?‚Äù he asks, gesturing to Snape.

She pauses a moment, and then nods. ‚ÄúA concussion, that‚Äôs all. He‚Äôll have to take a potion in the morning for the next week and then he should be good as new.‚Äù

James exhales, feeling his whole body relax.

Okay.

Well.

At least there‚Äôs that.

‚ÄúYou did good James,‚Äù she says, voice softening. A minute later he hears the infirmary door closing behind her.

James passes a hand over his face and winces as he brushes against the cuts on his cheek and forehead. He gives Snape a lingering look, hair now stuck to his face as the blood dries, robes covered in dust and dirt. He hates him. He‚Äôs not sure if he‚Äôs right to in this moment but he does. It‚Äôs easier than hating Sirius.

Eventually he gets up, moving to a chair across the room so he doesn‚Äôt have to look at him anymore. He leans his head back against the wall, closing his eyes. He hopes that Peter actually went into the shack and isn‚Äôt just waiting outside the door. He hopes that him being there helps get Moony to relax. He hurts himself when he gets worked up‚Äîespecially when he‚Äôs trapped. He very determinedly doesn‚Äôt think about Sirius. Or where he is. Or what he‚Äôs going to say when he sees him next.

The numbness of before is wearing off, and everything aches and twinges. And he‚Äôs tired. So fucking tired. He has to figure out what he‚Äôs going to tell Remus‚Äîhow he‚Äôs going to stop him from reverting back to first year. To a boy who smiles politely but doesn‚Äôt say much. Doesn‚Äôt trust anyone enough to give any part of himself away.

‚ÄúPotter?‚Äù

James blinks his eyes open, not remembering hearing anyone come in. The world is blurry for a minute, but slowly, a looming McGonagall comes into view, mouth pursed, tartan housecoat wrapped tightly around herself.

‚ÄúAre you alright?‚Äù she asks, somehow managing to sound both concerned and brisk at the same time.

‚ÄúUh‚Äîsure,‚Äù he pulls himself up straighter, wincing at the tightness of his muscles. The infirmary is fully lit now, the curtains drawn around Snape‚Äôs bed. He must have fallen asleep.

Behind McGonagall are Dumbledore and Slughorn, both staring at James expectantly, while Pomfrey flits in and out in the background, moving between her office and Snape‚Äôs beside.

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú James doesn‚Äôt like where this is going at all.

‚ÄúHow, precisely,‚Äù McGonagall presses on, clearly not in the mood for smalltalk, ‚Äúdid you and Snape find yourselves in the shrieking shack?‚Äù

James blinks up at her.

Oh.

Right.

Questions.

‚ÄúThe whomping willow,‚Äù because he figures the more literal his answers are, the safer he‚Äôll be.

She arches her eyebrow. ‚ÄúAnd how did you know that the tree was an entrance? ‚Äù

Remus, Remus told them. But James isn‚Äôt about to tell her that, so instead he shrugs. ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt remember.‚Äù

He thinks he hears Dumbledore chuckle in the background, but he can‚Äôt be sure.

‚ÄúReally,‚Äù McGonagall says slowly, ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt remember?‚Äù

This is a time tested method of the marauders. When in doubt, amnesia is always an excellent defence. ‚ÄúNope.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù she exhales mightily. ‚ÄúAnd why, may I ask, were you trying to get into the shrieking shack at all?‚Äù

He meets her eyes, gaze steady. ‚ÄúI went to stop Snape.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo stop Snape? Stop him from what?‚Äù

Really? he thinks, is she really going to make me say it?

‚ÄúProfessor,‚Äù he says meaningfully, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs one of my best mates, we‚Äôve shared a room for five years. You don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve noticed that he always gets sick around the full moon?‚Äù

She looks more surprised by this revelation than he expected her to. Pomfrey, of course, now standing still in the background, does not appear the least bit shocked.

‚ÄúFor how long have you known about Lupin‚Äôs‚Ä¶condition.‚Äù

In for a penny, in for a pound; ‚ÄúSecond year.‚Äù Not that he wasn‚Äôt bloody suspicious in first year, but if they were going by the first time they got Remus to admit to it, that was second year, just before Christmas.

‚ÄúIs it sunrise yet?‚Äù James asks suddenly, even though he knows the interrogation isn‚Äôt over. He‚Äôs not sure how long he‚Äôs been asleep. He looks around McGonagall trying to see the window.

‚ÄúNot yet,‚Äù Pomfrey offers. ‚ÄúAnother hour still, than I‚Äôll go get him.‚Äù

James nods, turning his attention to Dumbledore. ‚ÄúYou have to protect him.‚Äù

‚ÄúPotter‚Äî‚Äú McGonagall starts, but as much as he likes her, and he does, he‚Äôs not interested in manners or rules. Not right now.

He looks Dumbledore dead in the eye. ‚ÄúSnape is going to spread this around to who ever will listen, you have to stop him. You have to make sure that doesn‚Äôt happen.‚Äù

Dumbledore‚Äôs blue eyes twinkle in the candlelight. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve protected him so far have I not?‚Äù he says after a brief pause.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù James says, because he doesn‚Äôt. As far as he can tell, Remus has protected himself. ‚ÄúBut I need your word that you‚Äôll protect him now.‚Äù

He can feel Dumbledore‚Äôs attention like a hand on his shoulder, fingers digging in, squeezing, looking for something. But James doesn‚Äôt back down, doesn‚Äôt blink.

‚ÄúYou have it. Of course. Snape will be made well aware of the importance of Lupin‚Äôs privacy, and of what the consequences will be if he violates it.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow, now Dumbledore,‚Äù Slughorn pipes up. ‚ÄúLets not forget, Severus is the victim in all this.‚Äù

Dumbledore looks over at him, passively. ‚ÄúI daresay that there have been several victims tonight. Due largely to Snape‚Äôs curiosity.‚Äù

James nearly laughs at the look of outrage on Slughorn‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúBut how did he know about the shack?‚Äù McGonagall asks, bringing all eyes back to James.

He doesn‚Äôt know why he lies, stupid really, when Snape will no doubt rat Sirius out the moment he‚Äôs conscious. And honestly, serves Sirius right, he‚Äôs not interested in protecting him. Not this time. But for some reason he just can‚Äôt make himself‚Ä¶

‚ÄúSorry, I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

McGonagall stares him down, as if expecting him to crack under the pressure of her disapproval. In fairness, he‚Äôs sure it‚Äôs worked for her in the past. But James doesn‚Äôt even fidget.

‚ÄúYou can return to your room now Potter,‚Äù she says, eventually, ‚Äútry to get some sleep.‚Äù

But James shakes his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going anywhere.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus will be in good hands James,‚Äù Dumbledore says calmly. ‚ÄúYou have nothing to worry about.‚Äù He smiles, but James doesn‚Äôt smile back.

‚ÄúWith all due respect Sir,‚Äù he leans forward, clasping his hands between his knees, ‚Äúone of my best friends just had to live through his worst nightmare. If you think there‚Äôs anyway I‚Äôm going to let him wake up alone you don‚Äôt know me very well.‚Äù

He feels the other three adults staring at him, a new tension falling over the room. James isn‚Äôt stupid, he knows who Dumbledore is‚Äîknows he‚Äôs much more than the headmaster of a school. He‚Äôs heard the things his parents have said. The way they look up to Dumbledore. And he does too, honestly, has the chocolate frog card and everything.

But he‚Äôll fight him if he needs too.
