Eventually Dumbledore smiles again. ‚ÄúQuite right,‚Äù he says, ‚ÄúMinerva, Horace,‚Äù he nods in the direction of Madame Pomfrey‚Äôs office, ‚Äúa word.‚Äù

McGonagall does not look at all pleased about the way things have gone, but with one last look at James she allows herself to be herded away. Leaving him and Pomfrey alone again.

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù she says, stepping closer, ‚Äúlets do something about that face shall we?‚Äù

He nods, not paying much attention to the waves of magic that wash over him. Some of it hurts, but he registers it in a distant way, not really feeling it properly. Eyes staying, the whole time, on the brightening sky outside the window.

‚ÄúDo you know what they‚Äôre talking about in there?‚Äù James asks after a while, nodding his head in the direction of her office.

Pomfrey makes a ‚Äútisking‚Äù noise. ‚ÄúNo doubt trying to figure out how to keep the Ministry out of this.‚Äù

James snaps his head out of her hands. ‚ÄúThe Ministry? Why would the Ministry get involved?‚Äù

She huffs, clearly unhappy to have her work interrupted. ‚ÄúWell, they like to keep a rather tight rein on‚Ä¶y‚Äôknow‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWerewolves?‚Äù

She frowns.

‚ÄúYou can say it you know,‚Äù James pushes. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it makes him feel better when people act like it‚Äôs a dirty word. It‚Äôs just‚Äîjust a part of him that‚Äôs all. Not bad or good. Just there.‚Äù

He‚Äôs worried, for a moment, that she‚Äôs going to argue with him. He doesn‚Äôt have much patience for people having a go at Remus on a good day. He certainly doesn‚Äôt have the ability to handle it well right now.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs lucky to have you,‚Äù she says eventually.

James lets that sit with him for a moment before he shrugs. ‚ÄúActually, I think we‚Äôre the ones lucky to have him.‚Äù

She smiles softly at him, and together they watch the sun come up.

¬†

When Pomfrey comes back from the shack an hour later it‚Äôs with an unconscious Remus floating beside her and James is up and at his side immediately.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt right,‚Äù he says anxiously, keeping his voice down so that the others won‚Äôt hear, ‚Äúhe should be awake.‚Äù

Pomfrey sends him a side-long look as she folds back the covers of the nearest bed and lowers Remus into it.

‚ÄúIt used to happen a lot before.‚Äù

‚ÄúBefore?‚Äù

She nods, tucking Remus in. ‚ÄúWhen he was younger it would take him quite a bit longer to wake up. Right up until the latter half of his second year I would say,‚Äù she sends him a meaningful look across the bed. But James still doesn‚Äôt understand.

‚ÄúWhy though?‚Äù he whispers, taking the chair beside Remus‚Äôs bed.

She exhales, running her wand over him and fixing the smaller nicks and bruises before brushing the hair back from his forehead. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs not much work that‚Äôs been done on lycanthropy, but, from what I can tell, it helps if you want to wake up. Want to come back to yourself.‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt sure which part of that hurts more. The fact that eleven year old Remus didn‚Äôt want to wake up. Or the fact that fifteen year old Remus doesn‚Äôt want to wake up. Without thinking he reaches out and takes Remus‚Äôs hand.

‚ÄúIs he‚Äî‚Äú James swallows. ‚ÄúI had to hit him, to get away, is he‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs alright, few bruised ribs, nothing he hasn‚Äôt had before,‚Äù which James knows is meant to be comforting but isn‚Äôt at all.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he squeezes Remus‚Äôs hand a little more tightly.

‚ÄúJust give him time James,‚Äù she says as she goes to leave, closing the curtains around them. James is glad that none of the others come in. Glad that when Remus wakes up he won‚Äôt be surrounded by a bunch of unwelcome faces.

It‚Äôs strange thinking about it now, that Christmas in second year. James and Sirius had been certain for months but Peter still wasn‚Äôt convinced.

‚ÄúWhat if we‚Äôre wrong?‚Äù he‚Äôd worried. ‚ÄúWhat if he gets offended?‚Äù

But all they‚Äôd cared about was being right‚Äîbeing clever enough, observant enough, to spot it. They tease Remus about being a swot but the truth is, it was James and Sirius who were obsessed with being the brightest, the most talented, top of the class. Who wanted to be seen. They hadn‚Äôt once considered what it would mean for Remus, for people to know. Or how unfair it was, not to let him tell them himself.

The day before they were due to leave on Christmas break the four of them had been in their room packing. It had been Sirius‚Äôs idea. Because of course it had.

‚ÄúOi, Remus,‚Äù he‚Äôd called out, ‚Äúwanna throw me the cufflinks on my dresser?‚Äù

Sirius had been sitting on his bed, mountains of clothes piled around him.

‚ÄúI think that might be the poshest thing anyone‚Äôs ever asked me,‚Äù Remus laughed, missing the meaningful look exchanged between James and Sirius, Peter standing nervously by the window.

Almost as soon as he touched the cufflinks he recoiled. ‚ÄúOw‚Äîwhat‚Äî‚Äú he clutched his hand to his chest, face going ashen as he looked at them more closely.

Silver.

They were silver.

James and Sirius thought they were so clever.

It made him feel a bit sick to think about it now. How triumphant they had felt. Look at us, they had thought, we figured it out!

‚ÄúSomething you want to tell us Remus?‚Äù Sirius had said grinning, while Remus stared between the three of them in horror.

‚ÄúIt was just static‚Äîthey shocked me,‚Äù he‚Äôd stuttered.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon, we‚Äôre not that dim,‚Äù James was off his bed at that point, leaning against the dresser next to Remus.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre right aren‚Äôt we?‚Äù Sirius leaned forward. ‚ÄúGone every full moon, can‚Äôt touch silver, and the scars‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThey aren‚Äôt that noticeable,‚Äù it had come out of him like a reflex, something Remus had no doubt spent his childhood being reassured of. An age old insecurity he was trying to talk himself out of. Not that James or Sirius picked up on it at the time.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre wicked is what they are,‚Äù Sirius said.

For some reason, that hadn‚Äôt made Remus feel any better.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù he‚Äôd begged. ‚ÄúPlease.‚Äù

And suddenly James has a horrible sense of de ja vu, having just heard that exact same plea echoing through the halls of the shrieking shack.

They had been young, only twelve, they couldn‚Äôt understand‚Äîcouldn‚Äôt even begin to comprehend all that Remus had been through. All that he had to be afraid of. It had seemed fun to them‚Äîlike a super power. A party trick. But they aren‚Äôt those kids anymore. They know better now‚Äîthey‚Äôve seen enough to know better. So how did this happen? How did they end up here?

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù

James opens his eyes, not realizing he had closed them in the first place, finding Remus wide-eyed and awake.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù this time his name is a desperate sound. ‚ÄúFuck‚Äîwhat happened? Snape‚ÄîSnape was there‚Äîhe‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHey, hey,‚Äù James says gently, squeezing his hand. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, everything is okay.‚Äù Which isn‚Äôt really true, but he‚Äôs not sure what else to say.

‚ÄúHe was there,‚Äù Remus says again, his voice a wrecked thing and he looks at James like he wants him to tell him he‚Äôs wrong. That he made it up. That none of it happened. And James wishes he could. More than anything.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says pointlessly. ‚ÄúYeah Moons, he was there.‚Äù

Please. Please.

‚ÄúHe saw‚Äîhe knows?‚Äù

James can hear voices on the other side of the curtains and silently begs the universe to just give them a little more time before the adults come in with their questions and accusations.

‚ÄúHe knows.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs chest hitches and for a second James thinks he‚Äôs stopped breathing all together, but then he starts jerkily nodding his head. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says, sounding anything but, ‚Äúokay, okay. So‚Äîso I‚Äôm going to have to‚ÄîI‚Äôm going to have to leave,‚Äù he isn‚Äôt looking at James anymore. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs okay, I can take my OWLs at home, by post, and then‚Äîand then‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know I‚Äôll‚ÄîI‚Äôll get a job I guess‚Äîa Muggle job, where no one will know me and‚Äîand that‚Äôs okay. I can do that. I can‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMoons‚ÄîRemus,‚Äù James yanks on his hand, pulling him back. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not being expelled.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôll tell everyone James,‚Äù he uses his free hand to try and wipe away the tears now sneaking from his eyes, ‚Äúand once he does they won‚Äôt let Dumbledore keep me here. It‚Äôs‚Äîbut that‚Äôs okay. I never should have been here in the first place really. This was all a bit of a gift anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey‚Äîno, stop that, none of that is happening okay? Remus‚ÄîRemus look at me?‚Äù

And he does, with eyes that say he‚Äôs spent his life cutting away pieces of himself. Trying to carve out the person he thinks the world wants.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve talked to Dumbledore, he‚Äôs going to make sure Snape keeps his mouth shut, you‚Äôre not going anywhere, okay?‚Äù

Remus seems to swallow with difficulty. ‚ÄúDumbledore said that?‚Äù

James nods, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs probably going to come through those curtains any minute and explain it to you himself,‚Äù James squeezes his hand again. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going anywhere okay? I promise.‚Äù

It takes a minute for that to sink in, for Remus to accept it, even a little bit, and James watches as he sits back against his Pillows.

‚ÄúSnape‚Äôs okay?‚Äù he asks in a small voice.

‚ÄúCompletely fine I‚Äôm sorry to report.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt acknowledge the joke. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt hurt him‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt hurt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúPushed us down the stairs but, other than that? Nah, you‚Äôre puppy really.‚Äù

Remus lets out a noise somewhere between a laugh and a sob. ‚ÄúFuck James,‚Äù he finally pulls his hand free, bringing it up to his face. ‚ÄúHow did this happen? How did he know?‚Äù

And oh how James has been dreading this question.

For some reason he can‚Äôt get Sirius‚Äôs face out of his head. The way he‚Äôd looked in second year when he‚Äôd thought of the cufflinks. And then somehow that smile turns into the one he‚Äôd had in the dorm room. All teeth. All pain. That‚Äôs always been the problem with Sirius Black. He‚Äôs all light or all dark with no in between.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Remus‚Äôs hands have fallen back into his lap, ‚ÄúYou know don‚Äôt you?"

He wants to lie. He desperately wants to lie.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù it‚Äôs rough and frayed. He clears his throat. ‚ÄúYeah I know. It‚ÄîSirius.‚Äù He has to force it out, because otherwise he doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôll ever be able to say it.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he can already hear the horror in Remus‚Äôs voice.

‚ÄúSirius told him‚Äîhow to get past the tree.‚Äù

Please. Please.

Remus just stares at him, like maybe if he‚Äôs still enough the words won‚Äôt find him. And then he won‚Äôt have to deal with it.

‚ÄúBut why‚Äî‚Äú his voice cracks and James can see him fighting tooth and nail to keep it together, ‚Äúwhy would he do that?‚Äù

His voice is barely there, breathless, chest starting to heave again‚Äîshort, jerky, inhales.

‚ÄúJust breathe Remus okay? I need you to breathe?‚Äù but he doesn‚Äôt think Remus is listening to him.

‚ÄúWhy would he do that?‚Äù

Please. Please.

James shakes his head, feeling helplessly cracked. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. I‚Äôm sorry Remus, I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

And James knows then, that he will never be able to hate Sirius Black.

Because he doesn‚Äôt.

But oh how he wants to.

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

I realize that for a Jegulus fic there was very little Regulus in this chapter but I promise our boy will be back next chapter.

Honestly, doesn't matter how many times I read it, The Prank gets me every time. Like the BETRAYAL. Sirius bb, please, why.

Thank you for your wonderful comments, hope you're having a great day / evening / night (it's late here idk if you can tell I am tireeeeeed)

Chapter 14

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

James spends the day in the infirmary with Remus. They don‚Äôt talk much. Peter brings their schoolwork and breakfast, stays for a while.

‚ÄúHave you seen him?‚Äù James asks as Peter is leaving, they walk away from Remus‚Äôs bed, talking quietly by the door.

Peter nods. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs in the room. He asked about Remus‚Äîhe wanted to come but I‚ÄîI thought it would be a bad idea.‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúThanks.‚Äù

‚ÄúSee you at dinner?‚Äù Peter asks hopefully.

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù he pats him on the shoulder before heading back to Remus, whose been burying himself in a history book for the last hour.

‚ÄúMoons?‚Äù he asks tentatively, leaning against the end of the bed.

Remus‚Äôs eyes flick up briefly before dropping back down. ‚ÄúMm?‚Äù Everything about his posture is closed off, since their conversation this morning he‚Äôs been nearly silent. James doesn‚Äôt blame him, not at all, but he hates it.

‚ÄúI just have to do something real quick, but I‚Äôll be back soon okay?‚Äù

There‚Äôs silence and then Remus sighs. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to be here James,‚Äù he says quietly, eyes not lifting from the page in front of him.

‚ÄúI know, but I want to be.‚Äù

They‚Äôve already had this conversation several times this morning and James doesn‚Äôt think that either of them feels like getting into it again.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be back,‚Äù he repeats, and this time Remus just nods his head.

Before he makes it out of the infirmary he casts a look at the bed a few paces away. According to Pomfrey Snape is awake now. James knows that he‚Äôs talked to Dumbledore, knows that he told them all that Sirius was the one who told him about the whomping willow, which, of course, led to James being interrogated again.

He feels a bit wary of leaving Remus alone with him, even knowing Pomfrey is just in her office and that Snape hasn‚Äôt got his wand back yet. This won‚Äôt take long though, and if he wants to do it he has to go now. So, reluctantly, he pushes through the door and into the corridor.

Pomfrey told Remus he was well enough to return to the dorms if he wanted to. He didn‚Äôt. James wasn‚Äôt surprised, and he doesn‚Äôt blame him. He doesn‚Äôt want to go back there either if he‚Äôs being honest. But he can‚Äôt have Remus hiding out in the infirmary for the rest of the year.

‚ÄúProfessor?‚Äù James says, tentatively knocking on the open door to McGonagall‚Äôs office.

She looks up from the paperwork on her desk, brows drawing together at the sight of him. ‚ÄúPotter?‚Äù

He steps further into the room. ‚ÄúCan I talk to you for minute?‚Äù

She only pauses briefly before gesturing to the seat in front of her. He sits on the edge, not intending to get comfortable. He doesn‚Äôt want to be here long. She leans forward across her desk, fingers weaving together as she waits patiently for him to continue.

‚ÄúIs Sirius going to be expelled?‚Äù for some reason those words feel like nails being dragged up his throat. He wouldn‚Äôt fight it, if it happened. It would be right after what he‚Äôs done. But the thought still breaks his heart. They‚Äôve always been together, the four of them, ever since they first met. And if he‚Äôs being honest, James has never thought that would change. Not as they got older, or left Hogwarts. It felt like this unquestionable law of the universe‚Äîthe marauders belonged together. Always.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid it is not my place to discuss that with you,‚Äù McGonagall says after a long pause.

James nods. He‚Äôd been expecting that, but he figured he‚Äôd try anyway.

‚ÄúWell if he isn‚Äôt,‚Äù he presses on. ‚ÄúI think he should be moved to a new dorm.‚Äù He says it very matter of fact, like it doesn‚Äôt shred him on the inside. He can‚Äôt really think about it. About what he‚Äôs asking. Because if he does he won‚Äôt do it.

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù McGonagall says carefully. ‚ÄúIt is not‚Ä¶commonplace, to remove students from their dorms.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt exactly a common situation though, is it?‚Äù

She dips her head in acknowledgement but doesn‚Äôt say anything else.

James sighs. ‚ÄúLook, it isn‚Äôt fair to Remus‚Äîto make him have to face him like that, have to see him every day. He deserves to feel safe, and how will he ever feel safe if he has to share a room with the person who‚Äî‚Äú Betrayed him? Lied to him? Used him? Broke his heart? James isn‚Äôt sure how to best sum up what Sirius did.

McGonagall nods slowly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see what I can do, there are no more available beds, but if I can find someone willing to switch with him would that be acceptable to you?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù James says quickly, even though the thought makes his stomach clench. Having someone else in their room. In Sirius‚Äôs bed. ‚ÄúYes that would be acceptable.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood.‚Äù

He gets out of his chair, anxious to get back to Remus. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre still with Mr. Lupin in the infirmary I imagine?‚Äù McGonagall says as he turns to leave.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîyeah?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúBest that you stay there. The parents will be arriving soon.‚Äù

James‚Äôs heart plummets into his stomach. ‚ÄúThe parents?‚Äù

¬†

An hour later James finds himself in Dumbledore‚Äôs office with Remus, Sirius and Snape. It is maybe the most awkward he has ever felt in his entire life. None of them speak‚Äînone of them even look at each other. Sirius is sunk low in his chair, eyes on the floor, a sick expression on his face. Snape sitting rim-rod straight, face pale, eyes unwavering on the Headmaster. James separates them from Moony, whom he sneaks glances at every few seconds. But Remus‚Äôs face is unreadable. Wiped clean of the pain of this morning. And while he understands why, part of James wants to tell him to drop it‚Äîlet them see, let them see how much fucking damage they‚Äôve done.

As much as he was dreading the arrival of the parents, it‚Äôs almost a relief when McGonagall opens the door. The tension was starting to make his skin itch.

‚ÄúBoys,‚Äù his mum is the first one through, dressed in muggle clothing‚Äîshe usually is when she‚Äôs at home‚Äîblue jeans, white floral blouse. He‚Äôs sure Snape will be bringing that up at some point.

‚ÄúMum,‚Äù James doesn‚Äôt know if he should stand up or not, but his mother doesn‚Äôt really give him the chance. She‚Äôs almost instantly in front of them.

‚ÄúRemus love,‚Äù she kisses the top of his head, ‚Äúalright?‚Äù she asks softly.

James can see him swallow. ‚ÄúYes, Mrs. Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Effie darling,‚Äù she kisses his head one more time before moving on to James, the other parents still filing in, somewhat less determinedly than Euphemia Potter. She takes his face in her hands kissing him as well. Of course. On the forehead. The cheek. The top of his mess of hair.

‚ÄúMum,‚Äù he says, exasperated. Except that, the truth is, he‚Äôs so glad she‚Äôs here. Now that he can feel her and see her. Glad that someone else can take control of the situation, because James honestly doesn‚Äôt know what to do with it.

His mother presses here forehead to his. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay?‚Äù she asks, in the same soft voice she used on Remus. James wonders if it‚Äôs actually some kind of spell, the way it calms him down instantly.

‚ÄúYeah‚Äîyeah, I‚Äôm okay.‚Äù

She nods, forehead rubbing against his as she pulls away. James isn‚Äôt sure if he was expecting Walburga to come or not, but she isn‚Äôt there. Snape‚Äôs mother is‚Äîa mousy woman with brown hair and nervous eyes. And the Lupins, coming to stand at their son‚Äôs side, Hope looking nervous, whispering something in Remus‚Äôs ear, Lyall looking‚Äîtired. James assumes Fleamont is at work.

‚ÄúOh Sirius,‚Äù he hears his mother coo, turning to see her crouched in front of his best friend, trying to meet his eye. It takes James a moment to realize that Sirius is crying and trying desperately to hide it. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, sweetheart, it‚Äôs okay. We‚Äôll sort it out, I promise.‚Äù

Sirius just shakes his head, letting out a shaky breath as he quickly wipes his eyes on his sleeve. James is angry and sad at the same time and he isn‚Äôt at all sure what to do with that. Mostly he wishes his mother would stop acting like all Sirius did was break a dish or cheat on a test. Instead of put two peoples lives at risk.

Dumbledore clears his throat and Euphemia stands, moving to stand behind their chairs, one hand on Sirius and one on James.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve all been informed of what transpired last night,‚Äù McGonall is standing beside him.

‚ÄúDoes the Minister know you keep a werewolf at this school?‚Äù Mrs. Snape has a high reedy voice, and James clenches his teeth.

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt keep him Eileen,‚Äù Euphemia answers before Dumbledore can. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a student, he attends Hogwarts just like everyone else.‚Äù Her voice is light but there is an undeniable sharpness to her words.

‚ÄúLeave it Effie,‚Äù James hears Lyall mutter beside them, which almost makes James angrier. Remus looks as though he‚Äôs trying to cave-in on himself.

‚ÄúIt would seem,‚Äù Dumbledore presses on, ‚Äúthat Sirius and Severus took a game of chicken a bit too far.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know there was going to be a werewolf in there,‚Äù Snape says sulkily.

James thinks if someone refers to Remus as ‚Äúa werewolf‚Äù one more time, he‚Äôs going to lose it.

Dumbledore‚Äôs cool blue eyes fall on the Slytherin. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs true. You did know, however, that both the willow and the shack were off-limits, correct?‚Äù

Snape scowls. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd, do forgive me, but while Mr. Black did not tell you exactly what you were walking into, I do believe he made it clear that it wasn‚Äôt a surprise party, correct?‚Äù

Snape doesn‚Äôt answer this time, just glares.

‚ÄúTherefore you did make the decision to enter into a dangerous situation, even if you were not entirely aware of how dangerous it was in order to‚Äîprove yourself to Mr. Black?‚Äù

Snape scoffs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to prove anything to him.‚Äù

Dumbledore smiles. ‚ÄúTo satisfy your own curiosity then. Either way, while Mr. Black certainly enticed you, he did not force you to do anything, or am I mistaken?‚Äù

There are several long seconds of silence before Snape finally answers, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs correct.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am glad we can all agree,‚Äù there is something slightly off about Dumbledore‚Äôs cheerfulness‚Äîsomething dangerous‚Äîthat makes the hair stand-up on the back of James‚Äôs neck. ‚ÄúThen you will understand why I have decided to take a hundred points from Slytherin,‚Äù Snape‚Äôs mouth literally falls open, ‚Äúand give you detention with Professor McGonagall every weekend for the rest of term.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is ridiculous!‚Äù his mother sparks up again. ‚ÄúThat thing attacked my son!‚Äù she points a bony finger in Remus‚Äôs direction.

James moves to stand, ready to take this woman apart, but his mother pushes him back down.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll kindly ask you not to refer to my students as ‚Äòthings‚Äô Eileen,‚Äù McGonagall says coldly.

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôll ask less kindly,‚Äù Euphemia adds, earning her a barely repressed smirk from McGonagall.

‚ÄúYes, I think you will find this is still my school Mrs. Snape,‚Äù Dumbledore seems unfazed by all of this. ‚ÄúIf you disagree with my methods, feel free to remove your son from the premises.‚Äù

James sees the sudden fear in Snape‚Äôs eyes and he grabs hold of his mother‚Äôs wrist just as she opens her mouth to speak again. ‚ÄúLeave it mum, please, it‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

She looks down, seemingly startled that her son has spoken to her, and then back up at Dumbledore. ‚ÄúFine,‚Äù she hisses, crossing her arms over her chest. ‚ÄúBut I want it known that I think it is absolutely barbaric that‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYes, yes, we‚Äôve noted you,‚Äù Euphemia cuts her off. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre outnumbered Eileen, bow out gracefully.‚Äù

James thinks there is a very good chance that Snape‚Äôs mum is going to combust. Her face somehow manages to grow even more pinched, her high cheeks flushing a bright and unattractive red.

Once again, Dumbledore appears unbothered by the squabbling. ‚ÄúExcellent,‚Äù his gaze moves onto Sirius. ‚ÄúNow, Mr. Black, this whole situation does seem to start with you, doesn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

Sirius says nothing, head still down, which makes James somehow angrier. He shoots a a worried look over at Remus, who‚Äôs sitting with his shoulders rolled in, like he‚Äôs trying to pull as far away from his parents as he can without actually getting out of his chair, eyes very determinedly on his hands. James hopes Dumbledore puts them all out of their misery soon because this was really the last thing Moony needed.

‚ÄúIt has been decided that you will remain at school‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not being expelled?‚Äù Sirius croaks. The first words he‚Äôs spoken.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Dumbledore says softy, ‚Äúbut you will be removed from the Gryffindor quidditch team.‚Äù
That hits James surprisingly hard. Maybe because he hadn‚Äôt really thought that far ahead. Thought of what the day to day was going to look like after this.

‚ÄúAnd you will be serving detentions for the remainder of the term, like Mr. Snape, with Professor McGonagall. I will also be taking a hundred points from Gryffindor,‚Äù Sirius swallows, nodding along to all of this, face pale. ‚ÄúAnd you will be moving dorms.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Sirius looks like he didn‚Äôt mean to let the word out, and James‚Äôs eyes shoot to McGonagall who gives him a slight nod.

‚ÄúAfter the events of last night is has been deemed inappropriate for you to continue to share a dorm with Mr. Lupin, so Frank Longbottom has agreed to switch with you.‚Äù

James does his best not to be bitter about the fact that this means Sirius will be getting his own room. The alternative would be Moony switching with Frank and, if he‚Äôs honest, the last thing he wants is for Remus to be isolated.

‚ÄúI have to leave my room?‚Äù Sirius says, somewhere between dazed and heart broken.

James makes a scoffing noise that earns him a squeeze from his mother‚Äôs hand but he doesn‚Äôt care. He feels Sirius‚Äôs eyes on him but refuses to feel bad. Moony could have died. He could have killed Snape‚Äîwhich honestly, for Remus, would have been worse.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù McGonagall answers Sirius after a brief pause, ‚Äúfor the safety of everyone involved.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think I‚Äôm unsafe?‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs voice breaks.

‚ÄúSurely, that isn‚Äôt necessary,‚Äù Euphemia speaks up.

‚ÄúThe hell it isn‚Äôt!‚Äù

‚ÄúJames.‚Äù

But he‚Äôs had just about enough of listening to a bunch of people who have no idea what they‚Äôre talking about, acting like they have any right to decide what happens here.

‚ÄúHe put Remus at risk‚Äîhe could have been hurt, Snape had his wand on him when I got there,‚Äù James feels something slightly hysterical clawing at his chest, like everything he couldn‚Äôt feel last night is bubbling to the surface. He‚Äôs always loved the way his mother takes care of everyone, the way she protects Sirius. But there are things that are unforgivable. Maybe James doesn‚Äôt hate Sirius, but he sure as hell doesn‚Äôt like him very much.

‚ÄúThese are peoples‚Äôs lives we‚Äôre talking about,‚Äù he looks at Sirius for the first time, and the other boy stares back, eyes wide. ‚ÄúThey aren‚Äôt fucking toys‚Äîthey don‚Äôt exist for your amusement.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú his mother tries again, but it‚Äôs too late, he‚Äôs on a roll.

‚ÄúI mean, house points?‚Äù he turns to Dumbledore. ‚ÄúDetention? This is a fucking joke.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat would you suggest James?‚Äù Dumbledore asks calmly.

‚ÄúAnything‚Äîsomething‚Äîthis isn‚Äôt‚Äîthis is a crime. You can‚Äôt just allow them to treat people like this.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú Euphemia tries to calm her son down for the third time.

‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt there!‚Äù he‚Äôs never shouted at her before. ‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt there, you didn‚Äôt have to‚Äî‚Äú his voice falls to pieces in his mouth. ‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt there.‚Äù He closes his eyes for a second, trying to get a hold of all the feelings forcing their way to the surface. Trying to rip his skin apart.

‚ÄúIt must have been very scary for you,‚Äù Dumbledore says eventually, ‚Äúto find your friend in such a vulnerable position.‚Äù

James exhales, and after several seconds forces his eyes to open again. ‚ÄúYou know what was scary, Professor?‚Äù he says, as flatly as he can manage. ‚ÄúWatching my best mate smile while he told me what he‚Äôd done.‚Äù

A pained noise comes from Sirius but James ignores it.

‚ÄúMcGonagall was right, it is safer for all of us if he‚Äôs on his own.‚Äù

His mother squeezes his shoulder but doesn‚Äôt bother objecting again. There‚Äôs an eery silence now, and James almost regrets freaking out on everyone, except that he can‚Äôt quite shake the feeling that they deserved it.

‚ÄúThe Lupins have agreed not to press charges,‚Äù Dumbledore goes on eventually.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve decided not to press charges?‚Äù Eileen interjects. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs MY son whose been attacked here.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs we already discussed,‚Äù Dumbledore goes on in an extraordinarily patronizing tone. ‚ÄúSince your son quite knowingly put himself in danger, you would hardly have a case.‚Äù

She makes an affronted noise but Dumbledore‚Äôs attention has already returned to Remus.

‚ÄúGiven all that has happened, we‚Äôve told your parents that you are more than welcome to go home for a period of time, to rest, recover.‚Äù

James sees Remus stiffen in his chair. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says almost too quickly. ‚ÄúI‚Äî I want to stay. I want to be here. Please.‚Äù

Hope worries her bottom lip, fingers fidgeting with her sleeve. ‚ÄúAre you sure Rem? It might be good for‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúHe said he didn‚Äôt want to,‚Äù Lyall cuts his wife off, sounding more tired than anything else. ‚ÄúStop fussing over him and leave it be.‚Äù

Dumbledore is still focused on Remus. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure that‚Äôs what you want?‚Äù he asks him.

‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù still without hesitation.

‚ÄúVery well, then the last order of business is to collect the memory from James.‚Äù

James blinks. ‚ÄúI‚Äîer‚Äîwhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Ministry, while agreeing to allow us to handle this internally, needs confirmation that the events occurred as we have described‚Äîthat Mr. Lupin was in fact safely secured,‚Äù James sees Remus flinch out of the corner of his eye. ‚ÄúAnd that there was no unprovoked attack, and no mauling of you or Mr. Snape. Since you are the only witness to the entirety of last nights events, your memory is needed.‚Äù

Remus, once again, curls in on himself. James grits his teeth.

‚ÄúOkay. Fine. Whatever.‚Äù

His mother squeezes his shoulder. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be right here,‚Äù she says comfortingly.

‚ÄúThe rest of you are free to go, Professor McGonagall will show you out.‚Äù

James hears the others shuffling, chairs being pushed back, floorboards squeaking, but he isn‚Äôt looking at them. He‚Äôs looking at Dumbledore, who pulls out a vial and places it on the desk in front of him. Now that the room is empty, there is suddenly space for James‚Äôs fear, and he feels it creeping up his spine, pricking his heart.

‚ÄúWill it hurt?‚Äù he asks, eyes still on the vial.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Dumbledore says calmly.

James nods, getting to his feet and walking forward, he can feel his mother following behind him as he picks up the glass tube, cold in his hands.

‚ÄúWill they be able to hear my thoughts‚Äîwhat I was thinking when it happened?‚Äù the thought makes a vaguely sick feeling wash over him‚Äîa bunch of Ministry lackeys listening to him run around, terrified.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Dumbledore says again. ‚ÄúThey will view the memory as third party observers. The perspective change is part of what makes the pensieve so useful.‚Äù

James swallows, throat dry as he pulls out his wand. He looks up at Dumbledore one last time. ‚ÄúWill I forget? Once it‚Äôs out of me?‚Äù

Dumbledore takes his time now, eyes running James over. James used to think that those blue eyes were kind, safe, but these last few hours he‚Äôs looked at them too many times to believe that anymore. There‚Äôs something underneath the playfulness. Something cold and calculated. It makes James shiver.

‚ÄúWould you like that?‚Äù he asks finally, not answering James‚Äôs question.

‚ÄúAlbus,‚Äù he hears his mother warn from behind them, but Dumbledore doesn‚Äôt take it back, his stare doesn‚Äôt falter.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù James answers truthfully. ‚ÄúNo, I guess. I wish it hadn‚Äôt happened, but since it did, I‚Äôd rather know.‚Äù

Dumbledore smiles softly. ‚ÄúIgnorance is peace, but knowledge is freedom.‚Äù

James stares back at him blankly and eventually Dumbledore chuckles to himself.

‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt forget,‚Äù he goes on. ‚ÄúIt may‚Äîfade slightly, feel less vibrant, but it will still be there.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James brings the tip of his wand to his temple. ‚ÄúGood.‚Äù

It does hurt.

Dumbledore is a dirty liar.

Or maybe it isn‚Äôt the spell. Maybe it‚Äôs just the memory.

The night before runs through him at double speed. And he feels every second of it. Every scratch. Every crack in his heart. Every scream out of Moony‚Äôs mouth. It tears itself from him violently, and unwillingly. Claws digging in as he attempts to pour it into the vial, his hands shaking.

I told him how to get past the tree.

Please, please.

A werewolf? The freak is a werewolf?

James.

James.

James please, please I‚ÄîI just wasn‚Äôt thinking. I‚Äôm sorry. I‚Äôm so sorry.

He nearly drops it, gasping as the last of the night bleeds out of him. His mother instantly steps forward, placing the vial on Dumbledore‚Äôs desk before wrapping James in her arms.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay my love, you were so brave,‚Äù she murmurs into the top of his head, placing kisses between her words. It‚Äôs not until then that James realizes his cheeks are wet‚Äîthat he‚Äôs been crying.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù he says, though his voice is all over the place when it comes out of his mouth.

‚ÄúThank you James,‚Äù Dumbledore places a stopper in the top of the vial before sliding it into a small wrack on his desk. ‚ÄúVery helpful.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh well,‚Äù his mother say bitterly. ‚ÄúAs long as he could be helpful to you.‚Äù

Dumbledore doesn‚Äôt respond to her and James wonders if she speaks to him like this often. If this is what they‚Äôre like, when they close all those doors in his face.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll give you two some privacy,‚Äù Dumbledore says eventually, stepping out from behind his desk, indigo robes fluttering behind him. ‚ÄúFeel free to take as long as you need.‚Äù

Euphemia is still holding James, he should probably feel embarrassed by that but he doesn‚Äôt. He should probably step away but he doesn‚Äôt do that either. He hadn‚Äôt realized how much he needed this until now.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù he says again, though he doesn‚Äôt know who he‚Äôs trying to comfort.

‚ÄúI know baby,‚Äù she gives him another squeeze before pulling back enough to hold his face, thumbs wiping away the tears he doesn‚Äôt remember shedding. ‚ÄúI love you, you know that?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúYeah I know, I love you too.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù she pulls him forward, kissing the top of his head before letting go.

They stand still for a minute, James wiping his nose on his sleeve. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I can forgive him for this,‚Äù he says finally, voice rough.

His mother nods sadly. ‚ÄúI know you don‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt know how you can brush it off.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not brushing it off,‚Äù she says firmly. ‚ÄúIt was horrible what he did James, I know that. But I also know a broken person when I see them. I can‚Äôt imagine me shouting at him would have done much.‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt sure he agrees. ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Walburga?‚Äù he asks instead of arguing.

His mother looks surprised. ‚ÄúWalburga? Why would she be here?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs his mother,‚Äù James says, though the words taste bitter in his mouth.

Euphemia watches him for a moment before nodding, slowly. ‚ÄúShe is. But she‚Äôs not his guardian. Not since last summer.‚Äù

It isn‚Äôt surprising. James doesn‚Äôt know why it hadn‚Äôt occurred to him before. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says dumbly. ‚ÄúYou and dad?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

A beat of silence. ‚ÄúDid‚Äîhow did you do that?‚Äù

His mother lets out a sigh, leaning back against Dumbledore‚Äôs desk. ‚ÄúWe asked for custody and Walburga and Orion gave it to us.‚Äù

Another fact that shouldn‚Äôt surprise him as much as it does. ‚ÄúThey just‚Ä¶gave him away? Just like that?‚Äù

She grimaces. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd appreciate it if you didn‚Äôt put it to Sirius like that, but yes, more or less.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not talking to Sirius,‚Äù he says, because it‚Äôs the only thing he can think to say, his stomaching squeezing at the idea that anyone could treat their child so casually. Like they were disposal.

‚ÄúRight well, when you start to again‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so certain I will?‚Äù his voice sounds sharp even to his own ears, but she only smiles softly at him.

‚ÄúYes. I am,‚Äù and when James only scowls she goes on. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve watched you two since you were eleven years old James. You fit together so well‚Äîso beautifully. Oh and when you came back after first year,‚Äù she smiles more fully now. ‚ÄúThe looks on your little faces when you had to say goodbye. You cried the whole way home, do you remember?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was a kid. I cried over loads of dumb stuff,‚Äù he says defensively.

Euphemia shakes her head. ‚ÄúNot like this. As soon as we got home the first thing you did was write to him. Wrote to him every day that summer.‚Äù

James runs a hand through his hair, not appreciating this particular walk down memory lane. ‚ÄúWe aren‚Äôt those people anymore.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù she allows, ‚Äúbut it wouldn‚Äôt hurt this bad, if you didn‚Äôt love him.‚Äù

His mother, he firmly believes, is an expert in Legilimency. The way she cuts right through everything. Striking at your core.

‚ÄúSometimes,‚Äù James‚Äôs voice breaks but he forces himself to go on; ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm lying to everyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúLying about what?‚Äù she asks softly.

He almost laughs. ‚ÄúEverything. People look at me like I‚Äôm supposed to know what I‚Äôm doing and I have no idea. I want to do‚Äîyou know‚Äîthe right thing. Mostly. Most of the time. And I used to be so sure I knew what that was, but now‚Ä¶‚Äù If you had asked him a day ago if there was anyone on the planet he trusted more than Sirius Black he would have answered without hesitating. No.

No one.

He‚Äôs the best person I know.

The bravest.

The strongest.

No.

If you had asked him a day ago if Sirius would ever use Remus as a prop‚Äîto get back at Snape or because of some petty bullshit some guy said to him in a fight‚Äîhe would have had an answer for you too. No question.

And he would have been wrong.

‚ÄúMostly,‚Äù he goes on, after a long pause. ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm just treading water, like I‚Äôm barely keeping my head above the tide. And I keep waiting to grow up. Everyone wants me to. To be better. And I want that too, I do. So I just‚ÄîI wait. Wait for the day that I don‚Äôt feel like everything is too big. Cause somehow life got so big, and I still feel so fucking small.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh honey,‚Äù his mother reaches out, brushing a hand though his hair, ‚Äúthe truth is, no one knows what they‚Äôre doing. We‚Äôre all just trying our best. I‚Äôm afraid that feeling never really goes away.‚Äù

James lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúWell, that‚Äôs depressing."

‚ÄúYeah, a bit,‚Äù she admits. ‚ÄúBut it also means you can cut yourself some slack. You‚Äôre only fifteen James. And you‚Äôre doing wonderfully, considering the circumstances.‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty sure you have to say that, as my mum.‚Äù

She smiles, pulling him into a hug. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt, actually. If you were being a little shit I‚Äôd let you know, believe me.‚Äù

James snorts into her shoulder, squeezing her back, trying to soak up as much comfort as he can.

‚ÄúThank you for coming,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know why he says it, like she wasn‚Äôt summoned, like she had a choice. Still, he means it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll always come for you James,‚Äù she says, chin resting on the top of his head. ‚ÄúI promise.‚Äù

¬†

When he walks into his dorm room everything is just as it was when he left. It‚Äôs not surprising, nothing happened here, there‚Äôs no reason for it to be any different, and yet it feels insulting almost, that it should be so untouched when everything else is unravelling.

There are no lights on, the blue of the summer evening the only thing lighting the space, and so it takes him a minute to realize that, actually, everything is not exactly the same. Sirius‚Äôs clothes have gone from the floor. The trunk missing from the end of his bed. The records his uncle gave him gone. James stands, frozen, staring at the empty holes now suddenly so painfully obvious to him, and feels a wave of mourning crash against his ribs.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre back.‚Äù

He looks behind him and finds Remus standing in front of the washroom, door closing behind him.

James nods. ‚ÄúPete?‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat Hall.‚Äù

‚ÄúShit, is it dinner already?‚Äù

Remus nods, walking slowly forward to stand next to James, both of them at the foot of Sirius‚Äôs bed. Like a blackhole in the centre of the room, drawing them in. All James can think is‚Äîit was never supposed to be this way‚Äîwhich just drags all his anger back to the surface. Because fuck Sirius. Fuck him for doing this to them.

Beside him Remus lets out a shaky breath, shoving his hands into his pockets. James looks over at him but Remus keeps his eyes on the bed, even when he starts speaking.

‚ÄúHe kissed me,‚Äù those words are big. They have weight. They take up space.

He watches Remus for a few more seconds before moving to sit on the end of the bed, facing him. Listening.

‚ÄúHe was upset,‚Äù Remus goes on eventually. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd been hit by the bludger, you were still in the infirmary and he was upset and I was trying to comfort him and he kissed me,‚Äù Remus screws up his face, pulling his mouth to the side, and James can tell that he‚Äôs trying not to cry. ‚ÄúAnd I kissed him back,‚Äù those words are barely a sound, so quiet and delicate James worries if he listens too closely they‚Äôll break. ‚ÄúI took advantage of him.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù he says softly, but his friend shakes his head.

‚ÄúI should have stopped it, I should have pushed him away but I just‚Äî‚Äú his mouth hangs there for a moment, words unable or unwilling to come out. ‚ÄúI just wanted him‚ÄîI‚Äôve wanted him for so long.‚Äù

James wonders how it is that he never noticed it, not until this year, not until everything started to fall apart. How could he have been so clueless? So self involved that he couldn‚Äôt see what was growing between two of the most important people in his life?

‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt‚Äîreact well,‚Äù Remus says finally, voice choked. ‚ÄúWe stopped talking‚Ä¶for a bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúI noticed.‚Äù

Remus nods, still talking more to the bed than to James. ‚ÄúBut then things, recently, they‚Äôve been‚Ä¶better. He‚Äôs been so‚Äî‚Äú his voice cuts out again and it‚Äôs several moments of silence before he gets it back again. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, affectionate?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúYeah. I noticed that too.‚Äù

Remus makes a noise, something between a laugh and a sob. ‚ÄúGood, I‚Äôm glad someone else did,‚Äù he closes his eyes briefly. ‚ÄúWorried it was all in my head.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt.‚Äù

He nods slowly, a grimace shooting across his face, like he‚Äôs in pain. ‚ÄúDo you think‚Äî‚Äú his voice is thick, eyes still closed. ‚ÄúDo you think that‚Äôs why he did it?‚Äù

It takes a minute for the full meaning of Remus‚Äôs words to hit him, and when they do they‚Äôre a punch to his gut.

‚ÄúNo. No, Remus, no way.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt see his face‚Äîafter we kissed‚Äîyou didn‚Äôt see,‚Äù he takes in a shaky breath, opening his eyes, wet and shinning in the dim light. ‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs ever looked at me like that before,‚Äù a horribly sad laugh comes out of his mouth. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm a werewolf.‚Äù

Every word pulls and yanks and drags James down low.

‚ÄúOr maybe that was it,‚Äù Remus‚Äôs voice is steady, but James can see the tears making their way down his face. ‚ÄúMaybe he wasn‚Äôt upset that he‚Äôd kissed a boy. Maybe he was upset that he kissed a fucking wolf.‚Äù

‚ÄúStop,‚Äù James says‚Äîbegs. ‚ÄúRemus stop, none of that is true. He doesn‚Äôt think like that,‚Äù even as James says it he can so clearly see Sirius lying on this bed, smiling.

We have a fucking werewolf.

‚ÄúYou sure about that?‚Äù Remus looks at him properly for the first time and it aches.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù because two days ago I told him I was seeing a boy and he hugged me and said I was his brother. Because I saw the pain in his eyes when you walked away from him at Christmas. Because I saw the way he looked at you yesterday, when he thought no one else could see.

James leaves too much unsaid. He knows it. But for some reason none of those words can make it out of him.

Remus opens his mouth at the same time that there‚Äôs rustling at the door. He quickly brings his hands to his face, scrubbing the tears away before he turns back to the bathroom.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to take a shower,‚Äù he says over his shoulder, the door to the dorm room opening.

‚ÄúRemus‚Äî‚Äú but it‚Äôs too late, he‚Äôs already disappeared into the other room, shower humming.

James sighs, running a hand over his face, turning around, expecting to see Peter and instead finding Frank, dragging his trunk with one hand and holding a box of stuff in the other.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù James says dumbly, staring at the older boy.

‚ÄúHello to you too.‚Äù

James quickly jumps out of his way as he struggles over, dumping his box of stuff onto Sirius‚Äôs bed. He huffs, hands on his hips as he looks around.

‚ÄúBit dark in here isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

James smiles grimly, moving to sit on his own bed. ‚ÄúYeah, a bit.‚Äù

Frank flicks his wand, lighting the lamps, eyes trailing over the beds surrounding him. ‚ÄúWell, privacy was nice while it lasted.‚Äù He shoots James a look as he bends over and starts riffling through his stuff. ‚ÄúHeads up, Alice will be coming up here from time to time.‚Äù

James snorts, this conversation feeling so out of place after the one he was just having. ‚ÄúJust close your curtains yeah? And use a silencing charm or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúObviously, we‚Äôre not barbarians.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey, thanks for doing this,‚Äù James says eventually, rubbing awkwardly at the back of his neck.

Frank sends him a sidelong look as he places his jumpers neatly in a drawer. Remus will at least get the orderly roommate he‚Äôs always wanted.

‚ÄúI said no at first,‚Äù he says eventually.

‚ÄúOh yeah?‚Äù

Frank nods. ‚ÄúTold McGonagall it was a lost cause. That you‚Äôd tear the school apart before you let someone take Black from you.‚Äù

James tries to swallow but his throat has grown too tight. ‚ÄúWhat changed your mind?‚Äù he croaks.

‚ÄúShe told me it was your idea,‚Äù he pauses in his unpacking, eyes meeting James‚Äôs. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how I knew.‚Äù

‚ÄúKnew?‚Äù

He nods, ‚ÄúThat whatever happened, it was serious.‚Äù

They‚Äôre still for a moment, and James waits for the questions that ought to follow that‚Äîthe what happened? What could be so bad? What did he do? But they don‚Äôt come. Eventually Frank goes back to his unpacking.

‚ÄúI figured, if something that bad happened, that was probably more important than me having my own room.‚Äù

James has always looked up to Frank. As an only child, he had no older siblings to emulate, to chase after. There was his dad, but, that was different. Plus, Fleamont had a tendency to go places James couldn‚Äôt follow. Then he came to Hogwarts and he met Frank. When they were first years he was a third year, which at the time felt like a big deal‚Äîfelt old. He was one of the youngest members on the Gryffindor quidditch team and even then he had been bloody brilliant. James remembers watching him and thinking‚Äîme, that‚Äôs going to be me, I‚Äôm going to be just like that.

On top of that, Frank was just‚Ä¶nice. He was always there, if you got lost or forgot the password, he never seemed frustrated or exasperated like some of the other older kids. Even before he became Prefect or Head Boy, he would go out of his way to help people. He never made a show of it. Frank didn‚Äôt want attention, never seemed to know what to do with it once he got it.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù James finds himself saying again.

Frank looks up from the trousers he‚Äôd been folding. He pauses for a moment, before finally speaking. ‚ÄúOf course, if you‚Äîyou need to talk James, you let me know yeah?‚Äù

James nods, stomach tightening because he knows that he can‚Äôt‚Äîcouldn‚Äôt‚Äîeven if he wanted to. ‚ÄúSure,‚Äù voice strained, he coughs, trying to clear it away; ‚ÄúSure, yeah, I will.‚Äù

¬†

He waits for Remus, but when he doesn‚Äôt come out of the bathroom after an hour James takes the hint and goes down to the Great Hall alone. He wonders if this is what it‚Äôs going to be like from now on. The three of them orbiting around each other, polite but distanced. He wonders if there are things that can‚Äôt be fixed. If change actually isn‚Äôt gradual but fast and sharp and violent. He wonders if he should have just let Sirius wipe their memories.

¬†

When he walks into the Come and Go Room Regulus is sitting on one of the sofas. It hasn‚Äôt been that long since they last saw one another but it feels like ages and James‚Äôs heart does something weird in chest as he stops by the door, grey eyes holding him still.

‚ÄúListen,‚Äù Regulus starts, that familiar determination in his voice. He stands up but doesn‚Äôt come closer, a full room between them. ‚ÄúI know you‚Äôre angry about what happened yesterday.‚Äù

James almost laughs. Because, of course, Regulus has no idea what happened yesterday.

‚ÄúI know I went too far, I do,‚Äù he goes on, and for the first time in hours, James feels his body relax. Because he‚Äôs here, with Reg, here in their space. Because Regulus‚Äôs voice is steady and familiar and he‚Äôs been craving it all day. Desperate to find something to ease the anxiety growing in his stomach. And here it is. Because of course it is. ‚Äú‚Äîand Evan and Barty,‚Äù James blinks, realizing that Regulus has been speaking this whole time. His face is scrunched, serious, ‚Äúthey were out of line‚Äîway out of line. They‚Äôre assholes honestly, but, their parents are friends with my mum so I can‚Äôt really‚Äîit‚Äôs complicated.‚Äù

It isn‚Äôt that he's not mad. About all of it. About everything that happened in that hallway. It‚Äôs just that he can‚Äôt feel it right now. Doesn‚Äôt have the space for anymore anger or betrayal. Maybe it‚Äôs because he hasn‚Äôt slept at all or because everything in his life seems to be falling apart, but all he feels when he looks at Regulus is warmth and home and it‚Äôs so‚Ä¶nice. After everything that‚Äôs happened, he just wants to hold onto that.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Regulus asks, bringing James‚Äôs drifting mind back to the present. He really does need to get some sleep. ‚ÄúI am sorry, I didn‚Äôt‚ÄîI mean he followed be into the corridor and I swear I tried to walk away but he wasn‚Äôt having it. He just kept‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúI love you.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs mouth abruptly slams shut, eyes growing wide, the room suddenly very quiet. There‚Äôs a long moment of stillness, in which neither of them seems quite able to deal with what James has just thrown into the middle of the room, but eventually, the older boy breaks.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to fight with you,‚Äù his voice is scratchy when he speaks again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm tired and I‚Äôm‚ÄîI‚Äôm having a really, really shitty day and I just‚ÄîI need you,‚Äù he tries not to wince at the whine in his voice. ‚ÄúI just need you‚Äîis that‚Äîis that okay?‚Äù

Regulus is staring at him, stalk still, grey eyes blinking. ‚ÄúSay it again.‚Äù

James laughs roughly. ‚ÄúWhich part?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know which part.‚Äù

He swallows, he doesn‚Äôt know why he suddenly feels nervous when he‚Äôs already said it. ‚ÄúI love you Regulus.‚Äù

It surprises him when Regulus moves, closing the space between them in record time. Suddenly his mouth is on James‚Äôs and he can‚Äôt hold back the noise that it pulls from him. Needy, is the only word that comes to mind. Regulus has his hand on the back of James‚Äôs neck, bringing him to his level, mouth opening him up, warm and sweet and‚Ä¶safe. When James regains control of his body he wraps his arms around Regulus, pulling him closer, until there‚Äôs no space between their bodies, and still, somehow, it isn‚Äôt close enough.

His hands move down, down Regulus back, his sides, slipping under his thighs and lifting him up, Regulus‚Äôs legs wrapping automatically around his waist.

‚ÄúStupid jock,‚Äù Regulus mutters into his mouth and James laughs. It feels good. It all feels so fucking good, and he‚Äôs starving for it. For something that doesn‚Äôt ache. That doesn‚Äôt feel like treading water. When Regulus‚Äôs hands are on him he can breathe.

He stumbles towards the bed, spilling Regulus onto his back and holding himself above. The other boy blinks up at him, eyes bright and reaching into him, pulling on his chest, squeezing the air out of his lungs. It isn‚Äôt new, feeling overwhelmed by this. By him. But James is raw tonight, and all of the sudden looking at Regulus under him is too much. Because he wants him. He wants him here, like this, always.

Except didn‚Äôt last night prove that he can‚Äôt have that? That you can‚Äôt keep people‚Äîthey‚Äôre too hard to hold. That everyone slips through your fingers eventually, no matter how much you love them.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Regulus says softly, reaching up to press his hand to James‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù his voice is ragged. ‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm a bit of a mess right now.‚Äù He drops his head, forehead resting against Regulus‚Äôs.

‚ÄúGood to know you‚Äôre human.‚Äù

James goes to laugh but it gets trapped in his throat.

‚ÄúYou wanna tell me what happened?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he‚Äôs whispering, like that‚Äôll make it easier, ‚Äúbut I can‚Äôt.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs thumb brushes against his cheek before his hand slowly trails down to James‚Äôs chest, gently pushing him down onto the bed. They lie facing one another.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù James says again but Regulus just shakes his head.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to apologize to me,‚Äù he leans forward, pressing a quick kiss to James‚Äôs mouth. Sweet. Innocent. It makes something in James sing.

They just lie there for a minute, James trying to work out what the hell is going on with him, and Regulus just waiting. Eventually the younger boy reaches out, running his hand through James‚Äôs hair and James closes his eyes, leaning into the touch.

‚ÄúSirius‚Äîhurt‚Äîsomeone,‚Äù the words are choked when they finally come out of him. Because he has to tell someone. Someone who isn‚Äôt directly involved. Because it‚Äôs eating him up inside.

Regulus‚Äôs hand stills. ‚ÄúDid he hurt you?‚Äù

Yes, James almost says, because it feels true. But there‚Äôs an edge in Regulus‚Äôs voice that gives him pause. He opens his eyes to look at the boy across from him.

‚ÄúWould it matter?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says without hesitating. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd kill him.‚Äù

The thing is, James thinks he might be serious.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt think that‚Äôd help, but I appreciate the offer.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes narrow. ‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James says quickly. ‚ÄúNo. Not me. But someone‚Ä¶important.‚Äù He sees Remus‚Äôs face, standing in their darkened room, the pain in his eyes. He hears him begging Snape to leave. He hears him screaming.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù James hisses, rolling onto his back and bringing his hands up to his face. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do. He‚Äîit was bad Reg. It was so fucking bad.‚Äù

There‚Äôs stillness, everything is quiet here, like the rest of the castle doesn‚Äôt exist.

‚ÄúDo know why he did it?‚Äù Regulus asks eventually.

James lets out a humourless laugh. ‚ÄúMerlin, I don‚Äôt know. He was upset but‚Äîall he‚Äôs said to me is that he wasn‚Äôt thinking.‚Äù Even saying that out loud makes the anger boil his blood again.

‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt thinking,‚Äù Regulus repeats slowly. And then, all of the sudden, he‚Äôs sitting up.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù James asks, a little startled, propping himself on his elbows.

Regulus‚Äôs legs are crossed, his expression distant.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù James reaches out, tugging lightly on his shirt. ‚ÄúSorry, do you not want to talk about‚ÄîI realize he‚Äôs your brother and things are‚Äî‚Äú

Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs fine,‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúListen, I don‚Äôt know what happened,‚Äù he runs a hand nervously through his short curls, ‚Äúbut he might not mean what you think he does when he says he wasn‚Äôt thinking.‚Äù

James‚Äôs brows draw together. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to need you to explain that.‚Äù

He nods, clearly expecting it. ‚ÄúYou remember how I said that sometimes I have to lock parts of me up? That I can‚Äôt‚Ä¶feel everything?‚Äù his eyes are focused on some distant point on the bed.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James says slowly, ‚ÄúI remember.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius was the one who taught me that trick.‚Äù

James feels his eyebrows raise. ‚ÄúTrick?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe were‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚ÄîSeven and eight? Maybe he was nine, I can‚Äôt remember. I was bawling my eyes out because our mother had gone on one of her rampages and he was just‚Ä¶fine,‚Äù Regulus shakes his head, an almost rueful look on his face. ‚ÄúHe was always fine, even though he got the brunt of it, put himself in her line of fire every time. He never cried, I was so jealous of that when I was a kid.‚Äù

He pauses, James watching him pick at the blanket in front of him, trying not to think about Sirius in Dumbledore‚Äôs office today, trying to hold back his tears.

‚ÄúSo he told me,‚Äù Regulus goes on eventually, ‚Äútold me that he just took all the things he didn‚Äôt want to feel or think, that he didn‚Äôt want our mother to see‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúTo see?‚Äù James interrupts.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù his voice goes a little wonky. ‚ÄúWalburga is very good at Legilimency. It‚Äôs hard to hide things in that house.‚Äù

James can feel the horror on his face. ‚ÄúJesus Christ.‚Äù

Regulus flashes him a grim smile before he goes back to staring at the bed. ‚ÄúYeah, anyway, you can kind of‚Äîhide things, inside yourself‚Äîwe used to practice. We got good at it. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs proper Occlumency or not, but, it works,‚Äù he takes a deep breath. ‚ÄúThing is‚Äîwhen you hide things from yourself, feelings, thoughts, it makes the rest of the world feel kind of far away and ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know, pointless,‚Äù he looks up again and holds James‚Äôs gaze this time. ‚ÄúYou can do things you wouldn‚Äôt normally.‚Äù

And James has no idea what to do with‚Ä¶any of that. The idea of Sirius and Regulus hiding out in Grimmauld Place teaching themselves how not to feel is heartbreaking, and he wonders, not for the first time, how either of them survived it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying that to excuse whatever it is that he did,‚Äù Regulus goes on. ‚ÄúBut when he says he wasn‚Äôt thinking, it‚Äôs just, it means more coming from him, that‚Äôs all,‚Äù he smiles weakly. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the best of us, really. Even when he was a kid. Always stood up to her. And they made him pay for it,‚Äù he chews on his bottom lip. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre still making him pay for it.‚Äù

James feels his eyes go wide. ‚ÄúAre you‚Äîdo you think Sirius is right? About your uncle? That they had him killed for reaching out to him?‚Äù

Regulus shrugs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, but, I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised. You don‚Äôt just get to walk away from the House of Black. That‚Äôs not how it works.‚Äù

It‚Äôs all too much. How do people handle these things? What are you supposed to do? Because James has no fucking idea. He pulls himself up to sit properly, bending his knees on the mattress and hanging his head for a minute.

He doesn‚Äôt want to talk about Sirius anymore.

He can‚Äôt.

It‚Äôs too confusing.

It hurts too much.

‚ÄúDo you still have to do it?‚Äù he asks instead.

‚ÄúDo what?‚Äù

James looks up, Regulus‚Äôs eyes on him. Every time, he thinks, every bloody time he finds that stare his insides catch on fire.

‚ÄúHide things from yourself?‚Äù

Regulus looks at him for a long time. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúI had to hide you.‚Äù

‚ÄúMe?‚Äù

Regulus nods and then looks away. James can see him chewing on the inside of his cheek. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs part of the reason I was such a wreck when I came back. You‚Äî‚Äú he laughs sadly. ‚ÄúYou take up so much space in me, that when I had to feel it again‚Äîit was too much. So much more than it had ever been before. I couldn‚Äôt bear it‚Äîwell, you saw.‚Äù

James watches him, eyes running over the ends of his hair, the tip of his nose, the way his lips quirk. He tries to breathe through everything going on inside him. Tries to hold it all.

He reaches out, makes sure Regulus can see, makes sure he goes slow enough that he could pull away.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon here,‚Äù he says roughly, linking their fingers together and giving Regulus a light tug. He comes, the pair of them failing back onto the bed, Regulus in James‚Äôs arms, face burrowing in his neck.

‚ÄúJe t‚Äôaime,‚Äù Regulus whispers, kissing behind his ear, ‚Äúje t‚Äôaime, je t‚Äôaime, je t‚Äôaime.‚Äù Every word is punctuated with a kiss‚Äîquick and sweet. Under his jaw, along his neck, Regulus‚Äôs breath warm against his skin. James‚Äôs eyes flutter closed.

‚ÄúEnglish,‚Äù the word punches out of him. ‚ÄúJust once. Say it in English once.‚Äù

Regulus stills but doesn‚Äôt pull away, lips still brushing against James in an accidental way that sends shivers down his spine. Eventually Regulus props himself up on his elbows, looking at James like he‚Äôs the only thing in the world, and James can barely stand it. Regulus leans down and brings their mouthes together, slow and purposeful, ripping a gasp out of James when he pulls away.

‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù Regulus says, stare determined even as his voice shakes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt understand that, doesn‚Äôt know how to make sense of it over the blood rushing in his ears, the heart beating in his chest.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt apologize,‚Äù he lifts himself up to Regulus‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt ever apologize for loving me.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hello lovelies!

Remus is heartbroken and James has basically divorced Sirius but Regulus said I love you so it all evens out in the end, right?

Honestly, I always find the fallout from The Prank so stressful. Because I, like Euphemia Potter, am a firm believer that James and Sirius belong together (platonically but also they are soulmates)

Thank you for your wonderful comments! Always appreciate it!

Chapter 15

Chapter Summary

Guys, gals, and non-binary pals, I give you: Remus John Lupin.

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

When Remus Lupin was five years old a monster broke into his bedroom and bit him. It sounds ridiculous doesn‚Äôt it? Some story made up to scare little kids. Remus isn‚Äôt sure he would believe it himself if it hadn‚Äôt happened to him. But it‚Äôs there on his side, between his ribs and his hips, the unmistakable imprint of teeth. The skin white and puckered, the ugliest, he thinks, of all of his scars.

I don‚Äôt think they‚Äôre ugly, Sirius had said to him once, third year. I think they‚Äôre beautiful.

The infuriating thing about Sirius Black‚Äîwell, one of many‚Äîis that he can just say things like that. Without thinking. Without caring. Everything about Sirius is careless‚Äîhis hair, his flying, his words. Sirius acts like nothing matters. It should be annoying‚Äîobnoxious‚Äîbut really, it‚Äôs addictive. Remus feels like he can never get enough of it. Like he‚Äôs hungry for him all the time.

He worries that it isn‚Äôt hormones.

That it‚Äôs the wolf.

That one day he‚Äôll lose control and eat Sirius whole.

When Remus Lupin was five years old a monster broke into his bedroom and bit him. It was his father‚Äôs fault. His father who hates werewolves. Who wants them dead. Ended up with one for a son. Talk about family dysfunction.

Sometimes Remus wishes it had happened later‚Äîthat he could have had more time with his parents before all they saw when they looked at him was tragedy. He expects it would be easier to be angry with them. But he isn‚Äôt. Mostly he just hurts for them. They‚Äôre good people, they probably would have been good parents. If things had been different.

He knows that they tried for a while, to have another kid. He supposes that‚Äôs another thing he should be angry about. But he just thinks it‚Äôs too bad that it didn‚Äôt work out. They deserved a do-over.

When Remus Lupin was five years old a monster broke into his bedroom and bit him. It was the worst pain he had ever felt in his life‚Äîthat is, until he transformed for the first time. Locked in the cellar. No windows. No light. Stone floors and stone walls. His father had revarnished the door with wolfsbane. Every time Remus touches it his skin burns, even when he isn‚Äôt a wolf. It‚Äôs a trick his father has used a few more times‚Äîon his office, the bedroom. Precautions. Incase Remus gets out on some full moon. Incase he comes for them in the night.

Most children ask their parents to check for monsters under their beds. Or in their closets. But thanks to Fenrir Greyback, Lyall and Hope Lupin never had to check. The monster had come and gone and Remus never thought it likely any others would visit. Because he wasn‚Äôt a little boy anymore. Not really. Not after that. He was a wolf. Just as scary as anything else that goes bump in the night.

¬†

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Lily says as she drops abruptly into the seat across from him, making Remus jump. The books that had been in her hands fan out in front of her. ‚ÄúWhat is going on?‚Äù

He looks at her for a moment before returning his attention to the book in front of him. He‚Äôs finished all his homework, now he‚Äôs just revising for his OWLs‚Ä¶again.

‚ÄúHello to you too,‚Äù he says without lifting his eyes.

‚ÄúRemus.‚Äù

‚ÄúLily.‚Äù

He can practically hear the frown in her voice. ‚ÄúSirius is off the quidditch team, Frank is living in your dorm, and the four of you are avoiding one another like the bloody plague.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are not,‚Äù Remus says, feeling particularly defensive about that last point. Because, the truth is, he has been avoiding James and Peter, but he hates that he‚Äôs doing it, and hates it even more that people have noticed. Especially Lily.

‚ÄúYou are. I tried to ignore it but I can‚Äôt bear it anymore. What happened?‚Äù

Remus bites down on his lower lip, staring intently at the words that he‚Äôs no longer reading. Honestly, Lily‚Äôs so pushy she could give Sirius a run for his money.

‚ÄúRemus!‚Äù she says exasperated, before she yanks the book right out from under him.

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù he tries to snatch it back but he‚Äôs too slow.

An aggressive ‚Äúsh-ing‚Äù noise comes from the table next to them. ‚ÄúI was reading that!‚Äù Remus whisper-shouts. ‚ÄúAnd I swear if you get me band from the library I will never forgive you.‚Äù

Lily does not look particularly concerned by either of these statements. She promptly folds down the corner of Remus‚Äôs page‚Äîlike an animal‚Äîbefore closing the book on the table and resting her hands on top of it.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù she whispers back, ‚Äúyou‚Äôve been sulking for weeks.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have not been sulking,‚Äù he crosses his arms over his chest and then, realizing how little that helps, quickly uncrosses them.

Lily arches a disbelieving eyebrow. ‚ÄúYou have. You all have.‚Äù

He wishes she would stop bringing James and Peter into this. He feels bad enough about them already, he doesn‚Äôt need her reminding him what a shit friend he‚Äôs been. Or how it‚Äôs all his fault that any of this happened in the first place. Yes, obviously Sirius is the biggest asshole on the planet. But if Remus just hadn‚Äôt been‚Ä¶if he had just been someone else. Then none of it would have happened.

James puts on a brave face but Remus can see how much it kills him, not talking to Sirius. Part of him wants to tell James it‚Äôs okay, that he can forgive him if he wants, but the truth is, Remus is too selfish. Because if there‚Äôs a choice‚Äîbetween Remus and Sirius‚ÄîRemus knows who James‚Äôll pick. And he just can‚Äôt bear the thought of losing James. At least not yet.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Lily reaches forward, tapping the back of his hand lightly. ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôd you go?‚Äù

Remus shakes his head, trying to get his thoughts straight. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

Lily looks genuinely concerned now. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs bad, huh?‚Äù

Remus almost laughs, running a hand over his face. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúYeah it‚Äôs bad.‚Äù

Her eyes are bright and green and very intent on looking directly at him. Remus does his best not to squirm but he‚Äôs not sure he manages it. He‚Äôs never gotten comfortable with being looked at. His parents spent so much of his life looking at the floor, or the ceiling, or some spot over his shoulder, that coming to Hogwarts and having people stare right at him has never felt natural.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù Lily says suddenly, scooping up their books in her arms and getting to her feet.

Remus blinks. ‚ÄúUm‚Äîwhat are you doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going for a walk,‚Äù she nods her head over her shoulder, towards the door. ‚ÄúCome on, lets go.‚Äù

Remus considers fighting her but something in her eyes tells him it would be a lost cause, so reluctantly he gets to his feet, grabbing his bag off the back of his chair.

‚ÄúI hope you know that I‚Äôm only letting you boss me around because I like you.‚Äù

She beams in a way that‚Äôs so reminiscent of Sirius it makes his heart hurt.

‚ÄúAnd that right there is why we‚Äôre friends,‚Äù she says as she hands him back his book and they start making their way to the exit.

‚ÄúBecause I like you?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause you liking me leads to you doing what I say.‚Äù

Remus snorts. ‚ÄúOh right. Of course,‚Äù and then; ‚Äúalso because you know that I‚Äôm the only one who actually takes notes in Binns's class.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù she gasps with mock indignation. ‚ÄúI would never use you for your History of Magic notes. Besides, it‚Äôs a fair trade, since I‚Äôm loads better at potions than you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúToo good. Now I have to deal with Slughorn coming after me about his bloody dinner parties and Sirius and James coming after me for actually considering going.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin, those two are a nightmare, aren‚Äôt they?‚Äù she says as she steers them towards the courtyard.

Remus shrugs noncommittally, ignoring the tightening in his chest. He can feel Lily giving him a look out of the corner of her eye.

‚ÄúYou should come you know,‚Äù she says eventually.

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúTo the Slug club? Nah, I don‚Äôt think so. Not for me really.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot for you or not for James and Sirius?‚Äù

Remus stops abruptly, so abruptly, in fact, that Lily is a few steps ahead before she realizes, turning back to him with a questioning look.

‚ÄúIf this is going to be a James Potter bashing fest, I‚Äôm really not interested, okay?‚Äù

Lily‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúNo‚ÄîI‚Äîsorry,‚Äù she sighs, tucking her hair behind her ear. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù she repeats. ‚ÄúOld habits die hard. I just meant‚Äîthey seem like the type of thing you might like if you let yourself.‚Äù

Remus looks at her skeptically, but starts walking again, the pair of them pushing through the doors to the outside, the spring evening warm and sweet, the sky pink as the sun dips below the horizon.

‚ÄúI went to one, if you remember.‚Äù

She nods, clearly trying to hide a smile. ‚ÄúI do. I remember you talking to absolutely no one and then leaving early.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell everyone there was a social climbing prat,‚Äù he shoots her a quick look. ‚ÄúNo offence.‚Äù

She laughs, ‚ÄúNone taken,‚Äù they pull up to one of the benches and Lily collapses, dropping her book bag with a dramatic sigh. ‚ÄúWell, if you‚Äôre not going to make new friends you‚Äôre going to have to stop avoiding the ones you already have.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs mouth forms a flat line, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not avoiding them,‚Äù he repeats for the hundredth time.

Lily sends him a skeptical look. ‚ÄúYesterday I watched you make a u-turn in the middle of the hallway when you saw Sirius walking towards you.‚Äù

Remus had hoped he‚Äôd managed to be a bit more subtle about that. ‚ÄúWell, okay,‚Äù he mutters eventually, picking at some lint on his pants, ‚Äúhim I am avoiding.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius? Why?‚Äù

Why.

There are so many reasons really. Or maybe just one. He‚Äôs never sure with Sirius. Never sure of where they stand or how he feels or what he wants.

He‚Äôs memorized all the moments they‚Äôve touched. He has a list in his head that he pulls up on bad days. Halloween, second year, when Sirius threw his arm around Remus‚Äôs shoulders. Or his birthday in fourth, when Sirius got tipsy for the first time and kissed his cheek. Or a few weeks ago, the last time, when he laid in bed and Sirius caressed his cheek.

Maybe those are the reasons he‚Äôs avoiding Sirius. Because if they didn‚Äôt exist maybe it wouldn‚Äôt hurt so much that Sirius had told Snape. If he didn‚Äôt have lists of Sirius Black in his head maybe he could just brush it off. So what if he only saw Remus as a pet? He‚Äôd been worse things.

‚ÄúHello?‚Äù Lily waves her hand in front of his face, snapping him back to the present. ‚ÄúYou still with me?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, sorry, my mind kind of‚Ä¶‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know how to finish that sentence.

‚ÄúWas it‚Äîdid he do something to you specifically?‚Äù Lily asks, when Remus can‚Äôt seem to summon anymore words. ‚ÄúI guess that makes sense, it would have to be something like that to get Potter to stop talking to him.‚Äù

Remus sighs, pinching the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúPotter, Lily? Really? Are we back to that?‚Äù

Now it‚Äôs her turn to get defensive. ‚ÄúYou said you didn‚Äôt want this to be a James Potter bashing fest.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen I suggest we change the subject.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt avoid him forever.‚Äù

‚ÄúFirst of all, yes, I absolutely can. And second, pot? Kettle?‚Äù

‚ÄúI am not avoiding James.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh my God Remus, we‚Äôre talking in circles. You are. You know it and I know it. So lets get over the denial bit shall we?‚Äù

Remus scowls. ‚ÄúWell, I have a valid reason.‚Äù

‚ÄúBrilliant, so do I.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot hardly.‚Äù

‚ÄúUm, excuse me?‚Äù Lily waves her hand in the direction of the lawn.

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt an exile worthy offence.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think the silent treatment can reasonably be considered exile.‚Äù

But Remus doesn‚Äôt take it back, crossing his arms over his chest and sending her a pointed look.

Lily holds his gaze for a second or two before throwing her arms up in exasperation. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you want me to say. I thought he‚Äôd grown out of being a berk, clearly he hasn‚Äôt, and honestly? I don‚Äôt have the energy to deal with it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think you could cut him a little slack here?‚Äù Remus asks. ‚ÄúThey were extenuating circumstances.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey were extenuating circumstances for everyone, you didn‚Äôt see the rest of us trying to undress someone in front of the whole school.‚Äù

‚ÄúOr shouting out slurs,‚Äù Remus counters, causing a dark look to pass over her face.

‚ÄúYeah, well, I‚Äôm not speaking to him either.‚Äù

Silence falls around them, and when Remus can‚Äôt hold Lily‚Äôs stare any longer he turns to the sky, eyeing it wearily. A month really isn‚Äôt a very long time and the full moon is coming up again. The first full moon where Snape will know. Where Sirius won‚Äôt be there.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying,‚Äù Remus breaks eventually. ‚ÄúIt would be a shame if you two went back to how you were,‚Äù he looks over at Lily. ‚ÄúYou were good together.‚Äù

She makes a noise somewhere between a cough and a gag and Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what I meant. You‚Äôre both just so‚Ä¶bright, y‚Äôknow? Watching you go head to head when you‚Äôre having fun is brilliant.‚Äù

‚ÄúFun?‚Äù Lily repeats, brow raised.

‚ÄúOh fine, pretend like you don‚Äôt know what I mean, but I know you do.‚Äù

She shakes her head, slipping down in her seat and resting her head on the back of the bench. ‚ÄúI like him more than I thought I would,‚Äù she confesses eventually, and Remus thinks he feels himself genuinely smile for the first time in a while.

‚ÄúOh yeah?‚Äù

She turns her head, a sharp look in her eyes. ‚ÄúBut don‚Äôt you dare tell him I said that. I‚Äôm still mad at him. Besides, his head doesn‚Äôt need to get any bigger.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really not that big, it‚Äôs just his hair.‚Äù

Lily lets out a surprised huff of laughter. ‚ÄúThat was a terrible joke.‚Äù

Remus shrugs. ‚ÄúSorry, best I got. But I won‚Äôt tell him,‚Äù he leans in a little closer, mock-whispering. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm avoiding him remember?‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù she nods. ‚ÄúBut not for the same reason you‚Äôre avoiding Sirius?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo‚Äîor, yes‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he sits back, running a frustrated hand through his hair. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs complicated.‚Äù

He can feel Lily eyeing him and can‚Äôt decide if she‚Äôs waiting for more information or if she just can‚Äôt find anything better to look at. Part of him wants to tell her, to let it all out. It‚Äôs exhausting. The lies. Where does he go every month? What are all his scars from? Why is he always getting sick? His schoolmates don‚Äôt really ask anymore. Not because they‚Äôre satisfied with the stories he tells, but because they‚Äôre tired of hearing them. Of never getting a straight answer out of him.

He looks over when he hears Lily start rummaging through her bag. ‚ÄúI swear I threw them in here,‚Äù she mutters to herself, ‚Äúcome on you‚Äîah ha!‚Äù she pulls herself back up, a small silver box in her hand. She slides the lid open to reveal a neat row of cigarettes.

Remus arches his brow as she places one between her lips before offering him the box.

‚ÄúLily Evans, I never,‚Äù he laughs as he takes one for himself. ‚ÄúIs this really respectable behaviour for a Gryffindor prefect?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou tell me,‚Äù she says, words slightly muffled as she gestures him forward until the ends of their cigarettes are almost touching. He expects her to pull out a lighter but instead she brings her fingers up and snaps. She makes a pleased trilling noise when they both light, pulling back to inhale.

‚ÄúNever done two at the same time before,‚Äù she says proudly.

Remus is still feeling rather stunned by the whole thing. ‚ÄúYou ever shown James that trick?‚Äù he asks eventually, the smoke is dry and scratchy in his lungs. It‚Äôs not that he‚Äôs never smoked before, only that he hasn‚Äôt done much of it. The last time he tried he practically coughed up the entire contents of his chest.

‚ÄúI have not.‚Äù

Remus nods. ‚ÄúProbably a good idea to keep it that way, I think he‚Äôd combust.‚Äù

‚ÄúCool isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Lily snorts. ‚ÄúMary taught me last summer.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, Mary, of course. I should have guessed,‚Äù the cigarette doesn‚Äôt feel natural between his fingers, not the way it looks between Lily‚Äôs. He feels like a kid playing at being a grown-up.

A few moments pass, Lily blowing elegant grey clouds into the sky, Remus trying to stop himself from choking.

‚ÄúMy dad used to smoke,‚Äù Lily says eventually. ‚ÄúThe smell, I don‚Äôt know, makes me feel better‚Äîcalm. Thought it might help.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt know much about Lily‚Äôs dad, apart from the fact that he died when she was in second year. He remembers that morning, the pale look on her face, the way she had walked away from the table and not come back to class all day.

‚ÄúWere you close?‚Äù he finds himself asking.

She smiles a little, looking up at the sky. ‚ÄúSure, I mean, I wasn‚Äôt telling him my deepest darkest secrets or anything, but‚Ä¶‚Äù she closes her eyes for a minute, inhaling deeply. ‚ÄúHe used to make me laugh,‚Äù the smoke slips between her lips. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôd do anything for a good joke. And he used to build things‚Äîturned our garage into a workshop, made wooden swords and little thrones for me and my sister. I loved that place,‚Äù she sighs. ‚ÄúNow it just has a car in it.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs watches her for a minute, the evening growing dimmer. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he says eventually.

She looks over at him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry about Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot sure it‚Äôs quite the same as your dad dying,‚Äù he offers her a weak smile but she doesn‚Äôt return it.

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt mean it isn‚Äôt still painful. You reckon you‚Äôll be able to get passed it?‚Äù
