Remus grimaces, looking down at the cigarette in his hand and flicking the ash off just for something to do. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. Not sure I know how.‚Äù He inhales too quickly, suddenly spluttering and coughing, leaning forward as his eyes water.

‚ÄúWoah, breathe cowboy,‚Äù Lily pats him on the back, laughing.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Remus‚Äôs voice comes out scratchy, ‚Äúnot much of a smoker.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can see that,‚Äù she smiles. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm surprised, I would have thought James and Sirius would be all over it, fits so nicely with their bad-boy images.‚Äù

Remus half-chokes and half-laughs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, do wizards even smoke cigarettes? I‚Äôve seen some old ones with pipes, but I‚Äôve never walked into a shop in Diagon and seen a pack of cigarettes for sale.‚Äù

Lily arches her brow. ‚ÄúI mean, you would know better than me.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he asks, momentarily confused as he wipes the last of the tears from his eyes. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

She sends him a bemused look before pointing at herself. ‚ÄúMuggle-born.‚Äù

He blinks a few times. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîoh, well. I‚Äôm not much better,‚Äù when her brows draw together he explains. ‚ÄúGrew up in the country, not really around anyone else, my dad‚Äîhe‚Äôs the wizard of the family‚Äîhe‚Äôs always been pretty‚Ä¶busy‚Ä¶with work,‚Äù with avoiding his werewolf son, but Remus figures that level of candour is unnecessary. ‚ÄúSo it was my mum who was around mostly, and her mum, my granny, a few cousins would come visit from time to time, all muggle,‚Äù he shrugs. ‚ÄúBarely saw magic before I came to Hogwarts.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù Lily says thoughtfully, rolling the cigarette between her fingers. ‚ÄúI always figured if you were magic you would use it all the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think some people probably do.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will,‚Äù she shoots him a grin. ‚ÄúGod, the minute I‚Äôm allowed I‚Äôll use magic for everything.‚Äù

Remus laughs. ‚ÄúEverything?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúEverything. Cooking? Ha! Magic. Need something from the next room? Please, I‚Äôll accio all day, never move. I‚Äôll never flick another light switch, never pick up another dustpan. I‚Äôll apparate everywhere I go, who needs to walk?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs good to know you‚Äôll be putting your powers to good use,‚Äù Remus says dryly.

She only grins wider. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be brilliant. I can‚Äôt wait to have a house full of magic‚Äîplants and potions and moving portraits.‚Äù

Remus nods, though he does his best not to think about the future. He‚Äôs not sure what it holds for him, but he can‚Äôt imagine it‚Äôs anything good. Not a lot of opportunities out there for werewolves, and it won‚Äôt take long for any wizard with half-a-brain to sniff him out.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he looks over as Lily pulls lightly on his shirt. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be okay you know?‚Äù she says, even though she can‚Äôt possible have any idea what he‚Äôs thinking. He wonders what it is that she sees on his face.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he manages after a moment, dropping the cigarette from his hand and crushing it under his heel. ‚ÄúSure, Lily.‚Äù

¬†

He doesn‚Äôt know when he fell in love with Sirius Black. It might have been the first time he saw him‚Äîstampeding into their dorm room with James behind him, so big and loud and full of life in a way that Remus craved. It might have been the first time Sirius smiled at him‚Äînot just around him, but at him. Because of him. Or one of the late nights when Pete and James had fallen asleep and Sirius and Remus had stayed up, sitting in the window, talking, legs tangled in each other.

He misses being able to touch like that. Casually. Naturally. He knows that he always liked it, that he always kept lists of those moments. But he hadn‚Äôt really thought much about why. About what it meant. Not until last year, when he started having to watch Sirius touch other people. When he would stay up late by himself because Sirius wasn‚Äôt back yet. Sometimes he would check the map, he wasn‚Äôt proud of it, it felt like an invasion of Sirius‚Äôs privacy, and it certainly wasn‚Äôt good for Remus. But he couldn‚Äôt help it. He would check and inevitably find Sirius in some broom cupboard, or in the astronomy tower, his name too close to someone else‚Äôs.

He did cry about it. Once. Maybe twice. Pathetic.

You can always feel Sirius, he takes up space in every room he enters, drawing you to him without even saying a word. He‚Äôs magnetic. And Remus has always been powerless against it. So really it‚Äôs impressive, when he stops at the end of the hall, feet away from the portrait to the Gryffindor common room. Impressive that he doesn‚Äôt go rushing right to the lithe figure leaning against the wall. It‚Äôs been weeks since he‚Äôs been properly near Sirius and he can feel the pull in his chest, the hunger in his stomach. Sirius‚Äôs eyes meet his.

‚ÄúMoons‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre on nickname terms right now,‚Äù Remus cuts him off.

Sirius nods, turning to face Remus properly but not attempting to close the gap between them. For a moment they just stand there, staring at one another. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been waiting for you,‚Äù Sirius says finally, looking hopelessly awkward.

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äîlisten, can we talk?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are talking.‚Äù

Sirius makes a frustrated noise at the back of his throat that Remus thinks is entirely unwarranted. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve given you time, okay‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHow generous of you,‚Äù Remus says coldly, feeling his anger slowly overshadowing everything else going on inside of him. Which is good. Anger is the easiest thing to feel.

‚ÄúI just mean‚Äî‚Äú Sirius swipes a hand over his face. ‚ÄúI just mean‚ÄîI want you to talk to me. Please. Just let me‚Äîgive me this chance.‚Äù

No, Remus‚Äôs brain answers automatically. No we can‚Äôt talk. No you don‚Äôt get chances. Not after everything you‚Äôve done, you selfish, manipulative, lying piece of‚Äî

‚ÄúTalk then,‚Äù says Remus‚Äôs traitorous mouth.

Sirius looks surprised. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou want to talk? Go for it, I‚Äôm waiting.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äîer‚Äîwell, maybe we should go, I don‚Äôt know, somewhere a little more‚Ä¶‚Äù he looks around, a pair of first years walking up behind him towards the portrait, another group of students laughing further down the hall, ‚Äúprivate?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere?‚Äù Remus demands.

Sirius‚Äôs hand rubs the back of his neck nervously. ‚ÄúFrank‚Äôs‚ÄîI mean‚Äîmy room, we could‚Äî‚Äú

Remus laughs. ‚ÄúI am not going back to your room with you.‚Äù

Sirius wrinkles his nose. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to make it sounds so‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSo?‚Äù

‚Äú‚Äîsinister.‚Äù

‚ÄúEverything with you sounds sinister now.‚Äù

Sirius stiffens for a minute, staring back at him with those ridiculous eyes, and that ridiculous mouth. Remus has never hated someone so much. Never missed someone. Never wanted to sink his teeth in so deep.

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù Sirius says eventually, walking towards Remus but not stopping at him, ‚Äúcome on.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äù and it‚Äôs habit that has Remus following after him even before he gets an answer, like a fucking dog. He grits his teeth but doesn‚Äôt turn back.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to come back to my room, fine,‚Äù Sirius mutters as they turn the next corner, walking unnecessarily fast. He stops at an unassuming door, swinging it open and gesturing for Remus to enter.

It takes him a minute to realize what he‚Äôs looking at. ‚ÄúOh you would know where all the broom cupboards are,‚Äù Remus snarks as he walks inside.

‚ÄúNot all,‚Äù Sirius corrects unhelpfully, ‚Äújust the ones close to the common room.‚Äù

Remus isn‚Äôt sure if Sirius means for that to sting but it does, his heart giving an inconvenient tug as Sirius closes the door behind them and mutters a silencing charm. And then‚Äî

And then.

And then.

Nothing.

They just stand there, Sirius suddenly looking much less confident.

‚ÄúWell?‚Äù Remus demands eventually. ‚ÄúSay something or stop wasting my fucking time.‚Äù

Sirius flinches. ‚ÄúRight‚Ä¶right,‚Äù he exhales, looking up through his eyelashes. ‚ÄúRemus.‚Äù

And Remus hates it. Hates the way he says his name. Like it‚Äôs hurts. Like it matters. Hates that it makes him want to cry.

‚ÄúThat all you got?‚Äù he croaks, when the truth is, from Sirius it‚Äôs almost enough. So much of Remus just wants to forgive him. Just wants to have him back.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Sirius laughs without humour. ‚ÄúNo I‚Äîlisten, I didn‚Äôt want to hurt you‚ÄîI‚Äôve never wanted to hurt you,‚Äù Sirius is speaking quickly, hands held out pleadingly in front of him, like forgiveness is something Remus can just give to him. Here you go. Make sure to keep that somewhere safe now.

‚ÄúI know that I did,‚Äù Sirius goes on. ‚ÄúI know, and I hate that, you have no idea, but I‚Äî‚Äù he swallows with difficulty, ‚ÄúI meant what I said at Christmas. You‚Äôre important to me.‚Äù

Remus snorts, even though he feels like each one of his bones is cracking apart. ‚ÄúJust not as much as you cared about getting back at Snape though, right? Or Rosier? Or was it Regulus you were trying to hurt? It‚Äôs not really clear to me,‚Äù he can see Sirius shrinking back from his words, taking each one like a blow to the face. ‚ÄúWhat is clear,‚Äù he pushes on, ‚Äúis that you didn‚Äôt think about me at all, not for a single second. That whoever else was involved in this, I never entered the equation, not for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus I‚Äî‚Äú Sirius tries desperately, but these words have been building in Remus for weeks and he wants them out. He is tired of having them rot inside him.

‚ÄúDid you forget that there was a person inside that wolf?‚Äù he asks. ‚ÄúOr is that all you see, when you look at me? Some fucking‚Äîfucking circus act or something. An animal taught to walk on its hind legs?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt think that,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt Remus.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat else am I supposed to think?‚Äù fighting the sob he can already feel building in his chest. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre worse than Snape you know that? At least I know where I stand with him. At least I know what he thinks of me. You‚Äîyou had the fucking audacity to make me believe‚Äîto make me believe that maybe‚Äî‚Äú but he cuts himself off, unwilling to let that last pathetic truth go.

He can‚Äôt stand it anymore, looking at Sirius, feeling him, smelling him. He turns around, pressing his palms flat against the cold wall behind him and trying to breathe.

The silence comes back, wraps itself around them, carving holes in their armour. There never used to be silences between them. Not before this year. Not before the kiss. He used to be able to talk to Sirius for hours. Remus quickly closes his eyes against the burn.

He hears Sirius exhale. ‚ÄúI know that I fucked up. I have no idea how to make it right‚ÄîI‚Äî‚Äú his voice breaks, falls away, cracks as it hits the ground. Sirius growls in frustration and starts again. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to forgive me, I don‚Äôt deserve it. I understand that, really, I do. I just want you to know‚ÄîI just need you to understand‚Äîthat you are so beautiful. Every inch of you, every part of you. You‚Äôre the most beautiful thing I have ever seen, and I‚Äôm so‚Äîso fucking sorry,‚Äù his voice is thick, it carries his words like they hurt to hold, ‚Äúif I made you feel, for even a second, like you aren‚Äôt.‚Äù

Remus cries then. And he hates it. Hates that he isn‚Äôt stronger than this. Hates Sirius for existing. For being all that he is. For burrowing so deeply into Remus‚Äôs bones. For breaking his heart. With those girls. With that kiss. With Snape. He feels sore and raw and bleeding. He presses his forehead against the wall, unwilling to turn around, everything coming out of him in choked gasps, like there isn‚Äôt enough air.

‚ÄúFuck Remus, please‚Äî‚Äú he hears Sirius step forward, and he wants to tell him to stay the fuck away, because hasn‚Äôt he done enough? Did he think Remus needed this? Needed someone else to take him apart? But he can‚Äôt speak, he tries, but all that comes out is some pitiful gasping noise, his shoulder shaking as he tries desperately to shove the sobs back down. Sirius comes up behind him, arms wrapping around him, pulling Remus into his chest.

I hate you, Remus thinks.

I hate you.

I hate you.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs voice is by his ear. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I‚Äôm sorry, I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

And then, somehow, Sirius‚Äôs breath isn‚Äôt the only thing brushing against Remus‚Äôs skin.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he kisses his cheek‚Äîmessy and desperate. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù his neck, his jaw. ‚ÄúPlease, please, I‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù It‚Äôs sad. It all feels so fucking sad and warped. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Sirius kisses the tears off of his face. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

It‚Äôs the first time he‚Äôs kissed him since James was hurt. And it curdles his stomach.

‚ÄúEnough,‚Äù Remus pushes him off, hands shaking as he turns around to face him, back pressing against the wall. Sirius is a wreck‚Äîall pale faced and red-eyed.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt get to do that,‚Äù Remus says, as steadily as he can manage. ‚ÄúNot now‚Äînot like this‚Äînot just because you want me to forgive you.‚Äù

Sirius shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo that isn‚Äôt‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know why I did that,‚Äù and the fear in his voice makes Remus believe him. Which feels worse, if he‚Äôs being honest. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why I did that,‚Äù he repeats to himself.

Remus almost laughs, running a hand over his face, finding himself wishing for the days when the hardest thing about this was Sirius‚Äôs denial.

‚ÄúBrilliant,‚Äù he bites out, maybe more harshly than he should. He isn‚Äôt sure anymore. Doesn‚Äôt know what either of them deserves. ‚ÄúGreat talk, you can go now.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDo you have anything else to say?‚Äù he‚Äôs barely getting the words out, desperately trying to drag his anger back to the surface to block out the rest of it. ‚ÄúBecause if not, you can go.‚Äù

He sees the flare of irritation in Sirius‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúAnd what? You‚Äôre just going to hide out in the broom cupboard?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy,‚Äù Remus growls, ‚Äúdo you need it for something?‚Äù

He sees that hit land, it‚Äôs not as satisfying as it ought to be.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not‚Äîthere isn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú Sirius grimaces, clearly frustrated, though whether it‚Äôs with himself or Remus, Remus doesn‚Äôt know. ‚ÄúThere isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶anyone‚Ä¶right now,‚Äù his words are broken pieces.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care,‚Äù Remus lies.

He knows that Sirius can tell, he‚Äôs grateful when he doesn‚Äôt push it. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to stay here‚ÄîI‚Äôll wait if it‚Äôs‚Äîif you just don‚Äôt want to be stuck walking back together or whatever.‚Äù

What I want, he almost says, is for you to not argue with me for once in our lives.

‚ÄúI want to not look like I‚Äôve been crying when I walk through the common room,‚Äù he says instead. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the asshole, you get to walk out there looking like a mess.‚Äù

Sirius gives him a quick once over, and really, Remus must look terrible, because Sirius doesn‚Äôt bother arguing after that.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he says, nodding, eyes on the ground, contrition doesn‚Äôt suit him. ‚ÄúYeah, okay.‚Äù

And Remus should just let him go. It‚Äôs what he wants. To be left alone. And yet, for some inexplicable reason, when he sees Sirius‚Äôs hand on the door, he hears himself say: ‚ÄúI told James.‚Äù

Sirius freezes, a brief pause before he turns back to look at Remus. ‚ÄúTold him?‚Äù he asks cautiously.

Remus nods. ‚ÄúAbout‚Äîthat you kissed me.‚Äù

He isn‚Äôt sure what kind of reaction he‚Äôs expecting from Sirius, but in the end he doesn‚Äôt get much. A stiff nod, Sirius‚Äôs teeth slipping over his bottom lip. ‚ÄúHe took that well I expect?‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs sarcasm or not. ‚ÄúHe already knew I think‚Äîor, he had some idea that something was going on. He didn‚Äôt seem surprised. Just‚Ä¶listened. You know how he is,‚Äù Remus clamps his mouth shut, trying to put an end to the word vomit now pouring out of him.

‚ÄúI know how he is,‚Äù Sirius repeats quietly, before letting out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúBe hypocritical for him to have an issue with it.‚Äù

Remus feels his brow furrow. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know how he‚Äôs been sneaking out at night?‚Äù Sirius asks.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

Sirius doesn‚Äôt say anything, just arches his brow and waits for Remus to catch-up. Under different circumstances it probably wouldn‚Äôt have taken him so long.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says, when it finally hits him. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

Sirius gives him a weak smile. ‚ÄúYeah, took me a bit by surprise too, after‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúLily,‚Äù Remus finishes for him, a dozen assumptions and moments reconfiguring themselves in his head.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs voice is rough. ‚ÄúLook, don‚Äôt‚Äîuh‚Äîdon‚Äôt go saying anything alright? The bloke, whoever it is, doesn‚Äôt want anyone to know, I reckon James wasn‚Äôt really meant to say anything to me so‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúNot great at keeping people‚Äôs secrets are you?‚Äù it‚Äôs a cheap shot, that slips out of Remus before he can think better of it.

He watches Sirius absorb the hit, watches him fight his natural urge to push back. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says eventually, voice gravel. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he turns back to the door but pauses again, clearing his throat without turning around. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äîuh‚Äîif you figure out what you need me to do, to make this right, to fix this, let me know okay?‚Äù he breathes in. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do anything for you Remus.‚Äù

Those words hit Remus like a blow to the head, Sirius pushing out into the corridor before he has the chance to recover.

¬†

He can‚Äôt sleep. He hasn‚Äôt been able to since the full moon. Five years he‚Äôs slept with Sirius next to him, and now that he‚Äôs gone the room isn‚Äôt right. Frank doesn‚Äôt breathe right or snore right or move right. Everything he does sets off alarm bells in Remus‚Äôs head screaming ‚Äúwrong, wrong, wrong.‚Äù Remus lies on his bed, staring up at the canopy over his head, mind thrumming with thoughts and memories.

When they were eleven, Sirius found the books Remus‚Äôs mum had bought him.

‚ÄúWhat are these?‚Äù he‚Äôd snatched one off of Remus‚Äôs bedside table before collapsing next to him on the mattress.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a book. You read it. A foreign concept to you, I know.‚Äù

Sirius swatted at him, ‚ÄúPrick.‚Äù But Remus had only laughed, watching Sirius roll onto his back and hold the book over his face.

‚ÄúNo really,‚Äù he‚Äôd said after a few minutes. ‚ÄúWhat is this?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a book!‚Äù

Sirius screwed up his face, wrinkling his nose and sticking out his tongue and Remus couldn‚Äôt stop himself from laughing again.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt look right.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Remus had tried to get himself under control. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs muggle, maybe that‚Äôs why?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo way!‚Äù Sirius promptly flipped onto his stomach, legs dangling off the side of the bed. ‚ÄúWicked, what‚Äôs it about?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh,‚Äù Remus watched Sirius flipping enthusiastically through the pages with a fondness he wouldn‚Äôt understand for several years to come, ‚Äúlots of things really, friendship, adventure, magic‚Äî‚Äú

Sirius‚Äôs head shot up at that. ‚ÄúMagic? Muggles have books about magic? What the heck, does the Minister know about this?‚Äù

Remus rolled his eyes. ‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs not our magic.‚Äù

‚ÄúOur magic?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt know that magic is real, so they make up what they think magic would be like if it was.‚Äù

Sirius continued to stare at him for a moment and Remus was sure he‚Äôd lost him, but then he smiled.

‚ÄúWicked,‚Äù he repeated, turning back to the book.

Remus had watched him for a minute, mouth feeling oddly dry. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äîuh‚Äîborrow it, if you want?‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes flicked back to him. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus nodded, probably too enthusiastically. ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù he‚Äôd smiled again and Remus had smiled back, feeling an odd bit of pride at having been able to give Sirius something. He‚Äôd always felt like he was lagging behind in those first few years. And for once he‚Äôd known something Sirius hadn‚Äôt. Had something Sirius wanted. He‚Äôd often wondered since then what it would do to Sirius‚Äôs bad-boy reputation if people knew he was a nerd for muggle fantasy books. Remus never said anything to anyone though, not even James or Peter. The books were their thing‚Äîhis and Sirius‚Äôs. He had liked that.

Groaning, Remus curls onto side, willing his brain to shut-up and leave him alone and let him sleep. Shockingly, this does not prove to be a particularly effective strategy. He flips back onto his back, running his hands over his face a few times before peeking his head out of his bed-curtains. He can hear Frank‚Äôs out of place breathing and Peter‚Äôs snoring and James‚Äôs, predictable, absence. Carefully, he slides out of bed, padding towards James‚Äôs bedside table and opening the drawer.

It‚Äôs been a long time since he looked for Sirius on the map. He doesn‚Äôt want to start again. Doesn‚Äôt want to need to. But he still pulls out the faded parchment, sitting down on James‚Äôs empty bed, wand in hand. He spends a good five minutes like that, just staring at it, trying desperately to convince himself to just put it away and go back to sleep. This isn‚Äôt going to help. But. Of course. He doesn‚Äôt.

The map unfolds in his lap. He‚Äôs not sure what he‚Äôs expecting, but there‚Äôs Sirius, alone in Frank‚Äôs old room, apparently not able to sleep either because according to the map he‚Äôs pacing. Remus watches him, feeling something deep inside him ache.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù he whispers to the little name, ‚Äúfor a minute there, I really thought you saw me.‚Äù It‚Äôs all very anti-climatic, and predictably does nothing to make him feel better.

He sighs, about to put the map away when the sudden appearance of two other names catches his attention.

James Potter.

Regulus Black.

Standing together somewhere on the seventh floor in the middle of the night. Remus blinks several times before rubbing his eyes, but even when they refocus the names remain the same. And incredibly close together. Then Regulus starts walking towards the Slytherin common room, James waiting until he disappears around the corner before heading for Gryffindor Tower.

There is probably a very valid reason for them being together, Remus tries to reassure himself. Like they just ran into one another, by coincidence, at three in the morning. Stranger things have happened.

Except Sirius said‚Ä¶

Interjects the troublesome voice in his head. But no. No. Remus shuts that right down because there‚Äôs no way‚Äî

‚Ä¶said that James is seeing a‚Ä¶

Yes, sure, but that doesn‚Äôt mean that just because Regulus is a bloke‚Äîa bloke James is meeting in the dead of night. At the same time that he confessed to Sirius he was spending with his‚Äîhis what? Hook-up? Boyfriend? Jesus, is Regulus Black his boyfriend?

NO.

That‚Äôs ridiculous. James isn‚Äôt that stupid. He can‚Äôt be. James, the boy who can‚Äôt stand anyone who even entertains the idea of dark magic. Who has been running around since he was eleven trying to rid the world of evil doers. That James Potter would never get involved with Regulus. It isn‚Äôt possible.

Remus hears someone on the stairs and quickly taps the map blank, shoving it back in the drawer with a little more force than he ought to considering there were two sleeping people in the room. He‚Äôs only just closed the curtains around his bed when the door quietly opens, James slipping in as he does most nights. For some reason Remus‚Äôs pulse is jackhammering in his chest.

He spent months trying to get Sirius to leave it alone. To let James come to them when he was ready, talking him down time and again from following James through the castle and now‚Äînow he thinks maybe that was a mistake. Because if he really is seeing Regulus‚Ä¶then someone should have stopped this.

He hears James get into his bed and resists the urge to go over there right now and demand answers. Demand how he could be so fucking stupid. But he can‚Äôt, not with Frank‚Äîhell, not even with Peter. Forget the fact that Regulus is, at best, an unpleasant person. If Sirius every finds out he‚Äôll kill him. And not metaphorically.

Remus barely represses a groan as he shoves his face into his pillow. As if his own love life wasn‚Äôt messy enough.

¬†

He watches James the next morning, looking for some sort of‚Ä¶sign. A convenient ‚ÄúRegulus was here‚Äù scribbled across the back of his neck or something. Honestly it‚Äôs so ludicrous he keeps wondering if he didn‚Äôt just make it up. Misread the names. Hallucinate for a few minutes.

‚ÄúAlright, Moony?‚Äù James asks, standing by the door, double checking his books.
Are you snogging Regulus Black? he nearly blurts out, but, luckily, despite his lack of sleep, he still has some self-control.

‚ÄúYou do look a bit peaky Moons,‚Äù Peter looks at him, head slightly tilted, concern written across his face.

‚ÄúWhy Moons?‚Äù Frank asks as he comes out of the washroom, filling the room with the smell of a distinctly new aftershave. It isn‚Äôt that it‚Äôs bad, nothing about Frank is bad. Just wrong.

‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù James asks, tearing his eyes away from Remus.

‚ÄúThe nickname, you call him Moon or whatever,‚Äù Frank hoists his book bag over his shoulder. ‚ÄúWhere did it come from?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve never called him Moon,‚Äù Peter says, in such a matter of fact tone that Remus almost laughs.

‚ÄúI just heard‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPete is right, we‚Äôve never called him Moon, no idea what you‚Äôre on about Frank.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know what I mean,‚Äù the older boy says, sounding slightly exasperated. He really doesn‚Äôt have the stamina to handle them.

James nudges Pete with his elbow. ‚ÄúYou know what he means?‚Äù

Peter shakes his head. ‚ÄúNot a clue.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou literally just‚Äîit‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs a secret, you walk around calling each other nonsense in front of everyone,‚Äù Frank‚Äôs eyes go back and forth between their blank faces before shaking his head. ‚ÄúYou know what? Forget it. It‚Äôs too early for this.‚Äù

James laughs as they all start moving towards the door. He shoots Remus a look, concern flickering back across his face. ‚ÄúMoons?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry, yeah, coming.‚Äù

‚ÄúI BLOODY HEARD THAT!‚Äù comes Frank's voice from down the stairs.

¬†

He could just let it go‚Äîshould just let it go. Not like he doesn‚Äôt have enough to worry about as it is. Besides, James is allowed to go off and snog whoever he wants. Even Regulus Black. Remus cringes without meaning to.

Anyway, what does Remus know about anything? He isn‚Äôt exactly a relationship expert. What makes him think he has a right to decide what is and isn‚Äôt good? Other than the fact that he‚Äôs caught Regulus and his asshole friends several times picking on younger muggle-born students. Regulus is never actively involved, which is smart of him really, means he never gets detention, but he is always there. Laughing and jeering with the rest of them. Remus‚Äôs eyes trail to James who‚Äôs walking just slightly ahead of him, discussing quidditch strategies with Frank. He wonders if James knows that. He wonders if he just doesn‚Äôt care.

He shakes his head, trying to get that thought out, angry with himself for even thinking it in the first place. James isn‚Äôt like that. But then, he hadn‚Äôt thought Sirius was like that either, and look how that turned out.

And then, as if his thoughts are manifesting themselves, he spots a dark head down the hall.

‚ÄúHey Pete,‚Äù it‚Äôs a stupid split-second decision. ‚ÄúI just remembered I forgot to return something to the library, I‚Äôll be back in a sec alright?‚Äù he starts pulling away.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to wait until after breakfast?‚Äù Peter asks, sounding slightly scandalized.

‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt take long. I‚Äôll see you in the Great Hall, yeah?‚Äù

Remus starts walking more purposefully, checking over his shoulder to make sure James isn‚Äôt watching, but him and Frank have already disappeared around the corner.

‚ÄúOi, Black!‚Äù

Regulus looks up from the conversation he‚Äôd been having with two other Slytherin‚Äôs, fourth years by the looks of them, neither of them Rosier or Crouch though, which will make things easier.

Regulus doesn‚Äôt say anything, just gives him a cold once over before arching a dark eyebrow.

‚ÄúA word?‚Äù Remus says, trying to interject as much Prefect authority into his voice as possible.

There‚Äôs a pause during which Remus thinks Regulus might refuse, and he isn‚Äôt at all sure what his course of action will be then. Slink back to the Great Hall with his tail between his legs? But then Regulus turns back to his companions, saying something too quiet for Remus to hear before he pulls away from the wall and walks towards him.

‚ÄúAm I in trouble?‚Äù he asks dryly, hands in his pockets, face impassive. Remus searches his eyes for any hint of what it is that James sees in him but he finds nothing. Regulus has none of Sirius‚Äôs warmth, or ease, everything about him is tight and controlled and‚Ä¶superficial.

‚ÄúJames trusts too easily,‚Äù Remus isn‚Äôt interested in pleasantries, though he does make sure to lower his voice. He watches Regulus‚Äôs eyes widen and feels his stomach drop. He really had been hoping he was wrong about this. ‚ÄúHe sees the good in everyone, even when there isn‚Äôt any.‚Äù

‚ÄúKnow that from personal experience Lupin?‚Äù the younger boy snaps back, quickly recovering from his shock.

Remus hates the way those words tie him up in knots. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he answers without wavering. Remus rarely uses his height to intimidate, but he does so now, hovering over the other boy, making himself big. ‚ÄúI want you to know, that if you hurt him, I will take you apart bone by bone. Do you understand?‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs grey eyes are unwavering, running over Remus‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúDid he tell you?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

Regulus nods slowly. ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt know you‚Äôre here then, threatening me?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a threat,‚Äù Remus says with confidence. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a promise. I know you think you‚Äôre very tough and scary, that you‚Äôve become immune to the dark after living in that haunted mansion you call a home. But I promise you I am worse than anything you have every faced. And there is nothing I won‚Äôt do for him.‚Äù

Another moment of silence passes. It‚Äôs unnerving, the similarities between Regulus and Sirius. Their faces, their eyes, their hair‚Äîall so familiar. And yet, while on Sirius they‚Äôre untameable, on Regulus everything has been meticulously manicured and controlled. Forced into a shape it doesn‚Äôt want to take.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt scare me Lupin,‚Äù the younger boy says finally,‚Äúbut you also don‚Äôt need to.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to hurt him.‚Äù

Remus snorts. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll have to excuse me if that doesn‚Äôt mean much coming from you.‚Äù

Regulus only shrugs. ‚ÄúBelieve what you want. Can I go now, or are you going to take house points or something?‚Äù

Remus grinds his teeth, contemplating painting several more violent pictures just to really drive his point home. But one look in Regulus‚Äôs bored grey eyes tells him there would be no point.

‚ÄúGo on then,‚Äù Remus says eventually, waiting another beat before he heads for the Great Hall. Of all the bloody people James could have chosen, and really, he could have had any of them‚Äîapart from Lily. He had to choose Regulus. But then again, Remus had to have Sirius didn‚Äôt he? What was it people were always saying about glass houses?

‚ÄúIdiots,‚Äù he mutters under his breath, ‚Äúthe both of us.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

Oh hey, it's wolfstar ft. Lily Evans.

I just really needed some more Sirius/Remus interaction, so hopefully you guys felt the same!

Your comments are pancakes and hot chocolate with really big marshmallows (fun fact: I have never once spelt marshmallows right on the first try) !

Chapter 16

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It‚Äôs nice out. Late spring, the sun has set, the breeze cool but not cold. James closes his eyes for a minute and breathes in, letting the night fill his lungs, stars just starting to wink themselves into view.

‚ÄúWhat about that one,‚Äù he‚Äôs on his back in the Quidditch stands, pointing up at the sky.

‚ÄúWhich one?‚Äù Regulus asks beside him.

‚ÄúThe group there, to the left of the moon.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh to the left of the moon, well that clears it right up,‚Äù Regulus says dryly and James elbows him.

‚ÄúThose ones there you prat, the group that looks like a turtle.‚Äù

Regulus lets out a juvenile snort that makes something warm pool in James‚Äôs stomach. He turns his head to look at the other boy who‚Äôs also lying on his back.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs so funny, it does look like a turtle,‚Äù James says, shuffling just close enough that his words ghost over Regulus‚Äôs neck. He grins as he sees the other boy shiver, eyes fluttering closed.

‚ÄúI promise you it doesn‚Äôt,‚Äù Regulus says, a little breathlessly, and James likes that so much that he leans forward and plants a kiss just behind his ear, staying there for a few seconds before pulling back to look at the sky again.

‚ÄúOh, it totally does, look, right there,‚Äù he uses his finger to connect the dots, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs the shell and there‚Äôs the neck and the head.‚Äù

Regulus squints up at the sky. ‚ÄúYou‚Äîoh Jesus Christ, Ophiuchus? You think Ophiuchus is a turtle? You really are an uncultured heathen aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft, sorry I wasn‚Äôt named after a bloody constellation.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus isn‚Äôt a constellation, it‚Äôs a star, thank you very much.‚Äú

‚ÄúIf anything that‚Äôs more embarrassing.‚Äù

Regulus glares at him. ‚ÄúYou know, I don‚Äôt know where you get off mocking my name when you‚Äôre the one named after the gay king. Bit on the nose don‚Äôt you think? Overkill, even.‚Äù

James blinks, looking over at him. ‚ÄúWait. Really?‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know astronomy or history? Tell me, why do people think you‚Äôre so smart again?‚Äù

‚ÄúWas there really a gay king? Of England?‚Äù

Regulus lets out an exasperated sigh but James can tell that he‚Äôs enjoying this. ‚ÄúJames I of England and the VI of Scotland‚Äîhad a string of young, very pretty, male lovers.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo shit.‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúEloquent as always James.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, call me your majesty.‚Äù

‚ÄúI definitely am not going to do that.‚Äù

James grins wickedly, ‚ÄúAw come on Reg,‚Äù he tickles his side.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt‚ÄîJames‚Äî‚Äú he‚Äôs already giggling.

‚ÄúCome here pretty male lover,‚Äù he pulls a squirming Regulus on top of him, Regulus pitching forward, hands landing on either side of James‚Äôs face. Their eyes meet and hold, the world no bigger than this‚Äîthis moment between them, this breath, this look.

James reaches his hand up, fingers running through Regulus‚Äôs hair, swooping down to cup his face.

‚ÄúWill you bow to me Regulus?‚Äù he asks cheekily.

‚ÄúMm,‚Äù Regulus turns and kisses the inside of his palm. ‚ÄúI could, but I‚Äôd rather get on my knees for you.‚Äù

James almost chokes on his next inhale, Regulus smiling as he drops his head and brings their mouthes together. So much in James‚Äôs life is a mess right now, but this, this has felt so right recently. This has been all good days. And James is grateful, because he‚Äôs not sure how he‚Äôd be managing without it.

Regulus trails kisses across his jaw, his throat, James‚Äôs hands sliding up his shirt.

‚ÄúFuck, your hands are cold,‚Äù Regulus murmurs against his skin.

‚ÄúNeed you to warm them up.‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre terrible at this.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù James says, as Regulus pulls back, hovering above him, knees on either side of James‚Äôs hips. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm endearing.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre something alright.‚Äù

James makes an impatient noise at the back of his throat, sitting up so that Regulus is essentially in his lap. ‚ÄúSo much teasing, not enough kissing.‚Äù

Regulus laughs into his mouth as James‚Äôs hand goes to the back of his head and brings them together again. James is still surprised by how warm Regulus is, how soft. He goes pliant in James‚Äôs arms, leaning into the kisses, making small, happy noises when James bites his lower lip.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to have to stop,‚Äù Regulus is breathless, forehead pressed against James‚Äôs, ‚Äúor I won‚Äôt be able to concentrate tomorrow.‚Äù James‚Äôs gut twists at the mention of tomorrow but he tries to push those feelings aside.

‚ÄúAh, you‚Äôve discovered my brilliant strategy,‚Äù James says, his fingers playing with the hair at the nape of Regulus‚Äôs neck.

‚ÄúBrilliant strategy?‚Äù he asks skeptically.

‚ÄúDistract the other team‚Äôs seeker with memories of my sexual prowess.‚Äù

Regulus leans his head back and laughs, the noise echoing in the empty stadium.

‚ÄúOh sure, you laugh now,‚Äù James goes on, holding back his own smile, ‚Äúbut have you ever tried flying a broom with a hard-on? Bloody difficult.‚Äù

Regulus buries his face in James‚Äôs shoulder, still shaking. ‚ÄúJames please‚Äîstop‚ÄîI can‚Äôt breathe.‚Äù

Which, really, Regulus ought to know is the surest way to get James to keep talking. ‚ÄúCan you imagine the commentary?‚Äù he clears his throat, putting on a voice. ‚ÄúThis is shaping up to be an especially hard game today folks, specifically for the Slytherin Seeker. Wonder who he‚Äôll be Slythering into later?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a child,‚Äù Regulus‚Äôs words are muffled as he buries his face further into James‚Äôs shoulder.

James laughs, about to continue when another thought occurs to him. ‚ÄúOh my God, can you imagine McGonagall‚Äôs face?! I bet she‚Äôd shut the whole bloody game down. Give you detention for violating the sanctity of Quidditch or something.‚Äù

Regulus shudders, sitting up so that James can see him again. ‚ÄúCould there be a better boner killer than McGonagall‚Äôs face?‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù James pinches him, causing the other boy to let out an incredibly adorable squeak. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll not have you slandering Minnie in front of me.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh my God,‚Äù Regulus pinches him back, ‚Äúhave you had fantasies about Professor McGonagall?‚Äù

James only snorts. ‚ÄúPersonally? No. Mommy issues are not my thing.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a brief beat of silence before Regulus‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúNo!‚Äù he gasps, James biting his lip to hold back a smirk. ‚ÄúNo, he never! Tell me he hasn‚Äôt!‚Äù

James only shrugs. ‚ÄúListen, it is not my place to judge what your brother does or doesn‚Äôt fantasize about.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh my God, oh my God, oh my God,‚Äù Regulus brings his hands up to cover his eyes, laughing as he shakes his head. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe he did that. I can‚Äôt believe he TOLD you.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey, the dorm room is a safe space,‚Äù those words do something annoying to the pit of his stomach. It‚Äôs only a joke, but there was a time when he would have meant it. He doesn‚Äôt know what their dorm is now, but he certainly wouldn‚Äôt call it safe.

‚ÄúWell, your strategy has been neutralizes now, because there‚Äôs no way I‚Äôm getting a boner for the rest of my life with that image in my head.‚Äù

‚ÄúShame that,‚Äù James nuzzles at Regulus‚Äôs neck, kissing it a few times before pulling back again. ‚ÄúGuess we‚Äôll just have to win the old fashioned way.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, cheeks flushed from James‚Äôs mouth. James has learned that necks are a particular weakness of Reg‚Äôs. Breathing, touching, kissing‚Äîit all brings that slightly glazed look to his eyes.

‚ÄúOld fashioned way?‚Äù

James nods, grinning even though he can feel the return of those nagging feelings in his gut. ‚ÄúBribery and blackmail.‚Äù

Regulus arches his brow. ‚ÄúVery Slytherin of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúDesperate times,‚Äù he really does try to keep his voice light, playful. But tomorrow is the final Quidditch match of the season. Gryffindor versus Slytherin. And James cant fly.

Well, he can fly. Technically. He can get on his broom and get into the air but then‚Äîthen it‚Äôs just‚Äîbecause Sirius isn‚Äôt there. And it shouldn‚Äôt matter, their second-string beater is perfectly adequate. But James and Sirius have always been on the team together. Since they were twelve. And now flying without him feels like flying without his bloody right arm.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Regulus says, tugging lightly on the collar of James‚Äôs shirt to get his attention, ‚Äúfuck him, okay? You‚Äôre going to be brilliant.‚Äù

James‚Äôs huffs. ‚ÄúNot if I play anything like I have been,‚Äù he runs a hand through his hair, leaning back. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just‚Ä¶this is supposed to be my thing, you know? I‚Äôm supposed to be good at this.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou are good,‚Äù Regulus says vehemently. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs honestly annoying how good you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúApparently not on my own.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not on your own, you have a whole team behind you.‚Äù

James closes his eyes, dislodging his glasses as he massages the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúI know, I know, it just‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt feel like it. It‚Äôs like there‚Äôs no one out there who can read me anymore, who has faith in me. I know it doesn‚Äôt actually make a difference, he was a beater, it‚Äôs not like I relied on him to pass me the Quaffle. But it just‚Ä¶made me a better player, knowing I was out there with someone who believed in me a hundred percent, no matter what stunt I pulled.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, the cool air causing the forest to rustle behind them. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt rely on other people to believe in you,‚Äù Regulus says eventually. James opens his eyes and finds Regulus‚Äôs stare trained on him.

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt think, when you‚Äôre up there, about faces or names,‚Äù he can hear the competitiveness in Regulus‚Äôs voice, the same way he sees it in his body when he plays. The need to win. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just players, pieces on a chess board, that‚Äôs it. Focus on the game.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes sir,‚Äù James considers saluting but decides against it. Regulus still rolls his eyes.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying. It doesn‚Äôt have to be personal.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt have to be personal,‚Äù James repeats, pushing himself up so that their faces are close again, ‚Äúthe Regulus Black motto.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, if you‚Äôre just going to mock me I‚Äôm not going to bother trying to help you.‚Äù

James bites back a smile at Regulus‚Äôs pouty expression, brushing their noses together. ‚ÄúYou help me, you always help,‚Äù he kisses him, softly, slowly. All kissing is not the same, that‚Äôs something he‚Äôs learned with Regulus, having never kissed anyone else enough to understand the differences. It‚Äôs one of his favourite pastimes, figuring out all the different ways to open the other boy‚Äôs mouth. All the different ways to taste him.

‚ÄúYou are good James,‚Äù Regulus says when they break apart. ‚ÄúI mean that.‚Äù

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúBetter than you?‚Äù

Regulus scoffs, though his eyes are all play. ‚ÄúYou wish.‚Äù

James laughs and Regulus quickly brings their mouthes back together.

‚ÄúSo loud,‚Äù he says into the kiss, pushing James onto his back again. The older boy pulls at his lower lip.

‚ÄúGuess you‚Äôll just have to shut me up then.‚Äù

¬†

Turns out, James is not at all good. In fact, he is very, very bad. Playing what may be the worst game of his entire life. And if the pinched look on Frank‚Äôs face is anything to go by, he thinks so too.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù the older boy says, running a hand over his sweaty face. The game is running long so Hooch called for a break, which is why the Gryffindor team is currently gathered in the locker room, looking ragged and hopeless. ‚ÄúListen, I know things aren‚Äôt good, but the game isn‚Äôt over yet, alright?‚Äù

Mary snorts, leaning up against the lockers, arms crossed over her chest. Frank sends her a sharp look but honestly, James doesn‚Äôt blame her. The Snitch hasn‚Äôt been caught, but Slytherin is currently leading 140 to 80. All eight goals scored by Mary, of course, because for some reason James can‚Äôt seem to keep his hands on the fucking ball.

‚ÄúBeaters, I need you to be more aggressive, take more shots‚Äînothing illegal‚Äîbut the Chasers are getting too comfortable out there. Macdonald, good job on those goals, keep it up, Marlene‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI know, I know, I swear I‚Äôm looking,‚Äù Marlene is sitting with her elbows on her knees, head in her hands, sweat bleeding through her uniform.

Frank just nods, ‚ÄúSometimes it‚Äôs like that, keep your eyes peeled, and stick close to Black. He moves, you move.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, cause that worked so well for Morrow,‚Äù Mary says dryly.

‚ÄúYou got anything helpful to add Macdonald?‚Äù

Mary doesn‚Äôt balk, sending Frank‚Äôs glare right back at him. ‚ÄúYeah, actually, why doesn‚Äôt James help me the fuck out out there?‚Äù

James grimaces, hand tightening around his broom handle.

‚ÄúBack off Mary,‚Äù Alice says, hand going to James‚Äôs arm and giving it a squeeze. James has no idea what Frank has told her about Sirius, but he‚Äôs grateful for the two of them either way.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThis is a team sport,‚Äù Frank interrupts. ‚ÄúThe fate of this game isn‚Äôt up to one of us, if we‚Äôre doing poorly that‚Äôs on everyone in this room.‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúOh come on, there‚Äôs clearly one person who is monumentally fucking up more than the rest of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin Mary, shut-up!‚Äù Alice snaps.

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Marlene‚Äôs head pops up. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt talk to her like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen tell her to stop being such a cow.‚Äù

Mary laughs, pushing off the lockers and stepping forward. ‚ÄúYou know what Alice, just because you‚Äôre screwing the Captain doesn‚Äôt mean you get to do whatever you want.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay that‚Äôs enough,‚Äù Frank tries to interject, but neither of the girls is paying any attention to him.

Alice smiles in a way that is not remotely pleasant. ‚ÄúOh, you really don‚Äôt want to go there.‚Äù She tries to step forward too, but James grabs hold of her arm and pulls her back.

‚ÄúLeave it Alice,‚Äù he says quietly.

She looks back at him, face flushed with indignation. Honestly, he‚Äôs not sure which of them is scarier‚ÄîMary or Alice‚Äîbut he‚Äôs pretty sure he couldn‚Äôt take either of them in a fight.

‚ÄúLook, James, I‚Äôm not trying to be a bitch,‚Äù Mary says bluntly, hands on her hips. ‚ÄúBut come on, I‚Äôm right, no? You‚Äôre playing like garbage. I just don‚Äôt see what good it‚Äôs doing us to act like you aren‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin Mary,‚Äù Marlene mutters under her breath.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Mary looks around the room. ‚ÄúDid I miss something? Potter‚Äôs a big boy, he can take it.‚Äù

Alice is still pulling against James‚Äôs grip, ready to fight.

‚ÄúMacdonald‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right,‚Äù James interrupts Frank. ‚ÄúI am playing like garbage.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you!‚Äù Mary sighs, ‚ÄúSo, stop fumbling the Quaffle and just pass it to me every time you get it, okay?‚Äù

James snorts, finding himself surprisingly appreciative of Mary‚Äôs ‚Äúno bullshit‚Äù attitude.

‚ÄúYou got it Macdonald.‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat, now maybe we can close that fucking gap,‚Äù she looks around the room again. ‚ÄúEveryone okay with that?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence.

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù Frank says, running a hand over his face. ‚ÄúBut James, you get a shot you take it, okay? Don‚Äôt second guess yourself.‚Äù

Frank is hoping that he‚Äôll wake up. That he‚Äôll suddenly be able to fly like there isn‚Äôt a chunk of him missing out there. Hell, he‚Äôs been hoping the same thing, trying to do what Regulus told him‚Äîto think of them as faceless players, pieces on a board. To not look for Sirius. But he just can‚Äôt quite manage it.

‚ÄúSure Frank.‚Äù

Before anyone else can speak there‚Äôs the ringing of a magically magnified voice in their ears.

‚ÄúTeams back to the pitch, I repeat, the teams are now to return to the pitch.‚Äù

Frank looks back at them, eyes running over each of their haggard, sweaty faces. ‚ÄúWe are a bloody good team, whatever happens out there. And I‚Äôm proud of each and every one of you.‚Äù

James feels his chest grow tight. This is Frank‚Äôs last chance to win the cup. And he‚Äôs fucking it up.

‚ÄúYou got it daddy Frank,‚Äù Marlene stretches, getting back on her feet.

As they start down the tunnel back towards the field, James realizes that, for the first time, maybe in his entirely life, he doesn‚Äôt want to get on his broom.

¬†

The second half of the game is not going any better. James‚Äôs passes are sloppy, his aim off, and he keeps flinching every time he sees a goddamn Bludger. Luckily, the rest of his team is doing a bit less shit. Slytherin hasn‚Äôt scored anymore goals and Mary has managed to get in two. At least if they lose now it‚Äôll be respectable. Which is not a thought James has ever had during a Quidditch match before. Usually he‚Äôs more of a fight to the bitter end kind of guy. But everything feels wrong this game. The team. Him. Nothing is meshing well, and he just wants to go back to his room and wash the whole thing out of his skin.

Mary makes an unsuccessful attempt on the Slytherin goal and the Keeper chucks the Quaffle well across the pitch, overshooting his mark, so that there‚Äôs no one on the receiving end. Normally James would revel in this‚Äîan easy steal. But the way this game is going, the Slytherin‚Äôs will have it out of his hands in no time. Still, he has to try, doesn‚Äôt he?

He‚Äôs almost got it when another set of hands come out of nowhere, snatching the Quaffle before he can reach it.

‚ÄúWhat the hell is‚Äîsorry Professor‚Äîwhat the heck is going on here? The Slytherin Seeker has just taken possession of the Quaffle!‚Äù booms the commentators voice across the field.

James feels just as stunned as everyone else, staring at the dark haired boy hovering on the broom in front of him.

‚ÄúRegulus‚Äî‚Äú

But Regulus doesn‚Äôt let him finish, grey eyes sharp. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre throwing a temper tantrum.‚Äù

James blinks. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre mad that he‚Äôs not here so you‚Äôre throwing a temper tantrum. Stop it. You‚Äôre better than this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am not‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJust because it isn‚Äôt how you pictured it doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs broken. And I‚Äôm tired of watching you give up,‚Äù his eyes scan the sky behind James, watching as the other players get closer.

‚ÄúWhat the hell Black!‚Äù that‚Äôs one of the Slytherin‚Äôs‚ÄîZabini maybe?

‚ÄúStop harassing my Chaser!‚Äù that‚Äôs Frank.

‚ÄúThis is highly irregular folks, I quite honestly have no clue what‚Äôs going on‚Äîweird strategy on Slytherin‚Äôs part.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes stop moving for a moment, locking on James. ‚ÄúI believe in you,‚Äù he says quietly.

The wind pushes against James, rocking him like a boat. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said you missed having someone out here who believes in you‚Äîwho has faith in you,‚Äù he puts weight in his words, so that they don‚Äôt float away, so that James has to hear them. ‚ÄúI have faith in you.‚Äù

And then he‚Äôs gone, flying past James and sending the Quaffle careening over his head towards one of the Slytherin Chasers. James blinks, trying to get his bearings.

I have faith in you.

Those words bounce around his head. Those words set fires in his chest. And then, slowly, James feels himself smile.

‚ÄúPOTTER!‚Äù Frank shouts, as James turns his broom around. ‚ÄúGet your head in the fucking game!‚Äù

¬†

And he does. The rest of the game is brilliant. Hard flying, fast game plays, James is out of breath and beaming by the time it‚Äôs done. Gryffindor is leading 200 to 160 when Regulus catches the Snitch. It‚Äôs work for James to hide his smile at the sight, Reg with the golden ball held over his head, the stands going wild. They‚Äôve lost and it sucks. Really. But fuck, it feels like the first time he‚Äôs really been able to fly in weeks.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry Frank,‚Äù Marlene says even before she‚Äôs off her broom. The team landing on the field, all sweating and red-faced. It was long game and the sun is starting to dip below the horizon, evening rolling in.

Frank shakes his head. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be, you played beautifully. You all did.‚Äù

It‚Äôs loud and chaotic, the Slytherin‚Äôs chanting in the stands, a few of them running onto the field along with Madame Hooch and Professor Slughorn. Green and Silver scarves are thrown onto the pitch.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck did Black say to you and do I need to fight him?‚Äù Alice asks as she comes up beside James.

He laughs. ‚ÄúNah, it was nothing,‚Äù he feels almost guilty about dismissing Reg like that‚Äîdismissing what he did.

I have faith in you.

He stopped a whole bloody Quidditch match, in front of the entire school, for James.

‚ÄúI knew all you needed was a little antagonism,‚Äù Mary winks at him as she walks towards the locker room, squirting water into her mouth.

James laughs. ‚ÄúYou trying to say that take down at halftime was all for my benefit?‚Äù

She turns around to face him, walking backwards. ‚ÄúAnything for you James, baby.‚Äù But there‚Äôs something not quite right‚Äîcold and sharp. It takes James by surprise, but before he can answer Alice beats him to it.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre lucky you didn‚Äôt get socked in the face Macdonald,‚Äù there‚Äôs a playfulness to her voice as they start following after Mary.

‚ÄúAs if you‚Äôd dare Prewett.‚Äù

‚ÄúBad idea to bet against me, just ask Marlene.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs right,‚Äù Marlene admits, throwing her broom over her shoulder.

‚ÄúMar!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? It is!‚Äù

James smiles at the three girls, hanging back so that he can walk with Frank.

‚ÄúAlright Potter?‚Äù Frank asks, dragging his feet like he‚Äôs reluctant to leave the pitch.

James nods as they slowly come to a stop near the edge of the field, Frank looking out at it all with a wistful expression on his face. James watches for a moment before clearing his throat, foot kicking nervously at the ground.

‚ÄúListen, I reckon I owe you an apology.‚Äù

Frank looks over at him, eyebrow raised.

‚ÄúI let you down out there.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, in which James feels Frank‚Äôs eyes on him but can‚Äôt quite bring himself to meet them.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù the older boy says eventually. ‚ÄúTwo years ago‚Äîhell‚Äîlast year, if Mary had said the things she said to you today, you‚Äôd have lost it on her. There‚Äôd have been a bloody duel in my locker room. But the way you handled yourself today‚Ä¶‚Äù he shoots James a proud smile. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve always been a good player James, no doubt about it. But I was never convinced that you could actually lead the team, not until today.‚Äù

James blinks, brain suddenly going a mile a minute. ‚ÄúI‚Äîwait, am I‚Äîare you making me Captain?‚Äù

Frank smirks, just out of the corner of his mouth. ‚ÄúBut you didn‚Äôt hear it from me. So do try to look surprised when the badge comes in the mail yeah?‚Äù

James nearly chokes on all the words that are trying to force their way out of his mouth. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to thank me, you earned it. I‚Äôm excited to come back next year and see what you do with them. You‚Äôve got a good core here, but it‚Äôll be nice to get some fresh blood on the field.‚Äù

James only nods, still feeling a little stunned. For some reason he‚Äôd always assumed that the captaincy would go to Marlene. Her being the most patient and reasonable of the lot of them.

Beside him Frank takes in a deep breath, eyes scanning over the field one last time. ‚ÄúI got into the Auror program,‚Äù he says eventually.

James feels something tug on his gut. ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs official then, no more Quidditch.‚Äù

Frank nods, slowly. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs official.‚Äù

It shouldn‚Äôt bother James as much as it does. The Aurors is the right choice‚Äîthe noble choice. But he can‚Äôt shake the feeling that it‚Äôs unfair.

‚ÄúAlice too?‚Äù he finds himself asking.

‚ÄúYup.‚Äù

James bites down on his lower lip. ‚ÄúBe careful yeah?‚Äù his chest squeezes. Aurors always feel so big and scary and untouchable. Like you could throw them into anything and they would survive. Not like Frank and Alice. They‚Äôre just kids. Just his friends.

Franks drags his eyes away from the pitch and back to James. ‚ÄúYou too.‚Äù

There‚Äôs more to say. There almost always is. But James has no idea what, and before he can figure it out Madame Hooch is shouting at him across the field.

‚ÄúPOTTER, here, now!‚Äù

James squints in her direction, there are still scattered groups of revelling Slytherin‚Äôs on the pitch, though the stadium has sufficiently emptied, only one or two straggles still left in the stands.

Frank lets out a low whistle. ‚ÄúShe sounds pissed.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James grimaces, ‚Äúthink she‚Äôs figured out I‚Äôve been stealing Snitches all year?‚Äù

Frank laughs, patting James on the shoulder as he turns down the hallway behind them and starts making his way inside. ‚ÄúMerlin help you if she has.‚Äù

That, James thinks, is wholly unhelpful.

Walking towards Madame Hooch, he realizes that he‚Äôs not the only one who‚Äôs been summoned. A spike of anxiety cutting through him that has nothing to do with stolen Snitches as he stops awkwardly across from Regulus.

‚ÄúMr. Black has something to say to you,‚Äù Hooch crosses her arms over her chest, eyes bouncing between the two boys, her gaze particularly harsh when it falls on Regulus.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîokay?‚Äù James shifts his weight between his feet, feeling thoroughly uncomfortable. He can‚Äôt quite look at Regulus, not this close, not with Madame Hooch watching them.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry for my un-sportsman like behaviour,‚Äù Regulus says flatly.

James blinks. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYour sincerity is truly inspiring Mr. Black, I‚Äôll be taking fifty points from Slytherin. I‚Äôve never seen such vicious behaviour on my pitch and I won‚Äôt tolerate it again, understood?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo‚Äîwait‚ÄîMadame Hooch‚Äî‚Äú

But Regulus cuts him off, voice sharp. ‚ÄúI honestly was only making an observation, it‚Äôs hardly my fault that he was playing like a drunken baboon.‚Äù

James chokes, half-way between laughter and indignation. ‚ÄúA drunken baboon?‚Äù he arches his brow at Regulus, but the younger boy‚Äôs face is made of stone.

‚ÄúYes, thank you Mr. Black,‚Äù Madame Hooch says coldly. ‚ÄúNext time I‚Äôll disqualify you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes ma‚Äôam,‚Äù he says dryly.

Hooch gives him one last look over before turning to James, hand clapping his shoulder as she walks off; ‚ÄúExcellent turn around in the second half Potter, really brilliant flying.‚Äù

‚ÄúUm‚Ä¶thanks?‚Äù he watches her walk away, brow knitting in confusion. ‚ÄúRegulus why‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSupply room,‚Äù Regulus whispers, quiet, direct, ‚Äúpast the locker rooms, on the left.‚Äù And then he turns on his heel, heading back towards his remaining teammates, leaving James feeling as though he‚Äôs just been hit with a stunning spell. He watches Regulus‚Äôs back for a moment before following what, he‚Äôs assuming, are instructions.

Frank is no longer at the entrance of the stadium, the hallway clear as James makes his way down the hall, finding the supply room on the left just like Regulus said. He doesn‚Äôt have his wand on him so the only light is from the small, high window on the far wall, illuminating rows of well-used brooms and mismatched Quidditch gear. The ceiling and floor are grey, the room smelling very distinctly of sweat and leather.

James runs a hand through his damp hair, wondering exactly what he‚Äôs meant to be doing, when the door opens behind him. He turns around and finds Regulus slipping through.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he says, when Regulus doesn‚Äôt speak, the two of them standing awkwardly in front of one another.

Regulus nods. He looks tense and the fact that James has no idea why is wigging him out a little. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt tell people what I said to you during the game, you realize that right?‚Äù

James blinks. Oh. Of course. This is a PR meeting. ‚ÄúSo what do I tell them?‚Äù

Regulus waves his hand in the air dismissively, and for some reason that irks James. ‚ÄúThat I was taunting you, the specifics aren‚Äôt important, though it‚Äôs probably best if you choose one story and stick to it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou want me to tell everyone that you were being an asshole?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

James frowns, unsure why it bothers him so much. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have to, it was a dumb thing for me to do in the first place, I wasn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú Regulus shakes his head, looking off to the side for a moment before his gaze returns to James. ‚ÄúLook, it‚Äôs what everyone will think anyway, so just go along with it okay?‚Äù

James thinks about Alice, and knows that Regulus is right.

‚ÄúWell they shouldn‚Äôt‚Äîthe way that Hooch was treating you out there? That wasn‚Äôt fair. I don‚Äôt‚Äîyou don‚Äôt have to be the bad guy. I don‚Äôt want people to think‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAnd what is the alternative?‚Äù neither of them have stepped any closer, the space between them poking holes in James‚Äôs lungs. ‚ÄúHuh? Because people are going to ask and if you tell them the truth then they‚Äôll know that we‚Äôre‚Äî‚Äú he cuts himself off. They‚Äôve said they love each other but they haven‚Äôt said much else. Like what they are. What they‚Äôre doing. What it means.

‚ÄúWould that be so bad?‚Äù James asks.

He sees Regulus‚Äôs eyes widen, but not with shock, with anger. ‚ÄúAre you joking right now?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

Regulus stares at him for a minute, a look of complete disbelief washing over his face. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre being ridiculous.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so,‚Äù he takes a step forward and Regulus instantly steps back, causing them both to freeze. James does his best to ignore the tightening in his chest. ‚ÄúWhat are you so afraid of Reg?‚Äù

For a second the expressionless mask cracks and something so much more powerful than anger or irritation slips through. And then it‚Äôs gone.

‚ÄúYou have no idea‚ÄîI can‚Äôt be‚Äî‚Äú he starts and then stops, shaking his head. ‚ÄúAnd anyway, it doesn‚Äôt matter. I told you‚ÄîI told you before this started.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis?‚Äù James repeats, a new edge to his voice. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs ‚Äòthis‚Äô Reg? What are we doing? Huh? What am I to you, exactly?‚Äù

He can see Regulus‚Äôs chest rising and falling like he‚Äôs still playing the game. Still trying to outmaneuver an opponent. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt start James,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúI told you that this had to be secret. You agreed,‚Äù that last word is ground out of him, almost desperate sounding.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not the one who flew up to you in the middle of a Quidditch match,‚Äù he shoots back, petulantly.

Regulus pinches the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúAll I am asking,‚Äù his voice carefully level, ‚Äúis that you confirm their biases.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm just telling you, that I don‚Äôt want to go around bashing you to everyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh get over yourself,‚Äù he drops his hand. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not as though you‚Äôve never done it before. My brother, I‚Äôm sure, has given you plenty of opportunities to practice.‚Äù

Now it‚Äôs James‚Äôs turn to take a step back. That attack taking him by surprise, in no small part, because it‚Äôs true.

Eventually Regulus sighs, breaking the new silence that‚Äôs grown up around them. ‚ÄúJames, please. I‚Äôm asking you. I made a mistake‚Äîa miscalculation‚ÄîI wasn‚Äôt thinking. I need you to do this for me.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not fair really. Not with the desperation in his voice, his words. He needs him. And really, that‚Äôs all James has ever wanted. To be needed. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says quietly, ‚Äúfine, if that‚Äôs what you want.‚Äù

Regulus nods curtly, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what I want.‚Äù

Another beat of silence.

‚ÄúI should go,‚Äù Regulus‚Äôs voice is clipped, grey eyes somewhere distant, somewhere not on James.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù he stops him with his hand on the door, the younger boy looks back over his shoulder but doesn‚Äôt turn around. ‚ÄúIt meant something to me, what you did out there. So just‚Äî‚Äù there‚Äôs an unnecessary strain in his voice and he coughs, trying to make himself sound normal. ‚ÄúJust don‚Äôt call it a mistake, okay?‚Äù

Something uncomfortable and heavy grows in James‚Äôs chest as he waits for an answer, enduring a silence that stretches on too long. Eventually Regulus nods. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he turns back to the door but doesn‚Äôt open it, hand still tightly gripping the handle. After several seconds he sighs, like he‚Äôs giving up. Losing the fight. When he turns back around his eyes are softer than before.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt‚Äîjust‚Äîstay still alright? Don‚Äôt touch me.‚Äù

Surprised, James nods, clasping his hands behind his back in a way that Regulus can see, the younger boy approaching him slowly. Regulus‚Äôs curls are long enough now to be messy after the game, his cheeks still flushed, making his eyes stand out‚Äîthe grey bright and intense, trained on James‚Äôs face. When they come toe to toe Regulus pauses for a moment, looking at James intently before rising up on the balls of his feet to press a quick kiss to his lips. The touch is soft, and when he pulls away both of them are breathing heavy.

‚ÄúI got distracted watching you,‚Äù Regulus says quietly, and James can tell that it costs him something, to give up that truth, ‚Äúusually I can tune everything out when I‚Äôm flying, that‚Äôs why I love it so much, but you‚Äîall that time I was supposed to be looking for the Snitch and I couldn‚Äôt take my eyes off of you.‚Äù

James feels his breath hitch, he knows what this is. An apology. An olive branch. James almost tells Regulus that it isn‚Äôt necessary, except that he doesn‚Äôt want Regulus to move. To hide behind his walls again. They aren‚Äôt touching, James‚Äôs hands still behind his back, but they‚Äôre close. And there‚Äôs something about the soft tones of Regulus‚Äôs voice, low and gravelly, that send shocks of electricity through him.

‚ÄúYou take it on too easily,‚Äù James says eventually, when he‚Äôs certain he‚Äôll be able to keep his voice under control. Regulus sends him a questioning look so he continues. ‚ÄúThe role of the villain, like you think you deserve it. Like you‚Äôre trying to atone for something. Your family‚Äôs guilt isn‚Äôt your own Regulus, you don‚Äôt have to bear it. You aren‚Äôt them.‚Äù

Something complicated is happening in the other boy‚Äôs eyes, and James wishes he knew what it was.

‚ÄúSometimes,‚Äù his voice gets even quieter, eyes closing, ‚ÄúI think I was born with blood on my hands.‚Äù

James wants so desperately to reach out, to pull him close, to hold him. But he doesn‚Äôt. Because Regulus doesn‚Äôt want that. Because he trusts James not to.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been saving me,‚Äù he says instead, the next best thing. If he can‚Äôt wrap him in his arms he‚Äôll wrap him in his words. ‚ÄúThese past few weeks, everything that‚Äôs been going on with Sirius, if it weren‚Äôt for you I‚Äôd be sunk,‚Äù he takes in a deep breath, leaning closer but still not touching, it‚Äôs Regulus who ends up bringing their foreheads together. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not bad Regulus.‚Äù

The other boy lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù there are fault lines in his voice, ready to shake him apart, ‚Äúbut I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm good either.‚Äù

‚ÄúReg,‚Äù James whimpers, voice breaking. He has no idea what they‚Äôve been telling him at Grimmauld Place, but he knows it‚Äôs fucked him up, made him think he‚Äôs something he isn‚Äôt. It hurts, he realizes, to love someone who can‚Äôt love themselves. Like watching a work of art set itself on fire.

They stay like that, frozen, pressed together. James closes his eyes and listens to Regulus breathe, surprised by how comforting it is. He doesn‚Äôt know how much time passes before Regulus steps back.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my person,‚Äù he says suddenly, like it‚Äôs a struggle. Talking always is for him.

James blinks. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou wanted to know what you are to me,‚Äù Regulus explains, flush high in his cheeks. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my person. You‚Äôre mine.‚Äù

James feels a smile tug at his mouth, something fluttering in his stomach. ‚ÄúOkay Reg,‚Äù he says warmly, ‚Äúyeah, I‚Äôm yours. You‚Äôre mine too.‚Äù

The other boy nods, exhaling, like he‚Äôd been worried. James can‚Äôt imagine why. He‚Äôs completely gone on the kid, he thought he‚Äôd made that clear.

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt be able to get away tonight,‚Äù Regulus goes on awkwardly.

‚ÄúI figured.‚Äù

‚ÄúTomorrow?‚Äù

James nods, ‚Äútomorrow.‚Äù

This time Regulus doesn‚Äôt pause at the door.

¬†

The locker room is empty by the time James gets there. He doesn‚Äôt mind, he feels a little raw. He needs time to pull himself together before talking to anyone. It isn‚Äôt that it‚Äôs bad exactly, just‚Ä¶intense. But then, it always is with Reg.

He thinks of all the art‚Äîpaintings and music and plays‚Äîabout love. Lines and lines dedicated to trying to get this feeling out. Metaphors and similes, blended colours and golden frames. Trying to make it into something that can be spoken and seen and touched. James thinks he gets that now, at least a little bit. The desperate desire to take the swelling inside his chest and say ‚Äúlook, it‚Äôs real.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames!‚Äù

It is clear, the minute he walks through the portrait hole into the common room, that the Gryffindor team has spent the time since he last saw them getting drunk. Well, the team and company. Peter and Remus are there, along with Lily. His eyes meet her‚Äôs briefly before looking away. They still haven‚Äôt spoken since that day on the lawn and James isn‚Äôt sure he‚Äôs up for anymore confrontation today.

‚ÄúYou lot certainly seem to be having a good time,‚Äù he smiles, though, quite honestly, he‚Äôd like nothing more than to go upstairs and sleep for several hours.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre mourning,‚Äù Mary says, holding up a half-empty bottle of something James can‚Äôt recognize but assumes is alcoholic.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù he says, dropping his bag and sitting next to Remus.

‚ÄúSorry, about the game,‚Äù Remus presses into his side just enough to be comforting before pulling away.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù someone hands him a bottle and he takes it without thinking, though he doesn‚Äôt really feel like drinking.

‚ÄúTo Frank,‚Äù Mary hoists her drink in the air, all brown curls and red lips and devilish eyes, ‚Äúthe most anal-retentive captain at Hogwarts.‚Äù

There are a few laughs and ‚Äúhere, heres,‚Äù everyone raising their own glasses and taking a drink, the alcohol burns on its way down James‚Äôs throat. He really needs to get something to eat. He‚Äôs not sure when the last time he had food was‚Äîthis morning?

‚ÄúTo Mary,‚Äù Frank returns, Alice between his legs, leaning back against his chest, ‚Äúthe biggest pain in my ass.‚Äù

Mary throws her head back and laughs as the rest of them raise their glasses again. More burning liquid pooling in James‚Äôs stomach. He doesn‚Äôt know why he feels so off.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd have thought that title would go to James,‚Äù Remus says playfully.

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúPlease, Frank and James are basically the same person.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot quite the same I don‚Äôt think,‚Äù Frank says dryly. ‚ÄúFor starters, I‚Äôm pretty sure I‚Äôve never had detention.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus, really?‚Äù James asks. ‚ÄúBlimey, what‚Äôve you been doing the last seven years? Sleeping?‚Äù

Alice giggles. ‚ÄúSome of us are just smart enough not to get caught.‚Äù

‚ÄúSmart enough or not bold enough?‚Äù James asks with a grin.

‚ÄúAlright, alright, settle down children,‚Äù Mary says from her perch on the arm of the sofa, lording over the rest of them on the floor. ‚ÄúI meant when it comes to quidditch. They‚Äôre both big nerds.‚Äù

‚ÄúI believe the term you‚Äôre looking for is top tear athletes,‚Äù James says primly.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll drink to that,‚Äù Frank sends James a smile, tipping his bottle to him.

‚ÄúI still can‚Äôt believe I missed that bloody Snitch,‚Äù Marlene is sitting at Mary‚Äôs feet, knees pulled up, head in her hands, and at least two empty drinks bedside her.

‚ÄúOh are you still on that?‚Äù Mary says, looking down at her friend with extreme disinterest. ‚ÄúReally darling, it‚Äôs done. Move on.‚Äù

But Marlene only makes an aggravated noise. ‚ÄúWe could have won‚Äîif I‚Äôd just been a little faster‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMcKinnon,‚Äù Frank leans around Alice to put his hand on Marlene‚Äôs arm. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, you‚Äôre a brilliant Seeker, you‚Äôll get them next year, yeah?‚Äù

Marlene scrunches her nose. ‚ÄúBut you won‚Äôt be here,‚Äù she says thickly.

‚ÄúO-kay,‚Äù Mary reaches down and takes the drink right out of her hand. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs enough for you, you bloody lightweight.‚Äù

‚ÄúMar, baby, look at me,‚Äù Alice says, leaning forward. Marlene turns her big eyes on the older girl. Her big red eyes.

‚ÄúJeez,‚Äù James whispers to Remus. ‚ÄúHow long were you guys drinking before I got here?‚Äù

Remus snorts. ‚ÄúNot long, she‚Äôs just been pounding them back‚Äîit was impressive honestly.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe do not,‚Äù Alice‚Äôs voice cuts across the room, she‚Äôs taken hold of Marlene‚Äôs hands and is looking at her very intently, ‚Äúwin Quidditch games for boys.‚Äù

Marlene sniffles, nodding her head. ‚ÄúRight, yeah,‚Äù but that only lasts for about a minute before another frustrated groan rips out of her and she pulls away from Alice, collapsing onto her back. ‚ÄúI can‚Äô believe I didn‚Äôt see it!‚Äù

‚ÄúThere, there,‚Äù Mary nudges her with her foot in what James thinks is supposed to be a consoling gesture.

‚ÄúStupid Regulus Black,‚Äù Marlene mumbles, arm now thrown over her face.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll drink to that,‚Äù Alice says, a general mumbling of agreement sweeping around the circle. For a second James thinks he feels Remus go stiff beside him but he can‚Äôt figure out why. Maybe because Regulus makes him think of Sirius? James doesn‚Äôt know, and he‚Äôs too tired to figure it out, downing the rest of his bottle before looking for a new one.

‚ÄúI still can‚Äôt believe that little twerp had the audacity to fuck with you like that,‚Äù Alice says, and James can hear the anger in her voice. She‚Äôs always been too much of a mama bear for her own good.

‚ÄúWhat did he say anyway?‚Äù

It takes a second before James realizes that the question is directed at him, and that every set of eyes in the circle is now turned in his direction. Of course, he knew that Regulus had been right, that conversations would inevitably end up here. But somehow he still feels unprepared.

Eventually James shrugs, a motion he hopes looks more natural than it feels. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt remember, wasn‚Äôt really paying attention," he takes a deep pull of his drink.

Mary arches her brow, ‚ÄúThat bad huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt say that.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs bad enough that you don‚Äôt want to tell us what it was?‚Äù Peter pipes up, unhelpfully.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt say that either,‚Äù James growls.

‚ÄúMaybe we should talk about something else?‚Äù Remus looks around hopefully. And not for the first time, James thanks the gods for Remus bloody Lupin.

‚ÄúWait, wait, now I‚Äôm intrigued,‚Äù Alice leans further forward in Frank‚Äôs lap, a look in her eyes that says she‚Äôs not about to let this go. ‚ÄúWhat did he say James? Cause whatever it was, it got you playing like a rockstar.‚Äù

James looks at her for a long minute before leaning forward himself. ‚ÄúWho says my playing had anything to do with him? Remember Alice, we do not win Quidditch games for boys.‚Äù

She cackles, clinking her glass against his as she falls back against Frank‚Äôs chest. ‚ÄúTouch√©.‚Äù

‚ÄúWas it about Lily?‚Äù

Everyone looks up at Mary who‚Äôs now considering James thoughtfully.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt bring me into this,‚Äù says Lily, who, up until this point, has been uncharacteristically quiet. She‚Äôs sitting against the side of the armchair, knees bent and pulled up, bottle hanging between them.

James looks at her and then away. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says bluntly.

But, of course, Mary can‚Äôt let it go. If anything, his flat denial seems to egg her on, that same sharp look in her eyes that he noticed on the field. The one that doesn‚Äôt feel like joking.

‚ÄúI bet it was.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy would Black interrupt a Quidditch game just to rib James about Lily?‚Äù Frank asks skeptically, and while James appreciates the sentiment, he really doesn‚Äôt think audience participation is going to help the situation.

Mary shrugs, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a well known weakness.‚Äù

‚ÄúI told you, he didn‚Äôt,‚Äù James says flatly.

‚ÄúThen what did he say?‚Äù she pushes.

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, something about how shit I am. Does it matter?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh wow,‚Äù Alice says suddenly, the spark back in her eyes, making James‚Äôs stomach squirm, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre lying.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am not,‚Äù James is starting to feel a little desperate now.

‚ÄúI really think we should change the subject,‚Äù Remus tries again. ‚ÄúFrank, Alice, when do you guys start Auror training?‚Äù

But it‚Äôs too late.

‚ÄúMakes sense that you wouldn‚Äôt want to tell us if he said something horrible about her,‚Äù Mary goes on.

‚ÄúI told you to leave me out of this,‚Äù Lily says again.

‚ÄúAnd I told you that he didn‚Äôt say shit about Lily,‚Äù James grumbles, somehow finishing off his second drink. He reaches for another.

‚ÄúMaybe you should slow down,‚Äù Remus says quietly.

‚ÄúIf I have to deal with her,‚Äù he motions jerkily in Mary‚Äôs direction as he grabs another bottle. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to need more alcohol.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat was it Potter? Come on, I‚Äôll never sleep if I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt couldn‚Äôt have been that bad, could it?‚Äù Alice asks, intrigued. ‚ÄúRegulus has always seemed pretty harmless to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know about that,‚Äù Remus says quietly, which surprises James.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he turns to his friend. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

Remus looks thoroughly uncomfortable, like he hadn‚Äôt meant to let that slip out. ‚ÄúNothing, never mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm with Lupin,‚Äù Mary says, ‚Äúthe quiet ones are always the ones with sharpest teeth.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, piss-off would you?‚Äù James says, now starting to get angry.

‚ÄúBut why not just tell us what he said?‚Äù Peter asks.

‚ÄúPete,‚Äù Remus shoots him a silencing look.

‚ÄúHad to be some death eater nonsense,‚Äù Mary goes on, eyes intently on James, clearly enjoying how uncomfortable this is making him. ‚ÄúLet me guess, he called her a Mudblood?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not Snape,‚Äù James snaps back, and the room suddenly goes quiet. A moment passing where they all seem to be holding their breath.

‚ÄúWell fuck you both,‚Äù Lily says finally, getting to her feet and storming out of the common room.

‚ÄúLily!‚Äù Marlene calls after her, but the redhead doesn‚Äôt turn around. ‚ÄúJesus Mary,‚Äù Marlene hisses when the portrait closes behind her,‚Äúwas that necessary?‚Äù

Mary shrugs, though James doesn‚Äôt quite believe she feels as indifferent about it as she‚Äôs making it seem. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know she was still so touchy about it.‚Äù

Marlene lets out a deep sigh before collapsing onto her back again.

‚ÄúI should go check on her,‚Äù Alice says eventually, patting Frank on the leg as she starts to get to her feet.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James takes a mouthful of his drink before setting it down and getting up himself. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll go.‚Äù

No one looks particularly confident about that plan.

‚ÄúJames, are you sure you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI said it,‚Äù already moving towards the corridor. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll go.‚Äù

¬†

At first he worries he won‚Äôt be able to find her. He doesn‚Äôt have the map, and, truth be told, he has no idea where Lily Evans goes when she‚Äôs upset. Luckily, the corridors are mostly empty, and he only has to wander around for a few minutes before he spots a red head sitting in one of the windows.

‚ÄúGo away please,‚Äù she says wearily, not even bothering to check who it is.

James, predictably, does not go away. Instead he leans against the wall next to the window. ‚ÄúLook, I‚Äôm sorry for bringing him up okay? Mary was just‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúBeing a bitch, yes, I know. She‚Äôs angry.‚Äù

That surprises James, knocking him off course for a second. ‚ÄúAngry?‚Äù

Lily sighs. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs worked really hard to be as good as she is at Quidditch.‚Äù

James blinks, feeling lost. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîokay. I get that, losing sucks.‚Äù

Lily laughs dryly, shaking her head. ‚ÄúShe isn‚Äôt angry about losing.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen what is she‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThis was going to be her game,‚Äù Lily says, with the air of someone who is having to explain something very simple to someone very, very stupid. ‚ÄúFor once, she was the star, she was scoring the goals and you were‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPlaying like shit, yeah, I know.‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes, but doesn‚Äôt look away from the window. ‚ÄúThen all of the sudden you‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚Äîwoke up, stole the show the way you do.
