Now all anyone can talk about is your bloody comeback and all that work she did for the first half of the game is forgotten. So she‚Äôs pissed, but she‚Äôs also Mary, so she can‚Äôt just shout about it like the rest of us. She has to pretend she doesn‚Äôt care. That she‚Äôs above it all. God forbid she actually care about something, it‚Äôd ruin her reputation.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äîokay,‚Äù he fidgets against the wall, unsure of what to do with any of this information. Though he supposes it does help explain why Mary‚Äôs been having a go at him all bloody day. ‚ÄúI guess I don‚Äôt really see how any of that is my fault?‚Äù

Lily sighs, forehead leaning against the glass. ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs just‚Ä¶infuriating.‚Äù

James blinks, looking down at her, long red hair braided down her back, green eyes reflected in the glass ‚ÄúI‚Äôm infuriating?‚Äù he asks.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all infuriating.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is?‚Äù

She shakes her head, finally sitting up straight and looking at him properly, eyes sharp. ‚ÄúAll of it. We‚Äîwe come here at such a disadvantage. We‚Äôve never seen magic before, never even known it existed, and then suddenly we‚Äôre thrown into these classes with people like you who have been here their whole lives and it‚Äôs like we‚Äôre always playing catch-up.‚Äù

James tries to keep up with her. ‚ÄúWhen you says ‚Äòwe‚Äô you mean‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMuggle-borns, yes. Or Mudbloods I guess, the amount that people are throwing that word around these days it might as well be a bloody nickname.‚Äù James flinches, but Lily doesn‚Äôt give him the chance to respond. ‚ÄúMary has to work twice as hard as you do to be on that team. The first time she saw a broom, flew on one, she was eleven, by which time I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôd been flying as long as you‚Äôd been walking,‚Äù which James has to admit, it‚Äôs not an inaccurate statement. ‚ÄúShe can‚Äôt practice when she goes home for the summer, or Christmas, hell she doesn‚Äôt even have her own broom because she can‚Äôt bloody afford it.‚Äù

The words pour out of Lily and James realizes that they‚Äôve been building in her for quite some time.

‚ÄúNone of that is your fault, I understand. You were born a Pureblood, you were born wealthy, you can‚Äôt help it. But sometimes it‚Äôs fucking aggravating. Especially when you walk around acting like we‚Äôre all equals, because we aren‚Äôt. Because we never will be. No one will ever look at you and decide that they can‚Äôt be seen with you anymore because of your fucking blood,‚Äù her voice breaks on that last word and she looks away again. Leaving James shaken.

It feels like a long time that they stay like that, not speaking or moving, neither of them even bothering to make eye contact. Eventually he sits down beside her, elbows on his knees, hands clasped between them.

‚ÄúIt scares me,‚Äù he says finally.

‚ÄúWhat does?‚Äù Lily asks.

He exhales. ‚ÄúHow easy it is, for me to hurt people. Because I can‚Äôt always see it‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt‚ÄîI never thought about how much longer I‚Äôve been flying than Mary, just because of who I am. We don‚Äôt use magic before we turn eleven, before we come here, so I never saw it as an advantage. But you‚Äôre right, of course, I might not have been using it, but I was around it, I understood it.‚Äù

He swallows, running a hand over his face. He can feel Lily‚Äôs eyes on him but he doesn‚Äôt look at her, staring intently at the wall across from him.

‚ÄúSirius hurt Remus,‚Äù he says finally, voice straining.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Lily says, though James is well aware that she can‚Äôt possibly‚Äîat least not really.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so fucking mad at him, you know? But part of me is terrified too. Because Sirius and I, we‚Äôre more similar than we are different. And I don‚Äôt believe for a second that he meant it‚Äîthat he meant to hurt Remus. But he did anyway. Because he didn‚Äôt see it‚Äîsee how this is all different for Remus‚Äîmore fragile. And I‚Äôm scared that I could make that mistake too. That I make it all the time, without even realizing.‚Äù

James still hasn‚Äôt figured out whether it makes it harder or easier to forgive Sirius, being certain that he would never consciously hurt Remus. Does intent matter when the wounds you‚Äôve made are so big?

Eventually he hears Lily groan, shifting so that they sit side by side, backs to the window. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really irritating how difficult you make it to stay angry with you.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúDo you want to be angry with me?‚Äù

Lily pull her mouth to the side, thinking. ‚ÄúSometimes, maybe. Simpler that way, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess.‚Äù

A beat of silence passes before James manages to speak again.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sorry about punching Snape,‚Äù he says, pushing on even when he feels Lily stiffen beside him. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like him, I don‚Äôt think he‚Äôs a good guy, but‚Äîbut I know that I went about things wrong, that day on the lawn. That I ‚Ä¶created a situation that was‚Ä¶volatile. And that you got hurt because of that,‚Äù he turns to her now, their eyes meeting. ‚ÄúThat I am sorry for.‚Äù

There is nothing weak or delicate about Lily Evan‚Äôs stare. It is all fight. She has the type of eyes you go to war with.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she says eventually. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

James nods, and then, after a brief pause, gets back to his feet. ‚ÄúThis mean we‚Äôre friends again?‚Äù he asks, hands in his pockets.

She smiles. ‚ÄúSure Potter, we‚Äôre friends.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù he smiles back. ‚ÄúI missed having you around Evans.‚Äù

And he means it.

¬†

When he gets back to the common room Marlene, Alice and Frank are in the middle of a blow out argument about Quidditch teams. The specifics are hard to work out but James definitely hears the words ‚ÄúChudley Cannons‚Äù followed by ‚Äúno loyalty‚Äù and ‚Äúcouldn‚Äôt catch a Snitch if it bit him in the face.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre really going at it, huh?‚Äù James pulls up next to Mary, who is still perched on the sofa.

She nods, bringing her drink to her lips. ‚ÄúIt would be interesting if they weren‚Äôt all completely wrong.‚Äù

James snorts, watching as a very red faced Marlene gets on her knees, hands gesticulating as she explains why the Chuddley Cannons will never take the cup without a proper Seeker.

‚ÄúHow is she?‚Äù Mary asks eventually, voice pitched low.

James looks over at her but but her eyes are still on the fight below them.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs alright, yeah.‚Äù James realizes then that he doesn‚Äôt really have any idea what the girls‚Äô friendships are like. He assumes they‚Äôre close, but he doesn‚Äôt actually know.

‚ÄúListen, James, about earlier,‚Äù Mary goes on, sounding as though she‚Äôd rather have her teeth pulled than continue this conversation. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean to pry‚Äîwell, actually, I very much did mean to pry, but I probably shouldn‚Äôt have.‚Äù

James waves her words away. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry about it,‚Äù and then; ‚Äúlisten, thanks for‚Äîthanks for picking up the slack today. That game would have been really fucking embarrassing if it hadn‚Äôt been for you.‚Äù

She looks at him out of the corner of her eye, giving him a sharp smile. ‚ÄúOh I know.‚Äù

He snorts. ‚ÄúGood,‚Äù that‚Äôs when he notices that Peter‚Äôs sitting alone, ‚Äútalk to you later yeah?‚Äù he absentmindedly pats Mary‚Äôs shoulder as he maneuvers his way over to the other marauder, crouching down beside him.

‚ÄúGood to see Lily didn‚Äôt dismember you,‚Äù Pete says with a smirk.

‚ÄúO ye of little faith,‚Äù James sing-songs, earning him a low laugh. ‚ÄúHey, where‚Äôs Moony at?‚Äù he watches the tightening of Peter‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîhe went to bed.‚Äù

James‚Äôs eyebrows raise, surprised. ‚ÄúBed? It‚Äôs barely eight?‚Äù

Peter only shrugs, though his mouth has formed a firm line. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what he said.‚Äù

‚ÄúWormtail,‚Äù James pushes, eyes running him over. ‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù

Peter shoots him a sidelong look. ‚ÄúSirius‚Äîcame by.‚Äù

James swears every muscle in his body grows tense at those words. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd he do?‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing,‚Äù Peter shakes his head. ‚ÄúMary told him to sit down, and he said he had homework to do and ran up the stairs. But‚Äîuh‚Äîwell, you know. Moony got pretty quiet after that. And then said he was tired.‚Äù

Is this how it‚Äôs going to be now? James thinks, with an ache in the pit of his stomach. Avoiding each other for the next two years?

‚ÄúI thought about going up to check on him, but‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚Äîit‚Äôs hard to tell with him these days, whether he wants us around or not,‚Äù Peter goes on, driving the blade in a little deeper.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James croaks, slapping him on the back. ‚ÄúYou stay here, I‚Äôll go.‚Äù

Peter looks worried but nods, ‚ÄúLet me know if there‚Äôs anything I can do, yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure Pete,‚Äù James says, sparing their friends a brief look, just enough to confirm they‚Äôre all too engrossed in the debate to notice him leave. And then he slips up the stairs.

The room is dark when he walks in, and for a moment he thinks that maybe Remus really did go to sleep, but then he sees him. Standing by his bed, book in one hand, bottle in the other. He doesn‚Äôt recognize the book‚Äîhe thinks it might be muggle‚Äîbut Remus isn‚Äôt exactly reading it, just, looking.

‚ÄúHey Moons,‚Äù James says softly, leaning against the bedpost opposite him.

Remus doesn‚Äôt look up. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so tired of feeling like this,‚Äù he says quietly, making James‚Äôs heart squeeze.

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

Remus gives the book in his hand one last look before chucking it on his bed and bringing the bottle to his lips, chugging it back.

‚ÄúMerlin, now who needs to slow down?‚Äù James laughs nervously, watching as Remus wipes his mouth on the back of his hand.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs supposed to help right?‚Äù he squeezes his eyes shut. ‚ÄúI just need something to make it‚ÄîI just need something to make it stop.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù James says softly.

Remus‚Äôs eyes open, bright in the shine from the moon outside. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what you were trying to do earlier, right?‚Äù

James blinks, taking in the slightly unstable posture of his friend. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîdon‚Äôt know what you mean.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou were trying to forget him.‚Äù

Something slightly uneasy flutters through James‚Äôs stomach. ‚ÄúForget who, mate?‚Äù

Remus stares at him long and hard for a moment before exhaling. ‚ÄúNothing. No one. Never mind.‚Äù He holds out the bottle to James who takes it without thinking. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to bed,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt bother with his clothes, just shucks off his shoes before crawling onto his mattress.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll get easier you know,‚Äù James says helplessly. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll figure it out.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think?‚Äù Remus says skeptically, then he squeezes his eyes shut again, pressing his face into his pillows. ‚ÄúYou want to know what the worst part is?‚Äù words muffled by the bed.

No, James thinks, isn‚Äôt this bad enough? ‚ÄúSure Moons,‚Äù he says instead.

‚ÄúSometimes I don‚Äôt even care‚Äîdon‚Äôt care what he‚Äôs done, don‚Äôt care that it was wrong. Sometimes I think I‚Äôd let him do anything he wanted to me just as long as I still got to be around him. As long as he was still mine sometimes.‚Äù

Those words burn all the way down. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù is all James says, all that he has left.

‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs sorry,‚Äù Remus mutters. ‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs always sorry and none of it ever makes a difference. I fucking hate that word,‚Äù his voice is heavy and slow, eyes still shut. It‚Äôs clear that sleep is sneaking up on him.

James sighs, moving back towards the door when Remus stops him. ‚ÄúNo don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú his voice calls out and James looks back to see him curled on his side, eyes wide open. ‚ÄúStay‚Äîcan you stay, just for a few minutes?‚Äù He sounds so small.

‚ÄúCourse Moony,‚Äù James gives him a weak smile he isn‚Äôt sure he can see, ‚Äúalways.‚Äù

He puts the bottle down on his bedside table before lying on his own bed, face towards the ceiling. ‚ÄúI know you don‚Äôt believe me,‚Äù he says after a few minutes, voice soft. He‚Äôs not sure how much Remus is listening. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm going find us a way out of this. I don‚Äôt know what it is yet, but it won‚Äôt be like this forever, okay? I won‚Äôt let it be.‚Äù

He waits for a few moments before turning his head, finding Remus‚Äôs eyes closed.

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

Finally, we get some Jegulus in this Jegulus fic!

Also, so many scenes in this chapter were just completely rewritten, like originally that bit in the supply room involved a lot more kissing and the chapter ended with James drunk and Remus comforting him, it was truly a wild ride.

I am so glad that people care about this fic because I care about this fic so thanks as always for your comments, love to know what you think!

Chapter 17

Chapter Summary

Summer '76 babyyyyy

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

James spent the last night before summer holidays with Regulus. They laid on their backs, Regulus‚Äôs fingers tracing the lines of his palm and the veins of his arm, causing every inch of his skin to tingle and spark to life. Over sensitive under Regulus‚Äôs barely-there touches. They talked a little, they kissed a lot, Regulus had that faraway look in his eyes‚Äîlike he was already back in London. Already trying to close off parts of himself. James tried not to notice. Not to let it hurt. But, of course, it did anyway.

It was late when he finally said it, not sure why he had waited so long; ‚ÄúI have something for you.‚Äù

He pulled out a stack of letters, eight to be precise, one for every week of summer.

‚ÄúI thought about writing one for every day,‚Äù he laughed, rubbing the back of his neck. ‚ÄúBut it seemed excessive.‚Äù

Regulus stared at the envelopes in his hands, running them over, like he couldn‚Äôt quite believe they were real. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I understand‚Ä¶‚Äù he said finally.

‚ÄúWell I know‚ÄîI know I can‚Äôt send you post, over the summer, so, I thought I‚Äôd give them to you now.‚Äù

Regulus blinked up him. ‚ÄúGive them to me now?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre all dated,‚Äù James went on, ‚Äúso you can read them like I‚Äôm sending them to you in real time. I just thought‚Ä¶‚Äù he trailed off, shrugging. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want you to be alone all summer,‚Äù after another long pause he dropped his eyes, more nervous laughter. ‚ÄúMaybe that‚Äôs dumb‚Äîactually‚Äînow that I‚Äôm saying it out loud it‚Äôs definitely dumb. Sorry, you don‚Äôt have to‚Äî‚Äú

Regulus kissed him then. It had been a big kiss‚Äîfull of feelings and words and desperation. All James could do was take it. Was hold him.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Regulus said, when they finally came up for air. ‚ÄúI love them. I love you.‚Äù

¬†

Several weeks later, lying on his bed in his childhood home, James runs over that memory for the hundredth time. The way it had felt to hear Regulus say those words again‚Äîwithout needing to be forced or asked. Like they came naturally to him. He closes his eyes and tries to imagine the feel of the other boy‚Äôs lips, the weight of him in his hands. He doesn‚Äôt know if Regulus is okay, if he‚Äôs read any of the letters, if he‚Äôs thinking about James the way James is thinking about him. Constantly. Incessantly. He feels raw with all the things he doesn‚Äôt know.

‚ÄúJAMES!‚Äù his mother shouts, even though there are a dozen spells and a house elf who all could have communicated with him more efficiently, ‚ÄúBREAKFAST.‚Äù

James slides out of bed, already dressed but reluctant to leave his room. Sirius hasn‚Äôt tried to talk to him since they‚Äôve been here, but that doesn‚Äôt mean it isn‚Äôt still incredibly uncomfortable to be in the same room as him. Part of James, the petty childish part, is mad at Sirius for not trying harder. He should be bending over backwards to make this right. He should be begging for James‚Äôs forgiveness. For Remus‚Äôs. For Peter‚Äôs. Instead, he‚Äôs just gone silent, keeping his eyes down and his face hidden behind a curtain of dark hair. Like he‚Äôs trying to disappear.

James drops into his chair at the kitchen table, Sirius in the seat across from him, eyes trained on his breakfast. It‚Äôs bright out, has been almost every day this week, skies clear and sun fat in the sky. It‚Äôs aggravating, since James is not feeling particularly sunny at the moment.

‚ÄúWell look who it is, risen from the dead,‚Äù his mother chirps as she drops a plate of eggs and toast in front of him, giving his head a quick kiss. ‚ÄúHave you boys got any plans for today?‚Äù she sweeps around the kitchen, brewing coffee with the twirl of one hand and sending dishes into the sink with the brush of another.

Though he wouldn‚Äôt have thought it possible, he thinks he sees Sirius curl further in on himself. His mother insists on acting as though everything is fine‚Äîas though they‚Äôll wake up one morning and it‚Äôll all be forgotten. Like Sirius didn‚Äôt fucking betray each and every one of them.
‚ÄúGoing to Remus‚Äôs,‚Äù he says tersely, shoving eggs into his mouth like they‚Äôve personally offended him.

‚ÄúBoth of you?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

He glares across the table at Sirius, daring him to say something, but he just keeps staring at his plate, barely touching his food.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you think‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMum,‚Äù he cuts her off, ‚Äúleave it.‚Äù

He meets her gaze, her stare not nearly as lighthearted and carefree as her tone would suggest. After a few moments of intense eye contact she sighs. ‚ÄúWhen will you be back?‚Äù

James shrugs, barely tasting the food he‚Äôs eating, just desperate to finish and get away from this table and out of this house. He‚Äôs spent nearly every day this summer at Remus‚Äôs, which James knows Remus hates but there‚Äôs nothing to be done for it. They can‚Äôt hang out at Pete‚Äôs‚Äîhis mother is really weird about having people in her house, as in, she hates it and they‚Äôre not allowed. And they can‚Äôt come here for obvious reasons, so the Lupin‚Äôs is their only option.

James actually quite likes Remus‚Äôs house‚Äîa small farm in the Welsh countryside. James has always thought it a crime that Remus hasn‚Äôt got an accent but he claims he doesn‚Äôt actually speak to any Welsh people, and since neither of his parents are from there originally he‚Äôs never picked it up.

James wipes his mouth on the back of his hand before standing and dumping his plate in the sink.

‚ÄúMerlin James, where‚Äôs the fire?‚Äù his mum laughs.

‚ÄúGotta catch the Portkey,‚Äù he says blandly, kissing her quickly on the cheek and not sparing Sirius a single glance.

He slips on his trainers at the front door before pushing outside, not even bothering to do up his laces. Instantly he feels lighter, even as the early August heat sticks to his skin. Lately that house is full of all the things he can‚Äôt fix‚Äîpromises he hasn‚Äôt kept. He told Remus it wouldn‚Äôt always be like this and he meant it. He just hasn‚Äôt quite figured out how yet.

There are a couple Portkeys set up in the area, leaving at designated times throughout the day. It‚Äôs not a terrible way to travel but it‚Äôs also not the most convenient. The Portkey only gets him to Wales and then he has to take a muggle bus to Remus‚Äôs. He‚Äôs become quite familiar with muggle transportation this summer. Far more familiar than he ever wanted to be, if he‚Äôs being honest. Not that he‚Äôd never used it before of course, his mum used to take him into London when he was little, before Hogwarts. Day trips to the museums and parks and things, so he‚Äôd ridden the tube a few times. But public transport in a major city and public transport in the middle-of-nowhere-Wales, are two very different experiences, James has come to learn.

The bus takes ages, of course, and then there‚Äôs still another twenty minute walk from the road to Remus‚Äôs front door. By the time he gets there James is drenched in sweat and the day is half-gone.

‚ÄúOh, hello James,‚Äù Hope opens the door for him. ‚ÄúYou look knackered, come in, come in,‚Äù she waves him inside. ‚ÄúCan I get you anything? Lemonade?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, please, that would be brilliant,‚Äù he tries not to sound too desperate, but she smiles at him like she knows.

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Remus?‚Äù he asks, following her into the kitchen. James is completely obsessed with the Lupin‚Äôs kitchen. It‚Äôs full of muggle appliances he‚Äôs never seen before. Like a fridge‚Äîwhich apparently keeps things cold no matter what the temperature is outside?! James has asked Remus multiple times but he swears it isn‚Äôt magic. There‚Äôs also a microwave that instantly heats up your food‚Äîalso, allegedly, not magic‚Äîand an iron that makes waffles. Brilliant, James thinks, all of it.

‚ÄúRemus is out back,‚Äù Hope smiles as she hands him a cold glass of lemonade that he proceeds to gulp down likes he‚Äôs just spent a week in the desert. Hope arches her brow, smiling in a way that looks so much like Remus it‚Äôs almost scary.

‚ÄúAnother?‚Äù she asks.

James chews on his bottom lip like he‚Äôs actually considering saying no. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt mind?‚Äù

She laughs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind,‚Äù Hope Lupin, James has learned this summer, is infinitely more relaxed when a) her husband isn‚Äôt home and b) she isn‚Äôt surrounded by Wizards. Well, adult wizards anyway. She doesn‚Äôt seem to mind James and Peter so much, but the one time his mother came to apparate him home he noticed her getting jumpy again. James doesn‚Äôt think it‚Äôs prejudice or anything. It feels more like fear.

He can‚Äôt imagine what that must be like. To be married to someone you‚Äôre afraid of. To have a son you‚Äôre afraid of. He knows Remus feels it, the constant humming of fear beneath his mother‚Äôs skin. Like she‚Äôs expecting to be attacked. Though he imagines some of that is Fenrir‚Äôs fault.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been so nice having you boys over so much this summer,‚Äù she says as she returns his refilled glass. ‚ÄúUsually we barely get to see Rem, he‚Äôs at your place so much.‚Äù

James smiles, nodding noncommittally.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame Sirius hasn‚Äôt been able to join you, but then, it‚Äôs good for a teenage boy to have a summer job. I always worked in the summers, at my father‚Äôs shop.‚Äù

James freezes mid-swallow. ‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú he chokes back the last of his lemonade, looking uncertainly at Hope. ‚ÄúSorry? What was that about Sirius?‚Äù

‚ÄúHis job, at the Quidditch shop in Diagonal Alley or whatever it‚Äôs called. Remus told me that‚Äôs why he hasn‚Äôt been around this summer.‚Äù

She‚Äôs still smiling at him, though it feels a little forced, and James suddenly has the intense desire to get out of this kitchen.

‚ÄúRight, yeah‚Äîyeah, no that‚Äôs‚Ä¶true. Definitely true. He‚Äôs been really busy. At his‚Ä¶job.‚Äù he rubs nervously at the back of his neck, trying to understand why Remus would lie about that. ‚ÄúWell, I should,‚Äù he nods towards the back door.

‚ÄúOf course, let me know if you need anything. Plenty more lemonade and snacks. Feel free to help yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight, thanks,‚Äù James says, before quickly turning around and bolting out of the house.

The Lupin‚Äôs garden is just an untended field. It might have grown crops at some point, but now it mostly grows wildflowers and weeds. James cuts his way through it, sun beating down, eyes peeled for a sandy blond head. Eventually he spots it, under the only tree for a mile, right at the edge of the property.

‚ÄúCould you have gone any further, Jesus Christ,‚Äù he wheezes when he finally makes it up to him.

Remus is leaning against the trunk, dark shades pushed up into his hair, book in his lap. The bastard barely even looks up.

‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm any closer to the house she comes out every five minutes to check on me,‚Äù he says flatly, James collapsing onto the ground in a sweaty heap. ‚ÄúMind you, I don‚Äôt know what she‚Äôs so worried about. I‚Äôve already been bitten by a werewolf.‚Äù

James lets out a bark of laughter. ‚ÄúJeez, in a real chipper mood today aren‚Äôt we?‚Äù

Remus just shrugs, going back to his book as James tries to catch his breath.

‚ÄúSpeaking of your mum,‚Äù he says eventually, pushing himself up onto his elbows so he can look at his friend properly. ‚ÄúWhy did you tell her that Sirius has a summer job?‚Äù

Remus groans, letting his head fall back against the trunk behind him. ‚ÄúBecause she wouldn‚Äôt stop asking why he hasn‚Äôt been over.‚Äù

James feels like he‚Äôs missed something. ‚ÄúSurely she knows why? She was was there in Dumbledore‚Äôs office.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, but as far as she‚Äôs concerned that never happened.‚Äù

James blinks. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Remus nods, running a hand over his flushed face. ‚ÄúYou know how she is. Something bad happens and she just sort of‚Äîdecides that it didn‚Äôt. Him not hanging around was ruining the illusion for her, so she kept asking until I gave her a lie that would make her feel better.‚Äù

James can feel his eyes widen. ‚ÄúJesus,‚Äù he hisses.

‚ÄúYup.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize she was so invested in your friendship.‚Äù

Remus grimaces. ‚ÄúShe isn‚Äôt really, it‚Äôs‚Äîit‚Äôs not about him. It‚Äôs about me. She‚Äî‚Äú Remus struggles for a moment, dropping his book onto the ground beside him and leaning forward, arms balanced on his knees. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs worried that I‚Äôm going to end up alone, just, in general, in life,‚Äù he laughs dryly, kicking at the ground, ‚ÄúWerewolves don‚Äôt have friends. Lonely, pitiful creatures,‚Äù he goes on bitterly, and James feels his blood run cold, realizing that Remus is repeating things his parents have actually said to him.

‚ÄúMy dad‚Äôs told her that my life is doomed to be pretty fucking miserable,‚Äù he goes on, shooting James a wry look. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs worried that this thing with Sirius is the start of that.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe start of what?‚Äù James demands, trying to sort through the various levels of anger currently boiling under his skin.

‚ÄúMe losing friends because of my‚Ä¶condition.‚Äù

‚ÄúBullshit.‚Äù

Remus just shrugs, falling back against the tree again. ‚ÄúMakes her feel better, thinking he‚Äôs just busy.‚Äù

Jame stares at him for a moment, before reaching forward and jabbing him in the side with his finger.

‚ÄúOw, James, what the hell?‚Äù

‚ÄúStop it.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs eyes narrow. ‚ÄúStop what?‚Äù

James gestures to him with his hand. ‚ÄúBeing so melancholic. We‚Äôre not going anywhere.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah okay, still don‚Äôt see why the violence was necessary.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù James repeats. ‚ÄúI mean it. You‚Äôre not going to be alone. Not ever. And you‚Äôre about the least pitiful person I know, so that‚Äôs out too.‚Äù

They‚Äôre staring at one another, and James sees the small crack in Remus‚Äôs sarcastic exterior.

‚ÄúLeast pitiful person, huh?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúDefinitely. Marlene‚Äôs a close second though.‚Äù

He snorts, pausing for a minute before taking a deep breath. ‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù he says, and James tries to pretend he doesn‚Äôt hear the shake in his voice.

He nods, collapsing onto his back again, looking up at the tree branches above them. ‚ÄúYour family‚Äôs pretty fucked up, huh?‚Äù

That gets a proper big laugh out of Remus, the noise swallowed by the never ending fields surrounding them. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah a bit.‚Äù

In the ensuing silence James can hear the sound of the breeze blowing through the tall grass, but doesn‚Äôt feel any of it on his skin, his body slowly overheating. He was not made for the heat. Or for Muggle public transportation.

‚ÄúHow is he?‚Äù Remus asks eventually, sounding resigned.

James cringes, in no doubt about who ‚Äúhe‚Äù is. ‚ÄúMiserable.‚Äù

Remus snorts. ‚ÄúI feel like that‚Äôs supposed to make me feel better but it doesn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James nods, even though he‚Äôs not sure that Remus can see, ‚Äútell me about it.‚Äù

Another brief pause.

‚ÄúLook, James, if you want to forgive him‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNot a chance,‚Äù and then, turning his head to look up at his friend. ‚ÄúUnless you want to‚Ä¶?‚Äù

Remus sighs, closing his eyes. ‚ÄúWant to? Absolutely. Can I? Fuck, I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

And oh, does James ever feel that right down in the pit of his stomach. He misses Sirius, desperately, almost more so now that their home, without anything else to distract him. Since he was eleven all he‚Äôs wanted is for Sirius to live with him, and now he does and they‚Äôre not even speaking.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll figure it out,‚Äù he says eventually, which seems to be all he says these days. They‚Äôve pulled off elaborate pranks, figured out how to make a map that tracks everyone in the castle, turned themselves into animagi. Surely they can work their way through this too?

He can feel Remus looking at him. He does that a lot these days, like he‚Äôs trying to figure James out. Like something is bothering him. James keeps waiting for Remus to bring it up but he never does. Which James supposes shouldn‚Äôt be a surprise.

He exhales. ‚ÄúMoony?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre staring.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm not.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes, propping himself up on his elbows again. ‚ÄúYou were.‚Äù

Remus looks at him and then away, gaze running over the field in front of them, James can‚Äôt tell if the flush on the tops of his cheeks is from the sun or from being caught.

‚ÄúSomething you wanna ask me?‚Äù

Remus lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúNothing you want to answer.‚Äù

That catches James‚Äôs interest. ‚ÄúTry me.‚Äù

He watches Remus chew his bottom lip, hands fidgeting in his lap as he keeps looking out at the field instead of back at James.

‚ÄúSirius told me you‚Äôre seeing a bloke,‚Äù he says finally. Bluntly. So bluntly, in fact, that it takes James a minute or two to catch up.

‚ÄúI‚Äîhe,‚Äù he shakes his head, sitting up properly and staring at his friend who still isn‚Äôt looking at him. ‚ÄúWhen did you talk to Sirius?‚Äù

Remus looks down. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, few weeks after it happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt?‚Äù

He rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou know what I mean.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know you were talking to him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt‚ÄîI‚Äôm not,‚Äù Remus has started pulling up the grass beside him. Nervous habit.

‚ÄúWell clearly you are,‚Äù James isn‚Äôt entirely sure why he‚Äôs so peeved by this, maybe just because it feels like a secret, something that‚Äôs been kept from him on purpose. Or maybe it‚Äôs because he‚Äôs so desperate to talk to Sirius himself.

Remus sighs, scrubbing at his face with his hands. ‚ÄúIt was only once okay? Is that really what‚Äôs important here?‚Äù

James just stares at him for a minute, t-shirt two sizes too big, ratty jean cut-offs he definitely made himself. Remus Lupin in his natural habitat. The unhappiness is oozing out of him.

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù James says eventually, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúFine, okay, so he told you. I reckon you don‚Äôt have a problem with it?‚Äù

Another dry laugh. ‚ÄúNo, I don‚Äôt have a problem with it,‚Äù but it‚Äôs clear there‚Äôs more, James can feel it, feel the weight of it hanging in the silence between them. Finally, Remus looks back at him. ‚ÄúIs it Regulus Black?‚Äù

He wishes he was better at controlling his face. Wishes he couldn‚Äôt feel his eyes widen or his mouth drop open. He is eventually able to school his features into something resembling neutral but by then it's too late. Remus has seen.

‚ÄúJesus fuck James,‚Äù Remus hangs his head between his knees like he‚Äôs going to be sick and James thinks he might join him. Despite being in the middle of a field James suddenly feels claustrophobic‚Äîtrapped.

‚ÄúHow do you know‚Äîdid Sirius‚Äî‚Äú

Remus laughs, though the noise isn‚Äôt quite pleasant. ‚ÄúYou think if Sirius knew either of you would still be breathing?‚Äù

James flinches. Not that he didn‚Äôt know that already but it feels worse having someone else say it out loud.

‚ÄúI saw you, on the map, saw you together in the middle of the night,‚Äù Remus goes on, sounding weary. ‚ÄúPut two and two together, though Merlin I really wanted to be wrong.‚Äù

James swallows, throat tight, he‚Äôs not sure what to say. How to explain‚Äîwhat to explain. It‚Äôs all a bit of a mess really. Apparently Remus feels similarly because for too long they stay frozen, neither of them looking, or speaking, or moving. The heat is getting too much for James.

‚ÄúHow long?‚Äù Remus asks eventually.

‚ÄúLast fall.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Remus hisses. ‚ÄúWhat the fuck James? What are you doing? What are you thinking? After everything‚Äîafter what they did to Sirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt Regulus,‚Äù James snaps, anger flaring in his chest, which is better than whatever sad ache he‚Äôd been feeling before, so he‚Äôll take it, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs trapped there just like Sirius was.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo he isn‚Äôt, you know he isn‚Äôt. Sirius has been trying to get out of that house since he was eleven bloody years old. I mean, he got sorted into Gryffindor for Merlin‚Äôs sake. From where I‚Äôm sitting Regulus looks pretty fucking comfortable.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have no idea what you‚Äôre talking about,‚Äù James can hear himself getting louder, and is suddenly very grateful to be out in the middle of nowhere, away from everyone. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs fucking terrified. Did you know that Walburga uses Legilimency on them?‚Äù and judging by the look of horror that flashes across Remus‚Äôs face James is going to assume he didn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre all in his head, fucking him up, making him burry himself. So don‚Äôt sit there and act like it‚Äôs just as easy as walking away, because it isn‚Äôt.‚Äù

There‚Äôs something new in Remus‚Äôs gaze now‚Äîsomething softer. Pity, James thinks. It doesn‚Äôt make him feel much better.

‚ÄúBut is he trying?‚Äù Remus asks softly.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù something scratches at the inside of his chest.

‚ÄúI‚ÄîJesus James, I get it, okay? I was there too, yeah? All those times Sirius showed back up to school looking like he‚Äôd had the fucking life beaten out of him. I know it‚Äôs not easy. None of this is easy. But Sirius has always tried. Regulus walks around like he‚Äôs one of them. He takes the protection it gives him. The privilege,‚Äù Remus pinches the bridge of his nose while James just stares at him, the scratching in his chest growing violent.

‚ÄúMaybe he doesn‚Äôt agree with what his friends are doing, I don‚Äôt know. But he isn‚Äôt stopping them. Didn‚Äôt stop them from hurting his brother. I‚Äîis that okay with you? Can you get past that? Because to be honest James, I‚Äôm having a bloody hard time understanding how.‚Äù

James wants to scream, an unbearable pressure building behind his lungs. He shakes his head, closing his eyes, trying to get his thoughts in order. He can see Regulus in the supply room, eyes wide and earnest.

You‚Äôre my person.

You‚Äôre mine.

‚ÄúWhere is he supposed to go Remus?‚Äù he asks finally, barely able to get the words out. ‚ÄúSirius had us. Regulus has no one.‚Äù

When Remus doesn‚Äôt speak James forces himself to open his eyes again, finding his friend‚Äôs gaze focused on him.

‚ÄúHe has you now, doesn‚Äôt he?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúIn the dark. In secret. Doesn‚Äôt exactly inspire confidence, does it?‚Äù

Remus takes that in, leaning his head back against the tree again and looking up at the branches above. ‚ÄúThat your idea or his?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù James answers, not sure if it‚Äôs a lie or not. Then, after a few seconds, he sighs, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs more scared than I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúMakes sense, don‚Äôt expect his lot will be particularly accepting.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James says flatly. ‚ÄúI need time, to make him see‚Äîmake him understand that I‚Äôm not going anywhere. That he can trust me,‚Äù he takes in a shaky breath, trying to ignore the sting that confession causes. Because he can see it, in Regulus‚Äôs hesitancy, in the way that he still pulls away, that there is a part of him that doesn‚Äôt trust that James will be there when he needs him.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to get him out of there, Remus,‚Äù he says.

Remus looks back over at him, expression unreadable, ‚ÄúIf anyone could it‚Äôd be you,‚Äù he says quietly, almost more to himself than to James. And then, louder; ‚ÄúJust‚Äî‚Äú he bites his lower lip, the pity making a reappearance, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt wear yourself out trying to save someone who doesn‚Äôt want to be saved, okay?‚Äù

He breathes through the ache that causes. ‚ÄúHe wants to be Moons, really,‚Äù James hopes that that‚Äôs true. He‚Äôs almost certain it is. Almost.

His friend only nods. ‚ÄúYou planning on telling Padfoot about this at some point?‚Äù

James lets out a huff, collapsing onto his back again. ‚ÄúBefore? Maybe. Now? No. Lets just‚Äîone problem at a time, yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus answers distantly, and James tries to ignore the skepticism in his voice.

¬†

It‚Äôs nearly dinner by the time James gets home. He missed the bus, and the next one took ages. How Muggles get anywhere on time he has no idea. Right now he just wants to go upstairs and lie down. Maybe take a shower. He‚Äôs covered in sweat and dirt from sitting on the ground all afternoon.

‚ÄúJames, hun, that you?‚Äù his Mother calls from his father‚Äôs office.

James groans internally, heading grumpily down the hall. ‚ÄúYeah, you need something?‚Äù he asks as he swings into the room, not moving far beyond the door.

His mother snorts. ‚ÄúHello to you too.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm just tired.‚Äù

She‚Äôs sitting at his father‚Äôs desk‚Äîa giant, wooden monstrosity, that reminds James far too much of Dumbledore‚Äôs office.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôs Remus?‚Äù his mother asks pleasantly.

‚ÄúFine.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood, I haven‚Äôt seen him much recently.‚Äù

Jeez, what is it with mother‚Äôs and not being able to take a hint?

‚ÄúI wonder why that is,‚Äù he responds flatly.

‚ÄúYou can be angry without being snotty you know,‚Äù she says, eyebrow arched.

James sighs, running a hand through his sweaty hair. ‚ÄúThanks for the tip. Did you call me in here just to lecture me about my attitude or is there something else you want?‚Äù

‚ÄúWow, you really are in a mood aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI hate the bus.‚Äù

That gets a laugh out of her, big and bright, enough that it pulls the corners of James‚Äôs mouth up.

‚ÄúFair enough I suppose,‚Äù and then she pushes something forward across the desk.

James squints at it, stepping closer. ‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúA letter,‚Äù she says simply. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs address to you, it came by Muggle post.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he scrunches his face, looking back at her.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she smiles, ‚ÄúI was rather surprised too‚Äîso was the mailman, now that I think about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúMailman?‚Äù

She waves his question away. ‚ÄúMuggle owl.‚Äù

‚ÄúInstead of owls Muggles use men? That sounds bloody inefficient. Almost as inefficient as their stupid buses that only come once a stupid hour.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she says, biting back a smile, ‚Äúfocus.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh‚Äîright,‚Äù he picks up the white envelope, with its funny little picture in the corner, and neat handwriting spelling out his name and address. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs it from?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, there‚Äôs no return address.‚Äù

‚ÄúReturn‚Äîwhat?‚Äù

His mother laughs again. ‚ÄúNever mind. I had to run some spells on it, make sure it was safe. Technically I‚Äôm supposed to give anything odd to Moody to check out but‚Ä¶‚Äù something twinkles in the corner of her eyes that James doesn‚Äôt quite understand. A joke he‚Äôs missed. ‚ÄúI feel confident it‚Äôs safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Äîokay, cheers,‚Äù he starts to open it and his mother quickly gets up.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll leave you to it shall I?‚Äù she says lightly, planting a kiss on the top of his head as she breezes past.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you want to know who it‚Äôs from?‚Äù he asks, confused as he watches his mother head for the door.

‚ÄúOh I have my suspicions, though feel free to confirm them for me later if you like.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait mum‚Äî‚Äú she pauses, turning back to him. ‚ÄúIs Sirius here?‚Äù

She shakes her head. ‚ÄúGone into town, to the shops. That‚Äôs what he said anyway,‚Äù she smiles sadly. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what he does most days.‚Äù

James nods, suddenly not sure why he asked, he‚Äôs just‚Ä¶used to knowing. ‚ÄúThanks.‚Äù

She gives him one last smile before closing the door, leaving James alone in his father‚Äôs office, arguably his least favourite room in the house. He‚Äôs only ever called in here when he‚Äôs in trouble. It‚Äôs a dark space, wooden floors and walls, never ending bookcases, an overly ornate fireplace. All rather suffocating if you ask James.

Slowly, his attentions drags back to the letter in his hands and he drops into the chair his mother just left, sliding his finger under the seal and pulling out the pages inside.

Hi.

James pauses, squinting at the word, the curving script, recognition slowly dawning on him.

Don‚Äôt ask me what I‚Äôm thinking,

The letter goes on.

I‚Äôve spent too much time with you, clearly, all my common sense has gone out the window.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù the word comes out of James on his next exhale, chest aching as he hears the words so clearly in Regulus‚Äôs voice. He hadn‚Äôt been ready for this.

I can‚Äôt send you post via owl but I thought‚Äîwell‚Äîit‚Äôs not as though my mother is checking the Muggle mail. I don‚Äôt think so anyway. I suppose we‚Äôll find out. I‚Äôm not even sure this will get to you. Bertha, she works at the postoffice here, tried to explain to me how it all works‚ÄîMuggle mail, I mean‚Äîsounds like a dreadful system if you ask me, but she double checked that I addressed this correctly so maybe there‚Äôs a chance it‚Äôll make it to you anyway. I hope it makes it to you.

I‚Äôm in Scotland, at the summer house. It's good to get out of the city, and I can fly here which is‚Äîwhich helps. My dad loves it, he grew up in the country and mostly just tolerates London for my mother‚Äôs sake. He spends most of his days out in the back garden watching me fly. It makes him happy, though I‚Äôve no idea why. Still, I‚Äôll do anything at this point. He‚Äôs worse than he was at Christmas. The Healers don‚Äôt expect him to last much longer, but then, they‚Äôre always saying that.

Sorry, I‚Äôm rambling. I‚Äôd start over, but I‚Äôve already done this three times and I have to go home soon. I‚Äôve been reading your letters. See, this is where I always get stuck. It‚Äôs the reason for the rambling at the top. Because I‚Äôve been reading your letters, that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm writing this ridiculous letter and sending it in the ridiculous Muggle post. Because every time I read them I just‚ÄîI just want to talk to you. I miss talking to you. I miss your voice. I miss the way you laugh. I miss your atrocious hair. I miss. I miss. I miss. That‚Äôs all I do these days.

Well, that and go to the gallery. I‚Äôve visited Patroclus and Achilles a few times, told them you say hi. God, sorry, that was awful, I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm saying. Look, all I meant to say really, is that the letters are beautiful. Your letters are beautiful. And I wish that I could‚Äîthat I could be what you are, to me. I know I‚Äôm not very good at this. But I want to be. For you.

Anyway, this is enough embarrassment for one letter. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll try this again. But I hope that you‚Äôre happy, whatever you‚Äôre doing, whoever you‚Äôre with.

Yours, always.

¬†

James rereads those last two words a few times. To anyone else it would be a half finished sign-off. But James understands.

You‚Äôre my person. You‚Äôre mine.

Okay Reg, yeah, I‚Äôm yours. You‚Äôre mine too.

He traces them with his finger a few times, imagining Regulus sitting in some Muggle postoffice in Scotland penning them out.

Yours.

Yours.

Always.

He takes in a deep breath and fights the urge to find the closest Portkey to Scotland. Not that he‚Äôd have any real idea where he was going, Regulus never mentions specifics. His eyes flick across the page again. Once. Twice. Greedy for every word. Every sentence. Every piece of Regulus he can squeeze out of it.

I miss.

I miss.

I miss.

Me too, James thinks, God me too. He tries to remember if he thought to put that in his letters. But he must have. He misses Regulus the minute he walks away.

¬†

The next morning, like every morning, James finds himself sitting silently across from his best friend. Both of them working overtime not to look or speak to one another‚Äîor indicate that they are, in any way, aware of the other‚Äôs existence. Euphemia attempts to engage them in conversation a few times before giving up and going back to her work, parchment spread out in front of her as she ladles marmalade onto her toast. James asks her what the papers are for but she‚Äôs cagey with her answers. She always is these days.

When the owls arrive it‚Äôs a welcomed break from the tension. Well, until James realizes what they‚Äôre delivering.

‚ÄúYour school lists already?‚Äù his mum says, peering over his shoulder.

The letters is pretty standard, all his books and supplies for next term neatly laid out and‚Äî

‚ÄúOh, James,‚Äù his mother beams as he holds up the Quidditch Captain badge. He allows himself a brief look across the table but Sirius is staring with an odd intensity at the parchment in his hands.

‚ÄúYour father is going to be over the moon,‚Äù his mum goes on, getting up to grab a mug for her coffee.

James only nods. It‚Äôs bitter sweet really. I mean, it‚Äôs what he‚Äôs always wanted, but Sirius won‚Äôt be there. Or Alice or Frank. The loss of them makes it all a bit more‚Ä¶hollow. He passes the badge through his fingers a few times before turning back to the letter. Realizing, suddenly, that there‚Äôs another page hidden behind the first.

Dear Mr. Potter,

It reads.

As you are aware, Frank Longbottom graduated last year, leaving your dorm with an empty bed and Sirius Black without a room. It would be possible to place him in another room but that would require you to accept a new roommate. Since you were the one who first suggested his removal, and since some time has passed since the inciting incident, I thought it prudent to verify that it is still your wish not to room with Sirius Black.

Please discuss this with Mr. Lupin and respond to me quickly with your decision.

Sincerely,

Minerva McGonagall

He forgot about this. About what it means that Frank is gone. He had always been a temporary fix, a stall, putting off the inevitable of having to deal with Sirius. James scans the letter a few more times but doesn‚Äôt come up with any solutions. Part of him never wants to share a room with Sirius again. The other part is desperate to have things go back to the way they were.

Of course, it isn‚Äôt about him. It‚Äôll all come down to what Remus wants. Maybe he‚Äôll go back there later today and‚Äî

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs voice cuts through the kitchen with such urgency that James forgets he‚Äôs supposed to be ignoring him, looking up just as his mother reaches Sirius‚Äôs side.

‚ÄúWhat is it love?‚Äù she asks, he passes her the parchment in his hands, wide-eyed and pale. It‚Äôs only then that James realizes that Sirius‚Äôs Hogwarts letter is still lying unopened on the table.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand why‚Äîthat can‚Äôt be right, I must be‚Äîbecause why would he do that?‚Äù his voice is small and shaking and James has the irritating urge to reach out and squeeze his arm. He doesn‚Äôt, of course, he just keeps staring, eyes bouncing between Sirius‚Äôs face and his mother‚Äôs.

‚ÄúOh Sirius,‚Äù his mother says softly, eyes flicking over the page in front of her, hand falling on his shoulder.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a mistake right? They‚Äôve made a mistake?‚Äù

His mother chews her bottom lip. ‚ÄúNo, I don‚Äôt think so. It all seems to be rather legitimate.‚Äù

It‚Äôs hard for James to work out what emotion is playing across Sirius‚Äôs face‚Äîpain, disbelief, awe‚Äîhe can‚Äôt take it. He breaks.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on?‚Äù he asks, bringing both of the heads across from him snapping in his direction.

‚ÄúHis Uncle Alphard,‚Äù Euphemia says softly, ‚Äúhe seems to have changed his will not long before he died and left everything to Sirius.‚Äù

James‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúEverything?‚Äù

Sirius sinks down in his chair, face pale. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why he did that, I don‚Äôt‚ÄîI barely knew him.‚Äù His voice is thick and he coughs like he can get the feelings out of it.

James watches his mother squeeze Sirius‚Äôs shoulder again, thumb making comforting circles. ‚ÄúClearly you were very important to him.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs breath hitches, eyes somewhere on the floor, not looking at either of them. James remembers the look on his face, the first time he mentioned his uncle, remembers the care he always took with the letters he sent him. Sirius may have barely known Alphard, but knowing him at all had meant a lot to him. Sirius could be glib about his family, but however awful they were, walking away from them had still cost Sirius something. Not because he missed Grimmauld Place or Walburga, but because he missed belonging. However much the Potter‚Äôs embraced him, he would always be a Black. An extra piece.

‚ÄúWe should go into town today, sort this out,‚Äù his mother breaks the silence that‚Äôs crept up around them. ‚ÄúThe lawyer‚Äôs office is in Diagon Alley so that‚Äôs easy.‚Äù She leans down and kisses the top of Sirius‚Äôs head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll go get ready and we can leave in an hour, okay?‚Äù

Sirius nods quietly, Euphemia giving him one last squeeze before moving quickly out of the room, spelling her papers to follow behind her. The two boys remain frozen in their seats‚ÄîSirius unable to look at James and James unable to look away from Sirius. He has no idea what‚Äôs in that will but he reckons it‚Äôs probably a good amount of money, Alphard was a Black after all. He wonders if he had a wife and children, but he mustn‚Äôt have, not if he‚Äôs left everything to Sirius. James realizes, suddenly, how very little he knows about Alphard Black, guilt worming its way into his gut. He should have asked Sirius more about him.

Eventually, Sirius gets up, not looking at James until he reaches the kitchen door. ‚ÄúWill‚Äî‚Äú he croaks, voice startling James, who turns to face him, ‚Äúwill you come with us?‚Äù

He hesitates, feeling entirely unprepared for all of this.

Sirius quickly shakes his head. ‚ÄúSorry, that was stupid, never mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù he calls to him before he can get too far down the hall. The other boy turns back and James wonders if this is the first time they‚Äôve spoken since the night it all happened. It feels like it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll come,‚Äù he exhales, ‚Äúof course I‚Äôll come.‚Äù

Too many emotions flash across Sirius‚Äôs face for James to makes sense of them. But when he speaks, it sounds like the first breath after a deep dive.

‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

¬†

The lawyer‚Äôs office is in a worryingly thin building, squeezed between a botany shop and a Chinese food restaurant. It‚Äôs possible that at one point it was an actual colour, but it‚Äôs covered in so much soot and dirt that it‚Äôs now just a murky grey.

They‚Äôre all sitting in front of a tall, spindly wizard, his hair is orange and curly, streaked at the temples with grey, his robes starch straight and black. He has a very thin face, high cheek bones, and big, watering eyes. Like he‚Äôs in a constant state of distress. It makes it very hard for James to take him seriously. Sirius is sat next to him, his mum on Sirius‚Äôs other side. He has his head down, hands fiddling in his lap, and James is reminded unkindly of that day in Dumbledore‚Äôs office.

‚ÄúCan I just say again, Mrs. Potter,‚Äù the lawyer‚ÄîMr. Beagle‚Äîsays for the hundredth time, as he scrounges through the papers on his desk, ‚Äúwhat an absolute honour it is to have you here‚Äîto be able to serve you‚Äîan indescribable honour.‚Äù

His mother smiles kindly. ‚ÄúThank you, but you really don‚Äôt need to fuss.‚Äù

To be honest, James isn‚Äôt sure this man has ever done anything but fuss.

‚ÄúAh‚Äîha!‚Äù He pulls out a scroll, slowly unfurling it between his hands. ‚ÄúThe last Will and Testament of Alphard Black,‚Äù he announces proudly, peering over at them as though expecting some kind of reaction‚Äîapplause. When he doesn‚Äôt get any he turns back to the parchment. ‚ÄúThere are several logistical elements that I expect you‚Äôre not interested in but‚Ä¶ah, here we are,‚Äù he clears his throat. ‚ÄúTo my Nephew, Sirius Black III, I leave the entirety of my estate, including my home in Cornwall, my flat in Diagon Alley, and the contents of my account at Gringotts, totalling three-hundred-thousand Galleons, seven-hundred Sickles and fifty Knuts. Included in this is my art collection, encompassing‚Äî‚Äù

Sirius seems to sink further into his chair with every word the lawyer says. Unable to help himself, James shifts closer, knocking their shoulders together, leaning on Sirius just long enough for him to know that it was intentional. The other boy looks up for the first time, their eyes meeting. James doesn‚Äôt need him to speak to know what he‚Äôs thinking.

I killed him.

I killed him and now I‚Äôm getting all his stuff.

The lawyer continues to list the numerous priceless artefacts also being left to Sirius, his voice droning on. Eventually Sirius‚Äôs eyes break with James and return to the man in front of them.

‚ÄúExcuse me,‚Äù he cuts in, interrupting a description of gold plated tableware. The lawyer looks up, startled.

‚ÄúYes, sir?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure he meant to do this?‚Äù Sirius asks, looking at him a little desperately. ‚ÄúThat he wasn‚Äôt‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚Äîdrunk or held at wand-point or something?‚Äù

‚ÄúCertainly not,‚Äù the man seems affronted that such a question would even be asked. ‚ÄúI was here when the will was drawn-up, I witnessed it with my own eyes. Mr. Black was of sound mind, everything above board,‚Äù his eyes shift nervously over to James‚Äôs mother.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure it was,‚Äù she says softly, putting him at ease.

‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt understand why he did it,‚Äù Sirius is talking to Euphemia now. ‚ÄúI never gave him anything.‚Äù

She smiles sadly, reaching out to brush the hair off his forehead. ‚ÄúMaybe you did, and you just didn‚Äôt realize it. You are quite remarkable Sirius.‚Äù

He flinches at that, and James knows that he‚Äôs partly responsible for Sirius‚Äôs astronomically high levels of self-hatred at the moment. After a brief pause Euphemia looks back at the Lawyer. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre ready to continue.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh‚Äîyes, yes‚ÄîOf course.‚Äù

In the end all they need is to confirm Sirius‚Äôs magical signature in order to authenticate the will. The tap of a wand and he‚Äôs suddenly rich all on his own. No need for his mother or his inheritance. You would think he‚Äôd find some of that comforting, but he stays tense and sober the whole time, even when they make it back out onto the street.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù his mother says, squinting through the sun, ‚Äúsince we‚Äôre already here, shall we check it out?‚Äù

‚ÄúCheck what out?‚Äù James asks.

She looks over at him, hand shielding her eyes. ‚ÄúThe flat.‚Äù Her gazes skips from James to Sirius, cocking her brow in question.

It takes him a minute, but eventually he nods. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says, ruffling his hair. ‚ÄúYeah okay.‚Äù

They don‚Äôt talk as they maneuver through the busy streets, Sirius with his head down and his hands in his pockets, James awkwardly at his side, following the back of his mother‚Äôs head. He knows he should say something, that he probably would have already, if things were different. But, given that they‚Äôre still fighting‚Äîbecause they are, aren‚Äôt they?‚Äîhe‚Äôs not really sure what the right course of action is here.

‚ÄúThis is it,‚Äù Euphemia stops in front of a blue door with a bronze knocker, pulling a key from the envelope the Lawyer gave them and holding it out to Sirius. ‚ÄúYours I believe.‚Äù

He takes it hesitantly, fumbling as he fits it into the lock. The door opens into a small foyer with a set of stairs leading up. James thinks he hears Sirius gulp as they push inside.

The apartment is‚Ä¶nice. Warmer than James was expecting. He always pictures the Blacks living in recreations of the Slytherin common room, but this space isn‚Äôt that. It‚Äôs got warn wood floors and butter yellow walls, a big bay window in the living room, with a rug and sofa covered in blankets and pillows. None of the expensive art pieces Mr. Beagle had mentioned are hung up here, instead the walls are covered in concert posters‚Äîsome looking like they were literally torn off of walls and lampposts. None of them are magic, as far as James can tell.

There‚Äôs one bedroom, the sheets still messed up, a small kitchen with a mug in the sink, shoes carelessly removed by the door. All the signs of someone meaning to return. James half-expects him to walk through the door.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù his mum says, once they all find themselves back in the living room. She stands by the front door, Sirius across the room, leaning against the entrance to the kitchen, ‚Äúthis is lovely. We should find a time next week, go through everything, figure out what you want to keep. I‚Äôll tell Mimi to pop by every once and a while to make sure it‚Äôs kept in good shape for you until you decide you want to use it‚Äîif you want to, that is,‚Äù she corrects herself. ‚ÄúYou could always sell it or rent it out of course, it is a rather fabulous location.‚Äù

Sirius has a look on his face, like he‚Äôs got something stuck in his throat. He nods along, fingers nervously playing with his lower lip.

‚ÄúActually,‚Äù he says eventually, ‚ÄúI was thinking I might‚Ä¶move here.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause.

‚ÄúYou mean now?‚Äù Euphemia asks, causing something cold to run down James‚Äôs spine.

Sirius nods, very purposefully not making eye contact with anyone.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre still a minor Sirius‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI know, but you‚Äôre my guardian right?‚Äù

‚ÄúI am.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you could‚Äîcould give me permission, to be on my own?‚Äù

James is waiting for his mother to laugh. To tell Sirius what a ridiculous suggestion that is and of course he can‚Äôt move in here. But that isn‚Äôt what happens.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd have to talk to Fleamont, but if you really want to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAre you joking?‚Äù James can‚Äôt take it anymore. ‚ÄúHe can‚Äôt move out,‚Äù he turns to Sirius. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt move out.‚Äù

Sirius glares back at him defiantly, it‚Äôs the most like himself he‚Äôs looked all summer. ‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù James demands. ‚ÄúBecause you‚Äôre a kid‚Äîyou don‚Äôt even know how to make bloody toast. How the hell are you going to live on your own?‚Äù

‚ÄúFirst of all, I‚Äôm not a kid you prat, and I can totally make toast,‚Äù he says defensively. ‚ÄúWhy the hell do you care anyway? Isn‚Äôt this what you want?‚Äù

‚ÄúFor you to starve to death? Not really, no.‚Äù

Sirius throws his arms up in frustration. ‚ÄúI can manage feeding myself James, Jesus Christ.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt move in here,‚Äù he doubles down, teeth clenched.

‚ÄúYes, I can.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, you can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. I. Can.‚Äù

James turns back to his mother, jabbing an indignant finger in Sirius‚Äôs direction. ‚ÄúAre you really going to let him do this?‚Äù

‚ÄúI do remember saying something about needing to talk about it,‚Äù she sounds far too casual for James‚Äôs liking.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt get to decide what I do Prongs.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do when you‚Äôre being an idiot.‚Äù

Sirius scowls. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not being an idiot,‚Äù and then, with a frustrated huff. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get you. You kick me out of our dorm, you don‚Äôt speak to me for weeks, and now suddenly you‚Äôre desperate to have me living in your house? What do you want from me?‚Äù

‚ÄúI want you to have not fucking told Snape!‚Äù he snaps, the words ripping out of him like they hurt. Because they do.

Sirius looks like he‚Äôs just been hit, anger fleeing his face and that familiar lost look back in place. The one that‚Äôs been a permanent fixture all summer.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to wait for you two at the bottom of the stairs,‚Äù Euphemia says quietly, neither of them turning to watch as she slips out of the room.

‚ÄúI want you to have not done it,‚Äù James repeats, voice gravel. ‚ÄúYou think this has been fucking fun for any of us? You think I want to be mad at you? I hate it,‚Äù his voice cracks but he pushes on, Sirius watching him with wide eyes. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt know what else to do. I don‚Äôt know how to forgive you Sirius.‚Äù

And now he‚Äôs begging, really. Begging Sirius to tell him how. How do we get past this? How do we go back? I don‚Äôt want to be broken anymore.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Sirius says. It's all he ever seems to say these days.

James sighs, bringing his hands up to his face and turning away, towards the window.

‚ÄúBut I did it,‚Äù Sirius goes on, talking to James‚Äôs back. ‚ÄúI wish I hadn‚Äôt‚Äîget me a time-turner, I‚Äôll go back. I‚Äôll change everything.‚Äù

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúI want you to have not done it,‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúI want you to be incapable of doing it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought we were on the same page‚ÄîI thought we were going to protect each other no matter what, have each others‚Äô backs no matter what,‚Äù God it sounds so stupid now that he says it out loud. So childish.

‚ÄúWe are‚ÄîJames, I swear I never meant to hurt him. I would never hurt him. I wasn‚Äôt‚ÄîI wasn‚Äôt thinking. I didn‚Äôt‚ÄîI was just‚Äîmy head was all fucked up and I saw Snape and his stupid sneering face and I just‚ÄîI acted. I didn‚Äôt think. You know me, I never think.‚Äù Sirius sounds breathless, the room filled with ghosts. With what if‚Äôs and maybe‚Äôs and should have‚Äôs. All of it stings. Their friendship an open wound.

Eventually James turns back around to face him. Sirius has stepped forward, face pale, hair mussed from running his hands through it. James knows he means it. Means all of it. Knows that he‚Äôs sorry. When you‚Äôre younger it all feels so much simpler. Someone apologizes and you accept. It‚Äôs supposed to be enough. But it doesn‚Äôt feel like enough anymore.

‚ÄúBut you were supposed to think about us,‚Äù he says eventually, watching Sirius flinch.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the thing,‚Äù he croaks, voice splintering on its way out of his mouth, ‚ÄúI do. All the time. You guys are all I think about. What I‚Äôm going to tell you, what would make you laugh, where you are, what you‚Äôre doing, if you wish I was there like I wish I was there. I do think about you,‚Äù he‚Äôs as close to sobbing as James has ever seen someone who isn‚Äôt already crying. ‚ÄúIt was one time‚Äîthe one time I wasn‚Äôt thinking about you and I‚Äî‚Äú dry and cracked and desperate. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so fucking scared. So scared of what I did. That all it took was one moment and I hurt the most important people in my life. And the worst part, is I didn‚Äôt even feel it. I‚Äî‚Äú

He squeezes his eyes shut, trying to pull his words together. ‚ÄúI knew that you were upset, that Peter was upset, that it wasn‚Äôt funny. But I couldn‚Äôt feel the wrongness of it. Not until I saw you crawling out of the tree, covered in blood, and then it was like‚Äîsomething in me cracked open and all the sudden it was all there.‚Äù

There is a desperate look in his eyes when he opens them again. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs wrong with me,‚Äù he whispers.

James is moving before he can think about it, pulling Sirius into his arms as he falls apart. It hurts. But then, James is used to that at this point, so he just holds Sirius tighter. He wonders how this is allowed to happen, how anyone ever let Sirius stay in that house so long, how they let Regulus stay there still. How can he be the only one who sees them?

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Sirius huffs, pulling away and wiping his face on the inside of his shirt. James is reluctant to let him go.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt move out,‚Äù he says, a confidence in his voice that he doesn‚Äôt feel about anything right now.

Sirius looks tired. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt stay there like this James, I can‚Äôt handle us acting like we don‚Äôt know each other. Like we hate each other. It‚Äôs fucking killing me.‚Äù

‚ÄúMe too,‚Äù James agrees, doing his best to keep his voice under control. For the first time in a long time Sirius looks hopeful.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt hate you Sirius, I never have.‚Äù

Sirius lets out a wet laugh. ‚ÄúThank fuck for that.‚Äù

James smiles back, even if it is a little shaky.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt move out,‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying everything is fixed but‚ÄîI don‚Äôt want you to go. Can that be enough?‚Äù

Sirius sniffles, wiping his nose on his sleeve. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúThat can be enough.‚Äù

¬†

James sends Remus an owl as soon as they get home. Brief. To the point.

Moons,

Can we talk tonight?

Fireplace? Midnight?‚Äù

James

He doesn‚Äôt want Sirius there for this. The two of them are‚Äîthey‚Äôre better. But they‚Äôre fragile. They make awkward small talk on the way home. Not really able to look at one another but trying not to look away. It‚Äôll be easier, James thinks, after he talks to Remus. It‚Äôll feel less like a betrayal.

He waits by he fireplace in his father‚Äôs office, door closed, mum and Sirius up in their bedrooms, McGonagall‚Äôs letter clutched in his hand. The flames flicker a few times before Remus‚Äôs face emerges.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he says lamely.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Remus returns, ‚Äúeverything okay? Your letter seemed kind of‚Ä¶urgent.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, yeah, yeah, everything‚Äôs okay,‚Äù he tries to swallow but his throat is too tight. ‚ÄúListen, um, I got‚Äîer‚ÄîI got my Hogwarts letter today.‚Äù

Remus gives him a funny look. ‚ÄúYup, I figured. They usually send those out at the same time,‚Äù he laughs a little. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up with you James? You‚Äôre acting like I‚Äôm Lily or something.‚Äù

That brings a smirk to James‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúYou think I‚Äôm trying to seduce you Lupin?‚Äù

Remus arches his brow, impressively sassy even in the fireplace. ‚ÄúAre you?‚Äù

‚ÄúAlways.‚Äù

They both laugh at that, breaking the tension. James can do this. He can. He just doesn‚Äôt know how to start.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Remus pushes.

‚ÄúRight, sorry, so, I got another letter, with my‚Äîah‚Äîwith my school list.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he nods, feeling the parchment in his hand like a hot coal. ‚ÄúYeah, it‚Äôs from McGonagall, she wants to know if‚Äîif we want to room with Sirius again or if she should find us a new roommate.‚Äù

He sees the surprise on Remus‚Äôs face, and then sees him try to suppress it almost immediately.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says.

‚ÄúYeah that was‚Äîthat was how I felt too. Bit of a‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGut punch.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

They‚Äôre both nodding at each other, neither of them sure where this goes next. James doesn‚Äôt want to tell him about the conversation he had with Sirius, not yet anyway. Doesn‚Äôt want him to feel pressured into anything because he thinks it‚Äôs what James wants.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you going to tell her?‚Äù Remus asks finally, and James almost laughs.

‚ÄúWhatever you tell me to.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

But he shakes his head, cutting Remus off. ‚ÄúYou were fucked over here Remus. The rest of us were just‚Äîcollateral damage. You decide what you need, what makes you feel comfortable. Whatever you want I‚Äôll support it.‚Äù

He can sees Remus biting his lower lip, the nervous energy wafting off the fire like smoke.

‚ÄúGod, it shouldn‚Äôt be this hard,‚Äù Remus mutters, and then laughs at himself, it‚Äôs a heavy sound. ‚ÄúFuck it, okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù James asks.

Remus swipes a hand across his face. ‚ÄúTell her it‚Äôs okay, I‚Äôm not rooming with a stranger that‚Äôs ridiculous. The amount I‚Äôd have to hide every full moon? It was hard enough with Frank and we liked him,‚Äù he shakes his head. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll deal with Sirius‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know how, but we will. Besides, it would feel wrong, having anyone else in there. Don‚Äôt you think?‚Äù

James nods, trying to contain his relief. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah I do.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor good or bad, he already knows all my secrets,‚Äù Remus sighs.

‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah‚Äîor, no, not really,‚Äù he gives James a sad smile, ‚Äúbut I‚Äôm not really sure about anything these days.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know the feeling,‚Äù James feels his grip loosen on the letter in his hand. ‚ÄúOkay, well, I‚Äôll write her tonight.‚Äù

Remus nods. ‚ÄúI should go, my mum won‚Äôt sleep until she knows I‚Äôm in my room.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight, okay. I‚Äôll come ‚Äòround tomorrow yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds good, I think Pete‚Äôs planning to come by too.‚Äù

‚ÄúBrilliant‚ÄîMoony?‚Äù he says.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

James takes a deep breath. ‚ÄúI have your back, always, you know that right?‚Äù

Something flickers in his eyes, but James isn‚Äôt sure if it‚Äôs really there or if it‚Äôs just the fire. ‚ÄúYeah James, I know. Me too‚ÄîI have your back. I know I was a little‚Ä¶harsh, yesterday. But I‚ÄîI‚Äôm here, if you need anything. Okay?‚Äù

James nods, smiling. ‚ÄúG‚Äônight Moons.‚Äù

‚ÄúNight James.‚Äù

The fireplace splutters, flames reaching out for a second and then receding back as the connection is severed. James sits back on his heels, trying to let go of some of the anxiety still clinging to his skin. It‚Äôs okay, everything went okay. Remus said yes. Sirius can come back. Nothing is fixed, of course, not completely, but‚Ä¶at least it‚Äôs a start. They‚Äôre mending.

He gets up, rounding his father‚Äôs desk and pulling out a fresh piece of parchment. He scribbles McGonagall a note, nothing fancy, but he wants to get this done now. When it‚Äôs sealed and addressed he goes into the back garden and whistles for Hoot. He comes almost instantly, happy to have a job‚ÄîJames hasn‚Äôt had much for him to do this summer.

‚ÄúThat a boy,‚Äù he says softly, tying the letter to his leg and ending him off. He‚Äôs almost instantly lost in the black night sky.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James whispers to himself, hand running through his hair. ‚ÄúOkay, okay,‚Äù it‚Äôs rubbish, trying to comfort yourself. Never works. Still, he tries to get himself to relax. Today was a good day. Hard and long and bloody exhausting. But good.

He‚Äôs only just come back inside when he hears the crack of someone apparating into the front hallway.

‚ÄúBloody hell,‚Äù they curse as he walks through the kitchen towards them. He knows it‚Äôs his dad, there‚Äôs no one else who‚Äôs keyed into their wards‚Äîwell, except for Dumbledore and Moody. But that ‚Äòbloody hell‚Äô was definitely his dad.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre back late‚Äî‚Äú James stops at the top the hall, his father looking up at the sound of his voice, face bloodied. ‚ÄúD-dad?‚Äù

Fleamont tries to smile and then winces. ‚ÄúBad huh? Haven‚Äôt had the chance to look in a mirror yet.‚Äù

And then he starts limping towards his office, as though showing up in the middle of the night beaten to a fucking pulp is nothing out of the ordinary.

‚ÄúWhat the hell happened? Are you okay?‚Äù he follows him into the office, watching as he throws his cloak on his desk, the shirt underneath dirty and blood splattered.

‚ÄúShh,‚Äù he says, opening the closet door and peering into the mirror hung-up on the inside. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to wake your mother.‚Äù He pulls out his wand and starts casting healing charms. James watches as the skin on his face starts stitching itself back together, bruises fading.

‚ÄúDad,‚Äù he repeats, still standing in the doorway, ‚Äúwhat happened?‚Äù He can see that his dad is okay, he‚Äôs standing right in front of him, so he doesn‚Äôt know why he suddenly feels so afraid.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù his father sighs, eyeing his face one more time before deciding it‚Äôs good enough. He pulls away from he mirror and leans against the front of his desk, facing James. ‚ÄúI encountered a bit of a‚Ä¶situation, trying to leave work.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can see that,‚Äù James says, fighting between concerned and annoyed now.

Fleamont offers him another small smile. They‚Äôre really the only kind he has, everything he expresses is tinged with a bit of self-conscious embarrassment, nothing like the boisterous emotions of James‚Äôs mum.

‚ÄúThere have been attacks,‚Äù his father sighs, sagging a little bit. Now that the blood is gone James can clearly see the deep bags under his father‚Äôs eyes, lines marking up his forehead and mouth in a way they never have before. For the first time in his life, James finds himself thinking that his father looks old. ‚ÄúThree in the last two weeks.‚Äù

‚ÄúThree?‚Äù James demands, because he‚Äôs been reading the paper everyday and he hasn‚Äôt seen a single bleeding thing about attacks.

Fleamont nods. ‚ÄúAll Ministry employees, usually leaving or coming to work. Moody thinks it‚Äôs a new kind of initiation.‚Äù

‚ÄúInitiation for what?‚Äù

His father sends him a look.

Oh.

OH.

‚ÄúDeath Eaters are attacking the Ministry now?‚Äù

His father does not seem nearly as concerned as James thinks he should be. ‚ÄúIt's only a theory, no one‚Äôs died yet, they don‚Äôt seem to be very well organized. That‚Äôs what makes us think they‚Äôre not proper members.‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt sure if that‚Äôs supposed to be comforting, but it isn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt they have extra security then?‚Äù

A rueful smile finds its way onto Fleamont‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs some, but the Minister doesn‚Äôt want to allow Moody to post too many, afraid if people start seeing hoards of Aurors marching around they‚Äôll get the wrong idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich is?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat we‚Äôre in trouble.‚Äù

James feels something squirm in the pit of his stomach. ‚ÄúAre we?‚Äù he asks, voice tight, ‚ÄúIn trouble?‚Äù

The good humour slowly drops from his father‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù which James realizes is a stupid and inadequate response, but it‚Äôs the only one he has.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not trying to scare you James,‚Äù his father says softly. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt want to lie to you either.‚Äù

Feeling slightly dazed James shakes his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not scared,‚Äù an automatic response.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù a sad smile finds its way onto his father‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a braver man than I am.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt believe that for a second.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs late,‚Äù his father pushes off the desk. ‚ÄúYou should head up to bed before your mother comes down here and gives us both grief.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt going to bed?‚Äù James asks.

His father nods at the fireplace behind him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to call Dumbledore, let him know whats happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight, okay,‚Äù he‚Äôs hesitant to move but he can‚Äôt think of any excuse to stay so, reluctantly, he starts making his way towards the door.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù his dad calls to him before he‚Äôs out of the room. James turns back. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve had the chance to tell you, but I‚Äôm really proud of how you handled everything this past year at school.‚Äù

When James‚Äôs brows inevitably draw together in confusion his father chuckles, explaining; ‚ÄúI know you and the Snape boy aren‚Äôt exactly on the best of terms. But it was incredibly brave and decent, what you did, going after him. Saving him.‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt exactly sure what to say to that.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do it for him,‚Äù he manages eventually. ‚ÄúI did it for Remus.‚Äù

His father nods, a knowing look on his face. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a good friend.‚Äù

James shrugs. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre important to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù his father says, moving slowly behind his desk. ‚Äúhold on to that‚Äîthat feeling‚Äîlet it keep you together.‚Äù

There‚Äôs no wavering in James‚Äôs voice when he answers; ‚ÄúI intend to.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hello lovelies!

Oh my God this chapter is the bane of my existence, like, just, cannot get it right. But here we are! Mostly because I'm impatient and want to work on the next one.

I also wish I had a rich uncle who would die and leave me everything in his will but oh well.

THANK YOU for being so nice all the time it is truly so lovely to read your comments! Hope you're all having a good day!

Chapter 18

Chapter Summary

It's Lily-he-has-her-eyes-Evans

Chapter Notes

TW: very very vague reference to suicide or suicidal thoughts

TW: discussion about homophobia

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Lily lies on her bedroom floor, record player on in the background, music drifting over her. It‚Äôs brutally hot, too hot to move, or think. Her fingers drag lazily through the beige carpet that covers every room in the house except the bathroom and kitchen. Her father always used to talk about tearing it out, but he never got around to it. She‚Äôs glad that he didn‚Äôt. It feels like home now‚Äîafter spending all year surrounded by stone, she comes back to soft floors and warm colours.

‚ÄúLily!‚Äù a shrill voice cuts through the music.

She doesn‚Äôt move. Doesn‚Äôt open her eyes. Maybe if she lies very, very still they won‚Äôt be able to find her.

Barely two minutes later the door to her room is being thrown open. ‚ÄúJesus Lily, couldn‚Äôt you hear me?‚Äù

She sighs, cracking one eye open to peer up at the towering figure of her sister, dark hair still in curlers, the mint green nightgown she‚Äôs had since she was thirteen brushing against her knees.

‚ÄúNo, sorry,‚Äù Lily says mildly, not bothering to move. This, predictably, infuriates Petunia.

‚ÄúYou said you would help,‚Äù everything with her sister is a lightly veiled guilt-trip.

You said you would help.

You owe me.

Make up for it.

For the magic.

For not being here.

You said you would help.

Lily sighs, pulling herself upright and resting her arms on her knees.

‚ÄúWhat d‚Äôyou need?‚Äù

Petunia is really rather pretty‚Äîprobably the prettier of the two of them‚Äîthe problem is, she‚Äôs always got this pinched look on her face. Sour and unhappy and constantly let down. It makes her unappealing to look at.

‚ÄúFood for my hen do, nice food though, not just crisps from the grocery store.‚Äù

Lily blinks up at her. ‚ÄúNice food?‚Äù

Petunia sighs like Lily is the stupidest person she has ever met. ‚ÄúCheeses and baguettes and char-cootie boards.‚Äù

‚ÄúCharcuterie?‚Äù

‚ÄúGazoontite.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo it‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú Lily laughs. ‚ÄúNever mind,‚Äù she gets to her feet. ‚ÄúYeah, okay, I can go get you some posh snacks. When do you need them for?‚Äù

‚ÄúFour.‚Äù

Lily‚Äôs eyes skate over to the clock on her bedside table. It‚Äôs only ten in the morning. What all the yelling was about she‚Äôs no idea. As if snacks are going to take more than six hours to get‚Äîeven posh ones.

‚ÄúAlso, pick us up some Presecco.‚Äù

Lily gives her a flat look. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm under age.‚Äù

Her sister smiles unpleasantly. ‚ÄúAnd yet you still manage to get those dirty cigarettes you don‚Äôt want mum to see.‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúYes, okay, I‚Äôll try. But if they don‚Äôt take my fake it‚Äôs not my fault.‚Äù

Petunia makes a very lofty ‚Äúhmph‚Äù noise. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll be fine. If anything goes wrong you can just use your little stick and magic it all away.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not how it‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLily!‚Äù their mum‚Äôs voice echoes from downstairs. ‚ÄúPhone for you!‚Äù

‚ÄúOh thank God,‚Äù she murmurs under her breath.

‚ÄúHey, wait‚Äî‚Äú

But Lily slips passed her, ‚ÄúSorry, I gotta take this!‚Äù she says over her shoulder as she skids around the corner.

‚ÄúLily‚Äîugh!‚Äù

She practically crashes into her mum who‚Äôs leaving the living room at the exact moment that she makes it to the bottom of the stairs. She looks at Lily and then behind her where Petunia can still be heard grumbling‚Äîprobably cursing Lily‚Äôs name.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll get her snacks, I promise,‚Äù Lily says before her mother can start.

Mrs. Evans sighs. ‚ÄúListen, I know she‚Äôs being‚Ä¶‚Äù she trails off but sends Lily a look that is clearly meant to say ‚Äúa crazy bitch‚Äù so Lily nods. ‚ÄúBut she‚Äôs just stressed, Vernon‚Äôs sister is coming to the hen do and she wants to impress her.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure mum, I get it,‚Äù Lily doesn‚Äôt point out that Petunia is always like this around her. Has been since she was eleven years old.

Her mum smiles a little sadly. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a good girl Lily.‚Äù

She tries not to cringe. ‚ÄúThanks mum, I‚Äîuh‚ÄîI better‚Ä¶.‚Äù she nods towards the telephone in the living room.

‚ÄúOh yeah, of course, go on.‚Äù

Lily does. Enthusiastically. Not even bothering to ask who it is, any conversation is better than whatever was happening up in her bedroom.

‚ÄúHello?‚Äù she sings as she throws herself into the armchair by the phone.

‚ÄúJesus, where were you coming from? Alaska? We‚Äôve been waiting on the line for ages.‚Äù

Lily smiles at the sound of Mary‚Äôs voice. ‚ÄúWe?‚Äù she asks.

‚ÄúOh yeah, Mar‚Äôs here, you‚Äôre on speaker by the way, so if you have anything nasty to say about her it‚Äôll have to wait until later.‚Äù
