‚ÄúOh my God Mary,‚Äù she can practically hear Marlene rolling her eyes over the phone. ‚ÄúHey Lily, how‚Äôs it going? How‚Äôs home?‚Äù

She grimaces, glad they can‚Äôt see. Lily does her best not to let it get to her, and by ‚Äúit‚Äù she very much means her sister. With Petunia it‚Äôs easier to pretend it‚Äôs all a joke‚Äîthe glaring and passive aggressive comments. Some ridiculous sketch on a comedy program. Better to laugh than to yell and fight.

‚ÄúHello? Earth to Lily?‚Äù Mary‚Äôs voice crackles over the line.

Lily shakes herself awake. ‚ÄúHi‚Äîsorry‚Äîum, home is fine.‚Äù

Mary makes a skeptical scoffing noise. ‚ÄúSister being a nightmare then?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, Jesus Mary,‚Äù Marlene hisses. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt make me muzzle you.‚Äù

‚ÄúPromises, promises.‚Äù

Lily laughs, her free hand coming to her mouth to try and catch it. Laughter is an odd sound in this house, without her father. It‚Äôs not that they‚Äôre unhappy, not exactly. Or‚ÄîLily isn‚Äôt. She‚Äôs not so sure about her mum and sister.

‚ÄúIt is your sister though isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Mary pushes on, never one to demure.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Lily says.

‚ÄúFull bridezilla?‚Äù

She snorts. ‚ÄúYou could certainly say that.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave you got your bridesmaid dress yet?‚Äù Marlene asks.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù this time much more grudgingly.

‚ÄúOh no,‚Äù Lily can already hear Mary laughing. ‚ÄúJust how horrible is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs dusty rose‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNO!‚Äù Lily has to pull the phone away from her ear. ‚ÄúNo it isn‚Äôt! She wouldn‚Äôt! Oh and with your hair? Pink, Lily?‚Äù

‚ÄúYup,‚Äù she says flatly, ‚Äúwith sleeves the size of my head and ruffles as far as the eye can see.‚Äù Mary starts making fake retching noises in the background.

Lily‚Äôs only a bridesmaid in the first place because their mother made Petunia include her. While Lily appreciates the gesture, she really, really, wishes she hadn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs been nothing but a misery, and besides, Lily would rather just sit anonymously in the crowd, ignored. Invisible. Or not go at all.

‚ÄúAnyway,‚Äù she says eventually, ‚Äúhow‚Äôre you two? I expect you didn‚Äôt call just to gag over my sister‚Äôs wedding?‚Äù

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúNo, we most certainly did not. We called to inform you of the party you will be attending on Friday.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe means we called to ask you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAsking implies a choice, there‚Äôs no choice here.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs going to be there?‚Äù Lily interrupts their bickering before they can really get on a roll. There‚Äôs a pause which means that Marlene and Mary are doing that thing where they talk with their eyes.

‚ÄúWhy,‚Äù Mary asks eventually, voice teasing, ‚Äúwho do you want to be there?‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúNo one.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay‚ÄîMarlene, who is going to be there?‚Äù

There‚Äôs ruffling and muffled voices until eventually Marlene comes through, crisper and louder than before. Clearer she won the battle for the phone.

‚ÄúSorry Lily‚Äîerm‚Äîthe whole Quidditch team‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOoh Alice and Frank too? I haven‚Äôt seen them in ages!‚Äù

‚ÄúI know right?‚Äù Marlene agrees. ‚ÄúAuror training is a bitch, but yeah, they said they‚Äôd be there. Dorcas too, Lucy and Tanner from herbology, uh, that prat Diggory because Mary has decided she wants to shag him.‚Äù

Lily wrinkles her nose. ‚ÄúEw, Diggory? Why?‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me about it, but she said something about his‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOKAY!‚Äù Mary interrupts. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you just cut to the chase and tell her about the people she really cares about huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere aren‚Äôt people I really care about!‚Äù Lily insists, though she has a feeling it‚Äôs a losing battle.

Marlene sighs. ‚ÄúJames, Remus and Peter are coming too.‚Äù

There may be, possibly, potentially, in a theoretical situation that one could think up, a small skip in her pulse. But Lily doesn‚Äôt let herself consider it. And she certainly doesn‚Äôt intend to admit it to Mary who for some reason has decided that now that her and James don‚Äôt hate each other they are suddenly going to fall in love.

‚ÄúNo Sirius?‚Äù she asks.

Mary sighs. ‚ÄúI invited him, but things are apparently still‚Ä¶tense, between that lot. James said he didn‚Äôt have a problem with him coming but Sirius seems to think it‚Äôll be awkward.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you ask Remus?‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus? Why?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs him and Sirius who‚Äôre fighting I think,‚Äù Lily says, ‚ÄúJames and Peter have just taken Remus‚Äôs side.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äîhow do you know that?‚Äù Marlene interjects.

Lily shrugs even though they can‚Äôt see her. ‚ÄúJames told me‚Äîwell, basically told me, anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh he did, did he?‚Äù

Lily can practically hear her eyebrows waggling on the other end of the phone. ‚ÄúDown girl.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying, you would make a hot couple.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh well, with that sound logic.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry‚Äîbut‚Äîwhat did he do? Sirius I mean.‚Äù Marlene cuts in again. ‚ÄúI spent like all of the end of the year trying to figure out what could have happened. I mean, for James to turn on Sirius?‚Äù she lets out a low whistle. ‚ÄúThose two were like‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúBrothers?‚Äù Mary supplies. ‚ÄúNot that Sirius has terribly good luck with those, does he?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of shocked silence before Lily hisses. ‚ÄúWow, Mary, that was particularly mean, even for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease tell me you didn‚Äôt say that to him when you talked?‚Äù

Mary huffs. ‚ÄúYou two have no faith in me‚Äîof course I didn‚Äôt. But it doesn‚Äôt mean I‚Äôm not right.‚Äù

Neither of them want to touch that.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what he did,‚Äù Lily says instead. ‚ÄúJames didn‚Äôt say, neither did Remus.‚Äù

‚ÄúDamn,‚Äù Marlene sighs. ‚ÄúI mean obviously, it‚Äôs their business and everything but like‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI want to know too,‚Äù Lily admits guiltily.

Mary makes a scoffing noise, ‚Äúhonestly you two, I know what happened.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, Lily sitting bolt upright in her chair.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean you know?‚Äù she demands.

‚ÄúYeah, what the hell Macdonald?‚Äù

Lily can‚Äôt see her but she can just picture Mary‚Äîreclining slightly, smug look on her face while she shrugs off their indignation. A ‚Äúsorry, it slipped my mind‚Äù smile pulling at her mouth.

‚ÄúLike you said, it‚Äôs their business.‚Äù

Another pause.

‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre going to tell us right?‚Äù Marlene prods.

Mary makes a little ‚Äúhmph‚Äù noise. ‚ÄúI could I suppose.‚Äù

For a solid five seconds Lily truly does think about murdering her.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt really know,‚Äù Marlene says finally, sounding as though she‚Äôs been debating with herself. ‚ÄúIf you did half the school would have heard by now‚Äîow, don‚Äôt start fighting with me Macdonald I have a Seeker‚Äôs reflexes!‚Äù

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt manage to dodge that hit.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt ready.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see, so you have a Seeker‚Äôs reflexes as long as someone notifies you in advance then?‚Äù

Marlene mumbles something under he breath that Lily can‚Äôt quite make out but she doubts is family friendly.

‚ÄúMary,‚Äù she says pointedly. ‚ÄúDo you know or not?‚Äù

‚ÄúI have a theory.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat is not the same!‚Äù Marlene shouts indignantly.

‚ÄúOh well, sue me, it‚Äôs more than either of you have.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo on then,‚Äù Lily says, still intrigued. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your theory?‚Äù

‚ÄúSimple,‚Äù Mary says, which Lily doesn‚Äôt think is a promising start, because whatever is going on between those boys, it certainly doesn‚Äôt seem simple. ‚ÄúSirius made a move on Remus.‚Äù

Lily is so unprepared for that that for a second her brain doesn‚Äôt process it. Made Remus move what? Moved what on Remus? Moved Remus where? Her brain cycles through every combination of those words and their possible meanings before finally landing on what, of course, Mary is saying.

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

It seems Marlene is similarly stunned because she doesn‚Äôt have much more to add.

‚ÄúI expect the other three lads freaked out on him, stopped feeling comfortable sharing a room with him, changing in front of him.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Marlene says finally. ‚ÄúNo, they wouldn‚Äôt do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúBoys are assholes about that kind of thing,‚Äù Mary goes on, undeterred. ‚ÄúYou saw how they got at Christmas, with spin the bottle.‚Äù

Lily grimaces. She did, in fact, see that.

‚ÄúMcGonagall would never agree to kick him out of the dorm or off the Quidditch team for that, no way,‚Äù Marlene goes on.

Mary scoffs. ‚ÄúWhy? Because she‚Äôs so progressive? And besides, anyone else notice that they moved him into a single room? Awfully strange punishment don‚Äôt you think? Unless the whole point was to keep him away from other boys?‚Äù

‚ÄúStop it,‚Äù Lily hears herself say.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not agreeing with it!‚Äù Mary says defensively. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs horrid. I love Sirius, you know I do. I just also think it makes sense,‚Äù after a small pause. ‚ÄúPeople are horrid.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames would never let that happen,‚Äù Marlene says finally, a new conviction in her voice.

‚ÄúI told you, blokes are‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, they‚Äôre more sensitive about that sort of thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Marlene says firmly. ‚ÄúNot James.‚Äù

‚ÄúI agree with Marlene,‚Äù Lily pipes up, feeling slightly dazed by the whole situation.

‚ÄúGod, I forgot I was talking to James Potter‚Äôs bloody fan club‚Äîlook ladies, I‚Äôm sorry to break it to you, but he‚Äôs a pigheaded jock just like the rest of them.‚Äù

Lily is shaking her head even before she speaks. ‚ÄúNo‚Äînot about Sirius. He‚Äôd die for him,‚Äù she doesn‚Äôt know why she says it, but she knows it‚Äôs true. ‚ÄúThe way he was talking‚ÄîI don‚Äôt think this could be it. I don‚Äôt think Remus would react this way either. Besides, you‚Äôre forgetting about Severus.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh yeah!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat does Snape have to do with this?‚Äù Mary asks, Lily can hear the distaste in her voice.

‚ÄúYou remember Mary,‚Äù Marlene answers for her. ‚ÄúHe was in the infirmary and then he had detentions with Sirius for the rest of the year‚ÄîI keep forgetting about him. God, what a weird situation.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould be unrelated.‚Äù

Lily snorts. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôd be quite the coincidence. What even makes you think Sirius would‚Äîwould be interested in Remus in that way? Bit out of left field that.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, too long really, and Lily finds herself suddenly frustrated with the phone because she really wants to see what Mary‚Äôs face is doing right now.

‚ÄúHe told me,‚Äù she says eventually.

‚ÄúHe told you?‚Äù Marlene asks.

‚ÄúWhat? Really?‚Äù Lily didn‚Äôt see that coming.

Another pause.

‚ÄúWell, I mean, not exactly. He just sort of, said his name once. While we were hooking-up.‚Äù

Lily‚Äôs eyes go so wide she‚Äôs afraid they‚Äôre going to fall right out of her head. ‚ÄúOh my God,‚Äù she hears herself say.

‚ÄúOh my God!‚Äù Marlene repeats on the other end of the line.

‚ÄúYou two are so dramatic,‚Äù Mary uses her most I‚Äôm-more-worldly-than-you tone.

‚ÄúIs that why you two‚Ä¶stopped‚Ä¶seeing each other?‚Äù

Lily can hear the shrug in her voice. ‚ÄúNot exactly, but it certainly made things a bit awkward from then on. So I told him I was interested in Connor Davies, that way he wouldn‚Äôt have to feel bad about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù Lily says, ‚Äúthat was very decent of you Mary.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome might even say nice,‚Äù Marlene adds.

Mary sniffs. ‚ÄúI can be nice.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, ‚Äòcourse you can,‚Äù Marlene says, sounding like she‚Äôs holding in a laugh.

‚ÄúI still don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs what caused the marauders to‚Ä¶‚Äù Lily trails off.

‚ÄúBreak up?‚Äù Marlene finishes for her.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Lily runs a hand through her hair, turning to the window. She can see Remus that day in the courtyard, the sad look in his eyes, the way he was avoiding everyone. Mary‚Äôs theory just doesn‚Äôt feel‚Ä¶right somehow.

‚ÄúWell, you two can believe whatever you like. Now, back to the party. We‚Äôre thinking big here Evans, an epic end of summer bash.‚Äù

Marlene makes a whining noise. ‚ÄúNo‚Äîdon‚Äôt say that‚Äîit‚Äôs not the end of summer yet.‚Äù

‚ÄúCome now darling, everything good must come to a close.‚Äù

Lily watches as the cars drive a long the street, sun bright outside. This summer truly has been beautiful, if only it had been filled with less wedding madness she might have actually enjoyed it.

‚Äú‚Äîno, no way, you‚Äôre not allowed to make the punch again,‚Äù Marlene‚Äôs voice drifts through Lily‚Äôs daydreaming.

‚ÄúAnd why not?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause last time you nearly killed Dorcas.‚Äù

Lily used to love summer, but then, she supposes most kids do. Those days when all you do is run around outside until the sun sets. Coming back dirty and tired, with scuffed knees and stories to tell. She used to go monster hunting with Severus and then come back and tell her father all about it. He loved that stuff‚Äîonce he made a book about it, all the monsters they‚Äôd caught. Lily still has it somewhere.

‚ÄúLily do you think you could pick that stuff up?‚Äù

When she first sees him she thinks she‚Äôs making it up. She‚Äôd just been thinking about him after all. Maybe it‚Äôs a trick of the light. Of her memories.

‚ÄúLily?‚Äù

But no. She blinks, wiping a hand across her eyes, and still he‚Äôs there. Not a little kid anymore of course. Not as interested in hunting monsters as joining them.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù she hears herself say distantly into the receiver. ‚ÄúI have to go.‚Äù

She hangs the phone up, getting out of her chair and walking towards the window. He‚Äôs standing across the street, hair longer than it was the last time she saw him. He always looks younger in muggle clothes. Softer.

He looks like he‚Äôs still mine, her traitorous mind supplies.

She hasn‚Äôt seen him all summer, she thought they‚Äôd come to some sort of agreement.

‚ÄúMum?‚Äù she calls as she shoves on her shoes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm heading out.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt forget to buy my‚Äî‚Äú

She slams the door shut on her sister‚Äôs voice, watching the boy across the street stand up straighter as she walks towards him, hands already shaking. She stops a few feet away on the pavement.

‚ÄúCan I help you?‚Äù

He winces, looking down so that his hair falls forward, nearly swallowing him completely.

‚ÄúI was hoping we could‚Ä¶talk.‚Äù

It‚Äôs harder here, in the place where they met, where they grew up together‚Äîaway from castles and magic and other people‚Äîit‚Äôs harder to hate him.

‚ÄúYou were hoping we could talk,‚Äù she repeats coldly. ‚ÄúAbout what exactly?‚Äù

His eyes dart up off the pavement to meet her‚Äôs, but only for a moment. ‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNot Mudblood?‚Äù she interrupts. ‚ÄúWhy so formal all of the sudden Severus? Or, I suppose now that no one‚Äôs around it‚Äôs alright for me to have a name?‚Äù she can already feel the tears trying to weasel their way up her throat, but she has no intention of crying. Not again, not over this. She‚Äôs tired and it‚Äôs pointless.

Severus‚Äôs next exhale punches out of him like he‚Äôs just been hit. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚ÄîI told you‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt mean to say it, I was just‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúVulnerable,‚Äù she cuts him off. ‚ÄúI understand how it happened Sev, but it came to you so fucking easily. So quickly. Like it didn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù there‚Äôs a catch in her voice that she tries and fails to clear. ‚ÄúTell me, if it had been Mary standing there instead of me, would you still have come slinking up to the Gryffindor common room to apologize?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt never would have been Macdonald.‚Äù

Lily lets out a frustrated growl. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not the point Sev.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you know why it never would have been her?‚Äù he goes on, not getting it. On his war path like always. You know, there had been a time when he had been an incredible listener. But these days she feels like he barely ever hears her.

‚ÄúBecause she‚Äôs one of their bloody groupies.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh my God,‚Äù she throws her arms up in frustration. ‚ÄúThis is so much more important than your petty bullshit with the marauders.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is all about them! And you used to be able to see it,‚Äù he‚Äôs lifted his head now, hair falling away from his eyes as they lock onto her‚Äôs.

‚ÄúSee what Severus?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat a bunch of privileged narcissistic assholes they are. It would have made you furious what Potter did-‚Äú

‚ÄúIT DID!‚Äù she yells, loud enough that he takes a step back. She is sure she is going to be getting complaints from the neighbours in a few minutes but she can‚Äôt bring herself to care. ‚ÄúI stood up for you, I held my wand to his head, and you called me a Mudblood,‚Äù her chest is heaving. ‚ÄúYears Sev, years I spent defending you to everyone and then, in front of the entire school, you showed them what an absolute fucking idiot I‚Äôve been.‚Äù

‚ÄúLily.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo think that you were different‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLily please‚Äî‚Äú

‚Äú‚Äî to believe that you were my friend, that you cared about me‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI do care about you!‚Äù he says desperately, and he sounds like he means it, really he does. The expression he usually wears, around school, that empty mask, it disappears when they‚Äôre together. She used to think this was the real him. The person he was with her. Now she‚Äôs not so sure.

‚ÄúThe thing is Severus, you don‚Äôt care about me,‚Äù God it hurts, like pouring salt in an open wound. ‚ÄúYou care about you.‚Äù

He opens and closes his mouth, like he can‚Äôt figure out what to say. She doesn‚Äôt blame him. I mean, what‚Äôs left at this point?

‚ÄúWe just keep going in circles,‚Äù she says eventually. ‚ÄúSo just‚Ä¶just go away okay? We‚Äôve dragged this out enough.‚Äù She doesn‚Äôt wait for him to respond, turning on her heel and starting back towards the house

‚ÄúLily‚Äîoh come on, Lily please. Please, I‚Äôm trying here.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrying?‚Äù she demands, stopping on her doorstep. ‚ÄúTrying to what? What are you even doing here Sev? Surely this all makes you sick,‚Äù she gestures to the building behind her. ‚ÄúMe and my muggle home and my muggle mum and my muggle sister, surely it all disgusts you?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know it doesn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow?‚Äù she tries to keep her volume in check, they‚Äôre too close to the house now and the last thing she needs is her mother or sister coming out here to see what‚Äôs going on. ‚ÄúHow would I know that? You do realize that it‚Äôs not just that you‚Äôre friends don‚Äôt like me, right? They want me dead Sev,‚Äù saying it out loud makes a slightly hysterical laugh come out of her. Because it‚Äôs all so absurd. All so terrible.

‚ÄúNothing is going to happen to you,‚Äù he steps forward now, trying to close the space between them. Which is the last thing she needs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll keep you safe‚ÄîI‚Äôll protect you, always. Always Lily.‚Äù

There is something heartbreaking about it all. The swelling in his eyes, the sincerity, the way he reaches his hand out. She doesn‚Äôt know how they got here, but she can‚Äôt help feeling that it was all supposed to be different. That they were supposed to grow old together. She blames him for that. For breaking them. Because for a while, they really were something special.

‚ÄúTo what end Sev? Until I‚Äôm the last Mudblood on the planet‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúStop using that word,‚Äù he hisses.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll use it if I fucking want to,‚Äù she snaps back. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt protect me. And if you really believe in all of this, in the Death Eaters and the violence and the Great Chain of Magical Beings, then I can‚Äôt figure out why you‚Äôd even want to.‚Äù

He used to be shorter than her, but he‚Äôs not anymore, she always forgets that until moments like this, when all of the sudden she realizes he‚Äôs looking down at her, taking up too much space in her chest.

‚ÄúI want to,‚Äù he says, voice suddenly quiet, causing goose bumps to pebble her skin, ‚Äúbecause I love you.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a reflex really. She‚Äôs barely thinking when she pulls her arm back and punches him right in the stomach. He doubles over immediately, clutching at his middle like he‚Äôs afraid he‚Äôs going to split in half.

‚ÄúFuck you,‚Äù her voice shakes. ‚ÄúStay the hell away from me.‚Äù

He looks like he‚Äôs about to say something but she‚Äôs not interested, slamming the door shut behind her and running up the stairs with her shoes still on. She can hear her mother and sister calling after her but she doesn‚Äôt answer, doesn‚Äôt turn around, shutting the door to her bedroom and collapsing against it.

And oh.

Oh hello.

Here they are.

Tears stream down her face as she chokes into her hand, trying not to make too much noise. Somehow she ends up on the ground, knees pulled into her chest, forehead resting on top of them. They‚Äôve done this so many times by now, her and Sev, she doesn‚Äôt know why it still feels like this. Like cutting something out of herself.

I love you.

How dare he. How fucking dare he. After everything. After years.

I love you.

She lifts her head like that‚Äôll help her breathe, sobs taking up all the space in her chest, leaving no room for air.

I love you.

It hurts because he does. Because she wants him to. Because she waited so long to hear him say it. So many nights when they got quiet and their hands got close and their noses almost touched. It hurts because it‚Äôs part of the reason she held on to him for so long. Held on to this. Because she knew deep down, everything she felt. Everything he felt. It hurts because she understands now that it isn‚Äôt enough. Loving someone. It doesn‚Äôt save you. Not in the end.

¬†

Petunia‚Äôs hen do is about as awful as one would expect. Pink and white decorations are strewn about the living room which slowly fills with women who are on ridiculous diets and therefore do not eat fancy cheeses and baguettes. Fine, Lily thinks, more for me. Admittedly, the cheese does help make her a little less miserable. Well, the cheese and the wine.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù a girl with a garish shade of orange lipstick says to her on one of her many trips to the food table. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt even know Petunia had a sister, isn‚Äôt that funny?‚Äù

Lily looks at her flatly. ‚ÄúHilarious. Baguette?‚Äù

The woman looks a little startled. ‚ÄúOh no, I‚Äôm not eating carbs.‚Äù

Lily isn‚Äôt sure if she smiles or grimaces.

She sits in the corner with her plate of food and watches her sister make small talk and receive gifts and play games like Purse Scavenger Hunt and Pin the Veil on the Bride. Some sort of soft melodic music playing in the background.

Lily had always been under the impression that hen dos were meant to be a bit more wild than this, but then, she supposes she isn‚Äôt surprised. Petunia doesn‚Äôt do wild, not anymore. She does tight and ordered and stiff. Their grandmother, before she passed, had a case of little porcelain figurines, beautiful cherub looking things. Somedays Lily thinks that‚Äôs Petunia‚Äôs aspiration in life. To be a porcelain figure in a glass case.

‚ÄúLily,‚Äù Petunia hovers over her chair. The heels she insisted Lily wear, even though they are in their own house, have been left in a heap on the carpet, her legs tucked up under her skirt. ‚ÄúRefill the refreshments please.‚Äù

Lily‚Äôs brow arches. After all, she‚Äôs the only one who‚Äôs been eating the refreshments, she can‚Äôt really see the point in‚Äî

‚ÄúNow,‚Äù Petunia hisses, before floating away.

Rolling her eyes Lily heads towards the kitchen to get the rest of the food, maneuvering her way through the sea of women who are all dressed up far too much to just be puttering around their living room.

‚Äú-selfish. Spends all her time at that posh boarding school, barely ever comes home. Petunia has to manage everything.‚Äù

The sound of voices causes Lily to stop in the hallway, hidden from the people talking in the kitchen.

‚ÄúHow can they even afford it? I mean, I was under the impression that their mother hasn‚Äôt much money?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey can‚Äôt, but apparently she won‚Äôt hear of going anywhere else. Like I said, selfish. Did you know that she didn‚Äôt even come home for their father‚Äôs funeral?‚Äù

Lily takes a step back, feeling as though she‚Äôs just been hit, her face burning. The two women are still talking but she can‚Äôt hear anything, the buzzing in her ears growing too loud. It‚Äôs not until someone laughs somewhere behind that she starts moving again. She needs to get out of here. She needs to breathe.

Without thinking she pushes her way through the house, sliding out the back door and into the garden. The fresh air feels good on her hot skin, pulse going a mile a minute as she presses her back against the house and inhales, eyes falling closed.

She‚Äôd only been twelve when her father died. She would have come home, she would have been here, if she could have been. But it had happened so suddenly. A car accident. No warning. No preparation. There are no telephones at Hogwarts, if her mother was a witch she could have used the floo, but, of course, she isnt. Lily hadn‚Äôt had an owl then, because her mother didn‚Äôt know where they would keep it during the summer (and honestly, they couldn‚Äôt afford it). Which meant that the only way to contact her, was through the Muggle post.

Letters addressed to Hogwarts do make it there, but it takes time. More time than an owl. So by the time Lily found out about her father‚Äôs death, by the time all the arrangements were made for her to be able to floo her mum, to speak with her, a week had passed. Her father was buried. The funeral over.

Even now Lily feels the ache of that pain cut through her. How fucking devastated she had been. How lonely. Sometimes being Muggle born feels like floating‚Äîwith no anchor, no port. She belongs nowhere. In the magic world she‚Äôs a person without a history‚Äîmagical families have legacies and friendships that stretch back millennia. They know who their great-great-great grandfather‚Äôs were (sometimes they‚Äôve even spoken to them, if they have portraits). Lily has none of that, no link to the magical world, no familiar faces, she‚Äôs on her own. In the Muggle world she finds it hard to relate to people. There‚Äôs a whole part of reality that they know nothing about, a whole part of her that they know nothing about, and she‚Äôs never sure how to bridge that gap.

She startles at the sound of the screen door opening, looking over to find her sister stepping out into the yard. Petunia walks forward, not seeing Lily yet, and takes in a deep breath, letting her face tilt up towards the sky on the exhale. After a few seconds she reaches into the pocket of her skirt and pulls out a packet of cigarettes.

‚ÄúAnd after all the shit you‚Äôve given me for smoking,‚Äù Lily says, voice sounding loud in the quiet.

Petunia whips around, eyes narrowing as she picks Lily out of the dark.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing out here?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat are YOU doing out here?‚Äù Lily repeats petulantly. Even in the dark she can see her sister roll her eyes.

‚ÄúWhatever,‚Äù Petunia turns back around, looking out over the garden as she brings the cigarette to her mouth, the burning tip the brightest thing in the yard. Lily knows the smart thing for her to do would be to go inside. Nothing good ever comes from the two of them being left alone together. But she‚Äôs had just enough wine to feel reckless.

‚ÄúWhy are you doing this?‚Äù

‚ÄúDoing what?‚Äù her sister asks, without turning around.

‚ÄúThis,‚Äù Lily gestures at the house, at the dismal party going on inside. ‚ÄúGetting married. You‚Äôre barely out of school, you have so much time, and Vernon‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôd be careful if I were you,‚Äù there is danger in her tone.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not a match for you,‚Äù Lily says anyway.

Petunia actually laughs at that, tilting her head back and blowing smoke up into the sky, catching the moonlight. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says finally, ‚Äúhe isn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Well, Lily thinks, at least we can agree on that.

‚ÄúDoes he just look right then? Is that it? Very domestic, very proper, straight-laced.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething like that.‚Äù

Behind them the noise of the party drifts closer, someone‚Äôs started playing ABBA, there‚Äôs the sound of laughing, the buzz of polite conversation.

‚ÄúDad would hate him,‚Äù which is the wrong thing to say on every level. But the wine is still thrumming through her and so is the pain from conversation she overheard in the kitchen.

Petunia finally turns around. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you talk to me about dad.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk about whatever I want.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt here‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not my fault!‚Äù Lily steps forward now, off of the wall, into her sister‚Äôs space, trying to restrain her childish desire to kick and scream and throw a temper tantrum.

Not my fault.

Not my fault.

Not my fault.

‚ÄúIt is your fault,‚Äù Petunia jabs her cigarette at her. ‚ÄúYou chose that school.‚Äù

Lily blinks, slightly taken off guard. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could have stayed here, you could have stayed with us. But you chose to go off and leave us behind. So you weren‚Äôt here. Not when the police showed up, not when we had to identify the body, not when we buried him,‚Äù chills run up Lily‚Äôs spine and she does her best not to flinch. ‚ÄúI was the one who had to plan the funeral‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou had mum!‚Äù Lily interrupts, finding her voice. ‚ÄúI had no one, I was alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúHa!‚Äù Petunia laughs cruelly. ‚ÄúMum was bloody catatonic. I had to force her to get out of bed, to eat, to shower. I started sleeping in her room because I was afraid to leave her alone, afraid she was going to‚Äî‚Äú but her voice cuts out, and Lily can see her hand shaking as she takes another drag from her cigarette, turning away again.

Lily doesn‚Äôt know what to do with any of this, her chest a storm of feelings she can‚Äôt work through. ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt you tell me?‚Äù she whispers finally.

Petunia sends her a sharp look, eyes bright under the stars. ‚ÄúYou. Weren‚Äôt. Here,‚Äù another pause, and then; ‚ÄúSo yes, Vernon is boring and predictable. But at least I will always know where he is and when he‚Äôs coming home and I won‚Äôt have to worry about him running off places I can‚Äôt follow or getting drunk and trying to fucking drive himself home.‚Äù Her voice breaks and Lily feels her chest grow tight, feels herself struggle to breathe.

They never talk about that apart.

The part where their father was twice over the legal limit.

The part where it was his fault.

‚ÄúMaybe dad would have hated him,‚Äù Petunia goes on eventually, throwing her cigarette on the ground and turning back towards the house. ‚ÄúBut to be perfectly honest I couldn‚Äôt care less about that man‚Äôs opinion,‚Äù the pain in her voice makes the words difficult to believe. Her eyes meet Lily‚Äôs, running her up and down, a familiar look of disgust on her face. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just like him you know?‚Äù

And with that she goes back inside.

¬†

Mary calls the next day, asking Lily to pick up some last minute things for the party and she can‚Äôt say yes fast enough. Anything to get out of the house. Anything to get away from her sister.

Technically, she doesn‚Äôt need to go to Diagon Alley to get the things Mary asked for. But, the truth is, she misses magic. Desperately. So she takes the train into London and then walks to the Leaky Cauldron, getting butterflies in her stomach as the familiar brick wall dissolves in front of her revealing the bustling wizarding street on the other side. She feels instantly as though a weight has been lifted off of her.

Her eyes bounce everywhere, sucking all of it in, feeling her own magic humming below her skin, desperate to get free. Mary says she can never decide which she likes better‚Äîthe Muggle world or the wizarding one. Lily doesn‚Äôt have that problem. For all its faults, she loves magic. Loves it to bits.

She gets some sweets for tomorrow even though she can already see Mary rolling her eyes ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not six Lily‚Äù she‚Äôll say. Personally, Lily takes great offence at the idea that only six-year-olds are allowed to get excited about candy. She also gets butterbeer and ice cream from Florean‚Äôs‚Äîthat‚Äôs just for her‚Äîand is debating going into the bookshop when she hears her name called out behind her.

‚ÄúLily Evans, as I live and breathe.‚Äù

Sirius Black is sauntering towards her through the crowd, leather jacket over his tight black t-shirt and jeans. She smiles because it just feels so right‚Äîlike yes, of course this is how he dresses outside of school.

‚ÄúFancy seeing you here.‚Äù

He gives her a one armed hug that she can only lean into because of the aforementioned bags and ice cream.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù he says, scanning the display window she‚Äôd been admiring. ‚ÄúLast minute school shopping?‚Äù

She shakes her head. ‚ÄúActually, I was thinking of just going in for fun.‚Äù

‚ÄúCourse you were,‚Äù shakes his head. ‚ÄúWaisting your last few precious days of freedom reading. Doesn‚Äôt surprise me at all.‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúOh please, you‚Äôre basically top of our year, so you‚Äôll have to excuse me if I don‚Äôt buy the whole ‚Äòreading is lame‚Äô routine.‚Äù

Sirius shoots her a wolfish grin, ‚ÄúYou got me,‚Äù he leans his head a little closer to her‚Äôs. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell anyone though, okay? I‚Äôve a reputation to uphold.‚Äù

‚ÄúScouts honour.‚Äù

His eyebrows draw together in confusion. ‚ÄúScouts?‚Äù

Lily smiles a little, ‚ÄúNever mind, Muggle thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù he nods thoughtfully before his eyes drop down to the bags in her hands. ‚ÄúWhat d‚Äôyou got there?‚Äù

It takes Lily a minute to answer because she‚Äôs just shoved the rest of her ice cream cone in her mouth. ‚ÄúParty supplies,‚Äù she says, mouth still partially full.

Sirius gives her a bemused sort of smile. ‚ÄúYou know, you‚Äôre adorable when you‚Äôre being gross.‚Äù

She swallows before letting out a laugh, the back of her hand coming to her mouth, trying to hold some of it back. ‚ÄúThat might be my favourite compliment‚Äîor insult? I‚Äôm not sure which honestly.‚Äù

‚ÄúCompliment,‚Äù he confirms. ‚ÄúDefinitely a compliment. So, you‚Äôre throwing a party then?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äîoh! No, no,‚Äù she holds up the bags. ‚ÄúThese are for Mary‚Äôs thing tomorrow.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù she sees just the slightest dimming of his eyes and feels her heart give a pull.

‚ÄúShe said you didn‚Äôt think you should come?‚Äù

Sirius shrugs in an overly casual gesture, hands shoving themselves into his pockets. ‚ÄúWell, you know‚Ä¶‚Äù he looks back at the shop window.

‚ÄúThings are still‚Ä¶tense between you lot then? I would have thought, what with you living at James‚Äôs house‚Ä¶‚Äù

Sirius lets out a breath of laughter. ‚ÄúYes, that has been a little tricky,‚Äù he pauses and then; ‚ÄúThings with James are actually‚Ä¶alright, I think,‚Äù his faces scrunches up like he‚Äôs trying to work out something complicated. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not fighting anymore but we‚Äôre not‚Ä¶not normal.‚Äù

‚ÄúThus why you‚Äôre here alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he smiles dryly, ‚Äúthus why I‚Äôm here alone.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, Sirius still looking very resolutely at the book display and Lily looking at him.

‚ÄúIf you and James are‚Ä¶better,‚Äù she settles on eventually. ‚ÄúThen I can‚Äôt imagine he would mind you coming to the party?‚Äù

Sirius grimaces. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not him I‚Äôm worried about.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù she says knowingly, trying not to think about what Mary said the other day, because really, she shouldn‚Äôt know any of it anyway and besides, she doesn‚Äôt believe it. Doesn‚Äôt believe Remus would cut him off just for‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs where they are now,‚Äù Sirius goes on when she doesn‚Äôt. Lily gets the sense that he hasn‚Äôt had many people to talk to this summer, ‚ÄúRemus‚Äôs. You know I‚Äôve never been to his house before? Best mates five years and I‚Äôve never been to his house. James has‚ÄîI mean now he‚Äôs been loads, but even before. It didn‚Äôt really bother me then but now, now I think that maybe it‚Äôs because Remus always knew, deep down.‚Äù

‚ÄúKnew what?‚Äù Lily asks, voice gentle.

‚ÄúThat he couldn‚Äôt trust me.‚Äù

It hurts, the way he says it. So strange to see Sirius Black anything but cocky and carefree. She finds herself reaching out and squeezing his arm.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a casual thing for him, having people at his house, meeting his parents. He guards those parts of himself, keeps them safe, shares them with the people he believes in most,‚Äù he shrugs. ‚ÄúI guess I was never one of them. He‚Äôs always been a good judge of character our Moony.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù she ducks her head, trying to get him to meet her eye again. Eventually it works. ‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt get upset‚Äîdon‚Äôt get hurt‚Äîby just having their suspicions confirmed. He did trust you, and maybe whatever you did broke that, but broken things can be fixed.‚Äù

He looks about as earnest as she‚Äôs ever seen him. ‚ÄúNot all of them.‚Äù

She thinks of Petunia, standing in the garden at night, her voice breaking.

You weren‚Äôt here.

It is your fault.

Lily shakes her head, trying to shut those thoughts off. ‚ÄúCome to the party,‚Äù she says suddenly.

Sirius looks at her skeptically, but Lily doubles down.

‚ÄúCome to the party Sirius. You know, you do have other friends besides those three.‚Äù

And that, finally, brings the light back to his face. ‚ÄúNot so long ago you would have stuck a nail in your eye before admitting to being my friend.‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù she scoffs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre being dramatic.‚Äù

He gives her a pointed look.

‚ÄúOh alright, maybe in first and second year.‚Äù

The look continues.

‚ÄúAnd third year,‚Äù she concedes eventually, ‚Äúbut you were definitely growing on me by fourth year.‚Äù

Sirius laughs. ‚ÄúI am an acquired taste.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike caviar.‚Äù

He taps the tip of his nose like they‚Äôre in cahoots. ‚ÄúLike caviar.‚Äù

She smiles, ‚ÄúCome to the party Sirius,‚Äù she says for the third time. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll all have to be together in a week when we go back to school anyway.‚Äù

He continues to look unconvinced. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll think about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThinking doesn‚Äôt strike me as one of your strong suits.‚Äù

He laughs, big and barking, ‚ÄúOh, you have no idea.‚Äù

The sun has started getting heavier in the sky, hanging low and threatening to sink below the horizon. The crowds on the street have thinned but only slightly. It‚Äôs summer, so it‚Äôs never completely empty, people sitting outside on patios and inside at candlelit tables.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Sirius jabs her with his elbow, ‚Äúyou got any plans tonight Evans?‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus, do you sharpen your elbows or something?‚Äù she asks, rubbing her side. ‚ÄúAnd no, not really, why?‚Äù

‚ÄúLets get dinner, the Leaky, my treat.‚Äù

She lets out a huff of laughter. ‚ÄúYou asking me on a date, Black?‚Äù

‚ÄúGingers aren‚Äôt really my type.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù

‚ÄúFirst off,‚Äù he says, while annoyingly dodging her fist, ‚ÄúI share a dorm room with three marauders, if you wanna hit me you‚Äôre going to have to be faster than that,‚Äù she glares at him. ‚ÄúSecondly, are you saying you want to be my type?‚Äù he raises his eyebrows at her suggestively.

‚ÄúEw, no.‚Äù

He laughs, swinging his arm around her shoulders. ‚ÄúGlad we‚Äôre on the same page freckles, now, come on, let me buy you dinner. I‚Äôm rich now, did you know?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust now?‚Äù she says, allowing herself to be dragged down the street. ‚ÄúI thought you were always rich. I thought being rich was like 85% of your personality.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah, my family was rich. But now I, personally, Sirius Black III, am rich.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe III? Really? There are three of you?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, not currently.‚Äù

She snorts. ‚ÄúIn that case, I hope you know I‚Äôm getting the most expensive thing on the menu.‚Äù

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd expect nothing less.‚Äù

¬†

The next day Lily gets to Mary‚Äôs house early to help set up. They mix drinks and listen to music and get dressed. Getting ready is honestly Lily‚Äôs favourite part of going out. She likes the ritual of it, the easiness. Just the three of them giggling and dancing like goofs. Not trying to impress anyone.

‚ÄúWell, well, look at you,‚Äù Lily says as Mary walks out of the bathroom in a mini dress that on anyone else would be trying too hard but on Mary is absolutely divine.

‚ÄúThank you, thank you,‚Äù she gives a little bow.

‚ÄúOw ow!‚Äù Marlene whistles as she walks in with the punchbowl, setting it down on the table they‚Äôve set up in the living room. Mary‚Äôs parents are on vacation with her little brother so they have the place to themselves. The one downside being that there‚Äôs no floo so everyone will have to get there the muggle way, well, except for Alice and Frank who can apparate.

Lily flips the record, turning the volume up. ‚ÄúGod I love this song.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou say that about every song,‚Äù Mary quips, earning her a rude hand gesture from Lily that makes Marlene laugh.

It‚Äôs not long before there‚Äôs a loud crack in the front hall and then: ‚ÄúWHO‚ÄôS READY TO PARTY BITCHES!‚Äù

‚ÄúI think Alice might be here,‚Äù Marlene says dryly as the short, dark haired girl bursts into the living room, a bottle in each hand.

‚ÄúWhat an entrance Prewett,‚Äù Mary pulls the older girl into a hug as Frank rounds the corner significantly more quietly.

‚ÄúHey Captain,‚Äù Marlene grins.

‚ÄúNot anymore I‚Äôm not,‚Äù he laughs, rubbing the back of his neck. Alice moves on to hug Marlene, dropping her bottles off on the table before making her way to Lily.

‚ÄúHey babes,‚Äù she pulls her into a quick embrace, ‚Äúhaven‚Äôt seen you in ages.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been busy.‚Äù

Alice lets out something between a laugh and a groan. ‚ÄúHaven‚Äôt I ever.‚Äù

Lily opens her mouth to ask more but Mary‚Äôs voice cuts across the room, eyes on Frank.

‚ÄúSo who did get the badge of honour in the end, since I noticed you made the grave mistake of not naming me as your successor,‚Äù Mary‚Äôs leaning against the wall, hip cocked, eyes glittering in that way they do where you can‚Äôt tell if she‚Äôs flirting with you or threatening you.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôll be Potter.‚Äù

Marlene groans. ‚ÄúI bloody knew it, he‚Äôs going to be insufferable.‚Äù

‚ÄúInsufferable? He‚Äôs going to be a monster. Watch, I bet the little Quidditch freak makes us start practice at five in the morning,‚Äù Mary says disdainfully.

‚ÄúYou guys aren‚Äôt giving him enough credit,‚Äù Frank, ever the earnest one. ‚ÄúI think he‚Äôll do a really good job of it, honestly.‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúPlease, that‚Äôs just because you‚Äôre in love with him.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm in love with Alice, thank you very much.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes dear, but you do get a bit of glazed look in your eyes when you watch James fly,‚Äù Alice sing-songs, causing Frank to let out a series of mortified choking noises.

‚ÄúI‚Äîthey do not!‚Äù

Lily really does try not to laugh, but he just looks so precious, blushing and spluttering. Alice links her arm through Lily‚Äôs pulling her in close as though the whole room can‚Äôt still hear what she‚Äôs saying.

‚ÄúHe thinks I don‚Äôt know about his little crushes but I do.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh my God,‚Äù Frank passes a hand over his flushed face. ‚ÄúI need a drink.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight here Frankie-boy!‚Äù Marlene grins from the table, lifting up her own cup. ‚ÄúWhat do you want?‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething strong.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôll be Mary‚Äôs punch then.‚Äù

Frank makes a slightly queasy expression. ‚ÄúUgh, maybe not that strong.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw, big tough Auror can‚Äôt handle a little punch?‚Äù Mary says in a baby voice.

The teasing does not appear to phase Frank, who starts pouring himself a glass of firewhiskey and apple juice. ‚ÄúNot if you‚Äôve had anything to do with it.‚Äù

Alice and Lily meander over to the others, getting their own drinks.

‚ÄúOooh, we should toast,‚Äù Mary holds up her cup.

Lily arches her brow, ‚ÄúShould we?‚Äù at nearly the same time that Marlene asks; ‚ÄúTo what?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, to us!‚Äù

‚ÄúTo us?‚Äù Marlene repeats. ‚ÄúNot a very inspiring toast Mary.‚Äù

‚ÄúI still don‚Äôt understand why we‚Äôre toasting at all?‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes at the both of them while Alice snickers. ‚ÄúFine. To being young and beautiful and hooking up with Amos Diggory tonight.‚Äù

Marlene makes a retching noise.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Lily agrees, wrinkling her nose. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not toasting to that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am also not toasting to that,‚Äù Frank pipes up, looking thoroughly disturbed.

‚ÄúOh Jesus, you lot are so high-maintenance,‚Äù she shakes out her shoulders and tries again. ‚ÄúTo winning the Quidditch cup this year.‚Äù

‚ÄúHere here,‚Äù Frank and Marlene immediately raise their glasses, and with such enthusiasm that some of their drinks rain down on the table.

‚ÄúBetter than Amos Diggory I guess,‚Äù Lily tries to hide her smile at Marlene‚Äôs affronted look, all of them clinking their glasses together.

¬†

People start arriving quickly after that, Mary‚Äôs house filling up with a surprising number of strangers. Lily had assumed that she would know most of the people coming but she seems to have miscalculated Mary‚Äôs popularity. A rookie move. The woman in question is nowhere to be found. She had been draping herself over Amos‚Äôs lap on the sofa not ten minutes ago, but now Lily can‚Äôt find the couple anywhere. Not that she‚Äôs really looking, that‚Äôs one thing she absolutely does not need to walk in on.

It‚Äôs hot, too hot really, even with all the windows and doors open. Lily sticks mostly to the wall, something about standing in the open always makes her feel awkward and suddenly she‚Äôll forget what she‚Äôs supposed to do with her arms and legs‚Äîat least when there‚Äôs a wall she has a prop to work with.

‚ÄúWe have got to stop meeting like this.‚Äù

Lily turns to find Sirius leaning next to her, his hair is pulled back tonight, likely because of the heat. It ought to look ridiculous but, as with everything, it kind of suits him.

‚ÄúYou came,‚Äù she says smugly.

‚ÄúAh well, after you practically begged me to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúUm, excuse me?‚Äù she demands in mock indignation. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt remember any begging.‚Äù

He cocks his eyebrow. ‚ÄúReally? I could‚Äôve sworn there was begging. Then again, maybe that was the dream I had last night, except in that you weren‚Äôt wearing any‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOH MY GOD Sirius,‚Äù she punches his arm, and this time he actually stands still. ‚ÄúYou are unbelievable you know that? I thought gingers weren‚Äôt your type.‚Äù

He laughs. ‚ÄúMeh, depends on the day really.‚Äù

‚ÄúIncorrigible.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I‚Äôve been told.‚Äù

She shakes her head, smiling despite herself as she looks back out at the party. She can see Remus and Peter now, standing on the other side of the room with Frank and some seventh year boy Lily barely recognizes. She turns back to Sirius and finds him staring in the same direction.

‚ÄúHave you talked to them?‚Äù she asks.

He shakes his head, not dropping his gaze.

‚ÄúThey know you‚Äôre here?‚Äù

‚ÄúI told James to check with Remus, see if it was okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, that‚Äôs encouraging,‚Äù she pauses, Sirius still looking at his friends. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm assuming he didn‚Äôt say no?‚Äù

Sirius lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúNo, he didn‚Äôt say no. But you‚Äôve met him, he never would, even if he wanted to.‚Äù

Lily isn‚Äôt sure if that‚Äôs actually true, but then, she wonders if maybe it‚Äôs just that Remus would never say no to Sirius.

‚ÄúAre you going to talk to them?‚Äù

Sirius grimaces, finally turning back to her. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôd be a good idea. Peter‚Äôd probably talk back but he‚Äôd be stressed out the whole time.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd Remus?‚Äù

He sighs. ‚ÄúGod, I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he‚Äôs looking at him again, like he can‚Äôt help it, and Lily feels her heart ache for him a little. He really does look heartbroken. Fuck, she thinks, maybe Mary was right.

She opens her mouth to speak but before she can the undeniable voice of Alice Prewett cuts through the party.

‚ÄúSIRIUS!‚Äù

They both turn to look as Alice hops up and down, trying to be seen over the tops of people‚Äôs shoulders.

‚ÄúGET YOUR CUTE ASS OVER HERE!‚Äù

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúHow gone is she?‚Äù he asks.

‚ÄúGive her a break, it‚Äôs her first day off in months.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat Auror training‚Äôs really something huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúWho would have thought.‚Äù

‚ÄúSIRIUS‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYes darling, I‚Äôm coming!‚Äù he trills, attempting to forge a path through the crowd. He looks back at Lily over his shoulder. ‚ÄúComing?‚Äù

She waves him off. ‚ÄúYou go, I think I need to step out for a minute, get some fresh air.‚Äù

He nods. ‚ÄúAlright, I‚Äôll find you later yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, definitely.‚Äù

Sirius is promptly swallowed by the wall of bodies in front of them, and when Lily‚Äôs eyes trail back over to the other side of the room she finds Remus watching him.

Jesus, she thinks, what a mess.

She does eventually manage to make it out into the backyard. Sweat suddenly cold on her skin as the night air brushes against her. There‚Äôs one or two people she doesn‚Äôt know standing by the house so she decides to venture further out into the garden. It‚Äôs dark, but the stars are bright tonight, brighter than they‚Äôve been all summer, so Lily doesn‚Äôt mind.

It‚Äôs because of the lack of light that it takes her so long to notice him. James Potter, lying on the grass, looking up at the sky. She freezes for a moment, just staring at him, wondering if she should turn back‚Äîsurely she‚Äôs had enough of the marauders for one night? But her traitorous feet don‚Äôt start towards the house again, instead they make a B-line straight for him.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù she says lamely, and then nearly makes a u-turn right back around because what is she even doing? It‚Äôs not like she has anything to say to him.

James blinks up at her, eyes cloudy and a little blood shot. Ah, she thinks, he‚Äôs drunk.

‚ÄúDid you fall or are you down there on purpose?‚Äù she asks.

He snorts. ‚ÄúOn purpose.‚Äù

She nods, pausing for a moment before sitting down next to him, crossing her legs and looking up. She‚Äôs always liked astronomy, even if it is a bit trickier than some of her other classes. There‚Äôs something nice about the way it‚Äôs always there, in the sky, no matter where you are. After a few seconds James pushes himself up so that he‚Äôs sitting too, though he‚Äôs a bit clumsy about it.

‚ÄúHow long have you been here Potter?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Äîdunno‚Äîhour maybe?‚Äù

She quirks her brow. ‚ÄúReally been throwing them back huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúHm,‚Äù he hums, eyes still on the sky. ‚ÄúPunch.‚Äù

That checks out.

‚ÄúYou ought to know better than to touch Mary‚Äôs punch.‚Äù

But he shakes his head. ‚ÄúNah, this is good,‚Äù he closes his eyes for a minute. ‚ÄúThis feels better‚Ä¶even if the world is spinning a bit.‚Äù

There‚Äôs something sad in his voice that catches her off guard. ‚ÄúFeels better than what?‚Äù

‚ÄúI miss, I miss, I miss.‚Äù

‚ÄúWow, you really are drunk.‚Äù

His eyes blink open again. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

They sit in silence, the party rumbling on behind them, an indistinct mess of music and shouting. Lily wonders if she should leave him alone but she can‚Äôt quite seem to make herself move. Maybe she‚Äôs drunker than she thought? Though to be honest she feels almost painfully sober right now.

‚ÄúSo who is it then?‚Äù she decides to ask.

He blinks, looking over at her. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúWho is it you‚Äôre out here missing?‚Äù

He looks oddly panicked for a second. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt say‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt say there was‚Äîright? I didn‚Äôt say anything‚Äîanyone‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt say there was anyone. Jesus,‚Äù he brings his fingers up and pinches the bridge of his nose.

Lily gives him a minute, and then; ‚ÄúNo one gets this melancholic over something that doesn‚Äôt have a heartbeat.‚Äù

He laughs at that. ‚ÄúMight be true, though you‚Äôve never seen the way Sirius looks at his leather Jacket.‚Äù

Lily smiles. ‚ÄúI can imagine.‚Äù

James sighs, looking back out at the sky. Lily waits for him to answer her question but when he speaks that‚Äôs not what happens.

‚ÄúYou see those stars?‚Äù he asks, pointing at a cluster just above her.

‚ÄúUm‚Äîyeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs,‚Äù he stops, swallows, starts again, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs Ophiuchus, it‚Äôs supposed to be a guy wrestling with a snake, I looked it up. I always look up the things he‚Äîanyway‚Äîapparently he tried to warn the Trojans about the Trojan Horse, so the gods sent a pair of sea serpents to punish him.‚Äù

Lily looks from James to the stars. ‚ÄúHuh, didn‚Äôt realize you knew so much about Muggle myths.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt,‚Äù she waits for him to explain but he doesn‚Äôt.

She keeps looking at the constellation‚ÄîOphiuchus‚Äîtilting her head to the side. ‚ÄúIt kinda looks like a turtle.‚Äù

And that gets a laugh out of him, a proper one, probably bigger than it would have been if he was sober. ‚ÄúRight? That‚Äôs what I said, but he was all‚Äî‚Äú James stops abruptly, coughing like that will make it more natural.

Lily looks over at him. ‚ÄúHe? Sirius you mean?‚Äù because his whole family is named after stars so if anyone‚Äôs been teaching James Potter about the constellations it makes sense that it would be him.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîsure,‚Äù but James almost immediately pulls a face. ‚ÄúUgh, actually no, no, definitely not, too gross.‚Äù

‚ÄúGross?‚Äù

‚ÄúEvans, what‚Äôs with the questions huh? I‚Äôm too drunk for questions.‚Äù

Lily holds her hands up in surrender. ‚ÄúHey, you‚Äôre the one going on astronomy rants not me.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, well, again,‚Äù he points at his face, ‚Äúdrunk. I don‚Äôt know what the fuck I‚Äôm doing. You‚Äôre supposed to be the responsible one here, stop me.‚Äù

Lily laughs. ‚ÄúStop you? Stop you what? Talking.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. Please.‚Äù

She sits there for a moment, traitorous eye dropping to his mouth which‚Äîno, ew, what‚Äîshe quickly looks away, reaching into her back pocket and pulling out her cigarettes. She‚Äôs going to have to quit after this summer. It wasn‚Äôt a habit before now, just something she did on hard days. But then, maybe there have been more hard days recently.

She puts one between her fingers before offering the box to James, he looks skeptical.

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt peg you for a smoker Evans.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you do know what they are.‚Äù

He looks up, affronted. ‚ÄúOf course I know what they are.‚Äù

Lily shrugs, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to tell with wizards.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm mildly offended by that.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood.‚Äù

He snorts, looking back down at the pack.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to take one you know?‚Äù she says, watching him hesitate.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he rubs the back of his neck. ‚ÄúThing is, okay, I know what they are, I just don‚Äôt‚Ä¶don‚Äôt quite know how they‚Ä¶work.‚Äù

Lily does her best to stifle a laugh. ‚ÄúGod and they think you‚Äôre the bad one, Remus at least had some idea what he was doing.‚Äù

James‚Äôs eyes flash up. ‚ÄúHave you been corrupting my Moony?‚Äù

‚ÄúYour Moony?‚Äù she arches her brow, trying to ignore the bit of her stomach that flutters at the adorableness of the statement.

‚ÄúDid you think he belonged to someone else?‚Äù James asks.

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt aware he belonged to anyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he looks down and, with a little trepidation, pulls a cigarette out of the pack, ‚Äúnow you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù she bites down on a smile, ‚ÄúAnd Peter?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúAlso mine.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt quite see the point in asking but‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYes, Sirius too, honestly Evans, I thought you were supposed to be clever, keep up,‚Äù he snaps his fingers and Lily laughs.

‚ÄúI guess I didn‚Äôt realize you were quite so territorial.‚Äù

‚ÄúClearly you haven‚Äôt been paying enough attention to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúClearly,‚Äù she repeats, amused. ‚ÄúAlright, put this,‚Äù she holds up her cigarette, ‚Äúbetween your lips, I‚Äôm going to light the end and you‚Äôre going to inhale okay? Inhale and hold it, right in your chest.‚Äù

James is looking at her like she‚Äôs insane. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to light it while it‚Äôs in my mouth?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Looking very concerned he does as she asked. ‚ÄúJust know,‚Äù he talks around the cigarette, ‚Äúthat if you burn my face I will sue you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat a posh threat,‚Äù she holds her fingers beneath his smoke and snaps. It always gives her a bit of a thrill when that works.

James‚Äôs eyes widen slightly, but he inhales before he can speak and then immediately starts coughing.

‚ÄúMerlin‚Äôs tits,‚Äù he wheezes. ‚ÄúOh my God,‚Äù Lily is laughing so hard she can‚Äôt light her own cigarette. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fucking awful,‚Äù tears are spilling out of the corners of his eyes. ‚ÄúWhat the fuck Evans, what the actual shite is this?‚Äù his free hand clutches at his chest as he doubles over.

‚ÄúIt gets better,‚Äù Lily finally manages, winded from her laughter. ‚ÄúThe first one is the hardest.‚Äù

‚ÄúGets better?‚Äù he wipes at his eyes with the back of his hand. ‚ÄúI should fucking hope so.‚Äù His face is bright red and wet, eyes all puffy, holding the cigarette away from his body like it‚Äôs a bomb he‚Äôs afraid is going to go off.

‚ÄúJust‚Äîjust try again,‚Äù Lily is still struggling to keep her giggling under control.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be better this time? You promise?‚Äù he gives the cigarette sidelong look.

‚ÄúSure, yeah, just, you have to breathe in deep, into your chest,‚Äù she points unhelpfully at her sternum.

‚ÄúYeah I fucking breathed in Evans that‚Äôs the god damn problem, shit,‚Äù he spits on the grass next to him. ‚ÄúOkay, okay I‚Äôm trying this once more but I swear if it‚Äôs not better‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll sue me, I got it. Big deep breath, hold it, let it out.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù he looks thoroughly unimpressed as he brings the cigarette back to his mouth and takes a tentative inhale. Instantly he starts coughing again.

‚ÄúOh‚Äîf‚Äîfuck you,‚Äù he sputters, now shoving the cigarette at her. Lily slips the unlit one behind her ear and takes James‚Äôs. ‚ÄúEvans you dirty fucking liar.‚Äù He has his hands on his knees, bracing himself as he tries to breathe through it, Lily cackling beside him.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you‚Äôre so bad at this,‚Äù though she sounds very pleased about it.

‚ÄúLiterally how can you be good at it‚Äîit‚Äôs like breathing fire into your lungs.‚Äù He wipes his hand across his face, finally able to sit up straight again.

Lily smiles as she brings the cigarette to her mouth and inhales, then tilts her head back and blows rings up into the sky.

‚ÄúWHAT THE HELL!‚Äù James yells‚Äîliterally yells‚Äîjabbing an accusing finger at her. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a spell, it has to be.‚Äù

But she shakes her head, still grinning. ‚ÄúNope, this is all Muggle my friend.‚Äù

He shakes his head, running a hand through the mess of hair on his head. ‚ÄúHow?‚Äù

‚ÄúPractice.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy would you practice if it always feels like shit the first time?‚Äù

Lily shrugs. ‚ÄúLooks cool I guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúUgh, fuck off, you sound like Sirius.‚Äù And then; ‚ÄúDo not, I repeat, under any circumstances, show him these hell sticks‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHell sticks?‚Äù Lily laughs.

‚Äú‚ÄîI‚Äôll never know peace again,‚Äù he goes on, ignoring her. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll start smoking them all the bloody time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, they certainly do match his look.‚Äù

James fixes her with a pointed stare. ‚ÄúLily.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh okay, I won‚Äôt, cross my heart,‚Äù she makes the motion with her hand.

He shakes his head again, collapsing back down onto the grass. ‚ÄúI never would have thought you‚Äôd be one to do it for the aesthetic Evans.‚Äù

I‚Äôm not, she almost says, but honestly, she doesn‚Äôt feel like having the dead dad conversation right now.

‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôve got to put in a little more effort now that I don‚Äôt have someone following me around proposing to me every five minutes.‚Äù

James groans. ‚ÄúFirst of all, I never proposed‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMm, pretty sure you did. Third year, middle of Magical Creatures.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was a joke!‚Äù

‚ÄúSure it was,‚Äù she‚Äôs glad it‚Äôs so dark, glad he can‚Äôt see the blush that is, for some reason, making its way to the tops of her cheeks.

‚ÄúBesides, I was never that interested in your looks anyway.‚Äù

Lily lets out a startled laugh. ‚ÄúYou really know how to make a girl feel special Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äî‚Äú and then she sees his eyes go wide. ‚ÄúOh come on, that‚Äôs not what I meant, you know that‚Äôs not what I meant.‚Äù

She looks at him, brow raised. ‚ÄúDo I?‚Äù

James rolls his eyes before propping himself up on his elbows. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre beautiful, you know you‚Äôre beautiful,‚Äù the blush starts to burn but Lily can‚Äôt seem to break eye contact with him. ‚ÄúBut there are a lot of beautiful girls, most girls honestly.‚Äù

Lily snorts at that and he shoots her a sheepish grin.

‚ÄúI liked you because the first day we met you put me in my place,‚Äù he laughs a little, hand running over his face. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a fucking force Lily Evans and you always have been, trying to get your attention was like chasing after a storm‚Äîterrifying and exhilarating and unbelievable every time.‚Äù

It‚Äôs only when he stops that Lily realizes she‚Äôs been holding her breath. Unsure what to do with herself she starts giving the cigarette in her hand a bit too much attention.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she says after her next exhale, ‚Äúwhen you put like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm drunk, I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôm explaining this right.‚Äù

Lilly quickly shakes her head. ‚ÄúNo, you‚Äîyou are, thank you.‚Äù

His face scrunches. ‚ÄúThank you?‚Äù

But all she can do is shrug.

They lapse into silence again, Lily trying very hard to focus on the grass in front of her, fingers nervously flicking at the cigarette in her hand, while James looks up at the sky.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad that we‚Äôre friends now,‚Äù he says eventually, not dropping his eyes. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs better this way, don‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Something in the pit of her stomach violently disagrees but she holds it down, smothering it. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she manages after a brief pause, ‚Äúbetter as friends.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

HELLO!

The next chapter is ALL Regulus I swear, but I always feel like the girls get a little neglected and also I just had a fun time writing this chapter so I hope you had a fun time reading it!!

Thank you for taking the time to read my lil story, I appreciate it a ton! Your comments are always enjoyed!

Chapter 19

Chapter Notes

You know it's a Regulus chapter when there are all these TWs honestly I'm sorry

TW: Referenced sexual assault
TW: Animal abuse (nothing is graphically described cause that would be TERRIBLE but you know it's happening)
TW: Child abuse (via magic)

** Also, I realize I operate under the assumption that everyone knows the story of Achilles and Patroclus, but incase you do not, real quick thing you might want to know for this chapter (Iliad spoilers???) : Achilles gets angry at Agamemnon (for being just generally garbage), and refuses to fight for him, the Greeks get crushed by the Trojans without him so Patroclus dresses up in Achilles's armour to scare the Trojans away and that's how he gets killed by Hector (if you do know the story and are like "girl this is a terrible summary" I know and I'm sorry)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

There‚Äôs no point in screaming.

It took Regulus a long time to learn that. He expects that‚Äôs Sirius‚Äôs fault. As long as he was here, there was always the chance that someone might come.

No one comes anymore.

Regulus is on the ground, feeling as though he‚Äôs had the skin flayed from his bones. He can‚Äôt tell where the borders of his body end anymore. He is just pain. No longer stuck behind the lines of his fingers and toes. He has no shape. He is bleeding out

‚ÄúUp.‚Äù

No.

‚ÄúGet. Up.‚Äù

No.

He doesn‚Äôt move, doesn‚Äôt think he can, can‚Äôt remember why he ever wanted to.

‚ÄúRegulus, get up.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can still Crucio him on the ground.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not the point‚ÄîGET UP.‚Äù

A boot slides under him and flips him clumsily onto his back.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he blinks his eyes open, finding Lucius hovering overtop of him.

‚ÄúWell look at that, he is alive,‚Äù he gives him another kick and Regulus curls onto his side, a pathetic attempt to protect himself.

‚ÄúNo, no,‚Äù it‚Äôs someone else who grabs him under his arms and pulls him up. ‚ÄúNo more hiding.‚Äù

Rodolphus‚Äîthat‚Äôs who picked him up‚Äîgives him a shove and he stumbles, legs shaking as he tries to keep himself standing.

‚ÄúThis didn‚Äôt have to be so difficult, you know,‚Äù Lucius grabs his jaw and forces his head up. Being this close to him always makes Regulus‚Äôs skin crawl, his pulse jackhammering in his chest.

‚ÄúCast the curse Regulus, that‚Äôs all we‚Äôre asking. According to your parents you get excellent marks, very bright, this really shouldn‚Äôt be so hard.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve tried,‚Äù Reg manages finally, teeth clenched. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt.‚Äù

Lucius‚Äôs hand starts squeezing, and Regulus is too tired to hold back the yelp it pulls from his throat.

‚ÄúTry. Harder.‚Äù

Lucius lets go, gesturing towards the pen that‚Äôs been set up in the middle of the yard. There are two bunnies in it. Well. There were. One is dead now. Bella got a little overzealous during her demonstration. Not to worry though, she doesn‚Äôt need a bunny when she has Regulus.

‚ÄúGo on Reg,‚Äù Narcissa is standing a little further back from the others, watching with a tense look on her face.

Regulus swallows, trying to get his eyes to focus before raising his wand. He‚Äôs not sure what the problem is anymore. At first he didn‚Äôt want to, but now? Now he‚Äôd do just about anything to put an end to this.

‚ÄúCrucio,‚Äù he says, with as much authority as he can muster.

Nothing happens. The bunny continues eating grass, Regulus‚Äôs wand continues to be absolutely useless in his hand. He closes his eyes. Fuck.

That‚Äôs about all he has time to think before another ‚ÄúCrucio‚Äù rings out behind him and suddenly he‚Äôs on fire again.

When he comes to he‚Äôs back on the ground, Lucius crouched beside him, elegant brow arched. There‚Äôs a new expression on his face‚Äîpity, Regulus thinks.

‚ÄúYou really aren‚Äôt doing yourself any favours here,‚Äù Lucius reaches out and brushes the hair off of Regulus‚Äôs forehead. Regulus hates it. Hates that he‚Äôs touching him, hates that he‚Äôs too weak to do anything about it.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù Lucius grabs him by the arm and pulls him back to his feet. The world swims around Regulus and he has to close his eyes to keep from throwing up.

‚ÄúAlright, maybe that‚Äôs enough Crucio for today huh? Why don‚Äôt you just Avada the thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt the plan Lucius,‚Äù Rodolphus grumbles in the background. ‚ÄúThe kid‚Äôs supposed to learn all three.‚Äù

When Regulus opens his eyes again he‚Äôs met with Lucius‚Äôs stare, still on him even when he answers.

‚ÄúYeah well, if you want him to learn anything you‚Äôre going to need to control your wife.‚Äù

There are spots in Regulus‚Äôs vision and he knows he‚Äôs on the verge of passing out, which he absolutely cannot do. Not here. Not with them.

‚ÄúHe needs toughening up,‚Äù Bellatrix slinks into view, her dark hair let loose down her back. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs too soft,‚Äù she drags her finger up Regulus‚Äôs arm as she circles him, hooking her chin over his shoulder and her hands over his chest.

He‚Äôs shaking, he‚Äôs sure she can feel it. He has to‚Äîto breathe. To remember to breathe. To remember that he can. He has to keep it together even though every part of him is filled with the desire to fall apart. To slip out of his skin. It‚Äôs covered in their fingerprints. It‚Äôs barely even his.

‚ÄúSee, little cousin,‚Äù she hisses in his ear. He wishes she would just Crucio him again. It would hurt less. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to be king one day.‚Äù

Bellatrix is all over him, and he has to bite down on his tongue as a sob starts to make its way up his throat. It doesn‚Äôt matter, he tries to tell himself, they‚Äôre just hands. Just bodies. It doesn‚Äôt matter.

Inhale.

Exhale.

‚ÄúLittle King Black,‚Äù she runs a bony knuckle down his face. ‚ÄúSo you need to be big and strong,‚Äù she‚Äôs slips easily into a baby voice. ‚ÄúNeed to lead the family to greatness. Because if you fail I will shred you with my teeth just like I intend to do to your brother.‚Äù

And then she bites him. Teeth digging into the meat between his neck and his shoulder before pushing him away. He doesn‚Äôt make any noise, mostly because he can‚Äôt. You have to be breathing to make noise. He stumbles forward, his body too clumsy to catch itself so he ends up on his hands and knees, heaving into the dirt, trying desperately not to throw-up. Bellatrix laughs in the background.

‚ÄúGo on Regulus,‚Äù she calls out, ‚Äúkill the wittle wabbit. Maybe next time we‚Äôll catch some Muggles instead.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know if she‚Äôs joking. He doesn‚Äôt want to think about it. With a deep breath he gets back to his feet, not looking at any of them. It‚Äôs bright, one of the last days of summer, the Scottish countryside stretching out in front of him. His father loves this view, it‚Äôs half the reason his parents bought the house in the first place.

Regulus wipes the sweat out of his eyes on the back of his wrist before lifting his wand again.

‚ÄúAvada Kedevra,‚Äù he knows better than to look away, knows they‚Äôll only make him do it again. Find some other thing for him to kill. He‚Äôs not sure why this spell is easier. Why he can manage one but not the other.

Lucius claps him on the back, making his shoulders tense. ‚ÄúGood boy.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeone should get the elf, I‚Äôm feeling like rabbit for dinner,‚Äù Bellatrix cackles.

Slowly, Regulus slips his wand back into the holster on his forearm, turning around and moving towards the house. He feels weak, light-headed, covered in sweat and dirt and desperate to just get the fuck away from everyone.

‚ÄúRegulus!‚Äù Lucius calls out to him, but he doesn‚Äôt stop, doesn‚Äôt turn around, doesn‚Äôt look at Narcissa as he pushes past her. He just needs to make it to his room. Needs to close the door. Needs to lock it.

‚ÄúSame time tomorrow‚Äîand you better be able to curse the bloody rabbits!‚Äù

He slams the backdoor shut behind him, running up the stairs to his room. His mother isn‚Äôt here right now, which is a blessing. He can feel his consciousness threatening to slip, pins and needles running up and down his legs and arms, vision blurring at the edges. He just needs to sit down. He just needs to breathe. He just needs no one to fucking touch him ever fucking again.

He very nearly cries when he gets to his room, throwing the door closed. ‚ÄúColloportus,‚Äù he snaps at it, hearing the clicking of the locks.

He collapses onto his bed. Still wearing his shoes. Still covered in dirt. He needs to shower and change but right now all he can manage is lying on his side and forcing himself to breathe.

Inhale.

Exhale.

Nothing matters.

None of it matters.

It doesn‚Äôt hurt.

It doesn‚Äôt hurt.

Stop crying, it doesn‚Äôt hurt.

He curls in tighter. It‚Äôs the fucking Crucio. It breaks him down inside, all his carefully built walls, all the ways he protects himself‚Äîshattered. It‚Äôs impossible to describe, that spell. It‚Äôs called the torture spell but that isn‚Äôt right. When you think torture you think skin and bones and blood. But Crucio is something else, something inside you. It unstitches every part of your psyche until your mind is nothing but lose threads.

There‚Äôs a hoot at the window. Regulus doesn‚Äôt even bother checking whose owl it is.

‚ÄúGo away,‚Äù he croaks.

Owls, unfortunately, are not particularly compliant creatures. The beast hoots again, fluttering its wings as it flies from the windowsill to the headboard.

‚ÄúI said go away,‚Äù he grabs the pillow next to him and hurls it up at the bird who lets out an indignant squawk. A few moments pass before he hears fluttering again, the owl landing next to him on the mattress.

Rolling his eyes, Regulus pulls himself up. ‚ÄúFine, give me the stupid letter then.‚Äù

Holding its head high, as though deeply offended, the bird sticks out its leg so Regulus can untie the parchment.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he snaps when the bird continues to stand there expectantly. ‚ÄúGo on, I‚Äôm not giving you anything.‚Äù

He swears the bird actually narrows its eyes, giving his hand a vicious peck before flying back out the window.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Regulus brings his hand to his mouth, willing to admit that he probably deserved that.

He doesn‚Äôt even need to see the name to know who the letter‚Äôs from. He‚Äôd recognize Evan‚Äôs messy scrawl anywhere.

Reg,

Tonight. Another one. Meet at the east corner at 11:45 pm.

Evs

He rolls his eyes at the nickname. It‚Äôs something stupid he started this summer. The only person who calls Evan Rosier ‚ÄúEvs‚Äù is Evan, but he‚Äôs convinced it‚Äôll catch on. The rest of the letter is less amusing. Regulus‚Äôs eyes scan over it one more time before throwing it on the floor and collapsing back onto his bed.

These nighttime excursions are another invention of the summer. Mulciber, Evan, Barty, some of the other boys, have decided they need to get Voldemort‚Äôs attention. And the best way they can think to do that is by attacking Ministry employees in the dead of night. Personally, Regulus thinks it‚Äôs a stupid idea that‚Äôs only going to put the Ministry on high alert for no reason. But according to someone‚Äôs brother‚Äôs cousin‚Äôs mother the Dark Lord has heard about it and voiced his approval, so now the boys are determined to get in as many attacks before the summer ends as possible.

When Regulus had voiced his negative feelings on the matter, Evan had just scoffed. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs different for us,‚Äù he‚Äôd said, ‚Äúnot everyone is guaranteed the Mark you know. Some of us have to work for it.‚Äù

Oh yeah, Regulus had thought bitterly, because I‚Äôm just having the time of my fucking life over here.

Mostly he opts out, but he can‚Äôt say no every time. It wouldn‚Äôt look good. So every once and a while he tags along, throws a few punches and curses, pretends like he doesn‚Äôt think it‚Äôs all ridiculous.

There‚Äôs a knock at his door and Regulus‚Äôs whole body instantly goes stiff. He lies still for a moment before sliding his wand into his hand.

‚ÄúFuck off Lucius,‚Äù he‚Äôs glad to hear his voice come out flat, unshaken, pushing himself up off the bed.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not Lucius,‚Äù the person on the other side says eventually.

Oh.

‚ÄúNarcissa?‚Äù he waves his wand and the locks click open, followed a few seconds later by his fair haired cousin.

She closes the door behind her and then just stands there, the two of them facing one another like they‚Äôre about to duel. It takes a few seconds before Regulus realizes he still has his wand out and he quickly slides it back into its holster.

‚ÄúUh‚Äîdo you need something?‚Äù he asks eventually, because Merlin, one of them has to say something.

That seems to wake her up. ‚ÄúI‚Äîno, no I just wanted to make sure you were okay. I know that things got a little‚Ä¶‚Äù

He blinks at her. Things got a little‚Ä¶intense? Is that the word she‚Äôs looking for? Is that what happened? Sometimes Regulus honestly can‚Äôt tell, like he‚Äôs lost his barometer for acceptable behaviour. Maybe he never had one.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he says eventually, because it feels like she‚Äôs waiting for an answer. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶fine, thanks.‚Äù

She nods, walking further into his room, looking around. He can‚Äôt remember if she‚Äôs ever been up here before. He likes this room better than his one at Grimmauld Place, but then, he could say that about pretty well any room in this house. There‚Äôs a big bay window that lets in the sun and the moon and the stars. The wallpaper a gentle green, brighter and softer than everything in London.

He sits down on the edge of his bed, watching her walk slowly around, stopping at his desk. There isn‚Äôt much there, just school books mostly. Eventually she turns back to him, leaning against it.

‚ÄúWhy did you think I was Lucius?‚Äù

Regulus feels his pulse start to pick up but he keeps his expression neutral. Forces his voice to come out flat, free of any hills or valleys. ‚ÄúFigured Bella convinced him to drag me down and finish the lesson.‚Äù

He wonders if she knows, there‚Äôs a look in her eyes, just in the corners‚Ä¶but then it‚Äôs gone. She nods. It‚Äôs a plausible excuse, one that works for both of them. She goes quiet again, arms crossing over her chest.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre trying to get pregnant,‚Äù she says eventually.

She‚Äôs looking at him again. Right at him.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he can‚Äôt quite parcel through all the complicated things that sentence drags up in him. Of course he knew that they would have children, honestly he‚Äôs surprised they haven‚Äôt already. The Malfoys, the Blacks, they need heirs. Still, the idea of Lucius having a child‚Ä¶a son. He feels his nails start to dig into the mattress beneath him.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve started to see a Healer, to figure out why it‚Äôs taking so long, to see what we can do to‚Ä¶help things along.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Regulus fidgets uncomfortably, finding her gaze increasingly difficult to hold.

‚ÄúI worry about having a baby in the middle of all of this, but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúDuty calls?‚Äù Regulus supplies.

She shoots him a rueful smile. ‚ÄúIndeed.‚Äù

They lapse back into silence and Regulus finds himself wondering what the hell she‚Äôs doing up here. Then has the horrible thought that maybe she‚Äôs trying to test out her mothering on him.

‚ÄúYou two,‚Äù he finds himself saying eventually, mostly in an attempt to end the uncomfortable silence, ‚Äúhow did that happen?‚Äù

She arches her brow, the familiar smirk tugging at her mouth, the one that is softer and kinder than her sister‚Äôs. ‚ÄúYou know how it happened, the same way it always happens.‚Äù

Regulus just shakes his head. ‚ÄúRomance isn‚Äôt really my area of expertise.‚Äù

She laughs. ‚ÄúYes, I‚Äôve noticed.‚Äù

Oh, he thinks, great. They‚Äôve been talking about me.

‚ÄúNot that there‚Äôs much romance involved in any of this,‚Äù Narcissa goes on, dimming slightly.

‚ÄúNo?‚Äù

He wishes that she would stop dying her hair, he likes it better as it is naturally‚Äîlight brown‚Äîit suits her. The blond is too harsh.

She gives him another half smile. ‚ÄúNo. My mother chose him, well, and his mother chose me I suppose.‚Äù

Regulus nods, memories coming vaguely back to him. ‚ÄúI remember‚Äîweren‚Äôt you dating someone else?‚Äù

Her eyes flicker, but her expression remains in place. ‚ÄúMatthew,‚Äù she says the name softly, with reverence. It hangs between them, big with all she doesn‚Äôt say, all Regulus doesn‚Äôt need her to. He knows what it‚Äôs like, to hold onto a name like it‚Äôs the hand pulling out of the deep. The only thing keeping you from going under.

‚ÄúYour mother didn‚Äôt choose him then?‚Äù

She snorts, ‚ÄúNo, well, he was a half-blood so‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúHow scandalous.‚Äù

‚ÄúIndeed,‚Äù her gaze grows distant for a moment, unfocused, no doubt disappearing to somewhere else. ‚ÄúWe all have our childish indiscretions. Things we have to give up.‚Äù

Regulus very forcibly keeps his thoughts from wandering to where, of course, they want to go. To that smile, that laugh, those hands that seem to be the only ones that don‚Äôt pull him apart.

‚ÄúExcept your sister‚ÄîAndromeda‚Äîright? She kept her‚Ä¶childish indiscretion?‚Äù

Narcissa‚Äôs eyes instantly grow sharp. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd leave that alone if I were you Reg.‚Äù

Right. Of course.

‚ÄúSure Cissy.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not some hero, not someone worth anything but your pity.‚Äù Regulus has the feeling Narcissa has said those words a few times before, mostly to herself.

‚ÄúLike Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcept‚Ä¶are we?‚Äù

Narcissa‚Äôs brow furrows. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre we worth anything but pity?‚Äù

She stares back at him, eyes wide, betraying all that doubt. All that pain. All that love. Regulus knows how that feels. Knows it exactly.

‚ÄúWhy did you come up here Narcissa?‚Äù he asks eventually.

‚ÄúWhy did you think I was Lucius.‚Äù

Ah.

So she does know.

He swallows the embarrassment. The fear. The disappointment‚Äîhe‚Äôd really thought, if there was anyone here who would have helped him‚Äî

‚ÄúWe all have our childish indiscretions, right?‚Äù he says coldly.

He sees that land and then quickly watches her eyes shutter, watches her expression close down completely.

She gives him a sharp nod. ‚ÄúRight. Well, I‚Äôll let you rest.‚Äù

She starts towards the door but for some reason Regulus can‚Äôt quite let it go.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre still going to do it then‚Äîstill going to let that man near a child?‚Äù
