She pauses, hand on the doorframe. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be dramatic Regulus,‚Äù and she sounds so much like his mother that he can‚Äôt help but wince. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre hardly a child. And Lucius would never do anything to compromise his heir.‚Äù

Compromise. That word hits him somewhere deep. He nearly doubles over. Is that what I am? He wonders. Compromised?

‚ÄúWell, as long as you‚Äôre sure,‚Äù he somehow manages to get out.

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt let anything happen to my child.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you think all mothers say that?‚Äù his voice is cold enough that it drags her gaze back over her shoulder. ‚ÄúHow many of them end up being liars, I wonder.‚Äù

Surprisingly, she doesn‚Äôt answer.

¬†

When he goes down to his father‚Äôs room the next morning he isn‚Äôt there. Regulus sighs, rubbing a hand across his face.

‚ÄúCrazy loon,‚Äù he mutters grumpily, moving quickly down the stairs and out into the garden.

They have a garden at Grimmauld Place too, but it‚Äôs narrow and overcrowded and the wards don‚Äôt let you get far. Here they‚Äôre surround by nothing for miles‚Äîjust wide open space. Right at the back of the house there are intricately woven flowerbeds and stone paths, the type of thing you‚Äôd expect from a palace or Victorian mansion. His father did it all before he got sick.

‚ÄúPapa,‚Äù he says, finding his father staring at bush of purple hyacinth. ‚ÄúHow many times do I have tell you, you can‚Äôt just go wandering off.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou make me sound like a mischievous puppy,‚Äù Orion‚Äôs long hair is pulled back in a bun, the streaks of grey standing out more starkly in the morning sun. He pulls out his wand and waves it at the flowers, sending the dead blossoms tumbling to the ground.

‚ÄúPAPA!‚Äù Regulus makes a grab for the wand, ripping it out of his hand. ‚ÄúJesus, what the hell are you doing?‚Äù

Orion rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúMon chou, c'est juste un peu de magie.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo magic,‚Äù Regulus says sternly. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not supposed to be doing any magic. Especially not for something as stupid as this,‚Äù he gestures dismissively at the bush bringing a frown to his father‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúMy garden is not stupid.‚Äù

Now it‚Äôs Regulus‚Äôs turn to roll his eyes. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what I meant.‚Äù

‚ÄúNon?‚Äù his father asks, eyebrow arched.

‚ÄúYou know I love your garden.‚Äù

Orion smiles, ‚ÄúDid you see the vegetable patch, those tomatoes are looking bon, no?‚Äù

Regulus tries and fails to hold back his own smile. ‚ÄúYes, I saw them, very impressive.‚Äù

Orion preens. ‚ÄúBien, alors, we can both agree this is not a waste of magic then,‚Äù he holds out his hand to Regulus, looking at him expectantly.

‚ÄúWe can hire gardeners, or we can ask Kreacher to do it‚Äî‚Äú

His father lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúKreacher wouldn‚Äôt know the difference between a Peony and a Ranunculus if they were right in front of him, and you know how your mother feels about strangers.‚Äù

I don‚Äôt know, Regulus almost says, there seem to be more than a few strangers running through this house recently. Though it‚Äôs not as bad as it was at Grimmauld, before they‚Äôd left that place had felt like King‚Äôs Cross. People in and out, with nervous eyes and heavy cloaks.

‚ÄúThen let me do it,‚Äù Regulus says exasperated, still not relinquishing his father‚Äôs wand.

‚ÄúI am not an invalid Regulus.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou are actually.‚Äù

That makes his father laugh, he always sounds like Sirius when he laughs‚Äîor maybe it‚Äôs Sirius that sounds like him‚Äîboth of them bark like dogs.

‚ÄúYou might be right,‚Äù his father wipes a hand across his forehead, catching beads of sweat. ‚ÄúBut surely I can still be allowed to have a little fun, huh?‚Äù It‚Äôs not really that hot, the sun is bright and there are no clouds in the sky, but still, he shouldn‚Äôt be sweating.

‚ÄúAre you running a fever?‚Äù Regulus asks, stepping forward to feel his father‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúMon coeur‚Äîarr√™te, arr√™te‚ÄîI‚Äôm fine, stop fussing,‚Äù he bats Regulus‚Äôs hand away, taking a step back.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt act like this,‚Äù Regulus sighs, frustrated. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not always here to‚Äîyou have to take care of yourself,‚Äù those last words come out pleadingly, and he sees the softening in his father‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù he says, in that way parents do when they‚Äôre about to break your heart. Regulus knows the tone well. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dying.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all dying,‚Äù he says flatly, hand curling too tightly around the wand in his hand. In the distance he can hear birds chirping.

His father smiles. ‚ÄúYes, well, I am dying a little bit quicker than the rest of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know that.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúStop saying my name like that,‚Äù he snaps.

His father quirks his brow. ‚ÄúLike what?‚Äù

‚ÄúLike I‚Äôm a child.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù and then, opening his palms, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid to me you always will be.‚Äù

Then why are you never there when I need you?

He knows it‚Äôs a stupid thought to have, that his father is sick, that he‚Äôs too weak to do anything and Regulus would never want him to hurt himself trying. That you can‚Äôt expect other people to fight for you‚Äîto protect you. That‚Äôs always been Regulus‚Äôs problem. He‚Äôs always needed a hero.

‚ÄúPapa, please,‚Äù he says finally.

His father gives him a sad smile before reaching out‚Äîthis time not for his wand‚Äîhe pulls Regulus into him and Reg goes willingly. Even though the feeling of being held makes his skin crawl.

‚ÄúThere are things that can‚Äôt be changed mon coeur, things we just have to accept.‚Äù

He thinks about Narcissa. About himself. Forget Toujours Pur, the Black family motto ought to be ‚Äújust accept it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want you to know,‚Äù his father says after a moment, pulling back as he brings his hands to gently hold Regulus‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúThat I‚Äôm so proud of you. I know how hard its been, since your brother left, all the pressure you‚Äôve had placed on your shoulders. But you‚Äôve handled it so beautifully Regulus.‚Äù

He looks up at his father, eyes searching, wondering if he knows‚Äîknows about all of it. About what happens in this garden when he‚Äôs up in his room and the others come over. Wonders if that‚Äôs what he‚Äôs proud of?

Before he can stop himself his eyes go to the mark on his father‚Äôs forearm. It‚Äôs new, the ink still jet black, standing out starkly against his skin. His father drops his hands to Regulus‚Äôs shoulders and squeezes.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to be brilliant Regulus, you needn‚Äôt worry,‚Äù Regulus looks up and knows that his father has caught him staring. ‚ÄúThis is your birth right. It‚Äôs in your blood.‚Äù

What is? he doesn‚Äôt ask, which part? Because none of it ever seems to come naturally to him. But then, nothing ever seems to come naturally to Regulus, not like it does to Sirius.

Eventually, his father smiles.

‚ÄúLets make a deal, huh? I‚Äôll promise to sit here like a good little boy and do no magic, if you go get your broom and let me watch you fly, yes?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why you like watching me fly so much, it‚Äôs always the same.‚Äù

He reluctantly hands his father back his wand, the older man nodding his thanks as he slips the slender stick into the pocket of his robes.

‚ÄúThat is because you have never had the pleasure of seeing yourself fly,‚Äù his father‚Äôs eyes sparkle. ‚ÄúIt is like listening to a symphony.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYes, ok, I‚Äôm getting my broom, no more comparing me to symphonies please.‚Äù

His father laughs, ‚ÄúI only tell you the truth mon coeur.‚Äù

Regulus waves him off as he heads towards the shed.

My heart, that‚Äôs what his father calls him. My heart. Don‚Äôt put your faith in me, he wants to tell him. I‚Äôm not the son worth betting on.

¬†

‚ÄúReally Regulus?‚Äù

He blinks up at Lucius, on his back again, sun in his eyes. The older man offers Regulus his hand but he doesn‚Äôt take it, pushing himself onto his knees and then, eventually, to his feet. They‚Äôve limited Bellatrix to strictly forgivable curses today.

He hears Lucius huff out a laugh behind him. ‚ÄúSuit yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is starting to get pathetic little Black,‚Äù Rodolphus pushes himself off the back wall. ‚ÄúWhat good are you if you can‚Äôt even stomach this, huh?‚Äù he gestures at the cat they‚Äôve trapped.

Why‚Äôd it have to be a cat, Reg thinks dully. I like cats. Why couldn‚Äôt it be a rat or a snake or possum. As if hearing his thoughts the animal lets out a mournful meow.

‚ÄúOi, back off of him,‚Äù Narcissa steps in, though Regulus honestly couldn‚Äôt tell you why. ‚ÄúHe can brew more potions than you can name, and he‚Äôs managed everything else you‚Äôve thrown at him.‚Äù

That‚Äôs not technically true. He couldn‚Äôt manage the Patronus.

Rodolphus turns his skin-crawling leer on her. ‚ÄúYes, he‚Äôs a pretty little swot. But none of that matters if he chokes when he needs to actually point his wand at someone.‚Äù

Mostly, Regulus doesn‚Äôt let himself think about what they‚Äôre practicing for. He doesn‚Äôt let himself think about most of what‚Äôs happened this summer. Easier that way. To just‚Ä¶let it go.

‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt choke.‚Äù

Even in the August heat, his mother‚Äôs voice still sends a chill down his spine. They all turn towards the house where Walburga stands inside the door. Dressed in black, eyes intently focused on her son.

‚ÄúWill you Regulus?‚Äù

It feels like everything has suddenly gone still‚Äîthe wind, the tree branches, the birds overhead. Nothing moves. Nothings breathes. Nothing makes a sound.

‚ÄúNo maman,‚Äù he forces the words out.

She gives him a sharp nod, taking a step forward, arms crossing over her chest. ‚ÄúGo on then, show them.‚Äù

Fuck.

His hand is sweaty as he adjusts his grip on his wand, turning back to the cat, feeling each and ever set of eyes on him. Bellatrix is frightening in her absolute disregard for everything and everyone, but his mother is scary in another way. The way that her hatred can zero in and focus itself on just you.

He swallows, trying to put everything away in boxes and shove it all down. To not think about the cat as a cat. Or an animal. Or a living being. But an ‚Äúit.‚Äù Just an ‚Äúit.‚Äù

The first time he ever saw someone Crucio‚Äôd it was Sirius. The summer before he ran away. Regulus had felt many things about his mother before that point‚Äîanger, fear, love‚Äîbut that day, that was the first day he had really hated her.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù his name comes out of her mouth as a warning.

He exhales, pulling on that memory, on that hatred, letting every horrible feeling fill him up.

It‚Äôs for his own good, his mother had said, staring at her eldest son while he writhed on the floor in agony.

For his own good.

‚ÄúCrucio.‚Äù

It‚Äôs work not to be sick. Not to drop his wand. He wonders if this is what he looks like to them, if this is how they feel when they watch. Or maybe they feel nothing at all.

He waits for someone to tell him to stop but no one does, eventually he pulls back, shaking and out of breath. The noise doesn‚Äôt stop though. The cat‚Äôs screaming. He knows the feeling, the way the burn sits in your bones afterwards. In your head.

‚ÄúFinally,‚Äù he hears Rodolphus mutter under his breath.

Regulus stares at some indistinct point in the distance, focusing on his breathing, on not falling to the ground. His mother begins to clap. Slow. Poignant. It doesn‚Äôt feel like celebrating.

‚ÄúExcellent,‚Äù she says, waiting until Regulus‚Äôs eyes meet her‚Äôs. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll be here on Sunday.‚Äù

That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs all she says. She‚Äôs back inside the house before he can even blink.

‚ÄúAw, did someone just need their mommy?‚Äù Rodolphus says mockingly.

Regulus doesn‚Äôt bother responding, doesn‚Äôt know how. The cat is still crying in the background and honestly he feels like he might be sick. Without thinking he starts moving, Bellatrix and Rodolphus are laughing about something but he isn‚Äôt sure what, he thinks Narcissa reaches for him but he keeps going. He doesn‚Äôt make it far‚Äîjust to the other side of the house‚Äîbefore his hands are on his knees and he‚Äôs vomiting up the entire contents of his stomach.

He falls against the wall, wiping his mouth on the back of his hand as he slides down to the ground. Sunday. She said he‚Äôd be here on Sunday. A shiver runs through Regulus. There‚Äôs no question who ‚Äúhe‚Äù is.

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù he looks up to see an amused Lucius leaning against the wall next to him. ‚ÄúYou really did throw-up, I wasn‚Äôt sure if you actually would.‚Äù

Regulus gives him a flat look before dropping his head down onto his knees. ‚ÄúGo away,‚Äù he mumbles, not able to muster anything more threatening.

Lucius kisses his teeth. ‚ÄúYou used to be so much more agreeable.‚Äù

Regulus laughs, because it‚Äôs such a horrible, fucked up thing to say that he‚Äôs not sure what else to do. It‚Äôs too hot. Too hot for all of this.

‚ÄúAre you really this awful,‚Äù he finds himself asking, lifting his head just enough to speak. ‚ÄúOr is it some kind of act?‚Äù

Lucius lets out a dry chuckle. ‚ÄúAm I your villain Regulus?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù not even close. ‚ÄúBut you are a fucking nightmare.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can accept that.‚Äù

He wants to punch him. He doesn‚Äôt. Can‚Äôt. Hasn‚Äôt the energy, the courage. But God does he want to.

‚ÄúSo, how‚Äôs the boy then.‚Äù

Regulus stiffens, looking over Lucius‚Äôs shoulder, half expecting Bellatrix or his mother to appear. He doesn‚Äôt know which would be worse.

Lucius smirks, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve already cast a privacy charm,‚Äù he waves his hand dismissively at the air.

Regulus does not find that at all comforting and it must show on his face because the older man rolls his eyes.

‚ÄúOh stand down, I‚Äôm not about to do anything out here am I?‚Äù

This, Regulus thinks, this right here is why I‚Äôm so fucked up. That he can talk about it like‚Äîlike it‚Äôs nothing. Normal. Casual. Like it hasn‚Äôt left holes in my skin.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no boy,‚Äù he says flatly. And then, for good measure; ‚ÄúGo away.‚Äù

Lucius snorts. ‚ÄúNah, I don‚Äôt buy it. Big attitude change like this? Must be a boy. Could be a girl but, I don‚Äôt expect you‚Äôre quite lucky enough to swing both ways.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt say anything, nails digging into his knees. Apparently Lucius takes this as an invitation to keep talking because he steps forward and crouches down next to him.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not one of ours I‚Äôd bet, that‚Äôs why you‚Äôve been so‚Ä¶resistant lately,‚Äù he laughs dryly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm surprised it‚Äôs lasted this long, though I can‚Äôt imagine it‚Äôll go on much longer, not once you have the mark. Those lot are too self-righteous to let something like that slide. Hypocrites.‚Äù

‚ÄúHypocrites?‚Äù Regulus doesn‚Äôt know why he asks.

Lucius shrugs. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre fighting for their power like I‚Äôm fighting for mine, don‚Äôt see where they get off feeling so damn morally righteous.‚Äù

Regulus isn‚Äôt even sure where to start with that.

‚ÄúYour power? Or the Dark Lord‚Äôs?‚Äù is what makes it out of his mouth.

Lucius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúOh, like they‚Äôre not fighting for Dumbledore? One mad old man is no better than the next.‚Äù

Regulus isn‚Äôt sure if that‚Äôs true. Though he, personally, has never much cared for Dumbledore. Something about the way his smile doesn‚Äôt reach his eyes.

Still, when he speaks it‚Äôs only to say; ‚ÄúLast I checked, Dumbledore isn‚Äôt branding his followers.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh come now Regulus,‚Äù Lucius pulls back his sleeve, the snake on his arm squirming in the sunlight. ‚ÄúSurely you‚Äôre not afraid of a little ink?‚Äù

Regulus looks down at it and then away. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not scared,‚Äù he says wearily, and he means it. He isn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just so fucking tired of not having any control.‚Äù It‚Äôs proof of how lonely he‚Äôs been that he‚Äôs having this conversation with Lucius Malfoy at all.

The older man leans in close and Regulus tries and fails not to flinch. ‚ÄúWhat do you think we‚Äôre fighting for?‚Äù he lingers there for a moment before pulling away. ‚ÄúWe have the power, they want the power, we crush them, we reign supreme again. It‚Äôs really all very simple.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want power.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt have to look at Lucius to know he‚Äôs rolling his eyes. ‚ÄúPower, control, it‚Äôs all the same.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs head leans back against the wall, looking up at the dimming sky. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs how they see it‚Äîthis fight‚ÄîI don‚Äôt think they see it as being about power.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell then they‚Äôre idiots, everything is about power. You think Dumbledore aligned himself with the Mudbloods out of the goodness of his heart? Please, he saw an opportunity and he took it.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt answer, closing his eyes and trying to will his exhausted body to stand. Hopefully they can stop these lessons, he‚Äôs managed all three unforgivables, surely they can leave him alone now?

‚ÄúYou think you‚Äôll get control on the other side?‚Äù

Again, Regulus doesn‚Äôt answer. He knows a trap when he hears one.

‚ÄúDumbledore will turn you into his little creature, have you do all his spying for him, and then toss you aside. I bet you a thousand galleons that‚Äôs what‚Äôll happen to your brother. At least with us you have value, have something that can‚Äôt be taken from you‚Äîblood.‚Äù

In Regulus‚Äôs personal opinion, his blood has never done very much for him. But he doesn‚Äôt bother voicing that thought either. Eventually, he hears the sound of Lucius getting to his feet.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù he says, because he can‚Äôt ever seem to shut-up. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd be careful if I were you, wouldn‚Äôt want Bellatrix to find out about your little boy-toy.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes fly open as his head snaps towards Lucius.

‚ÄúIs that a threat?‚Äù he finds himself asking.

Lucius clutches dramatically at his chest. ‚ÄúRegulus, you wound me. It‚Äôs merely some helpful advice. Because if she finds out what you‚Äôve been doing and, God forbid, with whom, that poor boy is going to find himself dismembered.‚Äù

Despite his best efforts to stay calm, Regulus can feel his heart racing in his chest. ‚ÄúI told you, there‚Äôs no boy.‚Äù

Lucius laughs. ‚ÄúSure, sure. Tell me, how good are you at Occlumency, again? Cause I reckon she could crack you open after a few rounds of Crucio.‚Äù

Fuck.

‚ÄúLucius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOh listen to that, do you hear it? You‚Äôve gone all soft, and after being so rude to me.‚Äù

Regulus grits teeth, trying to keep some semblance of control. ‚ÄúPlease.‚Äù

The older man smiles. ‚ÄúI do love hearing that word out of your mouth.‚Äù He walks forward and Regulus has to force himself to stay still‚Äîto not pull his wand out or run. Especially when Lucius reaches out to run a hand through his curls.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù he says, hand sliding down Regulus‚Äôs jaw, thumb running over his lower lip. The fear and anxiety building inside him are almost unbearable‚Äîthere are no words to describe this feeling. Like he‚Äôs going to burst open. Spill out of his skin. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so much prettier when you‚Äôre quiet.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt breathe again until Lucius steps back. Sharp and desperate. Lucius must notice because he laughs.

‚ÄúYou see Regulus? Everything is about power.‚Äù

There are dots in Regulus‚Äôs vision, memories of hands and weight and muffled sobs clawing at his throat.

It takes him a long time to realize that Lucius is gone.

¬†

He manages to make it into town on Saturday. He goes once a week. To get away. To visit the gallery. To think about all the things he‚Äôs not supposed to think about. To read James‚Äôs letters.

He sits on a park bench, fingers running over the envelopes in his hands. He always brings them all with him. Afraid to leave them behind. Desperate to read them again. There‚Äôs only one left unopened, the rest of them scarred with creases and smudge marks from all the times he‚Äôs pulled them out, all the times he‚Äôs told himself ‚Äújust once more.‚Äù

He slides his finger under the sealed envelope, pulling out the fresh pages and getting the same fluttering in his stomach as he does every time. It‚Äôs the kind of feeling that makes him do stupid things like try and send letters through the Muggle post. He unfolds the pages.

Dude,

Regulus groans out loud, causing the old woman on the bench across from him to jump. ‚ÄúSorry‚Äù he mouthes at her, but honestly, dude? Dude, James? Somehow he manages to keep reading.

We did it! We‚Äôre almost there. Two more days and we‚Äôll be back! Full disclosure, I am probably going to be a little much, I can already feel it. I‚Äôm going to miss you like crazy Reg. I always miss you.

So listen, this is what I‚Äôve been thinking about today‚Äîyou and me, in the pros. It‚Äôs basically guaranteed to happen so it‚Äôs barely even a daydream. Does that sound obnoxious? Whatever. It‚Äôs true. I can‚Äôt decide which I like better, us on the same team‚Äîbecause honestly, we‚Äôd be unstoppable. Or us on opposing teams, because baby, that sexual tension? Killer. Either way, we‚Äôd be such a power couple. They‚Äôd make like posters and shit with our faces on them.

‚ÄúOh my God James,‚Äù Regulus mutters, smiling despite himself.

We could put them up in our house (yes, we have a house, we‚Äôre international Quidditch stars so it‚Äôs probably like a super amazing house too). We‚Äôd both make it on the national team, obviously, and go off and win the Quidditch World Cup for England. Then retire at thirty-five and fuck off to a beach somewhere. I‚Äôm telling you Reg, the two of us, together, we‚Äôll conquer the world.

Regulus feels his heart squeeze too tight.

See, these are the things I think about. Sometimes I wonder if you know, if you think maybe this is just me messing around or something. But it isn‚Äôt. When I think about my future I think about you. Us. It feels right Reg, I don‚Äôt know how to make you see that. I know it‚Äôs not right, right now. But it will be. We can get there. We can get anywhere.

Anyway, I‚Äôll be waiting for you in two days, in our room. Even if it‚Äôs too much, if you can‚Äôt come, it‚Äôs alright. I just want you to know that I‚Äôll be there if you need me. I‚Äôll always be there.

Love you,
James

He hates him. Hates him. Hates him. He blinks the tears out of his eyes while thinking about how much he hates James Potter. It feels like this every time. Like breaking his own heart. But then, he supposes that‚Äôs what this whole thing has been. Seeing the pain and heading straight for it. Pretending he can be someone else. Someone better. Someone who deserves to be loved the way James loves.

He sniffles, re-reading the letter just to torture himself. Just to hear it again. He‚Äôs never thought about his future, never been able to picture it. But the image James paints is beautiful‚Äînot the Quidditch or the fame but the two of them. Together. Living in a house. ‚ÄúOur house‚Äù James had called it.

It was selfish of Regulus to let this happen. To let it go on. To let James get sucked in. Selfish and dangerous. Because Lucius is right. If they find out‚Äîhis mother, Bella‚Äîthey‚Äôll kill James. Horribly, painfully, slowly. For the dishonour, for the shame of it, they‚Äôll make it their personal fucking mission. Taking in Sirius was bad enough, but this?

So we‚Äôre agreed, says the voice in his head, we stop this now. We end it. We keep him safe.

And it sounds good. It sounds right. The right thing to do. But it‚Äôs immediately followed by another voice. Weak and whinny.

I can‚Äôt. I can‚Äôt. I can‚Äôt.

You can.

I need him.

Enough to risk his life? Because if he‚Äôs dead you can‚Äôt have him anyway.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Regulus hisses, pressing the heels of his hands into his eyes. He‚Äôs been having the same conversation with himself all summer. Round and round in circles it goes. Of course, that was before Lucius explicitly threatened him. Before he knew for sure that he was getting the mark.

You could refuse.

Yeah, that‚Äôll go over well.

What‚Äôs the worst they can do?

Kill me.

Would that be so bad?

No, probably not, but he doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôll do it anyway. Dying takes courage. The brave and the bold die, the cowardly survive.

So we run away.

Where?

To James‚Äôs?

No. His mother could afford to lose one son, after all, she had a spare. And Sirius had always been too much trouble. But both? Walburga would kill everyone in that fucking house before she let Regulus go.

You have to end it. You have to keep him safe.

I can‚Äôt. I can‚Äôt. I can‚Äôt.

Regulus sighs, slipping James‚Äôs letter back into its envelope and getting to his feet. It‚Äôs a short walk to the gallery from here, and the sun has finally been dimmed by the clouds and the encroaching fall. So he starts moving, hands in his pockets, thoughts still running in circles.

I can‚Äôt. I can‚Äôt. I can‚Äôt.

¬†

It‚Äôs busy today, the gallery. It‚Äôs a Saturday and with the weather Regulus supposes it‚Äôs to be expected. There‚Äôs no entrance fee but they do take donations, so Regulus always makes sure to bring Muggle money to slip into the little plastic box by the entrance.

Hands in his pockets he wanders through the big rooms, with their towering ceilings and beautiful paintings. He pretends to meander. To be purposeless. With no destination. All the while moving very consciously in the direction of the one painting he wants desperately to see. The one he always wants to see.

He can never remember why he fell in love with it in the first place. Just that after he saw it he couldn‚Äôt look away. Couldn‚Äôt stop coming back, wondering what had happened, wondering who they were. Eventually, he‚Äôd asked one of the tour guides. She‚Äôd said a lot of things that he hadn‚Äôt understood. Words he‚Äôd never heard‚Äîpeople, places‚Äîso he‚Äôd asked her to write it down. Then he‚Äôd gone to the Muggle library.

‚ÄúI love this one.‚Äù

He blinks, looking beside him to see a lanky girl, in mustard yellow bellbottoms and long, dark braids.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù is the only word he seems to think of. He‚Äôs not sure if he means it as a question or a statement.

‚ÄúYou know what I think it is?‚Äù he hears an irritating smacking noise and realizes she‚Äôs chewing gum.

‚ÄúAre you allowed gum in here?‚Äù

She looks over at him for the first time, smiling. ‚ÄúWhy, you going to tell on me pretty boy?‚Äù

He honestly has no idea what‚Äôs going on right now. ‚ÄúUh‚Ä¶no,‚Äù he manages eventually.

She nods, satisfied, before turning back to the painting. ‚ÄúSee, the thing is, you think the tragedy is Patroclus but it isn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Regulus finds himself looking at the painting too. The pale figure in Achilles‚Äôs arms, the crowd of mourners around him.

‚ÄúI mean look at his face right? Totally peaceful.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs dead,‚Äù Regulus says dumbly.

She rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúYes, but that‚Äôs the point isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

Which could mean so many things that Regulus isn‚Äôt sure where to go with it.

‚ÄúThe real tragedy, is Achilles,‚Äù she goes on eventually, pointing at the pained face in the centre. ‚ÄúThe people who get left behind, that‚Äôs what hurts the most, that‚Äôs what makes this painting so good.‚Äù

Regulus lets his eyes drag between the two faces, the two men, who had loved so fiercely, who had made it so far.

‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt the tragedy,‚Äù he says finally, bringing her dark eyes back to him.

‚ÄúNo?‚Äù she pops her gum.

He shakes his head. ‚ÄúThe tragedy is that Achilles could have stopped it. Instead he lets Patroclus die because he isn‚Äôt brave enough to face his own fate. The fate he chose when he sailed for Troy. The fate he tries to use Agamemnon to chicken out of at the last minute. Achilles is the death of Patroclus, not Hector. That‚Äôs the tragedy ‚Äù

‚ÄúAgamemnon sucked though, and besides, Achilles was defending his honour.‚Äù

Regulus is silent for a moment, staring at the broken figures in front of him. ‚ÄúIf he‚Äôd actually loved him, he would have put the armour on himself.‚Äù

He can feel her watching him. ‚ÄúYou are a very intense guy.‚Äù

He looks back at her. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre very blunt.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrue,‚Äù holding out her hand. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Marybeth.‚Äù

At first he‚Äôs not sure what she‚Äôs doing but then his brain wakes up. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîah‚ÄîRegulus.‚Äù They shake.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù she arches her brow. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a wicked name.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks, Marybeth is also‚Ä¶nice?‚Äù

She snorts. ‚ÄúVery convincing.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm not good at‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúCompliments?‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù she nods wisely. ‚ÄúWell, your taste in art definitely doesn‚Äôt scream ‚Äòfun and approachable‚Äô that‚Äôs for sure.‚Äù

Regulus smiles a little, despite himself.

‚ÄúI see you here a lot,‚Äù she goes on eventually.

When Regulus raises his brow she explains. ‚ÄúMy mum works here, so, I end up spending a lot of time here too.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, I guess that‚Ä¶makes sense,‚Äù Regulus, once again, finds himself with no idea what else to say‚Äîhow to carry on a basic conversation. No one‚Äôs ever talked to him here before.

‚ÄúThis is the part where you explain why you‚Äôre here so much,‚Äù her mouth twitches, like she‚Äôs trying not to smile.

Regulus just blinks back at her. ‚ÄúUh,‚Äù before looking at the painting in front of them.

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù she asks. ‚ÄúJust this one painting? Just cause you‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúLike it?‚Äù Regulus answers uncertainly. He honestly hasn‚Äôt got a better reason for her.

She laughs, it‚Äôs a pretty noise. ‚ÄúFair enough I guess,‚Äù there‚Äôs another pause, both of them staring forward. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she goes on eventually, ‚ÄúI just thought I‚Äôd introduce myself, put in my two-cents about your little obsession,‚Äù she nods towards the painting. ‚ÄúIt was nice to meet you Regulus,‚Äù there‚Äôs a look in her eyes‚Äîlike she‚Äôs smiling without using her mouth. Flirting, his brain supplies. She‚Äôs flirting with you.

‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôll see you around huh?‚Äù she says while walking away backwards. ‚ÄúConvince you to look at something else for a change,‚Äù she winks, before turning around and continue on her way.

He stares after her, thinking about how she has no idea what‚Äôs happening in the wizarding world. No idea what‚Äôs coming. That he could kill her with the flick of his wand and at this point probably wouldn‚Äôt even get in trouble for it‚Äîthe Death Eaters have the Ministry under such tight control. He thinks about the person Marybeth must think that he is, to look at him like that, to wink at him. How nice it would be to be that boy.

He exhales, shoving his hands in his pockets and turning away, heading for the exit.

¬†

Marybeth never does see him again.

¬†

He‚Äôs seen Voldemort before. Not up close. But he has seen him. It was at Grimmauld Place, his mother had offered it up for some meeting. Regulus had waited on the stairs, just to see‚Äîsee who everyone kept whispering about. The man who had the wizarding world in such an uproar.

Truthfully, he‚Äôd been a little disappointed. Voldemort was just a man, middle-aged, tall, with almost translucently pale skin, exaggerated by his dark hair and dark eyes. He couldn‚Äôt see anything particularly frightening about him. Or inspiring. He just‚Ä¶was.

And then his gaze had found Regulus on the landing. Regulus had wondered, at the time, if it was a spell, silent, wandless, but a spell. Because the cold feeling that had rushed along his bones then had been so startling he‚Äôd nearly fallen down the stairs.

He knew now, standing in front of Voldemort properly, that it hadn‚Äôt been. They say that the eyes are the windows to the soul. Well, Regulus doesn‚Äôt know what it is he‚Äôs looking into, but it doesn‚Äôt feel like a soul. Doesn‚Äôt feel alive at all.

They‚Äôre in the dining room, it‚Äôs smaller than the one at Grimmauld Place, homier, making this all feel that much more absurd. That much harder to believe. It‚Äôs dark out, the floating candles above the table the only light in the room, illuminating the masked faces that line the walls. Lucius is here, so are Bella and Rodolphus, his mother and father. And others. Some people he‚Äôs known his whole life, some people he‚Äôs never met before. Not that he can tell them apart now.

Voldemort stands at the head of the table, in dark robes, Regulus in front of him, several inches shorter and feeling like a child. The man smiles, it‚Äôs not a pleasant expression.

‚ÄúRegulus Arcturus Black,‚Äù his voice is higher than Regulus expected it to be, the sound causing the hair to stand up on the back of his neck. Voldemort‚Äôs head twitches to the side. Like a snake, sizing up its prey. Regulus is used to it. He‚Äôs been looked at like that before.

‚ÄúMy Lord,‚Äù the words feel like they‚Äôve come from someone else‚Äôs mouth.

‚ÄúYour family has been a great source of support for me during these long years. It is their wish for you to receive this honour, to join us here, and out of my gratitude to them I have agreed. But I need you to understand what it means, to bare my mark, to bind your life to mine,‚Äù he shakes his sleeve back, showing his own mark.

‚ÄúWe will become one, you and I, you will feel me when I need you, when I call, when I am strong, when I am weak. This is not empty symbolism. It connects us,‚Äù another smile‚Äîthis man is all teeth. Regulus takes it back, not like a snake. Like a wolf. ‚ÄúWe are a family.‚Äù

There is a quiet rumbling of agreement around the room.

‚ÄúYou are young,‚Äù he lets his sleeve drop back down over his forearm, ‚Äúso I will give you the mercy of reconsidering, if you do not feel you can give yourself to me as you must, as this demands. As your parents have.‚Äù

His dark eyes take hold of Regulus and keep him still. Unable to move. To think. To see anything but him.

‚ÄúYou have a choice,‚Äù like two empty pits in his face, dark and swelling, and pulling Regulus under. Drowning him. ‚ÄúWill you choose us?‚Äù

Achilles should have put the armour on himself.

You‚Äôre Beautiful.

He should have accepted that some things can‚Äôt be changed, some endings can‚Äôt be rewritten.

Okay Reg. Yeah, I‚Äôm yours. You‚Äôre mine too.

He should have fallen on his sword before he let Patroclus go out there. Knowing how dangerous it was. Knowing what could happen.

I love you.

Say it again.

He told James, told him ages ago that he wasn‚Äôt a very good person. Told him over and over again. That he wouldn‚Äôt be able to do the right thing. To stop this. To end this. He still can‚Äôt.

I love you Regulus.

He never should have been with James in the first place, and not even because of his family, because of the politics, but because of who Regulus is; mangled, and damaged, and compromised. Maybe if it had happened earlier, if he had known James before‚Äîbefore he let his family twist him up.

I just want you to know that I‚Äôll be there if you need me. I‚Äôll always be there.

Regulus had let himself pretend that things could be different. But he won't do that anymore. This is who he is, this is who he was always going to be, and he won‚Äôt get James killed trying to fight fate. He‚Äôll only lose. They always lose.

He swallows, eyes still holding Voldemort‚Äôs stare, unwavering.

‚ÄúI choose you.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

Believe it or not the next chapter is actually going to be pretty fluffy SO there's that to hold onto.

Thank you for all the comments! I honestly would respond to them all but I always worry that that would get annoying for some reason? BUT I see you, I appreciate you, you make this very fun :)

Chapter 20

Chapter Notes

TW: Referenced Sexual Assault

See the end of the chapter for more notes

It‚Äôs too hot for the jumper he‚Äôs wearing. He keeps pulling at it, fabric itchy against his sweaty skin, making it impossible to ignore. He‚Äôd take it off but he needs something with sleeves. There‚Äôs already an annoying voice in his head saying it‚Äôs not enough, that somehow people will know. That his sleeve will ride up. That it‚Äôll bleed through the fabric. Slither down his arm.

‚ÄúBlimey you look miserable,‚Äù Evan is leaning against the pillar next to him, waiting for the train to arrive. He‚Äôs got a bag of candied popcorn in his hands that he insists on eating by throwing pieces in the air and catching them with his mouth. He keeps looking over at the group of fourth year girls to the left of them to see if they‚Äôre watching‚Äîthey are not.

‚ÄúI thought that was my role,‚Äù Regulus says dryly, eyes lazily scanning the platform. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the miserable one, you‚Äôre the optimist.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat does that make Barty?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou figure out what Barty is you let me know.‚Äù

Evan laughs. His laugh is all nose‚Äîit makes him sound like a perpetual twelve year old.

‚ÄúHonestly, I can‚Äôt believe you came back. If I were you I‚Äôd be so fucking out of here.‚Äù

His mother had tried to stop him, but eventually he‚Äôd managed to convince her that there was still some value in his education, even if it was just because it kept him closer to Dumbledore. Behind enemy lines, collecting information, etcetera, etcetera.

‚ÄúSurprisingly enough,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúI do like being educated.‚Äù

Evan snorts. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why you‚Äôre so miserable.‚Äù

Regulus can‚Äôt help the smirk that pulls at his mouth. ‚ÄúProbably.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm telling you Reg, the less you know the better life is.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, the Evan Rosier life motto. When in doubt, be a fucking idiot.‚Äù

They both laugh now, catching the attention of the aforementioned fourth year girls. Regulus imagines it‚Äôs because of the noise and not some suddenly materializing desire, but Evan appears to be of a different opinion.

‚ÄúHey, hold this will you?‚Äù he smacks his popcorn into the middle of Regulus‚Äôs chest.

‚ÄúMerlin Evan, leave it.‚Äù

But it‚Äôs no use, his friend is already walking away, an overly exaggerated swagger in his step. Regulus rolls his eyes, leaning back against the pillar and glaring down at the popcorn in his hands. It‚Äôs an unappealing blue colour that Regulus can‚Äôt quite believe is edible.

His arm twinges. He‚Äôs pretty sure it‚Äôs just in his head. Or at least that‚Äôs what he tells himself. Just like he tells himself that nothing is trapped under his skin. Nothing is squirming below the surface. Trying to get out. However much it might feel like it. He curls and flexes his fingers like that will help. Trying to think about something else.

‚ÄúHey.‚Äù

The word is soft and quiet and still makes Regulus jump. Still makes him drop Evan‚Äôs disgusting popcorn on the floor. Still makes his pulse race.

He turns around to find James behind him, sheepish smile on his face, eyes bright. Don‚Äôt look at me like that, Regulus wants to tell him, you don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôve done.

He opens his mouth but no sound comes out. He‚Äôd meant to be more prepared than this, meant to wrap himself in an armour of apathy and distain. He hadn‚Äôt expected James to just walk up to him and‚Äîbut of course, he should have. It‚Äôs so like him.

He‚Äôs been quiet for too long and he can see the worry start to crease James‚Äôs brow. He should let it. He should turn around and walk away. He‚Äôs usually better at this. At being an asshole.

‚ÄúWhere are they?‚Äù he asks instead.

James doesn‚Äôt seem to need clarification to know he‚Äôs talking about the other Marauders, gesturing over his shoulder. ‚ÄúJust there, I can‚Äôt stay long, but, I saw you and I just‚Ä¶‚Äù There‚Äôs that smile again, and Regulus wonders if it‚Äôs too late to cut off his arm. Not that it would make a difference.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWhat the hell Reg? I told you to hold my popcorn not feed it to the bloody birds.‚Äù

Regulus very briefly closes his eyes.

Fuck.

James has already gone stiff, Evan coming to an abrupt stop as he realizes who Regulus is talking to. There‚Äôs a moment of surprise before an unsettling smile stretches across his face.

‚ÄúWell look who it is. You just can‚Äôt leave my mate here alone can you?‚Äù

‚ÄúDrop it Evan,‚Äù Regulus tries to nudge him away but he isn‚Äôt having it, staring at James like someone‚Äôs just told him it‚Äôs Christmas morning‚Äîwhich can‚Äôt be good.

‚ÄúAre you referring to the time I kicked your ass?‚Äù James asks, cocky smile spreading across his face and doing unhelpful things to Regulus‚Äôs chest. ‚ÄúBecause that‚Äôs one of my fondest memories.‚Äù

Evan‚Äôs eyes go sharp. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs your dad Potter?‚Äù

The change is so quick it‚Äôs almost frightening. The mocking humour drains from James‚Äôs face, replaced by an anger that burns and Regulus can‚Äôt help feeling like he‚Äôs missed something.

‚ÄúCause the last time I saw him,‚Äù Evan goes on, having absolutely no self-preservation instinct to speak of, ‚Äúhe was in a right state. Could barely walk.‚Äù

And then several things click into place. Like the fact that Evan-just-be-a-fucking-idiot-Rosier spent his summer attacking Ministry employees. And that Fleamont Potter is, in fact, a Ministry employee.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to destroy you,‚Äù James growls.

‚ÄúLets hope you throw a better punch than your dad yeah?‚Äù

Things move quickly then.

Both James and Evan step forward, Regulus moving between them, one arm wrapping around Evan‚Äôs chest and hauling him backwards, bracing for the impact of James‚Äôs fist which had already been pulled back. It doesn‚Äôt come though. What does come is the sound of a new voice.

‚ÄúWoah, woah mate, hold on,‚Äù Sirius says behind him.

‚ÄúYou piece of shit,‚Äù James shouts. ‚ÄúYou spineless pathetic fucking wanker.‚Äù

‚ÄúCome and get me Potter! Come and get me and we‚Äôll see if you cry just like your daddy!‚Äù Evan shouts over Regulus‚Äôs shoulder.

Regulus slams him against the pillar behind them, able to turn just enough to see Sirius in a similar position with James. Their eyes meet.

‚ÄúReg,‚Äù he says by way of greeting, voice slightly laboured as he continues to struggle with his best mate.

‚ÄúSirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe really have to stop meeting like this.‚Äù

Regulus lets out a breath of laughter before shoving Evan back again as he makes another attempt to break free.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll have my people call your people,‚Äù he says dryly.

‚ÄúYou know people?‚Äù Sirius huffs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm shocked.‚Äù

It almost feels natural, this back and forth. And for a minute Regulus can pretend‚Äîthat they‚Äôre on the same side. That they don‚Äôt hate each other.

That is, until Evan‚Äôs hand grabs hold of his left arm and everything goes white. Pain searing through him as he drops to his hands and knees.

That definitely wasn‚Äôt in his head.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù is the first thing he hears once the pounding in his ears clears. ‚ÄúFuck Reg, I‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs skin is burning hot, covered in sweat. He tries to breathe through it. It‚Äôs not the worst pain he‚Äôs ever felt, it just caught him off guard.

It will fade, his father had said to him before he left. He‚Äôd been holding Regulus‚Äôs arm out in front of him, running a gentle hand over the fresh mark. Regulus hadn‚Äôt known if it was the ink or the pain his father was talking about.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck did you do to him?‚Äù

That‚Äôs James. Regulus opens his eyes, not realizing he‚Äôd closed them in the first place.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù

He looks over to see Evan crouched beside him, ignoring James completely.

Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine,‚Äù he croaks. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething happen to your arm Reg?‚Äù Sirius asks, the cold edge in his voice sending fear dripping down Regulus‚Äôs spine. Of course Sirius would notice.

He makes sure to keep his expression neutral when he turns back to his brother. ‚ÄúJust Evan‚Äôs claw like nails. You‚Äôre lucky he didn‚Äôt get a shot at your face Potter, your fans would never have recovered.‚Äù

James looks like he can‚Äôt decide whether to be worried or pissed, eyes bouncing back and forth between Regulus and Evan. But Sirius, Sirius doesn‚Äôt take his eyes off of Regulus. Regulus can practically feel him trying to pick him apart, and he has to resist the urge to pull down on his sleeve.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù Sirius finally looks away, shoving James back in the direction they came from. ‚ÄúLets go Prongs, they‚Äôre not worth it.‚Äù

James resists for about a second, sending Regulus one last look before reluctantly allowing Sirius to haul him away.

‚ÄúYeah, you better‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúEvan, shut the fuck up,‚Äù Regulus snaps, pushing himself back to his feet. Evan gapes at him.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you went after Fleamont Potter,‚Äù Regulus hisses, careful to make sure no one is near enough to overhear, ‚Äúdo you have any idea how important he is?‚Äù

‚ÄúSome idea,‚Äù Evan says defensively.

‚ÄúAnd you just thought you‚Äôd rub it in his son‚Äôs face did you? You could be sent to Azakaban for the rest of your fucking life.‚Äù

‚ÄúSays the bloke with the Dark Mark on his arm.‚Äù

Regulus freezes for a second, just a second, before shoving Evan into the pillar again. Just because it feels good. ‚ÄúFine, fuck it, go ahead. In fact, while you‚Äôre at it, why don‚Äôt you just pop up to Dumbledore‚Äôs office and let him know what you‚Äôve been up to all summer, huh?‚Äù

Evan glares at him. ‚ÄúYes, alright, I get it. You‚Äôve made your point. But it‚Äôs not as though Potter has any proof does he? Besides, everyone knows Azkaban is ours these days.‚Äù

Regulus feels something in his stomach squirm but he pushes it down. So what if the Death Eaters have control of Azkaban? Of the Ministry? He always knew this was how it was going to be. Always knew they would win. There‚Äôs no point in caring about something that‚Äôs inevitable. His eyes trail momentarily to the spot where Sirius and James disappeared and he wonders if they know‚Äîif they have any idea how lost their cause is?

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù Regulus looks up at the sound of his name, something about Evan‚Äôs expression tells him he‚Äôs said it a few times. ‚ÄúI really am sorry about‚Ä¶‚Äù he trails off but looks pointedly at Regulus left arm.

Regulus sighs. ‚ÄúYeah Evan, I know,‚Äù he‚Äôs not sure why he thought he could talk any sense into Evan. He was stupid and reckless when they were kids and he‚Äôs stupid and reckless now.

Regulus exhales, pinching the bridge of his nose, feeling almost comically old. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù he says eventually, ‚Äúlets go find Barty, make sure we get a compartment together.‚Äù

Evan arches his brow. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you have to go to that swot meeting?‚Äù

Regulus groans. ‚ÄúFuck. I forgot about that,‚Äù he was somewhat shocked to find a Prefect badge in his school letter this summer. He‚Äôs still not convinced it wasn‚Äôt a mistake.

Evan snorts, the noise of the approaching train in the background. ‚ÄúYou and Snape will have a blast I‚Äôm sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe always do,‚Äù he says flatly, watching the train pull into the station, all noise and smoke.

‚ÄúOh my God mum look!‚Äù

Regulus follows the voice to a particularly tiny looking first year‚Äîeyes wide, luggage nearly the same size as her. As hard as he tries, he can‚Äôt remember being that young. I mean, he can remember being eleven, but not‚Ä¶not like that. Not the type to light up at the sight of a train. What he does remember, is thinking: what if it crashes? What if there aren‚Äôt enough seats for everyone? What if I get lost? Sirius slow down. Wait for me. Wait for me. Wait.

He doesn‚Äôt recognize the little girl‚Äôs mother. Not a Pureblood then.

Go back, he wants to tell her, it isn‚Äôt what you think. This world is full of wolves.

‚ÄúOi, look,‚Äù Evan elbows him, bringing his attention forward. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs our boy.‚Äù

Through the crowd Regulus can just pick out Barty Crouch, leaning against his trunk, ankles crossed, smug look on his dark face. And just slightly behind him, a man in Ministry robes.

‚ÄúHis father sent one of his lackeys again I see,‚Äù Regulus says as they move towards him.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like our parents are here waving us off, at least his old man cares enough to send someone.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, but it bothers Barty more than us.‚Äù

Evan rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúBloody daddy issues, so predictable. The pair of you.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt bother arguing.

¬†

The train is moving by the time Regulus starts making his way towards the Prefect‚Äôs carriage, leaving his stuff with Evan and Barty who give him a good amount of grief for the badge now pinned to his chest. He still has no idea what Slughorn or Dumbledore were thinking giving him this thing. Maybe they want to keep a closer eye on him? Keep him out of trouble? Not that he‚Äôs ever gotten into much trouble mind you, that‚Äôs more Sirius‚Äôs area of expertise.

There‚Äôs someone standing at the door to the Prefects‚Äô carriage when Regulus gets there. He slows down, watching her bounce up and down on her tippy-toes, peering inside. He knows her, he realizes. She‚Äôs the Greengrass girl‚ÄîCerci‚Äîhis year.

‚ÄúDeciding whether or not to go in?‚Äù he asks, causing her to jump and spin around.

She‚Äôs pretty‚Äîfreckles and tawny skin, with the biggest eyes he‚Äôs ever seen. It all ends up making her look very deer-like.

She laughs, ‚ÄúSorry, hey, hi, yeah I‚Äî‚Äú she cuts herself off, sending him a look and lowering her voice. ‚ÄúI have to be honest, I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing here. I‚Äôm completely useless, I‚Äôm not sure what they expect me to do with this,‚Äù she gestures to the pin on her robes.

Regulus smiles a little, nodding to his own. ‚ÄúTrust me, I understand.‚Äù

She exhales, ‚ÄúOh thank Merlin I‚Äôm not the only one.‚Äù

He stands next to her, following her gaze through the glass door, ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs all there?‚Äù he asks, trying to make out the blurry faces.

‚ÄúEveryone‚ÄîI mean, no one I know, obviously. Well, no one I know-know, like, I know OF them, but I don‚Äôt know about them, and they certainly don‚Äôt know about me. It‚Äôs a very base level of knowing, you know?‚Äù

Regulus looks over at her. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîsure.‚Äù He can‚Äôt decide if her frazzled demeanour is endearing or annoying.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù her face lights up suddenly and she smacks his arm. ‚ÄúI just realized‚Äîwe‚Äôre partners.‚Äù

Regulus arches his brow. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs how it‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúHonestly, I‚Äôm glad it‚Äôs you,‚Äù she talks over him. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre scary, don‚Äôt get me wrong, but I was worried it was going to be Parkinson,‚Äù she leans in, lowering her voice and cupping her hand around her mouth. ‚ÄúHe asked me out in third year and did not take the rejection well.‚Äù

Regulus snorts despite himself, he‚Äôs never liked Parkinson.

‚ÄúYou think I‚Äôm scary?‚Äù he can‚Äôt help but ask.

She nods without hesitating. ‚ÄúAbsolutely. Terrifying. You do this whole brooding stare thing and those eyes?‚Äù she shivers. ‚ÄúBut hey, at least you didn‚Äôt ask me out in third year and then knock over my pumpkin juice and start crying when I turned you down.‚Äù

Regulus actually chokes on his laughter it comes out of him so unexpectedly. ‚ÄúNo well,‚Äú he has to stop, still trying to pull himself together. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to worry about that with me, I‚Äôm not really big on dating.‚Äù

‚ÄúGosh, me neither. Sounds bloody terrible doesn‚Äôt it? My mates are always on me about it, but honestly? Having a boy‚Äôs tongue down their throats hasn‚Äôt made any of their lives any better.‚Äù

Regulus has no idea what he‚Äôs meant to say to that, still fighting to maintain some level of decorum. If nothing else, this girl sure can paint a vivid picture.

She opens her mouth again, Regulus isn‚Äôt sure if she has an off switch, but it‚Äôs another voice that cuts across the train.

‚ÄúWell, this is just pathetic.‚Äù

Severus Snape makes his way towards them, looking every inch the miserable son of a bitch he always does. Maybe even slightly more miserable. He runs them both up and down with great distain.

‚ÄúI mean really, you two? There used to be some pride in this house.‚Äù

Regulus just looks back at him blankly, if there is one person he has no energy for it‚Äôs Severus Snape.

‚ÄúI mean, apparently Salazar Slytherin was actually a bit of a hermit who mistrusted the muggle ritual of regular bathing so I‚Äôm not sure if that‚Äôs true,‚Äù Cerci says, very matter of fact.

Regulus snorts. He‚Äôs not sure what‚Äôs funnier‚Äîthe fact that Cerci has apparently memorized information about Salazar Slytherin‚Äôs grooming habits, or the look on Snape‚Äôs face. It really is impressive the amount of distain he‚Äôs able to fit inside those beady little eyes of his.

After a stony silence Snape gestures impatiently at the door. ‚ÄúGo on then, surely between the two of you someone can open a door?‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes, sliding the door open but purposefully blocking Snape‚Äôs path as he gestures for Cerci to go in first.

‚ÄúAfter you,‚Äù he says to her, which causes a smile to spread across her face.

‚ÄúOh, thank you, wow,‚Äùshe slips inside, Regulus about to follow when Snape reaches out and grabs his arm‚Äîhis right one, thankfully.

It still sends shocks through him though, just different ones. Memories of Lucius hauling him off the ground, grabbing his face, his hair. It‚Äôs work not to flinch, not to drop Snape‚Äôs gaze. He hopes the other boy can‚Äôt feel him shake.

‚ÄúIs it true?‚Äù Snape asks, dark eyes narrowed.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre talking about.‚Äù

Snape tightens his grip. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt play stupid with me Black, have you been‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

Reg looks back over his shoulder to see Cerci standing a few feet inside, eyes moving between him and Snape, brow arched in question.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù she says eventually, nodding at the seats behind her, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre sitting together right, partner?‚Äù

It takes Regulus a minute to realize that she‚Äôs trying to save him. He blinks, turning back to Snape who seems similarly surprised, making it easy enough for Regulus to pull himself free.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he clears his throat, straightening out his robes. ‚ÄúYeah, coming.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus‚Äî‚Äú

But Reg has already turned his back on Snape, Cerci smiling as he falls into step beside her.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù he says softly.

She looks over at him and winks.

¬†

Regulus doesn‚Äôt know the Head Boy and Girl, neither of them are from Slytherin, and both are far too perky for his liking. Far too excited about scheduling.

‚ÄúProfessor McGonagall has said she wants patrol teams to be more mixed this year,‚Äù the boy‚Äîblond haired and blue eyed‚Äîis smiling.

‚ÄúThat means that you won‚Äôt just be running patrols with your housemates,‚Äù he goes on, a collective groan emanating from the carriage.

‚ÄúWow, rude,‚Äù Cerci whispers beside him. ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt split up the dream team,‚Äù she nudges him playfully.

He arches his brow. ‚ÄúDream team?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right. Too generic. I‚Äôll brainstorm some new names and get back to you.‚Äù

Despite himself, Regulus smiles.

‚ÄúThe pairs for the rest of the train ride have already been decided,‚Äù the Head Girl holds up a clipboard. ‚ÄúAnd the schedule for the next month will be posted in the Prefect office after the feast so make sure you stop by and write down your shifts. Missing shifts is not acceptable, okay people? Neither is being late. We plan on running a tight ship this year.‚Äù Her smile is wide enough that it‚Äôs starting to feel unsettling. ‚ÄúOkay, so for our first train shift we have‚Ä¶.‚Äù

Not me.

Not me.

Not me.

His arm has started aching, and all he wants to do is go back to his compartment and nap to the sound of Barty and Evan‚Äôs inane chatter.

‚ÄúRegulus Black and Remus Lupin,‚Äù she says brightly.

Regulus sighs, closing his eyes.

‚ÄúOh come on, it‚Äôs not that bad. Remus is nice.‚Äù

He turns to Cerci, ignoring the rest of the names the Head Girl rattles off for the remaining shifts. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre friends with Remus Lupin?‚Äù

She shrugs. ‚ÄúHe holds a study group sometimes.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course he does.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkie-dokie,‚Äù the Head Girl‚Äôs voice cuts through the carriage again. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it for now, I think we have a really good group here and I‚Äôm so excited to get started. Lets have a great year everybody!‚Äù There‚Äôs a smattering of half-enthused applause. It‚Äôs work for Regulus not to roll his eyes.

Everyone starts getting to their feet and shuffling out the door. He can see Lupin up near the front of the carriage with Lily Evans. The sight of her makes something ugly in Regulus rear its head. He, like everyone else in the school, had a front row seat to James‚Äôs obsession with her. So yeah, Regulus is jealous. Which is stupid and pointless. But unfortunately, when it comes to James Potter, Regulus is plagued with a host of stupid and pointless feelings.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll see y‚Äôah later partner,‚Äù Cerci pulls him out of his thoughts as she pats his arm, heading for the door.

‚ÄúYou sure do get attached quick, huh? I thought I was scary?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh you are,‚Äù she shoots over her shoulder. ‚ÄúBut I happen to like scary.‚Äù

He watches her go with a slightly bemused look on his face, certain he has never met a person that he understood less.

Eventually, he turns around to see Evans and Lupin making their way towards him. The carriage is still a little crowded with lingering groups of friends catching up after the summer. Which is maybe how Snape doesn‚Äôt see them as he slides out of his own booth, head down, hair hanging in front of his eyes.

‚ÄúOh‚Äî‚Äú Lupin mutters as they collide, stumbling back. It‚Äôs nothing really, not until Snape realizes who he‚Äôs run into.

‚ÄúWhat the hell‚Äîdon‚Äôt fucking touch me,‚Äù he jumps back, staring at Lupin like he‚Äôs done a lot more than just causally bump into him. Regulus‚Äôs eyes bounce between them, trying to figure out what he‚Äôs missed. But Remus just looks resigned, holding up his hands in surrender.

‚ÄúYou ran into me Snape.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou should be more careful. Fucking animal‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOKAY,‚Äù Evans steps between the pair of them, staring Snape down. ‚ÄúYou can go now Severus.‚Äù

Something complicated contorts Snape‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGo. Now.‚Äù

Behind her Lupin has gone pale, which also, in Regulus‚Äôs opinion, seems like a bit of an overreaction.

There‚Äôs a moment where it looks like Snape might actually fight her (a bad move on his part since Regulus is fairly certain Evans could lay him out flat), but then he steps back.

‚ÄúReally picking sides these days aren‚Äôt you Lily?‚Äù he says bitterly.

If he‚Äôs expecting those words to wound her he must be disappointed because Evans doesn‚Äôt even flinch. ‚ÄúPot meet kettle,‚Äù she says dryly.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying, you should be careful who you hang around with.‚Äù

‚ÄúAgain, the irony of that coming from you.‚Äù

Snape rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúFine, whatever. But I tried to warn you,‚Äù he gives Lupin another scathing look before turning on his heel and booking it out of the carriage

There‚Äôs a flash of something like sadness in Evan‚Äôs green eyes before she turns back to Lupin. ‚ÄúYou alright?‚Äù she asks.

He nods slowly and then, after a second, seems to wake up, eyes refocusing.

‚ÄúLily Evans, my hero,‚Äù he smiles dryly.

She rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt start.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames would be so proud.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh yes, my mission in life, please James Potter.‚Äù

It‚Äôs irrational, he knows it is, but part of him wants to rip James‚Äôs name out of her mouth. Never let it pass her lips again.

Lupin looks like he‚Äôs going to speak but stops when his eyes find Regulus over Evan‚Äôs shoulder.

‚ÄúBlack,‚Äù he says, causing the red headed girl to turn around.

‚ÄúLupin.‚Äù

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù Evans has a slightly mesmerized look on her face as she runs him over. ‚ÄúSorry, I just‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt realize how much you looked like him until now.‚Äù

Regulus just stares at her, straight faced. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs taller.‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú she shoots Lupin a look, clearly uncertain what to do with him. ‚ÄúI guess that‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAnd funnier,‚Äù Lupin supplies, nearly matching Regulus‚Äôs deadpan tone. The two boys share a pointed look before Lupin breaks it to turn to Lily. ‚ÄúYou should go, no point hanging around here longer than you have to.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure you‚Äôre alright‚Ä¶with‚Ä¶everything?‚Äù

There is no doubt in Regulus‚Äôs mind that he‚Äôs included in that ‚Äúeverything.‚Äù

Lupin gives her a weak smile. ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôm alright Lils,‚Äù

‚ÄúM‚Äôkay, see you later?‚Äù

Remus nods as she starts towards the door.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù she says as she passes him.

He‚Äôs slightly thrown by the use of his first name but still manages a clipped; ‚ÄúEvans‚Äù before she‚Äôs out the door and beyond hearing. Leaving just him and Lupin.

He looks back at the older boy who sighs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm supposed to show you the ropes.‚Äù

A beat of silence.

‚ÄúSounds thrilling,‚Äù Regulus says flatly.

Lupin gives him a dry smile. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only two hours, lets just‚Ä¶get through it.‚Äù

Regulus nods in agreement, he hasn‚Äôt the energy to be difficult, and by the looks of it, neither does Lupin. The older boy starts moving and Regulus follows.

‚ÄúSo the train‚Äôs pretty straight forward,‚Äù he says as they exit the carriage. ‚ÄúBasically you just do laps up and down, technically you‚Äôre allowed to check the compartments but no one ever does‚Äîunless, you know, you hear someone being murdered or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou get a lot of murder attempts on the Hogwarts Express?‚Äù

Lupin snorts. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd be surprised.‚Äù

Regulus doubts it.

‚ÄúYou can dock points, but on the train that‚Äôs pretty redundant since no one has any. Also, you can‚Äôt take points from other Prefects.‚Äù

They move to the side as a group of Hufflepuffs pass them. Two of them giggle, eyes moving from Lupin‚Äôs face to the floor and back again. The third girl, apparently less shy, waves.

‚ÄúHey Remus!‚Äù

Remus smiles mildly. ‚ÄúHey, good summer?‚Äù

Blush blooms across her face. ‚ÄúYeah, brilliant. You?‚Äù

He shrugs. ‚ÄúIt was alright. Can‚Äôt complain. I‚Äôll see you around yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah!‚Äù she joins her friends in their giggling.

Regulus struggles not to roll his eyes as they continue along the carriage. ‚ÄúHufflepuff outreach part of Prefect duties?‚Äù

Lupin huffs out a laugh. ‚ÄúHonestly, I have no idea who any of those people were. It‚Äôs a side effect of being friends with James and Sirius.‚Äù He shoots Regulus a look almost immediately after he speaks but Regulus keeps his expression blank.

‚ÄúFans you mean?‚Äù

Lupin wrinkles his nose. ‚ÄúI guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúI expect they‚Äôre more thrilled about that than you are.‚Äù

They keep walking, moving into the next car, passing a few more students as they go, more waving happens, though Lupin doesn‚Äôt stop to talk to any of them. Eventually he speaks again, sounding the whole time like he‚Äôs not sure if he‚Äôs supposed to.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think James notices honestly,‚Äù he sends Regulus a sidelong look. ‚ÄúSirius does though. Plays it up a bit.‚Äù

Regulus nods. ‚ÄúMakes sense.‚Äù

There‚Äôs an annoying tightness in his chest every time Lupin says James‚Äôs name. A pain just under his ribs. Soft and aching. He finds his hand absentmindedly rubbing his sternum. He hasn‚Äôt figured out how he‚Äôs going to do it‚Äîhow he‚Äôs going to end things. What he‚Äôs going to say. He could always just show him the mark he supposes. Then there‚Äôd be no need to say anything.

After a long period of silence Lupin speaks, voice quieter this time.

‚ÄúJames said Rosier attacked his dad,‚Äù Regulus can feel Lupin‚Äôs eyes on him. ‚ÄúIs that true?‚Äù

Fucking Evan.

It‚Äôs a blessing really, that Regulus hadn‚Äôt been there that night. He‚Äôs not sure what he would have done‚Äîprobably nothing. He probably would have stood back and watched. Added it to the list of things James is never going to forgive him for.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre talking about,‚Äù is the answer he gives, making sure to meet Lupin‚Äôs stare when he says it, to show him the neutral expression on his face.

For a moment, he actually thinks he sees disappointment in Lupin‚Äôs eyes. But then it‚Äôs gone. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure James will believe you when you tell him that.‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth, annoyed that the dig actually bothers him. ‚ÄúYou think he‚Äôs gullible?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think he would never lie to you, so he won‚Äôt expect you to lie to him,‚Äù there is an irritating stoic quality to Remus. Something unflappable. It makes Regulus want to poke him.

‚ÄúWhat happened back there with Snape?‚Äù he asks, figuring that‚Äôs a good place to start. Almost instantly he feels the older boy tense.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not exactly friends,‚Äù Lupin says evasively, looking out the window beside him.

It‚Äôs work for Regulus not to smile.

Got you, he thinks.

‚ÄúThat was a little more than just not-friendly back there. That was fear.‚Äù

Lupin snorts. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not afraid of Severus Snape.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus agrees. ‚ÄúBut he‚Äôs afraid of you.‚Äù

He sees it again, the jolt of tension that runs through Lupin, the clenching of his jaw.

‚ÄúSo afraid,‚Äù Regulus goes on, ‚Äúthat he completely lost control in there, which he doesn‚Äôt normally do in general but specifically not in front of Evans,‚Äù still Lupin says nothing, watching the Scottish countryside roll by like it‚Äôs the most fascinating fucking thing he‚Äôs ever seen.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs scared of you,‚Äù Regulus repeats. ‚ÄúAnd you feel bad about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel bad about it,‚Äù his expression is still neutral but there‚Äôs a new tension in his voice that lets Regulus know he‚Äôs winning.

‚ÄúYou do. You didn‚Äôt enjoy it at all.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo most people enjoy being frightening?‚Äù Lupin asks, failing to keep his voice light.

‚ÄúOh come on, if he‚Äôd acted that way around my brother Sirius would have lapped up every second of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, well, some of us have a little more fucking humanity than Sirius bloody Black.‚Äù

That actually takes Regulus by surprise. The anger. And not directed at Snape.

Sirius hurt someone, that‚Äôs what James said. Someone important.

‚ÄúYou and my brother haven‚Äôt made up then?‚Äù he finds himself asking before he can think better of it.

Lupin‚Äôs eyes snap to him. ‚ÄúDid James tell you?‚Äù Regulus can‚Äôt quite figure out his expression‚Äîfear? Anger?‚Äîit‚Äôs one of those, or both. Normally he‚Äôd toy with him a bit more but he doesn‚Äôt want to make things difficult for James.

‚ÄúNo, not really. Just that my brother messed up, that he didn‚Äôt think he could forgive him.‚Äù

Lupin holds his stare for a moment longer before looking away again. ‚ÄúWell, he‚Äôs managed that last bit.‚Äù

It‚Äôs undeniable, the bitterness in his voice, and before Regulus can stop himself a dry laugh falls out of his mouth. Lupin sends him a look like he thinks he‚Äôs lost it.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúI just didn‚Äôt expect us to have anything in common.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have something in common?‚Äù Lupin sounds hesitant, like he‚Äôs afraid of what the answer might be.

‚ÄúYeah. We're jealous.‚Äù

Lupin comes to a stop near the end of the car, facing Regulus properly for the first time. ‚ÄúJealous of what?‚Äù

Regulus waves his hand indistinctly in the air. ‚ÄúOf the two them‚ÄîJames and Sirius, Sirius and James‚Äîtheir names have practically molded into one they‚Äôre said together so often. They‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, make sense together. You‚Äôve see it.‚Äù

After a moment, Lupin nods.

‚ÄúAnd you just know that nothing will ever matter to them as much as they matter to each other,‚Äù Regulus goes on, feeling the familiar barbs of jealousy that have been there since he was ten years old. ‚ÄúDrives me mental.‚Äù

Lupin actually laughs at that, leaning back against the wall behind him. ‚ÄúYou know sometimes they don‚Äôt even have to speak?‚Äù he swipes a hand across his face. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll just look at each other and it‚Äôs like they know. And I want that, I want S‚Äî‚Äù but he cuts himself off. And Regulus finds himself wondering what it is that Remus Lupin wants so badly he won‚Äôt say it out loud.

‚ÄúI hated James for it at first,‚Äù Regulus goes on after a brief pause, ‚Äúfor being so close to him.‚Äù

Lupin arches his brow. ‚ÄúAnd now?‚Äù

‚ÄúNow I hate them both. Bloody confusing honestly.‚Äù

Lupin gives him an earnest smile, different entirely from every way he‚Äôs looked at him before. ‚ÄúI know that feeling,‚Äù and then, as if worried he‚Äôs given something away, he wipes his expression clean, standing up a little straighter.

Regulus watches as a pair of Ravenclaws pass them, small and murmuring, arms linked. It always surprises him how young the other years look, when really there‚Äôs so little space between them.

‚ÄúYou never told James,‚Äù Lupin brings his attention back to him.

‚ÄúTold him?‚Äù there are a lot of things he‚Äôs never told James, though which of them Lupin knows he hasn‚Äôt a clue.

‚ÄúWhat I said to you in the hallway that day.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, it hadn‚Äôt really occurred to him before. ‚ÄúOh. No. I didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Lupin crosses his arms over his chest, giving him an appraising look. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt figure out why,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúYou could have used it against me.‚Äù

Regulus almost laughs. ‚ÄúBelieve it or not, I don‚Äôt actually have anything against you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI threatened to dismember you.‚Äù

Regulus shrugs. ‚ÄúYou were protecting him. If anything I respect it.‚Äù

A slightly bemused look comes across Lupin‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúYou would have come out looking the better for it, James would have been pissed at me.‚Äù

That‚Äôs certainly true. ‚ÄúIt only would have upset him,‚Äù he says simply.

‚ÄúStill would have been in your favour.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really consider James being upset as being in my favour.‚Äù

Lupin leans back, as though seeing him for the first time. ‚ÄúI thought‚Ä¶‚Äù he trails off, and then shakes his head and starts again. ‚ÄúI thought maybe you were just doing it to get back at Sirius.‚Äù

Oh.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fair,‚Äù he says, though his stomach has just pulled itself into a knot. ‚ÄúBut no. Not quite.‚Äù

Lupin keeps staring at him before eventually giving up, like Regulus is a math equation he can‚Äôt parcel out.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get it, really I don‚Äôt, but he‚Äôs mad about you,‚Äù Regulus feels that knot in his stomach pull tighter. ‚ÄúAnd, as hard as it is for me to believe, I think you might actually care about him too.‚Äù

More than breathing.

‚ÄúIs this you giving us your blessing?‚Äù Regulus asks dryly, thankful that none of his feelings bleed into his voice.

Lupin laughs, ‚ÄúNo, absolutely not. This is a terrible bloody idea, and, no offence, but I don‚Äôt like you very much.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe feeling is mutual.‚Äù

Lupin bows his head, accepting this. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying‚Äî‚Äú he seems to fight with the words in his mouth. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying, I am mildly less opposed to it than I was before.‚Äù

Regulus wants to tell him not to worry.

That he‚Äôll do the right thing.

For once.

That he‚Äôll put an end to this, before he hurts James too much. Before he breaks him beyond repair. It would be such a tragedy to dim James Potter‚Äôs light.

But, of course, he doesn‚Äôt say any of that.

He doesn‚Äôt say anything.

Lupin gives him one last look before he starts walking again, throwing his next words over his shoulder:

‚ÄúBut God help you both when Sirius finds out.‚Äù

¬†

He really wasn‚Äôt going to go. Wasn‚Äôt going to meet James in their room. Not tonight, not any night. It would be better that way, easier. They‚Äôd talk somewhere public. Somewhere that James couldn‚Äôt make a scene. Somewhere that Regulus couldn‚Äôt kiss him. Touch him. Couldn‚Äôt even think about those things.

It‚Äôs done.

We‚Äôre done.

We never should have started.

But now we‚Äôre done.

He meant to be cold and detached. Meant to be precise. A clean break. Better for the both of them. What is it people are always saying? Rip the band-aid off? Something like that. That‚Äôs what Regulus was going to do.

So he doesn‚Äôt know how he ends up standing inside the door of the Come and Go Room, staring at a beaming James Potter and feeling every ounce of his self-control fading away.

Stop it, he wants to shout at James, just like on the platform. Stop looking at me like that, like I mean something to you. I shouldn‚Äôt. I can‚Äôt. You should have known better. I tried to warn you.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù James says eventually, almost shyly.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù Regulus returns.

James is practically bouncing on the balls of his feet, like an over excited puppy. No one has ever wanted Regulus like this. Honestly, he‚Äôs not sure anyone has ever wanted him at all.

He feels a spark run up his left arm.

‚ÄúCan I‚Äî‚Äú James holds out his hand.

No.

No.

No.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù there‚Äôs barely a breath between the word leaving his mouth and James pressing into him, pushing him back until he hits the wall behind him, James‚Äôs mouth on his, hands in his hair. Under his shirt. Skating over his skin. James is everywhere, he‚Äôs all consuming, he‚Äôs warm and heavy and solid. Regulus is helpless against it.

He knew it would be like this. That‚Äôs why he did what he did. There‚Äôs no taking it back now. All he has to do is roll up his sleeve and James will leave and never look back. And James will be safe.

But Regulus doesn‚Äôt roll up his sleeve.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù James is whispering, his breath hot against Regulus‚Äôs neck. ‚ÄúToo much?‚Äù

Yes.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus closes his eyes as James moves under his jaw, down to his shoulder, pushing his shirt collar out of the way, lips trailing along his clavicle.

‚ÄúTell me,‚Äù James says, voice breathy, ‚Äútell me if you need‚Äîtell me to stop.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs hands sweep up James‚Äôs back, strong from all the Quidditch, fingers tangling themselves in his hair. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

James growls and suddenly his mouth is back on Regulus‚Äôs and Regulus tells himself not to think. Just this once. James picks him up, holds him against the wall.

It‚Äôs too much.

It‚Äôs too fast.

It shouldn‚Äôt be happening at all.

Regulus knows all of that, but he does nothing to stop it. Because he wants. He wants. And maybe he can have it, just this one time. Just for this moment. After that he‚Äôll give James up. He will. He just needs a little bit more.

They end up on the bed. They kiss and kiss and kiss. Kissing James has always felt like flying to Regulus. Like it‚Äôs the thing he was made to do. The only part of his life that doesn‚Äôt feel like drowning.

The problem is, there‚Äôs always the moment when it gets all‚Äîall messed up. All tangled in everything that came before.

He wishes it didn‚Äôt.

He wishes it was simple.

Because he wants.

Sometimes he wants James so much he thinks he‚Äôll die from it.

It‚Äôs too much.

It‚Äôs too fast.

But maybe that‚Äôs okay. Maybe it can hurt this time. Maybe it‚Äôs supposed to. If it means he gets to have him. If he can pretend a little longer that he belongs to someone. And before he can think about it the words are tumbling out of his mouth‚Äî

‚ÄúI think we should have sex.‚Äù

‚ÄúMm,‚Äù is all James says, kissing the point between his neck and his shoulder.

Stop, says the rational part of Regulus‚Äôs brain, don‚Äôt.

It‚Äôs too much.

It‚Äôs too fast.

‚ÄúNo, I think we should really‚Äîproperly‚Äîhave sex.‚Äù

James stills. After all the movement‚Äîthe hands and mouths and breath‚Äîit feels loud, his stillness. A few seconds pass before James pulls back, sitting up so that he‚Äôs straddling Reg‚Äôs hips. His face flushed, hair more mussed than usual.

‚ÄúYou mean‚Ä¶‚Äù

Regulus nods.

Too much.

Too fast.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Regulus swallows. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I mean.‚Äù

James just keeps looking at him, eyes wide, hands running through his hair. Eventually he laughs, it‚Äôs a nervous sound, skittish. Regulus can see the new tension in his shoulders, in the way he holds himself.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm saying this but I‚ÄîI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm ready‚Ä¶for‚Ä¶that.‚Äù

And being the self-involved narcissist that he his, Regulus hadn‚Äôt considered that James would say no. Hadn‚Äôt considered what this would mean to him.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù is what comes out of his mouth, which is the wrong thing. He instantly sees the uncertainty flicker across James‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúIs that okay?‚Äù James asks, rubbing at the back of his neck the way he does when he gets nervous.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Regulus hates his voice sometimes, how even when he tries to make it warm and soft it never seems to come out that way. There‚Äôs too much Black in him. Too much of his mother.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he tries again. ‚ÄúYes it‚Äôs okay. Of course it‚Äôs‚Äîit was a stupid thing to ask anyway‚ÄîI don‚Äôt even know‚Äî‚Äù his throat is suddenly dry, anxiety building under his skin.

Too much.

Too fast.

He just wants it to go away. He just wants to be able to do this‚Äîthis normal thing. He just wants to pretend for a moment that he‚Äôs somebody else. Somebody that deserves to be here. But he can‚Äôt. Because the memories are always there. A rotting feeling in the pit of his stomach.

Too much.

Too fast.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he says again, because he doesn‚Äôt know what else to say.

‚ÄúHey, woah, no, don‚Äôt be,‚Äù James looks at him a little curiously. ‚ÄúReg, you get to‚Äîyou know‚Äîask for stuff. Ask for the stuff you want.‚Äù
