‚ÄúIs it though?‚Äù James asks gently, breaking the silence, still looking at Regulus like he‚Äôs not sure what he‚Äôs seeing. ‚ÄúWhat you want, I mean? Are you‚Äîare you ready for‚Ä¶‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt know how to answer that question.

No.

He never will be.

It will always feel like this. Because he‚Äôs broken.

But he just wanted‚Äî

He just wanted‚Äî

His hands come up to his face, hiding it from view, and he must be tired, or wrecked, or something, to let the next words come out of his mouth; ‚ÄúI just wanted to be with you.‚Äù

It‚Äôs so pathetic.

So utterly pathetic.

And desperate.

And grasping.

As though sex would change anything.

Would make him feel better about walking away.

Would make him feel whole.

‚ÄúReg, hey, look at me?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt want to. He doesn‚Äôt know how to.

‚ÄúRegulus.‚Äù

No one says his name like James. Like it‚Äôs worth something.

It‚Äôs a few more seconds before he‚Äôs able to let his hands fall away from his face, forcing his eyes up to meet the boy still hovering above him.

‚ÄúYou have me,‚Äù James says softly, running a finger along Regulus‚Äôs jaw that sends shivers through his whole body. ‚ÄúWe have time.‚Äù

And don‚Äôt those words just feel like a knife in his side.

Regulus doesn‚Äôt answer. Can‚Äôt really, if he‚Äôs being honest. So he lets James run his gentle fingers along the shapes of his face, his neck, his shoulders. Purposeless touches‚Äîmore reassurances than anything else. They say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here‚Äù but all Regulus can think is ‚Äúyou shouldn‚Äôt be.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never,‚Äù James starts eventually, clearing his throat. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never done that before.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, coming back to himself. ‚ÄúYou mean‚Ä¶with a boy?‚Äù

James lets out a breath of laughter. ‚ÄúI mean with anyone.‚Äù

It isn‚Äôt that Regulus hasn‚Äôt‚Ä¶guessed that. It‚Äôs only that sometimes he still forgets. Forgets that there‚Äôs the James Potter who everyone sees‚Äîthis larger than life, cocky, asshole. And then there‚Äôs the actual James Potter. Just a boy. A boy who loves people more than he probably should.

‚ÄúBut you‚Äôve‚Äî‚Äù James struggles with his words. ‚ÄúYou have?‚Äù

Regulus feels too tight. His chest. His throat. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he finally manages to say.

James nods above him. ‚ÄúWith the‚Äîer‚Äîwith the guy you were seeing before?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt seeing each other,‚Äù he‚Äôs struggling to breathe. ‚ÄúCan‚Äîcan you‚Äî‚Äú he taps on James‚Äôs thigh, which by some miracle seems to be enough for him to understand.

‚ÄúOh‚Äîyeah, sorry,‚Äù he slides off, Regulus sitting up, feet planting on the floor at the end of the bed. James is sitting next to him but Regulus doesn‚Äôt look at him. Can‚Äôt right now. He presses the heels of his hands into his eyes, trying to get himself back under control. He‚Äôs supposed to be better than this.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù James says gently. Regulus doesn‚Äôt know how long they‚Äôve been sitting in silence.

‚ÄúYes, sorry,‚Äù he pulls himself up straight, finding the posture that was beaten into him throughout his childhood. Black‚Äôs don‚Äôt slouch.

‚ÄúOkay, you really need to stop apologizing.‚Äù

Regulus isn‚Äôt sure that that‚Äôs true. That it ever will be. All he feels is regret. He is made of apologies.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú James starts and stops, Regulus still can‚Äôt look at him, eyes focused on the hands in his lap. James sighs and starts again. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have to talk about it if you don‚Äôt want to but‚Ä¶something is‚Äîsomething is wrong, yeah?‚Äù

Regulus lets out a dry laugh. Yeah, something‚Äôs wrong.

‚ÄúIs it‚Äîis it about the guy‚Ä¶?‚Äù

Regulus squeezes his eyes shut. Maybe this is the easiest place to start‚Äîto start showing James what‚Äôs really living inside his skin. How twisted up he is.

‚ÄúHe was older,‚Äù Regulus manages on his next exhale. He hears James shuffle closer.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says the word softly, and Regulus knows it‚Äôs his way of letting him know that he‚Äôs listening, but part of him wishes he wouldn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú Regulus‚Äôs voice shakes, and he swallows, trying to centre himself. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt exactly my proudest moment.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay Reg,‚Äù unfazed.

It isn‚Äôt.

God it isn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúIt‚ÄîI was thirteen when it‚Äîwhen it started.‚Äù

He hears James‚Äôs sharp inhale and does his best not to flinch. Pushing on with the story. ‚ÄúSirius was always at yours, even before he left for good, and I was‚Äî‚Äú it‚Äôs ash in his mouth, it‚Äôs bitter and vile and pathetic. ‚ÄúI was lonely.‚Äù

Regulus swallows, nails digging into his knees. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI liked it at first, the attention, the looks and the smiles and compliments. I didn‚Äôt know,‚Äù he lets out a breath, his whole body shaking. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know where it was going until it‚Äîit happened the first time.‚Äù

The silence is deafening and Regulus has the intense desire to just disappear inside of himself. He could walk away, James might let him now.

I won‚Äôt even have to show him my arm, he thinks ruefully.

‚ÄúHow long did this go on for?‚Äù James asks eventually, Regulus has never heard his voice sound like that‚Äîcold.

He doesn‚Äôt want to have this conversation. He doesn‚Äôt want to think about this at all. It‚Äôs so much worse than he thought it‚Äôd be‚Äîdragging it all up out of the corners he‚Äôs stuffed it into.

‚ÄúI promise not while we‚Äôve been‚Äînothing since we‚Äôve been together,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs the right answer but it‚Äôs the only one he has.

There‚Äôs another aching pause, Regulus is about ready to crawl out of his skin. People always tell you to talk about things, he doesn‚Äôt know why. It‚Äôs never made him feel better. Just like he‚Äôs been pulled inside-out. Exposed.

‚ÄúSo last summer‚Ä¶?‚Äù there‚Äôs still something wrong with James‚Äôs voice but Regulus can‚Äôt make himself look at him.

‚ÄúListen, it‚Äôs not‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt want it, but I just couldn‚Äôt‚Ä¶see the point in making an enemy in that house. I‚Äôm not a very‚Äî‚Äú he laughs dryly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a very brave person. Not very bold. I guess the sorting hat got that bit right.‚Äù

He rests his elbows on his knees, face in his hands as he tries to breathe, tries not to look like he‚Äôs falling apart. And fuck, his stupid arm really fucking hurts and he knows it‚Äôs in his head. It has to be. But it keeps getting worse, keeps getting sharper. Like it‚Äôs being burned into his skin all over again. He didn‚Äôt scream the first time, he wonders if he will now.

‚ÄúWho?‚Äù James demands, barely even a question.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho fucking‚Äî‚Äú James stops himself, and Regulus hears him take in a shaking breath. ‚ÄúWho was it, Regulus?‚Äù

Finally, Regulus forces himself to face him, to meet his stare. He‚Äôs surprised to find James seething. Every muscle in his body looks like it‚Äôs vibrating with tension, eyes on fire.

‚ÄúLucius Malfoy, he‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI know who he is,‚Äù James cuts him off, voice like steel. ‚ÄúWorks with my dad sometimes, he‚Äôs married to your cousin.‚Äù

Regulus swallows, nodding. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

They sit there, staring at one another. Regulus doesn‚Äôt know where they go from here.

Nowhere, hisses the voice in his head. Exactly where you were always going.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to kill him.‚Äù

James‚Äôs words are full of blades. They are barring their teeth. Not afraid of cutting you open and spilling you out. It‚Äôs frightening honestly.

And of all the things Regulus could say‚Äîdon‚Äôt, and stop, and no‚Äîall he can think is:

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

James‚Äôs face breaks for a second, the anger turning into pain and Regulus has to look down again‚Äîlook away‚Äîhe hates it. ‚ÄúReg,‚Äù James‚Äôs voice is gentle.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt matter‚Äîit‚Äôs not‚Äîit isn‚Äôt what you think.‚Äù He clenches his teeth, trying to get a hold of the tremors in his voice.

‚ÄúWhat I think?‚Äù James repeats slowly.

Regulus has started picking at the comforter. ‚ÄúI told you,‚Äù he whispers, ‚ÄúI was lonely.‚Äù

A pained noise comes from James‚Äôs throat. ‚ÄúYou were thirteen.‚Äù

‚ÄúHardly a child,‚Äù he repeats Narcissa‚Äôs words, though he doesn‚Äôt make them sound quite as convincing as she did. Something about the break in his voice, he imagines.

‚ÄúJesus Christ Regulus.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt make this into something it‚Äôs not.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething it‚Äôs not? Regulus he‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNO.‚Äù

The word comes out of him quickly and over loud. It lingers around them, like the smoke after a gunshot. And Regulus wants to go back to murderous James, to angry James, anything to get James to stop looking at him like he‚Äôs an open wound.

He tries to shake it off, forcing his words to come out flat. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt fight him James.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou. Were. Thirteen.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd then I was fourteen, it didn‚Äôt make a difference. I barely even registered that anything was wrong. I let it happen, I always let it happen. So it wasn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú but he can‚Äôt finish that sentence. He‚Äôs never even thought it really. It would make it all so much harder, to name the things that have happened to him.

‚ÄúAlways?‚Äù James asks. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean always?‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head, getting off the bed, pacing, considering just walking out the door. He should. He should have never walked in in the first place. ‚ÄúI mean always. With all of them‚ÄîFlint and Snape and‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSnape?‚Äù

Oh.

Oh Regulus knows better than that. But his brain is all scattered, like a stack of papers he can‚Äôt get in order, that keep slipping out of his hands.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck did Snape do?‚Äù James is on his feet now too, that look back on his face‚Äîlike he‚Äôs about to kill someone with his bare hands.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus says, ‚ÄúNot‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt mean‚Äî‚Äú his hands run over his face and he breathes in. ‚ÄúHe‚Äîhe found out about me, about me being‚Äî‚Äú and he can‚Äôt say that one either, for fear that somehow his mother might magically appear in the middle of the room. Sighing, frustrated, he pushes forward. ‚ÄúHe used it to blackmail me‚Äîget me to do things for him‚Äîand I just let him, for years I just let him. Because that‚Äôs what I do. That‚Äôs who I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, well he‚Äôs also going to die‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo, don‚Äôt you get it?‚Äù and now he‚Äôs getting angry, except it‚Äôs the kind of angry where his throat is too tight and his eyes too wet. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs me. I‚Äôm the problem. I‚Äôm the common denominator here.‚Äù It comes out sounding so much more desperate than he means it to. Because he doesn‚Äôt care, really, he doesn‚Äôt. He knows who he is. He‚Äôs always known. He grew up watching Sirius fight and stand his ground. He grew up leaving Sirius behind, to face their mother on his own while Regulus hid in his bedroom.

He knows who he is.
