And so he does. It‚Äôs a saying‚Äîthe world stopped‚Äîbut the world really does stop when he looks at James Potter. The entirety of the universe suddenly holding its breath.

‚ÄúYou are not the bad things that have happened to you.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck. Off.‚Äù

But, of course, that doesn‚Äôt stop James. ‚ÄúNone of it was your fault Reg. None of it, I can‚Äôt‚ÄîI can‚Äôt even‚Äîyou didn‚Äôt deserve it.‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head, not sure how he‚Äôs still standing when his legs are shaking this badly. ‚ÄúI did. I did. Can‚Äôt you see that?‚Äù he‚Äôs begging, begging for James to understand. To let him have this. Because if it was his fault than it doesn‚Äôt hurt. Than he didn‚Äôt lose anything, because things never could have been any different. Because no one could have saved him. And if nobody could have than it doesn‚Äôt matter that nobody did. Not even Sirius.

‚ÄúI deserved all of it,‚Äù he‚Äôs crying now, voice cutting itself up on its way out of his mouth. ‚ÄúI deserved it. I deserved it. I deserved it.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù and James sounds nearly as wrecked as he does, eyes wide as he steps forward. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

He just shakes his head, he has nothing left, he‚Äôs wrung out. ‚ÄúI deserved it,‚Äù he chokes, words barely audible.

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt Reg.‚Äù

And he hates him, even as he stands there, arms open but not coming closer. Because he won‚Äôt touch Regulus, not until he tells him it‚Äôs okay. And even though every rational thought in Regulus‚Äôs head screams ‚Äúno‚Äù he feels himself reach out, pulling James to him, burying his face in his chest. Like coming home. Warm and safe.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù James rests his chin on the top of Regulus‚Äôs head, hands stroking slow circles on his back. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, we‚Äôre going to be okay.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt bother correcting him. He doesn‚Äôt have the energy.

‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù James whispers into his hair, causing Regulus to push into him further, like he‚Äôs trying to crawl inside his ribcage. ‚ÄúI love you so much.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wish you didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

James lets out a noise somewhere between a laugh and a sob. ‚ÄúI know,‚Äù he says, squeezing Regulus tighter. ‚ÄúBut I do, I always will.‚Äù

And God, Regulus hopes that isn‚Äôt true. Hopes that one day James Potter forgets all about him. That he goes on and lives his beautiful perfect life. That he isn‚Äôt weighed down by everything dark and heavy that sits inside Regulus‚Äôs skin. James deserves more. Deserves better than that.

You could roll up your sleeve.

You could let him go now.

It would be so easy.

Regulus‚Äôs hands are twisted-up in the back of James‚Äôs shirt and he pulls him closer even though there‚Äôs no space between them.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna protect you Reg,‚Äù James is whispering again.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need you to protect me,‚Äù he mutters into James‚Äôs chest.

‚ÄúWell fuck you, I‚Äôm going to anyway.‚Äù

You can‚Äôt, Regulus doesn‚Äôt say. You never could have. It was always too late for me. I was always a lost cause.

‚ÄúThen I‚Äôll protect you back.‚Äù

I‚Äôll show him the mark.

I will.

Soon.

James laughs wetly. ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôm pretty sure that‚Äôs how it works.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow what works?‚Äù Regulus sniffles, only pulling away from James enough to speak.

‚ÄúBeing with someone.‚Äù

Another blade in his side. Another ache in his arm. This boy is exhausting, always tearing down the walls that Regulus has spent years building up, that have kept him together for most of his life.

‚ÄúI hate you,‚Äù the words are out of his mouth before he can stop them.

James sighs, kissing the top of his head. ‚ÄúYeah, I know that too.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hello lovelies!

Listen, for a Regulus chapter that wasn't that bad.

I mean, that last scene still makes me cry every time I read it, but no one was actively trying to harm him so for Regulus that's really a win.

I hope you're all having a great day!

Chapter 21

Chapter Summary

Snuffles

Chapter Notes

tw: referenced/implied child abuse (specifically involving food at one point)

tw: internalized homophobia (but like, self-aware internalized homophobia?)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

There‚Äôs a sort of high that comes from not giving a shit. At least if you do it right. It‚Äôs almost like a switch in Sirius‚Äôs brain that he can just‚Ä¶flick. And then it‚Äôs as if nothing matters‚Äîwhat people think, what they want from him. It‚Äôs better than sex, honestly.

The come down‚Äôs a bitch though.

He used to think he could control it‚Äîthe switch. It wasn‚Äôt until last year, until he told Snape about Remus, until he watched the horror wash over James‚Äôs face, that he realized how stupid that was.

To this day he can‚Äôt really remember that moment‚Äîthe moment he decided to blow-up his whole life. It certainly hadn‚Äôt occurred to him that that was what he was doing. It had all just seemed so pointless for a moment‚Äîthe secrets, the fear‚Äîand then it had seemed funny. The idea of Snape face to face with a werewolf.

Not a werewolf.

His brain corrects itself.

Moony.

Remus.

The boy with the beautiful eyes and the shaggy hair and the smile that‚Äôs afraid of itself.

That boy.

Mine. Mine. Mine. Mine.

He hadn‚Äôt had any of those thoughts that night though. Hadn‚Äôt felt any of that ache. He‚Äôd been alone for hours by that point, slowly growing more and more numb. Until he didn‚Äôt mind so much that his uncle was dead. That it was probably his fault. It was so like his mother honestly, to kill someone just to get back at him. Just to punish him. He‚Äôd stayed alone until he could make himself not feel it anymore.

And then Snape had been there, making some crack about Remus being sick. About how frail he was. How pathetic. Sirius could remember laughing at that. Because it was funny, honestly, to have Severus Snape calling Remus Lupin weak. When at that very moment he was mere minutes away from turning into a full-fledged monster.

Not a monster.

Moony.

Remus.

Mine. Mine. Mine. Mine.

In that moment the only thing that had felt funnier than Snape not knowing what an ass he was making out of himself. Was him knowing exactly how much of an ass he was making out of himself. So he‚Äôd told him where to go, if he wanted to know why Remus was always so sick. And as he‚Äôd watched Snape walk away he‚Äôd felt that familiar high. Of doing the thing he wasn‚Äôt supposed to do. Of not giving a shit.

The comedown really is a bitch.

¬†

It‚Äôs early, too earlier, honestly. No one in their right mind would be up this early, but then, James has always been a little more nuts than people give him credit for. At least in Sirius‚Äôs opinion.

He‚Äôs sitting in the stands, watching the Gryffindor team finish their first practice since tryouts. They look alright, the holes left behind by Frank and Alice are big, but not insurmountable, and James has been able to find some good new talent. The Keeper in particular‚Äîa third year, Jeremy or Renly or something‚Äîis going to be an absolute star. Sirius can already see it.

He watches them land, watches them huddle around James on the ground. Mary‚Äôs the easiest to pick out even from this distance‚Äîdark hair braided down her back, hip cocked, arms crossed. He can‚Äôt help but wonder how that‚Äôs going for James‚Äîgetting her under control. Mary‚Äôs a brilliant player, and honestly the funniest person Sirius knows, but she‚Äôll cause problems just for the hell of it. And she‚Äôs certainly not afraid to push James around.

Sirius tears his eyes away from the ground, grabbing hold of his own broom and heading down to the pitch. Him and James are‚Ä¶honestly, he doesn‚Äôt really know. They‚Äôre friendly, he guesses. But even thinking the word makes him scrunch up his face like he‚Äôs smelt something bad. Him and James have never been ‚Äúfriendly‚Äù before. They were strangers and then friends and then brothers. There was no intermediate stage of awkward polite small talk.

Sirius hates it.

He gets down to the field just as the team starts breaking up and heading towards the locker rooms. He stays in the shadows of the stands, watching James talk to one of the newer players. Sirius can‚Äôt hear what he‚Äôs saying, but he imagines it‚Äôs some sort of pep talk. James looks fully in his element.

This is a big deal, James being Captain. It‚Äôs one of those things he‚Äôs always talked about, even back in first year. He had so many dreams‚ÄîSirius had never met anyone like that before. Someone who knew what they wanted and thought they could get it. He came from a family with very specific requirements. You had your life dictated to you and you coloured within those lines. The Black family didn‚Äôt have dreams, they had expectations.

James claps the kid on the shoulder, and as the younger boy starts to pull away Sirius steps forward, trying to pretend he isn‚Äôt nervous. Because he shouldn‚Äôt be. Because he never used to be.

‚ÄúOi! Wanker with the bad hair,‚Äù he calls out, causing James to swivel around, confusion soon replaced by a surprised grin.

‚ÄúNah, it can‚Äôt be, look at you! All up and dressed and it‚Äôs not even eight a.m yet. I‚Äôve never been so proud,‚Äù James wipes a nonexistent tear from the corner of his eye.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre about as funny as the Bloody Baron you know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúI happen to think the Baron is plenty funny, thank you very much.‚Äù

‚ÄúI love it when you prove my point.‚Äù

James snorts, shoving Sirius‚Äôs shoulder playfully before his eyes fall on the broom in his hands. He looks back at Sirius, brow arched in question.

He feels his nerves flare up again but quickly shuts them down. It‚Äôs such a stupid feeling. Especially here. About this.

‚ÄúI was wondering if you had any energy left for a quick fly?‚Äù his causal tone almost sounds convincing.

‚ÄúEr‚Ä¶‚Äù James pauses, and Sirius feels his heart sink. There never would have been a question before, but he knows that now James is thinking about Remus. How Remus will feel when they walk into breakfast together, how quickly he‚Äôll excuse himself from the table.

‚ÄúYou know what, don‚Äôt worry about it,‚Äù Sirius tries to laugh it off. ‚ÄúNever mind, it‚Äôs fine.‚Äù He starts to turn away.

‚ÄúHey‚Äîno,‚Äù James calls out, causing Sirius to pause, turning back to him. ‚ÄúCourse I have energy for a fly,‚Äù James shoots him a slightly strained smile as he picks up his own broom. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got‚Äîwhat? Half an hour?‚Äù

Sirius nods. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah, about. You sure? Cause if you‚Äôre‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù James gives him a pointed look, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt be an idiot, get on the bloody broom.‚Äù And with that James swings his leg over his own and kicks off, bringing the first genuine smile to Sirius‚Äôs face.

It feels good‚Äîthe minute he‚Äôs off the ground‚Äîit feels real good. He didn‚Äôt touch his broom all summer, couldn‚Äôt quite bear it. Every time he looked at it it was just a reminder of another thing he‚Äôd lost. He isn‚Äôt James, flying isn‚Äôt his life, but that doesn‚Äôt mean he doesn‚Äôt miss it. That he isn‚Äôt still gutted that after years of talking about what they were going to do when James made Captain he isn‚Äôt even there to see it. To be a part of it.

They fly a few laps around the pitch, doing dives and flips. Sirius can do this one move that James has never mastered‚Äîwhere he swings down, hanging off his broom by his legs. Technically, it‚Äôs against regulations (it‚Äôs not, strictly speaking, safe) and when he tried it in a game McGonagall benched him (it was worth it honestly), but it drives James batty that he can‚Äôt do it.

‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt understand how you get back up,‚Äù James says as he circles around Sirius who is just settling back onto his broom. ‚ÄúWhere does the momentum come from?‚Äù

‚ÄúA magician never reveals his secrets.‚Äù

James lets out an irritated scoff. ‚ÄúPrick.‚Äù

‚ÄúTwat‚Äù

They both smile, it feels good. It feels normal. Sort of. Almost.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Sirius says, as they float lazily in the air, the early morning sky growing brighter around them. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs the team?‚Äù

He sees James shift into captain mode, sees the serious look in his eyes, the straightening of his shoulders. That‚Äôs his best mate right there. Fucking unstoppable.

‚ÄúReally good actually, it‚Äôs the most new players since our second year but so far they‚Äôre meshing really well. I think we stand a chance.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou better, if I have to watch Slytherin win again I swear I‚Äôm going to drown myself in the lake,‚Äù he ignores the scratchy feeling in his chest when he talks about himself as a spectator. Just another member of the crowd.

‚ÄúMerlin, me too,‚Äù James runs a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúThey have a solid team, but, I think our real competition is Ravenclaw. They have a chip on their shoulders after last year.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh they have a chip?‚Äù Sirius asks coldly. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one who had a Bludger lodged in your fucking skull. Tell your beaters to give them shit all game. I swear I‚Äôll get up here and do it myself if I have to. Cheating bastards.‚Äù

James stops moving, looking at Sirius and arching his brow.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Sirius demands defensively.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just sounding a bit bitter that‚Äôs all.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, bitter? Moi? Never. I‚Äôm sweet as honey,‚Äù he smiles with all his teeth, causing James to laugh through his nose. ‚ÄúI just might have also meticulously planned the deaths of every single Ravenclaw player who was on the field that day.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou know it wasn‚Äôt all of their faults right?‚Äù

Sirius shrugs, unconcerned by this fact. ‚ÄúGuilt by association.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not how that works.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see.‚Äù

James shakes his head, laughing dryly. ‚ÄúThank Merlin you won‚Äôt be playing against them,‚Äù he freezes, realizing what he‚Äôs just said, eyes growing wide. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mean‚Äîobviously I want you to be‚Äî‚Äú he sighs. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean that the way it came out.‚Äù

Sirius nods stiffly. ‚ÄúYeah, I got that. Don‚Äôt worry about it. It‚Äôs fine,‚Äù which is not true but he doesn‚Äôt want James‚Äôs pity. It won‚Äôt fix anything. It‚Äôll just make him feel like even more of a fuck up.

He hooks his feet under his footrests and lies back on his broom. James making a disapproving noise in the background that brings the smile back to Sirius‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know why you do that, it‚Äôs bloody uncomfortable.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe you‚Äôre just doing it wrong.‚Äù

James flies over him sticking out his tongue before climbing higher in the sky. Sirius laughs, watching James do a few flips and barrel turns. He can hear birds somewhere‚Äîit sounds far away‚Äîand the noise of the lake gently brushing against the shore. Right now, Remus is probably showering, then he‚Äôll try to do some reading before going down to breakfast. He‚Äôll have eggs‚Äîover easy‚Äîon toast‚Äîlightly buttered‚Äîwith some gross mixture of every juice available at the table.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he‚Äôd said once, when he caught Sirius making a face at his glass. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all just fruit anyway.‚Äù

Of course, Sirius won‚Äôt be there to see Remus‚Äôs incredibly predictable morning routine or incredibly gross beverage habits. He doesn‚Äôt sit with them at meals anymore. One look at Remus‚Äôs face on their first day back was enough to tell him that he wasn‚Äôt welcome. So he sits with the girls instead. It‚Äôs what he did at the end of last year too.

‚ÄúI just want you to know,‚Äù James is slightly breathless from all the flying as he pulls himself back up to Sirius‚Äôs side. ‚ÄúThat if you fall asleep and roll off your broom I‚Äôm not going to catch you.‚Äù

Sirius snorts, still staring up at the sky. ‚ÄúSome best mate you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey man, I‚Äôm just being honest.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence.

‚ÄúYour boy doing alright then?‚Äù Sirius asks, cringing at the falsely cheery sound of his voice. Not because he isn‚Äôt happy for James, but because he doesn‚Äôt know how to talk about this.

More silence.

Sirius thinks it‚Äôs probably good that his current reclined position prevents them from making eye contact.

‚ÄúMy boy?‚Äù James asks eventually.

‚ÄúOh I‚Äôm sorry, does he have a title?‚Äù Sirius asks dryly. ‚ÄúBoyfriend? Lover? James‚Äôs bitch?‚Äù

James laughs. ‚ÄúDefinitely that last one.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought so,‚Äù another pause, this has been a new thing with them recently, this stilted air to their conversations. Both of them hesitating too often, tiptoeing around one another. ‚ÄúBut seriously‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSiriusly?‚Äù

Sirius glares, even though he‚Äôs still not looking at James. ‚ÄúPotter, we‚Äôve had this discussion. That pun belongs to me and me alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry, sorry,‚Äù he hears the sound of him stifling a laugh. ‚ÄúForgive me, I forgot. You were saying something?‚Äù

Sirius huffs. ‚ÄúWell now I‚Äôm feeling way less generous, but I was saying‚Ä¶‚Äù he clears his throat. ‚ÄúThat, you know, whatever you want me to‚Äîto call him, or you, or this thing‚Äîwhatever you want. Just‚Ä¶let me know okay?‚Äù They haven‚Äôt really talked about it since James told him. Too much happened after that. Too much silence. Of course, James is a bit like that in general‚Äîloud and obnoxious about the things that don‚Äôt matter and quiet about the things that do.

Finally, Sirius pulls himself upright again, getting a bit of a head rush as he sits properly on his broom. He look over at his best friend whose face is a knot of emotions Sirius can‚Äôt seem to untie. He‚Äôs about to change the subject again when James finally speaks.

‚ÄúHonestly, I don‚Äôt really have names for‚Ä¶any of it,‚Äù he says, a bit nervously.

Sirius nods. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fair. Personally, I‚Äôve never been a big fan of labels.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James rubs the back of his neck, looking distant.

‚ÄúDo Effie and Fleamont know?‚Äù

James lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúFunny, that‚Äôs the first thing he wanted to know too.‚Äù And then he cringes, like he‚Äôs just given too much away.

Sirius, who, quite honestly, was never going to like anyone James seriously dated because he‚Äôs always been bad at sharing, definitely isn‚Äôt a fan of this guy. Not a fan of the sneaking and lying and secrets. James has never kept anything from Sirius before‚Äîat least not that he knows of. And he hates this guy for putting that wedge between them.

‚ÄúHe know them?‚Äù Sirius asks. Because while, yes, he respects James‚Äôs privacy, he is also desperate to figure out who this guy is.

James shrugs. ‚ÄúKnows ‚Äúof‚Äù them more like.‚Äù

Ah. That sounds like a pureblood then. Interesting. Certainly narrows it down.

‚ÄúSo?‚Äù he prods.

James blinks. ‚ÄúSorry?‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes, exhaling dramatically. ‚ÄúDo they know?‚Äù

James continues to stare at him blankly before his brain catches up to him. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîmy parents? Merlin, I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he runs a hand over his face. ‚ÄúPretty sure my mum does, you know how she is.‚Äù

Sirius nods, smiling a little. He does. She‚Äôs brilliant.

‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt talked about it or anything, but, she says things sometimes‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know. She doesn‚Äôt seem to care. My dad? Nah, not a clue. You saw him though, he‚Äôs so busy these days.‚Äù

Sirius likes Fleamont. He‚Äôs a bit of nerd, but funny, and kind‚Äîand busy. He always has been, as long as Sirius has known him. James doesn‚Äôt really talk about being bothered by it, but Sirius thinks sometimes he is.

‚ÄúIt‚Äîmy parents, they‚Äôve never, I don‚Äôt know, they‚Äôve never talked about marriage or heirs or any of that,‚Äù James wrinkles his nose. ‚ÄúI know that stuff is, like, important. I know that the Potter name is important. But they‚Äôve never made me feel like that was something that I had to carry on or plan my life around,‚Äù he‚Äôs looking at Sirius earnestly. ‚ÄúIt was different for you?‚Äù

Sirius blinks, surprised by the question, and then he laughs. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah it was different. It‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú he‚Äôs not even sure where to start, memories flashing through his head he‚Äôd rather not see. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs everything to them, the family name, you sort of‚Äîyou sacrifice yourself to it. And I was‚Äî‚Äú He can feel it, the ghost of her fingers, on his shoulder, on the back of his neck, nails digging in. Reminding him that he was owned. She was always touching him like that. Possessively.

‚ÄúAnyway,‚Äù he shakes his head, eyes focusing again. ‚ÄúAnything that threatened the line was the root of all evil. That would have included‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúFancying boys?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius bites his lower lip, remembering how it had felt to press against Remus. To hold him properly. The way he hadn‚Äôt realized he‚Äôd been craving. Hadn‚Äôt let himself think about. ‚ÄúIt would be a kind of corruption to them. Only a Black who was deficient in some way, weak or broken, would act against the interest of the family.‚Äù

That sits between them, and Sirius swears they sink lower, like the words are an anchor, a weight dragging them down. He tries not to think about what came after that kiss. The way the shame and fear had felt so sharp‚Äîso real‚Äîlike claws dragging through his chest, ripping him apart. He tries not to think about the look on Remus‚Äôs face when he‚Äôd jumped back. When he‚Äôd left. Left him there. Alone.

It‚Äôs all so much more complicated than people make it seem. I hate myself, he‚Äôd wanted to explain to Remus. I hate myself for doing it. For wanting it. But I don‚Äôt hate you. I don‚Äôt hate you for being there. I don‚Äôt hate you for wanting it too.

James has gone pale and Sirius tries to smile, to shake it off. ‚ÄúBut hey, it‚Äôs not like I needed to snog blokes to be deficient in their eyes anyway right? I mostly ignored all that bullshit.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a blatant lie and he knows that James can tell. That he, more than anyone, knows all the insidious ways that Walburga has managed to stick to Sirius. The ways he hears her voice, and smells her breath, and feels her magic. They‚Äôre so unimaginative, the insults she whispers in his ears on an almost daily basis:

Disappointment.

Worthless.

Embarrassment.

As though he wants to impress her. As though he wants to be something she‚Äôs proud of. Of course, he knows that part of the reason his mother hates him so much is that she had been proud of him. She‚Äôd had a son, first try, provided an heir for the Noble House of Black, did her duty. Sirius was supposed to be her crowning achievement. And he had failed her at every turn.

‚ÄúPadfoot?‚Äù James brings him back to the present, the sun now almost fully in the sky. He meets James‚Äôs eyes‚Äîkind and warm, the polar opposite of his own. ‚ÄúIt really is bullshit, all of it. You know that, right?‚Äù

Sirius struggles to swallow. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says, eyes trailing treacherously in the direction of the Whomping Willow.

‚ÄúRemus told me,‚Äù he finds himself saying suddenly, ‚Äúthat you know about‚Äî‚Äú he grits his teeth, a frustrated noise coming from the back of his throat. They‚Äôre just words. When the fuck did he start being afraid of words? ‚ÄúMe and‚Ä¶him‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI do.‚Äù

Sirius nods, still looking off into the distance. ‚ÄúYou haven‚Äôt said anything about it,‚Äù he goes on eventually.

James lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúWell, to be fair, it kind of got dropped on me in the middle of‚Ä¶everything. But,‚Äù he pauses for a moment, like he‚Äôs trying to be careful about what he says next. ‚ÄúI sort of figured you deserved the chance to tell me yourself‚Äîor, you know, not tell me, if that‚Äôs what you wanted.‚Äù

Fucking James.

‚ÄúYou already knew though,‚Äù he finally tears his eyes away from the scenery and back to the face of his best mate. ‚ÄúRight? That night you said‚Äîyou said it was going to break his heart that it was me, out of all of us. You knew.‚Äù

A complicated expression comes over James‚Äôs face that Sirius can‚Äôt quite work out.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúI knew,‚Äù he shrugs. ‚ÄúI saw the way you looked at him.‚Äù

Sirius lets out a huff, strangling the pain that tries to rear its ugly head inside his chest. ‚ÄúSee, that‚Äôs what bothers me about this whole‚Äîwhole thing with you.‚Äù

James arches his brow so Sirius continues.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt notice. If you‚Äôve been making heart-eyes at someone I haven‚Äôt seen it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou knew I was seeing someone,‚Äù but Sirius only shakes his head.

‚ÄúOnly cause you came back to the common room with your bloody shirt on inside out. Anyone would have noticed that, but I‚Äôm supposed to‚ÄîI‚Äôm supposed to know you better. This big thing happened to you and somehow I missed it.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo be fair, I was trying to hide it.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot the point.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not a mindreader Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm supposed to be!‚Äù and despite the ridiculousness of the statement he says it earnestly. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs us isn‚Äôt it? We see each other.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, James‚Äôs gaze growing fond, and when he speaks Sirius can hear the affection in his voice. It makes him feel guilty. He doesn‚Äôt deserve it.

‚ÄúYou do see me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt see this,‚Äù he throws his hands up in exasperation.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James bites his lip, clearly trying to hold back a laugh, ‚Äúhonestly, Sirius, of all the things you have to worry about, this is not one of them.‚Äù

Sirius lets out an aggravated sigh, scrubbing at his face before he‚Äôs able to look at James again. ‚ÄúYou thought that you couldn‚Äôt tell me,‚Äù he says weakly.

James‚Äôs eyes get a little sad. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt really.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou did.‚Äù

They float there, next to one another, wind gently knocking into them.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs less that I thought that I couldn‚Äôt,‚Äù James says eventually. ‚ÄúAnd more that‚Äîthe stakes just felt so high.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

James blows the hair off his sweaty forehead. They‚Äôll have to go down soon, they‚Äôre cutting it close now and James is still in full Quidditch gear.

‚ÄúI thought you‚Äôd be okay with it, but I also knew that if I was wrong we would be‚Äîthere‚Äôd be no coming back from that.‚Äù James lets out a breath, ‚ÄúAs much as I didn‚Äôt think you‚Äôd react badly, as long as there was a chance‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThere wasn‚Äôt,‚Äù Sirius cuts him off, face stern. ‚ÄúThere was no chance.‚Äù

A sort of sad half-smile pulls at James‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúI mean, with people there‚Äôs always a chance.‚Äù

Sirius narrows his eyes, then reaches across the space between them and smacks James on the back of the head.

‚ÄúOw! What the hell?!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the pessimist,‚Äù Sirius points emphatically at his chest. ‚ÄúMe, my job. You don‚Äôt say shit like that‚Äîyou‚Äôre James bloody Potter‚Äîyou believe in people, all people, even the shitty ones. Example A,‚Äù he gestures to himself.

James grumpily rubs at the back of his head. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not my job to be optimistic all the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh‚Äîyeah, it is. It‚Äôs like, literally your job.‚Äù

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúActually, it‚Äôs very literally literally not my job.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell it certainly isn‚Äôt metaphorically your job.‚Äù

James blinks at him. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell if it‚Äôs the head injury or this conversation that‚Äôs making me feel dizzy.‚Äù

‚ÄúI barely touched you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can feel a bump‚Äîlook‚Äîfeel it.‚Äù James tries to move his broom closer but Sirius instantly backs up.

‚ÄúEw no, you‚Äôre all sweaty and gross.‚Äù

James glares at him. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt mind a minute ago when you were brutalizing me.‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúSo dramatic‚Äîbesides, I was filled with righteous indignation. Now I‚Äôm just wishing you washed your hair a little more. Jesus James, are you taking grooming tips from snivellus?‚Äù

James actually gasps. ‚ÄúYou take that back!‚Äù

Sirius can‚Äôt help it, he bursts out laughing.

‚ÄúI mean it,‚Äù James punches him in the arm, Sirius laughing too hard to dodge it, ‚Äútake it back.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright, alright,‚Äù Sirius hiccups, trying to get himself together. ‚ÄúYour hair is nothing like Snape‚Äôs.‚Äù

‚ÄúDamn right it isn‚Äôt. Stop smiling!‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt help it! You‚Äôre so cute when you get all riled up about your hair.‚Äù

James shakes his head, trying and failing to keep a straight face, the pair of them dissolving into a fit of snickering, no longer sure what they‚Äôre even laughing at.

‚ÄúListen,‚Äù Sirius says when he‚Äôs able to be sincere again. ‚ÄúI just want you to know, you can talk to me about‚Äîabout this. About him.‚Äù

The childish joy fades from James‚Äôs face and he shifts on his broom, looking suddenly uncomfortable.

‚ÄúI told you, he doesn‚Äôt‚Äîdoesn‚Äôt want anyone to know.‚Äù

Sirius nods. ‚ÄúUnderstood, but I can still give excellent advice even if I don‚Äôt know his name.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh really?‚Äù James smirks. ‚ÄúExcellent advice huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, clearly you‚Äôll need guidance from someone more experienced.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you have the kind of experience I need.‚Äù

‚ÄúEh,‚Äù Sirius shrugs. ‚ÄúGirl, boy, what‚Äôs the difference really?‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not inspiring confidence here.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe real question,‚Äù Sirius smiles, leaning forward on his broom, ‚Äúis, is the great James Potter still a virgin?‚Äù

James blushes, the colour deep and quickly spreading up his neck and over his cheeks.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll take that as a yes. Jeez, you two are really taking your time huh? It‚Äôs been like, what? A year?‚Äù

‚ÄúWow, you know what? I don‚Äôt think I have ever wanted to have a conversation less than I want to have this one."

‚ÄúListen, if it‚Äôs your game that needs work, I can help with that.‚Äù

James glares. ‚ÄúMy game is fine, thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, apparently not.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell we can‚Äôt all be Sirius Black.‚Äù

Sirius beams despite the rather sarcastic tone of James‚Äôs voice. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs certainly true, but you can always try.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo modest.‚Äù

‚ÄúOne of my best qualities.‚Äù

James laughs, shaking his head, cheeks still bright red. ‚ÄúListen it‚Äôs‚Äîwe‚ÄîI like where we are. Okay?‚Äù

There‚Äôs something in his voice that gives Sirius pause. It‚Äôs all‚Ä¶warm and gooey. James has a stupid smile on his face too, like maybe he means it, like maybe he‚Äôs happy.

Sirius lets out a low whistle. ‚ÄúWell shit, you really like this guy huh?‚Äù

James blinks, like he hadn‚Äôt realized what a stupid mooning expression he‚Äôd been making. ‚ÄúI‚Äîer‚Äîyeah. A bit.‚Äù

Sirius nods, giving James a small smile. ‚ÄúI hope he deserves it.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe does,‚Äù James doesn‚Äôt hesitate.

I doubt it, Sirius can‚Äôt help but think. Few people deserve James.

‚ÄúBut he doesn‚Äôt want you to talk to your friends about him?‚Äù Sirius asks.

James‚Äôs grimaces. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Ä¶complicated.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt always is.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

But Sirius holds up his hands in surrender. ‚ÄúLook, I don‚Äôt know him, so my opinion basically doesn‚Äôt matter. Just, be careful, okay? You deserve someone who isn‚Äôt afraid to love you back.‚Äù

James sits there for a moment, a thoughtful expression on his face. ‚ÄúHow can you say that to me when you can‚Äôt say it to yourself?‚Äù he asks, not unkindly.

Sirius shrugs. ‚ÄúEasier to care about other people I guess.‚Äù

James looks sad about that but Sirius doesn‚Äôt really feel like getting into it so he quickly adds; ‚ÄúWe should probably head back.‚Äù

James opens his mouth, like he might object, but then closes it again. After a few seconds he sighs. ‚ÄúYeah, probably.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a quiet descent back to the ground.

¬†

They do walk into the Great Hall together, but stop a good ways away from where Peter and Remus are sitting. For a minute the pair of them just stand there staring.

‚ÄúWell," Sirius manages eventually. "I'll see you later I guess,‚Äù he tries to inject as much casual ease into his voice as he can while simultaneously drinking up the sight of Remus. Despite once again sharing a dorm room, he really doesn‚Äôt see him much.

‚ÄúYou could, you know, sit with us?‚Äù though James barely manages to say it without grimacing.

‚ÄúNah mate,‚Äù he ignores the ache in his chest. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre alright, I‚Äôm gonna go sit with Evan‚Äôs,‚Äù he nods to the redhead a few spots away, who is, surprisingly, eating alone this morning.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù James rubs the back of his neck. ‚ÄúRight okay, well, see you I guess.‚Äù James takes a few steps towards their friends before turning back. ‚ÄúIt was‚Äînice, this morning.‚Äù

Sirius smiles. ‚ÄúSecond date you‚Äôre paying. And if you take me somewhere fancy I might even put out.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes, smiling despite himself. ‚ÄúOh, get fucked Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the idea. Keep this up and you might actually lose‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúYES OKAY THANK YOU,‚Äù James is blushing again.

‚ÄúJust trying to help,‚Äù Sirius says in a sing-song voice, biting back a smirk.

James waves off his words, muttering curses at him under his breath as he turns around and keeps going this time. Sirius pretends that he doesn‚Äôt feel it like a hook in his gut, the overwhelming sense of being left behind.

‚ÄúLily, darling, light of my life, how are you?‚Äù he‚Äôs big and showy and obnoxious, sliding into the seat next to her. It‚Äôs easier this way. To pretend to be this other person. To flick the switch.

She looks up from her coursework, a slightly bemused smile on her face. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in a good mood today.‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù he scoffs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm always in a good mood.‚Äù He reaches over and snags a piece of bacon off her plate.

‚ÄúOi‚ÄîSirius! Honestly, there‚Äôs some right there,‚Äù she points to the full platter in the centre of the table.

Sirius shrugs, smiling around his bacon. ‚ÄúJust doesn‚Äôt taste the same when it‚Äôs not stolen.‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes, very purposefully moving her plate further out of his reach.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù he asks, eyes lazily perusing the table in front of him, ‚Äúwhere is everybody?‚Äù

‚ÄúMary and Marlene are napping before class, and Dorcas is doing some kind of extra credit thing with the owls for Magical Creatures.‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúExtra credit? Jesus. And I thought you were the swot.‚Äù

Lily elbows him in the ribs. ‚ÄúYou know, some of us have interests outside of wreaking havoc and shagging every bird in sight.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you?‚Äù Sirius asks, frowning. ‚ÄúHow sad for you all.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomehow we manage.‚Äù

Sirius snorts, picking disinterestedly at the food in front of him. He isn‚Äôt hungry, rarely is these days, but that happens to him sometimes. His body will just‚Ä¶turn off. When he was younger one of his mother‚Äôs favourite punishments was starving him. No dinner. Not until you sit up straight. Not until you apologize to your father. Not until you learn some manners. He often wonders if somewhere along the line it became the way he punishes himself too.

‚ÄúOh bullocks.‚Äù

Sirius and Lily both look down the table to where James is currently standing up in his seat, water spilt all down the front of his white shirt.

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúIdiot,‚Äù he says fondly. ‚ÄúHow long do you reckon it‚Äôll take before he remembers he has a wand and can just charm it dry?‚Äù

After a beat of silence he looks over at Lily, but her gaze is still very much focused on James.

‚ÄúEvans? Yoo-hoo?‚Äù still nothing. That‚Äôs when Sirius notices the slightly glazed look in her eyes.

No, he thinks, no way.

His gaze darts between her and his best mate‚Äîwho is now being dried by Remus.

No way. No way. No way.

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù he snaps his fingers in front of Lily‚Äôs face and she starts, nearly knocking over her pumpkin juice.

‚ÄúShit, sorry,‚Äù flustered she runs a hand through her hair, speckled cheeks turning bright red.

‚ÄúEnjoying the wet t-shirt contest?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? No. What are you even‚Äî? I don‚Äôt even know what you‚Äôre talking about.‚Äù

Sirius watches her grab the wrong end of her fork and enthusiastically attempt to start eating her eggs, like that will somehow convince him that nothing is going on. It‚Äôs really a testament to her commitment that she doesn‚Äôt give up after the first try, instead doing her best to make it look as though she meant to use her utensil handle first.

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù he says, barely holding back a laugh.‚ÄúThe universe really is a bitch huh?‚Äù

He watches Lily grimace, eyes still trained on her eggs.

Sirius sighs, leaning in a little closer and lowering his voice. ‚ÄúThe gig is up Lily, I‚Äôve seen you ogling him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was not ogling!‚Äù she hisses.

Sirius gives her a pointed look, refusing to break until eventually she gives up attempting to eat her eggs with the handle of her fork and looks back at him.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù she says solemnly.

He bites his lip. ‚ÄúLily.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou cannot, under any circumstances, tell anyone.‚Äù

Sirius can‚Äôt hold it back any longer, he laughs, shaking his head. ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôve fallen into an alternate dimension or something. Like in what world does Lily Evans fancy James Potter?‚Äù

‚ÄúWill you keep your voice down!‚Äù she kicks him under the table.

‚ÄúOw‚Äîshit, you have pointy toes Evans,‚Äù he reaches down to rub his leg.

‚ÄúSirius, really, not a soul. Not even as a joke. Especially not Mary‚ÄîMerlin, she‚Äôll never let me hear the end of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you think I will?‚Äù

She lets out a groan. ‚ÄúNo, not really. But at least I can intimidate you.‚Äù

Sirius scoffs. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt‚ÄîJesus, fuck, my poor legs. Are you wearing steel-toed boots or something?‚Äù

He feels the quickly swelling bump on the top of his shin.

‚ÄúNot. A. Word.‚Äù Lily emphasizes each word, stare unwavering.

‚ÄúYes, alright, alright,‚Äù he straightens up, Lily watching him warily. There‚Äôs a brief pause before Sirius can work up he courage to risk another kick. ‚ÄúWhy haven‚Äôt you said anything though, to him I mean?‚Äù he gestures to James with his chin.

Lily exhales, collapsing back in her seat. ‚ÄúGod, I don‚Äôt know. I‚Äôve not really accepted it myself I guess. Plus,‚Äù she grimaces, ‚Äúover the summer he said he liked us better as friends.‚Äù

Sirius takes in a sharp breath. ‚ÄúOuch.‚Äù

Lily nods. ‚ÄúYeah, so, you know‚Ä¶‚Äù she wipes a hand over her face. ‚ÄúAnyway, I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôll pass.‚Äù She looks at him as though expecting reassurance. Funny really, seeing as he‚Äôs been telling himself the same thing for months.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîyeah, probably. These things do don‚Äôt they?‚Äù

Lily nods again, both of their eyes trailing back to the other end of the table, though Sirius suspects not to the same person.

¬†

The hours between classes and meals, which used to be Sirius‚Äôs favourite, have now become a little awkward for him. He finds himself floating around not really sure where he‚Äôs supposed to be. He can‚Äôt hang out with the marauders, which also means that the common room and library are somewhat off limits. He could, and does, hang out with the girls, but honestly, he can‚Äôt help but feel he‚Äôs intruding sometimes. Not unwelcome exactly but just‚Ä¶not wanted.

Which more or less sums up his entire existence at this point. Unwanted.

Sure, Sirius has a great many acquaintances. Some a little more desperate to hang out with him than he‚Äôd like. But he can never relax in those settings, he always has to perform. It gets exhausting. Besides, he doesn‚Äôt like any of them half as much as he likes James, Remus and Peter.

So that‚Äôs how he finds himself wandering around the castle one evening. How he stumbles on his brother alone in one of Hogwarts‚Äôs many courtyards, books and parchment surrounding him, nose practically pressed to the page in front of him.

Under normal circumstances Sirius would ignore him and keep going, but truth be told, he‚Äôs bored. And lonely. And reckless. So instead of continuing down the hallway like he knows he ought to, he finds himself stepping outside.

‚ÄúWell what do we have here?‚Äù he stops in front of his brother, hands in his pockets. It‚Äôs after supper, the sky overcast and gloomy. The summer heat still lingers these days but it‚Äôs starting to break. Sirius can just feel the start of a cold breeze, fall poking its head out.

Regulus looks up, eyes widening for a second before he pulls a blank expression over his face. They‚Äôve always been opposites, him and Reg. His brother hides behind dead eyes, Sirius hides behind a smile.

‚ÄúCan I help you with something?‚Äù Regulus asks flatly.

‚ÄúI doubt it.‚Äù

Regulus continues to stare at him for a few seconds before turning back to his coursework. ‚ÄúAlright then.‚Äù

Regulus is one of those things that Sirius flips the switch on. One of those things it‚Äôs easier not to give a shit about.

I mean, he‚Äôs not a thing.

Technically.

Technically, he‚Äôs a person.

But it‚Äôs easier not to think about him that way‚Äînot to think about him as his actual brother. As the boy who used to crawl into his bed at night and look at Sirius like he could protect him from the monsters. Some days, Sirius thinks the only reason he got into Gryffindor at all is Regulus. It‚Äôs always easier to brave for someone else.

Reg looks up again. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre still here?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure am,‚Äù Sirius grins, an empty expression. He knows Regulus can see it. Probably the only thing they know about each other anymore is how to spot their masks.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

Complicated question that. Why.

‚ÄúSomething‚Äôs been bugging me,‚Äù he goes on casually. ‚ÄúSince that day on the platform.‚Äù

It‚Äôs small‚Äîthe tensing of Regulus‚Äôs jaw‚Äîbut Sirius still catches it.

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù his little brother asks tersely.

‚ÄúWanted to make sure your arm was okay,‚Äù he nods towards the body part in question.

There it is again. His teeth clenching.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

Sirius nods, still smiling. ‚ÄúGood, good, wouldn‚Äôt want you to have to sit out your first Quidditch match or anything.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt reply.

‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶let me see it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSee what, my Quidditch match?‚Äù

If anything, Sirius‚Äôs smile gets wider, more manic, sharpening at the corners.

‚ÄúYour arm Reg. Let me see your arm.‚Äù

His little brother holds his gaze before looking back down. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

None of this feels like anything. None of it matters. It‚Äôs all one big fucking joke.

‚ÄúNah, come on Reggie, show me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like you to leave now.‚Äù

Sirius laughs, it‚Äôs a high tinny noise, sounding foreign even to his own ears. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you would. I mean, listen, I can fight you if you want. But I‚Äôd rather we be civil about this.‚Äù

Regulus looks back up. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have to show you anything.‚Äù

Sirius could leave it alone, he knows he could. But he‚Äôs never been very good at that.

He reaches out for Regulus‚Äôs arm, his brother moving just fast enough to pull out of his reach, spilling his books onto the floor as he gets to his feet.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck is wrong with you?‚Äù Regulus snarls, and Sirius has the sudden and unwelcome flashback to James saying those exact words. Covered in blood. An unconscious Snape thrown over his shoulder.

Flick the switch.

Flick the switch .

Flick the‚Äî

Regulus tries to make a grab for his wand, left behind on the bench‚Äîcareless of him‚Äîbut Sirius blocks his path.

‚ÄúCome on Reg, it‚Äôs just an arm.‚Äù

But Regulus just stands there, breathing heavy, stone faced. Shaking. It‚Äôs hard to see at first, but they‚Äôre closer now, close enough that Sirius can see the tremors in his brother‚Äôs hands. And for some reason that‚Äôs the moment it really hits him. How afraid Regulus is.

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù he‚Äôd been joking. Mostly. He‚Äôd thought he‚Äôd been joking. ‚ÄúYou really did it didn‚Äôt you? You really got it?‚Äù

Regulus barely flinches. ‚ÄúGo away Sirius.‚Äù

He‚Äôd been suspicious‚Äîthe way Regulus went down on the platform, something wasn‚Äôt right. But he hadn‚Äôt really let himself think about what it was he was suspicious of. What it would mean to be right.

Flick the switch.

Flick the switch.

Flick the switch.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe‚Äî‚Äú he laughs coldly. ‚ÄúActually, scratch that, this is just like you isn‚Äôt it? Tell me, did you thank him after? Get down on the ground and kiss his fucking feet?‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck you.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck you right back,‚Äù Sirius is shouting now, voice bouncing off the empty space around them and he can see Regulus‚Äôs eyes dart to the door, making sure they‚Äôre still alone.

‚ÄúShy?‚Äù he asks with a sneer. ‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt be able to keep that thing a secret forever you know.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt reply.

‚ÄúI bet she was so proud of you, her little Reggie. Such a good boy.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck. You.‚Äù

He hates Regulus.

Really.

He does.

He hates that Regulus looks like him.

Hates how much of himself he can see in him.

Hates that he used to need him. That having him made that house bearable.

‚ÄúTell me Reg, how do you manage to stand without a spine?‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes grow dark. ‚ÄúYou have no idea‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI have no idea?‚Äù Sirius is shouting again. ‚ÄúI was there Regulus. I was the one she hated, I was the one who stood in front of you. I let her break me into pieces for years for you. And you never did anything! You can‚Äôt even save your fucking self.‚Äù He‚Äôs shaking, a vaguely nauseous feeling drifting over him. By and large he likes to pretend not to remember anything that happened in Grimmauld Place. As though nothing that went on in that house exists in the outside world. He doesn‚Äôt even talk about it with James really.

‚ÄúIf I could get out,‚Äù Sirius is breathing heavy. ‚ÄúThen what the fuck is your excuse?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you get it?‚Äù Regulus demands, apathy long ago done away with. He‚Äôs all cracked open now. All bleeding eyes and desperate hands and a mouth that used to say:

I‚Äôm scared.

I‚Äôm so scared Sirius.

Flick the switch.

Isn‚Äôt this funny?

Isn‚Äôt all of this such a fucking joke?

‚ÄúYou got out because of me.‚Äù

Sirius blinks, surprised enough to forget how angry he is.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey let you walk away because they had me‚Äîyou really think that if she didn‚Äôt have a spare you would have got off that easy? I paid for your freedom. Me. Your life for mine.‚Äù

Sirius shakes his head, swaying slightly, like he‚Äôs just been hit. ‚ÄúNo‚Äîno that‚Äôs not right. They let me go because of the Potters, it had nothing to do with you.‚Äú

‚ÄúYou really think the Potter‚Äôs could have stopped her? You really think they have the power anymore?‚Äù when Sirius just stares back at him, lost, Regulus laughs. ‚ÄúYou really don‚Äôt have a clue what it‚Äôs like out there do you?‚Äù

He does.

At least, he thought he did.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no walking away for me,‚Äù Regulus goes on coldly. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not letting me out of there, not alive.‚Äù

Everything feels suddenly very far away, like Sirius is watching this conversation unfold from somewhere outside his body.

‚ÄúBetter to die than to let them have you,‚Äù he says. And even though he means it, and he does, he instantly regrets it.

Regulus looks back at him like he‚Äôs just been slapped. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he manages eventually, and Sirius can‚Äôt help but notice the gravel in his voice. ‚ÄúMust be nice not to be the one who has to make that choice.‚Äù

He steps around Sirius who makes no attempt to stop him, frozen to the spot, mind moving simultaneously too fast and too slow. Regulus waves his wand, gathering his books and papers into his arms.

‚ÄúReg‚Äî‚Äú Sirius finally manages to get out.

He‚Äôs surprised when Regulus actually stops, looking back at him over his shoulder.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want this,‚Äù he isn‚Äôt sure what else to say.

Regulus nods, eyes empty. ‚ÄúSure you did. You‚Äôre the hero Sirius. Congratulations.‚Äù

That takes the wind out of him. Sirius staggers backwards, collapsing onto the bench as he watches his little brother disappear inside.

He presses the heels of his hands into his eyes and tries to breathe. He always thought Regulus was going to be the good one. Thought he could shield him from everything that he‚Äôd been through. Everything that had made him selfish and callous and cruel. He remembers so vividly, watching Regulus get up in front of the whole school, watching the hat drop onto his head, barely there for a second before it announced Slytherin to the entirety of the Great Hall. And all he could feel, at twelve years old, was betrayal. That Regulus had chosen them‚Äîafter everything Sirius had done‚Äîhe‚Äôd still chosen them. And he‚Äôd never stopped. From that day on every time he‚Äôd had a choice, Regulus chose them.

I‚Äôm scared.

But maybe that wasn‚Äôt right. Maybe that wasn‚Äôt what happened at all. Maybe Sirius was the one who gave up first. Because he honestly can‚Äôt remember the last time he chose Regulus. The last time he stood in front of him. The last time he told him he loved him.

I‚Äôm so scared Sirius.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù the word is choked when it comes out of him. He brings his head between his knees and tries to breathe. Tries not to throw-up.

He starts going over every interaction he‚Äôs had with Regulus in the last five years. Tries to piece it all together, convince himself that he knows what really happened. But things are blurry. He‚Äôs never been very good at telling apart what‚Äôs real and what‚Äôs not. Spent too much time imagining parts of his life away he suspects.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù

He hears his name but doesn‚Äôt look up. Doesn‚Äôt want to. Whoever it is can fuck off. Can‚Äôt they see he‚Äôs in the middle of a mental breakdown here?

‚ÄúHey‚Äîhey Padfoot are you alright? Pads?‚Äù

It takes a minute for the voice to cut through all the noise in his head. He Blinks up at the uncertain figure in front of him.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù he croaks.

Remus, because it absolutely is Remus, looks thoroughly uncomfortable. ‚ÄúHi.‚Äù

Sirius lets out a choked laugh, leaning back and trying to scrub the emotion out of his face.

‚ÄúHi.‚Äù

That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs all they have to say to one another. Sirius is too much of a mess to process any of this and Remus looks like he‚Äôs desperately fighting the urge to run away.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to do this Remus.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know that,‚Äù Remus snaps defensively. And then, after another short pause; ‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù

Sirius laughs again, though it‚Äôs a bit all over the place, messy and wet and aching. ‚ÄúAlways.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlways,‚Äù Remus repeats, and Sirius can‚Äôt read his tone.

There‚Äôs more awkward silence, Sirius gradually pulling himself back together. It‚Äôs easier with Remus here. Easier to tell what‚Äôs real. Easier to ground himself.

Remus clears his throat. ‚ÄúWell, in that case I guess I‚Äôll‚Ä¶go.‚Äù

Sirius feels his heart jolt, like someone‚Äôs reached into his chest and tried to pull it out. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù is all he manages.

Remus nods stiffly, making it all the way to the edge of the courtyard before he stops. Sirius watches his shoulders rise and fall, watches him pause just a moment too long, always one to think things through. Never just moving‚Äînot like Sirius‚Äîevery step Remus takes is intentional. Makes it mean more.

Sirius arches his brow as the other boy turns around and comes to sit next to him on the bench. A safe distance between them, of course.

After a moment Remus sighs; ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt just walk away.‚Äù

Leave it to Remus to sum up everything Sirius wants to hear in one sentence. Sirius just looks at him. They haven‚Äôt spoken since the day in the broom cupboard and Sirius feels his skin itch with the closeness. With the sound of his voice. Sirius would speak‚Äîit‚Äôs usually his specialty. Except he doesn‚Äôt want to do something‚Äîanything‚Äîthat will make Remus go away again.

Eventually the other boy looks at him. ‚ÄúYou going to tell me what‚Äôs happened?‚Äù

Remus is looking at him and Sirius realizes how spoiled he used to be, when he would get this all the time.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù

He blinks, waking up. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he scrubs at his face. ‚ÄúUm‚Äîfuck, it was‚Äîit was Reg.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he leans forward, elbows on his thighs, hands clasped together. ‚ÄúRemus did I‚Äî‚Äú his voice cuts out. He grits his teeth and tries again. ‚ÄúShould I have stayed?‚Äù

‚ÄúStayed?‚Äù

‚ÄúAt Grimmauld.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

The answer comes so quickly that it makes Sirius laugh, even if it‚Äôs a dried up version of what it usual is.

‚ÄúDid Regulus say that‚Äîthat you should have stayed?‚Äù

Something warm curls in Sirius‚Äôs stomach at the indignation in Remus‚Äôs voice. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo, he said that I‚Äî‚Äú Sirius tries to hold the memory still, but it shakes in his head just like it shook in real life, ‚Äúthat he paid for my freedom.‚Äù

Sirius makes himself look at Remus again, his eyes are fierce, they burn so bright, boring into Sirius. Hard to hold. Impossible to let go of.

‚ÄúI left him there.‚Äù

Remus shakes his head. ‚ÄúYou had to get out Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúI should have taken him with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt exactly planned from what I‚Äôve heard.‚Äù

No. That‚Äôs certainly true. See, you had to agree to get the mark, that really pissed Walburga off. She‚Äôd been assuming that she could just hold him down and carve it into his skin. Then he‚Äôd have no choice. He‚Äôd have to behave. Have to fall inline. But it turns out that‚Äôs not how it works.

‚ÄúI never went back though.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was angry at him.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou had a right to be.‚Äù

Sirius wipes a hand over his face, thinking about the look in Reg‚Äôs eyes‚Äîhe‚Äôd never seen him like that before. At least not since they were kids.

‚ÄúDid I?‚Äù

Remus makes a frustrated sound. ‚ÄúSirius, listen, I‚Äîyou‚Äôve done a lot of shitty things in your life. But leaving that house was not one of them. Saving yourself isn‚Äôt selfish. Sometimes it‚Äôs all you can do. And Regulus,‚Äù there‚Äôs something resigned about his tone. ‚ÄúI think Regulus is very good at rationalizing things to himself, but you never asked him to be a marauder for you. If that‚Äôs the role he wants to play than that‚Äôs on him.‚Äù

The night Sirius left, he‚Äôd been passed out. He was thrown around and sliced open and crucio-ed and eventually, he passed out. Regulus had been there for all of it. He always was. Pale and wide-eyed. He hadn‚Äôt told them to stop, hadn‚Äôt come forward when Sirius was too weak to get back up. Sirius hadn‚Äôt expected him to, but somehow it still hurt when he was proved right.

He regained consciousness alone on the dinning room table. There were voices in the kitchen. He hadn‚Äôt paused to think, to come up with a plan. He‚Äôd grabbed his wand and left. Bare feet and all.

He hadn‚Äôt thought about Regulus as he cut across the lawn, as he‚Äôd hobbled down the pavement. Maybe he should have. He doesn‚Äôt know.

Eventually Sirius sighs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so fucking hard for me to talk to him,‚Äù he says finally, sitting back. ‚ÄúEvery time I tell myself I‚Äôm going to do it different. That I‚Äôm going to handle things better, but then he opens his mouth and I just feel all this‚Ä¶anger. It‚Äôs like I‚Ä¶‚Äù he struggles to sort out his thoughts. Eventually he laughs, rubbing his eyes. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like I love him so much I hate him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean,‚Äù Remus says slowly, ‚Äúhe is your little brother.‚Äù

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúYeah, I guess. I just wish that‚ÄîI just wish that life didn‚Äôt feel so messy, you know? I always end up losing the thing that matters. I always get caught up in everything else.‚Äù

After a while Remus nods. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

They‚Äôre just watching one another again. The world disappears with Remus. He always takes up so much space. In Sirius‚Äôs head. His chest.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been avoiding me,‚Äù the other boy says eventually.

Neither of them look away.

Sirius shrugs. ‚ÄúI thought that‚Äôs what you wanted?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù Remus pulls at the sleeves of his jumper. ‚ÄúIt is what I want.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

But Remus‚Äôs face is all screwed-up. Like he isn‚Äôt happy with that. Like it‚Äôs not quite right. Eventually he lets out a big breath, tearing his eyes away from Sirius and sinking down low, legs sprawling out in front of him, head resting on the back of the bench.

‚ÄúSo do we just do this forever now? Just‚Ä¶orbit around each other?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs kind of up to you.‚Äù

An irritated noise comes out of Remus‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs bullshit. This isn‚Äôt my fault. I didn‚Äôt do it. I don‚Äôt know why I have to be the one to figure out how to fix it.‚Äù

Sirius feels his chest squeeze. ‚ÄúBut you want to?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Remus turns his head towards him, eyes big and bright. Those eyes will save me, Sirius thinks, those eyes will carry me home.

He coughs, clearing his throat. ‚ÄúYou want to fix this? Us?‚Äù

Remus looks surprised, like he‚Äôs only just realizing what he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú he licks his lips. ‚ÄúI mean, it‚Äôs just too hard.‚Äù

‚ÄúFixing it?‚Äù

Remus laughs dryly, pinching the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúNo‚Äîbeing‚Ä¶angry at each other. I feel like I can‚Äôt breathe most of the time.‚Äù

There are so many things Sirius wants to say. But then, there always are when it comes to Remus.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù is what he goes with in the end, ‚Äúme too.‚Äù

Remus drops his hand, looking about as exhausted at Sirius feels.

‚ÄúWhat do you need Moony?‚Äù he‚Äôs practically whispering. ‚ÄúJust tell me what you need me to do.‚Äù

They‚Äôre so close‚Äîso close to maybe, possibly, getting passed this. Sirius can feel it. For the first time in months no one‚Äôs crying or yelling. They‚Äôre not fighting. He just needs Remus to tell him how to pull them all the way over, because he‚Äôll do it. He‚Äôll do anything.

Remus is watching him, a careful look in his eyes. Approach with caution, that‚Äôs what those eyes say.

‚ÄúWhy did you kiss me Sirius?‚Äù he‚Äôs whispering now too.

It feels as though someone‚Äôs just slammed Sirius into a wall. His whole body tenses, pulse skyrocketing. He tries not to, but he can‚Äôt help it‚Äîhis eyes quickly run the boundaries of the courtyard, making sure they‚Äôre still alone. He knows Remus sees. It‚Äôs clear in the disappointment that starts clouding his face.

You deserve someone who isn‚Äôt afraid to love you back.

He‚Äôd said that.

He‚Äôd meant it too.

Looking at Remus, glowing in the dim light of the setting sun, all he can think is; beautiful. Remus is always beautiful. Sirius was eleven the first time he thought it. It scared the shit out of him, honestly. The two of them had been lying on Remus‚Äôs bed, windows open, shirt sleeves half-rolled up, ties torn off. He‚Äôd looked over at Remus and before he could help himself he‚Äôd just thought: beautiful.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù

He swallows back the ache that crawls up his throat.

He told James that he hadn‚Äôt listened to his family‚Äôs bullshit. But he‚Äôs a liar.

Among other things.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù the same answer he‚Äôs been giving Remus for almost a year. Sirius‚Äôs voice sounds bruised. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why I did it.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of stillness and then Remus sighs, pulling himself upright. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus‚Äî‚Äú

But the other boy cuts him off with the wave of his hand. Getting back to his feet and straightening out his robes.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine Sirius. I don‚Äôt know what I was expecting.‚Äù

Sirius flinches.

‚ÄúLook, you can‚Äîum,‚Äù he runs a hand through his blond hair, making it stick out in little puffs, ‚Äúyou can sit with us.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes widen. ‚ÄúIn the Great Hall?‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd classes,‚Äù Remus shrugs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine, okay? I‚Äôm tired of trying to pretend I don‚Äôt see you,‚Äù he actually smiles a little then, though it‚Äôs a sad thing. ‚ÄúIt never works anyway.‚Äù

Sirius swallows. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah Pads, I‚Äôm sure.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know what to say to that, something in his chest starting to swell, to press against his ribs at the idea of being let back in. Even slowly. Even just sitting next to him again.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù his voice sounds rougher than he‚Äôs expecting.

Remus just nods. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm heading back to the common room, you coming?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think I‚Äî‚Äú he swallows. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm gonna stay out here for a bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Sirius can see the flash of concern in Remus‚Äôs eyes but he doesn‚Äôt say anything.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù for the second time Remus stops at the edge of the courtyard, turning back to him. ‚ÄúAre we‚Äîare we okay now?‚Äù

Something sad flutters across Remus‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says simply, an ice pick to Sirius‚Äôs heart. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just not fighting.‚Äù

And then he‚Äôs gone.

Chapter End Notes

Hey-o!

I really was going to end this chapter with Remus forgiving Sirius 100% but apparently I just hate happiness. Still, we're getting there. The Prank‚Ñ¢ is just so shitty.

Also, if you guys have songs for these characters let me know cause I am currently obsessed with the music people associated with this ship, like I do already have a 5hr long playlist but it could always be longer, y'know?

Y'all are the best, thanks so much for reading!

Chapter 22

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Sometimes, when Regulus is in a good mood, when he feels safe, he‚Äôll let James touch him. Not in a sex way‚Äîthough there is a bit of that too, something in the space between them that cracks and sparks and burns. But these touches are different, they‚Äôre soft and exploratory and caring. Like James can pull all of Regulus‚Äôs wounds closed, like he can rub away his scars. Like he can teach him how to love his skin. He can tell that he doesn‚Äôt, that Regulus and his body have a difficult relationship.

He runs his hands gently through his hair, along the outline of his jaw, his lower lip, he counts the ribs in his chest and circles every one of his knuckles. Worshipping him. Regulus closes his eyes and breathes in deep, slowly letting himself relax. Taking down his walls piece by piece until it‚Äôs just him‚Äînaked even while fully clothed.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre obsessed,‚Äù Regulus‚Äôs voice is low, rough from lack of use. James isn‚Äôt sure how long they‚Äôve been lying here like this. A while, probably.

‚ÄúWith you? Absolutely.‚Äù

He sees the corner of Regulus‚Äôs mouth twitch upwards and feels satisfaction purr in his chest before he leans forward and presses a quick kiss to his lips. He likes being able to do that, casually, likes how natural it feels. He‚Äôs currently drawing small circles on the inside of Regulus‚Äôs wrist.

‚ÄúWe should probably go back soon.‚Äù

James makes a noise of protest, something whiny at the back at his throat that makes Regulus laugh, blinking his eyes open and turning to James. All soft and sleepy. This is James‚Äôs favourite Regulus. I mean, he likes them all, but this one especially.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such a baby, you know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been mentioned.‚Äù He draws his finger slowly up Regulus‚Äôs arm making the other boy shiver, eyes fluttering closed again.

‚ÄúCheating,‚Äù Regulus sighs.

When he has good days like this, and this is an exceptionally good day, James realizes just how sensitive Regulus is. The lighter the touch the more it seems to take him apart, untangling all those knots that keep him together.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt cheat if there are no rules.‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúThere are rules. The rules are don‚Äôt get caught.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one can find us here.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt put it past Sirius, especially if you don‚Äôt come back for the second night this week.‚Äù

James‚Äôs hand stills, and even though he tries to recover‚Äîmoving it again a second later‚ÄîRegulus notices.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt look at his face, instead he focuses on where his finger is currently moving along the skin just under Regulus‚Äôs collar.

‚ÄúSomething you want to tell me?‚Äù he can already hear the tension returning to Regulus‚Äôs voice.

He sighs, pausing for a moment before letting his hand drop down onto the mattress. ‚ÄúOnly if you promise not to freak out.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes narrow. ‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt sound promising.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really not a big deal.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames, please tell me what‚Äôs going on and what it has to do with my brother?‚Äù

‚ÄúRight, sorry,‚Äù he says, frowning when Regulus sits up, pulling away from him. ‚ÄúSo‚Äîer‚ÄîSirius might know that I‚Äôm seeing someone.‚Äù

He can feel the stillness rock through Regulus, like every muscle in his body has just clenched.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt know who,‚Äù James goes on quickly, ‚Äújust knows that it‚Äôs some boy.‚Äù

‚ÄúBoy,‚Äù Regulus repeats. ‚ÄúHe knows you‚Äôre seeing a boy?‚Äù There‚Äôs an edge of panic to Regulus‚Äôs voice and James can see him scrambling to pull his walls back up again.

‚ÄúReg, it‚Äôs okay,‚Äù James sits up now too. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt care, honestly.‚Äù

This does nothing to ease the tension out of Regulus‚Äôs expression. He doesn‚Äôt respond, just keeps looking at James like he can‚Äôt believe he could be so stupid.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre angry at me?‚Äù James asks eventually, feeling himself deflate. He really doesn‚Äôt want to fight about this.

The tense silence continues, but James can see Regulus chewing on the inside of his cheek, fighting with himself.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not thrilled,‚Äù Regulus manages eventually, which honestly, is a tamer response than James was expecting.

‚ÄúReally Reg,‚Äù he goes on as earnestly as he can manage. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt give him any details, I just‚ÄîI needed to tell him something if I was going to keep sneaking off.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd it couldn‚Äôt have been something a little further from the truth?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot if he was going to believe it.‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head, letting out a heavy sigh. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre rubbish at keeping secrets James Potter.‚Äù But there‚Äôs the hint of fondness there that gives James hope.

‚ÄúI swear he has no idea it‚Äôs you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know he doesn‚Äôt, you wouldn‚Äôt be here if he did.‚Äù

James scrunches up his face. ‚ÄúSirius doesn‚Äôt decide who I can and can‚Äôt see.‚Äù

Regulus looks at him skeptically but before James can push the matter any further he goes on; ‚ÄúHe was okay with it?‚Äù there‚Äôs a sudden nervousness in his voice that takes James by surprise.

‚ÄúOkay with it?‚Äù James repeats, his brain needing a minute to catch up. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîwith me seeing a bloke you mean?‚Äù

Regulus nods, and James wonders how much of his life Regulus has spent worrying about Sirius‚Äôs reaction to this part of him. It makes his chest ache.

‚ÄúVery okay with it, yeah, actually he was‚Äî‚Äù James laughs a little, rubbing at the back of his neck. ‚ÄúHe was asking me about you the other day.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was asking about me?‚Äù James can‚Äôt figure out if Regulus sounds surprised or terrified.

‚ÄúWell, he didn‚Äôt know it was you specifically, but, he was asking about the boy I‚Äôm seeing, yeah.‚Äù

Regulus sits with that, mind turning behind his eyes. His expression is more serious than James would like it‚Äîalmost sad. ‚ÄúWhat did he ask?‚Äù

James feels his face heating up. ‚ÄúEr‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know, just‚Ä¶like‚Ä¶stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúStuff?‚Äù there‚Äôs a beat of silence before Regulus‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúOh my God, you were talking to my brother about sex.‚Äù And then; ‚ÄúSex with ME. Oh my God.‚Äù Regulus‚Äôs hands go to his face, shielding it from view. It‚Äôs honestly so adorable that for a moment James isn‚Äôt sure it‚Äôs actually happening.

‚ÄúHave a little faith in me Reg,‚Äù he says, biting back a smile. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt tell him anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe you,‚Äù Regulus says, words muffled.

James can‚Äôt help but laugh. ‚ÄúI swear, I didn‚Äôt,‚Äù he puts his hands up even though Regulus can‚Äôt see him. ‚ÄúI just told him that we haven‚Äôt, you know, gone all the way. But that I like what we‚Äôve been doin‚Äî‚Äú

James does not get to finish that sentence because at that moment he has a pillow thrown in his face.

‚ÄúI hate this,‚Äù Regulus says, but he says it while tackling James onto the bed, so it takes some of the sting out of it.

James laughs again, breathless as Regulus hovers above him, pinning his shoulders down.

‚ÄúNo talking to my brother about sex,‚Äù Regulus says sternly.

‚ÄúHave you met Sirius?‚Äù

He rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúNo talking to my brother about sex with ME.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut he doesn‚Äôt know it‚Äôs you,‚Äù James teases. ‚ÄúSo it doesn‚Äôt count.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt counts,‚Äù Regulus gives him a flat look that slowly grows more serious. ‚ÄúYou really shouldn‚Äôt be talking to him about me at all, okay? It‚Äôs not‚Äîhe‚Äôll figure it out.‚Äù

James can feel the tension returning to Regulus‚Äôs body‚Äîhonestly, it‚Äôs a testament to how far they‚Äôve come that this has gone as well as it has.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to let that happen okay? Not as long as you don‚Äôt want it to,‚Äù he brings his hand up to hold Regulus‚Äôs face, thumb stroking his cheek. ‚ÄúI told him he can‚Äôt know, he respects that.‚Äù

Regulus scoffs. ‚ÄúI promise you he doesn‚Äôt. So just‚Ä¶don‚Äôt tempt fate, okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James lifts himself up just enough to reach Regulus‚Äôs mouth, kissing it quickly before collapsing back down.

‚ÄúHonestly,‚Äù Regulus mutters, shaking his head, ‚Äúfirst Lupin now this.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah I‚Äîwait, I‚Äôm sorry, what? How do you know about Remus?‚Äù

Regulus shrugs, like it‚Äôs the most casual thing in the world. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had words.‚Äù

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúThat sounds ominous.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was honestly very civilized for the most part.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh was it?‚Äù he laughs. ‚ÄúWas there tea and scones? Did you discuss the weather? Your mother‚Äôs new hat?‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre ridiculous.‚Äù

‚ÄúSays the guy who did jello shots off a silver platter.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was one time!‚Äù

James is laughing again and somehow they end up wrestling, pushing and pulling on one another, rolling around in the gigantic bed. This is it, James thinks as Regulus laughs into the crook of his neck. This is all I want.

‚ÄúOkay, okay‚Äîenough,‚Äù Reg is breathless as they part, lying next to one another, Regulus‚Äôs hair an absolute mess. It makes James smile.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in a good mood today,‚Äù he says, watching Regulus‚Äôs eyes flicker.

Eventually the younger boy rolls towards him. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a good day.‚Äù

And part of James wants desperately to know why, and how he can make all of Regulus‚Äôs days good, because he‚Äôll do it. Whatever he needs. But mostly he knows that‚Äôs not how it works. That it‚Äôs not a fair thing to ask someone‚Äîfor the answers to themselves. It sounds too much like trying to fix something. He never wants to make Regulus feel like he‚Äôs broken.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad,‚Äù James says eventually voice quiet.

They stay like that, silently for a minute, before James starts to smile again.

‚ÄúYou ready for the party?‚Äù

Regulus groans, rolling onto his back. ‚ÄúMerlin, don‚Äôt remind me, Evan‚Äôs been obsessing over it for weeks.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a seventh year Slytherin‚ÄîCorban Yaxley‚Äîwho discovered in his third year at Hogwarts that he and the Bloody Baron have the same birthday. He therefore declared it a house wide holiday. So every year the entirety of Slytherin house celebrates, the bold kids skiving off classes, the bolder kids going to class already drunk. As much as James dislikes Slytherin, he does have to hand it to Yaxley, he knows how to get people to party. And James can always appreciate a little mindless chaos.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs making some kind of special punch,‚Äù Regulus goes on, wrinkling his nose. ‚ÄúI can only imagine what‚Äôs going to be in that.‚Äù

James smiles, ‚ÄúYou gonna get wasted and then sneak up to the astronomy tower and kiss me?‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes, though the tops of his cheeks do turn a shade of pink that warms James‚Äôs chest. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, are you going to have a panic attack when I do?‚Äù

James shrugs. ‚ÄúMight. Depends on how good the kiss is.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll my kisses are excellent. I promise you quality will not be an issue.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh yeah?‚Äù James‚Äôs eyes are bright, staring intently at Regulus as he inches closer. ‚ÄúProve it.‚Äù

There‚Äôs no reason for Regulus‚Äôs chest to hitch, no reason for him to look at James the way he does then‚Äîlike they haven‚Äôt already kissed for hours. But he does, rolling back onto his side, hand reaching out so he can run a knuckle down the side of James‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúIf you insist,‚Äù Regulus whispers, breath warm. ‚ÄúBut you have to promise me you‚Äôll remember to breathe.‚Äù

James smiles, ‚ÄúPromise.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs hand slides to the back of James‚Äôs head, pulling him forward, taking his mouth. And James lets him. Again. And again.

This is it.

This is all I want.

¬†

James sits against the headboard of his bed, tossing a Snitch up and down. He really should keep track of these things, eventually Hooch is going to realize she‚Äôs missing a dozen of them. Maybe more honestly. He‚Äôs technically supposed to be doing transfiguration homework but he‚Äôs in too good a mood to focus on school. He‚Äôs been riding the high of the night before all day. It had just been so‚Ä¶good. So warm and soft and happy. He smiles just thinking about it, hand curling around the cold metal in his palm, feeling the vibration of the Snitch‚Äôs wings.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd you get for question six James?‚Äù Remus is on the floor, notes and textbooks spread around him.

‚ÄúUh‚Ä¶‚Äù James looks down at his blank parchment.

‚ÄúI got Acromantula Venom,‚Äù Peter says from his own bed. He has one quill behind his ear and another in his hand. There are a plethora of parchment and books surrounding him too, though in a somewhat less organized fashion. Both Remus and James turn to look at him.

‚ÄúYou got‚Ä¶Acromantula Venom‚Ä¶for number six?‚Äù Remus asks slowly, as though certain he‚Äôs misheard.

‚ÄúYeah, is that wrong?‚Äù

James can‚Äôt help the laugh that comes out of his mouth but Remus, if anything, just looks concerned.

‚ÄúYou got Acromantula Venom‚Äîa very rare potions ingredient‚Äîfor the question: what are the limits of transfiguration?‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôm getting the sense that that is definitely not the answer?‚Äù Peter‚Äôs eyes bounce from Remus to James, the later is practically in hysterics at this point.

‚ÄúHow did you even‚Äî‚Äú

But at that moment the door to their room is thrown open and Sirius waltzes in, throwing his book bag on the ground and staring at the rest of them with a look in his eyes that can only mean trouble.

‚ÄúLads,‚Äù he stands in front of the window, which really adds to the drama of the situation, hands on his hips, long hair let loose. ‚ÄúI have just created the best charm of all time and I know exactly what to do with it.‚Äù

James lets the Snitch in his hand fly off as he slides closer to the edge of his bed. ‚ÄúGo on then?‚Äù he asks, intrigued.

‚ÄúI thought we were doing transfiguration homework,‚Äù Remus mutters bitterly, looking very determinedly at his textbooks and not at Sirius.

‚ÄúThis is better,‚Äù Sirius says, clearly excited enough to ignore the obvious tension between him and Remus. ‚ÄúPete, get off your bed.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Peter asks surprised.

‚ÄúOff. You. Now.‚Äù

Peter reluctantly climbs off his bed and Sirius immediately whips out his wand, pointing it at the aforementioned piece of furniture and making three swift slashes.

‚ÄúSternius Rem Tactus.‚Äù

All of them stare, waiting for something to happen. Nothing does.

‚ÄúEr,‚Äù James rubs the back of his neck. ‚ÄúNever thought I‚Äôd say this, but I think transfiguration homework might actually be better than this.‚Äù

Remus laughs, but Sirius doesn‚Äôt look the least bit deterred.

‚ÄúGo on Pete, back on the bed, hop to it.‚Äù

Peter narrows his eyes skeptically. ‚ÄúDo I look like an idiot?‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúDo you want me to answer that?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh fuck you.‚Äù

‚ÄúBuy me dinner first and then we‚Äôll talk.‚Äù

Peter proceeds to go an alarming shade of magenta, quickly looking away from Sirius.

‚ÄúLeave him alone Sirius,‚Äù Remus says flatly, still not looking up from his coursework. Sirius turns to him, a mildly stung expression on his face. Truth be told, James has no idea what‚Äôs going on with the two of them anymore. Remus has started to be okay with sharing the same space as Sirius, but they still don‚Äôt really‚Ä¶talk much. Not to each other and not to James and Peter. All James can get out of them is ‚Äúwe‚Äôre fine‚Äù ‚Äúwe‚Äôre not fighting anymore‚Äù which are both, clearly, lies.

Eventually Sirius tears his eyes away from Remus and back to Peter, who has inched his way carefully closer to his bed.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs it gonna do?‚Äù Pete asks.

‚ÄúWhat makes you think it‚Äôs going to do anything?‚Äù

‚ÄúSix years of friendship.‚Äù

That brings a grin to Sirius‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nothing bad, I promise.‚Äù

Peter does not look at all convinced. ‚ÄúYou get on it then.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeter, what did I just tell you about buying me dinner first?‚Äù

Peter rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúListen, there is no way in hell that I‚Äôm‚Äî‚Äú

Tired of the bickering, James reaches over and gives Peter a shove, sending him stumbling into his bed.
