A gust of dust blows out towards Sirius after what definitely sounds like an ‚Äúachoo‚Äù before the mattress falls back down into place.

Sirius grins, wiping the dust off his robes and fixing his hair. ‚ÄúBrilliant, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat the hell was that?‚Äù Peter demands, getting back to his feet.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm with Pete,‚Äù James says, swinging himself off his own bed and stepping closer to get a better look.

‚ÄúYou modified the Sternius charm,‚Äù Remus says, drawing all of their attention to him, he‚Äôs still sitting on the floor, parchments slightly ruffled from the mattress. He blinks, before looking up at Sirius, ‚Äúto work on inanimate objects?‚Äù

Sirius nods, grin growing slightly sheepish. ‚ÄúAnd to respond to touch instead of just going off continuously.‚Äù

Remus looks a little dazed. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Äîthat kind of spell modification is‚Äîis extremely advanced.‚Äù

Sirius just shrugs. ‚ÄúI was bored.‚Äù

If it weren‚Äôt for the fact that Remus was already on the floor James would be worried he was about to swoon.

‚ÄúYou were bored,‚Äù Remus says distantly, like he can‚Äôt quite believe it, the pair of them still staring at one another. It‚Äôs the longest eye contact James has seen them make in ages.

‚ÄúSorry to interrupt,‚Äù he says, causing them both to start. ‚ÄúBut what‚Äôs the Sternius charm?‚Äù

‚ÄúSneezing charm,‚Äù Sirius says, mischief returning to his eyes. ‚ÄúUsed in duels to distract your opponent, I modified it to work on objects and then to respond to touch.‚Äù

James smiles back, ‚Äúwicked.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, but that‚Äôs not the wickedest part. Do you know what tonight is Prongs?‚Äù

‚ÄúDid I forget your birthday again?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve never forgotten my birthday.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally? Cheers to me then.‚Äù

Sirius bites his lower lip, trying to stay in character. ‚ÄúUse that deer brain of yours, it‚Äôll come to you.‚Äù

And it does.

‚ÄúBloody Baron‚Äôs party,‚Äù he‚Äôs starting to smile now too.

‚ÄúI already hate where this is going,‚Äù Remus says flatly, but Sirius and James only have eyes for each other.

‚ÄúWe wait until they‚Äôre all smashed and then we sneak in and‚Äî‚Äú

Sirius is interrupted by the sound of Peter‚Äôs bed sneezing again.

‚ÄúPete, what the hell?‚Äù James asks, trying not to laugh as he helps his friend back up off the floor.

‚ÄúI thought it might have warn off,‚Äù he says sulkily, rubbing his shoulder.

‚ÄúOh no, it‚Äôs got a lifespan of at least twelve hours,‚Äù Sirius says, as though it ought to have been obvious.

‚ÄúTwelve hours!‚Äù Peter repeats outraged. ‚ÄúJesus, what‚Äôs the counter-charm?‚Äù

Sirius shrugs. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt have one. Didn‚Äôt have time.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou cursed my bed without‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSh, sh, sh,‚Äù Sirius holds out his hand, cooing at him like he‚Äôs an overexcited toddler. ‚ÄúNot important right now. What is important, is that you lot learn the charm so that we can sneak into the Slytherin dormitories and curse all their beds while they‚Äôre getting sloshed.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes!‚Äù James says, at the same time that Remus says, ‚ÄúAbsolutely not.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh come on Remus,‚Äù James turns to him pleadingly. ‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt pulled anything in ages.‚Äù

Remus looks back at him, unmoved. ‚ÄúIf you wanna go act like idiots be my guest, I‚Äôm not going to stop you. I‚Äôm just saying, I‚Äôm not interested.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be fun,‚Äù James pushes, feeling suddenly desperate to have the four of them back together again, acting like they always have.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs juvenile.‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly!‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes, picking up his quill and going back to his transfiguration homework. James looks to Sirius for help, usually convincing Remus to do stupid things is his forte. But, of course, he realizes as their eyes meet that Sirius can‚Äôt be that person anymore.

Sighing, James stares down at Remus, trying to decide on the best course of action. Eventually he walks over and proceeds to get down on the floor and physically lie across Remus‚Äôs notes.

‚ÄúUgh‚ÄîJames!‚Äù

He looks up at his friend, brow arched. ‚ÄúCome on Moons, come be an idiot with us.‚Äù

He sees a flicker in Remus‚Äôs armour, the first crack. He really is a lot like Regulus sometimes, even more than Sirius.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just going to lie here until you say yes, so if you don‚Äôt want McGonagall to tear into you for not getting the homework done, it‚Äôs really in your best interest to agree.‚Äù

Remus snorts. ‚ÄúPlease, I‚Äôd tell her what happened and she‚Äôd give me a biscuit and a pat on the back.‚Äù

‚ÄúTeacher‚Äôs pet.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvery other teacher is obsessed with you, let me have McGonagall.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou two really do have a weird connection.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs called exasperation.‚Äù

James smiles and, to his delight, Remus smiles back. He reaches out and pokes Remus‚Äôs knee. ‚ÄúPwetty Pwease?‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYes, fine, alright. But only because you look so pathetic.‚Äù

James‚Äôs smile widens. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my favourite, I ever tell you that?‚Äù

‚ÄúOi! What about me?‚Äù Sirius cuts back in and James turns to him as he pulls himself off the floor.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my favourite too.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt have more than one favourite Prongs, then you‚Äôre just being greedy.‚Äù

‚ÄúWatch me,‚Äù James scoffs, dusting himself off. ‚ÄúSo, what‚Äôs the plan?‚Äù

¬†

They have to practice the spell for almost two hours before they‚Äôre all able to get it right. They don‚Äôt try it on anymore beds‚Äîone of them being bed-less is more than enough‚Äîinstead they practice on the bar of soap in the bathroom, on one of James‚Äôs trainers, on a sock. Eventually most of the items in their room seem to have developed allergies.

‚ÄúI still can‚Äôt believe you charmed my bloody bed,‚Äù Peter grumbles every few minutes, earning him a series of increasingly exasperated apologies from Sirius.

They decide it makes most sense to split up: Remus and James will take the invisibility cloak and charm the beds in the boys‚Äô rooms, while Peter, as a rat, and Sirius, using a Disillusionment Charm, will take the girls‚Äô. They‚Äôre focusing on the fifth, sixth, and seventh years. For time purposes mostly. Though Remus also staunchly refuses to prank eleven year olds. Something about scarring them for life.

‚ÄúYou have the password for the common room?‚Äù James asks.

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúI do. Turns out Madelyn Avery thinks I‚Äôm very charming.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh. And the girl‚Äôs dorm? How‚Äôre you gonna get up there?‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúI told you, Madelyn Avery thinks I‚Äôm very charming.‚Äù

Remus clears his throat and the smug look on Sirius‚Äôs face quickly disappears.

¬†

James is honestly buzzing. The four of them, working together, plotting against Slytherin, it feels right. Falling back into something well-known and comfortable. And sure, it‚Äôs not exactly the same‚ÄîRemus and Sirius are still a bit‚Ä¶off with one another, but it‚Äôs close. It was hard, last year, this summer, but things are getting better. Things are good, even.

‚ÄúYou warn Regulus about this?‚Äù Remus whispers as they make their way towards the Slytherin common room. Sirius and Peter just up ahead, every once and a while, if James focuses on the right spot, he can see the outline of Sirius‚Äôs shoulder or hand, spelled to perfectly blend with his surroundings.

‚ÄúLike I would ever compromise the integrity of a prank like that. Honestly Remus, I‚Äôm insulted you would even ask.‚Äù

Remus snorts. ‚ÄúGood to know some things never change.‚Äù James wants to ask him what things have changed but doesn‚Äôt get the chance; ‚ÄúHe going to be mad about this?‚Äù

James considers it for a moment. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, he has a better sense of humour than you‚Äôd think.‚Äù

‚ÄúConsidering I don‚Äôt think he has any sense of humour, I‚Äôm sure that‚Äôs true.‚Äù

James looks over at Remus and then straight ahead again. He still forgets sometimes, how little people know Regulus.

They can already hear the music coming from the Slytherin common room and James wonders how the hell they get away with this without a silencing charm.

‚ÄúDo you think Slughorn ever enforces any rules?‚Äù Remus asks, as if reading James‚Äôs mind. ‚ÄúOr is he too busy kissing each and every one of their asses?‚Äù

James snickers, the entrance to the common room coming into view. He‚Äôs always found the Slytherin entrance to be the most boring‚Äîjust a stretch of blank wall, leading to a passage.

‚ÄúReady lads?‚Äù Sirius asks, voice seemingly coming out of nowhere.

It‚Äôs midnight, so they‚Äôre hoping that everyone inside is already too drunk or too busy to notice anything strange, like self opening doors for example.

‚ÄúHell yeah we are,‚Äù James says, and doesn‚Äôt need to see Sirius‚Äôs face to know that he‚Äôs grinning.

‚ÄúRemember the plan, get in, fuck their shit up, get out, meet back at our room. Got it?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a complicated plan but somehow I think we‚Äôll manage to remember it,‚Äù Remus says dryly.

Sirius laughs. ‚ÄúAh, that‚Äôs what I love about you Moony, so bloody clever.‚Äù

James is glad that Sirius can‚Äôt see the way that makes Remus go stiff.

‚ÄúAlrighty then,‚Äù there‚Äôs the sound of shuffling and then; ‚ÄúJormungand,‚Äù Sirius whispers. And the wall opens.

¬†

There are very clear differences between Gryffindor and Slytherin parties, the first being the lighting. Currently, the whole Slytherin common room is being lit only by the jellyfish someone has charmed to come to the windows, each of them glowing a different colour. James wonders if that‚Äôs painful for them‚Äîif they can feel it? Can jellyfish feel things? There‚Äôs just something about turning living things into inanimate objects that gives him the creeps.

Slytherin also has crap taste in music. Right now they‚Äôre playing something with a heavy bass, instrumental but not classical. James doesn‚Äôt recognize it but it‚Äôs making his ears bleed.

‚ÄúJesus,‚Äù he mutters as he tries to see his way through a crowd of people all wearing unhelpfully dark clothing, in an already unhelpfully dark room, ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the dress code for this thing? Coffin casual?‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty sure this is how they always dress,‚Äù Remus says, sounding no more impressed.

James isn‚Äôt really looking for Regulus‚Äîtonight is about the marauders‚Äîbesides, he doesn‚Äôt need to get distracted. But somehow, through the chaos and darkness, he finds him. He feels it in his whole body when he sees him, a tingling sensation running along his bones. James is about ready to choke on his disparaging comments about the fashion at this party because shit, funeral chic looks good on Reg.

He‚Äôs sitting in the corner, surrounded by people who seem to be talking around him more than to him and yet he‚Äôs definitely at the centre. His perfect posture has gone out the window, he‚Äôs slouched down but in a confident‚ÄîI don‚Äôt give a fuck about you‚Äîkind of way, drink held lazily in his hand, black button up undone to an obscene degree.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù the word punches out of James before he can control himself.

Remus looks over at him. ‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? Yeah‚Äîstubbed my toe.‚Äù

Remus raises his brow before looking down at the clear ground, completely free of toe stubbing objects.

‚ÄúOh look, there are the dorm rooms,‚Äù James says quickly, nudging Remus in their direction and very purposefully not looking back at Regulus.

They stumble their way up a flight of stairs and then down a long dark hallway, doing their best to avoid the shadowy clusters of people clinging to the corners and walls. Luckily for them, the door to the fifth year dorm is open so they don‚Äôt need to worry about surprising anyone.

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù Remus mutters, after they make sure the room is empty. ‚ÄúIs there anywhere in this place that doesn‚Äôt feel like an evil lair?‚Äù

James snorts, casting a quick Colloportus on the door. Remus turns to him, brow raised.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs going to be suspicious if they come up here and find their door locked?‚Äù

James shrugs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather they be suspicious than walk right in and find us. This way we get under the cloak first and they just think the door was jammed.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs actually‚Ä¶pretty smart.‚Äù

James laughs. ‚ÄúAlways so surprised.‚Äù

He steps further into the room, taking it in. Remus isn‚Äôt wrong, it definitely feels like the type of place someone plotting world domination would hangout in. The rest of the dungeon is made of grey stone but these rooms have walls of black‚Äîit might be some kind of marble, James can‚Äôt tell. The walls are broken up by arched alcoves that let beams of green light drift in from the water overtop of them.

‚ÄúAlright, lets do this and go,‚Äù Remus says, moving towards the beds. ‚ÄúThis place gives me the creeps.‚Äù

James smirks, doing the same. He gets through the first bed just fine, but on the second one he stalls.

It wouldn‚Äôt have occurred to him that it was Regulus‚Äôs‚Äîthere are no posters on the walls around it, no real identifying markers‚Äîexcept for the chest at the end, R.A.B penned out in gold on the lid. Sirius used to have one just like it, until last year. It got left behind with everything else he owned.

It‚Äôs always weird, the ways in which Sirius and Regulus are so connected and so disconnected all at the same time. James runs his fingers along the initials, along the perfectly made bed, the tiny telescope on Regulus‚Äôs bedside table. He smiles a little at the sight of it.

Almost of its own volition his hand wanders down to the table drawer, pulling it open despite the voice in his head shouting that this is boundary crossing territory. But there isn‚Äôt much in there, not that James was expecting there to be. A few quills, a small book on potions, rings, and‚ÄîJames pauses, fingers brushing against a piece of parchment. Shoved far to the back, clearly not meant to be seen. Be read. And he knows. He knows that he should leave it alone. But he‚Äôs never been very good at that.

It‚Äôs a letter, he realizes when he pulls it out.

It‚Äôs his letter.

The page is soft, the lines of the folds well warn, clearly something that is frequently read. That thought makes James ache. It‚Äôs the last one he wrote, and because of the dark it takes him a few seconds to realize that Regulus has written comments in margins.

‚ÄòDude‚Äô

James had written, and next to it, scribbled in neat cursive, Regulus replied:

‚ÄòThis is an indignity I do not deserve.‚Äô

James snorts.

A little further down James had said: ‚ÄòI can‚Äôt decide which I like better, us on the same team, or us on opposing teams.‚Äô

‚ÄòOpposing,‚Äô Regulus scribbled beside it. ‚ÄòObviously Potter, we‚Äôre born rivals.‚Äô

Most of the comments are like that, witty, cute. The words ‚Äúour house‚Äù have been underlined and circled, though James isn‚Äôt entirely sure why. But it‚Äôs the note at the very bottom of the letter that catches his attention‚Äîthat stands out as different from the rest.

James had written: ‚ÄòI just want you to know that I‚Äôll be there if you need me. I‚Äôll always be there.‚Äô

It looks like Regulus wrote something and then scribbled it out, but next to the blackened words there are several lines that, after reading through them twice, James realizes aren‚Äôt Reg‚Äôs. They‚Äôre quotes:

‚ÄòEverything is more beautiful because we‚Äôre doomed,‚Äô starts the first one, ‚Äòyou will never be lovelier than you are now. We will never be here again.‚Äô

And then, just below it:

‚ÄòNo man or woman born, coward or brave, can shun his destiny.‚Äô

James reads them over again, the words swelling inside him, foreboding and sad. He wonders when Regulus wrote them‚Äîhopes it was before he came back. That it was when he was still stuck in Scotland. Where James couldn‚Äôt reach him. Because these words sound like‚Ä¶

They sound like giving up.

But he quickly shoves that thought aside. He‚Äôd been with Regulus last night, and Regulus had been‚Äîhe‚Äôd been happy. He‚Äôd been having a good day. Just a few more of those and maybe James would finally get Regulus to see that life doesn‚Äôt have to be so fucking hard. That him and James can have more than secrets in the middle of the night.

‚ÄúAlright?‚Äù

James jumps at the sound of Remus‚Äôs voice, quickly throwing the letter back in the drawer and slamming it shut.

‚ÄúEr, yeah,‚Äù he turns around, putting on a smile. ‚ÄúNext dorm?‚Äù

Remus arches his brow and then, after a brief pause; ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be suspicious if his bed is the only one not charmed.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù James asks, still reeling, but then he follows Remus‚Äôs gaze to Regulus‚Äôs bed. ‚ÄúOh, yeah, sorry,‚Äù he quickly waves his wand casting the spell. ‚ÄúOkay great, should we go?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou sure you‚Äôre okay?‚Äù Remus asks, still looking at James skeptically.

‚ÄúUh-huh, never better,‚Äù he starts walking towards the door.

‚ÄúUm‚Ä¶James?‚Äù

James looks at him over his shoulder.

‚ÄúThink you might be forgetting something?‚Äù he nods to the cloak hanging out of James‚Äôs back pocket.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù James says dumbly. ‚ÄúRight, yeah.‚Äù

He holds it out and Remus steps closer to him, the pair of them disappearing.

‚ÄúYou sure you‚Äôre alright?‚Äù Remus whispers as they unlock the door and slip back outside.

‚ÄúAbsolutely.‚Äù

¬†

The sixth year dorm is pretty uneventful and they get through it quickly, the noise below them growing louder and rowdier as time passes.

‚ÄúYou think Slughorn will make them all hangover potions in the morning?‚Äù Remus asks as they make it to the last room. This one is way messier than the other two‚Äîas though their disorganization is beyond even house-elf help.

‚ÄúThat or Snape will, you know what a little suck-up he is.‚Äù

Remus only nods as they move further into the room. Since last year he always goes a bit stiff at the mention of Snape. At the sight of him. He‚Äôs afraid that Dumbledore‚Äôs word won‚Äôt be enough, that Snape will decide to tell people his secret anyway. The worst part, is that James thinks Remus probably should be worried.

‚ÄúOoh, sweet,‚Äù he pulls a full bottle of some kind of fancy liqueur out of the pile of clothes beside one of the beds. ‚ÄúFrench,‚Äù he mutters to himself as he tries and fails to read the label, deciding to open it anyway. ‚ÄúWhy is everything these wankers drink French?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think your choice of adjective answers that question,‚Äú and then, when he sees what James is doing; ‚Äú‚Äîno James, you can‚Äôt just drink from some random bottle you found on the floor,‚Äù Remus sounds thoroughly exasperated.

James only grins. ‚ÄúYou think it‚Äôs a plant? That they knew we were coming all along? Left us a poisoned bottle of‚Ä¶whatever the fuck this is?‚Äù

Remus clearly does not appreciate James‚Äôs sarcastic tone. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a bad idea to put unknown substances in your mouth.‚Äù

‚ÄúOoh, I love it when you talk dirty to me,‚Äù James winks as he brings the bottle to his mouth and takes a swig. The liquid is thick and syrupy and grossly sweet, but definitely alcoholic. That‚Äôs all that matters in the end.

James makes a face as he finishes, holding the bottle out to Remus.

‚ÄúYeah, no thank you, I‚Äôm fine,‚Äù his friend says, eyeing the bottle with distaste.

James shakes it at him. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon, you know you want to.‚Äù

‚ÄúI definitely don‚Äôt know that. Can we just get this done?‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt drop the bottle, and after several moments of a very determined staring contest, Remus surrenders. ‚ÄúHonestly, between you and Sirius‚Äîbloody children,‚Äù he grabs the bottle out of James‚Äôs hand and takes an impressively large gulp for someone who was so against it.

‚ÄúHappy now?‚Äù Remus doesn‚Äôt even flinch, wiping his mouth off on the back of his hand.

‚ÄúWow, how did you do that?‚Äù James asks as he accepts the bottle that Remus is shoving back towards him.

‚ÄúDo what?‚Äù Remus starts charming the beds.

‚ÄúTake that without even flinching?‚Äù

Remus shrugs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a better drinker than you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù James laughs. ‚ÄúSince when?‚Äù

Remus gives him a sidelong look, moving on to the next bed. ‚ÄúSince always.‚Äù

James narrows his eyes. ‚ÄúNo, that can‚Äôt be right, why don‚Äôt I know this?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause usually you‚Äôre too drunk to notice.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get that drunk,‚Äù though he‚Äôs not entirely sure how confident he feels about that statement. I mean, he certainly has gotten drunk. Once or twice. Or three or five or twenty times.

‚ÄúYou and Sirius, Hogwarts‚Äôs resident bad boys, under the table after a couple of beers.‚Äù

That gets a laugh out of James. ‚ÄúOof, don‚Äôt hold back Moony, tell me how you really feel.‚Äù

Remus shoots him a guilty look. ‚ÄúSorry, that sounded bitter didn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

‚ÄúLike a lemon,‚Äù James smiles.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs sour not‚Äîyou know what? Never mind,‚Äù Remus sighs, leaning against the bedpost next to him. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to be a lemon.‚Äù

He says it so sincerely that James has to bite down on his lip to keep from laughing. ‚ÄúAw shucks Moons, don‚Äôt look like that, you‚Äôre not a lemon‚Äîmaybe a lemon meringue.‚Äù

He wrinkles his nose. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a terrible desert.‚Äù

‚ÄúPersonally, I like meringues.‚Äù

That gets a huff of laughter out of Remus. ‚ÄúIs there anything you don‚Äôt like?‚Äù

James makes a face, voice grave. ‚ÄúBeets.‚Äù

‚ÄúFair enough,‚Äù Remus‚Äôs smile flickers and then goes out, hand coming up to scrub at his face. ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm making everything harder on everyone,‚Äù he says finally. And then, before James can respond, he reaches out and takes the bottle back, swallowing another gulp.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù James says, more sincere than he‚Äôs been all night, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre not making anything harder.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, you and Sirius are alright now, and Pete, well, he‚Äôll do whatever you do won‚Äôt he‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs exactly‚Äî‚Äú

‚Äú‚Äîso it‚Äôs me who‚Äôs stopping things from being‚Ä¶normal. And it‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt want them to be, I do.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know mate.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, Remus biting on his lower lip before he laughs, though it sounds kind of sad. He drinks again before speaking. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not even angry anymore, I‚Äôm just‚Ä¶scared.‚Äù Remus closes his eyes for a moment and James feels his heart clench. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm scared of him. It‚Äî‚Äú he exhales, breath shaky, ‚Äúit hurt so much.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù James says again.

Remus‚Äôs eyes blink open. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do that again. I can‚Äôt let him in and then‚Äîand that‚Äôs not even touching on all the rest of it.‚Äù

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúThe rest of it?‚Äù

Remus smiles dryly. ‚ÄúThe kissing.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù James says wisely, taking the bottle back and failing, once again, not to grimace as the alcohol goes down his throat. ‚ÄúThe kissing. He still being a prick about that?‚Äù

Remus frowns. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, I don‚Äôt know what he‚Äôs doing.‚Äù And then, after a moment. ‚ÄúRegulus isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶the same?‚Äù The sentence comes out stilted, like he can‚Äôt find the words‚Äîdoesn‚Äôt know how to ask it.

James thinks about it, tilting his head from side to side. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still‚Ä¶there‚Ä¶the fear. I don‚Äôt think he‚Äôs particularly happy about being‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúGay?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James rubs at the back of his neck. ‚ÄúBut I think he‚Äôs kind of accepted it‚Äîbeen forced to accept it‚Äîas a part of himself.‚Äù

‚ÄúForced?‚Äù

Anger and pain cut through him and he feels his hand tighten around the bottle he‚Äôs still holding. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he coughs, clearing his throat. ‚ÄúYou get all of them?‚Äù he gestures to the beds, eager to change the subject.

Remus blinks. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äîoh,‚Äù he looks around. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah think so.‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúAlright, lets get out of here shall we?‚Äù he takes a final swig from the bottle before tossing it on the floor. Fuck the French bastards.

‚ÄúMerlin yes,‚Äù Remus agrees eagerly as James throws the invisibility cloak back over the pair of them.

‚ÄúHey, Remus?‚Äù he says before they push out the door. He waits for his friend‚Äôs stare to meet his. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not a lemon.‚Äù

Remus smiles, rolling his eyes. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah, just go already.‚Äù

¬†

Things have grown slightly wilder since they went upstairs. People are getting sloppy, no longer able to maintain their ‚Äúcool‚Äù outer facades. There‚Äôs a lot of grinding and spilling and shouting over the‚Äîstill terrible‚Äîmusic.

There are also a lot fewer paths through the crowd. Remus and James do their best to stay out of people‚Äôs way but it‚Äôs near impossible at this point.

‚ÄúJesus,‚Äù James hisses, ‚Äúthe whole bloody school is here.‚Äù

‚ÄúCertainly seems like it,‚Äù Remus grumbles, pushing James to the side so that they miss the swinging arm of a girl emphatically pointing at something across the room.

‚ÄúOhmygod, ohmygod, ohmygod!‚Äù she yanks on her friend‚Äôs arm. ‚ÄúLook!‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt really pay the girl any attention, too busy looking for their next opening in the crowd. At least, he doesn‚Äôt until approximately three second later when Remus says the same words but in an entirely different tone of voice.

‚ÄúOh my God.‚Äù

James looks over at him, finding his friend‚Äôs gaze directed across the room, in the direction the girl had been pointing. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up?‚Äù he asks.

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

But it‚Äôs too late, because James is already looking. It‚Äôs slightly pathetic that the first thing he feels is still butterflies. That jolt of dopamine that he always gets when he looks at Regulus. It takes his brain a moment to catch up to what he‚Äôs actually looking at.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Remus whispers beside him, tugging lightly on his sleeve like he‚Äôs trying to pull him away, to get him to stop staring. But he can‚Äôt. Can‚Äôt move. Can‚Äôt look away.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he hears himself say. Everything suddenly feels like it‚Äôs moving very slowly, like he‚Äôs in a dream. A dream where he‚Äôs watching Regulus kiss some girl, which‚Äîwhich isn‚Äôt right. Why would he‚Äîwhy would he do that?

Except it‚Äôs not just a kiss. Because they‚Äôre still going. Regulus‚Äôs hand on the back of her head, the other on her lower back.

‚ÄúOh fuck,‚Äù James says as it all speeds up again, as it really sinks in. A sharp pain nearly cuts him in half, causing him to double over and grab hold of his knees. He feels dizzy.

‚ÄúI think I might be sick,‚Äù the words come out of him without his permission, and he tries to remind himself that there‚Äôs nothing actually physically wrong with him. He‚Äôs fine. He‚Äôs fine. He‚Äôs totally fine.

‚ÄúCome on James, come on, lets go.‚Äù

Remus wraps his arm around him, pulling him up and forward and James lets him. Somehow they make it into the corridor outside, and James knows that he should wait, that they need to get further away from the common room before they become visible again. But he can‚Äôt breathe.

He pulls away‚Äîaway from Remus and away from the cloak, barely making it around the corner before he needs to stop and grab onto something for support. He presses his palms into the cold stone of the dungeon and hangs his head. It‚Äôs not long before Remus catches up to him. He doesn‚Äôt say anything, just leans on the wall next to him.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú his voice shakes and he forces himself to breathe in and out before speaking again. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt see that coming,‚Äù he manages eventually, in what is probably the most obvious statement he‚Äôs ever made.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Remus agrees, ‚Äúme neither.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs probably drunk,‚Äù Remus says eventually.

And James has to grit his teeth against the pathetic noise that wants to come out of his mouth. The ‚Äúhe was drunk the first time he kissed me‚Äù that‚Äôs sitting on his tongue.

‚ÄúIt looked like he meant it,‚Äù is what comes out instead.

‚ÄúIt looked like he was snogging some girl at a party. Don‚Äôt read more into it James, not until you talk to him.‚Äù

James laughs, even though it feels wrong in his mouth. Finally, he lifts his head. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want me to be with him.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not a question but Remus still answers. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo why are you being so‚Ä¶fair.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause,‚Äù he says simply, ‚Äúwhat I really want is for you to be happy and, despite all reason and good judgement, he makes you happy. I‚Äôve seen it.‚Äù

James has to close his eyes for a minute to weather the new wave of nausea that comes with that statement. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says quietly. ‚ÄúYeah, he does.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut just so we‚Äôre clear,‚Äù James opens his eyes just in time to see Remus‚Äôs expression go from sympathetic to murderous in one blink. ‚ÄúAny good faith he had managed to build with me is now gone. And the next time I see that scrawny little twerp I‚Äôm going to ruin his fucking life.‚Äù

James laughs, running a hand over his face, feeling shaky and sweaty and all other kinds of awful.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not really scrawny.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe that‚Äôs what you got from that.‚Äù

James smiles weakly, leaning his head back against the wall and exhaling. ‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he says again, and then; ‚ÄúI should have had more of that posh alcohol. I‚Äôm too sober for this.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have alcohol back at the dorm. Speaking of, we should get going before the other two think a rescue mission is in order.‚Äù

James sighs pulling himself off the wall. He looks back in the direction of the Slytherin common room, feeling something tug on him, like a string attached to his bellybutton, pulling him backwards, back to Reg. Because he just wants to see him. To touch him. To remember that he‚Äôs his.

His person.

‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to have to stop saying that or Sirius is going to ask questions,‚Äù Remus says.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù James scrubs at his eyes. ‚ÄúI just‚ÄîI just really didn‚Äôt‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know what to do with‚Äîwith that.‚Äù

James looks at him and realizes, suddenly, how true that is. How many times Remus has had to standby and watch Sirius snog some girl.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù he nudges James with his elbow. ‚ÄúWe gotta go before the sneezing starts.‚Äù

¬†

Sirius is wired when they get back to the dorm. Which makes sense, first prank of the year, they got all the senior Slytherins, ruined their big night. All and all, a major success. He should celebrate. Normally, James would be right there with him. But instead he feels numb. Disconnected from all of it.

‚ÄúOkay, what‚Äôs going on with you?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù James drags a hand through his hair and offers up a sheepish smile. ‚ÄúJust tired.‚Äù

That brings some semblance of joy back to Sirius‚Äôs expression.

‚ÄúGod, it‚Äôs going to be brilliant.‚Äù

¬†

Listens to Remus‚Äôs hushed voice as he spells the lights out. And all the while he just lays there on his back, staring up at the canopy over his head. Somehow thinking and not thinking at the same time.

He feels like he has too much energy. Like it‚Äôs pressing against his skin‚Äîpushing, pushing, pushing. He can‚Äôt shut his mind off. Every time he closes his eyes he‚Äôs back in that room and he‚Äôs staring at Regulus and Regulus is holding that girl. Holding her like he means it. And she‚Äôs touching him.

James‚Äôs skin feels too hot.

Don‚Äôt read more into it, that‚Äôs what Remus said. Except Remus doesn‚Äôt know Regulus, he thinks he‚Äôs like Sirius but he isn‚Äôt. He isn‚Äôt, and so James just can‚Äôt make sense of it. He demands answers from his brain but it just sparks and fizzes and restarts.

His skin feels too hot. His ribs feel too tight.

He tries to remember what the girl looked like, tries to figure out if he knows her. If he‚Äôs seen Regulus with her before. Scours his head for any memory of Regulus mentioning her, but nothing in his brain is working right. Every thought he has is interrupted by that image of Regulus snogging someone else.

His skin feels too hot. His ribs feel too tight. His head feels too loud.

James is unmoved. ‚ÄúI can handle a few angry Slytherins.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan he?‚Äù

That question manages to pull James up short. He opens and closes his mouth, willing an answer to come, but before any does Sirius and Peter are blinking up at them.

‚ÄúWhat the hell?‚Äù Peter demands, rubbing his sleep heavy eyes.

‚ÄúI thought you two were tired?‚Äù Sirius adds, he doesn‚Äôt look‚Ä¶angry, necessarily, just‚Ä¶confused. His eyes bounce between Remus and James before they land on the invisibility cloak in James‚Äôs hand.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Sirius says, like he‚Äôs just figured something out. ‚ÄúGoing to see the boy.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe boy?‚Äù Peter repeats. ‚ÄúWhat boy? Who‚Äôs the boy?‚Äù

‚ÄúI get it, okay? I do, but this is not the right way to do this‚Äîthe right time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going fucking insane here Moons,‚Äù and he can hear it in his voice. Hear the desperation.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMoony, let him go have his fun, what‚Äôs the big deal?‚Äù

Remus grits his teeth, not looking at Sirius. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that simple.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I‚Äôm still confused, who is this boy?‚Äù Peter looks around at all of them.

‚ÄúNow that Petey, is the thousand galleon question,‚Äù Sirius says, tapping the side of his nose.

James just shakes his head, too tired to take in the ridiculousness of his current situation.

‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôm going.‚Äù

‚ÄúNO! James, I swear to God you can be such a fucking bullheaded idiot sometimes,‚Äù Remus grabs hold of his wrist and yanks him back into the room.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù James says as calmly as he can manage, which, to be honest, at this moment is not particularly calmly, ‚Äúlet go.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to get yourself hurt. You‚Äôre going to get both of you hurt.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus, mate, you‚Äôre being a little much yeah?‚Äù Sirius sounds uncertain for the first time. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve been doing this for a year now, I think they‚Äôve got it figured out.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs been doing what for a year!?‚Äù Peter shouts at the same moment that Remus rounds on Sirius.

‚ÄúWill you please shut-up? You literally have no idea what you‚Äôre talking about!‚Äù

Which, surprisingly, does shut Sirius up. At least for a second. ‚ÄúWait‚Äîhold on‚Äîdo you know?‚Äù

Remus instantly stiffens and James can feel his stomach start to roll, bile crawling up the back of his throat.

‚ÄúYou do don‚Äôt you?‚Äù and now he‚Äôs angry. ‚ÄúYou know who he is!‚Äù

James sees the second lightbulb go off in Sirius‚Äôs head, he‚Äôs too clever by half really, always has been. This time he turns to James when he speaks; ‚ÄúIs he in Slytherin?‚Äù

‚ÄúIs who in‚Äî‚Äú

But James doesn‚Äôt stick around for the onslaught of questions. Somewhere in the midst of the drama Remus let his grip slip and James takes full advantage, pushing himself through the door, down the stairs and back into the castle.

¬†

He has no idea what time it is at this point. Three in the morning? Four? Somewhere around there. The Slytherin common room has significantly calmed down. There are maybe a dozen people still around, half of whom are passed out, the other half are lying on top of one another. Luckily, he doesn‚Äôt see Regulus.

He can hear the fruits of their labour already. Under different circumstances he would be soaking up every minute of it‚Äîthe profanities intermingled with the creaking noises of beds sneezing.

‚ÄúMaybe we should give them Pepperup?‚Äù he hears one boy say from the doorway of his dorm room as James pushes up the stairs.

People are going in and out of each other‚Äôs rooms, confused and trying to figure out if anyone has found the counter-charm. The sound of footsteps and door slamming and people being thrown off their beds echoes around James. Sirius would be so proud.

He slips into Regulus‚Äôs dorm just as some other Slytherin he doesn‚Äôt recognize walks out. After the chaos outside the room feels startlingly quiet. That is. Until he hears Rosier.

‚ÄúMotherfucking bollocks, I was going to get laid tonight,‚Äù he kicks the leg of his bed which is apparently enough to set off the charm because the mattress lifts up and sneezes. ‚ÄúOh really? REALLY? Salazar‚Äôs balls ‚Äî how did they even get in here?‚Äù

James walks a little further into the room and sees that Rosier is talking to Regulus. Regulus is sitting on the floor, back pressed to the wall, arms resting on his knees. James‚Äôs traitorous heart leaps.

‚ÄúWhat makes you so sure it wasn‚Äôt one of the younger years?‚Äù he asks, though he doesn‚Äôt sound like he believes what he‚Äôs saying.

‚ÄúAre you kidding me? You think one of those brats could pull this off? That they would dare? No, this has Potter and your brother written all over it and I swear the next time I see them I‚Äôm going to permanently separate them from their bollocks.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt really react to this, expression blank as he stares back at Rosier. The door bangs open and Crouch comes through, James grateful that he‚Äôs moved far enough away to avoid a collision.

‚ÄúWell?‚Äù Rosier demands, but Crouch shakes his head.

‚ÄúNah, seventh years haven‚Äôt got a clue.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat. The. Fuck,‚Äù he kicks his bed again. There‚Äôs another sneeze. Rosier points his wand at it. ‚ÄúNovis Sternius,‚Äù nothing happens. ‚ÄúCome on you stupid piece of shit. Novis Sternius, Novis Sternius, Novis Sternius!‚Äù

‚ÄúEvan,‚Äù Regulus says from the floor, sounding exhausted. ‚ÄúGive it a rest.‚Äù

Rosier rounds on him. ‚ÄúYou know Reg, you‚Äôre being incredibly unhelpful right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm I?‚Äù Regulus asks dryly, causing Rosier‚Äôs eyes to narrow.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre supposed to be the clever one, what‚Äôs the bloody counter-charm?‚Äù

Regulus sighs, dropping his head back against the wall and looking up at the ceiling when he talks. ‚ÄúIts a mutation of the spell.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Crouch asks, it‚Äôs only then that James realizes that Crouch is swaying on the spot, eyes glassy, clearly the drunkest of the three.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve adapted the original spell, which means that there doesn‚Äôt exist a known counter-charm, we‚Äôd have to figure one out, which we could do, after a few hours of reading up on the etymology of the Sternius charm, though, of course, by that point the charm will likely have warn off by itself anyway and Evan still won‚Äôt have been able to shag Louise.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence before Rosier lets out a growl. ‚ÄúFucking fuckity fuck‚ÄîI‚Äôm going to kill them.‚Äù

Crouch, on the other hand, seems significantly more accepting of the situation. Likely, James imagines, due to the alcohol. He‚Äôs able to snag the blanket and pillow off his bed, though it does sneeze in the process. He throws them down on the floor and gets comfortable. Rosier, on the other hand, has started pacing, running his hands furiously through his hair.

‚ÄúYou know what? No. No. Fuck those assholes, I‚Äôm going to find Louise. How the bloody hell did they even get in here?!‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt sure if he‚Äôs really asking anymore, but apparently Regulus decides that he isn‚Äôt because he doesn‚Äôt say anything, watching passively as his friend storms out of the room, door slamming behind him.

Regulus sighs, leaning his head back against the wall again and closing his eyes. After a few seconds of silence James hears Crouch start to snore. He figures it‚Äôs now or never, so he walks forward, sitting himself beside Regulus but keeping the cloak on. He has no idea when Rosier‚Äîor anyone else for that matter‚Äîis going to come storming back in here.

‚ÄúGood party?‚Äù he asks quietly.

Regulus jolts upright, eyes flying open as he looks around.

‚ÄúCertainly looked like you were having fun,‚Äù James goes on, bringing Regulus‚Äôs gaze towards him, though it lands somewhere off his left shoulder rather than his face.

‚ÄúWhat the hell are you doing here?‚Äù Regulus hisses, eyes going to Crouch‚Äôs sleeping body and then the door.

James doesn‚Äôt see any point in beating around the bush. ‚ÄúYou were kissing someone.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, eyes coming back to James‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou were snogging some bird.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat are you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShut up.‚Äù

He drags James towards the bathroom, throwing him inside and then following after. Regulus shuts the door behind them, pulling out his wand, locking it and casting a silencing charm. Then he turns back to James.

‚ÄúTake it off, I‚Äôm not talking to the fucking air.‚Äù His voice feels loud now, after the whispering. James does as he asks, pulling the cloak off and tossing it on the counter. ‚ÄúWhat the hell are you doing here James?‚Äù

We‚Äôre not doomed, he wants to tell him. I won‚Äôt let us be.

‚ÄúYou look good,‚Äù James says, voice still a little rough.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll find some excuse to leave the room, open the door for you,‚Äù Regulus goes on, pulling out his wand so he can take down the spells.

Regulus sighs. ‚ÄúOf course you don‚Äôt.‚Äù And then; ‚ÄúAlohomora.‚Äù

¬†

Fuck.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been sitting here trying to come up with a single Slytherin bloke who isn‚Äôt a complete piece of shit, and I have to tell you James, I‚Äôm drawing a blank.‚Äù

James sighs, leaning against one of the chairs. ‚ÄúI never said he was in Slytherin.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, lets not.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWho is it James?‚Äù

James is entirely too tired for this conversation. ‚ÄúI told you, I can‚Äôt say.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus figured it out.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo what?‚Äù Sirius growls. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the difference?‚Äù

James‚Äôs fists clench. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt start Sirius.‚Äù

Sirius laughs coldly, hanging his head. ‚ÄúYou know, I expect most people to be full of shit. Everyone is principled until they have to sacrifice something. Until they have to put in the effort. Then all those morals seem to disappear, but you,‚Äù Sirius looks up again. ‚ÄúI believed in you.‚Äù

Those words hit him so hard James actually staggers back.

‚ÄúAnd to think,‚Äù Sirius goes on, not done yet, smiling in a way that sends chills down James‚Äôs spine. ‚ÄúYou were so fucking righteous last year when I messed up.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs it?‚Äù Sirius gets to his feet. ‚ÄúHow many people do you reckon your boy‚Äôs gonna hurt huh? How many has he already?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not a Death Eater.‚Äù

Sirius laughs unpleasantly. ‚ÄúSure, maybe he doesn‚Äôt have the uniform yet, but he is isn‚Äôt he? In here,‚Äù he taps his temple.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna get him out Sirius,‚Äù James sounds desperate now, words begging to be heard. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to show him it doesn‚Äôt have to be like that.‚Äù

For the first time since he walked into the common room James sees something other than anger in Sirius‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúYou really believe that?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

He does.

Deep in his bones.

Right down to his core.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt save people James,‚Äù Sirius says finally. ‚ÄúYou can show them the way out but they have to walk through those doors themselves. Don‚Äôt you think I‚Äôve tried?‚Äù

No.

Not like me.

You never loved him like I do.

And James knows that it‚Äôs such an unfair thing to think. But he does anyway. Clings to it.

He‚Äôll follow me.

He trusts me.

I‚Äôll show him that all love doesn‚Äôt have teeth.

That all families don‚Äôt make you bleed.

Sirius sighs when James can‚Äôt give him an answer, bringing his hands up to his face, scrubbing at his eyes.

‚ÄúI know that you can‚Äôt see it,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúBut this? What you‚Äôre doing? It‚Äôs the wrong thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt know that.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure I can,‚Äù Sirius looks like he has more to say but for once in his life holds his tongue, giving James a once over before shaking his head and turning towards the stairs.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs different,‚Äù James says suddenly, desperate for Sirius to understand. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not really him, the person everyone else sees, there‚Äôs so much good in him Sirius, I swear.‚Äù

Sirius stops on the first step, taking his time turning around. When he does all James sees is pity, it makes him flinch.

‚ÄúAnd how long is that going to be enough, huh James? Until he gets the mark? Until he kills someone? Or do you reckon you‚Äôll be able to make yourself believe that that‚Äôs okay too? That that‚Äôs not who he really is?‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThing is, it‚Äôs not a hypothetical for me,‚Äù something in his voice takes James off guard, something‚Ä¶bruised. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve sat at their table, I‚Äôve felt their teeth in my neck. There‚Äôs no fucking grey area here, okay? The things you have to do, to get by, to blend in‚Äîdo you think if it had been easy I wouldn‚Äôt have done it? I‚Äî‚Äú his voice cuts out and James finds himself unconsciously taking a step forward, reaching out to his best mate.

Sirius shakes himself, like pulling himself out of a nightmare, his dark eyes finding James. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre my family,‚Äù there is something heart wrenchingly vulnerable about those words. ‚ÄúI loved them. The awful truth, is that sometimes I still do. And if I could have made myself fit without crossing any lines I would have. But it‚Äôs not possible. You can‚Äôt be one of them and keep your hands clean. So if he‚Äôs friends with them? If he‚Äôs accepted by them? By that world? You can bet he‚Äôs doing some fucked up shit when you‚Äôre not looking.‚Äù

James shakes his head but doesn‚Äôt speak. Can‚Äôt. Doesn‚Äôt even know where to start. He expects Sirius to turn around and leave but he doesn‚Äôt, and after a few more moments of silence he walks back down the stairs, stopping in front of James.

‚ÄúI love him,‚Äù James says pathetically, because he has nothing else. Because it‚Äôs the one thing that he knows without a doubt to be true. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so‚Äîso strong and so‚Äîso much. And I‚ÄîI hope you‚Äôre wrong, I need you to be wrong. Because I can‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äù his voice cracks, unwilling to finish that sentence.

Sirius‚Äôs expression softens. ‚ÄúJesus James,‚Äù he pulls him into a hug and James goes willingly, sagging against his best friend. ‚ÄúYou really have terrible taste in men.‚Äù

James laughs wetly. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, I did alright with you lot.‚Äù

Sirius snorts, but when he speaks his voice is sad, and James doesn‚Äôt know whose heart hurts more‚Äîhis or Sirius‚Äôs.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius croaks, ‚Äúyou did alright with us.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hey! Hi! Hello!

I feel like this chapter has the most teenager-y angst which was fun.

Also Remus Lupin is 100% that friend that throws your phone out the window when you start trying to drunk text your ex (this is a James Potter call out)

I hope you liked it, as always, super appreciate all the comments and love to know what you think!

Chapter 23

Chapter Summary

Moony

Chapter Notes

OKAY, listen, I may have taken some creative liberties in this chapter and given the Shrieking Shack a front door (partially because in my head the Shrieking Shack is a pre-existing abandoned house that Dumbledore uses for Remus not one he builds for him, because that makes more sense to me even though I know it's not canon - but I digress) hopefully that doesn't bother people too much!

also...

tw: Death / implied suicide (happens off screen not graphically described)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

‚ÄúMarlene thinks you‚Äôre cute.‚Äù

Remus blinks down at his coursework and then up at Mary Macdonald, who has just dropped into the seat across from him at the library. The library he‚Äôd come to specifically to get away from people, choosing a table at the back, hidden by bookshelves and almost always empty.

‚ÄúHey, hello,‚Äù Mary sticks her hand in his face and snaps her fingers, ‚ÄúEarth to Remus, did you hear me?‚Äù

Remus sighs. ‚ÄúI heard you. I was just hoping you‚Äôd go away.‚Äù

Mary sticks her tongue out at him. ‚ÄúTough luck buttercup. So?‚Äù

‚ÄúSo?‚Äù

Mary waves her hand impatiently ‚ÄúSo, what do you think about Marlene calling you cute?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Ä¶that‚Äôs‚Ä¶nice of her?‚Äù Though honestly, Remus isn‚Äôt sure ‚Äúcute‚Äù is exactly the look he‚Äôs going for. Cute is for puppies. Or babies. Not‚Ä¶whatever he is. Boy-man-person-werewolf.

‚ÄúNice of her?‚Äù Mary demands, clearly offended on Marlene‚Äôs behalf.

Remus brings his hands up to his head, massaging his temples. ‚ÄúWhat exactly do you want from me Mary?‚Äù

She leans forward, dark braids slipping over her shoulder. ‚ÄúI want to know what you‚Äôre going to do about it.‚Äù

Remus blinks. ‚ÄúDo about it?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf I were you, I‚Äôd ask her to Hogsmeade this weekend.‚Äù

It takes Remus‚Äôs brain a moment to catch up‚Äîto understand the connection between being called ‚Äúcute‚Äù and asking someone to go to Hogsmeade with you.

‚ÄúLike‚Ä¶on a date?‚Äù he says slowly, hating everything about that idea.

The eye roll Mary gives him is truly spectacular. ‚ÄúYes, Merlin, I thought you were the clever one.‚Äù

‚ÄúCommon misconception,‚Äù Remus says off handedly, which is true. People think James and Sirius are idiots because they act like it, but that‚Äôs a choice on their part. Even Peter is smarter than most people give him credit for, he just isn‚Äôt good at school. He can learn anything if you explain it to him out loud, even if it‚Äôs only once. And he picks up spells just by watching. It‚Äôs books he struggles with.

‚ÄúSo we‚Äôre agreed then?‚Äù Mary says triumphantly. ‚ÄúYou should take her to the Three Broomsticks.‚Äù

‚ÄúBit obvious that, where else do you take someone in Hogsmeade?‚Äù He has no idea why he‚Äôs playing along with this, there‚Äôs no way he‚Äôs taking Marlene anywhere.

‚ÄúWell you were a little slow on the uptake so I‚Äôm not sure what‚Äôs obvious to you, and I don‚Äôt want you to do something stupid like bring her to Madam Puddifoot‚Äôs.‚Äù

Remus makes a face even just thinking about that place‚Äîpink and frilly and blasting sickly sweet smells into the street that give him a migraine every time he walks by.

‚ÄúYes, exactly,‚Äù Mary says gravely. ‚ÄúGood to know you have some taste. That bodes well for this.‚Äù

‚ÄúBodes well for‚Äîlisten, Mary‚Ä¶‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know how to finish that sentence though. He considers telling her the truth, but what would that even look like?

Hey Mary, I‚Äôm not going to go out with Marlene. I don‚Äôt fancy her. I‚Äôm in love with my psychotic best friend, or ex-best friend, depending on how you look at it, who‚Äôs too afraid to admit that he wants to kiss me let alone anything else. My love life is really complicated enough as it is. Also, I‚Äôm a werewolf.

Would that be too much?

‚ÄúRemus? Merlin, what is with you today?‚Äù

Remus blinks, coming back to the present as Mary impatiently taps her nails on the table between them.

‚ÄúSorry. Look, I like Marlene a lot‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGreat!‚Äù

Remus does his best not to cringe. ‚ÄúYeah, great, but I‚Äôm not‚Äî‚Äú his next words drop out of his mouth as Regulus Black walks into view, which in and of itself would have been annoying enough, but is even more annoying because Regulus is with someone. A girl someone.

‚ÄúThat little prick.‚Äù

‚ÄúWow what?‚Äù

Remus turns back to Mary, realizing what he‚Äôs just done. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîno, sorry, I didn‚Äôt, I wasn‚Äôt, it was‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúReally not into finishing your sentences today are you?‚Äù Mary asks, looking, to Remus‚Äôs relief, much more amused than angry. ‚ÄúI suppose it does give you a bit of a mysterious vibe, Marlene might be into that.‚Äù

Remus can‚Äôt tell if she‚Äôs joking or not. ‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRemus!‚Äù Someone shouts, far too loudly for the library.

To his horror, Remus realizes that the girl Regulus is with‚Äîwho he can now see is Cerci Greengrass‚Äîis coming towards them.

Mary tilts her head. ‚ÄúWow, she‚Äôs adorable.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt find that statement to be particularly helpful, especially considering that Cerci‚Äôs currently in the stacks with the boy who‚Äôs meant to be seeing his best mate. And the only reason people come to the stacks is to snog. Well, people who aren‚Äôt Remus anyway.

‚ÄúFriend of yours?‚Äù Mary asks.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt even know why he says it, he likes Cerci well enough, she‚Äôs very‚Ä¶energetic.

‚ÄúWell, maybe you should tell her that cause she‚Äôs coming over here with‚Äîbloody hell, is that Regulus Black? Weird couple.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not a couple,‚Äù Remus says harshly. Even though he‚Äôs not entirely sure that‚Äôs true.

‚ÄúHi Remus,‚Äù Cerci beams as she stops in front of their table, a very reluctant Regulus trailing behind her. He looks as happy about this situation as Remus is.

‚ÄúHey Cerci,‚Äù he says, because he doesn‚Äôt know what else to do. Mary clears her throat, drawing Remus‚Äôs attention back to her. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîuh‚Äîthis is my friend, Mary.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know who she is,‚Äù Cerci smiles. ‚ÄúMary Macdonald, Gryffindor Chaser, scoring average of eighty-points per game and owner of exceptionally fashionable shoes.‚Äù

‚ÄúOoh, I like you,‚Äù Mary then turns unnecessarily to Remus and fake whispers: ‚ÄúI like her.‚Äù

‚ÄúI heard,‚Äù he says flatly, busy glaring at Regulus whose expression is infuriatingly blank.

‚ÄúWe were just going to study,‚Äù Cerci, explains. ‚ÄúReg is helping me with potions, I‚Äôm absolutely useless at it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, I have fond memories studying back here,‚Äù Mary says wistfully, and Remus is pretty sure he can hear the air quotes around ‚Äústudying‚Äù in her voice. ‚ÄúActually, I did a lot of that with your brother,‚Äù she sends Regulus a meaningful look but the younger boy‚Äôs expression doesn‚Äôt shift, he just stares back blankly.

‚ÄúYou guys study together a lot?‚Äù Remus asks coldly.

Regulus meets Remus‚Äôs eye. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, we get together at least twice a week, that‚Äôs pretty often. Who do you study with more than twice a week?‚Äù Cerci looks back at Regulus sounding genuinely curious.

‚ÄúYes, do tell Regulus,‚Äù Mary leans forward across the table, hungry for gossip. ‚ÄúWho are you studying with more than twice a week?‚Äù

Remus grits his teeth and resists the urge to hex someone.

‚ÄúNo one,‚Äù the other boy says eventually, sounding incredibly exhausted by the entire conversation.

‚ÄúAh, a one girl kind of guy huh?‚Äù Mary says with a wink and Remus can‚Äôt help but scoff.

He‚Äôs going to kill this kid. He never deserved James in the first place, but this? It‚Äôs way over the line. All he can think about is the look on James‚Äôs face at that party.

‚ÄúI mean, we‚Äôre partners so, makes sense that we hang out together more,‚Äù Cerci smiles, elbowing Regulus playfully.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, you‚Äôre what?‚Äù Remus demands.

Regulus, being the absolute wanker that he is, has the audacity to roll his eyes. ‚ÄúShe means we‚Äôre Prefect partners.‚Äù

‚ÄúPrefect partners?‚Äù Mary repeats, before turning to Remus. ‚ÄúIs that a thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Remus doesn‚Äôt stop glaring at Regulus. ‚ÄúThat is definitely not a thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI kind of made it a thing,‚Äù Cerci smiles.

‚ÄúWow, okay, this is almost too adorable,‚Äù Mary says.

Remus violently disagrees. He feels his hands shaking with the desire to strangle Regulus.

‚ÄúI have to go,‚Äù he says instead, standing abruptly and spelling his stuff into his bag.

‚ÄúOh, sorry, did we interrupt or‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúHonestly, you‚Äôve made this trip to the library far more entertaining for me so I don‚Äôt know what his problem is,‚Äù Mary says nonchalantly, as Remus throws his book bag over his shoulder and turns to Regulus.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre unbelievable.‚Äù

The younger boy doesn‚Äôt even flinch. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre willfully misunderstanding.‚Äù

Remus shakes his head, turning around, fully intending to walk out of the library and leave it at that. Unfortunately, he‚Äôs spent far too much time with Sirius Black to be the bigger person.

‚ÄúLocomotor Wibbly,‚Äù he tosses over his shoulder, getting the satisfaction of watching Regulus‚Äôs unflappable expression crack open in surprise as his legs give out underneath him.

‚ÄúRemus, holy shit,‚Äù he hears Mary say as he walks away.

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù Cerci adds, voice following Remus into the hallway. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never seen a Jelly-legs jinx in real life before, that was brilliant.‚Äù

¬†

He probably shouldn‚Äôt have done that.

He‚Äôs a Prefect, as McGonagall reminds him several times after calling him into her office, taking two dozen house points from Gryffindor and giving him detention‚Äîunfortunately not on the weekend so he‚Äôs still going to have to figure out what to do about the Mary/Marlene situation. Maybe fake an illness? He‚Äôs ‚Äúsick‚Äù often enough, he can‚Äôt imagine anyone would question it.

By the time McGonagall is done dressing him down he has a headache and he‚Äôs tired and grumpy and just wants to sit quietly in a dark room and nap until supper. Which, really, he ought to have known was never going to happen, but he briefly forgot who his friends are.

‚ÄúRemus John Lupin,‚Äù he‚Äôs barely in the door before Sirius is throwing himself at his feet‚Äîliterally‚Äîbowing to him like he‚Äôs some kind of god. ‚ÄúYou are my hero.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes, walking very purposefully around Sirius towards his bed. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve talked to Mary then,‚Äù he says flatly, making brief eye contact with James who‚Äôs sitting at the end of his own bed, an expression on his face that Remus can‚Äôt read.

‚ÄúPretty sure half the school has talked to Mary at this point,‚Äù Peter adds unhelpfully.

Remus sighs, dropping his bag and collapsing onto his bed. ‚ÄúBrilliant.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, Jelly-legs jinx? In the middle of the Library? Merlin, the balls, I can‚Äôt,‚Äù Sirius goes on.

Remus very staunchly refuses to care that Sirius is impressed. Even if the little second year inside of him is loving the idea that Sirius Black thinks he did something ballsy.

‚ÄúTell me,‚Äù Sirius says, as he collapses onto the bed next to him, propped up on his elbows so that he‚Äôs hovering over Remus. Sirius has never had any concept of personal space. ‚ÄúWhat did he do? Did he squeal? Like a little girl?‚Äù

These days, Sirius has taken to trying to pretend that the tension between them doesn‚Äôt exist. Remus can‚Äôt tell if it makes him feel angry or sad. Or guilty. Because he knows that Sirius is trying, trying to make things better, and Remus isn‚Äôt letting him. Can‚Äôt let him.

‚ÄúShockingly,‚Äù he says finally, voice dry. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do it for your amusement.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy did you do it?‚Äù Peter asks. ‚ÄúI mean, he must have really pissed you off to make you hex him?‚Äù

Remus looks briefly at James again and then away. ‚ÄúHe was being a prick.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, well, that‚Äôs kind of Regulus‚Äôs default setting isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Sirius says casually. Not that Remus actually believes that anything Sirius feels about his brother is casual.

There‚Äôs a pause before Remus sighs, swiping a hand across his face. ‚ÄúIs he okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù Sirius scoffs, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs fine, ego probably knocked down a few pegs though.‚Äù

Remus makes the mistake of looking at Sirius then, Sirius who is much too close to him, with his bright eyes and pretty mouth. Sometimes Remus doesn‚Äôt know how he‚Äôs managed this for so long‚ÄîSirius always being so close, always touching him and whispering into his ear, lying on his bed. Ever since last year, ever since the kiss, being around Sirius feels like some strange form of torture. It makes Remus burn from the inside out.

He pulls himself up, reaching for his bag. At least coursework will give him something else to focus on.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd McGonagall give you?‚Äù

Remus looks up from his books. It‚Äôs the first time James has said anything since Remus walked into the room. He doesn‚Äôt find anger in James‚Äôs eyes, but then, he wasn‚Äôt expecting to. Just disappointment. He wonders if Mary mentioned Cerci Greengrass in her re-telling of the story?

‚ÄúMoony?‚Äù he blinks as Sirius waves his hand in his face, startling him out of his thoughts.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Remus shakes his head, ‚Äúbeen doing that a lot today. Um‚Äîdetention and I lost twenty points.‚Äù

‚ÄúTwenty!‚Äù Peter says outraged.

‚ÄúWorth it,‚Äù Sirius counters from Remus‚Äôs other side. ‚ÄúHey Moony, does this mean you‚Äôre missing Hogsmeade this weekend?‚Äù

He shakes his head, pulling out his Charms textbook, ‚ÄúNope.‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat, I was worried I was going to be all on my own.‚Äù

That makes Remus look up. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes, letting out an exaggerated sigh. ‚ÄúWell, Wormtail has gone and gotten himself a date with some Hufflepuff‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRebecca! I‚Äôve told you her name like ten times.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, yeah,‚Äù Sirius waves his hand dismissively. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt be expected to remember the name of every fair damsel.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs literally one name.‚Äù

‚ÄúANYWAY,‚Äù Sirius goes on. ‚ÄúPeter is abandoning us for Rachel,‚Äù Peter groans, ‚Äú and Jamie here is also going to be‚Ä¶occupied‚Ä¶apparently.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúLook, I already told you, I‚Äôm sorry. It‚Äôs only this one time, okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you see Moons, it‚Äôll be just you and I,‚Äù he smiles at Remus then, a little nervously, and Remus feels his pulse speed up.

Him and Sirius. Hanging out all day. Alone. In Hogsmeade. There was a time when that would have sounded like a dream come true to him, when he wanted nothing more than to have Sirius‚Äôs undivided attention. Now he can‚Äôt think of anything worse. It‚Äôs‚Ä¶too much. Too much like something he can‚Äôt have.

‚ÄúUh, actually I‚Äôm going with Marlene,‚Äù the words come out of his mouth before he can stop them.

There‚Äôs a beat of silence.

‚ÄúYou‚Ä¶you‚Äôre going with Marlene?‚Äù James asks.

‚ÄúLike on a date?‚Äù Peter adds.

And despite the fact that this whole thing is completely ridiculous and just Mary sticking her nose where it doesn‚Äôt belong because she‚Äôs‚ÄîRemus doesn‚Äôt know, bored?‚Äîhe actually finds himself a little annoyed at their surprise.

‚ÄúI can go on dates,‚Äù he snaps back, flipping aimlessly through his textbook, just to have something to do with his hands. He can see Sirius out of the corner of his eye, sitting stock still, his face drained of all expression‚Äîit reminds him eerily of Regulus.

‚ÄúYeah, ‚Äòcourse you can mate,‚Äù James says, though Remus can see him looking at Sirius too, concern creasing his brow. Which is completely unfair because if this is anybody‚Äôs fault it‚Äôs Sirius‚Äôs. With his ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt knows‚Äù and ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt handle this‚Äôs‚Äù what, is Remus just supposed to sit around and never fancy anyone again?

Suddenly, Sirius pulls himself off of Remus‚Äôs bed, not looking at him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to take a shower,‚Äù he says gruffly.

‚ÄúPadfoot?‚Äù but he ignores James, slamming the bathroom door behind him.

‚ÄúWoah,‚Äù Peter says, ‚Äúwhat was that about?‚Äù

Remus shakes his head, looking back down at the book in his hands and feeling his anger and sadness and guilt all twisting around one another. ‚ÄúNo idea.‚Äù

¬†

He isn‚Äôt able to track Marlene down until later the next day, when they‚Äôre coming back from transfiguration and he spots her alone in the common room.

‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôll catch up with guys later, okay?‚Äù he says as he starts pulling away.

James pauses, looking like he‚Äôs about to ask why when his eyes find Marlene. ‚ÄúUh‚Äîsure, yeah, okay Moons.‚Äù

Sirius doesn‚Äôt look at him. Doesn‚Äôt speak. Hasn‚Äôt all day.

Good, Remus thinks bitterly, stalking his way across the common room. Now you know how it feels.

‚ÄúHey Mar, can I talk to you for a sec?‚Äù he asks, standing awkwardly in front of her as his friends disappear up the stairs.

She looks up from the book in her lap and smiles. ‚ÄúMerlin please, anything so I can stop reading about allergy potions.‚Äù

Remus smiles weakly as he sits down next to her, palms already sweaty. He‚Äôs not exactly sure the best way to approach this‚Äîhe doesn‚Äôt want to lead Marlene on, but he also doesn‚Äôt want to give Sirius the satisfaction of knowing he lied.

‚ÄúOkay, so, I was wondering if‚Ä¶you‚Äôd wanna go to Hogsmeade with me‚Ä¶as a friend?‚Äù

She arches her brow, and Remus can tell she‚Äôs holding back a smirk. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre asking me out‚Ä¶as a friend?‚Äù

He grimaces. ‚ÄúYeah. And also maybe don‚Äôt mention the friend bit to anyone else. Like Mary. Or Sirius.‚Äù

Marlene makes an ‚Äúoh‚Äù shape with her mouth and Remus is glad that she seems to have understood something, because he is not at all confident that anything he just said made sense.

‚ÄúMary put you up to this?‚Äù she asks.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîa bit, but then also‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúAlso?‚Äù

He exhales, ‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú his voice cuts out, eyes going to the stairs. ‚ÄúJames and Peter are busy and I just can‚Äôt‚ÄîI can‚Äôt be alone with Sirius. It‚Äîwe‚Äôre‚Äî‚Äú he shakes his head, mouth helplessly opening and closing, begging Marlene to understand.

‚ÄúMerlin, Remus, I will happily go on a fake date with you if it‚Äôll get you to stop looking at me with your sad lost puppy dog eyes. Besides, it‚Äôll help me with Mary anyway.‚Äù

He sags back against the sofa. ‚ÄúOh thank God,‚Äù and then, after he‚Äôs caught his breath. ‚ÄúWhy is she so interested in finding you a date anyway?‚Äù

Marlene rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, she thinks I‚Äôm stunted or lonely or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúAre you?‚Äù

‚ÄúJeez,‚Äù she snorts. ‚ÄúRude much?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Remus says quickly. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean it to be, I‚Äôm a bit stunted and lonely myself to be honest with you.‚Äù

Marlene‚Äôs smile takes on a slightly new aspect, softer than it was before. There‚Äôs a brief pause before she speaks. ‚ÄúWell alright then, if we‚Äôre being honest, I‚Äôm a bit lonely and a bit stunted, but not in the ways she thinks. At least not exactly.‚Äù

Remus stares at her for a minute before shaking his head. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt follow?‚Äù

Marlene doesn‚Äôt look surprised by this.

‚ÄúSometimes,‚Äù she tries again, ‚Äúthe people we‚Äôre closest to, are the hardest people to be honest with. Because it feels like pulling the rug out from under them, if we turn out to be something other than what they thought. Does that make sense?‚Äù

Remus takes his time, trying to figure out the look in Marlene‚Äôs eyes. He knows that she‚Äôs saying more than the words coming out of her mouth. He‚Äôs just not entirely sure if it‚Äôs what he thinks it is.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre lonely and stunted because you‚Äôre pretending to be the person you think she thinks you are?‚Äù

‚ÄúBit of a tongue twister huh?‚Äù

Remus smiles dryly, running a hand through his hair before eventually speaking again; ‚ÄúWhat if she actually knows you better than you think?‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, well,‚Äù she walks her fingers along the spine of her book. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the problem isn‚Äôt it? We all secretly hope that the people we love really know us. So I guess I‚Äôm protecting myself as much as her. Because I‚Äôm not sure that I‚Äôm brave enough to find out that she doesn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Remus remembers how it had felt, the first time he realized that James knew he fancied Sirius. Remembers the fear, that he would lose him, that this person he had allowed himself to get so attached to would never look at him the same. Would suddenly see him as a stranger.

‚ÄúI think she‚Äôll surprise you,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúMary.‚Äù

Marlene looks up from her book, smiling sadly. ‚ÄúI hope so.‚Äù

¬†

It‚Äôs chilly out these days, the trees all changing colours, the summer completely evaporated. Remus listens to Marlene talk about Quidditch on their way down to Hogsmeade, he‚Äôs picked up enough from James and Sirius over the years that he can contribute here and there. Besides, it‚Äôs fun to hear about James‚Äôs captaincy from someone other than James himself.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs really good with the younger kids,‚Äù she says as they get a table at The Three Broomsticks. ‚ÄúI mean, I know James, I know he‚Äôs not as much of a tosser as he seems‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs debatable.‚Äù

She smirks at Remus before continuing. ‚ÄúThe way he is on the pitch though, you‚Äôd think he‚Äôd have no patience for teaching but,‚Äù she shakes her head, taking a sip of her butterbeer. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs brilliant at it.‚Äù

Remus smiles, hands closing around his own drink. ‚ÄúFun fact: James Potter is an excellent teacher, I would‚Äôve failed potions if it hadn‚Äôt for him.‚Äù

Marlene laughs. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

He nods. ‚ÄúYeah, but don‚Äôt tell Lily, she thinks it was her.‚Äù

Marlene mimes sealing her lips. ‚ÄúYour secret is safe with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Remus dips his head in a mocking bow. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all those boiling points and cutting techniques and measurements,‚Äù Remus shivers at the thought. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been shit at it, but James, well‚Ä¶his father invented Sleekeazy's Hair Potion, did you know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? No way! My brother practically lives off that stuff. I thought his dad worked for the ministry?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe does now,‚Äù Remus sips his drink. ‚ÄúI think he started once things got a little‚Ä¶dicy, politically. Came out of retirement.‚Äù

Marlene lets out a low whistle. ‚ÄúGood man, not sure you‚Äôd get me out of retirement to sort out this mess.‚Äù

Remus laughs, shaking his head. ‚ÄúYeah, no, me neither. But‚Ä¶it‚Äôs a very Potter thing to do. They‚Äôre all like that. Their capacity for empathy is a bit boundless. Makes me worry about James honestly.‚Äù

He tries and fails not to think about Regulus, about how that‚Äôs who James is with right now. He knows Sirius read him the riot act when he found out James was seeing someone in Slytherin but it doesn‚Äôt seem to have made a difference. Remus suspects that if Sirius knew which Slytherin his best mate was currently with he wouldn‚Äôt have let it go so easily. The problem is, this thing between James and Regulus, it‚Äôs going to get someone hurt. And Remus has a hunch that that someone isn‚Äôt going to be Regulus.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Marlene nudges him lightly with her foot, ‚Äúwhere‚Äôd you go?‚Äù

Remus blinks. ‚ÄúSorry, just‚Ä¶thinking.‚Äù

She squints at him, as if trying to work him out. ‚ÄúAbout James?‚Äù

He nods noncommittally, bringing his butterbeer to his mouth.

‚ÄúFunny,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI always thought it was Sirius you daydreamed about.‚Äù

The butterbeer proceeds to come straight back out, spraying across the table. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he yelps.

He can tell Marlene is holding in a laugh as she pulls out her wand and spells away the mess. ‚ÄúGuess I was right after all,‚Äù she looks at him smugly and Remus honestly has no idea what to say to that. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the eyes,‚Äù she goes on. ‚ÄúYou two are always making eyes at one another. Big ones. With hearts in the centre. It‚Äôs adorable really. Mary thinks that‚Äôs why you‚Äôre fighting by the way.‚Äù

She says it all so casually that Remus is having a hard time keeping up. ‚ÄúI‚Äîfirst of all, no we don‚Äôt. And second of all, why would Mary want me to date you if she thought‚Ä¶‚Äù

Marlene rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúRight, well, she hasn‚Äôt got it quite right. She thinks Sirius made a move on you so you kicked him out of the dorm.‚Äù

‚ÄúWHAT.‚Äù

‚ÄúMmhm,‚Äù she nods.

He doesn‚Äôt even know where to start with that. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not why we‚Äôre fighting,‚Äù is what he decides on.

She gives him a look. ‚ÄúYeah, I figured it wasn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy would she even think that Sirius would‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúThat,‚Äù Marlene tilts her glass towards him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not allowed to disclose.‚Äù

Remus can feel his breath coming too short and too fast. He doesn‚Äôt like this, people speculating about his life, people getting so close. Knowing things he never told them. It makes him feel trapped.

‚ÄúBut you didn‚Äôt tell her?‚Äù he manages finally. ‚ÄúAbout the‚Ä¶the heart eyes?‚Äù

Marlene smiles. ‚ÄúNo. I didn‚Äôt tell her. None of my business.‚Äù

Remus nods his head, trying and failing to make himself feel better about this. After a few minutes Marlene reaches across the table, squeezing his hand. ‚ÄúRemus, you don‚Äôt have to be afraid of me okay?‚Äù And when he continues to stare at her wide eyed and speechless she nods her head over her shoulder. ‚ÄúIf it makes you feel better, my secret‚Äôs standing right over there.‚Äù

It takes Remus a minute to hear what she‚Äôs said over the buzzing panic in his ears, but eventually he follows her gaze to the bar where Dorcas Meadowes is chatting with Rosmerta. Remus blinks a few times.

‚ÄúDorcas?‚Äù

Marlee nods, taking another sip of her drink.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what you‚Äôre pretending not to be for Mary?‚Äù

She nods again.

He sags back in his chair, running a hand over his still burning hot face. ‚ÄúGod,‚Äù he says, and then, before he can stop himself; ‚Äúwe must be the gayest year in Hogwarts history.‚Äù

Marlene‚Äôs face lights up and she laughs with her whole body. After a second Remus is laughing with her, both in relief and at the ridiculousness of all of it. All of them running around terrified of one another, of themselves. How exhausting. How unnecessary. He can‚Äôt help but notice Dorcas looking over at them.

‚ÄúDoes she know?‚Äù he asks quietly, once the pair of them have regained their sanity.

Marlene lets out a heavy sigh. ‚ÄúSometimes I think she does, there are these moments where I swear it sits in the room with us, you know?‚Äù

And oh boy, does Remus ever. ‚ÄúYeah, I know.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut we‚Äôve never said anything. Done anything,‚Äù she shrugs, looking down at the table.

Remus watches her for a minute before nudging her with his foot. ‚ÄúYou should go talk to her.‚Äù

For the first time he sees panic in Marlene‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúGod, I don‚Äôt know. Scarier than falling off a broom that.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, I‚Äôve seen you do it loads of times.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she laughs, ‚Äúand it was terrifying all those times.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay fine, but worth it. Wasn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

She bites her smile, sneaking a look over her shoulder. Dorcas quickly turns her attention back to Rosmerta, ‚ÄúYeah, it was worth it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo? No point sitting here on a fake date with me when you‚Äôve got something real right there.‚Äù

Marlene‚Äôs mouth pulls to the side, unconvinced as she turns her drink nervously in her hands.

‚ÄúListen,‚Äù he leans forward, ‚Äúif it helps, she hasn‚Äôt stopped looking at you the whole time I‚Äôve been watching.‚Äù

Marlene laughs, her cheeks flushing a deep red. ‚ÄúRemus Lupin, matchmaker.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh God, no one wants that.‚Äù

She smiles at him, taking in a deep breath. ‚ÄúOkay, okay, I‚Äôm going to do it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to do it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù she wipes her palms off on her jeans as she gets to her feet. ‚ÄúWish me luck?‚Äù

Remus raises his glass. ‚ÄúGood luck.‚Äù

He watches her walk across the bar, watches Dorcas‚Äôs face light up when she realizes Marlene is coming to talk to her, and he wonders why it always seems so much simpler when it‚Äôs other people? Why can he feel so confident about where Marlene and Dorcas stand after only a few minutes, but he never knows where he stands with the people in his own life? Hell, some days he isn‚Äôt even sure if Sirius likes him.

Marlene and Dorcas start heading towards the door and just before they disappear outside she looks back at him, giving him a megawatt smile and a thumbs up. He laughs a little, returning the gesture. He hopes it works out. Hopes he was right about Mary.

He passes his glass back and forth between his hands and tries to figure out what to do now. He supposes he could just go back to the dorm, it should be empty for once, maybe he‚Äôll actually be able to get some work done. Unless Peter decides to bring Rebecca up there‚Äîwhich, knowing him, he might. Remus grimaces into his butterbeer. Well, there‚Äôs always the library‚Ä¶

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs your date?‚Äù

His head snaps up and he almost laughs as his eyes meet charcoal grey. Sirius hovers at the end of his table, hands in his pockets, looking about as close to nervous as Remus has ever seen him. At least in a nonemergency situation.

‚ÄúUh, she left actually.‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúThat bad?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah‚Äîor‚Äîno, it was good, it was really nice but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúBut?‚Äù

Remus shrugs. ‚ÄúJust don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre meant to be more than mates.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Sirius says, though he doesn‚Äôt quite manage to keep the smile out of his voice. ‚ÄúIn that case, may I?‚Äù he gestures to Marlene‚Äôs empty seat, and Remus is faced with the realization that this is exactly the situation he was trying to avoid. Apparently fate has other plans.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù he nods, taking another gulp of his butterbeer just to have something to do. ‚ÄúSo, what‚Äôre you doing here?‚Äù

Sirius gives him a rueful smile. ‚ÄúOh, you know, I was‚Ä¶thirsty.‚Äù

‚ÄúThirsty?‚Äù

‚ÄúMhm,‚Äù he starts tearing up one of the napkins. ‚ÄúAlso I wanted to spy on your date. You know, make sure you were getting on okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh, you check on Peter too?‚Äù Remus asks flatly.

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù Sirius scoffs, ‚Äúobviously.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou need a hobby Pads.‚Äù

‚ÄúListen, I gotta check up on my boys alright? And good thing I did too, saved you from sitting here all alone and pathetic.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow instead I get to sit here and be insulted.‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly!‚Äù he grins at Remus who feels his chest grow tight. He tries to shake it off but he can‚Äôt get anything past Sirius. ‚ÄúMoons?‚Äú

‚ÄúSorry, I just‚Ä¶‚Äù he lets out a deep breath, staring down at the table for a minute.

‚ÄúDo you want me to go?‚Äù

He laughs humourlessly. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay‚Ä¶do you want me to stay?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Because really, that‚Äôs it, in a nutshell, how he feels about Sirius. He wants to never see him again, except that he also wants to see him every second of every day. It is endlessly frustrating.

Eventually Remus manages to force himself to speak. ‚ÄúWill you do something with me?‚Äù he makes himself hold Sirius‚Äôs stare, even if it cracks some of his ribs to do it.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Sirius says without hesitating.

He nods. ‚ÄúGood‚Äîor, thanks, I guess,‚Äù there‚Äôs an awkward pause. ‚ÄúWell, lets‚Äîer‚Äîgo then.‚Äù

He slides out of the booth and starts towards the door, Sirius jogging to catch up with him.

‚ÄúWow, you‚Äôre really on a mission huh?‚Äù he says as they push into the crisp fall air.

‚ÄúJust worried I‚Äôll lose my nerve if I stop to think about it.‚Äù

Sirius pauses for a minute, and then; ‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt.‚Äù

Remus lets out a short laugh. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt even know where we‚Äôre going.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt need to,‚Äù Sirius shrugs. ‚ÄúI know your nerves.‚Äù

Remus looks over at him, meeting Sirius‚Äôs eyes. God, he feels that look right down to his toes. He quickly goes back to staring straight ahead.

They don‚Äôt talk, which is unusual for Sirius but Remus gets the feeling that he‚Äôs trying to follow Remus‚Äôs lead and Remus is currently just trying not to be sick. He wants to get over it what happened last year, and this is the closest he‚Äôs come to figuring out how.

It takes Sirius longer than he would have thought to realize where they‚Äôre going. It speaks to the type of person he is that his steps only falter for a second.

‚ÄúAre we‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus says, the main street fading into the background behind them and the lone figure of the shrieking shack coming more fully into view. So named for the terrible screaming that comes from inside. He‚Äôs often heard the first and second years trying to guess what kind of monster makes them. On the days when he‚Äôs feeling especially bitter he thinks about telling them.

They climb through the fence, making their way silently up the front steps, unlocking the door with a simple ‚ÄúAlohomora.‚Äù Immediately Remus feels a chill run down his spine, legs locking-up on the threshold, his whole body revolting against the idea of being here.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù Sirius asks tentatively.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine,‚Äù he says, before taking a deep breath and pressing forward, he hears Sirius close the door behind them.

This building is only slightly less eerie in the daytime. The windows all boarded-up, light coming through the cracks in crisscrossing lines that cut scars in the dark. It smells heavily of rot and sweat and earth. Like the whole place is slowly decaying.

He stops in the bedroom‚Äîhis bedroom, really‚Äîstops in front of the dirty, stained mattress he dies on once a month. He can hear memories like ghosts. Can hear the sound of his bones cracking, voice breaking, thoughts falling apart. Sirius stays by the door, Remus with his back to him.

‚ÄúI told James not to come that night,‚Äù he says, slowly opening the door on memories he‚Äôs spent months trying to rip out of his head.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Sirius asks, when Remus doesn‚Äôt continue.
