‚ÄúBecause you weren‚Äôt back yet, because you‚Äôd just lost your uncle and I thought it was too much to ask you to do‚Ä¶this‚Ä¶after that. Because it seemed unfair to leave you alone.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence.

‚ÄúJames tell you to fuck off?‚Äù

Remus actually manages to laugh despite the constricting weight that‚Äôs been building in his chest since they walked through the door. ‚ÄúYeah, pretty much. Still, when you were all late I thought, I don‚Äôt know, maybe he‚Äôd changed his mind. Maybe you came back in worse shape than he‚Äôd thought.‚Äù

He can already feel the fear swelling inside him, the anxiety of that night crawling along his skin.

‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs worse alone, the full moon,‚Äù he finally manages to go on. ‚ÄúSo when I heard the door open downstairs I was‚Ä¶relieved. Selfishly,‚Äù he laughs again but this time it gets all strangled in his throat. This is where the story starts to hurt.

‚ÄúRemus‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo, please I‚ÄîI need to do this. I need you to hear this. To feel it. Because you weren‚Äôt here. Because you don‚Äôt have all these‚Ä¶memories, and I hate you for it. I can‚Äôt forgive you, for not being here. So I need you to be here now. I need you to hear it. I need you to help me fucking carry this, okay?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment of silence.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius croaks. ‚ÄúYeah Moony, okay.‚Äù

He nods, his nails digging into the palms of his hands. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll hate this, but I thought he was you at first. It was dark and his hair‚Äîso for a second, when he was walking down that hallway, I thought he was you. I thought, Sirius came. He came for me,‚Äù he has to stop again, stop himself from losing control. It seems stupid now, but at the time he had felt so happy seeing Sirius walk towards him. It made everything that came afterwards hurt so much more.

After a few minutes he goes on. ‚ÄúWhen I saw that it was Snape I thought I was in a fucking nightmare. Kept waiting for myself to wake up. He was asking me questions but I couldn‚Äôt really hear him, I was in so much pain at that point that everything was just fuzzy. I kept begging him to leave. He had his wand and I didn‚Äôt and he kept stepping closer to me so I had to back up all the way against the wall. I‚Äôve never felt so trapped before. Never felt so fucking scared.‚Äù

He‚Äôs shaking now, a cold sweat breaking out over his skin as flashes of that night rush through his head. ‚ÄúAnd then James was there and that was better and worse all at the same time. Because then there was the chance that I could hurt him too,‚Äù he closes his eyes briefly. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre different, my memories when I‚Äôm a wolf, but I do remember. I pushed them down the stairs. James and Snape. And there was blood, there was so much blood. I loved it,‚Äù his voice breaks. ‚ÄúI wanted more of it. Of the smell. The taste. I wanted more. And James was so scared, I could feel him. And I loved that too.‚Äù

It‚Äôs getting harder to keep his breathing even, small black spots flickering across his vision. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd never felt that before. Even as a wolf. Never felt the need to bite so badly. And I fucking hate that I know now, that it‚Äôs in me, that I‚Äôm capable of it. Hate that those feelings ever existed inside me. That they still exist inside me.‚Äù

He forces his fists to relax, forces himself to turn around. Sirius is still in the doorway, watching Remus, pale faced and wide-eyed.

‚ÄúI licked their blood off the floor,‚Äù his voice shakes, bile crawling up the back of his throat. Hunger stirring in his stomach. ‚ÄúGreyback might have made me a werewolf, but you, Sirius? You made me a monster.‚Äù

Sirius doesn‚Äôt flinch, doesn‚Äôt drop his gaze. ‚ÄúNo Remus,‚Äù he says, voice as earnest as Remus has ever heard it. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not the monster in this story, okay? None of that was your fault. It was mine. It‚Äôs me.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt know why he feels like fighting with him. Why some part of him violently reacts against that.

Sirius steps forward, hand reaching out, and Remus doesn‚Äôt move. Not away, not towards, letting Sirius cup his face. ‚ÄúLet me take this huh?‚Äù he says softly, eyes sad. ‚ÄúJust like you said, let me carry it. It‚Äôs mine anyway.‚Äù

Remus feels something choked at the back of his throat and he leans too much into Sirius‚Äôs touch. ‚ÄúI thought I knew how to live with this thing inside me but those memories make it so fucking hard.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not a monster Remus, not now and not when you turn.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm dangerous,‚Äù Remus pushes back, voice thick. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why we‚Äôre here, why there‚Äôs a Whomping Willow on the grounds. To protect you all from me.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo protect us from you and you from us,‚Äù his thumb strokes Remus‚Äôs cheek. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all dangerous Remus. I was dangerous when I told Snape how to find you, he was dangerous when he came in here with his wand raised. You think anyone in that castle is safe a hundred percent of the time? All of us have wolves Moony. All we can do is try and keep them on their leashes.‚Äù

Remus laughs wetly, sniffling as he looks up at Sirius. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he hears himself say, words barely there.

Sirius smiles sadly before his hand slips down from Remus‚Äôs face to his shoulder, pulling him into a hug, both of them holding on tightly, as though worried the other will disappear if they don‚Äôt.

It goes on too long.

Remus knows he should pull away.

He doesn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúWe should probably head back,‚Äù Sirius says eventually, breath brushing against Remus‚Äôs ear. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre cutting it close.‚Äù

No, Remus almost says. Not yet. I don‚Äôt want to let go yet.

But, of course, he has to.

Remus wipes at his face when they part, happy to find it dry. ‚ÄúThank you for coming with me,‚Äù he says, even though there is so much else to say.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Sirius nods, and then, a little sheepishly; ‚ÄúI‚Äôd do anything for you Remus.‚Äù

Which is a cruel thing to say in Remus‚Äôs opinion. Because it isn‚Äôt true, but he thinks that Sirius wants it to be. Wants to believe that he would do anything for Remus. Which hurts more in the end. Of course Remus doesn‚Äôt say any of that. Instead he just nods, aching as he follows Sirius back out into the sun.

¬†

If Remus and Marlene thought they were going to get away with torpedoing a date arranged by Mary Macdonald they were sorely mistaken. For the rest of the weekend it‚Äôs all Remus hears about every time he‚Äôs even remotely in her vicinity. And judging by Marlene‚Äôs tone on Sunday evening she‚Äôs had it just as bad.

‚ÄúMary, please give it a rest.‚Äù

The upper year Gryffindors have monopolized the common room, with Mary glaring at anyone who dares to try and sit on one of the sofas near them.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWe know what you‚Äôre just saying, you‚Äôve said it. I promise you, Remus didn‚Äôt ditch me to hang out with Sirius, if anything, I ditched him,‚Äù her cheeks heat slightly as she gives Dorcas a brief look and then turns away again.

Mary throws her hands up. ‚ÄúYou two are unbelievable.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo be fair, you‚Äôve never been a very good matchmaker,‚Äù Lily pipes up.

Mary‚Äôs eyes narrow. ‚ÄúExcuse me? I‚Äôm an amazing matchmaker.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemember that time you made me go out with Michael Kitchum?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry?‚Äù James sputters. ‚ÄúYou went out with Michael Kitchum? That guy‚Äôs like the biggest tool I‚Äôve ever met. And he‚Äôs not even in Slytherin.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Lily says solemnly. ‚ÄúHe was even worse than you.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù Marlene laughs. ‚ÄúI forgot about that. You didn‚Äôt talk to her for a week afterwards!‚Äù

Mary waves her hand dismissively. ‚ÄúOkay, so I made ONE miscalculation.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere was also that time when‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHOW was your date Peter?‚Äù Mary talks over Marlene who smiles in triumph, catching Remus‚Äôs eye and giving him a wink.

Peter has a dreamy look on his face. ‚ÄúIt was brilliant, she‚Äôs amazing.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw,‚Äù Dorcas says from beside Marlene. ‚ÄúCute.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to hang out again tomorrow at lunch.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù James demands. ‚ÄúPeter, mealtimes are sacred!‚Äù

‚ÄúAre they?‚Äù Remus asks.

‚ÄúFamily bonding!‚Äù James shouts, as though that makes any sense.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, you‚Äôre just making this up. This is not a thing,‚Äù he turns to Peter. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt a thing, right?‚Äù

Peter shakes his head but before he can speak James cuts across him.

‚ÄúPadfoot are you hearing this? Petey‚Äôs abandoning us at lunch of all times!‚Äù James says in mock outrage, Lily trying to hide her laughter beside him.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs so special about Lunch?‚Äù Peter demands.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs so special about lunch‚ÄîI can‚Äôt‚ÄîPa‚ÄîSirius, hello? Help me out here!‚Äù

Sirius blinks, ‚ÄúSorry?‚Äù he swipes a hand over his face before turning to James. He‚Äôs been in a weird mood since they got back from the shack.

James quirks his brow. ‚ÄúWow, you‚Äôre really spacing out over there huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, sorry, just feeling a bit‚Ä¶anyway,‚Äù he shrugs.

‚ÄúWell, while you were daydreaming Peter announced that he‚Äôs throwing us over for some floozy.‚Äù

‚ÄúHer name is Rebecca!‚Äù

Without a word Sirius reaches over and cuffs Peter on the back of the head.

‚ÄúOw, what the hell!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs your loyalty Wormtail?‚Äù Sirius demands. ‚ÄúBitches before witches.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait, hold on,‚Äù Lily says, still laughing. ‚ÄúDoes that make you three the bitches?‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù Sirius answers without hesitation.

‚ÄúSirius, darling,‚Äù Mary leans forward. ‚ÄúI feel like maybe you don‚Äôt know what that word means.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have a fairly decent grasp on the definition,‚Äù Sirius counters. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been partial to female dogs, very loyal creatures.‚Äù

And just like that the girls are giggling and James is giving Sirius a playful kick, and everything is back to normal. Except Remus can still see the tightness at the corners of Sirius‚Äôs eyes. He knows he put it there. That that was the plan. He just wonders if he can live with it now.

‚ÄúHonestly,‚Äù Peter is saying, and Remus realizes that the conversation has been going on while he‚Äôs been in his head. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm in love with her.‚Äù

James and Sirius both start booing, though they smile while they do it, James reaching over and mussing Peter‚Äôs hair, Sirius jabbing him in the stomach.

‚ÄúPeter it‚Äôs been one date,‚Äù Mary says, as the boys‚Äô chirping dies down. ‚ÄúDo try to pace yourself, or you‚Äôll scare the girl away.‚Äù

Peter‚Äôs face is bright red. ‚ÄúWell I wasn‚Äôt going to tell HER that,‚Äù he mumbles.

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù Sirius leans back against the sofa. ‚ÄúSure you weren‚Äôt. Mary‚Äôs right, you gotta play hard to get.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah, fuck these guys,‚Äù James is still laughing a little. ‚ÄúYou think you love her you tell her, she can‚Äôt handle it she‚Äôs not the girl for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúGosh James, I didn‚Äôt know you were such a romantic,‚Äù Lily says, only half-joking Remus reckons.

James looks over at her, brow arched. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, you didn‚Äôt?‚Äù Sirius concurs.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs like the biggest sap I‚Äôve ever met,‚Äù Marlene adds.

James laughs, looking over at her and bowing his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll wear that title with pride McKinnon.‚Äù

‚ÄúRomance is for optimists,‚Äù Mary declares confidently.

‚ÄúOh yeah?‚Äù Lily asks. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs for the skeptics then?‚Äù

Mary smiles. ‚ÄúSex mostly,‚Äù her eyes go to Sirius, ‚Äúisn‚Äôt that right?‚Äù

He salutes her. ‚ÄúAbsolutely.‚Äù

Remus remembers the first time he saw Mary and Sirius together, remembers the raw, all consuming jealousy that had bubbled up inside of him. Partially because she was touching him, and partially because he knew that he would never be able to fit with Sirius the way that Mary did. Never be able to look‚Ä¶right. And he suspects Sirius knows it.

That thought forms a rock in the pit of his stomach and suddenly he finds himself clearing his throat. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúas much as I love you all, I really need to go finish my Charms essay.‚Äù

A general chorus of boos emanates from the group around him.

‚ÄúAw, come on Moony!‚Äù James whines, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go, finish it tomorrow.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs due tomorrow,‚Äù he says as he gets to his feet, the whole time feeling Sirius‚Äôs eyes on him, hot and intense in a way that Remus knows he can‚Äôt look at directly or it‚Äôll take him apart.

‚ÄúRemus‚Äî‚Äú Marlene begins but Remus waves her off.

‚ÄúI know, I know, you‚Äôll all miss me terribly but I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll survive a few hours on your own.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know about that,‚Äù James says skeptically. ‚ÄúIf you go who‚Äôs going to stop Wormtail from proposing marriage to the girl he just met?‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Peter objects indignantly.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll manage.‚Äù

Sirius is still looking at him. Looking at him and not saying anything and Remus doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on but the attention is starting to make him feel jumpy.

‚ÄúAlright, well, night Remus,‚Äù Lily says.

‚ÄúYeah night.‚Äù

Remus smiles tightly before turning around, hoping that when he‚Äôs alone he‚Äôll be able to shake off this feeling, but he barely makes it to the stairs before Sirius‚Äôs voice pulls him back.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù

There‚Äôs something about the way he says it. Something desperate, that has Remus turning around right away.

Sirius is already on his feet, walking towards him.

‚ÄúWhat is it? What‚Äôs wr‚Äî‚Äú

But he doesn‚Äôt get to finish his sentence. Because Sirius‚Äôs hands take his face between them and Sirius‚Äôs mouth swallows up his voice.

For a second Remus can‚Äôt breathe. Can‚Äôt think. Certain he‚Äôs hallucinating. Except that Sirius‚Äôs touch is too warm and steady to be all in his head, his lips pressing too heavily into Remus‚Äôs own. And then he feels himself wake up, feels his body come to life, and madly, stupidly, he starts kissing Sirius back. One hand running through the hair at the nape of his neck, the other going to his lower back. Remus‚Äôs world suddenly becomes no bigger than the parts of him that Sirius‚Äôs touches. His whole life reduced to a sensation. To a single thought;

Please.

Don‚Äôt stop.

Don‚Äôt let go.

Don‚Äôt leave me again.

Please. Please. Please.

Sirius pulls back, hands dropping to clutch at Remus‚Äôs shirt, both of them breathing heavy. ‚ÄúI wanted to.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Remus asks, dazed.

Sirius‚Äôs eyes are ablaze, and Remus can‚Äôt look away. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why I kissed you. I wanted to. I want you. I know it‚Äôs been too long‚Äîthat I‚Äôve fucked up‚Äîbut I want you. I always have.‚Äù

Those words thrum through Remus, shaking his whole chest. He feels the familiar fear that‚Äôs been there every time he‚Äôs looked at Sirius since the incident last year. But it‚Äôs duller now, fighting back against all the parts of Remus that crave Sirius. That reach for him like he‚Äôs the sun.

‚ÄúHave me then,‚Äù he can barely believe the words come out of his mouth.

Sirius‚Äôs face breaks into a smile, it‚Äôs open and vulnerable and Remus wants to taste it. So he does.

‚ÄúHave me,‚Äù he whispers into Sirius‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúHave me, have me, have me.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus‚Äî‚Äú

Suddenly there‚Äôs noise‚Äîa lot of bloody noise‚Äîand both Sirius and Remus look up to find their friends on their feet‚ÄîJames is actually standing on the sofa‚Äîcheering like Gryffindor has just won the cup. The only person who looks surprised at all is Peter, but he‚Äôs clapping too, if not a little less enthusiastically.

‚ÄúThink our friends will be okay with this?‚Äù Remus mumbles, bemused.

Sirius laughs before dropping his head into the crook of Remus‚Äôs neck and that‚Äîeven that small gesture‚Äîsets fires in his chest.

‚ÄúI think they‚Äôll learn to live with it.‚Äù

Before Remus has the chance to say anything else James is off the sofa and practically tackling them both to the ground.

‚ÄúMerlin you two are idiots,‚Äù he says as the three of them stumble backwards.

‚ÄúJames‚Äîreally?‚Äù Remus laughs, trying and failing to push his friend off.

‚ÄúGroup hug!‚Äù He hears Marlene shout and then, before he has the chance to break free, he feels the weight of another five bodies collide with them, sending all of them to the floor in a tangled mess of limbs and laughter.

Somehow, in the chaos, Remus manages to find Sirius‚Äôs eyes again.

Okay? Sirius mouthes.

And Remus feels himself smiling too big, normally he would be embarrassed but he can‚Äôt find it in himself to care right at this moment, so instead he leans forward, kissing Sirius quickly on the mouth, sparks shooting through him when Sirius‚Äôs hand comes up to his neck, stopping him from pulling away.

‚ÄúPerfect,‚Äù he murmurs against the other boy‚Äôs lips. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm perfect.‚Äù

¬†

It all feels a bit like a dream. Even after everyone goes to bed. Even after Sirius sneaks over to kiss him goodnight. Even after he‚Äôs finally able to get himself to calm down enough to sleep. None of it feels real. This sort of thing‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt happen to Remus. It happens to James, maybe even Sirius, but not him. He isn‚Äôt the main character of the story.

‚ÄúMoony?‚Äù

His eyes blink open, the first cracks of morning light filtering into the room, and Sirius is on top of him, smiling, hair tussled.

‚ÄúThere you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat time is it?‚Äù Remus croaks, voice heavy with sleep.

‚ÄúEarly,‚Äù Sirius whispers. ‚ÄúJames just left for practice.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally early then. Especially for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, well,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs eyes drop down to Remus‚Äôs mouth and he feels his stomach flip. ‚ÄúI was going to go back to sleep. But then I remembered that I get to do this now,‚Äù and then he bends down, bringing their mouths together, messy and desperate and warm.

Please,

Remus almost moans out loud.

Don‚Äôt stop.

Don‚Äôt let go.

Don‚Äôt leave me again.

Please, please, please.

Because he knows deep down that this was never supposed to happen to him. He isn‚Äôt the main character of the story. But he wants it anyway.

¬†

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying,‚Äù Peter hisses, as they slide into their seats in Potions. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to start‚Ä¶doing stuff‚Ä¶in our room, you could at least use a bloody silencing charm.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh leave them alone Wormtail,‚Äù James says as he pulls out his textbook.

Peter looks mutinous. ‚ÄúEasy for you to say, you didn‚Äôt have to listen to them.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin Peter,‚Äù Sirius rolls his eyes, looking far too pleased with himself. ‚ÄúWe were only snogging.‚Äù

‚ÄúStill gross.‚Äù

Sirius pushes his chair back so that he‚Äôs balancing on its hind two legs, arms behind his head. Just under his collar Remus can see the mark he left on him this morning and a ridiculous flush rushes through his whole body. Sirius catches him looking and winks.

‚ÄúSorry Peter,‚Äù Remus says, when he‚Äôs able to make himself speak. ‚ÄúWon‚Äôt happen again.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe hell it won‚Äôt,‚Äù Sirius mutters under his breath, causing James to snort.

Remus is just about to tell them both off when he notices Professor Slughorn walking towards them.

‚ÄúMr. Lupin?‚Äù he says as he stops at their table.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîgood morning Professor,‚Äù Remus isn‚Äôt entirely sure what‚Äôs going on. ‚ÄúSorry, were we being too loud? We weren‚Äôt aware class had started yet?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, no,‚Äù the older man shakes his head. ‚ÄúProfessor McGonagall would like to speak with you in her office. She said to take your stuff and not to expect you back.‚Äù

Remus blinks. ‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

Slughorn smiles a little. ‚ÄúShe did not give me the impression that you were in trouble so there‚Äôs no need to look quite so frightened.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Remus lets out the breath he wasn‚Äôt aware he‚Äôd been holding. ‚ÄúThank you Professor.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a problem.‚Äù

Slughorn heads back to the front of the class while Remus reaches for his bag.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs this about then?‚Äù Sirius asks, chair slamming back down onto all fours. ‚ÄúYou curse someone else Moony?‚Äù he asks with a grin.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre turning into a right little bad boy aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù James adds, causing both him and Sirius to snicker.

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou heard him, I‚Äôm not in trouble. Must be something to do with Prefect duty. I‚Äôll see you guys at lunch yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúSee Peter?‚Äù James nudges Peter with his elbow. ‚ÄúLunch, that meal we have together.‚Äù

Peter rolls his eyes.

Holding in a laugh Remus turns to leave when Sirius‚Äôs foot hooks around his ankle. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt get into anymore fights on the way to her office alright? You‚Äôll break McGonagall‚Äôs heart if she thinks we‚Äôve finally corrupted you.‚Äù

‚ÄúHilarious. Can I go now?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah alright. See you later bad boy,‚Äù and then Sirius gives him a smile that makes tectonic plates shift in Remus‚Äôs chest.

All he can do in response is shake his head, blushing furiously as he ducks out of the classroom.

¬†

He‚Äôs in such a good mood that he almost forgets that he‚Äôs on his way to McGonagall‚Äôs office. He knows they still have so much to talk about, him and Sirius, so much to get past. But they will. Because Sirius wants him. He wants him. Those words sing through Remus, just like the memory of waking up this morning with Sirius‚Äôs weight on top of him.

‚ÄúCome in,‚Äù McGonagall‚Äôs voice calls out the second after he knocks. ‚ÄúClose the door behind you please.‚Äù

Remus is surprised to find her standing in front of her desk instead of sitting behind it and it pulls him up short.

‚ÄúProfessor?‚Äù he asks uncertainly. ‚ÄúProfessor Slughorn said you wanted to see me?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù there‚Äôs something in the look she gives him that isn‚Äôt quite right‚Äîit‚Äôs too soft, almost sad. ‚ÄúThough it‚Äôs your father who wants to speak with you not I.‚Äù

Remus blinks, now really lost. ‚ÄúMy father?‚Äù he repeats dumbly, looking around as though expecting him to jump out from behind some piece of furniture.

Professor McGonagall nods, gesturing to the fireplace just behind her. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll be calling any minute now,‚Äù she walks forward, hand squeezing Remus‚Äôs shoulder as she passes him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll give you two some privacy.‚Äù

‚ÄúPrivacy?‚Äù Remus repeats again as McGonagall closes the door behind her. He looks back at the office, which feels so much more ominous now that he‚Äôs in it alone.

Don‚Äôt panic, he tells himself. It can‚Äôt be that bad, not if he‚Äôs only fire-calling. If it was a real emergency he would be here. Just don‚Äôt panic. Not until you know‚Äî

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù

His father‚Äôs voice breaks him out of his thoughts.

‚ÄúHere‚ÄîI‚Äôm here,‚Äù he moves quickly, dropping down in front of the fireplace and finding his father‚Äôs flickering face staring back up at him. ‚ÄúWhat is it dad? What‚Äôs happened?‚Äù

His father looks stern, but then, he almost always does. ‚ÄúIs McGonagall there? Did she tell you anything?‚Äù

Remus shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo, she‚Äôs gone. Just said you wanted to talk to me.‚Äù And his father never wants to talk to him, not even when they‚Äôre in the same house.

Lyall lets out a heavy sigh, hand coming up to rub his forehead. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your mother,‚Äù he says finally.

Remus feels something cold run down his spine. It drips around his heart, fills his lungs.

‚ÄúWhat happened? Where is she?‚Äù

His father sighs again, dropping his hand. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs dead Remus.‚Äù

For a second, one second, he thinks his dad is joking. Not that it‚Äôs a very funny joke, and really, this is a bit of an elaborate set up. But that‚Äôs the only way his brain can make sense of what his father is saying. Because his mother isn‚Äôt dead. She just isn‚Äôt. She can‚Äôt be. There‚Äôs no reason for her to be. His father, sure, his job is dangerous, he has enemies. But his mum? All she does is live in their cottage and bake and send Remus about fifty letters a week and it‚Äôs annoying but mostly it‚Äôs sweet, because he knows she‚Äôs just doing her best. And he loves her for it. He loves her. His mum. His mad overprotective mum. He loves her and really, she‚Äôs all he has, if you think about it. So she isn‚Äôt dead.

She isn‚Äôt.

She isn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand,‚Äù he manages to say eventually, but his father is already moving on.

‚ÄúThe funeral will be Thursday, McGonagall is going to organize a Portkey so that you can come, I‚Äôll write to you with the time. She said you could come home until then but I told her no, I‚Äôm just going to be at work the whole time so I can‚Äôt see the point.‚Äù

‚ÄúDad,‚Äù he chokes out, when what he really wants to say is stop. Stop now please. You‚Äôve made your point, whatever sick point it was. I want to see her. I want to see my mum. I need to. I love her. And she isn‚Äôt dead. So. I need to see her.

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù is what makes it out of his mouth.

The silence stretches on too long.

‚ÄúThere was an accident,‚Äù his father says finally, almost grudgingly. There‚Äôs no hint of emotion in his voice, hasn‚Äôt been the whole time. He talks like this is a business meeting. Remus one of his colleagues.

‚ÄúAn accident?‚Äù

No.

She isn‚Äôt.

She isn‚Äôt.

She isn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean there was an accident?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe took too much of her medication, bloody muggle stuff. I told her not to bother with it but she insisted,‚Äù his father goes on irritably.

Remus blinks, no more equipped to deal with that information than any of the information that had come before it.

She isn‚Äôt.

The voice sounds pathetic and grasping.

She isn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt sound like an accident,‚Äù Remus says finally, which is clearly the wrong thing to say because his father‚Äôs face instantly hardens.

‚ÄúLeave it Remus.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow did she accidentally take too much of her medication dad?‚Äù

‚ÄúI told you to leave it.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was so alone in that house,‚Äù and he knows, knows he should stop, but he can‚Äôt. The words just keep coming. Words he‚Äôs meant to say forever but could never bring himself to. Was never brave enough too.

‚ÄúYou took her away from her family, her friends, you brought her into this world that doesn‚Äôt want her and then you just left her. Just left her all fucking alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúENOUGH,‚Äù his father has never raised his voice before but Remus barely hears it.

‚ÄúHow could you do that to her? How could you do that to us?‚Äù

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt make any of it better,‚Äù Lyall says finally. ‚ÄúNot you. Not her. I couldn‚Äôt fix either of you. What was I supposed to do?‚Äù

Remus stares at him and oh‚Äîoh no. He thinks he might actually start losing it now.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he curls over like he‚Äôs just been punched in the gut. Pressure building behind his eyes. ‚ÄúOh fuck, oh fuck, she‚Äôs dead. She‚Äôs dead. Fuck.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù he hears his father‚Äôs voice distantly. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the matter?‚Äù

Which is a ridiculous question given the circumstances. And he suddenly realizes how much he doesn‚Äôt want to do this here. In front of him. On the floor of McGonagall‚Äôs office. So he tries to pull his denial back around himself, cracked and chipped as it is. Tries to push this all down, just until he can get back to his room. His bed.

‚ÄúWhy did you marry her?‚Äù the question punches out of him as he raises his head to look at his father again. Because he‚Äôs always wondered. Because suddenly he just needs to know. ‚ÄúWhy did you have me?‚Äù

His father watches him for a minute, like maybe, for once, he‚Äôs actually seeing Remus. ‚ÄúI thought it would be different.‚Äù

Remus almost laughs. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he says shakily, feeling certain that any minute he‚Äôll break down into a million tiny pieces. ‚ÄúSorry we couldn‚Äôt live up to your expectations.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus‚Äî‚Äú and for the first time he almost sounds sorry.

‚ÄúGood-bye dad.‚Äù

The face flickers in front of him for a second longer before it disappears.

Remus tries to get up but doesn‚Äôt make it very far, grabbing hold of McGonagall‚Äôs desk for support.

His mum is dead.

His mum who tried so hard to take care of him. To be there. To make up for the one time that she wasn‚Äôt. Who squeezed him so tight sometimes he thought he was going to burst. He‚Äôs never going to see her again. He‚Äôs never going to touch her. Never going to hear her sing or see her cooking in the kitchen.

Remus tries to breathe, but there are just so many fucking nevers, they‚Äôre crowding his chest, filling his lungs. How is he meant to let go of all of that at once? How does he cope with losing all of her at once?

There‚Äôs a knock on the door and after a few seconds McGonagall steps in.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Remus stutters, reaching down and clumsily grabbing his bag. ‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm sure you want your office back.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, it‚Äôs more than alright, take all the time you need. I just wanted to let you know that you will not be required to attend any of your classes for the rest of the week.‚Äù

Remus nods stiffly.

‚ÄúAnd that I have also had Mr. Potter, Black and Pettigrew excused from their classes as well, though just for today. I expect by now they‚Äôll be waiting for you back at Gryffindor Tower.‚Äù

Remus looks up, meeting her kind eyes, feeling his throat grow tight. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he whispers.

‚ÄúAnything you need Remus,‚Äù it‚Äôs a shock, hearing his first name come out of her mouth. ‚ÄúYou let me know.‚Äù

He nods, moving towards the door, desperate to get out, to get to the safety of his own room, but still he pauses before he leaves.

‚ÄúReally,‚Äù he turns back to look at her. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôs ever meant anything quite so much.

She gives him a sad smile. ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

And then Remus is pushing out the door and into the corridor outside.

¬†

He doesn‚Äôt remember much of the walk back to the dorms. Mostly he keeps his head down and tries not to think. He knows that death happens, knows that people get left behind and that they find ways to move on with their lives. He just can‚Äôt quite figure out how. Because she isn‚Äôt just dead today. She‚Äôs dead tomorrow too. And the day after that. And that. And that. She will be dead every day for the rest of his life. How are you supposed to deal with loss that big?

He nearly trips up the stairs to his room, taking them two at a time, glad that everyone is still in class. When he pushes through the door he finds his three best friends waiting. James leaning against his bedpost, Sirius pacing in front of the window, Petter sitting down, legs crossed. They freeze at the sight of him. The room more quiet than Remus has ever heard it. None of the lights are on, the space lit only with the dull morning sun.

Remus can feel himself cracking already. All those thoughts he‚Äôd been pushing out rushing in. And he wonders if McGonagall told them what‚Äôs happened and feels a jolt of fear at the thought of having to tell them himself. Of having to say the words out loud because he‚Äôs not sure he can.

But then Sirius is stepping forward, pulling Remus into his arms, and he goes willingly, burying his head in Sirius‚Äôs chest. James is next, then Peter. The three of them holding him together as he slowly starts to shatter and break apart. They keep all the pieces of him, stop them from rolling away, from getting lost. Making sure his grief doesn‚Äôt do anything that can‚Äôt be undone.

In the haze of tears and choking sobs Remus discovers the answer to his own question. Because this, of course, is how people deal with loss. This is how they survive their grief.

Together.

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

I'm not gonna lie, I'm a little nervous about this chapter, just cause I feel like it does a lot (maybe too much???) but hopefully you liked it!

Thank you so much for all the comments and song recs, love it all!!

Chapter 24

Chapter Notes

TW: Religion (this is not an important plot point at all but I know it's a touchy subject for some and it is referenced a couple times in this chapter so I'm throwing this out there)

ALSO, I realize no one cares but this chapter definitely has a soundtrack and it is: Oh Lightning by Valley Maker, it was on repeat the entire time I wrote this so if you want the vibes it's that.

ALSO ALSO there is Jegulus in this chapter, I know it feels like there won't be but there is I promise (I missed them too)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I: REMUS

The day of his mother‚Äôs funeral Remus walks into the dorm room to find his three best friends dressed in black suits. He stops in front of the door, staring at them, his own suit heavy on his skin. They‚Äôre well into fall but the fabric somehow still manages to feel suffocating.

‚ÄúWhere did you get those?‚Äù he asks eventually, having to clear his throat to get the words out.

‚ÄúHave a little faith Moony,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúWe know how to buy Muggle clothes.‚Äù

‚ÄúLily got them for us,‚Äù Peter says, earning him an elbow to the ribs.

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúShe got you three perfectly tailored suits?‚Äù he tries not to let his eyes linger on Sirius, on the way the clothes hug his chest and thighs.

‚ÄúShe used magic for the tailoring,‚Äù James admits. ‚ÄúBut‚Äîuh‚Äîwe couldn‚Äôt figure out the‚Äîuh‚Äîlong cravat things,‚Äù he tugs on his collar.

Remus blinks, and then; ‚ÄúTies you mean?‚Äù realizing suddenly that not one of them is wearing a tie, making them look rather more like some sort of rock band than funeral guests. He almost smiles.

‚ÄúLily didn‚Äôt know how to tie them and we couldn‚Äôt find a spell,‚Äù he shuffles his feet. ‚ÄúIs that okay? Or do we need to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Remus croaks. ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs fine. It suits you,‚Äù he blinks a few times, getting the moisture out of his eyes. ‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre coming then?‚Äù

James looks taken aback by the question but it‚Äôs Sirius who speaks first.

‚ÄúDo you want us there?‚Äù

Remus meets his eyes for the first time. His beautiful eyes, on his beautiful face, wearing his beautiful suit. It‚Äôs too much really.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says softly.

‚ÄúThen we‚Äôll be there.‚Äù

He thinks about kissing him. Doesn‚Äôt. But he doesn‚Äôt look away either, desperate to suck the calm confidence out of Sirius‚Äôs stare, to steal it for himself.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù James says eventually, ‚Äúwe should get going, we have to be in Hogsmeade by half-past nine for the Portkey.‚Äù

Remus shakes himself awake. ‚ÄúRight, yeah, um‚Äîthank you‚Ä¶for‚Ä¶coming.‚Äù

James‚Äôs face softens as he walks forward, hand squeezing Remus‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to thank us. This is what we‚Äôre here for.‚Äù

They make their way out of the room, James and Peter up front, Sirius and Remus behind, walking close enough that their shoulders brush.

When they get to the common room Remus is pulled up short for the second time that morning, Sirius landing on the stair just below him, looking up.

‚ÄúWow, fantastic job with the suits,‚Äù Mary says impressed, eyes running the boys over.

Mary, Marlene and Lily are standing in the middle of the common room, each dressed in black and looking very much like they‚Äôve been waiting for them.

Remus opens his mouth but nothing comes out except a shaky exhale. After a few more of those Sirius reaches up, squeezing his hand until Remus is able to tear his eyes away from his friends and down to his‚Äîwell‚Äîdown to Sirius.

‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù Sirius asks.

Remus almost laughs. Almost cries. Finally he manages a nod.

‚ÄúWell alright then,‚Äù Mary‚Äôs voice cuts through the quiet room. ‚ÄúLets get this show on the road shall we?‚Äù

‚ÄúMcGonagall okay with this?‚Äù Remus finds himself asking as they make their way out of the common room and towards the front of the castle.

Marlene snorts. ‚ÄúLike Lily gave her a choice.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs eyes find Lily a few paces ahead and he feels his throat grow tight. He isn‚Äôt sure what he was expecting his friends to do, they hadn‚Äôt talked about it, but he never could have asked them for this. It‚Äôs too much really.
As if reading his mind Sirius leans a little heavier against Remus‚Äôs side, just to let him know that he‚Äôs there. They‚Äôre out to their friends but here in the halls it‚Äôs easier to be a little more‚Ä¶discrete.

It‚Äôs overcast today, the way it gets in the fall, making everything feel deep and saturated, the air cold. They walk down to the village in silence, Remus isn‚Äôt sure if that‚Äôs his fault or not but either way he hasn‚Äôt got the energy to rectify the situation. Honestly he kind of likes it, just listening to the sounds of their footsteps next his.

The Portkey is set up outside the post office, owls flying out overhead as they gather around the old satchel that McGonagall told them to look for.

‚ÄúIs your father meeting us here or at the funeral home?‚Äù Lily asks gently.

Remus clears his throat. ‚ÄúHis letter said here,‚Äù Lily nods, though he doesn‚Äôt miss the look she exchanges with Marlene. The Portkey is set to leave in fifteen minutes. Lyall is late. Not that that‚Äôs all that surprising. He usually is.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never been to a Muggle funeral before,‚Äù Peter says suddenly, voice sounding overly loud in the silence.

‚ÄúWhat? I‚Äôm shocked,‚Äù Sirius drawls, earning him a shove from Peter.

‚ÄúBoys,‚Äù James does his best impression of his mother, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt make me separate you.‚Äù

Sirius smirks.

‚ÄúI was just wondering if they were a lot different from wizard ones that‚Äôs all‚Äîlike, I don‚Äôt know, what do you do with Muggles?‚Äù Peter turns to Remus who shakes his head.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never been to one either. Never been to any funeral.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou do know that muggles aren‚Äôt another species, don‚Äôt you Peter?‚Äù Mary asks, her tone a bit sharper than perhaps is warranted. Pete didn‚Äôt mean anything by it, but then, he also doesn‚Äôt have to walk down the halls listening to the Slytherins whisper ‚Äúmudblood‚Äù under their breath.

Peter‚Äôs cheeks flush pink. ‚ÄúNo‚ÄîI know, of course, I just meant‚Ä¶I always feel a little uncomfortable around them. I never know what to say or‚Äî‚Äú he cuts himself off, realizing that none of this is making the situation better.

‚ÄúJust be polite Peter,‚Äù Lily says eventually, sending him a weak smile. ‚ÄúLet them talk to you about her. People like to tell stories at these things, it helps.‚Äù

Peter nods, perhaps a bit too enthusiastically. ‚ÄúThanks‚Äîyeah, er, I can do that.‚Äù

It‚Äôs at that moment that a translucent hawk sweeps down on them, startling a yelp out of Marlene as it lands. It looks vaguely like a ghost and had Remus not seen it a dozen times before he might have been scared. Still, as it is, his stomach drops.

‚ÄúHeld up at work,‚Äù his father‚Äôs voice booms from its beak. ‚ÄúGo without me.‚Äù

Remus blinks down at the bird, not quite able to accept what he‚Äôs just heard. Waiting for the second half of the message. The ‚Äúha, ha, just joking son, I‚Äôll be there in ten.‚Äù Of course, that doesn‚Äôt happen. And after a few seconds of silence the Patronus dissolves into nothing but white vapour.

Go without me.

His father does not know that Remus‚Äôs friends have volunteered to come with him. As far as Lyall Lupin is aware, his son is completely alone.

Go without me.

Remus‚Äôs chest suddenly feels uncomfortably tight.

‚ÄúBastard,‚Äù Sirius hisses beside him.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs scared of them,‚Äù Remus is impressed by how steady his voice sounds, eyes still trained on the spot where the hawk disappeared.

‚ÄúScared of who?‚Äù Lily asks.

‚ÄúHer family.‚Äù

Sirius scoffs. ‚ÄúThan he‚Äôs a coward and a bastard.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù James admonishes.

‚ÄúNo it‚Äôs alright,‚Äù Remus finally forces himself to look up, meeting Sirius‚Äôs gaze. ‚ÄúSomeone should hate him.‚Äù And it can‚Äôt be me, he doesn‚Äôt say. Because he‚Äôs my dad. Because he‚Äôs the only home I have left.

Sirius gives Remus a small smile, leaning into his side again as the satchel begins to light up in front of them. Remus takes a deep breath.

‚ÄúLets get this over with yeah?‚Äù

There‚Äôs general nodding around the circle as they all step forward and place their hands on the bag, Sirius on one side of Remus and James on the other, like two pillars, holding him up.

If he‚Äôs being honest, all forms of wizard transport make Remus feel a bit sick. Flooing. Flying. Portkeys. He hasn‚Äôt apparated yet but he‚Äôs sure he‚Äôll feel the same about that. When his feet slam into the pavement of the London suburb he feels the entire contents of his stomach enter his esophagus.

‚ÄúSteady on,‚Äù Sirius whispers beside him, one hand on his hip, the other on his shoulder. Remus can‚Äôt tell if his hands feel so good because this is new or because it‚Äôs old. Sirius has never been stingy with his touches. With affection in general, at least not in superficial ways like this. Peter once suggested it was because he wasn‚Äôt hugged enough as a kid and James shoved him off the bed.

‚ÄúYou know where we‚Äôre going?‚Äù James asks now, Remus blinking up at him through the haze of his memories.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus had been looking up the funeral home on the city map every hour since his father wrote to him with the time and place. In theory he shouldn‚Äôt have needed to, in theory his father should have been here to guide him there himself, but then, maybe some subconscious part of Remus had always known that that was never going to happen.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus repeats, voice a little stronger this time. ‚ÄúI know where we‚Äôre going.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a surreal experience, walking through the Muggle suburb with his friends. They feel so loud even though they barely speak. Like every person they pass, every house, knows they don‚Äôt belong.

Don‚Äôt you belong?

Asks the voice in his head. He isn‚Äôt James after all, isn‚Äôt Sirius. He‚Äôs just as much Muggle as he is Wizard. Except it doesn‚Äôt feel that way. He barely knows the Muggle part of himself.

His feet stutter as the funeral home comes into view‚Äîan unassuming building, made of redbrick and wood doors, a manicured garden in front, a parking lot full of cars he doesn‚Äôt recognize wrapping around the back. His friends stop behind him.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do this,‚Äù the words are out of his mouth before he can stop himself.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to,‚Äù James says, at the same time that Sirius says; ‚ÄúYes, you can.‚Äù

Remus lets out a dry laugh, because doesn‚Äôt that just sum the two of them up? James always so willing to shield you, Sirius always so willing to put the sword in your hands. He finds himself turning to Peter, who stands with an uncertain look on his face, hands in his pockets.

‚ÄúWhat do you think Pete?‚Äù

Peter‚Äôs eyes widen slightly at being asked, looking from James to Sirius and then back to Remus. ‚ÄúI think whatever you want to do is what your mum would want you to do.‚Äù Which is both sweet and unhelpful but that‚Äôs Peter for you.

Remus stares down the building in front of him, wishing he was somewhere else. Wishing he was someone else. It‚Äôs not a new dream.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says eventually, forcing himself to relax, to breathe. ‚ÄúOkay. Lets go in.‚Äù

Sirius squeezes his shoulder, Lily coming up beside him and taking his hand. He looks at both of them before letting out another shuddering exhale and stepping forward.

The inside of the building is beige. Beige carpet, beige wallpaper, beige furniture. It smells vaguely of rose potpourri and egg sandwiches and Remus almost immediately wants to turn around and head back out. He doesn‚Äôt belong here. He‚Äôs not entirely sure where he does belong but it‚Äôs definitely not here, not in this room where it feels like you can‚Äôt touch anything, full of people he doesn‚Äôt know.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù

He looks up and sees his aunt Mariam walking towards him, he hasn‚Äôt seen her in years but when he was little she used to visit in the summer with her two kids and her husband. He never noticed before how much she looks like his mother. He squeezes Lily‚Äôs hand and she squeezes back.

‚ÄúOh honey it‚Äôs good to see you, I was beginning to worry you‚Äôd gotten lost,‚Äù she pulls him into a hug that‚Äôs too tight, but he doesn‚Äôt bother fighting it. Eventually she pulls back, hands still resting on his shoulders. Her eyes are sad, red rimmed, clearly she‚Äôs been crying. Remus doesn‚Äôt know what he looks like. He hasn‚Äôt cried since the day he found out.

After a few seconds she starts scanning the small crowd around him. ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs your father?‚Äù she doesn‚Äôt quite manage to keep the bitterness out of her voice.

Remus clears his throat. ‚ÄúHe‚Äîuh‚Äîhe got held up at work.‚Äù He hates his father for not giving him a better excuse.

Her gaze comes back to him. ‚ÄúHeld up at work?‚Äù she repeats. ‚ÄúThey couldn‚Äôt let him go for his wife‚Äôs funeral?‚Äù

Remus shrugs helplessly and he sees her expression soften again.

‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶nothing to be done about it I suppose,‚Äù she pulls him forward, kissing the top of his head, all rather familiar for a woman he hasn‚Äôt seen since he was nine. ‚ÄúCome on, the family‚Äôs waiting in the room just over here, the ceremony will start in a few minutes. Your friends can go take their seats,‚Äù she smiles weakly at them over Remus‚Äôs shoulder, her eyes pausing on Lily. ‚ÄúUnless your girlfriend wants to come with you? Sarah might make a fuss, but she always does.‚Äù

For a second Remus considers going along with it just so he won‚Äôt have to be alone. A second too long apparently, because he feels Sirius go stiff.

‚ÄúUm,‚Äù Lily says awkwardly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not his girlfriend.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù his aunt laughs. ‚ÄúSorry I just thought‚Ä¶‚Äù she looks down at Lily‚Äôs hand, the one Remus has been clinging to for dear life since they first walked in. ‚ÄúWell, anyway, you can all go in, Remus will join you at the reception afterwards.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you sure I can‚Äôt sit with them?‚Äù Remus says, the collar of his shirt suddenly feeling too tight.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be silly Remus, you‚Äôre her son,‚Äù as though that means anything anymore. ‚ÄúBesides, you have to be up at the front with us to give your speech.‚Äù

Ah.

Right.

That.

Part of him had been hoping they‚Äôd forget about the speech. The parchment in his pocket feeling like an anchor, dragging him below the tide.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he manages finally.

There‚Äôs a beat of silence.

‚ÄúOkay well, we‚Äôll see you soon yeah?‚Äù James says, squeezing Remus‚Äôs shoulder as he passes, Peter following closely behind, sparing Remus a sympathetic smile.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll be alright,‚Äù Lily whispers, giving him a quick kiss on the cheek.

‚ÄúWhat she said,‚Äù Mary kisses him too before following after Lily, Marlene at her side.

Sirius drags behind, eyes flicking up to Remus‚Äôs aunt who‚Äôs still hovering behind him, a friendly smile on her face. Eventually, after giving up hope that she‚Äôd get the hint and give them some space, he reaches out and circles Remus‚Äôs wrist with his fingers.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm right here okay?‚Äù he whispers.

Remus nods. ‚ÄúYeah okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can do this Remus,‚Äù he leans in so close their foreheads are almost touching and Remus closes his eyes briefly, breathing in the familiar scent of him.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Remus repeats.

And then Sirius is pulling away, disappearing through the doors into the chapel.

‚ÄúYour friends seem lovely,‚Äù his aunt says as he turns to face her.

He tries and fails to smile back. ‚ÄúThey are.‚Äù

She guides him down a short hallway filled with generic paintings of landscapes and still life's. Everything about this place makes his skin itch. It‚Äôs too‚Ä¶soft. Coddling. As though muted colours and perfume will take away the sting of losing his mother. Besides, Remus has never been good at soft. He‚Äôs all claws and teeth and scars.

‚ÄúHere we are,‚Äù Mariam says as she opens a wood panelled door.

The room inside is no better than the rest of the building, worse maybe, if you take into consideration the dozen or so people dressed in black who all turn towards the door as they enter. He feels himself freeze, Mariam‚Äôs hand coming down on his shoulder and giving it a squeeze.

‚ÄúEveryone, this is Remus,‚Äù she says, as cheerily as she can manage.

He‚Äôs seen some of these faces before‚ÄîMariam‚Äôs children, his grandmother, his aunt Sarah‚Äîbut the rest of them are strangers.

Jesus, he thinks, looking around the room. Are these people supposed to be my family?

Mariam gives him a light shove into the room.

‚ÄúNot long now until the ceremony, just make yourself comfortable okay honey?‚Äù

He watches her walk over to a man he assumes is her husband, though he doesn‚Äôt recognize him. He swallows, straightening out his jacket and looking back at the room of somber faces, spotting a coffee cart against the far wall. Not that he drinks coffee but at least it‚Äôll give him something to do with his hands. He wonders if Sirius brought a flask with him. It seems like something he would do and Remus could use a shot of firewhiskey right about now.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck happened to his face?‚Äù he hears someone‚Äîone of his cousins he thinks‚Äîwhisper as he walks past.

He tries not to let it bother him. He knows what he looks like after all. Knows it‚Äôs shocking to people who haven‚Äôt seen him before. Over the years he‚Äôs gotten used to it, but his mum never did. She hated it when people would point them out‚Äîhated answering questions, being reminded of where the marks came from. Maybe that‚Äôs why it stings so much right now.

His hands shake as he reaches for one of the coffee mugs.

‚ÄúLyall not showing up then?‚Äù

Remus jumps, looking over to find his aunt Sarah standing beside him. If Mariam is warm and kind, Sarah is cold and harsh. She‚Äôs the oldest sister, with a long thin face and dark hair. You‚Äôd never know she was related to his mother, except for her eyes‚Äîit‚Äôs almost unnerving how similar they are.

‚ÄúUm‚Ä¶no, he got held up at work.‚Äù

Sarah scoffs. ‚ÄúSeems to happen to him a lot.‚Äù

Remus does his best not to grimace. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

They stand in silence for a minute, Remus playing nervously with the mug in his hands, trying to signal to Mariam to come rescue him. All the while Sarah looks him up and down with his dead mother‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúHonestly, I wasn‚Äôt expecting him to come,‚Äù she goes on eventually, pulling his gaze back to her. ‚ÄúAlways was a bloody coward. Never faced up to anything.‚Äù

Remus wants to feel indignant, but, well, she isn‚Äôt exactly wrong, is she?

‚ÄúBut then, I wasn‚Äôt expecting to see you either.‚Äù

That takes him by surprise. ‚ÄúMe?‚Äù he asks. And then, stupidly; ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs my mum.‚Äù

‚ÄúWas,‚Äù the word is sharp, meant to hurt. And it does.

Remus only just manages not to whine like an injured animal. ‚ÄúWas my mum,‚Äù he corrects himself.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve always been more his than her‚Äôs,‚Äù Sarah goes on unfairly. Remus isn‚Äôt sure that would have been a compliment coming from anyone but it certainly isn‚Äôt one coming from Sarah. ‚ÄúI could have saved her you know,‚Äù she goes on disdainfully. ‚ÄúI tried to save her. We were so close when we were kids‚Äîwe were close until the day that psychopath walked into her life. Shut her away in that house in the middle of nowhere. Sucked the life out of her.‚Äù

Remus puts his mug back down on the table, certain that if he doesn‚Äôt he‚Äôll end up smashing it on something.

‚ÄúI would have gotten her away from him eventually. I would have made her see sense. I think Lyall knew that,‚Äù she practically spits on the ground when she says his name, and through his own grief Remus can just make out the tremor in her voice, the way her nails are digging into her arm, the wetness at the corners of her eyes.

‚ÄúSo he knocked her up with you,‚Äù Sarah goes on bitterly. ‚ÄúThere was nothing any of us could do after that.‚Äù

Without thinking Remus reaches out and grabs hold of the table next to him, holding himself steady. The air suddenly feels too thin, the walls too close, too many people, too many strangers who know too much about him.

He‚Äôs saved from having to come up with some sort of response by the sound of the door opening, everyone turning as the Pastor enters the room in his black robes. Sarah gives him one last cold look before pulling away.

Remus wonders, as he struggles to get his breathing under control, if that made her feel better.

He hopes that it did.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to see you all, though unfortunate that it should be under such tragic circumstances,‚Äù the Pastor‚Äîan older gentleman with thinning grey hair and a kind face‚Äîgathers everyone around him. Well, everyone but Remus who is still currently clinging to the coffee table. ‚ÄúThe ceremony is ready to begin, so once we finish talking I‚Äôll lead you all into the chapel, the first two rows of seats have been reserved for the family. We‚Äôll watch the slideshow put together by Hope‚Äôs sisters, and then have her husband and son come up to say a few words,‚Äù his eyes bounce around the room, looking, no doubt, for the men in question.

‚ÄúJust son,‚Äù Remus forces himself to say, letting go of the table and standing up straight, his skin feeling clammy and too hot. A few people step back so that the Pastor can find him.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry?‚Äù the old man asks.

Remus swallows. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just her son. It‚Äôs just me.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù thankfully, he doesn‚Äôt seem to feel the need to ask anymore questions. ‚ÄúNo problem. No problem at all. Now, are we ready?‚Äù

There is a general chorus of solemn ‚Äúyeses‚Äù and head nodding.

‚ÄúAlright then, if you‚Äôll all follow me‚Ä¶‚Äù

He leads them back into the hallway, Remus trailing as far behind as he can, keeping his eyes on the floor and off of the faces of his mother‚Äôs family. He wonders, absentmindedly, if he‚Äôs leaving dirty footprints all over the pale carpet. He hadn‚Äôt even thought to wash his shoes and it would be so like him, to scar the funeral home.

‚ÄúOh thank Merlin‚ÄîRemus,‚Äù he hears as he enters the lobby, looking up at the sound of his name to find Alice and Frank standing by the front door.

He stops dead in his tracks, everyone ahead of him filing through the wooden doors into the chapel.

Alice rushes forward, instantly wrapping him in a hug that feels infinitely better than the one he‚Äôd received from Mariam.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äîhow are you here?‚Äù he stutters, slightly in shock as Alice pulls back.

‚ÄúMary gave us directions since she lives around here,‚Äù Alice explains, Remus had forgotten that Mary‚Äôs house was nearby, ‚ÄúSorry we‚Äôre late, we took the day off but Moody still had us doing paperwork this morning,‚Äù she rolls her eyes, Remus still struggling to wrap his mind around the fact that they‚Äôre standing in front of him.

‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre‚Äîbut the Aurors, I thought‚ÄîI thought you didn‚Äôt get days off?‚Äù he stammers.

Frank shrugs. ‚ÄúFamily emergency.‚Äù

Family emergency.

Those words lodge themselves somewhere in Remus‚Äôs throat. The way Frank says them so casually, like it‚Äôs obvious.

Family emergency.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù Alice asks, eyes soft as she reaches out and squeezes his arm gently.

He shakes his head, trying to get a grip on himself. Everything about this day has been surreal, honestly.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he manages finally, voice choked as his eyes move from Alice to Frank, trying to make them understand how much this means, knowing that he can‚Äôt possibly.

‚ÄúOh babe,‚Äù Alice pulls him in for another hug and Remus lets her, lets himself lean on her for a minute, soaking up her strength.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù

He pulls away, looking over his shoulder to see his aunt Mariam in the chapel doorway.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre about to start,‚Äù she whispers.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Remus looks back at his friends, reluctant to leave them. ‚ÄúI‚Äîer‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGo on,‚Äù Alice gives his arm another good squeeze.

Frank smiles sadly at him. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be in there.‚Äù

Remus nods, turning away to follow his aunt into the next room, feeling his heart ache as he does.

‚ÄúCertainly are popular aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù Mariam says quietly, the pair of them walking down the aisle, pews on either side of them. Her voice is kind.

‚ÄúNot really,‚Äù Remus looks back over his shoulder as Alice and Frank slip in and take their seats in the back row, ‚Äújust‚Ä¶lucky.‚Äù

They slide into the front pew, Remus thankfully on the end so the only person he has to sit next to is Mariam. Part of him wants to know why she‚Äôs so nice to him, why she still came around when none of the rest of his mum‚Äôs family did. He‚Äôs not sure why he never asked before. Why he never asked his mum anything about her family before.

You took her for granted, whispers the nasty voice in his head. You thought she would always be there. Thought she belonged to you. Existed for you.

He clenches his teeth, trying to focus on the Pastor instead of his spiralling thoughts.

‚Äú‚Äîwas a warm, compassionate and vibrant woman who always went out of her way to help others‚Äîno matter what,‚Äù the old man is saying.

The problem is, Remus had taken his mother for granted. She‚Äôd made him her whole life and it had never occurred to him that before he was born, before the accident with Greyback, all that time she spent worrying about him she had filled with something else. With someone else.

‚ÄúO Divine Master,‚Äù the Pastor goes on, ‚ÄúGrant that I may not so much seek to be consoled as to console; To be understood as to understand; to be loved, as to love; For it is in giving that we receive; It is in pardoning that we are pardoned; And it is in dying that we are born to eternal life.‚Äù

Was his mother religious? He‚Äôd never seen her pray, never been made to say grace at the table‚Äînot that his father would have allowed it. Far too Muggle. Had she gone to church every Sunday when she was a kid? Did she believe in heaven? Did Remus? He didn‚Äôt think so, but then, he‚Äôd never given it much thought.

The lights dim as a white projector screen is pulled down at the front of the chapel and suddenly his mother‚Äôs face appears‚Äîyounger and happier than Remus had ever seen it. Some song he doesn‚Äôt recognize plays in the background.

His mother has a bob with bangs, she has freckles on her cheeks that are squished up against her sister‚Äôs face, her front tooth is missing. He barely recognizes her.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he hears Mariam coo beside him, looking over to find her face streaked with tears. He wonders what she‚Äôs thinking about, what memories she has of his mum. All the stories he hasn‚Äôt heard. And suddenly he has a horrible sinking feeling that everyone knew his mother better than he did.

The pictures fade into one another, his mother slowly growing older‚Äîa teenager in floral dresses, her hair down to her waist. A university student at a Christmas party covered in tinsel. Walking across a stage in a cap and gown, holding a diploma proudly in front of her. Remus has no idea what she studied. He never asked.

In all these photos his mother is smiling, face free of the nervous cracks that he‚Äôd grown so used to, the ones that never really went away no matter how genuinely happy she seemed. The woman in these photos is beaming. She‚Äôs light.

The final photo is of his parents on their wedding day. His father is wearing wizard dress robes but they‚Äôre black and white so they could easily be explained away as some new suit style‚Äîor so Remus expects. His mother looks like a painting‚Äîhair braided, dress covered in lace, blooming out around her like she‚Äôs in the centre of a cloud. His father peers at the Muggle camera uncertainly, but his mother is still smiling. Remus wonders if that was the last time she would be that happy. That carefree.

The lights slowly come up again, an older woman hobbling onto the stage behind the Pastor and pulling on the screen several times before she‚Äôs able to send it zipping back up into the ceiling.

‚ÄúWell that was certainly beautiful. What a lovely soul,‚Äù the old man says, looking out at the tear stained audience. ‚ÄúAnd now, we will be hearing a few words from her son, Remus John Lupin.‚Äù

Oh.

Remus‚Äôs heart drops into the pit of his stomach as he feels all the eyes in the room fall on him. He‚Äôs never wanted to be able to apparate so badly in his entire life.

On shaking legs he rises to his feet, stumbling up to the lectern where the Pastor gives him a fatherly pat on the back before shuffling off to the side, leaving Remus to face the room alone. His throat feels tight, the air suddenly too dry as he reaches into his pocket and smooths out the parchment he‚Äôs been clutching all day.

‚ÄúUm‚Äî‚Äú he starts, the faces in the seats in front of him going blurry, he clears his throat, rubbing at his eyes, but it doesn‚Äôt help. His whole body suddenly feels like it‚Äôs blurring, something left out in the rain, all his colours running together.

How is he meant to talk about his mum when he didn‚Äôt even know her? When he‚Äôd never tried to? Something starts scratching at the inside of his skin and he brings his hand up to the base of his throat to keep the sobs from being able to escape. He just needs another chance‚Äîto speak to her, to listen, to let her tell him all the stories he never asked about. Never made her feel important enough to share.

He‚Äôs been standing up here silent for too long, he tries to open his mouth again but quickly shuts it, afraid of what might come out. He should have told them this was a terrible idea‚Äîhe doesn‚Äôt give speeches, doesn‚Äôt cut himself open in front of crowds of strangers. I mean, God, he can barely open up to the people he trusts.

He grips the lectern like it‚Äôs the last life raft in the middle of the ocean, forcing himself to look at the page in front of him. To say something.

Then, in the distance, he sees someone get up. Three someone‚Äôs, actually. Silently, James, Sirius and Peter make their way down the aisle, like it‚Äôs the most natural thing in the world. Not one of them looks uncertain, or like they aren‚Äôt sure whether or not it‚Äôs allowed, and Remus watches them. Desperate.

The minute they‚Äôre close enough Sirius‚Äôs hand finds his lower back, James‚Äôs on his shoulder, Peter‚Äôs circling his wrist, the three of them crowding around him. Remus feels himself sag into their touches. Into the warmth of their bodies. The comfort of it.

Home, he thinks.

This is home.

They don‚Äôt speak. They don‚Äôt need to.

With a shaking inhale he looks back down at the page in front of him, words slowly coming into focus. Remus swears he‚Äôll never love anyone or anything as much as he loves the three boys currently holding him up.

‚ÄúMy mum,‚Äù he hears himself say finally, words filling up the room, ‚Äúliked to sing Billie Holiday when she baked.‚Äù

¬†

The reception is in a small room connected to the chapel. The coffin is in there. His mum. His mum‚Äôs coffin. Remus doesn‚Äôt look at it. Instead he looks at the dozen or so tiny triangle sandwiches on black plastic trays.

‚ÄúDamn,‚Äù he hears James whisper across from him, Remus looks up as his friend runs a flustered hand through his hair. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know this many sandwiches existed. Are sandwiches some kind of a major food group for Muggles I wasn‚Äôt aware of?‚Äù

Remus snorts.

‚ÄúExcept they don‚Äôt have peanut butter and jelly,‚Äù Peter says morosely, picking up a ham sandwich and glaring down at it.

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù James‚Äôs eyes start scanning the table in front of him. ‚ÄúSeems like an oversight on their part.‚Äù

‚ÄúHonestly, it‚Äôs the best one.‚Äù

‚ÄúAgreed.‚Äù

Marlene, who is currently standing next to Peter, rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúYou two are idiots.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù

Remus smiles despite himself, not really paying attention to the food he‚Äôs putting on his plate, he doesn‚Äôt expect he‚Äôll be eating any of it, he just wants something to do with his hands.

Sirius gives him a nudge with his elbow as they move away from the table, leaving James and Peter to bicker about what the perfect ratio of jelly to peanut butter is.

‚ÄúYou doing okay?‚Äù Sirius asks quietly, leaning against the wall next to him. People mill about around them, making small talk, the constant hum of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry for your loss‚Äù filling the room. Remus hates that phrase; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry for your loss.‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt mean anything. Doesn‚Äôt make anything hurt less.

‚ÄúHey?‚Äù Sirius nudges his foot.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Remus blinks, eyes going to the coffin behind them and then instantly down to the floor. He‚Äôs not sure if he feels like crying or laughing. ‚ÄúIs this supposed to help?‚Äù he asks eventually.

‚ÄúIs what supposed to help?‚Äù

‚ÄúBeing here. Doing this. Is it supposed to help? Because I don‚Äôt feel any better‚ÄîI don‚Äôt feel like I have closure or whatever the fuck this is supposed to be. It‚Äôs just‚Äî‚Äù he shakes his head, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like I‚Äôm being crushed by something. By the weight of this.‚Äù

Sirius is silent for a moment. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think anything helps,‚Äù he says eventually, causing Remus to look up. Sirius is watching him, eyes full, overflowing, but with what Remus can‚Äôt tell. Something like affection but‚Ä¶more. ‚ÄúThis is a big hurt Moony.‚Äù

Remus laughs at that. ‚ÄúA big hurt,‚Äù he repeats, scrubbing at his eyes with the hand that isn‚Äôt currently holding a paper plate full of food he doesn‚Äôt want to eat. ‚ÄúThat sounds about right.‚Äù

‚ÄúStuff like this‚Ä¶‚Äù Sirius shrugs, hands slipping into his pockets. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt get fixed. Doesn‚Äôt get‚Ä¶put down, not for a long time. You just learn how to carry it.‚Äù

Remus looks at him for a minute before shaking his head. ‚ÄúJesus, Sirius Black when did you get so wise?‚Äù

That brings a smile to Sirius‚Äôs face that brightens the whole room. ‚ÄúOh I‚Äôm sorry, I thought you knew, I‚Äôm kind of a genius.‚Äù

Remus snorts. ‚ÄúDumbledore better watch out.‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft, that old hack? He ain‚Äôt got nothing on me.‚Äù

And suddenly Remus feels the desperate need to be closer to him, to wrap himself in Sirius‚Äôs smell and his warmth and his weight. He can‚Äôt, of course, not here in some Muggle suburb surrounded my his mother‚Äôs potentially religious family who already hate him. So instead he settles for pushing his foot into Sirius‚Äôs.

‚ÄúThanks for coming, for doing this, I know it‚Äôs‚Ä¶not the most convenient thing.‚Äù

Sirius gives him a weird look. ‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù he tilts his head a little closer. ‚ÄúIt wouldn‚Äôt matter if her funeral was on the top of bloody Mount Everest, we would still be here.‚Äù

Why? Remus almost asks‚Äîhas been dying to ask everyone all day. Why are you here? It‚Äôs how he‚Äôd felt first year too, when James and Sirius started sitting with him at meals even when they didn‚Äôt go down to the Great Hall together. When they‚Äôd include him in their conversations out of the blue. Invite him to join their pranks.

You could be friends with anyone, he‚Äôd thought, why on earth would you choose me?

He never did ask.

He doesn‚Äôt ask now.

Sirius wouldn‚Äôt understand.

Everyone has always wanted Sirius, even when they were kids. Sirius Black walks down the hallway and people look up, move closer. Some kind of primal instinct pulling them in. Even his family, in their own psychotic way, had wanted Sirius. Wanted him desperately. Really, in the end, it was Sirius who hadn‚Äôt wanted them back.

Lyall‚Äôs voice echoes through Remus‚Äôs head:

I thought it would be different.

Remus doesn‚Äôt know what his father wants. But it certainly isn‚Äôt him. Wasn‚Äôt his mother. His eyes go back to the coffin.

‚ÄúDo you want to see her?‚Äù Sirius asks softly, and Remus feels his heart drop.

He keeps staring at the polished wooden box, the top half thrown open, people walking past it like an exhibit at the natural history museum.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt feel real,‚Äù he croaks, not looking at Sirius as his throat grows tight. ‚ÄúNone of this feels real. I think there‚Äôs a part of my brain that still thinks she‚Äôs back at home, you know?‚Äù He tries to swallow. ‚ÄúBut if I see her‚Äîif I look at her face‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be real,‚Äù Sirius finishes.

Remus nods slowly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I want it to be, I‚Äôd rather pretend she ran away. Finally told my dad to fuck off and now she‚Äôs out there somewhere on some wild adventure.‚Äù

He likes that idea. His mother on the highway in a red convertible, the top down, a silk handkerchief in her hair. Smiling the way she used to‚Äîthe way she had in all those photos.

He feels Sirius‚Äôs fingers brush lightly against the back of his hand, bringing Remus‚Äôs attention back, pulling him in. And then he shrugs.

‚ÄúMaybe she is.‚Äù

¬†

PART II: JAMES

Old habits die hard.

It‚Äôs not that he‚Äôs looking for Lily. At least not consciously. But for an embarrassing number of years he was in the habit of knowing where she was at all times. The map did not help with that obsession. So, if he‚Äôs being honest with himself, the reason he ends up outside, walking through the parking lot of the funeral home, is because part of his brain has trained itself to find her.

And he does‚Äîleaning against the brick wall by the dumpsters.

‚ÄúHell sticks again, really?‚Äù he finds himself saying, bringing those green eyes in his direction, a cloud of smoke blowing out of the corner of her mouth.

‚ÄúI swear I haven‚Äôt had any since this summer,‚Äù she says, James taking up the wall space beside her.

‚ÄúWhatever you say Evans.‚Äù

She snorts, looking back out at the cars. There‚Äôs a cool breeze that pushes against them, moving the clouds overhead, letting beams of sunlight filter through.

Lily looks down at her hand, turning the cigarette over between her fingers. ‚ÄúBeing in there,‚Äù she says finally, ‚Äújust reminded me of my dad is all.‚Äù

James blinks. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù because like an idiot he‚Äôd gone and forgotten that Lily‚Äôs dad was dead. ‚ÄúAre‚Äîwas his funeral like this?‚Äù he nods at the building behind them.

Lily takes a drag from her cigarette, still not looking at James as she tilts her head back and blows the smoke up into the air. The smell burns James‚Äôs nose and the back of his throat but he refuses to cough.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Lily says finally.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know?‚Äù James repeats confused, pushing his glasses up so that he can rub at his eyes. ‚ÄúBecause it was so long ago you mean? Like you can‚Äôt remember?‚Äù

Lily smiles dryly. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

James‚Äôs glasses fall back into place and he stares at her, red hair lose, hanging down her back, freckles paler than they were this the summer. He supposes that‚Äôs the Scottish countryside‚Äôs doing. Too bad, he‚Äôs always liked her freckles.

She takes another deep pull of her cigarette before she continues. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt go to my dad‚Äôs funeral. Miscommunication or‚Äîlack of communication I guess,‚Äù James has no idea what to say to that, but luckily Lily doesn‚Äôt let him suffer for too long. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard for Muggles to get in contact with wizards, and it was still all so new to us back then.‚Äù

Her voice is calm, steady, but her eyes‚ÄîJames feels himself ache for her.

‚ÄúShit Lily,‚Äù he says softly. She‚Äôs looking right at him now, stare burning, too hot to hold. There were years when he would have done anything for this, to have her attention for even a second. Years when he DID do anything‚Äîstunts and grande romantic gestures. The irony, he supposes, is that all he ever needed to do was this.

Eventually Lily looks away again, leaving James a little breathless, like someone who‚Äôs just stepped back from the edge of a cliff.

‚ÄúIt is what it is,‚Äù she shrugs.

As Sirius Black‚Äôs best mate, James can spot a forced shrug a mile away.

‚ÄúWere you close, you and your dad?‚Äù

She bites down on her lip, flipping the ash off the end of her cigarette with the tip of her thumb. James doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôll ever get over how bloody cool she looks with those things. He definitely can‚Äôt let Sirius see her.

‚ÄúYeah, we were close,‚Äù she says finally, ‚Äúas close as you can be with your parents anyway, but‚Ä¶‚Äù she trails off for a second, ‚Äúmaybe that would have changed, the longer I spent at Hogwarts.‚Äù

James feels his brow furrow. ‚ÄúWhat d‚Äôyou mean, he didn‚Äôt like magic?‚Äù

Lily laughs, ‚ÄúNo, no he loved magic actually. God, I don‚Äôt know who was more excited when I got my letter, me or him. He was absolutely obsessed, used to make me tell him everything we learned, show him all my school supplies,‚Äù she smiles scuffing her shoes against the asphalt. ‚ÄúYou should have seen the way his face lit up the first time we went to Diagon Alley, I thought he was going to burst.‚Äù

Now James laughs. ‚ÄúHe sounds brilliant.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she nods. ‚ÄúHe was. He saw the‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚Äîthe fun in life, you know?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

But then something comes over her face, he‚Äôd call it a shadow but that wouldn‚Äôt be quite right. It‚Äôs something heavy, something that anchors down the corners of her smile.

‚ÄúIt builds walls between you though, between you and the people you love,‚Äù she says eventually, looking down at the cigarette in her hand before flicking it off into the distance.

‚ÄúWhat does?‚Äù James asks.

She looks up at him, green eyes bright. ‚ÄúGoing places they can‚Äôt follow.‚Äù

Lily Evans is a powerful witch, even when she isn‚Äôt using her wand. The strength in those words vibrates through James like they‚Äôre hands on his shoulders, shaking him.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he finds himself saying, wishing he had more.

Lily only shakes her head, giving him a sad smile. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be. We all make sacrifices for magic. I wouldn‚Äôt change it. Wouldn‚Äôt give it back. Not even for my family,‚Äù she wrinkles her nose. ‚ÄúDoes that make me sound horrible?‚Äù

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúMakes you sound pretty fucking ruthless though.‚Äù

That gets a proper laugh out Lily, loud and full, bouncing off the walls around them. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll take it‚Äîruthless‚ÄîI like that.‚Äù

James smiles back. ‚ÄúGood.‚Äù

They stand in silence for a minute, both looking out at the parking lot in front of them and the street beyond that, cars speeding along the road like comets. James is always surprised by how big the Muggle world feels, how full of strangers. There‚Äôs no anonymity amongst wizards, not really. Everyone is connected to everyone else and if you‚Äôre not, well, that‚Äôs it‚Äôs own identity.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôs Remus doing?‚Äù Lily asks eventually, startling James out of his thoughts.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúMerlin, I don‚Äôt know, hard to tell with him, he keeps everything pretty tightly bottled,‚Äù he takes a moment, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs doing better than I would be, I‚Äôll tell you that. If my mum was‚Äî‚Äú he can‚Äôt say it. Can‚Äôt even think it, a shiver running through his whole body. ‚ÄúHonestly I don‚Äôt how he‚Äôs still standing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think Remus expects the worst,‚Äù Lily says simply. ‚ÄúMakes it easier to handle when it happens‚Äînot easy, but‚Ä¶‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been through a lot.‚Äù

Lily looks over at him but when James doesn‚Äôt elaborate she doesn‚Äôt push him for details.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been‚Ä¶impressed with Sirius,‚Äù he almost feels guilty saying it. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been really good these past few days. He‚Äôs helped. I guess‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚ÄîI knew they were sort of a match, but I didn‚Äôt realize until this week how much that meant. If that makes sense?‚Äù

Lily smiles softly. ‚ÄúYeah, it makes sense. It‚Äôs been nice to watch, the two of them. You can really tell with Sirius, it‚Äôs like a weight has been lifted off of him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think he was suffocating himself for a little while there,‚Äù James agrees, hand rubbing at the back of his neck.

Lily looks like she might say something else but at that moment a car comes barrelling into the parking lot, and while James is the first to admit that he knows nothing about cars, this definitely does not seem like the right way to drive one.

‚ÄúOh Jesus Christ,‚Äù Lily hisses under her breath as she pushes off the wall.

‚ÄúWho the hell is that?‚Äù James asks.

Lily rolls her eyes as the car screeches to a halt in front of them. ‚ÄúMary.‚Äù

Almost at that exact moment the window on the driver‚Äôs side rolls down revealing a smiling Mary and nervous Marlene.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up lovebirds?‚Äù Mary demands, looking far too pleased with herself.

Lily ignores her, walking up to the car with James following behind. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe stole my dad‚Äôs car.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, thanks, I can see that. My question is why?‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes, as though the answer ought to be obvious. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre rescuing Remus, clearly.‚Äù

‚ÄúI just want to say,‚Äù Marlene pipes up from the passenger seat, ‚Äúthat I told her this was a terrible idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúRescuing Remus?‚Äù Lily repeats, sounding mildly outraged. ‚ÄúMary, it‚Äôs his mother‚Äôs funeral.‚Äù

In the same tone James adds; ‚ÄúExcuse me? You don‚Äôt rescue Remus. He‚Äôs a marauder, WE rescue Remus.‚Äù

Mary arches her brow, leaning around Lily to look pointedly at James. ‚ÄúDo the marauder‚Äôs have a car?‚Äù

He scowls. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen it looks like you‚Äôre not the hero today Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcuse me, hello,‚Äù Lily holds her hand in front of James‚Äôs face, stopping him from retaliating. ‚ÄúYou both seem to be forgetting that this is Remus‚Äôs mother‚Äôs funeral.‚Äù

‚ÄúI told her!‚Äù Marlene sing-songs.

Mary makes an exasperated noise. ‚ÄúLily, come on, you saw him in there. He‚Äôs miserable.‚Äù

Lily looks back at her, clearly waiting for Mary to realize the absurdity of what she‚Äôs just said. But, of course, she doesn‚Äôt. Lily pinches the bridge of her nose. ‚ÄúYes Mary, of course he‚Äôs miserable,‚Äù she sighs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs. His. Mother‚Äôs. Funeral.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù James shrugs, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm with Macdonald on this one. I don‚Äôt think being in there is doing him any good.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Mary says, eliciting an aggravated groan from Lily.

‚ÄúYou two are absolute lunatics. You can‚Äôt just drag him away.‚Äù

‚ÄúDrag?‚Äù Mary repeats affronted. ‚ÄúWho said anything about dragging?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just going to ask him Lily, Jesus,‚Äù James agrees. ‚ÄúGive him the option, if he wants it.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh he wants it,‚Äù Mary says confidently.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt possibly know that.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I said!‚Äù Marlene pipes up again.

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôll just go ask him shall I?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo‚ÄîJesus‚ÄîJames!‚Äù Lily grabs hold of his wrist, her grip impressively strong. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just‚Äîit‚Äôs insensitive‚Äîyou‚Äôll make him think you don‚Äôt want to be here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a funeral not a birthday party Lily,‚Äù Mary calls through the car window. ‚ÄúNo one wants to be here.‚Äù

But James looks back at her, making sure she can understand how sincerely he means this; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to be there for Remus, however he needs me. But I‚Äôm telling you Evans, Remus Lupin hates crowds, hates small talk, hates people fussing over him. Everything that‚Äôs going on in there is basically the antithesis of what he wants. So I‚Äôm gonna give him an out. If he wants to take it great, if not, I will sit in that room for the next week if that‚Äôs what he needs. Okay?‚Äù

Lily bites her lip, looking only slightly less worried.

‚ÄúHere here!‚Äù Mary cheers from he car.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Lily finally concedes. ‚ÄúOkay, but I‚Äôm coming with you.‚Äù

James sends her a lopsided grin. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you trust me?‚Äù

Lily huffs out a laugh. ‚ÄúTo be tactful? Absolutely not.‚Äù

¬†

The smell of stale perfume hits James full force as they walk back inside. He‚Äôs never been to a Muggle funeral before but he hopes they don‚Äôt all take place in buildings like this, as if death wasn‚Äôt depressing enough. They walk past a group of women at the entrance who definitely give James the evil eye.

‚ÄúJeez,‚Äù he whispers as they enter the reception area. ‚ÄúAre all Muggles this suspicious?‚Äù

Lily looks at him and then over her shoulder at the women behind them, smirking slightly. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think they‚Äôre suspicious. I just think they don‚Äôt like you.‚Äù

‚ÄúImpossible, I‚Äôm universally adored.‚Äù

Lily shakes her head but can‚Äôt quite keep the smile off her face.

‚ÄúJames, Lily!‚Äù
