James doesn‚Äôt seem surprised by this. ‚ÄúDo you not want me here?‚Äù he asks calmly. Impressively calm, considering a few minutes ago they were screaming at one another.

Regulus almost laughs. ‚ÄúYou know I do.‚Äù

James arches his brow and it takes a valiant effort on Regulus‚Äôs part not to roll his eyes.

‚ÄúI want you here,‚Äù he says. And then; ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt though. I wish I didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

James sits with that for a minute, eyes softening ever so slightly. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

Part of Regulus wants to tell James to go, to build on this space between them, to stretch it and pull it until they can‚Äôt reach one another anymore. Until it becomes insurmountable. But the other part of him‚Äîthe stronger, needier part‚Äîwants to walk over there and bury his face in James‚Äôs chest, wants to feel his arms wrap around him, wants to listen to James talk his sentimental nonsense until he falls asleep.

You are my happy.

He sighs. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing here James?‚Äù

James looks at him. ‚ÄúWhy am I not fucking Lily Evans you mean?‚Äù

Regulus tries and fails not to wince. But he doesn‚Äôt correct him. After a few moments of tense silence James goes on. ‚ÄúHoping you apologize I suppose.‚Äù

Regulus watches him. ‚ÄúFor calling her a Mudblood?‚Äù

James nods slowly. ‚ÄúAmong other things.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou really do hate that word don‚Äôt you?‚Äù

James looks at him with something nearing disappointment. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says, and then; ‚ÄúI wish you did.‚Äù

Regulus looks inside himself for the indignation that he knows James feels, but he comes up blank. Eventually he shrugs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel anything about that word.‚Äù

James grimaces. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

The word ‚Äúsorry‚Äù sits in Regulus‚Äôs mouth, ready to be spoken, to be set free. Yet for some reason the idea of saying it makes his stomach squirm. Several moments pass before he finally clears his throat. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

The corners of James‚Äôs mouth twitch. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he runs a hand through his hair and when he looks back at Regulus there‚Äôs the hint of worry there. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna need you to do something for me okay?‚Äù

Well, this doesn‚Äôt sound good.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Regulus says hesitantly.

‚ÄúI need you to tell Sirius that you won‚Äôt out him to the school.‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth, ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it enough that I tell you?‚Äù

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo, and there‚Äôs another thing.‚Äù

Definitely doesn‚Äôt sound good.

‚ÄúI need you to do it under Veritaserum.‚Äù

Regulus waits for the laughter. Because surely this is a joke. His indignation must show on his face because James throws up his hands in a placating gesture. ‚ÄúListen, I had to talk Remus down from having you make an unbreakable vow okay? This was the compromise.‚Äù

Regulus continues to stare at James like he‚Äôs lost his bloody mind. Which he must have. ‚ÄúThis is a terrible idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have a better one?‚Äù

Regulus grinds his teeth. He hates Veritaserum. It makes him feel too‚Ä¶exposed. Out of control. It‚Äôs violating. A shiver runs through him just thinking about it. Too much like Legilimency.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù James asks cautiously, he can see the concern in his expression.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll do it,‚Äù Regulus says finally, though every part of him revolts against the idea. ‚ÄúBut I have conditions.‚Äù

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúWhich are?‚Äù

Regulus holds his gaze. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one who does the asking.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a short pause before James nods. ‚ÄúOkay. Sirius will still have to be there though, probably Remus as well, he‚Äôs the one brewing it.‚Äù

Regulus grimaces. ‚ÄúI can brew it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs going to work for them.‚Äù

He‚Äôd assumed as much.

‚ÄúFine. But you ask. And it‚Äôs only the one question and I get to hear it before I take the potion, understood?‚Äù

Another pause. ‚ÄúYeah Reg, okay,‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt let anything happen that you don‚Äôt want, you know that right?‚Äù Those big eyes. Infuriatingly bright. And kind. Regulus nods.

That helps. Doesn‚Äôt fix anything. But it helps.

‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù he asks finally.

‚ÄúTomorrow?‚Äù

His stomach squirms but really, better to get this over with sooner rather than later.

You could say no, offers the voice in his head. You could make good on your threat.

The problem is, it‚Äôs hard to want to, staring at James.

Weak, the voice hisses.

Yeah, he thinks, I am.

‚ÄúIs that okay?‚Äù James ducks his head, trying to get Regulus‚Äôs attention.

Regulus blinks, realizing he‚Äôs just been standing there silently.

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù he‚Äôs says flatly.

The fire crackles behind them, casting shadows over the bed across the room. It feels uncomfortable to look at right now, like it doesn‚Äôt belong here, in this moment. This is usually such a happy space.

‚ÄúAre we done now?‚Äù Regulus asks stiffly, trying to keep his voice as detached as possible.

James looks up. ‚ÄúDone?‚Äù

‚ÄúFighting?‚Äù

James watches him for a minute before sighing, holding his hand out. After a few seconds Regulus finds himself taking it, being pulled into James, just the way he‚Äôd wanted, though he‚Äôd never admit it. He burrows his face into crux of the other boy‚Äôs neck.

‚ÄúYeah Reg,‚Äù James says softly, hand tracing circles on his back. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre done fighting.‚Äù

It feels good. Even if Regulus knows it isn‚Äôt true.

¬†

They don‚Äôt really talk much after that. Eventually James slides down onto the sofa, bringing Regulus with him, holding him too tight. It feels like denial. Like licking wounds they can‚Äôt heal. Still, Regulus doesn‚Äôt pull away. Not for a long time.

He‚Äôs yawning when he finally makes his way down the passage to the Slytherin common room. It‚Äôs late, close to two in the morning he imagines. He feels warn out by the day, by the cauldron of emotions bubbling in his chest. By all the things he can‚Äôt do.

Maybe if any of those things had been different he would have noticed sooner‚Äîthe unnatural quiet. The familiar buzzing of a Muffliato charm. But he doesn‚Äôt. Doesn‚Äôt notice anything until he gets to the door of his dorm and finds it locked. He looks down at the handle in his hands, trying to twist it again with no luck. He briefly considers going back to the common room and just sleeping on one of the sofas. He hasn‚Äôt got the energy for whatever the hell those idiots are doing in there. But after a few minutes of deliberating he pulls out his wand.

‚ÄúAlohomora,‚Äù he hisses, hearing the satisfying click of the lock. With a deep breath he slides his wand back up his sleeve and pushes forward.

The first thing that hits him is the noise. As soon as he passes the threshold some terrible wizard rock band starts shouting in his ears, the door closing behind him. The second thing he notices are the people. He blinks, adjusting to the dark lighting. Mulciber and Snape are sitting on his bed, girls Regulus doesn‚Äôt recognize dancing in front of them, the curtains around Barty‚Äôs bed have been drawn and Evan‚Äî

‚ÄúREG!‚Äù Evan shouts, cup in one hand, the other slinging around Regulus‚Äôs shoulders, pulling him further into the room. Regulus can smell the alcohol on his breath.

‚ÄúEvan, what the hell is going on?‚Äù He spots Avery in the corner, a girl on his lap, her back to Regulus.

‚ÄúAh, well, Severus over there,‚Äù he gestures to the miserable twat with his drink. ‚Äúactually had a good idea for once.‚Äù

‚ÄúI highly doubt that‚Äîis this a party? Are you throwing a party in the middle of the week in our dorm room? With Snape of all people?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, no, listen,‚Äù he thumps Regulus too hard in the chest, knocking the wind out of him. ‚ÄúOoh, sorry about that. But no, not a party‚Äînot just a party anyway‚Äîsee, after Macdonald‚Äôs little display in the corridor Snape decided that the Mudblood girls needed to be knocked down a few pegs, you know, reminded of who‚Äôs fucking in charge around here. Who their betters are so to speak,‚Äù Evan waggles his eyebrows in a thoroughly unsettling way.

Regulus still feels lost. ‚ÄúYou wanted to put them in their place?‚Äù he repeats, getting a nod of approval from Evan. ‚Äú‚Ä¶So you invited them back to your room for a drink?‚Äù

Evan snorts, gripping Regulus‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúNah, nah, no invites,‚Äù he brings his face uncomfortably close to Regulus‚Äôs. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need to ask the Mudbloods for shit. We can just take it.‚Äù

Regulus stares at him, feeling an uncomfortable scratching against his ribs as he takes in the room again, takes in the vacant looks on the girls‚Äô faces. ‚ÄúEvan,‚Äù he says slowly. ‚ÄúWhat did you do?‚Äù

Evan grins. ‚ÄúImperio. Surprisingly, Barty is very good at it,‚Äù he leans back, taking a sip of his drink.

Regulus steps away, a wave of nausea crashing into him. He remembers being in the kitchen. Remembers Bellatrix‚Äôs voice in his head:

On your knees.

Bark.

Kiss it.

Vomit crawls up the back of his throat, and he collides with the wall behind him, skin covered in sweat, everything too hot.

‚ÄúHey, woah, Reg?‚Äù Evan‚Äôs voice gets closer and Regulus cringes away.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt,‚Äù he hisses, stopping Evan‚Äôs hand mid-air as he reaches for him. Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt touch me.‚Äù

Evan looks genuinely frightened. ‚ÄúShit, you don‚Äôt look good. Are you okay?‚Äù

Regulus swallows, trying to figure out a way to answer that question when his eyes fall on Barty‚Äôs bed again. Curtain‚Äôs drawn.

‚ÄúEvan, what‚Äôs Barty doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Evan looks over his shoulder, ‚ÄúOh, uh,‚Äù he turns back to Regulus, his smile slightly less confident. ‚ÄúHe‚Äîyou know‚Äîhe got Mary.‚Äù

He‚Äôd been thirteen.

Lucius said: you‚Äôll like it. Trust me. Don‚Äôt you trust me Reggie?

And he had.

Of course he had.

He‚Äôd been thirteen.

They‚Äôre everywhere. The girls with the dead eyes. And suddenly they look just like him.

‚ÄúRegulus‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúStop it, stop this. They need to leave.‚Äù His back is pressed against the wall but it‚Äôs not enough, like the thick air of the room has grown hands and he can feel it. Feel them. On his skin. In his head.

‚ÄúHey, look, it‚Äôs okay alright?‚Äù Evan says, hands held up like he‚Äôs trying to calm a startled animal. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like they‚Äôll remember it anyway.‚Äù

Don‚Äôt you trust me Reggie?

Regulus‚Äôs nails start digging into the stone.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôll remember.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Regulus forces his eyes open, not realizing he had closed them in the first place. ‚ÄúEvan, please. I‚Äôm asking, please. Please. Get them out.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause. A few seconds. A few minutes. Regulus doesn‚Äôt know, but in the end Evan nods.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù and as easy as that he whips out his wand, spelling off the music and upping the lights, turning to face the room at large.

‚ÄúShows over folks, lets clear out, send the witches on their way.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you kidding me?‚Äù Avery demands, shoving the girl off his lap so that he can look at Evan properly. The girl doesn‚Äôt react, her expression remaining blank, Regulus has to look away.

‚ÄúGetting cold feet Rosier?‚Äù Snape asks, though his eyes are on Regulus.

Evan just grins at him. ‚ÄúGetting bored more like. Now, if you don‚Äôt mind, you can get the fuck out of my room.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat about Crouch?‚Äù Mulciber demands, jabbing a hand towards Barty‚Äôs bed.

‚ÄúWhat about him?‚Äù Evan asks. ‚ÄúYou do know that he lives here right?‚Äù

Mulciber scowls. ‚ÄúSo what? He just gets to carry on while the rest of us get blue balls?‚Äù

Evan gives him a flat look, but Regulus can tell he‚Äôs thinking about how difficult Barty is going to make this. Eventually, he turns to the bed in question.

‚ÄúBarty‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you fucking dare Evan!‚Äù a voice growls from behind the curtains.

Evan sighs. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon Barty. Get out here, it‚Äôs over.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause before the curtains whip back so violently Regulus is surprised they don‚Äôt come off their tracks. Barty is shirtless but his trousers are still on. That‚Äôs something, isn‚Äôt it? Regulus sags a little more into the wall.

There‚Äôs thunder in the look Barty throws at Evan. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre joking, tell me you‚Äôre joking? Because I swear if you don‚Äôt start laughing‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNow, now,‚Äù Snape interrupts, sliding off Regulus‚Äôs bed‚Äîhe‚Äôll have to get the house elves to wash the sheets‚Äîand coming to lean against the chest at the foot of it. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be too hard on poor Rosier, he‚Äôs only doing what he‚Äôs told,‚Äù Regulus makes sure to hold Snape‚Äôs gaze. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that right Black?‚Äù

Merlin he hates him.

‚ÄúYeah, I want you the fuck out of my room.‚Äù

Snape smirks. ‚ÄúAlright, fair enough. But surely you won‚Äôt have a problem with your friend carrying on?‚Äù

‚ÄúI have a problem with it,‚Äù Mulciber grumbles.

Snape takes another step closer to him and Regulus feels alarm bells go off inside his head. Too close. Too close. Too close. But he swallows that fear, however much it hurts going down.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù Barty demands.

But Regulus doesn‚Äôt take his eyes off of Snape. ‚ÄúYeah, I have a problem with it.‚Äù

Snape‚Äôs smile grows. ‚ÄúBut why?‚Äù he takes another step closer and Regulus wonders if he knows what he‚Äôs doing. There‚Äôs something cruel in Snape‚Äôs eyes. Something cold.

He has a vision of a hallway. Roger Flint crowding him into a wall. And Snape‚ÄîSnape standing there. Of course this had been his idea.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have to explain myself to you. Now get out and take them with you,‚Äù he motions to the blank faced girls.

‚ÄúReg what the fuck!‚Äù Barty is halfway out of his bed when a foot comes from behind and kicks him in the back, sending him catapulting onto the floor. Almost immediately a half-dressed Mary Macdonald follows, clear eyed and on a warpath. Regulus curses under his breath. This is the last thing they need.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let the bitch out!‚Äù Barty shouts, struggling to get up from the floor. Mulciber is the first one to move, throwing his huge body in her path.

‚ÄúYou want a kiss Macdonald,‚Äù he asks as he grabs her by the arms, pinning them to her sides.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt. Fucking. Touch. Me.‚Äù She knees him in the groin and he instantly drops her, doubling over in pain. But Barty is on his feet now and he grabs her by the hair before she can get far, yanking her backwards with too much force. She goes careening towards the floor, Barty noticing too late that she won‚Äôt be able to catch herself. A split second later Mary Macdonald's head hits the stone.

The room goes still.

They wait for her to get up.

She doesn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Barty is the first one to speak, all his bravado drained away. ‚ÄúOh fuck, oh fuck, my dad‚Äôs going to kill me.‚Äù

Regulus spares him a glance before he looks back at Mary, her eyes closed, hair definitely darker near the scalp. He steps forward, carefully kneeling down on the ground and hovering his ear above her chest.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs breathing,‚Äù he says eventually, sitting back.

‚ÄúFuck, that‚Äôs worse,‚Äù Barty starts to pace.

Evan crouches down beside him. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs bleeding pretty bad,‚Äù he says calmly. He doesn‚Äôt sound upset, doesn‚Äôt sound scared, simply commenting on the situation.

Regulus nods. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to give me the Dementors kiss,‚Äù Barty is still prattling on, Barty who wanted to DO something. To prove himself so badly.

Regulus gently prods at her head, trying to get a sense of how bad the damage is while running through every healing spell he knows. There aren‚Äôt many.

After a moment he pulls out his wand. ‚ÄúPatientiam,‚Äù he tries, hearing the noise of something vaguely wet slurping into place.

Evan wrinkles his nose, ‚ÄúWhat was that?‚Äù

‚ÄúStamina spell,‚Äù he mutters, turning her head gently to the side to inspect the wound. There‚Äôs still a gash, bleeding less profusely now but not healed. He pulls his hands back, they‚Äôre covered in blood. It‚Äôs on his wand.

‚ÄúSo is that it? Is she good now?‚Äù Avery asks, peering over Evan‚Äôs shoulder.

Regulus sends him an irritated look. ‚ÄúNo. She needs to go to the infirmary.‚Äù

That seems to garner a reaction out of everyone. Evan lets out a low whistle, Barty sits down on his bed and drops his head into his hands muttering ‚Äúhe‚Äôs going to kill me.‚Äù Mulciber and Snape decide to take a more verbal approach;

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt take her to the infirmary,‚Äù Mulciber blusters. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll find us out.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt does seem rather reckless Black,‚Äù Snape adds, sounding significantly less troubled than everyone else.

Regulus glares up at him. ‚ÄúThis whole thing was reckless.‚Äù He gets to his feet. ‚ÄúCan you perform a memory charm?‚Äù he asks Snape.

There‚Äôs a pause before the other boy nods.

‚ÄúGood. Make sure they don‚Äôt remember anything and then get them back to their dorms,‚Äù he gestures to the girls. ‚ÄúAnd get the fuck out of my sight.‚Äù

Snape‚Äôs dark eyes run him up and down. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre in charge are you?‚Äù

He considers hexing him, but honestly, they haven‚Äôt got the time. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he pushes his sleeve back, baring his Mark for the first time since he got it. ‚ÄúYeah I‚Äôm in charge.‚Äù

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù Avery says as he and Mulciber both crowd around.

He watches Snape take it in, watches him swallow his pride with a bitter look on his face, eyes flicking back up to Regulus‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúWell, well, who would have thought you had it in you?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt answer, just stares him down. Eventually Snape concedes. ‚ÄúGrab the girls,‚Äù he says to his friends. ‚ÄúBring them back to our room.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Regulus stops him, Snape shooting him a look, halfway out the door. ‚ÄúThey get back to their dorms.‚Äù

Snape nods. ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

None of the other girls seem to have broken free of the spell‚Äôs hold, Regulus isn‚Äôt sure if it‚Äôs because Mary Macdonald is exceptionally strong or Barty‚Äôs spell was just exceptionally weak. It could go either way. Regardless, Avery and Mulciber herd the others out without much fuss, leaving the room a silent mess.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so dead,‚Äù Barty keeps repeating, looking as though he‚Äôs trying to pull his hair out. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs gonna let them suck out my soul. He‚Äôs gonna watch them do it.‚Äù

Regulus looks down at Mary, eyes still closed, head still bleeding.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the plan captain?‚Äù Evan asks. There‚Äôs really only one option at this point.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll bring her to the infirmary.‚Äù

Evan arches his brow in question but Regulus only shrugs. ‚ÄúI already have the Mark right?‚Äù

He bends down to pick her up but stops halfway. ‚ÄúGet me her shirt.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Regulus looks sharply at Barty. ‚ÄúGet me her shirt.‚Äù

Barty looks somewhere between confused and angry but he doesn‚Äôt argue, reaching across his bed and coming back with a black t-shirt. Regulus is clumsy getting it on her, but he feels better once he does. Not that it changes anything.

He slips one arm under her legs and the other under her head, struggling to straighten up.

‚ÄúDisillusion us would you?‚Äù he asks Evan who nods, instantly obliging. ‚ÄúRight, I‚Äôll see you in a bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want me to come with you?‚Äù Evan asks, staring somewhere over Regulus‚Äôs head.

‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôll be easier alone.‚Äù Evan nods and Regulus turns for the door, the smell of blood already overwhelming his senses.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

He pauses. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

Barty fidgets, hair sticking out in all directions from the pulling, his face frightfully pale. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

But Regulus doesn‚Äôt respond, channeling his anger into a single look his friend will never see before pushing out the door and into the hallway beyond.

¬†

It‚Äôs the middle of the night now, so the hallways are fairly easy to navigate even while carrying an unconscious body. Still, by the time he gets to the infirmary he‚Äôs exhausted, breathing heavy as he lowers her carefully onto the floor, leaning her against the wall. He wipes his sweaty palms on his trousers before pulling out his wand, casting a silencing charm around them and then pointing it at Mary.

‚ÄúRennervate.‚Äù

Her eyes fly open, her mouth gasping for air, arms flying out as though she expects to find herself falling.

‚ÄúSh, sh,‚Äù Regulus tries to calm her. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, you‚Äôre alright.‚Äù

She looks like she‚Äôs about to speak but instead a moan comes out of her mouth. ‚ÄúOw, fuck, my head,‚Äù her hand goes to grab it but instantly flies out again. ‚ÄúOh my God, am I bleeding?‚Äù

‚ÄúMacdon‚ÄîMary, I need you to focus okay?‚Äù he takes hold of her shoulders making sure to keep his voice even, soothing. She‚Äôs shaking under his hands. ‚ÄúCan you focus for me?‚Äù

She blinks several times, wincing. ‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. I need you to tell me who did this to you? Do you remember?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äîow, oh ow, it hurts. Fuck, my head.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù and he does, she shouldn‚Äôt be conscious right now but he just needs to get through this. ‚ÄúJust tell me what you remember and then I can get you some pain potion okay?‚Äù

He can see her struggling through it. ‚ÄúUm‚Äîyeah,‚Äù but her face seems to implode in on itself and she goes quiet for a long time. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù she finally manages, the word half a sob. ‚ÄúSorry, it‚Äôs just‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù Regulus says. ‚ÄúI just need you to tell me if you remember who did this to you?‚Äù

She breathes in with difficulty. ‚ÄúUm, yeah, yeah. It was‚Äîit was Crouch‚Äîit was Barty fucking Crouch.‚Äù

Regulus does his best not to grimace, wand still in his hand. ‚ÄúRight, okay. That was really good Mary.‚Äù

Her eyes squeeze shut, teeth shattering from the pain. ‚ÄúCan I get that potion now?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, of course,‚Äù he lifts his wand. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúObliviate.‚Äù

Her face goes blank. All the tension from the pain and fear dropping away. Regulus lifts his wand again.

‚ÄúI really am sorry‚ÄîLegilimens.‚Äù

The thing is, they‚Äôre going to ask her questions. Pomfrey. McGonagall. Dumbledore even. A student shows up to the infirmary unconscious and brutalized? This doesn‚Äôt just go away, and a blank memory is almost as dangerous as a fully intact one. So he needs to replace it. For once in his life being his mother‚Äôs son actually comes in handy. He‚Äôs seen Walburga mess with enough people‚Äôs heads‚Äîmess with his own‚Äîthat he‚Äôs picked up a few tricks.

He forces his way into her head. She‚Äôs weak and doesn‚Äôt seem to know Occlumency so it isn‚Äôt hard, her memories fluttering around him, like he‚Äôs standing in a room full of butterflies, snippets of voices and faces coming in and out of focus. It‚Äôs always best to build on something real, so he focuses on her most recent memories, pulling them before him. It takes a heroic amount of mental energy to control someone else‚Äôs thoughts and he knows he won‚Äôt be able to maintain this for long. He needs to act fast.

Everything is a bit distorted because of the Imperio, the moments in the dorm room few and far between. Most of the night just black. Regulus wonders if that‚Äôs because she was slowly pushing back against the curse. If the moments of blurry memory are her coming back to the surface.

He‚Äôs Obliviated the last hour or so, meaning she has no memory of coming fully back to herself, of fighting with Barty or Mulciber. But there is the memory of her getting cursed. Regulus grabs hold of it, watching as Barty walks towards her.

Hey Macdonald?

It sounds like Regulus is listening to them under water.

Get lost creep.

Aw, come on, don‚Äôt be like that. Listen, I came to apologize.

Yeah, sure you did.

In the background Regulus‚Äîand more importantly, Mary‚Äîcan see Snape, Mulciber, and Avery. He doesn‚Äôt know where Evan is but that‚Äôs all for the better. Using every ounce of control he has Regulus pauses the memory like a video recording. He surveys the faces in the background, thinking. It would be so incredibly satisfying to frame Snape. But he‚Äôs too clever, he‚Äôd figure out what was happening, find a way out, hell, maybe even find a way to turn it around on Regulus. No. He needs someone stupid enough not to realize what‚Äôs happening until it‚Äôs too late. Or even better, someone stupid enough to want to take credit for this.

Like wading through water he pushes through Mary‚Äôs memory, grabbing hold of Mulciber and moving him into Barty‚Äôs spot, covering the first boy completely. Dispersing him like smoke. The image before Regulus flickers but he holds it tight, refusing to let go of the reins.

Hey Macdonald?

Mulciber walks towards her.

Get lost creep.

Aw, come on, don‚Äôt be like that. Listen, I came to apologize.

Regulus watches the whole thing play out again. Watches Mulciber move further and further into Mary‚Äôs space. Watches him pull out his wand, watches him Imperio her. Watches Mary‚Äôs memory shake and blur and fade to black. The voice isn‚Äôt quite right, still a bit too high for Mulciber, but there‚Äôs nothing he can do about that, he hasn‚Äôt the time or the skill to fix it.

Taking a deep breath he pulls back, catching himself on his hands and knees as the corridor reforms around him. He blinks the spots out of his vision, breathing heavy as he turns to find Mary slumped against the wall, eyes closed again. He checks her pulse just to be certain she‚Äôs still okay, and then gets to his feet.

The world spins for a moment and he worries that he‚Äôs going to pass out, but somehow he manages to keep hold of his consciousness. After a few more seconds he turns his wand on himself and casts a new Disillusionment charm, the old one having faded. Then he knocks on the infirmary door and starts walking.

He‚Äôs nearly at the end of the hall when he hears the door open.

‚ÄúThis better be important if‚Äîoh, oh sweetheart, what‚Äôs happened to you?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt stop. Doesn‚Äôt turn around. Even as the horror in Pomfrey‚Äôs voice trembles through him. The blood on his hands suddenly burning hot.

He wonders if he‚Äôll ever get the stains out.

Chapter End Notes

¬†Hello beautiful people!

Yeesh, like I know there are some intense chapters in this fic but this one felt particularly intense, maybe that's just me though...

I feel like Mary's attack is one of those things that is sometimes treated casually but tbh the idea of going to school with wizard Nazi's sounds terrifying so I wanted to kind of show how magic makes the situation more dangerous but hopefully it wasn't too much

THANK YOU FOR READING AND COMMENTING ect. ect. Hope you're all having a great day/night/whatever time it is where you are!

¬†

**Hi, hello, it is Soph from the future. I was asked on my tumblr why I chose to involve Reg in Mary's attack and a few people thought it would be helpful if I posted the answer here so I'm going to do that below for those of you who are interested in reading it (it's kind of long so I apologize):

I think there‚Äôs this thing that happens in fanfics or fandom or honestly in the HP books (where Snape is concerned) of having characters who are Death Eaters who never do anything wrong except becoming a Death Eater (does that make sense?) Like they‚Äôre portrayed as joining the club but never participating in any of the group activities and therefore we‚Äôre allowed to like them. And I think that‚Äôs a problem, because it sets up this narrative that you can be, y'know, a Nazi, or a white supremacist, or whatever real life group you wanna use in this metaphor, and still be a fundamentally moral person and I disagree with that.

If you are in anyway supporting and standing with this group you are morally compromised. And so I wanted to make clear that Regulus is not someone who does the right thing all the time (or who even knows what the right thing is) or who holds the right views or a healthy outlook on life. Because if those things are true than this story goes very differently. Then he never becomes a Death Eater, then he is essentially Sirius.

It was also a way of holding the audience accountable, like we‚Äôre out here rooting for this kid (and I think there are lots of reasons to root for Regulus I really do) but this kid becomes a Death Eater and you don‚Äôt get to act like that doesn‚Äôt mean something. This fic was meant to flesh Regulus out, to give him depth, but part of that includes him being a character you cannot love unproblematically.

I really wanted to avoid skipping over the Death Eater thing which, again, I think happens a lot in this fandom. I love a morally grey character. I love an arc. I love that Regulus switches sides at the end. But that doesn‚Äôt mean there isn‚Äôt still ugly stuff and that ugly stuff is not going to be forgivable to some people and that ugly stuff should make you feel uncomfortable. Even if ultimately I would like people to root for Regulus, it should be difficult. Because being a Death Eater is not insignificant and it should never be considered so, and you cannot become one and not have that effect the decisions that you make and the way you treat people.

It would have been too easy to have Regulus handle that situation perfectly and be like ‚Äúlook, he might be a Death Eater but he‚Äôs a good Death Eater‚Äù like there‚Äôs no such thing. And when you start to act like there is you are romanticizing bigotry, which is something I think Jegulus gets accused of a lot and something that I wanted to confront head on and not shy away from.

Ok, I hope that makes sense. I also don‚Äôt know that I actually managed to do any of the things I wanted to by approaching the story this way, but this is what I was trying for anyway!

Chapter 26

Chapter Notes

tw/cw: Sexual content (I wanna say that this is like YA level sexual content, I could be wrong but I feel like that's accurate)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I: LILY

The friendship of Lily Evans and Mary Macdonald began under a bed. Lily‚Äôs bed, to be exact. See, she‚Äôd been having a bad day. It was first year and everything was just‚Ä¶a little‚Ä¶much. She missed her mum and dad, back then she even missed Petunia, and Severus was there but he wasn‚Äôt there-there. He was in Slytherin. After the sorting Lily had briefly considered begging the hat to put her in Slytherin too. Especially after being placed in the same house as Black and Potter. There hadn‚Äôt been any posh kids at her old school but they were about as obnoxious and self-obsessed as she had expected. And Potter was so gaga for Gryffindor that she was certain it would be filled with people just like him.

In the end, however, Lily had not had the guts to ask anything of the sorting hat, so she had remained in Gryffindor. And mostly that had been okay‚Äîposh bespectacled prats aside. Her roommates were nice, her classes were fun, and she did rather like not living in a dungeon. But she was also‚Ä¶lonely. And out of place. And uncomfortable. There were so many things that the kids around her‚Äîeven if they weren‚Äôt Purebloods‚Äîseemed to know, and it felt impossible trying to keep up with it all. Severus did his best to help her along but she could tell that he was sometimes a little bit embarrassed by her. That was the worst feeling honestly.

One afternoon, at the end of September, for no reason in particular, it had all just felt too much. So she‚Äôd crawled under her bed, trying to make the world smaller. Easier to manage. About fifteen minutes into her pity party Mary had walked in. Lily watched her feet, listened to the David Bowie song she hummed under her breath. Her and Mary had barely exchanged more than a few sentences but she was secretly Lily‚Äôs favourite roommate, if only because she was the one who reminded Lily the most of home. The posters she hung on the walls were all of people Lily recognized and they didn‚Äôt move or talk, plus, sometimes she would complain about things that Lily could relate to‚Äîlike missing ballpoint pens and three-ringed binders.

She‚Äôs not sure, to this day, what compelled her to speak then. Surely the smart thing to do would have been to remain silent and hope that her new roommate wouldn‚Äôt notice her having a complete and utter mental breakdown. But being quiet had never been Lily‚Äôs strong suit.

‚ÄúDo you have records?‚Äù she wondered out loud.

‚ÄúAh!‚Äù Mary shouted, her feet stumbling back into her bed. ‚ÄúJesus Christ, Lily? Is that you?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just that I‚Äôve never seen you play any but you hum them all the time,‚Äù she said in lieu of an answer.

‚ÄúWhere the hell are you?‚Äù Mary demanded.

‚ÄúAt home I have a bunch of records but my mum wouldn‚Äôt let me bring them, she didn‚Äôt know how safe it would be here and she was worried they‚Äôd get stolen, not that Wizards are dying for Muggle music but, of course, she didn‚Äôt know that. Still doesn‚Äôt know, I suppose‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLily,‚Äù Mary said harshly. ‚ÄúDid you get turned invisible or something?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? Oh,‚Äù Lily blinked. ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm not invisible.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen why the hell can I hear you prattling on but there‚Äôs not a single freckle in my line of vision?‚Äù

Lily scowled up at the bottom of her bed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have that many freckles.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh and the Giant Squid doesn‚Äôt have that many legs.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you just‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWhere are you?‚Äù she was beginning to sound genuinely exasperated, but to be honest, Lily quite liked being a disembodied voice. It was freeing

‚ÄúI‚Äôm under here,‚Äù she said eventually, and with great reluctance.

‚ÄúUnder‚Äîoh honestly,‚Äù some shuffling later Mary was kneeling on the floor and peering at Lily under the bed.

What the hell are you doing, is what Lily expected her to say. If it had been Petunia ‚Äúfreak‚Äù might even have been thrown in there somewhere. But the thing about Mary‚Äîthe beautiful, fantastic, brilliant thing about Mary‚Äîwas that she never did what you were expecting.

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù is what she actually said, before sliding under the bed to lie right alongside Lily. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happened then? You and your boyfriend have a fight?‚Äù

‚ÄúBoyfriend?‚Äù Lily repeated confused, and then; ‚ÄúOh‚ÄîOH‚Äîno. Sev isn‚Äôt‚Äîwe aren‚Äôt‚Äîwe‚Äôre just friends.‚Äù Though her face blushed so furiously it burned.

Mary turned her head to look at Lily, brow arched. ‚ÄúReally? Then you two might want to stop making googly-eyes at one another all the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt do that!‚Äù Lily said almost desperately.

‚ÄúYou do.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt infinity.‚Äù

Mary rolled her eyes. ‚ÄúWhatever. So if that‚Äôs not why you‚Äôre under here, what is?‚Äù

Lily chewed on her lip, looking back up at the bottom of her bed. ‚ÄúI just think‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶that someone made a mistake.‚Äù

‚ÄúProbably, but you‚Äôll have to be more specific.‚Äù

At eleven Mary‚Äôs dry sense of humour was largely lost on Lily. Mary would later credit her wit to her childhood obsession with Monty Python.

‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm supposed to be a witch.‚Äù

Lily didn‚Äôt have to turn her head to know that Mary was staring at her. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean ‚Äúsupposed to be‚Äù ? You ARE a witch?‚Äù

Lily let out a frustrated noise. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm not really though, am I? I‚Äôm a Muggle.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat is literally not true.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, but I know Muggle things and I like Muggle things and I don‚Äôt know anything about Wizards really. People like Marlene or Alice or, God, even James bloody Potter, those people are meant to be Wizards and Witches. It‚Äôs in their blood. It comes to them so naturally. None of this is natural to me.‚Äù

Mary continued to stare at her for long enough that Lily started to squirm. She had rather been hoping that out of everyone Mary would understand.

‚ÄúDid you know that the Gryffindor Quidditch team is almost always Half-Bloods and Purebloods?‚Äù the other girl said suddenly.

Lily blinked, adjusting to this change in topic. ‚ÄúI‚Äîno, no I didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Mary nodded. ‚ÄúAnd even when there are Muggle-borns they‚Äôre always seventh years, because it takes them that long to pick up the game,‚Äù her voice was determined. ‚ÄúNot me though, I‚Äôm gonna get it in three. I‚Äôm going to be the youngest Muggle-born Quidditch player ever on the Gryffindor team and you know why?‚Äù

Lily shook her head and Mary inched a little closer. ‚ÄúTo piss them the fuck off.‚Äù

At that time swearing was still rather new to Lily so she actually gasped, and after several moments of shocked silence managed to stammer; ‚ÄúThem?‚Äù

Mary waved her hands above her as much as the bed would allow. ‚ÄúThe powers that be, the system, the Man. The snooty Purebloods. Because I am every bit as much a Witch as they are,‚Äù her eyes locked onto Lily‚Äôs, ‚Äúand so are you.‚Äù

After that they‚Äôd gone to the Great Hall and only eaten dessert for dinner and eventually Marlene had joined them and Lily had felt better and by Christmas she didn‚Äôt want to leave. But that moment under the bed, the moment her and Mary really became friends, had always stuck with her. Always made her smile a little. Made her feel better when someone in her class laughed at some bit of magic she didn‚Äôt know‚Äîsomething that was obvious‚Äîthat little kids learned. I am every bit as much a Witch as you are, she‚Äôd think, channeling Mary as best she could. Because Mary never apologized for herself. Never felt embarrassed. Never backed down from a fight. She was unstoppable.

¬†

The bruises take time to show up. When they do Lily waves them away with the flick of her wand. They‚Äôre blue and yellow, on Mary‚Äôs wrists, her neck, her jaw. They look like flower petals. Like fingerprints.

Mary hasn‚Äôt opened her eyes yet, at least not since Marlene and Lily have been here. Apparently she talked to McGonagall and Dumbledore, but they hadn‚Äôt been allowed in then. By the time they had Mary‚Äôd been given a sleeping potion. That was a few hours ago.

Marlene is sitting in the chair next to her, she hasn‚Äôt spoken all day, her eyes intent on Mary‚Äôs face. Pomfrey wouldn‚Äôt tell them what happened but she would tell them that Mary‚Äôs had a blow to the back of the head, a bad one. She‚Äôll have a concussion but there are potions for that, anymore severe brain damage and they‚Äôll have to send her to St Mungos but it‚Äôs hard to tell at this point if that‚Äôll happen because she hasn‚Äôt been awake long enough to know. Despite all of those horrible details, it‚Äôs still the bruises that Lily can‚Äôt stop thinking about. Someone did this. They did it on purpose. They did it with their bare hands.

‚ÄúWho though?‚Äù Marlene croaks beside her, causing Lily to jump. Apparently she‚Äôd said that last bit out loud.

She looks over at Marlene and after a second she shrugs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôd have to be Slytherin, older years. My guess is the boys, none of the girls could take her in a fight.‚Äù Could leave their fingerprints embedded in her skin.

Marlene‚Äôs face scrunches, eyes still on Mary. ‚ÄúBut why?‚Äù

That question takes Lily by surprise. A reminder of the difference between Marlene‚Äôs life and her own. And Mary‚Äôs. ‚ÄúBecause she‚Äôs a Mudblood.‚Äù

Marlene‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúYou think this was about blood status?‚Äù

Of course, she wants to say, obviously. Except it‚Äôs clear that this is not the obvious conclusion for Marlene.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve been getting bolder,‚Äù Lily tries to explain. ‚ÄúShouting at us in the halls, jinxing us, and Mary‚Äôs‚Ä¶‚Äù not likely to walk away from a fight.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Marlene drops her head into her hands, staying like that for a few minutes before she speaks again. ‚ÄúDo the teachers know?‚Äù

That is a question Lily asks herself frequently. ‚ÄúThey know, but sometimes I think they don‚Äôt quite‚Ä¶believe us. Or they think it‚Äôs as simple as house rivalries.‚Äù Her eyes trail back to Mary. ‚ÄúMaybe they‚Äôll take us more seriously now.‚Äù

Marlene lets out a pained noise. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize,‚Äù she drops her hands, looking up. ‚ÄúI knew they were jerks sometimes but I didn‚Äôt realize it had gotten this bad.‚Äù

To be fair to Marlene, Lily isn‚Äôt entirely sure she realized it had gotten this bad either. She certainly hadn‚Äôt considered the possibility of one of them being attacked like this‚Äîat Hogwarts. It crossed a line somehow. Kids were cruel. They name called and teased, Lily was no stranger to it‚Äîheck, she got it for her hair back home. For a while Mudblood hadn‚Äôt felt that much different. But this?

Mary starts to stir, grumbling as she turns her head from one side to the other. Instantly Marlene and Lily are on their feet.

‚ÄúMary?‚Äù Marlene says quietly. Desperately. She takes her friend‚Äôs hand and squeezes.

It‚Äôs odd to see Mary like this‚Äîsmall. There‚Äôs something about her that fills up every room, she‚Äôs colourful and loud and abrasive and a pain in the ass. But never small. Never fragile. Not until now.

Mary‚Äôs eyes blink open, bloodshot and momentarily terrified. She jolts upright and then instantly grabs her head.

‚ÄúJesus fuck that hurts,‚Äù she hisses, her voice rough and yet somehow incredibly comforting. Apparently Marlene thinks so too because she starts frantically wiping the tears from her eyes. Lily reaches out and squeezes her arm.

After a few seconds Mary‚Äôs face relaxes, hands dropping from her head as she looks at them properly. Her eyes go from Marlene, to Lily, and back again.

‚ÄúMar‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äîshit I‚Äôm sorry‚Äîit‚Äôs just, it just really good to hear your voice.‚Äù

Marlene is so busy trying to keep the tears off her cheeks that she misses the soft look in Mary‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúOkay enough, Jesus, I‚Äôm not dead.‚Äù

Marlene sniffles, but when her eyes come up they‚Äôre fierce. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt joke about that! Not right now‚Äînot when‚Äî‚Äú you could‚Äôve been, she doesn‚Äôt say, but judging by the new tension that falls around them they‚Äôre all thinking it anyway.

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù Mary scoffs, propping her pillow up behind her and then carefully leaning herself against it. It‚Äôs clear that she‚Äôs in pain. ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm going to die young it better be because I overdosed at an orgy or something, not because some twats Imperiused me while I wasn‚Äôt looking.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey what?‚Äù Marlene‚Äôs eyes grow to about twice their normal size.

‚ÄúThey used an unforgivable?‚Äù

Mary‚Äôs eyes travel between the pair of them. ‚ÄúPomfrey didn‚Äôt tell you anything?‚Äù

They shake their heads.

‚ÄúShe told us that you split the back of your skull open, that‚Äôs about it,‚Äù Lily doesn‚Äôt mention the bruises.

Mary snorts, ‚ÄúBoy did I ever,‚Äù she brings her hand back to her head. ‚ÄúI swear if these headaches don‚Äôt quit it I‚Äôm going to start breaking things.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want me to go get Pomfrey?‚Äù Marlene asks, but Mary waves her off.

‚ÄúNot yet, she‚Äôll only put me to sleep again.‚Äù She pinches the bridge of her nose, taking in a deep breath. ‚ÄúWhat time is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúSupper,‚Äù Lily answers quickly. ‚ÄúSix-thirty about.‚Äù

Mary nods and then winces. ‚ÄúThe day?‚Äù

Lily and Marlene exchange a quick glance. ‚ÄúThursday.‚Äù

‚ÄúThursday,‚Äù she repeats. And then; ‚ÄúYou reckon Slughorn will give me a pass on that potions paper?‚Äù

Lily can‚Äôt help it, she laughs. ‚ÄúYeah, I think he‚Äôll probably let it slide this time.‚Äù

‚ÄúSweet,‚Äù Mary drops her hand again, taking in another deep breath.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure you don‚Äôt want me to get Pomfrey?‚Äù Marlene asks nervously.

‚ÄúI just want to not be out of my head for a few more minutes.‚Äù Bit by bit Lily thinks she can see Mary growing paler. It‚Äôs clear that the longer she‚Äôs conscious the more she hurts.

‚ÄúThe boys were here by the way,‚Äù Lily hears herself say.

Mary opens her eyes. ‚ÄúThe boys?‚Äù

‚ÄúJames, Sirius, Remus, Pete‚Äîcame as soon as they heard, sat in the hallway waiting with us, but Pomfrey would only let in two visitors.‚Äù

Mary smirks. ‚ÄúNothing like a head injury to make a girl popular.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, none of them quite knowing what to say. It goes on for too long before Marlene finally breaks.

‚ÄúMary,‚Äù she says softly. ‚ÄúWhat the hell happened?‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, well,‚Äù Mary smiles in a cold kind of way, sending shivers down Lily‚Äôs arms. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that the thousand galleon question.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt remember?‚Äù Marlene asks.

Mary shrugs, wincing again. ‚ÄúBits and pieces, Pomfrey says it‚Äôll get better with time.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you know you were Imperiused?‚Äù Lily asks.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù her eyes flick down and she becomes suddenly very interested in smoothing out the wrinkles in her bedsheets. ‚ÄúI know that.‚Äù

Lily can‚Äôt quite imagine it. The idea‚Äîthe concept itself‚Äîis terrifying. To have someone gain complete control of you? To have the power to make you do whatever they wanted? It makes her skin crawl.

‚ÄúDo you know who?‚Äù Marlene reaches out to take her hand again, squeezing.

Mary scrunches her face. ‚ÄúSometimes.‚Äù

Marlene and Lily exchange another look and when Mary doesn‚Äôt continue Lily prods her; ‚ÄúSometimes?‚Äù

‚ÄúLike I said, it‚Äôs all bits and pieces,‚Äù she pulls her mouth to the side, still staring down at the bed. ‚ÄúIt gets all‚Äî-stretched out. I see a face and then it disappears. Then sometimes there are bodies without faces at all. Sometimes the faces switch bodies‚Ä¶‚Äù

Marlene looks about as terrified as Lily feels, Mary‚Äôs words have an itching quality to them. They creep along the floor. They grab at your legs. Crawl up your spine.

‚ÄúDo you know the faces?‚Äù Lily finally finds herself asking. It feels a bit like Mary isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶quite‚Ä¶there. Something distant about her eyes. It reminds Lily of the school ghosts.

‚ÄúMulciber,‚Äù she finally says, hands curling in the sheets. ‚ÄúIt was Mulciber. At least it‚Äôs usually Mulciber,‚Äù Lily has no idea what to do with the end of that sentence, Mary is starting to get frighteningly pale.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck,‚Äù Marlene hisses. ‚ÄúYou told McGonagall right? Dumbledore? What are they going to do?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo idea,‚Äù Mary says. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt tell me.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat can they do?‚Äù Lily finds herself asking. ‚ÄúExpel him?‚Äù

Marlene scoffs. ‚ÄúExpel? For an unforgivable? They better be calling the fucking Ministry in.‚Äù

‚ÄúMar,‚Äù Mary croaks, her free hand coming up to massage her temple. ‚ÄúI appreciate the righteous indignation but maybe a little less screechy.‚Äù

Marlene‚Äôs cheeks flush. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

Lily is about to suggest that they really ought to get Pomfrey now, since Mary is looking ready to keel over, but Marlene cuts her off.

‚ÄúWeird that it was Mulciber, when was the last time you even talked to him?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo idea,‚Äù Mary says.

‚ÄúWas he alone?‚Äù

Lily thinks she sees Mary tense. She definitely sees Mary‚Äôs eyes flick up to meet her‚Äôs before dropping back to the bed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. It‚Äôs not very clear.‚Äù

But that doesn‚Äôt sit well with Lily. ‚ÄúMary?‚Äù she says softly, eventually bringing her friend‚Äôs gaze back to her. And she can see it, see it right there in the white‚Äôs of her eyes. Lily feels her heart sink.

‚ÄúTell me,‚Äù she says, because she doesn‚Äôt want to have to wonder. To guess. She just wants to know. To hear it and face it.

‚ÄúAvery was there I‚Äôm pretty sure,‚Äù Mary says slowly and Lily knows what‚Äôs coming, really she does, knows it by the worry on Mary‚Äôs face and the reluctant way she drags out her words. But even knowing she somehow still isn‚Äôt ready. ‚ÄúAnd Snape.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a bit like getting punched in the stomach that sentence. A bit like having your heartbroken. A bit like falling off your broom. It‚Äôs so hard to explain to people, but she really had loved him. Loved him most of her life. Loved him still. Maybe that‚Äôs one of those things that never stops. Can‚Äôt be undone. She wonders how many times someone has to let you down before you don‚Äôt get back up again?

‚ÄúExcuse me,‚Äù she says tersely, shaking as she turns on her heels and starts for the door.

‚ÄúLily?‚Äù Marlene calls after her.

‚ÄúGet Pomfrey,‚Äù she snaps over her shoulder. ‚ÄúShe needs a bloody pain potion.‚Äù She doesn‚Äôt hear her response, already pushing through the door.

He‚Äôll be in the Great Hall for dinner. Most of the school will be there in fact. Lily doesn‚Äôt really care, hands in fists at her sides as she cuts across the castle. She doesn‚Äôt have a plan. Just a storm of rage inside her that demands an outlet. That‚Äôs been growing since she first saw her friend lying broken in that bed.

The Great Hall is noisy, it always is at this time, nearly everyone is here.

‚ÄúLily!‚Äù

Someone calls out to her‚ÄîRemus she thinks‚Äîshe doesn‚Äôt look. Eyes scanning the Slytherin table until they land on one particular black-haired head. Severus doesn‚Äôt see her coming until she‚Äôs practically on top of him.

‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúUp,‚Äù she snaps.

His brows draw together. ‚ÄúLily what‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGet. Up. Now.‚Äù

Still looking thoroughly confused he does as she asks, standing far too close to her. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happened?‚Äù he asks in a hushed voice, because, of course, he can‚Äôt have anyone overhearing him being decent.

Which only infuriates her more. Because he knows. He knows what‚Äôs happened. And for a moment she feels frozen with all the anger coursing through her.

‚ÄúLily,‚Äù he reaches out and touches her arm, she‚Äôs surprised honestly, that he would be so bold in front of his friends, ‚Äúlets go somewhere okay? Lets talk?‚Äù

But she doesn‚Äôt want to talk.

Childishly she shoves him hard in the chest and it‚Äôs probably because he isn‚Äôt expecting it that he falls back, ass slamming into the floor, barely able to catch himself on his hands. Suddenly, all that noise from earlier evaporates. The Great Hall as close to silent as Lily has ever heard it.

‚ÄúMerlin‚Äîwhat the hell,‚Äù Severus says from the ground.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt make a difference,‚Äù her voice shakes more than she‚Äôd like it to. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what you said, do you remember?‚Äù

He blinks up at her, eyes darting nervously to the table beside them. It feels like the whole hall is watching them now.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she laughs coldly. ‚ÄúOf course you don‚Äôt. Let me remind you. I asked you‚ÄîI ASKED you‚Äîif it mattered, being Muggle-born, and you said no.‚Äù

His eyes come back to her‚Äôs, dark and pleading. How did we get here? How. How. How.

‚ÄúWas it a lie then?‚Äù she goes on. ‚ÄúOr was it only later? Did you hate me always? Was any of it real?‚Äù

His face pales, and he shakes his furiously as he forgets about their audience, about his friends. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt hate you,‚Äù he says desperately. ‚ÄúYou know that. You have to know that. I told you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou told me it doesn‚Äôt make a difference!‚Äù and that shuts him up, sucks the words right back down his throat.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre the same, me and Mary, don‚Äôt you see that?‚Äù she goes on, shaking terribly. ‚ÄúEverything you think about her, that you say about her, that you do to her‚Äî‚Äú her voice cracks right down the center. ‚ÄúYou do it to me too.‚Äù

‚ÄúNO,‚Äù Severus says more fiercely.

She shakes her head. ‚ÄúI know you Sev, I know you think that doing this makes you strong. Makes up for all the time you spent in that house afraid. Unable to help her.‚Äù

How are things at your house?

Fine.

They‚Äôre not arguing anymore?

Oh yes, they‚Äôre arguing. But it won‚Äôt be that long and I‚Äôll be gone.

Doesn‚Äôt your dad like magic?

He doesn‚Äôt like anything much.

Severus has gone stock still on the floor of the Great Hall. He‚Äôs always hated talking about his family. Usually Lily lets him avoid the subject, though for a long time it killed her‚Äîstanding idly by while he was hurt. Over and over again.

Okay.

Maybe it still kills her.

‚ÄúI wish you could see,‚Äù she goes on eventually. The whole world disappearing, just as it always used to when it was only the two of them, ‚Äúthat this makes you just like him.‚Äù

He physically flinches. ‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú begging now.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a coward Severus,‚Äù her voice is splitters, breaking off in every direction. ‚ÄúFor what you did to me, for what you did to Mary? You‚Äôre a coward,‚Äù she tries to breathe, tries to keep herself under control. Tries to make sure he knows that she means it. She steps forward, leaning closer to him. ‚ÄúI hope you fucking choke.‚Äù

You can hate someone and love someone at the same time Lily has learned. First with her sister. Now with Severus. God, she thinks as she pulls back, you used to be my home.

She‚Äôs barely taken a step towards the doors before McGonagall‚Äôs voice rings through the silent room. ‚ÄúMiss Evans.‚Äù

Lily turns to face her, the older woman has walked out from behind the teacher‚Äôs table, nearly meeting Lily where she stands. ‚ÄúMy office,‚Äù she says sternly. ‚ÄúNow.‚Äù

Lily doesn‚Äôt fight it. How could she? Doesn‚Äôt regret it either. Following McGonagall out of the room with her eyes very determinedly on the space in front of her and not the faces around her.

‚ÄúSit,‚Äù McGonagall says when they get to her office, closing the door behind them with the flick of her wand.

Lily does as she‚Äôs asked, sitting in the chair in front of the desk and watching as McGonagall takes the one behind it. The ensuing silence makes Lily feel twitchy. The adrenaline pumping through her still demanding action.

Eventually she cracks.

‚ÄúLook Professor, I understand that what I did broke about a dozen rules and I am fully willing to accept any punishment you see fit. But I absolutely will not be apologizing to him.‚Äù

McGonagall continues to watch her in silence for another moment before pushing something towards her across the desk. A‚Ä¶tin?

‚ÄúHave a biscuit Miss Evans,‚Äù she says casually.

Lily blinks, looking down at the shortbread being offered to her. ‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú unsure what to do she reaches forward and takes one. ‚ÄúThank you?‚Äù

Professor McGonagall smiles tightly. ‚ÄúIf anyone asks, I gave you the dressing down of your life, you understand?‚Äù

It takes Lily far too long to catch on to what‚Äôs happening. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù she says eventually, and when McGonagall arches her brow she quickly adds; ‚ÄúYes, I will, of course.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù another moment of silence passes before McGonagall speaks again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always liked Mary Macdonald,‚Äù her voice is as soft as Lily has ever heard it and she isn‚Äôt sure if it makes her want to laugh or cry.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she croaks eventually, ‚Äúme too.‚Äù

¬†

PART II: REGULUS

Regulus is on edge, but no one comes for him. He isn‚Äôt called into any offices, isn‚Äôt interrogated by any teachers. Or Aurors for that matter. The day actually starts out rather normal. The only signs that something is wrong are the missing faces from the Gryffindor table during breakfast. No Marlene McKinnon, no Lily Evans, no James Potter or Sirius Black or Peter Pettigrew. No Mary Macdonald.

As the day goes on the rumours start to filter through the school. They‚Äôre vague. Mary Macdonald is in the infirmary. Someone‚Äôs jealous girlfriend took revenge. No, actually, it was a Quidditch accident. She‚Äôd been drinking and fallen off the astronomy tower. She‚Äôd been outside after dark and gotten attacked by a werewolf. That one Regulus finds particularly funny because a) as if there could be a werewolf at Hogwarts that no one knew about and b) last night was not a full moon. Regardless, with every reiteration the story gets further and further from the truth and Regulus feels himself start to relax. Maybe this whole thing will blow over?

Then dinner happens.

It‚Äôs not that he doesn‚Äôt enjoy watching Snape get his ass handed to him, he really does. The problem is that almost immediately after McGonagall drags Lily Evans away the tone of the rumours start to shift. Mary Macdonald is in the infirmary because of Severus Snape, people start to whisper. Which is not, by and large, a story that Regulus has a problem with, except that it‚Äôs just close enough to the truth to bring back the pressure behind his ribs.

It is at that moment, with his anxiety on the rise again, that Remus Lupin decides to show up.

‚ÄúEmpty charms classroom, third floor, fifteen minutes,‚Äù that‚Äôs all he says before walking away.

Regulus had been hoping they‚Äôd forget about the Veritaserum in the wake of Mary‚Äôs attack. But apparently not. Which is just excellent, because obviously what he wants to be doing after altering someone‚Äôs memory is be placed under Veritaserum in the presence of three angry hero-complex-having Gryffindor‚Äôs. And yes, he trusts James to keep his promise but he‚Äôs also not an idiot. He knows Sirius won‚Äôt stick to the agreement. Knows he‚Äôll try to take advantage of the situation. It‚Äôs just what he‚Äôs like. But Regulus can‚Äôt think of any other way to placate him and, by extent, James.

He berates himself as he marches down the hall towards the empty classroom. He knows better than to make threats he doesn‚Äôt intend to follow through on, because this is the kind of situation you end up in when you do. But stupid Sirius had to be stupid standing there with his stupid‚Ä¶boyfriend? Lover? Regulus pulls a face at the thought of his brother having a ‚Äúlover‚Äù and decides to drop that train of thought all together.

He can feel his hands shaking. He‚Äôs nervous. Actually, more embarrassing than that, he‚Äôs scared. He‚Äôs been going over in his head the different ways he can get around any questions Sirius might ask without lying. It‚Äôs not possible to disobey the Veritaserum‚Äîwell, at least not if its been made by any kind of competent potioneer‚Äîbut it is possible to control it to some extent. It takes strength though, and thoughtfulness. It also requires you to go slow‚Äîif you get on a truth telling roll it can be hard to rein it back in again.

Regulus‚Äôs feet stutter outside the classroom door and for a moment he considers just walking right by it. But he already has enough hanging over him right now, he doesn‚Äôt need anymore. With shaking, sweaty hands he reaches for the door and pushes.

‚ÄúFinally, Merlin, did you fucking crawl here?‚Äù Sirius is lying on his back on the teacher‚Äôs desk at the front of the class, Lupin in the chair beside him and James leaning against the wall.

‚ÄúBit bold to be rude to the person in possession of the information you‚Äôre so desperate to keep quiet.‚Äù

Sirius sits up so fast Regulus is surprised he doesn‚Äôt faint. ‚ÄúIs that another threat?‚Äù

‚ÄúMore like an accurate summary of the situation.‚Äù

Sirius growls, hopping off the desk and striding towards him. ‚ÄúListen here you spoiled brat‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPot meet kettle.‚Äù

Sirius gives him a shove. ‚ÄúWe are not the same.‚Äù

A cold smirk pulls at the corner of Regulus‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt we though?‚Äù

The rage that that inspires in his older brother is something to behold, eyes going dark, cheeks flushing red. Sirius reaches for something‚Äîhis wand maybe?‚Äîbut Lupin pulls him back, just like he did in the corridor.

‚ÄúEnough,‚Äù he says quietly.

Sirius is glaring so Regulus makes sure to flash him his most unpleasant smile. He‚Äôs pretty sure he picked it up from Walburga.

‚ÄúLets get this over with shall we?‚Äù James says, pushing himself off the wall. Regulus looks at him briefly and then away. It‚Äôs harder to keep his mask on when James is around.

James kicks out a chair and then gestures to it, Regulus notes that he‚Äôs not making much eye contact either.

With a confidence that he does not feel, Regulus strides forward and sits, watching as Lupin passes James the potion. His pulse starts to speed up again. James is many things, a good actor is not one of them. There‚Äôs worry in his eyes when he turns to Regulus. A question.

Because James always asks.

Always.

And Regulus can tell that it‚Äôs killing him that he can‚Äôt now‚Äînot really. Regulus can‚Äôt imagine how they convinced Sirius that James should be the one to do this, no doubt he‚Äôs already suspicious of something even if it isn‚Äôt close to the truth. And as Regulus stares at the vile in James‚Äôs hands all he can think is:

Please not the Mark.

Ask me anything else but don‚Äôt ask me about the Mark.

I‚Äôm not ready to lose him.

Not yet.

Juts let me have him for a little longer.

Just let me pretend for a little longer.

Eventually James holds out the potion and Regulus takes it, hoping it‚Äôs not obvious that his hands are shaking. He turns it over a few times before looking back up. He focuses on James. It helps.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the question?‚Äù

Sirius lets out a frustrated huff. ‚ÄúYou know what the question is.‚Äù

But Regulus doesn‚Äôt look away from James.

‚ÄúDo you, Regulus Black, intend to expose, in anyway,‚Äù James goes on, in a tone that suggests this has been rehearsed a few times, ‚Äúthe nature of the relationship between Sirius Black, your brother, and Remus Lupin, to anyone?‚Äù

Regulus stares at him and then, because he can‚Äôt help it, because Sirius brings out all the nasty childish parts of him, he says in a mocking tone; ‚ÄúBut what kind of relationship could they possibly have? Sirius isn‚Äôt gay after all.‚Äù He gets the reaction he wants. Lupin flinches and Sirius fumes.

‚ÄúFuck you Reg.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, fuck you right back.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, Merlin,‚Äù James steps forward, hand running through his hair as he sends Sirius a look that means something along the lines of ‚Äústand down.‚Äù After a few seconds he turns back to Regulus. It unnerving how much this hurts. Being so close but not being allowed to‚Ä¶know him. To touch him. It hurts more every time they do it.

Weak, the familiar voice in his head sneers. Everyday it sounds more and more like his mother.

I am, he thinks.

I am, I am, I am.

‚ÄúThat okay with you?‚Äù James asks.

Regulus blinks. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe question?‚Äù there‚Äôs that concern again.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Regulus shakes himself. ‚ÄúYes, that‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

James nods, followed by a moment of silence and Regulus realizes they‚Äôre all waiting for him to drink now. He looks down at the glass vile in his hands and fights the urge to smash it on the floor. This is his fault, he knows that, his miscalculation. His optimism that he would be strong enough to set this thing between him and James on fire. But he isn‚Äôt. Not yet.

Weak.

He pulls out the stopper and tips the potion into his mouth in one swift motion. If he thinks about it he knows he won‚Äôt be able do it. Better to have it over with fast. He swallows, and then, before he can help himself, he laughs, licking his lips and looking at Lupin.

‚ÄúLemon?‚Äù he asks.

There‚Äôs only the shortest of pauses before Lupin nods. ‚ÄúIt came through then?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, covers the aftertaste. It‚Äôs smart, most people try to make potions sweet but the lemon won‚Äôt interfere with the dandelion root.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, exactly,‚Äù Lupin seems to almost forget that they don‚Äôt like one another and Regulus wonders if this is the potion at work already. If he would have complimented Lupin without it. He thinks he would have, but the uncertainty adds a new level to the anxiety already bubbling inside him.

After a few more seconds of tense silence James turns to Lupin. ‚ÄúHow long until it kicks in?‚Äù

Lupin shrugs. ‚ÄúDepends on the person but‚Ä¶should be anytime now.‚Äù

James opens his mouth but Sirius beats him to it. ‚ÄúI want to be sure‚Äîbefore you ask it I want to be sure the potion is working.‚Äù

James grimaces. ‚ÄúAnd how do you propose we do that?‚Äù

Sirius looks at Regulus who feels his pulse speed up to an almost certainly unhealthy level. But James holds his hand out before Sirius can speak.

‚ÄúYou ask me,‚Äù he says to Sirius, ‚Äúif he agrees to answer I‚Äôll ask him.‚Äù

A loophole. Regulus is grateful. If Sirius finds this suspicious he doesn‚Äôt show it, but Regulus supposes that James being a self righteous asshole is probably par for the course.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Sirius says finally, eyes still on Regulus. ‚ÄúAsk him what his teddybear was called when we were kids.‚Äù

Regulus feels his whole body collapse backwards against his chair. That is a question he can answer. James still turns to him, eyebrow raised and Regulus nods, screw embarrassment, he‚Äôll can take that over heartbreak any day.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù James says firmly, ‚Äúwhat was the name of your teddybear when you were a kid?‚Äù

He feels it instantly, the tug in his chest, the words ripped out of his head. ‚ÄúCuddletons.‚Äù

‚ÄúCuddletons?‚Äù

‚ÄúSir Cuddletons III if you want to be formal.‚Äù Regulus stares flatly at James who is clearly fighting back a laugh. ‚ÄúChildren have given stuffed animals more ridiculous names.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave they?‚Äù And then, seeming to remember that his friends are in the room with them, James looks at Sirius.

‚ÄúYeah, that‚Äôs it,‚Äù Sirius nods.

James turns back to Regulus. ‚ÄúReady?‚Äù

He nearly rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYes. Please. Lets get this over with.‚Äù

James holds his stare like he‚Äôs holding his hand and Regulus wonders if the other two can see it. ‚ÄúDo you, Regulus Black, intend to expose, in anyway, the nature of the relationship between Sirius Black, your brother, and Remus Lupin, to anyone?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt waver, feeling the tug again and not trying to fight it. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat,‚Äù James gives him a tight smile, clapping his hands together and turning to his friends. ‚ÄúWell, that was rather anticlimactic but I think we‚Äôre do‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDoes he really ask about me?‚Äù Sirius cuts across James, looking right at Regulus who blinks back at him.

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù James objects, but Regulus waves him off.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm on Veritaserum,‚Äù he says slowly, eyes on his brother, ‚Äúand that‚Äôs the question you want to break our agreement to ask?‚Äù he can feel the answer tickling the back of his throat, the sensation growing more and more insistent with every moment that he doesn‚Äôt answer.

There‚Äôs a pause before Sirius nods. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says, voice a little rough, it surprises Regulus. Sirius has never seemed to care much about their father before. But then, he supposes that‚Äôs the Black family talent isn‚Äôt it? Aloofness.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says finally, feeling an exceptional amount of relief as he lets the truth escape his mouth. ‚ÄúI tell him you‚Äôre okay, that we still talk,‚Äù the words tumbling out without his permission. ‚ÄúIt makes him happy.‚Äù

Sirius scrunches his face, ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin Sirius, enough,‚Äù James is standing between them like he can physically shield Regulus from the questions. But this doesn‚Äôt feel like foul play. Doesn‚Äôt feel like Sirius trying to take advantage, at least not much. It feels sincere.

‚ÄúBecause he loves you,‚Äù the words come easily out of his mouth. On this potion he doesn‚Äôt have to think, it just rips the thoughts from his head. Terrifying and convenient all at once.

He sees the words hit Sirius, knows how much more they mean because of the Veritaserum. Lupin steps a little closer to him, hand reaching out, squeezing his arm. It‚Äôs work for Regulus not to look at James.

‚ÄúYou really believe that?‚Äù Sirius asks finally, its only barely a question, more rhetorical than anything, but the potion doesn‚Äôt distinguish between rhetorical and sincere. James doesn‚Äôt like this, Regulus can see him getting antsy, and he knows he has a right to be. Regulus is letting Sirius take too many liberties. But he‚Äôs been waiting for years for Sirius to care about their father.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù it‚Äôs an easy answer, one he isn‚Äôt afraid to give.

Sirius nods slowly. An expression on his face that Regulus can‚Äôt decipher. ‚ÄúAnd you Reg? You really hate me as much as you seem to?‚Äù

He feels his eyes go wide. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he grimaces, trying and failing to fight back the next sentence; ‚ÄúI love you. Even when you hurt.‚Äù Well, isn‚Äôt that embarrassing.

‚ÄúSirius, this isn‚Äôt fair,‚Äù James is saying, but Sirius doesn‚Äôt take his eyes off of Regulus and Regulus doesn‚Äôt look away.

‚ÄúAre you okay Reg?‚Äù he asks. ‚ÄúAre you‚Äîdo you need help?‚Äù

Oh.

Oh fuck.

He hadn‚Äôt been expecting that one.

‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm drowning.‚Äù The words come out of him too fast, he‚Äôs been letting the potion take too much control and he can‚Äôt stop himself, can‚Äôt modify his answer, can‚Äôt stall. It just comes out.

‚ÄúReg‚Äî‚Äú Sirius starts, sounding somewhere close to heartbroken and honestly, this has been more than enough for Regulus.

‚ÄúI have to go,‚Äù he says, getting to his feet and booking it towards the door.

‚ÄúRegulus!‚Äù Sirius tries again, reaching out for him, but Regulus manages to squeeze past him, narrowly avoiding Sirius‚Äôs fingers. He feels shaky, and like he might be ill, pushing through the door of the classroom and into the hall on the other side.

He is not going back to the Great Hall. Not like this. Of course, he isn‚Äôt exactly sure where he is going. The dorm? Jesus, all he needs is for someone to ask him where he‚Äôs been or what he‚Äôs been doing. Fucking Veritaserum. He has to go somewhere safe, somewhere he can ride this out alone without anyone else picking at his fucking soul. He‚Äôd expected Sirius to try something, but he‚Äôd thought that it would be cruel, something designed to make Regulus squirm. Not whatever the hell that was.

He tries to suppress the memory of his own voice.

I feel like I‚Äôm drowning.

God, why did the truth have to sound like that? So small and pathetic? Couldn‚Äôt he have just said no? Why couldn‚Äôt that be enough?

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù

He looks over his shoulder as James comes jogging down the hallway, then quickly checks that they‚Äôre alone. James rolls his eyes

‚ÄúGive me a little credit,‚Äù he mutters under his breath.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing‚Äîwhat did you tell them?‚Äù he looks behind James, waiting for his brother to appear, but he doesn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúTold them I was going to check on Mary,‚Äù James says, causing Regulus‚Äôs stomach to squirm more than it already was.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says, not sure what to do with that.

And I‚Äôm not sure how many times I have to tell you that it‚Äôs not enough.

James starts having nightmares again. He‚Äôs not sure why. It‚Äôs been almost a year, and it‚Äôs not like anything has happened. At least not to him. They‚Äôre different than they were before. Regulus is always standing alone in the dark. Not because it‚Äôs nighttime, or because someone has turned out the lights, but because there‚Äôs nothing else. No walls or floors. No sky, no earth. Everything is black and he‚Äôs just sort of‚Ä¶there. Alone. Afraid. James calls out to him but he doesn‚Äôt hear. Reaches for him but he doesn‚Äôt feel. And honestly, that‚Äôs scary enough. To watch the terror growing in his eyes and not being able to do anything about it. The dreams could end there and James would still wake up in a cold sweat.

They don‚Äôt end there though.

At some point, while James grows more hysterical in his attempts to get to Regulus‚Äîto get Regulus to even just look at him‚Äîhands start reaching out of the dark. If they belong to bodies James never sees them. Just hands. They grab hold of Regulus‚Äôs ankles, his calves, his wrists. And Regulus starts screaming. Begging. James. James. James. His voice splits open, it cracks itself in two calling out for him.

¬†

I‚Äôm here Reg. I‚Äôm here.

And I‚Äôm not sure how many times I have to tell you that it‚Äôs not enough.

¬†

James sits up, breathing heavy, sheets damp with sweat. He‚Äôs shaking, biting down on his tongue to keep back whatever it is that‚Äôs stuck in his throat. A sob. A scream. His supper. He cast a silencing charm over his bed before he went to sleep, does it every night. He can only imagine the things he‚Äôs yelling.

It takes a few minutes but he starts to settle, breath slowly evening out. It‚Äôs late but not nearly late enough, still another three hours before he can justify getting ready for Quidditch practice. That being said, there's no way in hell he's going back to sleep. After a few seconds of indecision he throws his blankets off, pulling himself out of bed.

If he‚Äôs going to be awake he might as well be useful. He grabs the Charms essay he‚Äôd been working on and slips out of the dormitory, trying not to resent the fact that Remus is clearly no longer sleeping in his own bed. Grumbling to himself he trudges down to the common room.

‚ÄúSomeone‚Äôs up late.‚Äù

His head snaps up as he reaches the last step, finding a pair of sparkling brown eyes staring back at him.

‚ÄúWhat the hell?‚Äù is all his half-asleep brain seems able to come up with.

Mary cocks her brow. ‚ÄúAnd good evening to you too.‚Äù She‚Äôs curled up in the corner of the couch, a pink housecoat James has never seen her wear before wrapped around her, face washed clean of make up, leaving her looking incredibly young.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù James brings his free hand up to scrub his face. ‚ÄúStill a bit out of it.‚Äù

Mary nods, eyes drifting towards the fire. ‚ÄúTell me about it.‚Äù A long moment of awkward silence passes before she rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúWell, are you gonna sit or are you going to keep standing there?‚Äù

James snaps awake. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîyeah‚Äîer‚Äîright.‚Äù

He drops his coursework on the coffee table and collapses next to Mary on the couch, sighing as he sinks down, head falling back so he ends up staring at the ceiling.

‚ÄúThat was a big sigh,‚Äù Mary says.

James smiles dryly, rolling his head towards her. ‚ÄúNo one gets up in the middle of the night for a little sigh.‚Äù

The corners of her mouth twitch up. ‚ÄúTouch√©.‚Äù

He yawns, turning back to the ceiling. ‚ÄúWhen are you allowed to start Quidditch again?‚Äù he asks, because if he doesn‚Äôt start talking he‚Äôs going to fall asleep and that‚Äôs the last thing he wants.

It‚Äôs Mary‚Äôs turn to sigh. ‚ÄúNot until after Christmas.‚Äù

James winces. ‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù

‚ÄúHead injuries are apparently serious,‚Äù she goes on flatly.

‚ÄúOh yeah, I vaguely remember that being mentioned.‚Äù Another pause, the low-burning fire crackling in front of them. James wonders absentmindedly what the house elves do if the common room never empties‚Äîdo they still come and clean it?

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll hold strong until you get back, only one more game anyway. We‚Äôre gonna take it this year, I can feel it,‚Äù he finds himself saying.

Mary makes a noncommittal noise that draws James‚Äôs eyes to her. She‚Äôs been back from the infirmary all weekend but tomorrow‚Äîtoady, actually, he supposes‚Äîwill be her first day in classes again.

James nudges her gently with his foot. ‚ÄúYou okay Macdonald?‚Äù

A long moment of silence passes. ‚ÄúHave you ever felt helpless?‚Äù she asks, eyes still on the fire.

James nods, slowly. ‚ÄúYeah, all the time.‚Äù

Mary‚Äôs fingers fidget with the sleeve of her housecoat. Despite the fact that she‚Äôs sitting next to him she feels far away. Like she‚Äôs drifting. James has the sudden desire to reach out and anchor her.

‚ÄúNot me,‚Äù she says finally. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never been helpless,‚Äù she bites down on her lower lip and James isn‚Äôt sure if she‚Äôs going to continue, but then; ‚Äúwhen I was little I used to watch all these movies, and no matter what the story was the girl always needed to be rescued. Like just, constantly. It didn‚Äôt matter if she was one of the heroes or a love interest or whatever. And I hated that. So I made this list in my head of all the things I needed to know,‚Äù she laughs at herself. ‚ÄúI thought; I‚Äôll learn all this stuff‚Äîhow to swim and fight and untie knots and fly planes‚ÄîI‚Äôll learn all this stuff, and then I‚Äôll rescue myself.‚Äù

James smiles, because yeah, that sounds just like Mary, even if he doesn‚Äôt really know much about Muggle movies or what the hell a plane is.

‚ÄúAnd did you?‚Äù he asks.

He can see her swallow.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù her voice is tight. ‚ÄúI got a letter telling me I was a Witch. Figured, what do I need to learn how to fight for? I have a wand now. I have magic. Who‚Äôs going to be able to touch me?‚Äù Somewhere beneath the anger and bitterness is something that hurts.

James doesn‚Äôt know what to say to that. Most people would probably go with something along the lines of: I‚Äôm sorry.

I‚Äôm sorry this happened.

Sorry it happened to you.

Sorry you‚Äôre hurting.

But he knows Mary well enough not to. It‚Äôd only irritate her.

‚ÄúAny word on Mulciber?‚Äù he asks instead.

A cold smile spreads across her face. ‚ÄúThey tried to expel him but his parents are kicking up a fuss. They have friends in high places apparently.‚Äù

James grimaces. ‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù

Mary nods. ‚ÄúThey promised me‚ÄîMcGonagall and Dumbledore‚Äîthat he won‚Äôt be in class, that he‚Äôll be doing all his school work in Slughorn‚Äôs office. Temporarily, anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúTemporarily?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúUntil he gets expelled or his parents get what they want and he‚Äôs let off the hook.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe used an unforgivable,‚Äù James says, outrage breaking through his exhaustion. ‚ÄúThey can‚Äôt just do nothing.‚Äù

Mary‚Äôs eyes narrow, glaring down at the fire. ‚ÄúYeah, well, maybe not.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe not what?‚Äù

She keeps glaring. ‚ÄúMaybe he didn‚Äôt use an unforgivable.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence, before James runs a hand over his face.

‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôm pretty tired here, so you‚Äôre going to have to explain that one to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to have to explain it to myself too,‚Äù she mutters. And then, after a bitter silence: ‚ÄúThey checked his wand.‚Äù

James blinks. ‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù

Mary grits her teeth, and James can see the muscles sliding in her jaw. ‚ÄúNo Imperius.‚Äù

It takes a moment for that to really sink in. ‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you were so sure‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThe working theory is I hit my head so nothing I think is reliable,‚Äù she sighs, collapsing back into the couch and closing her eyes, squeezing them shut. Her fingers come up and start massaging her temples.

James shakes his head, trying to wrap his mind around this. ‚ÄúJust because he didn‚Äôt Imperius you doesn‚Äôt mean he didn‚Äôt still‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúCrack my skull open?‚Äù she finishes for him.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe?‚Äù

She sighs, dropping her hand and looking at him. There are only the tiniest cracks in Mary‚Äôs shield‚Äîa spec of fear hiding in her eyes, in the corner of her mouth.

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù she repeats again. ‚ÄúBut I hit my head so nothing I think is reliable. Maybe he wasn‚Äôt even there. Maybe I made it all up. Maybe I slipped and fell and the rest is just some delusion.‚Äù

James hears himself growl. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs bullshit‚Äù

He almost gets a smile for that.

‚ÄúI think so too, believe it or not,‚Äù she says dryly. ‚ÄúBut then part of me almost hopes that they‚Äôre right.‚Äù Her hand goes to the back of her head, James wonders if she even knows she‚Äôs doing it.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù he asks eventually.

Her eyes have gone back to the fire, the light washing her out, exaggerating the bags under her eyes.

‚ÄúBecause I‚Äôve never been helpless.‚Äù

¬†

James hasn‚Äôt spoken to Regulus in days and he thinks it‚Äôs starting to get to him. Which, if he‚Äôs being honest with himself, is a bit pathetic. So he does his best not to be honest with himself.

It isn‚Äôt on purpose, the not talking to Reg. Well, not on his end. He has a feeling Regulus is avoiding him and he isn‚Äôt sure why. Reg has excuses, of course‚ÄîPrefect duty, homework, Quidditch practice. Not to mention the professors have started patrolling the halls at night, after the incident with Mary, and, as Regulus pointed out, not everyone has an invisibility cloak. James clings to these excuses, uses them to comfort himself when he starts feeling anxious. He knows they aren‚Äôt true of course, but it‚Äôs easier to pretend.

Which is also pathetic.

He really hates being honest with himself.

¬†

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù a balled-up piece of parchment collides with James‚Äôs head. ‚ÄúPay attention to me!‚Äù

James rolls his eyes, turning onto his stomach so he can glare at Sirius who is sitting on his own bed looking smug.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs alive!‚Äù Sirius crows dramatically.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a brat.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs grin only widens. ‚ÄúOne of my better qualities. You going to tell be why you‚Äôre sulking?‚Äù

James frowns. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sulking.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a no then.‚Äù

‚ÄúBrat.‚Äù
