James lurches to the side just in time to dodge Sirius‚Äôs pillow.

‚ÄúGood thing you‚Äôre a Beater because you can‚Äôt aim for shit,‚Äù James smirks as he pulls himself upright. Sirius gives him the finger.

‚ÄúPretty sure Beaters need to aim, or do you have yours just shooting Bludgers in random directions?‚Äù

‚ÄúI like to keep my players on their toes.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù Sirius smirks shaking his head. ‚ÄúWhatever you say El Capitan.‚Äù

Sirius has a pile of coursework around him that he‚Äôs clearly been ignoring. To be fair, since he and Remus have started‚Ä¶doing whatever it is that they‚Äôre doing‚Ä¶Sirius has been a much better student. James is pretty sure getting work done is like foreplay for Remus.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Sirius says, as though he can hear James‚Äôs thoughts. ‚ÄúYou shag your boy yet?‚Äù

A host of unwanted memories flood James‚Äôs thoughts. Regulus pressed against him, the tiny sounds escaping his mouth like he couldn‚Äôt help it, the look on his face when he‚Äôd‚Äî

‚ÄúMerlin Sirius, what the hell?‚Äù he says, attempting to push all thoughts of Regulus out of his head, resenting the curl of want that he already feels in his stomach just from thinking about him. Followed almost instantly by a pang of fear. Fear that he‚Äôs never going to get to see Regulus like that again. Fear that something has happened that he didn‚Äôt notice and now it‚Äôs all slipping through his fingers.

They fought. He gets that. But it hadn‚Äôt been relationship ending, had it?

Had it?

Had.

It.

‚ÄúJeez, you‚Äôre such a prude,‚Äù Sirius teases. He leans back, knocking a few of his textbooks onto the floor.

‚ÄúNot a prude,‚Äù James manages to say.

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúNo? How far have you two gotten then?‚Äù

James has a very clear memory of Regulus telling him not to talk about sex with Sirius.

‚ÄúListen, I don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúBecause me and Moony‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOH MY GOD,‚Äù James grabs the pillow Sirius had thrown at him and holds it over his ears. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you fucking dare!‚Äù

Sirius is already laughing. ‚ÄúYour face,‚Äù he wheezes, holding his stomach. ‚ÄúNot a prude my ass.‚Äù

Now it‚Äôs James‚Äôs turn to throw a pillow. ‚ÄúAre you trying to scar me or something? Jesus Christ.‚Äù

Sirius is still laughing. ‚ÄúListen,‚Äù he has to stop to take a breath. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just trying to figure out what the normal procedure is here.‚Äù

James blinks back at him. ‚ÄúNormal procedure?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, you know like, I know how it works with girls, how things‚Ä¶progress. But this is new territory for me. What are the steps? What are the rules? Is it hand job, blow job, and then‚Ä¶‚Äù he raises his eyebrows and James is not entirely sure that he even knows what‚Äôs being implied, ‚Äúor are there other steps I‚Äôm missing?‚Äù

‚ÄúSteps?‚Äù now he just sounds like a parrot.

‚ÄúYou know‚Äîlike first base, second base, third,‚Äù Sirius is looking at James like he should know what they‚Äôre talking about.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs a base?‚Äù James asks.

Sirius shrugs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, it‚Äôs just something people say.‚Äù

James looks at him skeptically. ‚ÄúWhat people?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust people‚Äîlook, forget about the bases, just, how‚Äôs this supposed to go? How do I up my game?‚Äù

It‚Äôs James‚Äôs turn to laugh now, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúShit Sirius, I don‚Äôt know. I don‚Äôt really think about it that much. I just‚Ä¶do what‚Ä¶feels good?‚Äù

Sirius looks at him for a minute before shaking his head. ‚ÄúI mean, it all feels good I would hope. I just‚Ä¶wanna make sure I check all the boxes.‚Äù

James feels terribly out of his depth. ‚ÄúHonestly, I‚Äôm the wrong person to talk to about this.‚Äù

A funny expression flickers across Sirius‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the only person to talk to about this.‚Äù

Which James realizes might actually be true and also is pretty tragic for the both of them because he‚Äôs pretty sure neither of them have a clue what they‚Äôre doing. James doesn‚Äôt even know what bases are.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîokay‚Äîwell,‚Äù James rubs at the back of his neck. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure as long as you‚Äôre checking the ‚Äúgetting off‚Äù box, you‚Äôre doing okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúWow, you really don‚Äôt know shit about sex do you?‚Äù

James glares at him. ‚ÄúFuck you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAfter this conversation I‚Äôd really rather you didn‚Äôt,‚Äù Sirius says grinning. James is running out of pillows to throw.

‚ÄúSeriously though,‚Äù Sirius moves back to the centre of his bed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been doing some research.‚Äù

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúResearch?‚Äù is sex something you have to research?

‚ÄúYeah, magazines and stuff, and there‚Äôs so much shit I‚Äôve never seen,‚Äù he wrinkles his nose. ‚ÄúAnd some shit I do not need to see ever again. But it‚Äôs like there‚Äôs this whole world of sex out there that I didn‚Äôt even know about. And things I never thought of‚Äîlike lube, do you use lube?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh‚Äîno?‚Äù should he?

‚ÄúApparently there‚Äôs a spell for it, which I am sure as shit gonna learn because that sounds convenient as hell.‚Äù

James makes a non-committal noise, only vaguely aware of what you might use lube for. He wonders if Reg knows more about this stuff but then, he doubts Regulus is spending his free time researching sex.

‚ÄúSo what do you reckon?‚Äù

James blinks, looking back at Sirius who is watching him expectantly, and James has the feeling that he‚Äôs missed something.

‚ÄúAbout?‚Äù he asks eventually, when Sirius doesn‚Äôt explain.

Sirius waves his hand impatiently. ‚ÄúTop or bottom?‚Äù

Which makes absolutely no sense to James so he just keeps staring blankly at Sirius who eventually starts smirking.

‚ÄúOh come on James, you know what I‚Äôm saying?‚Äù

No. He really doesn‚Äôt.

When James keeps staring, Sirius lets out an exasperated‚Äîif slightly fond‚Äîsigh. ‚ÄúOh my God, I can‚Äôt believe I have to explain this to you.‚Äù

And just because he‚Äôs feeling a little snippy about being patronized, James snaps back, ‚ÄúNobody is asking you to.‚Äù

But one of Sirius‚Äôs favourite hobbies is knowing more than other people and James can already see the look in his eyes that means there‚Äôs no way Sirius is going to pass-up this opportunity.

‚ÄúAre you the one getting or‚Ä¶y‚Äôknow‚Ä¶giving.‚Äù

Even that, James is embarrassed to admit, takes him a minute to figure out. But he does figure it out. Without needing anymore clarification from Sirius, thank God.

‚ÄúOh‚ÄîChrist, really Sirius?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a valid question!‚Äù

‚ÄúAccording to who?‚Äù

Sirius waves his arms around. ‚ÄúPeople James. People. Jesus. It‚Äôs like you‚Äôve never heard of sex in your life.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard of sex,‚Äù James grumbles petulantly.

‚ÄúIf you say so.‚Äù

‚ÄúReading a magazine doesn‚Äôt make you a porn star,‚Äù he adds, because it‚Äôs true, but it doesn‚Äôt seem to bother Sirius.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll lend you some if you want.‚Äù

‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt need your secondhand wank material thanks.‚Äù

But Sirius just grins. ‚ÄúSure about that? You might learn something. Your boy would appreciate it I‚Äôm sure.‚Äù

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúThis is officially my least favourite conversation I have ever had,‚Äù which only sets Sirius off cackling again.

‚ÄúDo you need me to explain what a condom is?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it, I‚Äôm leaving, I hate you, goodbye.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe that‚Äôs too advanced,‚Äù Sirius wheezes through his laughter because he is objectively an evil person. ‚ÄúWe can start simpler. See, kissing is when two people‚Äî‚Äù

James shoves him on his way out of the room, still able to hear him giggling from the stairwell.

¬†

James. James. James.

I‚Äôm here Reg. I‚Äôm here.

And I‚Äôm not sure how many times I have to tell you that it‚Äôs not enough.

¬†

James and Mary end up falling into a kind of routine. One which largely involves the two of them sleep deprived and sitting on the couch in the Gryffindor common room in the middle of the night. Sometimes Mary brings the Muggle candy her parents send her from home. James was skeptical at first but it‚Äôs actually pretty good, and nothing is vomit flavoured or trying to bite him so he might even like it better than wizard candy. He says as much to Mary who laughs.

They talk a lot, because there‚Äôs not really anything else to do. James gives up on trying to get homework done. He might not be able to sleep but that doesn‚Äôt mean he‚Äôs fully functioning at three in the morning.

He learns a lot about Mary, who apparently he didn‚Äôt know as well as he thought. He learns that she has three siblings, all Muggles like her parents. He learns that her brother plays football, which is like Muggle Quidditch.

‚ÄúWell actually, it‚Äôs nothing like Quidditch at all, but same idea,‚Äù Mary corrects herself, succeeding only in further confusing James.

‚ÄúHow can it be nothing like Quidditch but also the same idea?‚Äù

Mary gives him an exasperated look like that‚Äôs the stupidest question she‚Äôs ever heard. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre both sports.‚Äù The ‚Äúduh‚Äù seems to be implied.

James decides to let it go.

He learns other stuff too. Like that Amos Diggory is apparently a very bad kisser.

‚ÄúToo many teeth,‚Äù Mary shivers. James does not press her for details.

And that butter tarts are her favourite desert, and lilacs her favourite flowers and she‚Äôs never been to Paris but she‚Äôs certain she‚Äôll end up there one day‚Äîliving in some beautiful apartment, buying bread at the local bakery every morning and drinking red wine and smoking hand rolled cigarets.

‚ÄúI can just feel it you know?‚Äù she says, it‚Äôs the most sincere he thinks he‚Äôs ever seen her. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs where I‚Äôm supposed to be.‚Äù

He smiles back, her energy a little contagious even in the middle of the night. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll get there.‚Äù

He tells her stuff too, of course. About his parents. His mum.

‚ÄúThey wanted a kid so bad, tried everything, tried for ages,‚Äù James is on the floor, leaning back against the couch, lower lip caught between his teeth. ‚ÄúSometimes I feel the weight of that‚Äîof being their miracle. Of trying to deserve all the love they‚Äôve spent years saving up. Does that sound selfish? That my biggest problem is being loved too much?‚Äù He laughs at himself, voice still tight.

Mary shakes her head. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says confidently. ‚ÄúIt makes perfect sense.‚Äù

They remind him of the astronomy tower, these little talks, remind him of those first few weeks of sneaking up there to see Regulus before he really knew what he was doing. Where any of it was going. Of sitting and talking for hours and hours, about nothing and everything. It makes his chest ache so bad his hand comes up to press against his ribs, like he‚Äôs trying to keep something in, keep something together. It‚Äôs been nearly a week now since he last talked to Reg. He stares at the map every night but Regulus never goes to the room. Yesterday James went anyway. Because he missed it. Because he had this ridiculous hope that somehow Regulus would know that he was there.

He doesn‚Äôt know what he did. So he runs through everything they said the morning after the Veritaserum. Runs through it again and again. Making new wounds, pouring salt in the old ones.

He‚Äôd told Regulus once that even if he walked away he would always come back. It had never occurred to him that one day there wouldn‚Äôt be anyone to come back to.

Mostly he just misses him. With his whole body. With every inch of himself.

‚ÄúWhat are your nightmares about?‚Äù Mary is lying on the couch on her back, James mirroring her position on the carpet, both of them staring at the ceiling. The question comes after a long period of silence.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to tell me,‚Äù she goes on, not sounding apologetic‚Äîshe never is.

Mostly, when he can help it, when he‚Äôs awake, he does his best not to think about his dreams. Not to go back there. Not to let those images in. Hands and darkness and Regulus screaming his name. He shivers.

‚ÄúLetting someone down,‚Äù he croaks, deciding to keep it vague. He has to clear his throat before he can say anymore. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs someone who needs me and I can‚Äôt get to them‚ÄîI‚Äôm there and I can see it all happening, hear them screaming, but I can‚Äôt save them.‚Äù He closes his eyes briefly, swallowing.

There‚Äôs a moment of silence and James wonders if Mary‚Äôs actually fallen asleep but then she speaks; ‚ÄúYou really are the Gryffindor poster boy huh?‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt think Gryffindor had nightmares. Too brave.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt be brave if you aren‚Äôt afraid of something.‚Äù

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that the definition of bravery? Being fearless?‚Äù he turns his head just in time to see her roll her eyes.

‚ÄúNo, bravery is facing your fears, standing your ground when you want to run. Only psychopaths are fearless.‚Äù

James has never thought about it like that before‚Äînever thought of fear as a necessary part of bravery‚Äîthough he supposes he should have.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre your nightmares about then?‚Äù he finds himself asking.

It‚Äôs funny that he somehow manages to hear Mary go silent even though she hadn‚Äôt been speaking to begin with. There‚Äôs a shift in the space around her‚Äîa tightening of her whole body.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to answer,‚Äù he does sound apologetic‚Äîhe always is.

The silence stretches on and James watches her profile from his spot on the floor. Watches her chest rise and fall. He tries not to fidget, fights the urge to speak. Eventually Mary closes her eyes.

‚ÄúI think I was raped.‚Äù

The first thing he thinks is: Regulus never says it. Can‚Äôt even hear the word.

The second thing he thinks is: oh my God.

‚ÄúI dream about it,‚Äù Mary goes on when James remains silent. ‚ÄúI can feel the weight of him‚ÄîI can smell him‚Äîhis skin‚Äî‚Äú she falters, voice cutting off sharply.

‚ÄúDid you tell McGonagall?‚Äù James finds himself asking, not knowing if that‚Äôs the right response. ‚ÄúDumbledore?‚Äù

Mary exhales heavily, a wry smile in the corner of her mouth. ‚ÄúThey barely believe me about the curse, I can‚Äôt imagine they‚Äôll take this very seriously. I don‚Äôt even know what I would say. That I have dreams about some boy lying on top of me? That I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on but I know I don‚Äôt want it. I don‚Äôt‚Äîlike it,‚Äù she lets out a humourless laugh. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not even sure I believe me.‚Äù

Something twists in James‚Äôs stomach. ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù

Mary opens her eyes at that, turning to look at him. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

James nods, sitting upright so he can look at her properly. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know I hit my head pretty hard. I‚Äôm not a very reliable source.‚Äù

‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù

After a minute she gives him a sad smile. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a good guy James Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúMary,‚Äù he says softly. ‚ÄúWhat do you need? What do you want to do? I‚Äîwhat do you need?‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know. He doesn‚Äôt know what to do. Just knows that if she tells him he‚Äôll do it.

She shakes her head. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what I need honestly.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou want me to beat the shit out of Mulciber?‚Äù James isn‚Äôt entirely sure he won‚Äôt do that anyway.

There‚Äôs a pause. Mary presses the heels of her hands into her eyes, not the way people do when they‚Äôre crying but like she has a headache. Like she‚Äôs trying to push something through the back of her skull. James wants to tell her to be careful. He doesn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it was Mulciber,‚Äù she says eventually, sounding tired.

James takes that in, nods, ignores the nauseas feeling he has about this whole thing. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says simply.

She drops her hands, turning to look at him, still lying down. ‚ÄúSee? Unreliable.‚Äù

James decides to ignore that. ‚ÄúYou said you remember other Slytherins hanging around in the hall?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it was them either.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho do you think it was?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a long pause before she shakes her head. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. I don‚Äôt know anything. I have fucking brain damage or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could go a little easier on yourself here Mary,‚Äù because she could.

Mary only laughs. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre going to get away with it,‚Äù she mutters bitterly. ‚ÄúBecause they‚Äôre boys. Because they‚Äôre rich. Because my head is broken and I can‚Äôt get my story straight. They‚Äôre going to get away with it and it makes me so angry because something‚Äî‚Äú her voice cracks for the first time, wobbling out of her mouth. She lets out a frustrated exhale, blinking the moisture from her eyes.

‚ÄúSomething bad happened,‚Äù she goes on, voice small. ‚ÄúSomething really fucking bad happened and I can feel it in my chest and under my nails and behind my teeth and I must have taken a hundred showers since I woke up in that fucking hospital bed but I can‚Äôt seem to wash it off.‚Äù

James reaches out, squeezing her arm. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre remembering things, its coming back, just like Pomfrey said it would. Give it a few days, a week, see if your memory clears.‚Äù

James can feel her shake under his hand. He can‚Äôt imagine how she feels. How much this hurts. He tries but he can‚Äôt.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I can stand it,‚Äù she whispers finally, eyes squeezing shut.

James swallows around the lump in his throat. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not going to get away with it,‚Äù he says, voice nearly as quiet as her‚Äôs. ‚ÄúI promise.‚Äù

The silence stretches on for a long time before her mouth flicks up at the corner, eyes still closed. ‚ÄúOf course you do,‚Äù it comes out sounding overfond. ‚ÄúBloody Gryffindor poster boy.‚Äù

¬†

He watches the map. Doesn‚Äôt sleep. Watches the map some more. Doesn‚Äôt sleep. Watches Regulus walk to and from class with his friends. Watches him spend as little time in the common room as possible and as much time in his dorm as he can. Doesn‚Äôt sleep. Watches him avoid the library. The Quidditch pitch. Anywhere else James could reasonably run into him. Talk to him. Doesn‚Äôt sleep.

Sometimes he gets angry. Breaks an inkwell by accident when he‚Äôs throwing things around too aggressively. Very much on purpose destroys one of his textbooks by chucking it at the wall. Shoves the map roughly into his bedside table and swears not to look at it again. Swears that he doesn‚Äôt care. If Regulus wants to sulk or freeze him out or do whatever the hell bullshit thing he‚Äôs doing then he can. James is tired. He‚Äôs so fucking tired and he doesn‚Äôt care, so there.

Except he does care.

Cares a pathetic all consuming amount.

Except he always takes the map out again. Follows the same name around the castle. Wonders what he did. Wonders what Regulus is thinking.

Doesn‚Äôt sleep.

Doesn‚Äôt sleep.

Doesn‚Äôt sleep.

And then. It happens.

He sees Regulus alone, for the first time in days, and he practically sprints out of the dorm. Doesn‚Äôt answer Remus or Peter when they ask where he‚Äôs going. Doesn‚Äôt stop to grab the invisibility cloak.

It‚Äôs just after supper, eight o‚Äôclock, almost curfew. The sun through the castle windows is orange and pink and setting the sky on fire as it drips towards the horizon. James jogs to the random corridor on the third floor, hopes Regulus is still there, hopes he hasn‚Äôt gone too far.

He‚Äôs almost given up when he finds him, standing in front of one of the windows. James stutters to a stop, somehow, through the anger and fear and ache, he feels his breath catch.

Fuck,

He thinks inelegantly.

He‚Äôs so beautiful.

For a moment James can‚Äôt move, can‚Äôt bring himself to ruin the picture in front of him.

He‚Äôs so beautiful,

His thoughts ramble on.

I love him so much.

James really is screwed here, the sudden realization hitting him like a Bludger to the chest. Because he doesn‚Äôt know what he‚Äôs going to do if Regulus is finished with him. Doesn‚Äôt know how he‚Äôs going to get over this. It‚Äôs a clich√©, the teenager thinking they‚Äôre in love. Something his parents would laugh about. Call cute and pinch his cheeks.

But this doesn‚Äôt feel cute.

This feels like the person he wants most in the world has been avoiding him for days.

And he can‚Äôt sleep.

And he can‚Äôt think.

And looking at him hurts.

Loving him hurts.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

His head snaps in James‚Äôs direction so quickly it‚Äôs almost startling, hand going predictably to his wand before he recognizes James and then his eyes scan the space around them. Always hiding. Always so afraid of being seen.

‚ÄúWe shouldn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre avoiding me,‚Äù James steps closer, watching as Regulus barely suppresses a wince. He doesn‚Äôt answer, just turns his head, looking down at the ground.

It hurts.

It hurts.

It hurts.

‚ÄúWhat did I do?‚Äù he hates how weak it sounds but he doesn‚Äôt take it back. ‚ÄúI need you to tell me what I did.‚Äù

Regulus scoffs. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt do anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen what happened?‚Äù another step closer, Regulus still not looking at him.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù it‚Äôs said in a condescending tone, like he‚Äôs missing something obvious.

Everything feels a little fuzzy, his pulse beating too fast, fear clawing at his ribs. ‚ÄúAre you ending this?‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt manage to keep his voice level. Doesn‚Äôt manage to keep the pain out of it.

Regulus doesn‚Äôt even try to hide the flinch this time. Doesn‚Äôt try to answer either. Just stands there. The silence making James‚Äôs skin feel too tight.

He really needs to sleep.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù his voice scratches and cracks.

Regulus won‚Äôt look at him. Still doesn‚Äôt answer. It feels like one of his nightmares. He knows it isn‚Äôt. He digs his nails into his palms so he can feel the sting. Counts the fingers on his hands. He knows this isn‚Äôt a nightmare. But Regulus won‚Äôt look at him. Won‚Äôt speak.

He bends over, grabbing his knees, trying to breathe. Trying not to be sick.

He really needs to sleep.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù

Regulus sounds far away, James still trying to keep his dinner down. He hears the sound of footsteps but he doesn‚Äôt raise his head.

‚ÄúMerlin James, are you okay?‚Äù

He shakes his head, and when he speaks his voice is breathless. ‚ÄúAre you ending this?‚Äù

He needs to know.

He just needs to know.

Regulus makes a noise‚ÄîJames doesn‚Äôt know what it means‚Äîfrustration maybe? And then there‚Äôs a hand in his hair, on his face, his shoulders, forcing him upright.

‚ÄúI wanna be enough,‚Äù James says pathetically, barely able to meet Regulus‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúI wanna be enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúChrist James,‚Äù Regulus mutters, holding his face between his hands like he‚Äôs forgotten they‚Äôre still in the middle of the hallway. His eyes big and grey and full of regret.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou did.‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre enough, you‚Äôre more than enough, you‚Äôre so much more than I deserve. That‚Äôs the problem, can‚Äôt you see it?‚Äù his thumbs stroke James‚Äôs cheeks.

‚ÄúWhere have you been Reg?‚Äù he asks weakly.

Regulus‚Äôs usually schooled expression cracks. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just trying to do the right thing,‚Äù he whispers, which makes no sense to James at all.

‚ÄúThe right thing?‚Äù James repeats back.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMr. Black.‚Äù

Regulus jumps back, hands dropping from James‚Äôs face as he whips around, McGonagall walking towards them down the hall. James watches the colour drain from Regulus‚Äôs face and he wants to reach out and steady him but he knows that would only make it worse.

‚ÄúProfessor?‚Äù Regulus finally manages to get out, voice so tight it hurts.

To McGonagall‚Äôs credit she only gives James a brief glance, like finding the pair of them embracing in the middle of the hallway is completely normal.

‚ÄúThe headmaster would like to see you in his office.‚Äù

Regulus visibly stiffens.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù the word comes out of James‚Äôs mouth before he can stop himself. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

McGonagall arches her brow in his direction but doesn‚Äôt dignify that question with an answer.

When Regulus speaks next his voice is flat. James has heard that tone before. Knows that it means Reg is scared. ‚ÄúOf course, Professor,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt look back at James, just starts walking, like they weren‚Äôt in the middle of‚Äî

‚ÄúMr. Potter, I believe it is almost curfew, perhaps you‚Äôd better head back to your dormitory.‚Äù

James blinks, tearing his eyes away from Regulus‚Äôs shrinking back, barely resisting the urge to go after him.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happened?‚Äù he asks, earning him a rather exasperated sigh.

‚ÄúSurely you must know that I can‚Äôt disclose that information to you?‚Äù

James swallows with difficulty. ‚ÄúIs he in trouble? Has something happened with his family?‚Äù

‚ÄúMr. Potter‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt I wait for him?‚Äù he says desperately. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚ÄîI‚Äôll just wait outside, I swear. I just don‚Äôt want him to be‚Äîwe‚Äôre supposed to be in pairs right? If we have to go somewhere after curfew? So I can just‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúJames.‚Äù

His mouth shuts at the use of his first name, all further protests dying on his tongue. McGonagall gives him an appraising look over the top of her glasses. He‚Äôs not sure what she sees but when she speaks again her voice is softer than he expects it to be.

‚ÄúI will make sure that Mr. Black gets safely back to his dormitory,‚Äù she says calmly. ‚ÄúBut right now I need you to go to yours,‚Äù and when James still doesn‚Äôt move. ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt a suggestion.‚Äù

His hands are shaking, Regulus now gone, disappeared around the corner at the end of the hall. It‚Äôs painful, swallowing his questions. His fear. His indignation. Painful nodding his head and turning back in the opposite direction.

He feels useless. Helpless. All the things he keeps trying to convince Regulus that he isn‚Äôt. It burns the inside of his skin.

¬†

I‚Äôm here Reg. I‚Äôm here.

I‚Äôm here Reg.

I‚Äôm here.

I‚Äôm here.

I‚Äôm‚Äî

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

I really liked the idea of developing the James/Mary friendship so hopefully you guys liked it too!

Also shout-out to Sirius Black for providing the only comic relief in this whole chapter.

Thank you thank you thank you for the comments and kudos!

Chapter 28

Chapter Summary

Dumbledore is not a great guy. Thanks for coming to my TED Talk.

Chapter Notes

TW: referenced / implied sexual assault

**French translation in the end notes!**

ALSO: I feel like I've said this before but Reg is not a reliable narrator. Just because he as a character doesn't really see the difference between the Death Eaters and the Order doesn't mean I'm arguing that there isn't a difference, like there is. There very much is. Very important difference. They are not equally in the wrong just because Dumbledore is a dick. This is not a Death Eater apologist fic. Just wanna make sure that's clear.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

He‚Äôs not sure if it makes him feel better or worse that when the doors to the Headmaster‚Äôs office open, Regulus finds himself faced with Snape, Mulciber and Avery. Better, he decides, even though his steps falter for half a heartbeat. If he‚Äôs going to be royal fucked over he fully intends to take them all down with him.

‚ÄúMr. Black,‚Äù Dumbledore is standing with his back to Regulus, feeding something that might be fish to a rather intimidating looking phoenix. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you could join us,‚Äù as though he had a choice. ‚ÄúPlease, take a seat.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt speak, taking the only free chair available in front of the headmaster‚Äôs desk. He can feel the other three boys watching him the whole time, but he doesn‚Äôt look back until he‚Äôs seated, and even then only briefly. Only long enough to catch the smug look on Snape‚Äôs face.

This is not going to be going well for him then.

‚ÄúI expect your aware that Mary Macdonald was attacked a week ago?‚Äù Dumbledore finally turns around, face soft, almost smiling. Regulus has never particularly liked holding his gaze.

He nods and then, when it feels like Dumbledore is waiting for more; ‚ÄúYes sir, I‚Äôm aware.‚Äù

‚ÄúMs. Macdonald believes that these three boys were the ones to attack her,‚Äù he waves almost casually at the group of Slytherins beside Regulus. ‚ÄúBut they claim to have been in their dorm room and alas, their spell histories do not appear to match Mary‚Äôs testimony.‚Äù

It is work for Regulus not to react to that, because there is no way that Barty cast all those Imperius‚Äôs. He doubts Mulciber or Avery have the capability for that kind of advance magic so it must of been Snape. Which means that he either wiped his wand or Barty was stupid enough to let him cast using his. Which Regulus is loathed to admit, is a possibility.

‚ÄúIt is our belief,‚Äù Dumbledore goes on. ‚ÄúThat Mary Macdonald has had her memory tampered with.‚Äù

Once again, Regulus suppresses his reaction. Staring blankly back at Dumbledore, waiting for more. But no more comes. The room is submerged in silence, the only noise that of Avery fidgeting in the seat next to him.

Eventually Regulus clears his throat. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry professor, but what does this have to do with me?‚Äù

Dumbledore smiles mildly at him. ‚ÄúMr. Snape claims that you were rather upset about the way that Mary Macdonald spoke to your friend in the corridor that day. That he saw you hovering around the Gryffindor common room after supper.‚Äù

Regulus resists the urge to roll his eyes. ‚ÄúI see,‚Äù he says coldly, the kind expression remaining on Dumbledore‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúYour roommates claim you were out that evening, though they couldn‚Äôt tell me where.‚Äù

Oh.

That isn‚Äôt good.

He knows they probably thought they were doing him a favour, keeping him away from the scene of the crime. Not realizing they were robbing him of an alibi. Not realizing that he needed one.

‚ÄúSo tell me, Mr. Black, where were you, the night of Mary Macdonald‚Äôs attack?‚Äù

Regulus almost laughs.

He can‚Äôt tell him of course, doesn‚Äôt trust him, certainly doesn‚Äôt trust Avery or Mulciber or Snape. Snape who somehow knew that Regulus wouldn‚Äôt be able to answer this question, which makes something uneasy crawl into the pit of his stomach.

He can‚Äôt tell them that he‚Äôd spent that night cuddling Jame bloody Potter.

‚ÄúI was in the astronomy tower,‚Äù he hears himself say. Avery snorts.

‚ÄúThe astronomy tower?‚Äù Dumbledore repeats, eyebrow raised. ‚ÄúAny reason in particular?‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth. ‚ÄúStargazing.‚Äù

Dumbledore makes an ‚Äúah‚Äù shape with his mouth. ‚ÄúAlone?‚Äù

‚ÄúAlone.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see. Well, in that case, may I have your wand?‚Äù

Regulus blinks back at him. ‚ÄúSir?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust as a way to clear your name, confirm that you had nothing to do with this.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt know what Snape and his band of baboons did to keep their wands clean, but he knows that he hasn‚Äôt done anything. Meaning that his Legilimens is going to show right up.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

Dumbledore arches his brow. ‚ÄúNo?‚Äù

‚ÄúWith all due respect sir,‚Äù Regulus goes on with all the spoiled brat indignation he can muster. ‚ÄúIn order to check a minors wand you require the permission of their parent or guardian or a warrant from the Ministry.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?!‚Äù Mulciber squawks indignantly. And out of the corner of his eye Regulus thinks he sees Snape frown as well. Apparently they were unaware of that rule. It‚Äôs a small victory, not enough to get Regulus off the hook, but enough to buy him time at least.

Dumbledore has gone silent again, eyes unwaveringly on Regulus. He wonders if this usually works for him‚Äîif he just waits students out, until they can‚Äôt take the pressure anymore. If so, he‚Äôll be sorely disappointed. Regulus has spent far too much time in Walburga‚Äôs house to be intimidated by a staring contest. Even if it is with Albus Dumbledore.

Eventually, the older man smiles, sending a chill down Regulus‚Äôs spine. ‚ÄúMr. Snape, Avery, Mulciber, you‚Äôre free to return to your dormitory.‚Äù

Regulus isn‚Äôt proud of the spike of fear that shoots through his chest right then. Not that he trusted any of them to have his back, but the idea of being left alone in this office makes him nervous.

As the other boys shuffle out of their seats and towards the door he tries to focus on the feel of his wand against his skin, as though he would stand any chance against Albus Dumbledore. Still. It helps knowing it‚Äôs there.

Eventually, the door closes, and they‚Äôre alone.

Something isn‚Äôt quite right about this‚Äîthe timing, the lack of parents, Dumbledore sending the others away. It makes Regulus‚Äôs skin itch.

‚ÄúI was wondering,‚Äù Dumbledore goes on mildly. ‚ÄúIf your answer might change now that we‚Äôre alone?‚Äù

Regulus stares back at him flatly, even though he can feel his pulse beating out of the side of his neck. ‚ÄúJust to clarify,‚Äù his tone sounds especially posh, ‚Äúthose three have all been identified by the victim, but I‚Äôm the one you‚Äôre questioning?‚Äù

Dumbledore‚Äôs eyes twinkle. ‚ÄúThey all have alibis.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. Each other. You don‚Äôt find that suspicious?‚Äù

Dumbledore holds his gaze and then, after an extended silence, shrugs. ‚ÄúPerhaps, but I‚Äôd still like to know where you were that night, and why you‚Äôre so reluctant to hand over your wand?‚Äù

‚ÄúI told you where I was,‚Äù Regulus replies, stubbornly ignoring the second question.

‚ÄúIn the astronomy tower, stargazing?‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth, hands curling around the arms of his chair. He doesn‚Äôt want to be here. He feels trapped. He feels small.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he grinds out.

‚ÄúBut no one can confirm that?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhile Mr. Snape can confirm that you were angry at Ms. Macdonald, and waiting around her dormitory?‚Äù

It‚Äôs the look in his eyes that makes it sink in. That makes Regulus realize what‚Äôs really going on. Realize that Dumbledore wants him to be guilty.

‚ÄúSnape can confirm,‚Äù he repeats, trying to keep his voice steady, ‚ÄúSnape who has been accused of being involved in the attack. Do you not think that gives him an ulterior motive here?‚Äù

Another long pause. Another shrug.

‚ÄúI have to tell you, these allegation are quite serious,‚Äù the older man goes on.

None of this is right. Regulus knows that. Eyes bouncing around the dark office, looking for what he doesn‚Äôt know, but suddenly feeling surrounded.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt about Mary Macdonald, is it?‚Äù he finds himself saying, eyes returning to Dumbledore‚Äôs eerily calm face. ‚ÄúThis is about the war.‚Äù

Dumbledore smiles. It doesn‚Äôt feel friendly. ‚ÄúAre you aware of what your parents have been up to recently?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he‚Äôs not even sure if it‚Äôs a lie.

Dumbledore leans forward across his desk, not aggressively, but their increased proximity does little to quell Regulus‚Äôs growing anxiety. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe that. Just like I don‚Äôt believe that you were in the astronomy tower the night Mary Macdonald was attacked.‚Äù

‚ÄúI had nothing to do with that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid it‚Äôs looking more and more like you can‚Äôt prove it.‚Äù

Okay,

Reg tries to steady himself.

Okay. There has to be a way out of this.

Think.

You‚Äôre clever. You can do this.

Just think.

‚ÄúAre you threatening to expel me? Is that it?‚Äù he is proud that his voice doesn‚Äôt shake as badly as his hands have started to.

‚ÄúFor an unforgivable? A violent attack on a student? Expulsion is the least of your worries Mr. Black. The Ministry has already expressed their desire to be involved. They‚Äôre desperate for the chance to punish someone after the attacks last year and over the summer. They want someone to make an example of.‚Äù

Regulus swallows with difficulty but refuses to be intimidated. He has friends at the Ministry. Or‚Äîwell‚Äîhe has whatever Lucius and Roldolphus are. Has his father‚Äôs old colleagues. They‚Äôll help him won‚Äôt they?

‚ÄúI was under the impression you didn‚Äôt have much pull at the Ministry these days,‚Äù is the closest he‚Äôll come to saying any of that out loud.

Something dark flashes in Dumbledore‚Äôs blue eyes but when he speaks his tone remains light. ‚ÄúI have enough. I assure you.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs true. He worries it might be.

‚ÄúWhat do you want from me?‚Äù he feels hopelessly outgunned. He should have seen this coming, he should have known he couldn‚Äôt just come back to school with the Dark Mark on his arm and pretend like he was just any other student. Dumbledore isn‚Äôt just his headmaster anymore. He‚Äôs an advisory.

‚ÄúI want you to keep me informed on the actions of your parents, who they see, where they go, what they get up to,‚Äù he opens his hands in a placating gesture. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid we‚Äôve rather fallen out of touch.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs nails are digging into his chair, trying to get a hold of his swirling thoughts. Strangely, he feels bad, though not for himself. For James. Because he knows that James would never believe Dumbledore to be capable of such a dirty play. Regulus is less surprised.

‚ÄúYou want me to be‚Äîwhat‚Äîa spy?‚Äù

His eyes dance in the firelight. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôd like.‚Äù

A bitter laugh leaves Regulus‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúMary Macdonald know you‚Äôre using her attack as a bargaining chip?‚Äù

‚ÄúCome now Regulus,‚Äù he almost flinches at the sound of his name coming out of Dumbledore‚Äôs mouth. Somehow he manages to make it sound like a threat. ‚ÄúLets not pretend that you care about Mary Macdonald.‚Äù

Regulus glares back at him.

No,

he thinks.

Lets not.

‚ÄúI am giving you an opportunity here,‚Äù the old man goes on, as though it‚Äôs as simple as that. ‚ÄúWill you work with me?‚Äù

Me.

Not us.

Not ‚Äúthe greater good.‚Äù

Me.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù the word is out of his mouth before he‚Äôs even really thought it through. He should probably be more strategic about this. It‚Äôs an opportunity to switch sides, not something he‚Äôd ever thought he would have. But he doesn‚Äôt like being bullied. Doesn‚Äôt trust Dumbledore to keep him safe. To give a shit about him when things inevitably get messy and dangerous.

Dumbledore arches his brow. ‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. Can I go now?‚Äù his voice is sharp, his whole body trembling.

After a long look, Dumbledore nods. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll be seeing one another again soon.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt bother responding, too anxious to get out of that office, hating that in order to do it he has to turn his back on the old man. It‚Äôs not until he‚Äôs in the stairwell that he realizes how badly he‚Äôs sweating.

Fuck.

He hopes it's a bluff, that Dumbledore wouldn't really go through the hassle of trying to pin Macdonald‚Äôs attack on him. Of trying to turn it into some big deal.

He hopes.

Fuck.

He nearly jumps out of his skin when he steps into the corridor outside the Headmaster‚Äôs office and feels fingers wrap around his wrist. Disembodied fingers.

‚ÄúJesus Christ Ja‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShh,‚Äù the half-invisible boy hisses, and Regulus is just shaken enough that he doesn‚Äôt argue. ‚ÄúSnape is waiting for you around the corner,‚Äù James whispers.

Regulus looks up ahead as if he‚Äôd be able to see him.

Great. An ambush. That‚Äôs just what he needs right now.

James lifts his arm, revealing himself more fully, and beckoning for Regulus to join him. The younger boy gives him a skeptical look.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to fit.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll crouch.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes but doesn‚Äôt argue further. Doesn‚Äôt have the energy. James does crouch, practically folding himself around Regulus as the move down the hallway under the invisibility cloak, breath hot on the back of Regulus‚Äôs neck, arms warm over his shoulders.

Snape is, of course, waiting around the corner, leaning against the wall, wand twirling between his fingers. Maybe Regulus had underestimated Snape‚Äôs friendship with Mulciber. He‚Äôd been pretty confident that Snape would let his goon take the fall for them. Apparently he‚Äôd made a mistake.

James nudges him around the next corner and Regulus doesn‚Äôt need to ask where he‚Äôs leading them, though part of him wants to protest. He‚Äôs not sure he can deal with James right now. Not sure he knows where James falls in all this. Especially when there‚Äôs the possibility that McGonagall knows about them. A possibility she might tell Dumbledore, give him something else to use against Regulus.

The minute they cross the threshold of the Come and Go Room Regulus pulls away from James‚Äîaway from his touch and his heat and his smell and all the rest of it. All the things that cloud his judgement. Make him weak. He‚Äôs still shaking, he realizes, and he prays that somehow James didn‚Äôt notice.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù the other boy asks eventually.

And of all the things Regulus should say: go away. Leave me alone. I don‚Äôt want you here.

‚ÄúYou came back?‚Äù is what comes out of his mouth.

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

Of course. As if he would ever do anything else. James Potter always comes back. So fucking sweet he makes Regulus‚Äôs teeth ache. He wants to hate it. It‚Äôd be so much easier if he could hate it.

Regulus is thrumming his fingers on the back of the couch, staring at the far wall, trying to figure out what he should do. He could write to his mother, to Narcissa, to Bellatrix. For once in his life they might actually be of help. Though he isn‚Äôt at all confident that Dumbledore won‚Äôt check his mail, or that he‚Äôll like the help his family wants to give him.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù James says again, sounding closer. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happened?‚Äù

And then there‚Äôs this.

James.

James bloody Potter.

The boy he‚Äôs been trying so desperately to distance himself from. For both their sakes. Regulus isn‚Äôt sure he can stand watching James fall out of love with him, and he‚Äôd been certain that he‚Äôd started. That James was growing tired of him. Until today when James tracked him down practically in tears, begging to be enough. Which was heartbreaking and confusing and dangerous all rolled into one.

Regulus squeezes his eyes shut.

He doesn‚Äôt want to hurt James.

But it‚Äôs inevitable at this point.

No matter what he does.

He hears footsteps and when he opens his eyes again James is facing him, full of concern. Regulus reaches out, as weak as always, reaches out and grabs James‚Äôs wrists, his waist, his shoulders. Like he‚Äôs building him with his hands, confirming that he‚Äôs there and real and something that Regulus can have if he wants.

Because he does doesn‚Äôt he?

Want him?

Love him?

Hate him?

A huff of laughter forces its way out of his struggling lungs. He doesn‚Äôt think it‚Äôs ever like this in the stories. Love. The prince and the princess stand next to one another and there‚Äôs no question that they belong together. That it‚Äôs right. That it will make them happy. All Regulus has is questions. All Regulus has is the deep feeling of wrongness in his stomach every time James looks at him like he‚Äôs important.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù James says softly‚Äîsweetly. He grabs Regulus‚Äôs wrists, stilling his hands where they are, cradling James‚Äôs face.

He needs to learn not to give everything away, Regulus thinks as he stares up into the older boy‚Äôs eyes, which are all feeling. All heart. James Potter walks through life without any armour on and one of these days it‚Äôs going to get him killed. Just the thought sends a shiver through Regulus's body.

‚ÄúYou came back,‚Äù he croaks again, which is still not what he wants to say and he doesn‚Äôt know why that keeps happening. All he knows is that he‚Äôs been ignoring James for days and then the first time they speak he gets dragged to the Headmaster‚Äôs office and still, for some reason, James is here. Here waiting for him. Even though Regulus has shown him in every way that he doesn‚Äôt deserve it.

‚ÄúI told you I would,‚Äù James gives his wrists a light squeeze.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know how to explain to James that he never takes anyone at their word. Doesn‚Äôt know how to.

They just keep standing there, holding one another, looking at one another. Regulus focuses on James‚Äôs face instead of everything else going on inside him. There are finger smudges on his glasses‚Äîthere always are‚Äîflecks of gold in his eyes, barely there freckles on the bridge of his slightly crooked nose. Regulus has the sudden urge to be able to paint the Muggle way‚Äîhe wants to stare at this face for hours, for days, for weeks. Wants to figure out what shade of pink his lips are, wants to draw his smile just right, commit his dimples to memory. He wants to take his time. Wants to make James Potter his life‚Äôs work.

A stupid useless fantasy.

Eventually James sighs, pulling Regulus‚Äôs hands gently from his face but not letting go of his wrists, tugging Regulus towards the couch. When they‚Äôre sitting James turns to him, expectantly.

‚ÄúI can do this all night you know, it‚Äôs not like I‚Äôm gonna get any sleep anyway,‚Äù James says it with a half-hearted smile but Regulus suddenly notices the heavy bags under James‚Äôs eyes which are slightly bloodshot, his hair more of a disaster than usual.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not sleeping?‚Äù he finds himself asking.

James waves his hand dismissively. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not important right now,‚Äù James gives him a serious look. ‚ÄúWhat did Dumbledore want and what does it have to do with Snape?‚Äù

Regulus looks back, considers lying, finds he doesn‚Äôt have the energy. He‚Äôs not sure he can see the point.

‚ÄúMary Macdonald‚Äôs attack,‚Äù Regulus says, causing James to stiffen. ‚ÄúSnape, Avery and Mulciber are saying it was me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre WHAT.‚Äù

James‚Äôs indignation is almost flattering, unfortunately it‚Äôs followed by a swelling of guilt in Regulus‚Äôs stomach. Because he hadn‚Äôt attacked Mary Macdonald. But he had covered it up. Was still covering it up.

He pushes on, ‚ÄúAnd since I don‚Äôt have an alibi Dumbledore is willing to believe them,‚Äù he leaves out the politics. Afraid to hear what James would say about Dumbledore‚Äôs proposed deal. Afraid that he‚Äôd take the old man‚Äôs side.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have‚Äî‚Äú he sees the moment it clicks for James. ‚ÄúMe,‚Äù he says suddenly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm your alibi?‚Äù

‚ÄúTechnically.‚Äù

Regulus barely has time to blink before James is off the couch and heading for the door.

‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äù Regulus demands, quickly getting up to follow.

‚ÄúTo Dumbledore. I‚Äôm gonna tell him you have an alibi.‚Äù

Regulus feels his heart stop.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt do that,‚Äù James is too far ahead, hand already on the door. Regulus whips out his wand. ‚ÄúProtego!‚Äù he shouts, which somehow works because James is thrown backwards, stumbling until he trips onto his ass.

‚ÄúShit‚Äîwhat the hell Reg?‚Äù he looks up at him indignantly.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt tell Dumbledore about us.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy the hell not? They‚Äôre accusing you of having used a goddamn unforgivable! Of assaulting someone!‚Äù James looks at him like hearing it out loud will change Regulus‚Äôs mind.

It doesn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúWould you really rather be a rapist than gay?‚Äù

That takes Regulus back. ‚ÄúA rapist?‚Äù he repeats.

James‚Äôs eyes go wide, like he‚Äôs only just realizing what he‚Äôs said.

‚ÄúIs Macdonald saying she was raped?‚Äù

His thoughts start firing off in a dozen different directions. Nonsensically he thinks that that isn‚Äôt right, because he stopped Barty didn‚Äôt he? He thought he‚Äôd stopped him? And then, perhaps more troubling, he moves on to the fact that Mary Macdonald shouldn‚Äôt have those memories at all, he got rid of everything that was there. Everything that wasn‚Äôt dark. Something cold drips down his spine. Were the blindspots not permanent? Are those moments becoming clear for her?

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

At some point during Regulus‚Äôs spiral James managed to get himself back on his feet.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry I shouldn‚Äôt have just thrown that at you, not when‚Ä¶‚Äù

Regulus blinks, the room around him coming back into focus. ‚ÄúNot when?‚Äù

James looks back at him, like he can‚Äôt figure out if Regulus‚Äôs question is rhetorical or not, after a few minutes he shakes his head. ‚ÄúNothing. Never mind.‚Äù

Regulus barely pays him any attention, mind still reeling over all the memories that might be bouncing around in Mary Macdonald‚Äôs head. He should have been more careful‚Äîmore thorough. He shouldn‚Äôt have made assumptions about things he barely understands.

Fuck,

he thinks.

Fuck.

He can‚Äôt figure out what Dumbledore‚Äôs next move will be, or Macdonald‚Äôs, or Snape‚Äôs. He feels like he‚Äôs playing blind. He should probably write to his mother. He doesn‚Äôt want to, but he‚Äôs not sure he has any other options.

‚ÄúReg, hey?‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes snap up, meeting James‚Äôs.

‚ÄúLet me do this okay?‚Äù he says quietly. ‚ÄúLet me do this for you.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt even know what he‚Äôs asking.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

James lets out a frustrated sigh. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like Dumbledore is going to go around the school gossiping about our sex life.‚Äù

‚ÄúSnape would,‚Äù and he would know, if Regulus was suddenly let off the hook that wormy little bastard would make it his mission to find out why. He‚Äôs already suspicious of them.

James is opening his mouth to protest‚Äîmaybe volunteering to scare some discretion into Snape‚Äîbut Regulus cuts him off;

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs besides the point. I really don‚Äôt give a shit what anyone at this school thinks.‚Äù

James looks surprised by that. ‚ÄúOh. But‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMy family can‚Äôt know.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause. ‚ÄúThat you‚Äôre gay?‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not gay.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou sound like Sirius.‚Äù

He supposes he deserves that, though he still feels the intense desire to punch James for saying it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm slightly more self-aware than Sirius I imagine,‚Äù he says flatly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚ÄîI‚Äôm attracted to boys. Always have been. But I don‚Äôt have the privilege of being gay.‚Äù

James really does look lost. ‚ÄúIs this a riddle?‚Äù he asks, squinting at Regulus like that will make his words clearer.

‚ÄúSort of,‚Äù Regulus answers truthfully. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the heir now. Who I want to be with is irrelevant. I have to marry a woman and continue the line,‚Äù he feels tired even just talking about it. ‚ÄúThere is a long tradition of Black‚Äôs fooling around on the side, as long as you‚Äôre discreet about it and do your duty it‚Äôs tolerated.‚Äù

You would think, being a pureblood himself, that none of this would come as a surprise to James. But then, the Potter‚Äôs are a very different kind of family. They always have been.

James exhales, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúOkay, listen, we‚Äôll come back to how absolutely fucking miserable that sounds, but for right now, I still don‚Äôt see the problem. I‚Äôm just telling Dumbledore.‚Äù

Just.

Regulus almost laughs.

Just telling the man who threatened me with Azakaban the most vulnerable thing about me.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll get out.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know that,‚Äù James argues, because of course he does.

‚ÄúNo, but it isn‚Äôt worth the risk.‚Äù

James looks ready to pull his hair out. ‚ÄúNot worth the risk? I think the stakes here are a little higher than messing up your future unhappy marriage prospects don‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head, hating that he‚Äôs wasting his time on this conversation when what he really needs to be doing is strategizing.

‚ÄúMarriage is important to my family.‚Äù

James growls. ‚ÄúI get that but‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus cuts him off. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt. Marriage is important to my family. Take a moment James, please, and remember who we‚Äôre talking about. Try to imagine what disappointment looks like in my house. With my parents.‚Äù

And he does. He stands there looking and Regulus and he thinks. Just for a second. Just long enough for the blood to drain from his face.

‚ÄúReg‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIf it was just me that it would blowback on then maybe‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚Äîmaybe it would be worth it. But they won‚Äôt just be finding out about my‚Ä¶proclivities. They‚Äôll find out who I‚Äôve been‚Ä¶they‚Äôll know about you,‚Äù he finally manages to say, his next exhale shaky. ‚ÄúWhatever they think of me, they still need me around, but you James?‚Äù he shakes his head, unwilling to name all the possibilities. All the nightmare inducing possibilities.

‚ÄúSo you can‚Äôt tell Dumbledore,‚Äù he pushes on. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt tell anyone. This goes so far beyond sex. Do you understand?‚Äù

He does. Regulus knows he does. Can see it in his eyes. But James Potter doesn‚Äôt lay down his sword and bow out gracefully. He fights to the bitter, dirty end. He drags himself through the mud and blood until he has nothing left. And then he fights a little more. He doesn‚Äôt want to admit Regulus is right. He doesn‚Äôt want to sit back and watch injustice be done. Ever the Gryffindor.

Maybe you should tell him,

hisses the voice in Regulus‚Äôs head.

Tell him you aren‚Äôt so innocent.

He probably should. He won‚Äôt. But he should.

Eventually James sighs, leaning against the back of the couch. ‚ÄúIf I tell Dumbledore,‚Äù Regulus barely manages to hold back a groan, ‚Äúthat I was with you that night, that you couldn‚Äôt have done it, but that no one can know, he‚Äôll understand. He‚Äôll keep our secret,‚Äù James winces on the last word. Regulus isn‚Äôt sure why it feels so violent. But it always does.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Regulus starts and stops, not sure how to phrase this; ‚ÄúI know you believe that‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúReg‚Äî‚Äú

‚Äú‚Äîbut Dumbledore has no interest in protecting me. I‚Äôm sorry. I‚Äôm sorry it‚Äôs me you‚Äôve ended up with‚Äîanyone else and I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôd be right. But me and Dumbledore are‚Ä¶not on the same side.‚Äù

He sees that drive into James like a steel blade. The words that aren‚Äôt being said. That if Regulus isn‚Äôt on Dumbledore‚Äôs side he isn‚Äôt on James‚Äôs either. And he waits for the other boy to make that case. But after a few seconds James wipes a hand down his face.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt trust Dumbledore.‚Äù

It isn‚Äôt a question.

Regulus answers anyway.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

He‚Äôll use you against me, he almost says, but doesn‚Äôt.

After a moment of silence James turns to him, shoulders sagging. ‚ÄúSo what‚Äôs the plan then Reg? What are we going to do?‚Äù

We.

He said we.

Like any of this is his problem.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to write to my mother,‚Äù because he can‚Äôt bear to lie. He hates lying to James and he already does too much of it.

James makes a disgusted face, looking about as happy about this decision as Regulus is. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt quite picture a world where Walburga is the answer to anyone‚Äôs problems.‚Äù

Regulus isn‚Äôt sure if he laughs or groans. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says wearily, moving to stand next to James against the couch, their arms brushing. ‚ÄúMe either really.‚Äù

After a few seconds he leans his head on James‚Äôs shoulder, and James wraps his arm around his waist, pulling him in closer. Regulus closes his eyes, greedy. Always so greedy for this.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù James says quietly, face turned into his hair.

‚ÄúMm.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt do that again, okay?‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes blink open. ‚ÄúDo what?‚Äù

‚ÄúDisappear. You need space you tell me, you talk to me, but you can‚Äôt just walk away like that,‚Äù there‚Äôs a pause and then; ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre gonna break my heart you need to mean it.‚Äù

Regulus hates those last few words. Hates how real they are. How they sound wrapped up in James‚Äôs voice. He squeezes his eyes shut, pushing further into James.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to break any part of you,‚Äù Regulus whispers, painfully vulnerable. It helps to have his eyes closed.

James kisses the top of his head. ‚ÄúI love you.‚Äù

‚ÄúJe suis d√©sol√© de t'avoir fait √ßa,‚Äù the words come tumbling out of him, always so much easier when he knows James can‚Äôt understand. ‚ÄúJe suis d√©sol√© de ne pas √™tre assez fort pour te prot√©ger. Je pense que tu pourrais me d√©tester pour √ßa un jour. Mais j'esp√®re que non. Mon Dieu, j'esp√®re vraiment que non.‚Äù

James Squeezes him tighter. ‚ÄúReg?‚Äù he says in a low voice, breath tickling the top of Regulus‚Äôs ear, but he only shakes his head.

‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù he says instead. ‚ÄúI love you too.‚Äù

¬†

Over the years Regulus has, in passing, spoken to Mary Macdonald. Never for any great length of time or about anything important, but they‚Äôre only a year apart, in the same school, on opposing Quidditch teams. It happens. But neither of them has ever sought the other out, and he is more than certain they have never spoken alone.

Despite all that, when he walks out of Transfiguration and sees her leaning against the wall across from his classroom, he knows that she‚Äôs there for him. He considers, for one pathetic second, running away. He doesn‚Äôt. But it‚Äôs a near thing.

‚ÄúHello,‚Äù he says, stopping in front of her, she holds his gaze unabashedly.

A moment passes before she cocks her head to the side, ‚Äúover here,‚Äù and then starts walking.

Once again Regulus feels the strong urge to turn in the opposite direction and run for it. Instead he follows Mary down the hall, letting her stay a step or two ahead of him until she turns into, what appears to be, an empty classroom. Once he‚Äôs inside she flicks her wand, slamming the door shut behind them before she jumps up onto the teacher‚Äôs desk at the front of the class. If she‚Äôs nervous she doesn‚Äôt show it. Though she does look tired. A little paler than she was a few weeks ago, eyes a dimmer, though no less intimidating.

After a moment of tense silence Regulus speaks. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd he say?‚Äù because the only reason that Mary Macdonald would suddenly be hunting him down is because James had gone done something stupid. Well intentioned. But stupid.

Mary smirks and he wonders if that‚Äôs a good sign. ‚ÄúHe did try to be subtle.‚Äù

Regulus resists the urge to roll his eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me,‚Äù her eyes give him a once over that leaves him distinctly uncomfortable. ‚ÄúHow is it that you have James Potter doing your dirty work for you?‚Äù

He grimaces. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt. For this exact reason.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, alright, but you knew it was him that lead me to you?‚Äù

Fuck.

Maybe James wasn‚Äôt the only one failing at subtlety here.

‚ÄúHe was asking me questions the other day. I think my brother has prejudiced him against me,‚Äù Regulus is careful to keep his voice as neutral as possible. ‚ÄúNo doubt they would both happily blame me for every shitty thing that happens at this school.‚Äù

It‚Äôs what he would have said a year a go. He tries to drag up that old bitterness.

Mary arches her brow. ‚ÄúYeah, I don‚Äôt think so though. Because that isn‚Äôt how you said it, it isn‚Äôt how he asked it. Your tone is all off.‚Äù She waves her hand at him.

‚ÄúMy tone?‚Äù he repeats skeptically.

‚ÄúMmhm,‚Äù she places her hands on the edge of her desk and leans forward. ‚ÄúSo tell me Reggie Black, when did you and James Potter become friends and why the hell does he want me to tell Dumbledore that I didn‚Äôt see you the night I was attacked?‚Äù

It really is rather brave of her, when you think about it, to lock herself in a room with someone who might have actively tried to hurt her. Who might try to again. But then, maybe that‚Äôs what she‚Äôs hoping for‚Äîa fight‚ÄîGryffindors, they‚Äôre all idiots.

‚ÄúI thought you said he tried to be subtle?‚Äù Regulus says, instead of addressing any of the other numerous points she brought up.

She smiles again. ‚ÄúWhere James is concerned, anything less than skywriting is subtle.‚Äù

Regulus groans internally. ‚ÄúI suppose that‚Äôs fair.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo?‚Äù

‚ÄúSo?‚Äù Regulus repeats back at her, a bit more childishly than he would like to admit.

‚ÄúJames seems to think that I can help you, and maybe I can, but not until you start explaining this situation to me.‚Äù

He isn‚Äôt actually sure that Mary can help him, though he supposes it‚Äôs not the worst idea. Having the victim insist you aren‚Äôt guilty can‚Äôt hurt.

‚ÄúWhat situation?‚Äù he asks, because he has no intention of revealing anymore to her than she already knows.

She considers him for a minute, legs swinging so that the backs of her heels are banging irritatingly into the desk she‚Äôs sitting on. Regulus doesn‚Äôt see why she has to sit on the desk at all when there‚Äôs a classroom full of empty chairs surrounding them.

‚ÄúLets start with James.‚Äù

Oh goodie.

‚ÄúWhat about him?‚Äù

She rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúYou two. You‚Äôre‚Ä¶friends? Or what? Because the last time I checked you and your brother were not on good terms and James and Sirius are practically attached at the hip so‚Ä¶? What gives?‚Äù

The only thing that stings more than knowing that James will never be his, is knowing that he will always be Sirius‚Äôs. A fact he‚Äôs reminded of in this school almost daily. It‚Äôs so like his brother to become some sort of minor celebrity. All anyone ever wants to talk about are the Marauders.

‚ÄúPotter has a saviour complex, decided it was his Gryffindor duty to show me the error of my ways, bring me over to the side of light etcetera, etcetera,‚Äù he says flatly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve told him to bugger off, but he‚Äôs persistent.‚Äù

He thinks that‚Äôs believable, maybe even a little too close to the truth. He does his best not to squirm under Mary‚Äôs gaze.

‚ÄúAnd why does Dumbledore think you attacked me?‚Äù she asks finally and Regulus has to stop himself from letting out a sigh of relief at the change in topic.

‚ÄúSnape,‚Äù he says, maybe a bit too quickly. ‚ÄúNot a fan of this thing being pinned on his mate so he‚Äôs trying to blame it on me instead.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis thing,‚Äù Mary repeats, and it‚Äôs only when he hears it back in her slightly hollow voice that he realizes how insensitive that was.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù though he doesn‚Äôt think he sounds very sincere. His voice never does the right things. ‚ÄúThat was crude of me.‚Äù

Mary waves him off. ‚ÄúIf you weren‚Äôt there surely you can prove it?‚Äù her tone is light but her eyes are sharp.

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt there,‚Äù mostly. ‚ÄúAnd I can‚Äôt prove it.‚Äù

She raises her brow. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt in my dorm,‚Äù he says through clenched teeth.

‚ÄúWhere were you?‚Äù

‚ÄúOut.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere?‚Äù

‚ÄúAstronomy tower.‚Äù

He sees a flash of the mischief she‚Äôs so known for in her eyes. ‚ÄúWith who?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one,‚Äù he repeats, a little more growl in his voice.

Mary leans back on the desk. ‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs not very believable.‚Äù

He glares at her. ‚ÄúApparently.‚Äù

She goes back to just looking at him, like she‚Äôs trying to puzzle something out. This is a bad idea‚Äîfucking James Potter, Regulus told him to stay out of it but James just can‚Äôt help himself. He always has to save the day.

‚ÄúJames really doesn‚Äôt think you had anything to do with it,‚Äù Mary says eventually. It isn‚Äôt phrased like a question so Regulus doesn‚Äôt supply an answer. ‚ÄúWhat I can‚Äôt figure out, is why, since you‚Äôre clearly lying.‚Äù

Regulus resents that ‚Äúclearly.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt have an answer for her. Doesn‚Äôt want to be talking to her at all, afraid every minute that his face or his voice is going to jog some memory lose in her head. He can‚Äôt figure out if he‚Äôs a guilty man trying to get away with a crime or an innocent man wrongly accused. Neither he supposes. Somehow life never does fall neatly into either category. Everyone always some mix of both.

‚ÄúIs that all?‚Äù Regulus asks, after the silence goes on too long. Mary hasn‚Äôt looked away from him once, her gaze inscrutable and far too clever for his liking.

And then.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù she says suddenly, eyes going wide. ‚ÄúYou were in the astronomy tower with James.‚Äù

Which technically isn‚Äôt true, but the location is really the least important part of this.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says quickly. Probably too quickly.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Mary says again. Giving him a new look that makes him feel squeamish. ‚ÄúWell okay then.‚Äù

‚ÄúMacdonald, that is NOT what happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure Regulus, if you say so.‚Äù

God, he really needs to never speak to another Gryffindor again, they‚Äôre all so bloody nosy and insufferable.

After fighting with himself for a few seconds, he eventually forces himself to speak. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt tell anyone.‚Äù

Mary nods, strangely serious. ‚ÄúYeah, I figured.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor James‚Äôs sake, you can‚Äôt tell anyone,‚Äù he repeats, not feeling like going through this whole conversation again but hoping his tone is enough to get his point across.

Mary nods, slowly. ‚ÄúAlright. For James.‚Äù And then; ‚ÄúWhom you were with, the night I was attacked?‚Äù

Regulus lets out a heavy sigh, the annoying tug in his gut telling him that he‚Äôs losing control. Too many people know. There‚Äôs no way they‚Äôre going to be able to keep this secret much longer. Something like fear but a little worse grips his heart.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he finally manages to say. ‚ÄúIs that all?‚Äù because he really wants to get out of here and maybe murder James Potter for putting him in this position in the first place. For exposing them to someone else after everything he told him last night. And he knows he was just trying to help, to find a work around to their problem. But goddamnit James.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell Dumbledore,‚Äù for a brief moment Regulus feels his heart stop and his fear must show on his face because she quickly continues. ‚ÄúThat I don‚Äôt remember you being there that night,‚Äù she shrugs. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know if it‚Äôll help you, they‚Äôre not listening to me much these days but‚Ä¶‚Äù

Regulus can‚Äôt help but notice the bitterness in her voice and he thinks of Dumbledore, bargaining away her justice, using her pain to buy himself a new spy.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he finds himself saying, not sure what he‚Äôs really apologizing for.

She shrugs. ‚ÄúIt is what it is.‚Äù

Regulus nods. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says awkwardly. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm going to go now,‚Äù and when Mary makes no move to stop him he turns and heads for the door.

‚ÄúYou should know that I do though,‚Äù she says as he reaches for the handle, causing him to look back over his shoulder, forehead wrinkled.

‚ÄúDo what?‚Äù he asks.

She gives him another one of those long looks, penetrating in all the worst ways. Then she slides off the desk, walking towards him at a leisurely pace. She stops when they‚Äôre right next to one another and for a moment Regulus sees something new in Mary‚Äôs stare. Something violent. Like rage.

‚ÄúRemember you,‚Äù she says sharply, pulling the door open and leaving Regulus struggling to breathe in her wake.

Chapter End Notes

**French: I'm sorry I did this to you. I'm sorry that I'm not strong enough to protect you. I think you might hate me for this someday. But I hope not. God, I really hope not.**

Hello beautiful people!

This chapter feels short and I thought about extending it but I just like ending with a Mary Macdonald mic drop too much so here we are.

Thanks for all the nice things you write! Hope you're having a great day!

Chapter 29

Chapter Notes

tw: implied sexual assault

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I: REGULUS

¬†

They‚Äôre in his father‚Äôs garden in Scotland, the sun is out but it isn‚Äôt too hot, the grass soft underneath them. James‚Äôs eyes are bright, the tops of his cheeks flushed. He laughs at something Regulus says before leaning forward and nuzzling at his neck. The affection makes Regulus squirm but he doesn‚Äôt pull away, if anything he leans into it.

The air smells sweet‚Äîthey picked mint that morning and the scent still lingers on their fingers, their touches. Regulus takes James‚Äôs hand, holding it above himself, turning it over a few times before pressing a kiss to the inside of his palm‚Äîto each of his knuckles. James grins stupidly at him.

Overhead birds twitter and bugs hum and the rest of the world feels very, very far away. They have no one to hide from and nothing to do. Regulus breathes in deep and then exhales, before pressing another kiss to James‚Äôs wrist, feeling his pulse beat against his lips.

James hums happily, eyes drifting closed. ‚ÄúWe should stay here.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúForever.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

Regulus keeps making slow, aimless kisses along James‚Äôs forearm, enjoying the way it makes his cheeks grow rosier and his lips quirk up. James is a lot like a dog‚Äîhe loves to wag his tail.

‚ÄúTell me more,‚Äù James says lazily.

‚ÄúMore?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf the story. We were just getting to the good part.‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the good part, exactly?‚Äù

Regulus is pretty sure James opens his eyes just to roll them at him. ‚ÄúThe part where Achilles kills Hector, obviously.

Regulus arches his brow. ‚ÄúI thought you liked Hector?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure, but I also like Achilles kicking ass.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù Regulus has to bite his lip to keep from laughing, he feels a little delirious right now. Maybe it‚Äôs the sun. Maybe it‚Äôs the way that James keeps looking at him.

James taps the toe of his foot against Regulus‚Äôs heel. ‚ÄúGo on then.‚Äù

Regulus sighs like it‚Äôs some big inconvenience but the truth is, he loves telling stories. Always has. They‚Äôre a kind of magic. They let you be anyone, anywhere, doing anything. He‚Äôs not sure he would have survived his childhood without stories.

‚ÄúAs Dawn, in saffron robes, rose from the stream of Ocean, bringing light to gods and men,‚Äù Regulus starts, voice soft, drifting on the breeze. ‚ÄúThetis reached the ships bearing Hephaestus‚Äô gift. She found her beloved son groaning aloud, his arms round Patroclus‚Äô body, while his men stood by, weeping bitterly. The shining goddess came and took his hand, saying; ‚ÄòMy child you must let him go, however great your sorrow, and leave him here, dead for all time, slain by the will of heaven. Now, take up instead Hephaestus‚Äô marvellous armour, more beautiful than any that ever adorned a man‚Äôs shoulders.‚Äù

James scrunches up his nose, the expression so adorable that it actually takes Regulus‚Äôs breath away, sucking his next words back down his throat.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I could do it.‚Äù

Regulus has to get control of his breathing before he can answer. ‚ÄúDo what?‚Äù

‚ÄúLet you go.‚Äù

His heart gives a pathetic leap. ‚ÄúOh?‚Äù he has to clear his throat because his voice has grown far too sappy. ‚ÄúEven if I was a dead body?‚Äù

‚ÄúEven then,‚Äù James says quietly.

The next thing Regulus knows James is rolling on top of him, pining him to the grass. He hovers over Regulus, hair hanging down around his face. Always a mess. Always so lovely. ‚ÄúEven then,‚Äù James murmurs against his lips.

Regulus lifts himself up, just enough to take James‚Äôs mouth. Desperately. Needfully. He never has any shame when it comes to James. He feels the weight of the other boy slowly lowering on top of him. You‚Äôd think it‚Äôd be crushing but it isn‚Äôt. More like it grounds Regulus. Holds him together, in place, while his pulse races, and every nerve in his body sings.

Don‚Äôt let me go.

He thinks.

Don‚Äôt let me go.

Don‚Äôt let me go.

Don‚Äôt let me‚Äî

‚ÄúChrist Reg, get the fuck up!‚Äù

Something hits Regulus in the face causing him to shoot up, the world swimming around him.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna be late for class Prefect,‚Äù Evan sounds somewhere between annoyed and amused, standing at the foot of Regulus‚Äôs bed, doing up his shirt.

It takes another few seconds for reality to settle in. Regulus is not in a garden in Scotland. Not being smothered by James Potter. Quite the opposite in fact. He looks down at his lap.

‚ÄúDid you just throw socks at my me?‚Äù he asks, a little indignantly.

Evan smirks. ‚ÄúMight‚Äôve.‚Äù

Another, more worrying thought occurs to Regulus. ‚ÄúAre they clean?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh wow, look at the time, gotta go.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh fuck you,‚Äù he chucks the dirty socks at Evan‚Äôs retreating back, the door swinging closed behind him as he cackles on his way down to breakfast.

Regulus sighs, bending his knees and dropping his head into his hands. Trying to settle himself. Slowly his anxieties push their way to the forefront; Dumbledore, James, Macdonald. Happiness leaches out of him like he‚Äôs made of holes.

No,

he thinks pathetically.

Can‚Äôt I just have it for a little longer?

He half considers going back to sleep even though he knows he can‚Äôt.
Grumbling, he forces himself out of bed. Avoiding damp towels and dirty pants as he walks into the bathroom which is, of course, an absolute disaster. Thank God for house elves, they‚Äôd probably drown in their own dirty laundry without them. He finds his reflection in the bathroom mirror‚Äîhair a mess, eyes too pale to be anything but unsettling.

Little bits and pieces of his dream flicker through his head; gentle sun, fingertips, sweet lips. It fills him up with something warm‚Äîsomething that feels light and comforting and also aches. He sighs, gripping the edge of the counter.

It wasn‚Äôt real, he has to remind himself. The last time he talked to James they‚Äôd been doing damage control not frolicking in a garden. Damage control was all they ever seemed to be doing these days. He scrubs at his face, tired of looking at it, tired of seeing his mother in his expressions. In his eyes.

His shirt sleeve slips up his arm and a quick movement draws his eye‚Äîthe black tip of a slithering tail. Regulus freezes. Staring at it. He‚Äôs gotten very good at avoiding his forearm. Avoiding the reality of his situation. He‚Äôs worried that something has changed in him since this summer, that he‚Äôs starting to lose himself a little bit. Not that he ever had a particularly firm grasp on who he was in the first place. He only ever feels sure of himself when he‚Äôs with James.

It‚Äôs pathetic really, the relief he feels when he tugs his sleeve back down, hiding the Mark from view. It doesn‚Äôt change anything. Not really. Still, he can‚Äôt help thinking the same thing he always does:

Just a little more time.

Just a little more time with him.

Please, please please.

He‚Äôs not even sure who he‚Äôs asking anymore. Himself? The universe? The rest of the Wizarding World? Please don‚Äôt start your war yet. I‚Äôm not done being loved by him.

Regulus sighs, angry at himself for his stupidity. His weakness. He starts the shower, waiting until the water is scalding before he strips out of his pyjamas and climbs in. Hoping to wash all thoughts of gardens and forevers and love off his skin.

¬†

‚ÄúAlright, today is an exciting day class,‚Äù Merry-Thought claps her hands together at the front of the room, looking far too chipper for nine in the morning, at least in Regulus‚Äôs opinion.

‚ÄúOoh,‚Äù Cerci buzzes excitedly beside him. Speaking of too chipper.

Regulus is folded over his desk, chin resting on his arms, potentially regretting his choice of seat partner. He‚Äôd refused to sit with Evan and Barty after the sock incident this morning, but he‚Äôs not sure he can quite stomach Cerci‚Äôs energy at the moment.

‚ÄúNow, this is quite a complicated bit of magic but you have proven yourselves to be a very competent class so far this term so I‚Äôve decided to give it a try. Can anyone tell me what a Patronus is?‚Äù

That actually does get Regulus‚Äôs attention.

‚ÄúAre we learning how to cast a Patronus?‚Äù he murmurs, to no one in particular, but Cerci squeaks beside him.

‚ÄúMerlin this is gonna be the coolest class ever. My mum can cast a corporeal Patronus, it‚Äôs a duck.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, turning to look at her. ‚ÄúYour mother‚Äôs Patronus is a duck?‚Äù

Cerci does not seem to recognize how ridiculous that is. She just nods her head enthusiastically. ‚ÄúYup, it‚Äôs adorable.‚Äù

Walburga can‚Äôt cast a corporeal Patronus. Honestly she might not be able to cast a Patronus at all. His dad‚Äôs is a greyhound, lean and majestic, Regulus hasn‚Äôt seen him cast it for a long time now though. It hits him that he probably never will again. That his father is too far gone at this point. He tries to remember the last time he saw his father‚Äôs Patronus but he can‚Äôt. Honestly, his memory has never been that great, always a little fuzzy and muddled. He thinks it‚Äôs because his mum and Bellatrix are always messing around in his head.

‚ÄúNow I‚Äôll ask you to all get out your wands,‚Äù Merry-Thought is saying at the front of the class, leading to a symphony of rustling bags and screeching chairs as they all get ready to perform the most interesting piece of magic they‚Äôve been shown all year.

‚ÄúThis is very complex spell so I don‚Äôt want any of you to get discouraged if you aren‚Äôt able to get it today. We aren‚Äôt aiming for corporeal Patronuses on the first try, any sign of a magical shield should be considered a success, alright?‚Äù she looks around brightly at the class.

For a Professor of the Dark Arts, Merry-Thought is an incredibly bubbly person. A slightly plump, middle-aged witch, she wears bright patterned robes and huge dangling earrings. And she is always smiling. Always.

‚ÄúThe wand movements and incantation are relatively simple, you‚Äôll want to make a circular motion with your wand‚Äîyes, just like that Miss Linnens, well done‚Äîthe larger they get the more force you‚Äôll be able to put behind your spell. And the incantation is: Expecto Patronum. Now, I want you to all still your wands and just repeat that after me, alright? On three: one, two, three‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúExpecto Patronum,‚Äù the class choruses, with about as much enthusiasm as you can expect from a bunch of fifteen year olds at nine in the morning. Still, Merry-Thought is beaming.

‚ÄúVery good, very, very, good. Now, for the difficult part, you‚Äôll have to find a memory or a thought, something that makes you happy. It should be something important, something strong, not just the feeling you get when your favourite cake is being served in the Great Hall,‚Äù she looks around, getting one or two laughs. ‚ÄúThis should be the sort of happy that feels overflowing, like it could spill out of you at any moment, okay?‚Äù

There are a few scattered nods about the class but apparently that‚Äôs all the confirmation Merry-Thought needs.

‚ÄúExcellent, well, go on have at it, make sure you‚Äôre not pointing your wands at anyone!‚Äù

Regulus turns to Cerci who is practically vibrating in the chair next to him. ‚ÄúThis. Is. So. Freaking. Cool.‚Äù

He can‚Äôt help but smile at her enthusiasm. ‚ÄúSure,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you try first.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, okay, okay,‚Äù she closes her eyes and screws up her face, Regulus watching with mild amusement.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúShhh,‚Äù she waves her hand at him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to pick my happiest memory.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh.‚Äù

‚ÄúI need to concentrate.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere are just so many.‚Äù

He snorts, not worried that he‚Äôll have the same problem. In fact, he‚Äôs fairly certain he won‚Äôt be able to conjure a Patronus at all. Lots of Wizards can‚Äôt, and emotion based magic has never been his strong suit. It‚Äôs why he likes potions‚Äîit‚Äôs exact, clean. Certain ingredient in certain quantities under certain circumstances produce known reactions. He likes the stability of it. The reason. Old magic like this makes no sense to him.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Cerci pulls him out of his thoughts, her eyes opening again. ‚ÄúI have one, lets try,‚Äù she holds up her wand and Regulus quickly pushes it to the side so that it‚Äôs not pointing directly at him.

‚ÄúOh right,‚Äù she laughs. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy face is very important to me,‚Äù he says flatly.

She shoots him a grin. ‚ÄúI can tell.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that supposed to mean?‚Äù only slightly offended.

She shrugs, mischief still bright in her eyes. ‚ÄúThat you look like the type of person who spends a lot of time on their hair.‚Äù

His hand goes protectively to his curls. ‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShhh,‚Äù she hisses again, though he can tell she‚Äôs trying not to laugh. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm about to perform some very, very impressive magic here so please prepare yourself to be amazed.‚Äù

He rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúBy all means,‚Äù he gestures to the empty space in front of their desk.

She sticks her tongue between her teeth, squinting as she moves her wand. ‚ÄúExpecto-Patronum!‚Äù

Nothing happens.

‚ÄúThat was very impressive,‚Äù Regulus says flatly.

Cerci snorts, giving his shoulder a shove. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah, first try. Like me go again.‚Äù

So she does.

Again.

And again.

And again.
