‚ÄúWell, that was anti-climatic,‚Äù she sighs, sagging back in her chair and blowing her bangs off her forehead. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm tired,‚Äù she kicks his foot under the table. ‚ÄúYour turn.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll that nothing did look tiring,‚Äù Regulus says, ducking out of the way before she can swat the back to his head.

‚ÄúBig words from someone who hasn‚Äôt even tried yet,‚Äù she says, though she‚Äôs smiling. He wonders if her and Merry-Thought are related. If obscene good-cheer is genetic.

Regulus sits up a little straighter and pulls out his wand, realizing that after all that time watching Cerci struggle he still hasn‚Äôt come up with a memory. What is his happiest memory? A few moments with his dad come to mind‚Äîespecially his first time on a broom.

He‚Äôd been four, maybe five, his father still healthy enough to fly. He‚Äôd let Regulus ride with him, sitting him in front so he‚Äôd feel like he was the one driving even though, of course, he wasn‚Äôt. It was the best feeling in the world, the first moment his feet had lifted off the ground. His father going higher and higher, eventually doing a few simple turns and rolls. In his memory everything is haloed in sunlight. His dad laughing the whole time.

Regulus blinks, bringing himself back to the present.

‚ÄúYou okay there?‚Äù Cerci asks, somewhere between teasing and genuinely concerned.

‚ÄúShhh, I‚Äôm about to do some very impressive magic,‚Äù he shoots her a grin that makes her laugh out loud.

‚ÄúWell, by all means,‚Äù she says, doing a terrible impression of his posh accent.

Regulus stares determinedly at the empty space in front of him. He thinks about the feeling of being in the air, the sound of his father‚Äôs laughter; ‚ÄúExpecto-Patronum.‚Äù

Something pulls behind his belly button, just the lightest tug before a small puff of smoke comes out of the end of his wand. A barely-there mist.

‚ÄúOh my God!‚Äù Cerci claps her hands. ‚ÄúYou did it!‚Äù

Regulus looks at his wand skeptically, ‚ÄúBarely.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was very good Mr. Black,‚Äù he turns over his shoulder to see Professor Merry-Thought smiling at him. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got the right idea, but you probably need something a little stronger to ground yourself in. Remember what I said, about the feeling of happiness needing to be overflowing. That‚Äôs where the power of the spell is coming from. The memory should feel almost like a well, something that you can keep drawing on as long as you need to.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you professor,‚Äù he says, because he isn‚Äôt sure what else to say. A well? What the hell does that even mean?

Cerci nudges him with her elbow. ‚ÄúTry again, try again, try again.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not gonna be any better,‚Äù he says flatly, which only makes her roll her eyes.

‚ÄúTry it anyway.‚Äù

Regulus looks back down at his wand and frowns. A memory overflowing with happiness? He finds himself thinking of the morning before Christmas break last year. He thinks of waking up with James Potter for the first time. Usually Regulus can‚Äôt stand being touched, usually it makes him want to crawl out of his skin, but for some reason James‚Äôs arms were different. Comfortable. Safe. He‚Äôd laid there for longer than he wanted to admit, just looking at James. When he‚Äôd finally managed to force himself to wake James up the other boy had smiled, had kissed him, like it was natural. Like he couldn‚Äôt help himself. Regulus had never felt so warm in his life.

Those images are replaced by the pair of them in the forest, swimming by James‚Äôs waterfall, lying in the sun. By James standing in the doorway of the Come and Go Room and telling Regulus that he loved him for the first time. The pair of them lying in the grass in his father‚Äôs garden. Without any fears. Without a war hanging over their heads. James promising to never leave him.

‚ÄúExpecto Patronum!‚Äù

There is nothing gentle about the tug in his gut this time. He thinks he actually jolts forward as a bright, white light spills from his wand and Regulus finds himself face to face with a‚Ä¶reindeer?

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù Cerci gasps beside him, the whole class going silent as the animal blinks at Regulus. He knows it sounds mad, but there‚Äôs something‚Ä¶familiar about it.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs beautiful,‚Äù Cerci breathes, causing the phantom reindeer to turn to her. She smiles at him like he‚Äôs a real animal. ‚ÄúGod, a stag, that‚Äôs so cool.‚Äù

‚ÄúA stag?‚Äù Regulus repeats.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù and then, at the look of confusion on Regulus‚Äôs face she explains; ‚ÄúYou can tell because of the antlers, my father hunts them on our estate all the time.‚Äù

Regulus wrinkles his nose, looking back at the animal who steps towards him, bowing his head and nudging Regulus‚Äôs fingers. He can‚Äôt really feel it, not the way he would be able to if the animal was made of something solid. It‚Äôs more like a slightly cold tickling sensation.

‚ÄúHey you,‚Äù Regulus says dumbly, well aware that he‚Äôs speaking to a bloody incantation.

Then, suddenly, the class irrupts in applause. Regulus looks over to see that it is, of course, being led by Professor Merry-Thought. ‚ÄúWell done Mr. Black,‚Äù she says, beaming. ‚ÄúReally excellent work. Very, very, good.‚Äù

He turns back to his stag who definitely gives him a look like: ‚Äúisn‚Äôt this a bit much?‚Äù which yes, Regulus thinks, it absolutely is, far too much honestly. He‚Äôs glad they‚Äôre on the same page.

‚ÄúTo disperse him you merely need to wave your wand,‚Äù Professor Merry-Thought says.

Regulus looks at her and then back at his stag, who paws at the ground. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says stupidly. ‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he lifts his wand reluctantly, which is ridiculous. It‚Äôs not a real animal. It doesn‚Äôt have any feelings. Still, it seems cruel when he waves his arm and watches him dissolve into mist.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he says stupidly, blushing and hoping that no one is paying enough attention to hear him.

¬†

He tries and fails not to cringe when Mary Macdonald falls into step with him on his way back to the Slytherin common room.

‚ÄúYou look happy,‚Äù she says, somehow managing to make it sound like a threat.

‚ÄúMust be a trick of the light,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt look at her, doesn‚Äôt look down either‚Äîthat would be too weak‚Äîso his only option is to keep staring straight ahead.

‚ÄúMust be,‚Äù she muses.

They pass a group of Ravenclaws who give them both a strange look. Of course, Mary Macdonald and Regulus Black walking down the hallway together is just food for gossips. Especially because she used to date Sirius. He‚Äôs sure the rumours will be flying by dinner. Fucking Gryffindors, not a subtle bone in their bodies.

‚ÄúDo you want something?‚Äù he growls eventually, after a long and uncomfortable period of silence.

‚ÄúMany things actually,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt need to look at her to know she‚Äôs grinning. ‚ÄúYou have Quidditch Practice tomorrow night, right?‚Äù

Regulus is momentarily thrown. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîyes?‚Äù

She nods sharply. ‚ÄúGood. I‚Äôll be in the bleachers. Come find me.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs hand tightens around the strap of his book bag. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúTo chat.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbout?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow you can be of use to me.‚Äù

He cringes. Hating her maybe more than is justified. Hating himself for once again being in this position. Under someone‚Äôs thumb. Powerless.

‚ÄúAnd if I don‚Äôt?‚Äù he grounds out, turning the next corner into an emptier hallway.

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon Regulus, you‚Äôre a smart guy, I‚Äôm sure you can figure it out.‚Äù When he doesn‚Äôt answer she goes on. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt decided who I‚Äôll go to first, James or Dumbledore.‚Äù She knocks her shoulder against his like they‚Äôre old friends, it makes Regulus‚Äôs whole body tense. ‚ÄúWhat do you reckon is the better threat?‚Äù

Regulus grinds his teeth. ‚ÄúFine. Tomorrow. After practice. Is that all?‚Äù

‚ÄúOooh, so snippy. You‚Äôd think you were the one who had their head bashed in.‚Äù

Regulus stumbles, memories of Mary on the ground, the sound she‚Äôd made when she hit, the dark blood pooling around her head.

She puts her hand on his shoulder, it probably looks good natured to anyone passing by, anyone who can‚Äôt feel her nails digging through the fabric of his shirt.

‚ÄúI need information from you,‚Äù she says, voice dropping down. ‚ÄúBut I want you to know, that just because I‚Äôm not giving you up, doesn‚Äôt mean you don‚Äôt still make me sick.‚Äù

It‚Äôs work for Regulus to keep his expression neutral, but then, he‚Äôs had a lot of practice.

‚ÄúNoted,‚Äù he manages to keep his tone flat.

She releases her vice grip on him, turning in the opposite direction and walking away without another word. Regulus doesn‚Äôt look after her, doesn‚Äôt slow his pace. He wonders bitterly if the day will come when the universe will finally give him a choice. Give him the freedom to make decisions about his own fucking life without being at someone else‚Äôs mercy.

He doubts it.

¬†

PART II: REMUS

¬†

He needs to say something. He‚Äôs been meaning to. But it‚Äôs‚Ä¶delicate. Everything feels delicate between him and Sirius. Sirius is with him but he‚Äôs also‚Ä¶not. It was bold, kissing him in front of all their friends like he did, and Remus should have known better than to read into it. Because in the end, Sirius has always been good at the performance‚Äîthe big gestures‚Äîit‚Äôs the quiet he can‚Äôt handle. The moments when they‚Äôre alone and he has to be himself. Be honest. Face what this is. If it is anything. Remus thinks that it might be. It must be. He hopes.

Usually something like this, something you‚Äôve spent years building up in your head, wanting desperately, lets you down when you finally get it. In the light of day it loses its magic. Thing is, Sirius Black is all magic. Sometimes it‚Äôs overwhelming. Sometimes, when it‚Äôs focused on him, Remus doesn‚Äôt know how to handle it, is certain he‚Äôs going to crack. It isn‚Äôt a disappointment, being with Sirius. What it is, is delicate. One big push and Remus is certain that this thing will shatter.

So he needs to say something before that happens. Before all the silences between them start shoving.

¬†

Sirius has his head on Remus‚Äôs chest. Remus almost always sleeps in his bed now, with the curtains drawn and a silencing charm firmly in place. Remus loves it, loves the way the rest of the world disappears and it‚Äôs just them‚Äîtogether, warm.

He‚Äôs dragging his hand lazily through Sirius‚Äôs hair while the other boy reads one of his Muggle fantasy novels out loud:

‚ÄúThat foul-tempered nag is the only thing he cares about,‚Äô muttered the bard, ‚Äòand as far as I can see, the only thing that cares about him. They‚Äôre two of a kind, if you ask me.‚Äù

‚ÄúAdaon, sitting a little apart from the others, called Taran to him. ‚ÄòI commend your patience,‚Äô he said. ‚ÄòThe black beast spurs Ellidyr cruelly.‚Äù

Sirius, Remus has recently learned, has a talent for accents, and has taken it upon himself to give each of the characters in the book a specific voice. It makes Remus smile a stupid amount. There‚Äôs just something so‚Ä¶innocent about it. So soft. Something Sirius doesn‚Äôt let himself be often.

‚ÄúI think he'll feel better once we find the cauldron,‚Äô Taran said,‚Äù Sirius goes on. ‚ÄúThere will be glory enough for all to share.‚Äù

‚ÄúAdaon smiled gravely. ‚ÄòIs there not glory enough in living the days given to us? You should know there is adventure in simply being among those we love and the things we love, and beauty, too.‚Äù

For some reason that last line makes something in Remus‚Äôs gut squirm. ‚ÄúDo you think that‚Äôs true?‚Äù he finds himself asking, cutting Sirius off.

‚ÄúDo I think what‚Äôs true?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat bit about, y‚Äôknow, love being it‚Äôs own glory?‚Äù

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúNope.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo?‚Äù

Remus looks into his eyes and then away. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. A bit. Or‚ÄîI think being loved and loving is worth more in the end, than, you know, slaying the dragon.‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúWell sure, yeah, more than slaying the dragon, but not more than getting the bad guy.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn my example the dragon was the bad guy,‚Äù Remus smiles a little.

‚ÄúA dragon isn‚Äôt a bad guy though,‚Äù Sirius goes on, clearly taking this very literally. ‚ÄúA dragon isn‚Äôt bad at all, it‚Äôs dangerous maybe, but it‚Äôs not, you know, plotting world domination or anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Remus says slowly, feeling as though they might be getting off topic. ‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre saying that if the bad guy is bad enough, defeating him is more satisfying than being with the people you love?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying that love is nice and all, but it doesn‚Äôt mean shit if the rest of the world has gone to hell.‚Äù

Which Remus supposes is fair. ‚ÄúAlright.‚Äù

Sirius gives him a look. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think so?‚Äù

Remus shrugs‚Äîwith difficulty considering that Sirius is still on top of him. ‚ÄúI think saving the world would feel a little hollow if there was no one I loved in it.‚Äù

Sirius seems to consider this for a moment, bitting down on his lower lip in a way that Remus finds extremely distracting. ‚ÄúAlright, there‚Äôs definitely a compromise here.‚Äù

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúA compromise?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, like, you know‚Ä¶like saving the world WITH the people you love? Double glory.‚Äù

Remus snorts. ‚ÄúThat easy huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù he shoots Remus a grin that makes his stomach flip. ‚ÄúAfter all, we‚Äôre going to do it.‚Äù

Remus feels his breath hitch.

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù

Did Sirius just‚Äî

‚ÄúYou, me, James, Peter. We‚Äôll finish off the Death Eaters. Voldemort. Save the world. Side by side.‚Äù

Ah.

Of course.

‚ÄúRight?‚Äù Sirius prods him when Remus doesn‚Äôt answer.

He smiles. ‚ÄúYeah, ‚Äòcourse.‚Äù

Sirius smiles back before leaning forward and kissing him on the mouth. After a few seconds he pulls away but just enough to speak, Remus can still feel his breath against his lips. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre gonna kick so much ass when we get out of here.‚Äù

Remus can‚Äôt help but laugh. ‚ÄúIf you say so.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do,‚Äù Sirius drops his head back onto Remus‚Äôs chest and after a second Remus starts carding his hand through his hair again.

It‚Äôs nice. More than nice really. But there‚Äôs still a pit in his stomach that he can‚Äôt quite shake.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Sirius says eventually.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú his voice cuts out, and Remus hears him exhale shakily. ‚ÄúRegulus has a way of getting under my skin.‚Äù

Remus nods. ‚ÄúRight.‚Äù

Sirius blows out another breath. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I can be that.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs hand stills in Sirius‚Äôs hair. ‚ÄúBe what?‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt be gay?‚Äù he hears himself say, filling in the spaces that Sirius won‚Äôt touch.

Remus‚Äôs throat feels dry. ‚ÄúBecause you like girls?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù and then. ‚ÄúNo. I mean, I do, but‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThere are other things, it‚Äôs not just gay or straight or whatever. There are other things‚Ä¶‚Äù Remus is no good at this. He doesn‚Äôt know anything, the only gay person he‚Äôs ever met is himself. At least that he knows of. Actually, James too he supposes, though James is kind of like Sirius. Because he likes girls. Remus has never liked girls, not that way. Never had the choice. Maybe if he had he‚Äôd be more like Sirius.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm those things either. I don‚Äôt know. I can‚Äôt‚ÄîI just can‚Äôt think like that. I start to get overwhelmed and that‚Äôs when I run,‚Äù he props himself up, chin on Remus‚Äôs chest, eyes looking right at him. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to run away from you again Moony. It takes a lot of effort for Remus to control his expression, to not let Sirius see how much that hurts. Bites his lip so that he doesn‚Äôt say the words crowding his mouth. Doesn‚Äôt say that that sounds like a lonely fucking way to be with someone. Never thinking about it. Never acknowledging it.

Almost as soon as he has that thought Remus is overwhelmed with guilt. If it wasn‚Äôt for him Sirius wouldn‚Äôt have to deal with any of this in the first place, he could just continue on kissing every girl in the school, being the teen heartthrob he was clearly meant to be. It was Remus who started this. Remus who kissed him.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Sirius flicks his nose, causing Remus to let out a startled laugh. ‚ÄúStop it.‚Äù

‚ÄúStop what?‚Äù he asks.

‚ÄúWhatever it is that you‚Äôre thinking. He‚Äôs held in place by those eyes, breath catching in his chest.

Remus‚Äôs chest aches. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he lowers himself down enough that their foreheads touch. ‚ÄúSo bad. Always have. I don‚Äôt know about the rest of it, but I know that. I want you.‚Äù

Which is what he said that night in the common room. The night this‚Äîwhatever it is‚Äîstarted. Hearing it still makes Remus shiver.

Sirius doesn‚Äôt need more than that, his mouth on Remus‚Äôs, hot and desperate, like he has something to prove. Like if he kisses Remus hard enough maybe he won‚Äôt have to think. This always feels a bit like fighting with them‚Äîpushing and pulling‚Äî-leaving their marks on one another. Thank Merlin for silencing charms.

I want you, that‚Äôs what he says. That‚Äôs all he ever says. I want you.

Except that Sirius Black is looking up at Remus like maybe he‚Äôs the only thing he needs. Like he‚Äôs desperate for him. His wild black hair fanned out around his head, his cheeks rosy in a way they rarely are outside of this bed.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Remus murmurs, shaking his head as he leans back down, bringing their mouths together. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt wanna stop,‚Äù he says nonsensically against Sirius‚Äôs lips. ‚ÄúEven if this is it I don‚Äôt wanna stop.‚Äù

¬†

He‚Äôs actually kind of looking forward to Prefect duty, to being able to breathe for a moment, away from Sirius. Sirius who always takes up so much of the air in every room. So much of the space in Remus‚Äôs chest.

Remus does try not to think the word love about Sirius. It‚Äôs hard though. Everything with them always gets so muddled up. Friend, brother, lover. He means too much to me, Remus thinks every time he sees Sirius and feels like the sun is shinning out of his chest. The light slipping between his ribs. And then, the more frightening thought; I‚Äôll never recover from his. Whatever happens I‚Äôll never recover.

‚ÄúHello!‚Äù

The cheery voice startles Remus out of his thoughts as he looks up to see Cerci Greengrass walking towards him.

Oh perfect, he thinks dryly.

‚ÄúGreengrass.‚Äù

She wrinkles her nose. ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt, Cerci is fine. Better really. I‚Äôve never liked the whole last name thing. Feels silly doesn‚Äôt it? Like we‚Äôre all a bunch of business associates instead of students.‚Äù

Remus supposes she‚Äôs not wrong. Though there are several people that he‚Äôs more than happy to keep at a business-associate-length distance.

‚ÄúWell, Cerci, shall we?‚Äù he nods down the hallway and she grins.

He nods curtly. ‚ÄúGood. You?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm great.‚Äù

Remus would sincerely rather be eaten by the Giant Squid than have this conversation, but he can still appreciate that Cerci is being‚Ä¶nice.

‚ÄúSorry, we should have knocked.‚Äù

Oh my god.

He wants to die.

Remus wants to die.

Attacked by a werewolf at five years old but it‚Äôs this conversation that‚Äôs going to kill him.

She laughs. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîoh I don‚Äôt know. ‚ÄúSo he‚Äôs the smartest person you know huh?‚Äù Remus says, trying not to be a complete ass. He‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôd much like to listen to someone rag on James or Sirius for a whole Prefect shift.

‚ÄúOh yeah,‚Äù she nods her head enthusiastically. ‚ÄúMerlin you should see him do magic, like proper magic, it‚Äôs so impressive. The other day in Defence Against the Dark Arts he produced a full corporeal Patronus, it was like the most beautiful thing I‚Äôve ever seen.‚Äù

That, Remus has to grudgingly admit, is actually pretty impressive.

‚ÄúIt was a massive stag,‚Äù Cerci goes on, ‚Äúlike taller than me.‚Äù

Remus feels his feet stutter to a stop. ‚ÄúA stag?‚Äù he asks.

Regulus Black‚Äôs corporeal Patronus is a stag.

‚ÄúAre you alright?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äîoh‚Äîyeah, sorry. That‚Äôs just‚Ä¶really‚Äîer‚Äîimpressive.‚Äù

Regulus Black‚Äôs Patronus is a stag.

A fucking stag.

¬†

The library is closed by the time he‚Äôs finished his shift with Cerci but has enough books already that he figures one of them must have information on Patronuses. ‚ÄòThis ancient and mysterious charm conjures‚Ä¶‚Äô blah blah blah ‚Äò‚Ä¶The Patronus charm is difficult‚Ä¶‚Äô blah blah blah.. ‚Äòa guardian which generally takes the shape of the animal with whom the caster shares the deepest affinity.‚Äô

Remus‚Äôs finger hovers over that sentence. What affinity could Regulus Black possibly have with a stag? Except‚Äîexcept James. But had James told him about his Animagus form? A cold chill runs along Remus‚Äôs spine. Had he told Regulus about Remus? About‚Äî

No.

He thinks.

Please no. I can‚Äôt do this again. It was hard enough the first time.

But James wouldn‚Äôt. He wouldn‚Äôt.

That‚Äôs what you thought about Sirius, says the nasty voice in the back of his head.

Remus hadn‚Äôt, but then, he hadn‚Äôt been trying, too afraid of the shape his might take if he succeeded.

‚ÄòThe Patronus often mutates to take the image of the love of one's life because they so often become the 'happy thought' that generates a Patronus.‚Äô

He blinks, reads the sentence again.

Then again.

The love of one‚Äôs life.

That‚Äôs what it says. In his textbook. Not in some Witch Weekly article or pop song, in his textbook. They mean that. Literally. The love of one‚Äôs life.

Shit.

Oh shit.

Oh shit.

Oh‚Äî

Remus swallows, trying to get his heart rate under control. Eventually he manages to nod. ‚ÄúOkay, okay good. Does he‚Äîdoes he know you‚Äôre an Animagus?‚Äù

But you forgive him,

he has to remind himself.

Because he does.

Of course he does.

‚ÄúI was gonna head up but are you okay?‚Äù James asks, pulling him out of his thoughts.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus smiles, though it feels forced. ‚ÄúYeah, of course. I‚Äôll be just behind you.‚Äù

PART III: MARY

¬†

It‚Äôs dark, the sky black, the Quidditch Pitch lit by a series of glowing orbs that‚Äôve been levitated around the stadium. The bitterly cold December wind blows against Mary who‚Äôs standing on the top level of the Gryffindor stands. Arms crossed over her chest, a light dusting of snow on the ground where the Slytherin players are still milling about after their practice. It‚Äôs been a mild winter so far, but Mary has a feeling that that‚Äôs about to change. She can feel it, the shift in the wind.

Technically she isn‚Äôt allowed to be here, not just because it‚Äôs an opposing teams practice but because, since her attack, students aren‚Äôt supposed to leave their common rooms after eight, and if they do, they‚Äôre required to be in pairs. ‚ÄúGood. Now tell me who the fuck you took out of my head or I swear to God I will go right to James Potter‚Äôs bed and tell him that you were there. That you helped them do it.‚Äù

Silence.

‚ÄúBarty Crouch?‚Äù

That day in the hallway.

Of course it was him.

‚ÄúAre we done here?‚Äù he asks coldly.

Regulus blinks back at her. ‚ÄúAnd how exactly am I going to do that?‚Äù

Mary grins, reaching into her back pocket and enjoying the way it makes Regulus tense. She pulls out two Galleons, and tosses one to Regulus who fumbles, barely catching it. He turns it over in his hand before looking back at her.

‚ÄúAre you trying to bribe me? You do know I‚Äôm quite wealthy don‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Mary ignores him, holding up her own coin. ‚ÄúSqueeze it.‚Äù

He looks at her quizzically. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúIn the centre of your palm, squeeze it.‚Äù

Hesitantly, he does as she asks, causing the coin between her fingers to start to glow. Regulus blinks, looking from his coin to her‚Äôs.

‚ÄúImpressive,‚Äù he manages finally.

‚ÄúI am.‚Äù She slips the coin back into her pocket and lowers her wand. ‚ÄúNow we‚Äôre done.‚Äù

And as if they‚Äôve heard her, the glowing orbs hovering around them flicker and blink out. Plunging the pair of them into the dark.

Chapter End Notes
