‚ÄúYou could get hurt‚Äîkilled,‚Äù Regulus goes on through clenched teeth.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care.‚Äù

‚ÄúI care.‚Äù The sincerity in his voice makes something in James‚Äôs chest squirm. It‚Äôs sweet, it is, and yet‚Äî

‚ÄúStop making me your excuse Reg,‚Äù he sighs. ‚ÄúIf you stay it‚Äôs because you want to, not because you‚Äôre protecting me.‚Äù

Silence.

He can see the tension in Regulus‚Äôs back. Misses the lazy way he‚Äôd held himself before. The soft smile he‚Äôd given James when he‚Äôd opened his eyes. But this is important.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go back there,‚Äù he says again, when it‚Äôs clear Regulus isn‚Äôt going to speak.

‚ÄúI. Have. To.‚Äù

James feels something like anger flicker through him but he tries to push it down.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not asking anymore Regulus.‚Äù

It‚Äôs startling how quickly Regulus‚Äôs head snaps around at that, finally looking at James. His normally cold eyes burning.

‚ÄúAre you ordering me?‚Äù Regulus asks, voice sharp.

James could laugh. ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm begging,‚Äù and oh God does he ever sound like it. ‚ÄúPlease, Reg, please, I‚Äôm so fucking scared for you I can‚Äôt stand it. I‚Äôd take the Cruciatus over having to sit at home for two weeks knowing you‚Äôre trapped in that house with those people.‚Äù

A series of emotions flicker across Regulus‚Äôs face so quickly that James can‚Äôt make any sense of them. ‚ÄúThose people are my family.‚Äù

But James shakes his head. ‚ÄúFamily doesn‚Äôt hurt you.‚Äù

Regulus sighs again, pinching the bridge of his nose before he gets off the bed, pacing. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to be scared,‚Äù he says finally, sounding significantly less angry and more like someone trying to placate a small child. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs bullshit and you know it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been fine.‚Äù

James nearly chokes, barely able to get the words out of his mouth. ‚ÄúSurviving and being fine are not the same.‚Äù

But Regulus only waves a dismissive hand at him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be fine.‚Äù

It‚Äôs getting harder and harder for James to keep the anger out of his voice. ‚ÄúWill Lucius Malfoy be there?‚Äù

Regulus jolts to a stop so suddenly James is worried he‚Äôs hurt himself. When he looks at James the older boy almost cowers. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you dare throw that back in my face.‚Äù

James‚Äôs heart sinks. ‚ÄúThrow‚Äîwhat? Reg, no, no! I‚Äôm not‚Äî‚Äú Somehow James finds himself on his feet too. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt be safe in a place like that, with people like that. You can‚Äôt be fine. Not with him‚Äîaround,‚Äù at the thought of Malfoy James is always hit with the duelling urges to puke and punch someone. ‚ÄúI mean Jesus I‚Äôm not fine just thinking about it, it‚Äôs been gutting me for days, the idea of you having to be around him. I can‚Äôt stand it, I don‚Äôt know how you can.‚Äù

Regulus just stares back at him and James can‚Äôt read him but he knows he‚Äôs doing this all wrong, he just keeps hitting walls. Normally he‚Äôd be patient, he‚Äôd wear them down, but he doesn‚Äôt think they have time. In fact, he‚Äôs almost positive they don‚Äôt.

‚ÄúYou feel so much,‚Äù Regulus says eventually.

James lets out a sad sort of laugh. ‚ÄúYou noticed.‚Äù

Regulus just shake his head, curls all out of sorts, James loves it. ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt have told you about Lucius.‚Äù

James feels the floor shift beneath his feet. ‚ÄúNo, please don‚Äôt‚Äîyou should have. Of course you should have. Regulus I‚Äôm sorry, I didn‚Äôt mean to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt hurts you,‚Äù he interrupts, James going silent. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to hurt you.‚Äù

‚ÄúReg,‚Äù the name is barely a word, more an exhale as James collapses onto the bed again. He rubs a hand over his face. ‚ÄúEverything that hurts you hurts me. But that doesn‚Äôt mean I don‚Äôt want to know about it,‚Äù he makes sure that Regulus is looking at him. ‚ÄúI can handle it Reg. I can handle all of it.‚Äù

Regulus gives him a look that clearly says: ‚Äòobviously you can‚Äôt‚Äô but James ignores it.

‚ÄúI just wanna protect you.‚Äù

Another long look before Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúI could if you‚Äôd let me.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut then I wouldn‚Äôt be able to protect you.‚Äù

The face James makes must be really pathetic because Regulus instantly steps forward, forgetting to be mad or frustrated or whatever else he is with James. He pulls him forward and because James is still sitting his face ends up somewhere around Regulus‚Äôs stomach. He doesn‚Äôt complain.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Regulus coos, face buried in James‚Äôs hair.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do,‚Äù James says pathetically. ‚ÄúI hate that you won‚Äôt leave. Maybe that‚Äôs not fair but I do.‚Äù

Regulus only kisses the top of his head. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hate that they hurt you.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt expect Regulus to respond really, but after a few minutes he hears: ‚ÄúMaybe they won‚Äôt this time.‚Äù

James wrinkles his nose, burying it further in Regulus‚Äôs shirt. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

He shrugs. ‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôll fight back.‚Äù

James looks up at him then, grey eyes on his. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you fight back before?‚Äù

Regulus shrugs, like it‚Äôs no big deal. ‚ÄúNever saw the point.‚Äù

James swallows with difficulty. ‚ÄúAnd now?‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs hand slides up James‚Äôs neck to cup his cheek, thumb brushing just under his eye. ‚ÄúNow there‚Äôs you.‚Äù

¬†

They‚Äôre quiet in the morning. Whispering like they‚Äôre back in their dorms. For a while they just lay on their sides facing one another, James with his hand on Regulus‚Äôs arm, or side, or in his hair. Always touching. Afraid to let go.

Eventually they have to get up though. Still not speaking. What else is there to say? They‚Äôve both made their stances clear and James doesn‚Äôt want to fight anymore. He pauses when they both get to the door, sighing and dropping his head onto Regulus‚Äôs shoulder.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù the other boy says, hand making comforting circles on James‚Äôs back.

James can feel something like tears at the back of his throat and he sure as hell isn‚Äôt going to start crying right now‚ÄîMerlin. So he doesn‚Äôt say anything for a while, not until he‚Äôs certain he has himself under control. Then he pulls back enough to look at Reg.

‚ÄúI love you. You know that right?‚Äù

There‚Äôs only a brief pause before Regulus starts nodding. ‚ÄúYeah. Yeah I know that.‚Äù

James leans forward and kisses the top of his head. ‚ÄúSo fucking much Reg. So fucking much.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Reg says into his chest. ‚ÄúYeah, me too. I love you too.‚Äù

And that's all there is really.

¬†

PART II: SIRIUS

¬†

Sirius is sitting on the train, one knee bent, foot resting on the edge of the seat across from him. Remus had to go do Prefect duty and he‚Äôs left Sirius alone with a sulking James‚ÄîGod knows why‚Äîand a sleeping Peter. Every few minutes Sirius checks the time only to groan internally at how slowly it‚Äôs passing.

They‚Äôre all going to the Potter‚Äôs this year, well, except Peter technically, but his home is the closest to the cottage anyway so he‚Äôll be over loads. There was no way in hell Sirius and James were going to let Remus spend Christmas alone with Lyall‚Äîor, more likely, just alone because Lyall Lupin is a bastard who would absolutely bail on his son during his first Christmas without his mum. Besides, there‚Äôs supposed to be a full moon over the break, Remus is already getting twitchy about it. In general Remus is never particularly over the chuffed about the whole werewolf thing but he especially hates it when he has to transform away from the shack. Sirius isn‚Äôt sure what they‚Äôre going to do when they graduate but he pushes that thought aside. A problem for another day.

Needing a distraction he gives James‚Äôs shin a kick.

‚ÄúPrick,‚Äù James says, pulling himself out of Sirius‚Äôs reach without taking his eyes off the window. He‚Äôs been staring at the scenery all maudlin for like an hour. Sirius stretches out, kicking his shin again for good measure.

‚ÄúOw!‚Äù James hisses. ‚ÄúFuck off.‚Äù But at least he‚Äôs looking at Sirius now‚Äîwell, glaring anyway.

‚ÄúYou gonna tell me what‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù

James is rubbing at his leg like a little baby. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just tired,‚Äù he mumbles.

It‚Äôs work for Sirius not to roll his eyes. Instead he decides to shoot James a grin. ‚ÄúYes, that happens when you spend all night out with your boy toy.‚Äù

James really does roll his eyes, it‚Äôs all big and huffy and dramatic. He should win an award. ‚ÄúJust leave it would you?‚Äù

He means it. Sirius can tell the difference‚Äîwhen James is pouting and when he‚Äôs actually upset.

‚ÄúDid something happen?‚Äù he asks, tone suddenly sincere.

James sighs, looking warn out, hands scrubbing at his face. ‚ÄúNo. Nothing. I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

Sirius feels something vaguely violent starting to grow inside him. ‚ÄúDid he hurt you?‚Äù he almost barks.

A pained expression comes across James‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt talk about it Pads.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause he doesn‚Äôt want anyone to know?‚Äù

James nods and then stops himself, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, maybe that‚Äôs not fair, it‚Äôs‚Ä¶complicated.‚Äù

James always gives everyone more credit than they deserve. Sirius knows that better than anyone. ‚ÄúIt is not complicated,‚Äù Sirius says sternly. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs gone and made you miserable before Christmas and that‚Äôs grounds for retribution.‚Äù Sirius doesn‚Äôt ask the obvious question‚Äîthe ‚ÄòDid he end things‚Äô question. Because James will tell him if he wants to. And because sometimes answering that question hurts more than the rest of it.

James gives him a weak smile. ‚ÄúThanks but I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôll be necessary.‚Äù

‚ÄúUm, it‚Äôs definitely necessary. You look worse than that time someone nearly decapitated you with a Bludger,‚Äù James rolls his eyes but Sirius continues. ‚ÄúI really think he‚Äôs unclear on the rules here. I‚Äôm the only one allowed to ruin your life.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre so good at it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm an overachiever,‚Äù they share a grin before Sirius gets earnest again. ‚ÄúReally James, I mean it, are you okay? You can tell me, I won‚Äôt ask his name or like, birthday, or whatever you think is gonna give him away.‚Äù

James gives him a sad look. ‚ÄúThank you, really, but I just‚ÄîI can‚Äôt. I promised.‚Äù And that‚Äôs the end of it for James. He‚Äôs made a promise, and James Potter never breaks his promises.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Sirius says, even though it kills him.

James nods, going back to staring out his window. Sirius hates it‚Äîhe has half a mind to scream at James about how stupid he‚Äôs being but he refrains because he knows it wont accomplish anything. Once James loves someone it‚Äôs kind of game over. The kid has claws that would put Moony to shame and once he gets them in you he never lets go. It‚Äôs one of the things that Sirius likes best about him, one of the things that allowed him to relax around James. Knowing that he wasn‚Äôt just going to walk away.

But right now it‚Äôs fucking infuriating, because if it hadn‚Äôt been clear already that the guy he‚Äôs seeing is a complete douche-canoe, now he‚Äôs out here making James miserable at Christmas.

Christmas for Christ‚Äôs sake!

James loves Christmas. James loves Christmas so much that he‚Äôs managed to make Sirius love Christmas, which before having met James, Sirius would have thought was impossible. Everything was terrible at Grimmauld Place, including holidays.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go‚Ä¶I‚Äôm gonna go find the girls,‚Äù Sirius says eventually, because he‚Äôs pretty sure if he spends another second in this compartment he‚Äôs going to blow-up at James. James who is currently nodding his head.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù he says, not tearing his eyes away from the window.

It figures that James would have terrible taste in romantic partners. Things had been looking okay there for a while with Evans. I mean, sure, she was never going to go out with him (at least not until recently), but it seemed promising that he wanted her to. But this? This guy? Clearly a demotion.

Sirius skulks along the train, not really trying to find the girl‚Äôs compartment, and maybe a little bit trying to run into Remus on his Prefect rounds. It‚Äôs ridiculous how often he misses Remus when he isn‚Äôt around, even when it‚Äôs only for an hour or two. It‚Äôs definitely gotten worse since they started being more than platonic. Since he‚Äôs finally been able get his mouth on him. Been able to fall asleep with his head on his chest. Somewhere deep down he thinks he knew it would be like this. That once he got a little piece of Remus he would become insatiable. It‚Äôs frightening really.

He enters an emptier train car, most of the compartment doors thrown open, revealing vacant chairs. There are always spots left over on the holidays when everyone isn‚Äôt taking the train back to London. Some people‚Äôs parents taking them right from the school, other people‚Äôs parents not taking them at all. Sometimes Sirius wonders if that‚Äôd be him, if without James he would he be spending Christmas alone in his dorm room right now.

It‚Äôs a stupid thought.

Without James he never would have left Grimmauld in the first place.

The sound of murmured voices pulls him up short. Obviously it‚Äôs bad to eavesdrop blah blah blah, but then, if you‚Äôre too stupid to cast a silencing charm or a muffliato whose fault is it really if you‚Äôre overheard?

Sirius creeps slowly towards the voices, they‚Äôre too quiet for him to make out but it definitely sounds like a girl and a guy. He pauses just before the doorway of one of the only closed compartments, making sure to hang back enough that his silhouette won‚Äôt be seen through the glass.

‚ÄúI want to keep in contact with you,‚Äù are the first words Sirius is able to pick out. His brain spinning for a moment when he realizes that it‚Äôs Mary who‚Äôs speaking. ‚ÄúTwo weeks is a long time, I wouldn‚Äôt want you to go forgetting about me.‚Äù

Oh.

Oh shit.

Maybe he shouldn‚Äôt be listening to this. His ex-girlfriend getting mushy with her new guy is not something he needs to hear.

He‚Äôs already walking away when he the reply comes, a little louder than those before;

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think forgetting you is likely.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs feet freeze. He knows that voice. He‚Äôd know it anywhere.

It‚Äôs Regulus.

Mary is with Regulus.

That thought alone seems to short circuit his brain for a moment and he doesn‚Äôt hear anything else that‚Äôs being said only the noise of his own pulse pounding in his ears. He knows that he ought to go back to his own compartment, that he ought to calm down and talk it out with James and Remus. He‚Äôs too angry right now. Too caught off guard to handle this at all correctly.

So he‚Äôs not sure how he ends up turning around, or throwing open the compartment door, or pointing his wand at his brother‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúMerlin Sirius,‚Äù Mary says, shuffling out of the line of fire while Regulus backs up as far as he can against the window, hands in the air. At least they‚Äôre both fully clothed, Sirius thinks before shivering in disgust at the image that conjures.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you,‚Äù he hisses at Mary, eyes still on his brother who looks as apathetic about the whole thing as he always does.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt believe me?‚Äù Mary repeats, a dangerous edge in her voice warning Sirius to tread carefully here.

Sirius doesn‚Äôt answer her, doesn‚Äôt know how to put into words what a fucking betrayal this is. I mean, Regulus? REGULUS. His brother, his fucking Death Eater brother? It‚Äôs too close and too sore and too‚Ä¶mean. He wouldn‚Äôt have thought Mary capable of it.

‚ÄúAre you going to use that any time soon?‚Äù Regulus asks, voice flat as he nods at Sirius‚Äôs wand. ‚ÄúBecause if not I have places to be.‚Äù

Sirius growls, not at all appreciating his brother‚Äôs smug tone. He‚Äôs not sure if he‚Äôd actually been planning on hexing him or not, but before he can think better of it he hears the word ‚ÄúLevicorpus‚Äù spit out of his mouth. Regulus‚Äôs legs fly out from under him, pulling him towards the ceiling.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Regulus startles, while Mary rolls her eyes, collapsing into the seat behind her.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing Sirius?‚Äù she asks.

He really has no idea. ‚ÄúWhat am I doing?‚Äù he demands. ‚ÄúWhat the hell are YOU doing? Regulus, Mary? Really? I thought you at least had standards.‚Äù

Mary lets out a laugh that Sirius does not appreciate. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not fucking your brother Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo? Just hanging out in empty train compartments whispering sweet nothings into one another‚Äôs ears?‚Äù

Mary is still looking at him like this is somehow funny. ‚ÄúSweet nothings? Since when do I whisper sweet nothings into anybody‚Äôs ears?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt a fucking joke Mary.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs too bad because from where I‚Äôm sitting it‚Äôs hilarious.‚Äù

‚ÄúHilarious? Did he tell you he has the fucking Mark? Huh?‚Äù there‚Äôs a palpable shift in the compartment, like everyone has collectively started holding their breath. ‚ÄúWell?‚Äù Sirius goes on when Mary just stares back at him in horrified silence. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you gonna laugh? I thought this was hilarious.‚Äù

Mary just keeps staring at him, like she‚Äôs trying to work something out. Sirius can‚Äôt read her expression. Has no idea what it means. Eventually she turns her attention to Regulus.

‚ÄúIs he telling the truth?‚Äù Mary asks, voice serious. Regulus looks at her and then away. Which, of course, isn‚Äôt good enough for Mary. She stands on the seat she‚Äôd been sitting on, reaching out and grabbing hold or Regulus‚Äôs arm. He barely tries to fight her, maybe realizing how futile it would be.

She pulls his sleeve back without ceremony and part of Sirius expects there to be nothing there. Nothing to reveal. Part of him wants desperately to have misread all the signs. But it‚Äôs impossible to miss, a great ugly snake and skull squirming on his forearm. Sirius has to look away, something vile growing in the pit of his stomach.

‚ÄúDoes he know?‚Äù Mary asks, voice colder than Sirius has ever heard it. She‚Äôs still holding Regulus‚Äôs arm out and Sirius can see him starting to squirm, not able to meet her eyes.

‚ÄúDoes who know?‚Äù Sirius asks.

But Mary isn‚Äôt paying attention to him anymore. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt does he?‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù Regulus says, he‚Äôs shaking, face shockingly pale for someone who‚Äôs currently hanging upside down.

Mary looks at him like she‚Äôs never heard the word before. ‚ÄúPlease? Are you kidding me? You have this on your arm and you want me to, what, lie for you? Protect you? Do you have any idea what this means little boy?‚Äù she growls, shaking his arm, Sirius can see her nails digging into his skin, see the sick look on Regulus‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúThis means you want me dead and you have the fucking nerve, after everything else, to say ‚Äòplease‚Äô?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt answer, of course he doesn‚Äôt, silence has always been his shield. Anger Sirius‚Äôs. The louder their mother got the quieter Regulus always became.

Mary shakes her head, throwing his arm away and stepping onto the ground, heading for the open door.

‚ÄúMary what‚Äôs going on?‚Äù Sirius demands.

‚ÄúAsk your bloody best mate,‚Äù she doesn‚Äôt stop, doesn‚Äôt even look at him. Sirius Black likes to think of himself as brave but he does have some self preservation instinct and there is no way he is going to try and stop her.

For a moment after she leaves the pair of brothers sit in complete silence, neither Sirius nor Regulus able to look at one another or speak or move. Eventually Sirius sighs, waving his wand and letting Regulus drop back onto the ground, maybe a little less gracefully than he should have. Regulus doesn‚Äôt say anything though, doesn‚Äôt even stand up, just crawls into a sitting position with his back against the seats, hands gripping his knees.

‚ÄúI take it you‚Äôre not shagging my ex-girlfriend then,‚Äù Sirius says finally.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus doesn‚Äôt look at him, staring straight ahead, his voice strained like he isn‚Äôt getting enough air.

Sirius waits for him to continue but he doesn‚Äôt so eventually Sirius is forced to speak again; ‚ÄúWhat do James and Mary know?‚Äù

Regulus only shakes his head. Sirius does his best not to hex him again.

‚ÄúIs it about Mary‚Äôs attack?‚Äù

That gets a laugh out of Regulus but it‚Äôs all twisted and choked and nothing like Sirius remembers. Regulus brings his hands up to his face, holding his head with his elbows on his knees.

‚ÄúRegulus‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGod I don‚Äôt know, yes, a little. I don‚Äôt know. Just go away.‚Äù His words are muffled by his hands. Sirius considers going to find James who is more likely to provide him with answers anyway, but for some reason his feet won‚Äôt move.

He looks so small,

says the annoying voice in his head.

He looks so lost.

‚ÄúYou said you felt like you were drowning,‚Äù the words come out of him before he‚Äôs even really decided to say them. They‚Äôve been on his mind since the Veritaserum. He‚Äôd been meaning to find Regulus, to ask him about them, but it just somehow never felt like the right time.

‚ÄúNot now‚Äîwe‚Äôre not doing this now,‚Äù Regulus mutters. He‚Äôs still shaking from earlier and for a moment Sirius wonders if he‚Äôs crying but when Regulus drops his hands his eyes are dry.

‚ÄúI know what it‚Äôs like,‚Äù Sirius says, watching his brother warily, ‚Äúto be alone in that house.‚Äù

Regulus shoots him a sharp look, the first since Mary left. ‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt alone. You had me.‚Äù

Sirius is surprised by the conviction in his brother‚Äôs voice. Surprised by how much he means that. ‚ÄúDid I?‚Äù Sirius asks, not even in an attempt to be confrontational but just‚Ä¶honest. ‚ÄúBecause I don‚Äôt remember you ever being there Reg, not when it counted, not when I needed you.‚Äù

Silence.

Sirius sighs, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúBella, that day, the last one, she wanted you to torture me, you remember?‚Äù

After a brief pause Regulus nods.

‚ÄúWould you have? If dad hadn‚Äôt stepped in? Would you have done it?‚Äù

His brother is looking at him with his real face. Maybe that doesn‚Äôt make any sense, but it‚Äôs true. Most of the time when Sirius sees Regulus he‚Äôs walking around with this expression of distain that is far too similar to their mother‚Äôs. But here, now, he looks like Reg. Looks like the kid who used to follow Sirius everywhere, used to beg him to read stories and build snow forts. Who used to crawl into his bed at night when he was scared‚Äînot their parents bed, but his.

He‚Äôd always felt more like a parent than a brother to Regulus, maybe that‚Äôs why it hurt so much. That when things started to get bad, really bad, Regulus disappeared. He may not have chosen their parents, but he certainly didn‚Äôt choose Sirius either. Instead he‚Äôd gone and made himself as small and quiet as possible. As though hoping the world would simply overlook him. Never forcing him to make up his mind.

Eventually Regulus sighs, running a hand over his face before meeting Sirius‚Äôs stare.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Sirius closes his eyes for a second. It hurts. But only a little. After all, it‚Äôs not as though he hadn‚Äôt been expecting it.

‚ÄúSee?‚Äù he says, opening his eyes again. ‚ÄúAlone.‚Äù

Regulus only looks away, back down at his knees and Sirius realizes that he doesn‚Äôt even feel angry anymore, just‚Ä¶sad.

‚ÄúJoyeux Noel Reg,‚Äù he says dryly, "J'esp√®re que cette ann√©e tu apprendras √† nager." He walks away before his brother‚Äôs silence can get too loud.

Chapter End Notes

** "Merry Christmas Reg, I hope this year you learn how to swim"**

Hey! Hi! Hello!

I feel like this was short but concentrated - like all the scenes are pretty juicy (but maybe I'm wrong)

Thank you as always for the comments and kudos, makes my day! Love hearing all your thoughts and theories!

Chapter 31

Chapter Summary

Mary: the meaning is not known for certain, but there are several theories including "sea of bitterness," "rebelliousness," and "wished for child."

Chapter Notes

Tw: Referenced sexual assault

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Mary isn‚Äôt an idiot. She knows that she isn‚Äôt alright. Between her inability to sleep for more than a few hours at a time and her new paranoia that she‚Äôs constantly being followed, she‚Äôs definitely spiralling in a downward direction. Still, sitting on the roof of her childhood home blowing smoke into the pink evening sky, she‚Äôs finding it hard to care. Well, actually, she‚Äôs been finding it a bit hard to care in general lately.

It‚Äôs too cold for this but she can‚Äôt stand being inside anymore. She feels trapped. Trapped by the bedroom she grew up in, more full of the kid she used to be than the person she is now. She barely recognizes herself these days, barely remembers caring about the boys whose posters are hung-up on her walls, or the names of her stuffed animals or the girls who gave her the friendship bracelets still sitting on her dresser‚Äîcarelessly taken off one day and never put back on.

She breathes in deep, filing her lungs with all the smoke she can, letting it burn, holding it in until she starts to cough and choke. She sits up, throwing the nearly finished cigarette off the edge of the roof and letting the tears squeeze out of the corners of her eyes. She doesn‚Äôt really cry, hasn‚Äôt in a long time, this feels good though, even if it isn‚Äôt the same.

She hears him coming before she hears the window sliding open.

‚ÄúI thought dad fixed this?‚Äù Damian says, pulling himself through like he was invited.

‚ÄúHe did,‚Äù Mary nods at the window screen she‚Äôd popped out and thrown further down the roof.

Damian lets out a low whistle as he settles next to her. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna get hell for that.‚Äù

Mary only shrugs, looking out at the quickly darkening sky. A particularly bitter gust of wind blows through them, sneaking right under her jumper and through her skin.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù her brother hisses, crossing his arms over his chest. ‚ÄúBloody freezing out here.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs stopping you from going back inside.‚Äù

Her brother lets out a huff. They‚Äôre close in age, only two years apart‚ÄîDamian being the older sibling. They used to be close in other ways too, used to be friends. Though every time she comes home it gets harder and harder to remember that. Damian‚Äôs at Uni now. Mary can never remember which one. Can‚Äôt imagine she‚Äôll ever go to one herself.

‚ÄúWho was he then?‚Äù Damian asks.

Mary reaches into her pocket and pulls out another cigarette. Excessive, but she knows he hates the smell and she‚Äôs hoping it‚Äôll make him go back inside. ‚ÄúWho was who?‚Äù she asks, lighting the thing the old-fashioned way‚Äîwith matches she stole from the kitchen. She‚Äôs gotten too used to doing this with magic.

‚ÄúThe boy who‚Äôs got you out here being moody.‚Äù

She inhales, the smoke scratching her raw throat. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no boy,‚Äù she says on her exhale, it‚Äôs insulting but not surprising that he thinks everything she feels is because of some boy. But then, she supposes there‚Äôs no way he could guess at what the actual problem is.

It‚Äôs incredibly easy to hide things from your parents as a Muggle-born. For all their talk of inclusivity Hogwarts has never been particularly committed to communicating with the Muggle families of their students. From what Mary can tell, all her parents were told about her attack was that she got injured and would recover quickly. When her parents asked her about it she told them it was a Quidditch injury, just the mention of the word ‚ÄòQuidditch‚Äô made their eyes glaze over. There were no more questions after that.

‚ÄúThen what is it?‚Äù Damian pushes, she can feel him looking at her without turning her head. He coughs as she lets go of another cloud of smoke. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on with you?‚Äù

It‚Äôs an interesting question; what is her problem exactly? Is it that a group of boys she goes to school with violated her in every possible way? Is it that there‚Äôs a war coming that she has no choice but to be a part of? Or, perhaps, is it that the one person she trusted with the truth‚Äîwith her feelings about all of this‚Äîis involved with one the bad guys? Because maybe James doesn‚Äôt know about the Mark but he still knows who Regulus Black is. The kind of person he is. And what people like him do to people like Mary.

‚ÄúOi! Earth to Mary?‚Äù Damian snaps his fingers in front of her face.

She looks over at him and then back at the now black sky, flicking the ash off the end of her cigarette. ‚ÄúNever mind, you‚Äôre right, it‚Äôs a boy.‚Äù

Mary barely tries to sell it, but Damian doesn‚Äôt appear to need much convincing. ‚ÄúYou need me to beat him up?‚Äù She‚Äôs pretty sure he‚Äôs only half joking.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says firmly, something cold coiling in her gut. ‚ÄúI have it covered.‚Äù

¬†

‚ÄúOut?‚Äù Lily repeats.

Mary rolls her eyes, lying on her back on her bed, curling the phone cord around her finger. ‚ÄúYes, out. It‚Äôs New Years Eve.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure, but we normally do a movie night on New Years‚Äîyou, me, Alice, Marlene.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, I know, I‚Äôve been there. Aren‚Äôt you bored of it?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

That makes Mary smile. She‚Äôs always admired Lily‚Äôs ability to be completely immune to peer pressure. Lily does what she wants when she wants to and doesn‚Äôt care whether anyone else thinks it‚Äôs cool or not.

‚ÄúWell, I am, so I say we all go out this year.‚Äù

‚ÄúOut where?‚Äù she doesn‚Äôt need to see Lily‚Äôs face to know that she‚Äôs frowning.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a club in London,‚Äù Mary says, as casually as she can. As though going out to Muggle clubs is something she does all the time.

‚ÄúThere are several I would imagine.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell look at you with the jokes, little Miss Sarcasm. It‚Äôs called Infinity, they‚Äôre doing a whole New Years Eve thing. We should go.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a brief pause. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre underage.‚Äù

‚ÄúDamian can get us fakes.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll of us?‚Äù

‚ÄúMmhm,‚Äù Mary inspects her nails. ‚ÄúOh, also, can you invite James and the crew?‚Äù

There‚Äôs some static like maybe she‚Äôs dropped the phone. ‚ÄúYou want the boys to come?‚Äù

‚ÄúObviously.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you can‚Äôt invite them because‚Ä¶?‚Äù

Mary lets out an exasperated sigh. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm busy with other preparations.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy can‚Äôt Marlene‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Mary interrupts, sounding not at all sorry. ‚ÄúHave you lost your ability to speak with James Potter? Been hit with some kind of anti-James Potter curse I‚Äôm not aware of?‚Äù

Lily mutters something under her breath that Mary can‚Äôt hear.

‚ÄúWhat was that? I didn‚Äôt catch it,‚Äù she says in her most sickeningly sweet voice.

‚ÄúNo, I have not lost the ability to speak to James Potter.‚Äù

Mary grins even though Lily can‚Äôt see her. ‚ÄúExcellent, then put on your big girl pants and send him an owl.‚Äù

Lily huffs on the other end of the line. ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt understand why it has to be me.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh I‚Äôm sorry, I thought that was obvious. You fancy him, so I think it‚Äôs funny,‚Äù also, he‚Äôs currently fucking Regulus Black and I want to know how serious it is - of course, Mary doesn‚Äôt say that bit. But if Lily can turn his head then maybe the problem will resolve itself and Mary will have one less pit in her stomach.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a terrible person,‚Äù Lily says flatly.

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôve been told.‚Äù

‚ÄúI still think this is a bad idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre coming anyway?‚Äù Mary can practically hear Lily rolling her eyes over the phone.

‚ÄúAs if you‚Äôd let me say no.‚Äù

‚ÄúSmart girl.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a small pause and Mary instantly feels her skin start to crawl. She knows what‚Äôs coming and she ought to just cut it off at the pass, just say goodbye and hang up before Lily has the chance. But for some reason she‚Äôs decided to be a masochist today.

‚ÄúThis silence is feeling very poignant Evans.‚Äù

Lily huffs out a laugh. ‚ÄúIt is a bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell then, spit it out, what do you want to say?‚Äù Mary does her best to maintain an aurora of indifference.

Eventually Lily sighs. ‚ÄúAre you alright Mary?‚Äù

Ah, yes. There it is. Since the attack she hasn‚Äôt been able to have a single conversation with her friends without it ending up here.

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm bored as hell right now,‚Äù which isn‚Äôt exactly a lie.

She likes her family, really she does. Her mother is bright and colourful and her father is soft and sweet and their home is a mess but only if you don‚Äôt know it very well. There‚Äôs a genius to the chaos, to the walls that are covered in far too many photos and the red sofa hiding under far too many pillows. She likes her family. Her home. Except that these days they don‚Äôt really feel like her‚Äôs anymore. Magic building a wall between them. It makes her stir crazy.

‚ÄúDamian not keeping you entertained?‚Äù Lily asks. She‚Äôs met Mary's brother a few times, back when they were still young enough to have playdates. Despite being older Damian has always been more than happy to play with Mary‚Äôs friends. With her. Probably still would if she‚Äôd let him.

‚ÄúDamian‚Äôs a goody two shoes, you know that. Speaking of terribly dull older siblings,‚Äù Mary goes on, desperate to change the subject. ‚ÄúHow is Petunia?‚Äù

Lily snorts. ‚ÄúNot living here anymore, thank God. Me and mum went to visit her new place the other day and it was just‚Ä¶bleh, you know?‚Äù

Mary laughs. ‚ÄúWhere is she living now anyway?‚Äù

‚ÄúSurrey.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh God no.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh, it‚Äôs like no one there is even a real person, all the houses look identical and Petunia was wearing an apron when she answered the door and Vernon was in a suit and he made her serve us.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat!‚Äù

‚ÄúRight?‚Äù Lily‚Äôs tone is similarly indignant. ‚ÄúShe was in the kitchen basically the whole time and me and mum offered to help but she wouldn‚Äôt let us and then Vernon got all snobby about having a wife who didn‚Äôt need help, like that was some sort of brag?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat man is the worst person I have never met.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have no idea,‚Äù Lily sighs. ‚ÄúAnyway, I don‚Äôt know, she seems happy so I guess that‚Äôs all that matters. They‚Äôre talking about having kids soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh no! They want to procreate? That can‚Äôt be good for the future of the human race.‚Äù

Lily laughs. ‚ÄúGod, I shouldn‚Äôt find that funny.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course you should, I‚Äôm hilarious.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust be grateful that Damian hasn‚Äôt gone and married an absolute prick.‚Äù

Mary opens her mouth to confidently say that Damian would never, but finds that she can‚Äôt quite get the words out. Because she actually doesn‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs true. She finds herself looking at the wall that separates their bedrooms. She‚Äôs never met one of his girlfriends before, never been home long enough or at the right time. She actually has no idea what kind of girls he dates.

‚ÄúMary?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry‚Äîsorry‚Äîtalk of matrimony always makes me maudlin.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think you‚Äôll ever, you know, wanna get married?‚Äù

Mary laughs before she can stop herself. ‚ÄúFor some reason I just don‚Äôt see that happening for me,‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúWhat about you?‚Äù

‚ÄúMmm,‚Äù she can tell that Lily is biting her lip. ‚ÄúIt might be nice, I don‚Äôt know, have to be the right person though.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do think that is the general idea with marriage.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know what I mean.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

Lily laughs like she knows Mary is only humouring her. ‚ÄúRight, well, I should go. But Mary?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can talk to us you know? Really.‚Äù

Mary swallows. ‚ÄúI do know, yeah. I just‚Ä¶don‚Äôt want to.‚Äù She couldn‚Äôt say that to Marlene, it would upset her too much. But Lily, she somehow knows, will understand.

‚ÄúOkay. Well, I‚Äôll see you New Years Eve I guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo guessing. Say hello to Jamie for me!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm hanging up now!‚Äù

Mary makes a series of kissing noises into the phone until the line goes dead.

¬†

Okay, so it‚Äôs possible she isn‚Äôt actually getting their fake ID‚Äôs from Damian (because he‚Äôs such a bloody goody-goody that he would never), it‚Äôs possible that she is, in fact, magicking them, which may or may not be a little bit illegal. Usually she can get away with smaller spells without anyone seeming to notice, but since there are so many ID‚Äôs she decides to go on a day trip to Diagon and charm them there. It‚Äôs almost impossible for the Ministry to know who‚Äôs casting in a magic location that busy. Plus, it gets her out of the house and away from her family.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going out?‚Äù Damian had caught Mary trying to make a swift exit out the front door that morning.

‚ÄúMhm,‚Äù sliding a pair of oversized sunglasses onto her face. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo reason just‚Ä¶‚Äù he‚Äôd shrugged, shoving his hands into his pockets. ‚ÄúThought maybe we could hang out for a bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnother time, yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere are you going? Maybe I could come with, or give you a drive?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo!‚Äù she‚Äôd said too fast and too sharp, ‚ÄúSorry, it‚Äôs a magic thing.‚Äù

Damian had instantly frozen. ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù the hands returned to the pockets. ‚ÄúA magic thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúYup, okay, so‚Ä¶see you later?‚Äù

Now, sitting outside Florean‚Äôs with an ice cream cone, charming ID‚Äôs into existence, she feels a little guilty. She isn‚Äôt sure why she‚Äôs so desperate to get away from him, why the idea of spending time alone with her brother is so frightening. She just knows that it makes her skin crawl every time she thinks about it.

Maybe,

hisses the irritating voice in her head.

You‚Äôre afraid that he still knows you too well. That he‚Äôll see right through you like he always did. Maybe you‚Äôre afraid that you want him too.

‚ÄúStupid,‚Äù she mutters to herself, punctuating it with another flick of her wand. She picks the newly formed card up, squinting at the details. The ink is bleeding a little but it‚Äôll have to do. She has no idea why that happens.

Suddenly there‚Äôs the sound of screeching metal and then‚Äî ‚ÄúShit.‚Äù

Mary looks up to find Regulus Black on his hands and knees a few paces away from her, ice cream all over the cobble stone in front of him.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he mutters, pulling back so that he‚Äôs sitting on his heels, inspecting his hands which appear to have gotten scrapped on the way down. Mary wonders if he‚Äôs seen her but that question is answered a second later when his eyes flash up and meet her‚Äôs.

She arches her brow. ‚ÄúWas that my fault?‚Äù she asks, feeling a little smug that just the sight of her sends Regulus Black to is knees.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure you can take credit for my lack of coordination,‚Äù Regulus mutters. ‚ÄúBut I wasn‚Äôt expecting to...see you here...or anyone really.‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty popular place to be if you don‚Äôt want to see anyone.‚Äù

He nods, looking back down at his hands. ‚ÄúYeah well, most people aren‚Äôt getting ice cream in December.‚Äù Which might be a valid point, but since Florean‚Äôs patio has a warming charm permanently cast over it in the winter Mary hardly sees why the weather matters.

‚ÄúThey let you out on your own little Black? Or is your Mummy around here somewhere?‚Äù Mary asks, intrigued when she sees the colour rush to Regulus‚Äôs cheeks.

‚ÄúMy mother isn‚Äôt here, no.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut? I‚Äôm sensing a definite ‚Äòbut‚Äô at the end of that sentence.‚Äù

Regulus grimaces. ‚ÄúKreacher is with me‚Äîour house elf. We‚Äôre getting some things for Christmas dinner.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù she runs him over with her eyes. It‚Äôs strange to see him out of his Slytherin colours and Wizarding robes. Instead he‚Äôs wearing a grey peacoat and black pants, a pair of pointy leather boots on his feet. Dressed like this she can almost forget that he‚Äôs the heir to the Black family dynasty. Almost make the mistake of thinking he‚Äôs just another boy.

‚ÄúSo you left the elf‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúKreacher,‚Äù he corrects.

Mary arches her brow but doesn‚Äôt comment. ‚Äú‚ÄîKreacher, to do all the work while you fucked off to get ice cream? Very nice Black.‚Äù

‚ÄúActually, I was getting us both ice cream. Not that it matters now.‚Äù Both of them look down at the massacre in front of him.

‚ÄúYou were getting your house elf ice cream?‚Äù she repeats.

‚ÄúTechnically sherbet, that‚Äôs his favourite.‚Äù

Mary wrinkles her nose. ‚ÄúEw. Sherbet.‚Äù

Regulus nods gravely. ‚ÄúI know, I keep trying to get him to try something else but he‚Äôs adamant. Honestly, I think he just likes how colourful it is.‚Äù

It suddenly hits Mary that she‚Äôs having a conversation with Regulus Black about his house elf‚Äôs ice cream preferences and she has no idea how she‚Äôs meant to process any of that.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Regulus says knowingly, after a pause that is too long to be comfortable.

‚ÄúAh?‚Äù she asks.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve just remembered.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemembered what?‚Äù

He gives her a dry smile. ‚ÄúWho you‚Äôre talking to.‚Äù

Well at least he‚Äôs self-aware. If such things matter when it comes to psychotic blood purists, which Mary is pretty sure they don‚Äôt.

‚ÄúThat happen to you a lot?‚Äù

He shrugs. ‚ÄúProbably more than most people.‚Äù

Another long pause.

‚ÄúAre you planning to stay on the ground forever? Or are you waiting for your house elf to come help you up?‚Äù

Regulus blinks, looking down at himself like he‚Äôd forgotten he was still kneeling on the ground.

‚ÄúRight, no,‚Äù he mutters, getting to his feet and quickly vanishing the mess he‚Äôd made.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he brushes his hands off on his coat, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd better go.‚Äù

‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you gonna replace your ice cream?‚Äù

He shakes his head, looking a little rueful. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so. Running into you, falling‚Äîdoesn‚Äôt feel like the universe is a fan of me getting ice cream today.‚Äù

Mary very nearly laughs. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs absurd, you do realize that?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh yeah, absolutely.‚Äù

She shakes her head. ‚ÄúWell alright then,‚Äù turning back to her ID‚Äôs, not willing to actually say ‚Äògood-bye‚Äô to him, like this was a real conversation, like he deserves civil niceties.

And that should be the end of it.

Really, she means for it to be.

But then, before she can stop herself, she hears herself say:

‚ÄúYou said sorry.‚Äù

Regulus is already halfway into the road and Mary wonders if he‚Äôs going to pretend he didn‚Äôt hear her, but after a few seconds of hesitating he retraces his steps, coming to stand in front of her table.

‚ÄúWhen you left me outside the infirmary,‚Äù she clarifies. There‚Äôs no one around but she watches Regulus‚Äôs eyes do a quick search anyway.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúI said sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

He arches his brow. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. What exactly are you sorry for Regulus Black?‚Äù She stares him down, waiting for him to decide how honest he‚Äôs willing to be. How honest he‚Äôs capable of being.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúAll of it I guess.‚Äù

Which is barely an answer. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt have to do it, you could have just taken me to the infirmary and left my head alone. No one one was forcing you, there was no wand to your head.‚Äù

Regulus nods slowly. ‚ÄúI could have.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

His eyes keep hopping around, making sure no one is within hearing distance. Not that Mary thinks it would matter much if they were. If they can‚Äôt punish Mulciber for this because of his family connections there‚Äôs no one way that anything is going to happen to Regulus Black.

‚ÄúYou have your people and I have mine, I expect you‚Äôd do what you had to to protect them.‚Äù

Mary does her absolute best not to hex him. ‚ÄúMy friends don‚Äôt normally go around assaulting people.‚Äù

Regulus looks away but doesn‚Äôt move, even when Mary thinks he might‚Äîmight just walk away from this conversation.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt agree with what they do.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she say sharply. ‚ÄúYou just make sure they can keep on doing it.‚Äù And when he goes silent again, she continues; ‚ÄúYou must spend a lot of your time being sorry.‚Äù

A sad sort of smile comes across his face. ‚ÄúI do actually.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow fucking useless of you,‚Äù her voice is so sharp she‚Äôs surprised he isn‚Äôt bleeding. ‚ÄúA sorry Death Eater.‚Äù

He flinches, pulling nervously on his sleeve. ‚ÄúAre you going to tell him?‚Äù

She arches her brow. ‚ÄúWho?‚Äù he gives her a look like: ‚ÄòYou know who,‚Äô and she does. But she‚Äôs still going to make him say it.

After a few seconds of tense silence he sighs. ‚ÄúJames.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

She‚Äôs not sure what answer he was expecting but he recoils almost instantly, face going pale. Funny, she wouldn‚Äôt have thought he was capable of caring that much about someone other than himself. But then, James has always had a way with the Black boys hasn‚Äôt he?

‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù Regulus asks, sounding like he‚Äôs having trouble breathing.

Mary gives him a once over and then shrugs, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm seeing him New Years Eve.‚Äù

Regulus flinches.

‚ÄúI know that I‚Äôm not in a position to ask for favours‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo, you‚Äôre really not,‚Äù Mary interrupts, but that doesn‚Äôt deter him.

‚ÄúPlease, can I‚Äîcan I do it? Can I just‚Äîcan I be the one to tell him?‚Äù he looks at her beseechingly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried that if you tell him now, before he can‚Ä¶reach me‚Ä¶he‚Äôll do something stupid.‚Äù

Mary would like to dismiss this fear, but, she‚Äôs known James long enough to see the truth in it. ‚ÄúLike show up at Grimmauld Place demanding to speak with you?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Regulus says, voice tight. ‚ÄúExactly like that.‚Äù

Mary has no idea how that would end. Not well she imagines. Not well for anyone.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù she says finally, watching as Regulus‚Äôs whole body seems to relax, he has to reach out and grab the table in front of him for support. Mary leans forward, ‚ÄúYou have two weeks after we get back,‚Äù she says calmly. ‚ÄúIf you haven‚Äôt told him by then I will.‚Äù

Regulus still looks deathly pale. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says, sounding a bit hollow. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

Mary nods, leaning back in her chair. ‚ÄúGood. Glad that‚Äôs settled. Now get the fuck away from me.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt need to be told twice. Turning around without ceremony and stumbling across the street. Mary is not at all confident that James still won‚Äôt do something stupid, even if they are at Hogwarts, even if Regulus is the one to tell him. But she supposes that at least whatever he does at school will be less likely to get him killed.

She sighs, looking over at her melted ice cream and vanishing it. She should probably be a little more cautious with the amount of underage magic she uses but she can‚Äôt bring herself to care.

Without much pause she turns back to the task at hand: making sure her and her friends can get absolutely plastered on New Years Eve.

¬†

‚ÄúGive it back!‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have it!‚Äù

‚ÄúYes you do you little twerp! Give it back!‚Äù

Mary has barely closed the front door behind her when her little sister comes barrelling into the hall, throwing her arms around Mary‚Äôs waist and burying her head in her stomach.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up buttercup?‚Äù she asks, gently patting her head. There‚Äôs no time for an answer before Trinia walks in already rolling her eyes.

‚ÄúGod Lu, you‚Äôre such a baby.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey‚Äîno name calling,‚Äù Mary says without thinking.

‚ÄúShe stole my shirt,‚Äù Trinia says, crossing her arms over her chest.

Trinia is thirteen and Lu is eight. When they were younger their parents used to refer to the three of them as ‚Äòthe girls.‚Äô As in ‚ÄòHere comes Damian and the girls,‚Äô like they were some sort of band.

‚ÄúNo I didn‚Äôt!‚Äù Lu says into Mary‚Äôs stomach. It‚Äôs almost certainly a lie but Lu‚Äôs always been Mary‚Äôs favourite so she doesn‚Äôt say anything.

‚ÄúYou did. Now tell me where it is!‚Äù

‚ÄúWait,‚Äù Mary holds up her hand. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know where it is? Then how do you know she took it?‚Äù

Trinia puts her hands on her hips and rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúBecause it‚Äôs missing,‚Äù like Mary is the stupidest person on earth.

‚ÄúSo?‚Äù

‚ÄúSooo,‚Äù Trinia repeats, dragging out the word. ‚ÄúShe obviously took it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt!‚Äù Lu stamps her foot, still clinging to Mary.

Trinia narrows her eyes and looks like she‚Äôs about to say something vicious when Mary cuts her off. ‚ÄúHave you checked your room?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù she asks indignantly.

‚ÄúHave. You. Checked. Your. Room?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not in my closet or my hamper,‚Äù Trinia says stubbornly.

‚ÄúBut you didn‚Äôt check anywhere else?‚Äù

Trinia throws her arms up in the air. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to, I wouldn‚Äôt put it anywhere else. She‚Äôs taken it.‚Äù She jabs an accusing finger at their little sister.

‚ÄúYou really shouldn‚Äôt go around making unfounded accusations like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah! You‚Äôre being super unfunded!‚Äù comes Lu‚Äôs little voice, and Mary has to bite the inside of her cheek to keep from laughing.

‚ÄúUgh, whatever, you two are so annoying.‚Äù

With that she turns around and stomps back up the stairs to her room. Mary waits until she‚Äôs certain the coast is clear before she crouches down to Lu‚Äôs level.

‚ÄúDid you take the shirt?‚Äù she whispers.

Lu stares back at her with big brown eyes and for a moment Mary thinks she might not tell her, but then she smiles. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Mary smiles back, she can‚Äôt help herself. ‚ÄúI thought so. Where‚Äôd you hide it?‚Äô

‚ÄúMum‚Äôs bedroom. She‚Äôll never check there and even if she does, Trinia isn‚Äôt dumb enough to yell at mum for stealing her clothes.‚Äù

Mary laughs, mussing her hair before straightening up again. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a little evil genius aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Her sister grins at her, missing a few of her teeth. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright, go on you gremlin, before Trinia comes back and starts yelling at us again. Where is mum anyway?‚Äù

‚ÄúKitchen,‚Äù Lu says, already scrambling up the stairs, practically on all fours.

Mary nods, hanging up her bag in the front hall before walking to the other side of the house.

She‚Äôd hoped that Trinia would get a letter when she turned eleven. There‚Äôd never been any question that Damian was a Muggle, being older than her, but Mary had been convinced that she couldn‚Äôt be the only one‚Äîsurely her sisters would be witches. It had been devastating when Trinia‚Äôs birthday came and went and no letter arrived. Not for Trinia of course, or their parents, neither of them seemed to care much one way or the other. But Mary, Mary had been so desperate to have someone else in her family who understood. They‚Äôd all been so close when she was growing up, she missed that. Now there was this wall between Mary and the rest of her family. She‚Äôd thought that maybe if she wasn‚Äôt the only one it would help break some of that down.

She was doing her best not to hope with Lu.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Mary says as she slides into one of the chairs at the kitchen table and watches her mother flutter around making dinner. It smells good, warm and spicy, but then, it always does.

Carry Macdonald looks over her shoulder and smiles. ‚ÄúHello sweet-pea, how was downtown?‚Äù

Her mother has a head full of brown curls that are piled haphazardly on the top of her head, loosely held by a silk handkerchief and collection of pens and pencils she‚Äôs stuck in it and then forgotten about.

‚ÄúIt was good,‚Äù Mary loves watching her mother cook, she always has. It‚Äôs like a whole production, with music on in the background and her mum constantly chopping and stirring and mixing. The food at Hogwarts is good but it‚Äôs‚Ä¶impersonal. She tried to explain that to Marlene once but she doesn‚Äôt think she understood. There is just something about her mother‚Äôs food that is so undeniably her. Made with love, she always says.

‚ÄúDid you see any of your friends?‚Äù her mother asks while meticulously dicing an onion into tiny pieces.

Mary thinks of Regulus Black and nearly laughs. ‚ÄúNo, no I did not.‚Äù

Her mother glances up, something a little too knowing in her eyes. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs too bad.‚Äù

Mary tries to look casual. ‚ÄúSometimes it‚Äôs nice to be alone.‚Äù

Her mother holds her stare for a moment longer before turning back to her cooking. ‚ÄúSometimes.‚Äù

Part of her wants to tell her mother‚Äîtell her what really happened this term, tell her about the war and the Death Eaters. Wants to tell her that she feels like she‚Äôs in over her head and she doesn‚Äôt know who to ask for help, not because she doesn‚Äôt have people around her who care but because she‚Äôs not sure she has anyone who can bear it all.

‚ÄúDamian was pretty disappointed that he missed you today,‚Äù her mother interrupts her thoughts, snapping her back to the present.

Mary makes sure to keep her expression neutral. ‚ÄúIf he wanted to hang out he should have said something sooner.‚Äù

Her mother makes a noise that Mary knows means; ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt agree with you but it‚Äôs not worth fighting about‚Äô.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre still going out on New Years Eve to a friend‚Äôs place, yes?‚Äù she asks, and Mary doesn‚Äôt like where this is going.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she says cautiously.

‚ÄúYou should bring Damian with you.‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure he has his own friends.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe does, he sees them all the time. He wants to see you.‚Äù

‚ÄúMum,‚Äù Mary says in a tone of voice that is eerily similar to Trinia‚Äôs.

‚ÄúMary,‚Äù her mother volleys it back at her.

‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt know anyone,‚Äù which isn‚Äôt strictly true, Damian does technically know Marlene and Lily. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to have to babysit him the whole time.‚Äù

Her mother laughs, dumping something into a pan that sizzles. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure Damian will be able to manage a few social interactions without you holding his hand.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt make me bring him,‚Äù Mary says petulantly, folding her arms over her chest.

Her mother looks over at her, brow arched. It‚Äôs an intimidating expression, one Mary has stolen from her mother and put to good use on many occasions.

‚ÄúAre you and Damian fighting?‚Äù her mother asks finally, taking Mary by surprise.

‚ÄúI‚Äîno?‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù her mother rests her arms on the counter separating them, leaning towards her. ‚ÄúMary, he just wants to be your big brother, he doesn‚Äôt get to be very often, so‚Ä¶throw him a bone every once and a while okay? It‚Äôs Christmas.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre playing the Christmas card now,‚Äù Mary says, though for some reason her throat has grown unreasonably tight.

Her mother smiles. ‚ÄúAbsolutely.‚Äù

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù Mary sighs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll ask him. But he probably won‚Äôt want to come anyway.‚Äù

This does not stop her mother from beaming at her, walking around the counter so she can pull Mary into a hug. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she gives her a good squeeze before kissing the top of her head and going back to her cooking.

‚ÄúWill you set the table?‚Äù she calls over her shoulder. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost dinner time.‚Äù

Mary makes a big show of getting up and getting the plates, but the truth is, she doesn‚Äôt mind, she simply has a reputation as a brat to maintain. And if her mother‚Äôs smile is anything to go by, she knows it.

¬†

‚ÄúJust don‚Äôt be weird okay?‚Äù Mary says for the hundredth time as her and Damian walk down Carnaby street. It‚Äôs busy and dark and a little cold. Mary can feel the excitement in the air, people already tipsy and loud. It smells like cigarette smoke and cheap beer and something deep fried. In other words, it smells like a party.

Damian laughs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to be weird. You know, most people like me a lot actually.‚Äù He shoots her a grin.

‚ÄúYeah, yeah, you‚Äôre a big popular football lad, I get it,‚Äù she rolls her eyes.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you have against football.‚Äù

What she has against football is the fact that her parents have attended every game her brother has ever played since he was six. What she has against football is the cabinet full of Damian‚Äôs trophies in their living room that their father practically drools over every time they have company. ‚ÄòOh have you met my son, Damian, he‚Äôs a football star‚Äô which isn‚Äôt even true, by the way. He‚Äôs only playing on the Uni team and doesn‚Äôt plan on going pro.

What she has against football is that she is every bit as good a Quidditch player as her brother is a footballer and her parents will never understand that. Not because they actively don‚Äôt want to, not because they‚Äôre trying to choose favourites, but because they grew up with football. They can brag about it to their friends. They can‚Äôt even tell their friends where Mary goes to school, let alone that she plays a sport on a flying broomstick.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have anything against football,‚Äù she says, after too long a pause.

‚ÄúUh-huh. So, am I gonna be meeting anyone special tonight?‚Äù

She shoots him a look out of the corner of her eye. ‚ÄúSpecial?‚Äù

‚ÄúLove interests?‚Äù

Mary pulls a face that makes Damian laugh. ‚ÄúGross, don‚Äôt ever say that again.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just asking! I‚Äôm a good wingman you know.‚Äù

She gives him another skeptical look. ‚ÄúSomehow I doubt that. But no. No one of interest. One ex-boyfriend I suppose.‚Äù

Damian instantly stiffens. ‚ÄúIs this the guy who broke your heart?‚Äù

Mary scoffs as they round the next corner, music pouring out off every building they pass. ‚ÄúNo boy has ever broken my heart.‚Äù Mary is pretty sure that‚Äôs true.

‚ÄúFine, then is he the boy who had you sitting on the roof feeling sorry for yourself?‚Äù his voice has done that thing where it gets all low and macho and stupid.

‚ÄúI already told you I don‚Äôt need you to beat anyone up for me,‚Äù she says wearily.

‚ÄúMary.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh honestly,‚Äù she comes to a stop, turning to face her brother and causing the people walking behind them to grumble as they‚Äôre forced to maneuver around them. ‚ÄúNo, he isn‚Äôt. I broke up with him. We‚Äôre honestly very good friends when he isn‚Äôt being an idiot. He has a boyfriend now anyway so.‚Äù

There is the chance that maybe she shouldn‚Äôt have said that.

She watches her brother‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúHe has‚Ä¶‚Äù

Mary‚Äôs gaze hardens. ‚ÄúYes. Is that going to be a problem for you? Because if it is you can fuck right off.‚Äù

He‚Äôs still staring at her in shock. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîno, I‚Äîno, not a problem. Just‚Ä¶surprised, I guess?‚Äù he passes his weight back and forth between his feet, hand rubbing at the back of his neck. Uncomfortable. ‚ÄúIs that‚Äîer‚Äîcommon, with Wizards?‚Äù

Mary arches her brow. ‚ÄúAre you suggesting only Wizards are gay?‚Äù

Damian laughs a little, though it‚Äôs still laced with nerves. ‚ÄúNo, no I‚Äôm not.‚Äù

Her eyes narrow. ‚ÄúI mean it Damian, if you‚Äôre going to make this into a thing‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not,‚Äù he cuts her off. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not I swear, I‚Äôve just never met anyone who‚Äôs‚Ä¶y‚Äôknow‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúGay?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

She gives him another once over. ‚ÄúStatistically that‚Äôs unlikely, but they‚Äôre not going to be all over each other or anything so you really don‚Äôt need to worry about it.‚Äù

Her brother nods. ‚ÄúRight. Okay. Yeah. Cool.‚Äù

‚ÄúCool,‚Äù Mary repeats mockingly before she starts walking again.

The silence between them lasts for about a block before Mary gives in. ‚ÄúAre you seeing anyone?‚Äù she asks, imagining the answer is ‚Äòno‚Äô since he‚Äôs out with his little sister on New Years Eve.

‚ÄúNah, there‚Ä¶there was for a bit but, not anymore.‚Äù

She looks over at him. ‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù

He shrugs. ‚ÄúShe wanted to keep her options open and I‚Ä¶didn‚Äôt,‚Äù he gives her a self-deprecating smile.

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúObviously she didn‚Äôt deserve you then.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure that‚Äôs true,‚Äù Damian says, smiling a bit more genuinely. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs nice to hear you say it.‚Äù

Mary knocks her shoulder into his. ‚ÄúAnytime.‚Äù

The silence returns, except this time Mary can feel the glances that Damian keeps sending her way. It‚Äôs work for her not to roll her eyes. She knows exactly where this is going.

‚ÄúMary, are you okay?‚Äù

She really wishes people would stop asking her that. It‚Äôs such a ridiculous question, as if anyone can ever answer it truthfully.

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù she says, but she doesn‚Äôt look at him, doesn‚Äôt need to to know that he‚Äôs making that dumb expression he does when he‚Äôs concerned‚Äîall furrow browed and sad-eyed.

‚ÄúYou can tell me you know,‚Äù his voice drops, growing softer, reminding her of the way he used to talk to her after a nightmare or when their dad would put on a scary movie.

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

The concerned furrow doesn‚Äôt go away. In fact he goes so far as to reach out, squeezing her arm. ‚ÄúMary‚Äî‚Äú

But he‚Äôs cut off by someone else calling her name:

‚ÄúMary!‚Äù

Both of them follow the voice to a small group of awkward looking Wizard teenagers leaning against a closed storefront across the street. Mary smiles. It‚Äôs only been a week but she realizes as soon as she sees them that she‚Äôs missed these lunatics.

Marlene launches herself at Mary the second she‚Äôs close enough, causing the pair to stumble into the road laughing as Mary does her best not to lose her balance.

‚ÄúHAPPY CHRISTMAS!‚Äù her best friend shouts in her ear, clearly already intoxicated.

‚ÄúA few days late but your enthusiasm makes up for it,‚Äù Mary laughs, giving her a kiss on the cheek as the freckled blond pulls away, eyes falling on her brother.

‚ÄúOh my God, what‚Äôs up Damian!‚Äù

He smiles at her, the pair performing some weird handshake they developed years ago that Mary has always disliked. Firstly, because handshakes are tacky and secondly, because Damian needs to go find his own best mate and leave her‚Äôs alone thank-you-very-much.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Lily says, laughing a little as she gives Mary her own, slightly less aggressive, hug.

‚ÄúHow much has she had?‚Äù Mary asks in a low voice.

Lily‚Äôs green eyes sparkle. ‚ÄúOnly two glasses of wine I swear.‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúBloody lightweight.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can hear you!‚Äù Marlene sing-songs from beside them.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Mary says over her shoulder.

Marlene sticks out her tongue at her.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôs it going Macdonald?‚Äù Sirius grins from where he‚Äôs leaning against the wall, ankles crossed, Remus on one side of him and James on the other, with Peter standing just a step behind.

‚ÄúHappy New Years Mary,‚Äù Remus adds.

‚ÄúWhat Moony said,‚Äù James smiles, stepping forward to give her a one armed hug. She tries to push down all the things she has to say to him. All the things she‚Äôs been stewing over for the last few days. This is not the time. Not yet anyway.

‚ÄúGood to see Lily was able to reach you,‚Äù she says to him, enjoying the way Lily‚Äôs cheeks flush.

James just looks confused. ‚ÄúWhy wouldn‚Äôt she be able to reach me?‚Äù

But Mary waves the question away, turning back to the group at large.

‚ÄúAlright children,‚Äù she holds up her purse. ‚ÄúI brought presents.‚Äù She pulls out the stack of ID cards.

‚ÄúSanta is that you?‚Äù Sirius asks, earning him a snicker from James and Peter and an elbow from Remus.

‚ÄúYou betcha baby,‚Äù Mary gives him a wink as she starts handing out cards, noticing that Damian very purposefully looks away, like if he doesn‚Äôt see the ID‚Äôs he can pretend he didn‚Äôt stand by and allow their underage shenanigans to take place. She supposes she should be grateful he didn‚Äôt just run and tattle the minute she told him the plan.

‚ÄúHey Mary?‚Äù Remus asks quietly when she passes him his card.

‚ÄúMm?‚Äù

He nods his head in Damian‚Äôs direction. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs he?‚Äù

She looks over at him like she‚Äôd forgotten he was there. ‚ÄúOh, that‚Äôs my older brother‚ÄîDAMIAN!‚Äù she shouts, causing him to look up from his conversation with Marlene and Lily.

‚ÄúJesus Mary, spare our eardrums would you?‚Äù Sirius mutters.

‚ÄúThis is Remus, Sirius, James and Peter,‚Äù she points out the Marauders to her brother, ‚ÄúAnd you lot, that‚Äôs Damian.‚Äù

The boys all nod at one another and Mary can tell by the way that Damian‚Äôs eyes roam over them that he‚Äôs trying to figure out which one of them is Mary‚Äôs ex. She has no intention of helping him out, it‚Äôs much more fun to watch him guess.

‚ÄúAlright, now that we‚Äôre all acquainted, lets get drunk yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúHere, here!‚Äù Sirius calls out, arm swinging around Remus‚Äôs shoulders as he pulls away from the wall, Marlene grabbing hold of Mary‚Äôs hand while Lily very subtly maneuvers her way to James‚Äôs side. Mary feels her chest fill with an unfamiliar fuzzy feeling, so unfamiliar that it takes her a while to figure out what it is:

Love.

She loves them.

All of them.

As stupid and ridiculous and useless as they all are.

Marlene elbows her as they walk up to the club. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that look for?‚Äù

Mary shakes her head, ‚ÄúWhat look?‚Äù she demands automatically.

Marlene scrunches up her nose, pointing an accusing finger in Mary‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúThat one.‚Äù Mary playfully slaps her hand away.

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt anyone ever tell you it‚Äôs rude to point?‚Äù

Marlene grins, somehow bringing out the freckles on her cheeks. ‚ÄúNope.‚Äù

‚ÄúFigures.‚Äù

But Marlene continues to ‚Äòscrunch‚Äô at her. Eventually Mary lets out an exaggerated sigh.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nothing, I just‚Ä¶think I‚Äôve spent too much time with Lily. She‚Äôs made me all sentimental.‚Äù

Marlene laughs. ‚ÄúOh no, what a tragedy!‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, when we get inside I‚Äôll buy you a drink to dull the pain.‚Äù

Mary grins at her. ‚ÄúYou better.‚Äù

¬†

The club is everything Mary had wanted. Loud and dark and crowded. She is drenched in sweat within ten minutes of being inside, drinks sloshing around, glasses littering the floor where people have casually dropped them or knocked them from their tables. There is one almost constantly in her hands, the cold feel of the glass and the burning of the alcohol down her throat making her feel settled for the first time in ages.

They find themselves a booth somehow, tucked away in a corner, with ripped pleather seats and an unstable wooden table covered in years of sharpie‚Äîlike a bathroom stall‚Äîpeople have written names and quotes and bits of gossip. Stuck stickers of bands and political slogans all over it.

Somehow, using her magical drunken wiles, Marlene has managed to drag Damian, Lily and James all out onto the dance floor, giving Mary an unsubtle wink as she knocks James into Lily. Mary snorts.

It isn‚Äôt until they‚Äôre the only ones left that Mary realizes there is something wrong with Remus. He sits stiffly, flinching whenever anyone slides in or out of the booth or when the beat in a song is particularly loud. The club is dark but not so much that she can‚Äôt see the exhaustion in his eyes or the worry in Sirius‚Äôs. It‚Äôs odd to see Sirius acting so‚Äîthere‚Äôs no other word for it‚Äîmothering. He hovers over Remus, barely taking his eyes off him, though whenever he catches anyone looking he shoots them a sly grin or a wink. Makes some offhanded joke.

Eventually, and reluctantly, Sirius gets up to use the loo, at which point Mary downs the rest of her drink and scoots around the booth to take his place beside Remus‚Äîsince speaking across the table is nearly impossible with the music.

‚ÄúHello,‚Äù Remus says, his smile is, at best, delicate.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù she says, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want you to take this the wrong way, but you look terrible.‚Äù

A laugh that seems to surprise him falls out of his mouth. ‚ÄúYeah, I know. I was hoping‚Ä¶‚Äù but then he cuts himself off, shaking his head and looking down at his glass.

Mary stares at him for a moment before deciding to press forward. ‚ÄúYou can leave you know? You and Sirius. I won‚Äôt take it personally I promise. I‚Äôll even make sure James gets back to you in one piece.‚Äù

Remus grimaces running his finger through the water rings left on the table. ‚ÄúHe was so excited,‚Äù Remus‚Äôs voice has gotten significantly quieter, forcing Mary to bend her head closer to hear. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs never been to a Muggle club before, heard about them in songs though, in books, in movies. He forgot‚Äî‚Äù but Remus abruptly cuts himself off, growing stiff.

Mary doesn‚Äôt speak this time, instead waiting for Remus to take up the story again. And he does. Eventually.

‚ÄúI told him to come without me,‚Äù Remus sighs, ‚Äúwhen I started feeling‚Ä¶sick. But he‚Äîhe wouldn‚Äôt. Said he‚Äôd stay behind,‚Äù Remus laughs, running a hand over his face ‚ÄúSaid he had to kiss me at midnight.‚Äù

He sighs heavily before reaching for his glass and downing the rest of it. Mary waits for a few seconds, making sure Remus is done talking before she starts.

‚ÄúSo you decided to come even though you‚Äôre obviously in pain, because Sirius wouldn‚Äôt come without you?‚Äù

‚ÄúMore or less.‚Äù

She lets out a breath. ‚ÄúJesus, you two are a fucking toothache aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Remus looks at her, brow raised in question.

Mary smiles. ‚ÄúToo sweet.‚Äù

He rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúMore like dysfunctional.‚Äù

But she dismisses that with the wave of her hand before leaning forward again, careful not to brush against him. ‚ÄúListen, Remus, there will be other nights and other clubs. Has it ever occurred to you that however excited he might have been, being with you matters more to him?‚Äù

‚ÄúI just‚Ä¶‚Äù his mouth struggles to form the words. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried I‚Äôm going to hold him back. Worried he‚Äôll start to resent me. That he already does.‚Äù

If it wasn‚Äôt for the fact that she was certain it would cause him actual physical harm, Mary would have taken him by the shoulders and shaken him.

‚ÄúResent you for what Remus?‚Äù

He shrugs, swallowing with difficulty. ‚ÄúFor all of it. For being me.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor being you?‚Äù

He nods and then, running a hand through his hair; ‚ÄúFor being a boy. Other things too but that‚Ä¶it‚Äôs‚Ä¶harder for him to accept. And he wouldn‚Äôt have to if it wasn‚Äôt for me. He could just be‚Ä¶God, I don‚Äôt know, normal.‚Äù

‚ÄúNormal,‚Äù Mary repeats, like it‚Äôs a dirty word. ‚ÄúRemus, you do realize, as gorgeous and lovely as you are, that you did not turn Sirius gay, right?‚Äù

Remus huffs out a laugh. ‚ÄúYeah, I know, just sometimes it feels a bit like‚Ä¶I put him in this position. Forced him to make these choices. Cause we were mates first and he was afraid he was going to lose that and it‚Äôs‚Äîit‚Äôs really important to Sirius you know? With his family and all. Friends are really important to him. And so yeah, maybe he would have still been attracted to boys every once and a while with or without me, but he could have ignored that.‚Äù

Mary opens her mouth to object but Remus cuts her off.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying it would have been healthy, I‚Äôm just saying he would have had the option to act on it or not. And it‚Äôs like I took that away from him. Because if he didn‚Äôt act on it he was going to lose something else. Another family. So in a way I forced him to do this thing that maybe he never would have done otherwise.‚Äù He laughs then, swiping a hand over his face. ‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm rambling.‚Äù

There is honestly so much to unpack there that Mary isn‚Äôt at all sure where to start.

‚ÄúLook, Sirius is fucked up,‚Äù she says bluntly, going on before Remus can protest. ‚ÄúAnd that isn‚Äôt your fault. It‚Äôs his parents‚Äô fault, it‚Äôs, you know,‚Äù she waves her hand in the air, ‚Äúsociety‚Äôs fault. People suck, generally, they think a lot of stupid things and then feel the need to force those stupid thoughts on other people. That isn‚Äôt your fault either. But that kid,‚Äù she points after Sirius, ‚Äúlooks at you like the world starts and stops with you. Looks at you like he‚Äôs never seen anything so beautiful. Looks at you like he can‚Äôt believe you‚Äôre real.‚Äù

Even in the dark she thinks she can see Remus blush.

‚ÄúThere are people and things he might grow to resent, but you‚Äôre never going to be one of them. I promise you.‚Äù

Remus lets out a heavy breath, leaning back in his seat before shaking his head, a rueful smile twisting his mouth. ‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThat‚ÄîI‚Äîthank you.‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúNo problem.‚Äù

He gives her an apologetic look. ‚ÄúSorry this‚Äîthis is weird right? Considering‚Ä¶‚Äù

It takes her a moment to realize what he‚Äôs referring to. ‚ÄúConsidering I used to shag him?‚Äô she asks, unable to keep the smirk off her face.

Remus blushes again. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîyeah.‚Äù

Mary only shrugs. ‚ÄúNot really no.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Remus nods even though he clearly does not understand. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Ä¶good.‚Äù

‚ÄúMacdonald,‚Äù they both look up as Sirius comes swaggering back to the table, eyebrow arched. ‚ÄúTrying to take my place?‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, as if I have to try.‚Äù Still, she slides out of the booth, not bothering to sit back down once Sirius has retaken his spot at Remus‚Äôs side.

‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm going go find the others, do try to break a few public decency laws while I‚Äôm away.‚Äù

Sirius laughs out loud while Remus‚Äôs blush intensifies, causing Mary to leave the table feeling distinctly satisfied with herself.

¬†

It doesn‚Äôt take her long to find the others. Marlene with a drink she definitely doesn‚Äôt need, Damian and Lily apparently having an embarrassing dance moves competition. Lily currently performing a very enthusiastic ‚Äòsprinkler‚Äô which is quickly followed by her brother‚Äôs version of the robot.

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs James?‚Äù Mary has to practically snog Marlene‚Äôs ear in order to be heard over the music.

The other girl shakes her head, and then: ‚ÄúHe said he needed some air!‚Äù she shouts.

Mary nods, sparing on more look for her brother and Lily before pushing back through the crowd. She tries not to flinch at all the bodies and hands brushing against her, pulling on her, tries to stop constantly checking over her shoulder like she‚Äôs going to find someone there, watching her. Hunting her. It‚Äôs hot and loud and despite the room being large the crowd sucks up all the space. She doesn‚Äôt blame James for needing a break.

She stumbles out into the cold without her jacket, the wind feeling nice on her sweaty skin, though she has a feeling that‚Äôs going to change soon. She stands in the middle of the pavement, directionless, until she sees a shaggy haired boy a block away, sitting with his back pressed to the bar and his head tilted towards the sky.

‚ÄúYou look miserable,‚Äù she says as she sits down next to him. Fuck the pavement is cold.

He huffs out a laugh that freezes in front of his mouth, drifting off into the night. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not,‚Äù and then, closing his eyes, he says it again; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not.‚Äù Mary isn‚Äôt sure who it is he‚Äôs trying to convince. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the alcohol,‚Äù he goes on eventually.

Mary gives him a skeptical look. ‚ÄúYou look miserable not drunk.‚Äù

The corner of his mouth twitches up in a pathetic imitation of his smile. ‚ÄúYeah well,‚Äù as though that‚Äôs any kind of answer.

Mary, quite frankly, doesn‚Äôt have the patience for this.

‚ÄúRegulus Black,‚Äù his eyes snap open, head turning towards her. ‚ÄúExplain that one to me would you?‚Äù

‚ÄúMary‚Äî‚Äú

She holds up her hand. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre about to tell me you don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm talking about I will be forced to punch you in the face.‚Äù

He lets out another disbelieving laugh, running a hand over his quickly flushing face. It‚Äôs a few seconds before he speaks. ‚ÄúDid he‚Ä¶tell you?‚Äù

She arches her brow. ‚ÄúYou told me.‚Äù

James, bless him, looks genuinely confused. ‚ÄúWhat‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúSweetheart,‚Äù she says patronizingly. ‚ÄúYou practically begged me to help him.‚Äù

James opens and closes his mouth, something helpless in his eyes before he drops his head back against the wall and looks up. ‚ÄúDid you tell him?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

James closes his eyes again. ‚ÄúWas he angry?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says finally. ‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt angry.‚Äù

James gives a small nod, still without opening his eyes. Mary waits another minute before pressing on.

‚ÄúYou really care about him?‚Äù

James‚Äôs mouth forms another sad smile. ‚ÄúI really do.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe what has you out here being miserable?‚Äù

James lets out a shaky exhale, the cold starting to bite at Mary‚Äôs skin.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm scared for him. And I also just‚Ä¶I miss him. Fuck, I miss him all the time. It‚Äôs this clawing feeling in my chest, like there‚Äôs some monster in me that never settles unless he‚Äôs nearby. Unless he‚Äôs touching me. Talking to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúMonster sounds about right.‚Äù

James hisses like she‚Äôs burned him. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Mary.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to listen to you talk shit about him.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh? Am I supposed to have nice things to say about him?‚Äù

He swallows, shaking his head. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt even know him.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo? What about Sirius? Does he know him?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt.‚Äù

Mary scoffs, looking out at the road and trying to quell the trembling anger under her skin. ‚ÄúHas it ever occurred to you that you might be thinking with your dick right now?‚Äù she says bitingly.

‚ÄúYou have no idea‚Äî‚Äú
