Unless she found out that she‚Äôs been betrayed again.

He takes in a shaky breath, hand reaching out to grab hold of the table.

No.

He thinks. Has to think.

That isn‚Äôt what happened. Can‚Äôt be what happened.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Lily asks tentatively, causing him to look up and find both of his friends eyeing him with concern.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fi‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWhat the hell!?‚Äù

All three of them whip around to find a pissed off Sirius marching towards them, Peter in tow.

‚ÄúMr. Black!‚Äù Madam Pince, the sharp faced librarian, stands up behind her desk by the front doors, black hair pulled into a tight bun as she glares daggers at Sirius. ‚ÄúYou will keep your voice down in my library.‚Äù

It‚Äôs very clear to James that Sirius is struggling not to roll his eyes. ‚ÄúYes Madam Pince.‚Äù

‚ÄúQuieter, please,‚Äù she pushes, and while normally James would thoroughly enjoy watching Sirius get taken down by the school librarian, he really doesn‚Äôt need his best mate to be in a worse mood than he already is.

‚ÄúSorry Madam Pince,‚Äù Sirius repeats through clenched teeth, voice a near whisper.

Pince nods her head sharply. ‚ÄúIf I have to tell you again you‚Äôll be kicked out, understood?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúVery well, continue on,‚Äù she waves a bony hand in the air as she turns back to the parchments in front of her.

Fists at his sides and fire burning in his eyes Sirius stalks towards them.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù James hears Remus hiss under his breath and, quite frankly, James has to agree.

‚ÄúWhat the hell?‚Äù Sirius whisper-shouts when he gets to their table, eyes quickly dropping down to the map spread between them which basically makes them double fucked because they can‚Äôt even pass this off as homework.

‚ÄúYou fucking ditched me!‚Äù

‚ÄúUs!‚Äù Peter corrects from his side.

Sirius waves his hand in a ‚Äòyeah, yeah‚Äô gesture.

‚ÄúI had Quidditch practice,‚Äù James says, feeling like that‚Äôs a pretty solid excuse until Sirius turns to him with narrowed eyes.

‚ÄúLibrary‚Äôs a weird fucking place for Quidditch practice Prongs.‚Äù

Which is, admittedly, a good point.

‚ÄúIt‚Äîer‚Äîended early?‚Äù he says, rubbing the back of his neck.

‚ÄúEnded early?‚Äù Sirius demands. ‚ÄúFirst you‚Äôre cancelling practices and now you‚Äôre ending them early?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat is a little suspicious James,‚Äù Peter adds unhelpfully.

‚ÄúYes, thank you Wormtail,‚Äù he says flatly.

‚ÄúAre you dying or something? Because the way you‚Äôve been acting I would fucking believe it,‚Äù Sirius snarls, not sounding nearly as upset as James thinks he should about the idea of his best mates untimely demise.

‚ÄúSirius, your voice,‚Äù Remus warns, eyes flicking to Madam Pince who is now eyeing them threateningly.

‚ÄúAnd you,‚Äù Sirius turns on him. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt even get me started on you, sneaking out of bed in the middle of the goddamn night.‚Äù

Remus looks affronted. ‚ÄúI did not sneak.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally? I don‚Äôt remember hearing anything. Do you Pete?‚Äù

Peter shakes his head. ‚ÄúNah-uh.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou two sleep like boulders. I don‚Äôt need to ‚Äòsneak out‚Äô not to wake you.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe question is why are you two scurrying off while we‚Äôre asleep in the first place,‚Äù Sirius waves an angry finger between Remus and James. ‚ÄúThis is like the third time this week. And what the hell is Evans doing here!‚Äù

The three of them stare back at him, and then at one another. Unsure what to say at this point.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîstudying?‚Äù James offers up weakly, which is, of course, the wrong thing to say.

‚ÄúYou have got to be kidding me,‚Äù Sirius laughs humourlessly. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you just tell me you‚Äôre going for a walk‚Äî‚Äú James sees it then, sees something click in Sirius‚Äôs brain. ‚ÄúThis is about him isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

‚ÄúHim?‚Äù Lily asks.

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDoes she know?‚Äù he jabs an accusatory finger at Lily. ‚ÄúDid you tell her? Does she know who he is?‚Äù

‚ÄúWho who is?‚Äù Lily demands, which, if Sirius had been paying attention, he would have seen as a clear sign that James has told Lily almost nothing. But, of course, he wasn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúFirst Remus and now Evans? Do you trust everyone more than you trust me?‚Äù

James flinches. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says weakly. ‚ÄúPadfoot, listen‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMr. Black,‚Äù Madam Pince‚Äôs voice cuts across the library. She‚Äôs standing again, arms folded across her chest. ‚ÄúI told you not to make me ask you twice.‚Äù

James watches Sirius struggle to get himself under control enough not to snap at her.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my fault Madam Pince, sorry,‚Äù James tries to jump in, but the librarian only holds up her hand.

‚ÄúI know whose voice I heard Mr. Potter and it wasn‚Äôt yours,‚Äù she glares very pointedly at Sirius. ‚ÄúGet out Mr. Black.‚Äù

For a second James thinks he‚Äôs going to argue with her, but then he sees the fight drain out of him. ‚ÄúWhatever,‚Äù Sirius mutters, walking out of the library without even looking at the rest of them. James is about to go after him when Remus beats him to it, already spelling his things into his bag.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll go get him,‚Äù he says, halfway to the door. ‚ÄúYou two okay to finish here?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Lily says quickly. ‚ÄúYeah we‚Äôll be fine.‚Äù

Remus nods, jogging after his‚Ä¶after his Sirius. Making something itch in James‚Äôs chest.

Peter lets out a big exhale, ‚ÄúNot going to lie,‚Äù he says, running a hand through his dirty blond hair. ‚ÄúI have never been more confused in my life.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúThat says a lot coming from you.‚Äù

Peter glares. ‚ÄúOh fuck off,‚Äù but there‚Äôs no heat in it, and James gives him a half hearted smile before Lily clears her throat.

‚ÄúShould we‚Äîuh‚Äî‚Äù she nods towards the map before looking at Peter and then James. ‚ÄúOr do you want to do this later?‚Äù

James shakes his head. They‚Äôre already taking too long. He doesn‚Äôt want to waste anymore time.

‚ÄúPete, mind giving us a minute? I‚Äôll meet you in the Great Hall yeah?‚Äù

Peter looks between James and Lily a few times before nodding. ‚ÄúSure, yeah, okay,‚Äù he looks like he‚Äôs going to walk away but then pauses: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you two have worked things out. It‚Äôs always better when you‚Äôre getting along.‚Äù

James finds himself taken off guard but before he can think of a response Peter is already halfway out the door.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Lily sighs beside him, collapsing down into her chair. ‚ÄúThat was‚Ä¶a lot.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James says, copying her. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

She waves her hand, knocking his fears away. ‚ÄúSo,‚Äù she says eventually, ‚Äúdo you have the item for me? The one with the magical footprint?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù James had almost forgotten. ‚ÄúYeah I‚Äîyeah,‚Äù as he reaches into his bag and feels his fingers brush the small wooden box at the bottom he finds himself infinitely grateful that Remus isn‚Äôt there.

He brings it out carefully, reluctant to give it up when Lily reaches for it. He has the absurd desire to pull away, to tell her not to touch it. He does neither of those things, of course.

‚ÄúThis is beautiful,‚Äù she says, before her eyes flick up to him. ‚ÄúCan I open it?‚Äù

He clears his throat. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù voice still rough. ‚ÄúYeah, you can open it.‚Äù

He sees confusion on her face as her eyes find the red ball inside, resting on its satin cushion. She stares at it for a few seconds before looking back at him. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Quaffle,‚Äù he explains softly, ignoring the ache in his chest. Ignoring the memory of Regulus‚Äôs face when he‚Äôd given it to him‚Äîhow nervous he‚Äôd been, unsure, like James was ever going to do anything but love it.

‚ÄúA Quaffle?‚Äù she repeats.

He nods. ‚ÄúTake it out.‚Äù

She only hesitates for a minute before doing as he asked. As soon as she frees it it starts buzzing around her, causing a laugh to tumble from her lips. ‚ÄúOh my God, it really is a tiny Quaffle.‚Äù

James smiles back a little tightly ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never seen one of these before.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou wouldn‚Äôt have, he‚Äîer‚Äîhe made it,‚Äù James‚Äôs nails have started to dig into his palms. He‚Äôd taken the Quaffle out every day over the break. Held it in his hand, watched it flutter around his room during the few moments he found himself alone. Everything about it reminds him of Regulus.

‚ÄúIs this the‚Äîuh‚Äîthe ‚Äòhe‚Äô Sirius was talking about?‚Äù Lily asks tentatively.

James suddenly feels very vulnerable. Like he‚Äôs had something pulled back and stripped away. He swallows with difficulty, trying to keep his voice casual. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he meets her stare and doesn‚Äôt know what she sees. Or what she thinks. Or if it‚Äôs all written across his face.

You need to learn to hide yourself better,

Regulus said to him once.

Put on some armour every once and a while. You know, even brave men carry shields.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Lily says eventually, carefully picking the ball out of the air and placing it back in its box. There‚Äôs silence for a few seconds before she goes on. ‚ÄúIf he did all the spell work on this than it should work really well. It‚Äôll help if I can get a feel for the signature do‚ÄîI mean, would you mind if I kept this for a little while?‚Äù

Yes.

I mind.

It‚Äôs him.

It‚Äôs mine.

‚ÄúNo, that‚Äôs fine. I figured you would need to,‚Äù he shrugs, like those words don‚Äôt choke him.

Lily nods. ‚ÄúOkay, thank you,‚Äù there‚Äôs another pause, she‚Äôs bitting her lower lip as James fights every urge he has to snatch the wooden box back out of her hands. Eventually she reaches forward, squeezing his arm. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna take good care of it.‚Äù

He nods jerkily. ‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù in a voice so quiet Madam Pince would be proud.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Lily ducks her head to meet his eyes. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to find him okay?‚Äù

James laughs dryly. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt even know who he is.‚Äù

Lily shrugs. ‚ÄúI know you care about him,‚Äù she says simply. ‚ÄúI know he clearly cares about you,‚Äù she nods towards the box.

Those words feel like pressing on a bruise.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt get him a Christmas gift,‚Äù he says for some reason, voice too thick. He coughs, trying to clear his throat. ‚ÄúIt slipped my mind, or it never occurred to me, I don‚Äôt know. He went and made me that,‚Äù he gestures at the Quaffle. ‚ÄúAnd I didn‚Äôt even bother to‚Äî‚Äú his voice drops and after a few seconds finds itself again. ‚ÄúI got him something over the break, to make up for it, I was going to give it to him when we got back.‚Äù He looks helplessly at Lily.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre still going to give it to him,‚Äù she says, squeezing his arm. ‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù

He wants to believe her. Really he does.

‚ÄúYeah, okay. Thanks.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, I mean it. Thank you for‚Ä¶‚Äù he gestures at the books and parchment. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt have to. Especially not after New Years.‚Äù

She looks at him for a moment, something thoughtful in her eyes, maybe also a little sad. James doesn‚Äôt want to think too much about that last thing. About wether or not he‚Äôs the cause of it. He doesn‚Äôt want Lily to be sad. Not ever.

‚ÄúYou remember what you said the other day, about being there for me? About believing me?‚Äù

James nods slowly. ‚ÄúYeah, of course.‚Äù

She gives him a small smile. ‚ÄúThat goes both ways. I‚Äôm here for you. Always. I realize I‚Äôm not exactly a Marauder but, we can still have each others backs right?‚Äù

James feels something leap in his chest. ‚ÄúYes, totally,‚Äù and then, at a loss for anything else to say: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre basically an honorary Marauder anyway.‚Äù

That makes Lily laugh, loosening some of the tension in James‚Äôs chest. ‚ÄúDoes that mean I get a dumb nickname?‚Äù she asks.

James frowns. ‚ÄúHey! We have very cool nicknames I‚Äôll have you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh. So what‚Äôs mine then?‚Äù

His eyes run her over before the ghost of a grin starts pulling at his mouth. ‚ÄúFox.‚Äù

She arches her brow. ‚ÄúFox? Is it because of my hair or because I‚Äôm exceedingly clever?‚Äù

He smirks, leaning forward. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs because you, Lily Evans, are a stone cold fox.‚Äù

The pair of them are able to hold a straight face for exactly five seconds before they both burst out laughing.

‚ÄúI see your lines haven‚Äôt improved,‚Äù she says, choking back a giggle.

‚ÄúOi! I thought that one was pretty good!‚Äù

She snorts. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so corny Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, whatever, you were totally charmed. I could see it in your eyes.‚Äù

‚ÄúKeep dreaming.‚Äù

‚ÄúMiss Evans and Mr. Potter,‚Äù Madam Pince‚Äôs sharp voice slices through their giggling. ‚ÄúAm I going to have to kick you both out as well?‚Äù She tilts her head down, glasses sliding to the end of her pointed nose. She‚Äôs always reminded James of a very grumpy bird.

‚ÄúNo ma‚Äôam,‚Äù James calls back.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just leaving Madam Pince.‚Äù Lily says, already starting to pack her things away.

James feels his momentarily uplifted mood sink again as his eyes fall on the wooden box, as he watches her put it in her bag. Something must show on his face because Lily pauses.

‚ÄúI promise I‚Äôll keep it safe,‚Äù she reassures him again.

James looks at her quickly and then away. ‚ÄúI believe you,‚Äù he gets to his feet, slinging his bag over his shoulder. ‚ÄúWell, see you around I guess?‚Äù

She nods, sliding the last of her books into her own bag. ‚ÄúYeah‚Äîtomorrow morning?‚Äù

‚ÄúTomorrow morning,‚Äù James confirms.

They stand awkwardly for a moment, neither of them knowing what to do.

‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶‚Äù James says eventually, giving her a half-wave before walking out of the library with his head down, feeling like he‚Äôs just left part of himself behind in Lily Evan‚Äôs book bag.

¬†

¬†

‚ÄúWhat the hell is going on out there?‚Äù

James is breathing heavy, covered in sweat and looking out at a very defeated Gryffindor Quidditch team. They‚Äôre halfway through their game against Ravenclaw and they‚Äôre getting absolutely destroyed.

‚ÄúThis should be an easy win for us!‚Äù no one is making eye contact with him‚Äîwell, except for Mary. ‚ÄúStart bloody communicating and open your fucking eyes. Watch what‚Äôs going on around you, keep track of the other team. We‚Äôre making sloppy mistakes out there people, come on!‚Äù

Silence greets these words and James sighs, running a hand through his sweaty hair.

‚ÄúWe can still win this,‚Äù he says finally, earning him a snort from Mary that he decides to ignore. ‚ÄúBut we need to wake the fuck up, alright?‚Äù more silence, James does his best not to scream. ‚ÄúI said: alright?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes captain,‚Äù comes the less than enthusiastic response, but James is pretty sure that‚Äôs the best he‚Äôs going to get so he doesn‚Äôt push the matter.

It‚Äôs only a few moments later that Madam Hooch‚Äôs disembodied voice calls them back out to the pitch. James waits by the door, trying to rally himself as much as his team, giving each of them a pat on the back or high-five as they pass.

‚ÄúSorry James,‚Äù Marlene says when she gets to him.

‚ÄúNah don‚Äôt be,‚Äù he squeezes her shoulder. ‚ÄúBad games happen right? We can still make finals even if we lose this one.‚Äù As long as they win every other game by a substantial margin, but James doesn‚Äôt say that bit. Marlene knows it anyway.

Mary is the last one in line.

‚ÄúSave it,‚Äù James says wearily.

But she, of course, does not.

‚ÄúHalf the players on this team are new,‚Äù she starts, causing James to roll his eyes as he walks down the tunnel towards the Pitch. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve barely played together, I was out most of first term, we need all the air time we can get.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, I‚Äôm aware of that, thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou royally screwed us here James‚Äîwe can‚Äôt communicate out there because we don‚Äôt know how because you‚Äôve been skiving off practices.‚Äù

They walk out onto the sunny field, half the team already back in the sky, the stands cheering.

‚ÄúJust play the fucking game Mary,‚Äù he says, hands gripping his broom so tightly his knuckles are threatening to tear through his skin.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre personal life can‚Äôt effect your game.‚Äù

His head whips around so fast he‚Äôs surprised his neck doesn‚Äôt crack. ‚ÄúLeave my fucking personal life out of this.‚Äù

She holds his stare for one challenging moment before shaking her head. ‚ÄúYou know, the pros may be a guarantee for James Fleamont fucking Potter, but for the rest of us playing well here actually matters. So get your goddamn head out of your ass and pull it together.‚Äù

With that she kicks off, speeding into the blue sky, a cursing James following behind. The problem is, as big of a pain in the ass as Mary is, he knows she‚Äôs right. He‚Äôs fucking this up. Seems to be a common theme with him lately.

¬†

They lose.

It‚Äôs not a surprise. But it still stings.

James takes his time undressing. Takes even more time in the showers. He turns the heat up too high and rests his forehead against the tile and just‚Ä¶breathes. And waits. He‚Äôs the captain, he shouldn‚Äôt be in here hiding, he should be out there making sure his team is okay. Especially the younger players. Frank was always so good at that‚Äîat reassuring them all, making sure no one ate themselves alive with guilt. Quidditch is a team sport. They win together and they lose together. It never lands on just one person. That‚Äôs what he should be out there saying, he just‚Ä¶he can‚Äôt. Because this time the blame does fall on one person.

Him.

His skin is flushed and raw by the time he finally turns the shower off, wrapping a towel round his waist as he walks back into the changing room. His steps only stutter for a second when he finds someone in there waiting for him.

He sighs, walking over to his locker and pulling out his clothes. ‚ÄúHere to gloat?‚Äù

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre on the same fucking team, what the hell would I be gloating about?‚Äù

James shrugs, puling his boxers on under his towel before throwing it off. He should maybe feel more self-conscious about being practically naked in front of Mary but he isn‚Äôt. He‚Äôs known her since they were eleven. The novelty has warn off. Besides, they‚Äôve always been more family than anything else.

‚ÄúAbout being right,‚Äù he says finally, he has his back to her, yanking his shirt over his head.

‚ÄúRight about what?‚Äù Mary asks.

James sighs, leaning against his locker for a moment, feeling so utterly exhausted he can barely get his thoughts in order.

‚ÄúAbout me being crap.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not crap James.‚Äù

He laughs without humour, pulling himself off the wall and turning to look at her. She‚Äôs wearing sweatpants and an oversized jumper James is almost certain used to belong to Sirius.

‚ÄúYou having me on?‚Äù

She rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúGod, you‚Äôre so melodramatic. You‚Äôre not crap. You know you‚Äôre not. But you‚Äôve dropped the ball the last two weeks, and I know you know that too.‚Äù

He wants to fight back. Wants to argue. Wants her to be wrong.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says resigned. ‚ÄúYeah, I know.‚Äù

He turns back to his locker and grabs a hold of his jeans, shoving his legs inelegantly inside.

‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt come back then?‚Äù

James instantly tenses. ‚ÄúMary, I really don‚Äôt have the energy to fight with you right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not trying to fight, I‚Äôm just trying to understand.‚Äù

James sighs, only half believing her as he turns around and drops onto the bench. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says slowly, resting his elbows on his thighs and clasping his hands together between his knees. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt come back.‚Äù

Mary nods slowly, her eyes raking over him in a way that only she can. Like she sees every dirty, broken inch of you. James has always thought she‚Äôd make a good Auror. Give a suspect a few minutes locked in a room with her and they‚Äôd start spilling their guts in no time.

‚ÄúAnd you don‚Äôt think that was his choice?‚Äù she asks eventually.

He grits his teeth, trying not to get short with her. ‚ÄúNo. I don‚Äôt think so.‚Äù

Mary nods again, like she‚Äôs had something confirmed. ‚ÄúListen, if you need‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, a break? A time-out? Whatever. That‚Äôs fine,‚Äù she leans forward even though they‚Äôre a room apart. ‚ÄúLet me run some practices then, let me fucking help you. I‚Äôm a good player‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI know that,‚Äù James says, entirely taken off guard by this turn in the conversation.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù she holds his stare. ‚ÄúThis matters to me James,‚Äù she says with a level of sincerity that is uncommon for Mary. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my dream too. I want to win this year. Hell, I want to win next year. I want scouts to come here and watch us dominate.‚Äù

James runs a hand over his face, ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúYeah me too.‚Äù He shakes his head, laughing a little bit. ‚ÄúOkay, if I need to‚Ä¶if I can‚Äôt be here I‚Äôll let you take over. I‚Äôm sorry that I‚Äî‚Äú he doesn‚Äôt know how to finish that sentence, how to explain what a mess he‚Äôs been since coming back to school and finding Regulus gone. ‚ÄúThis matters to me too,‚Äù he settles on.

Mary nods, getting to her feet. ‚ÄúI know, if I didn‚Äôt think you cared I would have already overthrown you.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck, alright,‚Äù James snorts. ‚ÄúWell, thanks for showing some restraint I guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre welcome.‚Äù

He waits for her to head out, she looks like she‚Äôs going to, but instead she just keeps standing there. Like she‚Äôs trying to decide whether or not to say what she‚Äôs thinking‚Äîwhich is odd for Mary, who always seems to say anything regardless of how rude or callous it might sound.

‚ÄúWhatever it is, would you just ask it?‚Äù James says eventually. ‚ÄúHaving you looming there is making me nervous.‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes but her expression is suddenly determined. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm only going to say this once so listen alright?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Äîalright?‚Äù

She pinches the bridge of her nose. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Äîsorry.‚Äù

James blinks, almost positive that he‚Äôs misheard. ‚ÄúDid you just‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI told you I was only gonna say it once,‚Äù she snaps, and James finds himself biting the inside of his cheek to keep from smiling.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt take back what I said‚Äîwell, except maybe the stuff about Lily‚Äîbut I do take back the way that I said it. It wasn‚Äôt‚Äîanyway,‚Äù she shakes her head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a bitch but I‚Äôm not normally that much of a bitch.‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt entirely sure how to respond to that so eventually he just nods. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says, ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

Mary shoots him a dry smile. ‚ÄúWell look at us, working through our problems like adults. Go team.‚Äù

James laughs. ‚ÄúYeah, go team.‚Äù

¬†

He‚Äôs still smiling a little as he makes his way back up to the castle twenty minutes later, Mary having ditched him to go find Marlene. It‚Äôll be good honestly, having a little help with the team. He should have considered it earlier, Mary has always been one of the strongest players they have, and while he doesn‚Äôt intend to make a habit of skipping out on practices, having a second opinion on what the team needs might be good. It‚Äôs been a lot, doing it on his own. He‚Äôs not sure how Frank managed it, but then, Frank had Alice.

‚ÄúJames! James!‚Äù

He looks up and finds Lily running towards him across the foyer, a couple other people turning to look too.

‚ÄúLily? What‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú he doesn‚Äôt finish as she practically barrels into him, knocking the words out of his mouth as she skids to a stop, grabbing hold of his arms.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs working.‚Äù

He blinks. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe spell‚Äîthe spell‚Äîit‚Äôs working. Me and Remus were playing around with it earlier and we figured it out‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou figured it out and you didn‚Äôt tell me?‚Äù

Lily makes an impatient noise. ‚ÄúYou were already down at the Quidditch Pitch getting ready for the game and anyway, we were pretty sure it worked but we couldn‚Äôt be certain because it only does something if the person you‚Äôre trying to find is using magic. So Remus went to the game but I decided to stay behind and watch it and it just‚Äîit moved. It started moving.‚Äù

It moved.

Those words find their way deep inside his chest.

Regulus is using magic.

He‚Äôs okay.

He‚Äôs okay.

‚ÄúWhere‚Äîshow me,‚Äù James starts walking even though he has no idea where he‚Äôs going.

Lily grabs hold of his wrist and drags him down the corridor. It takes him a while before he realizes that she‚Äôs taking him to the Prefects‚Äô office. To be fair, it‚Äôs not a place he spends much time in.

With the wave of her wand she opens the door to the empty room, a few candles are lit here and there, two desks set up at the front for the Head Boy and Girl. There‚Äôs also a sofa and some chairs, a half empty bookshelf, a coffee table covered in Honeydukes wrappers and old Witch Weekly magazines.

Lily drags him all the way across the room to a small table that‚Äôs been pushed up against the window. He sees the familiar map and the small floating Quaffle except, unlike usual, it isn‚Äôt flitting around, but instead hovering in one fixed spot over the map.

Lily stops dead in her tracks, eyes going wide. James pulls out of her grasp moving closer.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs here then, it‚Äôs found him, he‚Äôs‚Ä¶‚Äù he squints down at the map trying to identify the place the ball is currently marking. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs‚Ä¶in the middle of the water?‚Äù James blinks, panic rising up inside him. His imagination assaults him with visions of Regulus just being dumped somewhere or left to drown, his family is psychotic so even though that sounds crazy they really might have done it. He tries to remind himself that they wouldn‚Äôt have been able to find Regulus at all if he hadn‚Äôt used magic and if he‚Äôs using magic then he can‚Äôt be lying at the bottom of the ocean dead, right? RIGHT.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand,‚Äù he can hear the tremor of fear in his voice as he turns to Lily for reassurance but doesn‚Äôt find any. Her green eyes are wide as she stares at the map. ‚ÄúMaybe it‚Äôs wrong, maybe the spell didn‚Äôt work, huh? Maybe we need to try again?‚Äù

Eventually Lily swallows, looking up at him. Is that pity he sees in her gaze? Oh he doesn‚Äôt like that, and neither does the fear currently writhing around in his chest.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she says slowly, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs the North Sea.‚Äù

Right now James‚Äôs brain isn‚Äôt really working very well, too crowed with white noise and nightmare scenarios so he just nods, hoping she‚Äôll explain what that means. Why it has her looking at him like that.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚ÄîJames, fuck, I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, please. Why? Don‚Äôt be. What‚Äôre you‚Äî‚Äú

She steps forward, hand circling his wrist, grounding him. ‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she says his name softly. He hates it. Sounds like the way you say someone‚Äôs name before you tear their world apart.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs in Azkaban‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

I'M SORRY THIS IS SO LATE

Really, I am.

I had a bunch of school / work stuff and it just took me way too long.

This is one of those chapters where I hope that the stuff I'm doing works even though maybe it's like a little more of an interpretation of HP than hardcore canon? IDK, IDK what the rules are.

ANYWAY, thank you, love you, y'all are so kind which is truly a gift on the internet. I will try to get the next chapter out faster!

Chapter 34

Chapter Summary

I feel personally victimized by this chapter (I KNOW I WROTE IT OKAY)

Chapter Notes

IMPORTANT: This chapter takes place at the same time as the last chapter (basically it's the last chapter from Sirius and Regulus's perspectives), if I was a better writer I wouldn't have to tell you that but unfortunately for all of us I am not

TW: Child abuse (thank you Walburga)

TW: Eating stuff (not related to body image more like stress management or even self harm I guess)

TW: Death / killing (no major characters were harmed in the making of this chapter)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I: REGULUS

AUGUST 1971

Sirius and Regulus sit crossed-legged on Sirius‚Äôs bed, the duvet hovering above them like a makeshift tent. Their father‚Äôs doing.

‚ÄúAgain,‚Äù Regulus whispers, eyes wide as he stares at the new wand clutched in his older brother‚Äôs hand. He can see Sirius‚Äôs grin even in the dark.

‚ÄúLumos.‚Äù The tip begins to glow, lightening up the fort and causing Regulus to gasp just like he did the last four times.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so beautiful,‚Äù Regulus says, before blushing. His mother doesn‚Äôt like when he talks like that‚Äîbeautiful, pretty‚Äîshe says it makes him sound soft.

But Sirius only smiles wider. ‚ÄúNeat huh?‚Äù he says, waving his wand around a little. ‚ÄúAll I had to do was read it in my textbook and I figured it out right away. This school things is gonna be so freaking easy.‚Äù

Regulus nods enthusiastically, certain he‚Äôs right, Sirius is the smartest person he knows. ‚ÄúWhy do you even need to go at all? Couldn‚Äôt you just learn all your magic from books?‚Äù he hopes his voice doesn‚Äôt sound as desperate as he feels.

Tomorrow Sirius is going to the train station, going to Hogwarts, going away from Regulus. Until Christmas. He feels his lower lip start to tremble and instantly stops thinking about it. Sirius doesn‚Äôt mind when he calls things pretty, but he hates it when Regulus cries.

‚ÄúI could probably teach myself yeah,‚Äù Sirius shrugs, with all the cocky assurance of an eleven year old. ‚ÄúBut then I‚Äôd have to stay here.‚Äù He wrinkles his nose, like the very thought leaves a bad taste in his mouth.

‚ÄúBut you‚Äôd be with me,‚Äù Regulus says meekly, causing his brother‚Äôs face to soften.

‚ÄúAw Reg, you know I love you right?‚Äù he claps Regulus on the shoulder. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my best friend. But I can‚Äôt stand this house. It‚Äôs too stuffy. It‚Äôs too small.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt really know what he‚Äôs talking about, the house feels plenty big to him. Too big even. He hates being alone on the top floor‚Äîhearing the floorboards creak or windows rattle and knowing that he has to run drown at least three flights of stairs before he‚Äôll find another person.

‚ÄúBesides, you‚Äôll be joining me next year, so it‚Äôs not even that long.‚Äù

A year feels like an eternity to Regulus.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll write?‚Äù he asks nervously.

‚ÄúOf course I‚Äôll write!‚Äù Sirius says, like it‚Äôs the most obvious thing in the world. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll write everyday.‚Äù

Regulus feels his heart leap. ‚ÄúEveryday?‚Äù

Sirius smiles again. ‚ÄúEveryday,‚Äù he knocks their foreheads together and Regulus laughs. A moment later Sirius‚Äôs wand flickers and goes out.

¬†

JANUARY 1977

Sirius never did, of course.

Write everyday.

Or any day.

Regulus forgave him. He forgave him at the time and he forgives him now. It‚Äôs an awful lot to expect of an eleven year old, to keep his promises.

Regulus can‚Äôt figure out if it‚Äôs irony or some other form of poetic justice that years later James Potter would manage what Sirius hadn‚Äôt. Writing him a letter for every week they were apart. Regulus thinks about it as he lies on his back in a cot in Azkaban, arm thrown behind his head as a makeshift pillow.

His feet hang off the end which is unfortunate because of the rats. They like to‚Ä¶snack. He tries to pull his legs in but his muscles cramp and his back hurts. He isn‚Äôt used to being this tall. Or strong. He‚Äôs clunky and awkward when he moves, unable to accurately judge his size in relation to the things and spaces around him. He ran into a few low hanging doors when they were smuggling him in.

Despite the fact that they‚Äôre technically family, Regulus doesn‚Äôt know the man whose identity he is currently impersonating. Rabastan Lestrange is Rodolphus‚Äôs younger brother, though only by a year and a few months. He‚Äôs muscular, with dark hair and thick dark eyebrows that hang over the rest of his face. He also, apparently, has skills currently required by Lord Voldemort. And while the Dark Lord does control the guards of Azkaban‚Äîas Evan is always so fond of reminding Regulus‚Äîhe does not control Minister Minchum, or Head Judge Crouch, who also happens to be Barty‚Äôs bloody dad. Both of them have taken to visiting the prison sporadically. So the Dark Lord needed a decoy.

Enter Regulus.

He had, of course, not been overly keen on the whole thing, especially when they informed him that he would not be able to keep his wand on him, on the off chance that Minchum or Crouch came into his cell to interrogate him and saw it. He had been reassured, however, that the Dementors would leave him alone. Which they have.

Mostly.

Every once and a while they linger at his door, eyeing him like a freshly cooked steak. It‚Äôs unsettling as all hell, but they never get any closer. You don‚Äôt need to be touching them to feel them of course. The cold sadness that bleeds out of them creeps along the floor and sneaks inside your skin. Sometimes the feeling lingers for hours after they‚Äôve left.

The cell itself isn‚Äôt as scary as it is dull. There are no windows, or even really any furniture to speak of. So Regulus passes the time day dreaming. He tries to remember bits of James‚Äôs letters from memory, he‚Äôs reread them enough after all. He closes his eyes and imagines James sitting beside his bed reciting them.

My mum makes these like crazy good burgers, James says today. It‚Äôs about the only thing she can actually make and doesn‚Äôt need Mimi‚Äôs help with. She does it without magic too. We have this weird Muggle thing‚Äîyou keep it outside and it has a grill and it cooks things? I don‚Äôt know if that makes any sense to you but, anyway, mum says they don‚Äôt taste right if you just magic them. I always help her make the patties. You take ground beef and spices and egg and roll them together into balls and then squish them. I‚Äôll show you one day. I‚Äôll cook you dinner. It‚Äôll be all romantic and shit. I know you‚Äôre rolling your eyes but you‚Äôll love it, I swear.

Regulus tries to imagine what James Potter‚Äôs kitchen looks like. Tries to picture him and his mum standing side by side. Tries to imagine James Potter cooking him dinner. Like they‚Äôre a real couple. They aren‚Äôt of course, but it‚Äôs a nice fantasy.

Sometimes he imagines the two of them in their own kitchen. In their own house‚Äîno, flat, a flat somewhere in London. Somewhere close to the Quidditch stadium. Or at least the Apparition point to the stadium. There‚Äôs one bedroom, it has big windows and a big bed with mountains of pillows. There are posters on the walls of their favourite Quidditch players. Of them. Because of course, they‚Äôre both playing on professional teams. Their brooms are hung up in the front hall. James always leaves his shoes in front of the door but Regulus doesn‚Äôt complain, just rolls his eyes and kicks them out of the way. Regulus always plays his music too loud but James doesn‚Äôt tell him to turn it down, just wanders around the flat afterwards pretending to be deaf and ignoring everything Regulus says until eventually he cracks and starts laughing.

Regulus has too much time here.

In Azkaban.

It‚Äôs dangerous.

Every day he builds more and more of this life he knows he can‚Äôt have.

Everyday he lets the one he does slip a little further away.

¬†

PART II: SIRIUS

JUNE 1972

Kreacher is the one to pick him up from the station. Sirius should have seen that coming since he was also the one who picked him up at Christmas but some part of him still feels‚Ä¶embarrassed. All the other kids have parents waiting for them‚Äîparents who are desperate to see them. James‚Äôs mum practically crushes him she hugs him so hard, covering his face in about a dozen kisses. James thinks that‚Äôs embarrassing but it isn‚Äôt. Not really. Mostly it just makes Sirius‚Äôs chest itch.

‚ÄúMadam is wanting Master Sirius in the dining room please,‚Äù Kreacher says as Sirius starts up the stairs towards his room, mouth already half open, ready to call out Reg‚Äôs name. His brother is the only reason Sirius is excited to be home. He has so much to tell him. Plus, he managed to get some of the older kids to bring him back stuff from Honeydukes and Zonkos that he knows Reg is gonna go absolutely mental for.

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt I just drop my bag off first?‚Äù Sirius whines.

In a crack Kreacher appears on the step above him, sliding the bag off his shoulder without even asking. ‚ÄúMadam said immediately after home getting, now go, go, go.‚Äù

Sirius scowls, huffing dramatically as he walks back down the stairs. Sometimes he really hates that elf.

It‚Äôs been months since he‚Äôs seen his mother. Oddly he wonders if he should thank her. The kids at Hogwarts all think Sirius is fearless‚Äîthe way he talks back to teachers and breaks rules. But the truth is, after Grimmauld Place, it‚Äôs hard to find the teachers at Hogwarts intimidating. What‚Äôre they gonna do? Make him scrub the floors? Write lines? Do homework? None of that seems like punishment compared to what happens to him when he misbehaves at home. So in a way, his mother terrorizing him all of his life has managed to turn him into a bit of a legend. And Sirius likes being a legend. Likes being talked about and gasped at. Notoriety suits him.

He pauses at the doors to the dining room, taking a deep breath before knocking lightly on the glass. You always have to knock in this house, it doesn‚Äôt matter what room it is. If the doors are closed you have to announce your presence.

‚ÄúCome in.‚Äù

Slowly Sirius opens the door. His mother is sitting at the head of the table, glasses on, several pieces of parchment spread out around her. His father isn‚Äôt there which is never a good thing. He, at least, keeps her civil. Most of the time.

‚ÄúMum,‚Äù Sirius says as he approaches her cautiously.

She looks up at him and then back down at her papers. So he waits. Back straight, hands clasped behind him. He doesn‚Äôt even have to think about it, it‚Äôs been beaten into him so many times‚Äîhow to stand and sit and eat. James mocked him endlessly for his table manners for the first few weeks of school. It‚Äôd taken Sirius a while to unlearn what his mother had drilled into him. But back in this familiar space it‚Äôs like his body can‚Äôt help it.

She leaves him waiting for a long time‚Äînot speaking to him or acknowledging his presence. It isn‚Äôt unusual. She does this a lot. Like everything else, it‚Äôs a test. To see if he can stand still and wait. If he can behave.

Eventually she puts down her quill and sits back, eyeing him for a moment, sharp eyes burning holes in his skin. He does his best not to fidget. It will only make whatever is coming worse.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve disappointed me and your father greatly.‚Äù

Of course I have, he doesn‚Äôt say. There was a time when those words would have hurt, but he‚Äôs heard them too often at this point. He‚Äôs numb to it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he says, what else is there?

‚ÄúNot only were you placed in Gryffindor,‚Äù that had been the topic of most of his Christmas holidays. He had received a howler at school as well. Another embarrassment, though not nearly as bad as when Albus freaking Dumbledore pulled him into his office to tell him that his mother had been writing, demanding her son be placed in Slytherin where he belonged.

So Dumbledore had asked him; what do you want?

And, well.

He was still in Gryffindor wasn‚Äôt he?

‚ÄúBut you have continued to disobey our explicit instructions to avoid unseemly associations.‚Äù

‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt lie to me,‚Äù she doesn‚Äôt yell, but her words are sharp and cold. She holds her threats behind her teeth.

Sirius swallows. ‚ÄúJames Potter and Peter Pettigrew are both Purebloods,‚Äù he forces himself to say even though it makes him feel vaguely nauseous to talk about his friends this way.

‚ÄúThe Pettigrews are a family of questionable lineage and the Potters are Blood traitors, neither worthy of the heir of the House of Black. But they are not who I was referring to.‚Äù

Sirius stands still, staring off her right shoulder because looking her straight in the eye is the easiest way to get your mind cracked open and read like a storybook.

‚ÄúRemus Lupin.‚Äù

Sirius isn‚Äôt able to stop his breath from catching, a reaction his mother will no doubt have noticed. He‚Äôd been so careful to keep Remus out of his mouth and out of his head when he‚Äôd been home for Christmas. Keeping him safely locked away inside himself where no one in this house could touch him.

‚ÄúWho?‚Äù he finally asks.

That was stupid.

She hits him across the face. Open palmed. A warning shot.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not interested in playing games,‚Äù her voices is steady, like nothing happened. Sirius still has his hands clasped behind his back. He knows better than to bring them up, then to touch his face.

‚ÄúWho told you about Remus?‚Äù he asks finally. It‚Äôs not the answer she wants. Too much defiance. But he won‚Äôt apologize for Remus. Not even to save himself.

There‚Äôs a momentary pause before she pulls out her wand and Sirius braces himself for whatever punishment is coming next. The slap was child‚Äôs play, Walburga is usually far more creative. But when she waves her wand he feels nothing‚Äîno stinging or burning, no force pushing him back against the wall. After a few seconds there‚Äôs the sound of fluttering. Letters slip under the dining room doors and pile up on the table between them. There must be nearly a hundred.

He looks at them then back at his mother, waiting for an explanation, but she only stares blankly at him.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîwhat are these?‚Äù he asks, after several awkward minutes.

Her face remains expressionless. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you recognize them?‚Äù

He squints at her like maybe that will make her words clearer and then turns the same gaze on the letters. He realizes that they do actually look familiar. Stepping closer he sees that each and every one of them is addressed to Regulus. Addressed by him.

His head snaps towards his mother, his shock and betrayal clearly plain on his face because Walburga looks pleased.

‚ÄúDid he‚Äîdid he give you these?‚Äù He‚Äôd wondered why Regulus never responded, but he‚Äôd assumed it probably had to do with their mother. Never, however, had he considered that Regulus had been selling him out. Handing over his letters, letting her pry into his life. It felt like a violation. Like the worst kind of betrayal.

‚ÄúRegulus is a good boy,‚Äù his mother goes on. ‚ÄúDoes what he‚Äôs told. You on the other hand‚Ä¶‚Äù she gestures to the pile of letters. ‚ÄúRemus Lupin is a half-blood from a family full of half-bloods. And on top of that I am told that he is sickly.‚Äù She says that as though illness is a character flaw. Which, of course, to his mother it is. Strong blood breeds strong wizards, or so she says. Sirius is not sure there is any proof to back that belief up.

‚ÄúYou will cease to associate with him, do you understand?‚Äù his mother continues, oblivious to Sirius‚Äôs mounting rage. He put a lot in those letters. Figures the only thing his mother would care about would be the blood statuses of his best friends.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù she snaps. ‚ÄúDo you understand me?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs my friend,‚Äù he says through clenched teeth.

‚ÄúNot anymore.‚Äù

It‚Äôs hard to describe all the ways those words tangle him up. The panic they cause to wrap around his chest, squeezing his ribs. A primal fear.

Don‚Äôt take him from me.

Please.

Please.

Sirius can‚Äôt describe what it is about Remus Lupin exactly. He just knows that the fear his mother has planted beneath his skin, that scratches and bites and never sleeps, goes quiet whenever he looks at Remus. Whenever he sits next to him. Or hears him laugh. Remus‚Ä¶ settles Sirius. He doesn‚Äôt know what that means. He doesn‚Äôt really think about it much. But he craves it.

Don‚Äôt take him from me.

Please.

Please.

‚ÄúDo you understand me?‚Äù Walburga starts to tap her wand threateningly on the table and Sirius‚Äôs eyes go right to it.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he finally manages to say.

Because he does understand.

He has no intention of doing as she says.

But he understands.

She nods sharply. ‚ÄúGood. Wash and change before dinner,‚Äù her eyes give him another once over, ‚Äúyou look ragged.‚Äù Which is her way of saying ‚Äúcommon.‚Äù

Sirius only barely refrains from rolling his eyes as he walks out of the dinning room, taking the stairs two at a time in his haste to get to the safety of his bedroom. He‚Äôs not at all sure what to do with the emotions swirling around inside him‚Äîfear, relief, betrayal, anger. He doesn‚Äôt have much time to sort it out either, he‚Äôs only just made it to the second floor landing when he runs right into Reg.

‚ÄúSirius!‚Äù his little brother somehow manages to turn their collision into a hug, sending them both careening into the wall. It‚Äôs instinct that has Sirius hugging him back even though he kind of hates him right now.

‚ÄúKreacher told me you were back, I‚Äôve been waiting out here for ages, what did mum want? What was the end of term like? Did Gryffindor win Quidditch? Did you get all the house points? Did you actually throw that cat in the lake like you said you would‚ÄîMrs. Norberry or whatever‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNorris,‚Äù Sirius answers reflexively.

‚ÄúOh yeah, Norris.‚Äù

Reg finally lets go, stepping back and beaming up at Sirius. His curls are all over the place and he‚Äôs missing a tooth. He looks like a little kid, even to Sirius who is, admittedly, also a little kid. And suddenly Sirius feels the anger drain out of him.

Regulus blinks, brow furrowing, seeming to catch onto Sirius‚Äôs mood for the first time. ‚ÄúWhat is it? What‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù

Sirius shakes his head. ‚ÄúNothing. I‚Äôm just tired Reg. I‚Äôll see you at dinner yeah?‚Äù he brushes past him, refusing to feel guilty about the dejected look on the younger boy‚Äôs face. He‚Äôll have to be more careful what he says around him, but maybe that‚Äôll just be for the summer, maybe once Reg is at Hogwarts, away from this house, away from their parents, Sirius will be able to bring him around. Reg‚Äôll be in Ravenclaw, Sirius is almost positive, he‚Äôs never met a bigger nerd. That‚Äôll be good, he decides, even if he does think the Ravenclaws are a bit obnoxious, at least Reg‚Äôll have the chance to meet people he isn‚Äôt bloody related to.

Sirius makes it to his bedroom, closing the door behind him and collapsing down onto his bed. He exhales. He‚Äôll write to James later, that‚Äôll make him feel better. He just needs to survive the summer‚Äîhim and Reg both. Once they get to Hogwarts everything will be okay. He knows it will.

¬†

JANUARY 1977

¬†

He hears whispers. He‚Äôs still too asleep to really take that in. To understand who‚Äôs talking or what they‚Äôre saying. But he hears whispers. And then he hears the door close.

It‚Äôs not until Remus comes back to bed that Sirius realizes he left it in the first place. That the part of his body once covered by Remus is cold. There‚Äôs a short pause before Remus kisses his temple and starts pulling away again.

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôre you going?‚Äù Sirius slurs. He manages to open his eyes but only barely. It‚Äôs dark, but not so dark that Sirius can‚Äôt see that Remus has gotten fully dressed.

‚ÄúJust‚Äîer‚Äîlibrary.‚Äù

Sirius blinks. Everything is swimming around in his head. He still isn‚Äôt awake enough to tell if this conversation is even real or if it‚Äôs a dream.

‚ÄúLibrary?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah‚ÄîJames just needs some help with something.‚Äù

None of this makes any sense. It must be a dream. Which is weird because Sirius‚Äôs dreams are usually much more fun than this. He squints up at Remus again. Usually Remus is more naked in Sirius‚Äôs dreams.

‚ÄúQuidditch?‚Äù is all Sirius is able to get out, reaching blindly for Remus and managing to get his fingers caught in his shirt, tugging him fully onto the bed

‚ÄúUrgh,‚Äù Remus practically falls on top of Sirius but Sirius doesn‚Äôt mind. ‚ÄúHe‚ÄîJesus Padfoot,‚Äù Remus mutters as he tries to unlatch Sirius‚Äôs fingers from his shirt. ‚ÄúHe cancelled practice.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes are suddenly wide open, and he lets go of Remus. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Remus pulls back, straightening out his shirt and looking a little sheepish. ‚ÄúYeah. So. I‚Äôm gonna go help him. You go back to sleep.‚Äù

‚ÄúHelp him what? Is he okay?‚Äù Sirius struggles to get up but Remus stops him, gently, but firmly, pushing him back down onto the mattress.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs fine, it‚Äôs just school stuff, go back to sleep okay? I‚Äôve got this,‚Äù he gives Sirius a small smile, hand slowly making its way up Sirius‚Äôs neck to his head, fingers running slowly through his hair.

‚ÄúCheating,‚Äù Sirius murmurs as his eyes grow heavy again. He loves this feeling‚Äîloves it when Remus plays with his hair‚Äîhe wants to bottle this feeling and drink it like a fine wine.

‚ÄúMhm,‚Äù Remus hums.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll tell me what‚Äôs happening right?‚Äù Sirius mumbles even as his eyes close.

There‚Äôs a pause. A long one.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù and then, ‚ÄúGo to sleep okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúI am asleep,‚Äù Sirius says nonsensically, earning him a soft laugh that makes his belly warm.

Remus leans down and kisses him again. ‚ÄúOf course you are.‚Äù

¬†


By the time Sirius is properly awake Remus is gone and so is James. For a second Sirius just sits and stares at their beds and tries to figure out the feeling in his chest. Somehow heavy and empty all at the same time.

When did this happen?

he can‚Äôt help but think.

When did I start getting left behind?

It‚Äôs a stupid question, because, of course, he knows the answer. Sighing he picks up his pillow and launches it at Peter‚Äôs still sleeping form.

‚ÄúTime to get up Wormtail,‚Äù he says, sliding out of bed and heading for the bathroom.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre worse than my mum,‚Äù Peter mutters into his pillow as Sirius closes the door.

Despite his winging, Peter does get out of bed, taking the shower after Sirius with nothing but a grunt of acknowledgement. Of the four of them, Peter and Sirius are the least pleasant in the mornings. Both of them more or less zombies before they get some food. Which is probably why it‚Äôs not until they‚Äôre dressed and ready to leave that Peter finally realizes James and Remus aren‚Äôt there.

He looks around, bewildered for a moment before turning to Sirius. ‚ÄúWhat the hell?‚Äù

Sirius shrugs. ‚ÄúI have no fucking clue. Something about the library?‚Äù he pauses, trying to drag up his vague memories of Remus‚Äôs departure. ‚ÄúJames cancelled practice.‚Äù

Peter‚Äôs mouth actually falls open. ‚ÄúIs he dying?‚Äù

‚ÄúDunno,‚Äù Sirius says around the lump in his throat. There‚Äôs so much he doesn‚Äôt know about James at the moment. It‚Äôs a bit crushing if he‚Äôs being honest. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù he says, walking towards the door. ‚ÄúLets get some food yeah?‚Äù

Peters nods, following him down the stairs. ‚ÄúCancelled bloody Quidditch,‚Äù he mutters under his breath. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs gotta be one of the signs of the apocalypse doesn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúSure seems like it.‚Äù

¬†

It‚Äôs weird, sitting down to breakfast just the two of them. I mean, yes, of course, the four of them don‚Äôt always eat together. But usually that‚Äôs because something is wrong. Someone‚Äôs sick or in trouble.

Something is wrong,

he can‚Äôt help but think.

James just doesn‚Äôt want to tell you what it is. James or Remus.

Sirius grimaces down at his eggs, suddenly feeling his hunger disappear. He pushes his plate aside, thankfully Peter is too engrossed in his own to notice. Almost out of habit Sirius‚Äôs eyes end up trailing over the Slytherin table. He looks for the familiar head of black curls but doesn‚Äôt find any. It‚Äôs a bit odd, Reg is such a dweeb that he‚Äôs almost never late for meals, but then, Rosier and Crouch aren‚Äôt there either so it‚Äôs possible his idiot friends are holding him up.

‚ÄúHey, sorry,‚Äù Remus huffs as he drops into the seat next to Sirius, startling him out of his thoughts. ‚ÄúThat took longer than I thought,‚Äù he shoots Sirius a quick smile before reaching for the food in the middle of the table and piling it on his plate.

Sirius blinks, looking around. ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs James?‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs mouth pulls a little tight. ‚ÄúUh‚Äîhe‚Äîuh‚Äîstayed behind.‚Äù

Sirius stares at him. ‚ÄúStayed behind? In the library?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, I think,‚Äù Remus doesn‚Äôt look up from his breakfast.

Sirius keeps staring at him. If Remus had looked up maybe he would have noticed the pleading in Sirius‚Äôs eyes. The ‚Äúno‚Äù and the ‚Äúplease‚Äù and the ‚Äúnot you too.‚Äù He‚Äôs already been doing this with James for the past year. Vague answers, obvious lies, unexplained disappearances. Now he‚Äôs getting it from Remus too. When did everyone in his life stop trusting him?

Can you blame them?

hisses the voice inside his head.

After what you did.

After Snape.

‚ÄúWhat is he doing in the library?‚Äù Peter demands through a mouth full of food, interrupting Sirius‚Äôs spiral.

‚ÄúCourse work,‚Äù Remus says, still giving all his attention to cutting up his pancakes.

Peter raises his brow and looks to Sirius in a very ‚Äúdoes that sound as ridiculous to you as it does to me?‚Äù kind of way, which, yes, it does. ‚ÄúCourse work? Term only just bloody started.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs stuff from last term,‚Äù Remus looks up briefly and then away again. ‚ÄúHe got an extension on it, wants to have it done before this term starts.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames needed an extension on work? Since when!‚Äù

Sirius appreciates Peter‚Äôs indignation.

Remus sighs. ‚ÄúSince now I guess. Can we talk about something else?‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess,‚Äù Peter sends Sirius another look before turning back to his own breakfast.

But they don‚Äôt talk about anything else. Instead they just sit there in silence. At one point Sirius notices Lily walking out of the hall and has half a mind to follow her. Just to have some excuse to get away from this table. He hasn‚Äôt spoken to her since New Years Eve but he knows something happened between her and James. Another thing he‚Äôs not talking to Sirius about. Plus there‚Äôs still whatever‚Äôs going on with Mary and Reg. Automatically his eyes go back to the Slytherin table. Rosier and Crouch are there now but no matter how many times he scans the rows of green and sliver Sirius can‚Äôt find Regulus.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Remus gently nudges him with his elbow, bringing his attention back to him. He‚Äôs finally looking at Sirius, eyes soft.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù Sirius says stupidly, because Remus‚Äôs eyes always make him stupid.

Remus‚Äôs lips quirk up just a little, before he nods at Sirius‚Äôs still full plate. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you gonna eat something?‚Äù

They‚Äôre holding eye contact longer than they probably should but Sirius can‚Äôt muster any desire to look away.

I‚Äôm sorry, he almost says.

Sorry I‚Äôm such a disappointment.

Eventually he shrugs, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not hungry.‚Äù

¬†

It‚Äôs been almost a week.

After that breakfast Sirius makes a conscious effort to look for Regulus in the Great Hall. But Regulus never shows. Not that day or the next day or any day after that. So Sirius decides to check the map, and according to the map, Regulus Black is not currently at Hogwarts. That fact makes something curdle in Sirius‚Äôs stomach.

He thinks about telling Remus. About telling James. But James is out of it these days‚Äîpale and distant and barely listening to anything Sirius says. And Remus‚Ä¶well, it‚Äôs not like Remus isn‚Äôt keeping his own secrets.

Something else the map has told Sirius is that James and Remus really are going to the library. Which he supposes is some sort of relief. At least everything they‚Äôre telling him isn‚Äôt a lie. Though they‚Äôre going there to meet up with Lily Evans and Sirius honestly has no clue what to do with that information. He thinks about asking but decides against it. If they don‚Äôt want to tell him that‚Äôs fine. He isn‚Äôt going to beg. At least not yet.

Today, however, he isn‚Äôt using the map to spy on his best friend and his‚Ä¶Remus. Today he‚Äôs using it to track down his brother‚Äôs asshole friends. Evan Rosier walks by just as Sirius is tucking the map away in his waistband, pulling his jumper over top and jogging to catch up to him.

‚ÄúRosier,‚Äù Sirius says as he falls into step with him.

If Evan is startled he doesn‚Äôt show it, just looks over at Sirius and grins. ‚ÄúWell look at that, if it isn‚Äôt Sirius Black talking to little old me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThought I‚Äôd slum it today.‚Äù

Rosier throws his head back and laughs. ‚ÄúI bet you did.‚Äù

Sirius stares back at him, brow arched.

‚ÄúBlimey, you know, I never saw it before, when people said you two looked alike but that expression?‚Äù another grin. ‚ÄúThat expression I know well.‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúWhere is he.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, there it is.‚Äù

Sirius waits for more, but, of course, there is none. They squeeze by a pack of Hufflepuffs before starting up the stairs.

‚ÄúRosier‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOoh, Reg does that too, gets all growly and shit. Honestly, the pair of you, leave some angst for the rest of us yeah?‚Äù

Sirius works to unclench his jaw. He knows that Rosier is trying to wind him up. Hell, he‚Äôd probably be acting the exact same way if their positions were reversed.

‚ÄúIs he not coming back?‚Äù the question is harder for Sirius to ask than he would have thought. Some part of him has always secretly felt that as long as Regulus was at Hogwarts there was hope. That eventually he would realize that the world was so much bigger than Grimmauld Place, than Walburga. That he didn‚Äôt have to be afraid of her. After all, that‚Äôs what it did for Sirius.

That hope had dwindled, of course, over the years. But still, some part of him felt comforted that his little brother was here. Away from their mother. Away from whatever was happening in that house.

‚ÄúFunny, you‚Äôve never seemed all that concerned with where he was before?‚Äù Rosier says as they continue the winding climb to the astronomy classroom.

‚ÄúYeah well, new year new me,‚Äù Sirius says flatly, earning him another laugh from Rosier. Rosier somehow manages to fall between genuinely gleeful and malicious. It makes it hard for Sirius to get his bearing. He likes it better when they‚Äôre just cursing one another.

‚ÄúYou sniffing around for old Dumbly huh? He send you to spy on us?‚Äù there‚Äôs an edge of sincerity in Rosier‚Äôs mocking tone. ‚ÄúIf he did you‚Äôre not doing a very good job. Not very sneaky.‚Äù

Something about the suspicion sticks with Sirius. ‚ÄúYou think Dumbledore cares about Regulus?‚Äù

Rosier doesn‚Äôt react, doesn‚Äôt even look over at him, which is its own tell, in a way. Sirius‚Äôs stomach clenches.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs off doing something for them isn‚Äôt he?‚Äù Sirius asks, voice low. Again, no reaction. ‚ÄúWhere?‚Äù

Rosier stops by the ladder up to the astronomy room, looking at Sirius for the first time. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know,‚Äù he says casually, like they‚Äôre discussing vacation plans. ‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt tell you if I did, but I don‚Äôt. I know he‚Äôs not here. I know he‚Äôs not at home. You do with that what you will,‚Äù he pauses, eyes running Sirius over, looking for something, though Sirius has no idea what.

‚ÄúBut if you wanna know if he‚Äôll be back‚Ä¶‚Äù Rosier shrugs. ‚ÄúIf it were me? No way. But then, Reg has always loved this place more than he should.‚Äù

It‚Äôs work for Sirius not to let his reaction to those words show on his face. He didn‚Äôt know that, about Regulus.

‚ÄúAlright well, fuck off would you? If you keep walking me to my classes the girls are gonna start getting jealous.‚Äù

Sirius isn‚Äôt sure who he‚Äôs inferring the girls will be jealous of but before he can ask Rosier is already scrambling up the ladder, letting the trapdoor slam shut behind him.

¬†

‚ÄúProngs and Moony MIA again?‚Äù Peter asks as he gets out of the shower.

Sirius is standing at the window practically vibrating with tension. With anger and frustration and fear. With all the things he can‚Äôt do and all the things no one is saying. This is the third day in a row he‚Äôs woken up alone in bed.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù Peter asks tentatively, standing beside him as he slides his book bag over his shoulder. ‚ÄúYou alright?‚Äù

Sirius almost laughs.

Almost.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm tired of this bullshit,‚Äù he says, hands clenched in his pockets.

Peter grimaces. ‚ÄúYou talk to Moony about it? What they‚Äôre doing?‚Äù

No. Not really. He‚Äôs tried. He always gets stonewalled. Homework. Special projects. Trying to get ready for NEWTS. Sirius has stopped asking because he hates the way Remus‚Äôs lies crawl under his skin.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù he says sharply, heading for the door.

‚ÄúBreakfast?‚Äù Peter asks.

‚ÄúNo, not today,‚Äù he practically shoves a group of first years out of his way as he cuts across the common room. ‚ÄúToday we‚Äôre going to the fucking library.‚Äù

¬†

It hurts to see them there. Heads bowed together. Like Sirius is suddenly on the outside looking in. How many times have the four of them been in that exact same position? Hunched over a table, trying to get the details of a prank ironed out or the charms for some big project. He aches for those days, those long nights. Wants desperately to be standing next to them. What he can‚Äôt figure out, is why they don‚Äôt seem to want him there too.

‚ÄúWhat the hell?‚Äù he hears himself shouting across the library before he can stop himself.

It‚Äôs all a bit of a blur after that.

¬†

‚ÄúSirius! Oh come on, Sirius would you just‚Äîcan you just slow down for like a second? Jesus.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Sirius says petulantly, storming through the castle with exactly zero idea where he‚Äôs going.

‚ÄúPlease, can‚Äôt we just talk?‚Äù

And that gets Sirius to stop. Swinging around and nearly knocking right into Remus who‚Äôd been jogging to catch up to him.

‚ÄúOh now you want to talk?‚Äù Sirius snaps.

Several emotions flicker across Remus‚Äôs face as he trips over his feet trying to stop. He‚Äôs all flustered, sandy hair sticking up in every direction, bag slipping off his shoulder, shirt untucked. Sirius loves this Remus. Loves all Remus‚Äôs.

Tell him, says the voice in his head. But he quickly dismisses the thought.

He doubts that Remus would believe him.

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt lie to me again because I swear I‚Äôll lose it Moons. I‚Äôm not a fucking idiot.‚Äù

Remus huffs. ‚ÄúI know that.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen why do you keep treating me like one?‚Äù it‚Äôs work for him to keep his voice down. They‚Äôre standing in the middle of the corridor, out in public, anyone could come by. Everything about this is reckless.

Remus makes a frustrated noise. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúBrilliant.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? Sirius what?‚Äù he demands. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre real good at saying my name Remus, but what the fuck comes after it? What am I supposed to do here? I mean, how exactly would you like me to handle this? You‚Äôre lying to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Remus says quietly.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been lying for a while now I reckon, since before Christmas, since last year.‚Äù

Remus looks like he‚Äôs going to argue but Sirius doesn‚Äôt give him the chance.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not an idiot,‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúYou think I don‚Äôt know something else is going on here? You really expect me to believe that you won‚Äôt tell me about the boy he‚Äôs seeing‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúKeep your voice down, Jesus.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Äîjust because he asked you to?‚Äù Sirius goes on, ignoring Remus‚Äôs warning. ‚ÄúBecause I don‚Äôt fucking buy it, Remus.‚Äù

Remus is shaking his head, hands running through his hair, making it even more of a mess. Sirius has to fight the urge to reach out and smooth it back down. Remus opens his mouth several times but nothing ever makes it out. Leaving them in silence.

Sirius sighs. ‚ÄúIs it‚Äîis it because of last year?‚Äù he asks finally, voice cracking somewhere in the middle.

Remus instantly looks up, eyes wide. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that why‚Ä¶‚Äù he waves at the library. ‚ÄúIs that why Evans is there and not me?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Remus repeats.

Sirius fights against the tightness in his throat. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre never gonna get past that are we? Not really. You and James, you‚Äôll never‚Ä¶‚Äù he shakes his head looking away, not able to finish that thought. ‚ÄúI fucked us all up didn‚Äôt I?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, Sirius,‚Äù before he knows what‚Äôs happening Remus is stepping forward, wrapping his arms around him and pulling him in for a hug. Sirius doesn‚Äôt fight it, head dropping into the crook of Remus‚Äôs neck.

‚ÄúI trust you,‚Äù he whispers into Sirius hair, the gentle words sending a shiver down Sirius‚Äôs spine.

‚ÄúYou promise?‚Äù

‚ÄúI promise.‚Äù

Sirius lets himself relax a little further into Remus, his arms squeezing tight. ‚ÄúI miss you,‚Äù he confesses weakly.

Remus makes a wounded noise at the back of his throat. ‚ÄúGod Sirius. I really want to kiss you right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in the middle of the corridor.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Remus says, hand making slow circles against Sirius‚Äôs back. There‚Äôs a pause and then: ‚ÄúI understand why James is keeping secrets but I don‚Äôt think he should. Not anymore. I don‚Äôt want to lie to you. I need you to know that, okay? It just‚Ä¶it can‚Äôt be me. Who tells you. It can‚Äôt be me.‚Äù

Sirius sighs, pulling back out of Remus‚Äôs embrace, scrubbing at his face. ‚ÄúThat sucks Remus.‚Äù Which doesn't even begin to cover it but it's the only word he can think of right now.

Remus gives him a weak smile. ‚ÄúI know. I‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

It isn‚Äôt really good enough. Nothing is solved. But then, as the king of shitty, useless apologies, Sirius isn‚Äôt sure he‚Äôs in any position to judge.

‚ÄúCan we go get breakfast now?‚Äù he finds himself asking, too tired and underfed for all of this.

Remus‚Äôs smile grows. ‚ÄúYou betcha babe.‚Äù

That manages to startle a laugh out of Sirius.

¬†

Nothing changes really.

Remus and James still disappear. Still stop talking when Sirius comes into the room. Regulus is still missing. Sirius isn‚Äôt eating much.

¬†

‚ÄúYou wanna go watch the Quidditch match?‚Äù

Sirius looks up from the Transfiguration coursework he‚Äôd only half-heartedly been attempting on his bed. Remus stands in the doorway, looking a little bit shy. Sirius blinks.

‚ÄúYou wanna go watch Quidditch?‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúOh don‚Äôt act like I don‚Äôt watch every Gryffindor game.‚Äù

‚ÄúDepends on how loosely we‚Äôre using the word watch.‚Äù Now Remus is openly glaring at him and Sirius has to bit back a smirk. ‚ÄúYou certainly attend every game.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou get points for proximity, definitely.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you done yet?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to know that you‚Äôre aware Quidditch is a visual event. Up until this point I was worried you thought it was auditory only, the way you‚Äôre always looking literally anywhere but at the pitch.‚Äù

Remus has his hands on his hips and Sirius is openly grinning now.

‚ÄúDo you want to go or not?‚Äù he asks flatly.

Sirius slams his textbook shut, bouncing off his bed and towards a Remus who is clearly struggling to maintain his unimpressed demeanour. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd go anywhere with you darling,‚Äù Sirius says smoothly, kissing Remus‚Äôs cheek and enjoying the blush that instantly blooms there.

They walk out of the dorm room with Sirius‚Äôs arm slung around Remus‚Äôs shoulders.

¬†

The game is, Sirius doesn‚Äôt think it‚Äôs dramatic to say, a train wreck. Passes are missed. Bludgers are sent in the wrong direction. Players are unclear about their plays. James still puts on a good show, still scores, still flies better than anyone else out there, Mary not far behind him. But two people can‚Äôt win a Quidditch match. You need a team. And the Gryffindor team is a mess.

‚ÄúThat was bad wasn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Remus murmurs to him as the players file off the pitch, Ravenclaw celebrating a massive win as the dejected Gryffindors seem to be caught somewhere between complete astonishment and anger. Sirius can‚Äôt blame them, he‚Äôs never seen their team play that badly before.

‚ÄúIt was bad,‚Äù Sirius confirms. And then, because maybe he‚Äôs feeling a little petty: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what happens when you cancel practice.‚Äù

Remus shoots him a look. ‚ÄúYeah, maybe don‚Äôt mention that to him.‚Äù

Sirius only shrugs. He won‚Äôt need to. James will know.

‚ÄúShould we‚Ä¶?‚Äù Remus pauses near the tunnel to the locker rooms, nodding towards them. ‚ÄúWait for him?‚Äù

Sirius takes one look down the tunnel before shaking his head. ‚ÄúNah, he‚Äôll want to be alone. Time to cool down. I bet he‚Äôs currently taking a very long shower.‚Äù

Remus arches his brow but doesn‚Äôt say anything, following Sirius out of the arena.

‚ÄúLets take the long way back yeah?‚Äù Sirius says, even though it‚Äôs fucking cold out.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Remus puts his hands in his pockets as the pair of them pull away from the parade of students walking towards the school. The sky is navy blue, stars just starting to blink into existence.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve never left him alone before,‚Äù Remus says after a long period of silence, his breath freezing in front of his lips.

Sirius looks over. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Remus clarifies. ‚ÄúWhen the team‚Äôs lost before, you‚Äôve always come back together. Sometimes‚Ä¶you know, slower than everyone else, but always together.‚Äù

Sirius nods, trying to ignore the knot in his stomach. ‚ÄúYeah, well, that was when I was on the team. It‚Äôs different.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow?‚Äù Remus asks.

‚ÄúWe were in it together I suppose.‚Äù That's been them in most situations. At each other‚Äôs backs. On the same side. Sirius has always thought he could take on just about anything as long as he knew James was with him.

‚ÄúHe still loves you, you know,‚Äù Remus says, correctly interpreting Sirius‚Äôs silence.

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúCan we not? I‚Äôm so tired of having conversations where no one says anything.‚Äù

Remus sighs, the pair walking a little further in silence before Sirius feels Remus lean against him. Just the slight press of their shoulders together. Letting his warmth bleed through Sirius‚Äôs too-thin leather jacket.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been tough, recently,‚Äù Remus says softly, ‚Äúbut it‚Äôll get better. Once he finds him it‚Äôll get better.‚Äù

Sirius feels his feet stutter to a stop. ‚ÄúWhat did you just say?‚Äù

Remus turns to him, brows drawn together. ‚ÄúI‚Äîthat things will get better?‚Äù

Sirius feels nauseous, standing there in the cold, staring at Remus. ‚ÄúOnce he finds him,‚Äù he repeats, lips numb. ‚ÄúYou said once he finds him. James‚Äôs‚Äîthe boy he‚Äôs been seeing, he‚Äôs missing?‚Äù

Remus blinks back at him, looking lost. ‚ÄúI‚Äîhe‚ÄîI shouldn‚Äôt have said that. Can we‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAnswer. The. Question.‚Äù Sirius isn‚Äôt sure what it is in his voice that makes Remus go pale but he doesn‚Äôt take it back.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus finally says. ‚ÄúYeah, he never turned up after Christmas.‚Äù

Something is breaking inside of Sirius. He isn‚Äôt sure what it is exactly. Only that it makes him want to crawl into himself and never come out again.

‚ÄúThe Slytherin James is seeing,‚Äù his voice shakes, he doesn‚Äôt bother trying to control it. ‚ÄúThe Slytherin boy James is seeing didn‚Äôt come back after Christmas.‚Äù

Sirius isn‚Äôt sure he‚Äôs ever seen Remus look so scared. ‚ÄúSirius what‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù the name chokes him. ‚ÄúRegulus. He‚Äôs seeing Regulus?‚Äù

He waits for Remus to contradict him. To tell him that he‚Äôs crazy. That James would never. He would never. He would never do that to Sirius. James who was there through all of it, through all the unanswered letters, and lonely summers and betrayals. There for every time Regulus went to Walburga. Sold Sirius out. Stood by and watched her take him apart. He would never.

Sirius reckons this is what it feels like to have your heartbroken.

He turns away from Remus, away from the school, and starts walking. He needs to be alone. He needs to get himself under control. There is too much noise in his head and his chest and he wants to rip the world apart. He wants to set it all on fire. Everything in him is violence and rage and he just needs to go.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù Remus‚Äôs voice sounds wrecked. ‚ÄúSirius‚Äîfuck‚Äîplease, please let me explain, let me‚Äî‚Äú Remus grabs hold of his arm and Sirius instantly whips around and shoves him back, sending Remus stumbling to the ground.

‚ÄúYou knew!‚Äù his voice is jagged edges. His voice is empty stomachs, and locked doors, and his mother‚Äôs handprint on his cheek. His voice is Regulus being such a good boy. ‚ÄúYou knew for a year and you didn‚Äôt tell me, I can‚Äôt‚Äîyou‚Äî‚Äú Sirius takes a step back hands shaking, so desperate to punch and scratch and tear apart. Remus is still on the ground, looking up at him with pleading eyes.

‚ÄúI know, I know, I‚Äôm sorry. Sirius I‚Äôm so sorry. I didn‚Äôt know what to do! I didn‚Äôt know‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúStop. Talking,‚Äù Sirius grounds out. ‚ÄúJust‚Äîjust leave me the fuck alone Remus because I‚ÄîI‚Äôm going to do something I‚Äôll regret if you don‚Äôt, so just‚Äî‚Äù he‚Äôs barely able to get the words out, barely able to take another step back and then another and another until he‚Äôs practically running in the other direction.

It‚Äôs funny maybe, seeing as that‚Äôs what Reg is always accusing him of. Running away. This time is different though. This time he has no one to run to.

¬†

PART III REGULUS

¬†

Polyjuice is how they‚Äôve been able to keep up the facade. Flasks are smuggled in and out by the cleaning lady who comes once a day to empty the chamber pot in the corner of the room. Well, chamber pot is generous. It‚Äôs really a bucket.

Except today she‚Äôs empty handed.

‚ÄúNothing?‚Äù Regulus asks, voice rough from lack of use.

She only shrugs. ‚ÄúThey did not give me anything, I cannot bring anything.‚Äù

So now Regulus is pacing his tiny cell, heart beating about a mile a minute as he feels the potion wearing off. Wondering if he‚Äôs just been sold out. If he‚Äôll be stuck in here forever. If the Dementors will still keep away once he has a different face. Not that they use their eyes really. They seem to just‚Ä¶feel you. Regulus shivers.

He wishes he‚Äôd asked more questions. Not that you can really ask the Dark Lord questions. Or Walburga for that matter. Seeing the two of them together, side by side at the end of the long dining table, had really been something else. Like walking into a nightmare.

Distantly he hears someone scream. That happens from time to time. From what he can tell prisoners here are kept fairly far apart, or at least he can‚Äôt hear anyone directly next to him. But the screams still find you, undaunted by distance or walls. Regulus doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôll ever forget them.

He takes in a deep breath, having a panic attack is going to solve exactly nothing. He closes his eyes, standing in the middle of his cell and breathes. Just like he does back at Grimmauld Place, when it gets to be too much.

Inhale.

Exhale.

Inhale.

Exhale.

He pictures his flat with James. Pictures them curled up on the couch, covered in blankets, Regulus reading while James tosses his Quaffle up and down. He thinks about the dirty dishes in the sink they‚Äôll fight over later. Thinks about the record player that will make James pull Regulus dramatically to his feet, twirling him around their tiny living room. Regulus will pretend to hate it, he‚Äôll roll his eyes and huff, but eventually he‚Äôll hook his chin over James‚Äôs shoulder and give in. Let James pull him close.

I am an excellent dancer, the James in his head says.

‚ÄúI had to take ballroom classes for most of my childhood so I wouldn‚Äôt get too cocky.‚Äù

James laughs. Oh my God! Did you really? I can‚Äôt believe I didn‚Äôt know this. Why haven‚Äôt you been trying to woo me with your dance moves?

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize ballroom dancing was such a turn on for you.‚Äù

Everything you do is a turn on for me.

Regulus lets out a laugh that somehow turns into a sob. Caught in his throat. It‚Äôs hard but he swallows it down. Keeps his eyes closed and his cheeks dry. He can feel himself shrinking, feel his hair brush his ears and the back of his neck, feel his mouth and teeth become his own again.

Reg?

‚ÄúI wish you were real,‚Äù he whispers into the dark. Now that he‚Äôs back in his own body he suddenly feels painfully vulnerable.

But I am real.

Regulus goes to speak when the sound of screeching hinges causes his eyes to fly open, his feet stumbling backwards at the sight of three hooded figures standing at the open door of his cell. At first he thinks the Dementors have finally come for him but it only takes a second for him to realize that that‚Äôs not right.

One of the figures steps forward pulling back his hood and revealing a shock of ash blond hair. Lucius Malfoy gives Regulus a wolfish grin as the younger boy collapses against the back wall, sucking in the breath he‚Äôd been holding.

‚ÄúMiss me?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt dignify that with an answer. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you doing?‚Äù

The two people behind him step forward as well, pulling back their own hoods, but Regulus doesn‚Äôt recognize them. Two men, they‚Äôre big, muscular, remind Regulus of bulldogs. He turns his attention back to Lucius.

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it obvious?‚Äù Lucius says with an infuriating amount of amusement. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to rescue you.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, his too big clothes slipping off his shoulder as he tries to get his bearings. ‚ÄúThe job is done?‚Äù

Lucius nods. ‚ÄúThe job is done. You bought the Dark Lord the time he needed, he is very grateful, now, hop to.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy wand,‚Äù Regulus says as the three men turn towards the door.

Lucius looks back over his shoulder, giving Regulus another grin. ‚ÄúAh, yes, of course.‚Äù He tosses him his wand and Regulus fumbles before dropping it. Still awkward back in his own body, his depth perception off.

‚ÄúCome along little prince, we mustn‚Äôt dally,‚Äù Lucius‚Äôs posh accent feels absurd in this place.

Regulus tries not to trip on his trailing pant legs as he half-jogs after the others. Last time they were able to Apparate outside the prison so Regulus assumes that‚Äôs where their headed until Lucius makes a sharp turn before the front doors.

Regulus‚Äôs stomach lurches.

‚ÄúLucius?‚Äù

‚ÄúCome along Regulus.‚Äù

He pauses, eyeing the doors, desperate to walk towards them. Not that he could Apparate himself, but it would be a relief just to see the sky again. He doesn‚Äôt even know what time of day it is.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù Lucius calls warningly from up ahead and one of the bulldogs gives him a hard shove in the back.

Gripping his wand tightly Regulus tears his eyes away from the doors and starts walking again.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre we doing?‚Äù he hisses once he catches up to Lucius.

‚ÄúTsk, tsk, so demanding,‚Äù Lucius says flippantly, though his eyes aren‚Äôt on Regulus but on the cells to the right of them.

Most of the cells they pass are empty but some aren‚Äôt. Some have prisoners who look up at them with wide, terrified eyes. Which is not nearly as bad as the ones who look up without any light in their eyes at all. Eventually Regulus just looks at his feet, praying that whatever Lucius is up to it‚Äôs over quickly.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Lucius says happily as they come to stop in front of one cell in particular. ‚ÄúHere we are.‚Äù

The man inside looks around Lucius‚Äôs age, maybe a little younger, barely out of Hogwarts. He has floppy brown hair and big blue eyes. He quickly scrambles to his feet when he sees them, more alert than many of the other prisoners.

‚ÄúHave you come to let me out? Did my parents finally get through to you? I didn‚Äôt do it, I promise I didn‚Äôt. I would never,‚Äù he steps towards the bars, babbling, clearly nervous. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a herbologist, that‚Äôs all, I tend to plants for my father‚Äôs potions business. I‚Äôm not involved in any of this I swear.‚Äù He‚Äôs gripping the bars of his cell, practically trying to pull himself through.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù he goes on desperately. ‚ÄúPlease, you have to believe me.‚Äù

Lucius smiles. It‚Äôs an expression Regulus has seen many times before. It isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶necessarily‚Ä¶pleasant. ‚ÄúOh I do.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou do?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Lucius says calmly.
