‚ÄúFair,‚Äù Dorcas concedes. ‚ÄúHard to tell where the line is, between hook-up and relationship,‚Äù she sends Marlene a significant look that the Gryffindor either doesn‚Äôt see or willfully ignores.

‚ÄúApparently they basically put on a porno in the middle of the Slytherin common room.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Peter,‚Äù Remus says, exasperated.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Peter demands. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying what I heard.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo be fair,‚Äù Dorcas interjects. ‚ÄúI also heard that.‚Äù

‚ÄúMe too!‚Äù Marlene agrees.

‚ÄúWait, what?‚Äù James has finally managed to regain control of his thoughts. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt hear any of this, what the hell are you guys talking about?‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin James, it‚Äôs been all anyone has been able to talk about all day. Where have you been?‚Äù Marlene demands.

James opens his mouth but finds he doesn‚Äôt actually know what to say. He‚Äôs been here, technically, he just hasn‚Äôt‚Ä¶his eyes go to the Slytherin table.

‚ÄúMaybe he‚Äôs just not interested in salacious gossip about his peers?‚Äù Remus intercepts, saving him. James sends Remus a quick look of thanks.

Marlene rolls her eyes at the same time that Peter says; ‚ÄúSince when?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been a bit out of it today,‚Äù James finally manages. ‚ÄúGo on, tell me the gossip.‚Äù

Marlene immediately launches into the story, complete with over the top hand gestures and a very bad impression of Richardson‚Äôs Irish accent that has Dorcas barely keeping it together. James listens and laughs in the right places, but he finds it difficult to be present. To care.

‚ÄúYou saving those for later?‚Äù

James blinks. Peter and Marlene are arguing over the details of the story‚ÄîPeter adamant that Richardson got fully naked in the common room and Marlene insisting that she heard he only got down to his pants. But Dorcas, James realizes, is looking at the small pile of food on Remus‚Äôs napkin. Remus blushes but his expression remains neutral.

‚ÄúI get a little peckish after dinner sometimes,‚Äù he says.

‚ÄúA little peckish?‚Äù which is fair considering the size of the pile.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you guys have like, secret access to the kitchens?‚Äù Marlene pulls herself away from her argument with Peter who is looking thoroughly dejected at this point. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt the House Elves completely in love with you?‚Äù

‚ÄúCan you blame them?‚Äù James shoots her a grin, feeling a bit like he‚Äôs on autopilot. Marlene sticks out her tongue at him.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like to make them do extra work,‚Äù Remus mumbles, looking down at his plate.

Marlene‚Äôs face softens an almost comical amount. ‚ÄúOh wow, that‚Äôs adorable.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs ears turn bright red.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs our Moony,‚Äù James reaches forward and pinches Remus‚Äôs cheek. ‚ÄúAdorable.‚Äù He gets a sharp jab in the side from Remus‚Äôs elbow, forcing the air out of him like he‚Äôd just been punctured. ‚ÄúAdorable and sharp,‚Äù James corrects, causing the others to laugh, even Remus, a little.

It‚Äôs at that moment that James sees Mary walking towards them and his stomach drops. He needs to talk to her, he knows he does, needs to ask her to explain everything she said on New Years. Needs to be sober when she does it. But watching her approach he realizes that he vehemently doesn‚Äôt want to. That he‚Äôs actually afraid of what she might say. Of what he might hear if he lets himself listen.

‚ÄúSorry, just remembered I forgot something in class,‚Äù James stands abruptly, not really looking at anyone, though he can feel Remus‚Äôs concerned gaze on him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll catch you guys back in the common room yeah?‚Äù

Dorcas and Marlene both wave goodbye, Marlene already distracted by Mary‚Äôs approach.

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú Remus tries as James starts making his way between tables.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine Moons,‚Äù he says, feeling itchy and nervous and suddenly claustrophobic. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you‚Ä¶‚Äù his eyes go to the extra pile of food, ‚Äútomorrow I guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúTomorrow,‚Äù Remus agrees, though it doesn‚Äôt sound like he likes it.

James doesn‚Äôt pause much longer. He needs to get out of there, needs some fresh air. The second before he exits the hall into the corridor his eyes go back to the Slytherin table, but Regulus isn‚Äôt there. James grimaces, pushing through the doors and trying to ignore the way Regulus‚Äôs absence makes his stomach twist.

He doesn‚Äôt want to be the kind of boyfriend that has to know where Regulus is all the time. It feels‚Ä¶controlling. Not something James has ever considered himself to be. But he can‚Äôt help the automatic panic that runs through him when he can‚Äôt check on Reg. Being the newly appointed heir to the House of Black is a precarious position these days, and Regulus doesn‚Äôt care enough to protect himself. Doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs worth the effort. The very thought makes James‚Äôs chest ache.

It takes a few minutes before he‚Äôs able to make it to one of the school‚Äôs courtyards, practically gasping as he steps outside. It‚Äôs cold, but James doesn‚Äôt mind, welcomes it in fact. The biting at his skin helps keep the panic at bay. He needs to get it together, the sight of Mary Macdonald can‚Äôt send him into a fucking anxiety spiral.

You have to talk to her. That‚Äôs how you fix this.

says the annoyingly reasonable voice in his head.

And yes, okay, it‚Äôs right. But he just got Regulus back. Can‚Äôt they have a little more time before he goes prying into things? Looking for answers he doesn‚Äôt want?

But what if‚Äî

the voice demands.

What if he was there? What if he helped them hurt her? What if he hurt her himself?

James shakes his head.

Regulus would never do that.

He just wouldn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúHey?‚Äù

James whips around to find Lily Evans perched in the alcove behind him. She has a book open on her lap but no coat or gloves. Like she‚Äôs impervious to the cold.

‚ÄúHi?‚Äù he says dumbly, standing in the centre of the courtyard staring at her. It‚Äôs magic hour, the sun low, everything glowing gold and pink. It makes Lily look like she could be part of the castle‚Äîpainted or carved‚Äîa work of art.

He shakes his head. ‚ÄúSorry‚Äîer‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt realize anyone was out here.‚Äù

She nods, smiling a bit. ‚ÄúYeah, I got that.‚Äù

James‚Äôs head is still a bit of a mess so it‚Äôs a struggle for him to drag together a thought coherent enough to say out loud. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you doing?‚Äù turns out to be the best he can manage.

Lily‚Äôs smile grows as she gestures to the book in her lap. ‚ÄúHomework. What are you doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúBreathing,‚Äù the answer comes to him so quickly he doesn‚Äôt have a chance to realize how absolutely mad it is until he‚Äôs hearing it out loud. Lily arches her brow but rather than try to explain himself James just pushes forward. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you cold?‚Äù

Lily shakes her head before picking up the wand sitting next to her. ‚ÄúWarming charm.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù James says, ‚Äúwell, in that case,‚Äù he shoves his hands into his pockets before stepping forward. He feels it instantly, the minute he‚Äôs inside her magic, a warm tingling feeling rushing through him and something citrusy in his nose and mouth.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs better,‚Äù he says unprompted.

Lily bites her lower lip. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment of silence during which James feels her watching him but can‚Äôt quite bring himself to meet her gaze, looking instead at the school grounds, watching the sun‚Äôs quick retreat towards the horizon.

‚ÄúYou can sit you know?‚Äù Lily says eventually.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

She nods to the spot across from her. ‚ÄúYou can sit.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúRight, okay, thanks.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a pit of a squeeze, his feet bracketing her‚Äôs as they sit across from one another. James can‚Äôt help but feel that she‚Äôs still watching him. Not just looking‚Äîbut searching. Seeing.

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù she asks eventually.

James lets out a big breath, blowing the hair off his forehead. ‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú but for some reason the rest of the sentence doesn‚Äôt make it out, leaving his mouth hanging open in awkward silence.

A look of concern flickers across Lily‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúJames?‚Äù she asks softly, reaching out to squeeze his knee.

He swallows, trying to start again. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he says, voice a little tight as he passes a hand over his face. ‚ÄúIts been a bit of a day.‚Äù

Lily nods like she understands though James isn‚Äôt sure how she could. Despite that it doesn‚Äôt feel insincere. Nothing Lily Evans does ever feels insincere and maybe that‚Äôs why James finds himself saying more than he means to.

‚ÄúI think someone is lying to me,‚Äù he nearly chokes on the words. ‚ÄúOr‚Äîsomeone tried to tell me that they were lying, but I wasn‚Äôt ready to hear it.‚Äù He‚Äôs floundering, with too many feelings and thoughts and fears. But Lily doesn‚Äôt waver.

‚ÄúAre you ready to hear it now?‚Äù she asks, without judgement.

James lets out an empty laugh. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúBut I think I need to anyway.‚Äù

Lily nods her head. ‚ÄúThen I‚Äôm sure you will.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally? Cause I‚Äôm not. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm here, just the thought of it had me running scared,‚Äù his cheeks heat with embarrassment. He‚Äôs not usually the type of person to run away from things.

‚ÄúSometimes you need to make a few false starts before you can jump into the deep end. But you‚Äôve already made it to the edge, I don‚Äôt doubt you‚Äôll take the last step eventually.‚Äù

James meets her eyes, bright green and shockingly warm. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

Lily shrugs, the smile back in the corner of her mouth. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the bravest person I know, also the stupidest mind you, but, I imagine there‚Äôs a lot of cross over between those traits.‚Äù

James cant help it, he laughs, the sound a little overloud in the empty courtyard, but it feels good, loosens some of the tension in his chest. It's then, just as he‚Äôs beginning to feel better, that he notices the tightness in Lily‚Äôs face. Subtle, but there.

‚ÄúHey, why are you really here?‚Äù he asks, tapping her heel with the toe of his foot.

‚ÄúTold you, homework.‚Äù

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúStudying outside, in the middle of January, during supper?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah well‚Ä¶‚Äù she trails off, clearly not able to come up with an excuse.

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù James says dryly. ‚ÄúVery convincing that.‚Äù

She scowls at him, though he doesn‚Äôt think it‚Äôs quite genuine. ‚ÄúI just‚ÄîI just needed to be by myself.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù James knows he‚Äôs prying but he can‚Äôt help it.

Lily lets out a heavy sigh, pinching the bridge of her nose. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs stupid.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcellent,‚Äù James rubs his hands together. ‚ÄúAs you just pointed out I‚Äôm an expert in stupid. Lets hear it.‚Äù

That manages to eek a smile out of her, though only until she starts talking again. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my mum‚Ä¶I‚Äôm‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶I‚Äôm worried something‚Äôs wrong.‚Äù

‚ÄúWrong?‚Äù James asks. ‚ÄúLike what kind of wrong?‚Äù

Lily shakes her head. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, it‚Äôs just‚Äîsomething about her letters. They feel the way they did right before my dad died. Like she‚Äôs hiding something from me.‚Äù She shakes her head. ‚ÄúSorry, I realize that sounds mad.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey, no, it doesn‚Äôt,‚Äù James says quickly. ‚ÄúConsidering what happened with your dad I think it‚Äôs reasonable that you would be extra sensitive to this sort of stuff,‚Äù he pauses, chewing thoughtfully on his lower lip. ‚ÄúWould it help to see her? To talk face to face? I‚Äôm sure if you told McGonagall she‚Äôd let you use her fireplace.‚Äù

She smiles sadly at him. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a bit more complicated than that.‚Äù

James scrunches his nose. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she sighs, ‚Äúmy mum isn‚Äôt a witch so she doesn‚Äôt have access to the Floo Network. In order to get access you have to get permission from the Ministry and then they have to set it up for her. Last time‚Äîwhen my dad died‚ÄîI think Dumbledore talked to them, but like, it‚Äôs not as though I can ask him to do that just because I‚Äôm feeling nervous.‚Äù

James looks at her thoughtfully. He‚Äôd never considered how difficult it must me for Muggle borns to get in contact with their parents. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk to my mum,‚Äù he says eventually, causing Lily to arch her brow.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll talk to your mum?‚Äù

James shrugs. ‚ÄúShe knows people at the Ministry and she‚Äôs also the only person I‚Äôve ever seen tell Dumbledore what to do. If I tell her you want to talk to your mum she‚Äôll make it happen.‚Äù

Lily‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúI‚Äîno that‚Äôs‚ÄîI‚Äôm probably just being silly.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so,‚Äù James counters, ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs silly is that the Ministry doesn‚Äôt immediately set up all Muggle-born families with a connection to the Floo Network,‚Äù when Lily continues to gape at him clearly at a loss for words, he goes on, tapping her foot again. ‚ÄúYou should be able to talk to your mum Lily, Merlin knows I‚Äôd go barmy if I thought I couldn‚Äôt talk to mine when I needed to.‚Äù

She lets out a bemused laugh. ‚ÄúThank you James that‚Äôs really‚Ä¶‚Äù she trails off like she can‚Äôt find the words. ‚ÄúJust thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù he tries to ignore the fuzzy feeling in the pit of his stomach, but Lily presses on before he can think too much about it.

‚ÄúYou and your mum are close huh?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúHonestly, she was my best friend before I met Sirius,‚Äù he realizes as he says it that he doesn‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs still true‚Äîif Sirius is still his best friend. If he‚Äôll ever be again.

Lily laughs. ‚ÄúJames Potter, trouble-maker and momma‚Äôs boy.‚Äù

Despite the tightness in his chest he manages a grin. ‚ÄúYou can mock me all you want but I‚Äôm never gonna be embarrassed of my mum. She‚Äôs like, the most bad ass person I‚Äôve ever met. You‚Äôd like her.‚Äù

Something softens in Lily‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure I would.‚Äù

James goes on unprompted. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôd like you too.‚Äù It makes his stomach flip, saying that out loud, remembering all the times he‚Äôd fantasized about introducing Lily to his parents. Introducing her as his girlfriend. It was bit pathetic maybe, but he hadn‚Äôt been able to help himself.

There‚Äôs silence but it isn‚Äôt awkward. The sun has all but set now, the sky a dark navy blue, the stars only barely visible as light flakes of snow start to fall. They catch in the moonlight and both James and Lily watch them. Entranced.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve always thought snow looked like magic,‚Äù Lily says eventually, before laughing. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt explain that so don‚Äôt ask me to.‚Äù

But James just nods. ‚ÄúNo, you‚Äôre right, it totally does.‚Äù

The flakes sparkle and glint as they land on the ground, instantly melting. Watching it James feels himself relax for the first time.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he says, breaking the silence again, ‚Äúwould you mind if I‚Ä¶just stayed here for a bit? This is sort of the most okay I‚Äôve felt all day.‚Äù

When he looks back at Lily finds an expression on her face that he can‚Äôt read.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù she says softly, and then, clearing her throat. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîas long as you don‚Äôt mind me reading.‚Äù

James smiles. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay then.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

Their feet press against one another, neither of them acknowledging it as Lily drops her eyes back to the book in her lap and James watches the snow.

¬†

By the time James makes it up to the Gryffindor common room everyone is back from dinner. He does a quick scan of the room before sidling up to Peter who appears to be in the middle of a breakdown. Aka doing Potions coursework.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù James says, causing Peter to look up from the parchment in front of him, black ink smeared across his chin.

‚ÄúHi‚Äîyou okay?‚Äù

James arches his brow before nodding towards the parchment. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine. Are you okay?‚Äù

Peter lets out pitiful noise. ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm completely fucked. This is due tomorrow and I have absolutely no idea what I‚Äôm doing. Usually Moons helps me but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúHe already take off back to the shack?‚Äù

Peter nods miserably. James claps him on the shoulder but before he can respond someone across the room catches his attention.

‚ÄúListen, Wormtail, I‚Äôll help you okay?‚Äù

Peter looks like might actually cry. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù he asks hopefully.

James very nearly laughs. ‚ÄúYeah, really, I just need to talk to someone first but then I‚Äôll be back.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my hero.‚Äù

Now James does laugh, giving his shoulder a squeeze before he pulls away. The moment he starts walking his nerves return. Everything in him says turn around. Says not now. Not yet. But he manages to keep going, manages to make it all the way across the room.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Mary asks, looking up at him when he stops in front of her.

James shoves his hands in his pockets in an attempt to stop them from shaking. ‚ÄúYeah, hey. Um‚ÄîI was wondering if I could talk to you for a second?‚Äù

Mary has clever eyes, the kind that pick you to pieces between every blink. ‚ÄúYeah alright,‚Äù she says eventually, getting up and sending Marlene a look that James does not remotely understand.

‚ÄúMy room okay?‚Äù he asks, because it‚Äôs the only place close by where he knows they‚Äôll be alone.

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúThe rumours tomorrow morning are going to be glorious.‚Äù

With the way a pack of first years are eyeing them on their way upstairs James knows that she‚Äôs right. He rolls his eyes. Why can‚Äôt people just mind their own damn business?

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Mary says, dropping down onto Sirius‚Äôs bed while James closes the door behind them, ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs up?‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt know how to answer that question, suddenly feeling vaguely sick. He starts pacing. Having this conversation feels like a betrayal. Even thinking that Regulus could have anything to do with Mary‚Äôs attack feels like a betrayal. Like James is no better than everyone else, everyone who only sees Regulus‚Äôs name and family and not who he is. Who James knows that he is.

‚ÄúPotter!‚Äù Mary snaps, bringing his attention back to her. ‚ÄúWould you stop? You‚Äôre making me sea sick.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù James says, stumbling to a stop and wiping his sweaty palms off on his jeans. After a moment‚Äôs pause he walks over and sits on the bed across from her, letting out a deep sigh. Even then it takes a few more minutes before he‚Äôs able to speak.

He lifts his eyes to meet Mary‚Äôs, sharp as always. ‚ÄúI need you to tell me again, what you told me on New Year‚Äôs Eve. I need you to explain it to me. All of it. Everything that happened and what the hell Regulus has to do with it.‚Äù

Mary‚Äôs face betrays her shock, which is a first. James doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs ever shocked Mary before. ‚ÄúOh?‚Äù

He nods, hands gripping his knees, nails digging in so deep they find skin. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt ready to listen before, but I‚Äôm ready now.‚Äù Which James thinks is not exactly true but he doesn‚Äôt take it back.

After a moment Mary nods. ‚ÄúWell okay then,‚Äù she says simply. ‚ÄúLets start from the beginning.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hey! Hi! Hello!

I feel like this is a lot of picking up where we left off before Christmas, so hopefully it wasn't too dry. Also surprise I'm making y'all wait for that Sirius James altercation that is 100% coming.

Thanks for all the comments and kudos, love hearing your theories about what's going to happen (though it's very hard for me not to just jump in and be like "I know" "I have the answers")

Hope you're all having a great day/night/morning!

Chapter 37

Chapter Summary

Tale as old as time (surprise, this fic is now a musical)

Chapter Notes

tw: death / murder (not graphically described, happens off screen, no main characters)

tw: discussions of rape / sexual assault

tw: like the briefest possible mention of Christianity

(I think that's it but if I'm forgetting anything let me know - this goes for always, if there is something you think should be tw that I miss pls let me know!)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

HOGWARTS YEAR 1013

PART I: SALAZAR

There is a room in the castle that reveals itself only when it is needed most. It cannot be seen on any map or located by any spell. Once inside its occupants are kept safe, the room cares for them, providing them with everything they require‚Äîto be comfortable, to be satisfied, to be happy. The idea had been Salazar‚Äôs, the others indulging him. Indulging his paranoia. Having a safe place to hide is very important to Salazar. It is, in fact, the reason that he is alive.

When he was six his mother woke him once in the middle of the night. There had been lots of yelling and people running about. Their whole family lived in one small cottage in the countryside. His brothers and cousins and uncles all worked the fields, while the women washed and sowed and cooked. The house was bursting with people and laughter and life. Salazar loved it. Loved all of them. But that night the shouting had not been drunken or joyous. It had been fearful.

‚ÄúCome my darling, my sweet thing, come, come,‚Äù his mother had cooed as she carried him out of the house and across the back lawn towards the small shed they used to store tools and dry meat. She had shoved around crates and other debris before laying a blanket on the ground in the corner and gesturing for him to lie down. Salazar had been too tired to ask questions.

‚ÄúSleep now darling,‚Äù she‚Äôd kissed the top of his head. ‚ÄúEverything will be alright. But you must stay here, yes? No moving, no making any noise at all, not until I come get you okay? Sal?‚Äù

‚ÄúM‚Äôkay momma,‚Äù he‚Äôd slurred, already half asleep.

‚ÄúGood boy.‚Äù

He was vaguely aware of her moving things back to their places in front of him. Hiding him from view.

That was the last time he saw his mother.

The last time he saw any of his family.

The Muggle town a day‚Äôs ride away had heard rumours about them. About what they were. As good Christians they could not allow such an abomination to continue. A family of witches and warlocks. Of devil worshippers.

Salazar would never know what happened exactly. Why his family hadn‚Äôt used magic against them. Or if they had, why it had failed. He‚Äôd been asleep in the shed. And when he awoke his family was dead, their home smouldering in the sunrise. The flames not quite burnt out.

Having somewhere to hide is import to Salazar.

It is especially important in a place that is made for children. Hogwarts is alive‚Äînot just a building, but a living being that thinks and feels and acts. It is the protector of every child within its walls. A surrogate mother. Who will keep her children safe when the monsters come looking for them in the middle of the night. That is why he added the room to the school‚Äôs plans, why he figured out the complicated Spell work required to make it possible. He spent months on it, so that it would be there incase of an emergency. When the students would need their mother most.

And yet, the first time the room was summoned, it was not by a frightened student in need of shelter. It was by two men, standing in a shadowy hallway, voices low and desperate, hands more so. It had given them a place to hide. To be together. To be safe‚Äînot from monsters necessarily, but from everyone else. Everyone who would never understand.

This is not the need Salazar had anticipated when he built the room. Not a need that had even occurred to him. And yet for years now, he had found himself here, standing in this room, created just for the two of them. He had stopped seeing this as a space of desperation, of last resort, and started thinking of it as home. A word he had not used since he was six years old.

¬†

He‚Äôs looking at a painting of the night sky when he hears the door open behind him. Salazar has always loved the night. The stars. They hold the future in their orbits and Salazar is jealous. He wants nothing more than to reach out and steal their secrets.

The man who enters the room doesn‚Äôt speak, his steps faltering only for a moment before he strides forward, the sound of his scabbard clanking against his hip. Without hesitation, or waiting for permission‚Äîhe‚Äôs never been very good at waiting for anything‚Äîhe slips one arm around Salazar‚Äôs waist and the other across his chest, pulling them together until there exists no space between them, until his warmth bleeds through their clothes and starts to make Salazar flush.

‚ÄúGodric,‚Äù he says softly, as the other man starts to nuzzle at his neck, placing gentle kisses along his jaw. ‚ÄúGodric,‚Äù he says again, trying and failing to sound more authoritative. ‚ÄúWe need to talk.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot yet,‚Äù Godric says into his skin, causing tremors to shoot through him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done nothing but yell at you across a table all day. I just want this for a moment longer. I just want to have you. Remember what it‚Äôs like when you‚Äôre mine.‚Äù

Salazar tilts his head back, resting it on Godric‚Äôs shoulder and giving the other man more access. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm always yours.‚Äù Which is embarrassingly and pathetically true.

Eventually Salazar turns around, because he has to, because he can‚Äôt take it anymore, and then they‚Äôre kissing properly. They love and fight and kiss all the same way. Godric pushes him back against the wall, Salazar runs a hand through his hair and pulls viciously. The fear and anger and betrayal they both feel sits just below the surface. Fighting with the rest of them. It‚Äôs never been this bad before. This painful.

They break apart, foreheads pressed together, Godric‚Äôs hands‚Äîbig and rough as they are‚Äîhold Salazar‚Äôs face like it‚Äôs something precious. Salazar‚Äôs fingers knotted in the back of his shirt. For a long time neither of them speak, frozen like that, heavy breathing.

Here,

Salazar thinks.

I want to always be here.

‚ÄúSal,‚Äù Godric‚Äôs voice is gruff, his thumbs brushing his cheeks, ‚Äúyou have to let it go.‚Äù

Salazar blinks, trying to come back to himself, to clear his head of lips and tongues and gentle hands. He feels his body go rigid.

‚ÄúJust so we‚Äôre clear,‚Äù he says coldly, ‚Äúby ‚Äúit‚Äù you‚Äôre referring to the murder of my entire family?‚Äù

Godric sighs, like he‚Äôs the one being attacked.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Salazar clumsily pulls away, walking to the fireplace and grabbing hold of the mantle for support, he needs to have something in his hands or there‚Äôs a good chance he‚Äôll punch Godric. ‚ÄúJust checking.‚Äù

‚ÄúThese children are not responsible for what has happened to you.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, they‚Äôll just be responsible for it happening to someone else.‚Äù

There‚Äôs the sound of aborted steps, as though Godric was going to come to him and then thought better of it. Smart man.

‚ÄúThey have every right to be here,‚Äù Godric says eventually.

‚ÄúThey outnumber us,‚Äù Salazar hisses, hands gripping the mantle so tightly his knuckles threaten to split through his skin. ‚ÄúThey outnumber us everywhere and now you want to let them in here too? To this space that is just for us? Where we are free of their prejudice and hatred? You want to tell them all our secrets so they can scurry off and expose us to their parents who will no doubt start showing up at every Wizard township with fucking pitchforks.‚Äù

‚ÄúSal,‚Äù he sounds sad more than anything else. ‚ÄúEveryone is not like that‚Äîyou cannot go through life thinking all people are cruel.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll people ARE cruel,‚Äù except you, he doesn‚Äôt say. Because he still has some self-respect.

Godric makes a frustrated noise before he finally moves all the way across the room. He wraps Salazar in his arms again, burying his face in his neck. Sal wants to resist, wants to push back, but he‚Äôs always been weak where Godric is concerned. Weak and hungry.

‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt cruel,‚Äù Godric says eventually.

Salazar lets out a dry laugh to cover up the way those words touch some softer part of him. The part that desperately wishes to be the hero of the story. ‚ÄúRowena would disagree with you.‚Äù The riff between them is recent and it hurts, though Sal would never admit that to anyone.

‚ÄúRowena doesn‚Äôt know what she‚Äôs talking about. Besides, Helga likes you.‚Äù

‚ÄúHelga likes everyone.‚Äù

He can feel Godric smiling against the skin of his throat. ‚ÄúTrue.‚Äù

After a moment Salazar sighs, melting further into Godric‚Äôs warmth. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre supposed to be safe here,‚Äù he says quietly.

‚ÄúWe are.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe cannot trust them.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have to stop thinking of this as ‚Äúus‚Äù and ‚Äúthem‚Äù, we are one. They have magic just like you and I. Muggle-Born or not, they are Wizards and Witches and they must be trained.‚Äù

‚ÄúAfter everything the Muggles have done to us, to our people‚Äîpushing us to the fringes of society, forcing us into hiding‚Äîthey do not deserve magic. They do not deserve access to our world.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause that‚Äôs longer than it should be before Godric tightens his arms around him. ‚ÄúMe, Helga and Rowena are all agreed.‚Äù

And doesn‚Äôt that feel like a blade in the back. For the second time that night Salazar pulls away, Godric reluctant to let him go. This time though, this time Salazar doesn‚Äôt flee to the other side of the room, doesn‚Äôt turn his back, but faces his lover head on.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve decided,‚Äù he repeats, hands in shaking fists at his sides. ‚ÄúAnd my word means nothing?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course not,‚Äù Godric says wearily. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôve been overruled.‚Äù

He wants to laugh.

He wants to cry.

He won‚Äôt, he never does, his father taught him better.

‚ÄúHave the three of you been speaking without me?‚Äù he asks. Godric has never been much skilled at hiding his emotions, and the guilt is now plain across his face. ‚ÄúI see,‚Äù Salazar does not wait for a response. ‚ÄúYou know, I did not expect loyalty from Rowena or Helga but you? After everything we have been through, after everything I have told you‚Äî‚Äú he is embarrassed to say that his voice breaks. ‚ÄúI would have thought you would understand.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do understand. I do,‚Äù Godric stretches out his arms but makes no move to close the gap between them. ‚ÄúBut just because I understand your feelings does not mean I think they are right. Sal, please, I‚Äôm begging you to see reason here. These are children.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know what they are,‚Äù Salazar snaps.

‚ÄúDo you?‚Äù and when a dangerous silence follows those words Godric decides to push forward, because he can never see the line. Never knows when to stop. ‚ÄúYou are punishing them for your family‚Äôs death.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am keeping our community safe!‚Äù

‚ÄúYou are being vindictive and short sighted,‚Äù and now he‚Äôs getting angry. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre smarter than this.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh fuck you.‚Äù

‚ÄúLove‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNO, stop, stop,‚Äù he jabs an accusatory finger in Godric‚Äôs direction. ‚ÄúYou do not get to speak to me like that‚Äîto address me in such a way when you are in the middle of betraying everything that we are‚Äîeverything that we have ever been to one another.‚Äù

Most people see Godric as a frightening figure, he is tall and broad and bearded, always walking around with a broadsword strapped to his back and several smaller blades hanging from the belt at his hip. But to Salazar he will always be delicate. And right now he takes satisfaction in watching him crack.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not true, you know that‚Äôs not true,‚Äù he takes a step forward and Salazar instantly pulls out his wand, hands shaking. ‚ÄúSal‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI will leave the school if you allow this to happen. I cannot, in good conscience, stand by and watch the three of you put in jeopardy everything I hold dear. I will not stay here, do you understand?‚Äù

And Godric looks so unbearably sad that he very nearly takes it back. ‚ÄúI understand.‚Äù Salazar‚Äôs chest is rising and falling in violent heaves, everything in him wrung tight. ‚ÄúBut,‚Äù Godric finally goes on. ‚ÄúI cannot, in good conscience, discriminate based on blood. It‚Äôs not who I am. Not the world I wish to live in.‚Äù

Now it is Salazar who is cracking.

‚ÄúYou would choose them over me?‚Äù he finally asks, voice tight as he stares at the person he has trusted more than anyone else in his life. ‚ÄúYou would choose the Muggles over me?‚Äù

Godric‚Äôs eyes are so sad.

Salazar wants to gouge them out.

‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù Godric says desperately. And Salazar nearly kills him. ‚ÄúYou know‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGet out,‚Äù he growls, voice low and dangerous.

Godric looks at him beseechingly. ‚ÄúSal‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGET OUT!‚Äù he shifts his wand ever so slightly, sending a curse just over Godric‚Äôs shoulder, shattering the mirror behind him. Shock and anger flicker across Godric‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúGet out before I take you apart.‚Äù

He sees Godric‚Äôs hand twitch, knows that he desperately wants to reach for his own wand. Fine. Let him. Godric may have brawn on his side but his spell work has always been sloppy compared to Salazar‚Äôs. There is no way he could beat him in a duel.

But it doesn‚Äôt come to that. Instead, after a few seconds of deliberation, Godric‚Äôs arm drops lifelessly back to his side.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says, still with Salazar‚Äôs wand pointed at him‚Äîright at the centre of his chest. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll go. If that‚Äôs what you want.‚Äù

No.

Never.

Please.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he hisses, half-sure the word comes out in Parseltongue

Godric just nods, tension clear in his body as he walks past Salazar, giving him a wide berth as he heads swiftly for the door, cloak sweeping behind him.

Salazar finally lowers his wand but doesn‚Äôt allow himself to turn around and watch Godric leave. Is almost certain it would break him.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt what I wanted,‚Äù he hears behind him. Salazar squeezes his eyes shut. ‚ÄúIn fact, all I‚Äôve ever really wanted is you. But I have to do what‚Äôs right Sal, I just hope you‚Äôll realize that. I hope you‚Äôll‚Äî‚Äú his voice breaks and Salazar doesn‚Äôt know if he‚Äôs going to finish that thought but after a few seconds he hears the sound of a throat being cleared. ‚ÄúI hope you‚Äôll come back.‚Äù

And with that the door closes.

¬†

HOGWARTS 1977

PART II REGULUS

Regulus stands in the Come and Go Room, staring at a painting of the night sky. He‚Äôs never really paid much attention to it before, but up close he can appreciate the beauty of it. The velvety texture of the sky, the subtle movement of the clouds and blinking of the stars. It wouldn‚Äôt be hard to forget that you were looking at paint and canvas and not out a window. Admiring it, picking apart the artistry, is helpful, because James is late‚Äîat least latter than usual‚Äîand the beautiful painting is helping to keep Regulus‚Äôs thoughts occupied.

Well‚Ä¶sort of.

When his thoughts do drift he tries to focus on the good parts of this morning. On James‚Äôs arms around him, his soft kisses across his face, in his hair, him whispering that Regulus was safe. That he was okay. He focuses on the smaller details‚Äîthe specific feel of his hands, the warmth, the slight pressure, the tickle of his thumb brushing Regulus‚Äôs cheek.

He tries not to think about the fact that Sirius knows about them.

Or about what Mary may or may not have told James.

Regulus shakes his head, trying to clear his thoughts.

Just think about his hands.

Just think about the night sky.

The door opens behind him but Regulus doesn‚Äôt turn around, he just closes his eyes and exhales. James came. He came. He came. There‚Äôs a moment of hesitation, James quiet, which is unusual for him, but eventually Regulus can hear his footsteps approaching, stopping just behind him.

‚ÄúYou can touch me.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus.‚Äù

And he knows just from the sound his voice that something is wrong.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù Reg says. ‚ÄúI just need a minute before we‚Äîplease can you just touch me?‚Äù It‚Äôs pathetic. He knows it is. And unfair. But he asks for it anyway. And of course, James gives. His arms strong and warm as they wrap around Regulus, pulling him back into his chest.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never noticed this one before,‚Äù he gestures to the painting in front of them.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Reg says slowly, eyes running it over one more time. ‚ÄúMe neither. And then today‚Äîit was the first thing my eyes went to when I came in.‚Äù

James hums, the vibrations shooting through Regulus.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs beautiful.‚Äù

You're beautiful, Regulus doesn‚Äôt say. He‚Äôs not sure why exactly. Except maybe that he has a feeling that today James might not say it back.

Regulus takes advantage of the new silence between them. Cataloging, in the greatest detail, everything about this moment‚Äîthis feeling‚Äîbecause he doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs coming but he knows it isn‚Äôt good, knows his days of this are dwindling and he wants to remember everything about it.

‚ÄúI can see you,‚Äù James says suddenly.

Regulus blinks, tilting his head to look up. ‚ÄúSee me?‚Äù

James gestures to the painting with his chin. ‚ÄúThe stars. I can see you‚Äîin the sky.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù it comes out more like a breath than a word and Regulus doesn‚Äôt know why it aches. Maybe because this is where they started. Looking at stars in the sky. Eventually James sighs, breath tickling Regulus‚Äôs ear.

‚ÄúReg.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

He breathes in, bringing his arms up to pull James more tightly around him. He gives himself five more seconds.

One.

James is wearing a crimson jumper. Not his Gryffindor one but close enough. He almost always dresses in house colours. Regulus doesn‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs on purpose but he suspects it isn‚Äôt.

Two.

He smells clean. He must have showered since this morning. He uses generic soap and some sort of pine-y aftershave.

Three.

James is bigger than Regulus, so when they stand like this it‚Äôs like he blocks out the whole world. All there is is James.

Four.

Sometimes his glasses hurt Regulus‚Äôs nose when they kiss. But for some reason he likes it. It reminds him that he‚Äôs kissing James Potter every time they press into his skin.

Five.

He never knew the difference between a house and a home before this.

Regulus opens his eyes and forces himself out of James‚Äôs arms, turning to face him. James looks wretched; tired and pale, eyes red rimmed. Like maybe he hasn‚Äôt been crying exactly, but he‚Äôs certainly been coming close.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù Regulus guesses, but James shakes his head.

‚ÄúRegulus.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease stop saying my name like that,‚Äù like it causes you pain.

James sighs before going to sit on the end of the bed. He rests his elbows on his knees, hands clasped, head hung. Regulus stays where he is.

‚ÄúI talked to Mary again,‚Äù James says finally.

Regulus does his best not to grimace. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt looking at him‚Äîcan‚Äôt look at him‚Äîwhich is never good. Regulus resists the urge to tug his sleeve more firmly over his forearm. She wouldn‚Äôt have done that would she? She wouldn‚Äôt have told him? Not after her warning today?

‚ÄúYou told me this morning that you weren‚Äôt there, for her attack,‚Äù James goes on carefully, like he‚Äôs afraid that if he speaks too forcefully he or Regulus or both of them will shatter. He might not be wrong. Regulus watches James‚Äôs shoulders heave up and down as he finally lifts his eyes. ‚ÄúThat was a lie.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not really a question, but Regulus feels he owes him an answer anyway.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

James nods, though the movement is jerky. Regulus watches him fight with himself, watches him chew on his bottom lip.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù the word sounds small.

Regulus has to clear his throat before he speaks, afraid of what he‚Äôll sound like otherwise. ‚ÄúWhy what?‚Äù

James looks so fucking sad. ‚ÄúWhy did you lie?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know why.‚Äù

James arches his brow but doesn‚Äôt give Regulus anything else. Doesn‚Äôt offer him an out, just waits for him to explain himself, to say the cowardly words out loud.

‚ÄúBecause. Because you would never have understood.‚Äù

‚ÄúUnderstood what?‚Äù

Regulus throws his hands up in frustration. ‚ÄúWhy I had to do it.‚Äù

James just keeps looking at him and suddenly Regulus wishes he would go back to staring at his knees. That was easier to deal with than this scrutiny.

‚ÄúWhy you had to wipe her memory in order to protect her attackers?‚Äù

Regulus looks at him helplessly. ‚ÄúYes. They‚Äôre my friends.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow? How can they be your friends after what they did? How can you of all people‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do that,‚Äù Regulus snaps.

James is starting to look annoyed. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do what?‚Äù

‚Äú‚ÄòYou of all people‚Äô as though me and Mary Macdonald have anything in common.‚Äù

The pity is worse than the annoyance. ‚ÄúReg, they raped her.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey didn‚Äôt. I stopped them.‚Äù

But James tilts his head back, letting out a sigh like he‚Äôs looking for help from some higher power. ‚ÄúHer shirt was off.‚Äù

‚ÄúI stopped them.‚Äú Regulus says through gritted teeth, hands in fists. ‚ÄúNothing happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúClearly something happened. And more would have if you hadn‚Äôt stepped in. How can you just get over that? How can you protect them after that? Surely you can sympathize with her?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Regulus asks coldly. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve noticed, but I don‚Äôt sympathize with most people.‚Äù

James looks genuinely surprised by that statement. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not true.‚Äù

‚ÄúI promise you it is.‚Äù

James just shakes his head, running a hand over his face and somehow managing to look both years younger and older than he is. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand how you can be angry at me right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not angry at you,‚Äù Regulus says, though even he has to admit that he certainly sounds angry. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not angry at you,‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just‚Ä¶it sounds so simple when you just say things but in the moment‚Ä¶there are so many factors that I have to consider all the time, so many ramifications that are so much bigger than what happens in this fucking school.‚Äù When James just looks back at him blankly Regulus forces himself to continue.

‚ÄúEvan, Barty, they‚Äôre my only allies. If I lose them I will have no one to watch my back. I don‚Äôt agree with everything they do and God knows they can be fucking morons sometimes but I‚ÄîI will not survive without them on my side. Do you understand?‚Äù

He‚Äôs trying to. Regulus knows he‚Äôs trying to. James always tries. But he also knows that James Potter will never really be able to understand.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Ä¶bad Regulus,‚Äù James finally says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs wrong. It‚Äôs‚ÄîI get that things are, are really messed up right now,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt. He doesn‚Äôt get it at all, ‚Äúbut what happened to Mary is so far outside of what is okay. And you helped it happen, helped them get away with it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI told them they were idiots.‚Äù

James lets out a cold laugh. ‚ÄúIdiots? Regulus they raped her.‚Äù

‚ÄúSTOP SAYING THAT.‚Äù

His voice is violent. It fills up the space and rattles his teeth. It‚Äôs dead silent afterwards, like a bomb has just gone off, James‚Äôs eyes wide behind his glasses.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James says eventually, like he‚Äôs speaking to a frightened animal. He runs a hand through his hair clearly trying to regroup. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he looks back at Regulus and suddenly seems so lost. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where we go from here.‚Äù

Regulus knows how it‚Äôs going to sound before he says it. How childish. How petulant. But it doesn‚Äôt stop the words from coming out of his mouth. ‚ÄúWe go to bed.‚Äù

‚ÄúReg‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWe go to bed and we sleep and we wake up and we move on because it‚Äôs done and over and we can‚Äôt change it.‚Äù

James just keeps looking at him like a kicked puppy. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do that.‚Äù

You can,

Regulus wants to argue. Wants desperately to argue.

You can. I know you can. I do it all the time. Just don‚Äôt think about it. Just lock it away. I‚Äôll show you. I‚Äôll teach you.

You can.

You can.

You can.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Regulus sighs, shoulders sagging as he turns away from James, unable to stand looking at him anymore. He grips the mantle of the fireplace, trying to give himself a moment to think.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äî‚Äú he starts and then stops, working to get his voice back under control. ‚ÄúWhat do you need me to do James?‚Äù he asks finally, speaking to the wall. ‚ÄúTell me and I‚Äôll do it.‚Äù

More silence. God Regulus fucking hates silence.

After a few minutes he hears the sound of James getting up, coming towards him. He wraps Regulus in his arms again and Reg is so grateful that he actually makes an embarrassing whining noise as he collapses back into James‚Äôs chest.

‚ÄúI know that being in that house, with your mother, with‚Äîwith all of them, I know it has you all twisted up,‚Äù he says softly. Regulus isn‚Äôt sure that that‚Äôs entirely true. It seems like it‚Äôs letting him off the hook far too easily, but James is holding him again, is speaking into his neck, so he isn‚Äôt about to argue.

Eventually James sighs. ‚ÄúYou know what I want Reg,‚Äù he says wearily. ‚ÄúI want you to leave. I want you to come home with me when school is done. Don‚Äôt go back to them.‚Äù

Regulus feels himself tense, his grip on the mantle tightening. Somehow they always end up back here.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt or won‚Äôt?‚Äù

The edge in James‚Äôs voice nags at Regulus and he shrugs off James‚Äôs arms, stepping away from the fireplace.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand why we‚Äôre having this conversation again.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause you never give me a straight answer,‚Äù James snaps.

‚ÄúI do. I have. I don‚Äôt know what else you want from me,‚Äù somewhere between angry and desperate.

‚ÄúI want you to be honest with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am honest with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúBullshit,‚Äù James takes a step forward, finger pointing accusingly at Regulus. ‚ÄúYou lied to me this fucking morning. Or have you already forgotten that?‚Äù

Regulus splutters. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Äîwe‚Äôre not even talking about that anymore.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes we are! We‚Äôre talking about all of it. You lie all the time Regulus, do you think I can‚Äôt see it? Do you think I don‚Äôt notice?‚Äù

Yes,

Regulus doesn‚Äôt say, because he can‚Äôt see how that would help.

‚ÄúDo you even feel bad about it?‚Äù James asks, when Regulus doesn‚Äôt bother to answer his previous question.

‚ÄúAbout what?‚Äù he says coldly.

‚ÄúLying?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. No I don‚Äôt feel bad. I‚Äôm protecting you.‚Äù

James‚Äôs eyes go so wide Regulus is surprised they manage to stay in their sockets. ‚ÄúProtecting me?‚Äù he demands indignantly. ‚ÄúAre you kidding?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt act like that‚Äôs some outrageous‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is outrageous!‚Äù

‚ÄúNo it‚Äôs not!‚Äù

They‚Äôre both shouting now, cheeks flushed and chests heaving, Regulus prays to Merlin that these walls are magically sound proof.

‚ÄúYou think your parents don‚Äôt lie to you?‚Äù Regulus demands. ‚ÄúYou think they don‚Äôt keep things from you? That they haven‚Äôt done that your whole goddamn life so that they can stop you from being hurt or scarred or‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚Äîbloody traumatized?‚Äù something other than anger has snuck into Regulus‚Äôs voice, something desperate and heartbreakingly young. ‚ÄúYou know what I wouldn‚Äôt give to have people in my life who loved me enough to lie to me? I don‚Äôt want this,‚Äù he holds his arms out plaintively. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to know the truth, I don‚Äôt want to see how things really are. I am so fucking tired of reality. I wish someone had fucking protected me from it.‚Äù

James is already shaking his head, hands pulling at his face. ‚ÄúFuck Reg, lying and protecting people are two different things,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAnd regardless, you aren‚Äôt my parents, you can‚Äôt protect me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

But James cuts him off. ‚ÄúNo you can‚Äôt, you really can‚Äôt, and more than that, you can‚Äôt lie to protect me from you. Like have you even thought about that? That the person your lies are trying to protect me from is YOU?‚Äù

Regulus flinches. He‚Äôs sure James didn‚Äôt mean it to be cruel but that doesn‚Äôt change the fact that it is. Doesn‚Äôt change the overwhelming wave of emotions that it drags up in Regulus as he lets those words sink in. Because no, no he hadn‚Äôt thought about it.

There‚Äôs the sound of breaking glass and both of them startle, turning to see that the mirror behind James has shattered.

Regulus hasn‚Äôt lost control of his magic like that since he was a kid.

‚ÄúWas that you?‚Äù James asks eventually, voice rough.

Regulus closes his eyes for a minute, breathing out slowly through his nose. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù James‚Äôs voice breaks on his name as he steps closer but Regulus only shakes his head.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to be something you need to be protected from. But I know that I am. I know. I hate it. I hate myself. I‚Äôm sorry. I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey‚Äîwoah, no, Reg, that isn‚Äôt what I meant. I'm not trying to say‚Äî‚Äú he cuts himself off, clearly frustrated, then starts again. ‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt a bad person.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh come on James.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt,‚Äù James says emphatically. ‚ÄúYou just‚Äî‚Äú he struggles with the words before eventually giving up. ‚ÄúLook, I love you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo don‚Äôt‚Äî" Regulus instantly recoils. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt say that just because you think it‚Äôll make the hard stuff easier to hear. I don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú he looks about himself, grasping for the right words. ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt say it if you don‚Äôt mean it. And not in some abstract ‚ÄúI loved you before maybe I‚Äôll love you again‚Äù kind of way. Don‚Äôt say it unless you mean it right now, because this is who I am right now. All of the stuff I‚Äôve done...I can‚Äôt go back. I can't be who I was before. Even if that person was easier to love. So don‚Äôt say it unless you‚Äôre saying it to me, now. Unless you mean it right now.‚Äù He feels desperate as words fall drunkenly from his mouth, all stumbling into one another.

James takes his time answering. Takes too much time in Regulus‚Äôs opinion. His lovely face all screwed up, his brows pulled together, his bottom lip caught between his teeth. The worst of it is, Regulus is still lying. James still doesn‚Äôt know about the Mark. About Jonathan. And despite the situation he‚Äôs in right now, Regulus has no intention of telling him.

‚ÄúI always mean it,‚Äù James says finally, causing something like a sob to come out of Regulus‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon Reg, you have to‚Äî‚Äú he takes a moment to gather himself. ‚ÄúYou must know that? I‚Äôm yours remember? And you‚Äôre mine. My person. You said that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did,‚Äù Regulus doesn‚Äôt know how he manages to speak.

James nods, like that confirms something for him. ‚ÄúI always mean it,‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúI always will.‚Äù

It‚Äôs such a big word.

Always.

Regulus wants desperately to believe in it.

He doesn‚Äôt. But he wants to.

It terrifies him that James does.

A long moment passes before either of them speak again. But eventually Regulus finds his voice. ‚ÄúWhat were you going to say?‚Äù

James blinks. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt sounded like you had more to say, before I cut you off. ‚ÄòI love you but‚Äô‚Ä¶?‚Äù he isn‚Äôt sure he wants to know, and by the look on James‚Äôs face, he isn‚Äôt sure he wants to tell him.

‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù James repeats, voice worn out, ‚Äúbut I can‚Äôt‚ÄîI‚Äôm not sure how to forgive you right now. I think I need‚Ä¶‚Äù he exhales shakily, looking down for a moment. ‚ÄúI think I need a break, for a minute, to‚Ä¶sort out how to‚Ä¶deal with this. How deal with Sirius.‚Äù

It takes a herculean effort for Regulus to keep his expression passive. ‚ÄúA break.‚Äù

James grimaces. ‚ÄúI know how that sounds‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt sounds reasonable.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do that,‚Äù James sighs.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do what?‚Äù

James waves a hand in his direction. ‚ÄúShut down on me. I‚ÄîI‚Äôm not going anywhere Regulus.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcept on a break.‚Äù

James looks back at him, helpless. ‚ÄúI know how it sounds,‚Äù he repeats, voice cracking. ‚ÄúI just got you back you think I want‚Äîyou think I don‚Äôt want to fall asleep in that bed with you? That I don‚Äôt want to touch you and listen to you talk and kiss every fucking part of you? I want it. I want you. I always want you. I just‚Äîit‚Äôs tearing me up right now. And I can‚Äôt‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt sort it out.‚Äù

The frustrating thing, is that Regulus knows that he means it, every word. Because unlike Regulus, James Potter is not a liar.

‚ÄúLook, I‚Äôm not walking away okay?‚Äù he says a little desperately, eyes red. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not even thinking about it. I‚Äôm just trying to figure out how to stay.‚Äù

Which is fair.

Regulus hates it.

Hates every word coming out of his mouth.

But it‚Äôs fair.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says finally.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah James,‚Äù Regulus nods. ‚ÄúI‚Ä¶understand. I just‚Äî‚Äú this part is always hard. The vulnerable bit. The ooey gooey feelings that can turn sharp so quickly. ‚ÄúI miss you.‚Äù

James gives him a broken smile. ‚ÄúI know. I miss you too. So fucking much Reg.‚Äù

Okay, he thinks.

This is okay.

Because James isn‚Äôt a liar. And he said he wants to stay.

‚ÄúI should go I guess,‚Äù James says eventually, eyes trailing back to the broken mirror on the ground.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù because apparently that‚Äôs the only word Regulus knows anymore.

James looks like he wants to say more but stops himself. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll‚Äîer‚ÄîI‚Äôll come find you okay? When I‚Äôm ready to‚Ä¶when I‚Äôm ready.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Regulus almost cringes at the weakness in his voice.

James makes his way slowly to the door, hand pausing on the handle. ‚ÄúI really do love you Regulus,‚Äù he says meaningfully. ‚ÄúRight now. At this moment.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt look at him. Can‚Äôt look at him. ‚ÄúI love you too.‚Äù

He hears more than he sees James leave, the door closing behind him with a foreboding finality. For a long time Regulus just stands frozen in the middle of the room where James left him, but after a while he feels his feet start to move. He ends up in front of the broken mirror, some of the pieces cracking under his shoes as he steps closer.

It‚Äôs a minute before he notices the initials in the wall where the mirror had previously been hanging. They‚Äôre carved into the stone but not like they would be if it had been done by students‚Äîscratched in with nails or knives or some other rudimentary tool. These look like they were done on purpose. By magic. Though Regulus isn‚Äôt sure how, it would take a great deal of power to be able to manipulate this room like that‚Äîto make it do something it didn‚Äôt want to.

G & S

The letters tangle around one another, inseparable. Regulus finds himself reaching out, fingers tracing the pathways through the stone. For the first time he wonders if they aren‚Äôt the only people to find this room. I mean yes, the Come and Go Room has obviously been used by other people at different points in time but this manifestation of the room specifically, Regulus always assumed existed just for him and James. And yet‚Ä¶

G & S

‚ÄúDid you come here too?‚Äù he asks stupidly. ‚ÄúDid it keep you safe?‚Äù

There‚Äôs no answer, of course. No one around to hear. Eventually Regulus lets his hand drop back down to his side. He hopes they‚Äôre okay, whoever they are‚Äîwere‚Äîhopes they‚Äôre still together like this, wrapped around one another. It makes him feel better to think that.

‚ÄúSorry I broke your mirror,‚Äù he says eventually, stepping back from the wall. ‚ÄúI promise I‚Äôll fix it.‚Äù

He slides his wand out of his sleeve and after a few attempts at various domestic spells he finally finds one that works, all the pieces of the mirror flying back together, the cracks between them disappearing completely.

‚ÄúThere,‚Äù he says softly, satisfied that he was able to fix something for once, the initials covered. ‚ÄúSafe again.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

AHH

Okay

Okay

Idk, maybe the beginning doesn't work? I've honestly gone back and forth on it so much but I like it, so I've just decided it works.

I've always thought the founders were cool and I just couldn't resist playing with the tension always specifically mentioned between Godric and Salazar so hopefully you guys also found those parallels between Godric and Salazar and James and Regulus interesting but if not I'm sorry.

ALSO Sirius is coming back, I promise, it was supposed to be this chapter but it just didn't feel right, so sorry for being a tease.

OKAY thank you, I am gonna go quietly stress about this chapter now :) :)

Chapter 38

Chapter Summary

Barty Crouch Junior's villain origin story (jk he was always a lil bitch)

Chapter Notes

tw: discussions of homophobia / internalized homophobia

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I JAMES

The next few days are lonely.

In fact, James is fairly certain it‚Äôs the most lonely he‚Äôs ever felt in his entire life.

Sirius and Remus don‚Äôt come back to the dorm but they do start coming to classes again. Sitting alone, away from James and Peter. Remus shoots James apologetic glances whenever they take the desks on the other side of the room. Sirius doesn‚Äôt look at him at all. Doesn‚Äôt come to the Great Hall or speak to anyone but Remus, at least not as far as James can tell.

It‚Äôs all far too reminiscent of last year. The four of them broken up, not speaking, not even looking at one another. James hates it. He thinks about just going down to the shack and forcing Sirius to talk to him. Thinks about it a lot actually. About what he would say, and how they would yell and scream but by the end everything would be okay. He never actually goes of course. Remus asked him to give Sirius time so he does. He just wishes Sirius didn‚Äôt need so much of it.

James floats between Quidditch practice and class. He talks to Peter‚Äîtalks to Remus when he‚Äôs alone‚Äîbut other than that he mostly keeps his head down. Every night he lies awake in bed and feels the pull to go to Regulus. A few times‚Äîpathetic times‚Äîhe pulls out the map to see if Regulus is there, in their room. To see if he‚Äôs waiting for James despite everything. But of course he isn‚Äôt. Regulus has too much self respect for that.

James doesn‚Äôt know how to fix things. Not with Regulus, not with Sirius. And so the floating continues. James can‚Äôt help but feel like he‚Äôs fading a little bit. An empty version of himself, just going through the motions.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking about starting a chess club.‚Äù

James blinks, coming back to the breakfast table and looking up at Peter while he chews thoughtfully on the bacon sandwich he‚Äôs just made for himself.

‚ÄúA chess club?‚Äù James asks, trying to make sure he‚Äôs heard him right.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Peter says, wiping his mouth clean on the back of his hand. ‚ÄúLike, you know, you have Quidditch, maybe I could have chess?‚Äù

James refrains from explaining all the ways in which a chess team and a Quidditch team are radically different things.

‚ÄúSure, yeah, okay,‚Äù he says instead. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize you were that into chess?‚Äù

Peter shrugs. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm not exactly. But I feel like I could be y‚Äôknow? Like I‚Äôm never going to be a Quidditch star no matter how hard I try‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know that,‚Äù James says automatically, earning him a skeptical look from Peter.

‚ÄúUh, yeah, I think I do. BUT,‚Äù he says before James can interrupt again. ‚ÄúI could be a chess star if I just put a little more effort into it. It might not be Quidditch but,‚Äù another shrug. ‚ÄúA trophy is a trophy right?‚Äù

He looks at James hopefully and James can‚Äôt bring himself to say anything even remotely negative. ‚ÄúSure, definitely. I thinks that‚Äôs‚Äîer‚Äîa great idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù Peter asks, looking far too happy about this.

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äòcourse.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôll put up posters yeah? See who‚Äôs interested. Hold try-outs.‚Äù

James has no idea what the hell chess tryouts would even look like.

‚ÄúHey, would you help?‚Äù Pater asks, eyes all big and hopeful. Fucking damnit Peter. ‚ÄúSince you‚Äôve done it so many times before‚Äîtryouts I mean‚Äîyou could give me some pointers?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú

Luckily, James is saved from having to continue this conversation by the arrival of the post. Hoot choosing that moment to land gracefully on the table beside him, only narrowly avoiding stepping in a bowl of porridge. He very insistently starts nudging at James‚Äôs shoulder with his beak.

‚ÄúHey buddy,‚Äù James gives his dignified head a little pat before untying the letter around his leg. Hoot shuffles forward staring very pointedly at the plate of cold cuts in the middle of the table. James laughs.

‚ÄúNot exactly subtle are you?‚Äù he swears Hoot glares at him. ‚ÄúAlright, alright, no jokes before treats. Got it.‚Äù James tosses him a piece of ham and with the contented flutter of his wings Hoot catches it and flies off.

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs the letter from?‚Äù Peter asks, as James slides his hand under the wax seal.

‚ÄúMum,‚Äù he says without looking up. He wrote to her the morning after he talked to Lily in the courtyard. It‚Äôs about the only useful thing he‚Äôs managed to do recently.

¬†

Dear chicken,

His mother writes.

Glad to hear you‚Äôre doing well and that Quidditch is back on track - I promise me and your father will make it up for your final match (which, if I‚Äôm not mistaken, is shaping up to be against Slytherin again is it not?) we‚Äôve both just been a bit slammed with work recently.

Anyway - Lily Evans, huh? Goodness, that‚Äôs a name I haven‚Äôt heard in a while. I must tell you, Jamie darling, I am rather thrilled to learn that the two of you have become friends. You were always so obsessed with the girl, it seemed a shame you two could never get along.

About your request - of course it is absolutely ridiculous that Muggle-born families don‚Äôt have access to the Floo. I‚Äôve talked to some of our friends at the Ministry and Dumbledore as well, I expect she‚Äôll hear from him before the week is out. If not, let me know and I‚Äôll march up to the school and sort it myself.

I love you very, very much.

Sincerely, her majesty,

Your mum.

¬†

James smiles down at the letter, ‚ÄúBrilliant,‚Äù he murmurs, before folding it up and sliding it into his pocket. He really does love his mum.

He shoves a piece of toast in his mouth before throwing his bag over his shoulder and getting to his feet. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you in class alright Pete? I gotta go talk to Evans.‚Äù

Peter looks vaguely surprised but doesn‚Äôt question him. ‚ÄúYeah alright. See y‚Äôah.‚Äù

It‚Äôs only the two of them at breakfast today, Remus having already come and gone, bringing Sirius his food. James thinks it‚Äôs starting to wear on Remus a little bit, spending so much time in the shack. But he‚Äôs not sure that criticizing the location of Sirius‚Äôs self-imposed exile is going to go over well with either of them at the moment.

‚ÄúHey guys,‚Äù James joins the sixth year girls a little ways down the table from where him and Pete had been sitting. They all look up briefly, Mary giving him a vague nod and Marlene a wave before they go back to whatever it is they were talking about.

‚ÄúAre you abandoning Peter then?‚Äù Lily asks, looking slightly amused as she scoots over to make room for him.

He smiles, shaking his head. ‚ÄúNah, never. Just wondered if maybe I could talk to you before class?‚Äù he nods in the direction of the doors, not missing the significant looks that Marlene and Mary send him across the table.

Lily looks surprised for about a minute before she recovers. ‚ÄúUh‚Äîyeah, yeah sure. Of course.‚Äù She grabs her stuff and slides out from under the table. ‚ÄúSee you lot later yeah?‚Äù she tosses over her shoulder.

‚ÄúYou two have fun,‚Äù Mary says in a sing-song voice. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do anything I wouldn‚Äôt do!‚Äù

Lily gives her a flat look at the same time that Marlene shakes her head, hissing under her breath; ‚ÄúMerlin Mary, really?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Mary says innocently as they walk away.

They‚Äôre quiet leaving the Great Hall, James shoving his hands awkwardly in his pockets, not quite sure what to say or how to start.

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù once they‚Äôre in the corridor he quickly guides them into the nearest empty classroom, certain he doesn‚Äôt want to do this in the foyer.

‚ÄúIs it something serious?‚Äù Lily asks when he closes the door behind them. ‚ÄúIs it about the map?‚Äù

James feels his chest tighten but quickly shakes it off. ‚ÄúNo, no, nothing like that. I just wasn‚Äôt sure how much you‚Äôd told anybody else about‚Äîor if you‚Äôd want them to know‚Ä¶‚Äù for some reason the ends of his sentences seem to be alluding him today. Eventually he sighs, pulling out his mum‚Äôs letter and handing it to her.

‚ÄúI wrote to my mum,‚Äù he says as he watches her unfold it.

She looks up at him briefly and then back down at the page, immediately letting out a bubble of laughter. ‚ÄúChicken?‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah, yeah,‚Äù he says, though he can feel his cheeks heating up. ‚ÄúJust read the third paragraph.‚Äù

She raises her brow, eyes skimming the letter. He sees the moment she understands. The moment the words sink it. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù she says softly. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

She looks up and James offers her a smile. ‚ÄúTold you my mum was brilliant.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú she sounds a little choked, hand coming to the base of her neck. ‚ÄúJames this is really, really, really‚Ä¶‚Äù she seems to be at a loss for words. ‚ÄúNice,‚Äù she finally settles on.

James laughs, he can‚Äôt help it. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôve been known to be nice from time to time. I think it‚Äôs Remus‚Äôs doing really. Some of his good must‚Äôve rubbed off on me.‚Äù

She gives him a quizzical look, letter still held tight in her hands, like if she lets it go it won‚Äôt be real anymore. ‚ÄúI can never tell, when you‚Äôre being self-deprecating like that, if you really believe it or if you‚Äôre just trying to be charming.‚Äù

He arches his brow. ‚ÄúYou think I‚Äôm charming?‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúRarely.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not a no Evans,‚Äù he gives her a wink.

Lily tries and fails to look unimpressed with him, her eyes eventually dropping back down to the letter. ‚ÄúThank you for this,‚Äù she exhales, pausing for a moment before she hands it back to him. ‚ÄúI know I‚Äôm probably just being silly but it‚Äîbut I really want to see her and I never would have been able to without your help.‚Äù

James shrugs, trying to ignore the tickling feeling in his stomach. ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean it,‚Äù she reaches out and squeezes his arm. She really is too pretty for her own good. Or maybe for his own good. He can‚Äôt decide which. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

They‚Äôre standing closer than James realized and suddenly he feels his mouth go dry. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú

They aren‚Äôt doing anything wrong.

Aren‚Äôt sneaking around.

Aren‚Äôt breaking any rules.

Aren‚Äôt‚Ä¶doing whatever else students get up to in empty classrooms.

So James isn‚Äôt sure why the sound of the door opening is so jarring, why it sends a quick flash of panic through him. Maybe it‚Äôs intuition. His mother did mention he had a Great Aunt who was a seer. Maybe he knows what‚Äôs coming without realizing it. Because really it doesn‚Äôt matter that someone is walking in on them. They‚Äôre only talking. It‚Äôs nothing. Not even the Hogwarts‚Äô gossips could turn this encounter into news. Except that, of course, it isn‚Äôt the gossips who are at the door.

It‚Äôs Reg.

For half a heartbeat he just stands there, staring, his eyes going to the point where Lily‚Äôs hand still rests on James‚Äôs arm. James doesn‚Äôt know why he suddenly feels like he‚Äôs been caught cheating. Because he hasn‚Äôt. But the look on Regulus‚Äôs face‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs only there for a second, barely that, before he‚Äôs able to wipe his face clean. But that second is enough to make every inch of James ache.

Regulus doesn‚Äôt say anything, just turns around and lets the door slam behind him on his way out, James watching helplessly.

‚ÄúUm,‚Äù Lily says after the poignant silence that follows, letting go of him. ‚ÄúIs everything alright?‚Äù

James swallows. ‚ÄúYeah, of course, I just need to‚Ä¶I need to go,‚Äù he looks back at her. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll tell me, when they let you talk to your mum? Tell me when you find out she‚Äôs alright?‚Äù

Something flickers across her face that James doesn‚Äôt know what to do with, already half-way to the door.

‚ÄúYou care about my mum?‚Äù she asks quietly. That question enough to make James pause.

He looks back at her. ‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù he says and then, nearly; I care about you. But that seems like too much somehow so he leaves it as is. ‚ÄúSee you, yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he hears her mutter as the door closes behind him and he finds himself in an unhelpfully empty corridor. He looks left to right, running a nervous hand through his hair and wondering if he should go get the map. Where the fuck would Reg go?

He hears voices around the corner, no doubt people slowly making their way out of the Great Hall and towards their first period classes. James starts walking in the opposite direction, deciding that‚Äôs what Reg would do. That he would want to be alone.

James can‚Äôt stop his brain from pulling up the image of Regulus‚Äôs face when he‚Äôd first opened the door. Fuck. James really needs to fix this. He knows exactly what Reg will be thinking and he can‚Äôt even blame him this time because first James asks for a break and then Regulus walks in on him and Lily in an empty classroom. He knows that Lily sets Reg off like no one else. That he feels insecure around her, always has.

Fuck. Fuck. Fuck.

He pulls up short when he rounds the next corner and finds Regulus at the back of a dead-end hallway, sitting on the ground with his back pressed to the wall, staring straight ahead. He doesn‚Äôt look up, not even when James manages to get his legs working again.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù he asks, voice quiet as he stops by his side. Standing feels incredibly awkward but he can‚Äôt help but feel that he doesn‚Äôt deserve to sit down. Regulus doesn‚Äôt answer, just keeps staring at the wall across from him, face blank, though his eyes‚ÄîJames thinks his eyes give him away. They look‚Ä¶bruised.

‚ÄúI was just helping her get into contact with her mum,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know how it looked‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou must know how it looked,‚Äù Regulus says coldly. ‚ÄúSince you‚Äôre here.‚Äù

Which, of course, is true.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather not do this,‚Äù Regulus says after a moment.

James feels the bottom of his stomach drop, like someone‚Äôs just thrown him from the astronomy tower. ‚ÄúRather not do what?‚Äù he asks weakly.

Regulus still isn‚Äôt looking at him. ‚ÄúYou want to finish with me you finish with me. I‚Äôm not interested in being let down easily or whatever it is that you think that you‚Äôre doing. Just‚Äîjust walk away James. Put us both out of our misery.‚Äù

For a second all James can do is stare at him, an uncomfortable storm of emotions waging in his chest.

‚ÄúOur misery?‚Äù he repeats finally. ‚ÄúDo I make you miserable Reg? Does being with me make you miserable?‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be stupid.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight back at you.‚Äù

Finally, the younger boy looks up.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to finish with you,‚Äù James says stubbornly. ‚ÄúYou know that. I told you that.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell you‚Äôll excuse me if I find it hard to believe when you‚Äôre out here holding hands with Lily Evans.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt bother to point out that they weren‚Äôt actually holding hands. ‚ÄúI want to be with you. I love you. I need space so that I can figure out how to move past this, but I do want to move past this.‚Äù

Regulus holds James‚Äôs stare but his expression doesn‚Äôt shift. ‚ÄúWanting to, and being able to, are different things.‚Äù

James growls. ‚ÄúJesus Christ Regulus, what do you want from me?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt answer, just keeps looking up at him with the same passive expression. Almost bored. And James knows that it‚Äôs an act. He knows. But sometimes it‚Äôs so hard to remember, especially when he‚Äôs feeling so raw. So vulnerable.

Eventually he sighs, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúSometimes‚Äî‚Äú he starts and then stops, not at all sure how to get this out. ‚ÄúSometimes I feel like I‚Äôm trying so hard to keep us a float, and all you‚Äôre doing is looking for ways to sink us,‚Äù he opens his arms, offering up his palms in surrender. In desperation. ‚ÄúI want to do this Regulus, I don‚Äôt know how many more times or ways I can say it. But I can‚Äôt do it on my own.‚Äù He looks at him pleadingly. ‚ÄúI need to know that we‚Äôre in this together. That you‚Äôre not just waiting for us to fail so you can point your finger and go ‚ÄúI told you so.‚Äù

For the first time Regulus‚Äôs mask cracks. Flickers of pain and desperation bleeding through. After a few more seconds of silence James crouches down, bringing them eye level.

‚ÄúI need you to stop treating us like we‚Äôre doomed,‚Äù he whispers, feeling the need to be soft now that they‚Äôre so close. ‚ÄúBecause I don‚Äôt believe that we are. I can‚Äôt.‚Äù

A wounded noise escapes Regulus before he immediately closes his eyes, like it‚Äôs too much. Like he can‚Äôt bare to feel and see and hear James all at the same time. It‚Äôs another few seconds before Regulus speaks.

‚ÄúYou wanna know what the really pathetic part is?‚Äù he says finally, eyes still shut. ‚ÄúWhen I saw you with her I wasn‚Äôt even angry. I just thought ‚Äúthey look so beautiful together,‚Äù his voice cracks and for a moment James can‚Äôt breathe it hurts so bad. ‚ÄúI just thought ‚Äúthis is how it‚Äôs supposed to be,‚Äù he shakes his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll never look like that, standing next to you.‚Äù

‚ÄúLook like what?‚Äù James whispers.

Wrinkles appear at the corners of Regulus‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he says on his next exhale. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll never look right. I‚Äôll never belong. No one will ever look at us the way they look at you and her.‚Äù

And James doesn‚Äôt know what to say‚Äîthere are so many things that his brain almost short circuits‚Äîby the time he opens his mouth he has no idea what‚Äôs coming out of it.

‚ÄúI will,‚Äù he says simply. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll look at us that way.‚Äù Maybe that sounds stupid, he doesn‚Äôt know.

Regulus lets out a shaky breath. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says weakly.

James knows they‚Äôre in the hallway. Knows it‚Äôs Reckless. All of this is reckless. But before he can stop himself he leans over and places a kiss on the top of Regulus‚Äôs head. Quick and chaste. And when he pulls away Regulus chases him, leaning into his side.

‚ÄúYou will always belong with me Reg,‚Äù James whispers against his temple. ‚ÄúAlways.‚Äù

Regulus sighs, pressing into him like he can‚Äôt be close enough. ‚ÄúYou really mean that,‚Äù it‚Äôs more of a statement than a question, but it‚Äôs said with enough awe that James feels compelled to answer anyway. Just to make sure Regulus believes it. Make sure he hears it.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says softly, placing another quick kiss on the side of his head. ‚ÄúI really do.‚Äù

¬†

PART II SIRIUS

¬†

He‚Äôs lying on his back on the floor of the Shrieking Shack, Remus tucked into his side, head resting on his shoulder. Both of them stare up at the window in front of them as the sky turns black and the stars come out to play. There's a draft sneaking through the floorboards but it‚Äôs alright, Remus always runs hot, a furness nestled under Sirius‚Äôs arm.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying,‚Äù he goes on. ‚ÄúI think a Unicorn could take a Centaur in a fight.‚Äù

Remus tries to make a dismissive noise but it comes out too much like laughter. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm just saying that that is the answer to a question that nobody asked.‚Äù

‚ÄúUm, excuse me,‚Äù he tickles Remus‚Äôs side making him squirm and giggle which is such a delightful noise that Sirius does it again.

‚ÄúOi! Stop that!‚Äù Remus swats his hand away but doesn‚Äôt manage to keep from smiling, Sirius feels rather smug about it.

‚ÄúSomeone did ask the question,‚Äù Sirius goes on. ‚ÄúAnd that someone was me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not even certain that‚Äôs true at this point.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo it is,‚Äù Sirius says indignantly. ‚ÄúI asked; which two magical creatures you‚Äôd most want to watch fight.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I refused to answer on the grounds that it‚Äôs an idiotic and vaguely insulting question.‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúListen, we can talk about which two Hogwarts students we‚Äôd like to fight next if it‚Äôll make you feel better. Anyway, you were being no fun‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI was being a morally conscious human being you mean.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike I said, no fun. So I answered: Unicorn and a Centaur. Because I think the Unicorn would kick the Centaur‚Äôs ass and that would be hilarious.‚Äù

Remus snorts. ‚ÄúWhy would it be hilarious?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause Centaurs are pompous assholes and Unicorns are famously underrated.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat!‚Äù Remus squawks. ‚ÄúIn what world are unicorns famously underrated? Unicorns are very rated.‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty sure that isn‚Äôt a saying Moons, and I don‚Äôt have time to explain to you everything that‚Äôs wrong with the cultural interpretation of Unicorns right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh you don‚Äôt do you?‚Äù Remus asks teasingly. ‚ÄúAnd why‚Äôs that? You got somewhere to be?‚Äù

Sirius turns his head to the side only to find that Remus is already staring back at him. Their noses brush. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve just got other plans for tonight that‚Äôs all,‚Äù he says, voice low.

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúDo you now?‚Äù

‚ÄúMhm,‚Äù Sirius uses his arm to pull Remus in closer‚Äîjust those last few inches so that their mouths can touch.

Sirius has kissed a respectable number of people. He‚Äôs always liked kissing. Liked the things that follow kissing too. But being with Remus is something else. The electricity that shoots through Sirius when Remus opens up for him, when he feels his teeth pulling on his lip, or scraping down his neck. Remus kisses like it‚Äôs the only thing he wants to do.

His hands slide under Sirius‚Äôs shirt and up his sides, making him shiver. ‚ÄúYou cold?‚Äù Remus asks against his lips.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Sirius moves, swinging his leg over Remus‚Äôs hip, straddling him. Remus is flush and disheveled beneath him, just as Sirius likes him. ‚ÄúDefinitely not cold,‚Äù he breathes, before ducking back down, taking Remus‚Äôs mouth with enough force that Remus moans. Hands running up Sirius‚Äôs back, through his hair, pulling lightly.

‚ÄúAs much as I‚Äôm enjoying this,‚Äù Remus murmurs after a few minutes. ‚ÄúThis floor is fucking killing me.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Sirius sits up, eyeing the dirty mattress on the other side of the room. When his gaze comes back Remus‚Äôs mouth has pulled itself into a firm line.

‚ÄúNo way in hell am I having sex on that thing.‚Äù

Sirius sighs dramatically, slumping off of Remus and back onto the floor beside him. They lie shoulder to shoulder for a moment, both of them still trying to catch their breath. Remus clears his throat. In Sirius‚Äôs experience, that‚Äôs never a good sign.

‚ÄúWe do have two perfectly good beds we could use.‚Äù

Sirius glares up at the ceiling. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot sure you can say no, it‚Äôs just a fact.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be a prick.‚Äù

He feels Remus shuffle beside him, turning on his side to look at Sirius who keeps his eyes stubbornly on the ceiling.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù he says softly. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt avoid this forever.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou underestimate me.‚Äù

Remus reaches out, brushing his fingers gently against Sirius‚Äôs arm, causing Sirius‚Äôs eyes to flutter closed. There‚Äôs a long period of silence, long enough that Sirius has started to drift off to the steady feeling of Remus‚Äôs touch. And then;

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do this for much longer Sirius,‚Äù he almost whispers. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt‚Ä¶be here. All the time. It‚Äôs too‚Ä¶hard.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes open and he turns his head, meeting Remus‚Äôs stare. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says, and then; ‚ÄúShit, Moons I didn‚Äôt‚Äîfuck.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, it is but‚ÄîI mean we just, none of us can keep going like this Sirius. James is‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt.‚Äù

Remus sighs beside him before sitting up, arms draping over his knees. ‚ÄúHe misses you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI said don‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah I know,‚Äù Remus pinches the bridge of his nose, shoulders tense. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôve been saying ‚Äòdon‚Äôt‚Äô for a week now and it‚Äôs enough. You have to talk to him,‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt think I don‚Äôt know you miss him too.‚Äù

Which is true, of course. James is Sirius‚Äôs other fucking half. That‚Äôs why this is so hard.
