Why he has no idea what to do with all the feelings that bubble up inside of him at the thought of his best friend. It‚Äôs easier not to think about it. Not to touch those wounds. That‚Äôs how you survive. A lesson he learned from his mother.

‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶‚Äù he exhales, scrubbing at his face. ‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt who I thought he was.‚Äù

Remus reaches over and runs a hand through Sirius‚Äôs hair. It feels nice. It always feels nice when Remus touches him. ‚ÄúYou sure about that?‚Äù

‚ÄúI trusted him,‚Äù Sirius says weakly. ‚ÄúI needed to trust him. To believe that I could‚Äîthat it was possible. I needed him to be‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPerfect?‚Äù

Sirius screws up his face. ‚ÄúNo, just‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know. Better, I guess. I needed to believe that people could be better. Could care for one another better than‚Ä¶‚Äù

Remus gives him a minute before filling the silence. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a lot of pressure to put on one person‚Äîrestoring your faith in humanity.‚Äù

Sirius sighs, ‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù though it never felt like it was something he put on James, it just felt like it was who James was.

‚ÄúAnyone else,‚Äù Sirius murmurs eventually, repeating the words that have been running laps around his head since he first found out. ‚ÄúHe could have chosen anyone else and I wouldn‚Äôt have given a fuck. Anyone else. Just not‚Ä¶Reg. Just not‚Ä¶fuck,‚Äù he squeezes his eyes shut again. He hates this. Hates how out of control it makes him feel.

He hates them both.

He loves them both.

At this particular moment he‚Äôd be happy not to feel anything about either of them at all.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a lot of choice in these things,‚Äù Remus says finally, fingers still carding through Sirius‚Äôs hair.

Sirius frowns. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs always a choice.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Sirius says firmly. Some choices hurt and some choices feel good and some choices linger for days and months and years. But there are always choices, and anyone who says otherwise is just too much of a coward to take responsibility for the ones they‚Äôve made.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Remus clears his throat nervously, hand stilling in Sirius‚Äôs hair. ‚ÄúSo you‚Ä¶chose me then?‚Äù

Sirius blinks, trying to follow this new direction in the conversation. He looks over at Remus, confused. ‚ÄúOf course?‚Äù

Something flickers across Remus‚Äôs face that Sirius doesn‚Äôt understand.

‚ÄúYou thought I didn‚Äôt?‚Äù he asks. ‚ÄúYou thought‚Äîwhat?‚Äîwhat did you think?‚Äù

Remus looks away briefly, swallowing with some difficulty. ‚ÄúNo I‚ÄîI guess I just assumed that if you felt like you had a choice you‚Ä¶wouldn‚Äôt‚Ä¶choose me.‚Äù

Sirius just stares at him for a minute, running over those words several more times, trying to figure out if he‚Äôs misheard somehow. If they might have some other meaning he isn‚Äôt aware of.

‚ÄúMoons‚ÄîRemus, look at me yeah?‚Äù and Remus does, light patches of pink on the tops of his cheeks, like he‚Äôs embarrassed. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt take this the wrong way, but that‚Äôs the stupidest shit you‚Äôve ever said, like ever in your entire life.‚Äù

Remus laughs like he can‚Äôt help it.

‚ÄúI mean it,‚Äù he reaches over and tugs on Remus‚Äôs arm. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt‚ÄîI chose you. I chose this. I‚Äôll always choose this. With you. As long as you‚Äôll let me.‚Äù

Remus ducks his head, eyes looking up through his lashes, driving Sirius mad. ‚ÄúBut‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúBut?‚Äù Sirius tugs on his arm again, causing Remus to fall forward, bracing himself with one hand on either side of Sirius‚Äôs head.

Remus searches his face for a moment, worrying his bottom lip.

‚ÄúBut?‚Äù Sirius prods again.

Remus lowers his face a little further down, floppy golden hair brushing Sirius‚Äôs forehead. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre not gay,‚Äù he says weakly, causing Sirius‚Äôs stomach to clench.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he manages eventually.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus doesn‚Äôt move, staying right where he is, inches away.

Sirius swallows, forcing himself not to look away, unsure how to explain all the tangled parts of himself. ‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú he starts then stops, letting out a shaky breath. ‚ÄúMy Uncle Alphard was gay,‚Äù he says finally, which is probably a strange place to start but Remus just nods.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says, brushing his nose against Sirius‚Äôs. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know that. Did he tell you?‚Äù

Sirius nods his head jerkily, wondering if Remus can feel him shaking. ‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt really‚Ä¶my mum didn‚Äôt burn him off the wall like she did with me but he‚Äîthey all treated him terribly. His parents pretended they didn‚Äôt even have a son. I mean we always knew about him growing up, but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause he was gay?‚Äù Remus asks.

Sirius grimaces. ‚ÄúYeah. I mean, no one ever told me so but‚Ä¶yeah,‚Äù he swallows with difficulty. ‚ÄúAlphard said‚Äîhe said his dad threatened him. Said if he ever did anything, you know, publicly. Had any kind of, relationship I guess, that he‚Äôd kill him.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ,‚Äù Remus hisses.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius says, wishing his voice was a little more stable. ‚ÄúSo he never did.‚Äù

Remus blinks. ‚ÄúHe never had a relationship?‚Äù

Sirius shakes his head. ‚ÄúAt least not one that was‚Ä¶you know‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúOut?‚Äù Remus supplies for him.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù his mouth feels dry. ‚ÄúNot that it mattered, they killed him anyway.‚Äù His voice breaks then and he has to use every ounce of his self control he has to keep the prickling behind his eyes from turning into tears.

‚ÄúOh Sirius,‚Äù Remus kisses his forehead, his nose, his eyelids. They‚Äôre soft and caring and Sirius lets himself relax into them, lets himself breathe.

‚ÄúI choose you,‚Äù Sirius says, as steadily as he can, barely able to get the next words out of his mouth. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm afraid of that‚Ä¶word. Of being. That. Of what it means.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat does it mean?‚Äù Remus asks, brushing the hair off his forehead.

Sirius can‚Äôt look at him anymore, eyes closing. ‚ÄúThat I‚Äôm broken.‚Äù His voice trembles, paper thin and barely holding it together. ‚ÄúThat I‚Äôm‚Ä¶sick.‚Äù

He hears the hitch in Remus‚Äôs breath.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Sirius says, even though he isn‚Äôt sure what he‚Äôs apologizing for.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù he says again. ‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt broken.‚Äù

He isn‚Äôt quite ready for the way those words ripple through him. The way they shake his bones. He tries to stop them, but the tears sneak out anyway, Remus brushing them away with his thumb.

‚ÄúI know it‚Äôs stupid,‚Äù Sirius says thickly. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt give a fuck what any of them think anyway, I don‚Äôt know why this‚Äîthis matters. It shouldn‚Äôt make a difference, what they said. What they thought. I don‚Äôt want to be someone they would like.‚Äù

Remus just keeps wiping the tears off his face. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre your family,‚Äù he says softly. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre allowed to be hurt by what they‚Äôve said. It‚Äôs kind of impossible not to be. No matter how hard we wish it wasn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Sirius breathes in, pressing his cheek into Remus‚Äôs hand. ‚ÄúI really fucking love you, you know?‚Äù he says, with as much conviction as he can muster. ‚ÄúI know I‚Äôm a mess but I‚Äîthat‚Äôs never gonna change okay?‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs lower lip wobbles. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he breathes. ‚ÄúYeah me too.‚Äù

They kiss again, it‚Äôs soft and tender and purposeless. Remus holds him and Sirius lets him, lets himself be taken care of. Loved. Worshipped. With gentle hands that don‚Äôt want anything, but to make him feel good. And arms that keep him safe. If he could make a home out Remus‚Äôs body he would.

¬†

They fall asleep tangled up together on the floor. Sirius is awake before the sun, his body stiff. It‚Äôs with great care that he extracts himself from Remus, conjuring a blanket to take his place, wrapping it around Remus, tucking him in. They never sleep on the mattress. It‚Äôs filthy but Sirius doesn‚Äôt think that‚Äôs the reason. It‚Äôs too close to the full moon for Remus. Too close to Moony.

Sirius watches him for a moment, the peaceful expression on his face, lips slightly parted, hair mussed. He bends down and kisses the top of his head.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he whispers, kissing him once more for good measure. ‚ÄúYou win.‚Äù

He leaves the Shack a few minutes later, making his way through the passage and back onto school grounds. The sky is only just beginning to warm by the time he gets there. It must be nearing 7:30 as he walks towards the Quidditch pitch, the distant specs of the Gryffindor team clear in the sky. Watching them makes him miss something he can‚Äôt quite name. I mean, he misses playing beside them but it‚Äôs more than that. He misses the way things were back then. The days when him and James would wake when it was still dark out and drag themselves down the hill. Most mornings they barely talked, but they were always together. On the ground, in the air.

Sirius leans against the entrance to the pitch, watching the practice come to an end, players standing around in a circle. There‚Äôs some laughter, James is speaking but he‚Äôs too far away for Sirius to hear. He wonders what James‚Äôs speeches are like, if he tries to mimic Frank or if he‚Äôs found his own style already. The sky is pink now, glowing bright over the still half-frozen campus.

Eventually the group breaks up, Mary lingering to talk to James. Sirius stays where he is until they start walking towards the change rooms, then he places his fingers in his mouth and whistles. James‚Äôs head instantly snaps towards him, though it‚Äôs a few seconds before he recognizes Sirius. It‚Äôs easy to see the moment that it happens‚ÄîJames‚Äôs whole body going rigid. Mary is looking too but James tells her to go‚Äîor at least Sirius assumes he does, he still can‚Äôt hear but he watches James say something to her and after a few reluctant moments Mary continues on her way towards the change rooms and James starts walking towards Sirius.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù James says once he‚Äôs in earshot, looking almost as nervous as he sounds. There are bags under his eyes, his skin pale, and hair more a mess than normal. Sirius doesn‚Äôt speak, just nods his heads towards the stands and starts up the stairs. He doesn‚Äôt need to check behind him. He knows James is following.

When they reach the top the cold wind whips Sirius‚Äôs hair back from his face, the sunrise bright in front of them. Sirius walks all the way to the railing, looking out over the field, overly sensitive to the sounds of James behind him.

‚ÄúIs this the part where you kill me then?‚Äù James asks finally. ‚ÄúThe locations not exactly subtle but I guess you always did love to put on a show.‚Äù

James is joking about the murder, but it scares Sirius how close to the truth he is. How part of Sirius wants to get his hands on James and squeeze and squeeze and never stop. Wants to break James for making him feel like this. Like he‚Äôs alone again. Or worse. Like maybe he was alone the whole time.

‚ÄúNot sorry enough not to fuck my brother though, yeah?‚Äù Sirius means it to be harsh. To be mean. But he doesn‚Äôt quite expect to feel himself flinching away from his own words.

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right, it doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

‚ÄúI would never hurt you on purpose Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou lied on purpose. You made Remus lie to me on purpose‚Äîand God fuck you for that one by the way. As if being betrayed by you wasn‚Äôt enough you really had to go and twist the knife in didn‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you hold a wand to his head? Threaten to Avada him if he told me the truth?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you?‚Äù Sirius asks coldly. They aren‚Äôt here because James finally decided to be honest, because he realized that what he was doing was messed up, they‚Äôre here because of a mistake. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying‚Äî‚Äú he makes a frustrated noise. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying‚Äîcan‚Äôt I love you both?‚Äù

No!

Sirius almost shouts. Almost stamps his foot. Balls up his fists.

No. No. No.

You‚Äôre mine.

You were supposed to be mine.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying here Sirius,‚Äù James says eventually, sounding exhausted.

‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt actually,‚Äù Sirius says bitterly. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre only here because of Remus.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wanted to tell you.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence.

‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt want me to.‚Äù

Sirius laughs coldly. ‚ÄúOf course he didn‚Äôt. And what Regulus wants Regulus gets, right?‚Äù Isn‚Äôt that how it‚Äôs always been?

Regulus, the good son.

The better son.

‚ÄúHe was scared Sirius‚Äîhe‚Äôs still scared. He doesn‚Äôt want to do anything to make you angrier at him. He really cares about‚Äî‚Äú

Sirius turns around for the first time, it‚Äôs a sharp movement, his entire body vibrating with barely contained anger. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna need you to shut up now.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt argue, mouth closing immediately as his hands come up in surrender.

It‚Äôs a few seconds before Sirius is sure that when he opens his mouth actual words are going to come out and not just profanities. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a clue what the hell goes on between the pair of you, I don‚Äôt really think I could stomach hearing about it. But Regulus is loyal to himself and himself only. I would have thought that you of all people would understand that but I guess not.‚Äù

James only shakes his head. ‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt‚ÄîI‚Äôm not sure you know him as well as you think.‚Äù Clearly seeing the outburst building behind Sirius‚Äôs closed lips James presses on quickly. ‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs a lot you‚Äôve hidden from each other over the years. Being in that house‚Äîyou‚Äôve both been hurt, but if you would just talk‚Ä¶‚Äù James trails off, looking at Sirius desperately. Hopefully. It almost makes Sirius feel sorry for him.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think I know him?‚Äù Sirius repeats slowly, dangerously.

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúDid you hear anything else I said?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, I heard it. We‚Äôre both fucked up. If only we would spill our guts to one another maybe we could be a big happy family.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, I liked my wording better but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúThe problem is,‚Äù Sirius goes on, voice pulled tight, sun now almost completely risen behind him. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt tell Regulus anything. He has about a dozen different faces and you never know which one you‚Äôre talking to. The only thing you can know for certain is that you can‚Äôt trust any of them.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm telling you, he‚Äôs not like that. I promise,‚Äù James is holding his hands out beseechingly.

Sirius just arches his brow. ‚ÄúBecause you know my brother so much better do you? Because he‚Äôs honest with you?‚Äù

He sees the small flicker of doubt in James‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúI know him,‚Äù he says instead of answering. ‚ÄúI know the kind of person he is. When it comes down to it, I know that he has it in him to be good.‚Äù

Sirius nods slowly. ‚ÄúGood,‚Äù the word is brittle in his mouth, prone to cracking apart. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve seen my brother‚Äôs true heart and it is good?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù James says adamantly.

The wind whistles through the stands. It sounds like a ghost. Maybe it is.

‚ÄúAnd how exactly,‚Äù Sirius sharpens every word on his tongue before spitting it out, ‚Äúdoes the Mark on his arm play into that?‚Äù

The stillness that comes over James is violent. Sirius feels it like hands pressing against his chest. Several emotions flash across James‚Äôs face in a matter of seconds‚Äîshock, anger, sadness‚Äîbut it‚Äôs fear that sticks in the end. James stares back at Sirius looking absolutely terrified.

‚ÄúWhat are you talking about?‚Äù he finally whispers.

For the first time Sirius‚Äôs anger fades a bit. There is something delicate about his best friend all of the sudden.

‚ÄúSo you don‚Äôt know?‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù the name barely makes it out of James‚Äôs mouth, eyes wide and pleading. This truth is an axe, Sirius realizes, and once it‚Äôs told something will be irrevocably severed.

‚ÄúThe Mark. Voldemort‚Äôs Mark. He‚Äôs taken it.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James says. Scared. So. So. Scared. At first Sirius thinks James is shaking his head but then he realizes that James is just‚Ä¶shaking. ‚ÄúNo. There‚Äôs no way. How do you know? How could you possibly know that when I don‚Äôt?‚Äù

Sirius is familiar with this moment.

Knows what it‚Äôs like to love Regulus. To trust him.

Knows how it feels when you realize what a mistake you‚Äôve made.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen it.‚Äù

A wounded noise escapes James‚Äôs throat. ‚ÄúNo. No he can‚Äôt. I would know. You said‚Äîyou said you had to choose it. You told me you had to accept the Mark.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius nearly winces at the pain in James‚Äôs voice. ‚ÄúYou do.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut he wouldn‚Äôt!‚Äù James says desperately, voice cracking. ‚ÄúHe wouldn‚Äôt. I know that he‚Äôs made mistakes. I know that. Terrible mistakes. But he‚Äôs‚Äîhe‚Äôs really not‚Äîhe‚Äôs not like that. He‚Äôs not like them. I promise. I swear. He wouldn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI know he hurt you,‚Äù James rambles on, like this is a problem you can talk yourself out of. ‚ÄúI hate that he did that, but he was just a kid and he didn‚Äôt know what to do. He‚Äôs so fucking sorry Sirius‚ÄîI couldn‚Äôt be with someone who could hurt you without being sorry about it. You have to know that. You have to know that I couldn‚Äôt be with someone who would‚Äîwho was anything like‚Äîhe‚Äôs so lovely,‚Äù James finishes weakly, pressing the heels of his hands into his eyes.

‚ÄúI love him. I‚Äôm sorry. I know that hurts you. I‚Äôm sorry. The last thing I ever wanted to do was lie to you. But I love him. So I can‚Äôt believe that he would‚ÄîI just can‚Äôt believe that. I‚Äôm so sorry. I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

He‚Äôs crying.

Sirius is well acquainted with what James‚Äôs voice sounds like when he cries. Choked and thin. It‚Äôs a sound that could call Sirius from a mile away‚Äîtell him he was needed. That someone was going to die because, as far as he‚Äôs concerned, no one makes James Potter cry and gets away with it.

‚ÄúFuck James,‚Äù he mutters under his breath, no longer able to stay away. He takes the seat next to him, wrapping his arm around James‚Äôs shoulders and pulling him into his side.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do,‚Äù James hiccups. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do. I don‚Äôt know what to do. This is too‚Ä¶fucking much. It‚Äôs too‚Äîno one ever taught me how to handle this shit. I love him so much and I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúShh, shh,‚Äù Sirius exhales, hand rubbing up and down James‚Äôs arm. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll figure it out,‚Äù he says, because what else is there? ‚ÄúWe always do.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment of silence, broken up by James‚Äôs sniffling.

‚ÄúWe‚Äîus‚Äîwe will?‚Äù he finally asks, face still buried in Sirius‚Äôs shoulder.

‚ÄúYeah, us.‚Äù

Another pause. And then, in the smallest voice;

‚ÄúI really fucking missed you Sirius.‚Äù

Sirius squeezes him tightly. ‚ÄúWell just for the record, I didn‚Äôt miss you at all.‚Äù

James gives him a watery laugh and Sirius counts it as a win.

¬†

PART III MARY

¬†

Mary sits in a window near the back of the school. There are no classrooms here, just storage cupboards and a few offices further down. She watches the corner up ahead, fiddling with the cigarette between her fingers. Its a loophole, being able to smoke at Hogwarts. Since Wizards don‚Äôt have cigarettes there are no rules against them in the school. She should probably be more careful if she doesn‚Äôt want that to change but then, she rather likes the idea of forcing the creation of a new school rule. She‚Äôd wear it like a badge of honour. Make James and Sirius jealous.

She inhales deeply, letting the smoke sit in her lungs until it starts to sting and then tilting her head back and exhaling. Shockingly, Regulus Black has turned out to be a snake of his word. Giving her his friends‚Äô schedules and alerting her whenever they leave the common room. As a result, she‚Äôs spent the past few days following them around, figuring out where they go and how they get there and who they‚Äôre with. All in all it‚Äôs been a very educational, if not dull, few days.

For instance, she‚Äôs learned that on Wednesdays Barty Crouch Junior takes a detour on his way back from his last period class so he can hook up with Delany Whispers‚Äîa fourth year Ravenclaw. Honestly, you‚Äôd think a Ravenclaw would have more sense, but Mary supposes they‚Äôre not exactly a house known for their good taste.

She stubs out her cigarette when she hears footsteps approaching but otherwise stays where she is, wand sliding into her hand. Barty Crouch is a boy of average height and looks. A bit thin and peaky for Mary‚Äôs taste but she supposes that‚Äôs to be expected after years of in-breading. He doesn‚Äôt notice her when he rounds the corner or when he struts past her on his way to get his rocks off. Clearly someone‚Äôs feeling desperate.

‚ÄúHey Crouch?‚Äù

Hey Macdonald?

Barty freezes down the hall, turning to find her walking towards him. There is nothing hurried about Mary‚Äôs steps. They echo confidently in the empty corridor. Crouch looking instantly suspicious.

‚ÄúWhat the hell do you want?‚Äù

Get lost creep.

‚ÄúAw, come on, don‚Äôt be like that,‚Äù she tilts her head to the side. A predator assessing her prey. ‚ÄúI came to apologize.‚Äù

Aw, come on, don‚Äôt be like that. Listen, I came to apologize.

There‚Äôs a new tension to Barty‚Äôs stance as she stops in front of him, his eyes bouncing nervously around like he‚Äôs afraid something is going to jump out at him. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he demands harshly, screwing up his face. ‚ÄúWhat are‚Äîwhat the fuck are you playing at?‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt quite manage to keep the fear out of his voice.

She only smiles. Red lips pulling up to reveal two pearly-white rows of teeth. ‚ÄúCome on Barty, you remember don‚Äôt you? It happened just like this,‚Äù she gestures at the space around them. ‚ÄúI was on my way back to my dorm and then there you were. Calling my name. Though you‚Äôll have to tell me the rest,‚Äù she leans towards the terrified looking boy, mock-whispering. ‚ÄúBetween you and me, it all goes a bit fuzzy after that.‚Äù

Barty instantly takes a step back. ‚ÄúListen, I don‚Äôt know what you think‚Äî‚Äú

But she isn‚Äôt interested in his denial. Or his threats. Or disarming the wand he is pathetically attempting to pull from his bag.

‚ÄúImperio.‚Äù

Instantly his whole body relaxes, face going slack, eyes unfocused, Mary‚Äôs mind suddenly controlling them both. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to let you keep that memory,‚Äù she says, stepping nearer, eyes running over her hostage. ‚ÄúSo that when you wake up you‚Äôll know it was me who did this to you,‚Äù she drags the tip of her wand down the side of his face.

‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôll know why.‚Äù

¬†

PART IV BARTY

¬†

It‚Äôs. Fucking. Cold.

He groans, reaching for his blanket.

Cold. And‚Ä¶prickly?

His hand is groping around for his comforter but something doesn‚Äôt feel right. His bed is‚Ä¶off. Everything is off. And Christ why the fuck is it so cold? He forces his eyes open, blinking against the light, waiting for the room to come into focus.

Except there is no room.

Barty sits bolt upright, head swimming for a minute as he tries to wake himself up. Because clearly he‚Äôs still asleep. Clearly this is a nightmare. And yet, regardless of how many times he pinches or slaps himself, nothing changes. He continues to be sitting in the dirt, dark trunks sprouting from the ground around him and stretching far over his head, cutting up the sunlight so that it‚Äôs hard for him to tell what time of day it is.

Something in the distance howls.

‚ÄúFuck, fuck, fuck,‚Äù Barty scrambles to his feet, scrapping his hand open on something sharp in the process. ‚ÄúFUCK,‚Äù he puts extra emphasis on that last one as he goes to wipe the blood off on his trousers.

Except he isn‚Äôt wearing trousers.

He‚Äôs stood in the middle of, what he has to assume is the Forbidden‚ÄîGoddamn‚ÄîForest, in nothing but his pants.

His heart is starting to pound against his ribs and he begs himself to remember what the hell happened, hands searching fruitlessly for his wand even though he already knows he doesn‚Äôt have it. A twig snaps behind him and he jumps, spinning around and stumbling backwards, nearly landing back on his ass in the dirt.

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù he hisses, staring into the dark shadows between the trees. There‚Äôs another noise, definitely footsteps. Something is coming.

‚ÄúH-hello?‚Äù

He wracks his brain for every ‚ÄòCare for Magical Creatures‚Äô class he‚Äôs ever taken. What even lives in the Forbidden Forest? He makes another desperate search for his wand, but he doesn‚Äôt see it on the ground and it sure as hell isn‚Äôt in his boxers. A cold wind blows through the trees then, they rattle above him, his teeth starting to chatter.

He tries to orient himself, looking around, figuring out which way to go. But all he sees are trees. Trees and shadows and thousands of places for scary things to hide.

That‚Äôs when hears something growl.

Barty doesn‚Äôt bother trying to figure out what made the noise or how far away it is. He takes off sprinting in the opposite direction, praying to Merlin and Salazar and every other great Wizard he can think of that he‚Äôs heading towards the school and not deeper into the forest.

Trees and shrubbery shred his skin as he blows threw them, heart beating faster than it ever has before. Something flutters its wing over his head. He thinks he feels something scaly brush against his leg.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he whimpers, trying to make himself go faster. ‚ÄúOh fuck, oh fuck, oh fuck.‚Äù He keeps waiting to wake up. This has to be a dream. It has to be. I mean, why the hell would he be in the Forbidden Forest half-naked, it doesn‚Äôt make any‚Äî

He‚Äôs hit with the blurry images of a memory.

Of Mary Macdonald in a hallway.

Of her voice in his ear.

I‚Äôm going to let you keep that memory. So that when you wake up you‚Äôll know it was me who did this to you. And you‚Äôll know why.

He almost cries.

‚ÄúOh fuck, oh fuck, oh fuck.‚Äù

¬†


Eventually he realizes that nothing is actually chasing him so he lets himself slow down, wandering aimlessly until he finds a tree he can climb. From up above he‚Äôs able to locate the castle a good forty minute walk to the west of him.

Fucking brilliant.

By the time he manages to get back to school he‚Äôs cut up and freezing cold and covered in dirt. People stare as he walks through the front foyer in his goddamn boxers. He gets a few gasps, but most people laugh. The assholes. He‚Äôs going to skin all of them alive the minute he gets his bloody wand back.

Given how absolutely absurd his morning has been he shouldn‚Äôt be surprised by the mess awaiting him in his dorm room and yet‚Ä¶

‚ÄúHoly shit, I thought I looked bad,‚Äù Evan laughs when Barty walks in. Evan is sitting on the end of his bed, shirt off, a pair of track pants on his lower half, Regulus healing some scrapes on his chest. It takes a few seconds of staring at Evan‚Äôs disheveled appearance before Barty realizes what it means.

‚ÄúI‚Äîyou‚Äîyou were there too?‚Äù he asks numbly.

‚ÄúIf by ‚Äúthere‚Äù you mean the‚Äîfuck me Reg‚Äù Evan hisses as Regulus heals a particularly nasty cut on his ribs. Apparently whatever spell he‚Äôs using stings.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Regulus mutters, though he doesn‚Äôt sound remotely sorry.

‚ÄúIf by ‚Äúthere‚Äù I mean what Evan?‚Äù Barty demands impatiently, Evan can never stay on topic, even in moments like this.

‚ÄúThe fucking forest of terrors,‚Äù Evan grimaces as Regulus moves on to another cut. ‚ÄúYeah I was there. So were Snape, Mulciber, and Avery.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat??‚Äù

Regulus steps back, sliding his wand into the holster on his arm. ‚ÄúThere, that should be most of the bad stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre you all together?‚Äù Barty demands, ignoring Regulus.

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù Evan groans as he reaches across his bed for his t-shirt, sliding it carefully over his freshly cleaned torso. ‚ÄúJust got back quicker than you,‚Äù he gives Barty a wink, like this is all some fucking joke.

‚ÄúIt was Macdonald.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Evan groans again when he stands. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre aware. Not exactly subtle that one, is she?‚Äù he sounds almost impressed, which makes Barty want to throttle him.

‚ÄúSo what‚Äôre we going to do about the bitch?‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing,‚Äù Regulus says coldly, bringing Barty‚Äôs attention back to him. He‚Äôs shorter than both him and Evan and yet somehow he can do this thing with his eyes where he makes you feel two feet tall.

‚ÄúSit down and let me take care of your face,‚Äù he goes on before Barty can argue. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt go to class like that.‚Äù

Barty has no idea what‚Äôs wrong with his face, though he‚Äôs fairly certain he got bitten at some point‚Äîeither during the night or his mad rush through the forest. The flesh near his eyes is itchy and swollen and, of course, he‚Äôs cut up too. Superficial cuts, but still. Oh, and there‚Äôs the mud. Who knew forests were so fucking filthy?

Grumbling Barty sits down on the bed in front of Reg, letting him inspect his face. ‚ÄúEvan, Snape, Mulciber, Avery, me, but not you?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot me,‚Äù Regulus confirms in a bored tone.

‚ÄúWhy the hell is that?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt there,‚Äù Evan is leaning against the bedpost next to them.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean he wasn‚Äôt there?‚Äù Barty demands. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the one who wiped her bloody memories.‚Äù

When neither of them respond he shakes his head.

‚ÄúHold still,‚Äù Regulus murmurs.

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt just let her get away with this?‚Äù he blusters on. ‚ÄúShe left us naked in the fucking woods. She took my wand!‚Äù which, now that he thinks about it‚Ä¶

As though he can read Barty‚Äôs mind Regulus says; ‚ÄúOn your bed. Along with your clothes. She even folded them.‚Äù

For some reason that makes Barty angrier. ‚ÄúThat Mudblood is gonna fucking regret this.‚Äù

Reg only rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúThis is getting repetitive now. Try to come up with some new material Barty.‚Äù Barty opens his mouth to snap back but Regulus doesn‚Äôt give him the chance. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna cast a cleaning charm first, get some of this mud off you, see what we‚Äôre really working with, okay?‚Äù

Barty glares petulantly back at him. ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo gracious,‚Äù Regulus says flatly before waving his wand and causing a cold wave to wash over Barty. It‚Äôs not as good as old fashioned soap and water but it still feels nice, having the dirt lifted from his skin. Makes him feel more like himself.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that on your face?‚Äù Evan tilts his head, looking down at Barty in confusion. That wouldn‚Äôt be so worrying‚Äîsince Evan is often confused‚Äîexcept that Regulus is looking at him with the same expression.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he demands, eyes bouncing between the pair of them. ‚ÄúWhat the fuck is on my face?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt looks like‚Äî‚Äú and then Evan starts to laugh. ‚ÄúOh my god, priceless.‚Äù

‚ÄúWHAT!‚Äù Thoroughly at his wit‚Äôs end he pushes past his friends and into the bathroom, hands grabbing either side of the sink as he stares into the mirror. He looks a mess‚Äîhis face cut up, hair tangled, but none of that is what Evan is talking about.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck,‚Äù he mutters, turning on the tap and aggressively scrubbing at the bright red lipstick mark on his cheek. ‚ÄúThat psychopath. I swear to Merlin I am gonna end her.‚Äù When water doesn‚Äôt do anything on its own Barty reaches for the soap, lathering his face up before rinsing. But when he dries his face off afterwards the mark is still there, pristine as before. Not even smudged.

Barty squints at it in the mirror before starting the whole process over again. Scrubbing and rinsing, scrubbing and rinsing, scrubbing and rinsing. By the fourth or fifth time the skin of his cheek is red and angry but the lips are still there, taunting him. For some reason the sight of them causes a panic to flutter in Barty‚Äôs chest. What if she did something to him? What if they‚Äôre permanent? What if he never gets them off?

‚ÄúWhat the fuck,‚Äù he repeats, ready to take his nails to it before Regulus appears behind him, grabbing hold of his wrist.

‚ÄúWait,‚Äù he says, lifting his wand and casting a quick diagnostic charm that Barty barely recognizes. Reg frowns for a minute before dropping his wand. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs magic.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo shit,‚Äù Barty snaps. ‚ÄúBut how the hell do I get it off!‚Äù

Regulus only shakes his head. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know‚Äîbut your nails aren‚Äôt going to do it so don‚Äôt go fucking up your face anymore than you already have. You‚Äôll just have to‚Ä¶wait for it to fade.‚Äù

Before Barty can fully grasp the absolutely absurdity of that, Evan appears behind him in the bathroom mirror, taking one look at Barty‚Äôs red marked face and bursting out laughing again.

‚ÄúNot helping Evan,‚Äù Regulus says, sounding weary, but Evan isn‚Äôt cowed.

‚ÄúDude,‚Äù he says, when he finally regains some manner of control over himself. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs fucking branded you.‚Äù

Because he‚Äôs standing in front of the mirror Barty has the privilege of watching his own eyes widen in horror. Evan might be an idiot but he is also, infuriatingly, right. That is exactly what she‚Äôs done.

He turns to Reg. ‚ÄúGet it off.‚Äù

Regulus looks back at him with the same bored expression he almost always wears. ‚ÄúI told you, I can‚Äôt. You‚Äôll just have to wait for it to fade.‚Äù With that he heads back into the main room, getting his books for class.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait for it to fade,‚Äù Barty snarls, following after Regulus with a delighted Evan on his heels.

‚ÄúWell then, by all means,‚Äù Regulus slides the strap of his book bag across his chest. ‚ÄúCarve it off your face,‚Äù his grey eyes run Barty up and down. ‚ÄúYou never know, a scar might give you some character.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck you Regulus.‚Äù

But Reg doesn‚Äôt respond, walking out the door without a backwards glance.

‚ÄúPrick,‚Äù Barty hisses, running a hand through his hair and wincing as the salt of his sweat stings some of the cuts on his hands.

‚ÄúYou reckon she got frisky with you before she dumped you in the forest?‚Äù Evan asks, leaning in to inspect the mark on Barty‚Äôs cheek again.

Barty growls shoving him off, which, predictably, only makes Evan laugh.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be disgusting.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Evan shrugs, grabbing his own bag. ‚ÄúMacdonald‚Äôs pretty hot.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a filthy Mudblood and a fucking psychotic bitch on top of that, what the hell is wrong with you?‚Äù Barty can hear the slightly hysterical edge creeping into his voice but he‚Äôs too far gone to care at this point.

Besides, Evan only blinks back at him. ‚ÄúStill hot.‚Äù And then, at Barty‚Äôs growl of frustration, he claps him on the shoulder. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon dude, we gotta go. It‚Äôs not that bad. Just play it off as a good night.‚Äù

Barty isn‚Äôt even going to touch that.

‚ÄúWhat am I supposed to do about these,‚Äù he gestures to the mess of cuts on his torso. ‚ÄúThe forest turned me into a bloody pincushion.‚Äù

Evan grimaces. ‚ÄúOooh, sorry mate, healing spells really aren‚Äôt my thing. That‚Äôs all Reg,‚Äù after a moment of silence in which Barty seriously considers murdering Evan, the other boy gives his shoulder another squeeze. ‚ÄúWell, see you in class?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a shit friend Evan.‚Äù

The other boy only laughs. ‚ÄúTakes one to know one. Plus, if I‚Äôm late again Sprout will give me detention which is pretty high on my list of things I don‚Äôt want.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolute shit.‚Äù

Evan only waves at him over his shoulder, whistling as he walks out the door. You would never know that only a few hours ago he‚Äôd been cursed and then dumped in a deadly forest half-naked.

Barty tries and fails to fix his own wounds, eventually giving up on healing spells and on going to class. He finds himself, still nearly naked, standing back in front of the bathroom mirror, unable to take his eyes off of the garish lipstick on his cheek.

She put her mouth on him.

The very thought sends a wave of nausea radiating through his whole body. The worst part is, she wanted this. Planned this. Wanted him to be embarrassed. Made a fool of. The faces of the students he‚Äôd passed on his way back to the dorm this morning fill his mind. The snickering and staring. And there will surely be more once people see his cheek.

Barty is not a fucking joke.

He is not an embarrassment.

And he most certainly isn‚Äôt some Mudblood slut‚Äôs play thing.

His fingers curl around the sink, eyes wild with rage.

He‚Äôll show her.

Show all of them.

His father.

Show them the kind of beast he can be.

Chapter End Notes

Hey-o !!!

Mary. Does. Not. Play.

I also love that when Regulus is written from James's perspective it's all "sweet angel baby, love of my life, a cinnamon roll" but when he's written from anyone else's perspective it's all "what a stone cold bitch"

ANYWAY love you all, thank you for sticking with me, we're getting closer to the end-ish (I mean ISH there's sill a bit to go but we're definitely more than halfway there) your comments and kudos are much appreciated!

Chapter 39

Chapter Summary

I hate this too.

Chapter Notes

TW Cancer

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I LILY

Lily doesn‚Äôt let herself get her hopes up when she‚Äôs told that McGongall wants to see her in her office. Doesn‚Äôt let herself think, even for a second, about what it might mean. About why she‚Äôs being summoned. Even after McGonagall tells her, after she leaves Lily alone, kneeling in front of the fireplace, she doesn‚Äôt quite let herself believe it. That she‚Äôs actually going to get to see her mum. Now. Today. Here. Doesn‚Äôt believe it until the moment her face appears in the flames.

‚ÄúMum!‚Äù Lily nearly reaches into the fire. ‚ÄúOh my God, Mum, hi, hello, can you hear me?‚Äù she laughs a little, instantly feeling some of the tension she‚Äôs been carrying around for the pass few weeks lessen just at the sight of her mum‚Äôs face.

She‚Äôs okay,

Lily tells herself.

Look at her, she‚Äôs okay.

‚ÄúHi, Lily? Darling? Goodness,‚Äù her mum laughs too. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll never get used to this.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lily agrees, ‚Äúme neither.‚Äù She really wishes she could hug her. Her mum gives the best hugs. ‚ÄúWhere are you?‚Äù Lily asks instead.

‚ÄúUm‚Ä¶neighbours house, a few blocks down,‚Äù she gives Lily a cheeky smile, lowering her voice. ‚ÄúTurns out they‚Äôre magic too.‚Äù

Lily smiles back. ‚ÄúImagine that.‚Äù

‚ÄúMinistry came by, asked them if they‚Äôd let me use their fireplace‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know what the Wizards call it‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThe Floo mum, it‚Äôs the Floo. Well, the Floo Network.‚Äù

Her mother arches her brow. ‚ÄúThe Flu? Really? Sounds like an illness.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, actually, you‚Äôre right. I never thought about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, anyway, I‚Äôve kicked the poor people out of their living room so I suppose we should keep this short. What‚Äôs going on darling? Why did you need to speak with me so badly?‚Äù

Suddenly Lily feels incredibly silly. How exactly is she meant to explain that she‚Äôs done all this just because of a feeling in her gut that something wasn‚Äôt‚Ä¶right?

‚ÄúI just‚Äî‚Äú she starts then stops, sighing as she crosses her legs and sits more comfortably on the stone floor. ‚ÄúI was worried I guess.‚Äù

Which is when she sees it.

The tension in the corner of her mum‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúWorried?‚Äù she asks, her voice ticking up. ‚ÄúAbout what?‚Äù

Lily‚Äôs stomach starts to squirm, the same unease she felt reading her mum‚Äôs letters coming back.

‚ÄúMum?‚Äù she asks. ‚ÄúWhat is it? What‚Äôs going on?‚Äù She has no idea what could be wrong. She just knows something is. Something her mother doesn‚Äôt want her to know. That she thinks she needs protecting from.

‚ÄúDid something happen to Petunia?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, no, of course not!‚Äù her mother gives a bit of a breathless laugh, eyes not quite meeting Lily‚Äôs. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs fine, we‚Äôre both fine.‚Äù

But Lily only shakes her head. She is an expert in her mother‚Äôs ‚Äúfines.‚Äù She‚Äôs heard this one before. Heard it a hundred times when she stood next to her mum as people asked her how she was after he father's death. Listened to her tell everyone who came by to drop off casseroles and flowers in the months that followed that she was ‚Äúfine.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù she says, not willing to play this game. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do this, just tell me what‚Äôs wrong yeah? I can‚Äôt bear being the last one to find out again.‚Äù

She can see her mother‚Äôs struggle even through the fire. See her trying and failing to keep the polite smile on her face.

‚ÄúOh Lily,‚Äù she says finally, letting out a deep breath. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to worry you, it isn‚Äôt‚Äîit really isn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú her voice cuts out and she looks away for a moment, hand going absentmindedly to the chain around her neck that her wedding ring hangs on. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not worth stressing over.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Lily says slowly, wishing her stomach would stop feeling like it was trying to squeeze itself out of existence. ‚ÄúWell, if you tell me I promise not to stress about it.‚Äù

Her mother gives her a wry smile, though it doesn‚Äôt quite reach her eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure either of us believes that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI already know something‚Äôs up mum,‚Äù she pushes. ‚ÄúI can feel it. I can feel you hiding something from me and it‚Äôs driving me mad. I‚Äôm not a little kid, you can‚Äôt keep me in the dark. It‚Äôs not‚Ä¶helpful.‚Äù

She can see her mother accept the truth of what she‚Äôs saying.

So she waits.

Waits for her to open her mouth again.

Waits for the other shoe to drop.

Whatever it is, she can handle it. She knows she can. If she just knows what they‚Äôre up against she‚Äôll be able to find a way to deal with it. To fight it. It‚Äôs the not knowing that‚Äôs the problem‚Äîlike having her hands tied behind her back. Once she‚Äôs free she‚Äôll be able to find a solution for whatever it is.

‚ÄúI went to the doctor after you left for school,‚Äù Lily just nods, not letting her thoughts run away down the dark hole they so desperately want to. Her mother kisses her teeth. ‚ÄúI have‚Äîthey found a tumour.‚Äù

Lily blinks. ‚ÄúA tumour?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere?‚Äù

Her mother sighs, rubbing the space between her eyes. ‚ÄúMy liver.‚Äù

Lily nods again, like she has any idea what that means. She‚Äôs not even sure why she bothered asking ‚Äúwhere‚Äù when she doesn‚Äôt know anything about tumours. But the liver seems fairly harmless doesn‚Äôt it? What does your liver even do? It‚Äôs not like a brain or a heart or a lung, right? It can‚Äôt be that bad.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Lily says eventually, when her mother doesn‚Äôt go on. ‚ÄúAnd did they‚Äîhave they done‚Äîtests or‚Äîbecause all tumours aren‚Äôt cancer right? I definitely feel like I‚Äôve read that somewhere. Some are just‚Ä¶lumps.‚Äù

Her mother gives her a weak smile. ‚ÄúYes, some are just lumps,‚Äù and then, ‚Äúbut not this one.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

Oh.

For a moment Lily‚Äôs brain seems to stall. It doesn‚Äôt have any thoughts or feelings. Like everything in her has suddenly gone blank.

Oh.

Oh.

Oh.

‚ÄúLily?‚Äù

And then it starts up again. Going a thousand miles an hour.

‚ÄúAlright, that‚Äôs alright. People fight cancer all the time. There are treatments. Are you being treated? How long ago did you find this out? Have you told Petunia? I also think you‚Äôre supposed to start eating a certain way‚Äîlike super healthy or whatever‚Äîand drink water. I mean, I know that drinking water doesn‚Äôt cure cancer but I bet it probably helps. What kind of treatment are you getting? What do the doctors say? What‚Äôs their plan? Are they good doctors? Do we need to get you better doctors? How do you even get better doctors, like where do you go, is there a directory or something? Actually, you don‚Äôt worry about that, I‚Äôll talk to Petunia she‚Äôll know. You just need to rest and eat healthy food and drink water and‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLily, Lily darling stop. Breathe. You need to breathe.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am breathing.‚Äù

‚ÄúLily.‚Äù

She takes in a big gulp of air just to prove to her mum that she is breathing. Except once she starts she can‚Äôt stop, panting like she‚Äôs just run a mile. So maybe she doesn‚Äôt have the breathing thing quite as under control as she thought.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be okay,‚Äù her mother says soothingly, eyes brimming with concern, which isn‚Äôt right at all. She‚Äôs the one with the cancer. She‚Äôs the one who they need to be concerned about.

‚ÄúI know it will be,‚Äù Lily says when she can speak again. ‚ÄúBecause you‚Äôre going to get treated and then you‚Äôre going to get better. Right?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause. Not a long one. But longer than Lily would like.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù her mother says eventually. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm being treated, it‚Äôll help.‚Äù

‚ÄúHelp?‚Äù Lily demands, thankful it‚Äôs her hands that are trembling and not her voice.

Her mother gives her another one of those looks, like Lily‚Äôs the sick one.

‚ÄúLiver cancer is very‚Ä¶serious,‚Äù she says delicately.

‚ÄúWhat does that mean mum?‚Äù Lily asks, her head buzzing as she tries to keep herself in check. If she breaks down her mum will never tell her anything important ever again.

‚ÄúIt just means that there is a chance I might not‚Ä¶‚Äù

She doesn‚Äôt finish that sentence.

Lily is grateful.

She‚Äôs almost certain she couldn‚Äôt bear hearing it.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù the word is out of her mouth before she can think better of it. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not going to happen.‚Äù

‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to happen.‚Äù

Her mother stares at her for a moment, eyes going soft. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she nearly whispers. ‚ÄúOkay darling.‚Äù

¬†

For some mad reason her mum tries to make small talk after that. Tries to tell Lily about Petunia‚Äôs garden and her new lawnmower that practically does all the work itself and some casserole recipe she really likes. By the time they say goodbye Lily is just about ready to explode with all the feelings trapped inside her. All the fear and confusion and helplessness. There are still months before she goes home for the summer and suddenly that feels unbearable.

She‚Äôs still sitting on the floor when McGonagall knocks on the door nearly twenty minutes later.

She‚Äôs meant to go to class but she doesn‚Äôt. The thought never even crosses her mind. Instead she heads straight for the infirmary. Wizards don‚Äôt get sick like Muggles, Lily knows that much. Knows they have spells and potions that Muggles can‚Äôt even dream of. She still remembers the day that Marlene told her and Mary that she‚Äôs never had the flu.

She knows that she should probably take a moment to compose herself, that her heads a mess. Her chest. She has no idea what she‚Äôs actually feeling. She wishes she could ask her mother‚Äôs doctors questions. Wishes she could take her to her appointments. Wishes she could be there for once.

This is just another thing Petunia will hold against me, she can‚Äôt help but think.

Everything in her is so muddled she hasn‚Äôt even had time to be angry that her mother was hiding this from her. Was she ever going to tell Lily? I mean, what the hell was she waiting for? She said herself that it‚Äôs serious and she was‚Äîwhat? Just going to keep lying to Lily until she couldn‚Äôt anymore? Until she was in the hospital or dead?

Even thinking that word sends a shock of fear through her. Her mother is not going to die. It isn‚Äôt possible, the universe just doesn‚Äôt work like that, it isn‚Äôt that cruel. It won‚Äôt take both her parents. Not when she still needs them so badly. When she still feels like such a kid.

‚ÄúMiss Evans?‚Äù

Lily‚Äôs head snaps up to find a confused Madam Pomfrey walking towards her. It seems she‚Äôs stormed into the infirmary without realizing it.

‚ÄúAre you alright?‚Äù the older woman asks as she stops in front of her.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîyes, or, no. But I‚Äîcan I speak with you?‚Äù she asks, feeling jittery and shaky and very much like she might be sick.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Pomfrey gestures her towards her office.

‚ÄúMy mother,‚Äù Lily says as soon as the door closes behind them. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs ill and I was wondering if you could help?‚Äù

Pomfrey looks confused for about a second before she recovers. ‚ÄúYour mother?‚Äù she repeats, leaning against the front of her desk, facing Lily. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a Muggle, yes?‚Äù

Lily nods. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs got cancer‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know if Wizards get cancer?‚Äù
Pomfrey shakes her head. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says gently, ‚Äúthey don‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù though the look on Pomfrey‚Äôs face seems to suggest otherwise. ‚ÄúThat means you have a cure for it right? Or some way to prevent it?‚Äù

Pomfrey is eyeing her with a pity that Lily doesn‚Äôt appreciate. ‚ÄúMiss Evans, it seems to me that this is going in an unfortunate direction‚ÄîI cannot treat your mother,‚Äù she says, not unkindly.

Lily doesn‚Äôt even blink. ‚ÄúNo, that‚Äôs okay. I can take her to the hospital in London. There‚Äôs a wizard hospital there right? St. Mu‚Äîu‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMungo‚Äôs, yes,‚Äù Pomfrey mercifully supplies for her.

Lily nods. ‚ÄúRight, yeah. Would you mind giving me their address?‚Äù She starts shuffling through her book bag looking for a spare piece of parchment and a quill.

‚ÄúMiss Evans,‚Äù Lily ignores her, still riffling through her bag. ‚ÄúLily,‚Äù Madam Pomfrey tries. ‚ÄúThey won‚Äôt be able to treat your mother in London either.‚Äù

Lily freezes, willing herself not to lose it, to remain calm as she looks back up at the older woman who is regarding her with such sadness.

Her mouth has gone dry. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a Muggle.‚Äù

Which isn‚Äôt really an answer, not as far as Lily is concerned.

‚ÄúBut she‚Äôs sick. She‚Äôs sick and you have a way to treat her so I don‚Äôt understand‚Äîit‚Äôs not like she doesn‚Äôt know about the Wizarding world, I‚Äôm her daughter. The Statute of Secrecy doesn‚Äôt extend to family, so I don‚Äôt see why I can‚Äôt bring her to the hospital?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry, really I am, but we cannot treat Muggles.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut why?‚Äù her voice cracks, and suddenly Lily feels like she‚Äôs five years old. Or twelve. asking her mother why she can‚Äôt come home. Why she can‚Äôt say goodbye to her dad. Why they didn‚Äôt come get her.

‚ÄúAre Muggles‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know‚Äîphysically different somehow?‚Äù Lily demands before Pomfrey can answer her question.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre legally different.‚Äù

Lily blinks.

Then again.

And again.

And suddenly her fear and sadness morph into something else.

Anger.

‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs fucking bullshit.‚Äù

Madam Pomfrey doesn‚Äôt correct her. In hindsight, Lily really ought to be grateful she doesn‚Äôt lose house points or get detention but she isn‚Äôt thinking clearly enough.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure your mother‚Äôs Muggle doctors will take good care of her.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you have a cure,‚Äù Lily feels like she‚Äôs outside of her body, watching this scene play out. It‚Äôs surreal. She can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs happening. That Madam Pomfrey can stand there and tell her to leave her mother‚Äôs life up to chance because of some antiquated laws.

Biting back her anger and the scream that‚Äôs sitting just behind her teeth, Lily tries again. ‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù if she thought it would make a difference she would get on her knees. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs all I have.‚Äù

But the woman before her doesn‚Äôt waver, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù she says, and Lily thinks she probably means it, which somehow just angers her more.

For a moment Lily just stands there, not sure she can trust herself to move and not break something. The injustice is too great. It sparks against her skin, threatening to light.

‚ÄúHow can you act like you think differently from them, the Death Eaters,‚Äù she says coldly, nails digging into her palms. ‚ÄúWhen you treat us like this?‚Äù

‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú

But she isn‚Äôt interested in a reply. In more excuses or apologies. She throws the door to the office open so forcefully it slams into the wall outside it. She needs to get out. She needs fresh air. She needs something to keep her from feeling like she‚Äôs losing all touch with reality. Her mother can‚Äôt be sick. Madam Pomfrey can‚Äôt be refusing to help. The laws can‚Äôt possibly allow this.

She finds her way outside, to the lawn at the back of the school. She presses her back to the cold stone wall, fingernails chipping as they try to dig into it, to grab hold of something solid. It‚Äôs fucking freezing but it feels good, cooling the sweat on her skin.

Wake up,

She thinks.

Wake up, wake up, wake up.

Because this has to be some sort of nightmare. It has to be.

It‚Äôs childish but all she can focus on is the deep unfairness of it. That this is happening to her. That it‚Äôs happening now. It‚Äôs horrible to wish this on someone else, but she does anyway. She would sacrifice someone else‚Äôs mum to save her own. She‚Äôs never pretended to be a good person.

Hand groping around in her bag her fingers finally wrap around the small tin buried at the bottom. It takes her several tries to light one of the cigarettes inside because she‚Äôs shaking so badly. She pulls on the smoke, hoping for the pathetic comfort it usually provides‚Äîclosing her eyes and focusing on the smell. But it rings hollow today. Losing her dad was the worst thing that ever happened to her and she never wants to feel that again. Doesn‚Äôt think she‚Äôll survive another hole in her chest.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù she throws the cigarette onto the half-frozen ground, bringing her hands to her face as she slowly sinks to the ground, snow soaking her uniform. She barely feels it. Nothing is helping. She can‚Äôt think. She doesn‚Äôt know what to do. Should she leave? Can she? Fuck, she‚Äôs sixteen bloody years old and she doesn‚Äôt even know how to get home from school. Does the Hogwarts Express run every day? Is it just for students? Is it a public train? Her nails dig into her scalp.

‚ÄúLily?‚Äù

She doesn‚Äôt look up. Doesn‚Äôt have the energy to act like she isn‚Äôt having a fucking breakdown right now.

‚ÄúHey‚ÄîLily, you alright?‚Äù

Someone kneels down in front of her, warm hands on her knees. The touch is steady. The most settling thing she‚Äôs felt all morning.

‚ÄúHey?‚Äù James Potter‚Äîbecause of-bloody-course it‚Äôs James Potter‚Äîsays softly.

Lily sniffles, dropping her hands away from her face and finding him across from her, crouched in the snow. His eyes swell with concern and she has the ridiculous desire to fall into him. To be held.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù she finally manages, her voice a car wreck. Mangled and burning and stranded at the side of the road.

He squeezes her knees because he‚Äôs still holding them, though she can‚Äôt tell if it‚Äôs for her benefit or to keep himself from falling backwards. His eyes search her and she makes no effort to hide anything. She doesn‚Äôt really feel the need with him, as mad as that sounds. Hell, two years ago she‚Äôd have punched him in the face for getting this close to her.

Oh how things change.

‚ÄúWhat can I do?‚Äù James asks eventually. Not ‚Äúare you okay‚Äù not ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs wrong‚Äù but ‚Äúwhat can I do?‚Äù

She nearly kisses him then.

She doesn‚Äôt.

Knows more than she ever has before that he wouldn‚Äôt kiss her back.

But she wants to.

Oh how she wants to.

‚ÄúGet Mary?‚Äù she finally croaks. It‚Äôs a strange request, all things considered‚Äîthey still aren‚Äôt on great terms after New Years. But the only person who could possibly understand this‚Äîany of it‚Äîis Mary. And God, Lily could really use some of her strength right about now.

James doesn‚Äôt question it. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù another squeeze before he gets to his feet. ‚ÄúWill you be okay alone out here?‚Äù he asks.

Lily nods. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt go back in there.‚Äù

He gives her a sympathetic smile, one that‚Äôs a little cracked around the edges in a way that makes Lily realize she‚Äôs not the only one having a bad day.

‚ÄúI know the feeling,‚Äù he says softly, disappearing inside before she can ask him what he means.

¬†

PART II MARY

It isn‚Äôt fear that Mary feels as she watches Barty Crouch make a B-line for her on her way to class. If anything, it‚Äôs closer to excitement. He‚Äôs been hiding from her‚Äîfrom everyone in fact‚Äîwhich was really anticlimactic if she‚Äôs being honest. That charm on his cheek was some of her finest work and she‚Äôs been desperate to see the final product.

Crouch has clearly not been able to come up with the dissolving salve needed to take it off because he‚Äôs currently covered half his face in a beige plaster that calls attention to the luridly pale pigment of his skin. Mary does her best not to laugh, but goodness it is a struggle.

‚ÄúYou bitch,‚Äù he snits when he gets close enough.

Mary doesn‚Äôt stop, barely acknowledges him at all in fact. ‚ÄúGood morning to you too darling,‚Äù she sings as she continues on her way. All things considered, the hallway is rather quiet. Mary‚Äôs running late, most students already in class.

‚ÄúDo you think you‚Äôre going to get away with this?‚Äù he demands, snarling at her heels like an overly excited bulldog.

‚ÄúGet away with what exactly? I‚Äôm sorry, I‚Äôm very busy, you‚Äôll have to be more specific.‚Äù

He tries to grab her but the second his fingers curl around her wrist she twists in a way that yanks his arm uncomfortably in its socket causing Crouch to immediately let go, howling in pain.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses grabbing his shoulder.

Mary clicks her tongue. ‚ÄúNow, now, we mustn‚Äôt touch what isn‚Äôt ours Barty dear. I would have thought you‚Äôd have figured that out by now.‚Äù

He glares daggers at her but doesn‚Äôt try to grab her again, though she doesn‚Äôt miss the way his eyes dart around the hallway, clearly trying to figure out how many witnesses there are and if it‚Äôs safe to pull out his wand.

It‚Äôs not.

Obviously he didn‚Äôt think this through.

Fucking amateur.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to answer for this I hope you know that,‚Äù he threatens her impotently.

Mary arches her brow, rounding the next corner. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I‚Äôm sill not clear on what has you throwing this little bitch fit Barty?‚Äù

‚ÄúTHIS!‚Äù he jabs a shaking finger at his covered cheek.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äú she says knowledgeably. ‚ÄúWell, I can obviously see why you‚Äôd be upset about that but you really can‚Äôt blame your face on me. Probably something you should take up with your parents.‚Äù

Barty actually growls at that, like a dog, ‚ÄúYou dirty fucking Mudblood, you have no idea what you‚Äôve done. I‚Äî‚Äú

But Barty doesn‚Äôt get to finish that particular thought as a hand yanks him back by the collar before slamming him into the stone wall beside them.

‚ÄúGet the fuck away from her!‚Äù James Potter has his hand on Crouch‚Äôs throat, pining him to the wall. The two boys are of equal height but where Barty is lanky and not quite grown into his limbs, James has the sturdy build of someone who plays Quidditch nearly as much as he breathes.

‚ÄúGet off,‚Äù Crouch‚Äôs words are muffled by his clear struggle to breathe. James does not get off, shockingly enough, in fact, what he does is drive his knee into the other boy‚Äôs stomach.

Mary rolls her eyes, more than aware that everyone in the surrounding area has now stopped to stare and no doubt, if this continues, a crowd will gather.

‚ÄúEnough James,‚Äù she says in a bored tone, though she has to admit that she does enjoy watching Crouch squirm.

There‚Äôs something slightly wild about the look in James‚Äôs eyes. Mary can‚Äôt remember the last time she saw him fight someone. James Potter is not, in general, a violent person, though he has been known to let Severus Snape have it from time to time. Mary can‚Äôt say she disapproves.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she snaps again, when he still hasn‚Äôt budged, Crouch‚Äôs face starting to turn a shade of red nearly dark enough to match the lipstick he‚Äôs so desperate to hide. ‚ÄúWho are you fighting for exactly‚Äîme? Or yourself?‚Äù

That finally seems to get through to him, his eyes meeting her‚Äôs for the first time before he blinks‚Äîlike he‚Äôs waking up‚Äîquickly letting go of Crouch. The Slytherin collapses to the ground, on his hands and knees, coughing and hacking.

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Mary shouts at the onlookers surrounding them. ‚ÄúGet lost before I use a permanent sticking charm to attach your tongues to your elbows.‚Äù That seems to do the trick, people quickly averting their eyes and scurrying from the corridor as quickly as their feet can carry them. It‚Äôs the smart choice. Mary doesn‚Äôt make idle threats.

She turns her attention back to the boys in front of her, walking forward and giving Crouch a nudge with her foot.

‚ÄúGet the hell out of my sight before I change my mind and let him squeeze the life from you‚Äôre pathetic excuse for a body.‚Äù Out of the corner of her eye she sees James wince.

Crouch glares up at her, tears in his eyes she‚Äôs sure he wishes weren‚Äôt there, bruises already blooming across his neck. Christ, she can‚Äôt help but think, James really wasn‚Äôt fucking around. For a second she thinks she might have to pull out her wand but then Crouch stumbles to his feet and starts clumsily making his way down the hallway without sparing either of them a second glance. She is under no illusions. He isn‚Äôt done with her.

There are a few moments of tense silence, Mary leaning back against the wall, arms crossed over her chest as she watches James. Watches him try to pull himself back together. He doesn‚Äôt quite seem able to manage it. Eventually he sighs, running a hand through his hair and giving her a sheepish look.

‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù he croaks.

Mary arches her brow. ‚ÄúAre you?‚Äù

His eyes dart away, which is unlike him, James Potter is many things but never meek. Never‚Ä¶skittish. Looking at him the word ‚Äòfrayed‚Äô comes to mind‚Äîlike a piece of fabric without a hem, the strands slowly unravelling with every pull.

‚ÄúYou look like shit,‚Äù she says finally.

James snorts. ‚ÄúFeel it too.‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúNot sleeping?‚Äù

His eyes glance up and then away again. ‚ÄúNo. Not really. Not much,‚Äù he sighs. ‚ÄúUm‚Äîlisten, I actually came to find you. It‚Äôs Lily.‚Äù

Wherever Mary thought this conversation was going it certainly wasn‚Äôt here. She instantly pushes off the wall, standing up straight. ‚ÄúWhat is it? What‚Äôs happened?‚Äù

James only shakes his head. ‚ÄúI dunno, I reckon it has to do with her mum but‚Ä¶I dunno. She‚Äôs having‚Äîshe‚Äôs in rough shape. Outside, against the back wall.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you left her?‚Äù Mary demands indignantly.

‚ÄúShe wanted you.‚Äù

That‚Äôs all Mary needs really, half jogging past James down the hall in the direction of the back of the school.

‚ÄúMary?‚Äù James calls out before she‚Äôs turned the corner.

She looks back at him impatiently, surprised to find him looking so small. James Potter has always been larger than life, even to the people who know him best.

‚ÄúWe should‚ÄîI‚Äîcan we talk? Later?‚Äù

Normally she would snap at him for slowing her down to ask such a stupid question, but she can feel the weight of the words. The weight of everything about him.

‚ÄúYeah James,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWe can talk.‚Äù

And with that she rounds the bend.

¬†

It isn‚Äôt hard to find Lily once she gets outside‚Äîher vibrant red hair standing out against the grey winter around her. She has her knees drawn up, arms wrapped around them, face buried. Mary sits down next to her without hesitating, wet snow seeping through her skirt. Lily must have heard her coming because she doesn‚Äôt jump, doesn‚Äôt even look up, and for a long moment they just sit in silence.

‚ÄúOkay babe,‚Äù Mary says eventually, knocking their shoulders together. ‚ÄúTime to tell me what‚Äôs wrong.‚Äù

It‚Äôs another few seconds before Lily lifts her head, tilting it back against the wall behind her. She sighs, closing her eyes‚Äîsqueezing them shut.

‚ÄúMy mum has cancer.‚Äù

Mary lets that sink in. ‚ÄúThat,‚Äù she says finally, ‚Äúreally fucking sucks.‚Äù

Lily lets out a weak laugh, opening her eyes and turning to look at Mary. Exhausted. Terrified.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt lose her too,‚Äù Lily whispers, like she‚Äôs afraid to say it too loud.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to,‚Äù Mary doesn‚Äôt hesitate. Doesn‚Äôt doubt. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt let it happen.‚Äù

Lily smiles weakly. ‚ÄúI knew you‚Äôd say that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know you do.‚Äù

Mary isn‚Äôt sure what to say to that so instead she waits for Lily. Knows instinctively that there‚Äôs more she has to say‚Äîsomething else sitting on her chest. Sure enough, a few seconds later Lily sighs again, looking back out at the grounds.

‚ÄúI went to Pomfrey.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù Mary asks, genuinely curious. She‚Äôs never thought about it before, what it would mean to combine magic and Muggle medicine.

Lily‚Äôs mouth pulls tight. ‚ÄúShe said she couldn‚Äôt do anything.‚Äù

Mary sits with that, taking in Lily‚Äôs hard expression. ‚ÄúCouldn‚Äôt?‚Äù she asks. ‚ÄúOr wouldn‚Äôt?‚Äù

Lily lets out a breath, blowing the hair from her forehead. There‚Äôs a long pause before she speaks, eyes staring harshly at the sprawling lawn in front of them. ‚ÄúYou know, I only know about my mum because of James?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh yeah?‚Äù Mary says, going with the sudden shift in conversation, letting Lily get out whatever it is she needs to.

‚ÄúHe wrote his mum, pulled strings, got them to set up a Floo connection.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was nice of him,‚Äù Mary says slowly, trying to figure out where this is going.

Lily nods her head. ‚ÄúIt was. And he asked me, you know, to keep him updated on how my mum was even before I knew for sure that anything was wrong. And then‚Äî‚Äú she stops herself, face scrunching as she gathers her thoughts. ‚ÄúAnd then he was here, trying to make sure I was okay, and I‚ÄîI thought about telling him‚Äîhe probably deserved to be told.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one deserve your truth,‚Äù Mary cuts in. ‚ÄúOr your pain. No matter what they‚Äôve done for you.‚Äù

Lily shoots her a dry smile. ‚ÄúMaybe, but it doesn‚Äôt matter, because the thought of having to explain to him that my mum is sick, and that that means something different for Muggles than it does for Wizards‚Äîsomething more serious‚Äîthe thought of explaining to him that the magical world‚Äîthis place that I‚Äôm supposedly a part of‚Äîis refusing to help, the same way they always refuse to help‚Äîit was too exhausting.‚Äù

Mary understands. Of course she does. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why you wanted him to get me, not Marlene or someone else?‚Äù

Lily nods, looking over at her. ‚ÄúIt would never have occurred to someone like James or Marlene that Pomfrey might refuse to help my mum because of‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, culture or tradition or prejudice. They never would have thought to ask whether it was ‚Äòcould‚Äô or ‚Äòwould‚Äô.‚Äù

Yes, Mary understands completely. ‚ÄúWhat did Pomfrey say exactly?‚Äù

Lily lets out a cold laugh. ‚ÄúShe said that, legally, Muggles are different. That magic folk can‚Äôt interfere even though they almost certainly have a cure,‚Äù she sighs. ‚ÄúThe really fucked up thing is that if it was me they‚Äôd have me cured in a few hours. How am I supposed to live with that? How am I supposed to watch my mum get sicker knowing that?‚Äù she sniffles though her eyes remain dry. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do.‚Äù

Mary can‚Äôt help but wonder how Poppy Pomfrey was able to look Lily in the eye and tell her that she would rather let her mother die than help a Muggle. Fuck the law, Mary can‚Äôt help but think, if you can save someone you save them. End of story.

‚ÄúIf they won‚Äôt help us,‚Äù Mary says finally. ‚ÄúThen we help ourselves.‚Äù

Lily looks over at her, a crease between her brows. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

Mary shrugs. ‚ÄúYou think there‚Äôs a cure? Okay, we‚Äôre witches, lets find it.‚Äù

Lily just keeps staring at her, eyes going wide. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre serious?‚Äù she asks after several moments.

Mary shrugs. ‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù she reaches over and squeezes Lily‚Äôs hand. ‚ÄúLets cure cancer.‚Äù

¬†

PART III JAMES

It‚Äôs been a few days since he talked to Sirius on the Quidditch Pitch. Sirius and Remus have returned to the dorm, have started sitting with them again in the Great Hall. In Class. Despite that, James hasn‚Äôt really said much to him. Hasn‚Äôt said much to anyone, skiving off pretty well everything except Quidditch practice. Luckily, Sirius seems to understand, not pushing, not following after him when he disappears into the grounds. Trudging around in the snow.

He keeps looking for answers that aren‚Äôt there.

Or maybe, more than that, he keeps looking for the answers he wants. But no matter how many times he goes over everything, how he phrases it or rearranges it, he can never quite get there.

So he keeps disappearing.

Keeps running away.

Keeps pretending he doesn‚Äôt know what he knows.

Some truths are too heavy to hold.

But running into Crouch and Mary shakes something in him. Reminds him that he can‚Äôt just force the world to look the way he wants it to. That‚Äôs how he ends up here‚Äîstanding outside the Slytherin common room. Waiting.

He keeps to the shadows, making himself inconspicuous. Regulus was alone at dinner so James is fairly certain he‚Äôll walk back alone too. It‚Äôs hard, staying still, fighting the urge to keep running, to keep avoiding this just like he‚Äôs been doing all week. Life is much easier to swallow when you pretend all the things you hate about it don‚Äôt exist.

When Regulus finally does come into view James feels his whole heart lurch, like it‚Äôs trying to rip itself out of his chest. Begging to hand itself over to the boy with the stormy stare and neatly combed curls. The boy who has become so intertwined in his life over the last year that Jame has no idea what to do without him.

Regulus is nearly at the entrance to the common room when James finally manages to force himself to clear his throat, stepping forward. He doesn‚Äôt even have to call out, Reg‚Äîalways on high alert‚Äîinstantly whips around, eyes colliding with James.

‚ÄúCan we talk?‚Äù James asks, watching as Regulus double checks that the hallway is empty.

A moment passes before Regulus nods, immediately taking off in the direction of the seventh floor without uttering a single word. James counts to thirty before following after, shoving his hands in his pockets because they‚Äôre already shaking. He keeps his head down and forces his mind to stay blank. He doesn‚Äôt want to think about what‚Äôs coming. He doesn‚Äôt want to think about what Sirius said to him. Or Mary. He just‚Ä¶doesn‚Äôt want to think.

Regulus is standing at the end of the bed when James enters their room. Watching the door, arms stiff at his sides. James stops, leaving far too much space between them. Now that he‚Äôs here he realizes that he doesn‚Äôt know how to start. Luckily, Regulus saves him from having to.

‚ÄúI see Sirius is back,‚Äù he says, tone neutral. Unreadable.

James blinks. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Regulus is clearly waiting for James to keep going but he can‚Äôt quite manage it. Doesn‚Äôt have any desire to push this moment forward.

‚ÄúYou two have made up then?‚Äù Regulus goes on in the same tone.

‚ÄúYeah, we talked,‚Äù James can‚Äôt take his eyes off of Regulus. It‚Äôs only been a few days since they last spoke but he feels that time like an aching hunger. An unbearable thirst. He needs this‚ÄîReg, them‚Äîhe needs it like he needs to eat and drink and breathe. It fucking hurts how bad he needs it.

‚ÄúAbout me, I‚Äôm assuming,‚Äù Regulus goes on when James, once again, fails to.

He swallows, throat like sandpaper. He wants to cross the space between them, wants to gather Regulus in his arms and take him to bed. Wants to hold him for hours. Weeks. Years.

I wanted a life with you.

Just thinking that almost causes an embarrassing noise to crawl out of his mouth. Like a sob. A whine.

I wanted a life with you.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James says finally, voice rough. ‚ÄúWe talked about you.‚Äù

Regulus nods, face as blank as his voice, taking this all in very academically, the way he always does when he‚Äôs trying to shield himself. Indifference has always been his first line of defence.

‚ÄúWhich means that either you convinced him to change his mind or he convinced you.‚Äù

James feels his stomach threaten to upheave. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that simple.‚Äù

Regulus arches his brow. ‚ÄúI beg to differ.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt talk to me like that,‚Äù James says finally, he means it but it‚Äôs also a diversion. An easy way to put off answering Regulus‚Äôs question. His accusation.

‚ÄúLike what?‚Äù Regulus asks coldly.

James sighs, wishing he could hide things as well as Regulus. Wishing his voice didn‚Äôt sound so raw. ‚ÄúLike I‚Äôm a stranger.‚Äù

Regulus stares him down for several tense moments before eventually shaking his head, hands running through his hair and dislodging his perfectly coiffed curls.

‚ÄúYou wanted to talk James,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúSo talk. Because you‚Äôre not giving me very much to go on right now. It‚Äôs putting me on edge.‚Äù

James nods, because that‚Äôs fair. And then, before he can stop himself, he finds his eyes dropping down to Regulus‚Äôs forearm. It‚Äôs only for a second‚Äîmaybe not even that‚Äîbut, of course, Regulus catches him. His face instantly going pale.

‚ÄúHe told you.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt bother answering.

‚ÄúHe told you,‚Äù Regulus repeats, and James can‚Äôt tell if it‚Äôs anger or pain that Regulus seems to be so desperately fighting against, but it twists up his words, making them sound choked.

‚ÄúWhen did it happen Reg? How long have you‚Äî‚Äú but James isn‚Äôt even sure what the end of that sentence is.

‚ÄúWhy does it matter?‚Äù Regulus bristles, arms crossing over his chest like he‚Äôs trying to hold something in. Protect something.

‚ÄúBecause you kept it from me‚Äîbecause you knew it would matter and you kept it from me. Because it‚Äôs another goddamn lie‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt lie!‚Äù

‚ÄúBullshit Reg, that‚Äôs bullshit. So tell me‚Äîwhen did it happen?‚Äù This is easier at least, than the sadness.

Regulus glares back at him, though James thinks it seems a little half-hearted. ‚ÄúThis summer.‚Äù

James feels his eyes go wide. ‚ÄúThis summer?‚Äù he repeats, reaching out for the back of the chair next to him. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been hiding this for months?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt bother responding.

‚ÄúHoly shit Reg,‚Äù James murmurs, his free hand scrubbing across his face. ‚ÄúWhat the hell were you thinking? How the fuck could you do this?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you want me to say James?‚Äù

And the honest truth is James doesn‚Äôt know. Mostly he wants him to say that it isn‚Äôt real. That Sirius was wrong. Or lying. That Regulus would never.

‚ÄúTell me that you didn‚Äôt want it,‚Äù the words come out of him almost without permission. His voice trembling. ‚ÄúTell me that they had to hold you down, that you fought back.‚Äù

But Regulus only shakes his head. ‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt how this works.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe it is.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. James. No. I chose this,‚Äù he rips his sleeve back, the dark ink on his forearm violent in a way that James never could have imagined. He physically shrinks away from it, feeling something inside him crumble.

‚ÄúI chose it,‚Äù Regulus says again, voice finally breaking‚Äîfinally exposing him.

James just keeps staring at it, like holding his hand over the fire. Every second he can‚Äôt blink the Mark away feels like tearing out his own fucking lungs.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú his voice breaks and he has to wait before he can find it again, hiding at the back of his throat, unwilling to push past his lips. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand,‚Äù he finally forces his eyes up to meet Regulus‚Äôs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fucking horrible Reg, it‚Äôs so fucking‚Äîwhy would you want this? How could you want this?‚Äù

Nothing makes sense. Everything inside him tangling up into a knot he‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôll ever manage to get undone.

A long moment passes before Regulus lets his sleeve fall back into place, arms hanging lifelessly at his sides. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs who I am,‚Äù he says finally.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James says. Begs. ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt. I know it isn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Finally, there‚Äôs something in Regulus's eyes that James can recognize. Pity.

‚ÄúSirius said to me once, that it was better to die than to be one of them,‚Äù he looks away, like he needs a moment to collect himself. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry James,‚Äù he says eventually, when his eyes come back. ‚ÄúReally I am, but I don‚Äôt want to die.‚Äù

Those last words come out as a whisper.

He sounds so young.

James just wants to hold him.

James just wants to scream.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a choice between life and death Reg,‚Äù he finally manages to say, but Regulus remains unmoved.

‚ÄúI think it is though,‚Äù something shifts, a new determination in his eyes. He steps forward, still too far to touch but closer. ‚ÄúListen, I could protect you.‚Äù

James blinks, not quite understanding.

‚ÄúIf you switched sides, I could keep you safe, I know how to survive them. I‚Äôm good at it, I swear.‚Äù

James just keeps staring at him, brain moving too slow. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù and then, two words hit him in the pit of his stomach.

Switch sides.

‚ÄúYou want me to join the Death Eaters?‚Äù he asks numbly.

‚ÄúI know how you feel about them,‚Äù Regulus presses on despite the horror on James‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúBut they have connections, they have power, there‚Äôs a lot to be gained from being connected to them. Security above all else.‚Äù

‚ÄúSecurity,‚Äù James repeats, still not able to comprehend what he‚Äôs hearing. Regulus takes another step forward, hands outstretched.

‚ÄúYour side is going to lose James,‚Äù he says bluntly, eyes begging him to understand. ‚ÄúYou must know that‚Äîthe war has barely started and you‚Äôve already lost. But if you switch sides now, if you let me take care of you, I‚Äôll keep you safe. And then, when it‚Äôs over we can go away somewhere. Somewhere far. From all of it. All of them. Start over. Safe. Alive.‚Äù

I wanted a life with you.

James closes his eyes briefly, unable to look at Regulus. At his pleading hands.

‚ÄúReg,‚Äù the name comes out as a curse. A prayer. A call for mercy.

‚ÄúI know it isn‚Äôt what you want,‚Äù Regulus goes on desperately, like a man treading water. ‚ÄúBut we can do it, I know we can. We can live. If you‚Äôll just let me‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúReg,‚Äù James says again, choking the other boys words on their way up his throat. He opens his eyes, aching at the expression on Regulus‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúWhat would be the point?‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs brows draw together. ‚ÄúThe point?‚Äù he repeats nervously.

‚ÄúIn staying alive just to live in a world run by monsters?‚Äù and then, ‚ÄúIn living just to become monsters ourselves?‚Äù

Regulus stares at him for a moment before his hands fall back to his sides. ‚ÄúTo be together.‚Äù

James very nearly doubles over then, the pain so real he could swear someone has just driven steel through his chest.

‚ÄúRegulus‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre saying no?‚Äù his voice is all business again.

James does his best not to wince. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying no.‚Äù

Regulus nods curtly, taking a step backwards, letting James‚Äôs rejection grow rotten between them. It feels like hours before Regulus speaks again.

‚ÄúThis is it, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

The world is spinning, the floor slipping under James‚Äôs feet. ‚ÄúI think so,‚Äù he whispers.

The pain is a wave that James can see coming a mile away. Feel rumbling in his bones. And he knows he needs to get out of here before it hits. Knows that he won‚Äôt be able to hold it together once it does.

‚ÄúI love you Regulus,‚Äù he just needs to say it. Needs Regulus to understand that, despite everything, it‚Äôs still true. Even if maybe it shouldn‚Äôt be.

‚ÄúJust not enough,‚Äù Regulus says cruelly.

James does his best not to choke on that. ‚ÄúI asked you to come with me. To be with me.‚Äù He had. So many times.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Regulus says. And selfishly James wants to hear it back. One more time. Hell, he‚Äôd even take it in French. He wants Regulus to promise that he still loves him too, even if it hurts, even through the betrayal and the anger. But all he gets is silence. All he sees is a stone wall.

Shaking so bad he can barely walk, James moves for the door. Desperate to leave, feeling the wave of grief edging closer, threatening to send him under.

‚ÄúI hope it‚Äôs worth it,‚Äù Regulus calls out to him when he gets his hand on the doorknob. ‚ÄúBeing a martyr.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt turn around, just pushes forward.

¬†
