He manages to get through the corridors okay. When he cuts his way across the Gryffindor common room he thinks he hears someone call his name but he‚Äôs not really sure. The sound of his own pulse booming too loudly in his ears. Regardless, he doesn‚Äôt look up. Doesn‚Äôt stop.

He struggles up the stairs, glad to find the dorm room empty as he walks right into the bathroom, slamming the door behind him and falling to his knees on the cold tile. He grabs hold of the porcelain toilet bowl and proceeds to vomit up nearly everything he‚Äôs managed to eat today.

His body shivers and sweats and heaves as he falls back against the bathtub, the back of his hand wiping his mouth. He‚Äôs crying‚Äîhe‚Äôs not sure when that started, hopefully after he got into the bathroom. James pulls himself in tight, knees tucked into his chest, arms wrapping around them, face buried. He makes himself small. As small as he possibly can. And then he lets the wave wash over him. This unmanageable pain. He can‚Äôt think anything. Can‚Äôt do anything. He just has to feel. It‚Äôs too strong and too loud for him to do anything else.

There‚Äôs a light knock on the door. ‚ÄúProngs?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt answer.

Can‚Äôt.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù

It‚Äôs Sirius. Of course.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to open the door okay?‚Äù Sirius says eventually. James doesn‚Äôt reply but doesn‚Äôt try to stop him either, listening to the sound of the door being slowly pushed open. If Sirius is surprised by the state he finds James in he doesn‚Äôt let it show, just sits next to him on the floor and wraps his arm around him.

James lets himself be held, the sobs turning vicious now, rattling through him, shaking his ribs.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he finally manages to say. Though he‚Äôs not sure what for. There‚Äôs so much lately. He‚Äôs done everything wrong.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be,‚Äù Sirius says, sounding steady. A few seconds pass and then; ‚Äúfor what it‚Äôs worth, I‚Äôm sorry too.‚Äù

James pushes further into Sirius‚Äôs side wondering when it‚Äôll stop. The crying. The pain. He isn‚Äôt at all certain that it will. This heartbreak feels endless. This heartbreak eats him whole.

¬†

PART IV REMUS

He‚Äôs supposed to be doing coursework but he can‚Äôt concentrate, eyes continuously going to the stairs that lead up to their dormitory. Remus has seen James upset before‚Äîmore than he would like recently‚Äîbut when he walked into the common room tonight the pain on his face was something else.

Sirius barely waited for him to get up the stairs before he was on his feet, chasing after him. Part of Remus wants to follow but mostly he knows that this isn‚Äôt about him‚Äînot the way that it‚Äôs about Sirius and James. He needs to give them space. Let them work through it together.

So he stays behind.

It‚Äôs something he‚Äôs used to.

‚ÄúWhat do you reckon that was about?‚Äù Peter asks after a few minutes, nodding his head in the direction of the dorms.

Remus hesitates, dropping his eyes back down to the parchment in front of him. He keeps his voice low when he answers. ‚ÄúIf I had to guess, I‚Äôd say that James and Regulus have‚Ä¶fallen out.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù Peter hums thoughtfully, causing Remus to look up. ‚ÄúHe seemed pretty‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, pretty gone on him, didn‚Äôt he?‚Äù

Remus feels a small ache in his chest. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah I think he was.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo why end things then?‚Äù

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúWhat makes you so certain it wasn‚Äôt the other way around?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause,‚Äù Peter snorts, ‚Äúif Regulus had broken up with James he‚Äôd have stormed in here with some big plan to win him back. Not‚Äîyou know‚Äînot looking like that,‚Äù he nods again at the stairs. Remus reckons he‚Äôs probably right.

‚ÄúI think it just became too much,‚Äù he says, feeling a little uncomfortable discussing this at all. He doesn‚Äôt want to gossip about their friend. Doesn‚Äôt want to make assumptions about a relationship he absolutely did not understand.

‚ÄúWhat became too much?‚Äù Peter asks, chewing on the end of his quill.

Remus wrinkles his nose‚Äîhe‚Äôs always thought that was a gross habit, but he‚Äôs not Peter‚Äôs mum so he‚Äôs not about to say anything about it.

‚ÄúYou know, the differences between them, the war.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see why the war should matter to them.‚Äù

Remus blinks, momentarily distracted from Peter‚Äôs disgusting quill chewing habit. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîyou don‚Äôt?‚Äù

He shrugs. ‚ÄúWhy would it?‚Äù

‚ÄúUm‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶it kind of‚Ä¶shows a lot about person. How they feel about things like that,‚Äù he squints at the boy across from him. ‚ÄúI mean, how could it not matter?‚Äù

Another shrug, though thankfully this one dislodges the quill from Peter‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúJust politics ‚Äòinnit?‚Äù

Remus stares back at him. ‚ÄúJust politics?‚Äù he repeats slowly. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äîwhat do you mean?‚Äù Something uneasy has started to settle in Remus‚Äôs chest.

‚ÄúWell like, my mum votes Tory and my dad votes Labour but they‚Äôre still married.‚Äù

Remus is thrown for a minute. ‚ÄúYour parents vote in the Muggle elections?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure. They think it‚Äôs fun or something. Like a game. They make bets.‚Äù

Remus opens his mouth and then closes it, deciding that that is a discussion for another time. ‚ÄúThis‚ÄîVoldemort, the Death Eaters‚Äîthey‚Äôre not exactly a bunch of blokes running for office.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, they sort of are,‚Äù Peter says, like that‚Äôs a totally reasonable thing to think. ‚ÄúThey have their supporters, the Ministry has theirs, they‚Äôre both, y‚Äôknow, campaigning.‚Äù

Remus feels like he‚Äôs just fallen into another dimension where the activities of Voldemort are so mundane that they can be considered ‚Äòcampaigning‚Äô. Like planting a sign on someone‚Äôs lawn or holding a rally.

‚ÄúRight, sure, except the Death Eaters ‚Äòcampaign‚Äô by murdering people,‚Äù he expects to see horror in Peter‚Äôs eyes when he realizes what he‚Äôs just said, the comparisons he‚Äôs just made, the way he‚Äôs just dismissed the disgusting things the Death Eaters want. That they‚Äôve done. But he doesn‚Äôt see any of that.

‚ÄúSuppose,‚Äù is all Peter says, before he looks back down at his coursework, teeth once again going to town on his quill. ‚ÄúHey, what‚Äôd you get for number seven?‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Salut beautiful people!

I'm sorry this is late! I was struggling, but we're here.

Also, just to be clear, this is not the end of Reg and James interacting or thinking about each other, they are always the focus of this fic. The "how" just sort of changes.

OKAY thank you love you hope you're having a great day!

Chapter 40

Chapter Summary

There's a lot more making out in this chapter than I think any of us expected.

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

PART I REGULUS

After Patroclus fails to convince Achilles to fight for the Greeks.

After Achilles lets Patroclus face the Trojans without him.

The great warrior tilts his head back and asks the gods to ‚Äúgrant that he may return unharmed.‚Äù

Bring him back to me, he begs them.

Bring him back to me.

Bring him back.

Gods are a Muggle invention and from what Regulus can tell they are rather unreliable when it comes to keeping people safe. But then, he‚Äôs not sure that magic has ever really protected anyone he loves either.

He stares at the door for a long time after James leaves.

Bring him back to me.

Bring him back to me.

Bring him back.

But Wizards don‚Äôt know how to pray. And Regulus doubts the gods would listen even if they did.

¬†

He does manage to make it back to the Slytherin dorms eventually, though he isn‚Äôt really sure how. His thoughts are radio static. Nothing in focus. Nothing clear. At least not until the moment he enters the common room. For some reason the noise‚Äîor the people‚Äîsomething jolts him. Causing things to start becoming real all of the sudden.

He‚Äôs hyperventilating by the time he reaches the bottom of the stairs, grabbing hold of the banister for support. This can‚Äôt happen here. It can‚Äôt. He cannot have a fucking breakdown in the Slytherin common room. He begs his legs to move but they won‚Äôt, tries to slow down his breaths and blink away the blurring in his eyes. He‚Äôs been through so much worse than this. He doesn‚Äôt know why it‚Äôs taking him apart.

‚ÄúHowdy partner,‚Äù says a familiarly cheery voice as Cerci comes down the stairs. Regulus can see her but only barely, partly hidden by the black that‚Äôs started to erase the edges of his vision. If he doesn‚Äôt get his breathing under control he‚Äôs going to faint.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù he hears her say, concerned.

He‚Äôs hoping no one else has noticed him. He‚Äôs not doing anything‚Äîliterally not doing anything‚Äînot crying or shouting or moving. He‚Äôs hoping everyone else is too busy to see him frozen at the bottom of the stairs. To notice the wheezing noises his breath makes as he sucks it in too fast.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Cerci is right in front of him now, voice low, ‚Äúare you okay?‚Äù

She reaches out to touch him and he immediately jerks back. Cerci‚Äôs eyes going wide and he wants to explain to her that he just can‚Äôt bear to be touched right now. That he‚Äôs too raw. But when he opens his mouth, to his horror, all that comes out is a sob. He instantly slams it shut again.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Cerci says, somehow making it sound like this is all perfectly normal. ‚ÄúOkay, it‚Äôs okay. You trying to get to your room?‚Äù

Regulus closes his eyes briefly, so angry with himself, with his body, with his mind, for falling to pieces like this. He‚Äôs meant to be stronger. Meant to be able to put this pain in a box and act as though nothing can touch him. Leave it to James Potter to be too fucking big. To hurt too much for any of Regulus‚Äôs hiding places to hold.

After a moment, teeth gritted, Regulus nods.

‚ÄúOkay, we can do that, why don‚Äôt you just look down, just focus on my feet okay? Just focus on them and nothing else. Just do what they do.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes fly open to find a determined Cerci across from him. After a moment he nods again, dropping his head down to stare at the floor. To focus on her shoes. Her shoes and nothing else, his whole world shrinking.

She takes one step. He takes one step. Miraculously. Thankfully.

Somehow they manage to make it all the way to the door of his room like that. With Regulus just focusing on her shoes, not letting his thoughts stray. Not letting himself pay attention to rest of the world.

‚ÄúHey Reg?‚Äù Cerci says softly‚Äîso softly Regulus wouldn‚Äôt have thought it possible for the human voice to sound like that. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre here?‚Äù she says after they spend several moments standing still, Regulus not lifting his gaze.

When he does finally look at the door he feels the panic return, listening to the sounds of Evan and Barty bickering. He‚Äôll need to get past them. Need to lock himself in the bathroom where he can lose it in peace. He knows it won‚Äôt be that simple of course, that Evan will want to talk to him, because he always wants to talk, and Barty will get growly if he hogs the bathroom for too long. He doesn‚Äôt want to be around either of them but he doesn‚Äôt know where else to go.

‚ÄúGive me a minute,‚Äù Cerci says suddenly, causing Regulus to jump as he looks over at her. But she‚Äôs already moving, pushing through the door into the dorm room and leaving Regulus thoroughly confused.

There‚Äôs silence for a second and then shouting. Regulus can‚Äôt really make out the words, his brain still fuzzy, the sound of static still loud in his ears. After what feels like ages but is probably only ten minutes at most, the door swings open viciously and Barty marches out fuming, not even looking at Regulus as he stalks down the hallway. Following after is a much more content looking Evan, who shoots Regulus a wide grin when he sees him.

‚ÄúGo get her champ,‚Äù he says, clapping Regulus on the shoulder as he passes, causing every atom in Regulus‚Äôs body to scream. Luckily Evan doesn‚Äôt stop, doesn‚Äôt hear the way Regulus starts gasping like he‚Äôs just been held under water.

For some reason he still doesn‚Äôt go inside the room. Probably because his brain is broken. Just stands there in the hallway trying not to collapse. Eventually Cerci comes to the door, opening it wide for him.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù she says, without pity or disgust. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs empty.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt know how she knew what he needed but he can‚Äôt ask, nodding because that seems to be the one form of communication he can manage at the moment. He walks in and quickly sits down on his bed, dropping his head between his knees and taking in big gulps of air.

Inhale.

Exhale.

Inhale.

Exhale.

‚ÄúDo you want me to leave?‚Äù Cerci asks.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus‚Äôs voice surprises him. Not just because it crackles and whines, like he‚Äôs been screaming it raw. But also because of what it says. No. He hadn‚Äôt realized he wanted her here until this moment.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she says softly and he listens to the sound of her walking over to the bed next to him‚ÄîEvan‚Äôs‚Äîand sitting down.

Inhale.

Exhale.

Inhale.

Exhale.

‚ÄúDid you tell them we were going to shag?‚Äù he somehow manages to ask, head still down.

Cerci laughs, it‚Äôs a comforting sound. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúBut I may have heavily implied it. Hope that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

Regulus snorts, sitting up slowly and wiping at his eyes which he finds are frustratingly damp. When he meets Cerci‚Äôs stare there‚Äôs nothing pitying about it and he‚Äôs grateful.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Regulus manages eventually.

Cerci offers him a gentle smile. ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

Inhale.

Exhale.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to tell me,‚Äù Cerci goes on eventually, causing Regulus to grimace. ‚ÄúBut I have to ask, at least once; what happened?‚Äù

Inhale.

Exhale.

Regulus looks down at his hands, shaking where they grip his knees. He hates how inescapable this pain feels. There‚Äôs nothing he can do to remedy it, to dull it. Wherever he goes, however much time passes, he knows it will always hurt, because James will always be gone. Because Regulus will always be alone.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù the urgency in Cerci‚Äôs voice wakes him up and he finds her kneeling on the floor, hands hovering close to him but not touching.

‚ÄúRegulus breathe.‚Äù

What?

‚ÄúRegulus, in and out, with me, come on.‚Äù

It‚Äôs only then. When he tries to speak, that he realizes he‚Äôs started hyperventilating again. Fucking of course he has.

‚ÄúIn and out,‚Äù Cerci repeats, making her own breaths big and over exaggerated. He has a brief flash of someone else kneeling in front of him. In a corridor. Begging him to breathe.

Regulus, I need you to breathe okay?

Okay, it‚Äôs okay, you‚Äôre okay.

So, it turns out my mum knows about Patroclus and Achilles.

Funny, he always thought his mother would be the one to break him. Or Bellatrix. Maybe even Lucius. But he should have known. Because of course. Of course it‚Äôs James-fucking-Potter. With his warm hands and sunrise laugh and heart that lives on his goddamn sleeve. Like an idiot. Like a work of art.

‚ÄúRegulus? Regulus listen to me, you‚Äôre okay, everything is okay. Just breathe.‚Äù

Which isn‚Äôt true.

Nothing is okay.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to need you to help me out here, I don‚Äôt know what to do.‚Äù

He should have told her to leave. This isn‚Äôt her problem and he hates that she‚Äôs seeing him like this.

‚ÄúTalk,‚Äù his voice is barely there, forced out on an exhale that shakes and trembles and immediately gets sucked back in.

‚ÄúTalk?‚Äù she repeats, and he really hopes she doesn‚Äôt need more instruction because he can‚Äôt give her any. ‚ÄúOkay, okay, I can talk. I‚Äôm like pro at talking.‚Äù

Anyway, I started reading the Iliad, which I thought was going to be a bit more, you know, soppy, but it‚Äôs mostly a bunch of guys killing each other. Not that I‚Äôm complaining.

‚ÄúSo my sister is getting married‚Äîor she‚Äôs engaged‚Äîwhatever, my point is, a wedding is eminent. And I am absolutely dreading it. First of all her fianc√© is like‚Äî‚Äú she makes a retching noise. ‚ÄúY‚Äôknow?‚Äù

And like, obviously I‚Äôm all for the Greeks, but, I‚Äôve got to be honest, I kinda like Hector.

‚ÄúI mean, she‚Äôs always had terrible taste in men but at least she wasn‚Äôt marrying any of them. Now I‚Äôm supposed to call this guy my brother? How weird is that? He is taking her name though, because, well, you know, being a Greengrass is kind of a whole thing‚Äîanyway, I told her I thought it was very progressive of them, the man taking the woman‚Äôs last name, and I swear Cereus almost set me on fire with her eyes.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour sister‚Äôs name is Cereus?‚Äù

Cerci beams at him, at the sound of the wretched thing his voice currently is. ‚ÄúOh hey.‚Äù

There you are.

Regulus swallows around the bile in his throat and forces his hands to let go of his knees. He‚Äôs almost certain his nails have poked holes in his trousers.

‚ÄúYour parents named you Cereus and Cerci?‚Äù he asks again, clearing his throat. Trying to focus on here and now and this. He can handle this. This moment. Even if he can‚Äôt bear the thought of anything that‚Äôs supposed to come after it.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre one to talk,‚Äù she teases, ‚ÄúYour parents named you Regulus and Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre stars, it‚Äôs tradition,‚Äù he says, without much conviction, flexing his fingers in an attempt to stop them aching. ‚ÄúWhat kind of name is Cereus?‚Äù

Cerci laughs. ‚ÄúUm‚Ä¶I think it‚Äôs a kind of cactus?‚Äù

Regulus can‚Äôt help but smile at that, even if it is a little shaky. ‚ÄúSo you get named after one of the most powerful witches in history and your sister gets named after‚Ä¶a cactus?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was their first born, they‚Äôd never named anything before!‚Äù

‚ÄúThey had nine months to figure something out and the best thing they could come up with was Cereus?‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Cerci says, trying to hold in another laugh. ‚ÄúI really think you have to let this go.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think your sister should sue your parents for emotional trauma, giving her a name like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh my God, you‚Äôre such a snob.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have standards, there‚Äôs difference.‚Äù

Cerci rolls her eyes, sitting back and stretching her legs out in front of her. The playfulness in her eyes dims. ‚ÄúAre you‚Äîare you okay?‚Äù

Regulus almost laughs, she must see it in his eyes because she tries again.

‚ÄúWhat I mean is‚Äî‚Äú he can see her trying to figure out the best way to phrase this. He can‚Äôt blame her considering her last question sent him spiralling into a panic attack, like some weak pathetic child. ‚ÄúDid someone hurt you?‚Äù

The ridiculous thing is, he nearly says yes. Because he aches. Because he feels hurt.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú he stops, swallowing around the lump in his throat and forcing memories back with every ounce of mental strength he still possesses. ‚ÄúActually, I think I‚Äôm the one who hurt someone.‚Äù

Cerci nods. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the worst feeling.‚Äù

For a second he almost asks her how she could possibly know, because the idea of Cerci hurting anyone seems ridiculous. But he stops himself. Certain that hearing about what she considers hurt would only make him feel worse.

‚ÄúCan you apologize?‚Äù

He smiles ruefully. ‚ÄúNo. Or I could, but it wouldn‚Äôt change anything.‚Äù

She chews on her bottom lip, using more of a filter than she ever has before. ‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù she asks finally. ‚ÄúI mean, why won‚Äôt it change anything?‚Äù

Regulus lets out a deep breath, resisting the urge to start digging his nails back into his skin. ‚ÄúBecause I am sorry, but I‚Äôm not going to‚Ä¶to stop doing the thing that hurts them. I can‚Äôt. So in the end, it doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

Cerci nods like she understands, maybe she does. ‚ÄúThat sounds‚Ä¶really hard.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Regulus swallows, not prepared for the weakness that bleeds out through that one word.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre important to you, this person?‚Äù

I love you Regulus.

Regulus had always expected James to walk away once he saw the Mark. Had counted on it in fact. To save James from Regulus‚Äôs selfishness. To do for him what he couldn‚Äôt seem to do once he was in the same room as James. Once he could feel him and hear him and touch him. But what he hadn‚Äôt expected was that.

I love you Regulus.

He had been certain there would be more anger. Betrayal. Certain that James would hate him, look at him with disgust the way Sirius sometimes does. But no.

I love you Regulus.

He‚Äôs certain that if you crack open his chest right now you‚Äôll find those words feasting on his heart.

‚ÄúYes, he‚Äôs important,‚Äù Regulus finally manages to whisper.

For a long moment‚Äîespecially for Cerci‚Äîneither of them speak, and then Cerci shuffles, moving so that her back is against Regulus‚Äôs bed, her shoulder lightly pressing into his leg. The whisper of a touch. So he can feel her without her having to lay her hands on him‚Äîhands that grope and grab and take. Instead he gets to just feel‚Ä¶ her. He exhales shakily before pressing back.

‚ÄúDo you want me to stay for a bit?‚Äù she asks after a while.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says, even though he feels embarrassed.

‚ÄúDo you want me to keep talking?‚Äù

He lets out a breath that might have been a laugh if he had the energy, ‚ÄúYes, tell me more about your terribly named sister and her horrible fianc√©.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe really is horrible,‚Äù she says sincerely. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîand I haven‚Äôt even started telling you about the flower drama!‚Äù

¬†

PART II MARLENE

The first time Marlene kisses Dorcas Meadowes she‚Äôs drunk. Actually, they‚Äôre both drunk. Which Marlene thinks is probably a good thing. It gives them an excuse. A way out. Drunk girls kiss all the time. It doesn‚Äôt mean anything.

And obviously this kiss doesn‚Äôt mean anything.

Right?

It can‚Äôt.

Not even when Dorcas‚Äôs hand slides up her neck and cradles her face, or when Marlene tangles her fingers in the other girl‚Äôs hair, or when that noise escapes Marlene‚Äôs mouth.

They‚Äôre drunk.

Alcohol makes people do stupid things.

Things they regret.

The problem is, she never does regret that kiss.

The problem is, the second time they‚Äôre both dead sober.

Marlene isn‚Äôt even sure how it happens. They‚Äôre in Hogsmeade talking about Quidditch. About books. About music. And it‚Äôs so easy. And terrifying. And exciting. Every time she makes Dorcas laugh it feels like a hundred bubbles are filling up her stomach. Like she‚Äôs made out of air.

This time it‚Äôs Dorcas. Dorcas who nudges her subtly into the alley between Gladrags and Scrivenshaft‚Äôs. Who crowds her against the brick wall, one hand by her head, the other on her hip. Who kisses her. Who tugs her bottom lip between her teeth and presses her warm body against Marlene. Who licks her way into Marlene‚Äôs mouth.

They don‚Äôt talk.

Not before. Not during. Not after.

Well, I mean, of course they talk. About Quidditch and books and music. But not about kissing. Never about kissing.

Marlene starts to think that maybe the ‚Äúnot talking‚Äù is kind of like the alcohol. If they don‚Äôt name it than it doesn‚Äôt matter.

Then it doesn‚Äôt mean anything.

Right?

The third time is the worst, because Marlene is almost positive she does something wrong.

It‚Äôs late, she‚Äôs in the library, sitting at the back, furiously trying to figure out which bloody potion uses African Sea Salt‚Äîwhen Dorcas drops into the chair next to her.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Dorcas says.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Marlene replies, feeling the press of Dorcas‚Äôs thigh against her own under the table.

‚ÄúLibrary‚Äôs about to close you know,‚Äù she says, ducking her head a little bit so she can catch Marlene‚Äôs eye.

‚ÄúI still have an hour, and if I head back to the common room I‚Äôll never get anything done. That place is a zoo.‚Äù

Dorcas smiles at her. ‚ÄúYou love it.‚Äù

Marlene can‚Äôt help but smile back, cheeks pinking. ‚ÄúWell, yeah, obviously. But not right now when I‚Äôm trying to catch up on my coursework.‚Äù

‚ÄúCome on Mar,‚Äù she jostles their legs under the table sending sparks of heat through Marlene‚Äôs whole body. Marlene has touched people before. Boys. Not like‚Äînot a lot‚Äînot, you know, not like Mary. But she has touched boys. They just always felt like bodies. And Dorcas feels like magic.

‚ÄúI know for a fact that‚Äôs not due until the end of the week. You can call it a night.‚Äù

Marlene turns to look at her, not realizing how close they are, not realizing that Dorcas has leaned in. She has the most beautiful brown eyes, flecked with gold in the sunlight, her skin dark as Marlene‚Äôs is light. She smells like lavender‚Äîsomething spicy and sweet. She smells like something that Marlene wants to taste.

And it‚Äôs so stupid because they‚Äôre in the library and sure it‚Äôs late and empty but still, anyone could walk by. But Dorcas always makes Marlene‚Äôs head go fuzzy, especially when she‚Äôs this close. When she‚Äôs touching her.

So Marlene leans forward, prepared to be stopped, to be pushed away, but that doesn‚Äôt happen. Dorcas welcomes her kiss with a pleased hum, nearly pulling Marlene into her lap as she tugs on her jumper. This is a supernova kiss‚Äîa universe ending, stars exploding, every atom in Marlene‚Äôs body dancing‚Äîkiss. She forgets about the library. The danger. She wants to stay here forever. She wants to live between Dorcas‚Äôs arms.

‚ÄúWait‚Äîwait,‚Äù Dorcas says breathily, pushing back just far enough that their noses brush.

Marlene blinks still in a daze.

‚ÄúWhat are we doing?‚Äù

Marlene blinks some more. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù she asks.

‚ÄúThis,‚Äù Dorcas waves a finger between them. ‚ÄúWhat is this?‚Äù

Marlene has no idea how to answer that question. She thought they weren‚Äôt talking about it. Thought that was what Dorcas wanted. She still can‚Äôt really read her. Does she not want Marlene to kiss her? She‚Äôd seemed pretty into it but‚Ä¶

‚ÄúUm‚Ä¶I‚Ä¶this is fun?‚Äù she curses herself almost as soon as the words come out of her mouth. Fun? FUN. But what else is she supposed to say?

Well, apparently something else, because Dorcas almost immediately pulls away.

‚ÄúFun?‚Äù she asks, expression guarded.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîno?‚Äù Marlene tries, not at all helping her cause.

Dorcas arches her brow. ‚ÄúNo?‚Äù That definitely was also the wrong thing to say.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äîwhat do you want me to say?‚Äù and she doesn‚Äôt mean it to come out sounding so‚Ä¶rude. It‚Äôs just that she really doesn‚Äôt know. How is she supposed to know?! They‚Äôve never talked about kissing! Never talked about a ‚Äúthis‚Äù or a ‚Äúwe‚Äù.

There‚Äôs a pause that goes on for far too long. ‚ÄúNever mind,‚Äù Dorcas says eventually, fully getting out of her chair.

‚ÄúHey‚Äîwoah‚Äîokay wait, that came out wrong,‚Äù probably, maybe, I mean, she‚Äôs still not exactly sure what answer Dorcas is looking for.

‚ÄúNah, you‚Äôre alright Mar,‚Äù Dorcas gives her a tight smile. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you in class yeah?‚Äù she doesn‚Äôt wait for an answer, walking through the bookshelves towards the exit in record time.

For a minute all Marlene can do is sit and stare at the spot where Dorcas had been sitting, where Dorcas had been KISSING her, the whole interaction giving her such whiplash that she has absolutely no idea what to do with it.

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù she hisses under her breath. ‚ÄúI really fucked that up, didn‚Äôt I?‚Äù

Predictably, her potions coursework does not respond.

¬†

It‚Äôs only about twenty minutes later that Marlene gives up and heads back to the dorms. She can‚Äôt concentrate, her brain running through her interaction with Dorcas over and over again in excruciating detail. She cringes harder with each rewatch.

She tries to catch Dorcas‚Äôs eye when she sees her in the common room but Dorcas either doesn‚Äôt know she‚Äôs there or is trying very hard to avoid looking at her, eventually turning her back to Marlene completely. Marlene sighs before giving up and heading to her room.

She wishes she could ask Mary for advice but of course she can‚Äôt. Even if she pretended it was a boy with Mary‚Äôs sleuthing skills and her many connections within the Hogwarts gossip channels she‚Äôd figure out Marlene was lying in no time and then it wouldn‚Äôt be long before she would figure out what was really going on. Marlene isn‚Äôt ready for that, especially considering SHE isn‚Äôt really sure what‚Äôs going on.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù she says flatly as she walks into the dorm room, dropping her book bag at the foot of her bed and collapsing onto it face first.

Mary and Lily are both there, sitting on Mary‚Äôs bed, books spread around them, their voices low. Which, actually, now that Marlene thinks about it, is a little odd. They haven‚Äôt been spending much time together since New Year‚Äôs. Neither of them will say what happened but Marlene has a sneaking suspicion it somehow involves James Potter. James who is a mess all on his own. Marlene doesn‚Äôt even know where to begin with that boy.

After a few more minutes of listening to them whisper Marlene props herself up on her elbows and looks over at the bed across from her.

‚ÄúI guess you guys made up then?‚Äù she asks.

‚ÄúMade up what? Why are you talking gibberish Marlene?‚Äù Mary says with the flourish of her hand, eyes not leaving the page in front of her.

‚ÄúJeez Mary, must you be such a brat?‚Äù Lily asks.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Mary says without hesitating, earning her an eye roll from Lily before she turns her attention to Marlene. ‚ÄúBelieve it or not, we actually have worked things out.‚Äù

Marlene bites back a smile. ‚ÄúGood, the tension in here was getting a little bit much.‚Äù

Mary scoffs but still doesn‚Äôt look up. Marlene leans over trying to figure out what they‚Äôre working on but she can‚Äôt recognize any of the books surrounding them.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you guys doing?‚Äù she asks, scooting closer to the edge of her bed.

There‚Äôs a pause, Mary and Lily exchanging a quick glance, communicating something Marlene doesn‚Äôt understand.

‚ÄúMy mum,‚Äù Lily says eventually. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs sick.‚Äù

Marlene feels her eyes go wide. ‚ÄúSick? What do you mean?‚Äù Of course she knows what sick means, but the way her friends are acting she can‚Äôt help but feel that there‚Äôs more. That there‚Äôs something she‚Äôs missing.

‚ÄúShe has cancer,‚Äù Lily goes on.

‚ÄúCancer?‚Äù okay, now Marlene is really lost. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very serious Muggle illness that we‚Äôre currently trying to figure out the cure for,‚Äù Mary answers, slightly more briskly than Lily.

Marlene isn‚Äôt sure if that‚Äôs a joke or not, though judging by both their expressions Mary is being very serious.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to try to cure Lily‚Äôs mum?‚Äù Marlene repeats, wondering if either of them will hear how mad it sounds when it‚Äôs repeated back to them. ‚ÄúNo offence but neither of you are exactly mediwizards.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt put us in a box,‚Äù Mary sing-songs, closing the book in her lap and reaching for a new one.

‚ÄúWe know it‚Äôs a long shot,‚Äù Lily says, looking tired. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs something. Better than sitting around and‚Ä¶waiting.‚Äù

There is a heaviness in her normally lively friend that makes something in Marlene ache. ‚ÄúHave you talked to Madam Pomfrey?‚Äù

‚ÄúHa!‚Äù Mary scoffs from beside her.

‚ÄúWhat Mary means is yes, I talked to her,‚Äù Lily runs a hand over her face, letting out a deep breath. ‚ÄúShe basically said there‚Äôs nothing she can do because my mum is a Muggle.‚Äù

‚ÄúBollocks,‚Äù Marlene hisses.

Lily offers her a weak smile. ‚ÄúPretty much, yeah.‚Äù

Marlene looks back down at the plethora of books surrounding her friends, before getting up and joining them on Mary‚Äôs bed, pulling one of the books towards herself. Both Lily and Mary look up at her.

‚ÄúWhat? You really think I‚Äôm not going to help? Give me a break.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLily, don‚Äôt be stupid, of course she does,‚Äù Mary says, before sending Marlene a wink.

When meeting Lily‚Äôs exasperated stare all Marlene can do is shrug, smiling a little. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs right.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Lily says softly, causing Marlene to reach out, grabbing hold of her hand and giving it a squeeze.

‚ÄúOf course, now, what are we looking for exactly?‚Äù

¬†

Trying to help Lily‚Äôs mum is a good distraction from the fact that Dorcas is currently avoiding her. Not that Marlene is happy that Lily‚Äôs mum is sick, obviously. But, as things are, it helps keep her mind off things. Sort of. Mostly.

‚ÄúOi? Earth to McKinnon?‚Äù

Marlene jolts upright, tearing her eyes away from where Dorcas is currently sitting across the room.

‚ÄúSorry, what?‚Äù

Mary arches her brow. ‚ÄúSpace cadet much?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Marlene repeats. ‚ÄúI think Quidditch practice really took it out of me this morning.‚Äù

Mary gives her a skeptical once over. ‚ÄúMmhm. Me and Lily are heading to the library after supper, you coming?‚Äù

Currently they‚Äôre sitting in the common room, Lily off doing whatever it is that Prefects do‚Äîprobably giving some poor sucker a detention.

‚ÄúUh, sure, yeah, totally.‚Äù

Mary eyes her again. ‚ÄúYou sure you‚Äôre okay?‚Äù

It takes every ounce of her self-control not to look back at Dorcas. ‚ÄúDefinitely.‚Äù

Marlene makes up some excuse about homework to stay behind when Mary eventually packs up and heads down to the Great Hall. She just needs some time to think. It‚Äôs purely a coincidence that Dorcas is now also sitting alone. The common room significantly emptier what with most people heading down for supper.

After a solid ten minutes of pretending she‚Äôs doing work, Marlene eventually gets up the courage to talk to her.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù she says lamely, clutching her half-finished essay to her chest, quill stuck through the bun at the back of her head. She probably looks mad.

Dorcas glances up and gives her a polite smile. Polite. Like they‚Äôre acquaintances. Merlin Marlene really fucked up.

‚ÄúHey Mar,‚Äù Dorcas says, before turning her attention back to her textbook.

‚ÄúEr‚Ä¶‚Äù she really, really, didn‚Äôt think this through. ‚ÄúCan‚Äîer‚ÄîI join you?‚Äù

Another polite smile. ‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

Marlene does her best not to grimace. This might be the most smiley cold shoulder she‚Äôs ever gotten. For a second she considers taking it back and just walking out of the common room, but she‚Äôs a Gryffindor goddamnit, so instead she sits down, spreading her homework out onto the table like she‚Äôs actually going to be able to concentrate on anything.

The properties of the ginger root, she begins to read, foot bouncing nervously under the table as she remains too aware of Dorcas sitting next to her.

The properties of the ginger root‚Äîfuck, no, she just read that. She blinks and tries again.

The properties of the ginger root are not properly activated unless the ingredient is sliced from right to left at a 90 degree angle‚Äî

Dorcas shifts beside her, not touching, not like before when they would sit with their legs pressed together or their feet or, on very rare and wonderful occasions, their pinky fingers. If anything, Marlene is pretty sure she shifts away.

The properties of the ginger root‚Äîoh goddamnit.

She sighs, sitting back and running a hand over her face. Traitorous eyes going immediately to Dorcas‚Äôs neck, the spot where her hair curls into little wisps just at the nape and around her ears. Marlene has never kissed her there but she desperately wants to.

‚ÄúDorcas,‚Äù she says eventually, unable to bear sitting in silence anymore.

‚ÄúHmm?‚Äù Dorcas doesn‚Äôt look up from her textbook, though Marlene is fairly certain that her eyes aren‚Äôt moving.

‚ÄúI‚ÄîI‚Äôm really sorry okay?‚Äù

She can see Dorcas shift but the other girl still doesn‚Äôt look around. ‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù

Marlene opens her mouth but nothing comes out. She just doesn‚Äôt know, that‚Äôs the thing. She doesn‚Äôt know what she did. She doesn‚Äôt know how to do any of this. She‚Äôs never tried before. Never had a reason to. She curses herself for tuning out Mary every time she started flirting with a boy‚Äîthose were valuable skills she could have been learning.

When the silence stretches on for too long Dorcas sighs. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry about it Mar, okay? We just‚Ä¶want different things.‚Äù She starts gathering up her books.

‚ÄúWe do?‚Äù Marlene asks, because she‚Äôs not at all certain that‚Äôs true. Especially considering the only thing she really wants is Dorcas.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Dorcas slips her book bag over her shoulder. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna head down to dinner, I‚Äôll see you,‚Äù she doesn‚Äôt make eye contact with Marlene as she leaves the common room‚ÄîMarlene who‚Äôs mouth is desperately opening and closing like a fish out of water, trying to find the words.

‚ÄúWhat do you want though?‚Äù she asks too late, the empty common room echoing the question back to her.

¬†

‚ÄúOw!‚Äù Marlene grumbles the next morning when Mary very rudely punches her in the shoulder. Rudely and undeservedly. She‚Äôs sitting on the bench in the Quidditch locker room, half dressed in her uniform and half still in her kit.

Mary drops down into the spot next to her fully dressed. It‚Äôs only then that Marlene realizes they‚Äôre alone.

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôd everyone go?‚Äù she asks, looking about.

Mary arches her brow. ‚ÄúBreakfast. Now spill.‚Äù

Marlene blinks. ‚ÄúSpill? Spill what?‚Äù

Mary waves her hand about in an exasperated motion. ‚ÄúWhatever it is that‚Äôs been causing you to bloody disassociate the last few days.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äîwhat?‚Äîwhat are you talking about?‚Äù she wishes she sounded more indignant and less flustered. She starts trying to finish getting changed.

‚ÄúUh-huh, come on Mar,‚Äù Mary pinches her side causing Marlene to yelp and jump away, sending Mary a vicious glare. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not fooling anyone. Especially not me.‚Äù

It‚Äôs true that Mary is somewhat inconveniently observant. Always has been. It‚Äôs like her evil superpower or something. Marlene cautiously returns to the spot in front of her locker.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nothing just stress. School.‚Äù

‚ÄúStress? Stress about what?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Marlene says, sounding a bit like a pouty child even to herself. ‚ÄúJust stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúStuff?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúStuff Marlene?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I said.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

Marlene slams her locker shut, rounding on her best friend. ‚ÄúWhat do you want from me Mary?‚Äù

Predictably, Mary is completely unfazed. ‚ÄúHow about the truth?‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay fine, the truth‚Äîthe truth is that there‚Äôs‚Äîthere‚Äôs this person.‚Äù She brings her hands up to her face already able to feel it heating up with embarrassment.

‚ÄúA person? A person I know?‚Äù

She drops her hands to give Mary a flat stare. ‚ÄúA person Mary.‚Äù

The other girl holds up her hands in surrender. ‚ÄúOkay, okay. There‚Äôs a person?‚Äù

Marlene nods before she starts to pace, unable to have this conversation while standing still and looking Mary in the eye. Slightly horrified with herself for having this conversation at all.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a person and I think I really messed things up but I don‚Äôt know how.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Mary says slowly. ‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know!‚Äù

‚ÄúStart from the beginning.‚Äù

Marlene looks at her briefly. ‚ÄúThe beginning?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe beginning of the problem,‚Äù Mary clarifies.

Marlene huffs, ‚ÄúWell, I mean, we were kissing‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAh, so this is a person we kiss.‚Äù

Marlene shoots her another look that has Mary raising her hands in surrender, ‚ÄúSorry, go on.‚Äù

Marlene‚Äôs cheeks are blushing furiously at this point and she can only hope that her freckles help to hide that fact at least a little. ‚ÄúSo we were kissing and then‚Äîthen they were all ‚ÄúWhat are we doing?‚Äù and I was all ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù because I thought what we were doing was pretty obvious you know, like we were kissing, that‚Äôs what we were doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Mary says, and Marlene pretends that she can‚Äôt hear her holding back a laugh.

‚ÄúAnd then they were all ‚ÄúWhat is this?‚Äù and I‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt know what to say,‚Äù Marlene admits pathetically.

‚ÄúDid you tell them that?‚Äù Mary asks, causing Marlene to let out a whine before covering her eyes with her hands.

‚ÄúNo! Was that an option? I didn‚Äôt know that was an option!‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre always allowed to tell someone when you don‚Äôt know the answer, especially when it‚Äôs a person you kiss,‚Äù Mary says, like it‚Äôs simple, which to her it probably is. To everyone other than Marlene it probably is.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Mary prompts when Marlene doesn‚Äôt go on. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd you say?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh‚Äîer‚ÄîI‚Äîum‚ÄîI can‚Äôt remember.‚Äù

‚ÄúMarlene,‚Äù she doesn‚Äôt need to look at Mary to know the expression she‚Äôs making right now.

Marlene throws her arms up in the air in defeat. ‚ÄúI said it was fun okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúFun?‚Äù Mary repeats.

Marlene lets out a pitiful moan. ‚ÄúYes. Fun. They asked ‚ÄúWhat is this?‚Äù and I said ‚ÄúThis is fun‚Äù and then they said ‚Äúnever mind‚Äù and now they won‚Äôt talk to me!‚Äù she stops her pacing, finally turning to face her best friend.

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù Mary says eventually. ‚ÄúYou really fucked that up huh?‚Äù

Marlene doesn‚Äôt dignify that with a response instead collapsing back down onto the bench in defeat.

‚ÄúBut what was I supposed to say?‚Äù she asks, rolling her head towards the other girl. ‚ÄúWhat was the right answer?‚Äù

Mary looks back at her, eyes soft the way they only get in moments like this, when it‚Äôs just the two of them. ‚ÄúWell, what do you want?‚Äù

Marlene scrunches her nose. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis thing with this person that you kiss. What do you want it to be? What do you want from them?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want anything from them,‚Äù Marlene says automatically. ‚ÄúI just want to‚Äîto be with them. Like all the time. It‚Äôs bloody awful.‚Äù

Mary smiles a little. ‚ÄúAnd do you want to be with anyone else?‚Äù

Marlene blows out her lips like a horse. ‚ÄúHell no. I don‚Äôt have the energy to do this with with one person let alone multiple people.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen you want something serious?‚Äù

Marlene shrugs. ‚ÄúYeah, I guess. Yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, then you need to tell them.‚Äù

Marlene chews on her bottom lip. ‚ÄúYou think that‚Äôll help?‚Äù

Mary shrugs, getting to her feet and patting Marlene on the shoulder. ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt hurt to try.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Marlene nods. ‚ÄúOkay yeah I‚Äôll‚Ä¶I‚Äôll do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Mary says, already half-way out the door, smiling to herself. ‚ÄúTell Dorcas I say hi.‚Äù

Marlene gapes after her.

Fucking evil superpower.

¬†

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù Marlene drops into the chair next to Dorcas. It‚Äôs late, the library nearly empty, Dorcas is sitting at the back.

Dorcas sighs, looking up and letting that polite smile flicker across her lips again. ‚ÄúHi Marlene, I‚Äôm actually kind of busy.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, no worries, I promise I won‚Äôt take long, I just‚ÄîI really need to tell you something?‚Äù

Dorcas looks at her warily but eventually nods her head. ‚ÄúOkay‚Ä¶shoot?‚Äù

Marlene exhales, trying to get her thoughts in order. She‚Äôs only gone over this in her head like a thousand times. Still, her hands are shaking, little bubbles of electricity thrumming under her skin.

‚ÄúYou said that we don‚Äôt want the same thing‚Äîwhich, not to start on the wrong foot here, but isn‚Äôt really fair, since you‚Äôve never actually toled me what it is that you want.‚Äù

Dorcas opens her mouth but Marlene quickly presses forward. ‚ÄúSorry, sorry, just‚ÄîI have to get this out okay?‚Äù

Dorcas blinks at her before nodding. ‚ÄúYeah okay.‚Äù

Marlene takes a fortifying breath. ‚ÄúSee, the other night? I didn‚Äôt really understand what you were asking me. And even if I had, I‚Äôm not sure I could have given you an answer. That I could have told you what I wanted because‚Äî‚Äú she breaks off, eyes dropping to the table top for a moment. ‚ÄúBecause it didn‚Äôt really occur to me that I could want anything. With‚Äîyou know‚Äîthis. And when you suggested that I could it kind of blew my mind for a second.‚Äù

Marlene takes in a another deep breath.‚ÄúSee, the thing is, it‚Äôs a scary questions because I don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôll like the answer. But I‚Äî‚Äú her voice shakes. ‚ÄúI want you.‚Äù Marlene presses her leg to Dorcas‚Äôs under the table, reaching for her eyes and holding them still once she gets them. ‚ÄúI want you,‚Äù she whispers again. ‚ÄúOnly you. All the time. It‚Äôs a little ridiculous.‚Äù

She watches Dorcas‚Äôs eyes go wide.

‚ÄúThis is fun, it is,‚Äù Marlene pushes on. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs also,‚Äù she knocks their knees together. ‚ÄúImportant.‚Äù

They‚Äôve leaned so close together that Marlene can hear Dorcas swallow. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù she asks Marlene eventually, voice weak.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

She watches Dorcas‚Äôs eyes dart around before she leans forward, quickly pressing their mouthes together.

Their fourth kiss.

Marlene almost cheers.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to me too,‚Äù Dorcas says when they break apart, foreheads still pressed together. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry I just‚Äîfreaked out like that. But I‚ÄîI‚Äôm kind of gone over you Mar and for a second there you made me feel like maybe it was one sided and‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, it kinda broke my heart a bit. I didn‚Äôt give you a chance to explain because I didn‚Äôt think I could take hearing that I was just‚Äîan experiment for you or something. But that‚Äîthat wasn‚Äôt fair.‚Äù

She kisses Marlene again, quick and sweet, like she can‚Äôt help herself.

‚ÄúGone over me huh?‚Äù Marlene asks, unable to keep the smile from spreading so widely across her face that her cheeks hurt.

‚ÄúOh shut-up,‚Äù Dorcas punches her playfully in the arm. ‚ÄúDid you hear anything else I said?‚Äù

‚ÄúNah not really,‚Äù Another kiss. All fast lips and tongues and teeth.

‚ÄúWe really need to find a better place for this than the library,‚Äù Dorcas breathes against her. Into her.

‚ÄúPretty sure there‚Äôs no one in our dorm room right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell shit,‚Äù Dorcas leans back, already shoving books into her bag. ‚ÄúMove your ass McKinnon, I want you in a bed.‚Äù

Marlene laughs so loud she nearly gets detention.

¬†

PART III JAMES

James is dead on his feet. Has been for days. Maybe weeks, depending on how you think about it. He wasn‚Äôt in great shape before. He‚Äôs certainly in worse shape now. He pushes food around his plate, eating some of it, leaving most of it, pretending he can‚Äôt see the worried glances his friends keep sending him. Recently Remus has taken to slipping chocolates into his trouser pockets. Chocolate always makes Remus feel better after a full moon, or before one, really anytime, if James is being honest. Sirius has offered to let James borrow his leather jacket on the next Hogsmeade weekend. James knows that that jacket always makes Sirius feel grown-up and cool. And Peter, well, Peter put his rarest chocolate frog card on James‚Äôs pillow the other morning.

They‚Äôre idiots. All of them.

Beautiful, lovely, incredible idiots.

He wishes he could thank them.

Wishes he could pretend he was alright just so they would stop looking so worried. But he just‚Ä¶can‚Äôt quite‚Ä¶manage it. Right now every day feels like bleeding out. He swears he‚Äôs leaving pieces of himself on the walls and floors. Pooling in his bed. He keeps waiting for the wound to heal but every morning it tears itself open again, when he thinks about Regulus‚Äôs laugh or his eyes or the way he feels tucked into James‚Äôs side‚Äîwarm and asleep and safe.

He pushes his plate away, the boys talking about something‚ÄîQuidditch maybe, he‚Äôs not sure. He reaches for the water jug, hating that his hands are shaky, hating that he feels sick and weak even though he is well aware that he is neither of those things. He takes a long drink, focusing on the feel of the water going down his throat, the coldness. Sometimes this helps, to shrink the world to a single sensation or actions. Makes it all easier to bear.

That‚Äôs when he makes the mistake of looking up. Across the hall his eyes snag on cold grey. Regulus, standing right inside the door, staring at him. James feels his breath catch the moment their eyes meet. He expects Regulus to look away but he doesn‚Äôt. And suddenly the world is out of focus except for this boy. James feels himself half rising out of his seat. He isn‚Äôt even thinking he‚Äôs just‚Äîpulled.

I love you.

I love you.

I lover you.

I miss you.

I miss you.

I miss you.

I don‚Äôt know how to do this without you anymore. I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm supposed to look forward to without you.

‚ÄúMind if we join?‚Äù

Jame‚Äôs head instantly snaps back to the table as he drops into his seat, no one seeming to have noticed that he‚Äôd risen at all.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Remus says as Mary, Marlene and Lily sit down with them, Lily across from James.

‚ÄúMorning,‚Äù she gives him a weak smile.

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú he shifts slightly, looking over her shoulder. But he‚Äôs met with an empty space. Regulus is gone. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he mutters, swallowing down his disappointment, trying not to let it show as he shoots Lily a pathetic imitation of his own smile. ‚ÄúMorning.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

I'm sorry it's so late!

But I think it's actually a surprisingly sweet chapter no? Honestly, writing Marlene was so fun, like a nice breath of fresh air from all the angst!

Anyway, hope you liked it, love you all!

Chapter 41

Chapter Summary

"We've been waiting for you"

Chapter Notes

tw: violence / assault

tw: drinking (I realize I am bad at tagging for drinking, but I am gonna try to be better plus it feels a little bit messier in this chapter idk)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I JAMES

Time passes.

James focuses on Quidditch.

On his exams.

Sometimes he sees Regulus‚Äîacross the Great Hall, walking through the corridor‚Äîhe tells himself they‚Äôre coincidences, that he isn‚Äôt looking for him. That he isn‚Äôt purposely hanging around Regulus‚Äôs classes or the hallways he knows he likes to take. Not that it matters. Regulus never sees him and James never says anything. They pass one another like strangers.

He talks to Regulus all the time in his head. He tells him about stupid things that don‚Äôt matter, or things he thinks Regulus would find funny. He tells him that he misses him. That he loves him. He tries to stop but he can‚Äôt, until eventually it feels like every thought he has is part of a one way conversation. Sometimes he imagines scenario‚Äôs where they run into one another or get forced into detention together‚Äîsomewhere that they have no choice but to talk. And for some reason that changes things, and suddenly Regulus decides to leave Slytherin and sleep in James‚Äôs bed every night and come home with him at the end of the year.

Sometimes he hates Regulus a little bit. But only a little. Only on his worst days. When he lies awake at night and wishes he could rip the heart out of his fucking chest.

‚ÄúOi, captain hurry up!‚Äù Sirius shouts from downstairs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna be late for your own bloody game!‚Äù

‚ÄúI know, I know!‚Äù James is frantically tearing through his things, looking for his Quidditch gloves. Dragon hyde, brown, water resistant, and with a grip that‚Äôs to die for. ‚ÄúWhere the fuck did I put them,‚Äù he curses, yanking open the drawers in his bedside table.

He starts throwing things on the floor‚Äîthe map ends up on his bed, some old quills clinking as he tosses them aside, a few letters from his mum‚Ä¶

‚ÄúWhere in the fuck,‚Äù he grumbles, now really starting to get annoyed. He yanks open the second drawer with such force that something heavy from the back slides forward, nearly falling out.

James freezes.

It‚Äôs a wooden box, shoved to the back during one of his many temper tantrum‚Äôs over the past few months.

For a moment he just stares at it, unable to move, or breathe, or think. His life has become a series of minefields. Faces he can‚Äôt see and words he can‚Äôt hear and things he doesn‚Äôt want to touch.

Slowly, he picks the box up, sinking onto the bed beside him as he holds it in his lap. The world suddenly shrinking. Becoming quiet. Reduced to no more than a tiny red ball. Carefully James takes it out, feeling the magic humming between his fingers. And there, when he turns it just right‚Äî

J & R

The sight of their initials entwined together sends a feeling so painful through his chest that James actually whimpers, fingers clutching more tightly around the ball.

Fuck.

This is not what he needs.

Not right now.

Not before the final Quidditch match of the year.

Not before he has to face him on the field.

‚ÄúJAMES!‚Äù Sirius screams, loud enough that McGonagall probably hears him. ‚ÄúYour bloody parents are waiting for us!‚Äù

‚ÄúC‚Äî‚Äú his voice comes out strangled and choked and he has to stop, clearing his throat. ‚ÄúComing!‚Äù he manages on the second try. He throws the box back in its drawer, slamming it shut. Sometimes it‚Äôs like he gets so sad he gets angry. Like he just wants to break everything. He‚Äôs never felt like that before‚Äînever been the type to punch walls.

It‚Äôs scary if he‚Äôs being honest.

He‚Äôs not sure where its come from.

Or how to handle it.

He knows Sirius has noticed. Remus. Peter. Knows it scares them too.

James closes his eyes, exhaling, trying to calm himself down. He can‚Äôt lose it right now, there are people counting on him. His parents have come for fuck‚Äôs sake. He tries counting, that helps sometimes.

He hears the sound of feet on the stairs and quickly stands up, shoving his hands in his pockets to hide the fact that they‚Äôre shaking. A second later Sirius swings through the door, he‚Äôs dressed in his house scarf and a t-shirt with a lion‚Äôs head on it that James is almost certain he got from Euphemia for Christmas.

‚ÄúDude?‚Äù is all he says.

‚ÄúYeah, sorry, can‚Äôt find my fucking gloves.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes drop to the massacre that their room has become. ‚ÄúReally tearing the place apart huh?‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt sound annoyed, but then, cleanliness has never been Sirius‚Äôs number one priority.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù James says anyway, because his mind is moving just a fraction too slowly at the moment.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt apologize to me mate, Moony on the other hand‚Äîhe might have your head for this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll buy him some chocolate to make up for it. C‚Äômon, lets go.‚Äù

Sirius sends James a curious look as he watches him make his way through the obstacle course their room has become.

‚ÄúYour gloves?‚Äù Sirius asks, but James waves him off pushing him through the door.

‚ÄúFuck it. I don‚Äôt need gloves to crush Slytherin.‚Äù

Sirius laughs, throwing his arm around James‚Äôs shoulders as they make their way into the common room. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the spirit!‚Äù

¬†

It‚Äôs a good game.

James‚Äôs favourite kind.

The stakes are too high for Slytherin to fuck around the way they normally do. The hits are aggressive but not illegal, the plays inching close to dirty but never crossing that line. They want this.

But James wants it too.

The scoring is neck in neck, no team ever ahead by more than one goal. James has to give it to the Slytherin Chasers, even if he does hate their guts, they know what they‚Äôre doing.

‚ÄúMacdonald!‚Äù James shouts, dipping under one Slytherin as two more come his way. He doesn‚Äôt have time to check that she‚Äôs in position just has to hope, chucking the Quaffle over his shoulder and taking a deep dive to avoid the Bludger that‚Äôs been shot at him from the left. Judging by the cheers roaring up through the Gryffindor stands, the Quaffle finds its target.

James gets back on track, speeding towards the Slytherin hoops, catching up to Mary who‚Äôs dodging the opposing team left and right. Their eyes lock for only a second but that‚Äôs all James needs to know what‚Äôs coming. She passes back to him, surprising the Slytherins who hadn‚Äôt realized he‚Äôd caught up. The rough leather of the Quaffle scrapes against his naked hands as he latches onto it and speeds towards the goal now with a slight lead.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna fucking choke Potter!‚Äù shouts the Slytherin Keeper. But James only smiles.

Not. Bloody. Likely.

He thinks about it for no more than a second, eyes bouncing to each empty corner and then back to the goal minder. James knows which way he‚Äôs going to dive. He can just feel it. So he shoots.

‚ÄúANOTHER GOAL FOR GRYFFINDOR‚Äù the amplified voice fills up the arena along with the cheering of pretty well every house except Slytherin. ‚ÄúThat brings the game back to a tie folks.‚Äù

Mary crashes into him, nearly knocking him off his broom. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre gonna beat them,‚Äù she hisses.

James grins back at her, feeling better than he has in months. ‚ÄúHell yeah we are.‚Äù

Marlene pulls up beside them, knocking her shoulder against James‚Äôs. ‚ÄúThat was brilliant you two.‚Äù

‚ÄúFucking pro material it was,‚Äù Mary‚Äôs eyes are bright, cheeks flushed from the wind and the adrenaline. She looks like a goddamn conquerer.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna get us that Snitch, I promise.‚Äù

James taps the end of his broom to Marlene‚Äôs. ‚ÄúI know you will,‚Äù he says, just as Hooch blows the whistle letting them know the Quaffle is back in play.

¬†

The game doesn‚Äôt get any easier. Neither team willing to give up ground. There are a few close calls but twenty minutes passes with no goals on either side. The crowd is getting restless and so are the players. James can‚Äôt remember an instance of the last game of the season being a tie. He has no idea what the protocol is.

He‚Äôs on the move, Quaffle under his arm, he passes to Mary but it gets intercepted. ‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses, turning his broom around and heading back towards his own goal. That‚Äôs when he sees it.

The Snitch.

For a second James is frozen. It‚Äôs not close to him, not by any stretch, and as soon as he starts going for it people will notice, but it‚Äôs not like he can get Marlene‚Äôs attention without giving everything away.

It feels like he‚Äôs hovering there in the air for hours, but it must only be seconds because nobody seems to catch on. And then Regulus appears. If he notices James he doesn‚Äôt show it, just hovers in the air near the Snitch, staring at it. James feels his heart sink. They were so close. They played such a good game. And now they‚Äôre going to lose.

Except Regulus doesn‚Äôt move.

Like James, he seems paralyzed by the sight of the Snitch.

And then‚Äî

And then‚Äî

He turns away.

‚ÄúWhat the fu‚Äî‚Äú

James doesn‚Äôt even have time to finish his curse before Marlene swoops in and snatches the ball. And then it‚Äôs pandemonium. Horns and cheering, bodies crashing into him.

‚ÄúGryffindor has caught the Snitch!‚Äù the voice fills up the stadium. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve won the game!‚Äù

James feels numb when he eventually lands back on the field. People are talking to him he‚Äôs sure, but he can‚Äôt hear them. Can‚Äôt hear anything really. Somehow, in the chaos of people‚Äîstudents running onto the field, teachers, players, everyone mixing‚Äîhe spots Regulus. By himself. Heading towards the locker rooms.

James drops his broom and starts walking. Blood boiling the closer he gets, hands in fists at his sides. He doesn‚Äôt really have a plan. He‚Äôs just so fucking angry. Because James knows they didn‚Äôt win, knows that it‚Äôs a lie, and what the hell is he supposed to do with that? Except pretend that he doesn‚Äôt. Pretend that he didn‚Äôt see what he saw. Somehow Regulus has managed to find a way to turn James into a liar. Again. What the hell kind of game is he playing anyway? Why can‚Äôt he just‚Äîjust‚Äîwhy does he have to twist everything in James‚Äôs life into knots?

He‚Äôs so angry that by the time he reaches Regulus he can‚Äôt stop himself from shoving him, hard in the back.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck was that?‚Äù James demands.

Regulus stumbles forward before turning around, expression, predictably, blank.

‚ÄúCongratulations Potter,‚Äù he says flatly, which only succeeds in pissing James off more.

‚ÄúFuck you,‚Äù he snarls. ‚ÄúYou fucking threw that game,‚Äù he jabs his hand at the sky.

Regulus arches his brow. ‚ÄúYou have so little faith in your own team? Don‚Äôt think they could beat us without my help?‚Äù

James is shaking. ‚ÄúI saw you,‚Äù he hisses, if this surprises Regulus he doesn‚Äôt react. ‚ÄúI saw you turn away.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a long moment of silence, James‚Äôs chest heaving. He has no idea what is happening in the rest of the stadium or if anyone has noticed them. He can‚Äôt bring himself to care.

Eventually Regulus shrugs. ‚ÄúYou wanted this,‚Äù he nods in the direction of the celebrations behind them. ‚ÄúAnd I could give it to you. This, at least, I could give to you.‚Äù

James has never wanted to scream so badly in his entire life.

‚ÄúFuck you,‚Äù he says instead, giving Regulus another shove, voice thick with everything that sits between them. ‚ÄúFuck you, fuck you, fuck you.‚Äù He punctuates every curse with a push‚Äîthey aren‚Äôt hard, aren‚Äôt meant to hurt, not really.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Regulus says quietly, and James thinks it‚Äôs been ages since he‚Äôs heard Regulus use his first name. Regulus wraps his hands around James‚Äôs wrists, holding them to his chest, both of them breathing heavy. Despite his calm exterior James can feel Regulus‚Äôs pulse pounding against his ribs.

‚ÄúYou think I care about a stupid Quidditch game?‚Äù James demands, fingers curling up in Regulus‚Äôs shirt like they can‚Äôt help themselves. Desperate to touch and hold and take. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want this,‚Äù he‚Äôs so confused, so wrapped up in his pain that he can't see anything else. ‚ÄúI wanted you. Why couldn‚Äôt you give me you?‚Äù his voice breaks and finally he sees Regulus‚Äôs mask give‚Äîsees the heartbreak in his eyes.

Oh thank God, he thinks.

Oh thank God I‚Äôm not alone in this.

Regulus looks like he‚Äôs going to speak but it‚Äôs then that a new set of hands grabs hold of James, yanking him back, and suddenly the world around them comes into focus again.

There‚Äôs people and yelling and then Madam Hooch is there.

‚ÄúI have never seen such a display of poor sportsmanship in my life!‚Äù she‚Äôs yelling at James. He tries to find Regulus, but he can‚Äôt see him through the crowd of people now surrounding him.

No, his thoughts whine.

No, please.

Don‚Äôt take him away yet.

‚ÄúTwenty points from Gryffindor,‚Äù Madam Hooch says, bringing his attention back to her. Mary‚Äîwho must be standing nearby‚Äîlets out an indignant noise.

‚ÄúAnd detention,‚Äù Madam Hooch goes on.

James is barely paying attention, still struggling to see Regulus so he can‚Äîhe can‚Äîfuck. What can he do? Here? Surrounded by a literal stadium of people. By his‚Äî

‚ÄúOh shit,‚Äù he hisses under his breath, suddenly looking up at the crowd. ‚ÄúOh shit my parents are here.‚Äù

‚ÄúMr. Potter!‚Äù Madam Hooch says sternly. ‚ÄúDo you understand?‚Äù

James blinks. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîyes. Sure. Points. Detention. Got it.‚Äù

Everything on the field is still chaos, there are too many people yelling and James can‚Äôt tell if they‚Äôre angry or celebrating, the inside of his head no better. Half of it occupied with the dread of facing his parents after the spectacle he just caused, the other replying the look in Regulus‚Äôs eyes over and over again. The way his voice had grown soft when he‚Äôd said James‚Äôs name.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon James,‚Äù he feels a steadying hand on his shoulder and turns to find Marlene. She gives him a look somewhere between pitying and sympathetic. He has no idea what she knows or what she thinks she‚Äôs just seen, but he doesn‚Äôt push her away.

‚ÄúLets get you to the locker room okay?‚Äù

He nods dully, allowing himself to be guided through the celebrations and into the quiet building beyond.

¬†

He takes a long shower.

Hot.

It is not a coincidence that the locker room is empty when he gets out. He wanted it. Skin growing raw as he counted steps and door slams, waiting for his team to disappear.

He dresses quickly but doesn‚Äôt leave, sitting on the bench afterwards, elbows on his knees, hands clasped, head hanging. He doesn‚Äôt want to move. Doesn‚Äôt want to face anything outside this room. Is pretty sure he‚Äôll fall apart if he does.

When he hears the door open he nearly screams at whoever it is to get the fuck out. Turns out to be a good thing he holds his tongue.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he hears his mother‚Äôs voice and instantly winces. ‚ÄúThat was quite the show.‚Äù

James would really rather not talk about it so instead he asks; ‚ÄúDad?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause that‚Äôs just a second too long. ‚ÄúHe had to leave about halfway through, work.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù James says, holding back a dry laugh. ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

He hears her walk over, sees her sit next to him out of the corner of his eye. ‚ÄúHe told me to tell you that he‚Äôs proud of you.‚Äù

That sounds like a joke considering how things ended, but James doesn‚Äôt point that out. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt even watch us win.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she says, sounding every bit like the mother she is. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to win to make him proud.You know he doesn‚Äôt care.‚Äù

That last sentence hurts in a way that it‚Äôs not supposed to. Because what she means is that his father doesn‚Äôt care if he wins. But he‚Äôs long suspected that perhaps that‚Äôs because his father just doesn‚Äôt care at all. About him. At least, not enough. Certainly not enough to sit through a whole Quidditch match.

He hates himself for thinking that.

It isn‚Äôt fair. He knows it isn‚Äôt.

His parents love him.

His father‚Äôs work is important.

There‚Äôs a war on.

James is ungrateful.

‚ÄúOh hey,‚Äù his mother coos, warm hand rubbing between his shoulder blades ‚ÄúHoney what is it? What‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know what he‚Äôs done to make her sound like that‚Äîso concerned‚Äîdoesn‚Äôt know how to stop it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve done everything wrong,‚Äù he final manages, voice small and full of holes. Like something‚Äôs been eating at it.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she says softly. ‚ÄúYou are aware you just won the season?‚Äù

He only shakes his head, trying desperately to shove the sobs climbing up his throat back into his stomach. They sit for a long moment in silence, his mother‚Äôs hand still making slow, soothing circles against his back.

‚ÄúI let him down mum,‚Äù he says finally, even though he knows he isn‚Äôt making any sense. Maybe she‚Äôll think he's talking about his father. Maybe he is. ‚ÄúAnd it hurts,‚Äù he‚Äôs crying now. Pathetic. ‚ÄúIt hurts so much.‚Äù

His mother‚Äôs hand slides from his back to his shoulder, pulling him into her. He goes willingly, allowing himself to be held, his mother kissing the top of his head before squeezing him tight.

‚ÄúYou are only one person James,‚Äù she practically whispers. ‚ÄúOnly one boy. You can‚Äôt expect yourself to be everything for everyone all of the time. It isn‚Äôt fair,‚Äù she kisses him again, letting another silence stretch between them before she speaks; ‚ÄúDid you tell him?‚Äù

Maybe his mother does know who he‚Äôs talking about. It wouldn‚Äôt be surprising really. Somehow she always does.

James sniffles. ‚ÄúTell him what?‚Äù

She squeezes him again. ‚ÄúHow much he means to you?‚Äù

I love you, Regulus.

I love you, Regulus.

I love you.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he croaks. ‚ÄúYeah I told him. He knows.‚Äù

He feels his mother nod. ‚ÄúThen you didn‚Äôt let him down.‚Äù

As if it‚Äôs that simple. As if it ever could be.

‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt leave.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù his mother says softly.

‚ÄúI begged him to. I fucking begged him to.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

His voice is thick and ugly. ‚ÄúI hate him for staying.‚Äù

She kisses his temple, his forehead, his cheek. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre allowed to hate people when they‚Äôve hurt you,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúEven the people you love.‚Äù

I love you Regulus.

I love you Regulus.

I love you.

James pulls away from his mother, scrubbing at his face until it stings and then dropping his head back against the lockers behind him, sighing as he looks up at the ceiling.

‚ÄúWill it always be like this?‚Äù he asks finally.

His mother takes her time answering.

‚ÄúNot like this, no,‚Äù she says eventually. Delicately.

But James hears the answer hidden under her words. ‚ÄúBut it will always hurt?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúLike pressing on a bruise.‚Äù

He laughs. It‚Äôs empty and cold and foreign. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want him to be a bruise,‚Äù he says without thinking, not allowing himself a moment to process the fact that he‚Äôs currently discussing his break-up with Regulus Black with his mum.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she says after several moments, reaching out and squeezing his hand. James looks over at her, meeting her bright eyes, and she smiles‚Äîif not a little sadly. ‚ÄúMaybe life will surprise you. Maybe he won‚Äôt be.‚Äù

¬†

PART II REMUS

‚ÄúDo you think we‚Äôre supposed to be doing something right now?‚Äù Lily asks from beside Remus, cup full of some dark Muggle liquid Mary‚Äôs older brother managed to owl them.

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúDoing something? Like what exactly?‚Äù

Quidditch celebrations were delayed so that they could coincide with the last day of classes. Two parties, one night. The Gryffindor common room is out of control.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù she gestures at the general revelries. ‚ÄúWe are Prefects.‚Äù

Remus snorts, looking over at her. The pair are leaning against the wall closest to the stairs. Remus pleasantly tipsy but not too drunk. ‚ÄúYou feel like being a Prefect right now?‚Äù

Lily doesn‚Äôt manage to keep from smiling. ‚ÄúNot really, no.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell then, there‚Äôs your answer.‚Äù

Across the room Sirius is currently attempting to get Peter laid. Not that that‚Äôs an impossible task, Peter really isn‚Äôt bad looking‚Äîa bit cherub-y maybe, but not bad. However, he is currently reaching above his station.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt really think that‚Äôs going to work does he?‚Äù Lily asks, following Remus‚Äôs gaze.

He only shrugs. ‚ÄúNever underestimate Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell sure, if it was Sirius trying to get with her but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius is a very skilled wingman,‚Äù he says, watching the boy in question pull out his most charming smile, arm slung around Peter‚Äôs shoulders, subtly pushing him closer to the girl he‚Äôs chatting up.

Lily scoffs. ‚ÄúNo one is that skilled.‚Äù

Remus looks over at her, amused. ‚ÄúI would have figured you for a personality first, looks second, kind of person.‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúIn an ideal world sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúAn ideal world but not this one?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying, it‚Äôs naive to think that people don‚Äôt care about how you look,‚Äù there‚Äôs a pause and then, in a rather forced casual tone Lily goes on; ‚ÄúTake James for example.‚Äù

Remus arches his brow. ‚ÄúJames?‚Äù he asks curiously.

‚ÄúHe was hounding me to go on a date with him before we‚Äôd even had two full conversations with one another, he had no idea who I was. He just liked my‚Ä¶face.‚Äù The tops of her cheeks have gone pink and as she sips determinedly on her drink Remus wonders if she‚Äôs had maybe a little bit more than he‚Äôd realized.

‚ÄúJames was hounding you to go on a date with him when he was eleven years old,‚Äù Remus says eventually. ‚ÄúHe had no idea who HE was.‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly!‚Äù Lily says emphatically. ‚ÄúAll looks.‚Äù

Remus appraises her for a moment, biting his lower lip, wondering if he shouldn‚Äôt just let this conversation go. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt though.‚Äù

Lily looks over at him, brow furrowed. ‚ÄúWhat wasn‚Äôt?‚Äù

‚ÄúJames‚Äôs thing for you‚Äîit wasn‚Äôt all looks.‚Äù

Something weird twists up her face and she drops her eyes down to her cup but doesn‚Äôt drink. After a few seconds she laughs.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù she says finally. And then, shaking her head and looking back up. ‚ÄúYou know what that bastard said to me? Said right to my face?‚Äù

Yup. Definitely drunk.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Remus asks, unable to help himself.

‚ÄúHe said: ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre a fucking force Lily Evans and you always have been,‚Äù she does a rather spot on impression of James, Remus can‚Äôt help but think, ‚Äútrying to get your attention was like chasing after a storm‚Äîterrifying and exhilarating and unbelievable every time.‚Äù She lets out a deep breath.

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù Remus says, not sure what else there is.

‚ÄúRight? I mean‚Äîright?!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen did he say that exactly?‚Äù

Lily waves a dismissive hand. ‚ÄúLast summer.‚Äù

Remus feels his brow raise. He hadn‚Äôt expected that. He would have thought‚Äîwhat with Regulus‚Ä¶His eyes start subconsciously scanning the room for James but he doesn‚Äôt find him. He‚Äôs been making himself scarce recently. Remus has given him space, forced Sirius and Peter to do the same, but at some point they‚Äôre going to have to talk to him. They can‚Äôt let him wallow forever.

‚ÄúI mean, how can he say that,‚Äù Lily goes on, pulling Remus back to the present. ‚ÄúHow can he say that and then not‚Äînot‚Äî‚Äú she looks pleadingly at Remus who feels his heart ache for her.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he says honestly. What exactly it is that James feels for Lily‚Äîor felt for Lily‚ÄîRemus has never been able to parcel out. Even at the time, it was a constant back and forth between does he or doesn‚Äôt he. Does he mean it? Does he love her? Or is it all just a laugh? It was hard to tell with James back then.

Remus is about to say something a little more comforting‚Äîor at least he hopes he is‚Äîwhen suddenly Lily‚Äôs eyes go wide and she nearly drops her cup. ‚ÄúHoly shit!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Remus demands, looking around, trying to follow her gaze. ‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù she‚Äôs smiling again, which Remus takes as a good sign. ‚ÄúHe actually did it.‚Äù

And that‚Äôs when Remus spots it‚ÄîPeter sucking face.

‚ÄúEw,‚Äù he can‚Äôt help but say, causing Lily to giggle beside him.

‚ÄúDid you just say ew?‚Äù comes another voice that instantly sparks something hot in the pit of Remus‚Äôs stomach. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs some of my finest work that is,‚Äù Sirius is grinning as he leans next to Remus, practically pressing their bodies together.

‚ÄúEvening Evans,‚Äù he tips his head to Lily who rolls her eyes.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you managed that.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat can I say, I‚Äôm endlessly talented.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a something alright,‚Äù Remus says, earning him a pinch to the side.

Lily just shakes her head. ‚ÄúOh my god‚Äîis she crawling into his lap?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs my boy,‚Äù Sirius says like a proud parent, wiping a non existent tear from his face. ‚ÄúThey grow up so fast. One minute they‚Äôre standing awkwardly in the corner too afraid to talk to anyone and the next they‚Äôre‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúOh please, no more play by plays,‚Äù Remus whines, looking very pointedly anywhere but in Peter‚Äôs direction. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need the mental images.‚Äù

They‚Äôre standing so close that when Sirius turns to Remus his lips brush his temple. ‚ÄúCome on Remus, don‚Äôt play the nun with me. I know what kind of mental images you have.‚Äù

Despite himself Remus shivers, Sirius‚Äôs hot breath snaking down his neck. He smells like alcohol. He smells like late nights and poor decisions and mouthes that love to devour.

‚ÄúAnd that,‚Äù Lily says, downing the rest of her drink and throwing a smirk Remus‚Äôs way, ‚Äúis my cue. G‚Äônight boys.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, Lily you don‚Äôt have to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSee y‚Äôah ginger,‚Äù Sirius cuts over him, causing Lily to throw-up the middle finger as she walks off into the crowded room.

‚ÄúYour manners, Master Black, are atrocious,‚Äù Remus does his best impression of Sirius‚Äôs posh accent.

Sirius snorts, nuzzling against Remus‚Äôs neck. It‚Äôs more affectionate than they usually are in public, but no one‚Äôs paying attention, and Sirius isn‚Äôt exactly famous for keeping his hands to himself.

‚ÄúAre you sure you have to go home?‚Äù he asks, voice tickling Remus‚Äôs skin.

‚ÄúJust for a bit,‚Äù he says, unable to stop himself from leaning into Sirius‚Äôs heat.

James, of course, has offered Remus a room at his house for the summer. Or, well, his mum offered him a room, James and Sirius made several crude jokes about exactly where they expected Remus would be sleeping. Remus accepted of course, but he still wants to go home first. Just for a week. He hasn‚Äôt been there since‚Äîsince his mother died. And part of him feels like he needs to. Like he‚Äôll never fully be able to accept that she‚Äôs gone until he walks into that house and finds it empty. Finds the kitchen gathering dust. He wants to be the one to pack up her stuff, not his father. He wants to say goodbye.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Sirius nudges him lightly and Remus blinks, coming back to the present. ‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus smiles at him. ‚ÄúYeah, sorry, my head just‚Ä¶but I‚Äôm okay,‚Äù he presses further into Sirius, feeling a little reckless. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm perfect actually.‚Äù He watches Sirius‚Äôs eyes drop to his lips.

‚ÄúGive me some of your drink,‚Äù Sirius says after a long pause, voice low. ‚ÄúI lost mine.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes, holding the cup out to him, ‚ÄúNot that you need it,‚Äù he adds.

But Sirius doesn‚Äôt move, instead, making direct eye contact, he parts his lips and waits. Remus feels his breath hitch as he stares at Sirius Black‚Äîbeautiful, and wicked, and pliant. His hand actually trembles slightly when he lifts the cup to Sirius‚Äôs mouth, eyes dropping momentarily to the bobbing of Sirius‚Äôs throat.

When Sirius finally pulls back he runs his tongue along his lower lip‚ÄîRemus swears it happens in slow motion.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre obscene,‚Äù it‚Äôs meant to sound teasing but it doesn‚Äôt. Instead it sounds hungry.

Sirius leans forward again, eyes sparkling, their noses nearly touching. ‚ÄúI want you.‚Äù

Another shiver runs through Remus. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he says, impressed by the steadiness of his voice, ‚Äúunfortunately for you, I‚Äôm very hard to get.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs lips twitch up. ‚ÄúOh I know. But I intend to work for it.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs skin feels burning hot, nerve endings crackling up and down his bones. He has to close his eyes just to give one of his senses a rest. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù is all he manages to get out. Barely a word. More a breath. He feels Sirius‚Äôs fingers circling his wrist, his thumb rubbing against Remus‚Äôs pulse. The touch is delicate, feather light, and Remus feels overwhelmed by it.

‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù he whispers, because in that moment he feels it so strongly that he can‚Äôt help himself.

‚ÄúI love you too,‚Äù thumb still playing with Remus‚Äôs pulse. ‚ÄúCome to bed with me.‚Äù

Remus opens his eyes, turning to meet Sirius‚Äôs. ‚ÄúThe others‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThe room is empty.‚Äù Not that that‚Äôs ever stopped them before. ‚ÄúCome to bed with me Remus,‚Äù Sirius asks again, letting go of Remus, the loss almost enough to make him whine as he watches Sirius make his way slowly up the stairs. Some days he thinks he‚Äôs trapped inside one of his fantasies, the ones he felt so guilty about at twelve or thirteen. When he would imagine what it would be like, to be wanted back. He never thought he was living the kind of life where Sirius Black could be his. He‚Äôs terrified every second that he‚Äôll wake up. That one day he‚Äôll look beside him and Sirius won‚Äôt be there. Remus has survived a werewolf attack, the death of his mother, the neglect of his father. But losing Sirius?

That would destroy him.

¬†

PART III LILY

She‚Äôs probably had too much to drink. Not in a concerning way just‚Äîshe knows if she wasn‚Äôt feeling so stressed about‚Ä¶everything, she wouldn‚Äôt have had so much.

On the one hand she‚Äôs desperate to get home. To see her mum, to hold her and touch her and know for certain that she‚Äôs alright. To be able to really find out what‚Äôs going on and how bad it is and how her doctors are treating her. Mary thinks that if they can find out more about the Muggle treatments it might help them figure out how magic can help. Lily isn‚Äôt convinced but it‚Äôs as good an idea as any.

On the other hand, there‚Äôs a part of Lily that dreads going back. Dreads the feeling of being stuck, without her magic, without her friends, constantly lying about what she‚Äôs been up to all year. Pretending all the time‚Äîthat magic isn‚Äôt real, that she doesn‚Äôt know who she is. And then there‚Äôs Sev.
