They haven‚Äôt talked, not since Mary‚Äôs attack, but‚Ä¶things between them are always messier at home. When all the other noise drifts away. Losing him hurts more there.

‚ÄúI need some air,‚Äù she murmurs to no one in particular. Mary is busy chatting up some seventh year Hufflepuff and Dorcas and Marlene have found themselves a corner where they are draped all over each other in a manner that is not believably platonic. Lily doesn‚Äôt really have a plan as she stumbles out into the hallway. It‚Äôs after curfew but seeing as it‚Äôs the last day of term she knows most of the professors will go easy on her‚ÄîI mean, it‚Äôs not as though they can give her a detention. The only person she really has to look out for is Filch.

She drags her hand along the cold stone walls as she walks. She wants to go outside, she decides. Wants to feel the crisp early summer night. Wants to look at the stars. It‚Äôs that last thought, she imagines, that sends her off towards the Astronomy Tower. A mistake. By the time she reaches the top she is feeling miserably sober‚Äîout of breath and sweating off all the alcohol she drank.

Outside the cold breeze brushes against her hot skin‚Äîa shock to the system. Though not as much of a shock as the presence of James Potter, who whips around the moment the door closes behind her, eyes bright and wide in the dark. His expression dims instantly when he sees her.

‚ÄúWaiting for someone?‚Äù she asks, standing still in front of the door, feeling a horrible ache in her chest. Jesus, did she really just walk in on James Potter waiting for his hook-up? What exactly is it that the universe has against her?

James snorts, swaying slightly, and that‚Äôs when she notices the bottle clutched in his right hand. Apparently she isn‚Äôt the only one who‚Äôs been drinking her feelings tonight.

‚ÄúNot really waiting, no,‚Äù he says, turning back towards the night sky.

After a few seconds of uncertainty Lily steps forward, coming to stand beside him. ‚ÄúHoping for someone then?‚Äù she asks, knowing all too well how that feels.

He smiles dryly, lifting the bottle up and taking a good swig. ‚ÄúMaybe‚Äîyeah actually, I suppose that‚Äôs about right.‚Äù

Lily nods, following his gaze off into the distance. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm sorry then, that‚Äôs it‚Äôs only me.‚Äù Oof, this feels terrible. She should really go back inside.

James lets out a bemused laugh. ‚ÄúOnly you? You‚Äôre Lily Evans,‚Äù he says, slurring a little. Lily waits for him to continue but he doesn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what that means,‚Äù she says finally.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he nods to himself. ‚ÄúYou wouldn‚Äôt.‚Äù He takes another swig from his bottle before handing it over to her, she takes it automatically‚Äîit‚Äôs practically a reflex.

‚ÄúWhat even is this?‚Äù she asks, turning the bottle around in her hands. She tries to read the label but it‚Äôs all in Latin.

‚ÄúNo idea,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúThe house elves nicked it for me.Tastes vile but it‚Äôs fucking strong.‚Äù

‚ÄúTempting,‚Äù Lily says, handing it back. ‚ÄúBut I think I‚Äôll pass.‚Äù

James arches his brow but doesn‚Äôt push, swallowing another mouthful without flinching.

‚ÄúMaybe we should take a step back yeah?‚Äù Lily says, wearily eyeing the edge of the tower. She‚Äôs in no shape to be babysitting a drunk and reckless James Potter. Predictably, he only grins at her.

‚ÄúWorried about me Evans?‚Äù

‚ÄúAlways,‚Äù she says without thinking, instantly feeling her cheeks heat up as she looks out into the night, avoiding James‚Äôs stare. ‚ÄúSeeing as you‚Äôre such a fucking idiot and all,‚Äù she‚Äôs not sure she even convinces herself with that one. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know how Remus stands it.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúMe either, honestly.‚Äù

They‚Äôre quiet for a while. It isn‚Äôt uncomfortable even though it probably should be, maybe it‚Äôs the alcohol. The sky is clear tonight, stretching on endlessly in front of them, dark and smooth and sparkling with stars. Lily breathes in deep, letting the sweet air fill her lungs. She isn‚Äôt planning on saying anything. She doesn‚Äôt even really know where the words come from, they just sort of‚Ä¶tumble out of her.

‚ÄúI think my mum‚Äôs dying.‚Äù

Saying that out loud feels simultaneously good and awful at the same time. Good, because the words have been hanging over her for weeks. Months. Since her mother first told her she was sick. Awful, because she wishes with her whole being that she could convince herself they aren‚Äôt true. That she‚Äôs being irrational. But the more her and Mary and Marlene fail to find any answers, and the more her mother‚Äôs letters refuse to talk about her health, the more Lily feels like she can‚Äôt avoid them.

James, she realizes eventually, is looking at her. He doesn‚Äôt speak for a few seconds and then abruptly shoves his bottle back into her hands.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOh hell no,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no way you aren‚Äôt drinking after that confession.‚Äù

Somehow Lily manages to laugh, bringing the bottle up to her mouth and instantly regretting it.

‚ÄúOh my God,‚Äù she coughs, shoving it back at him. ‚ÄúOh my god that really is vile.‚Äù

James smiles a little. ‚ÄúYou get used to it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you sure it‚Äôs fit for humans?‚Äù she spits on the ground, trying to get the taste out of her mouth. ‚ÄúThere is no way that‚Äôs good for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh sorry, you put flaming tar sticks in your mouth and suddenly you‚Äôre concerned with your health?‚Äù

‚ÄúFlaming tar sticks?‚Äù now she‚Äôs laughing and choking. ‚ÄúYou sound like my mum.‚Äù

To his credit, James only lets it be awkward for about a second. Maybe even less than that.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm taking that as a compliment,‚Äù he says, words gentle.

Lily sighs, wiping at her face and looking up at him, the moonlight reflecting in his glasses. ‚ÄúYou should.‚Äù

James‚Äôs face grows more serious, his eyes soft. ‚ÄúIs there anything I can do?‚Äù
‚ÄúAbout my mum dying?‚Äù it must be the alcohol letting her say that out loud without flinching.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Lily swallows. She wants desperately for there to be. For James to write another letter and magically solve her problems. But she knows this isn‚Äôt that simple.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so,‚Äù she says finally, giving him a weak smile. ‚ÄúBut thank you, for wanting to.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll tell me?‚Äù he says, so earnest it almost hurts. ‚ÄúIf I can? If there comes a time‚Ä¶‚Äù

She looks back at him with a reckless amount of affection. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell you.‚Äù

He nods, staring out at the sky. Looking at him, Lily can see the bags under his eyes, the frown lines near the ends of his mouth where they never were before. She can‚Äôt help but think of that day he found her freaking out in the snow. About the look on his face. And suddenly she‚Äôs hit with how strange it is that James Potter is hiding out here when there‚Äôs a party going on. Something he‚Äôd normally be the centre of, however obnoxiously.

After a few more moments of silence she nudges him with her elbow. ‚ÄúYou wanna tell me what‚Äôs going on with you?‚Äù

He lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúMy problems are pretty insignificant compared to yours.‚Äù

Lily frowns. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so.‚Äù

He looks at her out of the corner of his eyes. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt even know what they are.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf they hurt they hurt,‚Äù she shrugs. ‚ÄúPain isn‚Äôt a competition.‚Äù

‚ÄúMmm,‚Äù James says, like he doesn‚Äôt quite believe her. Eventually he sighs, letting something go as he closes his eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a little heartbroken at the moment, if I‚Äôm being honest.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Lily says, swallowing down whatever those words drag up in her. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs who you were hoping for then?‚Äù she asks, gesturing towards the door even though he can‚Äôt see her.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù his voice is a little rough. ‚ÄúI spend a lot of time hoping for‚Ä¶people these days.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù she says, because it seems like the right thing to say. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an awful feeling, heartbreak.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd think I‚Äôd be used to by now.‚Äù He gives her a sidelong look that has her rolling her eyes.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling attacked,‚Äù she teases, causing James to snort.

‚ÄúNot an attack.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, kinda felt like one.‚Äù

He looks over at her. ‚ÄúYou gonna make me apologize for having my heartbroken by you Lily Evans?‚Äù there‚Äôs amusement in his eyes, along with the sadness. Her throat feels tight.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says finally, offering him a shaky smile. ‚ÄúKnowing you, you‚Äôd make a big production of it.‚Äù

James laughs. ‚ÄúProbably‚Äîget the choir to sing to you at breakfast or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure you actually did do that to me once.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid not!‚Äù

‚ÄúDid too! And they were bloody off-key the whole time.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo be fair, that‚Äôs hardly my fault.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying, you could have held auditions. I mean, if you‚Äôre going to be an annoying prat at least put the effort in.‚Äù

James is still laughing. ‚ÄúIf anything, them being off-key makes it funnier.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor you maybe,‚Äù Lily says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the one who had to listen to them for an hour, put me off my beans on toast.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow that really is a tragedy.‚Äù

Lily nods gravely, barely able to hold back her smile. ‚ÄúTell me about it.‚Äù

There‚Äôs something warm in James‚Äôs eyes when she meets them again, something that reaches inside her chest and squeezes her heart.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he says finally, voice quiet.

Lily quirks her eyebrow up. ‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù

He shrugs. ‚ÄúI was having a really shit night before you came along.‚Äù

Lily tries and fails not to read too much into that, not to let her heart stutter and the butterflies in her stomach start to flap their wings. She swallows.

‚ÄúGlad I could help.‚Äù

¬†

PART III MARY

Mary Macdonald prides herself on many things, but first and foremost is her ability to slip out of a boy‚Äôs dorm room with exceptional stealth, and, if she may say so herself, poise. It‚Äôs early, the sun only just warming up the sky, streaking pink and orange across the corridor as she makes her way back to Gryffindor Tower from the Hufflepuff dorms. She stops by the kitchens on her way, grabbing a quick bite to eat since she fully intends to sleep through breakfast.

An older girl taught her a spell for freshening up her make-up back when she was in second year. She knows one for hair too but there‚Äôs something about ‚Äújust-shagged-hair‚Äù that Mary actually rather likes. She peeks at her reflection in one of the windows she passes and smirks. She hopes she runs into someone before she gets back to her room because she is looking unbelievably hot at the moment and it would be a shame if no one else got to see it.

Of course, she regrets that thought as soon as she hears the nasally voice calling out behind her.

‚ÄúOi slut!‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúAre you stalking me now Barty? This really is getting pathetic.‚Äù

She doesn‚Äôt turn around but she does slide her wand into her palm. She knows what‚Äôs coming next. She can feel it. He won‚Äôt want to waste time, not after what happened before. Not now that they‚Äôre alone.

‚ÄúPetrific‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúExpelliarmus,‚Äù she snaps before he can finish. She catches his flying wand in her empty hand, the outrage on his face almost comical. ‚ÄúCome now Barty, if you want to get me you‚Äôre gonna have to try a little harder than that. I mean, Petrificus Totalus? What are we, first years? I can‚Äôt imagine that would impress your big bad Lord, now would it?‚Äù

His face clouds over and he steps closer, jabbing his finger at her. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you dare speak of him.‚Äù

Mary bats her eyelashes. ‚ÄúWhy ever not? I hear he has loads to say about me.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou fucking wish.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh but he does,‚Äù she goes on in a sickly sweet voice. ‚ÄúMudbloods are ruining this, and Mudbloods are tarnishing that, and oh the Mudbloods are going to steal all our magic.‚Äù

‚ÄúShut your fucking mouth.‚Äù

Mary actually laughs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, what exactly is it that I said that is so offensive to you?‚Äù

He growls, eyes burning with rage. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your disrespect.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy disrespect?‚Äù she asks. ‚ÄúAnd who exactly am I meant to respect,‚Äù her eyes run him up and down. ‚ÄúYou?‚Äù

She should see it coming. She doesn‚Äôt. But she should.

In the blink of an eye Barty moves, one hand grabbing her by the throat and the other taking hold of her arm, slamming her wrist into the stone wall behind her until the wands fall from her hand. She struggles against him until his grip on her throat tightens. Mary has never been properly choked before, never gasped for breath and found none there. The burning fear it sends through her whole body is overwhelming. But Barty doesn‚Äôt let up, pinning her to the wall and squeezing, squeezing, squeezing.

He‚Äôs too big for her to throw off, especially like this. He‚Äôs not even that strong but he‚Äôs still stronger and she can‚Äôt use her fucking wand, can‚Äôt level the uneven biological playing field.

‚ÄúListen cunt,‚Äù he snarls, close enough that she can feel his spittle on her cheek. ‚ÄúI know you feel real safe, but one day you and your friends will have to leave this place, and when we meet outside these walls things are gonna be different.‚Äù He tightens his fingers and Mary is pretty sure she‚Äôs screaming. Or she would be if she had any air.

‚ÄúWhen we meet in the real world I am going to royally fuck everything you care about, and I am going to make you watch while I do it, make you witness the carnage before I cut you open and spill you out at the Dark Lord‚Äôs feet.‚Äù

She can‚Äôt breathe.

Can‚Äôt breathe.

Can‚Äôt breathe.

Jesus it hurts, her lungs are fucking burning. She didn‚Äôt know suffocating would feel like this, like someone set her chest on fire.

Her vision is bouncing around, in and out of focus, but she still sees it, the moment he leans forward and god she wishes she had the strength to do something. Anything. Wishes she could turn away. But all she can do is watch as he presses his mouth to the exact spot she left the lipstick mark on his cheek.

When he pulls back there is a sick glint in his eyes. ‚ÄúYou will never be rid of me,‚Äù he says in a low voice. And then, just as her vision becomes more black spots than anything else, his hand disappears.

Mary crumples to the ground, gasping and choking, lungs trying to suck in air too fast for their own good. The world spins, her body shaking like there are earthquakes under her skin.

Distantly, she hears Barty laugh as he walks away.

¬†

PART IV REGULUS

Regulus doesn‚Äôt see James after the Quidditch match. He‚Äôs no longer in the hallways outside of his classrooms, or mysteriously walking down to the Great Hall at the same time as him in the mornings. It hurts more then it should, losing those small moments of connection. Knowing that James is slowly letting him go more and more.

In his weaker moments Regulus imagines walking up to the Gryffindor common room and demanding to see him. Or crossing the Great Hall and kissing him senseless right there in front of everyone. They‚Äôre ridiculous thoughts of course, but he holds onto them anyway.

For the first time in his life there‚Äôs some sense of relief when he crosses the threshold of Grimmauld Place. Unlike Hogwarts these walls are not a reminder of everything he has lost. Of the life he pretended he could have. They are his reality. His past present and future. That used to hurt more, used to make him feel trapped, used to make him want to scream. But he‚Äôs had his taste now, of the light that exists outside these walls, maybe he can finally let it go.

‚ÄúCome in,‚Äù his mother says flatly when he knocks on the door of her study. ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù her eyes flick up and then back down to the parchment in front of her,‚Äúyou‚Äôre back.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says, shoulders pulled down and hands clasped behind him. ‚ÄúI wanted to speak with you.‚Äù

Walburga‚Äôs eyes flick up again, pausing slightly longer this time as though trying to read his thoughts. He knows she isn‚Äôt actually trying to read them of course, he would feel it if she was. She turns back to her papers, scribbling for a few more minutes before she eventually places her quill down and gives him her undivided attention.

‚ÄúYes, go on. What is it Regulus?‚Äù

For a moment, just a moment, the words stick in his throat.

I love you Regulus.

I love you Regulus.

I love you.

He coughs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt wish to return to Hogwarts next year.‚Äù Walburga raises her brow so Regulus quickly continues. ‚ÄúI believe I‚Äôve learned all I can there, and I‚Äôm ready to commit myself fully to the Dark Lord. To take my place at your sides.‚Äù Why bother pretending anymore? This is the path he has chosen. The one he was born for. The one he deserves. No reason to torture himself anymore with the person he wishes he was.

After a few seconds of silence Walburga rises from her chair and it is only years of training that keeps Regulus from flinching as she draws near, thin, pale fingers reaching for his face, cradling it in her palms.

He is terrified.

But he does not pull away.

And then, she does something he never expected, something he‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôs ever seen‚Äîshe smiles.

‚ÄúOh my son,‚Äù she says, voice nearly soft. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been waiting for you.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hello lovelies!

If fics had season finales this would be the season finale of this fic, everything kind of changes after this point so prepare yourselves!

I wanted to touch base with all the characters in this chapter (more or less) so hopefully that didn't feel too repetitive.

Thank you for all your lovely comments and messages and kudos, I know I've been a little bad at responding recently but I'm gonna get on that again!

Hope you're all doing swell :) :) :)

Chapter 42

Chapter Notes

tw: referenced sexual assault (very very very vague reference)

FRENCH TRANSLATION IN END NOTES

TWO YEARS LATER

June 1979

PART I: JAMES

‚ÄúYou reckon he‚Äôs having a wank in there?‚Äù

James nearly snorts champagne out of his nose as Remus shoots Sirius a dirty look from across the room.

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Sirius demands, holding his hands up innocently. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good stress reliever!‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemus John Lupin, you cannot stand there and tell me orgasming doesn‚Äôt relax you because we both know that‚Äôs not true.‚Äù

‚ÄúUgh, can you not?‚Äù Peter makes a face.

Sirius looks over at him, eyebrow arched. ‚ÄúCan I not what? Make Moony orgasm? Sorry, basically second nature at this point.‚Äù He throws Remus a wink.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm divorcing you,‚Äù Remus says flatly.

Sirius‚Äôs grin only widens. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd have to marry me first sweetheart.‚Äù

‚ÄúOne wedding at a time, alright boys?‚Äù James pushes himself off the couch and walks over to the bathroom where Frank has been hiding for the past forty-five minutes. He taps on the door lightly. ‚ÄúFrank?‚Äù

No response. He looks over at the others in time to see Sirius mouthing the word ‚Äúwanking‚Äù at Remus who throws his arms up in exasperation.

‚ÄúFrank? If you‚Äôve gone and drowned yourself in the bathtub I‚Äôm gonna be pissed,‚Äù James says, still getting no response. He counts to ten before sighing and pulling out his wand. ‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôm opening the door, alright?‚Äù he warns as he points his wand at the lock, murmuring under his breath; ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt actually be wanking,‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúAlohomora.‚Äù

He hears a satisfying click but doesn‚Äôt reach for the doorknob. He‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôs exactly who you want to be giving you your pre-wedding pep talk.

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs going in then?‚Äù he asks, looking hopefully over his shoulder only to find his three best friends staring blankly back at him. Remus actually steps further away from the bathroom.

‚ÄúWell I mean,‚Äù Sirius says casually. ‚ÄúYou are already standing there.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. He should have stayed on the couch with the champagne. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre rubbish mates you are.‚Äù

Sirius gasps. ‚ÄúThat is hurtful.‚Äù

‚ÄúBit true though,‚Äù Remus concedes, earning him a smack from Sirius.

James bites down on a smile because he is absolutely still annoyed with these idiots. ‚ÄúWill you lot shut-up? I‚Äôm about to have a very important heart to heart,‚Äù he gestures at the door in front of him.

‚ÄúYes Mr. Potter, we‚Äôll be so good Mr. Potter, we‚Äôll follow all your rules Mr. Potter.‚Äù

James glares at Sirius who only cackles. ‚ÄúAs soon as I get Frank out of this bathroom I‚Äôm punching you in the face.‚Äù

Sirius grins, reclining in the corner of the couch with a flute of champagne dangling from his hand, making him look every inch like the wealthy spoiled brat he is. ‚ÄúPromises, promises.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes, turning back to the task at hand. He doesn‚Äôt know much about weddings, but he‚Äôs fairly certain you need at least two people for it to work. James opens the door to the bathroom cautiously, sliding in like he‚Äôs expecting to have something jump out at him. Nothing does, obviously. Instead all he finds is Frank Longbottom sitting on the floor, head in his hands.

There‚Äôs a moment of silence in which James has absolutely no idea what to say. Luckily, Frank doesn‚Äôt let him suffer for long.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù the older boy mutters finally. He drops his hands, looking miserably up at James. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs wrong with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot that I have much experience with these things,‚Äù James says as he lowers himself down onto the floor next to Frank, back pressing into the tub. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôd say you‚Äôre acting pretty normally. Not exactly unheard of, is it? The groom freaking out right before the wedding?‚Äù

Frank groans. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not getting cold feet.‚Äù

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt think you were,‚Äù James says, because he means it, despite all evidence to the contrary.

‚ÄúI want to marry Alice,‚Äù he looks James right in the eye. His face, James notes, is paler than normal, his dark hair thoroughly dishevelled‚Äîthey‚Äôll have to do something about that. Not that he thinks they‚Äôll be able to find a single comb between the five of them.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good,‚Äù he says, when Frank doesn‚Äôt go on, ‚Äúconsidering we‚Äôre at your wedding.‚Äù

The older boy snorts. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the commitment or, I don‚Äôt know, some bullshit about losing my freedom. I wanna be with her, I always have.‚Äù

‚ÄúSoooo‚Ä¶what‚Äôre you doing on the floor of the bathroom then?‚Äù James asks, as gently as he can.

Frank lets out a deep breath, pinching the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried that we‚Äôre‚Ä¶ giving up.‚Äù

James blinks. Whatever he‚Äôd been expecting, it certainly wasn‚Äôt that. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù he asks.

Frank looks down at his hands, the expression on his face isn‚Äôt nervous or afraid but‚Ä¶tired. Exhausted. It‚Äôs been hard recently: more attacks, more disappearances, more deaths. And Alice and Frank have been in the thick of it the longest out of any of them.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if we would be doing this if things were different,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúMy mum says we‚Äôre too young and I reckon she‚Äôs probably right, which makes me think‚Äîmakes me worry‚Äîthat I asked Alice to marry me because I don‚Äôt believe we‚Äôre ever going to get any older. Because I don‚Äôt believe‚Äî‚Äú his voice cracks and he takes in a shuddering breath. ‚ÄúBecause I don‚Äôt believe we can win.‚Äù

James stares at Frank, suddenly wishing that Remus or Sirius had come in with him. Frank has always known what to do, as long as James has known him, he‚Äôs always been in charge of something. To have him look so fucking lost is making James feel off-kilter.

Eventually he swallows, knowing he has to say something. ‚ÄúYou know what Alice said, when she told me you two were getting married?‚Äù

‚ÄúProbably said that we were mad.‚Äù

James laughs and Frank actually manages to crack a smile. ‚ÄúWell, yeah, obviously. But after that,‚Äù James sobers up a little bit. ‚ÄúShe said that when things get hard people make the mistake of thinking that love is a luxury. But it isn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs the most important thing‚Äîthe only thing that matters. She said that if we wanna make it through this then we need to savour the things we love.‚Äù

Frank smiles weakly. ‚ÄúSounds like Alice.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt giving up Frank,‚Äù James goes on, thinking of the fierce look in Alice‚Äôs eyes that night on the beach. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre surviving. There‚Äôs a difference.‚Äù

Frank holds his gaze for a moment before shaking his head and chuckling softly. ‚ÄúMerlin, I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm getting life advice from James bloody Potter.‚Äù

James smirks. ‚ÄúImagine how I feel?‚Äù He gets to his feet, straightening out his robes before offering Frank his hand. The older boy only pauses for a moment before taking it.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Frank squeezes James‚Äôs hand before letting go. ‚ÄúReally.‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúOf course. Now lets go see if we can find a comb yeah? Your hair looks worse than mine.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

Lily stands across from him during the ceremony with the rest of Alice‚Äôs bridesmaids. She cries halfway through the vows, face crinkling under her freckles in a way that James thinks should be illegal. When she catches him staring at her she sticks out her tongue and James has to bite down hard on his lip to hold in a laugh.

Rings are exchanged and promises are made and eventually Frank is pulling Alice into his arms and kissing her while he blubbers worse than Lily. James has never been to a wedding before, didn‚Äôt really think it would be his thing, but as he watches his friends pull apart, hands still grasping at one another like they‚Äôre afraid to let go, everyone else clapping and cheering‚Äîor, in Sirius‚Äôs case, barking‚Äîhe can‚Äôt help but think that maybe they‚Äôre alright. After all, he hasn‚Äôt seen this many smiling faces in months.

‚ÄúAnd voila!‚Äù Mary says as she slides back into her seat at their table with a tray of tequila shots.

‚ÄúMerlin, I‚Äôm gonna die,‚Äù Dorcas mutters, eyes already looking hazy. In fact, the only one of them not currently showing signs of being absolutely plastered is Mary.

‚ÄúNo limes? Mary, what the hell?‚Äù Marlene demands.

‚ÄúLimes are for the weak.‚Äù

Lily snorts, taking two shots and passing one to James. He arches his brow. ‚ÄúYou gonna be able to stand after this?‚Äù

She gives him the finger. ‚ÄúRich coming from you Potter, fucking lightweight.‚Äù

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs got you there.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi! You‚Äôre supposed to be MY best mate.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am,‚Äù Sirius says easily. ‚ÄúAnd as your best mate I know better than anyone what a fucking lightweight you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúAmen,‚Äù Lily turns around and the pair high-five.

‚ÄúYou guys aren‚Äôt allowed to gang up on me.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw,‚Äù Lily coos. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre cute when you‚Äôre pouting.‚Äù

James glares at her. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs only like half a compliment.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd say less than half honestly,‚Äù Remus chimes in.

‚ÄúOh fuck off all of you, where‚Äôs Peter? He‚Äôs always nice to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúActually, that‚Äôs a good question,‚Äù Remus starts looking around the event hall. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt seen him in a while‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs probably getting laid,‚Äù Marlene says, earning a skeptical scoff from both James and Sirius. Remus shoots them a look.

‚ÄúYou two are too mean to him.‚Äù

Sirius makes a disbelieving noise, sitting upright in his chair and clutching at his chest. ‚ÄúI am not mean.‚Äù

‚ÄúEh,‚Äù James says, earning him a scandalized look. ‚ÄúListen mate, I‚Äôm sorry, but you can be kind of‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúKind of what?‚Äù Sirius sounds incredibly haughty when he wants to.

‚ÄúKind of a bitch,‚Äù Mary finishes for him, causing Lily, Marlene and Dorcas to start giggling uncontrollably. ‚ÄúEnough talking, lets drink,‚Äù she holds up her shot, gesturing impatiently for everyone else to do the same.

‚ÄúTo Alice and Frank!‚Äù Marlene sing-songs.

‚ÄúDo you toast with shots?‚Äù Dorcas asks. ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt seem like a toasting drink.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can toast with anything if you‚Äôre loud enough,‚Äù Mary says. And then; ‚ÄúTo the never ending monotony of marriage.‚Äù

Lily snorts. ‚ÄúJesus Christ Mary.‚Äù

‚ÄúOoh, ooh I want to do one!‚Äù Sirius chimes in, shimmying in his seat. ‚ÄúTo the only lay Frank‚Äôs ever had!‚Äù

‚ÄúNo way!?‚Äù James asks.

‚ÄúYes way,‚Äù Sirius says, a bit too proud of himself for spilling that bit of gossip. ‚ÄúOur Alice deflowered the Quidditch captain.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt take you anywhere,‚Äù Remus mutters under his breath, but he doesn‚Äôt quite manage to keep the fondness out of his tone.

‚ÄúWell I toast to true love,‚Äù Dorcas says, words slurring slightly.

‚ÄúUgh, God, please don‚Äôt, you‚Äôre going to make me nauseous.‚Äù Mary makes a revolted face.

‚ÄúWell I think it‚Äôs a cute toast,‚Äù Marlene says as her and Dorcas sway closer to one another, their noses nearly touching.

James notices the way it makes Sirius stiffen, makes his eyes dart around the room. Alice and Frank are both from old Pureblood families, meaning there are a lot of people milling about who might not look kindly on any relationship not likely to produce an heir. Normally Sirius would tell them to fuck off but James knows this sort of situation makes him twitchy‚Äîreminds him too much of the events his mother and father would drag him to. It is, after all, a very similar crowd. That‚Äôs no doubt the reason that, despite his dirty mouth, Sirius has barely touched Remus today.

‚ÄúAlright, alright enough fucking cheers-ing already,‚Äù Mary taps the bottom of her glass against the table before throwing the contents down her throat. The rest of them following suit.

‚ÄúBlah,‚Äù Lily makes a face as she drops her now-empty-glass back onto the table. ‚ÄúThat never gets any better.‚Äù

‚ÄúWould have been okay if we had limes!‚Äù Marlene sings from across the table before her and Dorcas dissolve into a fit of giggles for reasons no one understands.

‚ÄúWhat the hell you guys!‚Äù Alice skips towards the table with Frank trailing behind her, his bowtie undone and hanging around his neck, Alice‚Äôs shoes in his hands. ‚ÄúYou did shots without me!? Without ME? The bride! It‚Äôs my special day and you did shots without me!‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can get another round for you darling,‚Äù Mary offers easily.

‚ÄúNo!‚Äù Dorcas cries.

‚ÄúAbsolutely not,‚Äù Lily agrees.

‚ÄúI am not cleaning up vomit tonight,‚Äù Remus says, looking dubiously at Sirius.

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù Mary rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre all so fucking boring.‚Äù

‚ÄúHonestly, where‚Äôs your stamina?‚Äù Alice asks as she takes a seat in Mary‚Äôs lap, Frank pulling a chair over from the next table. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only‚Äîwhat time is it?‚Äù she whispers the second part to Frank who bites his lip in an attempt not to smile.

‚ÄúTwo in the morning.‚Äù

Alice throws her arms up‚Äînearly hitting Mary in the face. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only two in the morning! You lot are supposed to be the rowdy ones.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm almost positive that doesn‚Äôt include me,‚Äù Remus says.

‚ÄúOh please,‚Äù Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the worst of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcuse me?‚Äù Remus turns a slightly bewildered look on his partner.

‚ÄúYou heard me,‚Äù Sirius doubles down, not the least bit repentant. ‚ÄúYou and Evans, damn menaces to society the both of you. And poor James and I, just trying to be upstanding young gentlemen, following the rules, always doing what we‚Äôre told.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was such a good boy before she came along,‚Äù James opines, clutching at his chest. Lily is already in hysterics, Marlene and Dorcas not far behind.

‚ÄúI always did think Lily was a bad influence,‚Äù Alice chimes in with a grin.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre one to talk,‚Äù Lily says between giggles. "You're nearly as bad as Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? Little old me?‚Äù Alice bats her eyelashes and shimmies her shoulders. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm an angel.‚Äù

Frank lets out a snort that he quickly tries to cover with a cough.

‚ÄúOh my god‚Äîdo you guys hear that?‚Äù Alice demands, falling forward so that she can plant both hands flat on the table.

‚ÄúHear what?‚Äù Marlene asks.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my song! They‚Äôre playing my song!‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your wedding babe,‚Äù Mary says. ‚ÄúYou decided on the music, they‚Äôre all your songs.‚Äù

This fact does not appear to deter Alice who is already on her feet, yanking Mary up with her. ‚ÄúCome on, come on, come on! You have to dance with me, it‚Äôs my special day!!!‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin that‚Äôs getting so old,‚Äù Lily says, though she gets up nonetheless.

‚ÄúAbandoning me are you?‚Äù James asks.

Lily arches her brow. ‚ÄúYou wanna come dance with me?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt wanna outshine you.‚Äù

‚ÄúGosh, how generous.‚Äù

He shrugs. ‚ÄúJust the kind of guy I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúUpstanding gentleman, so I hear.‚Äù

James grins up at her as she steps between his thighs. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right.‚Äù She runs her hand through his hair before bending down and kissing him‚Äîprobably deeper than is strictly acceptable considering they‚Äôre in public but everyone‚Äôs so sloshed that it‚Äôs not like it matters.

She pulls back but not far. ‚ÄúI feel like we should leave soon,‚Äù she says in a low voice.

Something warm pools low in James‚Äôs stomach. ‚ÄúYeah. Definitely. Very soon.‚Äù

Lily laughs, teeth biting into her lower lip and James wonders if she knows how that drives him out of his mind‚Äîhow every time she does it he imagines replacing her teeth with his own. He wonders if she does it on purpose, it‚Äôs the kind of thing that Lily would do.

‚ÄúEVANS!‚Äù Alice shouts from the dance floor, causing them both to look up. ‚ÄúGet your ass over here!‚Äù

Lily snorts. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been summoned.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo on then,‚Äù James says, though he‚Äôs reluctant to let her go when she steps away. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm going to enjoy this. You look hot when you dance.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù Lily says, walking backwards towards their friends. ‚ÄúI look hot doing anything,‚Äù she winks before turning around and James swears his smile is so wide his cheeks are starting to hurt.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs my girlfriend,‚Äù he says, a bit in awe, earning him a slap on the back from Sirius and an indulgent smile from Remus.

On the dance floor Alice has jumped onto Mary‚Äôs back and begun to swing her veil around like lasso.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs my wife,‚Äù Frank says, without a hint of embarrassment.

‚ÄúYeah mate,‚Äù James laughs, squeezing Frank‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúYeah it is.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

James wakes to a splitting headache and the sound of the floo going off.

‚ÄúJesus Christ,‚Äù Lily murmurs beside him, grabbing a pillow and throwing it over her face. ‚ÄúAnswer it!‚Äù

James‚Äîwho feels like he is currently being beaten with an entire bottle of tequila‚Äîhas no real desire to get out of bed and even less of a desire to talk to anyone. ‚ÄúMaybe it‚Äôll stop,‚Äù he groans, voice raw. Several minutes pass and the noise does not stop.

Lily kicks him.

‚ÄúOw!‚Äù

‚ÄúGo see what they want.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou go see what they want,‚Äù he retorts, petulantly rubbing at his shin.

Lily pulls the pillow away from her face and glares at him. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause if I see the face of the person who has woken me up this morning I will dismember them bone by bone.‚Äù James honestly thinks she means it.

‚ÄúUgh, fine,‚Äù he rolls‚Äîquite literally‚Äîout of bed, his body shaky and nauseous as he crawls to the fireplace in the living room and answers the floo call.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck do you want,‚Äù he says before he even has a chance to recognize who‚Äôs calling. It‚Äôs then, as the world remains blurry no matter how many times he blinks or rubs his eyes, that he realizes that he‚Äôs forgotten his glasses.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Not that he needs them, once he hears that voice.

‚ÄúRemus? What is it?‚Äù he instantly feels more alert, sitting up straighter and trying to discern Remus‚Äôs expression through his blurry vision.

‚ÄúSorry, I know it‚Äôs early‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù James says sincerely, because it‚Äôs Remus so he means it. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on?‚Äù

Remus lets out a breath. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Sirius‚Äî‚Äú which doesn‚Äôt surprise James. The only thing that ever worries Remus enough to ask for help is Sirius. ‚ÄúMoody sent an owl this morning‚Äîsent it less than an hour ago‚ÄîI only saw it because I have this meeting with Dumbledore,‚Äù James vaguely remembers Remus mentioning this the night before. Something about Dumbledore saying he had a proposal for Remus but not giving him much more information.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd Moody say?‚Äù James asks, glad that his voice doesn‚Äôt betray the nerves currently building in his stomach. Moody has never, in James‚Äôs experience, been the bearer of good news.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Walburga,‚Äù Remus says wearily.

James feels his eyes go wide. ‚ÄúThe fuck she do now?‚Äù

Remus laughs dryly. ‚ÄúThe Aurors got her on some bullshit charge‚Äîillegal potions materials or books or something. They‚Äôve brought her in, want to question her, they know she‚Äôs at the centre of the Death Eaters, that she has information.‚Äù Sure, James thinks, though they‚Äôll never get her to talk. Unless‚Ä¶

‚ÄúAre they gonna use Veritaserum?‚Äù it‚Äôs against the law but given the circumstances James can‚Äôt imagine Moody would pass up the opportunity.

Remus only shakes his head. ‚ÄúI have no idea, but Sirius has gone-‚Äú

‚ÄúGone?‚Äù James demands.

‚ÄúTo the Ministry‚Äîthe Aurors office‚Äîno doubt to do something stupid. Normally I would have followed but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúDumbledore,‚Äù James finishes for him. And then, quickly; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going, I just‚ÄîI have to find my trousers but then I‚Äôll be right there.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

James almost tells him to fuck off‚Äîthanking him for this, like this isn‚Äôt a given, isn‚Äôt what they do.

‚ÄúAnd James?‚Äù Remus calls out as James is scrambling back to his feet.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù he asks, blinking down at the blurry face of his friend.

‚ÄúBe careful okay?‚Äù

James tries to give him his most reassuring smile. Sometimes it feels like that‚Äôs all they say to one another these days. ‚ÄúAlways Moons. I‚Äôll talk to you soon yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

His face flickers and then goes out, disappearing into the smoke.

James forces his body to move much faster than it wants to at the present moment. His stomach still threatening to upheave its contents every few seconds.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on?‚Äù Lily asks sleepily from the bed as James tries and fails to dress silently.

‚ÄúMoody‚Äôs brought Walburga in for questioning.‚Äù

Out of the corner of his eye he sees the mountain of blankets shift, a freckled face surrounded by frizzy orange hair emerging at the top. ‚ÄúShit,‚Äù she says, James nods as he hops around on one foot trying to get his socks on. The room spins slightly. Goddamn Mary and her bloody tequila shots.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôd they manage that?‚Äù

‚ÄúGot her on a technicality, they won‚Äôt be able to keep her long.‚Äù

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù Lily says again. ‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAlready there, according to Remus. So I gotta hurry before he does something unhinged like murder the old bat.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, that wouldn‚Äôt be that unhinged.‚Äù

James pauses just long enough to send her a bemused look. ‚ÄúMurdering your mother in front of the entire Auror department wouldn‚Äôt be that unhinged?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell it‚Äôs not as though she doesn‚Äôt deserve it!‚Äù Lily says exasperated.

James laughs even though it hurts his head, walking over and kissing her quickly on the mouth. ‚ÄúI love you you little psychopath.‚Äù

She catches his arm when he starts to pull away. ‚ÄúBathroom cabinet, third shelf,‚Äù when James just looks at her curiously she rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúHangover potion.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh thank god, you‚Äôre a bloody angel.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, yeah.‚Äù

Another kiss before he heads for the door.

‚ÄúWill you be here when I get back?‚Äù He asks as he grabs a jumper off the back of a chair on his way.

‚ÄúDunno,‚Äù she gathers the blankets more thoroughly around her until James can only barely see her face. ‚ÄúI have breakfast with mum today.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù James pauses with his hand on the doorframe. ‚ÄúYou going to be okay?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine, Marlene and Mary are coming. You go take care of our boy.‚Äù

James grins. ‚ÄúAye, aye captain,‚Äù saluting her before ducking into the hallway.

A very fond ‚Äúidiot‚Äù follows him out.

¬†

They‚Äôre members of the Order, but they aren‚Äôt, technically speaking, Aurors. There just wasn‚Äôt time. Wasn‚Äôt a point. By the end of their final year at Hogwarts the Ministry was collapsing in on itself, filled with more enemies than friends. No real need to get in deep there. But since the number of Aurors Moody trusts dwindles daily members of the Order are often recruited to assist in Aurorerly duties. None of it is official, of course, which largely doesn‚Äôt matter. Except when Moody decides it does.

The bullpen is chaos, Aurors rushing about, shouting at each other from their desks, memos zipping through the air so quickly James fears being decapitated by one. He‚Äôs used to it by now, understands that it isn‚Äôt quite the disaster area it looks like at first glance. That there is order to the madness. Still, it makes locating Sirius mildly more difficult.

‚ÄúMorning James,‚Äù someone says as he passes, James shoots them a quick smile in acknowledgement.

He has eyes on Moody‚Äôs office, he figures that‚Äôs as good a place to start as any. Unfortunately, in order to get into Moody‚Äôs office he has to get passed‚Äî

‚ÄúGood Morning Mrs. Newberry,‚Äù he tries to put on his most charming smile but the elderly secretary looks at him with the same contempt that she always does. ‚ÄúI was hoping to see Moody, is there any chance I could just‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDo you have an appointment?‚Äù she asks with a voice that sounds like it‚Äôs made of gravel.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîno, bit of a last minute thing. Is he busy or‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo one goes in without an appointment,‚Äù she recites monotonously, eyes going back to the copy of Witch Weekly on her desk. James grits his teeth and does his best not to lose his temper.

‚ÄúRight, yeah, except somethings happened‚Äîdo you know if he‚Äôs in there with Sirius Black by chance?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one goes in without an appointment,‚Äù she repeats, not looking up. She always wears a garish amount of blue eyeshadow and pink lipstick that makes her difficult to look at without getting a headache.

‚ÄúI was just asking who he‚Äôs meeting with,‚Äù he says through clenched teeth.

‚ÄúWho Head Auror Moody is meeting with is none of your business,‚Äù she says, before her eyes flick up over the tops of her glasses. ‚ÄúEspecially if you haven‚Äôt got an appointment.‚Äù

James is pretty sure he growls. ‚ÄúListen‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHello Dorris!‚Äù

James turns to see a chipper Alice marching towards them, smile on her face.

‚ÄúWhat the hell are you doing here?‚Äù James asks, unable to keep the shock out of his voice. While he knows that Alice and Frank don‚Äôt have the luxury of going on any kind of extended honeymoon, he was pretty sure they‚Äôd at least taken the day after their wedding off.

Alice pointedly ignores James‚Äôs question, instead choosing to focus all her energy on the bitter crone in front of them.

‚ÄúThank you so much for sending the flowers yesterday they were lovely,‚Äù Alice says, which earns her little more than a grunt of acknowledgement. ‚ÄúTell me, how is Pip doing? You said he was ill the last time we talked.‚Äù

The shift that comes over the secretary is so great that James is genuinely startled. He‚Äôs never seen the old woman smile before.

‚ÄúOh, he‚Äôs doing so much better. I found a wonderful potion that settled his stomach so he doesn‚Äôt throw-up his dinner anymore.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so glad to hear that, I was really worried about him.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh well, I appreciate that dear,‚Äù Mrs. Newberry reaches out and pats the back of Alice‚Äôs hand still smiling. James looks between them, understanding not a word of what‚Äôs just been said, and wondering if he‚Äôs fallen into some kind of alternative universe.

‚ÄúWell, Moody‚Äôs called me in so, I best get going,‚Äù Alice smiles, nodding her head towards the office.

‚ÄúOh of course, of course, go on,‚Äù James notices that the old woman doesn‚Äôt ask Alice if SHE has an appointment.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù Alice takes James by the arm and starts dragging him with her. ‚ÄúHe told me to take this one in with me,‚Äù she explains when Mrs. Newberry gives them a questioning look.

The old woman‚Äôs eyes run James up and down disapprovingly. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre sure.‚Äù

James makes an indignant noise but Alice shoves him forward before he can say anything. ‚ÄúUnfortunately I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúUnfortunately?‚Äù James whispers under is breath once they‚Äôre far enough down the short hallway to Moody‚Äôs office that he reckons Newberry can‚Äôt hear.

‚ÄúI got you in didn‚Äôt I?‚Äù Alice hisses back.

‚ÄúAnd who the hell is Pip?‚Äù

‚ÄúHer cat.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh of bloody course she‚Äôs a cat lady‚Äîow!‚Äù he says when Alice pinches him.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be mean.‚Äù

They stop in front of a door very helpfully labelled ‚ÄúAlastor Moody‚Äù not that you could mistake it for anybody else‚Äôs door. James can practically feel the protective spells wafting off of it.

‚ÄúNot that I‚Äôm not eternally grateful that you showed up, but what are you doing here?‚Äù James asks as he watches Alice wave her wand about, disabling the various security measures.

‚ÄúLike I said, Moody sent for me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe day after your wedding?‚Äù James demands indignantly.

Alice gives him a smile. ‚ÄúI could have refused, but I saw it was Sirius‚Äôs mum and‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶you‚Äôre here aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Which James supposes is fair enough.

‚ÄúFrank?‚Äù

She snorts. ‚ÄúStill sleeping.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin, the poor son of a bitch is gonna wake-up alone on his honeymoon.‚Äù

James can‚Äôt help but smile back. Alice really would have made an excellent Marauder.

‚Äú‚Äîou have no idea what the fuck you‚Äôre dealing with.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù James hisses under his breath as the door closes behind him. Neither of the two men seem to notice they have an audience, or if they do they don‚Äôt acknowledge it.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs my mother, I know how she works, how she thinks!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm aware, which is why there is no way I am letting you in that room with her.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can get her to talk!‚Äù

‚ÄúBullshit, she‚Äôll have you wrapped around her finger in a second‚Äîalready does.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not my type.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck. You.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not letting anyone who isn‚Äôt a trained Auror in that room.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis could be our only chance‚Äîyou‚Äôre lucky you got it in the first place.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm aware, that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm not taking any risks. And you kid, have risk written all over you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve had to face off against her before, I know what it‚Äôs like.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah? And how did that go for you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was a kid!‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd what are you now?‚Äù

Sirius stops his pacing then, looking at Moody, frustrated, and tired, and hurt. And then his face shutters and all those emotions meld into anger. James knows that expression well. Knows it means nothing good.

‚ÄúListen you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHey‚Äîwow‚Äîhi guys, how‚Äôre you doing?‚Äù James immediately steps forward placing himself between his best friend and the head of the Auror department. Sirius looks shocked to see him, eyes wide as his gaze bounces from James to Alice. Moody doesn‚Äôt even blink.

‚ÄúMaybe there‚Äôs a compromise here,‚Äù James goes on slowly. ‚ÄúMaybe Sirius goes in there with an Auror huh?‚Äù he looks between the two men. ‚ÄúWould that work?‚Äù

Sirius is still clearly trying to process the sudden appearance of James and Alice. He looks like he hasn‚Äôt slept‚Äîprobably because he hasn‚Äôt‚Äîand James fights the urge to reach out to him. To drag him away from here and keep him safe.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Sirius finally says, after a pause that stretches on so long James almost forgets his own question.

They turn to Moody.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúMoody‚Äî‚Äú Alice starts, but he holds up his hand and she instantly falls silent. ‚ÄúDo I look like a fool? I put you in there and you‚Äôll lose it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm telling you old man,‚Äù Sirius snarls. ‚ÄúI can do this.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm telling you that you can‚Äôt,‚Äù James does his best not to flinch, knowing how much that‚Äôll sting Sirius. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a liability.‚Äù

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù Sirius steps towards Moody and James brings his hands up, ready to hold him back if he tries anything. ‚ÄúThen I want it to be James.‚Äù

There's a beat of silence.

He hadn‚Äôt seen that coming.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù James and Alice ask at the same time.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean you want it to be me?‚Äù James demands, but Sirius only has eyes for Moody. The old man seems to be the only one not confused by this request. Finally, he turns to Alice.

‚ÄúPrewett?‚Äù he asks, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your call?‚Äù

Which again, confuses James, until he realizes that of course this is why Moody sent for Alice. Not because he was holding her friend‚Äôs mother in a cell at the Ministry, but because she‚Äôs the Auror he wants to question her. Moody has a soft spot for Alice. Everybody does really.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Longbottom now,‚Äù Alice corrects, causing Moody to raise his brow.

‚ÄúMarried the fool then?‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely.‚Äù

Moody makes some sort of snort in response that James can‚Äôt interrupt as being bad or good but Alice doesn‚Äôt seem offended so he decides there‚Äôs no point in being offended for her.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine with James being in the interrogation with me. As long as he does everything I say that is,‚Äù she shoots James a wink.

James feels like he‚Äôs moving slightly slower than everyone else. ‚ÄúThat what you want?‚Äù he asks Sirius.

‚ÄúYou know her,‚Äù Sirius says. ‚ÄúIf it can‚Äôt be me I want it to be you,‚Äù and then, in a quiet, desperate voice. ‚ÄúShe might finally have to pay.‚Äù

James knows how much this means to Sirius, that this is a moment he never expected to come‚Äîhis mother, the great Walburga Black, in Auror custody. The idea that she might be punished, sent to Azkaban, used against the Dark Lord‚Äîit‚Äôs important to him.

James reaches out, squeezing Sirius‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúShe will. I promise you she will.‚Äù They hold eye contact for a moment longer before James looks to Alice and Moody. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúhow do we do this?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre we using Veritaserum?‚Äù Alice asks, stepping forward.

Sirius lets out a bitter laugh that James doesn‚Äôt understand. Moody shoots him an unimpressed glare but answers Alice; ‚ÄúYes, though there are some‚Ä¶complications.‚Äù

‚ÄúComplications?‚Äù Alice repeats. ‚ÄúLike, legally you mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, the suspect has a tolerance.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù James and Alice ask for the second time.

‚ÄúThe bitch is immune,‚Äù Sirius answers, only marginally more helpfully.

‚ÄúImmune to Veritaserum?‚Äù James asks. ‚ÄúHow is that possible? IS that even possible?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a fucking demon that‚Äôs how,‚Äù Sirius mumbles, which James suspects is not the actual answer.

‚ÄúShe isn‚Äôt fully immune,‚Äù Moody corrects. ‚ÄúBut it doesn‚Äôt effect her as strongly as it does most people. We tried when she was first brought in and when we noticed something was off we had her examined by a Healer. He couldn‚Äôt say for sure but he thinks she‚Äôs been taking small doses of it over an extended period of time to build up a tolerance.‚Äù

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù James says, because that‚Äôs somehow the craziest and most brilliant thing he‚Äôs ever heard.

‚ÄúYes, thanks for that astute observation Potter,‚Äù Moody mutters. ‚ÄúSo you see, this interview will be difficult, she‚Äôs still been dosed but you‚Äôre going to have to pull the answers from her more than you normally would.‚Äù

Alice nods, basically bouncing on the balls of her feet with‚Äîif not excitement‚Äîanticipation. ‚ÄúUnderstood. Can we start now?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou better, the Black entourage isn‚Äôt going to let us keep their Queen Bee in holding for long.‚Äù

Alice nods again, looking back over at James who had fully expected to spend most of today sleeping in his cozy bed with his adorable girlfriend and not facing off against his best mates terrifying mother.

‚ÄúYou ready?‚Äù

No. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Alice grins. ‚ÄúThen lets do this.‚Äù

¬†

They head down to a floor James has never been to before. It‚Äôs in one of the Ministry‚Äôs many basements. There are no windows, and while magic can very easily create light where there is none, no one seems to have thought that was necessary down here. The walls are unnervingly grey and smooth, glowing orbs lighting the way along the ceiling, organized in a single file line. The silence down here feels unnatural, James suspects it‚Äôs the result of many very powerful silencing charms. No noise from the rooms escapes into the hallways and vice versa.

‚ÄúWhat exactly is our game plan here?‚Äù James asks quietly. Moody and Sirius stayed behind, though Moody very nearly had to tie Sirius to a chair to stop him from following.

‚ÄúThe plan is to find out as much information as we can‚Äîwho‚Äôs working for the Dark Lord, where they are, what they do, what he‚Äôs planning, if any of the hostages he‚Äôs taken are still alive.‚Äù

James nods, he had more or less figured that part out. ‚ÄúAnd what do we need to find out to put her away for good?‚Äù

Alice gives him a sidelong glance. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not the main goal here James.‚Äù

He‚Äôs so very glad that Sirius isn‚Äôt here to hear that. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs still a goal right?‚Äù He is aware that there are bigger things at stake than his best friend‚Äôs abusive mother paying for all the pain she‚Äôs caused him. But that doesn‚Äôt mean he‚Äôs going to let it go.

‚ÄúHopefully, if we get her talking, she‚Äôll incriminate herself. But it is possible we‚Äôll have to offer her immunity to get her talking in the first place.‚Äù

James‚Äôs feet stutter to a stop, Alice continuing on for a few seconds before realizing and turning back.

‚ÄúAre you kidding?‚Äù

She looks resigned. ‚ÄúWe only have so many options here James.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are not offering that woman fucking immunity.‚Äù

Alice‚Äôs gaze tells him that they will be doing whatever the hell she says. ‚ÄúIf it gets us information that will save lives and win us this war you bet your scrawny ass we are,‚Äù at the look of abject horror on James‚Äôs face she sighs. ‚ÄúLook, I don‚Äôt like it either, but we don‚Äôt have any good options at this point. And Walburga Black is not our biggest threat.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what you think,‚Äù James mutters under his breath but starts walking again anyway.

A few seconds pass before he feels Alice bumping her shoulder into his. He looks over at her. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do my best for Sirius okay?‚Äù she says sincerely. ‚ÄúI promise.‚Äù

He nods, knowing that she means it. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

They reach a door near the end of the hall with two burgundy robed Aurors guarding it.

‚ÄúGentlemen,‚Äù Alice smiles at the pair of them. ‚ÄúI believe you‚Äôve been expecting us?‚Äù

The men do not smile back. ‚ÄúPassword?‚Äù

‚ÄúFlitterby.‚Äù

The men nod. ‚ÄúThe prisoner is restrained by chains, remain on your side of the table, she has no weapons and no magical instruments, do not touch her and do not give her anything. Understood?‚Äù

‚ÄúUnderstood,‚Äù Alice says. There‚Äôs a pause that stretches on for a long time before Alice elbows James in the ribs. ‚ÄúDo you understand?‚Äù she asks through clenched teeth.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù James says, surprised. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîer‚Äîyeah, understood.‚Äù He imagines it would be better if he sounded a bit more confident. The guard‚Äôs eyes linger on him longer than they had onAlice before he eventual speaks again.

‚ÄúKnock twice when you want to be let out.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it,‚Äù Alice flashes them another smile as they wave their wands and the door unlocks. ‚ÄúThank you very much.‚Äù

James keeps close to her, trying not to make eye contact with the intimidating Aurors as he walks into a small square room with a single table in the centre. There are two chairs on one side of the table and one on the other which is currently occupied by a slender dark haired woman with a birdlike face‚Äîsharp bones and beady eyes. James feels himself freeze when those eyes find him, cutting right through his skin to the soft vulnerable parts beneath.

‚ÄúHello Mrs. Black,‚Äù Alice says, cheery as anything as she takes her seat across from Walburga. James does the same but without any warm greetings, eyes dissecting the woman in front of him.

It‚Äôs not that he‚Äôs never seen her before, of course he has. The Wizarding community is not very large and even if they despise one another the sacred 28 inevitably end up in the same room at some point. At gatherings he was dragged to as a kid he would see the looming figures of Walburga and Orion Black, though only ever from a distance.

Dark eyes stare expressionlessly back at them, first focused on Alice and then James. He feels a flash of anger course through him so hot he‚Äôs surprised he doesn‚Äôt burst into flames. He has to curl his hands around the edges of his chair to stop himself from reaching for his wand. He never drops her gaze, never flinches, holding that empty stare and forcing as much disgust as he can manage into his own.

Eventually Alice clears her throat, bringing the old crones attention back to her. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to be asking you a few questions today, okay? We‚Äôll start with the easy ones,‚Äù Alice‚Äôs ability to remain imperviously cheerful despite the emotional blackhole in front of them is truly astounding. James actually thinks it‚Äôs pissing Walburga off a little bit.

‚ÄúYour permanent address is currently Twelve Grimauld Place, London, England, correct?‚Äù She looks across at Walburga still smiling.

There's a moment or two of dead silence before Walburga responds. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

That surprises James, if Alice feels similarly she doesn‚Äôt show it.

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù is all she says. ‚ÄúAnd where are you residing now?‚Äù

Another long pause, and James wonders if this is the Veritaserum‚Äîif each one of these pauses is her fighting it, forced to say something but not everything. Feeling the tug but not strong enough to take anything from her that she isn‚Äôt willing to give.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve relocated to our holiday home in Scotland. It‚Äôs easier for my husband. He‚Äôs very sick.‚Äù All of this is said in a nearly mechanical voice, something vaguely sharp hiding behind each vowel.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Alice says, waving her wand and James notices the quill and pad of paper bedside her for the first time. The quill begins writing of its own accord. ‚ÄúExcellent. Does that mean that Twelve Grimmauld Place is currently empty?‚Äù

The woman‚Äôs eyes narrow. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says coldly. They wait for further information but none comes.

‚ÄúWho is occupying it then, if not yourself and your husband?‚Äù

There‚Äôs another long pause, longer than the others, she is clearly fighting the potion more, meaning there is more to hide in this answer.

‚ÄúMy son,‚Äù she says finally. ‚ÄúRegulus.‚Äù

Something lurches in James's chest and he‚Äôs almost certain he physically reacts, feeling Alice‚Äôs eyes flick over to him briefly and then away again.

Get it together Potter, he snaps at himself, trying to ignore the lingering ache. Trying not to picture Regulus alone in that house.

‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs just him? By himself?‚Äù Alice asks, as if reading James‚Äôs mind, though he knows she‚Äôs asking for completely different reasons.

Another stretch of silence. ‚ÄúHe has visitors,‚Äù the words have the same stilted air as everything else she‚Äôs said.

‚ÄúLike who?‚Äù Alice asks.

Walburga‚Äôs jaw is tense but she doesn‚Äôt look nervous, doesn‚Äôt look like someone afraid they‚Äôre going to let something slip. ‚ÄúHow would I know? I‚Äôm not there.‚Äù James almost laughs. No one is buying that.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure he tells you or they tell you, it is your house after all?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the Black family home, it exists for all who need it. And deserve it.‚Äù She looks at James when she says that last bit, bringing his anger back to the surface. They both know who she‚Äôs talking about.

"So you‚Äôre saying it acts as a base?‚Äù Alice pushes on. ‚ÄúA headquarters?‚Äù

Walburga almost looks bored now. ‚ÄúI quite literally said none of that.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut your youngest son‚Äôs house is open to all those you deem worthy?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not my youngest son,‚Äù Walburga says, answer coming more quickly than anything else she‚Äôs said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs my only son.‚Äù

Before James can open his mouth he feels Alice‚Äôs hand clamp down on his arm, a warning, to hold his tongue. So he‚Äôs forced to swallow the bile currently crawling up the back of his throat.

‚ÄúDoes he have final say on who‚Äôs allowed in or do you?‚Äù and James realizes suddenly that she‚Äôs trying to figure out if Regulus has taken over as head of the family, if Walburga‚Äôs move to the Scottish countryside symbolizes a shift in the hierarchy. He wants to tell her that she‚Äôs wasting her time. That Regulus would never‚Äîthat he only wants to survive, not move through the ranks.

But he doesn‚Äôt.

Because this is an interrogation.

And because he hasn‚Äôt seen Regulus in two years. Maybe he‚Äôs changed. That thought lances through James‚Äôs chest so brutally that he brings up his free hand to rub his sternum as though tending to a physical wound.

The silences are back, this one feeling particularly long. ‚ÄúThe house decides who it trusts.‚Äù

James scoffs, rolling his eyes and earning his arm another squeeze from Alice. It sounds like something the portraits of his great aunts would say. Something about old stones and blood and family homes. Love magic. That sort of thing. Superstitious nonsense. Old Wizarding homes are magic sure, but they aren‚Äôt sentient. More like‚Ä¶houseplants. Water them and give them sunlight and they‚Äôll prosper, neglect them and they‚Äôll shutter and wither. But they can't think.

Walburga turns her cold eyes on him. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt believe in the old magic? I‚Äôd have thought even your pathetic excuse for a mother would have taught you better.‚Äù

Alice‚Äôs fingernails are literally piercing through his shirt she‚Äôs holding on so tightly.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe anything that comes out of your mouth,‚Äù he snarls, once he can trust himself not to take things too far.

Her lips twitch. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôve taken your silly little potion,‚Äù Jesus Christ, James thinks with mild horror, is she smiling? ‚ÄúHow could I do anything but tell the truth?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you in frequent contact with your nieces?‚Äù Alice jumps in before the conversation can really derail itself. ‚ÄúNaricissa? Bellatrix? Their husbands?‚Äù

Walburga stares blandly at her. ‚ÄúI keep in touch with all my family.‚Äù

Another scoff comes out of James‚Äôs mouth before he can stop himself. All her family except her fucking son. Not that he isn‚Äôt better off for it.

‚ÄúThere are fears that perhaps your nieces‚Äô husbands may be passing Ministry information to the Dark Lord,‚Äù the fact that Alice is able to get that sentence out with a straight face, as though everyone in the room doesn‚Äôt know it‚Äôs true, as though it isn‚Äôt the worst kept secret in the Ministry, is impressive. The problem is, they can‚Äôt fucking prove it. And perhaps, beyond that, what would they do if they could? Who would convict them? Who isn‚Äôt in Lucius‚Äôs pocket? Or Rodolphus‚Äôs?

‚ÄúThey are both upstanding members of the Wizarding community,‚Äù Walburga answers haughtily. ‚ÄúLucius is practically a second father to my son.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus fucking Christ.‚Äù

This is a mistake. He shouldn‚Äôt be in here. He was ready for the jabs about Sirius, for the anger he would feel because of him, but he hadn‚Äôt been prepared for all the ways that Regulus would be present in this room with them. All the reminders of the boy he couldn‚Äôt save.

Both Alice and Walburga are looking at him now with matching expressions of confusion. He can‚Äôt explain himself. Even if he could he wouldn‚Äôt, not to this woman who calls herself Regulus‚Äôs mother.

‚ÄúSo Lucius Malfoy is a frequent guest at Grimmauld Place?‚Äù Alice pushes on, still shooting James curious looks out of the corner of her eye.

‚ÄúLucius is always welcome.‚Äù Which isn‚Äôt an answer, but nothing she‚Äôs said is. They‚Äôre getting nowhere. ‚ÄúFamily is always welcome.‚Äù

‚ÄúMakes sense,‚Äù Alice concedes with another smile. ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôd assume that would include Narcissa as well?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚ÄúBellatrix?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúRolduphus? Rabastan?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Walburga‚Äôs mouth snaps shut, realization dawning on her at the same moment that Alice‚Äôs smile becomes a little more sincere.

‚ÄúFunny,‚Äù Alice says, leaning forward across the table. ‚ÄúSeeing as Rabastan‚Äôs supposed to be in Azkaban.‚Äù

Walburga‚Äôs jaw locks, eyes somehow managing to grow even colder.

‚ÄúTell me, Mrs. Black, what exactly is a wanted man doing at your house?‚Äù

Still nothing.

‚ÄúA man very publicly connected to the terrorist group known as the Death Eaters.‚Äù

Silence.

‚ÄúMaybe you need a break huh?‚Äù Alice pushes away from the table, getting to her feet. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon James, lets give our guest a moment to mull that over.‚Äù

But James doesn‚Äôt move, eyes dead set on the woman in front of him. He isn‚Äôt done yet.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù

Ideally Alice wouldn‚Äôt be here, but he can‚Äôt see any scenario in which she walks out that door and leaves him alone with Walburga so it‚Äôll just have to do. In a weird way this is the closest he‚Äôs been to Regulus in a long time. He hadn‚Äôt thought it would matter.

He‚Äôd been wrong.

‚ÄúIs he okay?‚Äù the question comes out needer than he‚Äôd like, probably because he‚Äôs been obsessing over it for weeks and months and years. Ever since he came back to Hogwarts and Regulus didn‚Äôt. Back then he‚Äôd thought about going after him‚Äîgoing back to Grimmauld Place. But that hadn‚Äôt exactly worked out for him the first time, and he didn‚Äôt want to make things worse for Regulus. Besides, what would he have done anyway? Regulus made his choice.

Walburga arches her brow. ‚ÄúIs who okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúYour only son,‚Äù James sneers, lips curling over his teeth. James can feel Alice‚Äôs eyes on him but he ignores her.

Walburga‚Äôs shrewd gaze narrows. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause I want to know.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúIs Lucius living in that house with him?‚Äù James demands, the very thought making him feel sick.

For the first time Walburga looks genuinely thrown. ‚ÄúI told you, Lucius is like a father‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúBullshit,‚Äù James cuts her off. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs bullshit and you and I both know it. So tell me, did you leave him alone with that man?‚Äù he makes sure to pack as much disgust into those last words as he can.

The confusion has fled Walburga‚Äôs face and the sharpness has returned. ‚ÄúMy son is none of your concern James Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt deserve to be his mother,‚Äù James hisses back. ‚ÄúJust like you didn‚Äôt deserve to be Sirius‚Äôs.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Alice says in a warning tone behind him.

Anger flares in Walburga‚Äôs dark gaze, all pretence of neutrality gone. ‚ÄúYou corrupted him.‚Äù

James laughs coldly. ‚ÄúPlease, Sirius didn‚Äôt leave because of me. He left because of YOU. Because of who you are.‚Äù

But the old woman only bares her teeth. ‚ÄúI used to be able to get through to him, to make him listen, it was hard but I could still do it, then he went to that school. Then he met you. He was so beautiful when he was born‚Äîmy son, my heir‚Äîhe had so much promise.‚Äù

James is genuinely shocked by the emotion in her voice‚Äîin her words‚Äîand if the look on her face is anything to go by Walburga is surprised too. He wonders, if in the heat of the moment, the Veritaserum finally got the better of her.

‚ÄúSirius was never your‚Äôs,‚Äù James says finally. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not the one who got him sorted into Gryffindor, that was all him. Blame me if you want, but you‚Äôre the one who pushed him a way. With your cruelty and your hatred. There‚Äôs no world in which Sirius was ever going to be able to stomach it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou made him weak,‚Äù she practically spits.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James says firmly. ‚ÄúNot possible. Sirius Black is the strongest person I know.‚Äù

Her hand comes out of nowhere, the chains connecting them to the table rattling as she grabs hold of James‚Äôs wrists, nails digging in.

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù Alice yells, stepping forward, but James waves her off with the shake of his head. He might be terrified but he also wants to hear what else she has to say.

‚ÄúYou thought you could take them from me but you failed. Sirius may never have been mine but Regulus is, he always has been.‚Äù She sneers, no doubt feeling him flinch at her words despite his best efforts not to. Before James can think of a reply she presses on.

‚ÄúI saw you in his head,‚Äù she says, nails piercing James‚Äôs skin. ‚ÄúHe tried to hide you from me but I saw. He‚Äôd been looking at some ridiculous photo his brother left behind, he pretended his interest was Sirius but in his head all he saw was you.‚Äù

James jerks back, trying and and failing to pull his hand from her grip. This is too much. He wasn‚Äôt expecting this. It hurts so much more than he thought it would after all this time.

‚ÄúI decided then that we couldn‚Äôt wait any longer, that the next time he returned he would take the Mark. Take his rightful place.‚Äù She‚Äôs smiling again. It makes James‚Äôs blood run cold. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the youngest, you know. The youngest wizard to bare the Dark Lord‚Äôs Mark. And he owes that honour to you.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt know what his face does then but it‚Äôs enough to make Alice step in, she rips Walburga‚Äôs hand off of him, grabbing James by the arm and hauling him out of his seat. He feels numb, he knows he‚Äôs shaking, her words running laps around his head.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be back,‚Äù she snaps at a laughing Walburga as she knocks twice on the door causing it to swing open.

James thinks he hears her say something to the men outside but he can‚Äôt be sure, the buzzing in his ears too loud. They only pause for a minute before Alice starts dragging him away again.

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù she says, not unkindly, throwing open the door to an empty room once they‚Äôre out of the guards‚Äô sight. ‚ÄúSit.‚Äù

It looks like the room they were just in and James cringes as he takes his seat. A moment later Alice has conjured a glass of water and is handing it to him.

‚ÄúAlice‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDrink. Breathe. Then talk.‚Äù

He nods, taking the cold glass and doing as she said. Alice pulls up a chair across from him, waiting until he places the water shakily down on the table. She looks at him expectantly, brow raised, and when James doesn‚Äôt speak she reaches out and takes his hands gently in her‚Äôs.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù it‚Äôs a nudge, and he knows he won‚Äôt get out of this without saying something.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell Sirius,‚Äù he manages finally, eyes meeting her‚Äôs, the words tasting like ash in his mouth. Like betrayal.

She nods slowly. ‚ÄúThat you brought up Regulus?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. Please, it‚Äôll‚Äîit‚Äôll just stir up old shit.‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt want to see the look on Sirius‚Äôs face, doesn‚Äôt want to hear the tone in Remus‚Äôs voice when he finds out and decides they need to talk about it. He doesn‚Äôt want to unpack and process. He doesn‚Äôt want to answer the questions that will inevitably get asked.

Do you still want him?

Need him?

Love him?

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Alice says eventually, pulling him out of his spiralling thoughts. She squeezes his hands. ‚ÄúAre you good to go back up to Moody‚Äôs office?‚Äù

James takes a deep breath, trying to settle himself. Sirius reads him too well, he can‚Äôt go back with everything written on his face. Besides, it wouldn‚Äôt be fair. This isn‚Äôt about him. It‚Äôs Sirius‚Äôs family‚ÄîSirius‚Äôs mum.

‚ÄúI just need another minute‚Äîsorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey, it‚Äôs okay. We can stay as long as you need, alright?‚Äù

James laughs wetly. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such a mum.‚Äù

Alice grins. ‚ÄúGod willing, if Moody ever lets me get back to baby making.‚Äù

James makes a face. ‚ÄúEw, gross, way too much information.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou asked!‚Äù

‚ÄúDid not!‚Äù

‚ÄúDid too!‚Äù

He laughs again, more genuinely this time, pulling his hands from her grip to wipe at his face. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he says, voice quiet.

Alice‚Äôs eyes go soft. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here you know. Whatever it is‚Äîwe have your back James.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù he says, voice a little rough. ‚ÄúI have your‚Äôs too, always.‚Äù He just hopes he‚Äôll be able to prove it.

Alice leans forward and kisses his cheek.

‚ÄúJust a few more minutes I swear,‚Äù James says sheepishly, worried she felt the clamminess of his skin‚Äîthe shaking underneath.

‚ÄúAs long as you need,‚Äù is all she says.

Problem is, it‚Äôs been two years. Two years and all it took was hearing Regulus‚Äôs name spoken out loud to start James bleeding again. At this point, he isn‚Äôt sure there‚Äôs long enough.

¬†

PART II LILY

It's a beautiful day, especially after Lily gets rid of her monster hangover. She takes her time leaving the flat, hoping that James will come back so she can make sure him and Sirius are okay, but she knows it‚Äôs a bit of a lost cause. Nothing at the Ministry ever goes quickly and there‚Äôs no way Walburga is going to make this easy on anyone.

‚ÄúStupid cow,‚Äù she mutters as she heads out, hoping that Sirius is allowed to punch her at least once. I mean yes, okay, she is generally against people punching their mothers, but in this instance she feels she can make an exception.

‚ÄúOooh,‚Äù Marlene is leaning against a tree as Lily approaches. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd you bring, what‚Äôd you bring, what‚Äôd you bring?‚Äù

Lily smiles, holding up the brown paper bag in her hand. ‚ÄúCroissants. You?‚Äù

‚ÄúEverything bagels with cream cheese,‚Äù she gestures to the box in her own hands.

Lily hears her stomach rumble. ‚ÄúGod bless you, I‚Äôm starving.‚Äù

Marlene smirks. ‚ÄúWe have to wait for Mary, she‚Äôs bringing the coffee.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt believe we entrusted her with the most important thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúUm, excuse me,‚Äù Marlene shakes her box. ‚ÄúBagels are very important!‚Äù

Lily smiles. ‚ÄúSorry, of course, you‚Äôre right. It isn‚Äôt breakfast without multiple forms of carbs.‚Äù

‚ÄúAin‚Äôt that the truth,‚Äù Marlene knocks their shoulders together. ‚ÄúJames still asleep?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, he got called into the Ministry.‚Äù

The good humour instantly drains from Marlene‚Äôs face so Lily rushes to explain. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nothing‚Äîwell, it is serious but not‚Äîthe Aurors are holding Walburga.‚Äù

Marlene‚Äôs eyebrows nearly disappear into her fringe. ‚ÄúWalburga? Walburga Black? Walburga-Sirius‚Äôs-mum-Walburga?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe very same,‚Äù Lily says dryly, wishing desperately that she had some coffee, she checks down the road but sees no sign of Mary.

‚ÄúShit‚Äîdoes‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSirius knows,‚Äù she answers before Marlene can even get the question out. ‚ÄúJames said he was already at the Ministry when he left.‚Äù

‚ÄúDouble shit.‚Äù

They‚Äôre quiet for a moment, the sounds of the suburbs filtering in around them. Cars driving by, children shouting, a lawnmower going. And‚Äî

‚ÄúWell don‚Äôt you two just look so sad and pathetic standing there without me?‚Äù

Marlene rolls her eyes as they both turn to see Mary walking towards them still in last night‚Äôs clothes, coffee tray in hand.

‚ÄúIs this really an appropriate place to be doing your walk of shame?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre making the mistake of thinking that I am in anyway ashamed,‚Äù Mary says, pulling the coffee out of Marlene‚Äôs reach when she tries to grab one of the cups. ‚ÄúSlut shamers don‚Äôt get caffeine.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh come on! That is not what I was doing and you know it!‚Äù Marlene stares longingly at the cups of coffee.

‚ÄúHello Lily dear,‚Äù Mary gives her a quick kiss on the cheek. ‚ÄúSorry I‚Äôm late, the boy was still asleep when I left so I couldn‚Äôt ask him where the nearest Apparation point was and the tube was bloody dreadful.‚Äù

Lily smirks. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre alright, I only just got here too.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was on time!‚Äù Marlene says proudly, making another grab for the coffee.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you were,‚Äù Mary easily avoids her, ‚ÄúDid you remember the blankets this time?‚Äù

‚ÄúOi! You‚Äôre the one who forgot them last time!‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright children,‚Äù Lily says playfully. ‚ÄúLets go see mum, yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúExcellent idea Lily,‚Äù Mary says, Marlene sticking her tongue out at her.

‚ÄúSuck up,‚Äù she murmurs under her breath as the girls walk through the austere gates in front of them and start up the winding gravel path inside.

Mary shifts her tray of coffee so that she can link her free arm with Lily‚Äôs.

‚ÄúYou had a fun night I take it?‚Äù Lily asks quietly, everything here feels like it needs to be soft, though she isn‚Äôt exactly sure who it is she thinks is listening.

Mary grins. ‚ÄúVery fun, Alice has some talented cousins.‚Äù

‚ÄúCousins? As in multiple?‚Äù Marlene asks.

Mary ‚Äútsks‚Äù ‚ÄúHere we go again with the slut shaming.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am not slut shaming!‚Äù Marlene declares, a bit too loudly, her voice bouncing off of the trees and stones surrounding them.

‚ÄúWake the dead why don‚Äôt you,‚Äù Mary mutters, earning her a snort from Lily.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm NOT slut shaming,‚Äù Marlene repeats at a lower volume. ‚ÄúI just want all the details for when I tell Dorcas later. Obviously.‚Äù

Mary shoots her a smile. ‚ÄúOh well, in that case, yes. Cousins. Multiple.‚Äù

They pull off the path and onto the grass, Lily letting Mary and Marlene‚Äôs chatter fade into the background as her mum comes into view. Her arm slips free of Mary‚Äôs.

‚ÄúMorning mum,‚Äù she says softly, hand reaching out to touch the cold granite stone. She stays like that for a moment before looking around, to make sure no one else is there, and then pulling out her wand. She cleans up the debris that‚Äôs gathered around since her last visit, vanishing old dead flowers and replacing them with new ones. ‚ÄúThere we are,‚Äù she murmurs, giving the stone one last pat before turning around to see that Marlene and Mary have already laid out the blankets and food.

Lily joins them, grabbing a coffee and taking a big sip. ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù she says, the satisfying feeling of caffeine flooding through her. ‚ÄúSo, what do we have to catch her up on?‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, there‚Äôs the fact that Mary hooked up with several of Alice‚Äôs cousins last night‚Äîow!‚Äù Marlene rubs her arm after Mary punches her.

‚ÄúDoes that really sound like mum appropriate gossip Mar?‚Äù she demands, but Lily only laughs.

‚ÄúNah, she would have liked it. According to my aunt she was kind of a wild child when she was younger.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh yeah?‚Äù Mary asks, looking appreciatively at the stone where Lily‚Äôs mother and father‚Äôs names are carved side by side.

‚ÄúDetails, details, details!‚Äù Marlene chants, now clutching her own coffee cup.

‚ÄúWell okay, if you‚Äôre going to twist my arm,‚Äù Mary smirks. ‚ÄúDo you remember the brothers in the dark blue suits?‚Äù

Lily squints at her. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs is so vague.‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúIs not, they were the only ones there in navy blue.‚Äù Most of last night is a blur for Lily, she certain can‚Äôt remember anyone‚Äôs suit colour.

‚ÄúOh my god,‚Äù Marlene snaps her fingers. ‚ÄúWere they ginger?‚Äù

‚ÄúMmhm,‚Äù Mary hums, taking a bite out of her croissant.

‚ÄúGideon and Fabian?‚Äù Lily chimes in, surprised.

Mary points her croissant at her as she swallows. ‚ÄúDing, ding, ding.‚Äù

‚ÄúI cannot believe you hooked up with Gideon AND Fabian,‚Äù Marlene says, shaking her head. ‚ÄúThose family dinners are going to be so awkward now.‚Äù

‚ÄúListen, I can‚Äôt help that they‚Äôre both gorgeous, I couldn‚Äôt choose,‚Äù Mary turns towards the headstone. ‚ÄúI promise you Mrs. Evans they were absolute stunners, I normally have a rule about immediate family members but if you could‚Äôve seen them you‚Äôd understand.‚Äù

Lily smiles, tearing into a bagel. She isn‚Äôt sure how this started exactly, or, she is, but it still feels a bit mad to her.

It was hard, after her mother died. Lily hadn't really known how to process it, she had felt so much grief it had been overwhelming.
