He doesn‚Äôt know exactly what‚Äôs happening. He can‚Äôt breathe. And there‚Äôs a weight. He‚Äôs being crushed, something is crushing him‚Äîit feels like the roof‚Äôs caved in, that it‚Äôs lying on top of him. He‚Äôs struggling and gasping and then the weight is gone from his throat and it‚Äôs pinning his wrists above his head and that‚Äôs not the roof. Roofs don‚Äôt move like that. Don‚Äôt have hands.

Regulus‚Äôs eyes blink open, desperately trying to clear up the blurry world around him.

‚ÄúJames Potter?‚Äù comes an indignant voice.

His heart seizes, stuttering in his chest, fear so raw it is a physical pain. It‚Äôs Lucius. Lucius is on top of him, holding him down. He‚Äôs been here before. He doesn‚Äôt want to be here again.
‚ÄúJames fucking Potter?‚Äù he sounds hysterical and while Regulus bucks and pulls and desperately tries to wrench himself free he notices the blood on Lucius‚Äôs face‚Äîsplit lip, broken nose, eyes swallowed by deep blue bruises. Something‚Äôs happened. He doesn‚Äôt know what. He doesn‚Äôt care. He just needs Lucius to stop touching him.

‚ÄúGet off of me!‚Äù he finally manages, but Lucius just laughs, nails digging into Regulus‚Äôs wrists.

‚ÄúYou pathetic little slut, letting the enemy fuck you. Tell me, did you do it to get back at Sirius, huh? At least that I could respect. Does he know? Did it break his little blood traitor heart?‚Äù

‚ÄúGet off of me!‚Äù Regulus shouts again, he doesn‚Äôt know how Lucius figured it out, how he possibly could have all these years later, but he doesn‚Äôt care. He doesn‚Äôt care about anything right now except being free of the weight on top of him. He can‚Äôt breathe again and this time it isn‚Äôt because there‚Äôs a hand on his throat. The panic is like a wild animal trapped inside his skin, furiously clawing and scrambling and biting its way out.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve forgotten your place Regulus,‚Äù Lucius drops his face down, so close Regulus can feel his breath and he isn‚Äôt proud of the noise that comes out of him then. A whine. A sob.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù he says finally, weakly. ‚ÄúPlease Lucius please.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw,‚Äù the older man says. ‚ÄúHow cute. Tell me, did you beg James Potter too?‚Äù

Regulus closes his eyes, still trying to rip his hands out of Lucius‚Äôs grasp.

Accio wand, he thinks. Accio wand. Accio wand. Accio wand.

Please.

Please.

Accio wand.

Accio wand.

Acci‚Äîfuck, where did he put it? Why didn‚Äôt he lock his fucking door.

‚ÄúCome now Regulus?‚Äù Lucius says, voice still far too close. ‚ÄúWe used to have fun you and I. Don‚Äôt you remember? You were always such a good sport back then.‚Äù

I can‚Äôt believe this is happening again, Regulus thinks helplessly. I can‚Äôt believe I let this happen again.

‚ÄúGet off of him Lucius.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes fly open and find Narcissa standing above them, wand pointed at the back of Lucius‚Äôs head. Lucius goes stock-still.

‚ÄúCissy it‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGet. Off. Of. Him,‚Äù she jabs her wand more forcefully into Lucius‚Äôs head and he winces.

‚ÄúYou gonna curse me darling?‚Äù he asks bitingly.

‚ÄúYou think I won‚Äôt?‚Äù her voice doesn‚Äôt waver but Regulus thinks he can see the tiny sparks of fear in the corners of her eyes. His heart is still jack hammering in his chest‚Äîso fast it‚Äôs painful.

It feels like hours before Lucius finally moves, giving Regulus‚Äôs wrists one last squeeze before he lifts himself off, standing up straight and smoothing out his shirt. He‚Äôs toe to toe with Narcissa, looming several inches taller.

‚ÄúYou should be careful,‚Äù he says smoothly.

‚ÄúI could say the same to you,‚Äù she hisses, wand held between them. They glare at one another for a long minute, Regulus still on the bed, too afraid to move or breathe or make a sound. He spots his wand on the bedside table, just out of reach. If he needs to he thinks he can lunge for it, thinks he‚Äôll get there in time.

‚ÄúWell, Regulus,‚Äù Lucius says, running a hand over his hair, smoothing it out. ‚ÄúI do hope matrimony suits you better than it has me.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, mind too slow to understand. It isn‚Äôt until Lucius has left the room, walking pointedly around Narcissa and letting the door slam behind him, that Regulus finally connects the dots.

Walburga‚Äôs sudden interest in his marriage isn‚Äôt out of the blue. He‚Äôd been right, she knows, but it wasn‚Äôt his father who told her about Regulus‚Äôs inclinations. It was Lucius. And of course her solution is to have him married off before it becomes public knowledge. Before the pureblood families refuse him their daughters for fear that he won‚Äôt be able to perform his duty. Regulus almost laughs as he slides off his bed and onto the floor, pulling his knees into his chest and trying to breathe. He wants to disappear. He wants to not still feel Lucius on his skin.

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù he finally manages, because clearly he‚Äôs missed something. Narcissa is still standing where Lucius left her, looking down on him.

‚ÄúJames Potter attacked him in the atrium of the Ministry,‚Äù she says flatly, though the disapproval is clear on her face. Regulus sits with that for a minute, his brain still moving slowly.

‚ÄúAttacked?‚Äù he finally manages, looking at his knees. ‚ÄúHow?‚Äù

‚ÄúWith his fists,‚Äù she nearly spits the words. ‚ÄúLike some ingrate, it was pathetic.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause your husband lost?‚Äù

The silence that follows confirms what Regulus suspected. There‚Äôs no stopping James Potter once he‚Äôs started. Lucius didn‚Äôt stand a chance. Regulus should be angry, given how fucking stupid it was, how reckless and thoughtless. Considering what it just put him through. But James has always been the only person who ever really wanted to fight for Regulus. Who refused to believe he wasn‚Äôt worth it. And he can‚Äôt help but take comfort in the fact that it‚Äôs still true. After all this time. James said he wouldn‚Äôt give up on him and he hasn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúDid Potter‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOh don‚Äôt feign formality for my sake,‚Äù Narcissa interrupts coldly.

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúDid James say something?‚Äù

‚ÄúAbout sleeping with you?‚Äù she asks bluntly, making Regulus flinch though he doesn‚Äôt know why. ‚ÄúNo. I don‚Äôt think so. Had enough sense not to go screaming out your name. But he clearly said something to tip Lucius off.‚Äù

He looks up at Narcissa, inspecting her face. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not surprised.‚Äù

She arches her brow. ‚ÄúThat James Potter is a reckless baffoon? No, I‚Äôm not.‚Äù

But Regulus only shakes his head. ‚ÄúYou knew already. Knew about‚Äî‚Äú his words choke, some part of his brain desperate not to say the truth out loud in this house even under the current circumstances. But Narcissa doesn‚Äôt appear to need him to.

‚ÄúHe showed up here.‚Äù

Regulus blinks. ‚ÄúWhat.‚Äù

She rolls her eyes as though it‚Äôs ridiculous that he should need any further clarification. ‚ÄúI was on my way over one night and I found James Potter loitering in the park.‚Äù

Regulus continues to stare at her, not knowing what to do with that information. ‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù he finally manages to ask.

She waves her hand dismissively. ‚ÄúYears ago, I don‚Äôt know, before you left school.‚Äù

‚ÄúBefore I left school,‚Äù Regulus repeats numbly. It‚Äôs too much and it‚Äôs too hard. He squeezes his eyes shut.

‚ÄúOf all the people Regulus, honestly.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre judging me?‚Äù he asks with a humourless laugh. ‚ÄúWhen your husband just tried to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt!‚Äù she cuts him off.

Regulus only shakes his head. ‚ÄúWhatever Cissy.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou should be grateful, I just put myself on the line for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, I‚Äôm aware,‚Äù he says bitterly. ‚ÄúNo doubt it was meant as payback for the fertility potion I gave you. Now we‚Äôre even right? Your debt paid.‚Äù She doesn‚Äôt respond, which is as much a confirmation as anything.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you‚Äôre going to give that man a child,‚Äù he‚Äôs almost sick just thinking about it. About his role in it.

‚ÄúI told you, it won‚Äôt really be his.‚Äù The tone of her voice suggests this isn‚Äôt a new argument, but rather one she has with herself frequently.

He scoffs. ‚ÄúIf you say so.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre just going to be a brat I‚Äôll go.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo then,‚Äù his hands are still shaking where they grip his knees.

There‚Äôs a moment of stillness, her eyes on him, he can feel them without even looking. He‚Äôs always liked Narcissa best, but he isn‚Äôt sure that means much in this family. Eventually she starts towards the door, wooden floor creaking under her steps.

‚ÄúYou promised,‚Äù Regulus doesn‚Äôt know why he bothers, but sitting here on the floor, curled in a ball, he can‚Äôt help it. Narcissa looks back at him, hand on the door.

‚ÄúYou promised you would protect your child, if you had one.‚Äù

She eyes him for a moment before nodding. ‚ÄúI will.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood. Because I swear to God Narcissa if you let him use this kid I will kill you.‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt think he means it. He‚Äôs almost certain he doesn‚Äôt. But then, he‚Äôs done it twice before with his wand, and who knows how many times his potions have been used to end someone‚Äôs life. It‚Äôs not as though he can pretend he isn‚Äôt a killer. Not anymore.

After a long moment of silence something like a smile actually ghosts across Narcissa‚Äôs lips. ‚ÄúI believe you.‚Äù

The next thing Regulus hears is the click of the door closing.

¬†

PART IV JAMES

‚ÄúMum?‚Äù James calls out as he walks inside the house. He kicks off his shoes, not bothering to pay much attention to where they land as Lily closes the door behind them.

‚ÄúMum?‚Äù James calls out again. ‚ÄúDad? Mimi?‚Äù

James walks down the hall a little ways, finding the door to his father‚Äôs office wide open, lights off, fireplace empty. ‚ÄúWeird,‚Äù he mutters.

‚ÄúMaybe they got called into the Ministry?‚Äù Lily asks, coming up behind him and placing her hand on his lower back.

‚ÄúNo, they would have said‚Äîmum would have said,‚Äù he keeps looking at the room, trying to figure out exactly what it is that feels so off. ‚ÄúMy mother takes Sunday dinner very seriously.‚Äù

Lily looks like she‚Äôs about to say something when the sudden turning of the doorknob catches their attention.

‚ÄúYour favourite son has arrived!‚Äù Sirius sings as Remus and him tumble through the front door. Sirius throwing his arms open wide as though expecting his entrance to garner applause.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not here you prat,‚Äù James says.

‚ÄúOh James, I didn‚Äôt see you there, how awkward. Well, I suppose you were going to find out eventually.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not the favourite.‚Äù

‚ÄúMm, kind of am though.‚Äù

‚ÄúNuh uh.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah huh.‚Äù

‚ÄúNuh uh!‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHey Remus,‚Äù Lily interrupts, closing the gap between the couples as she pulls Remus in for a hug. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to see you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus smiles pulling away. ‚ÄúYeah, good to see you too. I‚Äôve been locked up with this loon the last few days and I think my brain has started leaking out my ears.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Sirius says indignantly.

James snickers. ‚ÄúWell, I guess we all know you‚Äôre not Moony‚Äôs favourite.‚Äù

Sirius gasps dramatically, jabbing an accusatory finger at him. ‚ÄúYou take that back!‚Äù

‚ÄúNope.‚Äù

Sirius frowns for a minute before a smirk tugs at his lips. ‚ÄúYou know what? It‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

James looks at him skeptically. ‚ÄúIt is?‚Äù

‚ÄúYup,‚Äù he pops his ‚Äòp‚Äô. ‚ÄúBecause for one, it‚Äôs a dirty and vicious lie, we all know I‚Äôm Moony‚Äôs favourite. Or at least my mouth is,‚Äù he gives Remus a wink that has the other boy choking and Lily laughing beside him.

‚ÄúGross,‚Äù James says flatly. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your second point?‚Äù

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúWe all know Evans would shag me over you in a heartbeat.‚Äù

This only serves to increase Lily‚Äôs laughter.

‚ÄúBullocks,‚Äù James says, but Sirius shrugs.

‚ÄúSorry mate, these are just the facts.‚Äù

James turns to Lily. ‚ÄúBabe, back me up here?‚Äù

But she‚Äôs grabbed hold of her stomach still laughing. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt breathe.‚Äù James rolls his eyes.

‚ÄúHave I ever mentioned that I hate that you two are friends?‚Äù

Sirius snorts, holding his hand out to Lily who high-fives him.

‚ÄúThey are a bit of an unholy alliance aren‚Äôt they?‚Äù Remus says as he eyes their partners with amusement.

At that moment the door opens for the third time, Sirius jumping out of the way, just barely avoiding being hit.

‚ÄúMerlin Peter,‚Äù he says as he mimes dusting himself off. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you knock?‚Äù James is pretty sure that Sirius has never knocked before walking into his parent‚Äôs house.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Peter mutters, taking in the scene around him. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you all doing standing by the front door?‚Äù

‚ÄúParents aren‚Äôt home,‚Äù James shrugs, earning him a justifiably confused look from Peter.

‚ÄúReally? That doesn‚Äôt sound like them.‚Äù

Something like worry tickles the back of James‚Äôs mind but he shakes it off. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon, we‚Äôll wait for them in the kitchen, I‚Äôll send an owl or something, see if Moody knows anything.‚Äù

There‚Äôs general agreement, Peter throwing his shoes in a pile with James‚Äôs as he follows the rest of them down the hall.

‚ÄúMerlin I‚Äôm so hungry,‚Äù Sirius whines, rubbing his stomach like a toddler. ‚ÄúYour mum said there were going to be those garlic mashed potatoes and I‚Äôve been thinking about them all day,‚Äù he makes an orgasmic noise.

‚ÄúKeep it in your pants Black,‚Äù Remus says, elbowing him in the side.

None of the lights are on. Which is weird, usually if his parents aren‚Äôt home Mimi still keeps the house running. Of course, for all James knows turning the lights off might be a new safety protocol Moody has them doing.

It‚Äôs Lily who notices first, freezing beside him as they enter the kitchen. ‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she grabs his wrist.

‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù he looks at her paling face and then follows her eyes to the table.

His mum is sitting slumped over in an unnatural position, her face hidden in the crook of her arm. And instantly everything in James crumbles.

‚ÄúMum?‚Äù he scrambles to her side, voice tight. ‚ÄúMum?‚Äù he feels it the second he touches her‚Äîthe stillness. It sends shivers down his spine. ‚ÄúMum? Talk to me. Talk to me‚Äîmum?‚Äù he pulls her back, it‚Äôs hard, like she‚Äôs fighting him, like her joints have rusted in place.

Something smashes‚Äîin his struggle to see her face he‚Äôs knocked a tea cup off the table. He hears it crunch under his feet. ‚ÄúMum, please? Please? Mum?‚Äù his voice is trembling so badly the words are barely intelligible. Her eyes are open but they don‚Äôt look at James, and he becomes vaguely aware of the sores covering her skin. She‚Äôs so cold. Before he can think about it he starts rubbing his hands up and down her arms like he can warm her up.

‚ÄúMum,‚Äù his legs give out, he‚Äôs on his knees now, hands still holding her up. ‚ÄúPlease, please, oh, please don‚Äôt. Please don‚Äôt. I‚Äôm sorry, I‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt even know what he‚Äôs saying anymore words just coming out of him. ‚ÄúMum‚ÄîI can‚Äôt‚ÄîI need‚Äîplease.‚Äù

He hears talking behind him but he barely registers what any of it means. His whole world cracking.

‚ÄúGet the fire in his father‚Äôs study going, call Dumbledore, Moody‚Äîand get them to bring a fucking Healer. You two check the rest of the house, see if anyone else is here.‚Äú

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm staying with him.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe needs me, I‚Äôll‚Äîhe needs me, so I‚Äôm going to be here,‚Äù there‚Äôs the smallest shake in his voice. ‚ÄúNow go check the rest of the house.‚Äù

There are no more words and a second later Sirius is on the floor at James‚Äôs side.

‚ÄúWe have to get her to Mungos,‚Äù he says, not taking his eyes off of his mother, still holding onto her fiercely. ‚ÄúMaybe they can‚Äîthey can fix‚Äîthey can help. There has to be something they can do.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople are coming,‚Äù Sirius says calmly. ‚ÄúPeople are coming, okay James?‚Äù

He shakes his head. ‚ÄúShe can‚Äôt be dead Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, no, no she can‚Äôt, she can‚Äôt. I need her. I need her. Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god,‚Äùand suddenly he‚Äôs sobbing, his whole body shaking as Sirius wraps him in his arms.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got you,‚Äù he says, James‚Äôs heart punching holes in the walls of his chest. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got you. I‚Äôm here.‚Äù

Wake up.

James thinks.

Wake up.

Nothing kills Euphemia Potter. She‚Äôs a force. She‚Äôs unstoppable. She loves us too much to die.

Wake up.

Wake up.

Wake up.

But he doesn‚Äôt. No matter how hard he tries he‚Äôs still on the kitchen floor of his childhood home, his best friend wrapped around him like a shield, his mother‚Äôs cold hand in his.

There are footsteps but James doesn‚Äôt move and neither does Sirius.

‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù Sirius asks above him.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù that‚Äôs Remus. ‚ÄúJames I‚Äôm so sorry, I‚Äôm so, so, sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù Sirius demands again, and he‚Äôs trying to be strong but James can hear the shaking in his voice. The barely restrained pain.

‚ÄúFleamont,‚Äù it‚Äôs Peter who answers. ‚ÄúUpstairs bedroom. The house elf too.‚Äù

‚ÄúHoly shit. What the fuck happened here?‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs arms tighten around James who can barely process anything.

More footsteps. ‚ÄúMoody and Dumbledore are on their way,‚Äù that‚Äôs Lily. ‚ÄúMoody said not to touch anything. He said‚Äî‚Äú her voice breaks, ‚Äúhe said not to touch them.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment of silence. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Sirius asks, voice tight.

‚ÄúBecause we don‚Äôt know what happened, we don‚Äôt know if there‚Äôs evidence or if whatever‚Äîwhatever killed them, if it‚Äî‚Äú

‚Äú‚Äîcan be passed on by touch,‚Äù Remus finishes for her with horrified understanding.

More silence.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Lily says finally. ‚ÄúJames you have to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo. No fucking way,‚Äù he holds onto his mother‚Äôs hand more tightly. He can‚Äôt let her go. He can‚Äôt. He‚Äôll never get her back if he does. He can't lose her if he doesn't let her go.

‚ÄúSirius don‚Äôt,‚Äù he says when he feels his best friend move, terrified that he‚Äôs going to fight him. That he‚Äôs going to take her away.

Please don‚Äôt take her away.

Oh god.

Oh god.

Oh god.

He lifts his head, Sirius‚Äôs eyes meeting his. For a moment nothing happens and then Sirius reaches out and takes Euphemia‚Äôs other hand.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù Remus says nervously from behind, but Sirius doesn‚Äôt flinch, doesn‚Äôt look away from James.

‚ÄúYou and me,‚Äù he says, his voice fraying at the edges. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs you and me okay?‚Äù

James nods, clinging to Sirius almost as desperately as he clings to his mum.

‚ÄúYou and me,‚Äù James repeats, and while it‚Äôs always been true, it‚Äôs never felt so fucking painful before.

Chapter End Notes

**FRENCH TRANSLATION**

"As I was walking by the clear fountain, I found the water so lovely I had to bathe. I've loved you for so long, I will never forget you"

"Under the oak's leaves, I lay and dried. On the highest bough, a nightingale sang. I've loved you for so long, I will never forget you. Sing, nightingale, sing, you who has a joyous heart. Your heart is made for laughing... mine can only cry. I've loved you for so long, I will never forget you." (song: √Ä la claire fontaine)

Hello beautiful people!!!

LISTEN. The Dragon Pox thing will be addressed okay. It will. I promise there won't be another time jump or anything, what happened to Euphemia and Fleamont is gonna be explored in the next chapter. Like I said at the beginning I'm sort of reinterpreting canon in a way that I think tells a better story (in my opinion, I'm not saying it actually IS better). Also I know that technically they die after Lily and James's wedding but I am ignoring that fact, hopefully that doesn't bother too many people, but I apologize if that's a big issue for anyone.

THANK YOU all for being so sweet and supportive with the comments and Kudos and messages and everything it's truly so so so incredible I cannot even describe it to you. Hopefully this chapter wasn't a let down and also hopefully you're doing okay wherever you're at, sending you all the warm fuzzies!

Chapter 45

Chapter Summary

Merry-day-late-Christmas

Chapter Notes

tw: discussion of miscarriages

tw: discussion of death

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I EUPHEMIA

March 1960

Oh no.

No.

Euphemia has been here before. Been here too many times.

‚ÄúNo, darling, no please,‚Äù she whispers, hand placed protectively over her stomach as another pain rocks through her body.

She‚Äôs losing her baby.

She‚Äôs losing her baby again.

Even in her head that thought sounds like a sob.

Grimacing she stands up, feeling something wet on her thighs‚Äîblood. It‚Äôs always blood.

‚ÄúMimi!‚Äù she calls out as loud as she can manage, wobbling over to the fireplace and gripping the mantle. There‚Äôs a crack and the house elf appears at her side, looking up with great concern.

‚ÄúCan you go to Mr. Potter‚Äôs office please,‚Äù she says with difficulty. ‚ÄúTell him‚Äîtell him‚Äî‚Äú her eyes close briefly. ‚ÄúThat I‚Äôm going to St Mungo‚Äôs. He‚Äôll know what‚Äôs happened,‚Äù they‚Äôve been through it enough.

The house elf nods. ‚ÄúMistress is certain she doesn‚Äôt want Mimi to come with her?‚Äù

She offers the elf a tight smile. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be alright, but thank you.‚Äù

The elf nods before there‚Äôs another crack and she disappears. After a few laboured breaths Euphemia throws some floo powder into the fire and steps through. She‚Äôs in too much pain to Apparate.

Euphemia Potter has always dreamed of being a mother. She wants a dozen children, wants a house filled with chaos, with the sounds of little feet pitter-pattering across the floors and little voices giggling and little hands getting themselves into trouble. She‚Äôs made lists of the things she wants to show her children and the places she wants to take them and the important things she wants them to know. She‚Äôs so ready for this. Has been for years. Decades.

It never occurred to her that it would be this hard.

That her body was a place where nothing could grow.

The miscarriages seem endless. Each heartbreak leaving her and Fleamont a little less hopeful. They‚Äôve tried everything‚Äîevery potion and charm and talisman‚Äînothing seems capable of giving them a child. But this time.This time really had been different. She had never carried a baby this long before.

When she gets to St Mungo's she‚Äôs ushered into a private room. Mediwizards run their diagnostics and promise her the Healer will be with her shortly before leaving her alone. Euphemia sits upright in bed, arms cradling her whale of a stomach as she tries not to cry. Instead she closes her eyes, taking in deep breaths and making a list of all the things in her life that make her happy. She tries to remember that this moment will not last forever and this pain will fade eventually even if that seems impossible right now.

‚ÄúI love you so much,‚Äù she whispers. ‚ÄúEven if this is all the time we get to have together I want you to know that I don‚Äôt love you any less,‚Äù her voice quivers ever so slightly but she comforts herself with the knowledge that no one is around to hear it.

A few minutes later the door flies open and Euphemia looks up to see her frazzled husband blustering into the room. Wild brown hair flying about‚Äîit‚Äôs longer than it ever has been before, well past his ears and on its way to his shoulders. It makes him look young.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he gushes, coming to her side and kissing the top of her head as he wraps his arm around her. ‚ÄúI came as soon as I could.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs alright, not as though there‚Äôs much to do now,‚Äù she gives him a watery smile and watches pity fill his eyes.

‚ÄúOh my love,‚Äù he says, hands coming to gently cup her face. ‚ÄúThis is not the end. We‚Äôll try again.‚Äù

Those words are a knife in her heart. ‚ÄúNo I‚ÄîI think this is it for me Monty.‚Äù

Confusion flits across his face. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

She bites her lower lip, hoping to stop its trembling. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do this again. It‚Äôs too hard.‚Äù

Fleamont looks genuinely shocked, mouth opening and closing several times as words fail him. She feels so guilty. He would have been such a wonderful father.

‚ÄúEffie‚Äî‚Äú

But at that moment the Healer enters the room and Fleamont cuts himself off. Effie straightens her posture, fixing her face. She can have a good cry about this once she‚Äôs home, alone, locked in a bathroom, the shower running so Monty can‚Äôt hear. That‚Äôs how she‚Äôs managed it all the other times.

The Healer looks up from her clipboard and smiles. ‚ÄúHello Mrs. and Mr. Potter, I‚Äôm Healer Hathaway, I‚Äôll be attending you today. Everything seems to be progressing rather nicely so far. This is your first child correct?‚Äù her eyes are a warm brown and they bounce between Euphemia and Fleamont, waiting for an answer.

‚ÄúI‚ÄîI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Euphemia screws her face up, trying to understand. ‚ÄúWhat did you just say?‚Äù

Healer Hathaway‚Äôs bright expression flickers for a moment. ‚ÄúI asked if this was your first child,‚Äù she looks back down at the pages in front of her. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no note here about any previous births but it‚Äôs possible the Mediwizards missed something.‚Äù

Fleamont‚Äôs hand has found her‚Äôs and he gives it a strong squeeze. ‚ÄúAre you saying,‚Äù Euphemia tries but her voice cuts out so she has to cough and start again. ‚ÄúAre you saying I‚Äôm having a baby?‚Äù

Now the Healer looks quite visibly confused. ‚ÄúYes? You‚Äôre in labour. Didn‚Äôt you‚Ä¶know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúA living baby?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I feel like we‚Äôve missed something here. Did no one care to mention to you what would be happening at the end of your pregnancy?‚Äù the Healer asks.

Before Euphemia can stop herself she bursts out in hysterical laughter. ‚ÄúWe did it. We actually did it. Monty, we‚Äôre having a baby, we're really having a baby this time,‚Äù she looks up at her husband who's smiling too, tears in his eyes.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre having a baby,‚Äù he whispers back, leaning forward to kiss the top of her head again, and then her temple, her cheek, her nose. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre having a baby,‚Äù he presses his forehead to her‚Äôs and for a moment they just stay like that, Euphemia feeling as though she has a dozen stars trapped in her chest, sparkling and glowing and burning bright.

Eventually she pulls away, wiping quickly at her cheeks before turning back to the Healer. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù she laughs a little again. ‚ÄúWhat were you saying?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh‚Ä¶‚Äù the Healer looks between them, like she‚Äôs debating asking for an explanation before eventually seeming to decide it‚Äôs none of her business. ‚ÄúWell, now that we seem to be on the same page, I‚Äôd like to perform a physical examination, see how dilated you are and then we‚Äôll go from there, alright?‚Äù

Euphemia is beaming. ‚ÄúYes, yes, perfect, whatever you need to do,‚Äù a delirious giggle escapes her, the hands on her stomach flexing. "I'm ready."

¬†

It‚Äôs hard. Well. Obviously. Childbirth does have a reputation to uphold. It‚Äôs hard, but it‚Äôs also magical‚Äînot like a spell or a potion, but the way falling in love is magical. Sunsets are magical. The night sky. Something beyond comprehension and yet so beautiful to behold. For the rest of her life Euphemia Potter will never forget the first moment she hears James‚Äôs voice. Crying in the Healer‚Äôs arms, all bloody and pink and wrinkly. All beautiful and delicate and breathtaking.

‚ÄúLet me have him,‚Äù her voice is rough, her body wrung out. Still she reaches for him with a desperation she has never known before and the second his skin touches her‚Äôs she cries.

‚ÄúOh hi,‚Äù she says through the tears, kissing the top of his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so happy to meet you. You‚Äôre so lovely, you‚Äôre so perfect.‚Äù

Monty is at her side, hair standing on end from all the fretting he‚Äôs been doing. He never could stand to see her in pain. ‚ÄúWow,‚Äù his voice cracks as he reaches out, running the backs of his fingers gently down James‚Äôs arm. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs really ours then?‚Äù

Euphemia lets out a wet laugh that has the baby blinking up at her. ‚ÄúYes, all ours.‚Äù

For a moment there‚Äôs silence. Well, I mean, the room itself is full of noise and traffic, but the three Potter‚Äôs suddenly seem to be in a world all their own.

‚ÄúMerlin this kid is going to be such a brat,‚Äù Fleamont says eventually.

‚ÄúMonty!‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôll be spoiled rotten between the pair of us.‚Äù

Euphemia smiles, nuzzling her son‚Äôs head; ‚ÄúGood.‚Äù She‚Äôs half falling asleep but she doesn‚Äôt want to give him back yet. ‚ÄúI love you so much,‚Äù she whispers. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll love you always. No matter what. I‚Äôll be here whenever you need me,‚Äù she barely resists the urge to squeeze him until his little head pops off.

‚ÄúLike I said,‚Äù Monty is looking down at them with unbridled fondness. ‚ÄúA brat.‚Äù

‚ÄúOur brat though.‚Äù

‚ÄúOur monster.‚Äù

She giggles, feeling a little delusional. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll be unstoppable.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike his mother then.‚Äù

She looks up at him, smiling so widely it hurts her face. Monty brushes the hair from her forehead. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know I could feel this happy.‚Äù

He smiles back at her. ‚ÄúI love you.‚Äù

She turns her head, kissing his hand as he starts pulling away. ‚ÄúI love you too.‚Äù The baby on her chest gurgles as if in agreement and it nearly has Effie in tears again, though she expects she‚Äôs allowed a few obscene displays of emotion under the present circumstances.

‚ÄúThis feels right doesn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Monty says after a small pause. Somehow she manages to pull her eyes away from her baby to look up at him.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

Fleamont has eyes only for James. ‚ÄúWe were missing something before. And now we‚Äôre whole,‚Äù he shrugs. ‚ÄúThe three of us. It feels‚Ä¶right.‚Äù

Effie‚Äôs heart nearly gives out it can barely take it. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she says a little breathlessly. ‚ÄúYes it does.‚Äù

¬†

PART II JAMES

1979

He sits at his father‚Äôs bedside in St Mungo‚Äôs. He‚Äôs in a comma, has been for the last three days. Nobody is saying it yet, at least not to James‚Äôs face, but they don‚Äôt expect him to recover. Still, James is here. Waiting. One way or the other.

His mother is dead.

She was dead before they got there.

Poison.

Moody and Dumbledore are discussing what they think happened. What they want to do about it. James tries, but he can‚Äôt seem to bring himself to care at the moment.

‚ÄúThis wasn‚Äôt personal,‚Äù Moody says, which has James looking up for the first time in a while. ‚ÄúThis wasn‚Äôt some vendetta. Euphemia and Fleamont were important to the cause. They gave people confidence. This was political.‚Äù

‚ÄúFeels pretty personal,‚Äù James says flatly. He‚Äôs done a lot of crying the last few days. And screaming. And begging. There‚Äôs not much left in him at the moment.

Maybe for the first time ever James sees Moody‚Äôs expression soften. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean‚Äî‚Äú

But James waves him off, eyes dropping back down to his father‚Äôs stiff body. ‚ÄúI know what you meant. It‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

Sirius moves behind him, squeezing the back of James‚Äôs neck, Remus knocking their shoulders‚Äô together, Peter nudging his foot. The three of them have been here as much as possible. When Peter isn‚Äôt working and Sirius and Remus aren‚Äôt with the Order. They keep touching him, like they‚Äôre keeping him together, gathering him up when he starts to crumble. Those touches say,

We‚Äôre here.

Those touches say,

It‚Äôs us and always us. No matter what you lose you will never be alone. We bleed together. And we cry together. And we survive.

Those touches say,

You don‚Äôt have to be strong enough to carry this on your own. We will do it for you. With you.

This isn‚Äôt their first time dealing with this kind of loss and that truth feels unbearable to James. Because it isn‚Äôt fair. Life wasn‚Äôt supposed to be like this.Wasn‚Äôt supposed to be this endless tragedy. Voldemort and his followers have stolen the future they were supposed to have. And it makes James want to claw his eyes out.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck?‚Äù Sirius demands.

James blinks, returning to the conversation. Sirius is glaring at Moody who glares right back.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs bullshit.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs strategic,‚Äù Moody grumbles. ‚ÄúHaving people panicking is only going to lead to reckless behaviour and careless mistakes, which is exactly what Voldemort wants. We have to keep people calm.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú Sirius seems to struggle to find the right word. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs disrespectful!‚Äù he decides on eventually. ‚ÄúThey deserve better than that.‚Äù

‚ÄúBetter than what?‚Äù James can feel it, everyone looking at him, uncomfortable with the fact that he‚Äôs clearly been too zoned out to hear what was said. Another reminder that he isn‚Äôt handling this well. And he isn‚Äôt. He has enough self-awareness to know that.

‚ÄúMoody wants to have the official cause of death be recorded as Dragon Pox,‚Äù Lily steps forward. When he meets her eyes she gives him a small smile, like she understands that it‚Äôs hard for him to pay attention right now. He tries to return it.

‚ÄúThey deserve justice,‚Äù Sirius goes on. ‚ÄúThey were fucking murdered. Are you even looking for the person who did it?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe know who did it,‚Äù Moody snaps back. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been trying to get them for years now incase you haven‚Äôt noticed.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, no fuck the war. I want you opening a case for the Potters. I want you to treat this like you would any other murder. This wasn‚Äôt a fight, didn‚Äôt happen in battle, it‚Äôs a crime and you‚Äôre a fucking Auror so do something about it.‚Äú

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think this is an act of war? Of battle?‚Äù Moody goes on. ‚ÄúSure it is, and Euphemia and Fleamont lost. They lost. They let someone in those wards, or they told someone something‚Äîsomething that let them sneak poison into their bloody tea. You think wars are only fought with wands, boy? This is what I keep trying to get you lot to understand, every word out of your mouths is a play in the game. Is a weapon that can be turned against you. People are dying everyday because of it. The Potters lost. We don‚Äôt have the fucking resources to launch an independent investigation but even if we did I wouldn‚Äôt. Their deaths cannot be separated from the war just because you think your pain matters more.‚Äù

James can feel Sirius vibrating with anger beside him. He wonders how much longer they can go like this before Sirius takes a shot at Moody.

‚ÄúYou‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù James interrupts. He feels exhausted by this. Who knew death came with so many complications. ‚ÄúSay it was Dragon Pox if you think that‚Äôs better,‚Äù he looks at his father again, reaching out for his hand and squeezing. ‚ÄúThough you may want to wait before you start giving my dad a cause of death. You know. Since he‚Äôs not dead.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Dumbledore says, one of the only things he has said. As always he seems to be here more to observe than to participate.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs also the matter of setting a date, do you want to do that now or are you hoping to wait for Fleamont to‚Ä¶well,‚Äù Moody actually seems a bit uncomfortable, but James doesn‚Äôt understand the question.

‚ÄúSet a date?‚Äù he asks.

‚ÄúFor your mother‚Äôs funeral. The Potter‚Äôs have a crypt, I expect you know, your mother expressed that she wanted to be laid to rest there with your father so that will have to be arranged as well.‚Äù

Everyone looks at James expectantly. Like he should have an answer for this. Like he should have been thinking about this. And maybe he should have been. He gives it all another second to sink in before squeezing his father‚Äôs hand and getting to his feet.

‚ÄúNo date,‚Äù he says firmly.

‚ÄúNo date?‚Äù Moody demands.

‚ÄúNo date. No funeral. No crypt.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you just going to keep your mother‚Äôs dead body in your house or something?‚Äù Peter asks, earning him an elbow from Sirius.

But James isn‚Äôt offended. He looks his friend dead in the eye and nods. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait, what?‚Äù Remus asks in shock.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not burying her,‚Äù I‚Äôm not letting her go. I‚Äôm not going to shut her up in some place where she‚Äôll never see the sun. This isn‚Äôt fair. And it wasn‚Äôt supposed to happen. This isn‚Äôt my life. I refuse to let this be my life.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Lily starts but doesn‚Äôt seem to know how to finish.

He turns back to Moody. ‚ÄúNo date,‚Äù he says for the third time and then, while everyone still seems to be at a loss for words; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going for a walk.‚Äù

He pushes out the door before anyone can stop him, leaving the room silent in his wake.

¬†

PART III REGULUS

‚ÄúWould you wear dress robes or a Muggle suit d‚Äôyou think?‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. Cerci and him are lying on their backs on the floor of his bedroom, Boo sitting happily in the corner watching over them.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not getting married,‚Äù he says, even though he still hasn‚Äôt figured out how he‚Äôs going to convince his mother of that.

‚ÄúMy sister says Muggle suits are very fashionable right now,‚Äù Cerci goes on as if she hasn‚Äôt heard him.

‚ÄúMy mother is trying to force me into an arranged marriage I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre quite progressive enough for Muggle suits.‚Äù

Cerci hums in agreement. ‚ÄúI guess that‚Äôs fair. Oh well, you look good in your dress robes so I‚Äôm sure your bride won‚Äôt be too disappointed.‚Äù

Regulus groans, bringing his hands up to cover his face. ‚ÄúThis is such a fucking nightmare‚Äù.

A moment passes before Cerci knocks their feet together. ‚ÄúHave you thought about, y‚Äôknow, just telling her no? You are an adult, technically, and she doesn‚Äôt even live here anymore.‚Äù

Regulus fixes her with a pointed look. You don‚Äôt say ‚Äúno‚Äù to Walburga Black and live to tell the tale.

This time Cerci is the one to roll her eyes. ‚ÄúAlright, alright, have you thought of telling her you‚Äôre gay? At least then she might set you up with a nice eligible bachelor instead.‚Äù

Regulus snorts, the very idea ludicrous. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure she already knows, besides, how many gay pureblood marriages do you know of?‚Äù

She screws up her face like she‚Äôs genuinely trying to think of some. ‚ÄúNone,‚Äù she admits eventually.

‚ÄúExactly.‚Äù

Another moment passes before Cerci rolls onto her side so that she‚Äôs facing him. ‚ÄúHow did you know?‚Äù

He arches his brow. ‚ÄúHow did I know what?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat you were gay?‚Äù

Regulus lets out a breath that‚Äôs almost a laugh, swiping a hand over his face. ‚ÄúMerlin, I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he‚Äôs not sure even he can manage to untangle the complicated web that is his sexuality. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think about it until the moment I did and then it seemed obvious.‚Äù

Cerci hums. ‚ÄúAnd what did you do after that?‚Äù

‚ÄúTried not to think about it again.‚Äù

Cerci reaches out, squeezing his hand briefly before pulling back again, using her arm as a pillow. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú she starts and then stops, nose all scrunched up the way it gets when she can‚Äôt find the right words. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel that way‚Ä¶about anyone.‚Äù

Regulus watches her for a moment, trying to parcel through what she‚Äôs just said. For the first time since he‚Äôs known her Cerci seems almost timid. Embarrassed. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt feel what way?‚Äù he asks slowly.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú and then she immediately shuts her mouth, making a frustrated noise. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel like‚Ä¶like I want to‚Ä¶you know.‚Äù

But he doesn‚Äôt, not really, and this seems important so he doesn‚Äôt want to go making any assumptions. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to need a few more words.‚Äù

She blows out a breath. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre supposed to be a genius.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a genius.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúCerci?‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

‚ÄúMore words please.‚Äù

She lets out a dramatic sigh, shoulders shrugging against the floor. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to, like, touch anybody,‚Äù she grimaces. ‚ÄúOr, I do. I like hugs and high-fives and handshakes‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWho likes handshakes?‚Äù Regulus demands, genuinely affronted.

Cerci rolls her eyes but Regulus can see her holding back a smile. ‚ÄúI do, okay? Can I keep going?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry, yeah, go on.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks. So, like I was saying, I don‚Äôt want to touch anybody‚Äîum‚Äîsexually‚Ä¶I guess?‚Äù

Regulus considers that for a moment. ‚ÄúNot anybody?‚Äù

She shakes her head.

‚ÄúNot anytime?‚Äù

Another no.

Unhelpfully, the only thing that comes to his mind is ‚Äúhuh‚Äù which he doesn‚Äôt think is a particularly adequate response.

‚ÄúI thought it would like‚Ä¶happen when I got older, you know?‚Äù Cerci presses on when Regulus pauses for too long. ‚ÄúAll my friends they‚Äôre always talking about the people they fancy and it‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt fancy people exactly but I don‚Äôt‚Ä¶.‚Äù she trails off.

‚ÄúWant to have sex with them?‚Äú Regulus finishes for her.

She nods, seemingly grateful that she didn‚Äôt have to explain it again. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want the things my friends want.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you want?‚Äù Regulus asks, genuinely intrigued.

She chews on her bottom lip. ‚ÄúI think I want to fall in love. To be held. To be‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, to find someone who feels comfortable and safe.‚Äù

Regulus still isn‚Äôt sure he a hundred percent understands. ‚ÄúBut you don‚Äôt want to have sex?‚Äù

She nods again.

‚ÄúDo you‚Äî‚Äú he pauses, worrying this might come across wrong but feeling he has to ask. ‚ÄúDo you think it‚Äôs possible you just haven‚Äôt‚Ä¶found the right person?‚Äù

She scoffs at the idea. ‚ÄúPeople want to have sex with the wrong people all the time,‚Äù which is certainly not a point that Regulus can argue with. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even want it in my head. I don‚Äôt even think about it. Merlin, that can‚Äôt be normal can it?‚Äù She looks at him with big pleading eyes and Regulus realizes, suddenly, that the question is not rhetorical.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think normal really‚Ä¶means anything, when it comes to sex,‚Äù not that he‚Äôs the one to ask, Jesus Christ.

‚ÄúBut normal people want to have sex,‚Äù she pushes.

Regulus shrugs. ‚ÄúAbnormal people also want to have sex.‚Äù That gets a laugh out of her which is nice, Regulus doesn‚Äôt like seeing her too serious, it doesn‚Äôt feel right.

‚ÄúI suppose that‚Äôs true,‚Äù she looks back up at the ceiling and lets out a heavy sigh.

He‚Äôs still watching her and after a moment he reaches out and squeezes her hand. ‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he says softly, ‚Äúwhat is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing‚Ä¶it‚Äôs just‚Ä¶‚Äù she frowns. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs ever going to want me like this?‚Äù

Regulus feels his brow furrow. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean ‚Äúlike this‚Äù you‚Äôre brilliant.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut who‚Äôll ever want to waste their time on someone who doesn‚Äôt even want to have sex?‚Äù

Regulus is feeling, admittedly, a little out of his depths here, but he can tell how much this means to Cerci. How much she‚Äôs clearly been worrying about it, so he‚Äôll do his best not to fuck it up.

‚ÄúSomeone who really cares about you, someone who deserves you, won‚Äôt ever feel like being with you is a waste of time, regardless of what you‚Äôre doing,‚Äù he says meaningfully.

The ghost of a voice runs through his mind.

I‚Äôm sorry.

it says,

I should have asked before I touched you.

Regulus‚Äôs heart stutters at the memory of James Potter, caring so much even after everything. James Potter who never made Regulus feel like a waste of time even when he couldn‚Äôt be normal.

‚ÄúYou think?‚Äù Cerci‚Äôs nervous voice brings him back to the present.

Regulus nods. ‚ÄúAbsolutely.‚Äù

A small smile flickers across her face. ‚ÄúHey, maybe we should just get married, huh?‚Äù

Regulus can‚Äôt help the laughter that bursts out of him.

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù she giggles, poking him in the side. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good idea! It would solve a lot of problems for the both of us.‚Äù

She‚Äôs not wrong. It would be incredibly convenient all things considered, and the Greengrass‚Äôs are a good enough family that his mother might actually consider it. For half a heartbeat Regulus considers it himself. But then‚Ä¶

‚ÄúYou said you wanted to fall in love.‚Äù

Cerci shrugs. ‚ÄúYeah but, not very likely is it?‚Äù

That‚Äôs not good enough for Regulus. Not nearly. ‚ÄúYou deserve that Cerci, you deserve to be in love with someone and to have them be in love with you. I want that for you.‚Äù

Her face softens and after a few seconds she leans over and gives him an innocent kiss on the cheek. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre very sweet you know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you say so.‚Äù

She snorts, shaking her head. ‚ÄúMerlin, I can‚Äôt believe I was ever afraid of you.‚Äù

Regulus bites the inside of his cheek, holding back a smile. ‚ÄúMe either, if anything you‚Äôre the scarier one out of the two of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúI KNOW!‚Äù she says with enough conviction that it shakes another laugh out of Regulus.

They go back to sitting in companionable silence, letting the distant voices and steps that fill the house wash over them.

‚ÄúHave you ever been?‚Äù Cerci asks, seemingly out of nowhere, which probably means she‚Äôs been thinking about it for a while.

‚ÄúHave I ever been what?‚Äù

‚ÄúIn love.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs chest gives a mighty squeeze and for a good moment he isn‚Äôt sure he‚Äôll be able to answer. Or breathe for that matter. He thinks about lying but decides against it. He doesn‚Äôt want to. Not to Cerci.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù his voice is rough and thin and he coughs to clear it out. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says more firmly. ‚ÄúI have.‚Äù

He can feel Cerci watching him but now he‚Äôs the one looking away, eyes firmly on the ceiling.

‚ÄúAre you still in love?‚Äù she‚Äôs whispers, like it‚Äôs a secret, which he supposes it is.

He takes a deep breath, closing his eyes on the exhale. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúReg‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOI BLACK!‚Äù Barty shouts up the staircase, startling Regulus into sitting up. ‚ÄúSend your girlfriend home, the meeting is about to start!‚Äù

He glares at the closed door like the other boy can see him. ‚ÄúFucking Barty,‚Äù he grumbles, and then to Cerci; ‚ÄúSorry about him, I‚Äôve told him were not together but he‚Äôs‚Ä¶well, a bit of prick honestly.‚Äù

Cerci smiles. ‚ÄúNah it‚Äôs okay. Kind of funny really, considering,‚Äù she nods to the floor, like all the truths that just passed between them are still lying there.

They both get to their feet, Regulus making a considerable effort to straighten out his clothes and hair and Cerci making comparably none. Boo raises his head and Regulus gives him a small nod before waving his wand and vanishing him into a pale mist.

‚ÄúOh!‚Äù Cerci gasps suddenly. ‚ÄúBefore I forget, I have your book!‚Äù

Regulus had almost forgotten. ‚ÄúBrilliant,‚Äù he says as she starts rummaging through her bag, dumping its vast and unexplainable contents onto Regulus‚Äôs bedroom floor.

‚ÄúIs that a bird cage?‚Äù he asks, squinting at the pile of rubbish she apparently carries around in her bag.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be ridiculous,‚Äù she looks up with a grin on her face. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a fairy cage.‚Äù And before Regulus can even begin to try and come up with a response to that; ‚ÄúAha!‚Äù

She holds up a black leather bound book, it has a thick spine and dark purple patterns carved into the cover. Cerci tosses it to him like it‚Äôs nothing but once it‚Äôs in Regulus‚Äôs hands it‚Äôs treated with reverence. Most books are. The letters on the front read: Secrets of the Darkest Art.

‚ÄúThank you, ‚Äù he runs his hand over the embezzled cover. Recently the Dark Lord has started making odd requests of Regulus, for vitality potions, the type of thing one might ask for if their magical core had recently been damaged. Except that if that had happened Voldemort would have been incapacitated and as far as Regulus can tell‚Äîand track‚Äîthe Dark Lord is as mobile as ever, hopping around the country and abroad. That paired with his changes in appearance has peaked Regulus‚Äôs interest.

‚ÄúMy mum hates all that stuff, all the old family antiques and things,‚Äù Cerci is going on as she swings her bag over her shoulder. ‚ÄúShe says it‚Äôs creepy, doesn‚Äôt match the decor, but obviously we can‚Äôt get rid of it,‚Äù she scrunches her face. ‚ÄúI think she tried once and dad threw a fit.‚Äù

Regulus lets out a small laugh, trying to imagine Walburga ever throwing away dark magical objects because they didn‚Äôt match the decor. The book in his hands contains information on some of the darkest magic possible. Regulus had been surprised that he couldn't find it in the Black family library. He‚Äôs been pulling everything he can think of on spells that are strong enough to tamper with someone‚Äôs magical core. This one is the last on his list and as far as he can tell there are only two copies in existence: one at Hogwarts and one in the Greengrass family‚Äôs private collections.

‚ÄúReally,‚Äù Regulus says, hiding the book under his mattress before following Cerci towards the stairs. ‚ÄúI appreciate it, I‚Äôve been looking for that for ages.‚Äù

Cerci gives him a funny look. ‚ÄúAny reason in particular?‚Äù she asks.

Regulus shrugs. ‚ÄúJust trying to solve a puzzle.‚Äù

‚ÄúHmm,‚Äù she keeps looking at him. ‚ÄúShould I be worried? That‚Äôs a pretty scary book.‚Äù

Regulus almost laughs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve noticed,‚Äù he gestures to the dark stairwell, the looming faces of the Black family glaring down at them. ‚ÄúBut most things in my life are scary.‚Äù He means it as a joke but it comes out sounding a little more strangled than he‚Äôd like and Cerci reaches out, hand circling his wrist as they stop on the last stair.

‚ÄúYou know I‚Äôm always here right? If you need anything?‚Äù

Regulus gives her a tight smile. ‚ÄúYeah, I know.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegggiiiieeeee! Baby, darling, we‚Äôre waitinnnnggggg,‚Äù comes Evan‚Äôs voice, Regulus looks over his shoulder to see his obnoxious friends standing by the dining room doors. He rolls his eyes but Cerci only laughs, leaning forward and kissing him on the cheek.

‚ÄúWe have a reputation to uphold don‚Äôt we?‚Äù she says with a wink. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you next week Reg.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, see you.‚Äù He smiles at her as she heads for the door and then steels himself for the teasing that he is sure is about to ensue.

‚ÄúThat,‚Äù Evan says as he walks towards them, ‚Äúwas adorable.‚Äù

‚ÄúShagging right before a meeting is a bold move,‚Äù Barty adds. ‚ÄúGuess you don‚Äôt need much time huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot much of a cuddler?‚Äù

‚ÄúNeed to work on your stamina.‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me, does Greengrass‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúALRIGHT, Jesus you two,‚Äù he gestures towards the doors behind them. ‚ÄúLets go shall we?‚Äù

Barty shakes his head. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such a tightwad Reg. Honestly, you‚Äôd think getting laid would relax you a little bit,‚Äù as if Barty is in any position to tell someone else they need to relax.

People are still standing around talking when they walk into the room, the Dark Lord predictably absent. Always wanting to make his entrance. They take their seats, thankfully this time Evan doesn‚Äôt force them to sit with Snape, though the other boy is there, looking as miserable as he always does these days.

Regulus can‚Äôt hold back the giant yawn that rips through him then.

‚ÄúWow, Greengrass really tuckered you out huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt start Barty,‚Äù Regulus warns. The truth is, he still isn‚Äôt sleeping well. Still having nightmares. He‚Äôs started brewing some dreamless sleep for himself, it ought to be ready in the next few days and hopefully he‚Äôll finally be able to get a full nights rest. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt want me making comments maybe don‚Äôt be so obvious about it,‚Äù Barty grumbles.

Regulus rolls his eyes but doesn‚Äôt bother continuing the conversation. He hasn‚Äôt got the energy for it.

Not even ten minutes later the doors open and everyone is suddenly rushing to their seats as the Dark Lord makes his way to the head of the table. Regulus scrutinizes his face, cataloguing details‚Äîthe way his nose has subtly lost some of its shape, the dimming of the colour of his eyes, slight thinning of his hair. It‚Äôs as though he‚Äôs‚Ä¶diluted somehow. But what the hell kind of spell does that? Is he cursed? Poisoned?

‚ÄúMy friends,‚Äù the Dark Lord begins, smiling out at them. ‚ÄúThere is joyous news to announce, this past week we were able to strike an incredible blow against Dumbledore‚Äôs cause.‚Äù

‚ÄúOoh goodie,‚Äù Evan whispers, but Regulus feels a wave of anxiety wash over him. He wasn‚Äôt aware of any plans to attack the other side, at least not anything important enough to warrant the glee currently flashing across Voldemort‚Äôs face.

It won‚Äôt be them,

he tries to calm himself down.

It won‚Äôt be James and Sirius, they aren‚Äôt important enough.

‚ÄúWilkes was able to gain Fleamont Potter‚Äôs trust,‚Äù Regulus‚Äôs whole body goes stiff. ‚ÄúHe was invited behind the Potter‚Äôs wards and able to poison their food. As of yesterday it has officially been announced that Euphemia Potter is dead and her husband is expected to follow her shortly.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a roar of approval from the room. A few jokes made about Euphemia Potter‚Äôs beauty and speculated sexual history. About Fleamont Potter‚Äôs bookish nature. Regulus can‚Äôt hear any of it, he just keeps watching the Dark Lord, waiting for him to open his mouth again, praying the next words out of it aren‚Äôt; ‚Äúand James Potter is also dead‚Äù.

‚ÄúIt is a job well done,‚Äù is what he actually says next, loosening the fear in Regulus‚Äôs chest ever so slightly. ‚ÄúThe Potters were important figures in the resistance against us, many will fall without their guidance.‚Äù

Oh James.

Oh god James.

I‚Äôm so sorry.

I‚Äôm so fucking sorry.

He has the foolish desire to go to him. He doesn‚Äôt know where James is living now but he does know where his parents house is and he imagines James will be there, at least eventually, to gather up their stuff if for no other reason.

Don‚Äôt be stupid, his brain hisses back at him.

He has Sirius.

He has Lily Evans.

He doesn‚Äôt need you.

‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs one more person deserving of some recognition my lord.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs focus snaps back to the present at the sound of Lucius‚Äôs voice. He looks over at where he‚Äôs sitting, close enough to touch the Dark Lord.

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù Voldemort asks. ‚ÄúAnd who else would you honour, Lucius?‚Äù

The blond man grins. ‚ÄúRegulus, of course, our little potioneer.‚Äù

At first Regulus can‚Äôt figure it out. Doesn‚Äôt know why Lucius would say that. Even when the whole room seems to turn to him he still hasn‚Äôt made the connection.

‚ÄúAh, of course,‚Äù the Dark Lord says, eyes falling on Regulus who does his best not to flinch under the cold gaze. ‚ÄúThere cannot be a poisoning without the poison. We are indebted to your skill as always Regulus Black.‚Äù

‚ÄúHere, here!‚Äù Evan cheers, as others begin to clap.

And that. Then. That‚Äôs when he finally understands.

He brewed the poison.

The poison that killed Euphemia and Fleamont Potter.

He is responsible for this. Oh god he is responsible for this.

‚ÄúOi,‚Äù Evan hisses under his breath as the meeting continues on. ‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù

No, Regulus wants to scream. No. No. No.

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù he chokes out instead, sitting stock still as he feels the blood draining from his face. He's going to be sick. He‚Äôs almost positive he‚Äôs going to be sick.

Oh James.

Oh god James.

I‚Äôm so sorry.

I‚Äôm so fucking sorry.

¬†

PART IV REMUS

He walks along the quaint streets of Godric‚Äôs Hollow. He‚Äôs always felt a sense of comfort here, of calm, that he never felt in his actual home. Now though, there‚Äôs a very insistent unease that‚Äôs creeping under his skin, growing greater as he gets closer to the Potter‚Äôs cottage‚Äîor maybe it‚Äôs just James‚Äôs cottage now? The thought makes him grimace as he slips through the front gate.

He knocks but no one answers, and after a few minutes he tries the handle‚Äîunlocked. He rolls his eyes. You‚Äôd think there wasn‚Äôt a fucking war the way James carries on.

‚ÄúHello?‚Äù he calls out as he steps into the entranceway. None of the lights are on, his voice echoing through the empty rooms. For a moment he‚Äôs frozen by the sight of the staircase. He knows that upstairs, in the master bedroom, the body of Euphemia Potter is lying on her bed, preserved by magic. The thought makes him shiver.

‚ÄúJames!‚Äù he calls out again, still receiving no answer. He forces himself to move from the front hall to the kitchen. ‚ÄúJames?‚Äù that‚Äôs when he notices the back door is ajar. Really, he should have guessed as much.

It‚Äôs a beautiful day out, sunny and not too humid, something sweet about the air. He walks across the Potter‚Äôs back garden towards the small Quidditch pitch Fleamont built for James when he was little. It only takes him a minute to spot him, high in the air, diving and twirling. It‚Äôs been a while since he‚Äôs been able to watch James fly and he feels something ache in his chest‚Äîfor the dream that was taken away from his friend. Remus has never cared about Quidditch, but he‚Äôs always loved watching his boys fly.

He doesn‚Äôt call out, choosing instead to sit on the grass, shielding his eyes from the sun as he stares up into the sky. It‚Äôs another twenty minutes before James finally touches down.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know you were coming over,‚Äù he says in leu of hello, dismounting his broom and dropping down onto the grass beside Remus.

He shrugs. ‚ÄúI was in the neighbourhood.‚Äù

James gives him a skeptical look.

‚ÄúWell, I mean, I was at Hogwarts.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not even remotely in the neighbourhood.‚Äù

Another shrug. ‚ÄúEverything is in the neighbourhood when you can Apparate.‚Äù

James snorts, looking out at the field in front of them, breathing heavy, dark hair plastered to his head with sweat. ‚ÄúSirius send you?‚Äù he asks finally.

‚ÄúAnd Lily,‚Äù they‚Äôre both busy with Order business; Lily still working on trying to track down the missing Order members, and Sirius‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶Sirius didn‚Äôt say. Remus expects that was out of spite.

James plays with the handle of his broom. ‚ÄúHow is Sirius?‚Äù he asks eventually. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs he‚Ä¶dealing with‚Ä¶‚Äù he waves his hand in the air, words failing him. James looks tired.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs‚Ä¶‚Äù something grows tight in Remus‚Äôs chest and he has no idea why. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs struggling I think. It‚Äôs hard for him.‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúThey were his parents too,‚Äù there‚Äôs no bitterness, no jealousy, the only person who wanted Sirius to be adopted by the Potters more than Sirius himself was James. ‚ÄúHe hasn‚Äôt said anything to me‚Ä¶about struggling.‚Äù

That doesn‚Äôt surprise Remus. ‚ÄúI think he feels guilty‚Ä¶like he doesn‚Äôt deserve to mourn them the way he is. Doesn‚Äôt deserve to feel it as much as he does. That‚Äôs just speculation though he isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶‚Äù the tightening increases, a vice grip around his lungs, ‚Äúisn‚Äôt really saying anything to me either.‚Äù

James gives him a look. It‚Äôs a ‚Äúcan you blame him?‚Äù look, which Remus does not appreciate in the slightest.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt start,‚Äù he grumbles.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt say anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour face did.‚Äù

James lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúWell my face is a dirty liar, you know that.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes, pulling at the grass for a minute before forcing himself to continue, unable to let it go. He‚Äôs both desperate to talk about it and desperate to avoid it at the same time.

‚ÄúWhat would you have done? If Dumbledore had made you swear not to tell anyone?‚Äù he looks up at his friend, sunlight reflecting off his glasses. ‚ÄúIf he said it was for the safety of the Order. What would you have done?‚Äù

James takes his time answering, eyes thoughtful. Remus feels himself squirm under the attention.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd have told Sirius.‚Äù

Remus scoffs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd have told Lily‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James corrects. ‚ÄúI would have told Sirius. Lily would be fine, I mean, she‚Äôd worry and all, but she wouldn‚Äôt eat herself alive. Wouldn‚Äôt think it was somehow her fault that I was gone. Wouldn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd choose never to come back to her.‚Äù

Remus looks away, his grass pulling growing a little more aggressive. ‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt even make any sense. How could he possibly think it was his fault?‚Äù he asks, even though part of Remus knows that James is right.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think a lot of what happened to him in that house made sense,‚Äù and then, like he‚Äôs read Remus‚Äôs mind. ‚ÄúBut you don‚Äôt need me to tell you that. You know it. So the only thing I can think is‚Äî‚Äú but he cuts himself off, causing Remus to look up again.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt bite my head off.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not biting your head off just‚Äîwhat were you going to say?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a long pause before James eventually goes on. ‚ÄúThe only reasons I can think of for you listening to Dumbledore‚Äîand don‚Äôt give me that following orders bullshit Remus, I know you too well, you‚Äôre as much a rule follower as I am‚Äîso either you really, honestly, don‚Äôt trust Sirius or‚Ä¶or you‚Äôre punishing him. Because you and I both know the easiest way to hurt Sirius Black is to leave him.‚Äù

Something drops from Remus‚Äôs chest into the pit of his stomach. He can‚Äôt speak at first, trying desperately to form words with his bone dry mouth. Mostly he just sits there staring at James, hating him a little for knowing him so well, hating himself for allowing this conversation to happen.

‚ÄúWhat could I possibly be punishing him for?‚Äù

James lets out a put-upon sigh. ‚ÄúYou know what.‚Äù

Remus makes a face. ‚ÄúThat was years ago.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh so we‚Äôve all forgotten it then?‚Äù

‚ÄúI forgave him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think you tried. I think you‚Äôre still trying.‚Äù

Remus lets out a growl before getting to his feet and walking a few paces away, his back to James. He tries his best to breathe‚Äîin through the nose, out through the mouth. It‚Äôs close to the full moon and he can feel the wolf prowling beneath his skin. Desperate to tear something apart.

Eventually he manages to calm down enough to speak. ‚ÄúI love him, you know?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù James says softly.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve only ever loved him,‚Äù Remus laughs humourlessly. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know what love means if it isn‚Äôt Sirius Black.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù James says again.

Remus closes his eyes for a second, trying not to choke on his words. ‚ÄúBut he can be so fucking cruel when he wants to be. When he‚Äôs angry. When he‚Äôs hurt. I don‚Äôt even think he means it, he just‚Ä¶snaps.‚Äù Remus exhales. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not trying to punish him. God I hope I‚Äôm not. But I‚ÄîI am scared of him.‚Äù

‚ÄúMoons‚Äî‚Äú

But he shakes his head. ‚ÄúI think Dumbledore is right, that we should keep what we know to ourselves, at least right now. Gives us fewer opportunities to make mistakes. To do things we don‚Äôt mean.‚Äù That was what Sirius had kept saying wasn‚Äôt it? After he‚Äôd taken the most sensitive part of Remus, the most vulnerable, the most painful, and served it up to Severus Snape on a silver plater as a joke.

I didn‚Äôt mean to hurt you Remus.

I didn‚Äôt mean it.

I didn‚Äôt mean it.

‚ÄúSo the lying is for his benefit then?‚Äù James‚Äôs voice drags him back to the present and Remus sends his friend a glare.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not lying.‚Äù

James makes a dissatisfied noise. ‚ÄúIf you say so.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you honestly telling me that you don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a world in which I tell him what I‚Äôm doing and then one day we have a row and he decides to go to the bloody Prophet with it, or take out a billboard, or whatever else he concocts in that mad head of his? Not thinking about the consequences. Not thinking about anything except how good a story he‚Äôs gonna get out of it. Not thinking period.‚Äù

James just stares at Remus for a minute. ‚ÄúFor the record,‚Äù James says eventually, ‚Äúhe isn‚Äôt fifteen anymore.‚Äù

And Remus actually feels a little ashamed at that, flush creeping up his neck.

‚ÄúBut what I‚Äôm actually trying to tell you,‚Äù James goes on. ‚ÄúIs that everything is a risk Remus, just like Moody says. Every choice, every word, every person. Loving each other, trusting each other, today? In this world? Right now? It‚Äôs a risk. But we do it anyway. Because having the people we love around us, next to us, in our beds, is worth it.‚Äù He runs a hand through his already thoroughly distressed hair. ‚ÄúYou have to decide what you‚Äôre willing to lose.‚Äù

Remus tenses at that. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to lose him.‚Äù The thought sends such an ache through him that he has to say it again, just incase the universe didn‚Äôt hear him the first time; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to lose him.‚Äù

James nods, not looking particularly surprised by this. ‚ÄúThen you‚Äôre going to have to start taking some risks.‚Äù

Remus isn't sure he‚Äôs quite ready to accept that. Ready to face that fear. Not sure he has the energy to admit that to James either. After a few seconds he comes back to sit next to him on the grass.

‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt supposed to talk about me you know,‚Äù he says eventually.

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize your visit had an agenda.‚Äù

Remus holds his stare, knowing that there‚Äôs probably a more delicate way to do this, but he‚Äôs never been a particularly delicate person. ‚ÄúYou have to bury her James.‚Äù

His friend instantly turns away, jaw tightening. Remus waits for him to speak, the trees in the distance rustling as the warm breeze blows through, further dishevelling James‚Äôs hair. The signs of grief are scratched all over him. Pale face and bruised eyes and fingers that won‚Äôt settle. Eventually, when the silence stretches on too long, Remus knocks his foot against James‚Äôs.

‚ÄúProngs?‚Äù he nudges softly.

It takes a few more seconds, but eventually James looks back at him.

‚ÄúYou have to burry her.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt actually,‚Äù he says coldly.

Remus bites his lower lip, all he‚Äôs done the past two days is think about this moment, think about what he wants to say to James. ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt fair,‚Äù he nods back towards the house. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt fair James, not to your mum, not to Sirius or anyone else who wants to mourn her, to say goodbye, to have closure. Not to you. I know that Lily and Sirius think you need to be dealt with gently but that‚Äôs never been us.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James agrees, and Remus is happy to be getting some participation out of him.

‚ÄúSo here‚Äôs the truth; you‚Äôre throwing a temper tantrum.‚Äù

That manages to get a startled laugh out of him. ‚ÄúMerlin Remus.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know, I know how insensitive that sounds, really I do,‚Äù he gives James an apologetic look. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not telling you that you need to get over this and move on, I‚Äôm not telling you to stop being sad or angry or whatever else it is that you are. I‚Äôm just saying‚Ä¶that you have to burry her. Because she‚Äôs dead,‚Äù James flinches and Remus reaches out and grabs his arm, squeezing tight. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry James, really I am, but you can‚Äôt change that, you can‚Äôt just stubborn her back to life by refusing to accept it.‚Äù

He watches James swallow with great effort. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to accept it,‚Äù he says honestly. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to move on. I don‚Äôt want her to go away somewhere that I can‚Äôt reach her,‚Äù he blinks the wetness out of his eyes, voice small.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Remus grimaces. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry. But you can‚Äôt fix this. I know that you want to but you can‚Äôt.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment of silence before James lets out a shaky exhale. ‚ÄúI miss them so much. I already miss them so much. How do you go through life missing people like this? Knowing it‚Äôll never go away? Never stop?‚Äù

Remus thinks briefly of his own mum. Of her smiling in the kitchen, baking, singing. ‚ÄúYou just do,‚Äù he says eventually, which is not exactly an inspiring piece of wisdom but it‚Äôs true nonetheless. There‚Äôs no choice. It‚Äôs keep going or give up. And Remus isn‚Äôt sure James is even capable of the second option.

James pulls his knees in, letting his head drop, face hiding behind his hair. Remus can feel the small tremors going through him, knows that he‚Äôs crying. Lets him. His hand migrates to James‚Äôs back, moving in slow circles. He hopes that one day they find out who did this. Who‚Äôs responsible. So he can tear every bone from their body with his fucking teeth.

After some amount of time James finally lifts his head, scrubbing quickly at his eyes, like he‚Äôs embarrassed, though Remus doesn‚Äôt know why.

‚ÄúStay for dinner?‚Äù he finally asks, voice a little thick but steadier than Remus would have expected.

Remus wrinkles his nose. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, are you cooking?‚Äù

James laughs, a little bit more sincerely than he has the whole time Remus has been there. ‚ÄúNo, take-away, obviously.‚Äù He gives Remus a small smile.

‚ÄúYeah okay, can‚Äôt stay too late though.‚Äù

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúYou got big plans Moony?‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs smile grows tight. ‚ÄúSomething like that.‚Äù

¬†

PART V SIRIUS

He‚Äôs tired.

He‚Äôs so fucking tired.

The stairs up to the flat feel fucking mountainous and all he keeps thinking about is dragging Remus to bed and curling around him, feeding off his warmth and his smell and the feel of his skin against his mouth.

‚ÄúRem?‚Äù he calls out when he shuts the door behind him. Remus‚Äôs mug is sitting on the table in the living room, the couch a mess of blankets. ‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù he tosses his keys into the bowl by the door and tears his boots off, too lazy to unlace them all the way.

He‚Äôs planning to go to the hospital tomorrow with James to spend some time with Fleamont. Then maybe go out after, get James some fresh air, give him something to do other than stare at his parents' dying or dead faces. The thought bites and scratches and tears on the way down.

He really is fucking tired.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù there‚Äôs no one in the bedroom, bed unmade, clothes on the floor‚ÄîSirius‚Äôs. He sighs as he heads back towards the kitchen. Remus must still be at James‚Äôs. Sirius thinks about just going to sleep but quickly dismisses the idea. If James needs people around than Sirius wants to be there. Wants to help.

He pours himself a glass of water and leans against the counter. He‚Äôll take a quick shower and then‚Äî

His brain stutters to a stop at the sight of a piece of parchment on the kitchen table. It could be anything really, Sirius doesn‚Äôt know why his first reaction is dread. Is suspicion. But the sight of it makes his stomach churn.

He places his glass in the sink and takes a cautious step forward. And then another one. And another one. Until he‚Äôs standing over it, reading the words with a shaking breath. He must go over it at least three times before actually touching it. Actually picking it up and admitting it‚Äôs real.

I‚Äôm sorry.

it says.

I‚Äôll come back. I promise I‚Äôll come back.

That‚Äôs all there is. Not that there needs to be more for Sirius to understand that Remus has left again. Left to do something somewhere that he won‚Äôt tell any of them about.

He‚Äôll be gone for the full moon‚Äîif it‚Äôs another week long disappearance Remus will be gone for the full moon. Fear overtakes Sirius‚Äôs anger for a moment. Because who‚Äôs going to look out for him? Who‚Äôs going to make sure he‚Äôs okay? Who‚Äôs going to bring him chocolate and tend to his wounds and make sure he doesn‚Äôt hurt himself too badly?

It‚Äôs been years since they were separated on the full moon.

Not since they were kids really. If you ignore those months in fifth year, after Snape...and Sirius usually tries to.

But then.

Remus chose this.

And there‚Äôs the anger again.

He reads the letter one more time before incendio-ing it. Walking to the bedroom and slamming the door. He doesn‚Äôt bother getting undressed, just crawls under the covers and wraps them around himself, pretending it doesn‚Äôt make him want to die that everything smells like Remus.

Chapter End Notes

HAPPY HOLIDAYS!!!!!!!!!!!!! (Or if you're not celebrating anything right now Happy Sunday)

I feel like there were so many good friendship moments in this chapter and that makes me happy.

Also fun fact, if you're sitting there thinking "where the heck is Mary Macdonald?" you're in luck, she's in the next chapter a lot (at least currently) sooo that's something to look forward to!

Thank you all so much for the comments and kudos etc. even as this fic has gotten a little more popular everyone has still been really nice and kind which I'm pretty sure isn't how the internet is supposed to work, so thank you for, y'know, being your lovely selves!!

Chapter 46

Chapter Summary

Tequila rarely leads to good life choices

Chapter Notes

TW: Drinking

CW/TW: Sexual content (ok I'm keeping the rating M for now cause that still feels accurate to me but if you follow me on tumblr you'll know I had a whole existential crisis about this, so if you think it should be changed to explicit let your girl know!)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I JAMES

A month after his wife, Fleamont Potter dies.

James isn‚Äôt there when it happens. Though he supposes at this point it doesn‚Äôt really matter. That‚Äôs what he tells himself anyway. They send him an owl, inform him that he needs to make arrangements for the body. In some ways, it‚Äôs a relief. They‚Äôve already been talking about his dad like he‚Äôs dead, at least now they don‚Äôt have to feel guilty about it.

James has only just brought his father home when he receives a summons from Dumbledore.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to go,‚Äù Lily says, as she reads the letter over his shoulder. ‚ÄúWrite him back‚Äîor hell, I‚Äôll go. Tell him to fuck off.‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúAs much as I appreciate the offer, I think I‚Äôd rather have something to do.‚Äù

She nods, giving him a soft smile and squeezing his arm. ‚ÄúPizza and butterbeer for dinner?‚Äù

James groans. ‚ÄúMerlin, yes. Have I ever told you I love you?‚Äù

‚ÄúOnce or twice.‚Äù

He kisses her then, one hand on the back of her neck, tilting her head up, her mouth warm and solid beneath his. ‚ÄúGood,‚Äù he murmurs against her, ‚Äúbecause I do.‚Äù

They‚Äôve unofficially moved into to his parents house, at least for the time being. James knows it‚Äôs been hard for Lily. Knows it isn‚Äôt ideal. But she‚Äôs still here, unshakable. A force of nature.

‚ÄúGo on then,‚Äù she says when they pull apart, giving his bum a smack. ‚ÄúGo see what the old man wants.‚Äù

James laughs. It helps, acting normal. Helps them both forget about the bodies upstairs.

Dumbledore has opened the Floo in his office so James is able to go directly to the castle instead of walking up from Hogsmeade. The old man is waiting for him, standing by the large window on the far wall, hands clasped behind his back. He smiles when he sees James, gesturing him into the chair in front of his desk.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to see you,‚Äù Dumbledore says, once they‚Äôre sitting across from one another. James doesn‚Äôt have a response for that, but it doesn‚Äôt appear that Dumbledore needs one. ‚ÄúHave you changed your mind on the matter of your parents‚Äô funerals?‚Äù

James grits his teeth. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll happen as soon as Remus is back.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Dumbledore nods sagely, not bothering to add anymore.

James arches his brow, voice sharp. ‚ÄúAny idea when that might be?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a twinkle in Dumbledore‚Äôs blue eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid I can‚Äôt say.‚Äù

James expected as much. It still pisses him off though.

‚ÄúYou wanted to see me?‚Äù he asks when the silence begins to drag, his knee bouncing impatiently up and down.

Dumbledore nods. ‚ÄúI did. We have it on good authority that Voldemort is going to be bringing some of his supporters from Bulgaria across the boarder in a weeks time. Very skilled and dangerous supporters. I intend to stop him.‚Äù

James stares blankly back at him. ‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúAnd you want me to‚Ä¶help?‚Äù

Dumbledore smiles. ‚ÄúOn the contrary, I want you to lead the mission.‚Äù

That takes James by surprise, Moody usually insists that only trained Aurors are given leadership roles. ‚ÄúEr, why me?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs our belief that the group will be flying over.‚Äù

It takes a minute for James to catch up. ‚ÄúOn brooms?‚Äù

‚ÄúPrecisely.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Ä¶‚Äù he shakes his head, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs bloody mental. That‚Äôs a multi-hour flight.‚Äù

‚ÄúIndeed,‚Äù there‚Äôs that twinkle again, ‚Äúbut seeing as the sky is the most difficult mode of transportation to monitor and control, I believe they think that it is the option that will give them the best chance of avoiding an ambush.‚Äù

It still sounds absurd to James, but he supposes he and Voldemort aren‚Äôt usually on the same wavelength so perhaps that makes sense.

‚ÄúWhy me though?‚Äù he asks again, which actually has Dumbledore chuckling.

‚ÄúAnd I was under the impression that you had a rather large ego. James, you are an exceptional flyer. The best in the Order, even better than the Aurors, though you‚Äôll not hear Moody say that aloud.‚Äù

‚ÄúFrank‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Dumbledore smiles. ‚ÄúYes well, Frank Longbottom was an excellent captain I think you and I can agree on that. But I‚Äôm afraid he can‚Äôt hold a candle to your flying. A fact he would freely admit himself if you asked.‚Äù

Deep down James knows that‚Äôs true, though he‚Äôll never be able to see Frank as being anything but aspirational. On and off the pitch.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he nods eventually. ‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôll do it. But I want Sirius with me.‚Äù

There‚Äôs the slight sharpening of Dumbledore‚Äôs expression. ‚ÄúSirius has his own assignments.‚Äù

But James shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo Sirius, no me. That‚Äôs nonnegotiable.‚Äù

The two men hold one another‚Äôs gazes for a long moment, neither flinching or looking away. Eventually though, Dumbledore does concede.

‚ÄúVery well, you‚Äôll be allowed at least three other people, if not four. Do you have any other‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúFrank, Alice, Marlene,‚Äù James lists off before Dumbledore has even finished the question. ‚ÄúAnd Mary.‚Äù

The old man arches his brow. ‚ÄúMary Macdonald?‚Äù he asks.

James nods.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not a member of the Order.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù James says without much concern. There‚Äôs another pause before Dumbledore inclines his head in James‚Äôs direction.

‚ÄúVery well, if you can get her to agree I don‚Äôt see why she can‚Äôt accompany you,‚Äù and then, a little wryly; ‚ÄúA Gryffindor team reunion.‚Äù

James hadn‚Äôt realized it, but he supposes it is what he‚Äôs doing isn‚Äôt it? He shrugs, ‚ÄúBest flyers I‚Äôve ever met.‚Äù

Dumbledore is smiling again. ‚ÄúIndeed.‚Äù

James feels the finality of that answer, rising to his feet. ‚ÄúAre we done?‚Äù

Dumbledore gestures to the fireplace. ‚ÄúWe are. Alastor and I will be in contact with you shortly to iron out the details.‚Äù

James stares at the fireplace for a minute, feeling his chest tighten. He‚Äôs not quite ready to go back yet. To that house. To everything in it. All the grief he still has to face. Eventually he shakes his head, taking a step back.

‚ÄúI think I‚Äôll go for a walk actually,‚Äù he nods towards the office doors. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve been to Hogsmeade.

There‚Äôs the flicker of surprise on Dumbledore‚Äôs face but he quickly wipes it away. ‚ÄúWell then, by all means.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt bother with much more of a goodbye. It isn‚Äôt that he doesn‚Äôt like Dumbledore exactly. He doesn‚Äôt agree with him always, but James knows that none of them would be here if it wasn‚Äôt for him. Knows that Dumbledore is the backbone of the resistance and that as hard as all of them try it‚Äôs nothing compared to him. James is, in many ways, grateful for Dumbledore. It‚Äôs just that he always leaves James uneasy and he can never quite pinpoint why.

It‚Äôs the end of the summer holidays, nearly September, but there are no children in the school yet. So James takes his time, walking leisurely through the familiar halls. There‚Äôs a deep aching nostalgia that settles itself in the pit of his stomach. His memories like bruises. They‚Äôd been happy here.
