They‚Äôd been other things too of course, but he thinks above all, when it comes down to it, they‚Äôd been happy.

It happens by accident really. He means to be making his way towards the front doors. He doesn‚Äôt know how he ends up on the seventh floor. Ends up in front of a wall that barely needs any prompting at all, as if it still remembers him after all this time, producing a familiar looking door out of thin air.

For a moment, just a moment, James considers walking away. But of course he doesn‚Äôt. He never could. His breath hitches when he steps through, like stepping back in time. Everything is the same‚Äîthe bed, the furniture, the painting on the ceiling. It even smells the same.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he says shakily. These memories are more than a bruise.

He forces himself to walk further inside, eyes and hands greedy to touch everything. It‚Äôs overwhelming. And he can‚Äôt help but wonder if the last time anyone was in this room was the day Regulus showed him his Mark. He wonders if it‚Äôs been sitting here all this time, waiting. If it‚Äôs missed them.

He reaches the back wall, places his palms flat on the stone and drops his head. Trying to breathe. Trying to understand what the hell he‚Äôs doing. He loves Lily. He loves her. So where do all these other‚Ä¶feelings fit? This painful need. To have him. To hold him. To keep him safe.

He remembers Regulus, sleep mussed and sitting in the middle of the bed, smiling.

I might even be happy,

he‚Äôd said.

If you can believe it.

James‚Äôs nails curl against the cold stone. He never did tell his dad about Regulus. It hadn‚Äôt felt important before. He isn‚Äôt sure why it feels important now. James tries to clear his head, tries to focus on the things he needs to do, tries to make lists. Get himself together enough to walk back out that door. But it doesn‚Äôt work. His brain a mess of black curls and hesitant smiles and love. So much love.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses again, pulling back and slamming his palms into the wall. Pain vibrates all along his forearms, the mirror next to him shaking before it crashes to the floor.

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù James steps back as broken pieces scatter across his shoes, the golden frame laying face down. ‚ÄúShit,‚Äù he repeats, having absolutely no idea how you‚Äôre supposed to fix things in an enchanted room. He bends down, carefully lifting up the nearly empty frame, a few more pieces sliding off and crashing onto the floor. He tries to run through all the domestic spells he knows, tries to figure out if any of them are any use in this situation, and that‚Äôs when his eyes find the now bare wall in front of him.

That‚Äôs when he sees the carvings.

He places the broken mirror back on the floor and steps forward. There, carved into the wall, are initials:

G & S

James traces them with his finger before his hand trails down to the second set of letters, carved just beneath:

J & R

The second carving is slightly rougher, but still clear, and James‚Äôs finger follows the twists and curves as he tries to make sense of it. Tries to convince himself that it‚Äôs just a coincidence. Because it couldn‚Äôt have been Reg could it? When would he have done it? Why wouldn‚Äôt he have said anything? Was it‚Ä¶was it after? Did he come back after all of it was over and carve them into the walls?

James flattens his palm over the letters, like he‚Äôs trying to press them into his skin. Like he‚Äôs trying to force a hole in space and time and go back to when they were written. He knows what they mean of course. Knows what this is.

It‚Äôs an I love you.

Reg never said it back that last time.

He carved them into stone but he couldn‚Äôt say it.

Not when James was walking away.

The same way Sirius had walked away.

I love you.

James pulls his hand back from the wall and starts moving. He has to. There‚Äôs nothing in this room but heartbreak, he doesn‚Äôt know why he came here. This is the last fucking thing he needs. He just wants to go home to Lily and curl up on the couch and eat pizza and drink butterbeer and pretend that things are getting better. And pretend that he doesn‚Äôt still feel as raw and lost as he did on the day he walked into that kitchen and found his mum slumped over the table.

He wants to be happy loving the things he has.

Because it‚Äôs killing him to want the things he doesn‚Äôt.

¬†

PART II REGULUS

The problem with Dreamless Sleep, is it only helps when you‚Äôre not awake. These days Regulus‚Äôs nightmares don‚Äôt stay under his bed. Though he supposes, depending on who you ask, maybe they never did. Maybe they always had faces and voices and hands. In any case, Regulus is nothing if not a problem solver.

He‚Äôs started playing around with different potions‚Äîthe endorphins of Amortentia, the high of Pain Potions, the peace of Calming Draughts. He hasn‚Äôt gotten the mix right just yet, but he thinks he‚Äôs close. Then maybe he‚Äôll be able to get them all to shut up. The ghosts in his head. In his chest. In the corners of his house. Two had been enough to keep him up at night. But four is driving him insane.

He‚Äôs been closing off Grimmauld Place, bit by bit. He suggested to the Dark Lord that meetings be held elsewhere, for the sake of maintaining the integrity of his potions, of course. There‚Äôs a new paranoia that Dumbledore may have gotten himself his own ‚Äòsource‚Äô and Regulus expressed his fear that someone might be tampering with his lab. It was a flimsy excuse but he received no push back, especially not once Lucius offered up Malfoy Manner. Always so happy to be of service. To make himself important.

Walburga was furious of course. As was Bellatrix. They yelled through the Floo. They sent howlers. They showed up and threw pots and vases and curses. But it‚Äôs no matter. Walburga isn‚Äôt coming back from Scotland and Bellatrix‚Äôs claim on the house does not supersede Regulus‚Äôs. So the unofficial Death Eater headquarters have moved and Regulus has started tightening up his wards. He can‚Äôt keep out his family of course, as much as he might want to. But there are no more strangers walking around.

The house is much quieter now.

Most days that‚Äôs good.

Some days it feels like suffocating.

The potions he‚Äôs currently brewing aren‚Äôt complicated enough to hold Regulus‚Äôs attention‚Äîto keep his mind from wandering. He‚Äôs taken some Calming Draught but it isn‚Äôt powerful enough and his homemade concoction still isn‚Äôt ready. After his third lap around the house he grabs his cloak and Apparates to the first place he can think of. Which turns out to be Diagon Alley.

It‚Äôs nearly September, which always makes him think of school, of coming here with Kreacher and picking out his books and gear. He expects that‚Äôs why he thought of it. And true to form the streets are filled with families‚Äîwith children whose eyes are nearly too big for their faces as they stare through shop windows, ogling sweets and racing brooms and potential new pets. It makes Regulus feel ancient.

He‚Äôs only eighteen.

He keeps the hood of his cloak up, doesn‚Äôt draw attention to himself, mostly stays out of the shops. He spots one or two Aurors lurking about but they don‚Äôt seem to notice him. He knows they‚Äôre only the tip of the iceberg, that Moody has this place locked down tight. This was a bad idea. Of all the places to go, he decided on the one place where he‚Äôs most likely to cause a scene. It isn‚Äôt that he‚Äôs technically ‚Äúwanted‚Äù but technicalities are a funny thing these days, and he knows that if the Aurors catch sight of him they‚Äôll do their best to find a way to drag him in for questioning.

He wonders if James would come, if he got arrested. If he would sit across some intimidating table and drill him with questions while dumping Veritaserum down his throat. Or if he‚Äôd drag him away to safety. The war be damned.

It‚Äôs a pathetic thought.

But he has a lot of those.

Daydreams about James Potter. He thanks Merlin every day he‚Äôs as good at Occlumency as he is.

The sun is out, peeking at them from behind the clouds that intermittently pass overhead. Regulus pauses near the end of the street where the crowds are thinner, tilting his head back ever so slightly and feeling the warm light brush his skin. He doesn‚Äôt go out much these days. Can‚Äôt even remember the last time he flew. The thought makes something in his stomach ache.

He sighs, dropping his head back down and getting ready to turn towards the Leaky Cauldron again, when something catches his eye‚Äîlong black hair, a leather jacket, a scowling face. Regulus‚Äôs whole body reacts to the sight of Sirius walking away down the street, like an electric shock has just been sent through him.

It‚Äôs been ages since he saw his brother.

Years.

Which shouldn‚Äôt matter really. Not in the grand scheme of things. It certainly shouldn‚Äôt change the direction Regulus is heading in. And yet, inexplicably, he feels himself moving forward, following after. He seems to be on a roll today, where poor decision making is concerned.

They turn off the main street, Regulus keeping a good distance between them and Sirius apparently not bothering to check behind himself. Typical. It‚Äôs not until he sees his brother heading for the side door of a shop that he realizes he‚Äôs about to lose him. Which is good, this has been going on long enough, he‚Äôs lucky Sirius is such an unobservant idiot that he hasn‚Äôt found him out already. Now he can watch him disappear inside and head back home where he should have stayed all along.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù

Oh goddamnit.

Sirius turns around infuriatingly leisurely, like they aren‚Äôt in the middle of a war where people are murdered and kidnapped on the daily. Like he isn‚Äôt an obvious target given his position in the Order and the galling nature of his betrayal of the Black family. He doesn‚Äôt look like someone who is being eaten alive by fear or anxiety. He doesn‚Äôt even have the fucking curtesy to look surprised when he sees Regulus, his eyes running the younger boy up and down before arching his brow.

‚ÄúWell look who the fuck it is,‚Äù he says eventually, leaning back against the door he was about to walk through and crossing his arms over his chest‚Äîthe opposite in every way to a prepared, defensive stance.

‚ÄúWhat the hell are you doing?‚Äù Regulus can‚Äôt help blurting out. ‚ÄúI could be here to attack you you fucking idiot.‚Äù

This too, does not appear to sway Sirius. ‚ÄúYour wands not out.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äîwell‚Äîit, I might‚Äîyou don‚Äôt‚Äîwhat if there were other people, what if I‚Äôm the distraction!‚Äù he says flustered.

Sirius‚Äôs brow remains arched. ‚ÄúAre there other people?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not the point!‚Äù

‚ÄúIt feels like the point.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ Sirius, how you aren‚Äôt dead yet is a fucking mystery.‚Äù

That manages to pull something vaguely resembling a smile out of his older brother, though Regulus has no idea why. ‚ÄúYou always were such a worrier.‚Äù

Regulus scowls. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a worrier, I‚Äôm just rational.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù his eyes run Regulus over again, it‚Äôs an uncanny move that reminds Regulus of their mother, the way she can make you feel so small with just a look. ‚ÄúSo what the hell are you doing here Reg?‚Äù

Regulus opens and closes his mouth, finding he has no answer for that question. So he decides to change the subject. ‚ÄúWhat the hell are you doing here?‚Äù he demands instead.

At first he thinks Sirius isn‚Äôt going to answer but then: ‚ÄúI live here.‚Äù

Which Regulus wasn‚Äôt expecting. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù and then, before he can stop himself. ‚ÄúI thought you lived with‚Äî‚Äú he cuts himself off.

Sirius only waits about half a second before he decides to finish the sentence for him. ‚ÄúWith James?‚Äù he asks, Regulus neither confirms nor denies that that was what he was going to say. ‚ÄúNo. Not since school. He lives with Lily.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvans?‚Äù Regulus hates the way that feels coming out of his mouth.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius says, laughing slightly, as though it‚Äôs ridiculous to think that there could be any other Lily on the planet.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Regulus fully intends to leave the conversation there, and yet; ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre together then?‚Äù It isn‚Äôt that he hadn‚Äôt suspected, only it feels different to know. To have it confirmed.

Sirius considers him for a moment before nodding.

‚ÄúHave they‚Äîsince‚Ä¶‚Äù Regulus fidgets. Merlin this is ridiculous, he can‚Äôt even believe they‚Äôre having this conversation. He needs to go, he needs to get out of here.

‚ÄúNot until the end of our seventh year,‚Äù Sirius says, surprisingly kindly. ‚ÄúIt took him a long time to‚Ä¶you know.‚Äù

Except Regulus doesn‚Äôt know, but he desperately wants to. Wants to know if James talked about him and what he said and how fucking painful it was for him because Regulus spent most of that first year without James feeling sick all the time.

Luckily, however, he does appear to have some self-restraint left, because all he says is;

‚ÄúRight.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment of tense silence before Sirius pushes himself off the wall. He steps forward and Regulus eyes him warily.

‚ÄúI expect you know,‚Äù Sirius says, a new weight in his voice. Regulus is about to ask what exactly it is he‚Äôs expected to know when suddenly he realizes‚Äîa wave a nausea washing over him.

‚ÄúYou mean about the Potters?‚Äù he asks, hoping his voice isn‚Äôt straining too much.

Sirius nods sharply, eyes intense. ‚ÄúWho did it Reg? Tell me who fucking did it.‚Äù There‚Äôs an edge that wasn‚Äôt there before but that feels familiar, an anger. And it hits Regulus that his brother has been behaving suspiciously politely.

‚ÄúYou wanted information,‚Äù he says out loud, more to himself than to Sirius. He should have known that was the only thing that would keep Sirius from ripping his head off. Honestly, it‚Äôs a miracle that neither of them has drawn their wand yet.

‚ÄúJust tell me this one thing, just this once have a fucking spine.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck you,‚Äù even if Sirius does have a point.

‚ÄúForget me, think about James huh? You want me to believe you really gave a shit about him? Tell me who killed his parents.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck. You.‚Äù

Regulus is shaking and it‚Äôs only partially from anger. Because he could tell Sirius the truth, could tell him it was Wilke‚Äôs who played the Potters. He could even tell him what department he works for at the Ministry. Except that maybe they would find him. And maybe they would talk to him before cutting him into pieces or flaying him open or doing whatever else it is they intend to do. And maybe he would let slip that it was Regulus who brewed the poison. Ice cold fear shoots through him and he takes a stumbling step backwards.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt,‚Äù Sirius warns, now letting all facades fall away. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you fucking dare try to run away. They were murdered, they were murdered by some cowards too afraid to face them. That‚Äôs whose fucking side you‚Äôre on. A bunch of weak backed Purebloods who can‚Äôt even look the people they‚Äôre about to kill in the eye,‚Äù he gives Regulus a disgusted look. ‚ÄúBut then, I guess that‚Äôs why you‚Äôve always fit in with them so well huh?‚Äù

Regulus turns on his heel while he still can, desperate to get away.

‚ÄúStupify!‚Äù he hears Sirius shout behind him, but he swerves to the side, listening as the spell bounces off the cobblestone as he rounds the corner onto the busier street. He‚Äôs shoving people out of his way, hood falling back, causing far more of a scene than he ever wanted to. He knows Sirius won‚Äôt try to curse him again, not in the crowd, but that doesn‚Äôt mean‚Äî

‚ÄúDEATH EATER!‚Äù he hears his brother‚Äôs voice carrying through the street, bouncing off the buildings, he winces, still pushing forward. ‚ÄúDeath Eater! Get him‚ÄîSampson fucking get him!‚Äù

Regulus is going to assume Sampson is one of the Aurors he saw earlier. Or maybe one of the Aurors he didn‚Äôt see. Either way he doesn‚Äôt look for him, doesn‚Äôt check behind him to see where Sirius is. There are spells placed on high traffic areas like this, that prevent Wizards from being able to just Apparate wherever they choose‚Äîthere would be too many collisions‚Äîother wise he would have done so already. But he can see one of the Apparation points just up ahead.

‚ÄúStop him! Don‚Äôt let him through, fucking‚Äî‚Äú

Regulus gasps as he stumbles out of the crowd and into the designated Apparating zone, air flying from his lungs as he throws himself into the spell, ripping himself away from the street. His brother‚Äôs voice a fading noise in the background.

¬†

PART III SIRIUS

He doesn‚Äôt tell James about Regulus. James already has enough to deal with and Sirius doesn‚Äôt feel like opening up old wounds. Plus, in general, he likes to think as little as possible about what happened between his brother and his best mate.

They‚Äôre meeting in the Hog‚Äôs Head tonight. Dingy pub run by Dumbledore‚Äôs brother, who is technically in the Order but who never seems to be around. Either way, he agreed to close down early tonight so that James could bring them together for this bloody mission he‚Äôs been given. Not that Sirius is complaining really, it‚Äôs the most interesting thing he‚Äôs had to do in weeks, and he needs a distraction. Remus has been gone more than twice as long as he was last time. Sirius has no idea if he‚Äôs okay or when he‚Äôs coming back and it‚Äôs started to drive him a little barmy. It‚Äôs not helped by the fact that James refuses to burry his parents until Remus gets back. Just adds to the list of things he‚Äôs pissed at Remus for.

‚ÄúDo we know what kind of brooms they‚Äôll be riding?‚Äù Frank asks about two hours into the meeting. As far as Sirius is concerned all the important details have already been hashed out and the rest is boring semantics.

If Remus was here‚Äîwhich he wouldn‚Äôt be anyway because the bastard can‚Äôt even fly‚Äîbut if he was here, right about now he‚Äôd be fighting back a smile because he‚Äôd know that Sirius was getting ready to jump out of his skin with impatience. And he‚Äôd be enjoying every minute of it. Of course he‚Äôd also make up some excuse to get them out early, and start laughing at Sirius the minute they left the room. Sometimes, when Remus laughs really hard he snorts and Sirius absolutely does not find it endearing.

Anyway. None of that matters. Because Remus isn‚Äôt here.

‚ÄúI think we can expect their brooms will be high-end,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúThe Purebloods in Bulgaria aren‚Äôt lacking in Galleons, and neither are our lot.‚Äù

Frank nods, ‚ÄúSome of the new domestic models have cloaking features on them. That might be a problem for us.‚Äù

‚ÄúCloaking features?‚Äù

‚ÄúTo help prevent any nosy Muggle neighbours from seeing you,‚Äù Alice explains. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty low-level invisibility and camouflage but, they wont have to worry about casting those spells themselves.‚Äù

James bites his lower lip, clearly thinking. ‚ÄúOkay, worth keeping in mind. I‚Äôll see if I can get my hands on one of those, take a look at what they‚Äôre all about.‚Äù

Great,

Sirius thinks.

Lets all go home now.

‚ÄúAny word on how many we‚Äôre expecting?‚Äù Frank asks, and Sirius barely holds back a groan.

They‚Äôll never have an exact number, there‚Äôs no way for them to get that information, surely Frank is aware of that?

‚ÄúDumbledore‚Äôs best guess is five at the least and ten at the most,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúBut that is just a guess, technically we have no idea.‚Äù

They never bloody do these days.

‚ÄúSo glad he only gave us enough people to handle the lowest possible number,‚Äù Mary says flatly, and Sirius fails to hold back a snort.

‚ÄúAw come on Macdonald,‚Äù James says good-naturedly, like their back in the Quidditch locker room. ‚ÄúYou really think you can only handle one Death Eater? I always figured you for more of a multitasker than that.‚Äù

Mary rolls her eyes, giving James the middle finger, but she doesn‚Äôt push the issue.

‚ÄúOkay great,‚Äù James claps his hands together. ‚ÄúAnymore questions?‚Äù

There better fucking not be.

‚ÄúActually I was wondering‚Äî‚Äú

Sirius thinks he should be commended for the fact that he simply decides to tune Frank out for the next thirty minutes and not murder him. Sirius couldn‚Äôt tell you what the hell he was asking but somehow he continues to come up with questions until eventually even James has had enough.

‚ÄúI think we better wrap up,‚Äù he runs a hand through his disheveled hair.

‚ÄúI second that motion!‚Äù Sirius says quickly.

‚ÄúMe too,‚Äù Marlene yawns, sliding out of the booth. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm knackered. Got guard duty tomorrow morning too.‚Äù

Everyone is nodding in similar states of exhaustions except for Frank. This is the problem with having a nerd on your team. I mean, arguably Remus is a nerd, but he‚Äôs more of an aloof sarcastic nerd and less of a bug-the-teacher-for-extra-coursework kind of nerd.

‚ÄúI still think we should go over‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDarling,‚Äù Alice drawls as she shoves him out of his chair and onto his feet. ‚ÄúIf you ever want to get laid again you‚Äôll stop talking now.‚Äù

Sirius snorts, sidling up to James at the front of the table as their friends start making their way outside.

‚ÄúGood meeting captain,‚Äù he says, knocking James with his elbow. James rolls his eyes.

‚ÄúNot a captain anymore.‚Äù

‚ÄúSays the man who just brought the Gryffindor Quidditch team back together.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou sound like Dumbledore.‚Äù

‚ÄúWise beyond my years?‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty sure he‚Äôs wise well within his years.‚Äù

Sirius laughs as he watches James finish packing up his notes, slipping them into the messenger bag he swings over his shoulder.

‚ÄúHey, stay for a drink yeah?‚Äù Sirius says, in a voice that he hopes sounds casual and not at all desperate. ‚ÄúOpen bar and all that,‚Äù he nods to said bar just over James‚Äôs shoulder.

His friend arches his brow. ‚ÄúAberforth give you permission to drink his booze did he?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, he didn‚Äôt explicitly tell me not to,‚Äù Sirius shoots him a grin. ‚ÄúWhich is basically the same thing.‚Äù

James smiles back at him but it doesn‚Äôt quite reach his eyes. ‚ÄúListen Pads,‚Äù he rubs the back of his neck. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just kind of‚Ä¶I‚Äôm a little tired can we‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYeah, ‚Äòcourse,‚Äù Sirius cuts him off quickly. He knows that it isn‚Äôt a rejection. Knows that James really is fucking tired. But for some reason it still burns like one. ‚ÄúAnother time yeah?‚Äù

James reaches over and squeezes his arm in thanks. ‚ÄúYeah, after we kick some Death Eater ass in a few days.‚Äù

‚ÄúDamn straight,‚Äù Sirius hopes his good cheer is believable. It must be at least a little bit because James goes, leaving Sirius alone in the empty pub. He should really go home himself, he knows that, but, quite frankly, he hates being home these days. And there‚Äôs a fully stacked bar just sitting in front of him, ripe for the taking.

He‚Äôs only just started pouring his first drink when Mary comes strutting out from the back, scaring the living daylights out of him.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck Macdonald!‚Äù he shouts, spilling tequila all down his front. ‚ÄúWere you hiding back there or something?‚Äù He pulls out his wand and vanishes the mess.

‚ÄúWhat? No,‚Äù she says, not bothering to hide the fact that she‚Äôs laughing at him. ‚ÄúI went to the bathroom.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a bathroom in this place?‚Äù Sirius asks, looking around and feeling certain that any bathroom in a pub like this is one he has no desire to visit.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been here how many times?‚Äù Mary asks, stepping up to the bar. ‚ÄúHow did you not know there was a bathroom?‚Äù

Sirius shrugs, pouring himself a new drink. ‚ÄúDunno, never looked I guess. Always just go outside,‚Äù he nods his head towards the door.

Mary wrinkles her nose in distaste. ‚ÄúJesus, men really are dogs aren‚Äôt they?‚Äù

Sirius bites his lower lip, holding back a smile. ‚ÄúYou have no idea.‚Äù

He grabs a new glass and holds it up. ‚ÄúDrink?‚Äù he asks.

Mary seems to debate with herself for a minute before giving up. ‚ÄúFuck it,‚Äù she says, sliding onto the barstool across from him. ‚ÄúWhy not.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the spirit,‚Äù Sirius grins as he gives her a generous pour, sliding the glass across the bar top. ‚ÄúSo, haven‚Äôt seen you around much lately.‚Äù

He‚Äôs leaning forward, resting on his elbows as he waits for her answer.

Mary only shrugs. ‚ÄúYes, well, you lot are all busy saving the world and I‚Äôm off to an office job every morning so‚Äîour paths aren‚Äôt exactly crossing.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere are you working again?‚Äù Sirius asks, taking a good gulp of his drink. It tastes awful‚Äîleave it to Aberforth to get the bottom shelf shite‚Äîstill though, it doesn‚Äôt stop him from drinking more.

‚ÄúInterning at a Muggle paper, it‚Äôs not bad.‚Äù

‚ÄúA Muggle paper? Damn, you‚Äôve really forsaken us huh?‚Äù

She gives him a smirk. ‚ÄúI did get an offer from the Prophet believe it or not.‚Äù

Sirius nearly chokes on his drink. ‚ÄúNo shit,‚Äù he shudders. ‚ÄúBetter off taking the Mark than working for that lot.‚Äù

Mary laughs. ‚ÄúYeah, that‚Äôs about what I thought too. Anyway,‚Äù she plays with the condensation her glass has left behind on the bar. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind my job. It‚Äôs kind of nice, being away from all this. Though I do worry about you lot.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou worry about me the most though right?‚Äù Sirius asks, batting his eyelashes at her.

When Mary answers it‚Äôs with far more sincerity than he‚Äôs expecting. Than he wants. ‚ÄúProbably, yeah.‚Äù Mary‚Äôs stare is unblinking, and Sirius finds himself pulling away from it. She always did see too much of him.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to,‚Äù his voice has lost some of its mischief. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúFine? Really? Wow Black, you‚Äôre so convincing.‚Äù

He glares at her. ‚ÄúFuck you. Not all of us get to just run away and pretend this isn‚Äôt happening.‚Äù

Mary is unfazed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not running and I‚Äôm not pretending. I‚Äôm just not interested in being Dumbledore‚Äôs little bitch.‚Äù

Despite himself, Sirius laughs. ‚ÄúListen, I‚Äôm not exactly a fan of the old man either but we need him. He‚Äôs smart and he‚Äôs powerful and‚Äî‚Äú Sirius‚Äôs throat grows unexpectedly tight. ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre kinda struggling out here, in case you haven‚Äôt noticed.‚Äù

Mary watches him calmly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve noticed.‚Äù

‚ÄúFrom your cushy office job,‚Äù Sirius can‚Äôt help but jab back.

‚ÄúWhen I‚Äôm needed I‚Äôm here,‚Äù she answers easily. ‚ÄúJames asks for help I help. The same way I do when Lily asks. Or Marlene, or you‚Äîif you need me Sirius? You let me know, okay? I‚Äôm here for you always. But I‚Äôm nobody‚Äôs bloody foot soldier.‚Äù

Sirius has always loved Mary. Always envied her. Envied the confidence she has. The confidence he‚Äôs always trying to convince everyone comes naturally to him. After a few seconds he lifts his glass, holding it out to her. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll drink to that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou say that like you won‚Äôt drink to anything,‚Äù though she meets his glass all the same.

‚ÄúTouch√©,‚Äù he says, before throwing the rest of his drink down his throat. Pretending he doesn‚Äôt see the concern sneaking into Mary‚Äôs eyes at the way he doesn‚Äôt even flinch when it goes down.

¬†

Eventually Sirius ends up beside her, the bottle of tequila between them. At some point they stopped using their glasses or chaser and started just taking sips. Mary has been regaling him for the better part of an hour with her office gossip. You would think it would be less enthralling considering he doesn‚Äôt know any of the people involved but Mary is a very good story teller and Sirius is entirely hooked on the apparent love triangle that has been brewing around something called a ‚Äúwater cooler‚Äù?

‚ÄúIs this even allowed,‚Äù Sirius makes a large wave-y motion with his hand.

Mary arches her brow, she‚Äôs acting more sober but the colour in her cheeks gives her away. ‚ÄúIs what even allowed? Trish shagging Jared? I mean, it‚Äôs not advised but I‚Äôm fairly certain there‚Äôs no law against it.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, no‚ÄîI mean, yes‚Äîbut no. The whole,‚Äù more hand waving. ‚ÄúSleeping with your coworkers thing, isn‚Äôt that like,‚Äù gosh his wrists are getting tired. ‚ÄúAgainst the rules or something?‚Äù

Mary seems amused by this. ‚ÄúWell, well, look at you, Sirius Black, concerned about rules all of the sudden. I think Remus is rubbing off on you.‚Äù
Sirius pointedly ignores that last comment and the horrible things it does to his stomach. ‚ÄúI never said people should follow them, I was just wondering if this was on the down low because Jared is a dickhead or because there was some actual wrong doing occurring.‚Äù

Mary shrugs. ‚ÄúNo official rule. Not that I know of anyway. And I‚Äôve gotten with at least three of the boys at the office.‚Äù

Sirius lets out a low whistle. ‚ÄúLook at you, shagging Muggles left and right.‚Äù

Mary snorts, reaching for the bottle and taking a sip before she speaks again. ‚ÄúNot sure I could go back to Wizards if I‚Äôm being honest,‚Äù she says, wiping her mouth off on the back of her hand. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre far too conservative in bed.‚Äù

Sirius makes several very distressed noises, ranging from shocked to outraged. ‚ÄúConservative! As if.‚Äù

Mary shrugs, trying and failing to conceal her smile. ‚ÄúJust calling it as I see it. Or‚Ä¶feel it in this case.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell clearly you aren‚Äôt sleeping with the right wizards.‚Äù

Mary gives him a pointed look and due to alcohol consumption it takes Sirius far too long to figure out why.

‚ÄúOh come on,‚Äù he throws his arms up in exasperation. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt judge a bloke on what he was like at fifteen!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not judging, you were very sweet,‚Äù she says mockingly.

‚ÄúFuck you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd‚Ä¶virginal.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh please,‚Äù Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt any more experienced than I was.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a short pause in which Sirius becomes aware of how close they‚Äôve shifted together, Mary‚Äôs eyes intent on his.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says eventually. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Something has shifted in the air between them and Sirius knows he should pull away, except that‚Ä¶it feels like ages since anyone‚Äôs touched him, and he doesn‚Äôt even mean sexually. He‚Äôs never had a very cuddly family life of course, but the Potter‚Äôs always somehow managed to fill that gap, with their easy comfort and affection‚ÄîFleamont swinging his arm over Sirius‚Äôs shoulders, Euphemia hugging him and peppering him with kisses.

They‚Äôre gone now though. And Remus is gone. And James is‚Äîwell‚ÄîJames is dealing with things the best he can. And Sirius understands, he does, it‚Äôs just that he‚Äôs so fucking lonely.

‚ÄúSirius‚Ä¶‚Äù Mary says warningly, but he only hears it distantly, barely registering it in some vague part of the back of his mind. And then, somehow, he‚Äôs moving forward and their mouthes come together. It‚Äôs terrible and twisted and not at all how it‚Äôs supposed to be. But at the same time Sirius can‚Äôt help but think that this is the closest thing to home he‚Äôs had since he found that fucking note on the kitchen table.

Mary kisses him back, but she‚Äôs also the one who pulls away first. The cold air hitting Sirius‚Äôs face only a second before Mary‚Äôs open palm.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Sirius says before he can stop himself, it‚Äôs a hard enough hit that even the alcohol can‚Äôt dull the ache.

‚ÄúThat,‚Äù Mary says evenly, ‚Äúwas for Remus.‚Äù

Before Sirius has the chance to respond she delivers another jaw cracking blow.

‚ÄúChrist Mary,‚Äù he spits on the floor of the pub, half-expecting to see one of his teeth on the ground.

‚ÄúThat,‚Äù she goes on when he‚Äôs finally managed to pull himself upright again, ‚Äúwas for me.‚Äù

Sirius can‚Äôt help but feel bitter that the alcohol that was enough to make him think snogging Mary was a real ace idea, is not strong enough to stop the shame currently crawling up from his stomach or the ache currently spreading across his jaw.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he finally manages, voice tight.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt get to use me just because you and your boyfriend are having problems.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not having problems,‚Äù Sirius snaps back‚Äîan automatic response.

Mary stares at him in disbelief for a few seconds before shaking her head. ‚ÄúMerlin Sirius, you really are a mess aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

He huffs out something that might be a laugh. ‚ÄúA bit.‚Äù And then the real weight of what he‚Äôs just done hits him and he groans, folding his arms over the bar and burying his head.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses into his sleeve. ‚ÄúFuck, fuck, fuck.‚Äù He stays like that, curled in on himself, wishing he wasn‚Äôt such a colossal asshole, for about ten minutes before Mary starts kicking him under the bar.

‚ÄúOkay enough, come on, lets go, time for bed,‚Äù and then, as if realizing what she‚Äôs just said. ‚ÄúSeparately. Very separately.‚Äù

Sirius snorts, lifting his head‚Äîwhich feels like it weighs about a hundred pounds at this point‚Äîand scrubbing at his face.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs wrong with me,‚Äù he mutters as Mary vanishes the empty tequila bottle and summons two glasses of water.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre lucky you‚Äôre so pathetic or I‚Äôd be much angrier right now,‚Äù she shoves the water at him. ‚ÄúDrink.‚Äù

He does. Though he honestly thinks he could use just a little more alcohol. Just enough to stop the hurting.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs gonna leave me,‚Äù fuck he must be drunker than he thought. The words come out just as whinny as they sound in his head.

Mary scoffs. ‚ÄúAlright drama queen, it was one drunken kiss. You don‚Äôt even have to tell him if you‚Äôre that worried, it‚Äôs not like I will.‚Äù

But Sirius only shakes his head, making the room spin. ‚ÄúNo not cause‚Äînot because of this,‚Äù he half slurs, causing Mary to tap on his water. He dutifully takes another drink.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù Mary says wearily, ‚Äúthat boy is in love with you, he‚Äôs not going anywhere.‚Äù

Sirius actually giggles at that. It‚Äôs giggle or cry. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs already gone though.‚Äù

She rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt count if he‚Äôs coming back.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think?‚Äù the bitterness clear in his voice. ‚ÄúFeels like it counts.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause in which Sirius takes it on himself to drink his water unprompted. If he doesn‚Äôt start getting a little more sober he‚Äôs going to have to take the fucking Knight bus home.

‚ÄúAnd here I thought you two weren‚Äôt having problems,‚Äù Mary says finally. Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúLook,‚Äù she goes on. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs doing his best I reckon, just like the rest of us.‚Äù

But Sirius isn‚Äôt having it. ‚ÄúNah I don‚Äôt think so. I‚Äôve seen Remus‚Äôs best, this isn‚Äôt it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI should go,‚Äù he gets up, too tired and too drunk for this conversation. Or maybe too sober. He can‚Äôt really tell anymore. ‚ÄúListen, Mary,‚Äù he says as he shoves his arms into his leather jacket, it‚Äôs not really cold enough out for it but he‚Äôs been wearing it anyway. A layer of armour. ‚ÄúI really am‚Ä¶I really am fucking sorry I‚Ä¶‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know what else to say. He knows that‚Äôs inadequate‚Äîknows he‚Äôs been fucking inadequate this entire conversation but he‚Äôs not sure he can manage anything else at the moment.

After a brief pause Mary nods her head. ‚ÄúJust don‚Äôt do it again.‚Äù

‚ÄúWon‚Äôt. Promise.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm not apologizing for slapping you.‚Äù

He manages a smile at that one. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt expect you to.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow‚Äôre you getting home Sirius?‚Äù she asks with a level of concern that is uncharacteristic for her. Sirius hates it.

‚ÄúKnight Bus,‚Äù he lies. ‚ÄúBut I think I‚Äôm gonna walk for a bit first, clear my head.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlone?‚Äù

He swallows with difficulty.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

She looks like she might argue with him but eventually just rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúWell fine, I guess. Go be a bloody idiot, but I swear to God if you fall into some river and drown or get hit by a car I will resurrect you just so I can kill you myself. Understood?‚Äù

Sirius nods, mustering a grin. ‚ÄúUnderstood.‚Äù

‚ÄúGoodbye then, prick.‚Äù

‚ÄúBye,‚Äù he‚Äôs at the door when he turns back, in time to see Mary refilling her water glass. ‚ÄúHey Mary?‚Äù

‚ÄúHm?‚Äù she looks up.

He chews on his bottom lip for a minute before eventually getting himself to speak. ‚ÄúCome around more yeah? We miss you.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt wait for a response. Pushing out into the night.

¬†

It‚Äôs three days later that he wakes up to the smell of bacon frying. He lies in bed for a minute and wonders if maybe he‚Äôs having a stroke or if maybe he‚Äôs had a stroke and gone and died. But eventually he wakes up enough to know that more plausible than sudden pre-mature death, is the possibility that someone in his flat is actually cooking bacon.

He‚Äôs not sure he prefers that.

Eventually, he does actually drag himself out of bed, shuffling down the hall with one sock half slipping off and nothing on but a t-shit and a plaid pair of boxers. When he gets to the doorway of the kitchen Remus has his back to him, his blond hair damp‚Äîjust showered‚Äîwearing a sweater that drips off his shoulders, exposing his collarbone in a way that usually drives Sirius mad.

He stands there for a long time‚Äîlonger than is socially acceptable‚Äîjust watching as Remus moves about, making breakfast, like he hasn‚Äôt been gone for nearly a month. Like everything is normal.

‚ÄúOh shit!‚Äù Remus lets out a nervous laugh when he catches sight of Sirius. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre up.‚Äù He smiles, stepping forward and kissing Sirius quickly on the cheek, not making eye contact before turning back to his cooking.

‚ÄúSit, I‚Äôve made food. A full breakfast.‚Äù There‚Äôs a falsely cheerful tone to his voice, at odds with the new angry scar cutting down his face from his temple to his jaw. Judging by the way he‚Äôs moving around the kitchen he‚Äôs dealing with other far less superficially wounds.

Eventually Sirius manages to force himself to move, taking a seat at the table and trying to swallow the bile working its way up the back of his throat. This is what they‚Äôre doing then. Pretending these gaps in their relationship don‚Äôt exist. It sounds frighteningly similar to something Remus‚Äôs mother would have done, though he doesn‚Äôt suspect the other boy would appreciate the comparison so Sirius bites his tongue. See? He is maturing.

‚ÄúI picked up this recipe ages ago‚ÄîI think Lily gave it to me, she‚Äôs a brilliant cook you know? James is well spoiled. Especially considering he can‚Äôt make a boiled egg without setting something on fire. Though I suppose you and he have that in common,‚Äù he throws Sirius a wink over his shoulder. He‚Äôs speaking too quickly, voice too high‚Äîalmost manic‚Äîdesperately making sure there‚Äôs no air left in the room, no space for Sirius to dredge up all the things he clearly doesn‚Äôt want to talk about.

‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm going to try cooking more, I always liked it as a kid. I mean, that was more baking, mum was really a baker more than she was a chef, still though. I like it. It‚Äôs calming. Plus, I like feeding people. It feels‚Ä¶intimate I guess? Like a way of telling people you love them without actually having to say it.‚Äù

Remus throws the empty skillet in the sink, grabbing two loaded plates off the counter and coming to sit across from Sirius.

‚ÄúBon app√©tit,‚Äù he says, mispronouncing the words horribly. Sirius takes great joy in listening to Remus butcher the French language, if only because he knows his parents would be clawing at their ears if they could hear him.

Remus really did go all out; bacon, eggs, fried bread, potatoes‚ÄîSirius doesn‚Äôt eat any of it, isn‚Äôt sure he could manage it at the moment, but he can certainly appreciate the lengths that Remus has gone to to see this denial through.

‚ÄúI went to this little grocers a few blocks over,‚Äù Remus is looking at his own breakfast and not at Sirius as he prattles animatedly on. Sirius doesn‚Äôt miss the way his hands are shaking as they lift his fork to his mouth. ‚ÄúIt was amazing, really, we should go there more often. The produce was way better than the place we normally get it.‚Äù

Under normal circumstances Sirius would laugh at that statement. They live largely off of takeaways and food items that come in various boxes and cans, vegetables are not a staple in either of their diets.

‚ÄúDid I mention I‚Äôm thinking of taking up cooking? I should probably get some books huh? I feel like that‚Äôs always a good place to start.‚Äù

Sirius feels like something is crawling all over the top of his skin. Tiny legs running down his spine, along his sides, into the crook of his neck and the caverns of his ears. He wants to tear them off. Wants to cut the skin from his bones.

‚ÄúWell go on, eat up, it‚Äôs good I swear.‚Äù

He just wants him to stop.

Stop acting like this.

Stop pretending.

‚ÄúI kissed Mary.‚Äù

Remus freezes across the table, forkful of egg halted on its way to his mouth. There it is then. The fiction shattered. Sirius has never been good with fragile things.

The silence continues, Remus eventually dropping his hand but still not looking up. There are people in the streets outside, there are owls and shop door bells and the sounds of the wind whipping between the buildings. All of that starts to feel unbearably loud in the wake of Remus‚Äôs stillness.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù when the question comes it‚Äôs small. It carves itself a home in Sirius‚Äôs chest where he expects it will live for quite some time.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú his voice fails him. He just wants Remus to be able to feel it‚Äîfeel the ache that has been building inside him since the first time he left. How it‚Äôs there, always, sometimes quiet and sometimes loud but never gone. How it stays even when Remus comes home. How it‚Äôs eating him alive.

‚ÄúI just wanted to be wanted,‚Äù he manages eventually. Which isn‚Äôt even the half of it. But is also maybe the most honest way he can answer.

Remus laughs bitterly but Sirius prefers it to the overly false cheer of earlier. Better to be something real, even if it hurts.

‚ÄúPoor Sirius, nobody around to fuck him, what a hardship for you.‚Äù

Sirius tries and fails not to flinch. ‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt what I meant.‚Äù

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not being fair.‚Äù

‚ÄúFair,‚Äù when Remus‚Äôs eyes meet Sirius‚Äôs they are all sharpened points and bleeding wounds. ‚ÄúYou snog someone else and I‚Äôm the one not being fair?‚Äù Sirius doesn‚Äôt know what to say to that so he says nothing, watching Remus struggle with where to go from here.

‚ÄúJust a kiss?‚Äù he asks finally.

Sirius nods. ‚ÄúShe slapped me, if you can believe it.‚Äù

There is no trace of humour in Remus‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúSo she stopped it?‚Äù he asks, voice struggling to remain even.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius says slowly. ‚ÄúYeah she stopped it.‚Äù

He watches Remus take that in. ‚ÄúWould you‚Äî‚Äú his voice chokes itself. ‚ÄúWould you have gone further?‚Äù he manages after a few tries. ‚ÄúIf she hadn‚Äôt?‚Äù desperate. Pleading.

There are a dozen ways Sirius could answer this. A dozen ways he could hurt Remus less. He can pretend he chooses the truth because it‚Äôs the right thing to do. But ultimately he thinks he does it out of spite.

‚ÄúProbably, if she had let me. I didn‚Äôt exactly have a plan but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù there‚Äôs that laugh again‚Äîcold and empty. He gets up out of his seat and walks over to the counter, bracing himself against it. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm supposed to do with that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, I know how that feels.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh you are not seriously comparing what you did to what I‚Äîwhat I have to do. Do you have any idea what I've been through the last few weeks and you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Sirius cuts him off. ‚ÄúNo I don‚Äôt Remus. I have no idea what you‚Äôve been through, why don‚Äôt you share with the class?‚Äù

Remus glares at him. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not fair.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that?‚Äù Sirius cups his hand over his ear. ‚ÄúNo? Nothing to share? Okay, how about I go huh? For starters, Fleamont died‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Remus‚Äôs face falls but Sirius pushes forward.

‚ÄúAnd James has been sitting around waiting to burry his parents because he doesn‚Äôt want to do it without you. Which has been jolly good fun for all of us let me tell you. I‚Äôve been stuck in this fucking flat, alone, with barely anything to do because Dumbledore thinks I‚Äôm a goddamn liability. I haven‚Äôt heard the case against me but I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs a good one if he‚Äôs got you on his side.‚Äù

‚ÄúDumbledore doesn‚Äôt think‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúReally? Is that why he told you not to tell me where the fuck you keep disappearing to?‚Äù

Remus sighs, scrubbing at his face. ‚ÄúNone of us are supposed to be telling each other where we are.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you think James and Lily are following that rule huh?‚Äù Sirius asks bitterly. ‚ÄúOr Alice and Frank? Marlene and Dorcas? You think they‚Äôre keeping secrets from each other?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell they should be‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre together Remus. They‚Äôre in relationships. That‚Äôs what you do in relationships, you tell each other things.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike how you snogged your ex-girlfriend? Those kinds of things?‚Äù Remus shoots back, but Sirius is too wound up to be cowed.

‚ÄúAt least I‚Äôm not a fucking liar.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Remus sneers, ‚Äújust a cheater.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was a kiss Remus grow up.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was a kiss because she stopped you you absolute asshole. Did you even want to or did you just do it so you could throw it in my face?‚Äù

Sirius isn‚Äôt sure he knows the answer to that question, though he‚Äôs almost positive neither of those options are the right one. He‚Äôd wanted to. He‚Äôd wanted Mary, because of everything she was and everything she meant and all the things she tasted of. Childhood and safety and four poster beds all squashed together under one roof. Back when he always knew where Remus was. And James. And Peter.

‚ÄúWhat did Dumbledore tell you, really?‚Äù

Remus throws his arms up in the air in exasperation. ‚ÄúLet it go Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, I want to know what he said that made you so convinced you can‚Äôt tell me where you‚Äôre going!‚Äù his voice cracks. ‚ÄúWhat the fuck did he say?‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing!‚Äù Remus finally shouts back, the word mutilated, like he barely allows it passed his mouth, teeth carving into it on the way out. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt have to say anything.‚Äù

Didn‚Äôt have to say anything.

Didn‚Äôt have to.

Of course. Because who knows better than Remus Lupin what a betrayer Sirius Black can be.

Sirius‚Äôs chair screeches as he pushes back from the table and heads out of the room.

‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äù Remus calls after him, panic clear in his voice.

‚ÄúBed,‚Äù is all Sirius says, before slamming the door to the bedroom closed behind him.

He curls up under the blankets, curtains drawn, lights off, and squeezes his eyes shut. He could keep fighting, he has it in him, he‚Äôs a Black after all. But he‚Äôs tired of saying terrible things. Tired of hearing them. Sometimes he feels the echoes of his mother in his voice and it makes him want to scrape out the inside of his skin. He just wants Remus to go away again. He likes himself better when he doesn‚Äôt have anyone around to bite.

It might be minutes or hours but eventually the door opens and closes and Sirius feels the mattress dip. He doesn‚Äôt look up, doesn‚Äôt unfurl from his ball. Remus sighs, his hand coming tentatively to run through Sirius‚Äôs hair. When Sirius doesn‚Äôt pull away his movements become more sure of themselves, fingers dragging across his skull.

‚ÄúI hate this,‚Äù Remus says finally.

Sirius only hums in response.

There‚Äôs a pause before Remus speaks again. ‚ÄúI want you,‚Äù he almost whispers.

Sirius finally pulls himself properly out of the covers, looking up to find Remus‚Äôs eyes already on him. The sight of him makes something trip in Sirius‚Äôs chest. It always does. Remus Lupin is a work of art. He deserves to be carved out of marble and placed on the palace steps. Deserves to be studied and admired and remembered for generations to come. One day you will find him in a museum and people will travel from all around the world to see him and they will say;

This.

This is what it looks like.

To be made of magic.

Of daydreams.

Of love in all its colours.

This is Remus John Lupin.

‚ÄúI want you,‚Äù Remus says again, voice sneaking beneath the blankets and kissing Sirius‚Äôs skin. ‚ÄúI want you.‚Äù

For a moment the past and the present blur, and Sirius can see two boys in their school dormitory. Together. Finally. After waiting for so long.

I want you.

‚ÄúThen have me,‚Äù he croaks, stealing Remus‚Äôs line.

He hears the other boy‚Äôs breath catch and in the next second they‚Äôre crashing together, desperate in a way that has nothing to do with bodies or heat and everything to do with the wounds they‚Äôre both nursing. Both constantly tearing open.

They‚Äôre clumsy as they push the blankets aside, Remus straddling Sirius‚Äôs hips as Sirius runs his hands up Remus‚Äôs sides, feeling like he might die from the sudden overwhelming sensation of having the only thing he‚Äôs ever wanted.

Remus pulls off his own shirt, revealing a map of cuts and bruises and ribs that are too close to the surface. Sirius makes sure to keep his touches gentle‚Äîreverent. They kiss with their teeth. Sirius lifts up and Remus pushes him back down, hands running along Sirius‚Äôs arms until he has him pinned by the wrists.

‚ÄúI want you,‚Äù Remus murmurs as he trails kisses along the underside of Sirius‚Äôs jaw, along his neck, his shoulders. ‚ÄúI want you.‚Äù

Sirius can‚Äôt help bucking up, can‚Äôt help whining in agreement. His life is empty when Remus is gone. His body is cold. His bed is too big. It is terrifying to know that someone can walk away and take so much of you with them. That without realizing it you have been cutting pieces of yourself away.

‚ÄúWhat do you want?‚Äù Remus asks, breath hot against the skin of Sirius‚Äôs stomach. He doesn‚Äôt remember losing his shirt. Doesn‚Äôt know how it happened or which one of them did it.

‚ÄúYou know what I want.‚Äù

Remus looks up at him for a moment, cheeks flushed, lips spit-slick and bitten raw. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says hoarsely. ‚ÄúYeah okay.‚Äù

It isn‚Äôt until later. When they are as close as it is possible to be. When Remus is filling him up and all Sirius can feel or smell or taste is him, that Sirius really embarrasses himself.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt leave,‚Äù he pants‚Äîwhines‚Äînot ‚Äúharder‚Äù, or ‚Äúfaster,‚Äù or ‚Äúmore baby more‚Äù, but; ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt leave.‚Äù He thinks it‚Äôs possible that there are tears escaping his eyes, rolling silently down the sides of his face. But he tries not to think about it.

Remus falters above him, concern washing over him. ‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo don‚Äôt,‚Äù Sirius huffs, out of breath as he digs his heel into Remus‚Äôs lower back, urging him on. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt stop. Please don‚Äôt stop.‚Äù

Remus looks like he‚Äôs trying to figure something out. Sirius isn‚Äôt sure if he manages it but he moans in relief when Remus finally starts moving again. When he brings them back together, opening Sirius‚Äôs lips and forcing his way inside.

Sirius is too hot, his skin too tight, everything dissolving into nothing but feeling.

Have me,

he thinks, as he comes apart in Remus‚Äôs arms.

Have me.

Have me.

Have me.

I‚Äôm yours anyway.

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

I honestly thought I wrote this chapter so fast, I was like "wow it's been like two days since the last update, look at me go" imagine my surprise when I realized that it has actually been a week since Christmas.

My grasp on time is so loose you guys. So loose.

ANYWAY! I hope this was worth the wait, still pretty overwhelmed by how nice everyone has been about this fic, I know it's not perfect so I appreciate how forgiving you are of the mistakes that slip through! Happy 2022 people, it can't get worse right? I mean...right?

Chapter 47

Chapter Notes

tw violence

tw blood

tw vague reference to sexual assault

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I JAMES

His parent‚Äôs funerals are held two days after Remus gets back. People fill the Potter‚Äôs home, they line up down the street. They bring flowers and food and alcohol. They bring pictures. Of his mother as a little girl. Of his father after selling his first potion. Of the pair of them dancing at their wedding and smiling at the camera.

Lily stands on one side of him and Sirius on the other. Remus is there. Peter. Mary, Marlene, Dorcas, Alice, Frank. They build walls around him. They stand guard. Never leaving his side. It‚Äôs an endless and brutal day. Maybe he‚Äôs supposed to take comfort in it. In how many people loved his parents. How many lives they touched. Maybe he‚Äôs supposed to think that they‚Äôre in a better place. That he‚Äôll see them again. But he doesn‚Äôt. He spends the whole day feeling their absence like stones in his chest. He spends the night trying to figure out how he‚Äôs ever going to fill the gigantic hole they‚Äôve left behind.

Naively, James thinks that burying both his parents will be the worst part of his week.

It is not.

¬†

‚ÄúWe should do our best to capture as many of them as we can,‚Äù Frank is saying as he pulls on his flying gloves. ‚ÄúInformation is what we need right now.‚Äù His voice is steady, he doesn‚Äôt sound nervous, or like he‚Äôs barking orders, merely advising.

‚ÄúBut surely we don‚Äôt need all of them for information,‚Äù Sirius is twirling his broom lazily in his right hand like a baton. It‚Äôs hard to see him through the night, what with his black leather jacket, jeans and boots. His hair is pulled back in a bun so at least his face is clear.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Frank admits reluctantly, ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt need all of them.‚Äù

Sirius grins, teeth catching in the moonlight. ‚ÄúWell then, lets go kill some motherfuckers.‚Äù

Frank‚Äôs mouth forms a thin line. ‚ÄúCareful Sirius,‚Äù he says, after pausing for a minute. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre starting to sound just like them.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood thing I‚Äôm on your side then, isn‚Äôt it Frankie boy?‚Äù he winks, throwing a leg over his broom and pushing off the ground.

Frank watches him go before turning his unimpressed look on James who rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs showboating,‚Äù James takes his own broom in hand. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just to hide how nervous he is.‚Äù

Frank doesn‚Äôt look convinced. ‚ÄúIs he going to be a liability out there?‚Äù

That irks James. ‚ÄúHas he ever been a liability in the sky?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you really want me to answer that?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù James‚Äôs stare meets Frank‚Äôs and doesn‚Äôt waver. ‚ÄúHe may not have always listened to what you said, but he never once made a choice that didn‚Äôt end up getting us the goal.‚Äù

He can see Frank clench his teeth, knows he‚Äôs unhappy that he can‚Äôt come up with an example to prove James wrong. They might have fucked around but neither James nor Sirius ever took winning lightly.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt Quidditch,‚Äù Frank says finally.

‚ÄúAnd Sirius isn‚Äôt a liability,‚Äù James matches his tone.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you boys talking about?‚Äù Alice calls out as her, Mary and Marlene start making their way over.

James holds Frank‚Äôs gaze for another beat before tearing his eyes away. ‚ÄúNothing. Time to go. You guys ready?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Sirius?‚Äù Mary asks as the other two nod.

James gestures upwards. ‚ÄúAlready flying,‚Äù he mounts his broom. ‚ÄúStay in formation yeah? Don‚Äôt break, at least not until the fighting starts. We wanna have prisoners at the end of this not bodies,‚Äù he shoots Frank a look and the other boy dips his head in thanks. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre no use to us if they‚Äôre all dead.‚Äù

‚ÄúAye, aye Captain!‚Äù Alice calls out.

Rolling his eyes, James kicks off into the sky. Almost immediately Sirius is at his side, maybe two arms width away and slightly behind. They‚Äôre flying in something of a pyramid formation, James in the lead, with Sirius and Mary on the second line and Alice, Frank and Marlene making up the base. It‚Äôs dark and cloudy out, the air heavy with unspilt rain. And the wind is cold even though it‚Äôs barely September.

They‚Äôve traveled south, waiting a few miles inland from the Channel. According to Moody‚Äôs sources overseas this is the route the Death Eaters are taking‚Äîlast spotted flying over Dieppe.

‚ÄúStrange,‚Äù Frank had said when they got the news. ‚ÄúI thought they were trying to avoid an ambush, why‚Äôre they being so obvious about it?‚Äù

That hadn‚Äôt sat particularly well with James either but Moody and Dumbledore held firm that the mission should continue. So here they are. It is some comfort that according to the reports there are only four flyers. Outnumbering the Death Eaters is really the best outcome they can hope for.

James flexes his hands on his broom, eyes peeled as they search the skies. There is every chance that the two groups will pass one another and never know it, especially in this weather. In many ways this mission is a bit of a hail Mary pass. The hope that maybe, if the timing is right, if the stars align and luck is on their side, they can stop this before anymore Death Eaters get the chance to step down on English soil.

They move swiftly through the clouds, the night sky coming in and out of view. It‚Äôs disorienting, like being intermittently dropped into the thickest fog you can imagine. Sometimes he‚Äôll even lose sight of Sirius and Mary in his periphery. For a moment James wonders if it‚Äôs a spell, if Voldemort has grown powerful enough to control the weather, but he quickly banishes that thought. That‚Äôs exactly how they want you to think‚ÄîJames has seen the pamphlets, heard the speeches‚Äîthe way Voldemort‚Äôs followers talk about him like some greater being. Above them all. Untouchable. James doesn‚Äôt buy it. He reckons if you pricked him he‚Äôd still bleed red, just like the rest of them.

‚ÄúJames, to the west,‚Äù Mary says sharply, voice somehow remaining quiet even while cutting through the wind.

He instantly follows her directions and, sure enough, there are four dark robed figures pulling out of the clouds and heading right for them, like the horsemen of the apocalypse.

‚ÄúEveryone ready?‚Äù James asks, to general agreement. ‚ÄúGood. Lets make this as clean and fast as possible alright?‚Äù He slides his wand into one hand, steering with the other as they start moving towards their targets.

James isn‚Äôt sure what to expect, isn‚Äôt sure if the Death Eaters will try to run first or just stand their ground. But as the two groups move closer and closer together neither dithers. James‚Äôs nerves are going haywire but he doesn‚Äôt fight them, instead he tries to grab hold of that feeling, tries to use it, just like he‚Äôs always done in Quidditch. Adrenaline is your friend, even when it tastes like fear.

When they get close enough both groups stop, floating in the air facing one another, lit only by the moon when it manages to get in front of the clouds. James suddenly feels like he‚Äôs taking part in some old-timey duel.

The man who appears to be leading the Death Eaters smiles, using all his teeth. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been waiting for you,‚Äù he says, which James thinks is not at all foreboding.

‚ÄúYou should have said something, we would have come sooner, I do hate being rude,‚Äù James quips back, which only causes the other man to smile wider. He‚Äôs dressed in black, with long curling locks of brown hair spilling over his shoulders.

When he doesn‚Äôt speak again James clears his throat, the realization of how unprepared he is for this dawning on him bit by bit. ‚ÄúListen, the way I see it, this goes one of two ways.‚Äù

The other man‚Äôs smile does not diminish. ‚ÄúOh?‚Äù he asks, tilting his head to the side, it‚Äôs a sharp and unnatural motion. James does his best not to let it shake him.

‚ÄúYou can make this easy on yourselves, come back with us to the Ministry, answer a few questions, and then turn around and go home.‚Äù

One of the Death Eaters snickers at that, and James tightens his grip on his wand, gritting his teeth.

‚ÄúOr?‚Äù the leader prods, voice dancing with amusement.

‚ÄúOr,‚Äù James pushes on, ‚Äúyou can try to fight us, in which case, some of you will die and the rest of you will still be brought in for questioning and then locked in a cell for the Dementors to snack on,‚Äù Azkaban is a bit of a hollow threat at this point seeing as the Death Eaters have more or less been running the place for years, but he‚Äôs not sure if these men know that. He‚Äôs hoping they don‚Äôt.

Their leader appraises him for a moment before he speaks. ‚ÄúYou think we will be so easy to defeat?‚Äù he asks, accent thick.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre outnumbered,‚Äù James says simply.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù the man seems delighted by this. ‚ÄúMy apologies, but I fear you are mistaken.‚Äù

Something heavy drops into the pit of James‚Äôs stomach and he resists the urge to start looking around for more flyers, that would only make him seem weak. So he keeps his eyes steadily on the man in front of him.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt think I am,‚Äù he says smoothly. ‚ÄúNot unless they count differently in Bulgaria.‚Äù

The man actually laughs, the noise echoing sinisterly into the night. ‚ÄúNo, no, I believe we count the same,‚Äù he points to the person next to him. ‚ÄúOne,‚Äù to himself, ‚Äútwo‚Äù, and to the empty space on his other side, ‚Äúthree.‚Äù

It is then that the air shimmers, the familiar sight of a charm being thrown off. A fifth flyer appears. And then behind him a sixth. A seventh. A tenth. A fifteenth‚Ä¶

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù he hears Marlene curse behind him.

Suddenly Frank is at his side, breaking formation. ‚ÄúHow many do you count?‚Äù he whispers quickly to James, whose eyes are still bouncing over all the materializing bodies, some of whom appear to be wearing full masks, others with their faces bare like the original four.

‚ÄúI-I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù James swallows to get the shakiness out of his voice. ‚ÄúThirty?‚Äù

Frank nods. ‚ÄúAt least, we should have known‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLike hell we should have,‚Äù that‚Äôs Alice, James doesn‚Äôt look for her, doesn‚Äôt tear his eyes away from the army in front of him. ‚ÄúAll the sources said it was a small group, I saw the reports my goddamn self.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell clearly they were wrong,‚Äù Frank replies flatly.

‚ÄúListen,‚Äù the man with the long brown hair calls out to them, eyes dancing with amusement, ‚Äúthe way I see it, this goes one of two ways,‚Äù that garners him a few laughs from his cohort.

‚ÄúOh brilliant,‚Äù James says through clenched teeth, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs a stand-up comedian.‚Äù

‚ÄúOur lord is not a cruel man,‚Äù the Bulgarian leader goes on.

‚ÄúThe hell he isn‚Äôt,‚Äù Mary hisses beside James.

‚ÄúHe offers you all the chance to join him and his noble cause to return the Wizarding race to its proper place atop the Great Chain of Being, rulers over all, the natural kings of the earth.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh fuck me,‚Äù James can hear the eye roll in Mary‚Äôs voice.

The man before them smiles, it seems to be his go to expression, though truthfully, James has never seen a smile that held so many threats.

‚ÄúSo the question is, what will you do James Potter?‚Äù

At this point James is barely even surprised to learn that they really had been expecting them, not just expecting someone, but them specifically. That would be the spy‚Äôs work, he imagines. Fucker.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Frank asks, he doesn‚Äôt sound afraid or pleading, just curious.

James wishes for a minute that he was better at Legilimency. It‚Äôs not as though he can say everything he wants to when the people ready to tear them to shreds are all staring at them, waiting, listening. But then, they‚Äôre Quidditch players. They can read each other better than anyone else. He meets each of their eyes and knows that they all understand. Eventually Frank gives him a little nod and James turns back to their captive audience.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he says, squaring his shoulders, wand in his hand, mind already casting. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre gonna kill some motherfuckers.‚Äù

James fires off two spells before he‚Äôs even finished talking, the others doing the same, breaking off in different directions. James drops into a feint, feeling the returning fire wizzing over his head as the cold night air bites his cheeks. One of the Death Eaters tries to follow him, but a feint is no beginner‚Äôs move and the man loses his grip, tumbling off his broom and down to the ground without James even having to lift a finger.

It‚Äôs then that he fully appreciates why Dumbledore asked him to do this. It‚Äôs been so long since he‚Äôs flown with people who aren‚Äôt players, he‚Äôd forgotten how awkward they are in the sky. Even now as he doges attacks left and right, he sees them struggling to keep their balance, to steer with only one hand.

James fires curses over his shoulder, keeping his flight patterns erratic, never staying in a straight line‚Äînot that that‚Äôs hard, seeing as he‚Äôs flying over and around Death Eaters while they fumble to get their wands aimed.

‚ÄúJames!‚Äù

He looks up to see Sirius a few feet above him with his own tail of pursuers.

‚ÄúBailey Switch!‚Äù

The Bailey Switch is a Quidditch move that Frank would be bloody embarrassed they‚Äôre pulling, but James nods anyway.

He makes a big swerve to the right, Sirius mirroring him to the left. Both of them increasing their speed as they circle around and head right for one another. If you were watching from above it might look as though they were making a sort of heart shape, their pursuers following behind.

The idea of the Bailey Switch, is that if two players on the same team are being trailed, they can orchestrate a collision. Flying towards one another at top speed and then ducking out of the way before the people behind them can react, causing them to run into one another.

In general, most players know to look out for this, it‚Äôs a fairly obvious move, and as long as you‚Äôre paying attention you‚Äôre unlikely to miss that the person you‚Äôre flying behind is heading straight for their teammate. But these guys are not Quidditch players.

Sirius and James run right towards each other, James almost pressing his chest to his broom handle he‚Äôs going so fast, the men behind him speeding up as well. Even in the dark he can see the grin on Sirius‚Äôs face as they get closer and closer. A game of chicken.

One.

James thinks, wind whipping the hair away from his face, the first few light drops of rain, splattering his glasses, hinting at the coming storm.

Two.

They‚Äôre close now. Any sane person would have ducked out already.

Three.

They both veer suddenly, and without warning, in opposite directions and almost instantly James hears the sounds of colliding flyers behind him, foreign curses filling up the night‚Äîscreams‚Äîas the men knock each other from their brooms.

‚ÄúTHATS WHAT I‚ÄôM TALKING ABOUT BABYYY!‚Äù Sirius shouts, shooting off a few spells into the chaos of the collision.

James actually laughs. It‚Äôs been so long since he‚Äôs flown‚Äîproperly flown, not just done lonely laps around his parents back garden. And flying with Sirius has always been different. They fit together, their connection never more obvious than when they‚Äôre in the sky, moving in sync, anticipating one another‚Äôs needs.

It‚Äôs the sound of clapping that makes James jerk his broom around to find the Bulgarian leader floating behind him.

‚ÄúVery nice. You two are good at tricks yes?‚Äù he‚Äôs still smiling, something undeniably sharp about it. ‚ÄúBut you fight like children.‚Äù

James answers with his wand, the man in front of him barely dodging the spell, but laughing all the same, returning it with one of his own. They circle around each other, firing off magic at rapid speeds. They‚Äôre parrying like they‚Äôre fighting with swords not spells, moving backwards and forwards, wrists and hands slicing through the air like blades. It‚Äôs strange, James finds, duelling someone who speaks a different language, spells coming at him that he doesn‚Äôt recognize and has never heard.

For all the complicated magic he throws out, all the training and years of study he‚Äôs had, the spell that finally manages to sneak under the Bulgarian‚Äôs defences, is nothing but a simple:

‚ÄúExpelliarmus!‚Äù

He‚Äôs barely even thinking when he says it, just knows he needs to return his opponent‚Äôs fire with something. But somehow, it‚Äôs the right moment, the right aim, sliding under the man‚Äôs shields and knocking his wand off into the night. For a moment both of them seem surprised, staring after it, frozen.

And then James aims his wand again, the Bulgarian‚Äôs eyes coming back to meet his. It‚Äôs James‚Äôs turn to smile.

‚ÄúGot you,‚Äù he says grinning.

James will never know why it catches his attention. The loud indistinct noise behind him. There are lots of noises, have been this whole time. So what it is about this one that has James looking over his shoulder at the exact moment he shouldn‚Äôt be, he doesn‚Äôt know.

But he does.

Look.

And what he sees is a riderless broom, suspended for a moment in the night sky.

And what he sees is Sirius falling.

There‚Äôs no thinking after that.

He dives after Sirius who is too goddamn far and falling too goddamn fast.

Behind him he thinks he hears the word ‚Äúweak‚Äù spat in his direction but he doesn‚Äôt care.

James tries to use his wand to slow Sirius‚Äôs fall but his aim is off, everything happening so quickly. He‚Äôs played Quidditch his whole life, he knows how you catch people‚Äîyou get under them. Grabbing people from above leads to injuries. And he‚Äôs trying, he‚Äôs really fucking trying but he isn‚Äôt going to make it, they‚Äôre too close to the ground. So the minute he can, he just reaches. One hand on his broom handle and the other grabbing for Sirius‚Äôs arm.

He stretches so far it hurts but it isn‚Äôt enough.

He can‚Äôt reach.

There‚Äôs too much distance and the ground is gaining on them.

James tries again, nearly swinging off his broom, hand groping around in the air until he‚Äôs finally able to latch onto Sirius‚Äôs arm. He feels a sickening give that he knows isn‚Äôt right. That he knows is very, very wrong. Something is tearing.

It‚Äôs Sirius.

James realizes with a horrified jolt.

Sirius is tearing.

He lets go of his broom completely, grabbing the front of Sirius‚Äôs jacket so that he can stop pulling on what is almost certainly a dislocated arm. His stomach drops as he‚Äôs dragged upside down on his broom, only holding on by his legs as they continue to spiral towards the ground way too fast.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù he hisses, sounding scared even to himself as he tries to pull up his own body weight as well as Sirius‚Äôs. He needs to get upright again, needs to slow them down. He uses all his core strength but it‚Äôs hard‚Äîin fact it feels impossible. Which it can‚Äôt be. James doesn‚Äôt have the luxury of impossible right now. Pain shoots through his back and shoulders as he forces his body to do what it almost certainly wouldn‚Äôt be able to without the copious amounts of adrenaline pumping through him.

With Sirius half draped over the front of his broom James gets himself sloppily upright, nearly falling off as he scrambles to pull up the handle so they don‚Äôt plummet to the ground. It‚Äôs still a rough landing, James‚Äôs legs buckling underneath him as they hit the earth too hard and he crumbles forward, Sirius in his arms.

‚ÄúFuck‚ÄîSirius?‚Äù he‚Äôs breathing heavy, hands shaking as he runs over his friend‚Äôs body. But he can‚Äôt find any injuries other than his arm. ‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù he demands again, voice high and tinny. Sirius‚Äôs eyes are closed, his face slack, body too stiff. James didn‚Äôt see what happened. Didn‚Äôt hear the spell, he doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs wrong. He just knows Sirius isn‚Äôt fucking moving.

‚ÄúSirius wake up, wake up, wake up. Come on. Please? Sirius?‚Äù James presses his ear to Sirius‚Äôs chest, searching for a pulse but he can‚Äôt hear anything, his own breathing deafening.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù the word trembles. ‚ÄúFuck, fuck, fuck.‚Äù Sirius is lying on his back in the dirt, body at an awkward angle, head in James‚Äôs lap and he has no idea what to do. No idea how to fix this. And he just keeps thinking. Keeps thinking what if‚Äîwhat if they hit him with‚Äî

A hand on his shoulder has James jerking around, heart in his throat, air only returning to his lungs when he sees it‚Äôs Frank.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell if he‚Äôs breathing,‚Äù he blurts out before Frank even has a chance to speak. He sounds young. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell if he‚Äôs breathing, I don‚Äôt know what happened but he isn‚Äôt moving, he isn‚Äôt‚Äîand Frank I can‚Äôt tell if he‚Äôs fucking breathing!‚Äù

Frank‚Äôs hand squeezes his shoulder. ‚ÄúOkay, alright, I‚Äôm gonna check okay?‚Äù

James nods, but he doesn‚Äôt move out of the way, doesn‚Äôt let go of Sirius, doesn‚Äôt stop touching him. Watching as Frank does exactly the same thing he had‚Äîpressing his ear to Sirius‚Äôs chest.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs breathing,‚Äù the other boys says, pulling away.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúI can hear his heart James.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù because he needs him to be sure, he needs this to be true. He won‚Äôt be able to keep it together if it isn‚Äôt. Everything he is will come crashing down if it isn‚Äôt.

It‚Äôs you and me.

That‚Äôs what Sirius had said that day on the kitchen floor.

It‚Äôs you and me.

That‚Äôs what James had had when he‚Äôd had nothing else.

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù Frank takes one of James‚Äôs hands and positions his fingers on Sirius‚Äôs neck. ‚ÄúFeel.‚Äù

But James shakes his head. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel it‚ÄîFrank I can‚Äôt feel anything, I can‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù he says firmly but not unkindly. ‚ÄúCalm down, and focus.‚Äù

James breathes in and out, closing his eyes briefly and doing as Frank asked. There. Then. That‚Äôs when he feels it. A fluttering pulse beneath his fingers.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs breathing,‚Äù he says with relief, eyes opening to find Frank giving him a weak smile.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs breathing.‚Äù

The spell comes out of nowhere.

A flash of light.

And then‚Äî

‚ÄúFRANK!‚Äù

¬†

PART II MARY

Contrary to popular belief, Mary has not forsaken magic. In fact, she practices frequently. Legilimency and Occlumency have been of particular interest to her. Learning how to build walls around her mind. Learning how to break down the walls that others have built.

Another interest of her‚Äôs, is Fiendfyre.

The flames pouring from her wand have grown wings, soaring over the heads of the Death Eaters around her and roasting them where they sit. It smells like Sunday dinner. It‚Äôs almost too easy honestly. Some of them seem to just be flinging themselves off their brooms. Earlier she caught sight of Frank trying to cushion their falls.

Mary has made no such efforts.

She pulls the fire back, it‚Äôs a slow process, something this powerful takes patience and skill to control. But eventually she‚Äôs able to put it out, nothing around her but smoke.

‚ÄúOh fuck off you prick,‚Äù Marlene‚Äôs voice cuts through the night, pulling Mary‚Äôs focus. She catches sight of her friend being dragged down to the ground by a man who appears to have latched onto the end of her broom.

Mary starts moving in that direction, incase Marlene needs back up. But as soon as they‚Äôre on the ground Marlene has an elbow in the guy‚Äôs face and then she hits him with a Stunner. Mary can‚Äôt help but smile.

At least, until a third figure appears.

He drops down right behind Marlene and she‚Äôs only just turned when the words; ‚ÄúStupefy‚Äù cut through the night.

Stupefy isn‚Äôt a particularly violent spell, except when used at close range. Marlene is thrown backwards, skidding across the dirt and landing on her front. She doesn‚Äôt get up. The man is starting to mount his broom again when Mary presses the tip of her wand to the back of his neck.

‚ÄúThat,‚Äù she hisses, ‚Äúwas a mistake asshole.‚Äù

He swirls around but Mary ducks, knowing the spell is coming. She immediately bounces back, casting her own. The man in front of her is wearing a mask and throws up a shaky shield that trembles against her. Mary fires off another curse, and another, not giving him a moment to breathe, the power of her spells forcing him to take a step backwards. His shield is barely holding, the air around him sparking and wobbling as it threatens to collapse under the onslaught of her attack. His mask, she notices, is also quivering.

It‚Äôs a spell, she realizes. The masks are charms. A stupid waste of energy and impractical. Sometimes the Muggle way really is superior. Mary makes sure to cast her next spell with particular force. She sees the shield shatter, like glass, broken pieces falling away, taking his mask with it.

The minute his face is clear in front of her, she starts to laugh. ‚ÄúOh this is too good. Tell me, does your daddy know where you are?‚Äù

‚ÄúOn your knees Mudblood,‚Äù Barty Crouch sneers, raising his wand.

But Mary can‚Äôt stop laughing. ‚ÄúVoldemort is sneaking a bunch of people across the boarder and he sends you to help them? You? What are you supposed to be exactly? Protection?‚Äù her laughing increases. ‚ÄúAnd here I thought you were such a good little boy now. Working for the Ministry and all that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI said ON YOUR KNEES!‚Äù his voice trembles, face flushed the way little kids get before they throw a temper tantrum. His confidence is shaken now that he hasn‚Äôt got his mask. Now that she knows his secret.

‚ÄúYes I heard you,‚Äù she finally manages to get herself under control, wiping tears of mirth from her eyes. ‚ÄúBut you see, the problem Crouch, is I get on my knees for no man,‚Äù she smiles then. ‚ÄúMen get on their knees for me.‚Äù She fires off a binding curse that Crouch only barely dodges and then they‚Äôre back at it again. This time though, he isn‚Äôt trying to hide behind his shield anymore, giving as good as he gets.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm surprised you‚Äôre even here Macdonald,‚Äù he grunts as one of her curses grazes his shoulder. ‚ÄúI heard you had gone full Muggle,‚Äù the last word is said with the ought most disgust.

‚ÄúYou keeping tabs on me?‚Äù she asks, careful not to let her voice betray how much the thought unnerves her. ‚ÄúThis little obsession of yours is getting out of hand.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not obsessed with you.‚Äù

"I can't wait to see your father's face when he hears what you've been up to," she swerves around his Cruciatus Curse, enjoying the terror in his eyes at the mention of his father. ‚ÄúTell me, do you think Voldemort will break you out of Azkaban after your daddy stuffs you in there? Or will he just let you rot? I mean, it's not as though he'll have any use for you once they all know the truth.‚Äù

"No one will believe you," he snaps, with all the confidence of a spoiled brat. Then, slowly, a smile stretches across his face. "Just like last time."

The killing curse leaves her wand before she even has time to think about it. Disappointment flooding her when it misses by an inch. Mary still has nightmares. Sometimes. She wonders if they'll stop after she severs his head from his neck.

"I see you managed to get rid of the lipstick," she says coldly. "A shame. It really was your colour." Crouch's whole face flushes red with embarrassment.

‚ÄúFuck you!‚Äù

‚ÄúOh but darling you already did that,‚Äù there are wars in those words. Ancient and on going. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you?‚Äù She can taste venom in her mouth.

Crouch falters.

Mary does not.

‚ÄúStupefy.‚Äù

They‚Äôre close enough, and Mary is angry enough, that when the spell hits him, square in the chest, it knocks him off his feet, like Marlene, sending him skidding into the distance. This is good. This is perfect. She wants to put her foot on his throat and watch him struggle to breathe. Wants to make sure he gets a Muggle‚Äôs death.

She steps forward.

‚ÄúMary!‚Äù

Alice lands clumsily behind her, barely standing before she‚Äôs walking. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù
