A spell shoots down from above, hitting the earth between them with a crack, and leaving the ground scorched.

Alice grabs hold of Mary‚Äôs wrist and starts dragging her towards Marlene with surprising strength. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going. Now.‚Äù

The figures above are getting closer, Mary doesn‚Äôt even have to look up to know it, she can feel them. Several more poorly aimed spells landing around them like meteors. The darkness is hiding them right now, but as soon as those men land Mary imagines their aim will improve.

‚ÄúNo wait,‚Äù she looks back, still able to just make out the shape of Crouch in the darkness. ‚ÄúI have to‚Äî‚Äú

But then her stomach is suddenly in her mouth as Alice rips her from the earth, everything dissolving around her as she‚Äôs side-alonged out of the valley. It‚Äôs a wretched feeling, made worse by the fact that she wasn‚Äôt expecting it.

Pain shoots up the fronts of her legs when they slam back onto solid ground, the world swimming around her as she tries to get her bearings.

‚ÄúJesus Christ Alice,‚Äù she swears, gripping her head and staring up at the looming building in front of her. It‚Äôs large and dilapidated, with hauntingly blank windows and rusted red brick walls. A faded sign across the front reads; Purge and Dowse, Ltd. It‚Äôs an illusion that Mary recognizes.

Somewhere in the distance there‚Äôs thunder.

‚ÄúSt Mungos?‚Äù Mary turns back to Alice and quickly moves to help her with Marlene. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs okay, it was a close proximity Stupefy, she‚Äôll wake up on her own,‚Äù she says, assuming Marlene is the reason they‚Äôre there. ‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt need a hospital.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good,‚Äù Alice starts pulling them towards the front of the building. ‚ÄúBut they do.‚Äù She nods up ahead and that‚Äôs when Mary spots three figures slouched against the hospital wall. The boys.

James is cradling an unconscious Sirius in his arms, while Frank is stooped next to him, clutching his stomach.

‚ÄúHoly shit Frank,‚Äù Mary says when they get close enough for her to see what he‚Äôs holding. Frank‚Äôs shirt has been torn, and through the shreds Mary can make out a huge gash cutting across his abdomen, blood covering his arms and soaking his clothes.

Without thinking she uses her free hand to pull out her wand. ‚ÄúVulnera Sanentur,‚Äù she casts, watching as the skin knits itself back together. And then. Watching as it tears itself open again.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck?‚Äù

Frank gives her a wane smile. ‚ÄúTried that already.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù Mary demands, but the older boy only shakes his head.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know what the spell was, but clearly it‚Äôs some kind of cursed wound,‚Äù his voice is rough, his skin glowing it‚Äôs so pale. It‚Äôs a miracle he‚Äôs still conscious with the amount of blood he‚Äôs losing.

‚ÄúMary, I‚Äôm gonna help Frank, can you handle Marlene?‚Äù Alice asks, pointedly not looking at Frank‚Äôs gaping wound.

Mary nods, tightening her grip on her friend, taking on more of her weight. Her eyes trail down to James and Sirius. ‚ÄúIs he okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs breathing,‚Äù James replies almost automatically. There‚Äôs something slightly panicked about James‚Äôs eyes, about the way he holds Sirius. Mary wonders if Lily ever gets jealous of the way they are together. Mary certainly used to. Oh sure, it was Remus that Sirius wanted to screw, but it was always James that Sirius loved.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon, lets go inside,‚Äù Alice says as she slips herself under Franks‚Äôs arm and guides them through the wall to the building hiding behind.

The overwhelming sense that something is wrong hits Mary the second she crosses the threshold. There are voices, shouting, no one‚Äôs at the front desk, a wheelchair left unattended by the door. It‚Äôs hard to tell exactly what is going on, everything just seems to be moving. People run past them in different directions, everyone agitated and nervous.

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Alice grabs the arm of a man scurrying past. His eyes are wide behind a pair of wire framed glasses.

‚ÄúGet out,‚Äù he says, before Alice even has the chance to ask anything. ‚ÄúYou have to get out.‚Äù

‚ÄúGet out?‚Äù Alice demands. ‚ÄúOf the hospital? Why?‚Äù

The man blinks several times in succession very quickly. ‚ÄúDeath Eaters.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn the hospital?‚Äù Alice asks, taken aback.

‚ÄúEverywhere,‚Äù he says ominously, before yanking his arm out of her grasp and continuing his sprint down the hall.

‚ÄúWell that was helpful,‚Äù Mary says, arms beginning to ache from the effort of having to keep Marlene supported. She adjusts her grip on her friend.

‚ÄúWhat do you think he meant?‚Äù Alice asks as they survey the unraveling chaos around them. ‚ÄúThat the Death Eaters are everywhere?‚Äù

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúDunno.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlice,‚Äù Frank says weakly, he‚Äôs started to wilt, shoulders curving over, face buried in Alice‚Äôs neck. ‚ÄúI need to sit.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou need a Healer,‚Äù she says, eyes scanning over the chaos. It is incredibly difficult to pick out who is who in the panicked crowd rushing around them, lights too bright after having been in the darkness outside, causing everything to blur.

‚ÄúCan I get a fucking Healer please?‚Äù Alice shouts. For all that Frank was captain, Mary isn‚Äôt sure she‚Äôs ever heard someone sound quite so commanding.

‚ÄúCan I get a healer please‚Äù someone behind them says mockingly.

Mary turns, fully ready to eviscerate them when she‚Äôs pulled up short by the sight of a masked man in dark robes, his wand already pointed at them.

He tilts his head to the side, the mask‚Äôs dead eyes staring right at them. ‚ÄúWell, well, what‚Äôs this? Little baby Aurors and their friends.‚Äù

Mary tries to shift subtly, to pull her wand into her palm again, eyes catching on James, knowing full well he‚Äôs trying to do the same. It‚Äôs a tricky business when your arms are full of your best mate.

‚ÄúWhat do you say little Auror,‚Äù he steps forward, wand pointed at Alice now, who, bless her, doesn‚Äôt even flinch. ‚ÄúDo you wanna come with me, we could have lots of fun with you I‚Äôm sure. All the pretty tales you could tell.‚Äù

Mary finally has her wand in the palm of her hand but it‚Äôs an awkward angle and she can‚Äôt quite lift her arm, not with the way she‚Äôs supporting Marlene. She looks over at James again who, if the wrinkles on his face are any indication, is having the same problem.

‚ÄúExpelliarmus,‚Äù the word is said as an after thought. At first Mary thinks maybe it was one of them, until she sees Alice‚Äôs wand flying out of her hand across the floor.

Fuck.

Fuck.

She needs to put Marlene down, she can‚Äôt fight like this, except every atom in her body rebels against the idea of letting go of her here.

The Death Eater‚Äôs wand presses under Alice‚Äôs jaw forcing her head back. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have to kill your little friends of course. This one‚Äôs already half there anyway,‚Äù he gestures to Frank who honestly might not even be conscious anymore, Mary can‚Äôt tell.

She sees James turn, sees him shift his grip on Sirius, trying to hold him with a single arm around his waist so he can get his other hand free. But the motion is too big, the Death Eater notices. His attention and his wand swinging in James‚Äôs direction before he‚Äôs ready, he fumbles and Mary prepares to drop Marlene because what the fuck else is she going to do? All three of them opening their mouthes at the same time, it‚Äôs anyone‚Äôs guess who‚Äôs spell will hit first. Will actual find its mark.

And then‚Äî

‚ÄúIncarcerous!‚Äù

Thick ropes soar through the air, wrapping the Death Eater in a vice grip, arms and legs tightly bound to his body. Without blinking Alice kicks in his knees, the man crumpling to the ground, spewing a tidal wave of profanities.

‚ÄúBlimey,‚Äù a man with shockingly ginger hair and wearing a brightly coloured paisley shirt steps forward. The man who cast the spell. ‚ÄúYou lot are hard to find.‚Äù He smiles at them all, the Death Eater on the floor squirming and kicking and failing to accomplish much of anything.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù the man says, sounding far too chipper as far as Mary is concerned. ‚ÄúBest not waste any time, we wouldn‚Äôt want to be late,‚Äù he says as he starts walking down the hall, leaving Alice, James and Mary to stare at one another in confusion.

‚ÄúDo you know him?‚Äù Mary asks Alice.

The older girl shakes her head. ‚ÄúNot a clue. James?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you all still standing there?‚Äù The ginger man calls from the end of the hall. ‚ÄúCome, come, we‚Äôve got to be quick or we‚Äôll be stuck here for another hour.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment in which they all just stare at him, gobsmacked, before Alice releases an exhausted sigh. ‚ÄúFuck it, no one else in this place has been of any use,‚Äù she looks over at the boy currently clinging to her for dear life. ‚ÄúYou still with me babe?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here,‚Äù Frank says, though his words are thick.

Alice nods, looking back out at the other two. ‚ÄúWell? Either of you got a better idea?‚Äù

‚ÄúThan following a complete stranger?‚Äù Mary asks flatly.

‚ÄúNope,‚Äù James says, throwing Sirius over his shoulder. ‚ÄúNone. And apparently we‚Äôre on a schedule so.‚Äù

The ginger is looking rather impatient, though somehow still‚Ä¶pleasant? Mary can‚Äôt figure it out but it‚Äôs disconcerting to her. Cheer generally is.

They hobble down the hall towards him, Alice scooping up her wand on their way. Mary‚Äôs arms are really beginning to struggle under Marlene‚Äôs weight.

‚ÄúYou said we were hard to find,‚Äù James asks as they catch up to their mysterious guide and he starts off again around the next corner. ‚ÄúThat makes it sound like you were looking for us?‚Äù

The man nods, keeping a brisk pace that they‚Äôre barely able to keep up with. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs because I was.‚Äù People run past them, doors slam closed, somewhere in the distance Mary thinks she hears something shatter.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Alice asks, out of breath.

‚ÄúOh sorry, didn‚Äôt I say?‚Äù he sounds like he genuinely doesn‚Äôt know. Which is ridiculous, considering he‚Äôs literally said nothing. ‚ÄúDumbledore sent me.‚Äù

‚ÄúDumbledore?‚Äù James repeats. ‚ÄúSent you to St Mungos to look for us?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow the hell would Dumbledore know we‚Äôre here?‚Äù Mary demands as they round another corner.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt,‚Äù the man replies easily. ‚ÄúHe sent me to the coast, but all I found there were some dead Death Eaters and a few abandoned brooms matching the descriptions of the one‚Äôs you were flying,‚Äù he shrugs. ‚ÄúAbandoned brooms made me think you left in a hurry. Hospital seemed like a good place to check after that. And here you are,‚Äù he shoots them a smile over his shoulder that looks sincere but that Mary doesn‚Äôt trust anyway, just on the principle that smiley people are usually at least a little unhinged.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Arthur by the way,‚Äù he adds quickly. ‚ÄúArthur Weasley. Don‚Äôt know if I mentioned that?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt,‚Äù Mary says flatly.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not in the Order,‚Äù James adds.

‚ÄúNo, no, I‚Äôm just a friend.‚Äù

A friend? Oh real legit that is. Real above board.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù he stops suddenly in front of what looks to be a broom cupboard, nearly causing a collision as Mary does her best not to run right into James‚Äôs back. ‚ÄúHere we are,‚Äù he throws the door open and gestures for Alice to go inside. ‚ÄúLadies first.‚Äù

She eyes him for about a second before moving forward, the rest of them following suit, cramming themselves into the tiny dark space that appears to be filled with cleaning supplies and bedpans.

‚ÄúThis is certainly cozy isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Arthur Weasley says as he closes the door, squeezing past them and rummaging through the shelves at the back. ‚ÄúAh ha!‚Äù he says triumphantly, turning around to place a yellow mop bucket in the centre of them. He looks up proudly.

‚ÄúEr,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre we supposed to do with a bucket?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, it‚Äôs a Portkey. Didn‚Äôt I mention that?‚Äù

Mary grits her teeth. If he says ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt I mention that‚Äù one more time she thinks she might actually murder him.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve set a few up in places we think we might need them. For emergencies and such.‚Äù

‚ÄúA Portkey to where?‚Äù Alice asks.

‚ÄúThe safe house,‚Äù then he gives them that proud smile again. ‚ÄúMy house.‚Äù Now that she has a good look at him Mary can see that he isn‚Äôt that old. Maybe thirty. With a slightly round face and pale skin dusted with freckles.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Alice demands. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need a safe house, we need a Healer,‚Äù she‚Äôs done an impeccable job so far of not, for a single moment, appearing panicked. But her voice cracks on those last words, her fear sneaking through.

‚ÄúM‚Äôalright,‚Äù Frank mutters, head still buried against Alice‚Äôs neck, arms barely trying to keep the blood from escaping his wound anymore.

‚ÄúYes, we thought you might,‚Äù Arthur says softly. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not safe here right now, especially not for you lot. But my wife sent for our neighbour before I left, she‚Äôs been trained as a Healer. She‚Äôll be able to help.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrained but not practicing?‚Äù Alice asks skeptically. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

Arthur shrugs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll have to ask her that, I‚Äôm afraid I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Mary cuts in. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre expecting us to take some random Portkey to some random house with someone we‚Äôve never met before just because you say you‚Äôre friends with Dumbledore?‚Äù she looks around at the rest of them. ‚ÄúIs that sounding fucking mental to anyone else?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes‚Äîno‚Äîquite right,‚Äù he offers her a self-deprecating smile. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing this all wrong aren‚Äôt I? Dumbledore did think you might be a little suspicious so he had me‚Äîer‚Äî‚Äú he cuts himself off, looking around the circle again. ‚ÄúSorry, which of you is James Potter?‚Äù

‚ÄúUm‚Ä¶me?‚Äù James says.

‚ÄúAh wonderful,‚Äù the man‚Äôs eyes go bright as he turns to James. ‚ÄúI talked with your girlfriend, through the Floo, lovely girl by the way,‚Äù James does not appear to know what to say to that so Arthur continues bumbling on. ‚ÄúShe told me to tell you, and this is a direct quote I‚Äôm afraid, that the night she stopped thinking of you as an irredeemable arrogant toe rag,‚Äù Alice snorts. ‚ÄúWas the night you found her crying in a stairwell over a boy and told her she needed to ‚ÄòGryffindor the fuck up.‚Äù

Mary turns to James, expression flat. ‚ÄúDid you really say that? Did the words ‚ÄúGryffindor the fuck up‚Äù actually come out of your mouth?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen did Lily ever cry over boys?‚Äù Alice asks.

Mary rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll have been Severus. It was always bloody Severus.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh god, of course, I think my mind has just blocked that phase out of my memory.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wish I was so lucky.‚Äù

‚ÄúGuys,‚Äù Frank croaks, ‚Äúany chance we could stay on topic?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Alice turns her head to kiss the top of his. ‚ÄúSorry, of course. James?‚Äù

James nods, looking a little dazed. ‚ÄúYeah‚Äîthat‚Äîyeah. That‚Äôs what happened. I don‚Äôt think he could know that if Lily hadn‚Äôt told him.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcellent, just in time,‚Äù Arthur says as the bucket in the middle of them begins to glow. ‚ÄúEveryone grab on now, and hold tight.‚Äù

Mary bites back the urge to tell him that they are not, in fact, children and have all used a Portkey before. She grips Marlene more tightly to her as she shifts to free one hand and grab hold of the bucket.

‚ÄúThree,‚Äù Arthur begins to count, Mary rolls her eyes, ‚Äútwo, one.‚Äù

And the hospital floor disappears.

¬†

PART III JAMES

James lands on his back, Sirius on top of him. For a moment he can‚Äôt move, the air knocked from his lungs as the world slowly comes into focus‚Äîthe dark sky above him, the light rain drops now more steady than they were before, splattering his glasses.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù someone groans.

‚ÄúMarlene? Hey Marlene?‚Äù

James turns his head, Mary is kneeling next to Marlene, which isn‚Äôt that surprising until Marlene lifts her arm of her own volition, hand pressing to her forehead.

‚ÄúMerlin my head hurts,‚Äù the blonde mutters.

Alice lets out a relived laugh, Mary reaching over and brushing the hair off of Marlene‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what you get for having your back turned.‚Äù

Marlene groans again. ‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù

‚ÄúStupefy, close range,‚Äù Mary says as she helps her friend up, reminding James that he should be doing the same. Sirius has not, unfortunately, made a similarly miraculous recovery, remaining lifeless in James‚Äôs arms. It‚Äôs awkward getting to his feet, his back screaming at him, still angry after the stunt he pulled on his broom.

‚ÄúCareful,‚Äù Mary steadies Marlene when she wobbles on her feet, arms still wrapped protectively around her.

‚ÄúWhere the hell are we?‚Äù Marlene asks, and James finds himself looking around for the first time. There are fields and swamps surrounding them, a tall, teetering house in front. As if on cue, the door opens, the light from inside spilling out, like a light house, telling them where to anchor.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôll be my wife,‚Äù Arthur grins, brushing himself off and starting towards the house. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon, lets get you lot inside.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho is THAT?‚Äù Marlene asks as he starts to walk away. ‚ÄúOh my god Frank!‚Äù

‚ÄúLets talk inside yeah?‚Äù Alice says, strain clear in her voice. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like being out in the open like this.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is going on?‚Äù Marlene hisses to Mary as they drag themselves up the lawn towards the open door.

‚ÄúHonestly?‚Äù Mary says, still not leaving her side. ‚ÄúWe have no fucking clue.‚Äù

It‚Äôs warm in the house. The ceiling low and made of thick wooden beams, the stone walls covered in pictures and over stacked bookshelves, not an inch of space free. Nothing in the house appears to match or follow any pattern, though all the furniture looks exceptionally comfortable. The second he‚Äôs over the threshold James feels a tiny bit of the fear that has been sitting in his chest all night give way. This is a good place. You can feel it in your bones.

‚ÄúBOYS!‚Äù a woman screams at the bottom of the stairs, fiery hair piled on top of her head in a messy bun, her wand stuck through it. ‚ÄúBACK IN BED!‚Äù James hears the unmistakable noise of tiny scurrying feet and giggling over their heads.

‚ÄúIf they wake the babies I swear to Merlin I‚Äôll feed them to the gnomes,‚Äù she grumbles, Arthur moving to her side and placing a quick kiss on her temple.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll go wrangle them in a minute,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúFirst there are some people I have to introduce you‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúMolly!‚Äù Alice says suddenly. James turns to look at her in surprise. ‚ÄúOh my god, Molly, oh of course. I forgot. I don‚Äôt know how I could forget you married a Weasley. I wasn‚Äôt thinking. Oh thank goodness. I was really starting to worry we had just followed some strange man into a trap‚Äîno offensive Arthur.‚Äù

‚ÄúNone taken,‚Äù he says happily.

‚ÄúYou know them?‚Äù Mary asks, eyes moving between Alice, half-covered in Frank‚Äôs blood and struggling under his weight, to the couple in front of them.

‚ÄúCousins,‚Äù Alice chokes out.

Mary arches her brow. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt remember your cousin?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell I‚Äôve never met Arthur before,‚Äù she says defensively.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve never met your cousins‚Äôs husband?‚Äù

‚ÄúTo be fair, Purebloods have a lot of cousins,‚Äù James tries to help her explain.

‚ÄúHere, Alice sweetheart, let me help,‚Äù Molly steps forward, slipping under Frank‚Äôs other arm.

‚ÄúSorry, if I get blood on you,‚Äù Frank mumbles, eyes remaining closed.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs quite alright dear.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe needs a Healer,‚Äù Alice‚Äôs voice cracks. ‚ÄúArthur said you had someone‚Äîwe need to do something he‚Äôs lost too much blood.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, Molly is‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here.‚Äù A girl walks towards them from the kitchen, she has dirty blond hair that‚Äôs braided down her back, dipping well past her waist, and she‚Äôs wearing more colours than James thinks he has ever seen on a single person. ‚ÄúI can help.‚Äù

The minute James makes eye contact with her he recoils, stumbling backwards and nearly sending him and Sirius crashing to the ground. ‚ÄúWho the fuck are you?‚Äù he snaps before he can help himself. It‚Äôs the eyes. He‚Äôs seen those eyes before. Seen them soften and seen them harden and seen them slice through people. Grey and endless.

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú Arthur says, clearly surprised by the outburst. ‚ÄúThis is our neighbour‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúPandora Lovegood,‚Äù she introduces herself easily, not seeming particularly thrown by James‚Äôs reaction to her. ‚ÄúA pleasure to meet you.‚Äù

Frank actually raises his head. ‚ÄúPandora Lovegood?‚Äù he says, groggily. ‚ÄúAs in, formerly Lestrange?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a Lestrange!‚Äù James demands, arms tightening instinctively around Sirius.

Still she regards them all mildly, lips twitching like she thinks this is amusing. ‚ÄúYou seem awfully outraged for someone currently holding the heir to the House of Black.‚Äù

James takes another step back, like he thinks she‚Äôs going to snatch Sirius from him. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not. Not anymore. Not for a long time.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, in that case,‚Äù she says calmly. ‚ÄúI am no longer a Lestrange. Not anymore. Not for a long time.‚Äù

James continues to glare at her but doesn‚Äôt have much to say to that admittedly.

‚ÄúHow do you know her Frank?‚Äù Marlene asks, leaning heavily against Mary. She looks pale and tired, but at least she‚Äôs awake.

Frank blinks, clearly struggling to focus, to keep his eyes open. ‚ÄúSurveillance. We keep an eye on people who might be‚Ä¶working for the other side. Person‚Äôs of interest.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt I feel special,‚Äù her expression remains pleasant but there is an undeniable edge to the words.

‚ÄúArthur said you trained as a Healer?‚Äù Alice asks, clearly hoping to get them back on track.

Pandora nods. ‚ÄúI did.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you aren‚Äôt practicing as one?‚Äù

An impish smile pulls at the older girl‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúNo. Too boring for me I‚Äôm afraid. They do everything very by the book at St Mungos. No room for imagination.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat does not inspire confidence,‚Äù Frank slurs.

‚ÄúWell, by all means, you‚Äôre welcome to bleed to death. If that inspires more confidence in you.‚Äù

Alice snorts. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre letting her help Frank,‚Äù there is no room for discussion, not that Frank has enough energy to argue.

‚ÄúThere are some spare rooms on the second floor, we can take them both there,‚Äù Molly looks over at James who is still clutching Sirius like he‚Äôs expecting someone to come and steal him away.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Alice prods, and when he meets her eyes; ‚Äúlets go, okay?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt argue. Isn‚Äôt in a position to. He can‚Äôt help Sirius on his own, he wishes he could but he can‚Äôt. So he follows Molly up the stairs, where she directs them into separate bedrooms.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll see to the bleeder first,‚Äù Pandora says as she comes up behind them. ‚ÄúSeems a bit more urgent.‚Äù

‚ÄúM‚Äônames Frank,‚Äù Frank grumbles.

‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs not nearly as much fun to say.‚Äù

James carries Sirius into the other bedroom, lying him gently down on the bed. His arm sticks out at an awful angle no matter what James does‚Äîhe can only imagine how painful it must be, how much damage all the moving around has done.

James‚Äôs own arms scream and ache now that they‚Äôre free of the weight of Sirius‚Äôs body, hanging lifelessly by his sides like they‚Äôve given up. He pulls a chair over to Sirius‚Äôs bedside and sits down, dropping his head into his hands and exhaling.

He feels wrung out, emotionally, physically, and if he‚Äôs being honest, he still has no idea what the hell is going on. He doesn‚Äôt understand what the Death Eaters were doing at St Mungos or what that man meant when he told Alice they were everywhere. He doesn‚Äôt understand why Dumbledore sent Arthur Weasley to drag them out here to the middle of nowhere. He doesn‚Äôt know what he‚Äôs supposed to do next.

He sighs eventually, lifting his head to look at his frighteningly still friend. His dark hair has slipped lose of the bun he put it in earlier, clothes dirty and skin so goddamn pale. Nearly as bad as Frank‚Äôs.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd they hit you with?‚Äù he asks desperately. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong Sirius? Huh? How can I help? Tell me how to help?‚Äù he reaches out and takes the other boy‚Äôs hand, squeezing. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not allowed to stay like this, you know that right? You‚Äôre not allowed to go and die on me. Not now. Not yet. We have so much shit we still have to do, you and me,‚Äù James swallows with difficulty, throat tight. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not burying another fucking body Sirius. I‚Äôm not.‚Äù

‚ÄúTalking is good.‚Äù

James jumps to his feet, heart hammering in his chest as he finds Pandora in the doorway, a small box of what James assumes are medical supplies in her hands.

‚ÄúThey can usually hear you,‚Äù she goes on. ‚ÄúI think it helps.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin, what‚Äôre you a fucking ghost?‚Äù he snaps, clutching at his chest. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you knock?‚Äù

She arches her brow. ‚ÄúThe door was open,‚Äù she says simply, as she walks forward, her attention going to Sirius. James watches her inspect him, watches her pull out her wand and fights the urge to rip it out of her hands when she points it at Sirius.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôs Frank?‚Äù James asks instead.

‚ÄúWeak. He lost a lot of blood. I‚Äôve been able to momentarily heal the wound but it won‚Äôt last, the curse used on him was too strong. There‚Äôs a potion that should help, but I‚Äôll have to brew it. I‚Äôve given him blood replenishers to keep him stable until it‚Äôs ready, they should be enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúShould be?‚Äù

Pandora looks up at him. ‚ÄúThere are no guarantees in healing.‚Äù

He can‚Äôt hold her stare for long, can‚Äôt stand looking into those eyes. ‚ÄúI thought you said healing was boring.‚Äù

She laughs dryly. ‚ÄúI said being a Healer was boring. It‚Äôs not quite the same.‚Äù

Silence falls over them as she starts to run her diagnostics. James is reminded unwillingly of the night that Sirius showed up on his doorstep all those years ago, battered and bruised and missing his shoes. Remembers watching his mother run her wand over him.

His heart aches.

‚ÄúY‚Äôknow, I‚Äôve never met Sirius,‚Äù Pandora says conversationally, wand hovering over Sirius‚Äôs arm.

James doesn‚Äôt particularly feel like making small talk but he still manages an ‚ÄúOh?‚Äù

With the single flick of her wrist Pandora snaps Sirius‚Äôs shoulder back into its socket with a chilling ‚Äúschlick‚Äù noise that makes James wince. Sirius doesn‚Äôt react though. His face doesn‚Äôt even twitch.

‚ÄúYou would think with our families being so interbred we would have crossed paths but no,‚Äù she goes silent, continuing her spell work, and James thinks she‚Äôs finished with the conversation, which is more than fine by him, but then; ‚ÄúI did meet his brother though, at Hogwarts.‚Äù

There‚Äôs an uncomfortable scratching in James‚Äôs chest. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt remember you being at Hogwarts,‚Äù voice strained.

‚ÄúAh well,‚Äù she says as she turns to her box, opening the lid and running her fingers delicately over the various vials inside. ‚ÄúI was five years above you so, our paths weren‚Äôt exactly crossing.‚Äù She shoots him a smile.

‚ÄúBut you knew Regulus?‚Äù

She shrugs. ‚ÄúI suppose it‚Äôs more accurate to say I knew of him,‚Äù and then, smirking. ‚ÄúWhen I was in seventh year, I was in my potions class, the highest level you know? We all had our OWLS and our NEWTS and were on our way to being great potioneers, I mean not one person in there wasn‚Äôt an incredible brewer.‚Äù

James nods hesitantly as he watches her turn back to Sirius, not quite sure where this story is going. ‚ÄúBut one class Slughorn gives us this brutal potion. One of the nasty ones, where the metal of the knife and the direction of your cuts all effect the outcome. Anyway, the most advanced potions students in the school and not one of us could brew it,‚Äù she pours something from one of the vials onto her fingers and begins to massage Sirius‚Äôs temples.

‚ÄúSo the next day,‚Äù she goes on. ‚ÄúSlughorn brings in this little kid. And I mean little, I haven‚Äôt seen him in years but at eleven Regulus was tiny, fifty percent hair, and with the face of a dictator.‚Äù

James feels something in his chest squeeze.

‚ÄúAnd this little kid just walks up to the table at the front of the class and starts working. I‚Äôm not sure he glanced up once. Now that I think about it, I‚Äôm not even sure he looked at the textbook,‚Äù she laughs to herself. ‚ÄúAnd he did it. We watched him work for three hours in complete bewitched silence and at the end he had perfectly brewed this potion that had stumped all of us.‚Äù

She pulls away from Sirius, drawing her wand again.

‚ÄúIt was impressive. Not sure it won him many friends but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think making friends was ever Regulus‚Äôs strong suit,‚Äù James says before he can stop himself.

Pandora glances at him. ‚ÄúNo, I don‚Äôt suppose it was,‚Äù before she starts casting again she reaches out and pushes the hair off Sirius‚Äôs forehead. It‚Äôs a gesture that reminds James so much of his mother that he nearly doubles over.

‚ÄúI always did think he‚Äôd come around,‚Äù she says almost wistfully. ‚ÄúHe seemed too smart to fall for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù James asks, not quite able to follow along, trying too hard to breathe.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù she clarifies. ‚ÄúI just figured he was smart enough that he‚Äôd work it out eventually. How hollow it all is‚Äîhow hollow they all are. Nobody who understands the theories of potion brewing can really believe in blood purity. Muggle-blood and Pureblood is all the same in a cauldron.‚Äù

There are too many feelings raging inside James‚Äôs chest. He remembers nights spent talking for hours. Regulus going on about the books he was reading and the classes he was taking‚Äîhe had favourite lectures and he would quote them sometimes. James would tease him but the truth was, he loved hearing it. Hearing all of it. Always greedy for anything Regulus was willing to give him.

He tries not to let everything that‚Äôs happened since turn those moments into something twisted. But maybe they always were. James doesn‚Äôt know anymore.

‚ÄúNow this is fascinating,‚Äù Pandora murmurs, still bent over Sirius.

‚ÄúWhat is?‚Äù James asks, stepping forward.

‚ÄúWell, it appears that the spell he was hit with was a sort of distant cousin of the Jelly-Brain Jinx. It‚Äôs messing with his brain function, blocking his senses, essentially cutting him off from all outside stimulation and trapping him inside his head.‚Äù

James stares at her for a moment, wondering if his expression is properly communicating the absolute horror he currently feels.

‚ÄúIt really is a fascinating bit of spell work,‚Äù she says, oblivious. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never seen anything quite so complex. Did you manage to hear the incantation?‚Äù

It takes James a minute to speak, his mouth gone dry. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúHm,‚Äù she frowns, turning back to her supplies. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôll make it more difficult to treat. Likely it will wear off on its own in a few hours‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúA few hours,‚Äù James repeats, staring down at Sirius with wide eyes.

‚ÄúThere are certain ways to speed up the return to full consciousness, at least with the Jelly-Brain Jinx, I‚Äôll try those and see if they help. If he‚Äôs still under in the morning we‚Äôll have to reassess.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚ÄîI mean why would anyone even use this spell? Why not just kill the person you‚Äôre fighting?‚Äù

Pandora shrugs, ‚ÄúSome people like to draw things out,‚Äù she says in the same tone of voice that one might use to describe the weather. ‚ÄúThough I expect it‚Äôs probably used most often on the subjects of interrogation. I‚Äôm sure it breaks down people‚Äôs mental walls rather efficiently.‚Äù

Fuck.

‚ÄúYou think they were going to try and interrogate us?‚Äù

Her grey eyes find his. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that what you were going to do to them?‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt bother answering, instead reaching out to take Sirius‚Äôs hand again.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be right back, there are just a few things I left downstairs that I‚Äôll need,‚Äù she places a vial on the bedside table. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a pain potion, he‚Äôll want it when he wakes up,‚Äù she looks pointedly at James. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm assuming you intend to stay with him?‚Äù

James has to clear his throat before he can speak. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he croaks. ‚ÄúYeah I‚Äôm gonna stay with him.‚Äù

¬†


James never lets go of Sirius‚Äôs hand‚Äînot when Pandora treats him, not when she leaves. He knows Sirius can‚Äôt feel him. Knows he can‚Äôt hear him. Knows he‚Äôs probably losing it, because this is his worst nightmare. But he hopes, irrationally, illogically, that somehow Sirius knows that he‚Äôs there. Even without having any sense of the world. Without being able to touch or smell or see. He hopes he just‚Ä¶knows. The way they feel each other when they fly. A sixth sense. Faith.

His eyes have glazed over and his brain has gone blissfully quiet when he hears a commotion downstairs. By the time he‚Äôs blinked himself awake enough to turn towards the door there are already footsteps bounding up towards him. And then Remus is sprinting into the room.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù he gasps when he sees him, eyes dropping instantly to Sirius. ‚ÄúIs he‚Äîis he okay? They didn‚Äôt say‚ÄîI asked but no one knew anything and I‚Äîfuck, he looks‚Äî‚Äú

For the first time in hours James lets go of Sirius, going to Remus and taking him by the shoulders. ‚ÄúHey, breathe okay? Breathe. He‚Äôs going to be fine. He got hit by a curse but it‚Äôll wear off.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat curse?‚Äù

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo idea, never heard of it, but he‚Äôs‚ÄîI mean apparently he‚Äôs trapped in his head.‚Äù

Remus stares at him with an expression James is sure mirrors the one he‚Äôd given Pandora. ‚ÄúIs that a fucking joke?‚Äù

James grimaces. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt think so, no.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ,‚Äù he looks back at Sirius, pulling away from James and moving to his side. He sits on the bed, taking the hand that James had been holding‚Äîtaking his place‚Äîwhich makes James feel a weird itch of jealousy that he doesn‚Äôt like in the least.

‚ÄúHe should wake up soon,‚Äù James says awkwardly from the middle of the room, no longer sure of his role here.

Remus nods. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been like this for‚Ä¶?‚Äù

James shrugs even though Remus isn‚Äôt looking at him. ‚ÄúMaybe two hours? Three?‚Äù

‚ÄúHours? Fuck,‚Äù and then; ‚ÄúLily came with me‚Äîshe‚Äôs downstairs.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù James still lingers in the doorway, staring at his two best friends. ‚ÄúUm‚Äîthere‚Äôs a pain potion on the bedside table, he might want that when he wakes up, I kinda dislocated his shoulder trying to stop him from running head first into the ground.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay‚ÄîJames?‚Äù Remus looks over at him. ‚ÄúAre you alright? Were you hurt too or‚Ä¶?‚Äù

James gives him a shaky smile. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine. No injuries to report,‚Äù well, except his back, but it doesn‚Äôt seem worth mentioning.

‚ÄúGood. That‚Äôs good,‚Äù Remus‚Äôs attention returns to Sirius.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll leave you to it then‚Ä¶‚Äù James doesn‚Äôt want to go, it feels wrong, but at the same time staying feels like forcing himself into a scene that has no room for him anymore.

Eventually his feet start moving, carrying him down a set of winding wooden stairs that announce each of his steps with an incredibly loud creak.

‚ÄúJames!‚Äù he‚Äôs barely reached the ground before Lily is flinging herself into his arms. His upper body screams in protest but James doesn‚Äôt care, holding her to him and squeezing her tight, like he hasn‚Äôt seen her in years.

‚ÄúAre you ok?‚Äù she asks as he places her back on her feet, her hands skimming over him, checking for injuries.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay.‚Äù

She cups his cheeks, her green eyes bright as they meet his. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt know,‚Äù after a few seconds. ‚ÄúGod James, there was a while there where we just‚Ä¶where we thought maybe‚Ä¶‚Äù she shakes her head.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he covers her hands with his own, pressing them closer. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay.‚Äù

Her smile is a little watery. ‚ÄúNo more missions for you. You can be my trophy husband from now on.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat, and let you go out and do all the dangerous stuff?‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just meant to sit at home looking pretty for you?‚Äù she laughs, the noise choked as she leans forward, going up on her toes.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

They kiss. Soft and gentle. An ‚Äúoh hi I‚Äôm so glad to see you‚Äù an ‚ÄúI missed you‚Äù an ‚ÄúI love you, I love you, I love you.‚Äù

Their foreheads are still pressed together when the sounds of crying fill the room, followed swiftly by a small ginger head darting down the stairs in footy pyjamas. The kid stops dead in his tracks at the sight of them, eyes going wide. Before any of them can speak a voice comes hurtling through the ceiling.

‚ÄúWILLIAM ARTHUR WEASLEY YOU GET BACK HERE RIGHT NOW!‚Äù

Though James wouldn‚Äôt have thought it possible, the boy‚Äôs eyes grow even larger. ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt tell her you saw me,‚Äù he says quickly, before darting off again and disappearing into the kitchen.

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù Lily watches the kid flee. ‚ÄúI feel like I just got a glimpse into your childhood.‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù James scoffs. ‚ÄúI was an angel, I don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre talking about.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù she pinches his side as the crying grows louder.

The cause of this is made apparent when Molly appears down the stairs with two squirming infants in her arms.

‚ÄúBill! Bill‚ÄîArthur‚Äîoh for goodness sake‚Äôs,‚Äù she‚Äôs wearing a housecoat, bags under her eyes that can‚Äôt just be from tonight. ‚ÄúWill you two take them for a minute?‚Äù she asks Lily and James. ‚ÄúI need to go get that little menace before he breaks something else.‚Äù

Without waiting for an answer she shoves a baby into each of their arms. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Fred and that‚Äôs George,‚Äù she pauses for a minute, eyes going back and forth between the babies. ‚ÄúOr maybe it‚Äôs the other way ‚Äòround, what do I know. They‚Äôll not be able to tell that you‚Äôre calling them the wrong names anyway.‚Äù

James bites his lip, stifling a laugh as he adjusts the position of the tiny crying child in his arms.

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt happen to see where my oldest went did you?‚Äù she asks, eyes scanning the room around them.

‚ÄúNope,‚Äù James says automatically.

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt see anyone,‚Äù Lily adds. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

Molly waves her words away. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a slippery one‚ÄîBill! Bill you get out here right now before I ground you for the rest of your bloody existence!‚Äù

James snorts as she walks off, starting to gently rock the red faced infant in his arms. ‚ÄúHey buddy,‚Äù he says as the kid continues to wail. James nods understandingly. ‚ÄúYeah, I get that. Honestly we could all do with a good cry now and then huh?‚Äù the little thing blinks up at him, eyes wet, sobs turning into hiccups.

‚ÄúBet it‚Äôs right rubbish being a baby, you can‚Äôt fly, can‚Äôt eat any sweets, bleak as hell that.‚Äù

There‚Äôs some gurgling that James takes as agreement, still rocking back and forth as he looks over at Lily who has her eyes intently on him, her own baby somehow already fast asleep in her arms.

‚ÄúUh-oh,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúYou see that buddy? She‚Äôs giving us googley eyes.‚Äù

Lily laughs. ‚ÄúI am not.‚Äù

‚ÄúMm, pretty sure you are. What d‚Äôyou think big guy?‚Äù he looks down at the baby who slobbers a little. James considers this another sign that they‚Äôre on the same page. ‚ÄúHe says I‚Äôm right.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh does he?‚Äù Lily asks.

‚ÄúMhm, you‚Äôve gone all gooey Evans. It‚Äôs pathetic.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one carrying on conversations with a baby.‚Äù

James makes a mildly offended noise. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just trying to be polite to little Fred-George here.‚Äù

Lily laughs again. ‚ÄúIf your‚Äôs is Fred-George does that make mine George-Fred?‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds about right to me.‚Äù

Lily looks down at her baby, kissing the top of his peach-fuzz head like she can‚Äôt help it. When her eyes find James‚Äôs again her smile grows.

‚ÄúNow who has googley eyes?‚Äù

But James doesn‚Äôt fight it. ‚ÄúMe. Definitely.‚Äù

Her expression softens. ‚ÄúYou want kids Potter?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, loads.‚Äù

‚ÄúLoads?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell you can‚Äôt just have one.‚Äù

Lily arches her brow. ‚ÄúI mean, unless there‚Äôs been a change in the laws I‚Äôm pretty sure you can.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúSure but they‚Äôll be lonely. You‚Äôve gotta give them someone to play with.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù Lily says, something vaguely sympathetic in her eyes. And maybe a little sad too. He wonders if she‚Äôs thinking about her sister. ‚ÄúHow many is ‚Äúloads‚Äù then?‚Äù

The answer comes to him automatically. ‚ÄúFour. At least.‚Äù

‚ÄúAt least? Jesus.‚Äù She continues rocking George-Fred. ‚ÄúAnd I expect you‚Äôll be wanting all boys then?‚Äù

James is actually surprised by the question, he hadn‚Äôt really thought about it. Eventually he shrugs, causing the baby in his arms to gurgle again. ‚ÄúNot really that bothered either way. As long as they wanna play Quidditch with me that‚Äôs all that matters.‚Äù

Lily‚Äôs face does something he can‚Äôt decipher.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he asks.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that look for?‚Äù he gestures to her with his chin.

She shrugs. ‚ÄúNothing, I just‚Ä¶love you a lot sometimes.‚Äù

James grins. ‚ÄúWell obviously, I‚Äôm awesome.‚Äù Fred-George starts to laugh and James looks down at him and then back up at Lily, positively beaming. ‚ÄúI made him laugh!‚Äù

‚ÄúYou did not make him laugh.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh, pretty sure I did. I told a joke and he laughed. Ergo, I made him laugh.‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes, biting back a smile. ‚ÄúIt was a coincidence.‚Äù

‚ÄúMm, you can‚Äôt prove that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre an idiot.‚Äù

James only smiles at her. ‚ÄúYeah, but you love me remember?‚Äù

She shakes her head, the pair of them going quiet. James watches his baby‚Äôs eyes droop, his little mouth stretching in a yawn as he slowly falls asleep. Honestly, James could go for a nap too right about now.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Lily says eventually.

James looks up but she‚Äôs still staring at the kid in her arms. ‚ÄúFour Quidditch players.‚Äù

Something stupid and fluttery happens in James‚Äôs stomach. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù he asks, voice coming out a little more sincerely than he means it to.

She meets his eyes. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

¬†

PART IV REMUS

He can‚Äôt remember if he‚Äôs ever seen Sirius this still. He doesn‚Äôt think so. Sirius Black is all action, all movement, all decisions that really ought to take more time. Even when he‚Äôs sleeping he still finds ways to struggle. Seeing him like this‚Ä¶frozen. Behaving. It‚Äôs so unnatural it makes Remus‚Äôs skin crawl.

He hates sitting here, being useless. Hates that he wasn‚Äôt there when Sirius needed him. That he never seems to be there anymore. He hates Sirius a little bit too.

He‚Äôs still holding his hand, keeps pressing his thumb over Sirius‚Äôs pulse just to reassure himself. James said that Sirius would be okay and Remus believes him, he does, except‚Äîexcept the room is so quiet. And Sirius is so dim. And everything about it feels wrong. So he keeps checking. He‚Äôs become familiar with Sirius‚Äôs pulse. He knows how to make it race and how to make it slow and how to hold it tenderly.

When everything first started falling apart tonight they didn‚Äôt know what had happened to Sirius and the others. They didn‚Äôt know if they were still alive or if they‚Äôd been taken hostage or if they were laying in a valley somewhere broken and bleeding out. Not knowing was the worst feeling.

Because he hates Sirius a little bit.

But he would bite off his own arm before he would live in this world without him.

Sirius groans and Remus feels his whole body react to the sound, instantly sitting up.

For the first time since he got here Sirius moves, his face‚Äîhis beautiful face‚Äîcomes back alive and he squirms, hand pulling out of Remus‚Äôs.

‚ÄúSirius? Hey‚Äîhey Sirius?‚Äù

The other boy‚Äôs eyes fly open, wide and grey, he gasps like he‚Äôs just been pulled back above the tide. ‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Sirius says, instantly closing his eyes again. ‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù His voice is soft, a whisper.

Remus waits for more but none comes, Sirius‚Äôs eyes remaining firmly shut. After a few seconds Remus reaches out, placing a tentative hand in Sirius‚Äôs hair but the other boy flinches and Remus instantly pulls away.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù he matches Sirius‚Äôs volume, keeping his voice low.

There‚Äôs more silence before Sirius eventually speaks. ‚ÄúHey Moons,‚Äù his voice gravel.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Remus wants to touch him so badly but he holds back.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Sirius says, mouth wrapping awkwardly around the word. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just‚Ä¶a lot,‚Äù he swallows. ‚ÄúI just need‚Äî‚Äú but his voice splinters off. ‚ÄúIt was so quiet,‚Äù he manages eventually, and there is something heartbreaking about those words.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay now,‚Äù Remus says instantly, not sure if it‚Äôs what Sirius needs to hear but not knowing what else to say. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre safe.‚Äù

Sirius gives him a stiff nod, eyes still squeezed shut.

‚ÄúCan I‚Äîcan I touch you?‚Äù Remus asks.

Sirius shakes his head. ‚ÄúToo much.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Remus whispers back. He doesn‚Äôt know what that means exactly, doesn‚Äôt know how to help. How do you help someone who‚Äôs just been trapped alone in their head for several hours? ‚ÄúDo you want‚Äîthere‚Äôs pain potion, would that help?‚Äù

Another pause. ‚ÄúNo. It‚Äôs not really‚Äî‚Äù his voice breaks off, he exhales and forces the words to come back. ‚ÄúNot really that kind of pain.‚Äù

Remus hates that answer.

‚ÄúWhat do you need me to do?‚Äù he asks eventually, desperately.

A shaky smile pulls at Sirius‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúStay.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going anywhere,‚Äù which feels like all he says these days, feels like what he‚Äôs trying to say even when he can‚Äôt open his mouth. The promise he breaks over and over again.

Remus isn‚Äôt sure how much times passes, how long they sit there, Sirius no longer still like he was, expressions flashing across his face that Remus tries and fails to understand. He does his best not to fidget, does his best to hold still and not let his mind spiral worrying about all the things this spell might have done to Sirius or wondering how long the after effects will last.

‚ÄúDo you remember,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs soft voice drifts through the room, ‚Äúwhen we made the map?‚Äù

The question is so out of the blue that it actually startles a laugh from Remus. ‚ÄúOf course I do.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt think we could do it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, to be fair, it was a very complicated piece of magic and we were a bunch of idiots.‚Äù

That soft smile comes back to Sirius‚Äôs face, his eyes still closed. It makes him look young. Makes him look like he did back then. Before it all got so complicated.

Actually, that‚Äôs not really true.

Things were always complicated for them.

The werewolf and the runaway.

The monster and the prince.

‚ÄúI believed in us,‚Äù Sirius goes on. And then; ‚ÄúI believed in you.‚Äù

Those words make Remus‚Äôs heart flip-flop in his chest even though he knows they don‚Äôt really mean anything.

‚ÄúIt was a group effort,‚Äù he says eventually.

‚ÄúMm,‚Äù Sirius hums. ‚ÄúBut you were the reason it worked. You‚Äôre the reason any of it works.‚Äù

‚ÄúAny of it?‚Äù Remus asks tentatively, throat tight.

‚ÄúThe four of us, the pranks, my life,‚Äù he laughs quietly, it‚Äôs a noise Remus has never heard from Sirius before. ‚ÄúIt works because of you. I don‚Äôt think I really understood that before. But when you‚Äôre gone it‚Äôs all just‚Ä¶broken pieces.‚Äù

Remus has no idea what to say to that, what to do with the complicated knot of feelings in his chest. But, predictably, Sirius doesn‚Äôt give him the time to sort it out, because a few seconds later he‚Äôs blinking his eyes open, letting out a shaky exhale before turning his head towards Remus.

‚ÄúHey Moons,‚Äù he says again, this time looking straight at him. Those eyes will be the death of Remus one day, he just knows it.

‚ÄúNot too much?‚Äù he asks gently, once he‚Äôs found his voice again.

Sirius grins and he almost looks like his normal self. ‚ÄúWorth it.‚Äù

¬†

PART V MARY

They sit in a living room filled with mismatched furniture and more pashmina rugs than Mary has ever seen in her entire life. Marlene is on one side of her and Lily on the other, Arthur Weasley taking the armchair across from them.

They hear the creaking of the stairs before they see James coming back into the room. ‚ÄúSirius is awake,‚Äù he says before they can ask. ‚ÄúBut he‚Äôs not strong enough to come down and Remus isn‚Äôt leaving his side. Pandora‚Äôs still working on Frank‚Äôs potion but Frank and Alice are asleep anyway,‚Äù he perches himself on the arm of the sofa. ‚ÄúSo it looks like it‚Äôs just us.‚Äù

They all turn to Arthur who nods understandingly. ‚ÄúRight, got it, so,‚Äù he rubs his palms together. ‚ÄúWhere to begin?‚Äù

Mary assumes this is a rhetorical question but the silence stretches on for a painfully long time. Eventually, when he continues to seem at a loss, Lily speaks. ‚ÄúThe Death Eaters have taken the Ministry.‚Äù

Mary turns to stare at her. ‚ÄúExcuse me?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve what?‚Äù Marlene demands at the same time.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs temporary,‚Äù Arthur jumps in quickly. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve been growing in numbers, in power, but they still don‚Äôt have enough of either to actually run the government long term.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey do have enough to hold it hostage though,‚Äù Lily adds.

‚ÄúAnd the group from Bulgaria was‚Ä¶what?‚Äù James asks. ‚ÄúA distraction?‚Äù

Arthur tilts his head from side to side. ‚ÄúThe group from Bulgaria was Voldemort trying to bring in reinforcements, to show that he‚Äôs an actual threat to the Ministry.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo Dumbledore sent us to fight an army then?‚Äù Mary asks flatly.

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt clear that that‚Äôs what they were before tonight, he was just as blindsided by that as the rest of us,‚Äù Arthur fidgets. ‚ÄúThe information we had really did make it seem like it was a mission to bring over specific high ranking members of his supporters from the continent, not‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúA whole bloody platoon?‚Äù Mary finishes for him.

Arthur gives her an apologetic look. ‚ÄúPrecisely.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, okay, but what the hell does that have to do with St Mungos?‚Äù James‚Äôs hair is an absolute disaster. You can almost always tell the state of James‚Äôs distress by the height of his hair.

‚ÄúThey went after a few other government institutions,‚Äù Arthur explains. ‚ÄúThey weren‚Äôt able to completely shut them down like the Ministry but‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶you saw the state St Mungos was in.‚Äù

‚ÄúBastards,‚Äù Marlene hisses. ‚ÄúWhat kind of assholes attack a hospital?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe chair of St Mungos is Muggle-born so,‚Äù Arthur grimaces. ‚ÄúIt has been the target of a few small scale attacks before, this one was the biggest of course.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait, I‚Äôm sorry, so the Death Eaters are in control of the Ministry?‚Äù Mary demands.

‚ÄúVoldemort and the Minister are currently barricaded in his office‚Ä¶negotiating.‚Äù

That instantly makes the hair on the back of Mary‚Äôs neck stand up. ‚ÄúNegotiating?‚Äù she repeats slowly. ‚ÄúWhat exactly are they negotiating?‚Äù

Arthur wipes a hand over his face, looking tired for the first time all night. Not that it‚Äôs night anymore. Through the windows‚Äîwhich are all different sizes and shapes, because nothing in this house is consistent‚Äîthe first pink and gold strips of light can be seen on the horizon.

‚ÄúThe Dark Lord has certain demands he wants met. He‚Äôs asking that all Muggle-borns and Half-bloods be removed from government offices. Including teachers at Hogwarts and Healers at St Mungos.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Marlene demands, outraged.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no way that the Minister is going to agree to that,‚Äù James says confidently.

‚ÄúMoody is working on regaining control of the Ministry, teams of Aurors have been sent in, but‚Ä¶‚Äù Arthur trails off again.

‚ÄúBut?‚Äù James prods.

‚ÄúBut there were a lot more sympathizers in the Ministry than we previously believed.‚Äù

Of course there were. Fucking politicians.

‚ÄúWhat does that mean?‚Äù James asks, sounding agitated.

‚ÄúIt means‚Ä¶‚Äù Arthur struggles. ‚ÄúIt means that agreeing to Voldemort‚Äôs terms is starting to look like the best way to end this without any bloodshed.‚Äù

There‚Äôs silence after those words, until Mary breaks it with a laugh.

‚ÄúWithout any bloodshed,‚Äù she repeats derisively. ‚ÄúYou lot really think this is where this ends? That you fire a few people and Voldemort and his merry band of assholes will just leave us all alone?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe anyone thinks that, no,‚Äù Arthur says softly.

‚ÄúThis is not harmless,‚Äù she‚Äôs on a roll now. ‚ÄúIf the Ministry agrees to these terms, if they fire all the Muggle-borns and Half-bloods they are sending a message. That Voldemort is right. That these people are lesser. That WE,‚Äù she gestures between herself and Lily, ‚Äúare lesser. And if you think that blood won‚Äôt be spilt because of that than you haven‚Äôt been fucking paying attention.‚Äù

Mary is breathing heavy, her words leaving silence in their wake. It‚Äôs fine, she doesn‚Äôt care, let them be uncomfortable. Let them feel it it. Eventually Marlene reaches out, hand wrapping around Mary‚Äôs wrist and squeezing.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs right,‚Äù Lily says, sounding a little bit less like she‚Äôs about to decapitate everyone than Mary. ‚ÄúIf we let them get away with this it‚Äôll be like admitting defeat.‚Äù

Arthur looks back at them helplessly, palms upturned. ‚ÄúListen, I don‚Äôt disagree with you, but unfortunately I‚Äôm not in charge of making decisions. All I know is that the feeling at the moment is that this is the best option.‚Äù

Mary laughs coldly. ‚ÄúAnd whose feeling is that exactly? I mean how many Muggle-borns are consulted when Albus fucking Dumbledore is making these decisions huh? Or Alastor Moody? For the people meant to be defending us you lot really don‚Äôt seem to talk to us all that often. To give a damn what we think or what we want.‚Äù

‚ÄúMary,‚Äù Marlene says quietly from beside her, and Mary doesn‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs meant to caution her or support her but she doesn‚Äôt try to figure it out.

‚ÄúI mean the only people who aren‚Äôt Purebloods here are me, Lily and Remus and would any of us even be here if we hadn‚Äôt fucked one of you?‚Äù

James actually chokes, Marlene‚Äôs eyes going wide, Arthur‚Äôs face flushing a deep red. Lily, on the other hand, laughs.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sick of this,‚Äù she goes on. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sick of this whole ‚Äúwe support you but only when it‚Äôs convenient‚Äù bullshit. There should be fucking bloodshed. At this point there should be fucking bloodshed.‚Äù

She gets off the couch because she needs to move and because she has about a dozen more rants in her and she knows if she doesn‚Äôt walk away now she‚Äôll never be able to stop herself. For all his annoying cheer this is not Arthur Weasley‚Äôs fault. Maybe it isn‚Äôt anybodies fault. Maybe it‚Äôs everyones fault. She‚Äôs just angry. She‚Äôs just so goddamn angry.

She walks through the open doorway into the front room, standing at the window with her arms crossed and doing her best to keep it together. The sky is navy blue, the sun growing stronger and stronger in the distance. She cannot help but wonder what this day will be like for all the Muggle-borns and Half-bloods about to lose their jobs. Where will they go? How will they support themselves? Who‚Äôs going to fucking help them?

She hears footsteps behind her, and then Lily is leaning against the wall next to her, Marlene wrapping her arms around her and resting her chin on Mary‚Äôs shoulder.

‚ÄúThat was‚Ä¶pretty hot actually,‚Äù Marlene says, causing Mary to snort.

‚ÄúCareful, Dorcas might get jealous.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù Marlene says easily, ‚Äúshe‚Äôd agree with me.‚Äù

Lily nudges Mary‚Äôs foot to get her attention, something heavy in her eyes. ‚ÄúThank you, for saying all that,‚Äù she nods back towards the living room. ‚ÄúSomeone needed to, it‚Äôs not fair that it always has to be you.‚Äù

‚ÄúThough I don‚Äôt know if that speech would have been quite as scandalous if Lily had said it,‚Äù Marlene adds. ‚ÄúNo offence Lily.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi, I can be scandalous okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll believe it when I see it Evans,‚Äù that earns Mary an eye roll.

They‚Äôre all quiet for a moment, watching the sun come up, Marlene still wrapped around Mary, Lily pressing their shoulders together.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs us first,‚Äù Lily says eventually, seemingly out of nowhere.

Mary looks over at her, brow arched.

‚ÄúThe Order is‚Ä¶the Order,‚Äù Lily waves a dismissive hand, looking intently at Mary and then Marlene. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs us first,‚Äù she gestures between them. ‚ÄúBefore all the rest of it, before everything else. You lot will always be what matters most. You know that right?‚Äù she looks specifically at Mary now.

They stare at each other for what feels like a long time, like a challenge. Lily doesn‚Äôt flinch. Doesn‚Äôt drop her gaze. Green eyes bright and fierce. Eventually, Mary nods. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she says slowly, meaning it far more than she ever thought she would. ‚ÄúYeah, I know.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hey,

so,

here's the thing, I'm struggling with this fic at the moment.

I was trying to write both these characters as flawed and complex, they don't always do the right things because I don't think people always do the right things especially in extreme circumstances (especially when they're kids). That being said, I think I've made mistakes in telling this story and in the ways I've written some of these characters and I promise you I get that. Believe me. It was never my intention to write anything that was dismissive of sexual assault or any other form of abuse or trauma and I cannot express how sorry I am if that's what I did write or if I have in anyway contributed to any toxicity in this space.

Thanks for listening and for reading, appreciate all of you!

Chapter 48

Chapter Summary

I do know that Sirius got his motorcycle in 1977. I simply don't care. Time is a construct. I don't recognize its authority.

Chapter Notes

tw: Drug use (in the form of potions)

tw: I mean like the mildest reference to sexual content

See the end of the chapter for more notes

October 1979

PART I REGULUS

This.

This is good.

He should have been doing this from the beginning.

Should have been doing this years ago.

The potions make the world distant and soft. Everything in him just a little less sharp. A little less in focus. He wonders if this is how everyone else feels all the time? If this is how they‚Äôre able to walk through life unafraid. Like their memories aren‚Äôt something heavy they have to drag with them.

Days and nights blend, he‚Äôs able to function enough. Enough to do what‚Äôs expected of him. But he rarely goes to meetings anymore. Originally it was the thought of being in Lucius‚Äôs house that made him stay away, now he just can‚Äôt be bothered.

Grimmauld remains largely empty aside from him and Kreacher.

Evan visits from time to time, Barty less, Cerci when she can get away from her job and her mother who has grown profoundly unhappy with their relationship, as it becomes more and more apparent that it won't be ending in a marriage proposal. But most of the time it‚Äôs him. Just him. Rooms left dark, left empty, the house starting to curl in on itself, like a plant that can‚Äôt find the sun. Kreacher does his best to tend to it but it‚Äôs no use, and Regulus is certainly not helping.

‚ÄúMaster Regulus is not eating enough,‚Äù the house elf mutters one day as he watches Regulus poking reluctantly at his dinner. ‚ÄúIs it being Kreachers fault sir? Is he not making it right? Is there something wrong with Master Regulus‚Äôs meals?‚Äù

Regulus looks up at him and manages a weak smile. ‚ÄúYour cooking is excellent as always Kreacher, I‚Äôm just not‚Ä¶hungry.‚Äù

Kreacher throws a dish towel in the air in frustration. ‚ÄúBut you is never being hungry anymore!‚Äù

Which is true. The potions fill him up and make food so much less appealing, his taste dulled. It‚Äôs all just mush.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll eat more, I promise,‚Äù Regulus says as he shovels a fork full of pasta into his mouth, but when Kreacher turns his back Regulus vanishes the rest of his plate.

¬†

‚ÄúAre you sick?‚Äù

He blinks, coming back to himself, sitting on his bed while Cerci stares at him with worried eyes. He isn‚Äôt sure how much time has passed between this conversation and the one with Kreacher.

Is it the next day? Is it two days later? A week? He‚Äôs aware that some time has passed, obviously, it‚Äôs just the specifics that his mind doesn‚Äôt quite seem able to hold onto.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he mutters, rubbing at his face. ‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm just tired.‚Äù

Cerci doesn‚Äôt look like she believes him. ‚ÄúI think you need a Healer, my family knows a good one, I can take you right now, I have the whole afternoon free‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo, I don‚Äôt want that,‚Äù he knows he sounds cranky and he doesn‚Äôt mean to be, but he can‚Äôt help it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine. I told you I‚Äôm fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know what you‚Äôve told me,‚Äù it‚Äôs the first time he thinks he‚Äôs ever heard her sound irritated. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre lying, and not even very well.‚Äù

He sighs, flopping down onto his bed and staring up at the ceiling. A few seconds later the mattress dips and Cerci sits next to him, face hovering above his.

She bites on her lower lip. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried about you.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a waste of energy.‚Äù

She rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúRight, okay well, I‚Äôm going to do it anyway.‚Äù

He shrugs, still staring at the ceiling. ‚ÄúYour prerogative I guess.‚Äù

He hears her sigh, a tense silence falling over them. The house creaks and groans around them, begging for help. For a little attention. A little magic to soak up. This place has always been the stronghold of the Black family, he‚Äôs sure it‚Äôs never felt so lonely before. He‚Äôs a bad caretaker. A bad son. A bad brother.

‚ÄúI miss Boo,‚Äù Cerci breaks the silence eventually, because of course she does. ‚ÄúYou never have him around anymore.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a spell,‚Äù Regulus replies flatly. ‚ÄúNot a pet.‚Äù

The truth is, Regulus can‚Äôt cast his Patronus when he‚Äôs high. That was‚Ä¶surprisingly hard at first. He‚Äôd grown used to the ghostly presence at his side, to the warmth it summoned up in him, a physical representation of something that had long ago disappeared from his life. But Boo never helped him sleep, never stopped him thinking, so in the end he kept swallowing the potions. He barely even notices the absence anymore.

‚ÄúAlright, enough, get up,‚Äù Cerci hops off the bed, taking Regulus‚Äôs wrist and tugging on it until he reluctantly sits up.

‚ÄúWhy are we getting up?‚Äù he grumbles.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to bathe, because quite frankly you look like you haven‚Äôt had a bath in a week.‚Äù

To be fair, he might not have.

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm going to make lunch.‚Äù

‚ÄúKreacher will be upset if you make food, you know that,‚Äù he says, though he does force himself off the bed.

‚ÄúWell, he can help then. C‚Äômon, lets go, I‚Äôm assuming you can run the bath yourself? Or have you forgotten how?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre hilarious.‚Äù

She smiles at him, maybe the first genuine smile he‚Äôs seen since she arrived. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

Regulus does bathe and Cerci does make lunch (with Kreacher‚Äôs help) and a few hours later she leaves, still looking at him like she‚Äôs worried he‚Äôs going to fall apart the minute she‚Äôs out the door.

He doesn‚Äôt though.

He isn‚Äôt.

Falling apart that is.

Falling implies some sort of speed and destination.

If anything, Regulus is rotting.

¬†

He sleeps at some point. Gets up at some point. Crushes ingredients and stirs cauldrons and bottles potions and whenever he starts thinking too hard about where those potions are going or what they‚Äôre being used for he drinks his own. Then floats around the halls. Haunting his own house.

He isn‚Äôt particularly observant at the moment, which he supposes is how it happens that he walks up the stairs to his bedroom one day and finds the Dark Lord standing there, staring at something on his desk. For a moment Regulus is certain this is some sort of hallucination, rubbing his eyes and wondering if he‚Äôs swallowed a bad batch of potions. But all thoughts of hallucinations disappear when the man in front of him turns around. The cold chill that runs through Regulus then is more vivid and real than anything he‚Äôs felt in weeks.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù the man says, voice slightly high and boyish despite his age. His skin seems almost translucent, eyes deep and dark and too large for his gaunt face. ‚ÄúIt has been too long.‚Äù

Regulus can‚Äôt say that he agrees.

‚ÄúMy lord,‚Äù he finally manages to force out. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI‚Äôm sorry I wasn‚Äôt expecting you,‚Äù he wracks his blurry brain for any memory of an owl or Fire Call, anything that would have warned him of Voldemort‚Äôs visit, but his thoughts slosh around in his head, running into one another and providing him with no answers.

‚ÄúNo, my apologies, I didn‚Äôt have time to call ahead I‚Äôm afraid.‚Äù The man‚Äôs gaze is sharp and Regulus wonders if he can tell that he isn‚Äôt at his best.

‚ÄúNo apology necessary,‚Äù Regulus says, forcing himself to speak slowly, to annunciate, running over every word in his head a dozen times before speaking, not trusting his judgement a single bit. For a moment the man in front of him simply watches, long bony fingers stroking the book on the desk next to him.

‚ÄúI see a great deal of myself in you Regulus.‚Äù

Which is about as shocking a statement as any. For a moment Regulus flounders, not sure how to respond. He can feel his fear scratching against the cage he‚Äôs put it in, but it‚Äôs distant and distorted by the potions running through his body.

‚ÄúI‚Äîthat is far too kind, I can‚Äôt imagine I deserve the comparison.‚Äù He means that and doesn‚Äôt at the same time.

Voldemort smiles again, the expression not reaching his eyes. ‚ÄúI have great hopes for you, as does your mother, your mind is far above many of your peers and intelligence like that excites me.‚Äù

Regulus is still standing in the doorway, not daring to step further into the room, to close the space between them. He‚Äôs overly aware of how alone he is. Of the bed beside them. Of all the other times he has found uninvited guests in his bedroom.

‚ÄúBut I think we can both agree,‚Äù the Dark Lord goes on, ‚Äúthat you could be doing more.‚Äù

God, Regulus wishes he was sober.

‚ÄúI want nothing more than to serve you, my lord,‚Äù he says tightly, he may not feel his fear as acutely as he normally would, but that hasn‚Äôt stopped his legs and hands from shaking.

‚ÄúThat is good to hear,‚Äù Voldemort says, as though Regulus could say anything else. ‚ÄúLucius was afraid that you would be resistant.‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth. ‚ÄúWas he?‚Äù he asks thinly.

‚ÄúHe feared your withdrawal from social life was a sign of your wavering support for our cause. But I was never concerned. Social connections are of little importance. I care only for your skill and your loyalty.‚Äù

Regulus swallows back the bile crawling up his throat. He doesn‚Äôt know why Lucius has been trying to turn Voldemort against him, if he‚Äôs still bitter over James or what, but it‚Äôs concerning. Whatever Voldemort might say now to his face, Regulus knows that Lucius is one of the most powerful members of his inner circle.

‚ÄúMy skill and loyalty are your‚Äôs my lord, of course.‚Äù

The man before him nods. ‚ÄúTaking the Ministry was far easier than we thought it would be,‚Äù he goes on bluntly. ‚ÄúWe intend to try again and hold it this time. I want you to be involved. I want someone with intelligence and not simply ambition making decisions on the ground.‚Äù

There is absolutely nothing Regulus wants less. His stomach gives a lurch, threatening to vomit up the few bites of food he‚Äôs choked down today.

‚ÄúI would be honoured,‚Äù he barely gets the words out.

‚ÄúExcellent. Severus will contact you soon with further details.‚Äù

As if this offer couldn‚Äôt be made more unappealing.

‚ÄúThis book,‚Äù Voldemort says suddenly, tapping the cover he‚Äôs been stroking for the entirety of the conversation. ‚ÄúWhere did you get it?‚Äù his tone is casual but a chill immediately runs down Regulus‚Äôs spine.

He squints, trying to work out which book it is without stepping forward. When he takes too long to answer the Dark Lord presses on.

‚ÄúI read it once, at Hogwarts,‚Äù he looks down at the cover. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt aware there was another copy.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs chest grows tight, suddenly realizing what book it must be. ‚ÄúI found it in the library here,‚Äù he lies, not wanting to bring Cerci‚Äôs name into it.

‚ÄúHm,‚Äù Voldemort hums softly, seemingly deep in thought before he picks the book up, holding it tightly in his grip. ‚ÄúWould you mind terribly if I borrowed it?‚Äù he asks, the request so ridiculous that Regulus almost laughs. As though he has the power to deny the Dark Lord anything he wants.

‚ÄúOf course not, please.‚Äù

The older man smiles again. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he pulls a pocket watch from his robes‚Äîa small metal thing, ornately engraved, catching the weak sunlight dripping through Regulus‚Äôs window. ‚ÄúI must be going unfortunately,‚Äù he says before snapping it shut. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs been a pleasure to see you again Regulus. Do take care of yourself.‚Äù

He isn‚Äôt sure why those last words sound like a threat, but he‚Äôs still trying to calm his heartbeat even after Voldemort has left the room.

It takes him a while but eventually he‚Äôs moving again, scrambling towards his desk, ruffling through the mess of papers until he finds his notes. He‚Äôs taken them meticulously on every book he‚Äôs read, trying to figure out what it is that‚Äôs been drawing on the Dark Lord‚Äôs magical core. He might be going out of his mind but he isn‚Äôt stupid. Voldemort didn‚Äôt take that book to do some light reading, there‚Äôs something in it that he doesn‚Äôt want Regulus to know. To have.

But what?

He drops onto the floor, spreading the pieces of parchment out in front of him and comparing the notes from every other book to the one the Dark Lord took. What was special about it? What did it have that none of the others did? What is Voldemort trying to hide? He runs through chapter names, through ingredient lists, through incantations. Matching them up line for line.

There is very little published about the Dark Arts, it‚Äôs a bit of a taboo area of interest. Much of the knowledge of the lore has been lost due to a reluctance to print it. Something his mother frequently laments. But it also means that there is a great deal of repetition in all the works Regulus has been reading. So whatever the Dark Lord is hiding, it ought to stand out.

He‚Äôs going through his copy of the book‚Äôs appendix when his attention catches on a single word;

Horcrux.

Something heavy drops into the pit of stomach as he starts shuffling through his other notes, checking all the other books, praying he finds a match, praying he can cross it off the list of possibilities even though, the more he looks, the more certain he becomes that he won‚Äôt be able to.

In all the research he‚Äôs done over the past few weeks the only book that spoke about Horcux‚Äôs in any length was the book that the Dark Lord just snatched from his room.

The walls start to spin and Regulus braces himself against the floor, closing his eyes even though that just makes his sense of vertigo worse. He blames it on the potions and his lack of food and not the reality that is slowly settling around him. The truth that he isn‚Äôt sure he can deny. It fits, fits with everything he‚Äôs noticed in Voldemort over the past few weeks.

He‚Äôs made a Horcrux. Made himself practically immortal. Anyone he goes up against will inevitably lose. And really it shouldn‚Äôt matter, because they were always going to lose. Voldemort was always going to win. Regulus knew that. But he also thought that one day Voldemort would die.

And now‚Ä¶

¬†

PART II LILY

Lily loves Alice‚Äôs flat. Red walls and velvet couches and vintage posters of pin-up girls who wink and blow kisses when you walk by. She has twinkly lights that, unlike the Muggle versions Lily grew up with, float along the ceiling uninhibited by cords and outlets. They look like fireflies. You can see pieces of Frank here and there‚ÄîQuidditch magazines on the coffee table, alphabetized bookshelves filled with magic theory textbooks, a Chuddley Canons mug in the sink. But in reality, Alice fills the space‚Äîall warm and bold and comforting. Lily doesn‚Äôt think Frank minds.

They‚Äôre sitting on the shag carpet in the bedroom, bags of sweets spread around them, the record player on in the background. Marlene tears viciously into a gummy wand. ‚ÄúYou think they‚Äôll call an election?‚Äù she asks, the serious nature of the question fully diminished by the half-chewed gummy in her mouth.

It‚Äôs been a few weeks since Voldemort and his followers gained temporary control of the Ministry. It all ended very civilly. The next day there were even pictures in the Prophet of Voldemort and the Minister shaking hands. A compromise reached‚Äîall civic employees were now required to have pureblood status, any current employees failing to meet this criteria would be let go. A small price, the Prophet had said, for the avoidance of violence. The whole thing was being talked about like it was some kind of political negotiation and not a hostile takeover. It made Lily feel sick.

‚ÄúWithin the year,‚Äù Mary says measuredly, watching her chocolate frog with vague interest as it hops around her palm. ‚ÄúHe was supposed to be a hard-liner. Not very hard-line is it, giving into Voldemort‚Äôs demands?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been in for a while now anyway hasn‚Äôt he?‚Äù Lily asks, she has a vague memory of the last Wizarding election. She‚Äôd only been fifteen, not old enough to vote, it hadn‚Äôt seemed that important at the time.

Marlene shrugs, swallowing the rest of her jelly before she speaks this time. ‚ÄúI mean, not really. Loads of Ministers have stayed on for ten years or longer.‚Äù

Lily makes a face. She isn‚Äôt sure there‚Äôs a single politician in the Ministry right now that she wants to be stuck with for the next ten years. She‚Äôs about to say as much when Alice comes bouncing into the room with an arm full of bubblegum pink potions.

‚ÄúI have them, I have them, I have themmmmm!!!‚Äù she sings, plopping down between Mary and Marlene and passing out the small glass vials.

Lily turns her‚Äôs over in her hand, the vibrant liquid inside hurting her eyes. ‚ÄúSo how do these things work exactly?‚Äùshe asks, shaking her potion.

‚ÄúWell, you swallow it‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúUsually a good place to start with a potion,‚Äù Mary says dryly.

Alice rolls her eyes and continues. ‚ÄúYou swallow it, give it fifteen minutes, and then if your tongue turns green, it‚Äôs positive.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù Lily says, still inspecting the liquid. ‚ÄúSo if you have a green tongue then you‚Äôre up the duff?‚Äù

Alice laughs. ‚ÄúExactly.‚Äù

Mary nods at the potion in Marlene‚Äôs hands. ‚ÄúSomething you wanna tell us Mar?‚Äù

The other girl rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúOh what, like you‚Äôre expecting to be pregnant?‚Äù

‚ÄúGod no,‚Äù Mary makes a disgusted face. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs certainly more of a possibility.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre doing this in solidarity,‚Äù Lily interrupts before the pair of them can get going, they‚Äôre honestly as bad as James and Sirius with their little quippy tangents. ‚ÄúPlus, I wanna see these things in action.‚Äù

Mary arches her brow. ‚ÄúYou and Potter looking to start a little brood of your own?‚Äù

She snorts. ‚ÄúOne day maybe, right now I‚Äôd rather live vicariously through Alice.‚Äù

‚ÄúOoh,‚Äù Alice shimmies her shoulders. ‚ÄúI do love being aspirational.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow accurate are these anyway?‚Äù Mary asks, holding her potion at eye level.

‚ÄúA hundred percent, as long as they‚Äôre brewed correctly. Though you‚Äôre supposed to wait at least an hour or so after the deed is done in order to get an accurate reading, which is a bit of a drag.‚Äù

Lily and Mary both stare blankly at her.

‚ÄúAn hour after‚Äî‚Äú Lily starts but isn‚Äôt quite able to finish the question.

‚ÄúYou mean to tell me,‚Äù Mary picks up where Lily leaves off. ‚ÄúThat an hour after I fuck some dude this potion,‚Äù she holds up the little pink mixture, ‚Äúwill tell me if I‚Äôm pregnant?‚Äù

Both Marlene and Alice seem at a loss for why their friends are so caught up on this particular point.

‚ÄúYes?‚Äù Alice ventures finally.

‚ÄúHoly shit.‚Äù

‚ÄúGod I love magic,‚Äù Mary laughs. ‚ÄúYou got any spares lying around Longbottom? I could use these in my life.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo Muggles not have a way to tell if you‚Äôre pregnant?‚Äù Marlene asks, sounding highly concerned.

‚ÄúI mean they do,‚Äù Lily explains. ‚ÄúBut not anything that can tell you right away.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow long do you have to wait?‚Äù Alice seems similarly concerned.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Lily looks at Mary who shrugs, ‚Äúweeks, at least?‚Äù

‚ÄúWEEKS?‚Äù Alice and Marlene demand in unison.

‚ÄúAnd if you don‚Äôt want to go the hospital for it it‚Äôs a bloody pain to do at home,‚Äù Mary grumbles. ‚ÄúThe kits are like a potions lessons. A lot of mixing things with urine.‚Äù

‚ÄúWITH WHAT?‚Äù

Lily bites back a smile, leaning into Mary ever so slightly. ‚ÄúI think we might be traumatizing them,‚Äù she mock whispers.

‚ÄúWizards,‚Äù Mary sighs, ‚Äúso delicate.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sending you both home with a dozen of these,‚Äù Alice says indignantly. ‚ÄúThat sounds completely barbaric.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôs barbaric, though it‚Äôs certainly inconvenient.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlso you are aware that we‚Äôre Witches right? We can buy our own potions?‚Äù Lily adds.

‚ÄúGive them out to your Muggle friends then! They shouldn‚Äôt have to put up with this.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs definitely illegal,‚Äù Marlene chimes in.

‚ÄúThough I do appreciate the sentiment,‚Äù Mary nudges Alice‚Äôs knee with her own. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôll take you up on those dozen potions.‚Äù

‚ÄúDone.‚Äù

‚ÄúSpeaking of potions,‚Äù Lily says, holding up the one in her hand. ‚ÄúMaybe we should take these, yeah? I wanna find out whether or not I‚Äôm going to be an auntie.‚Äù

‚ÄúYesssss,‚Äù Marlene drags out her ‚Äús‚Äù. ‚ÄúAll I want is to be a cool aunt.‚Äù

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúYou really think you‚Äôre going to be the cool aunt?‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù

‚ÄúTo everyone being the cool aunt,‚Äù Lily uncorks her vial and lifts it into the centre of the circle.

‚ÄúThis might be my favourite toast ever,‚Äù Alice lifts her own potion happily.

‚ÄúTo spoiled brats,‚Äù Mary joins them.

Marlene rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúTo adorable babies.‚Äù

Their potions clink together before each of them throws it back like a shot. The taste is vaguely sweet, almost like vanilla, but nothing too overpowering, and with the consistency of heavy cream.

‚ÄúGod I‚Äôm so glad that didn‚Äôt taste like bubblegum,‚Äù Mary says as she sets her empty vial down.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú Alice stretches, straining to see the clock on the wall. ‚ÄúThree-thirty now, so at three forty-five it‚Äôs tongues out.‚Äù

Marlene snorts, reaching for another gummy wand. ‚ÄúTongues out,‚Äù she murmurs under her breath with amusement. ‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Mary says, leaning back on her hand, ‚Äúwhere is Frankfurt today?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, he‚Äôs off visiting his mum. She‚Äôs been giving him a bit of a hard time about not coming by enough.‚Äù

Mary makes a face. ‚ÄúThat woman is obsessed with him.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs his mum,‚Äù Lily laughs, picking through the bag of Berty Botts for the best flavours. Cherry cheesecake is her favourite.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs still obsessed with him,‚Äù Mary says undeterred, turning to Alice to back her up. ‚ÄúAm I wrong?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs her only son,‚Äù Alice waves her hand dismissively, ‚Äúshe‚Äôs just very‚Ä¶proud.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat house is a shrine to him.‚Äù
