‚ÄúHonestly, James‚Äôs house is kind of like that too,‚Äù Lily says before frowning‚Äîshe‚Äôs just made the mistake of eating a cough syrup flavoured bean instead of a strawberry one. ‚ÄúMaybe it‚Äôs a Pureblood thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôve been to James‚Äôs house, it‚Äôs not the same.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah I‚Äôll give you that,‚Äù Alice concedes. ‚ÄúAugusta has really gone overboard with the photos and old broomsticks and trophies. It is a bit much.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat were you doing at Frank‚Äôs house anyway?‚Äù Marlene asks Mary around the wand in her mouth.

‚ÄúHe was trying to get rid of some old Quidditch gear, I went over to pick it up.‚Äù

Marlene groans, flopping down onto her back. ‚ÄúMerlin I miss Quidditch.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Mary agrees, sounding significantly more morose than she usually does. ‚ÄúYeah me too.‚Äù

Something squirms in Lily‚Äôs stomach. The war moves so fast and takes up so much time that it‚Äôs easy to forget everything they‚Äôve lost over the last few years. Everything they‚Äôve had to let go of. And then, in the moments like this, moments of stillness. Of calm. It hits you like a brick wall.

‚ÄúOkay, it‚Äôs three-forty-five, it‚Äôs time, it‚Äôs time!‚Äù Alice bounces around excitedly.

‚ÄúShall we do it on the count of three then?‚Äù Mary asks as Marlene pulls herself back up to sitting.

‚ÄúSounds good to me,‚Äù Lily agrees.

‚ÄúNo wait! Wait, wait, wait!‚Äù Alice puts her hands out, bracing herself against Mary and Marlene. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt‚ÄîI‚Äôm too nervous‚Äîcan we just do it one at a time? Someone else go first?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll go,‚Äù Marlene volunteers, straightening out her shoulders. ‚ÄúYou lot ready?‚Äù

‚ÄúOn the edge of my seat,‚Äù Mary says dryly. ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt imagine what the results will be.‚Äù

Marlene glares at her. ‚ÄúWatch me be pregnant just to spite you.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat certainly would be magical.‚Äù

‚ÄúPractically biblical,‚Äù Lily adds, earning her a smirk from Mary.

‚ÄúBibli‚Äîwhat?‚Äù

Mary waves her hand impatiently. ‚ÄúJust open your damn mouth already McKinnon.‚Äù

Rolling her eyes, Marlene does as she‚Äôs asked, sticking her tongue out an obscene amount. ‚ÄúWha‚Äô wolour wis bit?‚Äù Marlene asks.

‚ÄúPink,‚Äù Lily says.

‚ÄúDefinitely pink,‚Äù Mary agrees.

‚ÄúPersonally I think it‚Äôs more of a mauve,‚Äù Alice gets an exasperate sigh from Mary.

‚ÄúBummer,‚Äù Marlene closes her mouth. ‚ÄúI really was looking forward to having a spite baby.‚Äù

Mary throws a sugar quill at her that Marlene deftly avoids.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù the blonde says, grinning. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs next?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence in which they all try not to look at Alice but inevitably end up doing it anyway.

‚ÄúGuess it‚Äôll be me then,‚Äù Mary says, when Alice very pointedly does not volunteer. A second later she‚Äôs sticking her tongue out.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got a very average looking tongue there Macdonald,‚Äù Lily says. Mary shoves her.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never had any complaints.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you haven‚Äôt,‚Äù Lily gives her a smirk. ‚ÄúWell, I suppose I can‚Äî‚Äú but Alice cuts her off.

‚ÄúOkay, never mind,‚Äù she says a little flustered, colour high in her cheeks. ‚ÄúI lied, I can‚Äôt wait, I‚Äôve gotta know,‚Äù she squeezes her eyes shut and for a minute they all just watch her and then‚Äî

‚ÄúOh my God!‚Äù Marlene gasps, hands flying to her mouth.

Alice‚Äôs eyes pop open and her mouth snaps closed. ‚ÄúOh my God what? Oh my god what!‚Äù

Lily feels a whole mess of excited and shocked and happy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs green‚ÄîAlice it‚Äôs green.‚Äù

The other girl‚Äôs eyes grow to about twice their normal size. ‚ÄúWhat? Really?‚Äù But before any of them can answer she‚Äôs on her feet scrambling towards the bathroom, nearly tripping in her haste.

A few seconds later there‚Äôs a loud squealing noise and Alice is running back into the room. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs green!‚Äù

‚ÄúWe told y‚Äîoof‚Äù Mary says as she finds herself being tackled by a very excited Alice.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs green! It‚Äôs green! It‚Äôs green!‚Äù

Lily throws herself into the mix as well, hugging Alice and Mary before Marlene drops on top of them, the four girls essentially dog-piling on the bedroom floor

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs green, it‚Äôs green, it‚Äôs green!‚Äù they start to chant with Alice.

‚ÄúAs happy as I am for you, would you lot mind getting off? I can‚Äôt bloody breathe,‚Äù Mary grumbles, and reluctantly, the three of them start untangling themselves.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm having a baby,‚Äù Alice says to Lily, all dreamy eyed and sweet voiced. They‚Äôve ended up sitting in front of each other on the floor.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre having a baby,‚Äù Lily agrees, unable to keep the softness out of her voice. If anyone deserves to be parents it‚Äôs Alice and Frank.

Something flickers across Alice‚Äôs face then, the light in her eyes dimming as her brows draw together.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Lily asks. ‚ÄúAlice what is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú the expression on her face grows more serious, eyes focused intently on Lily. ‚ÄúYou never showed us your tongue.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Lily laughs. ‚ÄúNot really important now is it?‚Äù

But the expression on Alice‚Äôs face doesn‚Äôt go away. ‚ÄúLily‚ÄîLily open your mouth.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlice it really doesn‚Äôt matter, c‚Äômon.‚Äù

Alice shakes her head. ‚ÄúNo, I think you should open your mouth.‚Äù

Still feeling thoroughly jarred by the turn in the conversation Lily nods, ‚ÄúOkay, sure, fine.‚Äù She sticks her tongue out and somehow the room goes silent.

It‚Äôs not as though it was all that loud to begin with but Marlene and Mary‚Äôs talking in the background, the movement, the laughter‚Äîeverything stops.

‚ÄúLily,‚Äù Alice says delicately.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù she asks, feeling her heart begin to speed up as she takes in the expressions on her friend‚Äôs faces and the sickening realization hits her. She begins to shake her head. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says firmly, eyes bouncing between the three of them. ‚ÄúNo. No that‚Äôs not possible. That‚Äôs NOT possible. No, no, no,‚Äù and in a sick reenactment of the earlier moment of joy Lily finds herself scrambling to her feet and running to the bathroom.

Her reflection is wide-eyed and terrified when she finds it in the mirror, opening her mouth.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù she hisses, grabbing hold of the sink and dropping her head. ‚ÄúFuck, fuck, fuck.‚Äù Pins and needles run up and down her arms and legs as her whole world seems to tilt.

‚ÄúLily?‚Äù It‚Äôs Alice, she stands next to her, hand on her lower back, Marlene and Mary lingering in the doorway. ‚ÄúJust breathe okay? We‚Äôre gonna figure this out.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a mistake,‚Äù Lily says when she can speak again, looking pleadingly at her friend. ‚ÄúIt has to be a mistake. I want to take another test, this can‚Äôt be right. We‚Äôre careful. We‚Äôre safe. I swear we are, I swear I am. I always am. This isn‚Äôt‚Äîthis can‚Äôt be happening. I‚Äôm so careful.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know sweetheart, I know. It‚Äôs going to be okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want to take another test, I want to tak‚Äîthis just can‚Äôt be right, it can‚Äôt be,‚Äù she squeezes her eyes shut. ‚ÄúIt can‚Äôt, It can‚Äôt, it can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe tests are a hundred percent effective I don‚Äôt think‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMar,‚Äù Alice cuts her off. ‚ÄúJust go grab another one okay? Top shelf of the pantry is where I keep my potions, they‚Äôre all labelled,‚Äù Marlene doesn‚Äôt argue, quickly shutting her mouth and heading towards the kitchen. ‚ÄúMary can you go get her some water please?‚Äù

Mary nods, giving Lily one last pitying look before following after Marlene.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to be sick,‚Äù Lily mumbles. ‚ÄúOh fuck I‚Äôm going to be sick,‚Äù she pushes away from Alice, dropping to her knees in front of the toilet and feeling the entire contents of her stomach crawling up her throat.

Alice ends up holding her hair back as she vomits, eventually collapsing back against the wall and drawing her knees up. I want my mum, she almost says.

I want my mum.

I want my mum.

I want my mum.

‚ÄúLily,‚Äù Alice‚Äôs hand is on Lily‚Äôs back, making slow circles.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do this,‚Äù she croaks. ‚ÄúI just‚Äî‚Äú her whole body is shaking. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not you, I‚Äôm not ready.‚Äù

Alice is sitting crossed-legged next her, eyes all sympathy. ‚ÄúLily, you don‚Äôt have to, you know that right?‚Äù she says steadily. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to do anything you don‚Äôt want to. You say the word and you and I will go to St Mungos, there are‚Äîyou have options.‚Äù

Lily keeps staring at her, trying to work through how she feels about that. She doesn‚Äôt know why it doesn‚Äôt fill her with instant relief. Why she isn‚Äôt pulling them off the floor and saying they should go.

The problem is,

she doesn‚Äôt want this now.

Not like this.

But she does want this.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù she answers finally, voice thick. ‚ÄúI was supposed to have more time. I was supposed to be in control. I was supposed to decide when and how and with who. This was supposed to be good.‚Äù

Alice leans forward, her hand squeezing the back of Lily‚Äôs neck, her forehead resting against Lily‚Äôs temple. ‚ÄúI know babe, I‚Äôm sorry. Whatever you need I‚Äôm here okay? We‚Äôre here.‚Äù

Lily tries to even out her breathing, focusing on her inhales and exhales and nothing else. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù she says finally, ‚Äúthis is your moment and I‚Äôm kinda ruining it.‚Äù

Alice laughs. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell you how much I don‚Äôt give a fuck.‚Äù

Lily laughs too, even if it‚Äôs a little wet. A few seconds pass before she speaks again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm scared,‚Äù she whispers.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Alice says calmly. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôll figure this out okay? Whatever you decide you won‚Äôt have to do any of it alone, I promise.‚Äù

Now Lily thinks she really might cry, reaching out and grabbing her friend‚Äôs hand, squeezing far more tightly than is strictly necessary.

‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

¬†

PART III JAMES

‚ÄúWhat are we doing again?‚Äù Peter asks as they walk through rows of shinny Muggle cars, Sirius leading the way.

‚ÄúPadfoot almost died and now he‚Äôs having a midlife crisis,‚Äù James explains, causing Sirius to bark out a laugh.

‚ÄúMidlife crisis?‚Äù he throws over his shoulder. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt have much faith in my life expectancy then.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour shocking lack of a self-preservation instinct puts all bets on you dying young.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre one to talk.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre referring to, I am an exceptionally level headed person.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah right,‚Äù Peter says from behind him.

James reaches over and shoves Peter who shoves him right back. This is followed by a succession of pushing and hitting and attempted headlocks.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Sirius sighs, interrupting their scuffle, ‚Äúthere she is.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe?‚Äù Peter asks, sliding out from under James‚Äôs arm, hands still held in a defensive position incase he decides to attack again. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs she?‚Äù

But Sirius is already walking away from them, throwing himself into the seat of a giant black motorcycle. I mean, alright, it might not be giant, but James has very limited experience with Muggle vehicles and it certainly feels giant to him.

‚ÄúIs that the she?‚Äù Peter asks.

James sends him a look before swiftly smacking the back of his head and walking off towards Sirius.

‚ÄúPrick,‚Äù Peter murmurs behind him, glaring mutinously.

‚ÄúSo?‚Äù Sirius asks, hands on the handlebars, leaning back in his seat. ‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù

James stares blankly at him. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîwhat do I think about what?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe bike‚Äîlooks dead cool doesn‚Äôt it?‚Äù he grins, flexing his hands.

‚ÄúUh‚Ä¶‚Äù James looks to Peter for help but predictably the other boy only shrugs. Bloody useless. ‚ÄúSure. But you aren‚Äôt going to‚Ä¶you know‚Ä¶you aren‚Äôt really thinking about buying it are you?‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely I am,‚Äù Sirius says without a minutes hesitation.

‚ÄúIs this why you didn‚Äôt bring Remus along?‚Äù Peter asks, looking at the motorbike like he‚Äôs worried it‚Äôs going to bite him.

‚ÄúRemus is in a meeting with Moody,‚Äù Sirius says dismissively, only James doesn‚Äôt miss the tightening in his voice. Apparently, however, Peter does.

‚ÄúReally? What for?‚Äù

James elbows him hard in the ribs.

‚ÄúOw, fuck, what the hell?‚Äù Peter demands.

‚ÄúIxnay on the questions-ay,‚Äù James says through clenched teeth, causing Sirius to roll his eyes.

‚ÄúReal subtle Prongs, as always.‚Äù

‚ÄúSubtlety is my middle name.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike hell it is,‚Äù Peter mutters.

‚ÄúBack to the bike!‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, okay, the bike,‚Äù James rubs his neck. ‚ÄúDo you even know how to drive it?‚Äù

‚ÄúTheoretically.‚Äù

Peter snorts, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs encouraging.‚Äù

Sirius sticks his tongue out at him.

‚ÄúAre you going to get a license?‚Äù

Sirius and Peter both look at James.

‚ÄúA license?‚Äù Sirius repeats.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs a license?‚Äù Peter asks.

‚ÄúOh for‚Äî‚Äú James cuts himself off, dislodging his glasses as he pinches the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúA driver‚Äôs license? It proves that you can drive, all Muggles have to get one if they want to be on the road. Mary has one.‚Äù

Sirius screws up his face. ‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs ridiculous, we don‚Äôt need licences to fly.‚Äù

‚ÄúProbably should considering the way some people go at it.‚Äù

‚ÄúFair point.‚Äù

Despite this potential roadblock Sirius does not seem at all deterred.

‚ÄúHonestly, don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll need one. Don‚Äôt intend to spend much time on the road anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you just going to buy it and stare at it?‚Äù James asks, wondering if maybe the fall from his broom actually did some lasting damage to Sirius‚Äôs head.

The other boy grins, mischief dancing in his eyes. ‚ÄúNah, I‚Äôm gonna fly it.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence in which both Peter and James simply stare at him. And then‚Äî

‚ÄúAre you mental!‚Äù Peter demands. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs insane, you can‚Äôt fly something like this, it‚Äôs too big, it‚Äôll get seen, the balance will be off.‚Äù

Sirius ignores Peter, eyes fixed on James who finds himself slowly mimicking his friend‚Äôs expression.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna charm it?‚Äù he asks.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been looking up spells all week, I think we‚Äôll have to combine one or two to have something strong enough to last for any significant amount of time but, it‚Äôs definitely doable.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry ‚Äòwe‚Äôll‚Äô where did the ‚Äòwe‚Äô come from. I don‚Äôt remember agreeing to this,‚Äù Peter blusters on.

James steps forward, crouching down by the bike to inspect the mechanics, the engine, brain now swirling with possibilities. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell Moony I said this,‚Äù he looks up at Sirius. ‚ÄúBut this might be the best idea you‚Äôve ever had.‚Äù

Sirius laughs. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not that scary y‚Äôknow.‚Äù

‚ÄúI beg to differ,‚Äù James says, running his fingers along the brake cables. ‚ÄúPlus, the rest of us don‚Äôt get a blow job after he finishes reaming us out.‚Äù

‚ÄúGross,‚Äù Peter says from behind him.

‚ÄúCareful Prongs, or you‚Äôll damage Peter‚Äôs delicate virginal sensibilities.‚Äù

James snorts.

‚ÄúOi! I‚Äôm not a virgin.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure Wormtail, whatever you say.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am not!‚Äù

Sirius lets out a put upon sigh. ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre supposed to believe that you went and got laid and, what? Didn‚Äôt mention it?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt tell you everything you know,‚Äù he says petulantly.

Sirius grins at him, sliding his dark sunglasses down off his head as the sun starts peaking through the clouds. They‚Äôre well into fall now, the sky almost always overcast, but Sirius never fails to bring those bloody glasses with him. The same way he wore his leather jacket in the summer. It‚Äôs his uniform. The way he wants the world to see him. The only way he knows who he is.

‚ÄúI have a feeling,‚Äù Sirius goes on, ‚Äúthat this particular piece of information you would share.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve had sex,‚Äù Peter maintains.

‚ÄúWhen? With whomst?‚Äù Sirius prods, causing James to sigh, pulling his attention away from the bike.

‚ÄúLeave him alone Sirius,‚Äù he says.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just curious! I mean, we know he wasn‚Äôt shagging anyone in school‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHey, I did‚Ä¶stuff‚Ä¶in school!‚Äù Peter says indignantly, arms crossing over his chest.

Sirius, who is having far too much fun poking him, is practically beaming at this point. ‚ÄúStuff? I mean, I‚Äôm sure even Snivellus was doing stuff, but that‚Äôs still not the same as fucking someone.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt mean anything, James wasn‚Äôt shagging anyone in school either!‚Äù Peter says defensively, which James, quite frankly, doesn‚Äôt appreciate at all, having no desire to start picking apart his own sex life. Especially considering‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶

‚ÄúWhat exactly do you think him and Lily were doing at the end of seventh year?‚Äù

James almost lets out a sigh of relief, though he shouldn‚Äôt be surprised that Sirius is completely skipping over Regulus. It‚Äôs not exactly his favourite topic.

Peter looks genuinely shocked by this insinuation. ‚ÄúWhat? No way! With Lily? Lily had sex with you in school?‚Äù

Now both his friend‚Äôs are staring at him and James‚Äôs dislike of this conversation grows immensely. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîyeah?‚Äù

Peter shakes his head, looking like his world has just been turned upside down. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think‚Äîshe just seems like the type to wait.‚Äù

James had no idea Peter had put so much thought into his girlfriend‚Äôs sexual history.

‚ÄúI mean,‚Äù he goes on, thoroughly uncomfortable. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt exactly her first.‚Äù

Peter‚Äôs eyes grow large. ‚ÄúReally? Are they all like that d‚Äôyou reckon? Mu‚ÄîMuggle-borns?‚Äù

Now James is starting to get offended. ‚ÄúLike what?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, y‚Äôknow, like Mary.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Sirius interjects. ‚ÄúWhat are you trying to say about Mary?‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing, nothing just,‚Äù Peter wobbles his head from side to side. ‚ÄúWell you know she‚Ä¶she gets around a bit doesn‚Äôt she?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere isn‚Äôt anything wrong with that,‚Äù James says emphatically.

‚ÄúI mean‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúThere isn‚Äôt. Anything. Wrong with that.‚Äù

Peter looks thoroughly uncomfortable. ‚ÄúNo, I know, I know, it‚Äôs just‚Ä¶I mean, you‚Äôre not going to marry a girl like that are you?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat year are you living in exactly Pete?‚Äù James asks, thoroughly thrown by this whole conversation.

The other boy sighs. ‚ÄúI just think family is important and the person you bring into it, or make one with, should be‚Ä¶pure.‚Äù

‚ÄúPure?‚Äù Sirius repeats coldly.

‚ÄúYou know what I mean,‚Äù Peter waves his hands around in exasperation.

‚ÄúI promise you I don‚Äôt mate,‚Äù James says.

Peter‚Äôs cheeks have flushed and he‚Äôs stopped making eye contact. ‚ÄúNever mind, I don‚Äôt know why I thought you guys would‚Ä¶ anyway, I‚Äôm not a virgin.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell bully for you,‚Äù Sirius says sardonically. ‚ÄúWelcome to the little slut club with the rest of us pre-marital sex having heathens‚ÄîJesus Christ Peter,‚Äù Sirius shakes his head. ‚ÄúSometimes you sound like my fucking mother.‚Äù

Peter‚Äôs face drains of colour and James is about to suggest a change in topic when a man in a horrendous beige suit, bellbottom pants, and a receding hairline walks up to them.

‚ÄúHello lads, how‚Äôre you liking my bike?‚Äù he grins, teeth far too white to be natural. In fact, James almost feels he needs to look away.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs perfect,‚Äù Sirius says, the smile returning to his own face. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll take her.‚Äù

¬†

‚ÄúLily?‚Äù James calls out as he kicks the door closed behind him, dropping his keys into the bowl by the front door. ‚ÄúLily?‚Äù her shoes are lying in a heap at the bottom of the stairs and he thinks he can hear music coming from above him.

They‚Äôve officially given up their flat in London, boxes now filling the rooms of his childhood home. Half of it is stuff they haven‚Äôt unpacked, and the other half is stuff they‚Äôre putting away. The parts of his parents that have to move to make room for them. For a while he wasn‚Äôt sure if he could keep the pictures up‚Äîif he could look at their smiling faces and not instantly want to curl in on himself and fall apart. But it felt worse, when they weren‚Äôt there, and gradually, the pictures have started to become more of a comfort than a hurt.

He jogs up the stairs, the music definitely coming from their bedroom. ‚ÄúLils?‚Äù when James opens the door he finds Lily on the floor, she‚Äôs taken the duvet off the bed and wrapped it around herself, her record player going off in the background.

She‚Äôs looking at the ceiling, flat on her back, face only barely poking through the blankets. ‚ÄúHi,‚Äù she says in a small voice.

‚ÄúHey, woah, what‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù James walks into the room, dropping down onto the floor next to her, crossing his legs. Her eyes and nose are a little red, her freckles stark against her pale skin. After a few seconds Lily rolls towards him, onto her side, into a sort of fetal position.

‚ÄúI have to tell you something.‚Äù

James feels his chest grow tight but he tries not to panic, sliding down onto the floor and mirroring her position. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says softly, reaching out to cup her face, thumb brushing her cheek. ‚ÄúYou have my undivided attention.‚Äù

She smiles weakly, the expression wobbling at the edges. James wonders, for one fleeting panicked moment, if this is her breaking up with him. He knows he hasn‚Äôt been the easiest since his parents died. Knows he‚Äôs asked a lot of her. He‚Äôs not sure how he‚Äôll manage if she finishes with him. Not sure there‚Äôll be any getting over it.

When Lily continues to remain silent James decides to push. ‚ÄúI thought you were going to Alice‚Äôs?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúI‚Äîyeah. I did.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd something‚Ä¶happened?‚Äù he guesses, unable to figure out what it could possibly be.

The wobbly smile makes a return. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she says. And then. ‚ÄúAlice is pregnant.‚Äù

Despite the anxiety currently bubbling up inside him James can‚Äôt help but smile. ‚ÄúNo way, that‚Äôs amazing!‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù Lily agrees, though there‚Äôs something off about her voice. About her expression. Now James is well and truly lost.

‚ÄúBut something else happened?‚Äù

She nods again and then sighs heavily.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she says his name pleadingly and he doesn‚Äôt understand why. Because he‚Äôs right there. She doesn‚Äôt need to beg. Hell, she doesn‚Äôt even need to ask. He‚Äôll always be right there. ‚ÄúJames I‚Äôm pregnant.‚Äù

He blinks.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

I mean, he heard the words but‚Äî

‚ÄúWhat? No. I‚Äîno way you can‚Äôt, that doesn‚Äôt‚Äîno. I mean, right? That‚Äôs not, not possible? Right?‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt even know what he‚Äôs saying, his brain feels like it‚Äôs gone numb, unable to process this information. To properly grasp it.

Lily lets out a shaky breath. ‚ÄúTurns out it is possible.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù because James definitely isn‚Äôt, not that he really knows much about pregnancy or babies or any of that stuff if he‚Äôs being honest.

‚ÄúI took three tests at Alice‚Äôs,‚Äù she laughs humourlessly. ‚ÄúAlice even went out to Diagon and bought me a fresh one incase the first two were from a bad batch,‚Äù she looks at him straight on, unwavering. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pregnant James.‚Äù Holy shit.

Holy shit.

Holy shit.

Holy shit.

James sits up, bending his knees and dropping his head between them. He‚Äôs definitely hyperventilating, lungs rejecting the air as soon as he sucks it in.

Holy shit.

Holy shit.

Holy shit.

He feels Lily sit up too, feels her hand rubbing circles into his back.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he says between gasps. ‚ÄúSorry I‚Äôll‚ÄîI just need‚Äîa minute.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine, I threw up when I found out so you‚Äôre not even close to being on my level.‚Äù

James manages a choked laugh at that. He focuses on Lily‚Äôs hand, on her touch, the warmth of it and the steadiness, even though he knows she‚Äôs freaking out too. It takes a few minutes, but eventually he‚Äôs able to get his breathing back to something that resembles a regular pace.

He gives himself another minute before turning to Lily. The blanket has fallen away from her head, spooling around her shoulders, revealing a mess of staticky ginger hair.

‚ÄúWhat‚ÄîI mean‚Äîwhat do we do?‚Äù he asks, hoping she has some kind of answer because he sure as hell doesn‚Äôt.

Lily sighs, pulling her hand away from his back and scrubbing at her face. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, I‚Äîthe responsible thing is to,‚Äù she swallows, ‚Äúis to get rid of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù James says, he hadn‚Äôt really thought of that but yes, of course, that makes sense. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù Lily asks, something tight in her voice.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know you said that was the responsible thing to do, I don‚Äôt‚Äîis that not‚Äîwhat do you want?‚Äù he should probably answer that question for himself but he‚Äôs honestly still struggling to fully accept this. That this is real life and not some very very stressful dream. He can‚Äôt conceptualize that there‚Äôs a baby growing inside Lily. Or that it‚Äôs his. Or that it could be born and have a face and fingers and thoughts of its own. That reality is too big.

‚ÄúThe responsible thing to do is get rid of it,‚Äù she repeats. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre‚Äîwe‚Äôre too young and we‚Äôre not ready and we haven‚Äôt even been together that long, not to mention we‚Äôre in the middle of a bloody war,‚Äù she runs a hand through her hair, ‚ÄúThe responsible thing to do is get rid of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù James says, not knowing if he‚Äôs supposed to be giving feedback at this point but feeling that he needs to at least let her know that he‚Äôs listening.

‚ÄúBut,‚Äù Lily‚Äôs voice cracks, and she looks away, looks up at the ceiling, blinking the moisture from her eyes. ‚ÄúBut I just keep thinking‚Äîkeep thinking,‚Äù she laughs wetly, ‚Äúwhat if they‚Äôre a Quidditch player.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù James says for the second time, the entire contents of his chest lurching.

Eventually Lily brings her gaze back down, eyes still wet. ‚ÄúYou know?‚Äù

He nods, because he does. He does know. And suddenly James feels an overwhelming swell of emotion hit him. For Lily. For the life they have. For the life they could have.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú he starts and then stops, having to clear his throat before he continues. ‚ÄúI want this.‚Äù Lily‚Äôs eyes grow wide. ‚ÄúIf you want this,‚Äù he goes on. ‚ÄúI want this.‚Äù

For a minute she just stares at him, terrified, and then, slowly, she nods. ‚ÄúI want this,‚Äù she whispers, like maybe she thinks she‚Äôs not allowed to. And finally the tears spill down her cheeks and James pulls her in, wrapping her in his arms and feeling her burrow against his chest.

He kisses the top of her head before he laughs. ‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Lily agrees, words slightly muffled. It‚Äôs a few seconds before she speaks again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad it‚Äôs‚Ä¶I‚Äôm glad it‚Äôs with you,‚Äù she says, making James‚Äôs heart flip. He squeezes her a little tighter.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he murmurs into her hair. ‚ÄúYeah I‚Äôm glad it‚Äôs you too.‚Äù

¬†

PART IV SIRIUS

Sirius is whistling when he gets home, carelessly throwing his jacket over the sofa and heading for the kitchen.

‚ÄúHey, you‚Äôre back,‚Äù he smiles at Remus who is sat at the table, some terribly thick and boring looking book in front of him.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù Remus says a little hesitantly, as Sirius brushes past him to the fridge, pulling out a beer and twisting off the cap.

‚ÄúHow was Moody then?‚Äù he asks, leaning back against he counter and taking a drink.

‚ÄúFine. Y‚Äôknow, as pleasant as ever.‚Äù

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúRegular ray of sunshine he is.‚Äù

He can feel Remus looking him over. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in a good mood,‚Äù he says finally.

Sirius‚Äôs grin only widens. ‚ÄúI am. Listen, don‚Äôt freak out, but I‚Äôve bought a motorbike.‚Äù

Remus, much to Sirius‚Äôs surprise, doesn‚Äôt freak out. In fact, he barely reacts at all. Which is when Sirius notices the tension in Remus‚Äôs shoulders, in his face. He feels his smile slip. ‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù

Remus grimaces. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚ÄîI‚Äôm leaving again. For a bit.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs whole body goes stiff. ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù he says, placing his beer down on the counter with more force than is strictly necessary. ‚ÄúWell, I must have done something right, to earn the privilege of being told in person this time.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt bother trying to hide his flinch.

Sirius does the math quickly in his head. ‚ÄúAnother full moon,‚Äù he says.

Remus nods, looking at the floor or the table, but certainly not at Sirius.

‚ÄúWerewolves then,‚Äù the words tasting all wrong in his mouth. ‚ÄúThis‚Äîthis task Dumbledore has given you, this place you disappear to, it has to do with werewolves?‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù Remus says, in a tone that suggests that this is not going to be a fruitful direction for the conversation to go in.

‚ÄúYeah, right, sorry, top secret and all that. Wouldn‚Äôt want to let anything slip,‚Äù he picks up his beer again but finds he doesn‚Äôt want it anymore, chucking it in the sink before dropping into one of the available kitchen chairs, arms crossed over his chest.

The silence seems to stretch on forever but Sirius isn‚Äôt about to be the one to break it. Especially since he‚Äôs not sure he can trust himself to say anything pleasant right now.

‚ÄúAre you‚Äî‚Äú Remus eventually starts and then stops, face screwing itself up in frustration. ‚ÄúAre you going to be‚Ä¶hanging out‚Ä¶with Mary.‚Äù

The question catches Sirius completely off guard, Remus still not looking at him. They haven‚Äôt talked about what happened with Mary. About the kiss. Not that they ever talk about the things they should. Sirius feels a tidal wave of shame rise up in him.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú he clears his throat. He knows what the real question is here. Knows it has nothing to do with hanging out with Mary. ‚ÄúNo. I‚Äôm not‚Äîno.‚Äù He grits his teeth.

He needs to say more. He does. But apologies have always been difficult for him. Difficult when coming from a house where ‚Äúsorry‚Äù was nothing but another way for his mother to humiliate him. To force him to his knees. To make him beg. He‚Äôs never quite managed one without a bad taste being left in his mouth.

Eventually he reaches out, hand wrapping around Remus‚Äôs wrist and tugging, until, rolling his eyes, Remus allows himself to be pulled out of his seat and into Sirius‚Äôs lap. It isn‚Äôt exactly the most comfortable position, but it allows Sirius to burry his face in the crook of Remus‚Äôs neck. To bask in the heat of him. The weight. And like this. Like this it‚Äôs almost bearable.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

Sirius kisses his shoulder right after and he barely tastes the humiliation at all. Remus is silent for a while, but he has his arms wrapped around Sirius and he considers that a win.

‚ÄúI need us to be in this together,‚Äù Remus finally says, voice soft. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs too fucking painful being in it alone.‚Äù

Sirius squeezes his eyes shut for a minute, glad that Remus can‚Äôt see his face, can‚Äôt see the things those words do to him. He bites the crook of Remus‚Äôs neck and is rewarded with a huff.

‚ÄúWe are,‚Äù Sirius says finally. ‚ÄúI promise we are.‚Äù

He feels Remus nod, hair tickling his cheek.

‚ÄúWhen do you have to leave?‚Äù

‚ÄúTomorrow morning.‚Äù

It‚Äôs Sirius‚Äôs turn to nod, and then, in the next second, he‚Äôs getting to his feet and taking Remus with him.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck‚ÄîSirius‚ÄîOh for Merlin‚Äôs‚Äîput me down you lunatic!‚Äù

Sirius has managed to get Remus at least partially over his shoulder. He‚Äôs very limb-y and the task of carrying him isn‚Äôt made any easier by his squirming.

‚ÄúPut me down! Sirius‚Äîyou‚Äôre ridiculous you know that?‚Äù

Somehow Sirius manages to wrangle him into the bedroom, dropping him a little bit clumsily onto the bed, Remus laughing despite himself.

Sirius kisses him then, the way he used to dream about before kissing Remus Lupin was something he was allowed to do. Before it was something he allowed himself to want. He lays himself bare in that kiss, cuts himself open. It is all tenderness and longing. It is all love, love, love. Sirius never seems to be able to speak all the sweet nice words that lovers are supposed to. But he could write sonnets with his lips.

He wants Remus to know.

To understand.

That he never could have kissed Mary like this.

There are hands and teeth and nails. Spit and curses and heavy breathing. And I‚Äôm sorry‚Äôs. And I‚Äôm scared‚Äôs. And don‚Äôt leave‚Äôs. Those are the kisses that last the longest. That hit the hardest. That linger even after they are spent and sweaty and lying in one another‚Äôs arms.

¬†

Sirius wakes up to a dark room and the dreamy feeling of fingers in his hair.

‚ÄúHmm,‚Äù he hums happily, still caught between wakefulness and sleep. ‚ÄúI love when you do that.‚Äù

He can hear the smile in Remus‚Äôs voice. ‚ÄúYeah, I know.‚Äù

Sirius blinks his eyes open, looking up to find Remus sitting on the edge of the bed, fully dressed.

‚ÄúI have to go,‚Äù Remus says regretfully.

Sirius doesn‚Äôt know what his face does, too sleepy to be guarded.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Remus sighs, hand sliding down from Sirius‚Äôs hair to cup his cheek, thumb running along Sirius‚Äôs bottom lip. ‚ÄúI love you.‚Äù

In response Sirius turns his head and kisses Remus‚Äôs palm, eyes already drooping closed despite his best efforts. In the distance he hears Remus‚Äôs quiet laugh.

¬†

The next time Sirius wakes up the flat is empty.

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

Listen, a Jegulus reunion will happen. I promise you. I'm officially calling this fic a reverse slow-burn, like they get together fast, but they come back together slow.

I also just want to say that I am so overwhelmingly touched by the amount of support I received after the last chapter. It means so much, and some of those comments were just so thoughtful, and I promise I'm going to try and respond to them (I thought I would get through my messages on Tumblr first but it turns out that is taking longer than I thought). I also just want to make sure it's clear that criticism of this fic is totally valid so please don't feel like you have to defend it and especially don't, y'know, attack anyone who is offering up their opinion on it it's totally their right to do so and I 100% support that.

Okay, as always thank you all so much for hanging around and reading, and being your lovely selves, I read all the comments (even if I suck at replying) and appreciate them so yeah, hope you're having a great day!

Chapter 49

Chapter Summary

Welcome to Lupercal

Chapter Notes

tw Violence

tw Brief mention of suicide

tw Death (NOT main character, can't stress this enough, don't freak out, Regulus very much does not die in this chapter)

Oh yeah, and this definitely fucks with canon, I'm not sure specifically how, but definitely somewhere canon was fucked

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The sun is barely kissing the horizon as Remus jogs down the street, clutching his canvas duffle bag to his side. It‚Äôs cold this morning, his cheeks rosy, fingers going a little numb. The rusted blue Volkswagen Camper in front of him honks encouragingly as he hears the side door banging open.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre late!‚Äù a voice shouts, echoing in the empty street, scaring the pigeons.

Remus huffs the last few feet to the car, grabbing the roof and swinging himself inside. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm-not-late,‚Äù he manages between breaths, sliding into his seat. Someone else shuts the door. Remus flashes his watch at the driver with a grin. ‚ÄúSee, six AM, on the dot. I‚Äôm very literally on time.‚Äù

The old man rolls his eyes, turning back to face the road. He‚Äôs balding on the top of his head, with a thick auburn beard covering his face. ‚ÄúCheeky,‚Äù he mutters, eyes finding Remus in the rearview mirror, unable to hide his amusement as he pulls away from the curb.

Remus settles, nodding at the other six passengers in the camper. He‚Äôs seen a few of them on his other visits but there‚Äôs at least two of them that are new faces‚Äînew to him anyway. None of them talk, it‚Äôs too early, Remus turning his head towards the window and watching the sky light up as the day slowly creeps in and they leave the city behind. Buildings and cars turn into fields and endless motorways, the early morning sun sparkling against the asphalt.

The first time he‚Äôd come up, he‚Äôd done it on his own. He had to take a train and then a bus, and then walk for about two miles. By the time he saw the sign his feet were killing him.

‚ÄúLooks like you‚Äôre planing to stay a while.‚Äù

It takes Remus a moment to realize Arnold‚Äîthe driver‚Äîis talking to him. He blinks, still half-asleep, looking down at the bag in his lap. After a few seconds he shrugs.

‚ÄúMight be, never know, wanted to‚Ä¶keep my options open I suppose,‚Äù he tries to give the old man a smile that doesn‚Äôt betray any of the feelings swirling around inside of him.

‚ÄúOptions huh?‚Äù Arnold asks, nodding. ‚ÄúWell, I know plenty of the folks up there will be happy to hear that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not promising anything though, so don‚Äôt go gossiping,‚Äù Remus says, only half joking.

Arnold laughs, it‚Äôs a deep noise, coming right from his belly. Like Santa Clause. ‚ÄúNo, you don‚Äôt strike me as the type who makes many promises.‚Äù

Remus chews on the inside of his lip to stop himself from grimacing, turning back towards the window. Little does Arnold know, Remus actually makes promises all the time, he just isn‚Äôt particularly good at keeping them.

On his first visit things went wrong almost immediately. After the two mile walk he came to a painted wooden sign that read ‚ÄúLupercal‚Äù at the top of a dirt road, bordered on either side by thick woods. Somewhere, at the end of this road, there was supposedly an old farm house that Remus was meant to find.

Moody had specifically told him not to make first contact on the full moon, he figured it would be safer, and Remus couldn‚Äôt say that he disagreed. See, Lupercal is the largest group of werewolves all living in one place that the Ministry has ever been aware of. Moody refers to them as the ‚ÄúPack‚Äù but Remus can‚Äôt quite get over the discomfort that leaves him with. It makes it feel too much like they‚Äôre discussing animals.

‚ÄúSandwich?‚Äù

Remus turns to see the man next to him, who‚Äôd been asleep the last time Remus checked, offering him a Tupperware full of what appear to be ham and cheese sandwiches. Remus is going to refuse but he didn‚Äôt have time to eat before he left and even just the mention of food has his stomach grumbling.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù he gives in, reaching out and taking a quarter.

The man smiles. He‚Äôs one of the people Remus doesn‚Äôt recognize. He looks like he might be close to thirty, with freckles speckling his face.

‚ÄúNo problem. I always try to share, y‚Äôknow? Put that energy out into the universe, incase one day I need someone to return the favour.‚Äù

This kind of attitude, Remus has learned, is actually quite common amongst werewolves. He supposes it comes from living such unpredictable lives‚Äîbeing fired or evicted whenever their truth is discovered. Relying heavily on the charity of strangers and friends. There‚Äôs no such thing as stability when you‚Äôre a werewolf. Well, unless you have the good fortune of sitting in a train compartment with James Potter and Sirius Black one day.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre about to pass the last Petrol station for a while you lot,‚Äù Arnold calls back to them. ‚ÄúIf anyone needs a wee speak now.‚Äù

There‚Äôs some laughter, but no requests are made.

‚ÄúGoing once, going twice‚Äî‚Äú they speed past the station in a blur of colour. ‚ÄúGone.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought it was supposed to be ‚Äúsold‚Äù not gone?‚Äù someone from the back heckles.

‚ÄúDo I look like a fucking auctioneer McDavid?‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that a rhetorical question?‚Äù

There‚Äôs more quiet laughter, all of them turning back to their books or naps, or thoughts.

When Remus finally saw the farm house for the first time it was from a distance, down that dirt road, trees still blocking parts of it from view. It had been a sunny afternoon, not a cloud in sight, and while Remus had been nervous his guard had, admittedly, been down somewhat. And that's when he'd heard it.

Growling.

The hair on the back of his neck had stood up even while his brain screamed ‚Äúno, no it‚Äôs not possible‚Äù. And yet, despite everything reason told him, when he turned his head the impossible had been right there.

Two glowing yellow eyes, staring out at him from between the trees.

The shock had paralyzed him, unable to move, to think, to grab his wand, as he stared into the face of a werewolf. A fully transformed werewolf. In the middle of the day. Weeks away from the full moon. Remus simply couldn‚Äôt process a single part of that. And then, a second later, he felt claws and teeth sinking into his skin.

The wolf threw them into the trees on the other side of the road, branches and bushes whipping against Remus‚Äôs back with such force they shredded his shirt. He had wondered, in a very detached way, if there was some sort of poetic irony in him dying at the hands of a werewolf.

He isn‚Äôt sure how long it went on for, the wolf tearing him apart, Remus trying and failing to fight back. But eventually he heard a voice. Shouting somewhere in the distance. And then a howl. The wolf stopped, leaving Remus just floating there in the darkness, barely conscious. Eventually the weight on top of him disappeared, and the last thing he remembers before he slipped away completely, is the feel of a wet nose pressing against his cheek.

He was unconscious for three days after that.

‚ÄúHere we are,‚Äù Arnold says as he turns down that same dirt road, past the sign and through the trees.

Remus generally rather likes this drive. It‚Äôs scenic. Calming. This bit though, right at the end, still makes his stomach drop. Phantom claws prickling his skin.

The main building at Lupercal is a large, ancient looking farm house. Wide, two stories tall, made of grey stone with rows of windows and a thatched roof. The lawn in front is luscious and green, some of the kids running around.

‚ÄúAlright, get gone you lot, I have a busy schedule,‚Äù Arnold says as he parks the camper at the end of the drive.

‚ÄúThanks Arnold,‚Äù Remus says as he slides out of the car.

‚ÄúSee you soon Lupin, or maybe not so soon huh?‚Äù Remus sends him a look that has Arnold holding his hands up in surrender. ‚ÄúI know, I know, no promises,‚Äù he winks.

Remus adjusts the strap of his bag over his shoulder, the other travellers breaking off, some heading up towards the main house, others off towards the barn that‚Äôs also been converted into a living space. Remus has only just looked up when the front door flies open and a beaming face looks right at him.

‚ÄúRemus!‚Äù the boy shouts, jogging down the front lawn towards him and pulling him into a hug without a second thought.

‚ÄúOof,‚Äù it takes him a minute, but eventually Remus hugs him back. ‚ÄúHey Gabe.‚Äù

The other boy pulls away but keeps his hands on Remus‚Äôs shoulders. ‚ÄúYou came.‚Äù

Moody hadn‚Äôt exactly given him much of a choice on the matter. But the truth is, even if he had had a choice, Remus probably still would have come. He thinks of Sirius back in their flat, alone in their bed, and barely suppresses a wince.

‚ÄúI told you I would,‚Äù he says finally.

Gabe grins. ‚ÄúYou did.‚Äù

Gabe is the opposite of Remus in every way, at least physically. He‚Äôs shorter, muscular, with brown skin and a shaved head, tattoos snaking up his arms.

‚ÄúWhere the hell are your clothes Gabe?‚Äù Remus asks, as the pair heads towards the house.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure I‚Äôm dressed.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have any sleeves.‚Äù

‚ÄúObservant of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs October.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd he knows the date, gosh you are very impressive Remus Lupin. You really are.‚Äù

Remus sighs. He‚Äôs not sure what he did to piss the universe off so much that it decided to fill his life with nothing but sarcastic bastards, but he is more than willing to perform some sort of ritual sacrifice to make it end.

‚ÄúWell look who it is!‚Äù A girl with strawberry blonde hair comes around the corner, in ripped jeans and a Muggle band shirt. She hugs him too. Everyone here is very hug-y. Remus does his best to be accommodating.

‚ÄúHey Ava,‚Äù he says, when she pulls away.

‚ÄúI see this one‚Äôs already allover you,‚Äù she rubs the top of Gabe‚Äôs head.

‚ÄúOh fuck off,‚Äù Gabe pinches her side and she laughs, the three of them walking up the front steps and into the house.

The inside is warm, there‚Äôs no other way to describe it. Walls covered in finger paintings and photos‚ÄîMuggle photos‚Äîall of the furniture well loved. The sound of singing drifts towards them from the kitchen.

‚ÄúOi mum,‚Äù Gabe says as they walk towards the noise. ‚ÄúThe city slickers are here.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes. Having grown up where he did he‚Äôll never be able to think of himself as a Londoner, but then, he‚Äôs not about to tell Gabe that.

Mia is standing in the kitchen by the sink, a small girl in her arms. Well, Remus says small. She must be five or six, too old, he would have thought, to be held the way she is. Remus runs through all the kids he met last time but he can‚Äôt place her.

‚ÄúAh Remus, lovely to see you again,‚Äù Mia says with a smile, attention quickly hopping back to Gabe. ‚ÄúCan I get you to run to the barn and bring this to Harper? She‚Äôs still not feeling well,‚Äù she gestures to the covered dishes on the counter.

‚ÄúYeah, ‚Äòcourse,‚Äù Gabe squeezes Remus‚Äôs arm as he goes by, grabbing, what Remus can only assume is food, and heading out the back door towards the barn.

‚ÄúPut your bag down Remus, take a seat, take a seat, do you want tea?‚Äù Mia asks, blowing a strand of brown hair from her face, still bouncing the little girl on her hip.

‚ÄúUh, sure I‚Äî‚Äú

A shriek sounds from the front room, followed by loud whining; ‚ÄúWilliam that‚Äôs mineeee!‚Äù

Mia rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúAva do you mind‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOn it chief,‚Äù she gives Mia a two fingered salute before sending Remus a look, like he‚Äôs in on some sort of joke. Like she‚Äôs known him for years and not months.

‚ÄúSit, sit,‚Äù Mia says again. ‚ÄúTea, yes?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr,‚Äù he laughs a little, dropping his bag on the ground and taking a seat at the rickety wooden table that looks like it‚Äôs half covered in various art projects. ‚ÄúYeah‚Äîyes, please. Tea would be great, thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúLovely, do you mind holding Charlotte while I get it?‚Äù she asks while simultaneously transferring the little girl into Remus‚Äôs somewhat hesitant arms. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs nervous about being on her own at the moment,‚Äù Mia says as she sets the kettle on the stove.

The little girl doesn‚Äôt even bat an eye at being handed off to a stranger, instantly hiding her face in Remus‚Äôs shoulder. She‚Äôs heavy and warm and soft and he‚Äôs almost positive he is not responsible enough to be holding her.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôve you been then?‚Äù Mia asks, pulling a pair of mugs from the cupboard. One of them appears to be in the shape of a panda head.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been, y‚Äôknow, I‚Äôve been fine.‚Äù There's only so much he can tell. It's not that he hasn't said anything about himself, I mean, they know his name. Know who his father is. But they don‚Äôt know that he was sent here by Alastor Moody. That he‚Äôs meant to report back; what they‚Äôre doing and thinking and saying. Who they‚Äôre talking to. If they‚Äôve had any contact with Death Eaters. As far as anyone at Lupercal is aware, Remus heard a rumour about this place and decided to check it out for himself.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt sound fine,‚Äù Mia shoots him a knowing look over her shoulder. ‚ÄúYou sound miserable.‚Äù

He can‚Äôt help but laugh. She‚Äôs not wrong. Not exactly. The little girl in his arms squirms.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre too young to be miserable Remus,‚Äù she leans back against the counter, waiting for the water to finish boiling. ‚ÄúYou oughta be having fun.‚Äù

He smiles grimly back at her. ‚ÄúBit hard‚Ä¶under the circumstances.‚Äù

‚ÄúHmm,‚Äù she says, unconvinced. ‚ÄúBut are you even trying?‚Äù

Remus blinks, opening and then closing his mouth. All things considered, it‚Äôs an entirely unfair question. It‚Äôs not as though he can just decide to stop the war. But, I mean, is he trying to be anything but miserable? No, not really. He‚Äôs mostly just, accepted it‚Ä¶seems like the easiest option.

Luckily he‚Äôs saved from having to answer by the screaming of the kettle. ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Mia says, turning to lift it off the heat, ‚Äúhold that thought.‚Äù

The girl in Remus‚Äôs arms makes an unhappy noise, the first noise, in fact, that he‚Äôs heard her make this whole time. Wriggling again, adjusting herself on his lap. He looks down at her and feels his whole body go cold.

In her adjusting her shirt has slipped slightly down her shoulder. And there, brazen against her skin, is a large, angry bite mark. It‚Äôs healed but not scarred yet. Meaning it can‚Äôt be more than a few days old. Remus can‚Äôt look away, he wants to, desperately, but he just‚Ä¶he thinks he might be shaking.

A little boy sleeping in his bedroom.

Claws scraping on hardwood floors.

Teeth and Teeth and Teeth.

‚ÄúRemus? Remus?‚Äù

He blinks, finally forcing himself to look up, finding Mia at the table, tea forgotten, the expression on her face telling him this isn‚Äôt the first time she‚Äôs said his name. He opens his mouth to try to explain but finds that he can‚Äôt.

She doesn‚Äôt seem to need him to. ‚ÄúAva?‚Äù she calls out.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù comes her voice from down the hall.

‚ÄúCan you come take Charlotte for a minute please?‚Äù she never takes her eye off of Remus. He can hear the sound of Ava‚Äôs footsteps on the old floorboards.

‚ÄúOf course I can,‚Äù she says as she slips into the room. Remus sees the moment she registers something is wrong, eyes bouncing between him and Mia. He‚Äôs worried she‚Äôs going to ask for an explanation but instead she just puts on her little kid voice; ‚ÄúOkay darling, you‚Äôre coming with me, lets go wrangle those big kids huh?‚Äù she takes her easily from Remus‚Äôs arms, which barely even seem to be working at the moment.

He watches Mia nod to her, listens to the footsteps again, this time disappearing into the distance. And then Mia is sitting in front of him, her face level with Remus‚Äôs.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù he chokes out.

A sad smile pulls at her mouth. ‚ÄúOh honey, you are the farthest thing from okay.‚Äù

Remus isn‚Äôt sure he thinks that‚Äôs fair but he lets it slide. ‚ÄúShe wasn‚Äôt here the last time I was,‚Äù he finally manages, unsure if it‚Äôs even what he means to say.

There are a few seconds of stillness before Mia nods. ‚ÄúNo, she wasn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs chest feels tight. ‚ÄúGreyback?‚Äù

‚ÄúOr one of his supporters.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt think he hides his disgust. Or his fear. He‚Äôd been surprised by the number of kids here the last time he visited. He‚Äôd always thought that he was a bit of an anomaly, targeted because of his father‚Äôs work. He hadn‚Äôt realized that Greyback had made it his mission to turn as many children as he could get his hands on.

‚ÄúHer parents?‚Äù

Mia sighs, ‚ÄúSame old story, they don‚Äôt know what to do with her, don‚Äôt know how to handle it. They‚Äôre afraid.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre afraid?‚Äù Remus demands. ‚ÄúHow do they think she feels?‚Äù

She offers him a sad smile. ‚ÄúI expect they try very hard not to think about it.‚Äù

Gabe was the first kid Mia ever took in. Remus found that out last time. After she‚Äôd been turned Mia lived out here on her own, something of a hermit. Until one day she got an owl from an old friend working at St Mungos. It said a little boy had been left, abandoned actually, at the hospital‚Äôs front door. A werewolf bite on his stomach.

‚ÄúSo when you say she‚Äôs nervous‚Ä¶‚Äù Remus pushes, staring down the hall like he can still see Charlotte.

‚ÄúShe was attacked playing alone in her back garden, she starts panicking if you put her down for too long, poor thing. Thinks something is coming to get her.‚Äù

After Gabe, Mia told the friend to let her know anytime someone came in with a bite or symptoms. She wanted to help. To offer people like her a safe place, if they needed it. She had been just as surprised as Remus to discover so many of those people were children.

‚ÄúWill they come back?‚Äù Remus asks finally, after a long pause. ‚ÄúHer parents?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey might, they do sometimes, once they‚Äôve adjusted, wrapped their minds around it. Mourned the life they thought they would have.‚Äù

Remus can‚Äôt help but think of his own parents. Can‚Äôt help but be grateful for them. For all of Lyall Lupin‚Äôs faults, he hadn‚Äôt left his son on the hospital‚Äôs doorstep, and Remus supposes that counts for something.

‚ÄúSometimes they come back,‚Äù Mia goes on when Remus doesn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúBut sometimes‚Ä¶‚Äù

Gabe comes bounding through the back door, cheeks flushed from the run over to the barn, smile on his face as it almost always is. ‚ÄúOoh tea,‚Äù he says, reaching for one of the abandoned mugs on the counter. ‚ÄúBrilliant.‚Äù

¬†

Remus has the same bedroom he did last time, in the loft of the barn. It‚Äôs small, with a single bed and plain wooden dresser. The roof is slanted so he has to duck down in some spots, and there‚Äôs a circular window on the outside wall. There are several rooms like this at Lupercal, for people like him, who come only around the full moon, so that they can have a safe place to transform, away from their towns and cities. It‚Äôs far better than being locked in a cell at the Ministry. Or at least that‚Äôs what Remus has been told, he himself has been spared that particular indignity.

That‚Äôs where Arnold comes in. Driving the shuttle around to the areas surrounding Lupercal and picking up anyone who wants to come. Last time, Remus‚Äôs first time meeting Arnold, he‚Äôd asked him why he did it. It takes at least two or three days to pick up everyone, a rather monotonous task, and it‚Äôs not as though he‚Äôs getting paid. It had taken Arnold a while to answer, before finally he‚Äôd simply said: ‚ÄúSometimes all you need is one person to show up. To be there. Even if it‚Äôs just the man driving the camper van.‚Äù

Remus wanted to know more about Arnold. About how he‚Äôd met Mia, how he‚Äôd ended up living here, how he was bitten in the first place. But he refrained. Moody had warned him about coming on too strong. Not that he was as concerned with collecting information as he was with satisfying his own curiosity. He‚Äôd never seen another werewolf in real life before, well, besides Greyback. Not until the day he‚Äôd turned his head and found those glowing yellow eyes staring at him between the trees.

Suffice to say, on his first visit, he hadn‚Äôt had the chance to ask many questions. Nor had he had his own bedroom. He‚Äôd woken up in Mia‚Äôs bed. Disoriented and frightened and in nearly unbearable pain. He had never before been forced to endure injury without magic. Never had to let a wound heal on its own or a bone mend the slow way that Muggles do. Never had to feel any of it for longer than it took to unstopper a pain potion. But he had learned quickly that magic is not common at Lupercal.

There‚Äôs a knock on the door.

‚ÄúYou decent?‚Äù Gabe calls through, causing Remus to snort.

‚ÄúWhat exactly would I be doing right now that would make me indecent?‚Äù

The other boy shrugs as he slides into the room, hands in his pockets. ‚ÄúNever know, better not to assume though ‚Äòinnit?‚Äù

‚ÄúVery considerate of you.‚Äù

Gabe‚Äôs smile hangs recklessly in his mouth. ‚ÄúI do my best.‚Äù He reminds Remus of Sirius and he doesn‚Äôt at the same time. Because the truth is, no one is Sirius Black. No one comes close. But there are moments, moments when he almost feels like the universe is teasing him.

‚ÄúHello? Earth to Remus?‚Äù Gabe waves his hand in front of Remus‚Äôs face, snapping him awake.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Remus blinks, rubbing at his eyes, ‚Äúlong day. What did you say?‚Äù

Gabe gives him a funny look but doesn‚Äôt pry. ‚ÄúDinner‚Äôs ready, c‚Äômon, chop chop.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Remus gives him a slight smile as he gets off the bed.

At Lupercal everyone always eats dinner together. Mia‚Äôs rules. ‚ÄúLike a family‚Äù Remus had remarked last time, causing her to correct him. ‚ÄúNot like. We are a family.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Gabe says as they make their way across the lawn, sun dripping low over their heads, making the sky a milky orange and pink colour. It really is beautiful out here. ‚ÄúI noticed you brought a bigger bag this time.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs stomach clenches. When he thinks hard enough he can still feel the soft warmth of Sirius in their bed. ‚ÄúI did.‚Äù

Gabe just nods for a minute, and Remus wonders if he‚Äôll let it drop. ‚ÄúYou staying then? Longer I mean?‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt know how to answer that question. Moody would certainly like him to. Perhaps more frightening, is that part of Remus would too. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶thinking about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù there‚Äôs another pause and then. ‚ÄúBut theoretically, if you were going to stay longer, how long would longer be?‚Äù

Remus sighs. ‚ÄúYou just want me to stay because you‚Äôre bored.‚Äù

Gabe blows out his lips like a horse. ‚ÄúPlease. Me? Bored? How could I be bored when I have the drama that is Ava and Liam to keep me entertained?‚Äù

Remus can‚Äôt help but laugh. ‚ÄúHave they finally admitted they‚Äôre madly in love with each other?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh no, no, no, no, it‚Äôs much better,‚Äù Gabe says with a grin. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre pretending they‚Äôre just really, really good friends.‚Äù

Remus groans.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty good shit Remus, watching them try to explain to themselves why they‚Äôre making heart eyes at their platonic buddy. Sometimes I catch them trying to look at me the same way just to make themselves feel better.‚Äù

Remus scrunches his nose. ‚ÄúGross.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hilarious.‚Äù He sways a little closer to Remus, shoulders knocking. ‚ÄúSo you see, I don‚Äôt just want you here because I‚Äôm bored.‚Äù

Their eyes meet and then flick away.

Teasing.

The main house is bustling when they get there, clearly some of the last to arrive. They walk in through the back door and right into the chaos of the kitchen.

‚ÄúExcuse meee!‚Äù Ava sings as she swerves around them, carrying plates into the living room where the sound of voices and music drifts through the walls.

‚ÄúAh good, you two are here,‚Äù Mia says from where she‚Äôs stood, stirring something at the stove, Charlotte back in her arms. Remus finds he can‚Äôt look at the little girl. ‚ÄúGabe can you grab the casserole dish off the counter‚Äîcareful it‚Äôs hot, use the mittens you muppet! And Remus, darling, if you wouldn‚Äôt mind taking in the cutlery?‚Äù she nods over her shoulder to the piles of forks and knives.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù he says at the same time Gabe moves for the casserole‚Äîmitts on his hands. They head for the living room and nearly run straight into the gawky teenager coming in the opposite direction. The kid‚Äôs eyes go wide at the sight of Remus and then quickly drop to the floor.

‚ÄúHey Jack,‚Äù Gabe says easily. Jack hasn‚Äôt grown into himself yet, thin and clearly uncomfortable with his height, always stooping over, shaggy brown hair hanging in his eyes, hiding him. He‚Äôs quiet, at least around Remus.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú he starts and then stops. ‚ÄúI just‚ÄîI‚Äôm gonna‚Äîyeah.‚Äù He turns away, apparently no longer interested in whatever it was he was going to get from the kitchen.

Remus sighs. He knows he should say something to Jack, he‚Äôs just never sure what.

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù Gabe asks, concern in his eyes.

Remus nods, watching Jack sink down into his seat at the dinning room table, looking very much like someone who wants to disappear.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs afraid of me,‚Äù Remus says finally.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not afraid of you, he‚Äôs‚Ä¶he just feels guilty that‚Äôs all. It‚Äôs hard for him, getting over what happened.‚Äù

Remus sees flashes‚Äîthe Shack, Snape, James, blood. Hot and pungent and sweet on his tongue.

He knows a thing or two about guilt.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù Gabe nudges Remus with his shoulder. ‚ÄúLets get the table set yeah? I‚Äôm starving.‚Äù

The dining room is filled with a long wooden table and a plethora of candles dripping wax. The walls are covered in homemade artwork like everywhere else in the house, though in here it‚Äôs mostly done on canvases and not just scraps of paper. In the bottom corners the kids have signed their names.

When he finishes doling out the cutlery Remus heads to the end of the table where Ava, Gabe and Liam appear to be having a heated discussion. Well, Ava and Gabe anyway, Liam is mostly just spectating. He smiles and nods when Remus sits down.

‚ÄúGood to see again,‚Äù he says. Liam has short blond hair, shaved on the sides and left slightly longer on top. His eyes are big and brown. He‚Äôs slightly older than Remus‚Äîtwenty-two or twenty-three, somewhere around there.

‚ÄúGood to see you too.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt even believe you‚Äôre making this argument right now,‚Äù Ava throws her arms up in exasperation.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not my fault you read the book wrong.‚Äù

‚ÄúRead the‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt read the book wrong! You CAN‚ÄôT read a book wrong!‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean clearly you can.‚Äù

Remus leans towards Liam, keeping his voice low in an attempt to avoid being dragged into this. ‚ÄúWhat are they arguing about?‚Äù

Liam smirks. ‚ÄúYou ever heard of Little Women?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre friends!‚Äù

‚ÄúThey are not friends! That‚Äôs not how you act with your friends. It‚Äôs not my fault that I‚Äôm heartbroken when she wrote them like THAT.‚Äù

Gabe rolls his eyes, drinking from his wine glass before answering back. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just as bad as Laurie is.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt bad! It was a fair assumption!"

Gabe snorts. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just walk around assuming people are going to fall in love with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can when they act like they‚Äôre in love with you!‚Äù Ava looks about ready to start pulling her hair out.

‚ÄúNo really,‚Äù Remus whispers, ‚Äúwhat the hell are they talking about?‚Äù

Liam only smiles and waves his hand. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll lend you a copy. You‚Äôll like it.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe acted like his friend.‚Äù

‚ÄúBullshit, you and I don‚Äôt act like that.‚Äù

For the briefest of moments Gabe makes eye contact with Remus, mischief hiding just in the corner of his mouth, it‚Äôs an expression Remus has seen a dozen times before on another boy‚Äôs face. It says, look at me, I‚Äôm so clever, look what I just did. Remus doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs coming but he already feels sorry for Ava.

‚ÄúYou and Liam do,‚Äù Gabe fires back.

‚ÄúExactly!‚Äù the word is barely out of her mouth before she freezes. ‚ÄúOr‚Äîer‚Äî‚Äù her cheeks flush, the colour spreading all the way up her neck.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Gabe prods innocently. ‚ÄúExactly what?‚Äù

Remus kicks him under the table but that only makes his grin wider. Liam has suddenly become very interested in his napkin.

It‚Äôs clear that Ava‚Äôs aware she‚Äôs been tricked, giving Gabe a flat stare. ‚ÄúOh fuck off.‚Äù

But Gabe is far too pleased with himself. ‚ÄúNo really, I want to know. Because wouldn‚Äôt that prove my point? I mean unless there‚Äôs something more than friendship between you and Liam?‚Äú

‚ÄúFuck off Gabe. I mean it,‚Äù Remus sees her shoot Liam a worried glance, the boy in question still looking at the table.

‚ÄúOi, Ava, watch the language around the kids, you know better than that,‚Äù Mia says as she comes into the room with the last of the dinner, taking her place at the head of the table, causing all other conversation to die out as everyone turns to her. ‚ÄúWell go on,‚Äù she smiles, gesturing to the various dishes. ‚ÄúDig in everyone!‚Äù

¬†

The dinner is good, all hearty homemade food, the kind Remus hasn‚Äôt had since the Potters died. It wasn‚Äôt until he came here that he realized how much he missed it, Sunday dinners at James‚Äôs house. There was hole left in Remus by his mother‚Äôs death and his father‚Äôs absence that Euphemia and Fleamont filled so quickly, and so willingly, that it took losing them for Remus to realize that it was even there.

Ava and Gabe are back to laughing and joking with each other in seconds, Liam chiming in here and there, though the colour hasn‚Äôt quite left his cheeks, and Remus doesn‚Äôt miss the way his eyes linger on Ava a little longer than everyone else. After the dishes are cleared away and the younger kids escorted to bed, new bottles of wine opened, the conversation starts to get serious.

‚ÄúBut if it passes,‚Äù Ben is saying, when Remus starts listening to the adults, ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the plan? We won‚Äôt be able to stay here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt pass, ‚Äú Alexandra, a woman with jet black hair and intense eyes says from across the table. She sits at Mia‚Äôs side. The two of them are close, though Remus hasn‚Äôt quite been able to figure out to what extent.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just decide that,‚Äù Ben rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúWe need to prepare for that possibility‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing to prepare for,‚Äù Alexandra snaps back. ‚ÄúIf it passes we‚Äôre fucked. So it can‚Äôt pass. That‚Äôs what we need to focus on.‚Äù

Ben shakes his head, sitting back in his chair. ‚ÄúMia, c‚Äômon, we need to be practical.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt talk to her like I‚Äôm not here!‚Äù

‚ÄúOh no, I‚Äôm well aware you‚Äôre here.‚Äù

‚ÄúEnough,‚Äù Mia waves her hand like a white flag between them. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre bickering worse than the kids.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù everyone turns towards Remus who does his best not to buckle under the attention. ‚ÄúBut what are you talking about? What can‚Äôt pass?‚Äù

The room goes strangely quiet for a moment, everyone looking away, avoiding eye contact with him, except for Mia. Mia doesn‚Äôt even flinch.

‚ÄúHave you spoken with your father recently, about his work?‚Äù she asks calmly, without judgement.

Remus feels himself fidget. ‚ÄúNo I‚Äîno.‚Äù He hasn‚Äôt spoken to his father at all, about his work or otherwise. The last time he heard from him was on his birthday, he received a store bought card via owl. Remus wrote back a very polite thank you note. That was the entirety of their communication for the year.

Ben blows out a breath, earning him a glare from both Alexandra and Gabe, but Remus is mostly just focused on Mia.

‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù he asks eventually, throat tight. ‚ÄúWhat is he‚Äîwhat is he doing?‚Äù

There is nothing but kindness in Mia‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been trying, for the past few years, to pass a new law that would prohibit werewolves from gathering in groups larger than two.‚Äù

‚ÄúPrick,‚Äù Ava mutters under her breath before her eyes go wide. ‚ÄúShit, sorry Rem‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù he cuts her off, struggling a bit around the lump in his throat. ‚ÄúHe‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt realize he was still‚Äî‚Äú he tries to swallow but it‚Äôs difficult. He doesn‚Äôt know what to say. I mean he knew, of course, that his father‚Äôs views of werewolves had never really changed, and yet to hear that he was still campaigning against them‚Ä¶

It isn‚Äôt personal, Remus tries to tell himself. It isn‚Äôt about you.

Surprisingly that doesn‚Äôt help.

‚ÄúYou think you can stop him?‚Äù Remus manages to ask after a few minutes.

Mia tilts her head from side to side. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre certainly trying, we‚Äôve managed to delay him so far, but he‚Äôs gaining support. There was a piece about it in the Prophet, portrayed the law in a very positive light.‚Äù

‚ÄúFucking Prophet,‚Äù Alexandra mutters, twirling her wine glass between her fingers and staring mutinously at the table. ‚ÄúI swear to god one of these days I‚Äôm gonna burn that place to the ground.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh yeah, cause that‚Äôll really prove them wrong about us,‚Äù Ben says dryly.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to prove anything to them.‚Äù

Ben rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúHow nice for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúEnough you two, honestly,‚Äù Mia pinches the bridge of her nose.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been looking into old caselaw,‚Äù Liam interjects, getting Remus‚Äôs attention. ‚ÄúTrying to see if there‚Äôs precedent for a dismissal or anything else that might help us argue against him. We‚Äôll never win this fight based on emotion or public opinion, but maybe if we have the law on our side‚Ä¶‚Äù he trails off, shrugging.

‚ÄúI want to help,‚Äù Remus looks from Liam to Mia. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI‚Äôm good at this sort of stuff, research. I want to help.‚Äù This is exactly the opposite of what Moody wants him to be doing here, but Remus doesn‚Äôt care.

There‚Äôs something like pride in Mia‚Äôs eyes that makes Remus feel all warm inside. It‚Äôs been a while since he‚Äôs had that kind of approval directed at him.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she says eventually. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure Liam will be able to find some use for you, won‚Äôt you Liam?‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù the older boy grins, so does Gabe.

Moody read Remus the riot act before he left this time, about keeping his distance, about not getting attached. Or involved. But Moody doesn‚Äôt understand. Doesn‚Äôt understand that Remus‚Äôs whole life the only other werwolf he‚Äôd known had been a monster. And for the first time he has people around him who make it easier not to hate himself. Not to feel ashamed. He can‚Äôt just stand back and watch his father destroy that. He won‚Äôt.

He helps clean up the remaining dishes, eventually finding himself at the sink, washing and drying while everyone else heads off to bed, or to check on the kids.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to do that y‚Äôknow,‚Äù Mia comes up behind him, sliding the last few plates into the sink.

Remus shrugs. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind. I like having something to do.‚Äù Besides, his mind is spinning too much at the moment to go back to the quiet of his bedroom.

She leans against the counter, watching him for a minute. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she says eventually, ‚Äúask me then.‚Äù

Remus has no idea how she can tell, how she knows that he‚Äôs had a question gnawing at him, begging to be said. He keeps his eyes on the dishes in the sink.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs my dad,‚Äù he says eventually, causing Mia to nod, arms crossed over her chest.

‚ÄúHe is.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo why not‚Äîwhy haven‚Äôt you asked me to go to him? To plead your case?‚Äù The way they were talking it‚Äôs clear this isn‚Äôt a new problem, Remus doesn‚Äôt know how it wasn‚Äôt the first thing they asked him, the minute they heard his name.

Mia‚Äôs eyes soften, her answer taking its time. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs because he‚Äôs your dad,‚Äù she says eventually, ‚Äúthat it wouldn‚Äôt be a fair thing to ask of you.‚Äù

That answer surprises Remus. He picks up a plate and starts scrubbing, just to give himself something to do, time to think of a response. He can‚Äôt help but wonder if Dumbledore would have felt the same in her position. He doesn‚Äôt think so. He‚Äôs never known Dumbledore to waste an advantage.

‚ÄúYou barely know me,‚Äù he says finally, voice soft. ‚ÄúSurely getting this stopped matters more to you than my‚Ä¶‚Äù he‚Äôs not even sure what the word he‚Äôs looking for is. ‚ÄúThen being fair to me.‚Äù

Mia reaches out and squeezes his arm, something about her touch reminding him painfully of his mother, his hands freeze in the lukewarm water in front of him. ‚ÄúYou and your father aren‚Äôt close I take it?‚Äù she asks softly, instead of answering his question.

Remus lets out a shaky breath, bracing himself against the counter. ‚ÄúNo, not really, no. As you can tell he‚Äôs not exactly a fan of‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWerewolves?‚Äù

He only nods. Feeling embarrassed by the word the same way he always does.

‚ÄúThat must have been very hard, when you were growing up?‚Äù

Remus shrugs. ‚ÄúI had my mum.‚Äù And my brothers.

‚ÄúHad?‚Äù

His grip on the counter tightens, eyes on the dirty dish water. ‚ÄúShe died when I was in school,‚Äù and then, for no reason that he can understand, maybe because of the wine, he keeps going; ‚ÄúActually she killed herself. So,‚Äù he swallows with difficulty, ‚Äúyeah.‚Äù

Mia squeezes his arm again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry Remus.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt usually talk about his mum, doesn‚Äôt need to, everyone in his life was there. They saw it. Sometimes he feels guilty though, about the way his life has moved on, about the days when she doesn‚Äôt cross his mind. Every once and a while he‚Äôll smell something or hear something and it‚Äôll remind him of her and he won‚Äôt be able to remember the last time he thought about her. The last time he spoke her name out loud. He wonders if anyone does‚Äîtalk about her, that is. Or if they‚Äôve all let her down. Let her fade away.

Remus pulls back, rubbing at his eyes, trying to get the sting out of them. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think she really minded that much, that I was‚Ä¶a werewolf. But she was a Muggle so maybe that‚Äôs why, I don‚Äôt know. It bothered her more to see me in pain. To think about the future my dad told her I would have. She just‚Ä¶didn‚Äôt want me to be alone, you know?‚Äù Ironic, since that is apparently exactly what his father is trying to ensure.

‚ÄúAnd are you?‚Äù Mia asks finally. ‚ÄúAlone?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú god it must be the wine, his voice cracking as he goes to rub his eyes again, trying to force the tears back. He doesn‚Äôt even know why they‚Äôre there. Alone wouldn‚Äôt be the right word. More like he feels‚Ä¶anchor less. He didn‚Äôt realize how much Hogwarts was keeping them all together until they left, and now it‚Äôs as though none of them can find each other. None of them have a port. And he‚Äôs stuck watching everyone he loves drift further and further away from him.

His breath hitches and a second later Mia is pulling him into a hug. She‚Äôs shorter than him, so he has to stoop slightly, yet somehow she still manages to make it feel like she‚Äôs gathered all of him in her arms. That she will hold him together and keep him safe. And Remus isn‚Äôt crying, really he isn‚Äôt, he‚Äôs too old for that honestly. To break down so easily and in front of a stranger. But he is having a little trouble breathing.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to know you well to care about you Remus,‚Äù Mia says softly. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been so brave my darling. But you‚Äôre safe here. You‚Äôre wanted.‚Äù

Remus hiccups, holding onto her a little tighter. The shocking truth, he realizes then, is that he might actually believe her.

¬†

When he was last here he started helping Mia with teaching the little kids. To read, and write, to do their maths, but more than anything, Mia needed his help to teach them about magic. Most people at Lupercal are uncomfortable with magic. Gabe, Ava, and Liam, never went to Hogwarts at all, which shocked Remus when they told him, though in retrospect it shouldn‚Äôt have. They‚Äôre all around the same age, if they had been there Remus would have seen them.

Their discomfort with magic goes beyond lack of skill though. They feel rejected by the Wizarding world, so they, in turn, have chosen to reject it right back. It‚Äôs not as though they could get work as Wizards, most of the older wolves had basically been living as Muggles before they came to Lupercal, many of them don‚Äôt even have their wands anymore, and haven‚Äôt cast anything in years. But Mia still thinks it‚Äôs important for the little kids to know that part of themselves. To decide whether they want to embrace it or not.

‚ÄúDo it again!‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, that was like, totally awesome.‚Äù

Oliver and William both stare up at him, wands held awkwardly in their own hands. Neither of them are comfortable with them, they act like Muggles more than children who have grown up in the Wizarding world.

Remus bites back a smile. ‚ÄúYeah alright, once more, but then you two need to start doing it yourselves okay?‚Äù they nod enthusiastically.

‚ÄúWingardium,‚Äù Remus annunciates and moves his wand more obviously than he normally would, ‚ÄúLeviosa.‚Äù He points at William who is instantly lifted off his feet, laughing and flapping his arms around like a bird.

‚ÄúBrilliant,‚Äù Oliver says, jumping up and slapping his friend‚Äôs toes with the tips of his fingers. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs so‚ÄîI wanna fly. Do me next!‚Äù he‚Äôs practically bouncing up and down as Remus lowers William back to the floor. The kid is grinning from ear to ear, stumbling slightly as he gets his balance again.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve already done you,‚Äù Remus says. ‚ÄúNow, it‚Äôs your turn,‚Äù he points at the apples on the table in front of them. ‚ÄúRemember everything we talked about, clean wand movements and exact pronunciation, okay? No dragging out your ‚Äúa‚Äù or over pronouncing your ‚Äúg‚Äù got it?‚Äù

The boys grumble but nod, reluctantly turning to their apples. Remus adjusts their arms, their grips on their wands.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like holding a sword!‚Äù William pipes up, causing his best friend to roll his eyes.

‚ÄúOh like you‚Äôve ever held a sword.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have done!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?! When?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOi, boys,‚Äù Remus interrupts, feeling remarkably like he‚Äôs back in his dorm room at Hogwarts, trying to get James and Sirius to do their coursework. ‚ÄúLets focus shall we? Go on, try again.‚Äù

And they do. Remus having to correct their pronunciation and wand movements a few more times before‚Äî

‚ÄúI DID IT!‚Äù William is jumping up and down, causing his apple which had, in fact, risen several centimetres off the surface of the table, to come crashing back down, rolling onto the floor. ‚ÄúI did it! I did it! I did it!‚Äù

‚ÄúNo fair!‚Äù Oliver turns very crossly back to his own apple. ‚ÄúWingardium‚Äîbloody‚ÄîLeviosa,‚Äù he flicks his wand so hard it actually shoots out of his hand. ‚ÄúThis is stupid.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey, hey,‚Äù Remus says softly, coming to crouch beside him so that they‚Äôre closer to eye level. The younger boy has his arms crossed over his chest and is glaring at the place where his wand landed.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do it,‚Äù he says eventually, sounding just as sad as he does angry.

‚ÄúYeah you can, of course you can,‚Äù Remus reaches out, picking up the fallen wand. ‚ÄúThings take time Oliver, learning new things is hard. You can‚Äôt expect yourself to be perfect right away.‚Äù

The boy makes a grumpy ‚Äúhrmph‚Äù noise that Remus takes as an expression of skepticism. ‚ÄúHere‚ÄîWilliam, I‚Äôm gonna get you to cast the spell again in a second okay?‚Äù

William nods, looking nervously at his friend, clearly not pleased that he‚Äôs made him upset.

‚ÄúOliver, you know that thing you do, where you mimic everything Amelia does and annoy the heck out of her?‚Äù

A small smile picks up the corner of his mouth. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says, unable to stop himself from sounding pleased.

‚ÄúWell I want you to do that with William okay? Don‚Äôt even think about the spell or casting or anything, just mimic everything he does the same way you do with Amelia. D‚Äôyou think you can do that?‚Äù

Oliver chews on his bottom lip for a second before eventually nodding his head.

‚ÄúBrilliant,‚Äù Remus gives him a small pat on the shoulder before standing up again and taking a step back. ‚ÄúYou ready William?‚Äù The other boy nods. ‚ÄúAny time you want then, go for it.‚Äù

William faces his apple like it‚Äôs an adversary on a battlefield, all earlier silliness gone.

‚ÄúWingardium,‚Äù he begins, Oliver barely a second behind him, doing, honestly a spot on impression. No wonder Amelia finds it so annoying. ‚ÄúLeviosa!‚Äù

Two red apples tremble and shake and lift into the air with tremendous effort. But still, they do lift. It‚Äôs certainly a start.

‚ÄúIt worked!‚Äù

‚ÄúHoly heck this is the coolest!‚Äù

‚ÄúWe did it! I can‚Äôt believe we did it!‚Äù Oliver throws his arms around the boy next to him with such enthusiasm that both of them teeter and end up on the floor, laughing and wrestling, as their apples smash back down onto the table. Remus can‚Äôt help smiling at them, something aching in his chest.

Memories of different boys and different laughter and easier joy.

‚ÄúAlright you lot,‚Äù Remus turns around to find Mia leaning against the doorway, watching on with amusement. ‚ÄúLunch time, go on, the others are already eating.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre we having?‚Äù Oliver asks as he and William clumsily untangle themselves from one another.

Mia smiles. ‚ÄúGrilled cheese.‚Äù

‚ÄúSweet.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi, I‚Äôll race you,‚Äù William elbows his friend.

Oliver grins. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll lose.‚Äù

‚ÄúNuh-uh.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah-yuh.‚Äù
