‚ÄúHey, no running in the house,‚Äù Mia says, not that the boys pay much attention to her, eyes only for each other, the competition clearly on. ‚ÄúDid you two hear me?‚Äù she says, though she doesn‚Äôt sound particularly stern.

‚ÄúYeah Mia we heard you,‚Äù Oliver says lightly. ‚ÄúNo running, got it.‚Äù

However, the moment they‚Äôre out the door there is the unmistakable sound of pattering footsteps down the hall. Mia rolls her eyes, Remus unable to hold back a laugh.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre a menace those two,‚Äù she says, fondness in her voice.

‚ÄúI like them,‚Äù Remus looks over at the slightly mangled apples behind him and quickly vanishes the mess.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre good at that you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù he looks back at her, and she nods towards the now empty table.

‚ÄúTeaching. You‚Äôre a natural.‚Äù

For some reason he blushes at that. ‚ÄúI used to help people at school sometimes,‚Äù he shrugs, feeling slightly embarrassed though he isn‚Äôt sure why.

Mia nods, looking like she‚Äôs about to walk away before Remus speaks again.

‚ÄúCan I ask you something?‚Äù he leans back against the table behind him, arms crossing over his chest.

‚ÄúAbsolutely. Fire away.‚Äù

Remus pauses for a minute, working through exactly what it is he‚Äôs trying to say here. The afternoon sun is soft today, filtering in through the bay widow beside him, views of fields stretching out on the other side. This place feels a thousand miles away from everything‚Äîthe city, the Wizarding world, the war. Everything. Though he supposes that is the point.

‚ÄúWhy aren‚Äôt Oliver and William in school?‚Äù he asks finally. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre both of age, they should be at Hogwarts. And Gabe, Ava, Liam? I mean, did they just not want to go? Were you afraid they wouldn‚Äôt be‚Ä¶that people would find out about them?‚Äù

Mia just looks back at him for a moment, an indecipherable look on her face as she steps further into the room, sitting on the arm of one of the large chesterfields. ‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù she says slowly, like she‚Äôs trying not to spook him. ‚ÄúWerewolves aren‚Äôt allowed at Hogwarts.‚Äù

He just blinks.

Because

Well

That‚Äôs a bit of a ridiculous thing to say to him of all people.

‚ÄúI went to Hogwarts,‚Äù he finally manages, losing the ability to fully articulate his thoughts.

Mia nods slowly. ‚ÄúYes, I know.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo then you know that‚Äôs not true?‚Äù he can feel his brows drawing together, knows the confusion is written all over his face.

She smiles sadly at him. ‚ÄúDid you never wonder, why you were the only one?‚Äù

Remus opens his mouth and then closes it again. Because‚Ä¶no, not really, he hadn‚Äôt. He‚Äôd just assumed he WAS the only one. He certainly had felt that way. Completely alone. A freak.

‚ÄúThings changed with Dumbledore, did you not know?‚Äù he presses on. ‚ÄúIf you had written to him, if you‚Äôd told him, he would have let them come. If you do it now‚Äîhe‚Äôll let Oliver and William in, I promise you.‚Äù

There‚Äôs something sad in her eyes, something gentle in her voice. ‚ÄúNo Remus, he wouldn‚Äôt have and he won‚Äôt.‚Äù

But that just doesn‚Äôt make any sense to him. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand.‚Äù

She looks at him like she doesn‚Äôt quite know how to respond, before letting out a worn down sigh. ‚ÄúI have spoken to Dumbledore,‚Äù she says finally. ‚ÄúHe was very polite, which is more than I can say for most people I speak to,‚Äù she offers him a weak smile. ‚ÄúBut he made it clear that my kids would not be welcome at Hogwarts. That he simply did not have the resources to accommodate them.‚Äù

Something cold runs down Remus‚Äôs spine, his world trembling ever so slightly. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he says dumbly. ‚ÄúWhat.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry Remus,‚Äù she sounds like she means it but Remus can‚Äôt understand why, thoughts swirling.

‚ÄúBut why would he let me come then? That doesn‚Äôt‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt make any sense.‚Äù

Mia bites her lower lip, hands folded in her lap. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she starts slowly. ‚ÄúI can only tell you what I think his reasons were, but I don‚Äôt know anything for certain.‚Äù

His heart stutters in his chest. ‚ÄúTell me,‚Äù he says, even though he isn‚Äôt sure if he means it. ‚ÄúTell me, please?‚Äù

Mia sighs, running a hand through her hair. ‚ÄúPartly, I think it was because your father is an important man, and him and Dumbledore had at least some form of cordial relationship.‚Äù

Funny, Remus had never considered the possibility that his father was part of the reason he‚Äôd been able to go to school. It would require Lyall to stand up for Remus, to fight for him, claim him, and that just didn‚Äôt seem like something he would do.

‚ÄúBut I also think,‚Äù Mia goes on carefully, ‚Äúthat Dumbledore is a very smart man, that he had some idea, even back when you were eleven, that things were changing. That a war was coming. And that having a werewolf on his side might be useful.‚Äù

Oh.

It shouldn‚Äôt feel as destabilizing as it does. And yet Remus can‚Äôt help but grab onto the table behind him, forcing his breath to come out evenly. So what if Dumbledore used him? If he thought of him as a weapon? So what. So what. So what. It didn‚Äôt change anything. Did it?

‚ÄúAnd here you are,‚Äù Mia says finally, causing Remus‚Äôs eyes to snap up. And what he sees tells him that she hasn‚Äôt been fooled, that she knew the moment he showed up here that it wasn‚Äôt by choice or by accident, but because he had been sent. Doing exactly what Dumbledore had raised him to.

‚ÄúMia‚Äî‚Äú

But she waves his words away. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs alright Remus,‚Äù and it sounds like she means it. ‚ÄúSpy all you like, I have nothing to hide. And besides,‚Äù her smile is small but genuine. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy to have you here.‚Äù

Despite his best efforts Remus‚Äôs heart is racing in his chest, tremors running through his arms and legs. He feels like he can‚Äôt get his footing, can‚Äôt find anything stable to hold onto.

There‚Äôs a crash from down the hall and then crying.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Mia says knowingly, getting to her feet. ‚ÄúDuty calls,‚Äù she‚Äôs half-way to the door when she stops, turning back to Remus. ‚ÄúWill you be okay?‚Äù

He does his best to pull himself together. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he manages tensely. ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôll be okay.‚Äù

Mia doesn‚Äôt exactly look convinced but the crying down the hall is growing louder so with one final look over her shoulder she nods, disappearing out the door.

Remus hangs his head, nails biting into the wood of the table he‚Äôs leaning on. ‚ÄúThis doesn‚Äôt change anything,‚Äù he whispers to himself, trying to convince himself that his whole life hasn‚Äôt been a lie. That whatever political scheming brought him to Hogwarts he‚Äôs grateful for it.

‚ÄúThis doesn‚Äôt change anything.‚Äù

But he can‚Äôt help wondering, how many of the people in his life see him as nothing but a dog on a leash. A trained monster. Ready to bite on command.

No wonder they didn‚Äôt expel Sirius for what he did in fifth year.

After all, he‚Äôd only been using Remus as Dumbledore intended.

¬†

A few hours later Remus finds himself somewhere in the woods surrounding the farm with a very excited Gabe looking at him expectantly. It‚Äôs cold but not freezing, the leaves on the trees changing colours and falling to the ground. In the distance Remus can hear the sounds of running water, he expects it's from a small stream. Sunlight dribbles over them, highlighting little pieces of the world. Remus is wearing a sweater, Gabe is in a t-shirt.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never met a werewolf as cold as you, you know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat can I say,‚Äù Remus replies dryly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm one of a kind.‚Äù Not bothering to explain that he doesn‚Äôt cover up because he‚Äôs cold. But because it‚Äôs become second nature. Hiding his scars.

Gabe grins. ‚ÄúYou are though.‚Äù The sincerity in his voice makes Remus look away.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù he says, desperate to change the subject. ‚ÄúHow does this work then?‚Äù

He‚Äôd asked Gabe, the last time he was here, if he‚Äôd teach him how to transform on command. He‚Äôd never seen anything like the wolves at Lupercal, never even heard of it. He had always believed‚Äîbeen taught‚Äîthat wolves were tied to the moon. That they had no control. It turned out that wasn‚Äôt quite true.

‚ÄúWell, first of all,‚Äù Gabe picks up a stray stick and starts waving it around. ‚ÄúYou have to relax.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm never relaxed.‚Äù

Gabe laughs. ‚ÄúFair enough. But you don‚Äôt have to look so scared.‚Äù

That surprises Remus, mostly because he hadn‚Äôt realized that he was scared.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú he cuts himself off, unsure of exactly what it is he‚Äôs trying to say. After a few seconds of struggling he lets out a breath. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never not been scared‚Ä¶of transforming. I suppose moon or no moon I still‚Ä¶‚Äù because it‚Äôs more than just the pain. It‚Äôs the loss of control. Of who he is. Becoming something that has the power to cause so much harm. The power to make him cause so much harm. He hates it.

Gabe looks sad. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat for?‚Äù

Now it‚Äôs Gabe‚Äôs turn to struggle. ‚ÄúThat this has been so hard for you. Being what we are.‚Äù

Again, Remus finds himself surprised. ‚ÄúIt hasn‚Äôt been for you?‚Äù

Gabe‚Äôs head wobbles from side to side. ‚ÄúLife is hard,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúBut this?‚Äù he pulls up his shirt, revealing the pearl white teeth marks on his stomach. ‚ÄúThis is easy. It‚Äôs‚Ä¶natural. It‚Äôs not something that was done to me, not anymore, not for a long time, now it just is me. I wish you could feel that too.‚Äù Remus wants to know who these people are, that they think they know him when they‚Äôve barely met. And at the same time he understands that there are parts of him that these practical strangers see that no one else in his life ever will. Ever can. No matter how desperate he is to show them.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how to think of this as anything but a punishment,‚Äù Remus says eventually, truthfully. Harsh ugly words thrown into the beautiful woods surrounding them.

For once Gabe actually looks serious, walking towards him, slow and careful. He doesn‚Äôt stop. He keeps coming. Closer and closer until he brings his hand to the back of Remus‚Äôs neck and pulls him down, pressing their foreheads together. ‚ÄúLet me show you then,‚Äù he says softly.

Remus doesn‚Äôt move, barely breathes, watching Gabe intently. Watching his eyes close. And then, a second later, watching them open. Pupils turned into slits. Remus instantly stiffens but Gabe‚Äôs touch is firm, not letting him pull away.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù he says calmly. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay Remus. We‚Äôre okay.‚Äù

Remus exhales slowly, trying not to panic, trying not to let the fear overtake him.

‚ÄúCan you feel him, inside you?‚Äù Gabe goes on. ‚ÄúCan you feel your wolf?‚Äù

Remus shakes his head, nose brushing Gabe‚Äôs.

‚ÄúClose your eyes, listen.‚Äù

Remus has no idea what it is he‚Äôs listening for but he does as he‚Äôs told. The world behind his eyes is dark and he tries to convince himself not to be afraid of it. Of himself. Of the things that live inside this skin.

‚ÄúThat feeling you try so hard to silence, to push away, to pretend doesn‚Äôt exist,‚Äù Gabe goes on, a steady beat to his words. A pulse. ‚ÄúListen to it now. Let it grow loud. Let it speak to you.‚Äù

Every fibre of his being recoils at the idea. He has a body covered in scars. A body that cracks and breaks and rips him apart. He has a body that betrays him. That hurts him. And he does not want to know it. He does not want to hear it. He wants to walk through life barely acknowledging its existence. He lives in his head. He lives in his thoughts. In the smalls spaces of himself that he can control.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù Gabe says quietly. ‚ÄúBreathe okay? You‚Äôre safe. I promise you‚Äôre safe. Trust yourself. You are good. Every part of you. That means this too.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt,‚Äù Remus doesn‚Äôt know when his voice started getting so shaky.

‚ÄúYou can,‚Äù Gabe says soothingly. ‚ÄúThis hatred was given to you, but you don‚Äôt deserve it, you don‚Äôt need to carry it around. Put it down. Let yourself be free.‚Äù

He tries to listen. To search out the parts of himself that he has spent so much of his life denying. Ashamed of. Afraid of. He hears the sound of the wind in the branches over their heads. He hears the soft waves of Gabe‚Äôs breath. Of his own pulse. And beneath that. Beneath the hum of his thoughts,

he hears a howl.

His eyes snap open and the world around him is sharp, hyper focused. And something huge pushes against his skin. Against his ribs. Against the inside of his skull.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Remus whimpers, the fear coming back. ‚ÄúFuck, fuck, fuck.‚Äù He hates this. He hates this. Why did he think he wanted this?

‚ÄúShh,‚Äù Gabe says calmly as they stumble, Remus now off balance. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay. It‚Äôs okay. Don‚Äôt let the fear get the better of you.‚Äù

Remus is breathing hard, fighting against the tightening of his skin, his senses all feel overloaded. He can hear and smell and see more intensely than he ever has before.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how to stop being scared,‚Äù he pants.

‚ÄúI told you, trust yourself, stop fighting this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have to fight it. If I don‚Äôt fight it I‚Äôll hurt someone.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt, I promise you won‚Äôt.‚Äù

And it‚Äôs only because he feels as though he‚Äôs about to break apart that he says it. Knowing it‚Äôs cruel. ‚ÄúIs that what you told Jack?‚Äù

Something painful flickers in Gabe‚Äôs eyes and his hold on the back of Remus‚Äôs neck loosens ever so slightly.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Remus‚Äôs eyes snap shut. It‚Äôs too much. Too much is happening in his body all at once. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù Gabe says after a short pause.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I‚Äôm sorry. Please make it stop, I don‚Äôt want to do this anymore.‚Äù

He hears Gabe exhale before squeezing Remus‚Äôs neck. ‚ÄúYou can do this Remus.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can. I‚Äôm not asking you to trust me, I know you don‚Äôt have any reason to, but you have to trust yourself. You have to trust this part of yourself. Stop treating it like the enemy and maybe it will stop acting like it.‚Äù

Gabe gives the back of his neck another squeeze and then he‚Äôs gone and Remus feels like he‚Äôs falling even though he‚Äôs standing on solid ground.

‚ÄúGabe!‚Äù he calls out helplessly. He hears something snap and tear and then his eyes are flying open and all he sees is a giant black wolf standing in front of him.

Remus stumbles back, bones aching, begging to shift and break and reform. It‚Äôs like the full moon and nothing like it all at once. Remus feels high, feels adrenaline coursing through his veins making him too bright. The wolf just stares at him, yellow eyes intent, and Remus waits for the attack. For the teeth baring and back arching, he‚Äôs not sure he has enough control of his legs to run at the moment. Not sure he could bear to use his wand on Gabe.

But the wolf doesn‚Äôt move. Instead he sits back on his hind legs, tilts is head up towards the evening sky and howls. The noise touches every molecule in Remus‚Äôs body. Every particle, every atom. He feels it down to his very core.

And then, in the distance, back towards the farm house, another voice joins Gabe‚Äôs. And another. And another. They‚Äôre singing, Remus thinks, a little hysterically. The wolves are singing. It‚Äôs a heartbreaking sound. A beautiful sound.

He almost laughs.

He‚Äôs never thought anything about werewolves was beautiful before.

He closes his eyes and lets the noise fill him up. Listen, Gabe had told him. Listen. So he does. He is standing in front of a werewolf without a wand, with his eyes closed, listening to it howl. And he isn‚Äôt afraid. And he wants to join them. Some part of him is aching and desperate and begging to be with them. Like walls crumbling inside of him he feels his mind let go and his body take over.

It hurts a little. But nothing like normal. The world bends and flickers and reforms around him. Brighter and louder and fuller than it was only moments ago. Except it doesn‚Äôt hurt him now the way it did before. He blinks his eyes open as a wolf and the world sparkles. There are no locked doors, no windowless rooms, no dirty mattresses. It isn‚Äôt dark or hidden or secret. For the first time in his life Remus Lupin is a wolf. And he is free.

And he sings.

¬†

‚ÄúHoly shit.‚Äù Remus gasps as he comes back to himself some time later. He has no idea how long he was a wolf. Only that the sun has now set, the sky dark blue and quickly turning black, stars twinkling into view. He‚Äôs breathing heavy, chest heaving as he adjusts to his dulled senses. He‚Äôs sore, scratches here and there on his skin, but nothing like the moon usually is.

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù he repeats.

He hears Gabe laugh beside him and turns his head to see the other boy lying on his back in the dirt as well, looking up at the sky.

‚ÄúThat shouldn‚Äôt be possible. How is that possible? Werewolves can‚Äôt control their transformations.‚Äù

Gabe turns his head to look at Remus, eyes twinkling in the moonlight. ‚ÄúYou sure about that?‚Äù

He had been. He had been his whole life before he came here. He just stares dumbly back at Gabe who eventually takes pity on him.

‚ÄúThe full moon is the only time we really can‚Äôt control it, the rest of the time‚Ä¶‚Äù he trails off shrugging. ‚ÄúThe wolf is always there, you just have to learn how to talk to him.‚Äù

‚ÄúTalk to him,‚Äù Remus repeats, that turn of phrase seeming so ludicrous to him. In fact, this whole situation seems ludicrous and he can‚Äôt help but laugh. ‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre saying I can switch back and forth whenever I want except on the full moon?‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, I‚Äôm sure you could try not to transform on the full moon if you really wanted to, but it would hurt like a bitch. Well, more of a bitch.‚Äù Gabe shivers, but Remus isn‚Äôt put off by that description. Instead he feels a small spark of hope catch in his chest.

‚ÄúYou mean it is possible? To get strong enough that you would never have to transform again?‚Äù

Gabe‚Äôs expression grows serious. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what this is about,‚Äù he says sternly.

Remus‚Äôs brow furrows. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs not what this is about?‚Äù

Gabe waves his hand in the air. ‚ÄúSuppressing. Denying. That‚Äôs not why we learn how to control our transformations.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù Remus asks, because he can‚Äôt think why not. Rolling his eyes Gabe reaches over and smacks Remus lightly on the arm.

‚ÄúWere you even paying attention just now? This is about acceptance. Accepting the wolf not shutting it up more,‚Äù and when Remus stays silent he pushes on. ‚ÄúNothing good will come from that Remus. Surely you can understand that now? When you shove it down and deny it you turn it into something cancerous. Something poison. That isn‚Äôt what this is supposed to be.‚Äù

Remus holds his gaze a moment longer before looking away, back up at the sky, at the nearly full moon above them. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt supposed to be anything. There isn‚Äôt a greater meaning here Gabe.‚Äù

The other boy snorts. ‚ÄúSays the man who thinks he‚Äôs being punished.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what I said.‚Äù

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

Remus bites back his retort, letting the cool fall night lick at his sweaty skin. He can still feel the last tendrils of adrenalin flickering through him. The howling in his chest closer to the surface than it ever has been before. He isn‚Äôt sure if he‚Äôs ready to keep it there. If he trusts it the way Gabe does. The way he wants him to.

‚ÄúTell me what happened, the first day I showed up here,‚Äù he says finally, breath forming clouds against the night sky.

There‚Äôs a long pause before Gabe speaks. ‚ÄúYou know what happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me again.‚Äù He‚Äôd thought he‚Äôd understood before. Now he isn‚Äôt so sure.

Gabe sighs. ‚ÄúThe younger kids only ever transform on the full moon,‚Äù he starts. ‚ÄúYou remember what it‚Äôs like, when you‚Äôre young, when you‚Äôre new, how much more painful it is?‚Äù

Remus nods, and then, realizing Gabe probably isn‚Äôt looking at him, clears his throat. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù voice rough. ‚ÄúI remember.‚Äù

‚ÄúTransforming like this, having this kind of control, it just isn‚Äôt possible until you‚Äôre older, or until you‚Äôve done it a few times. Mia didn‚Äôt show me and Ava until we were seventeen. It‚Äôs easier to be in control when it‚Äôs not the full moon, but it still isn‚Äôt easy. I‚Äôm sure you noticed.‚Äù

‚ÄúI noticed,‚Äù Remus says after a moment. His thoughts had still changed, there had still been an element of wolf, of instinct above all else, but he‚Äîhe had felt present, in a way he never did on the full moon. ‚ÄúWhy is that?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe moon calls to the wolf,‚Äù Gabe explains, ‚Äúmakes it stronger, stronger than the rest of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that why it hurts so much?‚Äù Remus does his best to keep the memories at bay. To not feel them and see them, because sometime they‚Äôre so visceral he might as well be experiencing them in real time. ‚ÄúBecause the wolf is stronger?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt hurts so much because you‚Äôre fighting it so hard.‚Äù Gabe says, like it‚Äôs that simple. ‚ÄúIf you hold your breath when your body needs to breathe it‚Äôs going to burn.‚Äù

Breathing and turning into a werewolf do not feel like comparable experiences to Remus but he doesn‚Äôt feel like arguing the point. ‚ÄúSo what happened then, the day I first showed up? It wasn‚Äôt a full moon.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Gabe sounds tired. ‚ÄúNo it wasn‚Äôt a full moon,‚Äù there‚Äôs another brief pause before he presses on. ‚ÄúJack is fifteen, which is young to start learning how to transform on command but he‚Äôs, well, he‚Äôs smart and he‚Äôs honestly pretty grounded all things considered and we thought‚Ä¶well, I thought it would be okay. And it was.‚Äù

‚ÄúUntil I showed up?‚Äù

He sighs. ‚ÄúSee, we were going to turn back into our human selves, but that‚Äôs kind of tricky the first few times, so I switched back first, the way I just did with you, remember?‚Äù

Remus nods. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù One second he‚Äôd been running through the trees with another wolf and the next there had been a boy in front of him saying ‚Äúchange back Remus, it‚Äôs time to change back‚Äù. He‚Äôd forgotten for a minute there, that there was anything to change back to.

‚ÄúSo I was‚Ä¶I was like this, I was me, and I was trying to get him to shift back and then I saw‚Äîhis eyes flashed and his ears perked up and I knew he‚Äôd heard something or smelt something and I figured it was something back at the farm you know? But then he took off in the opposite direction and I thought, maybe it was a deer or, I don‚Äôt know, a fox or something. I wasn‚Äôt a wolf so I couldn‚Äôt, I couldn‚Äôt smell it, I couldn‚Äôt see.‚Äù

There‚Äôs something desperate in his voice, something pleading.

‚ÄúNobody comes here, I mean nobody just walks in the way you did. We‚Äôre in the middle of nowhere. I wasn‚Äôt‚Äîit didn‚Äôt even occur to me. And you didn‚Äôt, you didn‚Äôt scream Remus. You didn‚Äôt cry out for help. I‚ÄîI would have come faster, I swear I would have shifted faster if I had known. But I just‚Ä¶‚Äù he lets out a shaky breath. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt until I got to the driveway that I saw.‚Äù

Remus lets that sit between them for a minute, the cold finally beginning to creep inside his skin.

‚ÄúBut why did he attack, if he wasn‚Äôt‚Äîif he was still in control?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs young, it was his first time trying like this, you just felt it, you‚Äôre there and you‚Äôre not, it takes time to get used to. To really be able to keep your instincts in check. And you‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWere a stranger?‚Äù Remus guesses.

Gabe actually laughs at that. ‚ÄúSure, a stranger. But you smelt like fucking magic.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs brows draw together, turning his head to look back at Gabe who is still staring at the sky. ‚ÄúWhat? You‚Äôre all wizards too.‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly technically,‚Äù his profile is silhouetted by the moon. ‚ÄúBut god I‚Äôd never smelt anything like you. The minute I turned back into a wolf it hit me, set me on fucking fire more like. And I could feel what Jack had felt‚Äîthe instant fear. The need to tear and bite and protect. Fuck I almost ripped out your throat myself.‚Äù

Remus laughs, not sure what else to do with that information. Not willing to let himself really go back to that moment. When he‚Äôd felt so certain he was going to die.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Gabe turns away from the sky, eyes back on Remus, the ghost of a smile haunting his mouth.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says slowly, ‚Äúme too.‚Äù

¬†

Remus had been unconscious for three days after the attack. When he woke he was disoriented and weak and in pain. The only one at Lupercal comfortable performing magic on other people was Mia and she had no skill with healing spells. So he‚Äôd been patched and sown together. And he‚Äôd wanted desperately to get the fuck out of there.

They‚Äôd tried to explain what had happened but Remus had only barely been listening. The only piece of information he was really able to absorb, really able to bring back to Moody after that trip, was that these people could transform whenever they wanted. That they were not held prisoner by the moon. No one had seemed pleased by that.

The other thing that had stuck with Remus, from the blur of those few days after he‚Äôd woken up, was Jack. He‚Äôd come to see Remus, just before he‚Äôd insisted on leaving despite Mia‚Äôs many protests that he wasn‚Äôt strong enough. She‚Äôd been right of course. He wasn‚Äôt able to Apparate and the walk back to the road had torn open just about every one of his injuries.

Jack had hovered by the doorway, looking far younger than fifteen‚Äîthan Remus remembered looking at fifteen‚Äîbarely able to speak. His words were cracked and broken and stuttered. There was an apology in there, Remus was sure of it, but mostly what he kept saying. Repeating. Was ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt bite you.‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt bite you.

I didn‚Äôt bite you.

They checked.

They checked.

I didn‚Äôt bite you.

Remus was certain the refrain was for Jack more than it was for him. A reassurance that he hadn‚Äôt done the unthinkable. The thing all of them are terrified of. The fear that haunts their existences.

Remus should have said something comforting to the kid‚Äîlike that it really wouldn‚Äôt have mattered if he had‚Äîbut the truth is, he‚Äôd barely been able to process anything. Barely been able to eat. The minute he could stand he was walking out the door. He had no interest in staying in a house full of fucking werewolves who could shift at any moment. Especially not when he was injured and weak. On his way out the door Mia had told him about the shuttles that ran around the full moon. She had told him to think about it. To come back. To give them a chance.

If it had been up to him he wouldn‚Äôt have. Two werewolf attacks was more than enough for one lifetime he felt. But as Moody had been very keen to point out. It wasn‚Äôt up to him.

¬†

It‚Äôs late when Remus and Gabe get back to the main house. The children have all gone to bed, the candles have all been lit, someone has put the record player on. Ava and Liam are dancing‚Äîor well, Ava is dancing, Liam is sort of swaying, admiring her. Mia and Alexandra on the couch, discussing something with their heads bent close together. Some other people scattered around the front room, wine glasses held lazily in their hands, or abandoned on coffee tables and windowsills.

Gabe tugs on Remus‚Äôs elbow and nods at the stairs and though Remus isn‚Äôt quite sure what the plan is, he follows after him. Gabe‚Äôs bedroom is the last one on the second floor, it has indigo blue walls covered in posters, all Muggle, most foreign to Remus.

‚ÄúDo you want to take a shower?‚Äù Gabe has his back to Remus, rummaging through his dresser.

Remus blinks. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Gabe turns around, handing him a clean pair of clothes before nodding towards the ensuite. ‚ÄúShower? I‚Äôm taking one either way, but since you're the guest I figured I‚Äôd offer you first dibs.‚Äù

Remus blinks again before looking down at himself. He is kind of a mess. ‚ÄúRight, yeah‚ÄîI‚Äîyeah thanks.‚Äù

Gabe nods, kicking off his shoes and dropping down onto his bed. ‚ÄúThere are extra towels under the sink. And don‚Äôt use all the hot water.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúAs if you‚Äôre ever cold.‚Äù

Gabe grins back at him. ‚ÄúEvery man has his limits Remus.‚Äù

He shuts the door and quickly sheds the tattered clothes that survived his transformation. He inspects himself for a minute, mud smeared and scrapped up, though nothing serious. His hands tremble slightly as they run over his skin. He still hasn‚Äôt fully processed what just happened. What he just did. He‚Äôs not sure he ever will if he‚Äôs being honest. After a few more seconds he does actually get into the shower, the hot water stinging, but not in a bad way.

He thinks about the first time he came back from Lupercal. About Sirius holding him up under the water. How gentle he‚Äôd been. How caring. And then he thinks about the second time.

Remus had been so angry when Moody told him he was leaving again. Not because he hadn‚Äôt expected it. Or because he was scared‚Äîwhich he was‚Äîbut because James and Sirius had just lost their parents. Because they were both hurting so badly and Remus was supposed to be there. The way they had been there for him. The guilt had eaten at him the whole time he was away. Keeping him up at night. Especially when it turned out that Lupercal wasn‚Äôt some awful nightmarish place. Especially when he found himself feeling happy here.

That full moon, transforming with werewolves for the first time, it was different. Sure it helped, when he had Prongs and Padfoot and Wormtail. But there was always an undercurrent of fear. A need to hold back, that he felt even as a wolf, even if he couldn‚Äôt quite‚Ä¶think it. The frustration would linger even after the moon had faded and the sun had returned. Of being close to something but never quite getting what he needed. And then he‚Äôd transformed at Lupercal.

He didn‚Äôt have clear memories of being a wolf. But he did have‚Ä¶impressions. The happiness. The joy. At finally being with his own kind. They‚Äôd played without holding back. Without fear of injury. And it had left Remus battered and bruised in the morning but it had also left him feeling‚Ä¶fulfilled.

There was guilt about that too.

He felt guilty about everything honestly. Tearing himself apart trying to figure out how to make it right. How to make it up to Sirius somehow. Only to find out that while he‚Äôd been haunted by guilt Sirius had been snogging his ex-girlfriend.

You have no idea what I‚Äôve been through, he‚Äôd said to Sirius.

He‚Äôd meant the guilt. But he knew that wasn‚Äôt how Sirius took it. Not after the shape he‚Äôd been in the last time he‚Äôd come home. Not once he‚Äôd made the connection to werewolves. He knew exactly the sorts of horrors Sirius‚Äôs prejudices would lead him to imagine. And he hadn‚Äôt bothered to correct him. To say ‚Äúactually, the werewolves are quite lovely believe it or not‚Äù. Because he‚Äôd been angry. And petty. And childish. And because, maybe a little part of him, just as James had suggested, wanted to punish Sirius. Though if he was being honest, he wasn‚Äôt even sure what for anymore.

‚ÄúYou definitely did use all the hot water you bastard,‚Äù Gabe says when he steps out of the shower fifteen minutes after Remus, towel drying his hair. He‚Äôs in a pair of flannel pyjama bottoms and an oversized grey t-shirt, Remus wearing the hoody and sweatpants Gabe lent him.

Remus snorts, turning back to the window, feeling the familiar ache in his bones that he always does when the full moon is near. Except it isn‚Äôt the same this time. It doesn‚Äôt make him feel quite so‚Ä¶fragile.

‚ÄúNice try. I shared a bathroom with a bunch of teenage boys for seven years, I know how to preserve hot water,‚Äù not that Sirius could say the same.

The silence that follows is so uncharacteristic of Gabe that Remus actually turns around. The other boy is sitting at the end of his bed, towel held between his knees, a complicated look on his face.

‚ÄúGabe?‚Äù Remus asks tentatively.

‚ÄúWhat was it like then?‚Äù the words seem to come out of him almost unwillingly. ‚ÄúHogwarts?‚Äù

Remus is surprised by the question, though he probably shouldn‚Äôt be. It‚Äôs an impossible thing to answer. All that Hogwarts was for him. Everything it meant. Everything that happened there. He built so much of himself behind those walls.

Gabe laughs, though there‚Äôs little humour in it. ‚ÄúThat good huh?‚Äù he looks up finally, eyes meeting Remus‚Äôs.

Remus sighs, running a hand through his hair before walking over and sitting down on the bed next to him. He tries to figure out where to start. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think I was going to be able to go,‚Äù is what he decides on. He can feel Gabe watching him. ‚ÄúMy father made it pretty clear from the time of my attack what my‚Ä¶condition, would mean, when it came to my future.‚Äù

‚ÄúPrick,‚Äù Gabe hisses, causing Remus to laugh.

‚ÄúYeah, well, he wasn‚Äôt wrong. Except that then Dumbledore became Headmaster and suddenly things changed,‚Äù he grimaces. ‚ÄúFor me, I guess, things changed. I thought‚Ä¶I thought it meant that any werewolf would be allowed at Hogwarts but obviously‚Ä¶‚Äù he sighs, still struggling with this truth.

‚ÄúThat must have been lonely.‚Äù

Remus looks over at him, of all the reactions he‚Äôd expected that certainly wasn‚Äôt one of them.

‚ÄúLonely?‚Äù he asks.

Gabe shrugs. ‚ÄúThinking you were the only one.‚Äù

It had been lonely. And scary. But he didn‚Äôt deserve Gabe‚Äôs pity, not after everything that had been given to Remus and no one else. ‚ÄúSelf-absorbed more like,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúI should have looked into it, I should have known Greyback wouldn‚Äôt stop at just one victim but‚Ä¶‚Äù he runs a hand over his face. ‚ÄúMostly I just tried not to think about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe attack?‚Äù

Remus laughs. ‚ÄúBeing a werewolf.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnyway, getting to go to school, getting to be around other kids it was‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, a dream come true.‚Äù He sneaks a guilty look at Gabe who, if he feels bitter, has done a good job of keeping it off his face. ‚ÄúAnd it didn‚Äôt hurt that the food was fucking delicious.‚Äù

Gabe laughs, easing some of the tension from the room. ‚ÄúThere are like‚Ä¶teams or whatever, right?‚Äù he pushes Remus. ‚ÄúThat you all get sorted into?‚Äù

It takes Remus a second to catch up. ‚ÄúYeah, houses; Gryffindor, Ravenclaw, Slytherin and Hufflepuff.‚Äù Gabe nods though Remus can tell the words don‚Äôt mean much to him. It‚Äôs strange, when Remus comes from a world where these sorts of things define them. ‚ÄúGryffindor values bravery, Ravenclaw intelligence, Slytherin ambition, Hufflepuff fair play.‚Äù

This time when Gabe nods there‚Äôs light behind his eyes. ‚ÄúWhich one were you then‚Äîno wait,‚Äù he says when Remus opens his mouth. ‚ÄúLet me guess, Ravenclaw?‚Äù

Remus smirks. ‚ÄúShockingly, no.‚Äù

Gabe‚Äôs mouth makes a dramatic ‚Äúo‚Äù shape. ‚ÄúSlytherin?‚Äù

‚ÄúSlytherin!‚Äù Remus says indignantly, punching him playfully in the arm. ‚ÄúYour second guess is Slytherin? Really?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Gabe laughs. ‚ÄúI mean if it wasn‚Äôt Ravenclaw it could be any of them.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you didn‚Äôt want to go with fair play first?‚Äù

He grins, canines on full display. ‚ÄúNah, you don‚Äôt strike me as someone who plays fair.‚Äù

Remus punches him again. ‚ÄúTwat.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo on then, which was it?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell I don‚Äôt even know if I want to tell you now.‚Äù

Gabe rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be a drama queen.‚Äù

‚ÄúGryffindor. It was Gryffindor.‚Äù

Gabe gives him a considering look. ‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúOkay, I can see that I guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh well, don‚Äôt strain your imagination too much.‚Äù

Gabe pushes him hard enough that he collapses down onto his back, weaker than he normally is. Gabe lies down next to him.

‚ÄúWhat about me then,‚Äù Gabe asks, their heads turned towards one another. There‚Äôs something vaguely uncertain in his voice. Embarrassed. ‚ÄúWhere do you think they‚Äôd put me?‚Äù

Remus pauses but the truth is fairly obvious. ‚ÄúGryffindor, definitely.‚Äù

Gabe‚Äôs smile is soft. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúThink we would have been friends?‚Äù

Something wiggles in Remus‚Äôs chest. Four boys in a dormitory laughing. Running down the hallways. Sneaking through secret passages.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus clears his throat. ‚ÄúYeah, ‚Äòcourse we would have.‚Äù

Gabe nods, looking back up at the ceiling while the pair of them sit in silence for a minute. ‚ÄúI think I would have liked that,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúAll the classes and clubs and things. I think maybe I would have been good at it.‚Äù He‚Äôs trying to keep his tone light but he doesn‚Äôt quite manage to.

‚ÄúI could teach you, you know,‚Äù Remus says suddenly. ‚ÄúMagic, I mean. I know it‚Äôs not the same as‚Ä¶but I could teach you.‚Äù He knows that Gabe knows a few spells, that Mia taught him, but he never seems to use them. Never seems comfortable with it.

Something complicated flickers across Gabe's face. ‚ÄúNah I‚ÄîI don‚Äôt think so. Thanks though.‚Äù

But Remus isn‚Äôt quite willing to let it go, not when he can hear the longing in Gabe‚Äôs voice. He elbows him lightly. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a part of you, you know, the same way you‚Äôre always saying the wolf is part of me. You shouldn‚Äôt hide from it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah except that magic doesn‚Äôt want me,‚Äù Gabe says flatly, trying and failing to hide the hurt in those word. ‚ÄúSo it just makes it easier, not to want it back you know? Not to want that world,‚Äù he turns his head to face Remus then, the pair only inches apart. ‚ÄúBut the wolves? Us? we want you.‚Äù

And for a moment it feels so simple. The life he could have if he just‚Ä¶stayed. No more lying, no more fear. Just days filled with running through the woods, free and unchained.

Remus pulls himself up to sitting, rubbing at his eyes. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs late,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúI should go back to my room.‚Äù

Gabe is slower to sit up. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to, you know.‚Äù

Remus laughs, elbows resting on his knees, head dropping. ‚ÄúGabe‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just‚Ä¶I‚Äôm just saying it so you know. That you could‚Ä¶you could stay. That I want you to stay.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not that he doesn‚Äôt understand that there‚Äôs‚Ä¶something here. Something that could grow. And maybe it would be sweet and simple and pure. And maybe they would never hurt one another, maybe they would always be honest and kind, without any history to hold them back.

‚ÄúI just‚Ä¶‚Äù Remus starts, still looking at his feet, hands laced at the back of his head, overly aware of how close Gabe is. How warm. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt.‚Äù

The thing is, nothing feels as bright or as real or as alive as loving Sirius Black. Everything else pales by comparison. A candle flame to a forest fire. He knows that it isn‚Äôt the same for Sirius. Knows that he could be with people other than Remus. He accepted a long time ago that he would always love Sirius more. Honestly he never imagined he would get as much of him as he has. And maybe that should make him angry or bitter, but mostly it just makes him grateful. Because he knows that Sirius could walk away. And he can‚Äôt ever figure out why he doesn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Gabe says a little stiffly. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Äîyeah, yeah okay.‚Äù

He gets up off the bed and Remus feels a pang of guilt, finally lifting his head. ‚ÄúGabe‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay Remus.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said that already.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he‚Äôs standing over by his desk, back to Remus. ‚ÄúSorry I‚Äî‚Äú he exhales. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs stupid. I‚Äôm stupid. I don‚Äôt why I even‚ÄîI can‚Äôt believe I just‚Äîfuck, I‚Äôm so sorry if I made you uncomfortable.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey, no, Gabe, it‚Äôs fine. Really it‚Äôs fine. I‚Äôm just‚ÄîI‚Äôm seeing someone so I‚Ä¶‚Äù god Remus is far too awkward for this.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Gabe shoves his hands in his pockets. ‚ÄúShould have guessed, stunner like you,‚Äù he shoots Remus a cheeky grin over his shoulder but it doesn‚Äôt quite reach his eyes.

Remus scoffs. ‚ÄúPlease, you‚Äôre the one with the muscles and the tattoos.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou like my tattoos?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know what you look like.‚Äù

Gabe laughs but the sound dies far too quickly, hand coming up and rubbing over his shaved head.

‚ÄúSometimes I just think‚Ä¶I mean who‚Äôs ever gonna‚Äî‚Äù he exhales, looking down and kicking at the ground. ‚ÄúBecause there aren‚Äôt exactly werewolf clubs you know? And who else is ever going to want me?‚Äù He gives Remus a self-deprecating smile that nearly breaks his heart.

‚ÄúAll wizards don‚Äôt hate us you know.‚Äù

Gabe wobbles his head from side to side, expression skeptical. ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm sure there are a few of them who think we‚Äôd make real nice pets.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll find someone Gabe,‚Äù Remus perseveres. ‚ÄúI swear you will.‚Äù

The other boy nods. ‚ÄúSure, yeah,‚Äù tone falsely cheery. ‚ÄúSorry it‚Äôs, you know,‚Äù he gestures outside towards the sky. ‚ÄúFull moon always makes me fucking maudlin. Ignore me. I‚Äôll see you tomorrow yeah?‚Äù

Remus does his best not to grimace at the clear dismissal. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says, getting off the bed and heading for the door. ‚ÄúHey Gabe?‚Äù he calls out before he makes it into the hallway. The other boy actually looks at him properly this time. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre‚Ä¶we‚Äôre okay right? Because I‚Ä¶‚Äù but he doesn‚Äôt know what to say, only knows that it‚Äôs nice. Having Gabe. Having someone who doesn‚Äôt just sympathize but who understands.

Gabe smiles, genuinely this time, even if it is a little bruised. ‚ÄúYeah Remus, yeah we‚Äôre all good. Promise.‚Äù

Remus nods, feeling only slightly better. ‚ÄúGoodnight.‚Äù

‚ÄúNight Remus.‚Äù

¬†

True to his word nothing changes between them. Not really. The next morning Gabe has the same smile on his face he always does, sitting next to Remus at the table and jabbing and poking him every time he wants to get his attention. Though Remus can‚Äôt help but feel that there‚Äôs something heavier about the way he looks at Ava and Liam.

About halfway through breakfast Jack comes into the room, making eye contact with Remus and instantly freezing. When Evelyn eventually shoves him in an attempt to get to the kitchen table he jumps, quickly turning around and practically jogging out of the room. Remus sighs.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk to him,‚Äù Gabe says, voice low.

Remus pauses for a second before shaking his head. ‚ÄúNo I‚ÄîI think it has to be me.‚Äù

Gabe looks at him uncertainly. ‚ÄúYou sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says, with more confidence than he feels. ‚ÄúYeah tomorrow I‚Äôll‚Ä¶pull him aside or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Gabe swallows a mouthful of eggs.

At that moment a large bird flutters into the kitchen through the open window, an eagle Remus thinks, it‚Äôs sudden appearance making several of the younger kids scream. To be fair, it‚Äôs not a particularly friendly looking creature.

Mia takes one look at it and rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúOh Jesus Fen,‚Äù she mutters under her breath as she gets up, going over to where the bird has perched itself on the counter and untying the letter from its leg. It squawks indignantly at her, as though offended, but she silences it with a sharp ‚ÄúSh.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought you guys got letters by Muggle post?‚Äù Remus mutters to Gabe who‚Äôs watching Mia intently.

‚ÄúWe do. Usually.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat mother‚Äî‚Äú Mia quickly cuts herself off with a side look at the children who are still eyeing the bird on the counter with great suspicion. ‚Äú‚Äîtrucker,‚Äù she finishes eventually.

‚ÄúNice save,‚Äù Ava calls out, but Mia only bats her words away, eyes scanning and re-scanning the letter in her hands.

‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù Gabe asks, food forgotten as his knuckles tap nervously on the tabletop. ‚ÄúIs it the law? Has it passed?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, not that,‚Äù Mia sighs, pinching the bridge of her nose. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Greyback,‚Äù Remus instantly feels the hair on the back of his neck stand up. ‚ÄúHe wants to meet. To‚Ä¶talk,‚Äù she laughs dryly.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Liam asks. ‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù

‚ÄúToday.‚Äù

‚ÄúOn the full moon?‚Äù Gabe demands indignantly.

‚ÄúYes, well, you know him, he likes to be dramatic,‚Äù she lets out another sigh, leaning more heavily against the counter. It‚Äôs clear the full moon is drawing on her, she has less energy than normal, the bags under her eyes more pronounced, her shoulders slightly stooped.

‚ÄúYou could refuse‚Äîmake him pick another date?‚Äù Liam offers up.

Mia smiles ruefully. ‚ÄúI expect he would come anyway. He‚Äôd just be in a worse mood.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll go with you then,‚Äù Ava says.

For a minute Mia doesn‚Äôt answer, clearly thinking. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says finally.

‚ÄúNo!‚Äù Gabe begins outraged. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

But she holds up her hand to silence him. ‚ÄúAva and Liam, you two stay here, get everyone ready for the full moon. Gabe,‚Äù she looks very pointedly at him, ‚Äúyou can come but only if you promise to behave, you understand?‚Äù

Gabe‚Äôs mouth has formed a thin line but he nods his head curtly. ‚ÄúI understand.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù she looks down the table. ‚ÄúAlexandra‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYes, yes I‚Äôll come,‚Äù she groans slightly as she stretches in her seat. ‚ÄúI just wish my back didn‚Äôt feel like it got snapped in half last night.‚Äù

Mia gives her a dry smile. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre getting old.‚Äù

‚ÄúSpeak for yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll leave by noon, meet him in the clearing, I want to get this over with. We‚Äôll all only feel worse the later in the day it gets,‚Äù Mia‚Äôs eyes go to the clock on the wall. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll write back to him now.‚Äù

‚ÄúMia?‚Äù Remus finds his voice just as she starts heading out of the room. She stops in the doorway, turning back to him. ‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú Remus hasn‚Äôt seen Greyback, not since the night he was bitten. He doesn‚Äôt know how that will feel. What he‚Äôll do. But there is a part of him that can‚Äôt bear not finding out. ‚ÄúCan I come?‚Äù

Alexandra snorts. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

But Mia is more hesitant, staring at him so intently that it is work for Remus to stop himself from squirming.

‚ÄúIt might be useful,‚Äù Gabe jumps in. ‚ÄúHaving someone who actually knows how to use their wand.‚Äù

Mia rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúFine. Remus you can come. But you will do as I say, do you understand?‚Äù

He nods quickly, causing a small spark of pain to shoot through his skull. Damn full moon. ‚ÄúAbsolutely. I‚Äôll do whatever you want.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù she nods curtly. ‚ÄúTwelve o‚Äôclock sharp in front of the house.‚Äù And with that she disappears from the room, the giant eagle fluttering after her.

¬†

As they trudge through the dense forest Remus struggles to keep his heartbeat at a reasonable pace, fingers constantly playing with his wand, reminding him it‚Äôs there. He rarely uses it here, except when he‚Äôs teaching the kids. He learned early on that any casual displays of magic make the people of Lupercal uncomfortable. But it leaves him feeling ill prepared for this meeting. Rusty. It doesn‚Äôt help that it‚Äôs so close to the full moon, all his senses over ripe. Every smell and sound and branch brushing against his skin ten times more intense.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be alright,‚Äù Gabe says quietly. They‚Äôre walking side by side, Mia and Alexandra up ahead. Gabe brushes the back of Remus‚Äôs hand with his and then pulls away.

‚ÄúHave you met him before?‚Äù Remus asks, happy to find his voice doesn‚Äôt betray the boiling cauldron of fear and anxiety he feels on the inside. He isn‚Äôt ready for this moment. It‚Äôs come too soon. Too suddenly. He‚Äôs wondered for years what he would do if he ever came face to face with the man who did this to him. He still doesn‚Äôt have an answer.

‚ÄúOnce,‚Äù Gabe says grimly, ‚Äúlike this. He has followers but not like Mia. He wants her support.‚Äù

Something crawls under Remus‚Äôs skin. ‚ÄúSupport for what exactly? Attacking fucking children?‚Äù

Gabe doesn‚Äôt answer right away, teeth biting his lower lip. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a bit more‚Ä¶complicated than that.‚Äù

Which is not at all what he was expecting Gabe to say, and Remus feels his feet stumble. ‚ÄúWhat is complicated about it? He‚Äôs a monster.‚Äù

He sees Gabe flinch at the use of the word. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI‚Äôm not saying he isn‚Äôt. I‚Äôm just‚Ä¶I‚Äôm just saying it‚Äôs complicated.‚Äù

Remus wants to push him on this but it‚Äôs at that moment that they step through a particularly thick patch of bush into a small open area, Mia and Alexandra coming to a stop.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre meeting him here?‚Äù Remus murmurs, looking around at the surrounding trees as though expecting Greyback to jump out at them, his nerves accelerating again, bouncing against the walls of his skin, turning his stomach.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre meeting him here,‚Äù Gabe nods.

They stand in silence, Remus vibrating, passing the weight back and forth between his feet, too nervous to interrogate Gabe, too nervous to speak period. He has faint memories of Greyback, nothing solid, nothing concrete. He‚Äôs done his best over the years to scrub those memories from his head. Taking bleach and wire brushes to them. He wants them faded. And worn. And distant. Wants to be able to look back at them without feeling. Like they happened to someone else. Because they did really, in the end. They happened to a boy who was whole.

But the pieces of Greyback he has‚Äîrough voiced, huge, leather skinned, swelling black eyes‚Äîthose images haunt him. His constant nightmare. The face he sometimes sees right before he turns. The one he is always afraid will be waiting for him the next time he looks in the mirror.

‚ÄúOh honestly,‚Äù Mia says suddenly, snapping Remus out of his thoughts. He‚Äôs so jumpy that he actually startles, Gabe sending him a concerned look that he tries to wave off, shaking out his shoulders and settling himself.

‚ÄúYou need to tell him to cut that shit out,‚Äù Alexandra mutters, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fucking embarrassing. And‚Ä¶tacky.‚Äù

Remus isn‚Äôt sure what they‚Äôre talking about until Gabe elbows him, nodding above. There, in the sky, Remus can see two eagles, like the one from this morning, circling above them.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs with the birds?‚Äù he asks before he can stop himself.

Mia sighs, she‚Äôs standing facing the trees in front of them, feet slightly apart, shoulders squared, hands clasped behind her‚Äîlooking every inch the general. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs being poetic.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs being a tosser,‚Äù Alexandra corrects, causing Gabe to snort.

Remus looks up again and then back down. ‚ÄúI‚Äîsorry I‚Äôm still kind of lost?‚Äù

‚ÄúEagles,‚Äù Mia says wearily. ‚ÄúAre one of the ways that Muggles used to think the gods were communicating with them. They would be sent by Zeus to deliver messages, not literal messages of course, more‚Ä¶metaphorical ones.‚Äù

This all sounds mad to Remus. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äîso he thinks he‚Äôs a God?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell I‚Äôm certainly not a man.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs head snaps towards the trees, heart running head first into his ribs at the sound of that voice. He hears screaming.

He sees claws.

And stained sheets.

A pair of children‚Äôs pyjama‚Äôs ripped.

Teeth and teeth and teeth.

‚ÄúHello Fen,‚Äù Mia says wearily as a hulking figure pulls himself out of the shadows. Just behind him are two others‚Äîa woman and a man. They‚Äôre all dressed similarly but not identical. In black clothes, and heavy boots, looking a little worse for wear though in a way that makes it hard to tell whether it‚Äôs on purpose or not.

Greyback smiles and Remus notices that his teeth aren‚Äôt right, like his jaw is too big for his face, his canines too sharp. Wolf‚Äôs teeth, he realizes. Fuck, is it possible to choose to only partially transform? He looks briefly at Gabe and then back at Greyback. This isn‚Äôt the time for questions but Merlin it would be really nice if at some point in his life someone had thought to tell him a thing or two about fucking werewolves.

‚ÄúMimi, always a pleasure.‚Äù

Alexandra snorts, bringing his attention to her. ‚ÄúAlex,‚Äù he dips his head in acknowledgement, ‚ÄúI see you‚Äôre still a raging bitch.‚Äù

When she smiles she has almost as many teeth as Greyback. ‚ÄúRight back at you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou wanted to talk,‚Äù Mia cuts in, sounding like someone already reaching the limits of her patience. ‚ÄúSo talk.‚Äù

Greyback does not appear at all deterred by her terse tone. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs our little Charlotte doing?‚Äù

A growl rubbles in Gabe‚Äôs chest at the same moment that Alexandra indignantly shouts ‚ÄúAre you fucking kidding me?‚Äù

But Mia raises her hand, waving Alexandra off, eyes firmly on Greyback. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not here to play games. Say your piece or we‚Äôre leaving.‚Äù

The woman behind him growls, eyeing Mia with dislike, but when she moves towards her Greyback calls her off the same way Mia did with Alexandra. It feels a bit like the two leaders are talking without opening their mouthes.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve had an offer from the Dark Lord,‚Äù Greyback says eventually.

Remus‚Äôs heart trips. This is exactly what Moody and Dumbledore had been afraid of.

Alexandra snorts. ‚ÄúLord? Really? You know, you never struck me as a monarchist Fenrir.‚Äù

Remus expects him to get angry, disrespecting Voldemort isn‚Äôt something most Death Eaters take lightly. But Greyback doesn‚Äôt seem to care. In fact he grins, causing the white scars crisscrossing his face to become more visible. They distort him in an unpleasant way and Remus can‚Äôt help but wonder if his scars do the same.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm anything for the right price baby.‚Äù

Alexandra makes a revolted face. ‚ÄúSay baby again and I‚Äôm going to lose my breakfast.‚Äù

Greyback opens his mouth as if to retaliate but Mia cuts him off. ‚ÄúGet to the point Fen,‚Äù she snaps. ‚ÄúWhat did he offer and what in the hell does it have to do with us?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs willing to promise werewolves fair treatment under his rule,‚Äù Alexandra snorts again but this time Greyback ignores her and keeps going. ‚ÄúThe laws against us will be struck down and we‚Äôll be allowed to work Ministry jobs, to campaign for spots on the Wizenmagot, allowed to vote.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt vote?‚Äù Remus hisses. Gabe just gives him a look. A ‚Äúthis is not the time but also how the hell did you not know that‚Äù look. Surely his father should have mentioned this? Of course, that would have meant acknowledging that Remus was a werewolf. Which Lyall Lupin rarely, if ever, allowed himself to do.

‚ÄúBut only if you can bring him enough people right?‚Äù Mia asks, sounding bored. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why you‚Äôre here? You don‚Äôt have enough supporters to make it worthwhile for him on your own?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh don‚Äôt play coy, this is everything you‚Äôve ever wanted. You could even get your old job back,‚Äù he gives her a grin.

‚ÄúOur lives for there‚Äôs then,‚Äù Mia says. ‚ÄúThe Muggle borns are stripped of their rights and we get to fill their places?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how the world works Mia,‚Äù he says undeterred. ‚ÄúPeople always think it‚Äôs a climb to the top but no one is ever actually getting any higher, they‚Äôre just pushing everyone around them lower.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a depressing outlook to have.‚Äù

Greyback tilts his head ever so slightly to the side. ‚ÄúAnd how is the moral high ground working out for you?‚Äù he asks, voice pleasant but with a sharpness beneath his words. ‚ÄúHave they started listening yet? I mean, surely they must have, when you ask them so nicely. Oh please Mr. Minister Sir, I promise I‚Äôm such a good little werewolf, I never do anything wrong, please let me have a job.‚Äù

The woman behind him laughs.

Mia says nothing, watching his mockery of her with an unreadable expression.

‚ÄúAfter all your letter writing and meeting having and civility Lupin is still gonna pass his law,‚Äù Remus cringes at the mention of his father. ‚ÄúAnd all this,‚Äù Greyback waves behind them, ‚Äúis going to be taken away.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to pass,‚Äù Mia says finally, voice solid as a fortress wall. ‚ÄúAnd if it does we‚Äôll fight it.‚Äù

Greyback laughs. ‚ÄúFight it? Come on Mia, you can‚Äôt fight it. Not the way you want to. We have both lost enough people to know that, haven‚Äôt we?‚Äù and when Mia goes silent again, he takes a step closer, causing all of them to tense, Alexandra reaching for the hilt of the dagger Remus now sees resting at her hip.

‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you tired of burying all your friends?‚Äù he asks in a low voice.

It‚Äôs clear that there is a history here that Remus wasn‚Äôt aware of, but he can‚Äôt quite figure out what it is. Can‚Äôt quite see the shape of their relationship.

‚ÄúSo what are you suggesting Fen? Huh? That we run around attacking children?‚Äù she spits back at him.

There is the flicker of something like hurt in his dark eyes. It surprises Remus, but it‚Äôs gone so quickly he hardly has time to process it.

‚ÄúCome now, aren‚Äôt you the one always preaching about how it‚Äôs not a curse? I‚Äôm just embracing my nature. Werewolves hunt the young, we always have, it‚Äôs in our blood. You know the histories‚ÄîBurgot, Verdun, Garnier, our forefathers,‚Äù he laughs cruelly, clearly aiming to hurt, holding his arms out wide. Remus notices the claws at the ends of his fingers. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm being free Mia, isn‚Äôt that what you wanted?‚Äù

‚ÄúIs this the kind sermonizing that wins you supporters?‚Äù she asks dryly. ‚ÄúBecause I have to admit, I‚Äôm finding it a little underwhelming.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm giving these children a gift,‚Äù he growls. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm boosting our numbers at the same time. Win, win.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs hands curl into fists. He isn‚Äôt exactly sure when he slid his wand from his sleeve into his palm but his nails dig into the handle now. A gift. A fucking gift. He‚Äôs shaking, Gabe periodically shooting him worried looks out of the corner of his eyes.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Mia goes on dryly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure they‚Äôre very grateful to have been ripped from their families. To have their lives irrevocably altered.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the love for your wolf now Mia, you hypocrite,‚Äù he leers, but Mia is undeterred.

‚ÄúI am not ignorant of the way the world works,‚Äù she snaps back at him. ‚ÄúWhatever my views of Lycanthrope may be I know that many don‚Äôt share them and that makes this life hard. I would never force it on anyone who did not ask for it,‚Äù she says sharply. ‚ÄúA sentiment you used share.‚Äù

That last sentence clearly stings. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre dying Mia, we don‚Äôt have time to hope that they change, we need to force them to. If their children are affected they will have no choice but to start listening to us. Kids are a good motivator, you of all people should understand that.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe abandoned children in my house would disagree with you,‚Äù she says coldly.

Remus sees flashes of his father‚Äôs face, the empty way he looked at him after the attack, the way he kept his distance, home as little as possible.

‚ÄúWell if those sons of bitches are cold hearted enough that they‚Äôll abandon their own children what makes you think they‚Äôre ever going to change their opinions for you?‚Äù

Mia shrugs. ‚ÄúI have hope. But I refuse to become the monster they all accuse me of being.‚Äù

Greyback shakes his head, hand rubbing the stubble covering his jaw. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a monster to them either way. Nothing you do will make them see you any different. If we don‚Äôt start fighting back they‚Äôll crush us. They‚Äôre already crushing us,‚Äù this last sentence is said under his breath.

‚ÄúAnd you think Voldemort will be any different?‚Äù Mia asks. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going after the Muggle borns, what makes you think he won‚Äôt turn on you next?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt matter,‚Äù he says gruffly. ‚ÄúAll we need is a chance, a chance to grow stronger. By the time he comes for us we‚Äôll be able to defend ourselves.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a long pause and Remus starts to grow fidgety again, unable to tear his eyes away from Greyback. Memorizing every inch of him. He‚Äôs smaller than Remus remembers him, though he is, by no means, small. And despite the teeth and nails and scars, he is still made of flesh and blood, still human. At least in parts. That‚Äôs comforting, Remus thinks, to finally have his nightmare be something solid right in front of him. Something that can be fought. Destroyed.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt agree with your choices Fen, I‚Äôve made that clear. I don‚Äôt agree with Voldemort either. I‚Äôll not hurt others to further myself. Now get the fuck off my property.‚Äù Mia moves as if to turn away, back towards the house, but Greyback growls, lunging forward‚Äîwhich all the reason Remus needs to pull his wand.

Alexandra is moving too, dagger drawn from her belt, but Remus‚Äôs spell hits Greyback first, sending him slamming into the tree behind him, knocking the wind out of him. The man who was at his side lunges forward but Alexandra catches him, getting him on his knees, blade to his neck. Meanwhile, Remus fires off a curse at the female werewolf, ropes shooting from his wand, binding her up and sending her squirming to the ground.

Remus steps over her on his way to Greyback. He thinks he hears Gabe call out to him, maybe Mia too, but he pays no attention. Shoving the man in front of him back against the tree he‚Äôs trying to pull away from. Greyback has a few inches on Remus and probably a hundred pounds, but Remus has a wand. He jabs it right into the other man‚Äôs neck.

There‚Äôs a moment of bewildered confusion before Remus sees recognition in his dark eyes, a grin returning to his face. ‚ÄúWell, well, well, if it isn‚Äôt baby Lupin. You sure have grown up.‚Äù Remus is shaking, with fear, with anger, he can feel the stillness around them, as everyone watches, violence heavy in the air. ‚ÄúTell me,‚Äù the man goes on, ‚Äúdoes your daddy know where you are?‚Äù he laughs. ‚ÄúMerlin, I bet it fucking eats him up inside. I bet it rots his fucking soul.‚Äù The laughing continues.

‚ÄúShut. Up.‚Äù Remus punctuates his words by jabbing his wand further into Greyback‚Äôs neck. There's no fear in the other man, which only serves to make Remus angrier.

‚ÄúTell me,‚Äù Greyback goes on, somehow still managing to speak even with Remus practically crushing his windpipe. ‚ÄúHow does he do eh? How does he look you in the eye while he strips away your fucking rights? Your fucking freedom?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt.

Remus nearly says, the words trembling on his tongue.

He hasn‚Äôt in years.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù Mia says from behind him, stepping closer, like she‚Äôs going to try and pull him away, except Remus isn‚Äôt done yet.

‚ÄúYou think you gave me a fucking gift?‚Äù he snarls through clenched teeth, forcing himself to look into Greyback‚Äôs eyes even though it makes the child in him scream in terror. ‚ÄúYou ruined my life.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt ruin your life kid,‚Äù he says, like it‚Äôs nothing, like Remus means nothing. ‚ÄúThat was your parents.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know shit about my parents,‚Äù he‚Äôs never wanted to kill anyone as much as he does right now. Like maybe if Greyback stops breathing this curse will let go of him. The teeth marks in his skin will disappear. And he‚Äôll finally just get to be himself. Just Remus. Nothing special. Blissfully ordinary. It‚Äôs all he‚Äôs wanted since he was five years old.

‚ÄúI know your father‚Äôs a right bastard.‚Äù

Remus can feel the wolf prowling under his skin. Ready to pull to the surface To come out. He wonders what would happen if he let go now, the way Gabe is always telling him to. He wonders if that would be enough to scare Greyback. Give him a taste of the fear he‚Äôs inflicted on so many others.

‚ÄúRemus‚Äî‚Äù Mia tries again, but he cuts her off.

‚ÄúYou killed my mum.‚Äù

Greyback scoffs. ‚ÄúI never touched your mum.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou killed her, you made me this‚Ä¶ this thing and it killed her. Knowing what my life would be like, knowing she couldn‚Äôt protect me. And I had a front row seat. I had to watch the life drain out of her knowing it was because of me,‚Äù his voice cracks, pathetic and painful. ‚ÄúYou did that to her. To me. Fuck your politics I really couldn‚Äôt give a shit. You killed my mum. And if you think you‚Äôre walking out of these woods‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou gonna kill me baby Lupin?‚Äù Greyback interrupts, though Remus thinks there‚Äôs something different about his voice now. Something heavier. Darker. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you do it like a man huh?‚Äù he pushes. ‚ÄúPut down the little wand and use your fucking teeth.‚Äù

And Remus thinks about it. Almost does it, in fact. It would be so fucking satisfying. To taste his screams.

‚ÄúRemus,‚Äù Mia has her hand on his shoulder now, causing Remus to jerk, he hadn‚Äôt realized she‚Äôd gotten so close. ‚ÄúYou have to let him go.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? So he can go off and attack some other kid?‚Äù Remus feels like he‚Äôs coming apart. The moon.

His mum.

The screaming ringing in his ears.

His screaming.

Those black soulless eyes right in front of him. Taunting him. Boasting about what they‚Äôve done. What they‚Äôve taken.

‚ÄúThis stops now,‚Äù Remus barely holds in a growl, not knowing if belongs to him or the wolf. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm stopping this now.‚Äù

He‚Äôs never killed someone.

But he reckons he could.

It‚Äôs in his blood after all. Isn‚Äôt that what Greyback said?

‚ÄúI understand why you‚Äôre upset‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDo you?‚Äù he snaps, because he highly doubts that, but Mia presses on.

‚ÄúI need you to listen Remus,‚Äù her voice remains steady, calm. ‚ÄúI need you to tap into that other part of yourself and listen. He isn‚Äôt alone.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt understand, too far gone for anything but straight forward statements. ‚ÄúWhat are you talking about?‚Äù

But before she can answer Remus hears Gabe cursing behind them.

‚ÄúHow many do you count?‚Äù Alexandra asks.

‚ÄúI hear six heartbeats,‚Äù Gabe fires back.

‚ÄúHeartbeats? What the hell are you talking about?‚Äù Remus repeats, not that he cares, not really. He should just do it. No point in talking about this. In stalling.

‚ÄúMerlin, you really are repressed aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúShut up Fen,‚Äù Mia snaps before Remus can. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs brought others with him. They‚Äôre hiding in the woods,‚Äù she explains to Remus.

Remus shifts, feeling slightly uneasy. ‚ÄúWell, if they‚Äôre anything like this lot,‚Äù he nods to the two werewolves already on the ground. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll manage.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs us they‚Äôve been instructed to attack if things go wrong here,‚Äù Mia says, still calm.

It takes a second for that to sink in. ‚ÄúThe house,‚Äù Remus finally hisses and Greyback has the audacity to smile at him. ‚ÄúBut how would they even‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThey can hear his heartbeat,‚Äù Gabe answers before Remus can even finish the question. ‚ÄúThe same way we can hear their‚Äôs.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Remus curses, staring right into Greyback‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù

For a minute he pretends that he‚Äôs still going to do it, pretends that he‚Äôll say the words and watch with delight as the green light zaps the life from Greyback‚Äôs eyes. Pretends he could make it back to the house in time. That he could guarantee none of the kids would get hurt‚Äîmore hurt than they already have been.

And then,

when he‚Äôs done all his pretending,

he steps back.

‚ÄúGood boy,‚Äù Greyback leers, standing up and straightening out his shirt.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù Mia grabs Remus‚Äôs arm, pulling him away, causing him to wince.

‚ÄúYou really need to learn to control your pups Mia,‚Äù Greyback laughs. Remus swears to god he‚Äôs going to punch him but Mia has already spun around.

‚ÄúOne day Fen, when you aren‚Äôt threatening my family, when I get you on your own, I will kill you. For what you‚Äôve done. For who you‚Äôve become,‚Äù her eyes are as unwavering as her voice and more than any time before Greyback looks broken open by those words.

‚ÄúLiar,‚Äù he says, but his voice is quiet and Remus thinks uncertain. Nothing about Mia is uncertain.

‚ÄúI guess we‚Äôll see,‚Äù she turns back around. ‚ÄúLets go, back to the house, now. And Fen, I mean it, you and your lot get off my property.‚Äù

They head wordlessly back into the trees. Remus shaking, constantly checking over his shoulder, expecting Greyback or one of the other werewolves to come after them, but no one does. He tries to listen like the others seem to be able to, searching out heartbeats, but the only one he can hear is his own.

Gabe presses ever so lightly into his side. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll teach you,‚Äù he says, like he can read Remus‚Äôs mind. Remus just nods.

The walk back is slow and brutal. The moon is really starting to effect them and by the time they reach the house Remus‚Äôs whole body is vibrating with pain. There are no children playing outside like their normally would be, no one lounging in the chairs on the front porch. There is something convenient, Remus realizes then, about feeling like shit with a bunch of other people who are also feeling like shit.

"I swear to God,‚Äù Alexandra mutters as the four of them drag themselves into the kitchen. ‚ÄúThe next time he asks to meet on the full moon I‚Äôm stabbing first and asking questions second.‚Äù Remus collapses into one of the chairs at the kitchen table, Gabe sitting next to him, Mia starting the kettle.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna take a nap,‚Äù Alexandra says, chugging a glass of water before letting it clatter into the sink. ‚ÄúYou need me for anything?‚Äù

Mia shakes her head, giving her a wane smile. It‚Äôs about as tired as Remus has ever seen her. ‚ÄúNo, go on, we‚Äôll debrief tomorrow.‚Äù

‚ÄúJoy,‚Äù Alexandra says flatly, nodding at Remus and Gabe as she heads out of the back door, Remus‚Äôs eyes unable to resist looking at the dagger still hanging from her hip. There‚Äôs silence as they wait for the kettle to boil, Mia bringing them mugs of tea without even asking. Remus is grateful. There‚Äôs something settling about the warmth of it. The familiarity.

‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt wrong you know,‚Äù Gabe breaks the silence finally, causing both Remus and Mia to snap their heads in his direction. He rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúNot about‚Äîobviously not about everything, I‚Äôm not saying we should start going after kids, but‚Ä¶‚Äù he trails off, looking at them expectantly. Neither Mia nor Remus fill in the blank and eventually Gabe sighs.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre at the mercy of the Ministry,‚Äù he goes on. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt listen to us, they don‚Äôt respect us, everyone else is afraid of us. We need‚Ä¶we need to do something. Something has to change.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are doing things,‚Äù Mia says calmly, but Gabe only shakes his head.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a little kid anymore,‚Äù he says, eyes intense, giving Remus the impression this conversation has been had before. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt hide the truth from me. We aren‚Äôt making progress. The laws against us are piling up and Greyback is right, we can‚Äôt fight them with petitions and legal challenges. We need to get‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúViolent?‚Äù she cuts him off, voice sharp.

He sighs, looking exhausted, a hand ghosting over his face. ‚ÄúI mean‚Ä¶yeah. At this point, maybe. They haven‚Äôt left us with a whole lot of other options.‚Äù

She eyes him for a long moment. Remus knows that they‚Äôre especially close‚ÄîGabe and Mia‚Äîhe‚Äôs her second in command really, her successor, the one she‚Äôll leave the farm to when the time comes. There is a great deal of warmth in the way she looks at him now. Warmth and fear.

Eventually she turns to Remus, raising her brow, clearly waiting for an opinion. This moment is important. This moment is the reason he‚Äôs here. To keep the wolves from going over to the other side.

‚ÄúI think‚Äî‚Äù he exhales. ‚ÄúI think if you join Voldemort you‚Äôll never be able to forgive yourselves. They‚Äôll be no coming back from that, no getting out from under him, whatever Greyback says.‚Äù

There‚Äôs another pause and then Mia nods. ‚ÄúI agree.‚Äù

Gabe makes a frustrated noise, ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs not that simple, we‚Äî‚Äú

Mia hold up her palm and Gabe goes quiet instantly. ‚ÄúLike I said to Alex, we‚Äôll debrief tomorrow.‚Äù

Gabe rolls his eyes, pushing his chair back from the table and getting to his feet. ‚ÄúFine, I‚Äôm going to take a nap too then.‚Äù He lingers in the doorway, eyes on Remus, expecting him to follow.

Remus only nods at the mug between his hands. ‚ÄúGonna finish my tea,‚Äù he says, answering the question no one asked. He watches Gabe‚Äôs eyes pass between him and Mia, before eventually nodding. Steps echoing on the stairs as he heads up to his room.

Remus stares back down at his mug, the heat quickly receding. He takes in a deep breath, aware that Mia is watching him. Waiting.

‚ÄúYou and Greyback?‚Äù he says finally, not entirely sure how to ask the question.

Thankfully, Mia seems to understand. ‚ÄúWe were turned around the same time, kind of, grew up together in a way, I suppose. Figured out how to‚Ä¶manage all this,‚Äù she waves flippantly at the air. ‚ÄúThere were a few years where we only had one another‚Ä¶hard years. But, well‚Ä¶‚Äù she trails off for a moment, something undeniably sad in her eyes. ‚ÄúAs you can see, we‚Äôve chosen rather different paths.‚Äù

Remus tries to take that it in, tries to imagine a younger Greyback, perhaps one less willing to sink his teeth into people. Tries to picture him as the type of person you could call a friend. His imagination struggles.

‚ÄúThe names he mentioned, when he talked about attacking children being natural to us, in our blood‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Mia says knowingly. ‚ÄúYes, some very famous werewolves, all French actually. The French wolves have always been a tad more flamboyant.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd they were‚Ä¶like Greyback?‚Äù

She meets his gaze. ‚ÄúIn a sense.‚Äù

It feels like something is crawling under his skin, slithering around his spine, the sense of unease and anxiety growing. Though he doesn‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs from the moon or Greyback.

‚ÄúDo you think he‚Äôs right?‚Äù Remus asks finally, throat tight.

‚ÄúRight?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you think it‚Äôs in our blood?‚Äù

Sirius, James sand Peter have never talked much about what it‚Äôs like to watch Remus transform. He knows that there are moments when they‚Äôre nervous, frightened, but to his face they‚Äôve never‚Äînothing changed. He‚Äôd thought it might, after the first time they came to the Shack, but it didn‚Äôt. They didn‚Äôt even bat an eye. Too excited to have pulled it off in the first place.

But Snape.

Snape never looked at Remus the same after that night. And for the first time in a long time it had made Remus wonder if he really was a monster. If Dumbledore had made a mistake.

There‚Äôs a long pause before Mia speaks again.

‚ÄúDo you know the story of your name?‚Äù she asks, pulling Remus from his memories.

He blinks at her, brain moving a bit slowly. ‚ÄúLupin?‚Äù he asks, laughing dryly. ‚ÄúDerived from lupus, latin for wolf, believe me, the irony isn‚Äôt lost on me.‚Äù

She smiles gently. ‚ÄúNot your last name, your first name.‚Äù

That takes him by surprise. ‚ÄúI‚Äîno, I never‚ÄîI think it was mother‚Äôs choice. Something from a book I always figured, she liked to read.‚Äù

Mia nods. ‚ÄúRomulos and Remus were the founders of Rome. So the myths say anyway.‚Äù

He stares blankly back at her, not knowing at all what to do with that information. Mia seems to have expected this response, or lack thereof, and continues unprompted.

‚ÄúThey were twin brothers, their father a god, their mother of noble blood, and the King of the city they were born in was worried that they might pose a threat to his rule. So he ordered them killed.‚Äù

Remus grimaces. ‚ÄúBit harsh.‚Äù

‚ÄúVery harsh,‚Äù Mia agrees with a small smile. ‚ÄúSo the guards brought them to the river but they couldn‚Äôt quite bring themselves to commit the actual physical act of infanticide, so they left the babies on the bank. Thinking they would be washed away and drowned or eaten by some animal.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus.‚Äù

Mia laughs. ‚ÄúYes, humans can be rather callous when it serves them‚ÄîMuggles and Wizards both.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut they didn‚Äôt die?‚Äù he presses.

Mia shakes her head. ‚ÄúThey were saved, by a wolf who couldn‚Äôt ignore the crying of children.‚Äù

Well, that was not exactly how Remus saw this story going. ‚ÄúA wolf?‚Äù

‚ÄúA she-wolf came to them, saved them from the riverbank, bringing them back to her cave where she nursed them and protected them until eventually a farmer found them,‚Äù Mia sips her tea before reaching across the table and taking Remus‚Äôs hand, giving it a squeeze.

‚ÄúYou see Remus, there is good and bad in all things. In all life. In all people. We all have histories we would rather we did not, but we get to decide what shapes us. We get to decide who we want to be, what parts of ourselves we want to act on. For me, wolves are not the monsters under the beds of children. They are the mothers, protecting and caring for them. That is what is in my blood.‚Äù

Her eyes are bright, holding onto Remus just as firmly as her hand. And he realizes, suddenly, that he‚Äôs missed this. Missed this desperately. Having a mother.

‚ÄúSo you tell me Remus,‚Äù she goes on eventually, gaze no less intense. ‚ÄúWhat is in your blood?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt want her to let go.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he practically whispers. Because he really doesn‚Äôt. He has spent so much of his life trying to keep everything in, everything under control, that he has no idea who is when he lets go. No idea who he is when he is free. The other day was only a taste. And it was terrifying. And intoxicating. And he wants more.

He thinks he might see disappointment in Mia‚Äôs eyes but she only smiles, thumb brushing over the back of his hand before she eventually lets go. Remus misses the reassurance of her touch almost immediately.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs alright, you‚Äôre young, you have plenty of time to figure it out.‚Äù She gives him a wink. ‚ÄúGo, you look exhausted, rest, and I‚Äôll see you tonight.‚Äù

He is exhausted, more so than he has been in a long time. Still, he‚Äôs reluctant to go. He‚Äôs only just gotten to the back door when she calls out to him again.

‚ÄúThe cave,‚Äù she says, eyes sparkling. ‚ÄúThe cave the she-wolf took the babies to, it has a name. Can you guess what it is?‚Äù

The question feels so out of left field that for a moment Remus‚Äôs mind pulls a blank. And then: ‚ÄúLupercal?‚Äù

Her smile widens. ‚ÄúFate certainly does work in mysterious ways huh?‚Äù

¬†

He transforms under the night sky.

Transforms with the sharp crisp air of the woods in his lungs.

With Gabe at his side.

‚ÄúLet go,‚Äù he breathes heavy, chest heaving, colour high in his cheeks, eyes blown wide. ‚ÄúLet go, let go, let go.‚Äù

And he does.

And he does.

And he does.

Oh how happy.

To feel dirt beneath his paws.

And pack nuzzling his fur.

Oh how happy to play.

To sing.

To chase.

They howl into the night and their voices mix together, reaching up above and tangling with the stars.

Oh how happy.

How happy.

To be wolf.

¬†

The next day is slow. It always is. Most of them remain in their rooms. But dinner is had together, as always. And though Remus is tired and sore, with a few cuts here and there, he feels better than he has in ages.

‚ÄúSomeone needs to separate you two,‚Äù Ava says as she falls into step with him and Gabe on their walk across the yard towards the main house. She‚Äôs clutching a travel mug to her chest. She has bags under her eyes and a split lip but otherwise she‚Äôs unmarked.

It‚Äôs something he‚Äôs noticed, about the wolves here, at least the young ones. The lack of scars. Gabe and Ava have barely any. When Remus asked Gabe about it he‚Äôd looked sad. ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt normal you know, for wolves to hurt themselves,‚Äù he‚Äôd said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Ä¶almost an anxiety response. Happens when we‚Äôre alone. Trapped. We‚Äôre meant to have a pack.‚Äù

‚ÄúListen,‚Äù Gabe says now, half laughing. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt our fault,‚Äù he gestures at her lip. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one who got in the middle of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell you were getting the kids all worked up, chasing one another like you were.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw Ava, don‚Äôt be jealous.‚Äù He reaches over and gives her a nuggie.

‚ÄúOi,‚Äù she swats at him with the hand not holding the coffee cup. ‚ÄúGet off you little‚Äî‚Äú
