There‚Äôs a pause, and when Snape speaks again his voice has changed, like he‚Äôs making a conscious effort to take the antagonism out of his words. ‚ÄúI thought I understood what it was‚Ä¶And then I saw your face yesterday, in the kitchen‚Ä¶I‚Äôve seen that expression before.‚Äù

Regulus flinches, embarrassed, but he doesn‚Äôt think Snape notices.

‚ÄúMy father‚Ä¶‚Äù

His voice trails off, leaving those words hanging in the air, letting them grow big. It takes Regulus a minute to realize that this isn‚Äôt supposed to be an attack. He had just assumed Snape was going to use Lucius against him the way he has always used everything else. And yet‚Ä¶there is something in that broken sentence that suggests otherwise.

‚ÄúMy father hates magic,‚Äù it sounds like the words are difficult, like each one is being pulled unwillingly from his mouth.

Regulus blinks, surprised by the sudden shift in the conversation. Slowly he loosens his grip on the table so that he can turn around. Snape is standing awkwardly in the the middle of the room, though to be honest he rarely looks anything but awkward, a scowl still on his face, though the displeasure doesn‚Äôt quite reach his eyes this time.

‚ÄúI thought your father was a wizard?‚Äù Regulus says finally, trying to let some of the tension in his body go.

Snape snorts. ‚ÄúOnly technically,‚Äù he looks like he has more to say so Regulus waits, and eventually; ‚ÄúHe takes it out on her, my mum. When I was a kid I used to think they were just fighting, that it was both of them you know? But‚Ä¶the older I got the more I realized that she wasn‚Äôt fighting back. I‚Äôd walk into the room afterwards and she‚Äôd be wearing that same expression you were yesterday and I just‚Ä¶I knew something wasn‚Äôt right.‚Äù

They‚Äôre both silent for a long time after that. Neither of them seeming to know what to do. Everything feeling just a little too vulnerable. A little too close to the bone.

‚ÄúI can handle Lucius,‚Äù Regulus says finally, because someone has to say something and it‚Äôs the best he can manage at the moment.

A humourless smile ghosts across Snape‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúYeah, that‚Äôs what she always says too. I tried to get her to leave, after I finished school, when I could help her. But‚Ä¶‚Äù

Before Regulus can think better of it the words are out of his mouth; ‚ÄúYou sound like my brother.‚Äù

Snape‚Äôs expression instantly shutters. ‚ÄúI am nothing like your brother,‚Äù the hatred in his words is so visceral Regulus swears he can feel it. Sharp and violent and festering.
But he only shrugs. ‚ÄúSuit yourself.‚Äù

¬†

It‚Äôs relatively quiet after that, until the potion is done. They cork it and then look at the vial, seemingly at a loss for what to do next.

‚ÄúI could test it on you?‚Äù Regulus offers sweetly, batting his lashes.

‚ÄúThe fuck you will,‚Äù Snape says. ‚ÄúHow about I test it on you?‚Äù

Regulus sighs, leaning forward on the table in front of him, inspecting the vial in his hands. If all has gone well, the next time this solution is exposed to oxygen it will change states and render anyone who inhales it senseless. Asleep. Something sharp cuts through his stomach at the thought of how dangerous that actually is. About who‚Äôs going to wield that power.

There‚Äôs a crack and Regulus looks up to see Kreacher standing in the middle of the room.

‚ÄúMaster Regulus, lunch is being ready sir, where shall I be serving it? In the dining room or‚Ä¶down here?‚Äù it is clear from the look on the house elf‚Äôs face, as he surveys the lab, which of those two locations he deems more suitable.

Regulus opens his mouth to respond when Snape beats him to it.

‚ÄúLets use him.‚Äù

Regulus looks over his shoulder. ‚ÄúUse him?‚Äù he repeats dumbly.

Snape nods at Kreacher. ‚ÄúLets test the potion out on him.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Regulus demands. ‚ÄúNo. We‚Äôre not‚Äîno. I‚Äôm not doing that. What the hell is wrong with you?‚Äù

Snape rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that what they‚Äôre for?‚Äù

Regulus is starting to get genuinely angry, and Boo can clearly sense it, pawing at the ground with his hoof, like he‚Äôs getting ready to charge.

‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs not. Also he has a fucking name.‚Äù

Snape rolls his eyes again. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre being ridiculous.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm being ridiculous!‚Äù Regulus says outraged. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one suggesting we use my house elf as a lab rat.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen house elves used for worse.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell not by me.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike I said, ridiculous.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, you know what‚Äî‚Äú Regulus takes a step towards Snape, not entirely sure what he‚Äôs planning to do, but then Kreacher‚Äôs voice pulls him back.

‚ÄúIs there being something I can do for the young Masters?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus says, at the same moment that Snape says; ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

The house elf‚Äôs big eyes bounce between the pair of them.

‚ÄúLook,‚Äù Snape steps forward, now speaking to Kreacher directly ‚Äúwe have this potion and we need to know if it works‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShut up Snape.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Äîso we need to test it out on you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShut up!‚Äù

‚Äú‚Äîis that alright?‚Äù

And of course, Kreacher says what Regulus knew he would. What he has to say, to every request his Masters make of him. That any wizards make of him. Regulus has always hated it, hated it more when his mother was here. He tries not to ask too much of Kreacher, though he knows he doesn‚Äôt always manage it. Knows that these days he‚Äôs been using him as a stand in parent. But it‚Äôs never seemed right to him. Asking things of a person who can‚Äôt say no.

‚ÄúIt would be an honour,‚Äù Kreacher says, puffing out his chest a little.

Snape gives Regulus a look like ‚Äúthere, you see?‚Äù and it makes Regulus want to punch his stupid face.

He turns to the house elf himself now. ‚ÄúKreacher, you don‚Äôt have to do this, honestly.‚Äù

But Kreacher only shakes his head. ‚ÄúI would be liking to help Master Regulus and his friend,‚Äù Regulus barely holds back a scoff. Whatever him and Snape are, it certainly isn‚Äôt friends.

‚ÄúGreat,‚Äù Snape says, drawing out his wand. ‚ÄúIf we use Bubble-head charms it ought to protect us from breathing in the gas ourselves.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait, wait,‚Äù Regulus holds out his hands, ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt even have an antidote.‚Äù

Snape gives him a long, unimpressed look. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have an antidote for a Sleeping Draught?‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôll work with this new iteration of the potion.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Snape says slowly, like he‚Äôs talking to an idiot, ‚Äúfiguring that sort of thing out is exactly why we need to test it.‚Äù

They glare at one another for a moment, Regulus wishing desperately that he had some sort of comeback.

‚ÄúLike I said,‚Äù Snape goes on eventually, an infuriating smugness in his voice. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre uncomfortable using the elf, I am more than happy to test it out on you.‚Äù

There is no way in hell Regulus is allowing himself to be rendered effectively unconscious in the presence of Severus Snape. Scowling, he turns back to Kreacher.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just going to put you to sleep for a minute or two okay‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWell, really we ought to see how long it lasts, one would hope at least an hour.‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth but ignores the other boy. ‚ÄúIs that alright with you?‚Äù

Kreacher nods enthusiastically. ‚ÄúI is always wanting only to serve the house of Black. I is very happy to be of help to Master Regulus.‚Äù

‚ÄúAdorable,‚Äù Snape says flatly in the background and Regulus feels his hands curl into fists.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he exhales. ‚ÄúOkay, so when I unstopper the potion you won‚Äôt have to drink it, you‚Äôll just have to breathe it in, you understand?‚Äù

Another nod.

Regulus pulls out his own wand, casting the Bubble-head charm on himself and hearing Snape, behind him, doing the same. Kreacher waits, staring at him expectantly. Regulus hates this. Because it feels like taking advantage, but he can‚Äôt really see any other options so reluctantly he pulls the cork from the bottle.

Nothing happens.

Fuck.

What did they do wrong? Should they try smoking both the Lavender and the Valerian sprigs? Is that it? If they don‚Äôt figure this out‚Äî

But then, before his eyes, the potion begins to evaporate out of the vial, disappearing into the air.

‚ÄúI is not feeling any‚Äî‚Äú Kreacher starts, before his face goes slack. Regulus barely has enough time to drop the glass vial and step forward before Kreacher is falling to the floor. He catches him just in time, cushioning his head as he lowers him carefully to the ground.

Regulus finds himself grateful at least, that this is the potion they needed to test. Kreacher looks peaceful. It could have been so much worse. He feels Snape coming to stand behind him.

‚ÄúExcellent,‚Äù he says, though he doesn‚Äôt sound particularly enthused. He doesn‚Äôt really sound like anything. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll write Lucius.‚Äù

¬†

It‚Äôs two days later that Regulus finds himself back at Malfoy Manor. He expects Snape to be there, they‚Äôve been tinkering with the potion for the last few days. The effects seems to last for almost three hours, not as strong as it is when it‚Äôs consumed orally but more than good enough for what they need it for. And brewing in mass batches hasn‚Äôt produced any noticeable decrease in effectiveness, at least not so far.

Regulus assumes that‚Äôs why he‚Äôs here‚Äîto discuss the potion. But the longer the house elf leaves him standing alone in the insufferably grandiose lobby without any sign of Snape, the more nervous he starts to get. The owl he received had been vague, just stating that his presence was required at the Manner, final details for the coup in need of ironing out. It had been Lucius's handwriting. Regulus hadn‚Äôt thought much about it. But maybe he should have.

He shuffles his feet, accidentally catching sight of himself in the nearly wall sized mirror beside him. It‚Äôs frame is made of woven gold strands, flowers and cherubs holding up the corners. He doesn‚Äôt quite‚Ä¶recognize himself. He‚Äôs lost weight, which shouldn‚Äôt be surprising but he just hadn‚Äôt noticed, the bags under his eyes looking like bruises‚Äîblue and purple. His hair has grown long, the curls hanging in his face, brushing his shoulders. It‚Äôs messier than he usually has it.

He‚Äôs always liked his hair, especially when he was younger, because he‚Äôd thought it looked like Sirius‚Äôs. It wasn‚Äôt until his second year at Hogwarts that he started straightening and styling it. Trying to stop people from making those comparisons he had once craved so desperately.

I‚Äôm nothing like your brother.

That‚Äôs what Snape had said.

No, Regulus thinks, staring wistfully at his reflection. No, me either.

‚ÄúSorry for the wait,‚Äù Lucius comes strutting down the hall, heeled boots making that distinctive clinking noise that Regulus has to force himself not to flinch at. ‚ÄúBusiness, you know how it is.‚Äù

Regulus really doesn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúYou going somewhere?‚Äù Regulus asks, eyeing Lucius‚Äôs travel cloak.

‚ÄúWe are going somewhere,‚Äù the older man corrects, holding out his arm. After a few seconds Regulus realizes that Lucius wants him to side-along.

‚ÄúGoing where?‚Äù he demands, not moving an inch. There‚Äôs no way in hell he‚Äôs going anywhere with Lucius.

‚ÄúTo meet some new friends, they‚Äôll be joining us at the Ministry. We need to give them the run down of what‚Äôs going to happen.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy me?‚Äù Regulus asks skeptically.

Lucius ‚Äútuts‚Äù waggling his arm at Regulus who still doesn‚Äôt move. Eventually Lucius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúWell Severus has been sent to perform another task for the Dark Lord‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWhat task?‚Äù Regulus asks so quickly it makes Lucius laugh.

‚ÄúJealous?‚Äù and when Regulus refuses to respond he goes on. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, it‚Äôs far less fun than what we‚Äôre about to do. Now come on.‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me where we‚Äôre going Lucius and I‚Äôll Apparate there myself.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre being childish.‚Äù

Once again Regulus stonewalls him. Staring blankly back, silent and unwavering. It‚Äôs a trick he learned from his mother.

Lucius huffs. ‚ÄúMerlin, alright, alright. 88 Clements Avenue, London.‚Äù And with that Lucius swirls out of existence, leaving Regulus with more questions than answers.

‚ÄúClements,‚Äù he mutters to himself, running over the address a dozen times. He‚Äôs almost positive he‚Äôs never heard of the street before, meaning it‚Äôs likely a Muggle populated area. He wracks his brain for who the hell they could be meeting in Muggle London but he comes up blank.

Honestly he should just go home, Lucius has left, there‚Äôs no one to stop him. And yet‚Ä¶damnit if he isn‚Äôt just a little bit curious. In all his notes and newspaper clippings he hasn‚Äôt heard anything about a Clements Avenue. And the relentless part of his brain is latching onto that gap in his knowledge. Wanting it to be filled.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses under his breath.

A moment later his shoes are slamming into the pavement on a rundown residential street somewhere in London.

‚ÄúCertainly took your time,‚Äù Lucius drawls, from where he‚Äôs leaning against someone‚Äôs front gate.

It‚Äôs dark out today, cold. The trees are losing their leaves, and everything seems to be some shade of grey or brown here. Regulus wraps his arms around himself and tries to remember the last time he actually stepped foot outside.

‚ÄúWhat the hell are we doing here Lucius?‚Äù

There‚Äôs something distinctly shark like about the older man‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúTold you, we‚Äôre meeting our friend‚Äôs.‚Äù He gestures to the dull brick house in front of them that blurs into the one next to it. They are surrounded on both sides by borderless houses. Bleeding into each other so that the street just becomes walls of brick. There's very little green. The houses here don‚Äôt have lawns, just overgrown weeds poking through the cracked concrete.

He follows Lucius down the small walkway to a white screen door that Lucius unceremoniously throws open. Not even bothering to knock. Inside it‚Äôs a little dark and a little cramped and a little warm. The walls are clean but barren of photos or art or posters. There‚Äôs a table in the front room covered in paper‚Äîin scribbled notes and maps‚Äîtwo men standing over it, one smoking, neither of them looking up as Lucius and Regulus walk by.

Regulus can hear footsteps on the floors above them and voices coming from the room in front. The further in they get the more he starts to understand that this is not a house. Not a home where people live. It‚Äôs headquarters.

They come into a kitchen with what used to be pink wallpaper that has now faded to a murky white. Like the sitting room, there are papers and maps everywhere. Supplies piled in the sink and on top of the stove, takeaway containers stacked up high in the corner. All giving the impression that this is a space rarely actually used for cooking.

At the table in the middle of the room there is a group of people having a conversation, coffee cups clutched in their hands. When Regulus sees them he suddenly realizes that that‚Äôs the smell that seems to permeate the whole house. Coffee. At the centre of the conversation is a larger, gruff man that Regulus has seen before.

Fenrir Greyback.

Werewolves.

Regulus suddenly starts taking stock of the people he‚Äôs seen, the noises. This house is full but the last time he checked Greyback had barely a dozen followers. A somewhat unappealing ally for the Dark Lord. It‚Äôs clear things have changed.

Lucius stops in front of the table and clears his throat. He looks fundamentally out of place with his fussy appearance and expensive robes. It isn‚Äôt that anyone here is dressed in rags, but it‚Äôs a lot more sweatshirts and ripped jeans than silk and velvet.

Greyback looks up, smiling, and Regulus has to work to keep his expression neutral at the sight of his teeth. ‚ÄúAh, Malfoy, good to see you. Was worried you got lost there for a moment.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, I do apologize for the wait,‚Äù though he doesn‚Äôt even remotely sound like he means it. ‚ÄúThings came up, you understand?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Greyback is still smiling, though it‚Äôs clear from his eyes that he has not missed the dismissive tone of Lucius‚Äôs words. ‚ÄúWell then, shall we talk? Perhaps somewhere a bit more‚Ä¶quiet?‚Äù Lucius asks, looking the kitchen over with open dislike. Regulus does not think this seems like a particularly smart way to handle this interaction but he‚Äôs not about to step in. Quite frankly, he would pay good money to watch Greyback take a bite out of Lucius.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Greyback responds again, this time rising out of his seat and towering over both of them. Regulus is quite frankly surprised his head doesn‚Äôt brush the ceiling. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll talk upstairs. Luce,‚Äù he looks at one of the women still sitting down. ‚ÄúGo get the kid will you?‚Äù

The woman nods, apparently in no doubt about who ‚Äúthe kid‚Äù is. She slips past Lucius and Regulus on her way out of the room, causing Lucius to arch his brow.

‚ÄúThe kid?‚Äù

Greyback is grinning again. ‚ÄúYou have your prince,‚Äù he gestures to Regulus. ‚ÄúAnd I have mine.‚Äù

Regulus really needs to do something about that stupid fucking nickname.

He expects Lucius to argue, insist no one be in the room with them, it‚Äôs not as though he‚Äôs seemed to care much about offending Greyback so far. But he doesn‚Äôt, instead they follow quietly behind the large man as he leads them to the second floor.

They pass a ton of people‚Äîon the stairs, in the halls, the rooms they walk by‚Äîand Regulus is hit once again with the curiosity of where they all came from. And how they haven‚Äôt been arrested. Though he suspects that Lucius likely has something to do with that.

‚ÄúAfter you,‚Äù Greyback say dryly as he gestures them into a small empty room. Not just empty of people, of course, but empty of anything except a few lonely wooden chairs and a tacked up map of the London underground. Regulus finds himself momentarily distracted by it. He has never been on the Muggle underground before, but the idea of a train that runs underground appeals to him, if for no other reason than the engineering. The problem solving. How did they manage it without magic, he wonders. What stops the earth from caving in?

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre waiting for your friend I take it?‚Äù Lucius says, as Greyback sits himself gracelessly in one of the wooden chair. It creaks under his weight.

‚ÄúWe are.‚Äù

Lucius does not sit. Nor does he lean. Regulus gets the distinct impression he is doing his very best not to touch anything.

They don‚Äôt have to wait long, it‚Äôs only another five minutes before Regulus hears the door opening, his attention once again caught by the map on the wall.

‚ÄúFunny,‚Äù Greyback says. ‚ÄúI only remember asking for one insufferable know it all.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah well, you‚Äôre getting two. Congratulations.‚Äù

Regulus turns around, blinking at the two boys who‚Äôve just entered the room. It takes him a minute. Not because he doesn‚Äôt recognize him but because the idea that he‚Äôs standing here in this room is so absurd that his brain simply refuses to except it. And when reality continues to persist and the face in front of him doesn‚Äôt change, he feels himself start to laugh.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù Lucius asks, sounding genuinely startled.

But he just. He can‚Äôt. He looks around, wondering if anyone else will get the joke but he‚Äôs only met with slightly alarmed faces. For the first and only time in his life, Regulus finds himself wishing that Severus Snape was there.

Because in front of him.

Bold as anything.

Is Remus Lupin.

Remus fucking Lupin.

Just thinking his name makes Regulus start laughing again.

It‚Äôs so absurd. How can none of them see how absurd it is?

How unbelievable?

‚ÄúAll that inbreeding really makes you lot a bit wacky doesn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Greyback says, sounding mildly amused.

The problem is, Regulus realizes, none of them were there. At Hogwarts. None of them saw James and Sirius and Lupin and Pettigrew. They don‚Äôt understand. That Remus Lupin would never switch sides. Would never betray his friends. And it‚Äôs as he‚Äôs thinking this that another thought occurs to him. Probably the one he should have had first.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a werewolf?‚Äù he chokes out, struggling to get his hysterics under control.

Remus looks thoroughly uncomfortable, maybe a bit like he‚Äôs feeling sick, the boy next to him glancing between him and Regulus.

‚ÄúYou two know each other?‚Äù he asks Lupin specifically. Remus flounders for a minute before Lucius helpfully steps in.

‚ÄúOld school chums, aren‚Äôt you Regulus?‚Äù

For the first time Lupin meets his gaze but then he quickly looks away.

‚ÄúMore acquaintances really,‚Äù Regulus says flatly.

‚ÄúSmall world,‚Äù Greyback is clearly uninterested, though the boy next to Lupin keeps looking at him like he wants to say something. Wants to reach out. Which is interesting.

‚ÄúSo Malfoy, tell me, have you lot got a plan then?‚Äù Greyback leans back in his chair with his legs spread wide. He has scruff for a beard and clever eyes, scars marking up his weathered skin. Regulus expects this is a man who is often underestimated.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Lucius says smoothly. ‚ÄúOur little potion master here has managed to create a version of a Sleeping Draught that will become a gas when exposed to oxygen. Me and some others who still have ties within the Ministry are working on gaining access to their Floo network,‚Äù he smiles then. Or maybe it‚Äôs more of a leer. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been incredibly easy.‚Äù

‚ÄúI reckon most things are for you,‚Äù Greyback says.

If he‚Äôs expecting humility from Lucius he doesn‚Äôt get it, the blond man simply bows his head in agreement. ‚ÄúThe potions will go through the Floo first, uncorked, and then we will follow, divided into teams, each tackling different floors in the same manner.‚Äù

Greyback seems to consider this for a moment before speaking again. ‚ÄúAnd how exactly are we meant to get through the gas without falling asleep?‚Äù

‚ÄúBubble-head charm has been effective so far,‚Äù Lucius looks at Regulus for confirmation and Regulus nods.

‚ÄúNot gonna work for us,‚Äù Greyback says bluntly, causing a bemused expression to cross Lucius‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù he asks cutely. ‚ÄúAnd why is that? Have werewolves suddenly developed some sort of immunity to magic that I‚Äôm not aware of?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, but some of us are uncomfortable with it.‚Äù

Lucius makes a derisive noise. ‚ÄúAh, I see, well, I‚Äôm sure we could find someone willing to cast the spells on your skittish pups.‚Äù

The boy next to Lupin growls, which honestly doesn‚Äôt help his case much, but Lupin places a hand on his arm, grounding him.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Greyback says again. ‚ÄúThey are uncomfortable with the idea of having magic cast on them, not just casting it themselves. We‚Äôll have to find another way.‚Äù

Lucius is now clearly getting annoyed. ‚ÄúMaking demands are you?‚Äù there is the edge of a threat in his voice that Greyback obviously picks up, leaning forward, elbows on his knees, hands clasped.

‚ÄúI am,‚Äù he says slowly and deliberately, looking right at Lucius, his pupils flickering between round orbs and slits.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd be careful Greyback,‚Äù Lucius says, but the bigger man only smiles, showing all his teeth.

‚ÄúOh but I don‚Äôt think I need to be,‚Äù he says confidently. ‚ÄúBecause you never would have come to us if you weren‚Äôt desperate. Don‚Äôt think I don‚Äôt know that. You need bodies and I have them, but that doesn‚Äôt mean I‚Äôm going to bend over and let you fuck me however you want. Now, you‚Äôre gonna find a way to protect my people without magic, or you‚Äôre gonna be taking the Ministry by your goddamn selves.‚Äù

The room is silent, the two men with eyes only for each other. Lucius isn‚Äôt Snape, he isn‚Äôt glaring or scowling, but there is undeniably something antagonistic in the corners of his eyes, the slight downturn of his mouth. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre overestimating your importance,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúAfter all, we still have the support of the group from Bulgaria.‚Äù

Greyback snorts rudely. ‚ÄúThe Bulgarians are flighty allies at best, they have their own ministries and Aurors to deal with. Half of them have already gone back. They might be able to help you take control like they did last time but they won‚Äôt be able to help you keep it. And you and I both know that‚Äôs what Voldemort‚Äôs interested in now. Besides,‚Äù he grins, allowing his canines to slip over his bottom lip, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre much scarier.‚Äù

Regulus thinks he sees Lupin flinch.

It‚Äôs clear from every rigid angle of Lucius‚Äôs body that he is not a man used to being dressed down like this. His fingers twitch threateningly close to the handle of his wand. Regulus doesn‚Äôt know if Greyback even has a wand on him, but he also wonders if Lucius would be able to cast a single curse before Greyback had his teeth in his neck. And that‚Äôs all it would take really. He wouldn‚Äôt even have to kill him. Just get in one good bite.

He has a feeling Lucius is thinking the exact same thing.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù Lucius says finally, a brittle politeness in his tone. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you and the other children run a long and try to find a solution to this problem, leave the grown-ups here to talk.‚Äù

Greyback laughs, rubbing at his jaw. But he doesn‚Äôt argue.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt get to tell us what to do,‚Äù the boy next to Lupin snarls.

Lucius doesn‚Äôt even look at him, doesn‚Äôt take his eyes off Greyback. And after another long pause the werewolf speaks.

‚ÄúDo as he says Gabe.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

Greyback‚Äôs head snaps in his direction. ‚ÄúDo you want to go out there and tell those people we‚Äôre gonna have wizards performing magic on them? That they‚Äôll have to wear the spells for hours?‚Äù

The boy‚Äôs lips have pressed together in a firm line.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I thought. Go on, use the basement, I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs anyone down there.‚Äù

With one last mutinously look the boy turns around, slamming the door open as he goes, a rather resigned Lupin looking from Greyback to Lucius, before following after him.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Lucius says to Regulus, snippier than he was earlier that morning. ‚ÄúGo with them, make sure they‚Äôre not just down there rubbing one another‚Äôs bellies or whatever the hell it is werewolves do.‚Äù

Regulus could swear he sees something fiery pass over Greyback‚Äôs face.

He has to jog to catch up to Lupin and the other boy‚ÄîGabe, Greyback called him. They make quick work of the narrow house, stomping down to the basement which is colder than everywhere else, the walls and floors unfinished, a drain in the middle of the room pulling everything down in a slope. There‚Äôs a single metal table, and several boxes piled in the corners.

Gabe hops up onto the table, crossing his arms over his chest and looking nearly as unhappy to be there as Regulus.

‚ÄúWell alright then, how the hell are we gonna keep the gas from knocking us out?‚Äù

There‚Äôs an obvious answer that he waits for one of them to bring up, but instead Gabe stares very pointedly at Regulus and Remus stares very pointedly at the floor. Regulus lets the silence stretch on for a few more minutes before he eventually turns his full attention to Gabe.

‚ÄúDo you have parchment? I find I always think better with a quill in my hand.‚Äù

Gabe gives him a funny look. ‚ÄúEr‚ÄîI mean we have paper and pens?‚Äù

Of course they do. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fine. Thank you.‚Äù

Gabe pushes himself off the table, sparing a single look for Remus before taking the stairs two at a time. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be back in a sec,‚Äù he throws over his shoulder.

There‚Äôs a moment of silence.

‚ÄúYou two seem close,‚Äù Regulus says finally, earning him a sharp look from Lupin.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt what?‚Äù Regulus pushes. ‚ÄúI mean I can‚Äôt imagine you‚Äôre still with my brother, considering the obvious shift in direction your life has taken. Does he know you‚Äôre a werewolf by the way?‚Äù

Remus glares at him in silence.

‚ÄúYou know, it‚Äôs funny, given your obvious deep commitment to the cause, that you can't come up with a single solution to our problem here.‚Äù

‚ÄúGases are not my specialty,‚Äù Remus says flatly.

‚ÄúOh come on Lupin, weren‚Äôt you supposed to be the clever one? Teacher‚Äôs pet and all that?‚Äù

Lupin has gone back to glaring.

‚ÄúReally? Nothing? Raised by a Muggle mum and her family and you expect me to believe you‚Äôve never heard of a gas mask? It‚Äôs almost like you‚Äôre not even trying.‚Äù

That gets a reaction out of him. ‚ÄúAnd who told you I was raised by my Muggle mother? James?‚Äù there‚Äôs something vaguely cold about those words. Betrayal, Regulus thinks.

‚ÄúMight‚Äôve been, or it might‚Äôve been Sirius. I can‚Äôt remember to tell you the truth,‚Äù having been close, at different times, to the two men who have always loved Remus Lupin most, Regulus has unwillingly picked up quite a bit of information about him. ‚ÄúRegardless, my point still stands.‚Äù

Lupin‚Äôs eyes narrow. ‚ÄúHow do YOU know about Muggle gas masks?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent the better part of the last week working on a potion that turns into a gas, you think I didn‚Äôt do any research?‚Äù

‚ÄúOn Muggle inventions?‚Äù Lupin asks skeptically.

Regulus shrugs. ‚ÄúHaving to overcome problems without magic gives Muggles a different perspective on the elements than we have, requires them to be closer to them. Sometimes they pick up on things we miss. Most Muggle technologies are quite fascinating really.‚Äù

Lupin gives him an odd look. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an interesting opinion for a Death Eater to have,‚Äù he says eventually.

Regulus stares blankly back at him. ‚ÄúSays the Death Eater.‚Äù

He sees a whole spectrum of emotions play across Lupin‚Äôs face. First indignation, at the insult, then realization, as he remembers the role he‚Äôs meant to be playing, and finally, fear. At having been found out.

‚ÄúCareful Lupin,‚Äù Regulus says smoothly, unable to stop the small uptick in the corner of his mouth. ‚ÄúYour mask is slipping.‚Äù

Not that he ever really had one to begin with.

Lupin‚Äôs face has gone deathly pale. ‚ÄúRegulus‚Äî‚Äú

But the sound of footsteps pounding down the stairs cuts him off.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Gabe says, jumping the last two steps and dumping a pad of paper and pen on the table. ‚ÄúI was thinking, Muggles have these things, they‚Äôre called gas masks, they use them in wars and stuff. Maybe those might work?‚Äù he looks at them expectantly.

Regulus only smiles. ‚ÄúWow, you don‚Äôt say, gas masks?‚Äù his sarcasm is lost on Gabe. ‚ÄúDo tell me more.‚Äù

And the boy, bless him, does.

¬†

It‚Äôs all pretty straight forward after that. Finding somewhere to buy the masks, making sure they‚Äôll have time to test them before the day, to ensure they do hold-up against the potion. Gabe does most of the organizing, while Lupin twitches nervously beside him. Regulus can‚Äôt help but enjoy it, just a little bit.

When they come back up from the basement they find Lucius and Greyback standing in the entryway, neither of them dead or bleeding or bitten, so Regulus assumes their talk went fairly smoothly.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

He looks back over his shoulder. Lupin is standing in the doorway of the kitchen, Gabe having disappeared in the room behind him, presumably joining the group of people still sitting around the table.

‚ÄúCan I‚Äîcan we talk?‚Äù he steps closer to Regulus, keeping his voice low, eyes darting over Regulus‚Äôs head in the direction of Lucius and Greyback. Regulus is incredibly tempted to say no, however, in the end, his curiosity wins out.

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

Lupin nods stiffly before gesturing to the empty sitting room on Regulus‚Äôs right. There‚Äôs no door and the space is quite small, but it‚Äôll have to do.

‚ÄúRegulus!‚Äù Lucius snaps before he can make it into the room. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre done here, lets go, this isn‚Äôt the time for socializing.‚Äù Regulus clenches his teeth.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not my keeper Lucius,‚Äù he says clearly. ‚ÄúFeel free to leave without me,‚Äù he ignores the scandalized look on the older man‚Äôs face, not bothering to wait for a reply.

Lupin has his eyebrows raised when Regulus walks into the room but he ignores the question behind them. He‚Äôs not interested in discussing Lucius Malfoy.

‚ÄúGo on then, talk,‚Äù he crosses his arms over his chest, both of them hugging the wall near the door, watching incase anyone comes close.

‚ÄúWhatever you think you know‚Äîit isn‚Äôt what it sounded like downstairs, I‚Äôm a part of this. Part of this p-pack,‚Äù he struggles on that last word, like it gets lodged in his throat on the way up. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm committed to this a hundred percent.‚Äù

Regulus just stands there for a moment. Longer than is socially acceptable. Watching Lupin fidget.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre really very bad at this, you know that?‚Äù he says eventually.

Lupin lets out a breath, shoulders rolling forward as he leans against the wall. Regulus almost thinks he‚Äôs going to fess up to it right then but instead he rattles off a weak; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on your side. I promise you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, consider me convinced.‚Äù

Lupin grimaces but doesn‚Äôt bother with anymore pathetic declarations of loyalty to the dark side. Instead the pair lapse into silence, allowing Regulus to properly take in the ragged boy in front of him. Lupin really does look terrible. Barely better than Regulus. He can‚Äôt help but wonder how anyone is going to win this war if they all kill themselves before it‚Äôs over.

‚ÄúSirius and James,‚Äù Regulus‚Äôs voice comes out softer than he means it to, eyes flicking over his shoulder to make sure they‚Äôre still alone. ‚ÄúHow are they?‚Äù It‚Äôs a reckless question, but then, Lupin has been just as reckless here.

The other boy looks up, eyes curious as they run over Regulus‚Äôs face, like they‚Äôre trying to figure something out. He wonders if Lupin is actually going to keep pretending they don‚Äôt both know he‚Äôs still working for the Order, but then he speaks:

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre‚Ä¶they‚Äôre fine. Sirius is frustrated. He feels like he‚Äôs being‚Ä¶sidelined.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd is he?‚Äù

Lupin exhales, ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he scrubs at his eyes. ‚ÄúYeah he is. They don‚Äôt trust him.‚Äù

No. How could they. With a family like his.

With a Death Eater brother.

‚ÄúI wondered why they sent you and not him, he‚Äôs a better liar than you are.‚Äù

Lupin laughs quietly and without much humour. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll take that as a compliment.‚Äù

It isn‚Äôt one. But Regulus can see why he might be confused. ‚ÄúIf you want to.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlus, the werewolf thing kind of helps.‚Äù

Regulus nods, still trying to wrap his mind around that. Around how he could have not put the pieces together. It bothers him actually. James never could meet him on the full moon, and Lupin was always so sickly, and those scars‚Ä¶it‚Äôs fucking embarrassing that he didn‚Äôt figure it out.

‚ÄúHaven‚Äôt bitten him yet then.‚Äù

Lupin stiffens. ‚ÄúYeah, that isn‚Äôt funny.‚Äù

Regulus gives him a long look; ‚ÄúI suppose it isn‚Äôt,‚Äù though he‚Äôs not really sure he was joking. He doesn‚Äôt know much about werewolves, how they act, how they mate, what they can and can‚Äôt control‚Äîthough he fully intends to fix that after today. He doesn‚Äôt like being in the dark about things.

‚ÄúAnd‚Ä¶?‚Äù Regulus prods when Lupin doesn‚Äôt continue on his own.

‚ÄúAnd James is‚Ä¶James. Trying to keep us all together. Trying to get over his parent‚Äôs deaths,‚Äù Lupin pauses and then; ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs moved into their house with Lily.‚Äù

Ah.

‚ÄúAnd they‚Äôre‚Äîwell, they‚Äôre expecting a‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRegulus!‚Äù Lucius shouts from the front hall. ‚ÄúLets go!‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs hands curl into fists, nails biting into his palms. Of course Lucius stayed. If he thinks Regulus is going back to the Manor he‚Äôs out of his mind. Regulus is going home. He‚Äôs tired and he can feel the potions he took this morning wearing off.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a little all over you isn‚Äôt he?‚Äù Lupin says, casually. Like Lucius is a minor irritation.

‚ÄúRegulus!‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ,‚Äù Regulus rolls his eyes, turning towards the door.

‚ÄúWait‚Äî‚Äù

He does, looking back at a Lupin whose panic has resurfaced.

‚ÄúAre you‚Ä¶fuck are you gonna‚Ä¶gonna tell them?‚Äù

Tell them.

That Remus Lupin is quite obviously a spy.

That no doubt every detail of their plan will be meticulously relayed to Dumbledore and his Auror friends.

That they‚Äôre going to fail.

‚ÄúTell them what?‚Äù he says finally, voice flat. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything.‚Äù

He is happy that the anxiety and the fear those words cause don‚Äôt make it out of his mouth or onto his face. It would expose him completely.

Lupin has that curious look in his eyes again. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt figure you out,‚Äù he says finally. And Regulus nearly laughs. Because he‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôs ever figured himself out either.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll take that as a compliment.‚Äù

Lupin gives him a wane smile. ‚ÄúIf you want to.‚Äù

Regulus walks out into the hall, Greyback has gone, he doesn‚Äôt know where, Lucius standing in front of the door with his arms crossed and a pissy look on his face.

‚ÄúWhat the hell were you doing?‚Äù he demands.

‚ÄúI told you to leave without me,‚Äù is all Regulus says as he brushes past him and pushes his way outside. He instantly has to wrap his arms around his torso, having forgotten how cold it was. The light has almost completely left the sky, taking even the suggestion of the sun‚Äôs warmth with it.

‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äô Lucius demands as he follows after him.

Regulus doesn‚Äôt turn around. ‚ÄúHome.‚Äù

‚ÄúBack to that old house all alone? Come now, come to the Manner and we‚Äôll‚Äî‚Äú

Regulus doesn‚Äôt hear the rest of the offer, throwing himself into space, allowing his body to be broken down and reformed on the front stoop of his house. There was a time when the sight of this place filled him with dread. But now. Well. Now it‚Äôs the only place he wants to be most of the time.

‚ÄúMaster Regulus, is you being home?‚Äù Kreacher calls out as Regulus closes the door behind him.

‚ÄúYeah, it‚Äôs me Kreacher,‚Äù he quickly adjusts his wards and then heads towards the fireplace to close the Floo. He doesn‚Äôt want Lucius trying to get in contact. He could still send Narcissa to do his dirty work for him but Regulus will cross that bridge when he comes to it.

‚ÄúWill you be wanting your dinner soon Sir?‚Äù Kreacher asks, as he finds Regulus leaning against the fireplace, fingers curling around the mantel, staring at the portrait his mother had painted of them ages ago. Two little faces blinking out at him.

‚ÄúNo thank you,‚Äù he finally mutters. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not hungry.‚Äù

‚ÄúSir, you is not be eating anything today!‚Äù

‚ÄúI ate while I was out,‚Äù he lies.

Kreacher makes a disapproving noise. ‚ÄúI is a house elf sir, not a moron.‚Äù

Regulus snorts, shooting Kreacher a smile over his shoulder. ‚ÄúI know. I promise.‚Äù

His little face softens. ‚ÄúYou need to eat.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know, I know I do,‚Äù he turns back to the painting. He remembers having been impressed by the likenesses when it was first done. Like looking in a mirror. Now he can‚Äôt recognize any of the faces. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna take a nap,‚Äù he says finally, turning around to face Kreacher. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll eat after that okay?‚Äù

The house elf does not look convinced but he doesn‚Äôt push the matter either. ‚ÄúI will keep it warm for you in the kitchen sir.‚Äù

Regulus smiles in a way he hopes is reassuring. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a long climb up to his room. To the bottles hiding behind the mirror. He turns away from his reflection when he sucks down the potions. Drinks until he stops being able to feel all his thoughts. Then he walks past his bed, and out his door and down the hall.

Walks right into Sirius‚Äôs room.

He never comes in here.

Tries to pretend it doesn‚Äôt exist.

But he‚Äôs feeling nostalgic today.

Fucking Remus Lupin.

The bed is covered in dust but he‚Äôs in no state to care, sliding under the covers and wrapping them around himself, pretending that he isn‚Äôt willingly going to walk into a trap in a few days.

And for a little while, the potions even let him believe it‚Äôs true.

¬†

Regulus is not, generally, a nervous person. But the morning before they‚Äôre going to attack the Ministry he can‚Äôt sit still. He‚Äôs taken some Calming Draught but that‚Äôs it. He doesn‚Äôt want to be high for this. Not completely. Maybe that‚Äôs a mistake. But it‚Äôs too late now.

Kreacher is nice enough not to mention that he woke Regulus up in Sirius‚Äôs bed again. Kreacher has nothing nice to say about Sirius but he knows Regulus hates it when he starts going off about him. Not necessarily because he disagrees with the sentiment, but it reminds him too much of his mother.

His mother whose owls he‚Äôs been ignoring. Floo calls he‚Äôs been denying. He hasn‚Äôt been to Scotland in a while and he feels bad about that. But he knows the minute his father sees him he‚Äôll know. He‚Äôll just‚Ä¶know. And it‚Äôll break his heart, to see what a wreck Regulus has become. So really, he‚Äôs being kind, staying away.

By 8:00 AM Regulus is at Malfoy Manor, the mansion already a bit chaotic, people coming in and out, making last minute arrangements. He sees the werewolves down one corridor. Sees Remus Lupin whose eyes meet his briefly before they both look away. Perhaps both equally ashamed but for different reasons.

Regulus could change his mind. He could go to Lucius right now and tell him that they‚Äôve been betrayed. That Alastor Moody will almost certainly be ready for them. He thinks about it, thinks about it every time he sees Lucius‚Äîmoving between rooms, having discussions, making sure everything is in place.

But if he does.

If he does tell.

Then they‚Äôll kill Lupin.

He knows they will.

And well‚Ä¶Regulus already killed James‚Äôs parents. He can‚Äôt take his brother too.

Which is perhaps a weak reason for such a big act. Perhaps the wrong reason for doing the right thing. But if he‚Äôs really brutally honest with himself, it is the reason that he lets Lucius walk away.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so fucking pumped,‚Äù Evan says from beside him, bouncing on the balls of his feet and stretching out his arms like he‚Äôs getting ready to run a marathon. ‚ÄúThis is gonna be brilliant.‚Äù

Regulus says nothing, staring very pointedly at the front doors, watching people file in. He saw Narcissa briefly this morning. She isn‚Äôt showing yet, but she places her hands on her stomach often enough that you can‚Äôt forget that she‚Äôs pregnant. Regulus found he couldn‚Äôt watch. He was grateful she didn‚Äôt try to talk to him.

‚ÄúOi,‚Äù Evan elbows him, ‚Äúbuck up buttercup, you look fucking depressed.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have an unhealthy amount of energy this morning, I‚Äôm just trying to balance you out,‚Äù Regulus drawls, fingers once again tapping nervously against the side of his thigh. He just needs to get this over with. He just needs to know how bad it‚Äôs going to be.

‚ÄúI think you‚Äôll find I have the exact right amount of energy thank you very much,‚Äù and then; ‚Äúthough it‚Äôs possible I had like three shots of espresso.‚Äù

Regulus gags a little. ‚ÄúChrist.‚Äù

‚ÄúI just wanted to make sure I was awake, you know how I am with mornings.‚Äù

He does.

‚ÄúI like you in the morning, you‚Äôre a mess, it‚Äôs incredibly amusing.‚Äù

Evan snorts. ‚ÄúAw babe, you say the sweetest things,‚Äù he reaches over and musses Regulus‚Äôs hair. Reg swats his hand away, which only makes Evan laugh properly. It‚Äôs at that moment that Snape comes in through the door.

He looks twitchy‚Äîtwitchier than normal anyway‚Äîand his eyes scan the room until they land on Lucius who he heads straight for.

Regulus hasn‚Äôt seen Snape in days, he‚Äôs been on some sort of special mission, or at least that‚Äôs what Lucius keeps saying, never willing to share any of the specifics. At the moment the two men in question are exchanging a series of serious looking whispers, then Lucius points in the direction of his study and Snape is off again.

‚Äú‚Ä¶do you think you can overdose on caffeine?‚Äù Evan is rambling on. ‚ÄúNo right? That can‚Äôt be a thing can it? They‚Äôd have to put a warning label on coffee mugs wouldn‚Äôt they?‚Äù

‚ÄúHold that thought Evan,‚Äù Regulus says as he peels off the wall and starts following Snape. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be back in a second.‚Äù

He weaves his way through the busy house. Everyone won‚Äôt be able to Floo to the Ministry from here, so they‚Äôre all trying to figure out where they‚Äôre supposed to be‚Äîwhose fireplace they‚Äôre using. There are paintings, in the gallery back in Scotland, of Muggle knights, dressed in armour and mounted on horses, charging into battle, picking themselves up after it is all done. He wonders if this is what it was like for them too, before they took the field. Chaos and nerves and shouting across ballrooms.

Well, okay, maybe not that last bit.

The hallway by Lucius‚Äôs study is surprisingly empty, far enough from all the action that no one has bothered to wander over. The door is shut and Regulus is almost certain Snape will have cast some kind of silencing charm, but he walks towards it anyway, hugging the wall, listening intently.

He‚Äôs shocked when he actually hears voices.

‚Äú‚Äîthat all?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think there may have been more but unfortunately I wasn‚Äôt able to hear it, I was‚Ä¶well, the barman found me and I had to make a quick exit.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see.‚Äù

He‚Äôs speaking to the Dark Lord, his voice unmistakable, he must be using the fireplace because there‚Äôs no way Voldemort was able to slip into the Manner without anyone noticing.

‚ÄúDid they suspect anything?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Snape admits. ‚ÄúBut they let me go, and I made sure before coming here that they didn‚Äôt have me followed, so they can‚Äôt suspect much.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a lengthy pause and Regulus strains his ears, listening for any sign that Snape might be headed for the door, but there is no screeching of chair legs or squeaking of floorboards. Only complete silence.

And then:

‚ÄúTell me again,‚Äù the Dark Lord asks.

He can hear Snape taking in a deep breath, like he‚Äôs bracing himself, ‚ÄúThe seer woman said; the one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord approaches... Born to those who have thrice defied him, born as the seventh month dies.‚Äù

The seer woman.

Snape has been spying on a seer.

A seer who has just prophesied the potential fall of the Dark Lord.

‚ÄúThank you Severus,‚Äù Voldemort says finally. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve done well,‚Äù and then, as though he hasn‚Äôt just heard the foretelling of his own demise. ‚ÄúHow are things progressing there?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve only just arrived but Lucius seems to have things in hand. I expect everything will go according to plan.‚Äù

‚ÄúI should certainly hope so. And was your‚Ä¶time with Black at all enlightening?‚Äù

Regulus feels something cold drip down his spine.

‚ÄúHe was as committed to the project as I was,‚Äù Snape says, without sounding particularly happy about it. ‚ÄúI do not believe we have to worry about his loyalty.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood, well, we both have business to attend to then. I‚Äôll see you when this is all done.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, goodbye my lord.‚Äù

Regulus is already walking away, barely able to keep himself from breaking into a jog. But that would only draw attention. Thankfully, he manages to make it out of the hallway without hearing the sound of the door opening behind him.

‚ÄúJesus, where did you go, you look scared shitless,‚Äù Evan says when he makes it back to him.

‚ÄúNowhere, nothing. Just‚Ä¶nerves I guess.‚Äù

Some of the humour fades from Evan‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he says, reaching out and placing a hand on the back of Regulus‚Äôs neck. It‚Äôs work not to flinch but he manages it. And really, it‚Äôs not so bad. It‚Äôs only Evan.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre gonna be okay, alright?‚Äù Evan says seriously, ducking down so he can hold Regulus‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have each other‚Äôs backs out there, you and me, we‚Äôll get through it,‚Äù and then he grins, looking more like his normal self. ‚ÄúJust think about how much we can piss Barty off after, with stories of all the bad ass things we‚Äôre gonna do.‚Äù

Regulus manages a smile though he‚Äôs not sure it‚Äôs particularly convincing. He wants to tell him. He wants so badly to tell him‚Äîto go home. This is a trap. They know we‚Äôre coming. They‚Äôll be waiting for us.

But Evan isn‚Äôt like Regulus. He would say something. If he found out that Regulus had betrayed them he would say something and Regulus would never make it to the end of this day. So instead he swallows, throat tight.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have each other‚Äôs backs,‚Äù he repeats.

Evan gives his neck a squeeze before letting go. ‚ÄúFuck I can‚Äôt wait to kick some ass.‚Äù

¬†

Evan doesn‚Äôt have to wait much longer. It‚Äôs maybe an hour later that they‚Äôre being shuffled towards their assigned fireplace. They‚Äôre high ranking enough that they get to leave from the Manor, others Apparating off to their designated locations. Even with the Manor‚Äôs multiple fireplaces they still have to go in waves. Evan and Regulus are part of the second wave, standing in line behind those going ahead of them. Everyone watching the clock.

At exactly 11:00 the potions will be sent through. At 11:05 the first wave will follow. At 11:10 the second. Once they clear the atrium Evan and Regulus will be making their way to the Auror Department along with a handful of others, including Lucius and Greyback.

Evan is bouncing on the balls of his feet, hair a mess from constantly running his hands through it. He looks ridiculous with the bubble currently wrapping around his head, but Regulus supposes they all do.

‚ÄúRelax,‚Äù Regulus hisses, but Evan only shoots him a smile.

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt. I just need to fucking kill something already y‚Äôknow?‚Äù

Something.

Not someone.

Regulus thinks back to Azkaban. To the screaming and the darkness and the rats. To a man in a cell begging for his life.

Regulus isn‚Äôt sure what his face does but it‚Äôs enough to stop Evan‚Äôs bouncing. He looks at him confused, brows drawing together. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äî‚Äú

Regulus waves him off and Evan, surprisingly, lets the issue drop.

And then it‚Äôs 11:00.

And then it‚Äôs 11:05.

The line of people in front of them moves, disappearing into the fire. And Regulus feels his stomach fill with acid. It‚Äôs been a long time since he felt something this viscerally. It‚Äôs overwhelming, his hands shaking. When his toes reach the edge of the hearth he really thinks he might lose his nerve.

Fuck,

he thinks.

Fuck what have I done?

Evan gives him a little shove, gentle, encouraging, and Regulus lets it carry him forward. Shoes scuffing in the embers as he says the words and feels his body being ripped away. His friend‚Äôs smiling face disappearing in a blur of motion.

Regulus trips over something on his way out of the fireplace, instantly landing on his hands and knees on the hard stone floor of the Ministry atrium. This turns out to be a blessing because half a second later a curse flies right through the space where his chest would have been. There‚Äôs a lot of noise and movement and he still hasn‚Äôt managed to get his bearings when Evan appears. Regulus reaches out, wanting to pull his friend down and out of the line of fire, but he doesn‚Äôt need to. Evan trips just like he had.

‚ÄúOw,‚Äù he hisses. ‚ÄúWhat the fuck. Why aren‚Äôt they fucking asleep? And why are there so goddamn many of them?‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head, looking up to see a crowd of red robbed Aurors, all with bubbles protecting their noses and mouthes. Evan curses again.

‚ÄúSomeone ratted,‚Äù he snarls, and then; ‚ÄúWhat the fuck did we trip on any‚Äî‚Äú he cuts off, and Regulus looks over at him, and then follows his gaze to their feet.

A body.

One of the people who had gone through before them.

‚ÄúFuck!‚Äù Evan scrambles up, looking awfully woozy for someone who had just been talking about how badly he wanted to kill people. Regulus gets up too, grabbing Evan‚Äôs arm and yanking him away from the fireplace. They‚Äôre sitting ducks here.

‚ÄúWe should move it,‚Äù Evan says numbly, as Regulus maneuvers them through the crowd, stepping over empty potion bottles as he goes. ‚ÄúSo no one else trips.‚Äù

‚ÄúTripping is the only reason we‚Äôre still alive,‚Äù he finds a pillar, it has a chunk taken out of it but at least it‚Äôs something solid they can press their backs to.

Around them is chaos, Death Eaters and Aurors and werewolves all fighting. The bodies of the unsuspecting and unprepared piling up by the fireplaces. Regulus wonders if any of the first wave even made it through.

‚ÄúReg‚Äî‚Äú Evan barely gets out before he‚Äôs tackling Regulus to the ground, pain shooting through Regulus‚Äôs side as he lands hard on his shoulder with Evan on top of him. A few more chunks fly off of the pillar above as the curse hits it instead of Regulus‚Äôs head.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Regulus groans.

‚ÄúSorry, I just saw it coming and I didn‚Äôt know what else to do.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. Just maybe get off of me.‚Äù

Evan laughs. ‚ÄúYeah, alright,‚Äù he sits back on his knees watching Regulus struggle to push himself up. ‚ÄúAre you‚Äîoh shit.‚Äù

Regulus follows Evan‚Äôs gaze towards the three Auror‚Äôs advancing on them.

‚ÄúOh shit.‚Äù

Both of them scramble off the ground, wands raised.

Regulus throws up a shield first, dropping it the second the curses hit and firing back a Jelly-leg jinx before ducking behind the pillar. The sound of screaming lets him know that he hit one of them, another stray curse crashing into the wall behind him. He pulls himself back out from behind the the pillar, hurling a Stupefy at the still advancing Auror, but the man blocks it without a second thought.

They go back and forth, easier now that it‚Äôs one on one. Regulus keeps checking on Evan out of the corner of his eye, but the other boy is grinning again. Taunting his opponent. For all his other faults, Evan has always been a damn good fighter.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù the word punches out of Regulus as he‚Äôs thrown backwards, some spell clipping his shoulder. He didn‚Äôt hear it, maybe the Auror was casting silently, there‚Äôs so much noise that he can‚Äôt really tell. He slams into the wall and slides down onto the floor, trying to catch his breath, trying to figure out what the hell‚Äôs been done to him, his entire body aching with the impact of the hit.

And his wand.

Fuck his wand.

His eyes focus on the spot on the floor a few feet away where it landed. He starts dragging himself towards it when a boot drives right into the centre of his chest, causing him to choke and cough as he‚Äôs pinned against the floor, the Auror standing over him, watching as Regulus struggles.

He wishes he could say, that faced with the end of a wand, he became dignified. Composed. That he shot off some one liner, like

do it.

I fucking dare you.

But that isn‚Äôt what happens. Instead he scrambles and flails, like a bug about to be crushed, pathetic little grasping noises escaping him as he tries to get the boot off his fucking chest.

‚ÄúYou know, I knew your father,‚Äù the man above him says. ‚ÄúPompous piece of work he was,‚Äù he drives the point of his wand right into Regulus‚Äôs cheek and Regulus actually fucking sobs.

Like a child.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd prefer to be pointing this at him. But I suppose you‚Äôll do. Avada-Ke‚Äî‚Äú

There‚Äôs a flash of green light and Regulus is loathed to admit that he closes his eyes. He isn‚Äôt sure what he‚Äôs expecting it to feel like. No one‚Äôs ever told him. The killing curse. Death. He doesn‚Äôt know what he‚Äôs waiting for. Doesn‚Äôt even know what he‚Äôs afraid of.

The pressure disappears from Regulus‚Äôs chest, and he finds he‚Äôs able to take full breaths again. Though they‚Äôre stuttered and choked. He doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on. He doesn‚Äôt want to open his eyes.

‚ÄúReg! Reg!‚Äù he feels two hands land on his shoulders and that‚Äôs enough to get Regulus to look. Evan is crouched down in front of him, cheeks flushed, eyes bright. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre alright, you‚Äôre okay. I got him. I got him.‚Äù

At first Regulus doesn‚Äôt understand, mind moving too slow, and then he turns his head and sees the body of the Auror lying on the ground.

‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù

Evan nods, before shoving Regulus‚Äôs wand back into his hand. ‚ÄúYou really ought to hold onto that.‚Äù

Regulus lets out a shaky laugh, meeting Evan‚Äôs eyes, his friend gives him a wink before he stands up, offering Regulus his hand. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon, lets go.‚Äù And as much as Regulus would rather just stay here on the floor, he takes it.

He‚Äôs never really been in a fight like this. Never really been in very many fights at all, actually. Duels, sure. Wrestling matches with Sirius when they were little. But this is the first time that the war has ever felt like a proper war to Regulus. The type you read of in history books. Except when you read about it everything always seems so much clearer. Regulus always pictured it taking place on a field somewhere, with two opposing sides facing one another in neat, little lines, with very clear distinctions between one side and the other.

That isn‚Äôt what this is like.

There are no clear formations or boundaries. Everything is chaos. Spells flying around, bits of the Ministry being torn away and turned into weapons. Regulus doesn‚Äôt let himself linger on the bodies. You‚Äôd think he‚Äôd be used to it. Violence. Given the way he grew up. But then. Once a coward always a coward. Or something like that.

¬†

He fares better in his subsequent duels than his first. No one gets him on the ground again which Regulus considers a win. He‚Äôs just walking away from his latest opponent‚Äîa woman now struggling against the magical ropes binding her to one of the pillars, when Evan falls into step beside him. He has a swelling black eye and his shirt is stained red from the slashing curse he was struck with‚ÄîRegulus had thankfully managed to quickly heal the wounds.

‚ÄúYou just gonna leave her?‚Äù Evan asks, swerving to avoid an incoming piece of rubble.

‚ÄúI threw away her wand, and the charm is strong, she isn‚Äôt a threat.‚Äù

Evan looks at him for a minute before shaking his head, clapping Regulus on the back. ‚ÄúStop making more work for yourself Reg, just Avada them and be done with it, yeah?‚Äù

Regulus wonders how it is that Evan learned his unforgivable curses. If his family took him into the back garden and made him torture rabbits too. Or if he didn‚Äôt need that. If it came naturally to him. The way it never did to Reg.

It‚Äôs not because he‚Äôs a good person. He has no illusions about that. He doesn‚Äôt think he would mind so terribly if someone came along and killed the Auror he just left behind. Her death means very little to him. He just doesn‚Äôt want to be the executioner.

Coward, he hears whispered again in the back of his head.

The voice sounds like Sirius.

‚ÄúHoly shit is that Moody?‚Äù

Regulus follows Evan‚Äôs gaze to the grizzled looking man standing in front of the fountain. He swings his wand over his head like a lasso, casting a spell Regulus doesn‚Äôt recognize but that appears to be strong enough to take out four of the Death Eaters charging towards him. It‚Äôs an impressive display of power that Regulus has never witnessed before and he feels his chest grow tight.

‚ÄúHow much do you wanna bet I can take him?‚Äù Evan asks, eyes on the Head Auror, greedy and alight with the adrenaline of his last fight.

‚ÄúLeave it Evan.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah but fucking imagine,‚Äù he practically licks his lips his words are so hungry, ‚Äúif I was the one to take down Alastor fucking Moody. I think the Dark Lord would give me a bloody knighthood.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean it Evan, leave it.‚Äù

But when Evan looks over at him Regulus knows not a word he‚Äôs said has gotten through. ‚ÄúCome on Reg, have a little faith in me yeah?‚Äù He gives him a wink before charging forward.

‚ÄúEvan‚Äîfuck,‚Äù Regulus reaches out to grab him, to hold him back, but Evan is too quick and when Regulus starts to chase after him he finds his path blocked.

The Auror in question doesn‚Äôt bother trying to curse him and instead punches Regulus right in the jaw, sending him reeling. Thankfully he manages to stay on his feet, firing a curse the minute he can. The Auror blocks it easily, advancing again.

He‚Äôs tall, several inches taller than Regulus, and built like a house. No wonder he used his fists first. Regulus backs up, firing off another spell that is casually tossed aside. And another.

And another.

And another.

All knocked out of the way as though they‚Äôre nothing but flies. He clenches his jaw. This is starting to get irritating.

The man keeps advancing, and Regulus realizes that he has no intention of fighting back with his wand. He‚Äôs just going to keep blocking Regulus‚Äôs spells until he can get his hands on him again. And at this rate that isn‚Äôt going to take long. Regulus needs a new strategy.

He looks around desperately, still backing up, trying to keep the giant in front of him from closing the gap between them. His eyes snag on the windows above them‚Äîthe hundreds and hundreds of offices with views of the atrium.

He isn‚Äôt as good with silent casting as he‚Äôd like, but simple things he can manage. Like summoning charms. Perhaps, if he can get one of the panes of glass loose and bring it down on the advancing Auror with enough force, he might just get out of this.

‚ÄúFunny,‚Äù he says, trying to distract the man. ‚ÄúHere I thought Aurors were supposed to be good at duelling.‚Äù He starts the incantation in his head, trying to concentrate, to visualize, to keep his wand as out of sight as possible.

‚ÄúAnd here I thought Death Eaters were supposed to be scary,‚Äù the man doesn‚Äôt smile when he delivers the line. Regulus tries his best not to be offended.

He focuses on the second floor, the third office from the right.

Accio window.

Accio window.

Accio window.

‚ÄúTell me, how exactly did you manage to get past your OWLs? Did you just punch the Professor?‚Äù The man is still advancing and if he gets his hands on Regulus before he manages this spell Regulus will be absolutely fucked.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre such a skilled duelist why don‚Äôt you try getting past my shield little boy?‚Äù
He thinks Regulus is a joke.

And Regulus can‚Äôt really blame him.

Except that‚Äî

The pane of glass cracks when it rips out of its frame, though it doesn‚Äôt shatter, careening right for them over the hundreds of heads below, the Auror reaching for Regulus‚Äôs neck.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been a disappointment Regulus Black,‚Äù fuck, does everyone know who he is? ‚ÄúI thought you were going to put up more of a fight.‚Äù

He feels the Aurors‚Äôs fingertips brush against his collar at the exact same moment that the pane of glass crashes into him, shattering over the man‚Äôs head. Regulus flinches backwards, using his arms to shield his face as debris scatters everywhere. When he looks up again the man in front of him is bleeding from about a dozen places, shattered glass piling up like snow at his feet. The Auror stares back at him in a dazed kind of way, swaying slightly before he tries to take a step forward and ends up crumpling to the ground.

Regulus is breathing like he‚Äôs just run a mile, hands shaking slightly as he stares at the heap of Auror in front of him. He doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs dead, knows that he should fix that. And yet‚Ä¶his wand remains at his side.

There‚Äôs a booming scream from across the Atrium, loud enough that it rises above all the other noise. All the other screaming. It sounds like thunder, like it could shake the foundations of the city.

There, at the fountain, is a hunched over Alastor Moody, gripping his face as blood gushes into his hands and down his forearms, disappearing into the red of his uniform. And in front of him, is a beaming Evan Rosier.

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù Regulus mutters under his breath, suddenly moving again, trying to get to his friend.

Evan fires off another curse but Moody blocks it, even with one hand still clutching his face, quickly returning fire. Regulus tries to maneuver his way across the floor, through duelling pairs and over the various debris the fighting has caused. Moody and Evan come in and out of his line of sight, bobbing and weaving around one another. Regulus has no idea what spell Evan hit Moody with but he really is bleeding badly.

Merlin,

he thinks as he gets closer.

What if he really does it? What if Evan really‚Äî

The spell hits him right in the chest.

Evan that is.

Hits Evan right in the chest. Which is funny because Regulus feels it. Feels it like another giant Auror has decided to drive their fist into him. For a moment he can‚Äôt move. He just watches.

Waits.

Waits for Evan to get up.

To laugh.

To make some stupid inappropriate joke.

But he doesn‚Äôt.

Doesn‚Äôt move an inch. Not even when Moody walks over to him, no longer covering the monstrous gash on his face that looks like it‚Äôs taken half his nose. Not even when Moody spits on the ground beside his head, before turning away.

That‚Äôs when Regulus starts running.

He lands on his knees beside Evan‚Äôs body. His eyes are open. They stare across the room. They don‚Äôt blink. Don‚Äôt move.

‚ÄúEvan?‚Äù his voice shakes as he slides his hands under his friend‚Äôs torso and picks him up. He‚Äôs still warm. ‚ÄúEvan?‚Äù

He‚Äôs dead.

Regulus knows that.

Really he does. He understands. He watched it happen. He can feel the unnatural stiffness already starting to take hold.

He knows that he‚Äôs dead he just‚Ä¶he doesn‚Äôt know what to do with that. He pulls his friend into his lap, holding him close. Because they‚Äôre supposed to be here together. To have each other‚Äôs backs. Because he can‚Äôt just‚Äîjust leave him. Not alone.

This is your fault,

says the voice in his head.

You betrayed him. You did this.

You knew this was a trap. And you let him come anyway.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he whispers, rocking slightly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

He knows, deep down, that Evan Rosier was not a very good person.

But he also thinks it‚Äôs possible, that he was the only one in Regulus‚Äôs life who ever really loved him unconditionally.

And that loss feels‚Ä¶profound.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

His head shoots up, he feels like he‚Äôs in a daze, everything suddenly less real. This sensation is compounded by the fact that the person standing across from him is Frank Longbottom. The former Gryffindor Quidditch captain. Head boy. For a second Regulus feels like he‚Äôs back in school, reality sort of slipping around him, all wobbly and undefined. And then he sees Longbottom‚Äôs wand move.

Regulus lets go of Evan.

Because he doesn‚Äôt know how to fight with a body in his arms.

Because he‚Äôs always been good at letting people down when it comes to saving himself.

The spell is only an Expelliarmus, he feels it whiz past his ear as he rolls to his knees and then his feet, darting into the crowd. He doesn‚Äôt know if Longbottom is following. Doesn‚Äôt know why he doesn‚Äôt turn around and fight. Maybe because he‚Äôs always liked Frank Longbottom. He was a good Quidditch player. A better captain. Another person who matters to James.

He doesn‚Äôt want to be here anymore, all will to fight draining out of him. He wants to go home. Wants to drown out the buzzing inside his chest. His head.

Fuck.

Someone we‚Äôll have to tell his mum.

Someone will have to tell Evan‚Äôs mum that he‚Äôs dead.

That‚Äôs the last thought he has before he‚Äôs hit‚Äîpart of the fountain blown off in a misdirected spell. It catches his temple, slamming him into the wall beside him. The world gives a great tremble.

And then all there is is black.

¬†

‚ÄúGet up!‚Äù

Regulus grumbles, turning over, trying to swat Kreacher away as he buries his head in his pillows, he already has one hell of a hangover and he hasn‚Äôt even opened his eyes.

‚ÄúJesus fucking Christ,‚Äù someone grabs hold of the back of his shirt and yanks him up to his feet, causing a searing pain to slice through his brain.

‚ÄúAhh,‚Äù he cries, clutching his head, which is hot and wet and sticky. He stumbles against the person who dragged him up, his legs shaking. It feels like he‚Äôs on the deck of a ship, the floor beneath him moving.

That‚Äôs when the noise hits him. It‚Äôs so fucking loud. Too fucking loud to be his bedroom. And whoever he‚Äôs leaning against is too fucking tall to be Kreacher. He opens his eyes‚Äîa mistake‚Äîit burns, it‚Äôs so bright, the lancing pain in his brain back in full force.

‚ÄúMove,‚Äù the person holding him up snaps. ‚ÄúFucking move,‚Äù he shoves him forward, still gripping Regulus by the back of his shirt which is the only reason he doesn‚Äôt instantly fall to the floor.

Regulus tries to think. It‚Äôs hard when he‚Äôs this goddamn dizzy and nauseous and in pain. He needs to figure out where he is, what‚Äôs happening. He needs to figure it out now. He forces his eyes open again. It really goddamn hurts but he doesn‚Äôt let them close. There‚Äôs people. Chaos. The fountain.

The fountain.

The Ministry.

The coup.

The betrayal.

Evan.

Regulus gags, trying to stop, trying to grab hold of his knees and breathe but the person pushing him doesn‚Äôt let him. Shoving him relentlessly forward despite his weak protests.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt stop. It‚Äôs already a miracle we haven‚Äôt been spotted.‚Äù

The voice is vaguely familiar. Regulus forces himself to look over his shoulder even though moving his eyes feels like having nails dragged across his brain. It takes him a second, because the man is wearing a mask, because his brain just got smashed against a fucking stone wall. But eventually. He gets there.

‚ÄúLupin?‚Äù he asks, voice weak.

‚ÄúJust shut up and keep walking okay?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt have any idea what‚Äôs going on but he‚Äôs honestly in no position to fight. So he lets himself be dragged across the atrium towards what looks like the reception area. Everything is coming to Regulus in bits and pieces. Like his brain is a radio that keeps losing signal. He sees the floor. Then a desk. His shoes. Lupin‚Äôs arm.

And then all the sudden Lupin is shoving him into some kind of box. The minute Lupin lets go of him he collapses to the ground in the corner. He wonders if he‚Äôs cracked his skull. It sure as hell feels like it.

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù Lupin snaps his fingers in front of Regulus‚Äôs face, causing him to blink up at him. That hurts too. Blinking. ‚ÄúStay awake okay? You have to stay awake.‚Äù

Regulus isn‚Äôt sure why. Not being awake sounds like an excellent idea right now.

‚ÄúThis is the visitors entrance,‚Äù Lupin is explaining. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to get it to take you up, it‚Äôll dump you onto Whitehall, then you need to Apparate the hell away from here.‚Äù

There‚Äôs no way Regulus is going to be able to Apparate in the state he‚Äôs in. And the grimace on Lupin‚Äôs face suggests he knows that too.

‚ÄúFloo?‚Äù Regulus finally mutters. Because that would be so much easier, but Lupin shakes his head.

‚ÄúMoody‚Äôs already had the Floo network closed. They‚Äôll be coming this way soon to shut this off as well. Keep everyone in. So this is your only way out and you need to go now.‚Äù

There are about a dozen more things Regulus has to ask him, not least of which is ‚Äúwhy‚Äù. Why are you doing this? But then, if he had to guess, Regulus would imagine it‚Äôs probably the same reason he didn‚Äôt tell anyone that Remus was a spy.

James.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Lupin exhales, straightening up. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sending you now.‚Äù He turns to the weird contraption on the wall, tapping in some numbers before shooting Regulus one last lingering look and slipping out of the box.

A second later it starts to move.

The silence of the booth is soothing after the noise of the atrium. Though it also makes it nearly impossible to ignore the relentless thumping of his injured head. He closes his eyes.

Stay awake okay?

Lupin whispers in his ear.

You have to say awake.

The box jolts as it comes to a stop, Regulus‚Äôs eyes flying open again, met with the sight of a bustling city street. It‚Äôs grey out, the wind banging angrily against the walls around him. Regulus stumbles and slips as he pulls himself to his feet, he can smell the blood dripping down the side of his face almost as much as he can feel it.

‚ÄúSteady on mate,‚Äù a man in a beige suit says as Regulus practically spills out the doors of the box. The man gives him a dirty look but doesn‚Äôt stop.

Swaying, Regulus reaches for the nearest wall, feeling his way along it until he gets to an alley. Small and narrow, between two white buildings, he slips inside and proceeds to be sick. On his hands and knees. Beside the bins. It‚Äôs mostly stomach acid, he hasn‚Äôt eaten much. When his body has finally finished he presses his back to the wall behind him, wiping his mouth on his sweaty hand and looking at his wand.

He has to Apparate. He has to get out of here. Even if the Aurors don‚Äôt find him‚Äîand they might‚Äîhe is Regulus Arcturus Black and he‚Äôs not about to die here with the rubbish. But he‚Äôs also weak, and in pain, and he can‚Äôt even walk let alone fucking Apparate.

He grits his teeth, trying to force his head to cooperate for one second. Just long enough to get him home. Tries to stop the ground from moving and the colours from blending and the overcast light from feeling like a sharp sliver being driven into his brain.

Inhale.

Exhale.

Inhale.

Exhale.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù his voice cracks as he lifts his wand. ‚ÄúOkay. Okay,‚Äù he squeezes his eyes shut. And casts the spell.

¬†

The second he lands on the stoop of Grimmauld Place he‚Äôs screaming. Blood curdling, bone deep, screams that he‚Äôs never heard himself make. He‚Äôs splinched himself. The skin ripped from his arms and back in patches. Left somewhere in the space between Whitehall and here.

It‚Äôs fucking unbearable.

All he can do is lie there, bleeding and screaming and writhing in pain. And his head. His fucking head is splitting open. He‚Äôs never felt anything like this. Every single part of his body feels like it‚Äôs being torn apart. He‚Äôs going to black out. Merlin he hopes he blacks out.

‚ÄúMaster Regulus!‚Äù

He tries to speak but he can‚Äôt. He can‚Äôt fucking stop screaming. And it only gets worse when Kreacher starts touching him. Hands on his open wounds.

‚ÄúI is sorry, I is sorry, but you must get inside Sir. I is sorry.‚Äù

He wants to tell Kreacher it‚Äôs okay. Really he does. But the words only blink in and out of existence. A shadow in his mouth as he collapses back onto the floor in the front hallway. Into the blissful darkness of the house.

‚ÄúI will be bringing Master Regulus to the hospital sir, I will be bringing him now.‚Äù

Somehow, the fear manages to cut through the agony. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus mutters, his voice barely recognizable. Scratched raw and shaking.

‚ÄúSir‚Äî‚Äú

He looks at Kreacher even though it hurts. Even though is drives new holes into his brain. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an order, you cannot take me to St Mungos.‚Äù

He‚Äôll be arrested.

Or something worse.

Kreacher looks down at him so sadly, large eyes filling with tears. ‚ÄúBut sir, you is needing saving.‚Äù

Reality tilts.

Do you need to be saved Reg?

A boy in a tower. The night sky behind him.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù

Yes.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù

Please.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù

Help me. Please help me.

‚ÄúJames.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know why that‚Äôs all he can say, when there are so many other things trapped inside of him. Desperate to be let out.

But he supposes there are worse last words to have.

¬†

PART III PETER

Peter Pettigrew is a very average person. He knows that. Has always known that. Mediocrity seems to be sown into the seams of his being. So he has never understood why James Potter, a boy who puts the sun to shame, ever bothered to befriend him at all.

The first time Peter met James was not on the Hogwarts express. It was at his Great Aunt Betsy‚Äôs 100th birthday. She was somehow distantly related to Euphemia and, as a result, the Potters were there.

They‚Äôd been eight at the time, him and James, but already the room seemed to orbit around James like he was the singular point in the universe. Children and adults both were enchanted by him. Peter had stayed away. Too timid. Too embarrassed. He‚Äôd had a slight lisp when he was younger and his mother cut his hair, so it always came out looking like a mixing bowl had been placed on his head. Even at eight he had an acute awareness that he was not‚Ä¶cool.

So instead of embarrassing himself he snuck upstairs, where he knew his Aunt kept her collection of horse figurines. He rather liked playing with those. Which was where James found him.

‚ÄúWoah, neat.‚Äù

Peter had jumped, startled by the boy with the messy hair and giant glasses. James had walked right up to him, holding one of the horses up and inspecting it, then placing it back down.

‚ÄúHow do you play?‚Äù he‚Äôd asked Peter, who had felt rather certain someone was pulling a prank on him. Why on earth would the coolest kid at the party leave everyone behind to come up here and hang out with him?

‚Äú‚Ä¶Hello?‚Äù James tilted his head quizzically.

Oh no. Peter was being weird.

‚ÄúHi.‚Äù

James smiled, a little confused, but still bright enough that Peter felt he had to look away.

‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶how does it work? The game I mean,‚Äù James shook his horse for emphasis.

‚ÄúOh, oh I don‚Äôt know. Or‚ÄîI mean‚ÄîI just kinda‚Ä¶‚Äù he shrugged, before demonstrating moving his horse around the top of the dresser on his makeshift course.

‚ÄúCool,‚Äù James said, even though it definitely wasn‚Äôt, joining him with his own horse. ‚ÄúHey, you wanna race?‚Äù Peter had met his gaze again, surprised to still find it empty of mockery. He had a rather hard time fitting in, most kids seemed to think he was odd, or not worth their time. It was new to him, this easy camaraderie. This olive branch.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he smiled slowly. ‚ÄúYeah okay.‚Äù

And just like that, Petter Pettigrew made a friend.

Peter was there. The first time James Potter fell in love. And it wasn‚Äôt with Lily Evans, though he knows everyone thinks so. Everyone, maybe, except for Lily herself.

Peter had grown too complacent, that was the problem. Too comfortable with the idea that James Potter was his best mate. That he always would be. It wasn‚Äôt like there hadn‚Äôt been chances, between his Great Aunt‚Äôs birthday and the day they got on the Hogwarts Express for the first time. At any point James could have gone off and found himself a new friend, and he never had. Never made Peter feel less than, or unworthy, and eventually Peter had managed to forget, or at least push to the back of his mind, that he was those things. All of them.

And then Sirius Black had sauntered into their compartment.

It would have been easier, really, if it had been Lily. Because Peter was never going to be for James what Lily was. But Sirius, Sirius was the embodiment of everything Peter should have been. That James Potter‚Äôs best mate should have been. And the moment those two were in the same space, even when they had barely spoken more than just their names, something changed. Two sparks come to life. It was impossible to look away. And Peter really had tried.

It used to be that Remus was Peter‚Äôs ally. Sometimes, when James and Sirius would bounce off of each other too fast for anyone else to get a word in, Remus would look at Peter and Peter would look right back and it was like, the two of them understood one another. It was it‚Äôs own special kind of bond. It made it feel less like he was on the outside of something and more like there were layers. That‚Äôs different now‚Ä¶with Remus and Sirius being whatever they are.

Peter had tried for a while, to fight for his place as James‚Äôs best mate. But it was a losing battle. And by the end of first year he felt exhausted by it. So he stopped trying. He doesn‚Äôt think James ever noticed.

¬†
