She sighs, giving up on the registry for the moment and sitting back in her chair. ‚ÄúI think‚Ä¶I think there‚Äôs a lot of this that I don‚Äôt understand. Politics is not my strong suit. But‚Ä¶I liked Timmy Finchley.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, feeling like he‚Äôs missed something. ‚ÄúTimmy Finchley?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was my partner in Herbology in fifth year and sixth year and he was nice. And funny. And he helped me out this one time when I didn‚Äôt know the answers on a pop quiz.‚Äù

None of this is clearing anything up for Regulus. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand‚Ä¶what does Timmy Finchley have to do with the war?‚Äù

Cerci stares back at him. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs Muggle born.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence.

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd he was brilliant at Herbology,‚Äù Cerci goes on. ‚ÄúProbably the best in the class. Better than me. So I don‚Äôt know how you could say he wasn‚Äôt a real Wizard. How you could say he didn‚Äôt deserve to be there. Or that his magic wasn‚Äôt as strong as everybody else‚Äôs because it was. Or‚Äîwhat about Mary Macdonald?‚Äù

Regulus feels something like nausea at the mention of Mary Macdonald. ‚ÄúWhat about her?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was like, the most amazing Quidditch player I‚Äôve ever seen.‚Äù

Regulus gives her a look. ‚ÄúThe most amazing?‚Äù

Cerci rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah, after you, of course.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut she was amazing, you can‚Äôt deny that?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, I can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd she‚Äôs a Muggle born and if Voldemort had his way we never would have gotten to see her play and that would have been a shame. Like sucking some of the beauty out of the world.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou really think Mary Macdonald is that important?‚Äù Regulus asks before he can stop himself.

Cerci blinks at him. ‚ÄúI think everyone is important,‚Äù and then, while Regulus is still trying to grasp that; ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôm not claiming to understand all the complexities of what is going on here. But I do know that Muggle borns deserve to be treated better than they have been. And I‚Äôve never met any Muggles, but I‚Äôm sure the same goes for them.‚Äù It's so simple for her. Caring. It isn‚Äôt like that for Regulus. It‚Äôs this tangled up thing, hard to drag to the surface, to sort out. For Regulus caring is a finite resource, like he has to be careful who he chooses to spend it on or he‚Äôll run out. He‚Äôs not sure why that is. Not sure what‚Äôs wrong with him.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve never said anything to me.‚Äù

Cerci‚Äôs brows draw together. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know what I am,‚Äù Regulus manages, flipping his left forearm up without even thinking. He sees Cerci‚Äôs eyes snap to it and then back to his face. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôve never said anything?‚Äù

It takes her a moment, her eyes thoughtful, Regulus can practically see her mind turning. ‚ÄúDo you think Timmy Finchley is less of a Wizard than you?‚Äù

Regulus pokes and prods that thought. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúEven though his parents are Muggles?‚Äù

Regulus nods slowly. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù because he‚Äôs nothing if not rational, and rationally he knows that Muggle borns got top marks in plenty of his courses, not just Timmy Finchley.

‚ÄúThen why exactly do you have that thing on your arm Regulus?‚Äù

He opens and closes his mouth. Not sure what to say. There are so many reasons. So many that he can‚Äôt believe the one that makes it out of his mouth is: ‚ÄúI was scared.‚Äù

And he had been, whatever James thinks. He really had been.

Scared about so many things.

Still is.

Cerci gives him a sad smile. ‚ÄúLike I said, I don‚Äôt understand all the complexities.‚Äù

It‚Äôs an out he knows he doesn‚Äôt deserve. That he feels dirty for making her give him. He wants to tell her that she doesn‚Äôt need to, that he‚Äôs not worth bending her morals for, but just as he‚Äôs opening his mouth the house shakes.

Regulus rolls his eyes even though his whole body goes tense, hands gripping tight to the arms of his chair.

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù Cerci scrambles to keep the book from slipping off her lap. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs still trying to get in?‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth. ‚ÄúYup.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd think he‚Äôd take the hint.‚Äù

Regulus gives her a wane smile. ‚ÄúTaking hints is not Lucius‚Äôs specialty‚Äù

There‚Äôs another shake, a few books falling off the shelves around them. It doesn‚Äôt usually go on for long‚ÄîLucius trying to break his wards‚Äîlike he‚Äôs just tapping on his door, reminding Regulus that he‚Äôs there. That he wants in.

‚ÄúIt wouldn‚Äôt‚Ä¶I mean, you don‚Äôt think it would be simpler just to see what he wants?‚Äù Cerci asks tentatively, clearly aware that she isn‚Äôt seeing the whole picture.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he can‚Äôt quite bring himself to explain more than that, but Cerci just nods, not forcing him to.

‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you worried about what he‚Äôll do when he sees you again? He‚Äôll have to eventually right? If Voldemort summons you?‚Äù

‚ÄúLucius won‚Äôt do anything in public, especially not in front of Voldemort,‚Äù or at least that‚Äôs what Regulus is banking on. He hasn‚Äôt seen or spoken to Lucius since the day of the attack on the Ministry.

Another thunderous shake ripples through the house.

He‚Äôs locked them all out of his wards at this point; Lucius, Narcissa, Bellatrix. Fuck family. Besides, the last thing he needs is one of them showing up and figuring out what him and Cerci are working on.

‚ÄúHold on,‚Äù Cerci slams her finger down in the middle of the page she‚Äôs reading. ‚ÄúI recognize that name.‚Äù

Regulus looks up. ‚ÄúWhat name?‚Äù

But Cerci isn‚Äôt paying attention, already scrambling through the pile of books at her side and pulling up a relatively small one.

‚ÄúCerci, what name?‚Äù

‚ÄúTom Marvolo Riddle,‚Äù she mutters, still flipping through the book.

Regulus scrunches his face. ‚ÄúRiddle? That‚Äôs not a pureblood family.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, that‚Äôs not the name I recognize,‚Äù Cerci mutters.

‚ÄúIs it Tom? Because I hate to break it to you but that‚Äôs a pretty common name.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo I‚Äîah ha!‚Äù she says triumphantly, before holding up the book to show Regulus.

He leans forward, squinting. It‚Äôs a book on the Scared Twenty-Eight he realizes, and she‚Äôs showing him a page dictating the members of one particular family, finger pointing to a name.

‚ÄúMarvolo Gaunt,‚Äù Regulus reads out loud before looking back at Cerci. ‚ÄúYou think there‚Äôs a connection?‚Äù

‚ÄúTom might be a common name, but Marvolo is not.‚Äù

Regulus can‚Äôt really argue with that.

Cerci has started scanning the page for information about the Gaunt family. ‚ÄúHey, they‚Äôre descendants of Salazar Slytherin,‚Äù she looks up at Regulus. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt Voldemort a Parseltongue?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe is.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a pretty rare skill, Salazar‚Äôs descendants are some of the only wizards known to have that.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Regulus takes a deep breath, trying not to let them get ahead of themselves. ‚ÄúBut where the hell does Riddle come from? I‚Äôve never heard of any Riddles.‚Äù

Cerci shakes her head, flipping to the index of her book and quickly scanning down the list of words and names. ‚ÄúNo, they‚Äôre not part of the Twenty-Eight anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo that means,‚Äù Regulus says slowly. ‚ÄúThat means if this is Voldemort then‚Ä¶‚Äù he can‚Äôt quite say it out loud, certain if he does the Dark Lord will suddenly appear and send a streak of green light through his chest.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll write to Madam Pince, ask for some older registries, see if I can find any Riddles at Hogwarts before this. And maybe some other student records‚Äîhonour rolls, Quidditch teams‚Äîsee what else we can find out about Tom.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll check the histories,‚Äù Regulus gestures to the bookshelves behind them. ‚ÄúSee if there are any references to Riddles there.‚Äù

Cerci nods, seemingly still deep in thought. ‚ÄúIt would make sense though,‚Äù she says eventually.

‚ÄúWhat would?‚Äù

‚ÄúVoldemort being a half-blood.‚Äù

Regulus laughs, because he‚Äôs never heard anything that would make less sense.

‚ÄúNo, think about it though,‚Äù Cerci goes on. ‚ÄúIf he was a pureblood we would have grown up with him, or his mother or his aunt. We‚Äôd have gone over to his house for tea or holiday parties. But no one seems to know him, no one seems to be attached to him. Meaning‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt one of us,‚Äù Regulus finishes and then, before he can stop himself, he laughs again. ‚ÄúChrist. The Dark Lord, spokesman for blood purity, might have a Muggle dad.‚Äù

‚ÄúOr mum,‚Äù Cerci adds quickly.

Regulus dips his head in acknowledgement, still feeling utterly bemused by the whole thing. Still certain they must have it wrong. ‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù he says, swiping a hand over his face, ‚Äúthis all just got so much more complicated.‚Äù

¬†

He doesn‚Äôt take any potions before he goes to bed. He is trying. To be better. For James. He‚Äôs trying not to give up. It‚Äôs the least he can do. Unfortunately that means he doesn‚Äôt get much sleep. One nightmare bleeding into the next.

No, please, please, please. I‚Äôm a good man. I swear. I‚Äôm going to get married, please.

Regulus, I want you to know, that our door is always open okay? If you ever need it.

Come on Reg, have a little faith in me yeah?

They‚Äôre relentless. The ghosts. Being in his head feels like being on a boat in the middle of a storm. No matter how hard he tries he just keeps taking on water. Every time he thinks his thoughts have shown him the worst of it something more painful comes along and he‚Äôs sinking all over again.

Eventually he gives up on sleeping. Shaky and sweaty, he lies in his bed, clutching at James‚Äôs present. He wears it all the time now, never takes it off. Sometimes he talks to the stars, other times he just holds it, letting James‚Äôs magic hum in the palm of his hand.

Spring.

Spring.

Spring.

It helps. It doesn‚Äôt fix anything. But it helps.

There‚Äôs a crack and suddenly Kreacher is standing at the foot of his bed.

‚ÄúGood, Master Regulus is already awake,‚Äù he says as Regulus sits up. ‚ÄúMiss Cerci is waiting for him.‚Äù

Regulus blinks, rubbing the sleep from his eyes. ‚ÄúCerci? Is here?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes sir.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow?‚Äù he looks out the window, it can‚Äôt be later than eight in the morning. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúI is not knowing the courting rituals of witches, but she is here.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúHow many times do I have to tell you we‚Äôre not courting, Jesus.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell courting or no courting she is being here and waiting, so sir should be getting out of bed.‚Äù

Regulus dramatically throws the blankets off of him. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah, tell her I‚Äôll be down in twenty minutes.‚Äù

Kreacher scrunches his face. ‚ÄúYou should not be keeping ladies waiting so long.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell then ladies should call ahead of time,‚Äù he says as he gets into the shower.

Twenty minutes later Regulus is traipsing down the stairs, curls warm and soft from the drying spell he used. Cerci is standing at the bottom waiting for him, still wearing her coat.

He arches his brow. ‚ÄúNot staying?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going on a field trip,‚Äù she announces giddily.

‚ÄúA field trip? Where?‚Äù

‚ÄúBath.‚Äù

Regulus stops at the bottom of the stairs, bemused smile on his face. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause,‚Äù she says, eyes twinkling, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs where the Slytherin Archives are.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Slytherin Archives?‚Äù he repeats slowly. ‚ÄúWhat the fuck is that?‚Äù

Cerci rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs where they keep the historical records of the Slytherin family. They have a whole room dedicated just to Salazar‚Äîhis papers, books, letters, some personal items his relatives have been willing to give-up‚Ä¶or sell. I was thinking about going even before yesterday, but now that we know Voldemort might be a descendant of Salazar I think there‚Äôs a good chance the Horcrux will be something to do with him.‚Äù

Regulus takes this all in, hand going unconsciously to the locket around his neck. ‚ÄúSo we‚Äôre going to Bath,‚Äù he says finally, causing Cerci to smile.

‚ÄúSo we‚Äôre going to Bath.‚Äù

¬†

They Apparate onto the steps of a rather unassuming building‚Äîtall and thin, made of a warn white stone, with a slate roof and giant chimney. It‚Äôs cold today, nearing December, and Regulus wraps his arms around himself as his teeth start to chatter. There‚Äôs an ornate snake shaped knocker on the door but instead of using it Cerci turns to the small intercom on the wall beside it and presses a button. There‚Äôs a long pause, Regulus dancing back and forth between his feet trying to keep warm, before a crackly voice speaks to them.

‚ÄúHello?‚Äù

Cerci leans forward. ‚ÄúHi! It‚Äôs Cerci Greengrass, I have an appointment with Madam Wormstahl to go through the archives this morning?‚Äù

There‚Äôs another pause and then a buzzing noise as the door in front of them clicks open. Cerci walks through with no hesitation, seemingly unafraid, Regulus, on the other hand, slips his wand into his palm. He does not much like walking into strange buildings unarmed.

They enter what appears to be a reception area, with dirty white wall-to-wall carpeting and some generic harp music playing in the background. The witch behind the desk in front of them doesn‚Äôt look up from the magazine in her lap.

‚ÄúTake a seat,‚Äù she waves vaguely at the rickety chairs pushed against the wall. ‚ÄúWormstahl will be with you shortly.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkie dokie,‚Äù Cerci says happily.

The minute they‚Äôre sitting a wave of exhaustion hits Regulus, reminding him that he hasn‚Äôt slept. He didn‚Äôt take any potions this morning either. Which is an improvement. Should be an improvement. Except it‚Äôs left him feeling‚Ä¶delicate. A little weak. A little shaky. And so fucking tired. He sighs, leaning back in his chair and resting his head against the wall.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he hears Cerci ask softly, ‚Äúyou okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúHmm,‚Äù he answers. ‚ÄúJust tired.‚Äù

He‚Äôs only going to rest his eyes for a second.

Just a second.

Just‚Äî

Evan is lying in his arms, his body a heavy weight, eyes staring straight ahead.

Oh no.

Oh no.

Oh no.

Not again.

Please not again.

Regulus holds the body closer, tightens his grip, a promise not to let go. Not this time.

Evan‚Äôs dead unseeing eyes suddenly begin to move, it‚Äôs unnatural, sending shivers down Regulus‚Äôs spine as they find him.

Don‚Äôt leave me.

I won‚Äôt.

I won‚Äôt.

I promise I won‚Äôt.

Don‚Äôt leave me here.

I‚Äôm sorry.

I‚Äôm sorry.

I‚Äôm so sorry.

Don‚Äôt leave me here Regulus. Don‚Äôt leave me behind. I don‚Äôt want to be alone. Don‚Äôt let them have me.

I won‚Äôt.

I won‚Äôt.

I won‚Äî

But the hands come out of nowhere. Appearing from somewhere in the dark. Reaching fingers wrapping around Evan‚Äôs ankles, his wrists.

Regulus struggles, he kicks and thrashes but it‚Äôs no use. They pull Evan out of his hands.

NO!

No!

No!

And he‚Äôs so focused on Evan, on the loss of the weight of his body in his arms.

That he doesn‚Äôt realize he‚Äôs being pulled under too.

At least not until the moment he stops being able to breathe.

‚ÄúRegulus!‚Äù

He jolts awake, nearly falling out of his chair and wincing away from Cerci‚Äôs hand on his arm. She instantly pulls back, concern scrawled across her face as Regulus struggles to remember where he is. The woman behind the desk is finally looking up, and there‚Äôs a new woman‚Äîshe‚Äôs small, draped in a green shawl, hair pulled back in a bun.

Regulus drops his head between his knees and tries to breathe, nails digging into his thighs. Fuck.

Fuck this isn‚Äôt good.

He‚Äôs shaking, sweat covering every inch of his skin. It had felt so real.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù Cerci‚Äôs voice is soft as she crouches down next to him, not trying to touch him again.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he wheezes, hating himself for this. Hating himself for all of it.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so okay that I don‚Äôt even have a word for how okay it is.‚Äù

That makes Regulus huff out a laugh. Or at least something laugh like.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in Bath,‚Äù she says, somehow knowing that being reminded of what is real and happening and now, will help. ‚ÄúAt the archives, getting ready to do some sleuthing.‚Äù

Inhale.

Exhale.

Inhale.

Exhale.

God he‚Äôs getting so tired of this. He doesn‚Äôt remember ever having panic attacks this frequently before.

Inhale.

Exhale.

Inhale.

Exhale.

Stop this, he shouts at himself. Stop this right now. You‚Äôre being ridiculous.

He forces himself to sit up straight even though he‚Äôs still shaking. Even though he probably needs more time. He can‚Äôt stand the feeling of having everyone in the room staring at him. Slowly he relaxes his hands, pulling his nails out of his thighs.

Inhale.

Exhale.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù his voice is gravelly but at least it comes out of his mouth.

‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù Cerci asks, and Regulus nods. She watches him for a few more seconds, like she‚Äôs giving him time to take it back, and when he doesn‚Äôt she turns to the woman standing behind them‚ÄîWormstahl, Regulus presumes. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Cerci says more clearly, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre ready.‚Äù

The woman looks a little startled, ‚ÄúWe can reschedule if you aren‚Äôt feeling‚Ä¶up to it, today?‚Äù

Cerci looks back at Regulus who shakes his head. They‚Äôre here already and besides, they don‚Äôt have much time. He isn‚Äôt exactly sure what Voldemort will do when he learns about James‚Äôs baby, but he doesn‚Äôt want to wait and find out.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù the woman adjusts her posture, seeming to accept that she isn‚Äôt going to get rid of them, not that Regulus blames her for trying. ‚ÄúFollow me then.‚Äù

She heads down the hall in front of them, Cerci standing up and offering Regulus her hand. He actually has to take a minute, bracing himself against the chorus of

weak

weak

weak

that runs through his head before he can force himself to take her hand. Knowing he needs it.

‚ÄúDo you want me to let go?‚Äù Cerci whispers as they follow their guide, fingers still laced together.

He grits his teeth. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù Because it helps. Having something solid. And real. Having something he can trust.

He‚Äôs getting worse. The anxiety, the panic‚Äîit‚Äôs getting worse. The potions help, but they have their own side effects, Regulus knows that, he does. Knows that people get addicted to them. Maybe he‚Äôs one of those people, he can‚Äôt tell, it doesn‚Äôt feel quite that simple. He just knows that he can‚Äôt go to James like this. He needs to find a way to get himself under control.

‚ÄúThe archives here cover a wide variety of areas,‚Äù the woman in front of them says before pulling out her wand and unlocking the door on their right. Everything about this building is bland and uniform. Regulus isn‚Äôt sure what he was expecting exactly, but after growing up in Grimmauld Place he can‚Äôt help but feel that Salazar would not have appreciated his legacy being stored in such drab surroundings.

‚ÄúThe Slytherin family has a long and complicated history spanning many centuries,‚Äù she opens the door and leads them into a room with a low ceiling, harsh lights, and rows and rows of shelves. ‚ÄúBut going off your letter you‚Äôre specifically interested in Salazar?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes that‚Äôs right,‚Äù Cerci says cheerfully, looking around.

‚ÄúEveryone always is,‚Äù in a tone of voice that can‚Äôt be described as anything other than disdainful. ‚ÄúA pity, when the family has done so much more than simply help build a school.‚Äù

Regulus looks over at the woman, a bit impressed that she‚Äôs just been able to make the founding of one of the most infamous magical schools in the entirety of human history sound unimpressive.

‚ÄúOver there we have artefacts,‚Äù she gestures to a row of cabinets by the windows. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre locked, but the outside is labelled with the contents so if you wish to view any of the items you must tell me and I will handle them for you. You are not permitted to touch any of them yourself, understood?‚Äù

Cerci shoots Regulus a look before smiling at the woman. ‚ÄúAbsolutely.‚Äù

They receive a curt nod in response. ‚ÄúThe shelves in front of us are all the paper documents we have. These,‚Äù she puts great emphasis on the word, ‚Äúyou may touch yourselves but you cannot write on them or near them, there will be no folding down corners or underlining of any kind, understood?‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù Cerci answers again, causing the woman to stare her down for a minute, like she‚Äôs trying to figure out whether or not she‚Äôs being mocked.

‚ÄúVery well, feel free to have a look around and ask me if you have any questions.‚Äù

Cerci turns to Regulus, eyebrow raised. ‚ÄúWell, what do you reckon?‚Äù

He looks out at the mountains of stuff in front of them, not sure how exactly they‚Äôre going to sift through all of it to find anything useful. Eventually he shrugs: ‚ÄúYou start at one end, I start at the other?‚Äù

Cerci smiles. ‚ÄúPerfect.‚Äù

¬†

It would probably help if they had some idea what they were looking for. Mostly Regulus is just trying to see if there are places or objects that Salazar brings up a lot. Though most of his writing seems to be purely academic. Discussing different material breakdowns in potions‚Äîwhich, yes, okay, Regulus does actually find interesting‚Äîand comparing various chopping and brewing techniques. He has one letter to a friend in which he goes on for three pages about the appropriate thickness for cauldron bottoms.

He also writes a lot about the need of Wizards to guard themselves against Muggles. He does not think that they should be attempting to build political relationships with them, does not believe the Muggles can be trusted to honour any agreements they make. He writes very strong letters to the prominent leaders of the Wizarding world at the time. Not politicians as much as petty lords, each with their own tiny fiefdoms and array of vassals.

Which is fascinating.

Unhelpful.

But fascinating.

Regulus sighs, pushing the hair out of his face as he pulls out another folder of letters. He‚Äôs expecting more of the same‚Äîpolitics and potion theory‚Äîbut then he reads the first line:

Ma moiti√©

Regulus stops. Rubs his eyes. Reads the line again.

Ma moiti√©

My other half. My better half. That‚Äôs what that means, he‚Äôs heard his father use it when referring to his mother once or twice. It‚Äôs meant for intimates. Friends, lovers‚Äî

Ma moiti√©,

I was on a walk the other day, in the forest around my home, and I couldn‚Äôt help thinking about that time when we were young. Fifteen? Sixteen? And you declared that you‚Äôd had enough of farm work and from now on you wanted to instead be an adventurer. The look on your father‚Äôs face, I thought for certain he was going to end you. But then, you always got away with more foolishness than the rest of us (don‚Äôt even try to deny it you know it‚Äôs true). So instead he told you to go on, to try to be an adventurer, to survive on your own in the wilderness without all the comforts of the farm. You were the only one of us who didn‚Äôt seem to know exactly how that was going to end.

I would have been happy to leave you to it, but, of course, you weren‚Äôt having that. Wherever you went I was bound to follow. So we loaded our sacs with a few supplies, and a map we could barely read, and set off on what was inevitably going to be an absolute failure. That first night, out in the wilderness, it rained, do you remember? Started pouring and neither of us knew any spells to keep dry, so eventually we found a cave‚Äîwell, or at least a spot where the cliffs hung out just enough to offer us some shelter.

You started a fire, both of us stripping out of our wet clothes and laying them out to dry, down to nothing but our undergarments. We hadn‚Äôt even kissed yet at that point and seeing you, standing there in all your youthful glory, was absolute agony. You were beautiful even then, before you had properly grown into yourself, properly become the hero everyone knows you as today. Colour high in your cheeks from the fire, hair plastered to your head from the rain. I‚Äôm rather impressed I didn‚Äôt just fall to pieces right then.

And then. You had the audacity to turn to me and beckon. BECKON. Honestly, one smooth gesture, one flick of your wrist. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have to sleep together,‚Äù you said, so self-assured, as though it was the most natural thing in the world, ‚Äúto ward off the cold.‚Äù Ha. But Merlin help me I was powerless against that. The pair of us lying down, the single blanket we‚Äôd brought wrapped around us. I swear my poor heart almost combusted at the feel of you against my back, your arm around my waist, mouth at the nape of my neck.

Do you remember what you said then? Do you remember? The fire dying, the sound of the rain in the trees surrounding us, me slowly drifting to sleep in your arms you said: ‚ÄúI want to always be this close to you.‚Äù

I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôve ever recovered from that. Even all these years later.

I know there is a great deal of life that separates us now, that things are not nearly as simple as they were when we were fifteen. But I can‚Äôt help but hope that you still long for the days when we fell asleep in one another‚Äôs arms. Can‚Äôt help but hope that after it all you still want to be that close to me. Because not a day goes by that I don‚Äôt feel your absence at my side. That I don‚Äôt ache with all the time we‚Äôve lost.

One day maybe, you will feel the urge to be an adventurer again. And find your way back to me.

Yours always,

S.

¬†

Regulus stares at that last line for a long time.

S.

It‚Äôs not possible. It‚Äôs not. Before he can stop himself he starts flipping through the other letters. Most of them start the same way ‚ÄúMa moiti√©‚Äù a few just begin with ‚ÄúLove‚Äù others have no beginning address at all but instead start as though already in the middle of a conversation. He‚Äôs nearly at the end when he finds what he‚Äôs looking for, pulling the letter out of the stack,

Hello G,

it starts, and Regulus feels his heart run head first into his ribs.

Because it‚Äôs impossible. Unthinkable. And yet‚Ä¶and yet‚Ä¶

G&S

Still staring at the page in front of him Regulus gets up and stumbles towards Madam Wormstahl. ‚ÄúWas Salazar Slytherin married?‚Äù he asks numbly, looking up at the older woman. She puts down the parchment she‚Äôd been reading.

‚ÄúNo, he‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúFAMOUSLY A HERMIT!‚Äù Cerci calls from somewhere in the stacks. ‚ÄúI told you that the first time we met Reg JEEEEZ.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes, the woman in front of him looking somewhat disgruntled. ‚ÄúHe was a recluse later in life,‚Äù she goes on when she‚Äôs composed herself again, ‚Äúmoving out to the country and socializing only when forced.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut his line doesn‚Äôt end with him?‚Äù Regulus asks.

‚ÄúNo, it was continued by one of his cousins.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt have any brothers or sisters?‚Äù Regulus can hear Cerci walking towards them from the back of the room.

‚ÄúNo, his immediate family and most of his mother‚Äôs relatives were killed when their home was attacked by Muggles.‚Äù

Cerci gasps. ‚ÄúOh my god that‚Äôs awful.‚Äù

The woman nods soberly. ‚ÄúYes, quite, he was haunted by it for most of his life. Luckily, however, his father‚Äôs family lived to the South and therefore the Slytherin line was able to continue.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut that means there are no direct descendants of Salazar Slytherin?‚Äù Cerci is at Regulus‚Äôs side now, looking a little concerned.

Wormstahl nods again. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs correct.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Cerci shakes her head. ‚ÄúNo it isn‚Äôt. I‚Äôve read the histories of the Sacred Twenty-Eight, the Gaunt line claims direct lineage to Salazar.‚Äù

Wormstahl doesn‚Äôt roll her eyes, but Reg thinks it‚Äôs a near thing. ‚ÄúYes well, people will claim a lot of things if they think it will gain them status and power. But I am telling you now Salazar never had any children, or if he did, they were illegitimate and unrecognized.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd what about Godric Gryffindor?‚Äù Regulus cuts back in, feeling a little impatient. He couldn‚Äôt care less about bloodlines right now.

Both Wormstahl and Cerci turn to him with surprised expressions on their faces. ‚ÄúWhat about Godric Gryffindor?‚Äù

‚ÄúDid he marry?‚Äù

Still looking confused, Wormstahl nods, slowly. ‚ÄúYes, Godric married, had several children. Though later in life I believe him and his wife amicably agreed to live apart. And he moved out to the woods, tiring of being in the public eye.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe moved out to the country,‚Äù Regulus repeats, almost laughing. ‚ÄúLike Salazar?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell I doubt very much it was the same countryside.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you don‚Äôt know?‚Äù

She adjusts herself in her seat, clearly uncomfortable admitting that there is something she doesn‚Äôt know; ‚ÄúNo, I don‚Äôt believe the exact locations of either of their homes have ever been discovered.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo they might have lived together then?‚Äù Cerci pipes up, sounding intrigued.

Wormstahl shoots her a disapproving look. ‚ÄúI very much doubt so. I can‚Äôt see why either of them would want to.‚Äù

No, Regulus thinks, looking back down at the letters in his hands, no I‚Äôm sure you can‚Äôt. He does laugh then, because James was right. Ridiculous, illogical, absurd James Potter had been right. He brushes his thumb gently over the S at the bottom of the page in front of him.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure what about that is amusing to you,‚Äù Wormstahl wraps her shall more tightly around her shoulders.

‚ÄúNothing,‚Äù Regulus shakes his head, trying to get his expression under control. ‚ÄúJust‚Ä¶thought of something else. My apologies. One more question, these letters,‚Äù he holds them up, ‚ÄúAre their counterparts somewhere? It seems like they were all written to the same person.‚Äù

Wormstahl pushes her glasses down to the tip of her nose and motions with her hand for him to pass them over. Reluctantly, Regulus does.

‚ÄúAh yes,‚Äù she says as she begins to flip through them. ‚ÄúThe love letters.‚Äù

‚ÄúLove letters!‚Äù Cerci says excitedly, shimmying her shoulders. ‚ÄúHow scandalous.‚Äù

The woman glares at her. ‚ÄúThere is absolutely nothing scandalous about them, it was perfectly suitable for a man of his stature to write letters to the woman he was courting.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut he never married,‚Äù Regulus asks as she hands the letters back to him.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd we don‚Äôt know who he was writing to?‚Äù

‚ÄúThese were found floating around on the black market, being sold for a very hefty price. Older families sometimes fall on hard times and take to selling heirlooms,‚Äù the disgust she feels about this is clear on her face. ‚ÄúBut the counterparts weren‚Äôt with them, nor have they been found anywhere else. It‚Äôs possible Salazar burnt them, jilted lovers almost always prioritize themselves over historical record.‚Äù

Cerci starts to laugh and then quickly turns it into a cough when the woman‚Äôs ere swings in her direction.

‚ÄúGot it,‚Äù Regulus says, holding back his own smirk. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he turns around and gives Cerci a little shove. ‚ÄúBehave,‚Äù he whispers as they head back towards the shelves.

‚ÄúJilted lovers prioritize themselves over historical record,‚Äù she repeats, barely containing her giggles.

¬†

Regulus spends the rest of their time at the archives shamelessly reading the letters. He goes slow, desperate for every detail, wishing he had the other half of the conversation, that he could know what Godric was saying back. There are so many of them‚Äîyears worth‚Äîthat by the time they‚Äôre leaving, several hours later, he still hasn‚Äôt managed to get through them all.

Madam Wormstahl escorts them back to the front door and Cerci thanks her graciously for her help as they step out into the wintery afternoon.

‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äù Regulus asks as Cerci starts walking down the steps and onto the street. ‚ÄúWe can Apparate from here.‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù she says, staring up at him from the pavement. ‚ÄúCome on Reg, we‚Äôre in Bath,‚Äù she throws her arms out. ‚ÄúLets sightsee.‚Äù

Regulus makes a disgusted face. ‚ÄúYou want me to be a tourist?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh come on you snob, humour me. Besides, you spend too much time shut up in your house anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo not.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo too.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúFine. What exactly do you want to sightsee then?‚Äù

She beams at him. ‚ÄúI knew you‚Äôd come around. There‚Äôs a great ice cream shop just down the street.‚Äù

‚ÄúIce cream, Cerci it‚Äôs freezing!‚Äù

‚ÄúOh it‚Äôs fine,‚Äù she says as she starts walking, hands stuffed in the pockets of her coat. ‚ÄúWell, come on!‚Äù

Grumbling Regulus follows, though he isn‚Äôt happy about it.

The ice cream shop is small and cutesy‚Äîeverything pink with white frills. Cerci makes small talk with the cashier, stopping only to ask Regulus what flavour he wants. When he once again insists that it is too cold for ice cream she just orders him chocolate.

‚ÄúThis is absurd,‚Äù his teeth chatter as they push back out into the cold, clutching their ice creams, since there was nowhere to sit in the shop.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre being dramatic,‚Äù Cerci says, steering them towards an open bench with a view of the street. It‚Äôs all old buildings and cobblestones. Undeniably pretty, even if Regulus refuses to admit so out loud.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt eat this Cerci,‚Äù he says as they sit down. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to get hypothermia or something.‚Äù

She rolls her eyes, pulling her wand out and giving it a tiny flick. A second later Regulus feels the unmistakable sensation of a warming charm descending on him. He turns to her, sarcastically aghast.

‚ÄúThat was illegal!‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah well,‚Äù she licks her ice cream. ‚ÄúThe Ministry has bigger things to worry about then a cheeky warming charm.‚Äù

And, well, Regulus can‚Äôt exactly argue with that.

It‚Äôs quiet out, likely because of the cold, a few people walking down the street with grocery bags in their hands, shoulders pressed together, heads bowed against the wind. It‚Äôs mid-afternoon, the clouds drifting in front of the sun and occasionally blocking it from view, though the beams that slip down twinkle and sparkle off the windows of the buildings on either side of the street.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Cerci says eventually, ‚Äúdid you finish them?‚Äù

He looks over at her, there‚Äôs a spot of ice cream on her nose that he considers telling her about but ultimately decides not to.

‚ÄúDid I finish what?‚Äù

Cerci rolls her eyes, ‚ÄúOh come on, you were glued to that one spot for hours‚Äîthe letters! Did you finish them?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he takes a lick of his own ice cream, which he has to admit, is very good. ‚ÄúNo, there were hundreds of them, it looks like they were talking that way for years. But it shouldn‚Äôt take me too long to get through the rest.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre planning to come back?‚Äù Cerci asks, sounding surprised, and it‚Äôs work for Regulus not to grimace. He probably could have kept that last sentence to himself. He opts not to answer and to instead focus a ridiculous amount of attention on his ice cream, but he can feel Cerci‚Äôs eyes on him.

‚ÄúRegulus‚Ä¶‚Äù she says his name slowly. ‚ÄúDid you‚Äîyou didn‚Äôt‚Ä¶steal the letters did you?‚Äù

Again, he doesn‚Äôt answer, but he does shoot her a look that has Cerci throwing her hands in the air and nearly chucking her ice cream across the street.

‚ÄúAre you kidding me! You know that‚Äôs an actual crime, right?‚Äù

Regulus licks his lips, shrugging. ‚ÄúYes well, like you said, I think the Ministry has bigger problems right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúHonestly,‚Äù she mutters, head shaking. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt take you anywhere,‚Äù though there‚Äôs a smile tugging at the corner of her mouth that suggests she doesn‚Äôt mean it.

‚ÄúOh come on, I couldn‚Äôt leave them there with that woman, they deserve better than that.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you orchestrated a rescue mission for some love letters?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell when you put it like that it sounds ridiculous.‚Äù

Cerci has started to giggle, which Regulus does not appreciate, the noise filling up the empty street around them, bouncing off the stone walls. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such a sap.‚Äù

Regulus just rolls his eyes, returning his attention to his ice cream and refusing to look at her again until she calms down. He‚Äôs not a sap. Absolutely not. Ask anyone.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù she says, once she‚Äôs pulled herself back together, licking the melted ice cream off her hand. ‚ÄúI like the idea of writing love letters.‚Äù

Regulus turns to her, feeling the shift in her tone‚Äîthe new sincerity she‚Äôs trying and failing to hide. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

Cerci nods, not really meeting his eye. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really intimate, reading a letter about someone‚Äôs feelings for you. It‚Äôs this way to be close to them, to give them a part of you, that isn‚Äôt about‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúSex?‚Äù

She sighs, sounding tired. ‚ÄúI guess. It‚Äôs just‚Äîsometimes when you stand in a room with someone and you try to be vulnerable it feels like‚Ä¶a means to an end. But with love letters it‚Äôs‚Ä¶you have all these feelings and you‚Äôre telling this person and it connects you to each other and neither of you is expecting more than that. The point of a love letter is just to feel.‚Äù

She bites down on her lower lip nervously. ‚ÄúIs that a stupid thing to say?‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúI just, I have all these feelings in my chest, and I want to give them to someone but‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know how to do that without leaving them wanting more.‚Äù

Regulus looks out at the street for a moment, thinking. Trying to figure out what to say. Finally, after swallowing the last of his ice cream, he speaks: ‚ÄúIs there‚Ä¶someone specific we‚Äôre talking about here?‚Äù

Cerci‚Äôs cheeks flush pink. ‚ÄúI‚Äîmaybe.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, that‚Äôs‚Äîthat‚Äôs good. That‚Äôs cool. Um‚Ä¶‚Äù Merlin he‚Äôs bad at this. ‚ÄúIs he‚Ä¶nice?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs amazing.‚Äù

Regulus nods, laughing a little. ‚ÄúWell okay, not to, y‚Äôknow, state the obvious here but, have you tried‚Ä¶talking to her?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course I‚Äôve talked to her,‚Äù Cerci says, but her voice is a little too squeaky to be believable. It takes about three seconds of Regulus staring silently back at her for Cerci to crack. ‚ÄúI HAVE talked to her,‚Äù she says again, ‚ÄúA lot. About school and her job and where she wants to travel and how her favourite vegetable is squash because it‚Äôs decorative and tasty.‚Äù

Regulus arches his brow. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve talked about her favourite vegetable?‚Äù

Cerci glares at him. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a perfectly reasonable thing to ask someone.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, you actually ASKED her about her favourite vegetable?‚Äù

Cerci throws her arms in the air. ‚ÄúCan we not mock me right now!‚Äù

‚ÄúFine, fine, sorry,‚Äù Regulus bites down on his lip, trying to hold in his laughter. ‚ÄúOkay, so you‚Äôve talked‚Ä¶about‚Ä¶vegetables,‚Äù Cerci looks ready to punch him again so he moves on quickly, ‚ÄúBut have you, you know, talked about how you‚Ä¶feel?‚Äù

She continues to glare which has Regulus holding his hands up in surrender. ‚ÄúListen I‚Äôm just saying, she can‚Äôt read your mind‚Äîwell, unless she‚Äôs good at Legilimency, in which case I guess maybe you don‚Äôt have to tell her anything.‚Äù

Cerci rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not reading my mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, then‚Ä¶‚Äù

Cerci groans, taking a large bite out of her ice cream cone and then, with a full mouth: ‚ÄúWhamt do I evwen sway?‚Äù

Regulus grimaces, ‚ÄúYou have terrible table manners, you know that?‚Äù

Cerci kicks his foot. ‚ÄúFirst of all,‚Äù she says once she‚Äôs properly swallowed her food. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs not even a table here. And second of all, you‚Äôre spending too much time with Kreacher, you‚Äôre starting to sound like him.‚Äù

Regulus kicks her back.

‚ÄúJust tell your stupid crush that you have a stupid crush on her.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou say that like it‚Äôs simple,‚Äù some of the amusement has drained out of her voice, and Regulus knows that she has more to say so he lets the silence linger, lets her find her words. ‚ÄúI just‚Äî‚Äú she starts and then stops, sighing in frustration. ‚ÄúI just want to be with her all the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, so tell her that‚ÄîI mean, maybe not exactly that, that sounds a bit like she might wake up to find you hovering at the end of her bed watching her sleep or like, saving strands of her hair or something. But a more casual version of that.‚Äù

Cerci makes a disgruntled noise. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how to be casual.‚Äù

Which Regulus thinks might actually be true.

‚ÄúMaybe try just asking her on a date?‚Äù he suggests, fairly certain that‚Äôs something normal people do casually.

Cerci looks uncertain again, biting her lip. ‚ÄúBut won‚Äôt that be like leading her on? Don‚Äôt dates normally end with, you know, shagging?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus says, and then, ‚ÄúI mean, I don‚Äôt think so? Honestly I‚Äôve never really been on a date.‚Äù

Cerci‚Äôs head snaps towards him. ‚ÄúWhat! Not even with your boy toy? I really am going to have to have a talk with him.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes, hating the way the colour rushes to his cheeks. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have‚Äîugh, I can‚Äôt even say it.‚Äù

‚ÄúBoy toy?‚Äù she grins as he pushes her. ‚ÄúToo late to take it back Reg, drunk you already spilled the beans. Though he neglected to mention that this boy hasn‚Äôt taken you on a date!‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head, looking away and trying to keep his expression under control. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs complicated,‚Äù and then, because he‚Äôs being reckless, ‚ÄúActually, I guess we‚Äôve been on one date. Kind of.‚Äù

‚ÄúOooh, tell me more, I need ideas.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe went swimming,‚Äù Merlin that was so long ago. He sees little flashes‚Äîwarm sunlight, James smiling at him from the water.

‚ÄúLike you went to the beach?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, it was‚Ä¶kind of‚Ä¶a waterfall.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcuse me!!!‚Äù he feels Cerci sit up beside him but he vehemently refuses to look at her, face already too red. ‚ÄúYour date was to a waterfall! That is like the most romantic thing I have ever heard!‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah well,‚Äù Regulus does his best to keep his voice blank, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs stupid like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúStupid romantic, you mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, can we move on now please? I thought we were talking about your love life?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a love life,‚Äù she says, loud enough that she scares some of the pigeons that had gathered not that far from them.

‚ÄúWell ask this girl out and you will,‚Äù and then, when she starts grumbling under her breath, he knocks their shoulders together. ‚ÄúListen just‚Ä¶just be honest, that‚Äôs all anyone can ask,‚Äù he feels like a fucking hypocrite as the words leave his mouth.

And then something else occurs to him. ‚ÄúHave you‚Ä¶talked to your mum about‚Ä¶any of this?‚Äù

Another groan leaves Cerci‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúNo, she‚Äôs still inviting eligible bachelors over for dinner every weekend. It‚Äôs torture.‚Äù

Regulus grimaces. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always hated dinner parties.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt wouldn't be so painful if any of them were half-decent, if maybe I could at least like one of them, you know? But they‚Äôre all awful.‚Äù

Regulus can imagine, he‚Äôs been forced into close proximity with the sons of pureblood families for the majority of his life. Barty and Evan were always the only two he could stand. Or maybe that‚Äôs misrepresenting things, because they were also the only two who ever gave him the time of day. Everyone else wanted to play with Sirius. Regulus can‚Äôt blame them. He wanted to play with Sirius too.

‚ÄúWhat about your mum?‚Äù

He blinks, coming back to the present. ‚ÄúMy mum?‚Äù

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt she trying to marry you off as well?‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù with everything else going on, his mother‚Äôs desire to find him a wife has somewhat fallen off his radar. ‚ÄúTo be honest, I haven‚Äôt really been‚Ä¶speaking to her.‚Äù

Cerci looks surprised. ‚ÄúAnd she hasn‚Äôt just shown up at Grimmauld?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think‚Äî‚Äú Regulus clears his throat. ‚ÄúI think my father dying is taking up a lot of her time right now,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt quite manage to say that without his voice cracking.

‚ÄúOh Reg,‚Äù Cerci reaches out, squeezing his hand. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, really,‚Äù he takes a deep breath. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been coming for a long time I just‚Ä¶‚Äù he looks away. ‚ÄúI feel bad, about not going to see him, but I don‚Äôt want to worry him. I want to be‚Ä¶I‚Äôm not‚Ä¶right now just isn‚Äôt a good time.‚Äù

He‚Äôll see right through me.

I‚Äôll break his heart.

Regulus lets out a shaking breath. ‚ÄúOkay, changing topics again‚Äîdid you find anything useful in there,‚Äù he nods back towards the archives.

Cerci grimaces. ‚ÄúNot really, except that nothing is missing from their collections‚Äînothing out on loan or stolen.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo if Voldemort is using something connected to Slytherin he didn‚Äôt get it in there.‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúApparently members of the Gaunt family are still alive and have some heirlooms they haven‚Äôt sold, or at least that‚Äôs what Madam Wormstahl said. She gave me their address so we can try visiting them, see if they know anything.‚Äù

Regulus runs a hand over his face feeling a little overwhelmed by all the things they don‚Äôt know. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre also gonna have to figure out how to destroy the thing once we find it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere wasn‚Äôt anything in the book you read?‚Äù

Regulus lets out a frustrated sigh. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have anything in my notes but it‚Äôs possible I wasn‚Äôt paying enough attention at the time, that I missed something. Except now I can‚Äôt go back and check because‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúVoldemort has it,‚Äù she finishes for him and Regulus nods. ‚ÄúAnd the only other copy is at Hogwarts.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I can‚Äôt exactly see Dumbledore handing it over to either of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Cerci agrees. ‚ÄúLets put a pin in that for now, there must be another book about Horcruxes out there. But first we have to figure out what we‚Äôre looking for and where it is. Agreed?‚Äù

Regulus sighs. ‚ÄúAgreed.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo team!‚Äù

He snorts as she throws her hand up in the air like they‚Äôre at a Quidditch match. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think this is a ‚Äúgo team‚Äù moment,‚Äù he says, but Cerci only makes a disbelieving sound, looking at Regulus very seriously.

‚ÄúAny moment is a ‚Äúgo team‚Äù moment if you try hard enough.‚Äù

And, well, Regulus isn‚Äôt about to argue with that.

¬†

¬†

The second he gets home he rushes up to his bedroom and starts pouring over the letters. Greedily eating up every line. From what he can tell these were written at least a decade after Salazar left Hogwarts and they seem to go on for a decade more before they stop.

Because Godric finally came, whispers the childish voice in his head. Because Salazar finally let him in. Because after spending nearly their entire lives orbiting around one another it was finally time. Alone in the woods they spent their old age together. Hidden from the world.

Or at least that‚Äôs how Regulus is deciding the story goes.

Unwilling to accept anything else.

He feels a little giddy, his head filled with pages and pages of words. Words that aren‚Äôt his own and yet sometimes feel so close to his heart that he‚Äôs certain he‚Äôs thought them himself. He wants desperately to tell James. He knows he‚Äôll laugh when he finds out, knows his head will grow at least another two sizes.

He‚Äôll say something like ‚ÄúOf course I got it right. I can‚Äôt believe you ever doubted me.‚Äù

Before Regulus can stop himself he‚Äôs getting off his bed and sitting down at his desk, pulling out a fresh piece of parchment and a quill. Something in him feels lighter than it has in days, in weeks, in years and he knows it‚Äôs silly, knows it‚Äôs half-in his head. But maybe‚Äîmaybe if Salazar Slytherin and Godric Gryffindor could find one another after all they‚Äôd been through. After all that had happened. Maybe Regulus and James could too.

His quill draws elegantly across the page, the first words squeezing his heart.

Dear J,

¬†

PART II REMUS

¬†

It‚Äôs morning, and Remus is shamelessly staring at a slumped over Sirius Black, barely awake enough to keep his head out of his coffee. His hair is an absolute disaster‚Äîsticking up in all directions, static-y and probably in need of a good wash. The sunlight is soft and it makes the whole flat glow a sort of warm yellow, but especially Sirius, who looks almost golden in it. And for a moment, just this moment, Remus‚Äôs life is beautiful.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he nudges Sirius‚Äôs foot under the table and Sirius looks up, eyes still half shut, lines on his face from the bedsheets. ‚ÄúI love you.‚Äù

Something almost‚Ä¶sad, seems to flicker across Sirius‚Äôs face before he wipes it clean. ‚ÄúLove you too,‚Äù he croaks, not quite able to meet Remus‚Äôs eyes.

Alarm bells ring faintly in Remus‚Äôs ears as his brows draw together. ‚ÄúPads what‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú but he‚Äôs interrupted by some extremely loud and rude tapping on the window. He turns to see an owl, perched on the sill outside their living room, waiting to be let in. He spares one more look for Sirius who has his head down again, before he gets up to let the bird in.

‚ÄúHere you go,‚Äù he hands it a piece of bacon from his plate as he starts to detach the letter from its leg. The minute the roll of parchment is free the bird takes off, leaving Remus staring after it, a little startled. ‚ÄúNot expecting a response then?‚Äù he mutters to no one in particular as he closes the window and returns to the table.

‚ÄúWho's it from?‚Äù

Remus shakes his head, sliding his finger under the wax seal and unrolling the parchment. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt recognize the bird,‚Äù he mutters. However, the minute he sees the handwriting he knows who it is.

Dear Remus,

The request you made has been carried out. They‚Äôll be expecting you any day now.

Hope you are well,

A. Dumbledore

He reads the lines over a few more times before he finally starts breathing normally again. He always gets worried when he receives post from Dumbledore.

‚ÄúMoons? Rem? Oi! What does it say?‚Äù

He looks up to see Sirius wide awake, staring at him with a worried expression. He must have zoned out for a second. ‚ÄúSorry‚Äîeveryone‚Äôs okay, promise, it‚Äôs nothing like that,‚Äù he sees Sirius‚Äôs shoulders relax ever so slightly. They‚Äôre always expecting bad news these days.

‚ÄúWill you uh,‚Äù Remus clears his throat. ‚ÄúWill you come somewhere with me?‚Äù

‚ÄúAnywhere,‚Äù Sirius answers so quickly that Remus thinks his heart may actually melt. Sirius flushes, looking away like he‚Äôs embarrassed, but he still says: ‚ÄúYou know I‚Äôd go anywhere with you.‚Äù

It takes Remus a few minutes to recover from that.

A few lifetimes.

When his brain starts working again he folds up the letter and slides it into the pocket of his pyjamas, standing up and walking over to Sirius, kissing the top of his head. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he murmurs into his hair before going to get dressed.

¬†

Of course it takes Sirius ages to get ready. He spends at least thirty minutes on his hair, though doing what Remus hasn‚Äôt the foggiest, even after all these years. When Sirius finally comes out of the bathroom to find Remus leaning against the door with his arms crossed and his brow raised he rolls his eyes.

‚ÄúYeah, yeah I know, I know,‚Äù he grabs his leather jacket off of the back of the sofa where he tossed it yesterday.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs too cold for that,‚Äù Remus says as Sirius comes towards him.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt let the weather boss you around Moons, you gotta show it who‚Äôs in charge,‚Äù he shoots Remus a grin as they walk out the door, locking it behind them with the flick of their wands.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a mad thing to say, you do know that right?‚Äù

‚ÄúI would hope so. I‚Äôd hate to start saying sane things. Be bloody boring that.‚Äù

Shaking his head Remus pushes Sirius in the direction of the Leaky Cauldron.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not Apparating today,‚Äù he explains when he sees the confused look on the other boy‚Äôs face. They maneuver their way through the street, which is not nearly as busy as it would have been a year ago, or two years ago. The attacks and abductions are keeping people away. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre taking the Muggle bus.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù Sirius says carefully. ‚ÄúYou planning on telling me where we‚Äôre going or is this more of a surprise thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to an orphanage,‚Äù Remus does his best to keep his voice casual, like this is a perfectly normal thing to do. He‚Äôs not sure he sells it.

‚ÄúAn orphanage?‚Äù Sirius repeats. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs someone I want to see.‚Äù

For a long moment Sirius doesn‚Äôt speak, long enough that Remus sneaks a peek at him out of the corner of his eyes. He doesn‚Äôt look angry, which is good, though what he does look Remus isn‚Äôt quite sure.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre being very cryptic,‚Äù Sirius says eventually.

Remus winces. ‚ÄúI know. I‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù but he isn‚Äôt sure how much he‚Äôs allowed to tell him, knows he‚Äôs already going against Dumbledore by bringing Sirius along he just‚Äîhe isn‚Äôt sure he can do this on his own.

There‚Äôs another long pause before Sirius speaks again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad that you‚Äôre taking me with you this time,‚Äù his voice is smaller than usual, and it breaks Remus‚Äôs heart a little bit.

He reaches out, offering his hand, and Sirius immediately tangles their fingers together.

‚ÄúI always want to take you with me, you know that right?‚Äù he says, looking at Sirius properly.

He sees that same sad look from earlier. ‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù Sirius says finally. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to hear it though.‚Äù

Remus squeezes his hand tight. ‚ÄúI always want to take you with me,‚Äù he repeats.

They look at each other for a long time before Sirius speaks, ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

Remus lifts their hands up, kissing the back of Sirius‚Äôs. ‚ÄúChrist Sirius, don‚Äôt you have fucking gloves you‚Äôre freezing.‚Äù

And that makes Sirius laugh, breaking the tension. Sirius pulls his hand free so he can swing his arm around Remus‚Äôs shoulders and pull him into his side. ‚ÄúWhat did I tell you about showing the weather who‚Äôs in charge, huh?‚Äù

¬†

Sirius is fidgety on the bus. He has no patience, which always makes the process of actually travelling anywhere a chore. In a ridiculous way, Remus feels a little nostalgic about it, thinking back to all those trips on the train when Sirius couldn‚Äôt sit still. Tapping his feet or jiggling his knees or, in their younger years, running through the cars causing chaos.

In the end it only takes them thirty minutes before they‚Äôre walking up the drive of an austere looking brick building. There‚Äôs a black metal fence around it, the lawn more mud than anything else.

‚ÄúThis place gives me the creeps,‚Äù Sirius whispers as they make their way up the front steps.

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you literally grow up in a haunted house?‚Äù Remus asks as he holds the door open.

Sirius seems to consider this. ‚ÄúThe ghosts were honestly the least creepy thing about Grimmauld, but I take your point.‚Äù

They walk into a small reception area with white tile floors and harsh florescent lights. In front of them sits a brown haired woman behind a desk, she has a pug nose, and a pair of reading glasses on a chain around her neck. Remus suddenly feels uncertain, Dumbledore‚Äôs letter had been fairly vague and he isn‚Äôt exactly sure what he‚Äôs supposed to say here.

The woman looks up at them and smiles. ‚ÄúWell hello there,‚Äù she beckons them forward. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be shy, don‚Äôt be shy‚Äîmy names‚Äôs Aileen, how can I help you two handsome gentlemen today?‚Äù she has a friendly voice.

It‚Äôs not until Sirius nudges him with his elbow that Remus realizes he‚Äôs going to have to be the one to handle this social situation. He clears his throat, feeling thoroughly out of his depth. ‚ÄúYeah, um, we‚Äôre here to visit Charlotte?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you on her list?‚Äù

Remus blinks. ‚ÄúHer list?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf approved visitors?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Äîyes?‚Äù Dumbledore said everything was arranged‚Ä¶

‚ÄúExcellent, just give me your name so that I can double check.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight, okay, it‚Äôs Remus Lupin.‚Äù

‚ÄúOoh, that‚Äôs a new one, I‚Äôve never met a Remus before,‚Äù she says as she walks over to the filing cabinets behind her and starts flipping through folders.

Sirius moves closer to him, their shoulders brushing. ‚ÄúCharlotte?‚Äù he asks quietly, but Remus only shakes his head. He can‚Äôt explain who she is, especially not here.

‚ÄúAh! Got it!‚Äù Aileen pulls out a piece of paper, eyes scanning through it, Remus‚Äôs heart hammering in his chest. ‚ÄúOh you‚Äôre her Uncle, how lovely. Do you mind just showing me some ID?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh,‚Äù yes, actually he does. ‚ÄúI, um‚Äî‚Äú Merlin he‚Äôs an idiot. Of course, they need ID. And now he‚Äôs just standing here, looking dumb and suspicious. Jesus Christ. ‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOh, sorry mate,‚Äù Sirius laughs, rummaging in his coat pocket. Remus sees the wand in his sleeve, sees the flick as he transfigures his sunglasses into a small plastic card. ‚ÄúMust have grabbed it by mistake on our way out,‚Äù he hands the card to Remus and then shoots Aileen an exceptionally charming smile. ‚ÄúSorry about that.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh no problem at all,‚Äù she smiles back before reaching her hand out to Remus for the card.

‚ÄúOh right,‚Äù he fumbles a little, awkwardly handing it over. When her head is down, Remus mouthes the words ‚Äúthank you‚Äù to Sirius, who gives him a wink.

‚ÄúExcellent, well, everything seems to be in order,‚Äù she hands the card back to Remus. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll just go get her shall I? I‚Äôm so glad you‚Äôve come, she‚Äôs been so sad since she was dropped off.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs stomach squeezes, and he does his best to push the feeling away. To push his memories of Lupercal and everything Charlotte‚Äôs life would have been like there away.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Sirius says after Aileen disappears. ‚ÄúIs‚Ä¶is she your‚Äôs?‚Äù

Remus blinks, turning to look at Sirius who is staring very intently back at him. ‚ÄúIs‚Ä¶she‚Ä¶my what?‚Äù he repeats slowly.

‚ÄúYour kid.‚Äù

And that question is so absurd that for a minute Remus is fully incapable of understanding it. And then he‚Äôs laughing. Folded over, clutching his knees, laughing. ‚ÄúWhat?!‚Äù that‚Äôs all he can get out. ‚ÄúHow? How! Are you out of your mind?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell what the hell else am I supposed to think?‚Äù Sirius says grumpily.

‚ÄúAnything,‚Äù Remus is still struggling to get control of himself. He straightens up, wiping the tears of mirth from his eyes. ‚ÄúLiterally anything else. How could I possibly have a child?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell I don‚Äôt know what you get up to, do I?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a truth in that that Remus doesn‚Äôt want to touch right now. That he wants to pretend he can‚Äôt hear.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs like five.‚Äù

Sirius shrugs. ‚ÄúPeople have kids when they‚Äôre fourteen.‚Äù
‚ÄúBlimey, not me,‚Äù he can‚Äôt even imagine‚Äîhe didn‚Äôt even know where to start with sex at fourteen.

Sirius makes a humming noise, potentially seeing the sense in this, having known Remus then. ‚ÄúNot your illegitimate love child you‚Äôve been hiding away in a Muggle orphanage for years then? ‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt quite manage to stop his lips from twitching.

Remus snorts, ‚ÄúNo, she‚Äôs not.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause but Remus can tell Sirius isn‚Äôt done. Can feel the words sitting inside him.

‚ÄúThen who is she?‚Äù he asks eventually.

Remus swallows with some difficulty. He doesn‚Äôt know what to say. Doesn‚Äôt know how to explain without giving it all away. Wonders everyday why it matters. Because he trusts Sirius.

He does.

He does.

He does.

Except‚Ä¶

I was there too, in the office, when James said that Sirius smiled, when he told him what he‚Äôd done.

Remus shivers at the voice. At the memories. And he sees Sirius‚Äôs brows draw together. Sees him reach out. ‚ÄúRe‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRemus!‚Äù

It‚Äôs not a yell as much as a gush, like all the air flew out of her the moment she said his name. Remus and Sirius both turn to see Charlotte, holding Aileen‚Äôs hand and walking towards them. Funny, Remus isn‚Äôt sure he ever heard her say his name back at Lupercal. Truth be told, he wasn‚Äôt even sure she‚Äôd remember him.

But not only does she remember, she‚Äôs running towards him. It‚Äôs instinct that has him bending down so that she can crash right into his arms. So that she can burry her little face in his neck.

‚ÄúAw look at that, precious,‚Äù Aileen says, leaning against her desk.

Remus holds Charlotte close. ‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he says softly, at a loss for what else to do.

When she answers her voice is so quiet he barely hears it even though she‚Äôs speaking right into his ear; ‚ÄúAre you taking me back?‚Äù

He has to close his eyes for a moment at the excitement in her voice. He‚Äôs never wanted to lie to someone so badly.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

She sniffles and he‚Äôs worried she‚Äôs going to cry but all she does is nod against his neck and squeeze him tighter. With more effort than he would like to admit, Remus stands up with Charlotte in his arms, her legs wrapped around his waist.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been given permission to take her off the grounds but we do require the children to be back by seven at the latest, so I‚Äôll ask you to be mindful of the time,‚Äù Aileen explains, looking at them fondly. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîand here‚Äôs her jacket, I did try to get it on her, but she wasn‚Äôt so sure she was going to want to leave with you. I daresay she‚Äôs changed her mind though.‚Äù

Sirius reaches out and takes the little pink jacket, thanking Aileen as Charlotte whispers: ‚ÄúI thought you might be him.‚Äù

Greyback. She means Greyback.

Fuck.

He can‚Äôt imagine what that would be like. Surrounded by a bunch of adults who can never make you feel safe because they can‚Äôt be trusted with the truth. Remus remembers being afraid after the attack, remembers nights spent in his parent‚Äôs bed. But at least they‚Äôd had wands. At least he‚Äôd known that they would fight Greyback if they saw him and not invite him over for tea.

‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt going to come here okay?‚Äù a promise Remus feels fairly certain he can make now that he‚Äôs in Greyback‚Äôs inner circle. Greyback has no interest in the children he turns until they‚Äôre old enough to fight with him.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Sirius says, stepping closer, as Aileen returns to her desk. ‚ÄúShall we go on an adventure?‚Äù

Charlotte turns her head to look at him, cheek still pressed to Remus‚Äôs shoulder. He can feel the moment she sees him, sees his smile, and his dancing eyes, and his beautiful face. Sirius Black, the eighth wonder of the world.

‚ÄúHello sweetheart,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúShould we get your coat on?‚Äù

Remus isn‚Äôt expecting her to speak, she did it so rarely on the farm. But then: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm too hot,‚Äù she says in a soft voice.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Sirius says wisely. ‚ÄúLike your uncle Moony then.‚Äù Remus isn‚Äôt sure if Sirius has figured out just how much that‚Äôs true yet. He doesn‚Äôt think so, based on the lightness of Sirius‚Äôs voice.

‚ÄúMoony?‚Äù Charlotte repeats curiously.

‚ÄúSorry, that‚Äôs my nickname for Remus.‚Äù

There's a pause and then. ‚ÄúI like Moony.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs smile is so bright that Remus has to look away.

‚ÄúMe too.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a few seconds before Remus is able to find his voice again. ‚ÄúCharlotte this is Sirius, Sirius this is Charlotte.‚Äù

Sirius makes a big dramatic bow that has Remus rolling his eyes. ‚ÄúM‚Äôlady.‚Äù

Charlotte watches him for a moment before turning back to Remus and whispering in his ear: ‚ÄúIs he a prince?‚Äù

Remus has to bite the inside of his cheek to hold back a laugh, making eye contact with Sirius who is looking at him questioningly. ‚ÄúShe wants to know if you‚Äôre a prince,‚Äù he explains.

‚ÄúAh, is it because of my incredible manners and regal presence?‚Äù he directs the question at Charlotte who considers him before shaking her head.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your hair.‚Äù

And now Remus can‚Äôt help it, he bursts out laughing, harder than he has in a while, Sirius breaking not a moment later.

‚ÄúAlright, I like you, you can stay,‚Äù he reaches over and musses her hair and instead of telling him to shove off like Remus surely would have, she preens.

¬†

Remus does insist that she wear her jacket, Charlotte making little huffy noises the whole time he‚Äôs putting it on her, like she‚Äôs humouring him. Sirius does a terrible job of hiding his snickering.

‚ÄúAlright Princess, how do you feel about piggybacks?‚Äù Sirius asks once she‚Äôs all zippered up.

‚ÄúI like them,‚Äù Charlotte answers decisively.

‚ÄúGood, me too.‚Äù Not a second later Sirius is kneeling on the floor, helping Charlotte clamour onto his back.

‚ÄúSo I was thinking we could go out for lunch,‚Äù Remus says as the three of them traipse outside. ‚ÄúThere are some nice restaurants around here and then maybe we could, I don‚Äôt know, go to a park?‚Äù He‚Äôs not got very much experience with children, barely remembers being one himself, but he feels like food and open spaces are a pretty safe bet.

‚ÄúI mean, we could do that,‚Äù Sirius says, in a voice that instantly has Remus narrowing his eyes. ‚ÄúOr‚Ä¶we could take her to the greatest sweet shop known to mankind.‚Äù

Charlotte makes a small excited squealing noise.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not taking her to Honeydukes.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù Charlotte is resting her chin on the top of Sirius‚Äôs head and Remus is trying very hard not to think about how adorable they look.

‚ÄúYeah why not?‚Äù Sirius mimics her tone as they stop just inside the front gates of the orphanage.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs dangerous.‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúLiterally how?‚Äù

And Remus doesn‚Äôt have an answer for him exactly, just that the thought of taking her so far and exposing her to so much FEELS dangerous.

‚ÄúExactly,‚Äù Sirius says, eyes looking up like he can see Charlotte through his skull. ‚ÄúYou ever Apparated before kid?‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOnce, with mama.‚Äù

Sirius nods. ‚ÄúOkay good, so you know it‚Äôs going to feel a little wonky for a minute but you just have to hold on tight and breathe through it. Think you can do that?‚Äù

She nods her head, chin messing up his hair. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm strong.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, I can tell.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius.‚Äú

The other boy looks at him, something a bit more sincere in his expression than before. ‚ÄúLets give her some fun yeah?‚Äù He holds Remus‚Äôs eyes with all the intent of someone who was never given much fun himself.

And how can Remus say no to that?

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt leave our sight,‚Äù he says instead of yes, Sirius offering him a hand that Remus reluctantly takes. ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôll have her back before seven.‚Äù

Sirius nods. ‚ÄúCross my heart.‚Äù

Remus squeezes his hand before looking up at Charlotte who is bubbling over with excitement. Something he never saw at Lupercal. More time has passed since she was attacked, and that‚Äôs likely some of the reason that she‚Äôs thawed. But he also has no doubt that a bit of it is the magic of Sirius. Who when he looks at you, really looks at you, makes you feel like anything is possible if you want it bad enough.

A second later his feet are slamming down on the road just outside of Hogsmeade. Charlotte makes a little gasping noise when they turn towards the quaint town.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs beautiful,‚Äù she whispers, and Remus can‚Äôt help but look at Sirius who is looking right back, smiling.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Remus agrees. ‚ÄúYeah it is.‚Äù

¬†

If her eyes went wide at the sight of the town, they nearly fall out of her head when they walk into Honeydukes. Sirius gracefully lets her slide off his back and onto the floor, Charlotte instantly grabbing his hand. Honestly Remus is feeling a little overwhelmed himself. The moment they walk into the colourful shop that smells like something warm and sweet and safe, he realizes he hasn‚Äôt been here since he left school.

For a moment his heart stutters. And he thinks he hears James laughing, sees Peter making a mad dash for the chocolate frogs, sees Sirius with that careless smile of his, hanging in the corner of his mouth. The worst thing in any of their lives is the potions essay they‚Äôre all pretending isn‚Äôt due the next day.

Remus lets out a shaky breath.

God he misses them.

Misses them so much some days he thinks it‚Äôll take him apart.

‚ÄúThis is a lot of sweets,‚Äù Charlotte says, bringing Remus back to the present.

‚ÄúTrue,‚Äù Sirius nods his head soberly, ‚Äúbest to come up with a game plan,‚Äù the three of them are still standing just inside the door, Charlotte and Sirius staring out at all that lies in front of them. ‚ÄúSo where do you wanna start? Chocolate or candy?‚Äù

Charlotte seems to consider this quite seriously. ‚ÄúCandy,‚Äù she decides.

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúBrilliant choice.‚Äù

They end up needing a cart to hold everything Charlotte picks up as Sirius gives a rather informative tour of the shop. Remus thinks he must have studied the Honeydukes inventory harder than he ever studied for any class they took.

The tour finishes at the front counter where Charlotte is treated to a sample of about every fudge flavour imaginable and Remus is almost positive that he‚Äôs going to be vanishing vomit before the day is done. By the time they leave the store Charlotte is practically vibrating, sprinting down the street when Sirius points out their next destination‚ÄîZonko‚Äôs, of course.

‚ÄúStop at the corner!‚Äù Remus shouts after her, shaking his head as he looks down at the bags Sirius is holding. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you bought all that.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis? Please. I was holding back.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd what exactly are we going to tell them when we take her home loaded up with sweets?‚Äù

‚ÄúPfft, we‚Äôre not going to tell them about the sweets. Then they‚Äôll do something ridiculous like say she can‚Äôt have them before supper or make her share them! God forbid.‚Äù

Remus bites the inside of his cheek to keep from smiling. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a horrible influence.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw, is someone feeling grumpy?‚Äù Sirius makes a pouty face. ‚ÄúHere, have a sugar quill, those always put you in a better mood back at school.‚Äù

Remus can‚Äôt help laughing now, giving Sirius a good shove. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such an as‚Äî‚Äú of course it‚Äôs at that moment that Charlotte decides to turn back towards them. ‚ÄúAs-bsolute jerk.‚Äù

Sirius smirks, far too smug. ‚ÄúNice one.‚Äù

¬†

Zonko‚Äôs is about as chaotic as Remus remembers. Noises and flashing lights and things disappearing in puffs of smoke. It has none of the ‚Äúcuteness‚Äù of Honeydukes. Zonko‚Äôs is much more of a ‚Äúfend for yourself‚Äù kind of place, which of course James and Sirius always thrived off of. Luckily there aren‚Äôt many people there today, which lessens the urge Remus usually feels to get out as fast as possible. This is especially good since Sirius seems intent on taking his time.

‚ÄúWhat are these?‚Äù Charlotte picks up a flat purple disk.

‚ÄúAh, you have good taste,‚Äù Sirius bends down, gently taking it out of her hand. ‚ÄúThese, are wings,‚Äù with the swipe of his thumb a pair of child sized pixie wings sprout from either side of the disc, waving slowly in the air.

Charlotte gasps, her eyes growing wide as she stares at them. ‚ÄúCan you wear them?‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely! This little guy goes in the middle of your back and then bam! You‚Äôll be floating‚Äîwhat does it say‚Ä¶‚Äù he double checks the sign. ‚ÄúA whole three inches off the ground!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll fly!‚Äù Charlotte‚Äôs voice has gone up several octaves.

Sirius smiles. ‚ÄúIn a manner of speaking.‚Äù

Charlotte spins around, showing him her back. ‚ÄúPut it on! Put it on! Put it on!‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright, bossy pants,‚Äù he reaches forward when suddenly she spins back, nearly toppling him over.

‚ÄúWait, not on my jacket! On my shirt!‚Äù she starts fumbling with her zipper.

‚ÄúWoah, hey, it‚Äôs too cold for that. Why can‚Äôt you put the wings on your jacket?‚Äù Remus asks, though she already has the thing half-off.

‚ÄúFairies don‚Äôt wear jackets,‚Äù she says, like it‚Äôs a known fact. Remus resists the urge to tell her that these are not fairy wings.

Sirius helps her slide the jacket off and when Remus glares at him he shrugs. ‚ÄúAw, c‚Äômon Rem, I‚Äôll cast a warming charm on her. Fairies don‚Äôt wear jackets, it‚Äôll ruin the whole aesthetic.‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes, ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù

Sirius turns back to Charlotte who is bouncing impatiently on her toes, waiting for her wings. He freezes almost as soon as he looks at her, the smile sliding right off his face. Remus immediately steps forward, not understanding what‚Äôs happened until he sees that in the scuffle to get her jacket off Charlotte‚Äôs shirt has been pulled away from her neck. And there, on the skin of her shoulder, is a puckering scar.

Teeth.

Sirius turns to him, a question in his eyes that Remus can‚Äôt bare to answer out loud, so he just nods.

‚ÄúAre they on?‚Äù Charlotte asks, trying to look back at them. For a moment Remus is worried that she‚Äôs going to know that something‚Äôs wrong but Sirius is nothing if not a performer.

‚ÄúJust a second,‚Äù he says, expression wiped clean as he presses the circle between her shoulder blades. ‚ÄúThere you go. Now you just have to wave your arms‚Äîjust a little‚Äîand the wings will flap.‚Äù

She does, squealing and giggling when her feet start to lift off the ground.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm flying! I‚Äôm flying!‚Äù

She‚Äôs barely hovering really, toes only just in the air as she bobs about, moving her arms like she‚Äôs swimming.

Sirius straightens up, standing next to Remus. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre gonna need to get her a broom.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you dare!‚Äù

Sirius only laughs.

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù Charlotte sort of front-crawls towards them.

‚ÄúIf you put your arms down you‚Äôll be able to walk,‚Äù Sirius says with amusement. Charlotte very noticeably does not put her arms down.

‚ÄúYou need some too!‚Äù she says, looking up at him.

‚ÄúI need some wings you mean?‚Äù

She nods her head vigorously.

‚ÄúYou know what,‚Äù Sirius pulls out his own purple disc. ‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre right.‚Äù

There are no words to describe the way that Remus‚Äôs heart swells, when five minutes later they walk out of the store with Sirius and Charlotte holding hands and sporting matching pixie wings. He wishes he had a camera, James would die.

They find a bench to sit down on, Charlotte floating around in little circles in front of them, endlessly entertained by her new toy. Remus leans into Sirius‚Äôs side.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre good with her.‚Äù

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúHelps that we‚Äôre mentally the same age.‚Äù

But Remus shakes his head. ‚ÄúNo, I mean it. I‚Äôve never seen her smile this much before. Never heard her laugh. It‚Äôs‚Äîyou‚Äôre good at it.‚Äù

Sirius looks over at him, brow raised. ‚ÄúIt?‚Äù

‚ÄúKids.‚Äù

Sirius is silent for a moment, a long moment, at least for him. He watches Charlotte fluttering around, his eyes distant. ‚ÄúI guess I just‚Ä¶know what I needed. What I wanted. When I was‚Ä¶a kid.‚Äù

It still feels odd to say that. To have ‚Äúkid‚Äù be something they were not something they are. You spend so much of your youth trying to convince everyone that you‚Äôre grown, but the minute the world turns around and says ‚Äúyou, you‚Äôre an adult, you‚Äôre responsible‚Äù you can‚Äôt help but feel that a terrible mistake has been made.

Because to Remus, Sirius is still a kid.

Sometimes he‚Äôs even still trapped in that house.

He feels tugging on his sleeve and starts when he realizes that Charlotte is right next to him, her feet firmly on the ground for the first time since the wings went on.

‚ÄúHey, what‚Äôs up?‚Äù he asks her, bending down slightly.

She bites her lower lip. ‚ÄúI wanna‚Ä¶‚Äù she looks at Sirius and then back at Remus, lowering her voice. ‚ÄúI wanna see your wolf.‚Äù

Remus blinks. He hadn‚Äôt been expecting that, maybe he should have been but‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI never see any anymore,‚Äù she goes on. ‚ÄúI miss them.‚Äù

Even with all the time he‚Äôs spent with Gabe recently it still feels so foreign to him, this affection for the wolf. Remus has never felt anything but shame and fear. He doesn‚Äôt want that for Charlotte.

‚ÄúRem?‚Äù Sirius says, bringing Remus‚Äôs attention back to him. ‚ÄúWhat did she ask?‚Äù

He opens his mouth and then closes it, not sure he can explain. Thankfully, he‚Äôs saved by Charlotte tugging on his sleeve again. This time she doesn‚Äôt stop until he‚Äôs bent low enough that she can whisper in his ear.

‚ÄúIs he like us?‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt know why that makes his breath hitch. Maybe because it‚Äôs his biggest fear. He can hear Regulus Black‚Äôs dead voice in his head: Haven‚Äôt bitten him yet then?

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Remus finally manages, voice a little tight. ‚ÄúBut he‚Äîhe knows.‚Äù

She looks back at Sirius before nodding. ‚ÄúSo you can show me then?‚Äù

Merlin, can he? He‚Äôs done it a few times since Lupercal‚Äîtransformed on his own, or, well, by his own freewill. Gabe has always been there. Sometimes Gabe has bad days and he just needs‚Ä¶to escape. Originally Remus had suggested letting him see Charlotte but Dumbledore had denied that request. Incase somehow it lead to Gabe working out the relationship between Remus and Dumbledore and telling Greyback.

‚ÄúRemus?‚Äù that‚Äôs Sirius again, looking at him pleadingly, expecting some sort of explanation that Remus isn‚Äôt sure he can give him.

Finally, after his eyes have done a circuit of the surrounding area, making sure no one is close enough to hear, Remus manages to make himself speak. ‚ÄúShe wants to see my wolf.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs brows draw together, eyes bouncing between the pair of them, clearly trying to figure out if this is some sort of game. ‚ÄúBut‚Ä¶it‚Äôs not even close to the full moon?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy would that matter?‚Äù Charlotte responds before Remus gets the chance.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú Sirius lets out a shaky laugh, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm lost here. What are we talking about?‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt think this is the place to explain. Before he can second guess himself he‚Äôs standing up and offering Charlotte his hand. Her eyes growing bright.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

He nods. Short. Curt.

He‚Äôs nervous. Partially because it‚Äôs dangerous, and partially because Sirius is here. Is watching him. But he doesn‚Äôt want all of Mia‚Äôs hard work to be lost. He doesn‚Äôt want Charlotte to see a cell at the Ministry every time she thinks about this part of herself.

‚ÄúMoons,‚Äù Sirius says, falling into step with them as they head out of town and towards the school. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs she talking about?‚Äù

His hands are trembling, and he feels Charlotte give the one she‚Äôs holding a squeeze. He‚Äôs being comforted by a five year old. He nearly laughs.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna show you,‚Äù Remus says finally.

Sirius scrutinizes him for a minute longer before nodding his head. ‚ÄúAlright.‚Äù

They don‚Äôt actually go to the school. Instead turning towards the forest that starts at the bottom of its grounds and stretches far beyond. He‚Äôs not going to take Charlotte to the Shrieking Shack. He expects it‚Äôs no better than a cell at the Ministry. He knows the forest isn‚Äôt generally considered a safe place, but he‚Äôs never been able to see the sinisterness that everyone else does. Some of the happiest moments of his life have happened between theses trees.

Still, he keeps a firm hold on Charlotte‚Äôs hand, even when she tries to run off. While he might not be afraid of the forest like other people, that doesn‚Äôt mean he‚Äôs just going to hand it an unarmed five year old wearing pixie wings.

The whole time they walk Sirius shoots him nervous looks out of the corner of his eyes. For all that he loves springing them on other people, Sirius has never much liked surprises himself.

‚ÄúOkay, this ought to be good,‚Äù Remus says as they come to a small clearing, far enough into the forest that no one passing by on the outside can see them.

‚ÄúGood for what?‚Äù Sirius asks as Remus takes off his coat and jumper and folds them carefully on top of a nearby tree stump.

‚ÄúWolf! Wolf! Wolf!‚Äù Charlotte claps her hands, floating around again now that Remus is no longer anchoring her.

Sirius doesn‚Äôt bother responding to that, eyes on Remus who is a little worried he‚Äôs going to throw-up. Instead he steps forward, and before Sirius can ask another question he presses a quick kiss to his lips.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be scared okay?‚Äù he says softly when he pulls away, Sirius‚Äôs eyes desperately searching his, likely not finding anything helpful.
