Remus steps back, making sure there‚Äôs a good amount of space between him and the others. He notices Sirius moving closer to Charlotte and he tries not to take that personally. Exhaling he closes his eyes. He‚Äôs gotten better at this, the last few times, the walls in him coming down a little easier. Still, he‚Äôs more nervous this time, and it‚Äôs making it harder to concentrate.

‚ÄúRe‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShhh!‚Äù Charlotte silences him and Remus has to bite his lip to hold back a laugh.

It‚Äôs okay,

he tells himself.

It‚Äôs Sirius.

It‚Äôs only Sirius.

He exhales again, searching for the howl, the one that runs underneath his thoughts. His pulse. Always there. Steady. He tries to remind himself that it isn‚Äôt scary. That it‚Äôs just a part of him, like every other part. And then he pulls it forward. Makes it loud. As loud as it wants to be.

For a moment everything disappears.

And then it reforms and it is brighter and sweeter and realer.

‚ÄúHoly shit.‚Äù

He blinks his eyes open and sees Charlotte‚Äôs beaming face, she runs towards him, Sirius making a grab for her.

He‚Äôs afraid.

Afraid.

Afraid of me.

‚ÄúCharlotte don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

Moony instantly lowers himself, dipping his head, trying to show that he‚Äôs not a threat.

They both smell so familiar.

Especially Sirius.

Pack, he thinks.

Pack.

and pack.

and pack.

Charlotte is scratching behind his ears, making his back leg thump in appreciation on the ground.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so cute,‚Äù she coos, and he likes that, so he licks her‚Äîslobber covering half her face and making her giggle.

‚ÄúSirius come‚Äîcome pet him!‚Äù

Moony turns to Sirius.

Sirius who does not come.

And does not pet.

Unhappy with this he gets up, careful not to knock Charlotte over as he walks towards Sirius. It‚Äôs not until then that he realizes that there are tears in Sirius‚Äôs eyes. His beautiful eyes.

Beautiful.

Beautiful.

Beautiful.

Moony whines, it‚Äôs a desperately sad noise.

He doesn‚Äôt want Sirius to cry.

He does not want Sirius to ever cry.

‚ÄúSorry‚ÄîMerlin‚Äîsorry, it‚Äôs just,‚Äù he wipes at his face, voice a little shaky. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never seen you‚Ä¶I‚Äôve never seen you look so‚Ä¶so happy. I‚Äôve never seen your wolf look‚Ä¶you‚Äôre just‚Ä¶God Remus I don‚Äôt know how to explain it. I didn‚Äôt know it could be like this.‚Äù

Moony nods, though he‚Äôs not sure that Sirius catches it, and he wants to hold him. To protect him. To sink his teeth into him and never let him go.

Instead he steps forward, knocking his nose into the centre of Sirius‚Äôs chest, causing Sirius to laugh. He can hear his heart.

Thump,

thump.

thump.

‚ÄúHey, hi,‚Äù Sirius says softly, petting him and then leaning forward and pressing several light kisses across his head. No one has ever kissed his wolf before. Something akin to a purr seems to grow from his chest.

Sirius chuckles. ‚ÄúYou like that huh?‚Äù he kisses him a few more times for good measure, before pulling away, just staring. Moony stares back, not feeling any of the embarrassment he might normally.

Mine, he thinks.

He‚Äôs mine,

mine.

mine.

‚ÄúAHWOO!‚Äù

Both Sirius and Moony whip around at the noise, finding little Charlotte, floating in the centre of the clearing‚Ä¶howling. She looks at Moony and smiles.

‚ÄúAHWOO!‚Äù

A second later he‚Äôs joining her, head tilted back towards the sky, voice ripped from him like it‚Äôs desperate to be free.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon Sirius,‚Äù Charlotte says after a few seconds. ‚ÄúYou have to sing too.‚Äù

Moony turns back to him, worried he‚Äôll refuse, not sure why it‚Äôs so important that he doesn‚Äôt. There‚Äôs a moments pause before Sirius‚Äôs eyes find his. And then he howls. The noise shooting through Moony like an electric current. The sound vibrating in his chest.

The three of them sing.

Loud and proud and unafraid.

Pack.

Pack.

Pack.

¬†

¬†

Remus is able to patch his clothes back together with magic. He‚Äôs still looking rough, but once he has his jumper and his coat back on it‚Äôs not too bad. When he emerges from the trees he‚Äôd been hiding behind to make himself decent, he finds Charlotte no longer wearing her wings and instead sporting a little green backpack that Sirius is just zipping up.

When Sirius looks over at him Remus arches his brow; ‚ÄúYou put an extension charm on that?‚Äù because there‚Äôs no way all the stuff they bought today could fit inside there naturally.

Sirius nods, getting back to his feet. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm gonna put a disillusionment charm on it before we get back to the orphanage, that way there will be no awkward questions.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôll get to keep all my sweets!‚Äù Charlotte adds.

Sirius looks down at her fondly. ‚ÄúExactly,‚Äù he holds out his hand and she gives him a high-five without a moments hesitation.

Remus sighs. ‚ÄúBad influence.‚Äù

Their eyes meet.

‚ÄúSo you‚Äôve said,‚Äù and then something shifts in Sirius‚Äôs gaze and he‚Äôs stepping forward, wrapping Remus in his arms. It‚Äôs one of those feel-it-in-your-bones kind of hugs. Sirius tucking his face into the crook of Remus‚Äôs neck.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Remus says softly.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Sirius says back. And then; ‚ÄúThanks‚Ä¶for showing me.‚Äù

That makes Remus‚Äôs heart tremble, and for a moment he has to close his eyes just to relieve one of his senses. He turns his head, kissing Sirius‚Äôs temple. If he could, he would stay here forever. In this forest. In these arms. But unfortunately the world has not disappeared. And there is a rather sleepy looking toddler waiting for them.

Remus gives Sirius one last good squeeze before pulling back. ‚ÄúWe should probably take her home,‚Äù he gestures to Charlotte who chooses that moment to yawn.

Sirius nods, though he looks profoundly unhappy about it. ‚ÄúAlright you little menace,‚Äù he says as he walks over to her, kneeling down and offering up his back. ‚ÄúAll aboard.‚Äù

¬†

By the time they make it up the walkway to the orphanage Charlotte can barely keep her eyes open.

‚ÄúSomeone looks like they‚Äôve had a fun day,‚Äù Aileen says when they walk through the door, Sirius carefully easing Charlotte off of him. She hugs his legs sleepily before moving on to Remus, whose jumper she pulls until he brings his ear down for her.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll come back?‚Äù she whispers, causing Remus‚Äôs heart to squeeze.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he clears his throat, ‚Äúof course.‚Äù

Charlotte nods, very matter of fact, and then: ‚ÄúBring Gabe too.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay little missy, your uncles have to go now, time to finish up your goodbyes.‚Äù

And Remus desperately wants to grab Charlotte and carry her out of there. Desperately wants to take her back to Lupercal. To give her the beautiful life she was going to have. But he can‚Äôt do any of that, so instead he hugs her one last time.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll try,‚Äù he whispers before she‚Äôs pulled away, waving at Sirius as she goes.

¬†

They don‚Äôt talk for a while. Walking out of the building and down towards the road in silence.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Sirius says eventually, the sun setting above their heads. ‚ÄúThat bite‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúGreyback,‚Äù Remus isn‚Äôt sure he wants to know how Sirius was going to finish that question. ‚ÄúOr one of his followers,‚Äù his stomach twists at the thought that right now that includes him.

‚ÄúBastard,‚Äù Sirius hisses, hands in the pockets of his jacket. ‚ÄúI swear to god I‚Äôm gonna kill him one day.‚Äù

Remus snorts even though he knows that Sirius isn‚Äôt joking, which means there is nothing remotely funny about it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll join you.‚Äù

Now it‚Äôs Sirius who‚Äôs laughing. ‚ÄúFun new date night activity.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ,‚Äù but Remus is smiling despite himself.

‚ÄúMurder is the key to a healthy relationship.‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty sure that‚Äôs communication.‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty sure you have to communicate to murder someone together.‚Äù

And now they‚Äôre both laughing, because they‚Äôre terrible people, because they‚Äôre children, because what else can you do? When the world is ugly and cruel, what else can you do but laugh?

They usually aren‚Äôt particularly affectionate in public, for a great many reasons, but when they sit down on the bus Remus can‚Äôt fight the urge to lean into Sirius, flicking his wand and casting a disillusionment charm over them. Sirius raises his brow but still sneaks an arm around Remus‚Äôs waist, pulling him closer.

‚ÄúYou ever think about it?‚Äù Remus asks after a few minutes. ‚ÄúHaving kids?‚Äù

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúYou wanna have my babies Moony?‚Äù

Remus scoffs, turning his face and burying it in Sirius‚Äôs neck. He expects that to be the end of the conversation, but a few minutes later Sirius says:

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt now, because everything is‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶a mess,‚Äù Remus wonders if he‚Äôs talking about the pair of them specifically or the war in general. Frankly, he‚Äôs too afraid to ask. ‚ÄúBut later, when things are settled, safer, we‚Äôll get her out of there.‚Äù

It takes Remus a pathetically long time to work out what Sirius is saying, and when he does he pulls back, staring at the other boy. ‚ÄúCharlotte?‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúYou want to adopt Charlotte?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell we can‚Äôt leave her there. Besides, James and Lily‚Äôs brat will need someone to keep it in line, you know that kid is gonna be an absolute terror,‚Äù Sirius grins.

But Remus is still struggling to process this. ‚ÄúBut she‚Äîit‚Äôs hard, when you‚Äôre young, it would be‚Äîher being‚Ä¶what she is‚Ä¶it would be hard. Wouldn‚Äôt you rather‚Ä¶‚Äù a kid who isn‚Äôt already broken, he can‚Äôt say, doesn‚Äôt even mean. At least not about Charlotte. Given the choice his father would have. His mother too maybe.

‚ÄúI reckon we can handle it, don‚Äôt you?‚Äù

And before Remus can stop himself he‚Äôs kissing him, ‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù he says when they break apart, staring into Sirius‚Äôs eyes.

And whatever had been there that morning, whatever sadness, whatever hesitation, whatever doubt‚ÄîRemus doesn‚Äôt see it now.

‚ÄúI love you too.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

Is this an accurate portrayal of how orphanages work? No. But I ask you to suspend your disbelief so that we can read less about paperwork and more about Wolfstar being dads for the day!

I hope that the softer moments in this chapter were a nice little break from all the drama and angst, and if not, don't worry, the next three-ish chapters are ALL drama and angst (can you believe there are only three chapters left, like goddamn)

Thank you all so much! Sorry this update took a while again! I hope you're having a lovely day! :)

Chapter 53

Chapter Summary

Don't go to Troy

Chapter Notes

tw: referenced sexual assault
tw: referenced substance abuse (recovering from substance abuse)
tw: child abuse (via magic)
tw: Major Character Death (I feel like everyone is aware of this one at this point but, yeah, hey babes, we're here)
tw: suicide

In case it is still unclear at this point - this is an interpretation of canon

I tried to make his death more about closure than about, y'know, being scary and traumatic, like it's still scary but that isn't the focus

PART I REGULUS

Regulus sighs as he watches the sun rise outside his window.

Another night gone in a blur of faces and voices and moments he would rather forget.

It‚Äôll get better, he tells himself as he showers, as he does up the buttons of his shirt, as he wrestles his hair into something close to respectable. It‚Äôll get better. That‚Äôs what people say right? People like James Potter and Remus Lupin and‚Äîwell, he can‚Äôt really see Sirius saying anything remotely like that but he must pretend when he‚Äôs around them. Pretend to be the type of person who believes things get better. Regulus can‚Äôt imagine it comes naturally to him. It‚Äôs not how they were raised.

His hands twitch, wanting to pull open the mirror, to shut-up the guilt vibrating inside his skin. He grips the sink in front of him and drops his head, letting out a shaky breath.

He‚Äôs trying.

But then, he still hasn‚Äôt thrown them out‚Äîthe potions.

He could.

He could get rid of them all. Maybe lessen the temptation. But he just can‚Äôt quite bring himself to‚Ä¶what if he needs them? He‚Äôs going to have to sleep at some point.

How does the saying go? No rest for the wicked?

Evan is right by his ear. Echoing in his head. Regulus‚Äôs hands tighten around the sink. He tries to will the voice away, but even just doing that makes him feel guilty. He knows it isn‚Äôt really Evan, he does. He hasn‚Äôt completely lost it. But at the moment, it‚Äôs the closest thing he has to him.

What d‚Äôyou reckon your boyfriend will say huh? When you can‚Äôt sleep without getting fucked-up? Or better yet, when you start calling out his parents‚Äô names? How exactly are you going to explain that?

Regulus is afraid that if he looks up he‚Äôll find Evan in the mirror. That if he sees his face, figment of his imagination or not, he‚Äôll crack. So he just keeps staring at the drain, nails scraping the porcelain.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell him the truth,‚Äù he manages finally.

He won‚Äôt lie to James again. He won‚Äôt repeat old mistakes. Regulus tried to push James away, tried to make James stop loving him, it didn‚Äôt work. Not for either of them. And he isn‚Äôt interested in trying again.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell him the truth,‚Äù he repeats, hoping that he means it.

You‚Äôre a fool if you think he‚Äôll be able to get over that.

Maybe, but Regulus reckons, of all the things he has to live with, being foolish is probably the easiest.

It‚Äôs another few minutes before he‚Äôs able to let go of the sink and walk away. He should feel good. Triumphant. He didn‚Äôt take the potions. Didn‚Äôt open the cabinet. He isn‚Äôt sure that he does exactly, but there‚Äôs something‚Äîsome little tickle just beneath his ribs. Something that if he waters and feeds it and gives it a bit of sun, might just blossom into good.

¬†

Kreacher is waiting for him in the kitchen, sliding a loaded plate towards him as he sits down at the table. Sometimes he thinks about how his mother used to snap at him for spending time in here. Acting common. He takes some satisfaction in knowing that this isn‚Äôt her house anymore and he can spend his time wherever the fuck he pleases.

Regulus feels Kreacher‚Äôs eyes on him as he shovels eggs into his mouth and when he looks up he sees the house elf with tears in his eyes.

‚ÄúKreacher?‚Äù he asks, concerned.

Kreacher sniffles, before offering him a watery smile. ‚ÄúYou is eating sir, and I is not even having to throw things.‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really good Kreacher, thank you.‚Äù

Another sniffle, Kreacher using the dishtowel in his hands to dry his eyes. ‚ÄúI will be making it all the time if you will be liking it.‚Äù

Regulus feels his throat grow tight. He isn‚Äôt sure if it‚Äôs real, the care that Kreacher shows him, or if he can‚Äôt help it. Part of his obligation to their family. Isn‚Äôt sure he wants to know.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he manages eventually, before putting him and Kreacher both out of their misery and turning back to his breakfast‚Äîsaving them from anymore emotional outbursts.

It‚Äôs nice, being able to taste his food, even if he‚Äôs still feeling a little unsteady‚Äîhis stomach and head prone to aching, his skin hotter than is comfortable. He isn‚Äôt worried. He knows these potions well. Knows what withdrawal looks like. He‚Äôs just hoping no one else does.

‚ÄúFuck!‚Äù ‚Ä®‚Ä®

Regulus drops his fork as a sharp burning pain shoots up his arm.

‚ÄúMaster Regulus what is being the matter?‚Äù

By the time Regulus is rolling his sleeve back, he already knows what it is‚Äîwhat it has to be. And there, on his arm, is the snake wiggling inside its skull, glowing bright green.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses again, a little more controlled this time.

‚ÄúBut you is not being finished your breakfast yet!‚Äù Kreacher complains, sounding genuinely upset. It‚Äôs almost enough to make Regulus smile. Unfortunately, there‚Äôs already a sick feeling creeping up on him, threatening to make him vomit the food he has eaten. ‚Ä®‚Ä®

‚ÄúKeep it warm for me, yeah?‚Äù he manages, clearing his throat so he doesn‚Äôt sound quite so scared. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll eat it when I get back.‚Äù

He knew this was coming, of course. That after the dust had settled, and the wounds had been licked, they would have to come back together. To figure out their next move after the disaster that occurred at the Ministry. But god he‚Äôs been dreading it.

‚ÄúIs Mister Lucius going to be being there sir?‚Äù Kreacher asks as Regulus heads towards the front door, the mark on his arm begging to take him away, to Apparate to its master, unable to do so within the house‚Äôs wards.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Regulus says, happy that his voice comes out steady this time. ‚Ä®‚ÄúI expect so.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Kreacher hands him his jacket as they get to the entryway. ‚ÄúPerhaps if he be seeing you he will be leaving the house alone. It is most destructive when he calls.‚Äù Lucius has broken several vases (Regulus was not aware they had so many) in his attempts to get Regulus‚Äôs attention. It has not endeared him to Kreacher.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Regulus says noncommittally. ‚ÄúMaybe.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will be keeping your breakfast warm!‚Äù Kreacher announces, as though worried that Regulus might think he‚Äôs forgotten.

Regulus opens the door, throwing the elf a weak smile over his shoulder, ‚ÄúThanks Kreacher.‚Äù He‚Äôs barely on the front stoop before the magic in his arm is pulling him away. He can resist it of course, but when he doesn‚Äôt, the Dark Lord is able to call him wherever he pleases.

¬†

It‚Äôs not a surprise when he finds himself on the front lawn of Malfoy Manor, an angry peacock glaring at him as though he‚Äôs just personally offended it. He stumbles, the landing not as smooth as it would‚Äôve been had he chosen the destination himself. He stares up at the ugly house in front of him and sighs.

This should be fun.

‚ÄúWell, well, well.‚Äù

He‚Äôs barely crossed the threshold into the marble entryway when Lucius‚Äôs voice finds him. He‚Äôs lurking in the shadows, clearly waiting for Regulus, leaning against the wall just under the stairs. He‚Äôs wearing an expensive suit, his hair long enough that he‚Äôs started braiding it.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think you‚Äôd show,‚Äù he leers. ‚ÄúThe way you‚Äôve been hiding.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood morning to you too,‚Äù Regulus says flatly, not stopping on his way to the drawing room. He has no desire to engage in anything with Lucius.

‚ÄúOh come now Regulus, what‚Äôs the rush?‚Äù

Click.

Click.

Click.

Healed shoes on marble floors. Regulus thinks that noise will make him shiver for the rest of his life.

‚ÄúThe Dark Lord has summoned us,‚Äù he replies diplomatically.

Lucius snorts. ‚ÄúWell look who‚Äôs an eager little beaver. But then, I guess you were always something of a teacher‚Äôs pet weren‚Äôt you? Desperate to please.‚Äù

It takes a great deal of effort not to whip around and punch him.

The drawing room is just coming into view when Lucius grabs hold of Regulus‚Äôs arm and yanks him to a stop. A sickening feeling rocks through Regulus as he pulls himself free.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt. Fucking. Touch me.‚Äù He rounds on the older man, wand already in his hand.

Lucius laughs. ‚ÄúAre you going to curse me Regulus? Really?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt move. It‚Äôs a bluff, he hates that it‚Äôs a bluff, but he can‚Äôt really fight Lucius. He‚Äôs respected too much. By everyone, but most importantly, by Voldemort. And Lucius knows it.

The older man steps forward, still smiling, allowing the tip of Regulus‚Äôs wand to poke his sternum. ‚ÄúGo on,‚Äù he hisses, ‚Äúdo it,‚Äù and when Regulus still doesn‚Äôt move; ‚ÄúYou know, they‚Äôre looking for a traitor in there,‚Äù he nods towards the drawing room. ‚ÄúTrying to figure out who sold our secrets to the Aurors,‚Äù he leans slightly forward and it takes everything in Regulus not to flinch. Somehow he still feels trapped even though he‚Äôs the one with his wand raised. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve already told the Dark Lord my money‚Äôs on you. So go on sweetheart, prove me right.‚Äù

Regulus grits his teeth, hands shaking. ‚ÄúWhat the hell do you want from me?‚Äù

That only makes Lucius‚Äôs smile grow. ‚ÄúWhat do I want? I would have thought that was obvious,‚Äù vicious, hungry. ‚ÄúI want you on your fucking knees.‚Äù

Funnily enough, all he can think about is Bellatrix. Casting the Imperious on him. Making him crawl around like a dog.

The pathetic part. Is once upon a time he really did think they loved him.

‚ÄúBlack.‚Äù

He spins around to find Snape holding open the door to the drawing room, gaze cold, though surprisingly, not directed at Regulus.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù Snape says after a brief pause, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre late.‚Äù

‚ÄúMe and Regulus were actually just having a chat,‚Äù Lucius says, his manners brittle. ‚ÄúSo if you don‚Äôt mind‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI mind,‚Äù Snape interrupts. ‚ÄúBlack, lets go.‚Äù His tone is so blank that it‚Äôs hard to fully appreciate what this is.

A rescue.

Regulus doesn‚Äôt need to be told twice, slipping his wand back into its holster and heading towards the room without a backwards glance. He can‚Äôt quite bring himself to thank Snape, but he pauses at the door, the pair of them locking eyes for just a moment. Some sort of understanding passing between them. He isn‚Äôt doing this for Regulus, of course. Still couldn‚Äôt give a shit about him, just like in school.

This is about Snape‚Äôs mum.

About what he could never do for her.

Doesn‚Äôt mean Regulus isn‚Äôt still grateful.

He nods his head in recognition. Snape, surprisingly, nodding back. And then the moment passes, and Regulus is walking into the room, the door slamming behind him. Lucius left in the hall.

It takes the wind out of Regulus when his eyes scan the table in front of him and find Barty sitting alone. His feet stuttering as he walks towards him. It‚Äôs funny how much space one person can take up without you even realizing it. But everything feels emptier without Evan. Smaller.

Regulus slides silently into the seat next to Barty, trying to ignore the empty chair beside him. At least, until he notices the one across the table, and then a few more a little further down.

‚ÄúA lot of people are missing today,‚Äù Regulus says under his breath as he counts heads, trying to work out who‚Äôs not there.

Barty nods. ‚ÄúDead.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes snap to him. ‚ÄúDead?‚Äù he runs through the empty spaces again. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs too many.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know if he‚Äôll have to explain but Barty seems to understand. ‚ÄúNot all of them died at the Ministry. Some died after,‚Äù he looks at Regulus now. ‚ÄúSuspected traitors.‚Äù

A deep feeling of unease grips Regulus‚Äôs stomach. Partially, because he is a traitor, and partially, because he knows Lucius has been going around telling people so. He can‚Äôt help but wonder why he hasn‚Äôt been called on, eyes going automatically to where Snape is sitting at the other end of the table. He wonders if Severus‚Äôs word really carries that much weight with the Dark Lord‚Äîthat one positive review has shielded Regulus from all this fallout.

At that moment the doors open, Voldemort walking in with Lucius trailing behind him. With the flick of his wrist the heavy curtains pull closed, blocking out the natural light and plunging them into the shadowy glow of the candelabras.

‚ÄúGood morning my friends,‚Äù Voldemort says as he reaches the head of the table, Lucius taking his place at his side. Voldemort‚Äôs eyes run over each and every one of them, a sense of unease growing with every second he doesn‚Äôt speak. It starts at their ankles and then creeps up‚Äîtheir calves, their thighs‚Äîuntil it‚Äôs wrapping around their chests.

‚ÄúWe have much to discuss today.‚Äù

¬†

The Ministry was a hollow victory for Dumbledore. At least, that is how Lucius sees it. And Bellatrix. Rodolphus. The government still has little to no power, Death Eaters have still managed to insinuate themselves into almost all the departments, Muggle Borns have still been forced out of all positions of influence.

The Aurors are being run ragged by Moody and he is slowly losing their support. So far it‚Äôs been the hardest bastion of power for the Death Eaters to penetrate, but now? People are tired. They‚Äôre warn down. And Alastor Moody has no sympathy for them. But the Dark Lord does. Endless supplies of sympathy, if that‚Äôs what it takes to get them to switch sides.

It‚Äôs only a matter of time says Lucius. Bellatrix. Rodolphus‚Äîall the other bobbleheads surrounding the Dark Lord. Regulus doesn‚Äôt know how true that is. Secretly he hopes they‚Äôre all full of shit.

‚ÄúI would ask one more thing before we part today,‚Äù Voldemort says after nearly two hours. Regulus‚Äôs head feels stuffy, his mouth and eyes dry. He can‚Äôt wait to get the hell out of this place. ‚ÄúI have a task of great importance to complete‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI will happily take on any task you need my lord,‚Äù Lucius interrupts, causing Regulus to roll his eyes. He can practically hear Evan‚Äînot the voice that‚Äôs been haunting him, but the real Evan‚Äîmuttering under his breath about what a fucking swot Lucius is. Nudging Regulus with his elbow and smirking.

Voldemort gives Lucius a dismissive look. ‚ÄúYes, thank you for your enthusiasm Lucius, but I will be performing this task on my own,‚Äù that causes Regulus to sit up. The Dark Lord rarely gets his hands dirty, always sending one of his many willing followers to do the work for him. And if he does go, he has a constant guard, a shadow of people willing to throw themselves in harms way to protect him. So what could be so important that he‚Äôs doing it alone?

Regulus feels his pulse speed up. It‚Äôs a long-shot, he knows it‚Äôs a long shot, knows it‚Äôs wishful thinking but‚Äî

‚ÄúI will be needing a house elf,‚Äù the Dark Lord goes on. ‚ÄúI was wondering if any of you would be willing to lend me the use of one of your servants?‚Äù

‚ÄúI will,‚Äù Regulus nearly jumps out of his seat, Lucius with his mouth half-open, ready to offer the same. As the heads at the table all swivel in his direction Regulus clears his throat, trying to compose himself. ‚ÄúIt would be an honour,‚Äù he goes on, ‚Äúto be able to serve your lordship in such a way.‚Äù

Lucius is glaring at him, not one to take kindly to being outdone. They all wait for Voldemort to speak, but the Dark Lord appears to be in no hurry, watching Regulus without any concern for what is generally considered good manners. Regulus does his best not to squirm, not to drop his gaze.

And then‚Ä¶the older man smiles. Well, in a manner of speaking. ‚ÄúThank you Regulus,‚Äù he says, teeth on display. ‚ÄúYour devotion is most appreciated.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

He‚Äôll Floo Cerci when he gets home, they‚Äôll come up with a plan, figure out how to use this to their advantage, maybe give Kreacher a list of things to look out for.

‚ÄúI will be needing the elf now,‚Äù Voldemort goes on, putting a stop to Regulus‚Äôs planning and making him wonder if he needs to work on his Occlumency.

‚ÄúNow?‚Äù he asks, sounding alarmed even to his own ears. ‚ÄúAs in‚Ä¶this very moment‚Ä¶my lord?‚Äù

Voldemort arches his brow, seeming almost amused. ‚ÄúWill that be a problem?‚Äù

Regulus swallows. ‚ÄúNo, no of course not. I‚Äôll‚ÄîI‚Äôll go get him.‚Äù If he can just get home then maybe he can still prepare Kreacher.

‚ÄúSurely you can just summon him here? I would hardly want to inconvenience you with the unnecessary trips back and forth.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs throat feels incredibly dry. This is happening too fast, he hasn‚Äôt had enough time to think this through. But if this has anything to do with the Horcrux, then they might never get this chance again.

‚ÄúOf course, how kind of your lordship,‚Äù he finally manages to get out, nodding his head stiffly.

Voldemort smiles again. In that way he does. That way that feels like a threat. ‚ÄúExcellent,‚Äù then, looking around the table, ‚Äúthe rest of you are free to go.‚Äù

‚ÄúSee you,‚Äù Barty says briskly, barely looking at Regulus as he gets out of his seat. Others have gotten up as well, some leaving as quickly as Barty, some milling about. Lucius is currently in hushed conversation with Rodolphus and Bellatrix, dirty looks being cast in Regulus‚Äôs direction.

Regulus desperately wants a few moments alone with Kreacher but he‚Äôs not sure how to manage that without quite obviously disobeying the Dark Lord‚Äôs order. Because, however politely put, it was an order. Sighing, Regulus pulls out his wand and a second later a silver stag appears at his side, drawing some eyes and making Regulus‚Äôs heart ache a little.

Not in a bad way.

Just‚Äîhe‚Äôll never look at Boo and not see James now.

But it‚Äôs not in a bad way. How could it be?

‚ÄúKreacher,‚Äù he speaks, quietly and quickly, ‚Äúyou are needed in the drawing room of Malfoy Manor immediately,‚Äù I‚Äôm sorry, he thinks but doesn‚Äôt dare say, nodding at Boo to go.

A second later Boo is nothing but a streaming white light bounding out of the room. Regulus scrubs at his face as he tries to convince himself that he hasn‚Äôt just made a colossal mistake. Because he actually has no idea what Voldemort wants a house elf for. What if it has nothing to do with the Horcrux at all? What if he‚Äôs just volunteered Kreacher for something awful for no reason?

He runs his hands through his hair, fingers getting caught in his curls. This is a bad idea. He got overly excited at the prospect of a lead‚Äîthey haven‚Äôt had many of those. Or any. Other than their tentative theory that Voldemort is Tom Riddle, and that the Horcrux might be related to Salazar Slytherin, him and Cerci haven‚Äôt been able to come up with anything. And they‚Äôre running out of time.

There‚Äôs a loud crack beside his chair, causing Regulus to sit up straight, a new bolt of anxiety rushing through him now that Kreacher is here.

‚ÄúIs Master Regulus being unwell?‚Äù Kreacher steps forward, eyes doing a quick circuit of Regulus‚Äôs body, looking for injuries.

‚ÄúNo I‚ÄîI‚Äôm fine. Listen,‚Äù he turns in his chair so that he‚Äôs facing Kreacher properly, his back to the head of the table. The rest of the room has largely emptied out.

‚ÄúI need‚ÄîI‚Äôm so sorry Kreacher‚Äîbut I need to ask something of you, something that‚Äôs not fair.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù calls out a high, cold voice, ‚Äúis that your elf?‚Äù

He does his best not to grimace. ‚ÄúYes, my lord,‚Äù he says over his shoulder.

‚ÄúWell then, by all means, bring him here.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù he turns back to Kreacher.

‚ÄúMaster?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever happens,‚Äù Regulus says in a desperate whisper. ‚ÄúWhatever happens you come back okay? Whatever he says to you, wherever he takes you, whatever he‚Äî‚Äú his voice cracks, ‚Äúhe does to you. You come back home okay? That‚Äôs an order.‚Äù

Kreacher looks at him quizzically. ‚ÄúOf course, I is always being coming back to you sir.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt know what to say to that, to the sincerity in his voice. He squeezes his eyes shut.

‚ÄúMaster is you sure you is being‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRegulus, lets not keep the Dark Lord waiting. You‚Äôre being rude,‚Äù Bellatrix shouts across the room. It takes a huge effort for him not to snap back at her.

‚ÄúOkay, okay,‚Äù he opens his eyes, finding Kreacher‚Äôs concerned gaze still on him. ‚ÄúCome with me.‚Äù

It feels like it takes an obscenely long time for him to get to the other end of the table, the eyes of all the people waiting burning into him.

‚ÄúMy lord,‚Äù he dips his head when he finally gets there, Voldemort sitting back in his chair, reminding Regulus disturbingly of James. The cockiness, the ease‚Äîof a person used to being admired. ‚ÄúThis is Kreacher. He will be happy to serve you anyway he can,‚Äù the words nearly choke Regulus on the way out of his mouth.

Voldemort gives Kreacher a cursory look, Kreacher instantly bowing.

‚ÄúIt would be my greatest honour to make the Black family proud by serving the Dark Lord,‚Äù he mutters largely to the floor, as though he is not even worthy of looking at Voldemort.

‚ÄúAw, what a good wittle boy he is,‚Äù Bellatrix is hanging off of Rodolphus, pointed chin hooked over his shoulder. She‚Äôs speaking about Kreacher but she‚Äôs looking at Regulus, grinning. His nails bite into the palms of his fists.

‚ÄúYou may go,‚Äù Voldemort‚Äôs voice brings Regulus‚Äôs attention back to him.

‚ÄúMy lord?‚Äù

Voldemort waves his hand. ‚ÄúThank you for your elf, you are dismissed now.‚Äù

‚ÄúRun a long and play with your friends Regulus,‚Äù Lucius says, eyes sharp. ‚ÄúLet the adults talk.‚Äù

This is a mistake.

He can‚Äôt leave Kreacher here.

Can‚Äôt leave him at the mercy of these people.

This is a mistake.

As if he can hear his thoughts, Kreacher speaks in a quiet voice. ‚ÄúI will be being alright Master Regulus, I is most happy to do this for you. For Mistress Black. She will be proud I think.‚Äù

A mistake.

A mistake.

A mistake.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he croaks. ‚ÄúYeah she‚Äôll be proud.‚Äù If Walburga Black has ever considered Kreacher for longer than two seconds at a time Regulus would be shocked. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you soon okay?‚Äù

Kreacher nods. ‚ÄúYes sir.‚Äù

And what else is there after that?

Regulus‚Äôs feet feel like they‚Äôre made of lead as he walks away. Heavy and sinking and desperate to stand still. He looks back once, when he gets to the door, sees Kreacher standing at the side of Voldemort‚Äôs chair, ignored.

You‚Äôre good at this huh?

Evan‚Äôs hand on his shoulder. Breath on his neck.

Leaving people behind?

Regulus barely makes it home before the panic attack starts.

¬†

PART II SIRIUS

Sirius wakes up alone.

It‚Äôs not so bad.

He‚Äôs used to it.

At least that‚Äôs what he tells himself.

He spends a long time in bed, staring at the ceiling, trying to convince himself to get up. Get dressed. Drink some water. The idea of just going back to sleep is tempting. Of just staying in bed until Remus comes home. Whenever that is. He pulls the covers up over his head, wrapping them around himself, pouting even though no one‚Äôs there to see it.

Sometimes he pictures their dorm room back at Hogwarts. He tries to remember every detail‚Äîevery scratch in the wall, every fingerprint on the window, every sock lost under the bed. He closes his eyes and imagines listening to Peter and James bicker about Quidditch, to Remus telling them off for getting distracted from their coursework. He imagines the sly ways Remus used to look at him, used to touch him, especially in those last two years. Back when they really shouldn‚Äôt have but they just couldn‚Äôt help it.

The brush of a pinky finger.

The press of a thigh.

The hug that went on just a bit too long.

He imagines sitting in the Great Hall. Pictures it perfectly‚Äîevery table, every banner, the noise and chaos. Remus next to him, James laughing at something Marlene‚Äôs just said. Lily and Peter playing chess, Mary people watching.

Eventually, his imagining turns into dreaming, as he falls back asleep even though he told himself he wouldn‚Äôt.

When he wakes up he‚Äôs still alone.

No bickering. No touches. No noise.

It‚Äôs not so bad.

He‚Äôs used to it.

At least that‚Äôs what he tells himself.

¬†

‚ÄúSorry I‚Äôm late,‚Äù he says as he slides into the seat across from Alice forty-five minutes after he was supposed to be there. ‚ÄúSlept in.‚Äù

Most people would be pissed, but Alice just gives him a bemused smile, reaching over and mussing his hair. ‚ÄúYeah, I can tell.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù he slaps her hand away. ‚ÄúI ran a comb through it.‚Äù

She arches her brow, causing Sirius to roll his eyes.

‚ÄúWell, I thought about running a comb through it.‚Äù

Alice snorts. ‚ÄúThat sounds about right.‚Äù

They‚Äôre having lunch at a restaurant Alice picked, Muggle as far as Sirius can tell. That in itself is a bit suspicions. Not that they never go to Muggle places, but usually their number one draw is that you‚Äôre unlikely to be overheard.

‚ÄúBeen here before?‚Äù Sirius asks casually, as he pulls the menu towards himself. He smiles when he sees that they‚Äôre still serving brunch.

‚ÄúOnce or twice,‚Äù Alice shrugs, before quickly changing the subject. ‚ÄúSo, how‚Äôve you been?‚Äù she kicks him gently under the table. ‚ÄúFeel like I haven‚Äôt seen you in ages.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, that‚Äôs because you‚Äôre a big important Auror lady now,‚Äù he puts the menu down, looking up at her. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve forgotten all about us little people.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh please, as if I could ever forget about my first crush.‚Äù

Sirius laughs out loud, the noise coming right from his chest. ‚ÄúAlice Longbottom you‚Äôre a dirty liar.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? Me? How rude of you to even suggest such a thing,‚Äù she gives him an impish smile, Sirius merely needing to arch a single eyebrow to make her crack. ‚ÄúOh alright, fine, my first crush was actually Morgan Dubas, but you were a close second.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe lead Chaser for Yorkshire?‚Äù

Alice lets out a dreamy sigh. ‚ÄúHe was very good with a Quaffle, and those hands‚Äîgod, they were just‚Ä¶so‚Ä¶big.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin Alice, there are children around,‚Äù Sirius teases, clutching his imaginary pearls.

‚ÄúAnd since when do you care about being family friendly?‚Äù

They‚Äôre only joking. He doesn‚Äôt know why it reminds him of Remus, why he hears his voice so clearly in his head: ‚ÄúYou ever think about it? Having kids?‚Äù The empty flat waiting for him makes the memory sting. Makes him pause just long enough for Alice to notice.

Rookie mistake.

‚ÄúListen,‚Äù he presses on quickly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just trying to prepare you for your future as a respectable mum,‚Äù he looks very pointedly at her belly.

‚ÄúWho said anything about respectable?‚Äù her eyes twinkling. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to be a fun mum. No rules, no bedtimes, and ice cream for dinner!‚Äù

Sirius laughs, ‚ÄúFrank is going to have a fucking stroke.‚Äù

But Alice only smiles. ‚ÄúHe knows what he signed up for.‚Äù

The waitress comes by and takes their orders, Sirius asking for just about everything off the brunch menu, including the bottomless mimosas. Alice gives him a look after the waitress leaves.

‚ÄúYou know I can‚Äôt have any of those right?‚Äù she asks.

‚ÄúGood, cause I hate sharing.‚Äù

Alice only shakes her head. ‚ÄúBrat.‚Äù

They talk a bit about work but not much. Alice can‚Äôt say anything really. No one can these days. But he gets the gist of it; everyone is tired, everyone is scared, nothing is getting any better. In fact, what no one seems to want to outright say, not even Alice, is that things are undeniably getting worse. They‚Äôre losing this war. And no one seems to know how to stop it.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Sirius says, once they‚Äôve finished their food and he‚Äôs on his third drink. ‚ÄúWhat is this really about then?‚Äù

Alice‚Äôs eyes go wide and she gasps dramatically, hand flying to her chest. ‚ÄúWhat? A girl can‚Äôt just ask a handsome young man to lunch without having some ulterior motive?‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow, taking a sip of his mimosa and waiting. The smile eventually slips from Alice‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says, placing his glass down, ‚Äúthis IS serious then?‚Äù

She sighs, leaning forward, resting her arms on the table. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she says eventually. ‚ÄúYeah a bit.‚Äù

Sirius doesn‚Äôt know what to say to that so he just waits, the restaurant carrying on around them‚Äîmuted chatter, clinking glasses, waiters maneuvering between tables. When a good five minutes has passed and Alice still hasn‚Äôt said anything he reaches his foot out and nudges her‚Äôs under the table.

‚ÄúHey Alice, you‚Äôre scaring me a little over here.‚Äù

He sees her grimace. ‚ÄúSorry that‚Äôs‚Äîthat‚Äôs the opposite of what I wanted to do I just‚Ä¶I‚Äôm not exactly sure how to tell you what I‚Ä¶what I have to tell you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he says slowly. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you just start and I‚Äôll let you know when I need you to stop?‚Äù

She bites down on her lower lip, holding his gaze. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she exhales. ‚ÄúOkay, so‚Ä¶‚Äù running a hand over her face. ‚ÄúYou remember, a couple weeks ago, the attack on the Ministry?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, ‚Äòcourse?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúWell, me and Frank were there. And‚Ä¶you know, maybe you already know this and now I‚Äôve just made this a whole thing and it doesn‚Äôt even‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAlice,‚Äù he cuts off her babbling. ‚ÄúJust tell me okay?‚Äù

She swallows. ‚ÄúRight. So me and Frank were there. But‚Äîum‚Äîbut so was Remus.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence. Sirius just staring at her, forehead wrinkling.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand. Like‚Ä¶with the Aurors?‚Äù

‚ÄúSo he didn‚Äôt‚Äîhe didn‚Äôt tell you?‚Äù she asks tentatively.

Something like dread has started to fill the pit of Sirius‚Äôs stomach. ‚ÄúTell me what? That he was there with you guys? No. No he didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Alice looks slightly pained. ‚ÄúHe‚Äîhe wasn‚Äôt there with us,‚Äù she‚Äôs lowered her voice, leaning closer to Sirius, eyes darting around the restaurant, like she‚Äôs afraid of being overheard even here. ‚ÄúHe was there with Greyback.‚Äù

The dread grows, crawling up his esophagus, crawling into his chest, burning his throat. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Sirius finally manages. Because everything he knows about Remus, everything he has known about him since they were both eleven years old, rebels against that idea. He‚Äôd thought maybe Remus was working with werewolves. Maybe. But never Greyback.

Alice reaches across the table, squeezing his hand. ‚ÄúListen, hey, Sirius? Listen to me. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs Order business okay? We know that Dumbledore‚Äôs been sending him somewhere‚ÄîI‚Äôm sure this is it.‚Äù

Sirius nods, feeling numb. ‚ÄúHave you talked to Moody‚Äîhe would know wouldn‚Äôt he?‚Äù

She frowns. ‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt tell me anything, won‚Äôt tell anyone anything anymore. He‚Äôs completely paranoid. Honestly I‚Äôm a little worried‚Ä¶‚Äù she shakes her head. ‚ÄúNot the point. Look, I wouldn‚Äôt even have brought it up except‚Äîexcept he seemed, god how do I say this‚Äîthe way he was acting with the other werewolves it felt‚Ä¶close. The way they fought together, protected one another, touched each other‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúTouched each other?‚Äù

Alice rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt snogging anyone in the middle of the Atrium Sirius but it didn‚Äôt feel‚Äî‚Äú she lets out another breath, squeezing his hand. ‚ÄúLook, I‚Äôve known Remus for a long time. I know what it looks like when he cares about people and‚Ä¶and this didn‚Äôt seem like acting to me.‚Äù

Pins and needles prickle across Sirius‚Äôs skin as he struggles to maintain some semblance of composure.

‚ÄúSo what are you saying?‚Äù he asks finally.

Alice‚Äôs eyes are pitiful. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying‚Ä¶sometimes, when people go undercover, they get sucked in. They get attached. I‚Äôm saying‚Ä¶I think maybe, however his involvement with Greyback started, there‚Äôs a chance he‚Äôs‚Äîhe‚Äôs in too deep.‚Äù

‚ÄúDeep enough that he‚Äôs feeding him information about us?‚Äù Sirius asks.

She squeezes his hand. ‚ÄúNo‚ÄîI‚Äîat least not on purpose. I don‚Äôt believe he would ever put any of you in danger on purpose.‚Äù

‚ÄúOn purpose,‚Äù Sirius repeats.

‚ÄúIf he‚Äôs grown to trust them it‚Äôs possible that he‚Äôs‚Ä¶sharing more than he should. But that doesn‚Äôt mean‚Äî‚Äù she stops, looking at him for a long moment before she continues. ‚ÄúTalk to him okay? Just‚Ä¶I think you need to talk to him.‚Äù

Sirius shakes his head. ‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt talk to me. Won‚Äôt tell me anything. Hasn‚Äôt for months.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen maybe‚Äîgod I hate that I‚Äôm even saying this‚Äîbut then maybe be careful what you tell him okay? For your own sake.‚Äù

Sirius pulls away, pressing the heals of his hands into his eyes. ‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses. ‚ÄúFuck I hate this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

He laughs. ‚ÄúNot your fault, at least you‚Äôre‚Ä¶talking to me,‚Äù he drops his hands. He feels exhausted. Exhausted by the constant back and forth, by the uncertainty, by being so desperately in love with someone and so fucking terrified that you‚Äôve got it all wrong. Because he‚Äôs gotten it all wrong before. And he doesn‚Äôt trust himself. Doesn‚Äôt trust his judgement. He never has. But he‚Äôs always trusted Remus‚Äôs.

‚ÄúSirius, hey, Sirius, look at me?‚Äù Alice says gently, and eventually he does. ‚ÄúWhatever is happening here, whatever is going on with him, I don‚Äôt believe for a second that he‚Äôs doing anything he thinks would hurt you. People get turned around, especially these days, but Remus loves you. He loves all of you.‚Äù

My dad loves me, Sirius almost says. He‚Äôs glad he doesn‚Äôt. Not sure he could explain to her what he means. Not sure he could explain how little being loved really matters in the end.

¬†

When Sirius gets home the flat is still empty. Still quiet. He stands for a long time just inside the door, staring out at the place he‚Äôs made his home. Different in every way to Grimmauld. And in every corner, of every room, he sees pieces of Remus. His books, his mugs, his jumpers and blankets and records.

He walks down the hall and into the bedroom, climbs back into bed, pulls the covers around him and tries to get his thoughts to still. Tries to make them stop thinking about all the conversations he and Remus have had about what happened at the Ministry. How he never mentioned he‚Äôd been there. Acted just as surprised about it as all the rest of them. Sat there and lied to Sirius‚Äôs face so well that he never suspected a thing.

He doesn‚Äôt want to think about the other day either. About going to visit Charlotte. About whether or not that was all far more sinister than it appeared. About whether or not it had been Greyback who sent them to check up on her‚ÄîRemus never did say who the letter was from.

He curls further in on himself, burrowing deeper into the blankets.

Shut up.

Shut up.

Shut up.

But it‚Äôs so fucking quiet.

And he‚Äôs so fucking alone.

And his thoughts are so loud.

It‚Äôs bad.

It‚Äôs bad.

And Remus isn‚Äôt there to make it better.

¬†

PART III REGULUS

He doesn‚Äôt know what to do with himself. He paces around the house, thinks about firecalling Cerci, but he knows that she‚Äôs at work. It‚Äôs probably for the best, he doesn‚Äôt even have anything to tell her really, nothing‚Äôs happened. He realizes he never even asked Voldemort how long he would be taking Kreacher for. It could be days, it could be weeks.

Fuck he‚Äôs such an idiot.

He ends up in the kitchen, the part of the house that feels the safest, he makes tea because it‚Äôs one of the only thing he knows how to do on his own. He finds his breakfast still waiting for him. Still under a warming charm, ready to be eaten. Looking at it makes his stomach lurch. He hadn‚Äôt been thinking, too focused on maybe, finally, getting closer to the Horcrux‚Äîhe hadn‚Äôt been thinking about what he was actually agreeing to.

He leaves his lukewarm tea behind and retreats to his bedroom.

He stares at the newspaper clippings on his wall like they will suddenly provide the answers they have failed to for the last few weeks. Like suddenly he‚Äôll know exactly where Voldemort has taken Kreacher and he‚Äôll‚Äîwhat? Show up? Tell the Dark Lord he‚Äôs changed his mind and whisk Kreacher away? He sighs, scrubbing at his face before he starts to pace again.

One end of the room to the other.

One end of the room to the other.

One end of the room to the‚Äîwell, you get the point.

Hours pass.

The day a fleeting thing, flickering and going out, quickly turning into evening, drifting towards night. Eventually Regulus gives up on his pacing, sitting down at his desk with a quill and piece of parchment. He‚Äôll write Cerci, tell her what‚Äôs happened so far. If he calls she‚Äôll just come over‚ÄîI mean, she‚Äôll probably come over anyway but at least this way he gets to tell himself that she‚Äôs the needy one and not the other way around.

He presses the tip of his quill to the page‚Äî

Crack.

Regulus jumps, hand automatically grabbing the letter in front of him like it‚Äôs something he needs to hide. He spins around and finds Kreacher on the floor. He‚Äôs on his hands and knees, gasping for air and soaking wet. Regulus is instantly at his side.

‚ÄúKreacher? Kreacher, are you alright‚Äîshit, Kreacher?‚Äù the elf is shaking and muttering to himself. Regulus lifts his wand only to realize it‚Äôs not a wand but his quill. Rolling his eyes he stuffs it in his pocket along with the parchment he‚Äôs still clutching for some godforsaken reason. The second he has his wand out he dries and warms Kreacher who sags with relief, looking like he‚Äôs ready to collapse onto the floor.

‚ÄúKreacher what happened?‚Äù

The house elf‚Äôs eyes are panicked, looking at Regulus and then away, darting all over the room. Regulus reaches out to place a hand on his shoulder and Kreacher instantly flinches back, causing Regulus to freeze. For a moment the pair just stare at one another, both looking frightened.

‚ÄúI is‚Äî‚Äú Kreacher hiccups. ‚ÄúI is sorry I do not mean to be being so‚Äî‚Äú another hiccup, maybe it‚Äôs a sob but Regulus can‚Äôt quite handle that, so he does with it what he does with everything he can‚Äôt handle‚Äîpretends it doesn‚Äôt exist. ‚ÄúSo uncouth, is not proper for a house elf to be in such a‚Äîa state,‚Äù Kreacher struggles to get to his feet.

‚ÄúHey wait, Kreacher it‚Äôs okay, it‚Äôs okay,‚Äù he holds his hands out but doesn‚Äôt touch him, doesn‚Äôt try to help, it‚Äôs clear that Kreacher doesn‚Äôt want him to. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you‚Äîhere, sit on the bed yeah? Lie down?‚Äù

This only makes Kreacher more upset, already shaking all over, he backs away from Regulus on unsteady legs. Like he‚Äôs scared.

He‚Äôs never been scared of me before, Regulus thinks numbly. He stays on the ground, stays on his knees, hoping somehow that will help.

‚ÄúI cannot use Master‚Äôs bed!‚Äù Kreacher‚Äôs voice cracks, looking back at Regulus in absolute horror. ‚ÄúIt would be disgraceful‚Äîno respectful elf would ever‚ÄîI cannot degrade the house of Black in such a way. I serve. I wish to serve. I will serve no matter what. No matter what. I will do my duty.‚Äù He‚Äôs crying. And Regulus doesn‚Äôt know what to do. He‚Äôs never seen Kreacher cry before. Not really. Not like this.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù he says, bereft of anything else. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay. You‚Äôre a good elf. You‚Äîyou‚Äôre so good.‚Äù Fuck. Fuck. What has he done? What has he done. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry‚ÄîI‚Äôm so sorry Kreacher. I shouldn‚Äôt have made you go with him.‚Äù

He‚Äôs trying.

He‚Äôs trying to be a better person.

He doesn‚Äôt know why he can‚Äôt get it right.

‚ÄúI is be doing whatever my Master is needing me to do,‚Äù Kreacher says in a voice that shakes, doing his best to pull his shoulders back, to stand straight, even while he sniffles, tear tracks clear on his face.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù because there‚Äôs nothing else.

Well, almost nothing else.

Regulus grits his teeth. ‚ÄúKreacher I‚Äîcan you tell me? Can you tell me what happened? Can you tell me where he took you? What he‚Äîwhat he did?‚Äù Regulus is still on the floor, sitting back on his heels, making him and Kreacher the same height. Kreacher might even be taller.

The house elf shivers. ‚ÄúIt‚ÄîI is‚Äî‚Äú he stops, one thin hand coming to the base of his neck and holding there. He looks so frightened. Regulus has seen Kreacher take the brunt of his mother‚Äôs anger many times without even blinking. Whatever Voldemort did‚Ä¶

‚ÄúIf you can‚Äôt talk about it that‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú but Kreacher shakes his head, cutting Regulus off.

‚ÄúMaster Regulus wishes to know so I is be telling him,‚Äù he says, sounding angry with himself. He breathes out, determination in his eyes. ‚ÄúHe is taking me‚Äîtaking me to a cave sir.‚Äù

‚ÄúA cave?‚Äù Regulus crosses his legs, listening like a little kid being told a bedtime story.

Kreacher nods. ‚ÄúAnd there was‚Äîwas a potion,‚Äù another shiver. ‚ÄúHe is be making Kreacher drink it. It‚Äî‚Äú he seems at a loss for words, eyes haunted.

‚ÄúDid it hurt you?‚Äù Regulus doesn‚Äôt know why he‚Äôs whispering.

Kreacher blinks, as if coming back‚Äîback to Grimmauld, to the present, to Regulus. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says after a moment. ‚ÄúIt hurt, here,‚Äù he taps his temple. ‚ÄúAnd here,‚Äù over his heart.

Regulus has no idea what that means. He runs through every potion he can think of but he‚Äôs not sure he knows any that match that description. Not sure he can bring himself to ask Kreacher to go into detail.

‚ÄúThen he‚Äîhe took a necklace‚Äî‚Äú Regulus sits up straighter. ‚ÄúAnd he be placing it in the bowl and the potion is being returning.‚Äù

A necklace.

A necklace in a cave hidden in a potion designed to torture the drinker.

There is no way that Voldemort would go to such great lengths unless‚Äîunless‚Äî

‚Äú‚Äîand when I be trying to drink, when I is being at the edge,‚Äù Kreacher continues on. ‚ÄúWhen I drank from the water‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúCan you take me there?‚Äù Regulus cuts him off.

Kreacher blinks, startled. ‚ÄúNo! Master Regulus no! You cannot be going there it is a terrible place! Terrible! Kreacher does not want to be bringing you there.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut could you?‚Äù he asks. ‚ÄúCould you Apparate us back there?‚Äù

Kreacher looks profoundly unhappy about this, but he can‚Äôt outright lie to Regulus so instead he reluctantly answers, ‚ÄúYes, I is thinking so.‚Äù

Regulus nods, mind going a mile a minute. This is his chance. If he can destroy the Horcrux then James‚Äôs child might survive. Then he can prove to Sirius that he isn‚Äôt the person Sirius thinks he is. Then he can start over.

Maybe.

God, just maybe he can start over.

He wants to call Cerci but there‚Äôs no reason to put her in danger‚Äîa potion and a cave, Regulus can handle that on his own. And if they go now then he can be certain they won‚Äôt run into Voldemort. He won‚Äôt return tonight, not after he‚Äôs just been there.

This is his chance.

‚ÄúTake me,‚Äù he says decisively, finally getting to his feet.

Kreacher‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúNo‚ÄîMaster Regulus please‚Äî‚Äú

But he‚Äôs doing this. This time. Just this one time. He‚Äôs going to do it right. ‚ÄúTake me, that‚Äôs an order,‚Äù he holds his hand out to Kreacher who looks absolutely miserable.

‚ÄúI is scared Master Regulus,‚Äù he says in a small voice.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù Regulus reassures him. He‚Äôs scared too. Scared shitless. But he‚Äôs trying. He‚Äôs trying. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be okay,‚Äù his hand is still outstretched and after another few seconds Kreacher finally reaches out.

Crack.

The wind is the first thing Regulus feels, so strong and cold that it bowls him over, causing him to lose his balance in the rocky sand.

‚ÄúI is sorry sir,‚Äù Kreacher is at his side, helping him back to his feet. ‚ÄúI is meaning to Apparate inside the cave,‚Äù he scrunches his nose. ‚ÄúI is not knowing why we ended up here.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut this is it?‚Äù Regulus asks as he looks up at the dark rocks in front of them, jagged points forming a small opening, one you could almost miss. It doesn‚Äôt help that the sun has practically set.

‚ÄúYes sir, this is it. But I do not think we should be going any further. You is seeing it, now we should leave.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have to get the necklace Kreacher,‚Äù the sky is dark above them, clouds blocking out the waking stars. After a few moments Regulus looks down at the elf. ‚ÄúYou can wait here if you want, I won‚Äôt make you go in again.‚Äù

Kreacher gives him a look like that‚Äôs the most ridiculous thing he‚Äôs ever heard. ‚ÄúWhere Master Regulus goes Kreacher will go also.‚Äù

Regulus smiles faintly. ‚ÄúWe won‚Äôt be long, I promise.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not until he starts walking that he realizes that in his haste he forgot to put on shoes. His socks quickly filling with sand. Regulus grimaces but doesn‚Äôt stop. Knows if he turns around now‚Äîfor shoes or anything else‚Äîhe won‚Äôt be able to summon the courage to come back.

The wind howls around them, waves crashing angrily into the shore, like they know he‚Äôs not supposed to be there. The cave a secret no one was meant to find. But Regulus just ducks his head and pushes forward, the world going quiet the minute he steps between the stones.

He thought it was dark outside but his eyes still need to adjust to the dimmer light of the cave. He pulls out his wand.

‚ÄúLumos,‚Äù he whispers, doing his best not to step on any of the sharper rocks. The passage is narrow, everything about the space pointed‚Äîthe ground, the walls, the ceiling.

‚ÄúWhere exactly are we supposed to go?‚Äù he asks Kreacher, uneasy with how small the space is, already feeling trapped. His eyes are constantly sliding over his shoulder, ears peeled for the sound of footsteps. Of Apparation.

‚ÄúThere is a door,‚Äù Kreacher replies simply.

Regulus looks down at him and then at the dead end in front of them. He lifts his wand, wondering if he‚Äôs missing it in the shadows, but no matter how many times he runs over the rocks he can‚Äôt see a door.

‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù Regulus asks finally.

‚ÄúYes, he is be cutting Kreacher here,‚Äù Kreacher presses his hand to the stone.

Regulus blinks. ‚ÄúHe cut you?‚Äù

Kreacher nods, pulling his hand back from the wall and cradling it against his chest. Regulus steps closer to the rocks, slipping, as he does, on the wet ground. Biting down on his tongue to keep from cursing every time something sticks into his foot. When he‚Äôs close enough he reaches out, placing his palm flat against the wall.

It‚Äôs warm.

Everything else‚Äîthe wind, the water, the ground beneath their feet‚Äîeverything else is cold except for this. Regulus pulls back, eyeing it for another moment before drawing the point of his wand diagonally across his palm.

‚ÄúNo! Master Regulus!‚Äù Kreacher sounds genuinely irritated with him. ‚ÄúYou should have let me sir!‚Äù

Regulus gives him a small smile. ‚ÄúI already made you bleed once today Kreacher,‚Äù he says, blood pooling in his palm before he presses it to the wall. It stings, Regulus gritting his teeth against the pain. The rocks beside him begin to shimmer and shake, and after a few seconds they dissolve into a door.

Regulus pulls his arm away from the wall, blood staining his wrist and sleeve, his pulse beating in the palm of his hand.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he clears his throat, hoping that in the relative darkness Kreacher can‚Äôt see him shaking. ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt so bad.‚Äù

But Kreacher is not at all appeased. If anything he‚Äôs getting more nervous, eyes darting about nearly as much as Regulus‚Äôs‚Äîwringing out his hands and pulling at his ears.

‚ÄúPlease sir,‚Äù he whispers, and Regulus can see the little frozen cloud his breath makes as it‚Äôs caught in the light of his Lumos. ‚ÄúLet us turn back now.‚Äù

And oh how he wants to.

Every fibre of his being wants to turn around and go home.

And pretend not to know what he does.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be okay,‚Äù he tells Kreacher‚Äîtries to make himself believe it too‚Äîas he walks through the door.

If Regulus had thought the front half of the cave was dark, it is nothing compared to this. On the other side of the wall the black becomes almost impenetrable, Regulus able to see nothing but the small radius cut out by his wand. Fear runs up his spine, tensing his muscles. He doesn‚Äôt know what Voldemort has hidden in this darkness but he knows it can‚Äôt be pleasant.

Regulus lifts a shaking hand in what he is pretty sure is the direction of the ceiling and speaks clearly: ‚ÄúLumos Fons.‚Äù Light shoots from the end of his wand forming an orb in the space above them, brightening their surroundings. Regulus blinks, adjusting to it, ready for an attack. For something to jump out at him. But nothing does.

The ceiling here is higher, the cave much deeper than it was at the front. They appear to be standing on a shore of sorts, ink black water in front of them, and at the centre‚Äî

‚ÄúIs that it?‚Äù Regulus asks, nodding towards the small island. ‚ÄúIs that where the necklace is?‚Äù

Kreacher doesn‚Äôt follow his gaze, eyes intent on the water, but he nods. ‚ÄúYes sir. That‚Äôs where it is.‚Äù

Regulus looks around but he can‚Äôt see any pathways or bridges. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôd you get there?‚Äù he asks finally.

‚ÄúWe is taking the boat sir.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe boat?‚Äù Regulus repeats, eyes running along the shore again, but the space is barren. Nothing but rock. ‚ÄúWhat boat?‚Äù

Kreacher grimaces, gesturing ahead, ‚ÄúHe is calling it from the water. I is sorry, I do not know how.‚Äù

Every word they speak bounces off the walls around them. Repeated back. Like the cave is mocking them. Regulus closes his eyes for a minute. Trying to think of what he‚Äôd felt with his sliced palm pressed to the stone wall. The unnatural heat that had radiated off of it. He tries to focus on what that had tasted like. Smelt like. Dragged up inside him. The way he can feel James in the locket around his neck. Or Sirius, in the pictures stuck to his bedroom walls.

Magic leaves traces.

It takes a few seconds, to quiet his brain, his rapid pulse, but eventually he finds it.

Like metal at the back of his throat.

And he pulls.

The sound of something breaking the surface of the water has Regulus‚Äôs eyes snapping open just in time to see a glowing green chain shooting towards him. He‚Äôs barely able to keep it from slamming into his skull, fumbling to catch it before eventually getting his grip. It leads right back into the black water.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he hisses, heart jackhammering in his chest. The chain is cold‚Äîcolder than ice, cold in a way that instantly spreads through his whole body. Shivering like mad, he gives it a pull, stepping back and watching as the nose of a small raft begins to peek above the water.

Kreacher grabs lower down on the chain and together they manage to drag the boat to the surface. It looks barely big enough for the pair of them.

‚ÄúClearly he‚Äôs not expecting many visitors,‚Äù Regulus mutters as he walks cautiously up to the small vessel, wand raised, ready just incase. But still, nothing happens. That almost increases his unease. Something isn‚Äôt right. This should be harder. But after a few more seconds of waiting Regulus reluctantly hauls himself into the boat, Kreacher crawling in after him, quivering like a leaf, eyes forever trained on the water.

As if it knows, the boat starts moving.

The stillness of the cave is the most unnerving part. The part that slips under Regulus‚Äôs skin and makes him twitch. Even with the light hanging above them the dark is barely penetrated, so much of the cave remaining unseen. So many dark corners for things to hide in. Regulus swallows with difficulty and tries to focus on what‚Äôs ahead.

When the boat runs aground it does so with a jolt, sending both Regulus and Kreacher spilling onto the floor, practically on top of one another.

‚ÄúKreacher?‚Äù Regulus asks softly, trying to avoid the echo. ‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù

When Kreacher speaks his voice is tight. ‚ÄúYes, Master.‚Äù

Nodding, Regulus untangles himself from the elf, getting unsteadily to his feet and climbing onto the small island they‚Äôve docked at. Now that they‚Äôre here, he can see the amalgamation of stones at its centre‚Äîthey almost look like crystals‚Äîjutting up out of the ground, taller than everything around them. And at the top; a basin with a locket at the bottom.

‚ÄúThis is what he made you drink then?‚Äù Regulus asks, staring down at the clear liquid inside. He leans over, trying to smell it, to get a sense of what‚Äôs in it, but he doesn‚Äôt pick up anything noticeable.

‚ÄúYes sir, and I is‚ÄîI is ready to drink it again on your command,‚Äù that takes Regulus aback, he turns to Kreacher who looks like‚Äôs he‚Äôs going to be sick. Pale faced and wide eyed, shaking again.

‚ÄúKreacher,‚Äù Regulus says softly, waiting for the elf‚Äôs eyes to meet his. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to make you go through that again.‚Äù

He watches Kreacher‚Äôs forehead wrinkle in confusion. ‚ÄúBut sir is be wanting the necklace, yes?‚Äù

Regulus swallows, chest tight. ‚ÄúYeah. I‚Äôm going to drink it myself.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo! Sir no! Please, let Kreacher, let Kreacher! I will be doing it sir! I will, I will, I will!‚Äù Kreacher grabs hold of Regulus‚Äôs wrist in desperation, his voice so much louder in the empty space, the ghosts of his words still pleading for him as they bounce off the stones and disappear into the darkness.

It‚Äôs a tempting offer.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus says after a brief pause, taking a deep breath.

He‚Äôs trying.

Trying.

Trying.

‚ÄúIt should be me.‚Äù

Kreacher lets out a pitiful noise and Regulus takes his hand and squeezes.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù that‚Äôs turning into his new mantra, but he doesn‚Äôt have much else he can say. He lets go of Kreacher‚Äôs hand after a few seconds and re-positions himself in front of the basin, putting his wand away even though it causes a spike of fear to strike through his chest. He picks up the ladle.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll hurt?‚Äù he asks.

Kreacher looks thoroughly miserable. ‚ÄúYes, yes but not‚Äîbut here,‚Äù he taps over his heart again and Regulus nods as though he understands.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll make sure I finish it, yeah?‚Äù he says, wincing at the way his voice cracks, fear getting a little too close to the surface, making him feel light headed. ‚ÄúPromise you won‚Äôt let me stop.‚Äù

Kreacher makes another pained noise. ‚ÄúI is promising.‚Äù

Regulus exhales, staring down at the locket, feeling a bit like he might pass out. The terror is acid in his stomach, burning holes through his insides. But it doesn‚Äôt matter. Not this time. Not after everything. Not when maybe, maybe just this once he can have something beautiful. Regulus closes his eyes briefly and then forces his hand to move, to scoop up the liquid, to bring it to his mouth. He feels like he has to instruct his body on every step, like it‚Äôs suddenly forgotten how to work. Has to tell his lips to part and his throat to swallow.

It doesn‚Äôt take long.

Rarely does with a good potion.

The world around him rocks and Regulus grabs hold of the basin to steady himself as the cave blurs. There. Gone. There. Gone. Walls‚Äîfamiliar walls‚Äîsprout from the ground.

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt do it!‚Äù

‚ÄúI will not allow your selfishness to destroy centuries of hard work.‚Äù

‚ÄúHard work? Is that a joke? Since when does anyone in this bloody family work?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou will show your name the respect it deserves.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs exactly what I‚Äôm doing.‚Äù

‚ÄúLet me have go Auntie, I‚Äôm sure I can teach him some manners.‚Äù

‚ÄúStay the fuck away from me Bella.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh look, the wittle baby has a wand. You think you can fight me cousin? Really? Go on, I dare you. Breaking you is going to be such a treat.‚Äù

The world rocks again and Regulus is back in the cave. The walls of Grimmauld crumbling into dust, his feet freezing as the cold stones burn through his socks. His whole body is trembling.

‚ÄúSir?‚Äù Kreacher asks tentatively. He‚Äôs looking up at Regulus with fear in his eyes and it takes a second before Regulus manages to answer.

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù he croaks. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine.‚Äù

He stares down at the potion, pulse quickening. He‚Äôs never encountered anything like this before. It‚Äôs like jumping into a Pensieve except‚Äîexcept the memory isn‚Äôt quite right. Distorted. Like a nightmare.

Hand trembling, he reaches in for more.

They‚Äôre in the library.

Regulus is hanging back by the door, holding the frame as he watches books and shelves be thrown about the room. Sirius and Bella going at one another. He wouldn‚Äôt call it a duel exactly. It‚Äôs too chaotic for that.

‚ÄúReally Sirius? Are we playing hide and go seek?‚Äù He can‚Äôt see either of them, lost somewhere in the shelves. But his mother is standing not too far in front of him, frighteningly still, just watching.

‚ÄúI thought you were a big strong Gryffindor,‚Äù Bella says in a baby voice, causing Rodolphus, currently leaning against the wall with his arms crossed over his chest, to laugh. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you come out here and face me like the man you think you are, huh?‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt understand why Sirius is doing this. He‚Äôs outnumbered. He doesn‚Äôt stand a chance, he must know that? Know that they‚Äôll only hurt him until they get their way? Why not cut out the middle part and just do what they want?

‚ÄúFine.‚Äù

He see Sirius then, stepping into the aisle between two bookshelves.

He sees Bellatrix too.

He doesn‚Äôt know if she was throwing her voice, or using some sort of spell, but she isn‚Äôt where he‚Äôd thought. Isn‚Äôt where Sirius thought either, if the way he‚Äôs facing is anything to go by.

‚ÄúWell?‚Äù Sirius shouts, wand raised. He‚Äôs scared, he does a good job of hiding it but Regulus can tell. Bellatrix is coming up behind him, a wicked smile on her face, and Regulus wants to warn him. Wants to cry out. But he doesn‚Äôt. He never does.

‚ÄúWalburga, don‚Äôt you think this has gone far enough?‚Äù his father says quietly.

His mother only ‚Äúsh‚Äôs‚Äù him, doesn‚Äôt even look back. But it‚Äôs enough to catch Sirius‚Äôs attention. His head whips towards them, just as Bellatrix‚Äôs curse hits the middle of his back.

Sirius starts to scream.

This time, when Regulus finds himself in the cave again, he‚Äôs on his hands and knees. The ladle fallen a few feet away. He heaves in air like a drowning man.

‚ÄúSir,‚Äù Kreacher is at his side, sounding distressed. ‚ÄúSir, is you okay?‚Äù

He can‚Äôt quite find his voice, hanging his head and just trying to breathe, just trying not to vomit. It‚Äôs a good long while before he‚Äôs feeling strong enough to stand again, to pick up the ladle and go back to the basin.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù his voice crackles like firewood. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay.‚Äù

He forces down another mouthful.

Regulus isn‚Äôt sure how long the screaming goes on for. It feels like hours. Feels like days. He watches his brother contort, watches him flail and twist, limbs at impossible angles. The pain distorting his face into something barely recognizable.

Regulus‚Äôs legs give way but before he hits the ground his father grabs his arm, keeping him up.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù Orion says quietly, eyes never leaving the scene unfolding in front of them. ‚ÄúNone of that now.‚Äù

Sirius is in a heap on the floor, breathing heavy. It takes a few seconds but eventually he rolls onto his side, pushing gingerly to his hands and knees. ‚ÄúStupef‚Äî‚Äú

The spell doesn‚Äôt even make it out of his mouth, Bellatrix cackling as Rodolphus sends Sirius slamming into the bookshelves behind him, leather bound manuscripts raining down. Sirius isn‚Äôt able to stop the whimper of pain that leaves his mouth. He‚Äôs only fifteen.

Walburga‚Äôs steps are loud as she walks slowly down the aisle towards him, everyone else in the room freezing. Watching. Waiting. Sirius is sweating, hair plastered to his face, skin pale. Still, when their mother stops in front of him he glares. His hatred always stronger than his fear. Regulus doesn‚Äôt understand it.

‚ÄúAre you going to start cooperating?‚Äù her voice is empty, she could be discussing the weather.

Sirius bares his teeth. ‚ÄúFuck you,‚Äù he snaps, before spitting on the ground at her feet.

Walburga barely reacts, stare never wavering. And then, still without looking away: ‚ÄúAgain.‚Äù

‚ÄúI said‚Äî‚Äú

But, of course, she isn‚Äôt talking to Sirius.

A second later he‚Äôs screaming.

Bellatrix takes the lead but every once and a while Rodolphus will throw in a hex, lazily, like he‚Äôs bored. Passing the time. Sirius‚Äôs voice becomes something raw. Something stripped and carved and broken apart. His face streaked with tears. Sobbing in the short moments he‚Äôs allowed to catch his breath. It‚Äôs shocking, makes everything around Regulus feel fuzzy.

Sirius never cries.

The sound‚Äîthe sight‚Äîit does something terrible to Regulus‚Äôs insides. Makes them twist into knots. Every part of him feel nauseas‚Äîhis head, his chest, his stomach. He knows that if his father weren‚Äôt forcefully holding him up he‚Äôd been on the floor, on his knees.

He stares at his mother‚Äôs rigid back and silently begs her.

Make them stop.

Make them stop.

Make them stop.

Can‚Äôt stand to watch anymore. Dropping his eyes determinedly to the floor. Wishing he could cover his ears. Wishing he could runaway.

‚ÄúRegulus.‚Äù

He flinches as his mother‚Äôs voice cuts through the noise.

‚ÄúRegulus, look up.‚Äù

No.

No.

Please.

‚ÄúLook. Up. Now.‚Äù

His father gives his arm a little squeeze that Regulus knows means he won‚Äôt be getting any support from him. Taking in a shaking breath he lifts his head, meeting his mother‚Äôs cool eyes.

‚ÄúWatch.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaman‚Äî‚Äú

She reaches out, grip on his chin unforgiving, nails digging into his flesh. ‚ÄúYou will watch this, do you understand? And you will learn.‚Äù She jerks his head towards Sirius who is currently being sick, arms barely able to hold him up.

His mother lets go of him but Bellatrix has noticed the altercation, her clever eyes bouncing from Walburga to Regulus.

‚ÄúDoes little Reggie want to play?‚Äù she tilts her head to the side and Regulus feels as though the entire contents of his chest have just dropped into the pit of his stomach.

‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you give it a try little boy,‚Äù she nods her head at Sirius, who‚Äôs currently being pinned to the ground by Rodolphus‚Äôs boot.

Regulus blinks, looking from his brother to his cousin and back again, trembling so violently he can barely see anything at all. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh come on,‚Äù she grins. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell me you‚Äôve never thought about it‚Äîall those times he‚Äôs ignored you, made you feel inadequate? Now‚Äôs your chance.‚Äù

She gestures to Sirius like she‚Äôs a show girl, like he‚Äôs her prize. ‚ÄúGo on Regulus, do it.‚Äù

They‚Äôre all staring at him now, and Regulus keeps waiting for his mother to say something, to step in, to tell Bellatrix to stop playing around. But she doesn‚Äôt. She just watches. And he knows. Knows exactly what will happen if he refuses.

Sirius turns to him then, their eyes meeting. He‚Äôs never seen his brother look so small. So vulnerable. Sirius is mouthing something. Regulus can‚Äôt quite make it out.

He thinks it‚Äôs please.

Please Regulus.

Make them stop.

Regulus wants to look away, it hurts too much. But he doesn‚Äôt. He wants to tell Bellatrix no. No. I won‚Äôt. I can‚Äôt. But he doesn‚Äôt do that either.

This.

This is the moment.

He knows that now, years later.

It wasn‚Äôt the Mark. He‚Äôd already given up by then.

This right here, when he stares into his brother‚Äôs eyes‚Äîpleading and desperate and in so much need‚Äîand he does nothing.

Worse than that.

He lifts his wand.

This is the moment that Regulus Black makes his choice.

To be the kind of person who betrays the people he loves.

To be the kind of person who stands on the shore and watches you drown.

This is the moment he starts to rot on the inside.

Please Regulus.

Make them stop.

Please.

He wants to say he would do it differently now. But he still doesn‚Äôt know.

Still isn‚Äôt sure he could face the pain.

Please Regulus.

Make them stop.

Please.

The walls fall away.

Regulus‚Äôs face pressing into cold stone.

Someone is crying.

It takes a long time before he realizes it‚Äôs him.

¬†

It all goes a bit blurry after that. Regulus unable to tell one reality from the other. Kreacher must be keeping his promise because there‚Äôs no way Regulus is still managing to drink the potion on his own.

Sirius screams.

‚ÄúDoes little Reggie want to play?‚Äù

Screams.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell me you‚Äôve never thought about it.‚Äù

Screams.

‚ÄúGo on Regulus, do it.‚Äù

This is a box he never lets himself open. One he closed before Sirius was even down the drive. He can‚Äôt hold these memories. Not without falling apart. He‚Äôd known, even at the time, that he‚Äôd made a mistake. He just hadn‚Äôt realized how irrevocable that mistake had been.

‚ÄúSir? Master? Sir? Sir!‚Äù

Cold hands take hold of his face and Regulus tries to focus, Sirius‚Äôs voice still ringing in his ears. He‚Äôs propped up against one of the larger rocks, his whole body aching. His head too. And his mouth. It‚Äôs like he‚Äôs been eating sand.

‚ÄúSir?‚Äù

Kreacher.

He takes a deep breath.

Kreacher in the cave.

He‚Äôs has to drink the potion.

Has to get the Horcrux.

For James.

For James.

For James.

And his baby. And god, maybe even for Lily Evans.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù he barely sounds human. ‚ÄúI can take more.‚Äù

But Kreacher only shakes his head, eyes damp, hands still cradling Regulus‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no more sir, you did it, you drank it all.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs brain is a little fuzzy so it takes a moment for those words to sink in. ‚ÄúI did it?‚Äô he croaks.

Kreacher nods vigorously. ‚ÄúYes sir, yes.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Regulus leans back against the stone behind him, bringing his hands up to his face and exhaling. ‚ÄúI did it,‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúI did it.‚Äù He could cry. He chooses to laugh instead. Which, of course, turns into coughing. His throat is painfully scratchy. Every breath like dragging sandpaper up the back of it.

‚ÄúI will be getting the locket sir and then we will be going,‚Äù Kreacher pulls away, scrambling up to the basin. ‚ÄúWe will be getting you home.‚Äù

The coughing doesn‚Äôt subside and as Regulus is hacking up a lung his eyes go to the water‚Äôs edge. Not the most sanitary perhaps, but at this point, he really doesn‚Äôt give a fuck. He barely has to move‚Äîwhich is good, he isn‚Äôt feeling particularly stable‚Äîhe just has to reach over, cupped palm dipping into the water.

‚ÄúREGULUS!‚Äù

It‚Äôs the first time Kreacher has ever used his name like that. But he‚Äôs barely able to look at him, let alone say anything about it, before he feels something cold and slimy wrap around his wrist.

He‚Äôs expecting some kind of sea creature. A Grindylow maybe. What he isn‚Äôt expecting. Is a hand.

‚ÄúHoly fuck,‚Äù he rips his wrist out of its grasp, nails scratching along his skin as he scrambles up the rocks towards Kreacher. ‚ÄúWhat the fuck!‚Äù Regulus pulls his wand out, blood dripping from the scratch marks on his arm.

‚ÄúI is trying to tell you, I is trying to tell you!‚Äù Kreacher moans as Regulus stumbles clumsily to his feet, whirling around himself.

‚ÄúTrying to tell me what?‚Äù he demands.

Out in the water, in the shadows of light cast by his Lumos, he can see vague shapes bubbling up to the surface. Heads, he realizes.

‚ÄúThat I went to drink the water,‚Äù Kreacher is rambling on. ‚ÄúAnd when I went to drink the water the bodies came.‚Äù

‚ÄúBodies?‚Äù Regulus repeats. In every direction he sees them, no patch of water clear. And then, at the base of the rock‚Äîfingers. Grasping at the stones, slowly inching towards them, grey skin slouching off of knuckles and wrists.

‚ÄúInferi,‚Äù Regulus says in horror, body going cold. ‚ÄúHe put Inferi in the water.‚Äù

It‚Äôs the type of thing he‚Äôs read about but never considered, even for a second, that he would witness in real life. It‚Äôs horrific. Almost beyond comprehension, his brain fighting him, unwilling to accept what he can obviously see in front of him.

‚ÄúYou went to drink the water and the bodies came,‚Äù Regulus repeats slowly, trying to think of any spell that‚Äôll save him from an army of the undead.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Kreacher says miserably, wringing his hands again.

‚ÄúHow did you escape?‚Äù his eyes go to the boat but, of course, there are bodies creeping up that as well. He doubts they‚Äôll be able to push it off the rocks, let alone ride it to the other side of the water, without being capsized.

‚ÄúYou is telling me to come back.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs brow furrows as he tears his eyes away from the horrors in front of him. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou is telling Kreacher that he must come back!‚Äù his voice is high and strained.

Regulus is so tired and so turned around by the potion that it takes him far too long to understand: ‚ÄúYou Apparated? You can Apparate in here?‚Äù

Elves can Apparate places Wizards often can‚Äôt, but this‚Äîthis seems like a grave oversight on Voldemort‚Äôs part.

‚ÄúYes, of course,‚Äù Kreacher says, sounding almost offended.
