‚ÄúDo you have the locket?‚Äù Regulus asks quickly.

‚ÄúYes, yes I is having it,‚Äù Kreacher holds up the small golden amulet by its chain.

Regulus nods, offering him his hand. ‚ÄúThen lets get the fuck out of here.‚Äù

Kreacher doesn‚Äôt need to be told twice, grabbing hold of Regulus without hesitation.

Crack.

Regulus feels a jolt, like slamming into a wall, and then he drops down onto his hands and knees. Still in the cave. Still on the rock. Still surrounded by dead bodies. The only difference, is that Kreacher is no longer beside him.

That isn‚Äôt right.

He‚Äôs only just managed to get back to his feet when Kreacher appears again. Looking panicked.

‚ÄúI is so sorry sir, I is not knowing what is happening, I is Apparating just as always.‚Äù

Regulus waves his words away, ‚ÄúNever mind. Try again, yeah?‚Äù

Kreacher nods, this time taking hold of both of Regulus‚Äôs arms.

Crack.

Again Regulus slams into some invisible barrier, knocking him back onto the rock. ‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he shouts, gripping his wand and getting to his feet.

He tries Apparating himself‚Äîalways tricky when you don‚Äôt know exactly where you are‚Äîbut it doesn‚Äôt matter. The same thing happens.

Crack.

‚ÄúSir I is not knowing what is wrong!‚Äù Kreacher sounds close to tears.

Regulus‚Äôs eyes run the length of the cave, along the ceiling, the walls, the edges of the water. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll have put some sort of charm in place. Clearly he forget to account for elves but me‚Äîme he thought of.‚Äù

He eyes the boat again, wondering if there isn‚Äôt some way to salvage it, overrun with bodies or not. He lifts his wand: ‚ÄúStupefy,‚Äù he shouts. The spell finds its mark but the body is unaffected. Even if it had worked, what would he do? Stupefy every one of them? By the looks of it there are hundreds.

He closes his eyes, trying to think, trying to ignore the growing panic pulling at his seams, undoing him bit by bit. The cave here is fairly high, maybe‚Äîmaybe he can fly out? Eyes opening he raises his wand again.

‚ÄúAccio broom.‚Äù

That doesn‚Äôt work. He knows that immediately. Doesn‚Äôt feel the normal pull that he does when casting that spell. ‚Ä®‚Ä® ‚ÄúAccio broom,‚Äù he tries again. And again he feels nothing. ‚ÄúAccio broom, Accio broom, Accio‚ÄîAccio‚Äîfuck.‚Äù

Nothing moves. Nothing except the bodies in the water. Heads now popping up around their little island. Arms and shoulders pulling themselves to the surface.

Regulus can‚Äôt swim to safety. He can‚Äôt Apparate. He can‚Äôt bring anything to him. Before he can stop himself he folds over and grabs hold of his knees, laughing uncontrollably.

He‚Äôs stuck.

He‚Äôs stuck.

He‚Äôs fucking stuck.

‚ÄúSir?‚Äù Kreacher asks. ‚ÄúSir I is not seeing what is funny.‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing,‚Äù Regulus chokes out, still laughing. ‚ÄúNothing is funny, everything is so fucking‚Äî‚Äù

He‚Äôd done it.

Just for a moment he‚Äôd really thought‚Äî

‚ÄúWhat are we going to be doing sir?‚Äù

Regulus tries to breathe, he feels out of control, his mind and body overloaded with thoughts and feelings, leaving behind a numb sort of buzzing. In his chest. In his ears. In the spot just behind his eyes.

He forces himself to straighten up. What are they going to do? It‚Äôs a good question. An important one. What are they going to do? He exhales, struggling to think straight. To not scream or sob or collapse onto the ground.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to go,‚Äù Regulus says eventually, pleasantly surprised by how even his voice sounds.

‚ÄúI will be getting help?‚Äù

Regulus shakes his head, he‚Äôs not getting anyone else involved in this mess. ‚ÄúNo, you‚Äôre going to go,‚Äù he looks at Kreacher, then down at the locket in his hand. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre going to destroy that,‚Äù he points to it. ‚ÄúCan you do that for me?‚Äù

Kreacher‚Äôs bottom lip wobbles. ‚ÄúI is not leaving Master Regulus here alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt be alone,‚Äù he tries to smile, he‚Äôs not sure what it looks like. It feels broken. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt be alone. But I need you to go, and I need you to destroy that, and I need you not to tell anybody, do you understand?‚Äù because if it gets back to Voldemort, if he finds out, then all of this will have been for nothing. Then he‚Äôll just make himself another Horcrux and none of it will have mattered.

‚ÄúMaster please I‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an order,‚Äù Regulus says, hating how much he‚Äôs used that phrase today. Kreacher has started to cry again. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to go home, you‚Äôre going to tell no one about this, and you‚Äôre going to destroy that locket, okay?‚Äù

Kreacher sniffles, nodding his head. ‚ÄúI is not wanting to leave you,‚Äù he says in a small voice.

Regulus feels his heart crack, and before he knows what he‚Äôs doing he leans forward and presses a kiss to Kreacher‚Äôs forehead. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he says, struggling to control his voice, ‚Äúfor taking care of me. You were always so nice. I‚Äôm not sure I deserved it.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course you is deserving!‚Äù Kreacher says, as indignantly as he can with tears and snot running down his face. ‚ÄúMaster Regulus is being a good boy.‚Äù

And Regulus doesn‚Äôt have the heart to correct him.

Something splashes in the water behind them and Regulus winces. ‚ÄúOk,‚Äù he squeezes Kreacher‚Äôs shoulder before stepping back. ‚ÄúGo now.‚Äù

Kreacher looks as though he wants to say something else, but of course, he can‚Äôt resist a direct order.

‚ÄúMaster‚Äî‚Äú

Crack.

And he‚Äôs alone.

Regulus closes his eyes and tries to breathe, to block out the wet noises of skin slipping on stone. Tries to get a handle on himself. The numbness is good. The inability to fully accept the situation. Hopefully that lasts.

When he opens his eyes again the first thing he sees is the empty basin at the centre of the island. He walks up to it, noticing that the potion has not returned, running his fingers along the cold, slippery bottom. The empty space now feels so jarring, so obvious. He stares at it for a long time before his hand finally goes to the locket around his neck.

Spring.

Spring.

Spring.

A choked laugh leaves his mouth, Regulus cutting it off before it can turn into a sob. He‚Äôd been too rash to consider it before‚Äîthe need for a decoy. How convenient that he‚Äôs wearing one around his neck.

He slips it over his head, hands trembling as he opens it up, the night sky twinkling back at him.

Sirius.

Orion.

Regulus.

we‚Äôre all there, together, holding up the night sky,

He‚Äôd said that. Back when he‚Äôd still seen Sirius almost every day. Still talked to his father. Back before he knew how much further apart they all could be.

It makes me think that maybe in a different time, a different world, there‚Äôs an us that‚Äôs still‚Äîthere‚Äôs a place that‚Äôs not like this.

He looks at the stars now, fingers tracing over them.

‚ÄúIt got all messed up didn‚Äôt it?‚Äù he whispers, words just for them. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry about that. I know I let you both down. I know I didn‚Äôt figure it out fast enough. But maybe‚Ä¶in another life‚Ä¶‚Äù

He watches them for a second longer before pulling out his wand. It breaks his heart to undo all of James‚Äôs beautiful work. But in the end, it‚Äôs rather simple, transfiguring one locket into another.

As he holds it above the basin he can‚Äôt help but feel a little disappointed that he won‚Äôt live to see the look on Voldemort‚Äôs face, or his mother‚Äôs, or Lucius‚Äôs‚Äîwhen they realize that they lost him in the end. After all that work. The two Black heirs, both traitors. Who knew that all it would take to end a centuries long dynasty was a boy with ridiculous hair and glasses and a smile that could outshine the sun.

Suddenly it feels important.

Important that they know.

That somebody know; that after everything, Regulus Black finally made the right choice.

Before he can stop himself Regulus reaches for the Quill and parchment still stuffed in his back pocket. The letter to Cerci he never wrote. That he never will write. He tears off a piece, ink splotching the page as he starts scribbling.

¬†

To the Dark Lord,

I know I will be dead long before you read this but I want you to know that it was I who discovered your secret‚Ä¶

¬†

When he‚Äôs done he folds it up into a tiny square and fits it inside the locket, placing it at the bottom of the basin. The potion returning a second later.

There are full bodies on the rocks now. Regulus does his best not to look at their faces‚Äîsome more decomposed than others. He‚Äôs on the highest point, but his free space is quickly dwindling. His hands shaking so badly that he‚Äôs barely able to control his wand. It takes a few tries, but eventually he does manage the spell, Boo bounding into the cave.

Regulus lets out a relieved sigh at the sight of him, sinking to the ground, back pressed to the taller rocks. Boo runs laps around the island, the Inferi shrinking away from him, not very far mind you, but they‚Äôve stopped their slow crawl forward. Now simply sitting in wait. Regulus hadn‚Äôt known that would happen, though he supposes he isn‚Äôt surprised. He‚Äôd just wanted to see Boo.

He told Kreacher he wouldn‚Äôt be alone.

And he isn‚Äôt.

Regulus tilts his back, looking up at the ceiling instead of what lies in front of him.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù he says, swallowing with some difficulty. ‚ÄúI always thought I was Achilles in this story‚Äîthe over controlling mother, the famed heritage, the great expectations,‚Äù he smiles wryly. ‚ÄúBut here I am James, wearing your armour, rushing off into battles I have no business fighting. Playing the hero, and failing, like the secondary character I am,‚Äù he laughs. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú he has to clear his throat. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs where the metaphor ends okay? Fuck fate, fuck prophecies, let someone else handle it. Let someone else save the day. You just‚Ä¶go away somewhere okay? Go live your beautiful life. Fade into obscurity, leave the heroics to people who have less to offer the world. Don‚Äôt go to Troy.‚Äù

His hand reaches unconsciously for his neck but, of course, there‚Äôs nothing there anymore, so instead he ends up scrubbing at his face. He feels so fucking tired.

‚ÄúI would do it all again, you know. I would relive every miserable moment of my miserable life just for the chance to be yours,‚Äù his voice shakes, and he thinks about fighting back the tears but in the end he doesn‚Äôt bother. No one is here. No one can see him. He can cry now.

‚ÄúYou were‚Ä¶the best part for me. Of being here. Of‚Ä¶being. Just‚Äîthe best part. I never knew what it meant to be happy before I met you. Never knew what it meant to be full. And I‚Äôm so sorry that I wasn‚Äôt stronger. That I hurt you. That I‚Äîhurt,‚Äù there‚Äôs something freeing about not wiping the tears away. Not trying to hide them. ‚ÄúThank you for loving me,‚Äù a whisper. ‚ÄúI know that you probably shouldn‚Äôt have, but I don‚Äôt regret it. I can‚Äôt regret it. So just‚Äîthank you. Thank you for all of it.‚Äù

He sits up, finding Boo standing in front of him, looking right at him. And Regulus looks back. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt me giving up,‚Äù his words crack and Boo tilts his head, like he‚Äôs concerned. ‚ÄúI really thought I was going to come back to you. I really tried. I hope‚Äî‚Äú his words break off into a sob, a stuttering, choked thing. The world around him suddenly becoming very blurry.

Still, he sees the glowing white blob Boo has become getting closer, feels the lovely tickling sensation of his presence as he sits next to him, right by his side. Flooding him with warmth. With love. With giggles and playful teasing and beautiful, gentle hands. Regulus closes his eyes, pathetic little noises still squeezing out of his lungs.

He breathes in deep.

Spring.

Spring.

Spring.

Somewhere out there James Potter is alive. And safe. And happy. Somewhere out there James Potter loves him. Loves him still. After it all.

Spring.

Spring.

Spring.

Regulus opens his eyes, finally wiping away the tears, Boo shifting to set his head in his lap. Regulus laughs wetly. ‚ÄúT-thanks,‚Äù he manages, lightly passing his hand over Boo‚Äôs head, more miming petting than actually doing it.

They stay like that for a long time. Until Regulus‚Äôs breathing evens out, until his hands stop shaking. Boo settles him. Providing a comfort that Regulus has rarely felt. Like coming home.

Some of the Inferi have dragged themselves closer. Filling in the spots absent of Boo‚Äôs light. He can‚Äôt help but wonder who they used to be‚Äîif they have thoughts, if they can remember. If this is what will happen to him. It‚Äôs work to stop his breathing from getting out of control again.

He knows he could stay like this, shielded by Boo, maybe not forever, but certainly for a long time. But he isn‚Äôt sure it would be worth it. The last thing he wants is for Voldemort to find him here. For him to hand Regulus over to Bellatrix to play with before he kills him. To Lucius.

He looks down at Boo, the stag looking back. He really is such a beautiful creature. Regulus is disappointed he never got to see one in real life.

‚ÄúJe t‚Äôaime, James,‚Äù he says eventually, hand sliding down, holding the stag‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúJe t‚Äôaime,‚Äù he gives Boo a wet smile. ‚ÄúSince I was eleven.‚Äù

Boo doesn‚Äôt move. Waiting. Waiting to be told what to do. And Regulus thinks about sending him to James, he really does, but in the end he only lifts his wand; ‚ÄúGoodbye,‚Äù he whispers, the stag disappearing into a puff of white mist.

It‚Äôll be easier, if James just thinks he‚Äôs changed his mind.

If he doesn‚Äôt know.

The truth would only make him do something stupid.

The bodies have started crawling towards him again, and because Regulus would really rather not see them he points at the orb floating above his head and whispers: ‚Äúnox.‚Äù

The darkness is good, though it does nothing about the sounds of flesh and bone dragging towards him. His breaths are getting shorter again, panicked, and he drops his head between his knees doing his best not to completely lose it.

He‚Äôs holding on. To every second, every moment, greedy for every heartbeat.

Not yet,

he thinks.

not yet,

not yet,

I‚Äôm not ready to go yet.

Not until he feels the first curl of cold fingers around his ankles.

I‚Äôve been here before, he thinks nonsensically, lifting the tip of his wand to his temple, struggling to hold it there. The hands are starting to pull him towards the water. I‚Äôve dreamed of this.

‚ÄúAvada-Kedavra.‚Äù

¬†

Somewhere, in the West Country of England, James Potter can‚Äôt breathe.

Chapter 54

Chapter Summary

"My son, how long will you keep on thus grieving and making moan? You are gnawing at your own heart"

Chapter Notes

tw violence (via magic)
tw reference to sexual assault (very vague)
tw self harm

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I TOM

¬†

Little boys never do know their limits. Always pushing. Running too far. Too close to the edge. Asking too much.

Mummy please.

Please.

Please.

And she gives in doesn‚Äôt she? Makes him spoiled and weak until one day he calls and she doesn‚Äôt answer.¬†

Mummy please.

Please.

Please.

The beauty of having a mother who‚Äôs dead, is you learn early on that no one is coming. Innocent or guilty. Fair or unfair. No one is ever coming.

¬†

So you better know how to swim. ¬†¬†

¬†

Empty grey eyes stare up at him. Wide and unseeing. The body floating on top of the water, starting to bloat. Tom draws it to him with his wand, watches as it bobs against the island‚Äôs edge. He crouches down, running his knuckle along the side of its face.

Regulus Black really is a handsome boy. Even half-rotted.¬†

Clever too.

You never can trust the clever ones.

Or the pretty ones for that matter.

Tom knows that better than anyone.

Standing up he walks towards the basin at the centre of the rocks, reassuring himself, once again, that the locket is still where it should be. He lingers on it for a moment. The snake that‚Äôs carved into the front distorted by the liquid on top of it, making it look as though it‚Äôs squirming.

When he‚Äôd first learned of his connection to Salazar Slytherin as a boy he‚Äôd been rather delighted. Proud. But the more he learned of the Founder the more that feeling dulled. Salazar had no dreams of power. Merely defence. He wanted to build a wall around the magical world. But Tom, Tom wants to watch it grow.

Wizarding kind has become complacent. So many magical abilities remaining underdeveloped, so many possible avenues of study untouched‚Äîbecause they‚Äôre seen as immoral. It's provincial and small minded thinking. Tom has no patience for it. Even at school he found the idea that some magic is ‚Äúdark‚Äù tedious. That there was a ‚Äúrestricted‚Äù section of the library, laughable. These antiquated ideas have to be done away with. Especially if he is to achieve that which he wants above all else.

His eyes go back to the locket, thin fingers skimming the top of the potion before pulling away. He‚Äôs here because Regulus Black has been missing for three days. And Tom doesn‚Äôt need Lucius whispering in his ears to know that Regulus Black‚Äôs loyalty is paper thin and that he‚Äôs smart enough to do Tom‚Äôs plans serious damage. Especially not after he found that book in Regulus‚Äôs room. The one that had set Tom on this path in the first place.

So he decided it would be prudent to check on his locket. To make sure all was as it should be. And lo and behold‚Ä¶

He considers the dead boy, pressing the bottom of his boot into his cheek. He wonders if he even managed to get across the lake? Did he find the boat? Or did he try to swim? Tom supposes in the end it doesn‚Äôt matter. The cave‚Äôs defences worked.

He could bring the body back. He knows Walburga and Orion will want it. They‚Äôre very touchy about these sorts of things‚Äîthe old Wizarding families‚Äîwith their crypts and traditions. But after the stunt Dumbledore pulled with the bodies at the Ministry, Tom thinks he‚Äôd rather use Regulus to send a message.

You keep mine. I keep yours.

He‚Äôd suspected Dumbledore of having a spy for a while now, even though Pettigrew swore he didn‚Äôt. He hadn‚Äôt trusted Black, but he hadn‚Äôt quite believed that he had the courage for this type of betrayal either.

You never can trust the clever ones.

Or the pretty ones.

No, he‚Äôll be leaving Regulus Black here. Unburied.

Many believe that to be killed by the Inferi is to become one, but that is not the case. You have to be enchanted. Tom cocks his head to the side before pushing the body away from the shore with his foot. An eternity as the undead is too good for Regulus Black.

He can rot.

On the rocks outside the cave Tom pauses, closing his eyes and letting the wind blow through him. Exhaling. He‚Äôll tell everyone that Regulus was a traitor. He‚Äôll make it known that he killed him and that there‚Äôs no body left. That ought to scare anyone else thinking about doing the same. Maybe he‚Äôll throw in something about how loudly Black screamed.

Opening his eyes he looks out at the water stretching endlessly before him. It‚Äôs all coming together, he‚Äôs out maneuvering all of Dumbledore‚Äôs roadblocks, and soon it‚Äôll be over. He just has to finish his acquisition of the Ministry. Just has to deal with the contents of the prophecy. Just has to push a little harder, inch himself over the finish line. And then he‚Äôll have it all.

¬†

Little boys never do know their limits.

¬†

PART II SIRIUS

¬†

His gloves are wet, his fingers starting to go numb as he packs the snow more tightly. All in all it‚Äôs a rather impressive fort, if he does say so himself. He clearly has a future as an architect.

‚ÄúMake sure the walls are solid okay?‚Äù he calls over his shoulder. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want any holes.‚Äù

He wishes he knew a drying spell. Also wishes he had a wand. Sometimes his father lets him cast things with his wand but he isn‚Äôt allowed in the fort. No one is allowed in the fort except for Sirius and Reg. This is their home now. And they‚Äôll be safe here. Sirius‚Äôll make sure of it.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù he calls out again. ‚ÄúDid you hear me?‚Äù

There‚Äôs another pause and then;

‚ÄúSo this is where you keep us, huh?‚Äù

Sirius whips around.

Regulus is sitting behind him, leaning against one of the fort walls, knees bent. He‚Äôs big. Hair longer than Sirius has ever seen it‚Äîtheir mother never lets it get past their ears‚Äîand he isn‚Äôt wearing any of his snow stuff. No jacket. No snow pants. No gloves.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you‚Äî‚Äú his voice has dropped, and when Sirius looks down at himself he sees that he‚Äôs now in his pyjamas. Well, t-shirt and boxers, but he doesn‚Äôt feel the cold anymore. Doesn‚Äôt even feel the dampness of the snow.

‚ÄúNot real then,‚Äù he murmurs, looking back up in time to catch the dry smirk in the corner of Regulus‚Äôs mouth.

‚ÄúNot quite.‚Äù

‚ÄúDream?‚Äù

‚ÄúMmm,‚Äù Regulus hums noncommittally.¬†

He squints at Regulus, inspecting him. He‚Äôs surprisingly detailed for a dream. He looks old. And Tired. And thin.

‚ÄúYour hair is ridiculous,‚Äù Sirius says eventually.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre one to talk.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, my hair is an institution.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin, spare me.‚Äù

Sirius grins, sliding against the wall across from Regulus, their feet almost touching‚Äîit‚Äôs a snow fort after all, there isn‚Äôt much space.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Sirius sighs, ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt how this dream usually goes.‚Äù

Regulus quirks his brow. ‚ÄúYou have this dream a lot?‚Äù

Sirius shrugs. ‚ÄúUsed to have it loads. Less now though. More to think about I guess.‚Äù

Regulus is silent for a moment, the noise of the wind howling outside their fort filling the empty space between them. ‚ÄúTell me how it usually goes?‚Äù he asks eventually.

‚ÄúSurely you know. You‚Äôre there.‚Äù

There‚Äôs something a little sad in Regulus‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúTell me anyway.‚Äù

Sirius exhales, blowing the hair off his face. ‚ÄúWell, we build this magnificent fort,‚Äù he gestures to the walls around them. ‚ÄúAnd I try to convince you that we should add a swimming pool‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúTo a snow fort?‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYes, that‚Äôs exactly what you say, every time. It‚Äôs really sad you know, your lack of imagination.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd my grasp on reality.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sirius smirks. ‚ÄúThat too.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happens after I convince you that building a swimming pool in a snow fort would be a logistical nightmare?‚Äù he sounds eager, like he genuinely wants to know.

‚ÄúWell, usually we play Exploding Snap, because, of course, being the genius I am, I had the foresight to bring a pack with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis dream sounds thrilling.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Sirius kicks his foot. ‚ÄúI like it.‚Äù

There‚Äôs the glimmer of surprise in Regulus‚Äôs eyes before he quickly shuts it down. ‚ÄúWhy would you like this?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause snow forts are awesome.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYeah but‚Ä¶why not dream about building one with Lupin or‚Äî‚Äú his voice cuts out, James‚Äôs name sitting awkwardly between them. Sirius just stares at his brother for a minute.

‚ÄúI never built a snow fort with them. Bloody shame actually, now that I think about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally? That‚Äôs it? That‚Äôs the reason? Now who has no imagination?‚Äù

Sirius sighs, though he feels something uncomfortably like emotion growing in his belly. ‚ÄúAfter Exploding Snap,‚Äù he goes on instead of answering. ‚ÄúIt starts to get dark, and we don‚Äôt have any lights out here, so I ask you if you want to go inside because I know how you feel about the dark,‚Äù Sirius has to clear his throat, has to look away from his brother‚Äôs face and stare at the blank wall across from him.

‚ÄúAnd you say‚Äîyou say you‚Äôre not afraid of anything when you‚Äôre with me.‚Äù

He lets that sentence drift for a minute, unanchored, just floating in the air. It‚Äôs a while before he feels confident enough to speak again. He‚Äôs surprised Regulus hasn‚Äôt said anything but when he turns to him he finds his brother‚Äôs eyes blown wide. Innocent and vulnerable. Regulus on full display‚Äîa rare sight.

‚ÄúThis is one of the last times I remember,‚Äù Sirius says finally, waving his hand vaguely around, ‚Äúthat you really felt like mine.‚Äù

Sirius can see Regulus swallow. ‚ÄúYours,‚Äù his voice strained.

He shrugs. ‚ÄúI asked you to run away with me and you said yes. Just to the back garden mind you, but still, that felt far back then.‚Äù

Regulus is staring at him with an oddly vulnerable expression. He used to look like this a lot, when they were kids, his face wide open, his feelings spilling out. Sirius helped him fix that. It made him an easy target for people like Bellatrix and Lucius, who like to watch their victims squirm. Or their mother, who hates weakness. Still, Regulus has never been very good at doing things half-way. Once he shut himself up he never let himself out again.

Well. Except with James. Apparently.

‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù

Sirius blinks, coming back to the present. Whatever had been on Regulus‚Äôs face is gone now. Molded into something more passive. Less revealing.

‚ÄúWhat is what?‚Äù Sirius asks testily.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre scowling.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm not.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre too.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm not times a thousand.‚Äù

Regulus rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt even see your face.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can feel my face.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat were you thinking about,‚Äù Regulus presses on, ignoring him. ‚ÄúThat made you angry?‚Äù

Sirius glares at him, he doesn‚Äôt like being so easy to read. ‚ÄúNone of your business.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ Sirius you‚Äôre such a child.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm not.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre too.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm n‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not doing this again.‚Äù

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù Sirius crosses his arms over his chest, leaning his head back against the snow wall behind him and closing his eyes. ‚ÄúWe can just sit in silence until I wake up then.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

‚ÄúReally.‚Äù

There‚Äôs some mumbled complaining that Sirius can‚Äôt quite make out but he pretends he doesn‚Äôt hear.

They do sit in silence, for an impressively long time all things considered. And by ‚Äúthings‚Äù Sirius means himself and his almost pathological hatred of sitting still. It‚Äôs honestly a relief when Regulus speaks even if he pretends to be annoyed.

‚ÄúWhat were you thinking about Sirius?‚Äù he sounds tired‚Äîtired enough that Sirius opens his eyes, his brother‚Äôs grey meeting his. He really isn‚Äôt planning to say it, he doesn‚Äôt fancy sharing things with Regulus. It‚Äôs not a particularly smart move.

But.

Well.

It‚Äôs only a dream after all.

It‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs really him.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Sirius says finally.

Regulus looks confused. ‚ÄúYou were thinking about James?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou and‚Äî‚Äù Sirius grimaces. ‚ÄúJames.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah oh.‚Äù

Regulus looks down at his knees, fingers fidgeting with a piece of loose thread. It‚Äôs the first time Sirius notices that his brother isn‚Äôt wearing shoes‚Äîhis socks wet.¬†

‚ÄúHe wanted to tell you you know,‚Äù Regulus says finally.

Sirius blinks, tearing his eyes away from his brother‚Äôs feet. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù he clarifies, ‚Äúhe wanted to tell you about us. I wouldn‚Äôt let him. In case you thought‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThought what?‚Äù Sirius snaps. God he fucking hates talking about this. Thinking about this. ‚ÄúThat he happily lied to me for a year? If James had wanted to tell me he bloody well should have.‚Äù

‚ÄúI made him promise.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat, did he make you an unbreakable vow Regulus? Because otherwise that‚Äôs not good enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúSame thing to him isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

‚ÄúClearly not. Because he had no problem breaking the promises he fucking made to me!‚Äù

His hands have curled into fists, his voice overly loud in the small space. This is why he doesn‚Äôt talk about this. It picks at some sore part of him. Some unhealed wound. James knew, more than anyone, James knew what Regulus had done. He‚Äôd been there the night they broke Sirius down into little pieces, until he could barely remember how to talk. Until he could barely remember where he was or what was happening. James knew how much Regulus had let Sirius hurt. Had hurt him himself. So how could he. How could he‚Äî

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGo away!‚Äù he snaps, dropping his forehead onto his knees so he doesn‚Äôt have to look at Regulus anymore. ‚ÄúGet the fuck out of my head. I don‚Äôt want to talk about this.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment of silence before he hears Regulus sigh.

The next thing Sirius knows his alarm is going off.

¬†

¬†

He‚Äôs tired and grumpy when he drags himself to the Ministry. He‚Äôs wearing one of Remus‚Äôs jumpers which, yes, is pathetic, but he doubts anyone will notice. The sleeves are the biggest giveaway‚Äîtoo long, almost completely hiding his hands. He put it on by accident, stumbling around in the dark. And then he just‚Ä¶couldn‚Äôt quite bring himself to take it off.

Whatever. He‚Äôs pathetic. He doesn‚Äôt care. It‚Äôs not exactly new information.

He cuts across the Atrium without any real purpose. Laces slapping against the stone floor. The fountain has been decorated for Christmas‚Äîthe statues dressed in Santa hats and elf ears. Hung up around the walls tinsel sparkles, fake snow falling from the ceiling and then disappearing the minute it hits the floor.

Leaning against the wall by the lifts he spots Dorcas. She‚Äôs also wearing an oversized jumper‚Äîthough Sirius doubts it‚Äôs Marlene‚Äôs therefore making her less pathetic than him. She‚Äôs also holding a small paper cone in her hands.

‚ÄúAre you eating chips?‚Äù he asks when he gets close enough.

‚ÄúYup,‚Äù she pops her ‚ÄòP‚Äô before lathering an insane amount of ketchup on her next bite.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like eight in the morning.‚Äù

‚ÄúEight-twenty,‚Äù she looks up at him. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre late.‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes before reaching for a chip. Dorcas swiftly kicks him in the shins.

‚ÄúOw‚Äîfuck,‚Äù he hops around, grabbing at his leg and glaring.

‚ÄúGet your own chips,‚Äù Dorcas says flatly, before turning towards the lift doors and pressing the down button.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt have time,‚Äù Sirius mutters, reluctantly standing next to her, though not within kicking distance.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre twenty minutes late and you didn‚Äôt have time?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúInteresting.‚Äù

The doors open and a small witch in magenta robes pushes passed them, followed by a very harried looking owl. They step into the lift after her, avoiding the bird droppings as they do, Dorcas pressing the button for the basement.

‚ÄúYou know what room we‚Äôre in today?‚Äù Sirius asks, staring longingly at her chips. Dorcas does not seem to notice. Or if she does, she doesn‚Äôt care.

‚ÄúLove.‚Äù

Sirius pulls a face that makes her snort.

‚ÄúNot a fan of love?‚Äù

He crosses his arms over his chest, chewing on the inside of his cheek. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs eight in the morning,‚Äù he mutters finally, staring down the lift doors like they‚Äôve personally offended him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a fan of anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúEight-twenty.‚Äù

Sirius shoots her a flat stare but Dorcas has gone back to picking at her chips, expression blank, though Sirius swears he can see the smirk in the corner of her eyes.

¬†

¬†

The Love room is kept under especially tight watch. Besides the regular security checks that they have to go through when they get down to the Department of Mysteries‚Äîmaking sure they aren‚Äôt Imperiused, aren‚Äôt taking Polyjuice, don‚Äôt have tracking spells placed on them or any recording devices‚Äîthey also have the pleasure of having their minds probed by a skilled Unspeakable. A skilled Unspeakable using a charm to blur their face and disguise their voice, keeping their identity a complete mystery.

Not exactly confidence inspiring.

‚ÄúMister Black,‚Äù the Unspeakable‚Äôs patience is clearly being tested. ‚ÄúIf you will not allow me to enter your mind we will have to consider you hostile and you will be asked to leave.‚Äù

Sirius grits his teeth. This was a fairly easy process for Dorcas, took barely two minutes. But Sirius‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI am letting you enter,‚Äù and he is. Sort of. Well he‚Äôs trying to anyway. It‚Äôs not like he‚Äôs running away or punching the bloke. But he just‚Ä¶he‚Äôs had people in his mind before. It‚Äôs not a pleasant experience. Whenever his mum would do it Sirius would feel bruised for hours afterwards. The memories she had invaded sore, making him wince every time he thought of them. Like they didn‚Äôt belong to him anymore.

‚ÄúYour Occlumency skills are truly inspiring. However, not useful in the current situation. Shall we try again?‚Äù

Sirius glares at the blurry face in front of him. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

The Unspeakable doesn‚Äôt have to say the spell out loud, Walburga never did either. But Sirius feels it, feels it the minute he pours himself into his head, like poison in his ear. He winces.

Your defences Mr. Black.

The foreign voice echoes in his thoughts.

Lower them please.

He breathes out slowly, heart still catching, fear squirming in the pit of his stomach. But this isn‚Äôt his mother and he isn‚Äôt a child and goddamnit he just needs to get through this. Forcing himself to breathe, he lets a door appear in his mind.

That‚Äôs more like it.

The Unspeakable throws it open. Like it‚Äôs nothing. The sensation of having his thoughts revealed like nails scraping down Sirius‚Äôs spine.

Images start fluttering through his head, the Unspeakable flipping through his memories and thoughts like they‚Äôre the pages of a scrapbook. He‚Äôs meticulous. Professional. But every moment that passes makes Sirius‚Äôs stomach churn.

He sees Remus, asleep in their bed.

He sees James, smiling shyly as he tells them Lily is pregnant.

He sees Reg.

Reg in their snow fort.

Sees his socked feet.

Sirius gasps as his knees hit the hard stone floor. He‚Äôs covered in sweat, shaking all over, eyes out of focus.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he sees Dorcas‚Äôs shoes as she steps forward. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it. We‚Äôre done here.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe kicked me out before I was able to finish my examination!‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you find anything incriminating before that?‚Äù

There‚Äôs an unhappy silence.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not the point,‚Äù the Unspeakable say finally, Sirius still trying to catch his breath on the floor.

‚ÄúActually, that‚Äôs literally the whole point. He‚Äôs clear. I‚Äôm clear. Now let us do our jobs.‚Äù

Dorcas doesn‚Äôt shout. Everything she says is very matter of fact. Delivered with calm confidence. It reminds Sirius of Remus.

‚ÄúVery well,‚Äù the Unspeakable mutters. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôll be writing about this to the Head Auror.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, you do that.‚Äù

A second later Dorcas is crouching down beside him, Sirius can‚Äôt bring himself to look at her. Fucking embarrassing this is. Can‚Äôt even get through a routine security check without having a mental bloody breakdown.

‚ÄúYou good?‚Äù she asks softly.

Sirius swallows. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood.‚Äù

A second later she has her arm wrapped firmly around him, hauling him to his feet. His legs buckle for a moment but eventually he gets himself together, turning his head into his shoulder, breathing in the smell of Moony.

Pathetic.

Still. It works. Sort of. Settles the parts of his brain going haywire. Sparking and twitching and crossing.

Dorcas lets go of him but still eyes him with concern. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure you‚Äôre good?‚Äù

Sirius nods stiffly. ‚ÄúLets just go, yeah?‚Äù

He starts walking, shoving his hands into the pockets of his jeans and trying to pretend like he doesn‚Äôt want to go home. Crawl back into bed. And hide under the covers like a little kid.

After a few seconds of tense silence, their footsteps echoing around them, Dorcas clears her throat: ‚ÄúWant some of my chips?‚Äù she holds the nearly empty container into the space between them. Sirius looks at them and then at her face.

‚ÄúAre those pity chips?‚Äù

She shrugs. ‚ÄúMight be.‚Äù

He considers refusing them on principle, but then, that would contradict his other principle, which is to never turn down free food.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù he says eventually. The chips are cold at this point, and greasy, and covered in too much vinegar. But somehow, they still make him feel better.

¬†

¬†

He was six, he thinks, the first time his mother used Legilimency on him. They‚Äôd been playing a game‚Äîhim and Reg‚Äîhe can‚Äôt even remember what now, but something with a ball. In any case, Reg was only five, he threw it too hard and too far, cracked a window. An easy fix with a wand. But even at that age they‚Äôd known that wouldn‚Äôt matter to their mother.

So Sirius had lied. He told her he‚Äôd done it. To this day he doesn‚Äôt know why she didn‚Äôt believe him. It was just as probable as it being Reg‚Äîmore really. But she had whipped out her wand and torn his mind apart. Found the memory. She‚Äôd found other things too. Thoughts. He was already hiding things back then. Things he knew would anger her.

He‚Äôs been told, many times, by many smart people, that Legilimency does not have to hurt. That it shouldn‚Äôt hurt. It isn‚Äôt that Sirius thinks they‚Äôre lying to him. It‚Äôs just that he‚Äôs never had someone invade his mind who wasn‚Äôt trying to take something from him.

¬†

¬†

When they get to the door of the Love room‚Äîan unassuming, boring, black door‚ÄîDorcas knocks. There are a few awkward seconds of just standing there, blurry faced Unspeakables rushing down the large dark corridor behind them, before the door is swung open by a man whose head barely reaches Sirius‚Äôs shoulders.

‚ÄúWho in Bezoar‚Äôs name are you?‚Äù he has thinning hair, ginger, sticking out of his head in little tuffs. And small, round, wire glasses resting on the tip of his nose that Sirius does not believe are helping him see anything. He doesn‚Äôt know why his face isn‚Äôt blurred‚Äîbut then, he seems like the type of person who might forget about that kind of thing.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîthe Auror Department sent us sir,‚Äù Dorcas says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre providing security for this room today?‚Äù

The man rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúVery well, come in, come in,‚Äù he turns away, letting go of the door and nearly slamming it in Dorcas‚Äôs face. Sirius stops it with his boot, the pair of them exchanging equally startled looks.

‚ÄúStay by the front, don‚Äôt come any further than the fountain, and don‚Äôt disturb me. Do you understand?‚Äù the Unspeakable says while walking away from them, hurried little steps slapping against the stone floor.

The ceiling of this room is significantly lower than the corridor, automatically making it feel more intimate. The walls covered in red velvet, not that you can see much of it what with the hundreds of paintings hung up around them. Some move. Others stand still. The lights are low, there‚Äôs a fireplace, and floating candles near the ceiling, making everything warm and soft. Somewhere, Sirius is almost certain a piano is being played. And there, in the centre of the room, is a giant fountain.

‚ÄúWhat is this? Fucking Versailles?‚Äù he mutters as he turns around himself, trying to take it all in. The air here is thick‚Äîit smells like cinnamon, vanilla, chocolate‚Äîbreathing feels decadent.

‚ÄúExcuse me?‚Äù

Both Dorcas and Sirius turn towards the small wizard waiting impatiently in the archway behind the fountain.

‚ÄúDid you hear anything I said?‚Äù he demands irritably.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîyeah,‚Äù Sirius rubs at the back of his neck. ‚ÄúYou want us stay here?‚Äù

‚ÄúSir,‚Äù Dorcas interrupts, causing the Unspeakable to let out an impatient sigh. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre supposed to do rounds of the whole area. It allows us to provide more thorough security.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot here you‚Äôre not,‚Äù he says dismissively. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre lucky they‚Äôre even letting you in.‚Äù

Sirius struggles not to point out that this is, in fact, their jobs, and not something either of them is simply doing for fun. ‚ÄúLucky‚Äù is not the word he would use.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre sure‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure. Any other questions?‚Äù neither Dorcas nor Sirius speak. ‚ÄúExcellent,‚Äù he turns around, practically sprinting from the room. ‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt touch anything!‚Äù he shouts over his shoulder.

For a moment the pair of them just stand there, the noise of the running fountain and distant classical music filling the silence. Eventually Sirius can‚Äôt hold it in, he laughs, causing Dorcas to arch her brow.

‚ÄúOh come on, this place is fucking mental.‚Äù

Their shift is ten hours long. How the hell is Sirius going to survive ten hours in a room that looks like Valentines day just threw up all over it?

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs kinda cool,‚Äù Dorcas says mildly, looking around.

Sirius gives her an incredulous look. ‚ÄúAre you not hearing the bloody piano serenading us right now?‚Äù he gestures indignantly at the air.

Dorcas bites her lower lip, clearly trying to hold back a smile. ‚ÄúBit much that, fair point.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis place is disgusting.‚Äù

Dorcas laughs. ‚ÄúMerlin, Sirius Black, I had no idea you were such a curmudgeon when it came to love.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a curmudgeon. I just have taste.‚Äù

Dorcas arches her brow, leaning back against the wall behind her. ‚ÄúOh really? Do you? Because I distinctly remember you and James walking around for a week in third year wearing nothing but yellow robes with red polka dots.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh that. Well that was funny.‚Äù

‚ÄúMm, also there was that time you burnt part of your hair in potions class and instead of taking a hair growth potion you decided to cut it into a mullet.‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúThese are isolated incidents, you‚Äôre being a little unfair here I‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you show up to the Auror meeting a few weeks ago in leopard print trousers?‚Äù

‚ÄúOi! Those look good on me!‚Äù

Dorcas gives him a flat look that suggests she does not agree.

‚ÄúFine!‚Äù he throws his arms up in the air. ‚ÄúMaybe I have made some questionable style choices but this,‚Äù he gestures at the space around them. ‚ÄúThis is another level of awful, you‚Äôve gotta admit that?‚Äù

Dorcas shrugs, eyes trailing slowly around the crowded room before coming back to Sirius. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of stuff in here.‚Äù

Sirius looks at her suspiciously. ‚ÄúYes. I‚Äôve noticed.‚Äù

‚ÄúNone of it appeals to you? Not one thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis stuff is all bullshit!‚Äù he really means that, he realizes, suddenly growing much more sincere. ‚ÄúNone of this is‚Ä¶love.‚Äù

He glares at a particularly gooey painting of two figures snogging. They‚Äôre dressed in medieval looking clothes‚Äîthe girl in a blue dress, the man all dashing in his dumb giant hat and jacket, bending her over in the most aggressive display of PDA Sirius has ever seen.¬†

‚ÄúI mean, it‚Äôs part of it, don‚Äôt you think?‚Äù Dorcas asks, bringing Sirius‚Äôs attention back to her.

Something in him twinges, like stepping on a twisted ankle or pressing on a bruise. He runs a hand over his face and turns away, staring at the ridiculous fountain. ‚ÄúFuck, I don‚Äôt know. Maybe. It‚Äôs not like I know shit about love.‚Äù

He starts pulling at his jumper‚ÄîRemus‚Äôs jumper‚Äîwhich suddenly feels scratchy and heavy and all wrong. And he wants to take it off, but of course, he can‚Äôt just start stripping, and he‚Äôs already had his one allotted public meltdown for the day so he tries to get his fucking brain to shut up.

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs the first person you remember loving?‚Äù Dorcas asks after what feels like years of silence.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù Sirius says without thinking. Because he doesn‚Äôt have to think. It‚Äôs an easy answer.

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù that noise makes him turn around, finding Dorcas with a contemplative expression on her face.

‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù he asks.

But she only shrugs. ‚ÄúThat was just a very honest answer.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre you expecting me to lie?‚Äù Sirius fidgets, suddenly worried he‚Äôs given too much away.

Dorcas takes her time answering, eventually doing so with a wry smile on her lips. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt strike me as someone who‚Äôs quite that self-aware, that‚Äôs all.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh fuck off.‚Äù

Dorcas laughs and Sirius turns away again and starts pacing, unable to stay still. He trails his fingers along the paintings he passes, over the gilded frames, like they‚Äôre braille. Like seeing them isn‚Äôt enough. He needs to touch them to understand.¬† ¬†

‚ÄúHow did you know?‚Äù Dorcas asks eventually.

Sirius doesn‚Äôt look back, still making his slow progression around the room. ‚ÄúHow did I know, what?‚Äù He side-steps a Grecian looking statute of two figures wrapped around one another.

‚ÄúThat you loved your brother?‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúNow you‚Äôre just taking the piss.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not, I genuinely want to know.‚Äù

Sirius comes to an abrupt stop. In front of him the floor has split open to allow for a tree‚Äîa whole fucking tree‚Äîto sprout from the ground. Admittedly it‚Äôs a bit stumpy, not much taller than Sirius, with thick branches making a V shape. The leaves are green and big and nestled in the centre of them are small, round, fruits. Plums maybe? He thinks as he reaches out. Or‚Äî

‚ÄúFigs,‚Äù he says as he gets one in his hand.

‚ÄúSirius!‚Äù Dorcas is on the other side of the fountain, not quite visible. ‚ÄúTell me about Regulus!‚Äù

He rolls his eyes again, turning the fruit over in his hands. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a prat. What else is there to know?‚Äù

He hears her snort and he thinks she‚Äôs going to let it drop but then; ‚ÄúHow did you know you loved him? If he was the first person, how did you know?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs my brother.‚Äù

The fig rolls between Sirius‚Äôs palms, squat and purple. He‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôs ever seen a fresh one before. At his parents‚Äô fancy dinner parties sometimes Kreacher would cook them. Candied and caramelized and baked. He can‚Äôt for the life of him figure out what they‚Äôre doing here?

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not obligated to love your family,‚Äù Dorcas says eventually.

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúInstinct though, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù his nails puncture the skin of the fruit.

‚ÄúIs it?‚Äù Sirius doesn‚Äôt answer that one. Doesn‚Äôt even try. ‚ÄúBesides, you didn‚Äôt say your family‚Äîdidn‚Äôt say your mum or dad‚Äîyou said Regulus.‚Äù

The juices from the fruit begin to snake down his wrist as his grip gets tighter. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he clears his throat. ‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶he was the only other human being in that house so.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs why you loved him?‚Äù

Sirius sighs, dropping the mangled fruit from his hand and vanishing the mess. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, I‚Äî‚Äú

There‚Äôs only a little more than a year separating Sirius and Regulus. So he can‚Äôt remember life without him. You‚Äôd think that would make them more like twins than big brother and little brother but it didn‚Äôt. The first memories Sirius has of Regulus he‚Äôs taking care of him. He was good at it, he thinks. He could always make Reg smile. Make him laugh. Scare his monsters away.

Sirius never much liked being himself, but he‚Äôd loved being Regulus‚Äôs big brother. At least for a little while. Before things got bad.

‚ÄúHe was kind of my whole world when we were little,‚Äù it‚Äôs easier with the room of stuff separating them. Easier when he can‚Äôt see Dorcas‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúI wanted to look after him, to keep him safe, to make him happy. He felt like‚Ä¶mine, you know? That house was so fucking miserable and cold and Reg‚Ä¶Merlin you should have seen him, when he was small, he just‚Ä¶he used to light up. He had these huge fucking eyes and just‚Ä¶he noticed everything. Wanted to know everything. Never stopped asking questions.‚Äù

Sirius lets out a heavy breath, hand running through his hair. ‚ÄúI felt like I had a purpose, being his brother, it gave me a reason to‚Ä¶be.‚Äù He could stop there probably, but instead he pushes forward, ‚ÄúMy mum, she has this‚Ä¶talent,‚Äù he laughs humourlessly. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs real good at making you feel like you shouldn‚Äôt exist. Before Hogwarts. Before James. Regulus was the only thing that made me certain that I should.‚Äù

He regrets dropping the fruit now. He needs something to do with his hands. Something to distract him from that truth.¬† ¬†

‚ÄúHe really broke your heart huh?‚Äù Dorcas asks softly, sounding close, and when Sirius looks up he realizes he‚Äôs done a whole lap. Found himself back where he started, Dorcas leaning against the wall a few feet away.

It‚Äôs a second before he can speak. ‚ÄúYeah, ‚Äòcourse he did.‚Äù Because Sirius had thought that was obvious. Had thought everyone knew that. Thought James knew.

After a moment she smiles. It‚Äôs kind. Maybe a little sad. ‚ÄúSee? And you said you didn‚Äôt know anything about love.‚Äù

Something in him twists. A wave of nausea washing over him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried I‚Äôm doing it again,‚Äù he says, jaw clenching tightly immediately after, embarrassed.

Dorcas‚Äôs eyes widen just a fraction. ‚ÄúDoing what?‚Äù

He shakes his head, boot scuffing against the ground. ‚ÄúWhatever I did to push Regulus away, to make him be‚Ä¶the way that he is. I‚Äôm worried I‚Äôm doing it to Remus. I‚Äôm worried he‚Äôs making a mistake and that it‚Äôs my fault. Because he‚Äôs a good person, better than me, and so if‚Äîif he‚Äôs doing something wrong‚Äî‚Äú but he doesn‚Äôt even know what he‚Äôs trying to say, hands balling into fists. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm very good for people.‚Äù¬†

¬†He can‚Äôt meet Dorcas‚Äôs eyes, doesn‚Äôt know why he‚Äôs telling her this. It must be the perfumed air and the thousands of painted eyes staring down at him. Oh and the fucking piano. He pulls at his jumper again. He needs it off. He needs out. He needs to fight. Or fuck. Or both. He just‚Ä¶needs.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs true,‚Äù Dorcas says finally, causing Sirius to laugh coldly.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know‚Äî‚Äú don‚Äôt know that I told Snape how to get past the tree. That I get mean when I‚Äôm angry. That I kissed Mary because I was lonely. ‚ÄúThe first person I ever loved is a Death Eater,‚Äù he looks up at her and then away again. ‚ÄúThat should tell you something.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus‚Äôs choices aren‚Äôt your fault.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think?‚Äù he asks bitterly. ‚ÄúI raised him. I taught him how to shut his fucking emotions off. How to not think and feel. I taught him that he needed to be harder. And I wasn‚Äôt always nice about it either,‚Äù he shakes his head, nails biting so viciously into his palms that they‚Äôve started to draw blood.¬†

‚ÄúI thought I was protecting him,‚Äù he goes on, because apparently he can‚Äôt stop himself today. ‚ÄúI thought I was keeping him safe but‚Äîbut look who I fucking created? I raised him. Not my mum. Not my dad. I was with him every day until I was eleven years old. Telling him how to act and what to do. So whose fucking fault is it? Whose fucking fault?‚Äù

Silence.

The problem is, Sirius has been on his own too much. If Remus wasn‚Äôt gone this wouldn‚Äôt be happening‚Äîhe wouldn‚Äôt be spilling over like this. Usually he goes to James and Lily‚Äôs for dinner when Remus isn‚Äôt home but recently James has been away on assignments and the silence of the flat is getting to him. Everything Alice told him sitting on his chest. Crushing his ribs. Making everything feel wrong, taste wrong. Nothing soothes him. Nothing is comfortable.

‚ÄúAnd then,‚Äù he goes on, because it‚Äôs not as though he has any self-respect. ‚ÄúAnd then I left him.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù Dorcas says kindly, ducking her head, trying to catch his eye. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know you that well, and even I know that you couldn‚Äôt stay in that house.‚Äù

He tells himself the same thing‚Äîthat he couldn‚Äôt have stayed. That it would have killed him. But it feels a little weaker every time.

‚ÄúIt was bearable when I had Regulus,‚Äù he says instead. ‚ÄúIt was only once I was alone that‚Äî‚Äú he clears his throat. ‚ÄúIt feels a bit like that. With Remus. Like he‚Äôs slowly drifting away. And one day I‚Äôm going to wake up and he‚Äôll be standing right there but it won‚Äôt be him anymore. Won‚Äôt be someone I know.‚Äù

Finally, he forces himself to meet Dorcas‚Äôs eye. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs terrifying that. Looking at the person you love and not being able to recognize them.‚Äù Seeing Regulus at Hogwarts sometimes used to make Sirius‚Äôs skin crawl. Like looking at a corpse.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù she says calmly. ‚ÄúRemus isn‚Äôt Regulus.‚Äù

And he knows that of course.

He knows everything about them, everything about this, is different.

But for some reason it still feels so fucking similar.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he offers her a shaky smile. ‚ÄúTherapy session over, consider me officially emotionally tapped out.‚Äù

She offers him a smile back but he can see the hesitancy in her eyes. ‚ÄúAre you sure? Because I really don‚Äôt mind talking you know?‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks but‚Äîyeah I just‚Äî‚Äú there‚Äôs really no smooth way for him to exit this conversation. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd um, if you wouldn‚Äôt mind,‚Äù he rubs awkwardly at the back of his neck, messing up his hair, ‚ÄúMaybe don‚Äôt tell Marlene about‚Ä¶this.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù there‚Äôs a beat of awkward silence that Sirius absolutely can‚Äôt allow at this moment so his mouth fills it with the first thing he can think of; ‚ÄúSpeaking of Marlene, how‚Äôre, y‚Äôknow, things with you two?‚Äù

Dorcas gives him a look like "really?"¬†but Sirius doesn‚Äôt back down. More than happy to shift the focus of the conversation away from him. A first really. Usually he loves being the centre of attention.

‚ÄúWell, I mean, we‚Äôre perfect, obviously.‚Äù

Sirius sticks up his middle finger and Dorcas laughs.

‚ÄúOh you know,‚Äù she waves her hand in the air. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard. She‚Äôs gone. I‚Äôm gone. Neither of us know where or for how long. We‚Äôre scared all the time. We snap at each other more than we probably should because of it. It‚Äôs hard.‚Äù

Sirius nods. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he wishes his chest would loosen up.

‚ÄúBut then, that‚Äôs probably a good thing you know?‚Äù she goes on, drawing Sirius‚Äôs questioning eyes back to her. ‚ÄúMeans it matters. Means we have something to lose.‚Äù

Yeah, Sirius thinks before he can stop himself. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm afraid of.

¬†

¬†

His gloves are wet, his fingers starting to go numb as he packs the snow more tightly. All in all it‚Äôs a rather impressive fort, if he does say so himself. He clearly has a future as an architect.

‚ÄúMake sure it‚Äôs solid okay?‚Äù he calls over his shoulder. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want any holes.‚Äù

There‚Äôs no response.

‚ÄúReg?‚Äù

If he‚Äôs gone and wandered off again Sirius swears he‚Äôll‚Äî

‚ÄúYou can probably stop that now.‚Äù

Sirius blinks. And just like the night before, his gloves disappear, replaced by the clothes he went to sleep in, his adult body now crouching in his childhood snow fort. And behind him, sitting against the wall, is Regulus. Older too. And in his socks again.

‚ÄúOh motherfucker,‚Äù Sirius collapses down across from him. ‚ÄúI just want to sleep, is that too much to ask?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù Though he doesn‚Äôt sound remotely sorry, the little prick.

‚ÄúWhat the hell is going on with me? Why the fuck am I dreaming about you?‚Äù Sirius pinches the bridge of his nose. No doubt his conversation with Dorcas didn‚Äôt help.

‚ÄúMaybe you miss me,‚Äù Regulus says teasingly.

Sirius scoffs, dropping his hand. ‚ÄúI got over missing you a long time ago Reg.‚Äù

The younger boy flinches before he‚Äôs able to get himself under control. ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù he clears his throat, ‚Äúright.‚Äù

Sirius hates that he feels guilty. But he also hates that he said it. Which is always how it is with Regulus. No matter what Sirius does it always feels like the wrong thing.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he says eventually, hating that word and the way it reminds him of being a scared little boy, standing in front of his mother. ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt have said that.‚Äù

Regulus shrugs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù and then, a bit stiffly; ‚Äúnot like I‚Äôm real right?‚Äù

Sirius watches him for a moment before slowly nodding his head. ‚ÄúRight.‚Äù He leans back against the snow behind him, looking up at the very questionably constructed ceiling that seven year old him was so proud of it.

‚ÄúIs it true?‚Äù Regulus asks eventually.

‚ÄúIs what true?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat you don‚Äôt miss me anymore?‚Äù

Yes, the spiteful part of Sirius‚Äôs brain wants to say.

The part that‚Äôs always a little too close to the surface when his brother‚Äôs around.

That wants to make Regulus hurt the way Sirius hurt.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù is what eventually comes out of his mouth. The truth might not be that simple, but this is as close to it as he‚Äôs willing to get right now. He thinks he sees Regulus smile a little.¬†

Sirius points a finger at him. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let it go to your head.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus says wryly. ‚ÄúOf course not.‚Äù

Sirius remembers building this fort. Remembers him and Regulus stomping through the snow all the way to the very back of the garden where they could barely be seen from the house. He‚Äôd really thought they were doing something. Proving something. He‚Äôd really thought he could build them a new home. A proper one. The type he read about in books.

‚ÄúDo you remember the first time I tried to teach you how to fly?‚Äù Sirius asks suddenly, arms resting on his knees.

‚ÄúYeah, I fell off and you laughed.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh yeah,‚Äù Sirius grins. ‚ÄúTo be fair, you were only three feet off the ground, and the squeal you made!‚Äù

‚ÄúOh don‚Äôt start with the squeal again.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike a little pig.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, you called me piglet for weeks.‚Äù

Sirius laughs. ‚ÄúOne of my better nicknames. I don‚Äôt know why it didn‚Äôt stick.‚Äù He looks at Regulus then, tilting his head to the side. ‚ÄúYou do kind of look like a pig.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck off!‚Äù Regulus kicks him and Sirius kicks him back, still laughing.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your little nose,‚Äù he reaches over and flicks Regulus‚Äôs nose, causing Regulus to make an indignant squawking noise that does not help his case at all.¬†

‚ÄúYou picked it up fast though,‚Äù Sirius goes on, Regulus still glaring at him. ‚ÄúMerlin, watching you fly‚Ä¶‚Äù he trails off.

Later on, when they were at Hogwarts, when things got bad between them, it would make¬† Sirius jealous. The way Regulus handled himself in the air. The skill. The technique. But before then, when it was just the two of them at the country house in Scotland, he always felt so fucking proud.

‚ÄúYou should have been a bird,‚Äù Sirius finishes finally, snapping himself back to the present. ‚ÄúYou were always happiest in the sky.‚Äù

Something aching passes over Regulus‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt flown in years, you know?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat, no Death Eater Quidditch team?‚Äù it might have been funny, if it weren‚Äôt for the bitterness in his voice.

The words sit between them for a moment before Regulus eventually clears his throat.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúNo not quite.‚Äù

Sirius shakes his head, looking away. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt just sit here and pretend that I don‚Äôt know what you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt who I am Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúStill can‚Äôt take fucking responsibility can you Reg? Death Eater isn‚Äôt something you get to be part-time. You chose to get that Mark‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt choose anything!‚Äù

‚ÄúFine!‚Äù Sirius snaps back, eyes jumping to his little brother, meeting his defiant stare. ‚ÄúYou accepted it then. Can we at least agree on that? You accepted this. You accepted what they wanted, what they were asking of you. Maybe you didn‚Äôt choose this life but you didn‚Äôt fight it.‚Äù

Regulus looks as though he‚Äôs grinding his teeth.

In real life, this would be the moment that one, or both of them, would draw their wands. Reg would say something awful and Sirius would say something equally awful back, and it would all fall apart. Nothing but curses and punches. He‚Äôs never sure if they actually mean it‚Äîany of what they do to one another. Because sometimes he thinks he really does. Sometimes he really thinks he could kill Regulus, given the chance. And other times he wishes he could go back in time. That he could stop himself from leaving that house without his little brother in his arms.

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

Sirius blinks, not understanding. ‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù his brow knits together.

Regulus sighs, defeated, running a hand over his face, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right. I accepted it. I didn‚Äôt fight it. I couldn‚Äôt see the point.‚Äù

That last sentence causes Sirius to pause, words tripping on his tongue. ‚ÄúCouldn‚Äôt?‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúAs in past tense?‚Äù Regulus‚Äôs eyes widen a fraction at being called out but he doesn‚Äôt say anything. ‚ÄúCan you see the point now?‚Äù

Regulus swallows. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù his brother whispers, like it‚Äôs some big secret. ‚ÄúYes I see the point. Sirius I‚Äî‚Äú

And his alarm goes off.

¬†

¬†

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre late again,‚Äù Dorcas is exactly where she was yesterday, leaning against the wall, white high-tops crossed at the ankles.

‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre eating chips again,‚Äù he reaches forward but she slaps his hand away.

‚ÄúGet your own bloody breakfast Black, Jesus,‚Äù she presses the button for the lift, an army of paper planes zooming out when the doors open.

‚ÄúYou let me have some yesterday,‚Äù Sirius says petulantly as they step inside.

Dorcas rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs cause you were looking all sad and pathetic.‚Äù

Sirius looks down at himself‚Äîjeans slightly too big for him, boots scuffed, same jumper as yesterday‚Äîhe looks back at Dorcas. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, I feel like I‚Äôm still pretty sad and pathetic.‚Äù

Dorcas‚Äôs eyes run him over, performing the same assessment. Eventually she sighs, reluctantly holding out her chips.

Sirius grins. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a goddess you know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù she snatches them back before he can get too many.

‚ÄúSmo whamt room ware we win tmoday?‚Äù he asks, mouth full.

Dorcas is giving him an incredibly unimpressed look. ‚ÄúDeath.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes widen, before he swallows with great effort. ‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs‚Ä¶cheery.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

There‚Äôs no Legilimency today, thank Merlin, only the regular security checks. Apparently Death is not taken quite as seriously by the Ministry.

‚ÄúWell, to be fair,‚Äù Dorcas says as they walk down the large black tiled corridor. The torches that light their way have blue flames in them. ‚ÄúCan you imagine if Voldemort was able to make us all fall in love with him?‚Äô

Sirius pulls a face. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a disturbing image Meadowes.‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly!‚Äù they round the next corner. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather be dead honestly.‚Äù

‚ÄúFair point.‚Äù

There‚Äôs no Unspeakable to greet them at this door. The room they walk into is completely empty. It‚Äôs round, with a domed ceiling and grey stone pillars holding up the edges. And in the centre, on a raised floor, is an archway.

When he listens, Sirius thinks he can hear voices.

‚ÄúThis is‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúDepressing?‚Äù Dorcas offers, shoving her hands into the pockets of her checkered trousers and stepping forward, inspecting the arch.

‚ÄúPretty much yeah.‚Äù Sirius doesn‚Äôt move. Something in him itches at the sight of the archway, desperately pushing away. Trying to get out of his skin.

‚ÄúDeath is so freaking bleak in England,‚Äù Dorcas says suddenly, which is such an absurd statement that it startles a snort out of Sirius.

‚ÄúPretty sure death is bleak everywhere.‚Äù

But she shakes her head. ‚ÄúNah, when my grandad died we partied for like a week.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a popular guy I take it?‚Äù

‚ÄúMy grandad?‚Äù she looks back at him. ‚ÄúHe was amazing. Wouldn‚Äôt have been anything to celebrate if he hadn‚Äôt been,‚Äù and at the look of confusion on Sirius‚Äôs face she goes on; ‚ÄúI told you, this,‚Äù she gestures to the bare grey walls surrounding them, ‚Äúis very English.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôd your grandfather die then?‚Äù he asks, leaning back against the pillar behind him.

‚ÄúTrinidad.‚Äù

Sirius blinks.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an island in the‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI know where Trinidad is,‚Äù he cuts her off indignantly. I mean, okay, he doesn‚Äôt really. But he‚Äôs not about to admit to that is he? ‚ÄúWhat was he doing there?‚Äù

Dorcas gives him a bemused look, letting the pause stretch on like she‚Äôs expecting him to figure it out on his own. He does not.

‚ÄúHe lived there,‚Äù she says finally, the ‚Äúduh‚Äù is heavily implied. ‚ÄúAll my family‚Äîwell, extended family anyway‚Äîlive there.‚Äù

This is frankly shocking news to Sirius who already feels like Remus being from Wales is foreign and exotic. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know you were from Trinidad?‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, technically I‚Äôm from Lincolnshire, but my parents are from Trinidad.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve never mentioned that before.‚Äù

Dorcas shrugs. ‚ÄúYou never asked.‚Äù

Which. Ouch. Okay. Not great.

‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

She shrugs again. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs alright, you were busy with,‚Äù she waves her hand vaguely in his direction; ‚Äúbeing Sirius Black.‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt everyone busy being themselves?‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess,‚Äù she wobbles her head from side to side. ‚ÄúIt just always seems like more of a full time job for you.‚Äù

Sirius grimaces.

He‚Äôs self involved, he knows that. Wrapped up in himself and his thoughts. He‚Äôs so fucking loud, even to his own ears, it blocks the rest of the world out. He hates that about himself. It reminds him of his mother.

‚ÄúWell, go on then. What‚Äôs death like in other places?‚Äù

Dorcas raises her brow, like she doesn‚Äôt believe he really wants to know, but Sirius doesn‚Äôt take the question back.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she says eventually, sitting down on the sloped floor facing him. ‚ÄúFor my grandad we did this thing, it‚Äôs called Nine Nights, basically does what it says on the tin. For nine nights you have a sort of wake, where everyone shows up at the dead person‚Äôs house and they bring food and alcohol and music.‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds like a proper party.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, I mean, that‚Äôs the point. You‚Äôre meant to celebrate. To remember how beautiful that person‚Äôs life was, to recognize how many people they impacted, how their spirit lives on in them. It‚Äôs about being together, you know? Helping each other, helping the spirit move on.‚Äù She pauses for a moment, clearly thinking. ‚ÄúHere, there‚Äôs so much emphasis put on what you‚Äôve lost, but there, it‚Äôs all about what you had. What you still have. It isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶it isn‚Äôt so‚Äî‚Äù she gestures at the gloomy, lonely room they‚Äôre in.

Sirius feels something oddly achy in his chest, eyes drifting over to the archway as one of the voices gets particularly loud. Not enough that he can hear the words but‚Ä¶it makes the hair on the back of his neck stand on end.

‚ÄúThat sounds‚Ä¶nice,‚Äù he says finally. Certainly nicer than anything happening in this room.¬† ¬†

Dorcas nods, looking distant for a moment. Like she‚Äôs lost in thought, the archway illuminating her from the back, making her hair look like a halo. ‚ÄúLots of things are different over there,‚Äù she says finally. ‚ÄúSometimes I wonder if things here were different too maybe‚Ä¶y‚Äôknow, all of this wouldn‚Äôt be happening.‚Äù¬†

Sirius isn‚Äôt quite following.

‚ÄúDifferent how?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, the ‚Äústatute of secrecy‚Äù isn‚Äôt taken very seriously on the islands so there‚Äôs a lot more cross-over between Muggles and Wizards. It‚Äôs like,‚Äù she looks up, searching for the words. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like magic is just another culture in a place full of cultures, and they all kind of,‚Äù she brings her hands together, interlocking her fingers, ‚Äúmix.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù Sirius can‚Äôt quite picture it, so much of his life has been defined by the hard line separating Muggle and Wizard. It‚Äôs difficult for him to imagine a place where that line doesn‚Äôt mean anything. Where it blurs and fades and is easily crossed.

‚ÄúMy parents have moved back there,‚Äù Dorcas goes on, ‚Äúthey went when things got‚Ä¶intense here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs it safer?‚Äù Sirius asks, having not considered how this war might be playing out in other countries.

Dorcas shrugs. ‚ÄúFor now. If Voldemort is able to take over the Ministry I can‚Äôt imagine that will last. But I think they feel like‚Äîor at least my dad‚Äîthat if they‚Äôre going to put their lives on the line fighting for freedom, it‚Äôs not going to be in Britain.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs face scrunches. ‚ÄúHow come?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she goes on, with the air of someone explaining something obvious to a very small child. ‚ÄúTrinidad only just got independence from Britain. I think they‚Äôre a little bit keener to protect that than they are to protect the person who was trying to control them before Voldemort.‚Äù

Sirius blinks, feeling like he‚Äôs just been dropped on another planet. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize that was still‚Ä¶‚Äù he sort of waves indistinctly at the air, ‚Äúa thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? Colonialism?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù now that‚Äôs she‚Äôs said it out loud it does sound a bit dumb. ‚ÄúYeah. Seems very‚Ä¶Victorian.‚Äù

‚ÄúShockingly, it‚Äôs lingered.‚Äù

Silence falls over them, Sirius‚Äôs eyes trailing back to the archway, unable to ignore it, the ghostly white veil flowing between its pillars. It taps into some feral part of him, some animal instinct that says run, run, run. Honestly he doesn‚Äôt know how Dorcas can stand to sit so close to it. But then, clearly her relationship to death is different.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he says finally, doing his best to swallow the wince that word always causes. His eyes go back to her‚Äôs in time to see her face scrunch in confusion.

‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù

And he doesn‚Äôt quite know how to explain. As with most of his apologies, there‚Äôs so much. ‚ÄúFor not asking you more questions when we were in school.‚Äù He grimaces, because it sounds stupid, because it‚Äôs clunky, because there are so many other things he means, he just doesn‚Äôt quite know how to say them.

Dorcas considers him for a long moment, too long really, Sirius trying and failing not to fidget.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she says eventually.

Sirius nods, wishing he could make himself a different person. A less selfish one. A less careless one. Wishing he could cut all of Walburga out. ¬† ¬†

¬†

¬†

His gloves are wet, his fingers starting to go numb as he packs the snow more tightly. All in all it‚Äôs a rather impressive fort, if he does say so himself. He clearly has a future as an‚Äî

‚ÄúOh for fuck‚Äôs sake,‚Äù he looks behind himself and, of course, there‚Äôs Regulus. Fully grown and sitting against the wall. Sirius sighs, dropping back into his spot across from him.

‚ÄúThis is becoming a habit,‚Äù he mutters.

Regulus nods, not looking at him.

He watches his little brother for a moment, watches him struggling with whatever it is he clearly wants to say. Resists the urge to tuck him under his arm and tell him it‚Äôll be alright. It‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs true. It never was.

‚ÄúI was scared,‚Äù Regulus says finally. ‚ÄúI saw what they did to you, when you spoke up or acted out and it scared me.‚Äù

Sirius is momentarily silenced by those words. It‚Äôs a hell of a¬†way to start a conversation.‚ÄúSee that‚Äôs what I don‚Äôt understand,‚Äù he says eventually. ‚ÄúI was always the one who got the worst of it. Always the one she hated. Even before‚Ä¶‚Äù before he started trying to be, is what he means to say. There was a long time, as embarrassing as it is for him to admit, when Sirius wanted desperately for his mother to love him. A time when he was brutally denied that love over and over again.

‚ÄúShe always hated me most,‚Äù he finishes finally.

‚ÄúYou were the heir. You mattered more.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Sirius says bitterly. ‚ÄúAnd you were the perfect son. Always doing exactly as you were told. If anyone had a right to be scared of them it was me.‚Äù

Regulus looks up finally. ‚ÄúI was the easier target.‚Äù

‚ÄúI protected you.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot in the end,‚Äù Regulus says sharply. ‚ÄúNot once you had James.‚Äù

Sirius feels his hackles raise. ‚ÄúLets leave him out of this shall we?‚Äù

Regulus gives him a look that is somewhere between exasperated and sad. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a part of this Sirius. We have to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs my fault then?‚Äù Sirius interrupts, because he doesn‚Äôt want to talk about James. To think about James. Not here. Not with this.

Regulus looks startled. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúMy fault for not being there, for having a life outside of that goddamn house, for leaving. My fault for not sacrificing myself for you even when you were barely speaking to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Regulus says sternly. ‚ÄúStop it. You know that‚Äôs not what I‚Äôm saying.‚Äù

‚ÄúI actually have no clue what you‚Äôre saying Regulus. You became their puppet‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI told you, I was scared.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe fuck do you think I was?‚Äù Sirius demands. ‚ÄúYou think I was having fun? You think I didn‚Äôt feel like throwing up every time I saw her raise her wand? But I still stood in front of you. Still took the worst of it for you. So how can you sit there and blame it all on fear when you had me and I had no one.‚Äù

Regulus looks pained, hands rubbing over his face, through his hair, disheveling his usually meticulous curls.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not trying to make excuses,‚Äù he finally says, but Sirius is too riled up for this. Too tired of going in circles.

‚ÄúFuck making excuses, you want to blame me‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo!‚Äù

‚ÄúBullshit!‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs hands are shaking so he grips his knees. ‚ÄúYou blame me for leaving‚Äîyou‚Äôve always blamed me and I‚Äôm sick of it. I‚Äôm so tired of being the bad guy in this story when I had to leave,‚Äù his voice cracks. ‚ÄúI had to leave.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Regulus says weakly. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

And Sirius isn‚Äôt sure when they both started sounding so wrecked, isn‚Äôt sure where the pressure behind his eyes came from or the trembling in his mouth.

‚ÄúI had to leave,‚Äù he repeats, like he can‚Äôt stop himself. ‚ÄúBecause you drew your wand.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Regulus is crying now. Sirius might be too.

‚ÄúShe asked you to hurt me and you drew your wand.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know. I know. Sirius‚ÄîSirius I‚Äôm sorry. I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt get to blame me, not after that. It isn‚Äôt fair. It was never fair.‚Äù

Let me forgive myself. Let me let this go. I‚Äôm so tired of carrying this guilt around.

Regulus nods, sniffling and wiping at his face with the sleeve of his jumper. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt your fault. You had to leave. I promise I know that. You had to leave. You had to leave me.‚Äù

Sirius feels something in him break, something profound, and he can‚Äôt look at Regulus anymore. Tilting his head back against the wall and shoving the heels of his hands into his eyes. The emotions tear through him like a landslide, leaving broken homes in their wake. He‚Äôs waited years to hear Regulus say that.

You had to leave.

He‚Äôs waited fucking years.

You had to leave me.

It a long time before he‚Äôs able to take a proper breath.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry Sirius, for so much, honestly,‚Äù Regulus says eventually, voice rough. ‚ÄúBut I need‚ÄîI need you to understand, that you weren‚Äôt always there. That you couldn‚Äôt protect me from them.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes find his brother‚Äôs. It‚Äôs another long moment before he‚Äôs able to force himself to ask the question he never allowed himself to before. Never even allowed himself to think.

‚ÄúWhat didn‚Äôt I see?‚Äù

Several emotions flicker across Regulus‚Äôs face‚Äîtoo quickly for Sirius to figure out what any of them are.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

‚ÄúReg‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo, I can‚Äôt, I can‚Äôt,‚Äù his eyes close and Regulus lets out a shaking breath. It‚Äôs been years since he‚Äôs seen Regulus show this much. Feel this much. ‚ÄúI just need you to know‚Äîto know that I had things to be afraid of that you couldn‚Äôt protect me from.‚Äù¬†

Sirius winces, glad that Regulus can‚Äôt see him. It isn‚Äôt that he didn‚Äôt know this, deep down, it‚Äôs more that he didn‚Äôt want to know it. Believing that he‚Äôd saved Regulus from the pain his mother inflicted on him, believing that by the time he left they loved Regulus too much to hurt him, let Sirius live with himself.

‚ÄúWhy won‚Äôt you tell me Reg?‚Äù The truth is, he‚Äôs not sure he wants to know. Not sure he could bear it. Not sure it wouldn‚Äôt make him tear the world apart.

‚ÄúBecause,‚Äù Regulus sighs, ‚Äúbecause if I do it‚Äôll be all you see when you think of me. And I don‚Äôt want that. I don‚Äôt want this to become all that I am to you. I‚Äôd rather you hate me because of what I‚Äôve done. Not because of what was done to me.‚Äù

For a second all Sirius can do is stare at his younger brother. Because that really is so spectacularly fucked up. He feels like a bolder has replaced his stomach. Feels like the weight of all the unsaid things between them will crush him.

Eventually he swallows, reaching his foot out and nudging Regulus‚Äôs. ‚ÄúReg,‚Äù he nudges him again. ‚ÄúReg, look at me. Hey?‚Äù nudge, nudge.

Regulus seems to open and roll his eyes simultaneously.

Sirius takes a moment, gathering his thoughts. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so‚Ä¶so fucking angry at you. For so many of the things you‚Äôve done. The things you‚Äôre still doing. I‚Äôve been angry for a long time. Sometimes it‚Ä¶it blocks out everything else. Everything we were before. I‚Äôm angry Reg,‚Äù he takes in a breath,‚Äúbut I don‚Äôt hate you. I never have.‚Äù

He sees the surprise in Regulus‚Äôs eyes. His brother opens and closes his mouth like he can‚Äôt quite find the words. ‚ÄúMe either,‚Äù Regulus finally manages to croak. ‚ÄúI never hated you. Never.‚Äù

Regulus has told Sirius that before of course. Years ago, back in school, sitting in an empty classroom after downing a vile of Veritaserum. But it hadn‚Äôt felt real then. Potion or no potion. Maybe Sirius just hadn‚Äôt been ready to hear it. He doesn‚Äôt know why it‚Äôs realer now, even though it‚Äôs objectively anything but.

Only a dream.

This boy, this version of his brother, talking and feeling, a figment of his imagination.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he says anyway, not even clear what he‚Äôs thanking him for.

Regulus nods, and then: ‚ÄúSirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúSee, when you say my name like that I feel like I‚Äôm not going to like what comes after it.‚Äù

Regulus gives him an unimpressed look. ‚ÄúWe have to talk about James.‚Äù

Sirius groans. ‚ÄúGod, no, fuck, we don‚Äôt. We really don‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy everything but this? All the other terrible shit between us but not James?‚Äù

Sirius bites the inside of his cheek and tries to refrain from lashing out the way he wants to. The way he wants to rip James‚Äôs name out of his brother‚Äôs mouth. He digs his fingers into the snow beneath him. Wishing this wasn‚Äôt a dream. Wishing he could feel the burn of the cold against his skin.

When Sirius continues to refuse to speak Regulus sighs. ‚ÄúYou have to‚Äîhe‚Äôs going to need you,‚Äù Regulus finally manages to get out, bringing Sirius‚Äôs gaze back to him. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to need you and I won‚Äôt be there so you have to get over this. You have to get over this so you can do what I‚Äîwhat I can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat the fuck are you talking about?‚Äù

Regulus runs a frustrated hand through his hair. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter, I just‚ÄîI need you to forgive him for loving me too okay? I need to know that he‚Äôll have someone.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú but Sirius cuts himself off. Old habits die hard. He‚Äôs so used to the pair of them trying to take jabs at one another, that he keeps forgetting that isn‚Äôt what they‚Äôre doing. That somehow they‚Äôve formed some sort of truce. Only in his dreams.¬†

‚ÄúHe did love me‚Äîdoes love me,‚Äù Regulus‚Äôs voice is fierce when he says it but Sirius can see the doubt in his grey eyes. At least until he closes them again, shaking his head. ‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù he whispers. ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt take that from me.‚Äù

But he‚Äôs mine, the childish part of Sirius wants to scream. I saw him first, I needed him most, why did it have to be him? Out of everyone. Why did you have to take him away? Because he had. For a year that lie had sat between James and Sirius, festering and growing and pushing them apart.

Eventually Sirius clears his throat. ‚ÄúIs your Patronus really a stag?‚Äù

Regulus actually laughs, eyes glassy when he opens them again. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah he is.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe?‚Äù Sirius arches his brow.

‚ÄúI call him Boo.‚Äù

‚ÄúWow, that‚Äôs‚Ä¶‚Äù Sirius rubs at the back of his neck, ‚Äúsurprisingly wholesome.‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúYeah, well, I didn‚Äôt choose it.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you kept it.‚Äù
