Regulus lets out a breath, dropping his head back against the wall of the snow fort. ‚ÄúYeah,¬†I kept it.‚Äù

Sirius can hear the wind howling outside, can remember how it had felt as a kid, constantly listening for footsteps, for the sound of his mother‚Äôs voice. Or his father‚Äôs. Coming to take them away. Coming to lock them back in that house.

‚ÄúFor so long,‚Äù Sirius starts talking, not looking at Regulus. ‚ÄúI always knew where James was. At my side. Always at my side. And then one day I turned around and he wasn‚Äôt there and it felt like‚Ä¶‚Äù he forces the breath out through his teeth, body tensed. ‚ÄúThe day you drew your wand on me, and the day James started lying to me, they feel the same. Maybe that sounds stupid but‚Ä¶I didn‚Äôt see either of them coming. I really fucking didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

He feels more than he sees Regulus roll his head towards him. But it‚Äôs another few seconds before he speaks. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt take him from you Sirius,‚Äù and when he scoffs Regulus presses on. ‚ÄúNot because I‚Äôm a nice person, not because I didn‚Äôt want to, but because I couldn‚Äôt. I don‚Äôt think anyone ever could,‚Äù Regulus laughs dryly. ‚ÄúI might have needed James, but I think the only person James has ever needed is you.‚Äù

Finally Sirius looks back at him, chest too tight‚Äîtoo tight to be healthy, to be normal, to let his heart beat in any regular way. And then, before he can stop himself, he says; ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt you need me?‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú words stumbling, tripping on his tongue. ‚ÄúI did. Of course I did I‚Äî‚Äú but he stops abruptly.

At first Sirius just thinks he‚Äôs crying. Water suddenly spilling over the corners of his eyes. But almost immediately the streams become too thick and consistent to be tears‚Äîlike rivers running down his face‚Äîlike he‚Äôs leaking.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù Sirius sits up, watching as his brother feels the water rushing over his cheeks, his drowning eyes returning to Sirius.

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù he sounds chocked, and Sirius suddenly sees the small drips of water escaping from the corners of his mouth. ‚ÄúI thought we‚Äôd have more time.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegulus what‚Äî‚Äú but Regulus‚Äôs eyes roll back into his head and his hands go to his throat. Sirius lunges forward, pulling Regulus into his lap as he‚Äîas he drowns in his arms.

‚ÄúReg? Reg? Hey? What‚Äôs happening? What the fuck is happening?‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know what to do, doesn‚Äôt know how to stop this, just keeps holding him, arms squeezing tight. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be okay,‚Äù Sirius says shakily, even though it‚Äôs clearly a lie. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gonna be okay.‚Äù

So much water is pouring out if him that it‚Äôs begun pooling around them.

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù his brother shakes in his arms, horrible gurgling noises coming from his throat. ‚ÄúRegulus I lo‚Äî‚Äú

His alarm goes off.

¬†

¬†

¬†When Sirius shows up at the Ministry Dorcas doesn‚Äôt even make him work for it, just gives him one look and holds out her chips.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in the Time Room today,‚Äù she says as they ride silently in the lift.

Sirius nods.

He feels simultaneously exhausted and buzzing with tension at the same time. A pit of anxiety weighing heavily in his stomach as his mind constantly replays his dream over and over again, no matter how many times he tries to get himself to focus on something else.

The look on Regulus‚Äôs face.

The water.

The noises he made.

‚ÄúDo you want to talk about?‚Äù Dorcas asks. The time room is the busiest one they‚Äôve been in so far, with at least a dozen Unspeakables buzzing about doing god knows what.

Sirius gives her a weak smile. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay, thanks.‚Äù

Dorcas does not look remotely convinced but after a long pause, she nods. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here if you need to.‚Äù

His smile is feeling more brittle by the second. ‚ÄúThanks.‚Äù

When he gets home the flat is still empty, not that he thought it wouldn‚Äôt be but there‚Äôs always the chance‚Ä¶in any case, he tries to eat but can‚Äôt quite manage it. It‚Äôs like he has a hive of bees living inside his skin.

He wants to sleep but he tosses and turns for most of the night. Not managing to finally drift away until nearly morning.

He doesn‚Äôt have any dreams.

When he wakes up the buzzing under his skin is worse. He doesn‚Äôt have guard duty today so there‚Äôs no reason to get out of bed. Except that the silence. The stillness. It‚Äôs eating him alive.

He wanders around the flat, puts on a record, turns the volume all the way up, adds firewhisky to his coffee. But the foreboding feeling never leaves him. A cold hand on his shoulder. A sob caught in his throat.

Eventually he firecalls James.

‚ÄúHello you,‚Äù Lily says, hair spilling out of a messy bun on the top of her head, freckles on full display as her face pokes through the fireplace.

Sirius tries to put on an easy grin. ‚ÄúHey gorgeous, how‚Äôre you?‚Äù

He must be doing a shit job at seeming okay because he can already see the flickers of concern in Lily‚Äôs expression, but then, she‚Äôs always been too smart by half.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm alright, you know, getting by,‚Äù it‚Äôs the tone that really gives it away when she says; ‚ÄúWhat about you?‚Äù

He tries not to wince.

‚ÄúLiving the dream baby,‚Äù his voice is too tight, he knows it, sees all pretence drop from Lily‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIs‚Äîer‚Äîis your worse half there by any chance?‚Äù he cuts her off, not sure he can handle lying to her directly.

Lily grimaces. ‚ÄúShit, no, sorry. Frank asked him to go into the Ministry and help teach some of the rookie Aurors how to handle their brooms.‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow. ‚ÄúSounds kinky.‚Äù

Lily snorts. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure Frank could even say the word kinky without blushing.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always the quiet ones who are into the weirdest shit, I‚Äôm telling you.‚Äù

Lily wrinkles her nose. ‚ÄúOkay, enough, I don‚Äôt need to be picturing Frank in full body leather.‚Äù

‚ÄúEw! Lily! Stop giving me mental images!‚Äù

‚ÄúYou started it!‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, you‚Äôre supposed to be the reasonable one not me,‚Äù Sirius fires back‚Äîrightly so he feels.

But Lily only rolls her eyes and sticks her tongue out at him. ‚ÄúReasonable one my ass,‚Äù she mutters under her breath.

‚ÄúCareful, the baby might hear you.‚Äù

That makes Lily laugh. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs heard worse than that in this house I promise you.‚Äù

‚ÄúSpeaking of‚Äîuh‚Äîhow‚Äôs that going then,‚Äù he gestures vaguely towards her. ‚ÄúThe whole, growing a person thing?‚Äù

She gives him an amused look. ‚ÄúAlright. I mean, early days still so he‚Äôs not really doing much but,‚Äù she looks down at what Sirius imagines is her belly. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre getting along okay,‚Äù there‚Äôs a softness in her eyes that Sirius doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs ever seen before, and he isn‚Äôt sure why it suddenly makes him feel so horribly lonely.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he coughs. ‚ÄúI should‚Äîuh‚ÄîI should go and‚Ä¶you know‚Ä¶but it was lovely to chat with you.‚Äù

When Lily looks up the concerned expression is back on her face. ‚ÄúAre you sure you don‚Äôt want to talk about something? I know I‚Äôm not James but‚Ä¶‚Äù

I feel trapped, ¬†

In my body.

In my mind.

I want to unzip my skin.

I want to live in something softer.

Kinder.

I want to pull the thoughts from my head like teeth.

He gives her a shaky smile. ‚ÄúNah, it‚Äôs nothing. Don‚Äôt worry about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames will be back tonight, I‚Äôll tell him to come round yeah?‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs chest feels tight. He wants to see James. Needs to see him really. But part of him also hates that, hates that everyone knows it.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, I‚Äôm sure he‚Äôll be tired.‚Äù

But Lily only scoffs. ‚ÄúPlease. He misses you. Expect him around eight, yeah?‚Äù

Sirius doesn‚Äôt know why that makes him feel so delicate. ‚ÄúAlright, thanks.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù she smiles. ‚ÄúCall anytime Sirius, okay?‚Äù

He nods, not quite trusting his voice as he pulls away, lets the fire flicker until there‚Äôs nothing there but wood and ash. Sirius closes his eyes and tries to get a hold of himself. He flexes and curls his fingers, taking deep breaths.

‚ÄúIt was just a dream,‚Äù he murmurs.

It doesn‚Äôt help.

¬†

¬†

He takes about three showers but none of them make his skin feel like it fits right. Like it belongs to him when he brushes his fingers over it. He can‚Äôt sit still long enough to do anything, bouncing from empty room to empty room. He stops putting coffee in his mug and starts just putting whisky.

That doesn‚Äôt help either.

Eventually he ends up on the sofa, knee bouncing up and down, elbows resting on his thighs, staring into the fire. He needs to go somewhere. Needs to get out. He just doesn‚Äôt know where. He stares so hard his eyes start to water and he has to look away. Focusing instead on a picture on the wall.

It‚Äôs one of Alphard‚Äôs, though at this point his uncle‚Äôs stuff and his stuff has become so intermingled that he sometimes forgets it didn‚Äôt all always belong to him. In the picture Alphard is smiling, close mouthed, a bit camera shy, as three young girls laugh and giggle and joke around him. Sirius has clearly never looked at it closely before because if he had he would have thrown it out. Too many enemies in that frame, too many memories.

His eyes snag on one face in particular.

It doesn‚Äôt take long. For him to decide. It never does.

A second later he‚Äôs off the sofa and out the door. Jacket and wand in hand.

¬†

¬†

He‚Äôs never technically been here before, only seen the address on a few birthday cards. He takes one or two wrong turns but eventually he‚Äôs landing his bike in an open field, a quaint little farm house a few yards away from him.¬†

Most of the area is barren, what with it being winter, the sky above grey and dark even though it can‚Äôt be later than three. Sirius silences the engine of his bike and climbs off, hand running over his hair, making sure it‚Äôs all still secured in the small bun at the back of his head, eyeing the house in front of him. Now that he‚Äôs here the nerves are starting to kick in.¬†

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he says, straightening his jacket, ‚Äúhere goes nothing.‚Äù

Sirius takes no more than two steps forward before he runs into what feels like a brick wall. Or, well, a brick wall that‚Äôs also running into him‚Äîthrowing him backwards so that he slams into the ground a few feet behind his bike.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he wheezes, trying to get the air back in his lungs. He curls onto his side, coughing.

Wards.

He should have seen that coming.

Idiot.

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

His head pops up at the voice, dots appearing in front of his eyes‚Äîprobably the result of slamming his head into the ground‚Äîhe blinks them away, bringing into view a young woman holding the hand of a toddler with strikingly pink hair.

‚ÄúYou thought you were just gonna be able to walk right up to our front door did you?‚Äù the woman asks, amusement clear in her voice.

Sirius groans, pushing himself up to siting and rubbing at his eyes. ‚ÄúYeah, might not have thought that one through a hundred percent.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think?‚Äù

She walks towards him, her dark hair in lose waves down her back, eyes sharp.

‚ÄúI was wondering if you‚Äôd come by,‚Äù she says, letting go of the kid‚Äôs hand‚Äîher kid, Sirius assumes, though her skin is darker than her mother‚Äôs. Andromeda helps him to his feet.

‚ÄúYou were?‚Äù he asks. It seems a strange thing to say, considering he‚Äôs never come by before.

She shrugs. ‚ÄúJust a hunch. Good to be around family in times like these and‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶we only have so much family we can be around.‚Äù

Sirius assumes by ‚Äútimes like these‚Äù she means the war. Though he still feels a little wrong footed. Like he‚Äôs walked into a scene without knowing his lines.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

She gives him a long look. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a while, last time I saw you you were‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúFourteen,‚Äù Sirius answers. ‚ÄúWell, I think anyway.‚Äù His mother held a dinner a month or so before Andromeda left the family. Ran off with her Muggle boyfriend. Probably the only reason Sirius ever considered running himself. If it hadn‚Äôt been for Andromeda he wouldn‚Äôt have believed it was possible to get away from them.¬†

The corner of her mouth twitches ever so slightly. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve grown up.‚Äù

Have I? Sirius almost asks. Because most of the time he doesn‚Äôt feel much different than he did at fourteen. Or maybe he feels completely different but not in any helpful way. Not more mature. Not more knowledgeable. The opposite really.

‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôve grown a person,‚Äù he looks over at the kid and smiles. She crowds against her mother‚Äôs leg but smiles back nonetheless.

‚ÄúDora, say hi, this is your cousin Sirius,‚Äù she gives the kid a little nudge and Dora raises her hand.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù she says, with that slight lisp children sometimes have.

Sirius beams back. ‚ÄúHey, I like your hair.‚Äù

No sooner has he said that then the pink starts to drain away, replaced by dark brown‚Äînearly black‚Äîtied in a bun at the back of her head.

‚ÄúI wike your hair,‚Äù she says quietly.

For a second all Sirius can do is stare, but then he laughs. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt say,‚Äù he looks up at Andromeda for clarification.

‚ÄúI know, as if being a toddler wasn‚Äôt terror enough, this one‚Äôs gotta go and be a Metamorphmagus,‚Äù Andromeda looks down at her daughter fondly, mussing her hair. ‚ÄúDo you want to explain what a Metamorphmagus is to your cousin my darling?‚Äù

Dora gives her mother a big grin, showcasing her missing front tooth. ‚ÄúIt mweans that‚Äîit mweans that I can do‚Äîum‚Äîfunny things with mwy face!‚Äù

Sirius snorts, watching Andromeda frown slightly.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù the older woman says eventually. ‚ÄúFair enough I suppose.‚Äù She turns back to Sirius, nodding over her shoulder. ‚ÄúCome on then, it‚Äôs freezing. Lets get inside.‚Äù

Sirius looks at the space in front of him warily and his cousin rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúOh come on you big baby, they‚Äôll let you in now.‚Äù

Sirius believes her. Mostly. But he still walks behind her with both of his hands held in front of him, bracing for impact.

¬†

¬†

¬†¬†Andromeda‚Äôs house is sweet. That‚Äôs the best way Sirius can think to describe it. A Tudor style cottage, with a dulled orange roof. There are rose bushes under the front windows that have clearly been magicked to bloom all year round, and thin green vines snaking up the walls.¬†

‚ÄúJust kick your boots off anywhere,‚Äù she says when they get inside, Dora tearing off her jacket and running through the house. Andromeda rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúWhat have I said about leaving your things on the floor Dora!‚Äù she calls after her, shaking her head as she hangs up her coat on one of the available hooks near the door.

Sirius takes off his shoes but keeps his jacket on. It makes him feel‚Ä¶protected somehow.

‚ÄúTea? Coffee? Hot chocolate? Something stronger?‚Äù Andromeda asks as he follows her into the kitchen, her hair staticky from her winter clothes.¬†

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú the house is warm. A little cluttered. Discarded newspapers, and books, and toys spread about. There are dirty dishes in the sink, and a half-eaten piece of toast on the counter. The whole place somehow smells like lemon cake‚ÄîSirius thinks it must be a spell cause he can‚Äôt see anything baking. It makes him smile though. Reminds him of the Potters‚Äô.

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù

He blinks, finding Andromeda leaning back against the counter watching him. Then he sees her eyes do a quick circuit of the room.

‚ÄúOh yeah, sorry, place is a bit of a mess. I‚Äôd tell you it‚Äôs not always like this but that would be a lie.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo it‚Äôs good, I like it. It‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú he falters, throat a little tight. ‚ÄúYou did good Andy.‚Äù

Her expression softens and he wonders if she‚Äôs thinking about it too‚Äîthe houses they grew up in. Everything in its place. Nothing meant to be touched. Not even the people.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù she says eventually. ‚ÄúNow? Firewhisky? I feel like the occasion calls for it.‚Äù

He scrunches his face. Occasion? Him showing up, is that what she means? He‚Äôs about to ask when‚Äî

‚ÄúBabe have you seen my turquoise shirt? I can‚Äôt find it‚Äî‚Äú A tall, dark skinned man walks into the room. He‚Äôs shirtless, which is a bit of a shock. Not that Sirius is complaining.

The man‚Äôs eyes grow wide as they travel from Sirius to his wife. ‚ÄúUh‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWell now I feel overdressed.‚Äù

Andromeda rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúTed, this is my cousin Sirius, Sirius, this is my husband Ted.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour cousin?‚Äù Ted repeats, not seeming at all reassured by that information. To be fair, knowing their family, Sirius wouldn‚Äôt be either.

He leans closer to Andromeda and fake-whispers: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre helping.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh stop looking like that Ted, he‚Äôs harmless.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Sirius says indignantly. ‚ÄúI can be plenty harmful I‚Äôll have you know!‚Äù

Andromeda arches her brow. ‚ÄúNow who‚Äôs not helping?‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know you had harmless relatives,‚Äù Ted says, warily.

Andromeda makes a face that seems to say something along the lines of ‚ÄúYeah, fair enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius is a bit of an anomaly.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd also, I would like to once again point out, not harmless!‚Äù

‚ÄúAw,‚Äù Andromeda puckers her lower lip. ‚ÄúOf course you‚Äôre not sweetie.‚Äù

Sirius scowls, crossing his arms over his chest. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm starting to regret this visit.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, yeah, go sit down and I‚Äôll pour you a drink. And Ted?‚Äù

Ted blinks, clearly still thrown by Sirius‚Äôs sudden presence in his kitchen. ‚ÄúHuh? Yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúGo put on a shirt.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù he looks down at his torso. ‚ÄúOh shi‚Äîsorry. Totally wasn‚Äôt even‚Äîwow this is super embarrassing, I am‚Äîyup‚Äîokay, definitely going to do that now. Nice to‚Äîer‚Äîmeet you.‚Äù

He nods at Sirius briefly before ducking out of the room.

Andromeda shakes her head, pulling a pair of glasses down from the cupboard. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs ridiculous.‚Äù

Sirius smiles. ‚ÄúI like him.‚Äù

He can see her fighting the urge to smile back. ‚ÄúWell I do too, obviously, but don‚Äôt go telling him that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think marrying him might have tipped him off.‚Äù

‚ÄúEh,‚Äù Andromeda pours their drinks, carrying them over to the table. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd be surprised, men are unimaginably dense. No offence.‚Äù

‚ÄúNone taken.‚Äù

They fall into silence, Sirius passing his glass back and forth between his palms, watching the condescension it leaves behind on the table.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Andromeda says finally. He can feel her eyes on him, without even looking up.

‚ÄúSo.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve never visited before.‚Äù

Sirius grimaces down at the table. ‚ÄúI know, I‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey, not a judgement, just an observation.‚Äù

Sirius doesn‚Äôt know exactly what to say, or how to explain what he‚Äôs doing here. Why he thought this would help. I mean, it is helping, he feels better not being alone in his flat. But he‚Äôs not sure he wants to explain that to Andromeda. ¬† ¬†

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù she reaches out and gently taps the top of his hand, bringing Sirius‚Äôs eyes to her‚Äôs. She smiles, just out of the corner of her mouth. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you came.‚Äù

It really is pathetic that that makes him feel choked up.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúMummyMummyMummyMummy!‚Äù

Andromeda rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúSorry, children have no sense of timing whatsoever.‚Äù

Sirius only smiles, privately disagreeing. He is more than happy to be spared the struggle of coming up with a reply.

Dora speeds into the room, hair still an exact replica of Sirius‚Äôs. Strands slipping from the bun and hanging around her face. She has, in her hands, a stuffed animal. It‚Äôs a scruffy thing, well loved, missing an ear.

‚ÄúI wanted to show Sirius mwy wolf.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Andromeda says knowingly, sitting back in her chair and taking a sip of her drink. ‚ÄúWell then, by all means.‚Äù

Dora shoots Sirius a look and then shuffles forward. ‚ÄúThis is Soup. He‚Äôs mwy wolf.‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow, shooting Andromeda a quick look. His cousin sighs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my fault, I called him ‚Äúton loup‚Äù and, well,‚Äù she gestures at the stuffed toy with her glass.

‚ÄúSoup,‚Äù Sirius says, laughing a little as he looks back down at Dora. ‚ÄúMakes perfect sense.‚Äù

She grins, missing tooth and all. ‚ÄúI thought you‚Äôd like him, your hair is kinda similar.‚Äù

He hears Andromeda snort.

‚ÄúDo you wanna pwet him?‚Äù

‚ÄúHel‚Äî‚Äú

Andromeda coughs.

‚Äú‚Äîck yeah I do!‚Äù

She offers up the little wolf and Sirius gives him a good scratch behind the ears. Trying not to think about his own wolf.

‚ÄúThere you are!‚Äù

Sirius looks up to see Ted in the doorway‚Äîfully clothed this time.¬†

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he brushes his fingers over Andromeda‚Äôs shoulders before bending down to pick up a giggling Dora. ‚ÄúI was trying to keep this little gremlin out of your hair.‚Äù He tickles her belly and the giggling intensifies, Soup being whipped around in all directions.

When she settles Sirius sees that her appearance has changed again, hair now shorter and curlier, mimicking her father‚Äôs.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs her favourite,‚Äù Andromeda says, leaning towards Sirius ever so slightly. ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt matter who else is in the room, she always chooses him.‚Äù

Dora and Ted are trading words back and forth, quick and quiet. Every few seconds Dora will let out a wave of childish snorts, Ted beaming at her, eyes crinkling at the corners.

‚ÄúShe has good taste,‚Äù Sirius says eventually, struggling against the uninvited jealousy in his chest. He used to feel like this a lot back in the early days, when he would visit James. But then, Effie and Monty adopted him so quickly that the jealousy never really had much to feed off of.

‚ÄúThat she does,‚Äù Andromeda says, staring fondly at her family.

‚ÄúAlright bubba,‚Äù Ted settles Dora on his hip. ‚ÄúTime for your bath.‚Äù

Now, Sirius was under the impression that baths were something of a controversial subject when it came to children. Personally, he doesn‚Äôt remember them fondly. But Dora, Dora‚Äôs eyes light up.

‚ÄúBath time,‚Äù she says, in a little awed voice, as though she‚Äôs never heard anything so lovely.

Ted smiles. He has a nice smile, Sirius decides. It reaches all the way up to his eyes, big and vulnerable. He understands why Andy might be drawn to him. To a man who smiles with his heart instead of his teeth.¬†

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he glances over his daughter‚Äôs head at the two of them sitting at the table. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll leave you lot to it then.‚Äù

He gives Andromeda a look that Sirius interprets as ‚Äúdo you need me to rescue you? Blink twice if the answer‚Äôs yes‚Äù but Andy only smiles back, taking another sip of her drink.

‚ÄúHave fun, do try not to flood the bathroom again.‚Äù

Ted rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúThat was one time!‚Äù

‚ÄúBath time!‚Äù Dora interrupts, clearly having enough of this, Sirius doesn‚Äôt blame her. ‚ÄúBath time! Bath time!‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, yeah,‚Äù Ted kisses the side of her head, before turning to Sirius. ‚ÄúSorry, when this one‚Äôs down for her nap, I might be able to come out and meet you properly.‚Äù

Sirius smiles back. ‚ÄúNo worries, I expect bath time‚Äôs more fun than chatting with me anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúBath time! Bath time! Bath time!‚Äù Dora agrees.

‚ÄúCertainly is for one of us,‚Äù he offers Sirius another parting smile before hauling his chanting six year old back out of the room. Sirius watches them go, feeling the familiar itch in his chest.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Andromeda says eventually, snapping him out of his thoughts, bringing his gaze back to her. She nods down the hall where her husband and daughter just disappeared. ‚ÄúNot fair is it?‚Äù

Sirius doesn‚Äôt know how to respond to that so instead he takes a sip of his drink. It‚Äôs good. Strong. Burns on the way down just like it should. After another few seconds of silence Andromeda sighs.

‚ÄúSo look, Narcissa wrote me about the funeral,‚Äù she runs a hand over her face. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt going to go but,‚Äù she looks at him. ‚ÄúIf you want to, I‚Äôll go with you.‚Äù

Sirius blinks back at her.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a sickening moment of stillness in which he sees several emotions flicker across her face‚Äîconfusion, realization, horror.

‚ÄúOh no, oh Sirius don‚Äôt do this‚Äîtell me you know? I thought‚Äîwhy else would you all the sudden show up here?‚Äù

And stupidly. Irrationally. He thinks it‚Äôs Remus. Which makes no sense, because why would Narcissa know about Remus‚Äôs death before him? And if anyone was going to be planning his funeral‚Äîbut no, Sirius has to shut that thought down right there as an overwhelming wave a nausea washes over him.

‚ÄúWho?‚Äù Sirius finally manages to ask.

The pity in her eyes. ‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

But he cuts her off. ‚ÄúPlease Andy, tell me. I can handle it. Just tell me.‚Äù

She looks like she‚Äôd rather do just about anything else but instead she nods. ‚ÄúYeah, okay, okay,‚Äù exhaling. ‚ÄúSirius I‚Äôm so sorry, I‚Äôm so fucking sorry. If I had known‚Äî‚Äú she shakes her head. ‚ÄúNever mind. It‚Äôs Regulus. Regulus is dead.‚Äù

For a moment Sirius‚Äôs head goes silent.

But I just saw him.

I just saw him.

We were building a snow fort.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

Andromeda reaches out, taking hold of Sirius‚Äôs hand and squeezing it. ‚ÄúI know. I know.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äî‚Äú the word chokes itself and Sirius closes his eyes, trying to stay in control. ‚ÄúHow?‚Äù he finally manages to get out. The room suddenly lacking in oxygen.

‚ÄúVoldemort caught him trying to runaway,‚Äù a pause and then: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no body.‚Äù

He lets out something strangled. A laugh and a sob all rolled into one. He makes the noise with his whole chest.

Fuck Reg.

There‚Äôs no body.

Fuck.

Fuck.

Those big eyes.

Those socked feet.

‚ÄúSirius? Sirius are you okay?‚Äù

He hears Andromeda getting out of her seat, feels her sliding into the one next to him. Wrapping her arms around him. He isn‚Äôt crying, that would be too simple. And nothing between him and Reg was ever that.

He squeezes his eyes more firmly shut as he lets her hold him.

‚ÄúI thought we‚Äôd have more time.‚Äù

Water pouring from his eyes. Pooling around Sirius‚Äôs knees.

‚ÄúI thought we‚Äôd have more time.‚Äù

And Sirius doesn‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs him or Regulus speaking.

¬†

¬†

PART III JAMES ¬† ¬†

¬†

¬† James Potter is a coward.

This truth is inescapable as he sits in his bedroom, head in his hands, knees bouncing up and down, trying once again to figure out what the fuck he‚Äôs going to tell Lily.

He knows he‚Äôs waited too long.

Regulus could have turned up by now. Could turn up any second. And that would be‚Ä¶that would be bad.

I mean, okay, it‚Äôs all bad.

But that would be worse.

It isn‚Äôt how he wants to‚Ä¶do this. Whatever the hell this is.

His nails dig into his scalp, pulling at his hair.

He‚Äôs fucked up. He knows that. He does. He feels bad. Not‚Ä¶not maybe as bad as he should. Because he doesn‚Äôt‚Ä¶regret it. Which is, admittedly, another layer of fucked. For the hundredth time he tries to pull his ribs apart, to poke and prod some answers out of his bitch of a heart. But he gets nowhere.

He loves Lily.

Loves their life and their home and the idea of starting a family with her.

But there hasn‚Äôt been a day, since he was sixteen, that he hasn‚Äôt felt the absence of Regulus like a hole in his chest. He hadn‚Äôt realized how much until he was sat across from Walburga Black, listening to her tell him he‚Äôd lost. Tell him he‚Äôd been the reason she‚Äôd pushed Regulus to get the Mark when she had. So young. So fucking young. He hadn‚Äôt quite been able to appreciate that at the time. What children they were.

I love you both so much,

he thinks for the thousandth time.

And I just‚Ä¶I just want that to be okay.

He grimaces.

I know it isn‚Äôt. I know. But I just‚ÄîI just want to be whole.

Please don‚Äôt make me choose.

Please.

He groans, scrubbing at his face before he collapses back onto the bed.

He has to tell Lily. Tell her everything. All of it. He doesn‚Äôt like keeping things from her, he knows she can tell he has been. Sees it in the looks she shoots him out of the corners of her eyes. This isn‚Äôt fair. It isn‚Äôt right. But every time he goes to open his mouth the words evaporate.

How is he meant to explain something he doesn‚Äôt understand?

How is she ever going to believe him?

Forgive him?

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù Lily shouts up the stairs.

He‚Äôs going to tell her. He is.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius is calling, says it‚Äôs important.‚Äù

Shit.

James looks over at the clock. It‚Äôs nearly 8:30. He only meant to come up here and change and then he was going to head over to the flat. Lily said Sirius rung earlier, that he hadn‚Äôt looked well. Remus has been gone again. James knows it‚Äôs been hard on him.

Merlin he‚Äôs such a shit friend.

‚ÄúTell him I‚Äôll be over in five, yeah?‚Äù he shouts back, getting off the bed and looking around for a clean shirt.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not at home. He says it‚Äôs important he‚ÄîJames it looks important.‚Äù

Something in her tone makes his blood suddenly go cold. He drops the clothes in his hands and heads for the door, taking the stairs two at a time. Lily is waiting at the bottom, chewing on her lower lip.

‚ÄúWhat is it? What did he say?‚Äù he asks as he heads towards the room he still thinks of as his father‚Äôs study.

Lily shakes her head. ‚ÄúNothing really. Just that he wasn‚Äôt home. That he wanted to speak with you‚Äîjust you,‚Äù she pauses at the door, James‚Äôs hand on the handle. He turns back to her.

‚ÄúJust me?‚Äù he asks, confused. If it‚Äôs serious, if it‚Äôs an emergency, why wouldn‚Äôt he want Lily there?

‚ÄúJust go okay?‚Äù Lily looks scared but then, they‚Äôre all scared these days. ‚ÄúHe needs you, whatever it is, I don‚Äôt like seeing him look so fucking sad. So go work some of your James Potter magic and fix him,‚Äù she gives James a small smile and he can‚Äôt help leaning forward and kissing the top of her head.

‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù he says automatically, feeling a spike of guilt cut through his stomach so sharply he nearly doubles over.

‚ÄúI love you too.‚Äù

He‚Äôs going to tell her. He is.

He closes the door behind him, walking towards Sirius‚Äôs face in the fire. He looks distant. And‚Ä¶something else James can‚Äôt put his finger on.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù he says softly, kneeling in front of him. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up? What‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù

‚ÄúJames.‚Äù

The broken way he says his name makes James want to jump through the fire.

‚ÄúWhere are you?‚Äù he asks, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll come get you.‚Äù

A shaky smile flickers across Sirius‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúAre you going to rescue me James?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt ask stupid questions. Just tell me where you are. Tell me who I have to fucking murder.‚Äù Tell me who put that bruised look in your eyes. Promise it wasn‚Äôt me.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù Sirius says eventually, and apparently seeing the look of absolutely disbelief on James‚Äôs face he goes on: ‚ÄúI mean I‚Äôm safe. I‚Äôm at Andy‚Äôs.‚Äù

James blinks, momentarily taken off guard. ‚ÄúAndy‚Äôs? As in your cousin Andy?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the one.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat are you doing there?‚Äù

Sirius looks like the question makes him tired. ‚ÄúI just needed to‚Ä¶not be in an empty flat. And you were busy so‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúListen, I‚Äôll come over okay? I‚Äôll come over now‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù Sirius stops him.

Something is wrong.

It isn‚Äôt just Remus being gone.

Something is wrong with Sirius and it‚Äôs starting to make James panic.

‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm going to stay here, for the night anyway,‚Äù Sirius goes on.

James shakes his head, not understanding. ‚ÄúSirius, tell me what‚Äôs happening? Because I‚Äôm so fucking lost.‚Äù

Sirius shifts, sitting with his knees bent, hands clasped in front him. ‚ÄúI thought‚ÄîI wanted you to hear this from me,‚Äù he looks up and then away, and James swears he‚Äôs going to lose it if Sirius doesn‚Äôt start explaining himself because he can‚Äôt take the anxiety. The building pressure in his chest.¬†

It‚Äôs Remus,

the horrible voice in his head says.

Something‚Äôs happened to Remus.

Though James doubts Sirius would be this calm if that were the case.

Sirius sighs, scrubbing at his his face. ‚ÄúRegulus is dead.‚Äù

James just looks at him. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess he got cold feet, he was trying to get out, Voldemort caught him.‚Äù

No.

No.

No.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù¬† ¬†

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no body,‚Äù Sirius is just rambling on, barely listening to James, barely looking at him, like he can‚Äôt wait to have this all out of him. To stop tasting it in his mouth. ‚ÄúBut they‚Äôre having a funeral anyway, something small, in a few days. Me and Andy talked about it but I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre going to go. We‚Äôre not technically invited and it would probably just end in a fucking duel anyway.‚Äù

James‚Äôs whole body has gone cold, a faint sort of buzzing in his ears. ‚ÄúHe‚Äî‚Äú

But that‚Äôs as far as he gets. Nothing else comes out.¬†

He can‚Äôt think. He can‚Äôt think. Because every time he tries‚Äî

‚ÄúJames? Are you‚Äîare you okay?‚Äù

Nothing is making sense.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú¬†

He promised.

This time he promised.

So many years, and so many fights, and finally he was going to leave.

‚ÄúI just can‚Äôt quite‚Äî‚Äù nothing is coming out of his mouth. Nothing is coming into his head. Stuck between shock and the desire not to make this worse for Sirius. Sirius who looks so small right now. James has always done his best to protect him. It‚Äôs second nature. Even if what he‚Äôs protecting him from is himself.¬†

‚ÄúNo, I can‚Äôt really either,‚Äù Sirius lets out a heavy breath. ‚ÄúI mean, fuck him, fuck him for all of it, but I never thought this was as far as we would get you know? I thought there was going to be more than this, I thought eventually he would fucking‚Ä¶try to fix this.‚Äù

James squeezes his eyes shut. It feels as though his body is getting smaller and smaller, caving in on itself.

‚ÄúHe did try to fix it,‚Äù James croaks. ‚ÄúLike you said, he was trying to get out, that‚Äôs what‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYeah but who knows where he was going or why he was leaving. Him being too chicken shit to do whatever they were asking him to isn‚Äôt the same as him realizing he was wrong.‚Äù

James wants to tell him‚Äîneeds to‚Äîbut he can‚Äôt fucking breathe.

And suddenly he‚Äôs back in the Astronomy Tower.

And Regulus Black has just kissed him for the first time.

He should have seen it coming. He didn‚Äôt. But he should have.

He‚Äôs so warm.

His mouth.

His hands.

For a boy who walks around like he‚Äôs made of stone Regulus touches like the sun.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù

It‚Äôs okay. This is okay. This can be okay.

It‚Äôs just a kiss.

Except it isn‚Äôt.

It‚Äôs Sirius‚Äôs brother.

It‚Äôs Regulus Black.

It‚Äôs a boy.

Breathe.

In and out.

In and out.

A boy who touches like the sun.

‚ÄúJames!‚Äù

His eyes fly open, and they‚Äôre wet but he isn‚Äôt crying, though he‚Äôs almost certain that any second he‚Äôs going to be sick. He‚Äôs going to scream. He‚Äôs going to start digging into his chest. To get it out. Get it out. The ache. The pain. Get it out. Get it out.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he croaks. ‚ÄúSorry it‚Äôs been a long day and I can‚Äôt really‚Äîthis is doing my head in.‚Äù

Sirius gives him a concerned look. ‚ÄúI know, I‚Äî‚Äú There‚Äôs a voice in the background, Sirius‚Äôs head turning for a second. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says over his shoulder. ‚ÄúThanks.‚Äù He looks apologetic when he returns. ‚ÄúSorry, that was Andy, she‚Äôs just letting me know there‚Äôs food.‚Äù

James nods, hoping it doesn‚Äôt look as shaky as it feels. ‚ÄúYou should go.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt want to break down in front of Sirius. It doesn‚Äôt seem fair. It isn‚Äôt what he does. He‚Äôs the strong one. He‚Äôs the one that Sirius is supposed to be able to count on in moments like this. To lean on. He doesn‚Äôt want him here while he crumbles into dust.¬†

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have to‚Äî‚Äù

James swallows. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs helping, being with them?‚Äù

He sees the surprise on Sirius‚Äôs face and then the slight pinking‚Äîembarrassment. He‚Äôs always embarrassed every time he admits to wanting a family. Like it‚Äôs some dirty secret.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says finally, voice a little rough. ‚ÄúYeah, it‚Äôs helping.‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúThen you should go.‚Äù

Sirius hesitates for a moment before finally conceding. ‚ÄúOkay, yeah I‚Äôll‚Äîyeah. Take care of yourself okay? We'll talk later.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, you too.‚Äù

The minute he‚Äôs alone James collapses forward onto his hands and knees. Gasping for air. Dry heaving. He ought to find a bin, something to be sick into, but he isn‚Äôt sure he can move.

I just want to hold him.

It‚Äôs a stupid thing to think. But his brain won‚Äôt let it go.

I just want to feel him. The warmth of his skin, the weight of him, the pressure of his head on my chest. Knowing he‚Äôs safe because I have him. I have him and I‚Äôm not going to let anyone hurt him. Not anymore. Not again.¬†

I just want to hold him.

But he can‚Äôt.

Because Regulus is dead.

Regulus is dead.¬†

Regulus is dead.

There isn‚Äôt even a body.

James screams. He screams hoping it‚Äôll tear him apart. Hoping it will drown out every thought in his head. Every feeling in his chest. He screams and he screams and it isn‚Äôt enough. It isn‚Äôt fucking enough.

You‚Äôre going to be insufferable aren‚Äôt you?

Yes. God yes.

These screams have claws, dragging pieces of James with them on their way out. Good. Get it out. Get it out. Get the pain out. It‚Äôs driving him mad. He can‚Äôt take this. It‚Äôs driving him all the way out of his head.

You‚Äôre gorgeous, you know that?

You‚Äôre drunk.

Yeah, but it‚Äôd still be true if I was sober.

He needs a knife. Needs something sharp.

I‚Äôm glad you came.

Go to sleep James.

He‚Äôs started scratching at his skin, vicious red lines left behind. Get it out. Get it out. He‚Äôs panicking. He knows it. But people were not built to lose this much. His body can‚Äôt hold it.

Not everyone can be a hero.

There aren‚Äôt any heroes, remember? You said that. No heroes, no villains, just people.

It‚Äôs harder to believe that standing next to you.

I don‚Äôt know who or what made you give up on yourself Regulus, but I need you to stop.

James‚Äî

You are worth saving.

‚ÄúJames? James!‚Äù

Lily is on the floor in front of him, she‚Äôs blurry, but definitely there, pale faced and shocked as she grabs hold of his wrists, stopping him from tearing himself apart. He‚Äôs crying now, voice gone, unable to make sense of his own thoughts.

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù she lets go of his wrists, hands coming up to his face, thumbs desperately trying to wipe away his tears.

He is overflowing. Spilling out of himself. Staining the carpet. For generations people will find pieces of him between the floorboards.

‚ÄúJames please,‚Äù Lily says softly, hands steady, as they hold him. ‚ÄúTell me what‚Äôs happened?‚Äù¬† ¬†

He tries to blink through the tears, tries to find her, to use her as an anchor. But nothing feels solid enough to hold onto.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs dead,‚Äù the words come out as a whine. ‚ÄúOh fuck, oh fuck, he‚Äôs dead.‚Äù

He would give anything to be unconscious right now.

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs dead? James, who‚Äôs dead?‚Äù

His breaths are choked and stuttered, getting caught in his chest. He finds her green eyes through it all‚Äîstrong, like the rest of her. He tries to inhale, it‚Äôs hard, hard when he feels like he‚Äôs made of fault lines. Of earth quakes.

"Regulus,‚Äù he whispers, certain Lily‚Äôs hands are the only things keeping him together. ‚ÄúRegulus is dead.‚Äù

He wants to start screaming again.

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

He can‚Äôt make sense of her expression, can barely see it, but for some reason, now that he‚Äôs started he can‚Äôt stop. ‚ÄúHe‚Äîhe was,‚Äù James closes his eyes. ‚ÄúWe were together.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment of stillness.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Lily says finally. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

James‚Äôs eyes fly open. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Lily smiles sadly. ‚ÄúSixth year, someone important to you was missing, you gave me the little Quaffle‚Äîbeautiful magic that was, really, the charm work‚Äîbut in the centre, your initials were tangled around one another: J R. A few days later Regulus was back in school.‚Äù

He shakes his head. ‚ÄúBut you never said?‚Äù

‚ÄúI figured it was none of my business,‚Äù she shrugs. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôd wanted to tell me you would have. It‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt matter to me James, surely you know that?‚Äù

James Potter is a coward.

The worst kind of coward.

James Potter is also full of cracks.

‚ÄúI saw him,‚Äù he chokes.

Lily‚Äôs brow furrows. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúI saw him.‚Äù

She still looks confused. She won‚Äôt in a second. ‚ÄúYou saw him when? Where?‚Äù

‚ÄúA few weeks ago. Grimmauld Place.‚Äù

Her eyes shift, gaze growing just a tad bit colder, hands falling away. ‚ÄúYou went to his house?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

They stare at one another, James shaking, trying his best not to look away. It‚Äôs the least he can do. Her eyes run him up and down. Clever. Always able to read him. He sees the moment she understands. Really understands.

‚ÄúYou went to his house,‚Äù she repeats, a new edge in her voice.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù James blurts out. He means it and he doesn‚Äôt. Because he wouldn‚Äôt take it back. But he wishes he hadn‚Äôt done it. And he doesn‚Äôt know how to make sense of those two feelings.

Lily has gone almost frighteningly still, her face blank.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù and he is. Sorry to both of them. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Lily says finally, her voice careful. Her voice on a tight leash. Like she‚Äôs afraid if she gives it too much length it‚Äôll get away from her.

James‚Äôs surprise must show on his face because she keeps going; ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mean okay, as in ‚Äúit‚Äôs okay‚Äù I mean okay as in‚Ä¶‚Äù she takes a deep breath, frustration and anger and something else all building up around her. ‚ÄúAs in, we‚Äôll talk about this when you‚Äôre not in the middle of having a fucking break down. Okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù the word trembles. ‚ÄúOkay. I‚Äôm sorry. I love y‚Äî‚Äú

She holds up her hand, cutting him off. ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôm going to need you to not say that to me right now.‚Äù

¬†Which hurts, but it‚Äôs not even close to all the other hurt so he barely feels it. Nodding his head because he doesn‚Äôt trust himself to speak. He collapses back against his father‚Äôs desk and pulls his legs in, burying his face in his knees.

He doesn‚Äôt know what else to do.¬†

Doesn‚Äôt know what else to do but sit here and bear it.

He hears shuffling distantly. He assumes it‚Äôs Lily getting up. Walking away. He certainly doesn‚Äôt blame her. Except that a second later he feels the weight of a warm body at his side, and then, with a sigh, an arm wrapping around his shoulders and pulling him into her.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúShh,‚Äù she quiets him. ‚ÄúLater.‚Äù She tucks him under her chin and lets him sob into her shirt.

¬†

¬†

He isn‚Äôt sure how long it is before Lily drags him up to bed. She gets him out of his trousers and shoves him under the covers before putting a sleeping potion in his hand. He‚Äôs grateful, downing it the second he has the cork out, welcoming the blissful emptiness of sleep.

He doesn‚Äôt dream.

When he wakes there‚Äôs light outside. Morning probably, James has never been one to sleep in. There‚Äôs no sign of Lily, her side of the bed unused. His eyes are swollen, his throat sore. James manages to last a whole five minutes of being conscious, of remembering, before he goes to the bathroom and pulls out another sleeping potion, quickly tucking himself back into bed and drifting away again.

The next time his eyes open the sun is setting. According to the clock on the wall it‚Äôs nearly 7:30. He lies in bed for a long time, staring at the ceiling. He feels hollow. And somehow still tired. He doesn‚Äôt want to move. He doesn‚Äôt want to be awake. He doesn‚Äôt want to put one foot in front of the other. He doesn‚Äôt want to get through this.¬†

He does, eventually, manage to pull himself out of bed. Riffling through his dirty clothes for a pair of track pants. The first floor is dark but there‚Äôs a light on in the kitchen. He stops in the doorway when he sees Lily at the table, she‚Äôs in an oversized grey jumper she always wears when she isn‚Äôt feeling well, her hair piled on top of her head, a glass of water between her hands.

James hovers in the doorway, suddenly unsure if he‚Äôs allowed to enter. ‚ÄúH‚Äî‚Äú he has to clear his throat, ‚Äúhey,‚Äù it still comes out scratchy and warn.

She‚Äôs looking at the glass and not at him when she says: ‚ÄúYou should eat.‚Äù

‚ÄúProbably,‚Äù but he doesn‚Äôt move. He‚Äôs almost positive if he tries to eat he‚Äôll throw up. Won‚Äôt make it past the second bite.

After a few more moments of stiff silence Lily sighs. ‚ÄúWell, if you‚Äôre not going to eat then sit down,‚Äù she gestures to the seat across from her. James tries to ignore the small itch in his chest as he sinks down into the chair.

Lily is chewing on her lower lip, expression serious before she brings the water to her mouth and takes a long sip. When the glass bottom hits the table again her eyes don‚Äôt follow it, finding James instead.

‚ÄúGo on then. How exactly did you end up at Regulus Black‚Äôs house a few weeks ago, and why am I only finding out about this now?‚Äù her voice is steady, controlled. Dangerous.

James swallows, scratching at the tabletop, just to have something to do with his hands. ‚ÄúIt was the day of the attack at the Ministry, Regulus was there, he got hurt pretty bad,‚Äù he does his best to push away the memories. To talk clinically. To not let himself think about what he‚Äôs actually saying.

‚ÄúKreacher‚Äîhis house elf‚Äîhe came and found me. Told me Regulus needed help. So I‚Äîso I went with him. Helped patch Regulus up.‚Äù

Lily‚Äôs stare is unwavering, James isn‚Äôt even sure she‚Äôs blinked. Her face a mask. He‚Äôs seen her like this before of course, it‚Äôs the way she looks in a fight. A duel.

‚ÄúAnd then you fucked him, right?‚Äù she asks flatly.

‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo, don‚Äôt you say my name like I‚Äôm being unreasonable. You just told me a few weeks ago you nursed your Death Eater ex-boyfriend back to health after he tried to kill our friends, there is literally nothing I could say right now that could possibly be unreasonable.‚Äù

James takes a deep breath, nails digging into the table, ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt fuck him,‚Äù he says eventually, voice cracking. He needs to keep it together. Lily deserves that much.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a terrible liar James.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt fuck him,‚Äù forcing the words out between his teeth. He sighs, closing his eyes briefly before opening them again. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äîwe kissed.‚Äù

At first Lily doesn‚Äôt react, but then she raises her glass. ‚ÄúCheers.‚Äù

‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou sure do like saying my name. I hope it didn‚Äôt slip out while you were with your boyfriend, that would be well awkward wouldn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

James figures he deserves that.

After a few seconds he sighs, scrubbing at his face with his hands. He wishes he could stop here. Wishes he didn‚Äôt have more to say. Not now that it doesn‚Äôt even matter, now that Regulus is d‚Äîhe feels that thought get stuck in his throat, feels the ache it drags to the surface and attempts to shove it down again.

‚ÄúI asked him to come back with me,‚Äù he‚Äôs staring at some distant spot on the floor when he says it, but he can feel Lily stiffen, feel the new tension crackle between them.

‚ÄúCome back with you? Come back with you where? Here?‚Äù her voice has gone flat again.

This all feels so twisted now. He‚Äôd had this whole speech, been going over the words since he left Grimmauld, it wasn‚Äôt supposed to be this ugly.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he croaks. ‚ÄúYeah here.‚Äù

Silence.

And then she starts to laugh. It‚Äôs enough to make James look up, there‚Äôs a‚Ä¶manic quality to the laughter. Not the way it usually sounds. There‚Äôs no warmth in this. No joy. No comfort. He isn‚Äôt sure when she starts crying. When the tears start slipping from her eyes, and the subtle shift occurs from giggle to sob. He feels his whole body cave in.

‚ÄúOh Lily,‚Äù he says before he can stop himself.

She only shakes her head at him, getting to her feet and walking over to the counter, bracing her hands against it. He wants desperately to go to her, to gather her up in his arms, but he knows that‚Äôs about the last thing in the world she wants right now so he stays in his seat.

Several seconds pass before Lily inhales, her breath hitching slightly on the way out. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù her voice is impressively steady, if not a little thick. ‚ÄúI told myself I wasn‚Äôt going to do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to apologize to me.‚Äù

She lets out a dry laugh. ‚ÄúI know. I‚Äôm mostly apologizing to myself.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know what to say to that so he just waits for her to keep going.

‚ÄúWhat is this James?‚Äù she asks finally, she almost sounds scared. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre having a baby‚Äîfuck‚Äù she gasps like even saying that hurts right now, head dropping between her arms. ‚ÄúWhat is going on?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know.

That‚Äôs the reason he hasn‚Äôt been able to‚Ä¶talk about it.

He doesn‚Äôt know what this is.

What‚Äôs going on.

‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù he manages finally, causing her to scoff, but he keeps going before she can react. ‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù he squeezes his eyes shut. ‚ÄúBut I love him too.‚Äù

And it is love.

Love.

In the present.

Always.

Time or space or death.

It will always be love.

‚ÄúSo what was the plan James?‚Äù she still isn‚Äôt facing him. ‚ÄúYou were just going to bring him back with you and‚Ä¶put him up in our guest room?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

‚ÄúWere you going to leave me?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo? Just have someone else around for you to kiss then? When you got bored?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James says frustrated. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. I‚ÄîLily he was so lost. He needed help.‚Äù

She laughs, shaking her head and turning to face him. ‚ÄúYeah, they always do don‚Äôt they? And we‚Äôre gonna be the ones to fix them right? To save them? That‚Äôs what we tell ourselves?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat are you talking about?‚Äù

She arches her brow. ‚ÄúYou think I don‚Äôt know what it‚Äôs like to care about someone on the wrong side of this war?‚Äù

It takes James far too long to work out what she means. ‚ÄúRegulus isn‚Äôt Snape. Snape had a choice.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd so did Regulus. Sirius is proof of that.‚Äù

James only shakes his head. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that simple.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd things with Severus are?‚Äù

He grits his teeth. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause you don‚Äôt love him?‚Äù Lily asks coldly.

That question takes him off guard. ‚ÄúAre you telling me you‚Äôre in love with Snape?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù razor sharp, eyes pinning James to his chair. When her words come she delivers them slowly, pushing each one in deep. ‚ÄúWould that hurt you?‚Äù

Yes, James thinks automatically. Realizing, of course, the hypocrisy of it.

‚ÄúCan you imagine,‚Äù Lily goes on. ‚ÄúWhat you would have done if I invited Severus to come live with us? If I had kissed him?‚Äù James opens and closes his mouth, unable to answer.

It‚Äôs different, his thoughts scream.

It is.

It has to be.

He doesn‚Äôt say it.

He knows it isn‚Äôt true.

Eventually he sighs, dropping his head into his hands, resting his elbows on his knees. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúI know what a mess this is. I know how fucking unfair it is. I just‚Äî‚Äú his voice cuts out for a minute and he has to wait for it to come back. ‚ÄúI love you both so much. I just wanted you to be safe. I just wanted to take care of you.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a long silence. It feels like neither of them is even breathing. Both holding themselves still, waiting for everything to shatter.

‚ÄúYou have such a big heart James,‚Äù Lily says eventually, which is not at all what he was expecting. He looks up, meeting her eyes. ‚ÄúReally, it‚Äôs incredible, it is. But sometimes‚Ä¶‚Äù she trails off, shaking her head like she can‚Äôt find the words, ‚Äúsometimes you feel so much you forget to think. Sometimes James,‚Äù green eyes right on him, ‚Äúyou can be so fucking thoughtless.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt manage to suppress his wince. ‚ÄúI know,‚Äù his voice splinters. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

It isn‚Äôt enough.

Not even close.

After another endless stretch of silence that leaves James feeling mildly sick Lily sighs. She walks back to her chair but doesn‚Äôt sit down, instead pulling something out from under the table. A bag. James‚Äôs pulse starts racing.

‚ÄúLily?‚Äù he sounds desperate even to his own ears.

She slips the bag over her shoulder. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go to Mary‚Äôs for a bit. Until I can‚Ä¶sort this out.‚Äù

James feels something scrape along the inside of his stomach, hands trembling between his knees. He doesn‚Äôt know what to say. He just knows that looking at her standing there with a bag swung over her shoulder makes him want to break things.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù he manages finally. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want you to go.‚Äù

Her eyes are sad, maybe even a little wet, and after a few seconds she walks over, placing her hand on the back of his head and bending down to kiss his hair.

‚ÄúCall someone okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you should be alone right now,‚Äù she pushes on, no longer looking at him. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want you to be alone. I just‚Äîit can‚Äôt be me James. Not this time.‚Äù

She‚Äôs walking away.

And he doesn‚Äôt know what to do.

Doesn‚Äôt know how to stop it.

‚ÄúWhen will you be back?‚Äù he finds himself asking as she reaches the doorway. Her hand is gripping the strap of her bag so tightly he swears she‚Äôs going to snap it. They sit in silence for so long that James starts to feel a new anxiety bubbling under his skin.

‚ÄúYou‚Äîyou are coming back, right?‚Äù

She hangs her head for a minute before looking at him over her shoulder. She gives him a weak smile but her eyes are glistening. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

No.

No.

No.

‚ÄúLook, I‚Äôm‚ÄîI need to talk to someone,‚Äù her face screws up for a second. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to tell Mary what‚Äôs happened‚Ä¶is that okay?‚Äù

At first, in all the horribleness that‚Äôs happening inside him right now, James can‚Äôt understand what she‚Äôs asking. And then it hits him.

‚ÄúMary already knows,‚Äù and at the look on her face; ‚ÄúNot‚Äîjust that we were together in school,‚Äù god it all hurts so much. ‚ÄúMarlene knows too, and I reckon Alice has a pretty good idea about it,‚Äù no point lying.

A small laugh falls from Lily‚Äôs mouth. Desperately sad. ‚ÄúJames Potter and Regulus Black, the worst kept secret in the Wizarding World. But then, you never could love quietly,‚Äù he sees her mouth twitch and knows she‚Äôs trying not to cry. ‚ÄúI know that better than most people I imagine.‚Äù

"Lily,‚Äù he reaches for her.

Don‚Äôt leave.

Don‚Äôt go.

He wants to get down on his knees and beg.

But she only shakes her head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you James.‚Äù

He can‚Äôt speak. Can‚Äôt move. Watches her walk away. Listens as the front door slams behind her.

He‚Äôs lost them both.

After all of that.

He‚Äôs lost them both.¬†

¬†

¬†

He goes back to bed. Pulls the blankets around himself and buries himself deep. You‚Äôd think sleeping would be hard, considering he can‚Äôt possibly be tired, but it isn‚Äôt. The minute his head hits the pillow the warm dark creeps up and pulls him under. It reminds him vaguely of something Madam Pomfrey said once, when she was talking about Remus waking up after his transformations: it helps if you want to wake up. Want to come back to yourself.

James doesn‚Äôt want either of those things.

When his eyes do eventually blink open they‚Äôre heavy and crusted. He reaches up to wipe them clean, his whole body aching. He doesn‚Äôt know what time it is. Or what day honestly. The curtains are drawn so he can‚Äôt see if it‚Äôs light or dark outside. For a while he just lies there, hoping he‚Äôll be able to drift away again, but when it becomes apparent that that isn‚Äôt going to happen he forces himself to sit up.

The room is dark and stale. He smells like sweat, his mouth dry. He can‚Äôt remember the last time he ate or showered. Two days? Or has it been three? Eventually his eyes find the clock on the wall. 5:00 AM it tells him. Did Lily leave last night? The night before?

He pulls himself out of bed, dots prickling across his vision as he gets momentarily light headed, walking on unsteady legs down the hall to the bathroom and turning on the shower. He makes the water burn the way he always did after a bad Quidditch match. The pain of the scalding water on his skin feels good. He stands in it until the water starts to go cold, then pulls himself out, drying quickly and not bothering to look in the mirror. He doesn‚Äôt want to see himself.

He dresses in a Quidditch jumper and baggy tracky bottoms, before heading downstairs. The light in the kitchen is still on. Lily‚Äôs water glass still sitting on the table. He stares at it for a while before picking it up and throwing it‚Äîperhaps a bit aggressively‚Äîinto the sink.¬†

He needs to eat something, he‚Äôs already feeling like he‚Äôs going to pass out but impossibly he still isn‚Äôt hungry. He makes some toast anyway. Butters it and forces it down his throat. It‚Äôs the only thing he can manage.¬†

After he finishes he just sits at the table for a while. Staring into space. He still feels like he‚Äôs asleep in someways. His brain, his body‚Äîtired and sluggish. Everything a little bit dull. A little bit fuzzy. Eventually he forces himself to get up, to go call Sirius. To make sure he‚Äôs okay. He tries the flat but no one answers. Not Sirius. Not Remus. After that he tries Peter just‚Äîjust because he could use a friendly face. But there‚Äôs no answer there either.

He ends up returning to the bedroom, still with the curtains drawn and the lights out. Still dark even though it must be nearly mid-morning by now. He stands in front of the door, not really knowing what to do, until his eyes snag on the dresser. It‚Äôs a bad idea, he knows that even before he starts moving, but it doesn‚Äôt stop him.

He throws open the first drawer, scrambling around for the box hidden at the back, feeling his breath hitch when his fingers wrap around it. He holds it gently in his hand, thumb running over the smooth wooden lid as he stumbles back until he‚Äôs sitting down on the end of his bed.

He remembers when Reg gave this to him. Remembers it so clearly.

Did you get me a present?

Don‚Äôt make this into a big thing.

That‚Äôs adorable.

Fuck you.

Oh my god you were going to wrap it and everything! Did you get me a bow?

I honestly hate you so much.

Nah, I don‚Äôt think so. You don‚Äôt get Christmas gifts for people you hate.

He should never have let him go home that Christmas. He should have put him in a full-body bind. Should have carried him to Godric‚Äôs Hollow over his shoulder.

It wouldn‚Äôt have mattered,

mutters the voice in his head.

He already had the Mark by then.

Well then he shouldn‚Äôt have let him go home for the summer. Or the Christmas before. He should have listened to his mother. Should have gone and gotten him the minute Sirius showed up on his doorstep.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù the tears have started again and he wipes at them uselessly with his sleeve. "Fuck Reg.‚Äù He opens the lid, the little red ball sitting there, J R proudly facing out.

I want to give you everything James.

Everything.

With a shaking hand James reaches for it, but the minute he touches it he knows something is wrong. He lets it roll into his palm, watches it sit there. Motionless.

It‚Äôs the magic.

The magic is gone.

James wraps it up tightly in his hand, lying back on the bed and curling in on himself, the wooden box dropping to the ground as he clutches the ball to his chest.

Eventually he manages to fall asleep again.

¬†

¬†

He still has no idea how much time has passed. Everything blurs together, none of the lines of his life clear. But when he manages to pull himself out of bed again Lily still isn‚Äôt home. The house is still empty. The kitchen light still on. The Quaffle still refusing to fly. James slips it into his pocket. He thinks it‚Äôs morning again but he can‚Äôt be sure. Forces himself to scarf down another buttered piece of toast.

He tries Sirius, but there‚Äôs still no answer at the flat. He considers calling Mary‚Äôs but he knows that would be a mistake. Lily needs space. He owes her that. He‚Äôs about to go back to bed when something tapping at the kitchen window catches his attention.

He finds a very irate owl waiting for him, holding today‚Äôs paper in its mouth and standing on yesterday‚Äôs neglected copy.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù James says when he opens the window, relieving the owl of his delivery. He‚Äôs a small, auburn coloured thing and he glares mutinously at James, stamping his clawed feet on yesterday‚Äôs paper.

‚ÄúYeah, yeah, I know‚Äîer‚Äî‚Äú he looks around, fumbling for the can of owl treats they keep by the window. ‚ÄúHere you go,‚Äù he offers up a generous handful which seems to have the bird mollified. Or at least he doesn‚Äôt peck James‚Äôs eyes out before he flies off, which James counts as a win.

He throws both papers on the table, halfway out of the room when something starts nagging at him. So he picks up one of the copies and skims through it. Not entirely sure what he‚Äôs looking for until he finds it: a tiny box at the bottom of one of the last pages. An obituary. There‚Äôs no picture, no fanfare, nothing like it should be considering the importance of the subject.

Regulus A. Black

is bolded at the top of the small paragraph of text which reads:

Died in tragic accident, survived by his two parents: Walburga and Orion Black. Regulus was a Hogwarts Prefect and Seeker for the Slytherin Quidditch team. He will be dearly missed by all who knew him. His final resting place is to be the family crypt in Highgate Cemetery, London.

And that‚Äôs it.

That‚Äôs all there is.

James stares at that square for a long time, hands shaking. After all that Walburga did to him, all she put him through, all he gave up for her‚Äîthis is all she gives him? He isn‚Äôt sure why he‚Äôs surprised.

Before he knows what he‚Äôs doing James drops the paper back down on the table and heads for the door. Grabbing his jacket as he slips outside. Apparating as soon as he‚Äôs passed the wards.¬† ¬†

You can‚Äôt Apparate into cemeteries directly, of course. It only took one person ending up in an empty grave for that restriction to be put in place, so James finds himself on the pavement outside of Highgate. The front entrance looks almost like a castle‚Äîmade of grey stone with tiny turrets above the gate. All very medieval.

James walks forward, not knowing exactly where he‚Äôs headed, except that he‚Äôs looking for a mausoleum with the Black family name on it. It‚Äôs cold and James pulls his jacket more firmly around himself, the ground beneath his feet covered in a light dusting of snow. He walks through rows of headstones, along the winding gravel pathways, everything looking like it‚Äôs from another time. Even the trees, now bare without their leaves, have an ancient quality to them‚Äîto their thick twisting trunks and reaching branches that seem almost to be guarding the bodies below them.

He isn‚Äôt sure how long he‚Äôs walking for before he sees it‚Äîa small rectangular stone building, columns on either side of the door which has a stained glass window making up the top half. It shows a snake. That‚Äôs what catches his eye first, the dim light sparkling off the green glass. And then his eyes travel up to the ornately carved name above;

Black

It‚Äôs only when he ‚Äôs standing in front of it that he realizes he has no idea why he‚Äôs come. Regulus isn‚Äôt even here. And maybe that‚Äôs for the best. This place looks fucking depressing. Besides, Regulus was never meant to be shut-up underground. He always belonged in the sky.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre late,‚Äù a voice croaks, thin and frail and barely carried on the wind. ‚ÄúThe funeral was yesterday.‚Äù

James turns around to see an old man being pushed towards him by a vaguely familiar looking girl with dark brown hair. When her eyes meet James‚Äôs she gasps.

‚ÄúJames Potter?‚Äù¬†

It takes him a minute to place her. He knows they went to school together but he didn‚Äôt have many interactions with Cerci Greengrass, only vaguely knew her as a Prefect and Regulus‚Äôs friend. His eyes drop back down to the old man‚Äîthin, wispy strands of white hair haloing his head.

‚ÄúEr‚Äîhi.‚Äù He hadn‚Äôt expected to run into anyone and he isn‚Äôt exactly sure what to do now. Cerci is currently looking at him like she thinks he‚Äôs some kind of hallucination and he‚Äôs trying to remember whether or not he should be afraid of her. He feels like as a general rule it‚Äôs best to be afraid of most of Reg‚Äôs friends.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing here?‚Äù she asks, she hasn‚Äôt moved since she spotted him so her and the old man are still several feet away.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶‚Äù but he doesn‚Äôt know what to say. Doesn‚Äôt want to tell them anything because, well, Reg never wanted anyone to know about them. It feels wrong somehow, to break his trust, even now. Maybe especially now. James grits his teeth as something aching hollows out his chest.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs here for my son, yes? At least one of them,‚Äù the old man squints. ‚ÄúThough which one I‚Äôm not sure.‚Äù

James feels his mouth go dry. ‚ÄúYour son?‚Äù he repeats.

The last time he saw Orion Black in the flesh he was maybe seven or eight. At some Ministry function his father dragged him to a few years before he went to Hogwarts. Orion had felt like a giant to James then; six-five, head and shoulders above everyone else, and strong too, like a Quidditch player, a beater‚Äîbroad shoulders pressing against the fabric of his robes. His hair had been dark and slicked back, his face full, square, solid.

The man before him now is‚Ä¶unrecognizable.

Cerci seems to wake up all of the sudden because she starts pushing him forward again. Orion‚Äôs eyes firmly on the mausoleum in front of them, Cerci‚Äôs still firmly on James. Her gaze has taken on a new scrutinizing quality he doesn‚Äôt appreciate.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre Fleamont‚Äôs boy?‚Äù Orion says, as they stop beside him.

James blinks, surprised by the question. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîyeah.‚Äù

Orion nods slowly. ‚ÄúI liked Fleamont.‚Äù James snorts before he can stop himself, earning him a sidelong look from Orion. The old man‚Äôs lips twitch upward. ‚ÄúNot personally, perhaps, but he was smart, which is more than I can say for most people, and he was honest. Blunt. Never afraid of me. I appreciated that as well.‚Äù

James just stares at him, knowing full well his father would have hated being anything that Orion Black appreciated.¬† ¬†

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame,‚Äù the old man goes on, ‚Äúwhat happened to him and your mother.‚Äù

It‚Äôs work for James to restrain himself from reacting the way he wants to. Which would be by decking Orion in the face.

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt a natural disaster,‚Äù he says finally, voice tight, causing Orion to look up at him. ‚ÄúIt didn‚Äôt just happen. It was done. They were poisoned. Though I expect you know that.‚Äù

Orion holds his gaze, a shell of the intimidating man he once was. Regulus had cared deeply for his father, James knows that, it‚Äôs unfortunate that his father didn‚Äôt care as much for him. That he couldn‚Äôt bring himself to protect his sons.

‚ÄúI merely meant that things could have been different,‚Äù Orion says finally.

James nods, barely restraining his anger. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why we‚Äôre here isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù he gestures to the building in front of them and Orion‚Äôs eyes follow him.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he says quietly. ‚ÄúI suppose it is.‚Äù

They stand in silence, staring at the gothic structure, a few hundred years old at least, rust and mold gathering in the sharp corners, making the stone darker.

‚ÄúYou never did say who you were here for,‚Äù Orion goes on eventually. ‚ÄúSirius or Regulus?‚Äù James looks down at him.

‚ÄúSirius isn‚Äôt dead.‚Äù Even suggesting he could be sends a spark of fear shooting through James‚Äôs chest. ‚ÄúAnd if he was I wouldn‚Äôt bring him here.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good to know, though it isn‚Äôt what I meant,‚Äù Orion says, and then, after a moment, ‚ÄúSirius has always needed you to do a great deal for him. It would not surprise me if he needed you to mourn his brother for him as well.‚Äù

For the second time James has to resist the urge to punch him. Cerci must sense this because he notices her shifting Orion‚Äôs chair slightly further away from him.

‚ÄúWhat the hell makes you think you know anything about Sirius?‚Äù

Watery grey eyes meet James‚Äôs and he‚Äôs struck, suddenly, by how much they look alike. All of them.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs my son.‚Äù

James stares at him. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says after a few seconds. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs Fleamont‚Äôs son.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a flare of something in Orion‚Äôs eyes but James can‚Äôt tell what‚Äîanger? Pain? Orion might have his sons‚Äô eyes but the rest of his face is nothing like them. Full of feelings, lines crisscrossing, scars telling stories. There is so much emotion woven into Orion‚Äôs features that James feels overwhelmed. Doesn‚Äôt know which one‚Äôs he‚Äôs caused and which ones were already there.

‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre not here for Sirius then,‚Äù the old man says eventually, voice slightly more strained.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre here for Regulus,‚Äù no longer a question, but James answers anyway.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

The two men continue to stare at one another, neither backing down or looking away. Orion is now regarding James with the same scrutiny he‚Äôs been receiving from Cerci this whole time.

‚ÄúRegulus told me once,‚Äù the old man finally goes on, ‚Äúabout a boy he was in love with.‚Äù

And that.

That James wasn‚Äôt expecting.

He didn‚Äôt think Regulus had ever told anyone about them. Let alone his father. It makes him feel wrong footed. The floor under him tilting somewhat.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù because it‚Äôs all he can manage.

Orion either doesn‚Äôt hear him or chooses to ignore him, pressing on; ‚ÄúHe told me that this boy was kind and honourable and handsome.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe used pretty with me,‚Äù Cerci pipes up, and James looks at her.

Both of them? Regulus told both of them?

Suddenly James is having trouble breathing again, and he doesn‚Äôt want to completely lose it. Not here. Not in front of Orion Black of all people. But this grief is still fresh and he hasn‚Äôt figured out how to hold it yet. ¬† ¬† ¬†

He takes a few steps away, turning his back to them and grabbing hold of his knees. His breaths come in short gasps as James desperately tries to push the stinging in his eyes away. He needs to be stronger than this. What is he gonna do when Sirius comes home? Remus? Lily? He needs to have it together.

He feels a gentle hand press between his shoulder blades and when he looks up he sees Cerci standing beside him.

‚ÄúSlow now,‚Äù she says softly. ‚ÄúBreathe in with me yeah?‚Äù She inhales and James follows. She exhales and James follows. Once. Twice. Three times.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think he told anyone,‚Äù his voice makes it out somehow. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think he wanted anyone to know. He never wanted me to tell anyone I thought‚Ä¶‚Äù he squeezes his eyes shut.

What had he thought? What does it matter? Hardly their biggest problem. Or maybe it was. Because as long as Regulus wanted to keep them a secret it meant that he didn‚Äôt want things to change. Didn‚Äôt want to jeopardize his place here, in this world. It meant he didn‚Äôt want something different with James. Or if he did, he was too afraid to do anything more than dream about it. It meant he thought they were doomed.

‚ÄúAh well, Regulus was always a bit of a dragon with his feelings wasn‚Äôt he?‚Äù Cerci says, hand still on James‚Äôs back even as he straightens up. When he stares at her she explains; ‚ÄúGuarded them like gold.‚Äù

James manages to laugh wetly. ‚ÄúNot always.‚Äù

Cerci‚Äôs eyes soften. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says quietly. ‚ÄúNot always.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou managed to make both my boys fall in love with you James Potter,‚Äù Orion draws their attention back to him, sitting in front of the crypt that has no more of Regulus than his name but is still somehow the closest any of them can get to him now. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll have to tell me your secret.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt respond, certain he couldn‚Äôt manage anything civil. Instead he turns towards the mausoleum, eyes running over the decrepit exterior one more time before he lifts his wand. Flowers begin to sprout from the snowy ground, bright and colourful, vines with small blossoms pouring from the roof and wrapping around the pillars. He makes the stained glass shine.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs beautiful,‚Äù Cerci says quietly from beside him.

Finally, he faces Orion again, the old man watching him intently. ‚ÄúRegulus deserved better than this,‚Äù and he doesn‚Äôt just mean the crypt. He means all of it. It wasn‚Äôt fair, childish as it might be to say, everything he went through, it wasn‚Äôt fair. Someone should have stopped it. Someone should have helped. He doesn‚Äôt know why he didn‚Äôt‚Äîwhy he failed. It‚Äôs all muddled in his brain now. How he let this happen.¬†

Orion is quiet for a long time, tongue running over his cracked lips. ‚ÄúWe do our best.‚Äù

‚ÄúWas this your best?‚Äù James asks, nodding his head towards the grave, watching the old man wince. ‚ÄúBecause it sure as hell wasn‚Äôt mine.‚Äù

He watches as Orion‚Äôs grey eyes bounce around, agitated, anxious, watches him fidget in his seat. Cerci walks over to him, places a comforting hand on his shoulder, but Orion barely seems to notice her.

‚ÄúI tried to‚Ä¶to show them how to‚Ä¶navigate this world. But I could never save Sirius from himself. In the end‚Ä¶I could not save Regulus either.‚Äù

James stares at him. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it was themselves they needed saving from.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, well, you are young. You do not understand that you cannot simply do whatever you want or have whatever you want. Life is treacherous and you must be smarter than that. You must‚Ä¶how do you say‚Ä¶‚Äù his brow furrows, frustrated with himself. ‚ÄúIf you wish to survive in this world you must never forget who the gods are and your place next to them. My sons‚Ä¶‚Äù sadness fills his eyes. ‚ÄúRegulus forgot.‚Äù

The wind rattles through the naked branches surrounding them and James sees Orion shiver, sees Cerci murmur a quiet warming charm, sees the dampness on the old man‚Äôs cheeks.

‚ÄúVoldemort isn‚Äôt a god.‚Äù

That makes Orion laugh. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think so?‚Äù he asks amused. ‚ÄúI have seen many things but never anything like him. He has the world on its knees. Power beyond anything we have ever seen. You believe he is just like you or I? Truly? Just a man?‚Äù

James grits his teeth. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd what about Albus Dumbledore then? Is he nothing but a man? Do you not make sacrifices at his alter, hoping he will keep you safe? Protect the people you love?‚Äù

James flounders for a moment. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt make us sacrifice things to him.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo?‚Äù still with that same dark amusement. ‚ÄúYou make all your own decisions? You follow all your own orders? He does not tell you where or how to be?‚Äù

James opens and closes his mouth, frustrated when he finds himself with nothing to say. Trying not to think of all the secrets that exist between him and his friends at Dumbledore‚Äôs request. Of all the days that someone is missing and no one knows if they‚Äôre dead or just on a mission. How little control they have over their own lives.

Orion nods, taking his silence as confirmation. ‚ÄúBe careful mon fils, you would do well to remember what power you play with. If not for your own sake than for your father‚Äôs.‚Äù

That catches James off guard, every mention of his parents making his heart feel tender. Delicate. More than it did already. ‚ÄúMy dad is dead,‚Äù he says, unable to further explain himself. That nothing he does can hurt his parents now. Can help them. Can heal them.

Orion smiles sadly. ‚ÄúI could be in the depths of Hades, and I promise you I would still feel the loss of my boys like a dagger in my heart.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know if Sirius has any idea that his father still feels this way, to this day. That he talks about his sons. Plural, always. That he doesn‚Äôt deny him the way that Regulus‚Äôs obituary did. The way Walburga seems to. But then, if Orion loves him, it makes it all so much more egregious. Because how do you let someone you love be torn apart the way Sirius was? The way Regulus was? How do you stand by and do nothing?

James would fight the heavens if he needed to.

If that‚Äôs what it took.

To keep them safe.

Let the gods come.

They‚Äôve been standing in the cold for a while, small snowflakes beginning to peel off the clouds overhead, James‚Äôs hands going numb. He gives the mausoleum one last look but doesn‚Äôt feel anything. Whatever he was looking for it isn‚Äôt here. Regulus isn‚Äôt here.¬†

‚ÄúI should go,‚Äù he says finally, not sure if it‚Äôs necessary. ‚ÄúIt was‚Ä¶interesting meeting you,‚Äù he gives Cerci a curt nod as he starts walking away, hands shoved in his pockets.

‚ÄúWill you tell Sirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James cuts Orion off before he can start, looking back at the old man from the gravel path. ‚ÄúIf you have something to say to him he deserves the curtesy of hearing it from your mouth. I‚Äôm not passing along messages.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a small pause before Orion smiles. ‚ÄúC‚Äôest bon. You will protect him yes?‚Äù

‚ÄúWith my life.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat is all I can ask.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not doing it for you,‚Äù James says shortly, but Orion doesn‚Äôt seem bothered, only nodding his head.

‚ÄúGoodbye James Potter, I doubt very much we shall speak again.‚Äù

James has nothing to say to that, so he pushes through the snow, teeth starting to chatter as he heads for the gates.

‚ÄúWait!‚Äù

It isn‚Äôt Orion causing him to pause this time‚ÄîCerci Greengrass running up the path towards him.

‚ÄúWait,‚Äù she huffs, breath coming out in great clouds as she stumbles to a stop in front of him, her cheeks flushed, Orion watching them in the distance.

‚ÄúI have something for you,‚Äù she‚Äôs barely able to get the words out.

James arches his brow. ‚ÄúFor me?‚Äù

She nods. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been boxing up some of his stuff, for his parents,‚Äù she goes on. ‚ÄúAnd I found a letter‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt know who it was for, he didn‚Äôt use a full name, but it‚Äôs addressed to J and‚Ä¶well, I assume that‚Äôs you?‚Äù

James‚Äôs stomach drops. ‚ÄúA letter‚ÄîRegulus wrote me a letter?‚Äù

I have something for you.

I thought about writing one for every day, but it seemed excessive.

‚ÄúCan you wait for me? I just have to take him home,‚Äù she gestures to Orion over her shoulder. ‚ÄúBut if you go to Grimmauld I‚Äôll meet you there.‚Äù

I‚Äôm not sure I understand‚Ä¶

Well I know‚ÄîI know I can‚Äôt send you post, over the summer, so, I thought I‚Äôd give them to you now.

Cerci waves her hand in front of his face. ‚ÄúJames?‚Äù

He blinks, his head feeling heavy. ‚ÄúSorry? What?‚Äù

She gives him a curious look but doesn‚Äôt question it. ‚Äú12 Grimmauld, you know where that is?‚Äù

He almost laughs. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù gruffly. ‚ÄúI know where that is.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you‚Äôll wait for me? It won‚Äôt take me long to Apparate Mr. Black back to Scotland and then I can give you the letter.‚Äù

They‚Äôre all dated so you can read them like I‚Äôm sending them to you in real time. I just thought‚Ä¶I didn‚Äôt want you to be alone all summer. Maybe that‚Äôs dumb‚Äîactually‚Äînow that I‚Äôm saying it out loud it‚Äôs definitely dumb. Sorry, you don‚Äôt have to‚Äî

‚ÄúI‚Äôll wait for you,‚Äù he manages to get out.

Cerci nods, snow peppering her dark hair. ‚ÄúGood. I think he‚Äôd want that,‚Äù something sad flashes across her face but in the next moment she‚Äôs gone, jogging back to Orion‚Äôs side.

Thank you. I love them. I love you.

¬†

¬†

James feels uneasy standing outside Grimmauld Place. The scratching of grief in his chest growing more insistent, his brain dragging up images of the last time he was here.
