He bounces impatiently back and forth between his feet, trying to keep them from going numb. His teeth chattering so hard they nearly chop his tongue in half once or twice. He could cast a warming charm, he‚Äôs not sure why he doesn‚Äôt. The windows of Grimmauld watching him.

He starts at the sound of a ‚Äúpop‚Äù turning his head to find Cerci walking down the pavement towards him.

‚ÄúSorry, Walburga is sometimes a little challenging to get away from.‚Äù

James can‚Äôt help the snort that comes out of him. The fucking irony. ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôve noticed,‚Äù he says dryly.

Cerci only nods, gesturing to the house in front of them and sighing. ‚ÄúWell, shall we?‚Äù she takes a step towards it but James shakes his head.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll wait here,‚Äù he eyes the building before looking away, the thought of stepping inside there again right now makes his stomach drop.

He sees the question on Cerci‚Äôs face and then he sees her swallow it. She looks back at the house and James thinks she‚Äôs going to keep going but she doesn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúHe told me you took him on a date to a waterfall once, is that true?‚Äù

James blinks, the question coming so out of left field he‚Äôs not even sure he really heard it. ‚ÄúI‚Äîhe called it a date?‚Äù

She shoots him a look. ‚ÄúWas it not one?‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean‚Äîyes‚ÄîI just‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, I didn‚Äôt think he‚Äôd see it that way.‚Äù Apparently James understood very little about how Regulus saw them. He wishes he could talk to him one more time. Or two more times. Or a thousand more times. That he could hear all of this from him.¬† ¬†

Cerci considers James for a moment before speaking again. ‚ÄúRegulus saw good things as being fragile. Talk too much about them and they're more likely to break. But you should know, that when he let himself take you out, the way his face would brighten,‚Äù she shakes her head, smiling. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd never seen him like that. So I don‚Äôt know if he somehow managed to make you think this thing between you wasn‚Äôt precious to him, but I promise you it was.‚Äù

James‚Äôs whole body has gone tense with the effort of not falling apart, not crumbling to pieces on the side of the road. Somehow he manages to nod stiffly. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he practically whispers.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Cerci replies, in a similarly soft tone. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôll just go get that letter shall I?‚Äù she takes the front steps two at a time, the door practically swinging open for her when she gets to the top.

‚ÄúHello Kreacher,‚Äù James can hear her sing before it closes again.

James exhales, eyes shutting briefly as he tries to fight back the overwhelming desire to cease existing. To fight back the parts of him that are certain he will never find his way out of this pain.

His eyes snap back open at the sound of the door closing again. Cerci doesn‚Äôt bother to look both ways before she jogs across the street, an envelope in her hand.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù she says when she reaches him, ‚Äúhere we are then.‚Äù

James stares at it for a minute, stomach tangling itself in knots before he‚Äôs finally able to reach out a shaking hand. He sees it there, scrawled across the front. No address, no name. Just the letter J.

‚ÄúDo you know when he wrote this?‚Äù he asks, staring down at it, held delicately between his two hands.

‚ÄúNo, I mean, I can guess. But I don‚Äôt know for sure.‚Äù

His eyes flick up to her. ‚ÄúGuess then.‚Äù Because if it‚Äôs before‚Äîbefore Kreacher brought him here, before everything that happened on that day, James doesn‚Äôt know if he‚Äôll be able to bear reading it.

But then, maybe he won‚Äôt be able to bear it either way.

‚ÄúA few days before he died‚Äîwell, before he disappeared in any case‚Äîwe came across some love letters. Regulus was a little obsessed with them,‚Äù she smiles again. ‚ÄúIn the letters, the author only ever used initials for him and his lover, so..‚Äù

She trails off, gestures to the front of the envelope.

J

James thinks of the wall back at Hogwarts.

Thinks of the Quaffle in his back pocket.

Somehow, it feels so wrong. To see the J all on its own.

Stupid thing to think.

He shakes his head, slipping the letter into his jacket. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he says to Cerci, meeting her warm brown eyes.

She nods. ‚ÄúLike I said, I think he would have wanted this. I‚Äôm glad I found you.‚Äù

He wracks his brain for memories of her at school but he still can‚Äôt come up with much. He knows Regulus mentioned her but he can‚Äôt think of anything specific.

‚ÄúYou cared about him,‚Äù he says, a bit redundantly, but Cerci doesn‚Äôt seem to mind.

‚ÄúMore than anything,‚Äù there‚Äôs the smallest fraying at the ends of her words, though the smile doesn‚Äôt slip from her face. ‚ÄúHe was my partner.‚Äù

James has no idea how to take that. Honestly he isn‚Äôt sure he wants to know. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad that-‚Äù his voice breaks and he has to force himself to press forward. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad that he had you. That he wasn‚Äôt‚Ä¶alone‚Ä¶in there,‚Äù he nods towards the house in front of him.¬†

For the first time he sees her mask crack, pain flooding her eyes. ‚ÄúI should have been here more.‚Äù

James almost laughs. ‚ÄúYeah, well,‚Äù he clears his throat. ‚ÄúWe all should have been. Fat lot of good that does him now.‚Äù

Cerci looks at him pityingly, and he can‚Äôt stand the idea of whatever it is she‚Äôs going to say next to try and make him feel better. Try and make either of them feel better. When he isn‚Äôt sure they deserve to.

‚ÄúThank you, again, for the letter,‚Äù he says briskly, and before anymore can be said he‚Äôs throwing himself through space. Desperate to get as far away from that house as he fucking can.

¬†

¬†

His aim is a little off. It happens when he‚Äôs upset. Or drunk. So he ends up a few streets over instead of in front of his house. Exhausted and cursing himself, he flicks the collar of his jacket up against the wind and crosses his arms over his chest, tucking his hands in to shield them from the cold. Too afraid to use his pockets. To crush the letter. To touch it. He swears he can feel it weighing him down, even though he knows that‚Äôs irrational.

He spends most of the walk staring at the ground, so he doesn‚Äôt notice that someone‚Äôs waiting for him until he‚Äôs half-way to his front door. Looking up and stopping dead in his tracks.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Frank says, getting up off the steps. James just stares at him‚Äîprobably for longer than is socially acceptable.

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú Frank bounces on the balls of his feet. ‚ÄúAny chance we could talk inside? I‚Äôm kinda freezing here.‚Äù

That wakes James up. ‚ÄúRight. Yeah. Of course, sorry.‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt know why his voice sounds like that‚Äîall choked up. Well, okay, he does know. Because he‚Äôs fucking lonely. Because he‚Äôs so glad that Frank is here.

He fumbles a bit with the door, feeling entirely twisted up and all over the place and too fucking raw.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù Frank says as he steps inside, stamping his boots clean on the welcome matt. ‚ÄúYou really need to increase the strength of your wards, I was able to just walk right up here.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell yeah, you‚Äôre keyed in,‚Äù James shrugs his coat off, hanging it on one of the hooks by the front door and enjoying the momentary relief of finally being somewhere warm. He eyes his coat pocket for a minute but decides he‚Äôd rather not have to explain the letter to Frank.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm keyed into your wards?‚Äù Frank sounds surprised, following James into the kitchen. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve only been here twice.‚Äù

‚ÄúThree times now,‚Äù James says, opening the fridge and pulling out two bottles of butterbeer. He offers one to Frank who is looking, James thinks, unreasonably aghast.

‚ÄúJames, how many people are keyed into your wards?‚Äù he asks very seriously. They sit down at the table.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù James shrugs. ‚ÄúFifteen? Twenty?‚Äù

‚ÄúTwenty! Have you not read any of the safety protocol the Order sent out?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Ä¶I think I read the first few?‚Äù In truth, he read ‚ÄúSafety Protocol‚Äù and then immediately put it down.

‚ÄúMerlin,‚Äù Frank looks genuinely distressed. ‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt supposed to have more than five people keyed into your wards at a time.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? That‚Äôs ridiculous,‚Äù he takes a sip of his drink and then; ‚ÄúWait, does that mean I‚Äôm not keyed into your wards?‚Äù

Frank rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou shouldn‚Äôt be‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù

‚Äú‚Äîbut Alice isn‚Äôt exactly following protocol either.‚Äù

That sounds about right.

James snorts. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve alway liked that girl.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah well, it‚Äôs an ongoing discussion.‚Äù

James gives him a skeptical look. ‚ÄúIs it though?‚Äù

Frank doesn‚Äôt bother responding, grumbling something about the importance of following rules in times like these while he sips on his bottle.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù James says, once a somewhat awkward silence has fallen over them.

Frank meets his stare. ‚ÄúSo.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre here.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

James looks down, passing his bottle back and forth between his palms. ‚ÄúLily send you?‚Äù Because it‚Äôs the only reason he can think of for Frank just turning up here out of the blue.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Frank says cautiously. ‚ÄúAlice is over at Mary‚Äôs right now but, when they called Lily asked if I‚Äôd come check up on you so‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you came.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I came.‚Äù

There‚Äôs another pause and then, still looking at his bottle: ‚ÄúDid she‚Ä¶say anything else?‚Äù he feels something like fear swell up inside him. Of all the people he‚Äôs never wanted to let down, Frank is pretty high on the list. If you‚Äôd asked him at eleven who he looked up to the most he would have said Frank. He‚Äôs not sure the answer is much different now.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Frank says. ‚ÄúNo, I‚ÄîI mean obviously I know that something is going on between the two of you but‚Ä¶she didn‚Äôt tell me the specifics.‚Äù

James sags with relief, though he still can‚Äôt quite make himself look up. After a few moments of silence Frank finally speaks again.

‚ÄúI‚Äîlisten, I know it isn‚Äôt any of my business, but I want to‚ÄîI want to help, if I can. But it‚Äôs hard to help if I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happened?‚Äù

James lets out a shaky exhale. ‚ÄúThing is‚Äî‚Äú he starts, but his voice is too strained, snapping right away. He takes another drink, anything to give himself more time. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried,‚Äù he manages eventually. He means to say more but somehow it doesn‚Äôt make it out.

‚ÄúAbout what?‚Äù Frank asks gently.

He laughs without humour. ‚ÄúThat if I tell you‚Ä¶you won‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú he grimaces, frustrated with himself, with the broken shaky way his words are climbing out of his mouth. ‚ÄúI just‚Ä¶‚Äù eyes closed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to disappoint you.‚Äù

The silence seems endless, James keeping his eyes closed, hands gripping the bottle in front of him like that will somehow keep him anchored.¬†

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù something about the way Frank says his name reminds James so much of his mother that he very nearly cracks in two, ‚Äúyou could never disappoint me.‚Äù

It takes a minute for him to recover from that before he‚Äôs able to let out a shaky laugh. ‚ÄúLiar,‚Äù he forces his eyes open, forces himself to look up. ‚ÄúI could miss an open hoop in a tied game against Slytherin.‚Äù

Frank laughs too. ‚ÄúYeah okay, you COULD do that. But you would never.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James agrees, ‚Äúnever.‚Äù He swallows, feeling his face fall again. ‚ÄúI fucked up Frank.‚Äù

The other boy nods. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚ÄîI just wanted‚Äî‚Äú he shakes his head, back here again. Back to what he wanted. Back to not knowing what the fuck he thought he was doing. What the fuck he thinks he‚Äôs doing now. ‚ÄúI hurt people,‚Äù he says finally. Because it‚Äôs true. Lily. Regulus. He hurt them both in the end. He failed them both. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm the villain in this story.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not the villain.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know that villains don‚Äôt think they‚Äôre the villains. They do the most horrific, immoral things imaginable and they convince themselves that that makes them the hero. You think Voldemort thinks he‚Äôs the bad guy? You have to care about people in order to feel guilt. Villains? Real villains? It never even crosses their minds to care about the people they‚Äôve hurt.‚Äù And when James doesn‚Äôt respond;

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not a villain James. You fucked up? Okay. You hurt people? Okay. But that doesn‚Äôt make you a villain. It just makes you a person.‚Äù ¬† ¬†

James shakes his head, not willing to accept that. Not yet. ‚ÄúI think my mum would be fucking ashamed of me,‚Äù he admits miserably, a thought that‚Äôs been bouncing around in his head for a while now. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing. I just wanted to keep him safe. I don‚Äôt know how I got it all so wrong.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt know when he started crying. Hates that he has. Embarrassment flushing his cheeks.

‚ÄúJesus kid,‚Äù he hears Frank stand up. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre killing me here.‚Äù

He‚Äôs at James‚Äôs side a minute later, pulling him to his feet and into his arms.

‚ÄúJames? Listen to me okay?‚Äù and when James just sniffles Frank pulls back, holding his face in his hands. ‚ÄúYou are not a bad person. You might have done bad things but that doesn‚Äôt make you bad.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm supposed to be better than that,‚Äù his voice wobbles pathetically. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm supposed to be better.‚Äù

‚ÄúSays who?‚Äù

‚ÄúEveryone. Everyone says it. I‚Äôm supposed to be James Potter. But I don‚Äôt even know who the fuck that is anymore.‚Äù

He sounds like such a little kid. Feels like one, when he sees the pity on Frank‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not even twenty-one years old James, you‚Äôve just lost your parents, you‚Äôre in the middle of this shit show of a war. Cut yourself some slack.‚Äù

But Frank doesn‚Äôt understand. Understand who James is supposed to be.

‚ÄúThey need me,‚Äù he almost whines. ‚ÄúI have to‚ÄîI can‚Äôt be like this. I can‚Äôt be this person. They need me to be James Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou are James Potter.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, no I‚Äôm not. I used to be, maybe, but not anymore. Maybe not for a long time. And I have to‚Äînothing would be falling apart if I could just be that person. Remus and Sirius and Peter and Lily and Re‚Äînothing would be falling apart. Because James Potter would fix it. So I just, I have to be him again. I have to be him. And then I‚Äôll be able to fix it.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames, breathe.‚Äù

That‚Äôs the second time today someone‚Äôs had to tell him to do that.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be sorry. Just breathe.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll figure it out. I always figure it out. I can do this.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames, the only thing you have to do right now is breathe so just shut up and inhale for me okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

And he does. Because he always listens to Frank eventually, even if he gives him shit for it first. Always trusts him to know what to do. So he inhales. And then he exhales. Inhale. Exhale. Wash, rinse and repeat.

‚ÄúBetter?‚Äù Frank asks after a few minutes, his hands have dropped from James‚Äôs face to his shoulders.

James nods. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt. Don‚Äôt apologize. I‚ÄîMerlin, I‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

James blinks, surprised. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Frank sighs, running a hand through his hair. ‚ÄúYour parents died. Your parents died and I should have been here.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou came to the funeral.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what I mean,‚Äù he sighs again. ‚ÄúI knew that you weren‚Äôt going to take care of yourself and I should have been here. I should have made you let some of that weight you‚Äôve been carrying around go. Some of that responsibility. It‚Äôs too much James. You need to put some of it down because you‚Äôre eating yourself alive.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt know what to do with any of that. His brain all foggy. ‚ÄúThat‚Äîthat isn‚Äôt your job,‚Äù he manages finally.

Frank gives him a weak smile. ‚ÄúYeah, it is. You‚Äôre family. I should have been checking in. This shouldn‚Äôt be the third time I‚Äôm visiting. I got caught up in‚Äîin everything. But you get to need people too, James. You certainly get to need me.‚Äù

It shouldn‚Äôt mean so much, hearing those words, it‚Äôs not like he doesn‚Äôt know it. Deep down somewhere. Not like he doesn‚Äôt understand that he‚Äôs allowed to ask for things. It‚Äôs just that it doesn‚Äôt always‚Ä¶feel that way. It‚Äôs just that he knows that no one expects him to. Sometimes it feels like no one wants him to.

But he can‚Äôt quite bring himself to say any of that out loud so instead he shakes his head, pushing gently on Frank‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúMerlin, fuck off, you‚Äôre just trying to make me cry again.‚Äù

Franks smiles, ‚ÄúI promise it‚Äôs very much the opposite,‚Äù and then, after a brief pause: ‚ÄúI think there are things you need to say?‚Äù

James feels his heart squeeze, the anxiety scratching against his skin again. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Frank nods, ‚ÄúBut first, have you eaten?‚Äù

That takes James by surprise. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîtoast, this morning I think?‚Äù

‚ÄúMerlin, sit down, I‚Äôm making food,‚Äù Frank turns towards the kitchen. ‚ÄúYou have pasta somewhere here? Tomato sauce? Garlic?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, cupboards next to the sink.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcellent.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

Sitting at the table watching Frank cook is probably the best James has felt in days. Maybe weeks. Maybe since his parents died. It‚Äôs the comfort of feeling, for a moment, as though someone else is in control. That they have things in hand. That everything is going to be okay.

James puts on one of Lily‚Äôs records and Frank whistles while he boils and chops, his cooking a weird mix between muggle and wizard techniques. He talks to James about nothing‚Äîhis mother‚Äôs garden, the Cannons‚Äôs new seeker, an article on a specific broom polish he read‚Äîit‚Äôs nice.

There‚Äôs a knock at the door.

Both of them freeze, looking down the hall like they‚Äôll be able to see through the walls of the house.

‚ÄúDo you know who that is?‚Äù Frank asks, shoulders pulling back, face serious as he jumps into Auror mode.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù James says, walking towards the door. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one of the twenty people keyed into our wards.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ James‚Äîwait, you can‚Äôt just go opening the door!‚Äù

‚ÄúFrank relax, I doubt that Voldemort knocks,‚Äù James says as he swings open the front door and feels himself startled into stillness for the second time that day.

For a moment there‚Äôs a weird merging of the past and the present. Of Sirius standing on his doorstep, looking absolutely fucking heartbroken at fifteen. And Sirius standing on his doorstep now, looking nearly the same.¬†

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Sirius says, sheepishly, like he isn‚Äôt sure if he should be there. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been at Andy‚Äôs but I was kind of over staying my welcome. I just couldn‚Äôt stand the idea of going back to that empty goddamn flat so I‚Ä¶So I came here. Is that‚Ä¶is that alright?‚Äù

For a second James just stands there and then he‚Äôs wrapping his arms around his best mate. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a stupid fucking question and you know it,‚Äù James says, partially into his shoulder.

Sirius laughs. ‚ÄúSorry, you‚Äôre right, I‚Äôm an idiot.‚Äù

‚ÄúCompletely moronic.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolute dunce.‚Äù

‚ÄúFucking pea brain.‚Äù

‚ÄúDummy.‚Äù

‚ÄúDummy?‚Äù James asks, pulling back. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh come on, it‚Äôs no worse than pea brain.‚Äù

James‚Äôs mouth twitches upward. ‚ÄúI like pea brain, very visual.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù comes a concerned voice from inside.

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs alright Frank, I‚Äôm not dead, it‚Äôs only Sirius.‚Äù

‚ÄúFrank?‚Äù Sirius asks. ‚ÄúWhy is Frank here?‚Äù

James‚Äôs budding mood flickers. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fucking freezing,‚Äù he says instead of answering. ‚ÄúCome in yeah? Frank‚Äôs almost done supper.‚Äù

Sirius arches his brow as he lets James usher him inside. ‚ÄúFrank can cook?‚Äù

‚ÄúApparently.‚Äù

The warm smells wafting from the kitchen envelope them as James closes the door. Him and Lily have been too busy lately for much cooking. For much of anything really. The house feels more alive with the smells and sounds of dinner being made. James half expects to see his mother and Mimi when he walks back into the kitchen.

‚ÄúSirius,‚Äù Frank says by way of greeting, his back to them as he stirs something, ‚Äúcan you tell James he needs to up his security measures? He has twenty bloody people keyed into these wards.‚Äù

Sirius turns to James, brow raised. ‚ÄúTwenty? Really? And to think, you used to be popular.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes, shoving Sirius who shoves him right back.

‚ÄúOi! Not near the food!‚Äù Franks says as he desperately tries to protect the pasta he‚Äôs plating.

‚ÄúWhat did you make?‚Äù Sirius reaches over and swipes his finger along the top of the tomato sauce, earning him a smack to the back of the head.

‚ÄúWere you raised in a barn!‚Äù Frank demands.

‚ÄúVictorian mansion sadly, a barn would‚Äôve been wicked though.‚Äù¬†

Frank lets out an exasperated sigh, pinching the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúWill the two of you just sit down please?‚Äù

James and Sirius exchange a look. ‚ÄúThink we‚Äôre bothering him?‚Äù James asks.

‚ÄúWhat? Us? Can‚Äôt be. We‚Äôre a delight.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right, must be something else. We should probably stay close.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood call Prongs. I reckon the closer the better,‚Äù they both inch nearer to Frank, coming at him from either side.¬†

‚ÄúOh‚ÄîJesus,‚Äù Frank curses as they crowd him, poking and flicking, and generally just making the older boy squirm. ‚ÄúI forgot that you lot were like this.‚Äù

‚ÄúPractically perfect in every way?‚Äù Sirius bats his eyelashes at Frank.

‚ÄúSupremely good company?‚Äù James adds.

‚ÄúFucking intolerable‚Äîsit down or no one‚Äôs getting fed!‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúJeez Frank, all you had to do was ask.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James agrees, the two of them sharing a smirk as they sit down at the table. ‚ÄúNo need to shout.‚Äù

It feels good. Smiling. Teasing. It‚Äôs the most human James has felt in ages.

‚ÄúHere, not that you deserve it,‚Äù Frank grumbles as he brings over their plates, sitting at the head of the table like the dad he is. Something snags in James‚Äôs chest at that thought, it‚Äôs a thoroughly uncomfortable feeling. Because Frank really is going to be a dad soon.

And so is he.

That kid is going to be‚Ä¶so‚Ä¶loved.

I hope so. I want to be a good dad.

You will be.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù the voice is soft and accompanied by the feeling of someone nudging his foot under the table.

James blinks, realizing that both Frank and Sirius are watching him. That Frank is the one who spoke but Sirius is the one pressing their feet together.

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù Frank asks.

James swallows, smiling tightly. ‚ÄúYeah. Fine.‚Äù

They eat in silence mostly, with Frank and Sirius occasionally trading small talk back and forth, James piping in here and there. Sirius never takes his foot away. They get through the whole meal before he finally asks:

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Lily at anyway? Her and Alice hanging out or what?‚Äù

James goes tense, watching Frank‚Äôs eyes bounce from him to Sirius and back again, clearly confused.

‚ÄúHave you two not‚Ä¶been talking recently?‚Äù he asks eventually, which has Sirius sitting up, James can practically see his ears twitch, he might as well be Padfoot.

‚ÄúI was at my cousins,‚Äù he‚Äôs looking at James. ‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù

What happened.

James doesn‚Äôt think he has it in him to explain. Luckily, it‚Äôs Sirius, so he doesn‚Äôt need to. All he has to do is look at him. It‚Äôs only a second before the other boy‚Äôs eyes grow wide.

‚ÄúOh. Shit.‚Äù

Frank watches them intently but doesn‚Äôt comment.

‚ÄúShe?‚Äú

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd then she?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been staying at Mary‚Äôs the last few days.‚Äù At least he thinks it‚Äôs been a few days, his grasp on time isn‚Äôt the strongest at the moment.

Sirius sits back in his chair, letting out a low whistle. ‚ÄúShit,‚Äù he says again.

‚ÄúShit.‚Äù James agrees. He scrapes his fork across his empty plate, silence falling over them.

‚ÄúNot that that wasn‚Äôt a fascinating bit of Legilimency to witness but,‚Äù Frank leans forward, ducking his head, trying to catch James‚Äôs eye. ‚ÄúSomeone want to fill me in?‚Äù His tone is filled with concern. Of course it is, he was here for James‚Äôs meltdown. He grits his teeth, embarrassment returning.

He doesn‚Äôt know how to explain.

Doesn‚Äôt even know where to start.

You‚Äôre my person.

What?

You wanted to know what you are to me. You‚Äôre my person. You‚Äôre mine.

Okay Reg. Yeah, I‚Äôm yours. You‚Äôre mine too.

‚ÄúRegulus is dead,‚Äù James winces when Sirius finally says it, grateful to him. He knows that it hurts him too. Maybe differently. But pain is pain.

Frank blinks, clearly surprised by this sudden new information. ‚ÄúRegulus? Your brother Regulus?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôd be the one,‚Äù Sirius‚Äôs voice is carefully blank. James has heard that tone before. It‚Äôs never good.

Frank lets out a breath. ‚ÄúWow, jeez, okay I‚Äîhow?‚Äù

Sirius shakes his head. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know. He was running away, that‚Äôs what Andromeda thinks, Voldemort caught him. Or someone else did and brought him to Voldemort. Either way‚Ä¶well, you can imagine how that went.‚Äù

James squeezes his eyes shut.

No.

He won‚Äôt.

He refuses.

‚ÄúI saw him you know.‚Äù

That‚Äôs enough to make James looks up. ‚ÄúYou saw him?‚Äù

‚ÄúAt the Ministry,‚Äù Frank explains. ‚ÄúDuring the attack. I saw him, he looked‚Ä¶‚Äù Frank‚Äôs eyes go a little distant. ‚ÄúI mean, listen, I never liked the kid much, no offence Sirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNone taken.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was a damn good Seeker but other than that he was a bit of a prick. But‚Ä¶‚Äù Frank shakes his head, ‚Äúthe look on his face that day? When he saw me? I don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶it was‚Ä¶painful. Broke my heart.‚Äù

James bites down on the inside of his cheek trying to keep himself from doing something stupid. Saying something stupid. Fucking crying again.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand though,‚Äù Frank goes on after a brief pause, and James does his best not to cringe when he feels Frank‚Äôs gaze fall on him. ‚ÄúWhat does that have to do with you and Lily?‚Äù

‚ÄúUm,‚Äù he starts, the sound shaking in his mouth. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äî‚Äú

You‚Äôre my person.

Okay Reg. Yeah, I‚Äôm yours. You‚Äôre mine too.

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

Then why? Why do you want me to come with you?

Because I love you too.

James‚Äôs fingers have started anxiously tapping on the tabletop. ‚ÄúI was‚Ä¶I was with him.‚Äù

Inadequate.

How fucking inadequate.

‚ÄúWith him?‚Äù Frank repeats, looking briefly at Sirius and then back to James. ‚ÄúWhen? When he died?‚Äù

No.

No.

He did that alone.

I left him alone.

James manages to shake his head. ‚ÄúI was with him‚ÄîI‚Äîwe were together.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat of silence.

‚ÄúTogether?‚Äù

James can‚Äôt read Frank‚Äôs tone. Can‚Äôt look at his face.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

There‚Äôs another pause.

‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù Frank asks again, but there‚Äôs a different sound to his voice now. A different weight to the question. And James finally forces himself to look up, to hold the other boy‚Äôs gaze.

‚ÄúAt school,‚Äù Sirius answers for him, clearly thinking he‚Äôs helping. Saving James again. But Frank doesn‚Äôt look away and neither does James. ‚ÄúRight? James?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt want to answer.

Doesn‚Äôt have it in him for another fight.

‚ÄúThe day of the attack,‚Äù he finally manages, voice quiet.

To his credit, Frank doesn‚Äôt flinch.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Sirius demands. ‚ÄúWhat the fuck are you talking about?‚Äù

James swallows, his throat tight, turning to Sirius who is far less calm.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sorry?‚Äù And then, as though the information is only just sinking in. What James really means. What he‚Äôs saying. Anger flashes clearly in Sirius‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúWait, let me get this straight‚Äîyou were with him? With him with him? The day of the attack at the Ministry? ‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs expression is thunderous. A storm on the horizon. James feels the weight of it in his chest.

‚ÄúWhat about Lily?‚Äù

James just stares helplessly back at him. Naked. Without excuses.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been fucking weeks.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt say anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

Sirius shakes his head, a cold laugh falling from his mouth. ‚ÄúJesus fucking Christ, you know, you and Moony have really got this lying thing down pat‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI never figured myself for naive. Thought my mum fucked me up a bit too much for that, but you lot? You lot are really proving me wrong.‚Äù

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

But Sirius is on his feet, slamming his chair back so hard it falls over, storming out of the room. James braces himself for the sound of the door slamming again. For the hollow aching feeling of being left. But all he hears is Sirius‚Äôs footsteps on the stairs. James wonders if he‚Äôs going to his old room.

For a moment neither James nor Frank seem able to move. To speak. Until finally Frank sighs.

‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶I didn‚Äôt see that coming.‚Äù

James smiles shakily down at the table. ‚ÄúSurprise.‚Äù

Frank huffs out a laugh. ‚ÄúSo, at school?‚Äù

James does his best to work around the lump in his throat. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor how long?‚Äù

‚ÄúBit more than a year.‚Äù

Frank makes a noise of affirmation that James can‚Äôt quite decipher. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a long time in school,‚Äù he says eventually.

It had felt like it. Like all the rest of his seven years could fit into hours, but the time he‚Äôd been with Regulus took up years. Decades. Lifetimes.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù is all he says, the word barely a whisper.

Frank reaches out, hand wrapping around James‚Äôs wrist and squeezing. ‚ÄúI still don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre the villain James.‚Äù

Something that was supposed to be a scoff but ends up being more choked comes out of James‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the only one.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre hurt. It‚Äôs not the same thing,‚Äù James doesn‚Äôt bother replying. Something Frank lets him get away with for about thirty more seconds before he starts talking again. ‚ÄúI told you, I saw him that day. If it was heartbreaking for me I can‚Äôt imagine what it was like for you.‚Äù

James‚Äôs chest gives an unpleasant twist, and he exhales, slow, measured. Like he‚Äôs just been hit by a Bludger and he‚Äôs trying to stay on his broom.

‚ÄúI could count his ribs,‚Äù he says, voice small. ‚ÄúBeing there was killing him. I mean really‚Äîreally killing him. I‚Äôve never seen someone‚Ä¶waste away like that.‚Äù His voice trembles and Frank tightens his grip. ‚ÄúI just wanted to get him out. I just wanted to keep him safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù there he goes, saying his name like that again. ‚ÄúHis death wasn‚Äôt your fault, you know that right?‚Äù But James shakes his head.

‚ÄúI asked him to leave. I asked him to leave and they killed him.‚Äù

‚ÄúListen to what you just said,‚Äù Frank pushes on fiercely. ‚ÄúHe was dead if he stayed anyway. At least leaving gave him a chance.‚Äù

This doesn‚Äôt feel like a chance.

This doesn‚Äôt feel like anything.

James pulls away, wiping at his face even though there aren‚Äôt any tears. ‚ÄúI should go check on Sirius,‚Äù he says eventually, forcing his voice to behave normally. ‚ÄúMake sure he isn‚Äôt setting the house on fire or something.‚Äù

Frank hesitates for a moment before nodding his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll clean up down here. Shout if you need backup, yeah?‚Äù

James shoots him a shaky smile. ‚ÄúYeah. Okay.‚Äù¬†

¬†

¬†

He isn‚Äôt exactly sure what he‚Äôs expecting to find. Certainly some sort of destruction. Some evidence of violence. What he isn‚Äôt expecting, is for Sirius to be lying calmly on his back in his old bed, staring at the ceiling. It‚Äôs so unexpected James actually questions whether or not he‚Äôs in the right room. None of the lights are on, the only brightness coming from the sliver allowed in by the door.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so tired of secrets,‚Äù Sirius says finally, breaking the silence. ‚ÄúI thought we were done with that. I thought at least you and I were done with that.‚Äù

James stands in the doorway for a second longer before walking forward and lying down on the bed next to him. The way they used to when they were kids. Curtains pulled around their fourposter beds, whispering for hours. They‚Äôre a bit bigger now mind you, but James still manages to fit, and Sirius doesn‚Äôt instantly try to push him off so he takes that as a good sign.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù James says finally.

There‚Äôs a long moment before Sirius talks again. ‚ÄúSometimes I feel like I don‚Äôt even recognize us anymore,‚Äù his voice is small, curling up and lying in the space between them.

James squeezes his eyes shut. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

He can feel Sirius shake his head but he doesn‚Äôt say anything. At least not at first. ‚ÄúYou want to hear something really stupid?‚Äù he asks eventually.¬†

James turns his head to look at him. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

He can only see Sirius‚Äôs profile, highlighted by the light spilling in from the corridor. ‚ÄúI really thought we were going to be happy,‚Äù a joyless smile tugs at his lips.

James thinks he can hear the cracks forming in his chest.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says softly. ‚ÄúYeah me too.‚Äù

There isn‚Äôt much to say after that.

¬†

¬†

James isn‚Äôt sure how long they lie there before Frank comes up, stopping abruptly inside the door.

‚ÄúAre you napping or are you dead?‚Äù he asks.

‚ÄúNeither,‚Äù Sirius answers.

Frank wobbles his head from side to side. ‚ÄúFair enough. I take it I‚Äôm not going to need to separate you two then? We‚Äôve worked through our issues?‚Äù

James snorts, because the idea that anything that is happening right now can be worked through seems funny to him.

‚ÄúI think we‚Äôll manage not to scratch each other‚Äôs eyes out, don‚Äôt you Prongs?‚Äù

‚ÄúI should hope so, your eyes are your best feature.‚Äù

They‚Äôre attempting normalcy. Brevity. They don‚Äôt quite manage it. Both of their voices too scratchy and too tired to make any of it believable.

‚ÄúUh-huh,‚Äù Frank says from the doorway. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôll leave you to it shall I?‚Äù

‚ÄúExcuse me?‚Äù Sirius calls out. ‚ÄúWhere do you think you‚Äôre going?‚Äù

Frank turns back to them and even in the dark James can see the confusion on his face. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîto find the guest room.‚Äù Technically they‚Äôre currently in the guest room but James doesn‚Äôt bother pointing that out.

‚ÄúGet in the bed Frank,‚Äù he says instead.

Frank laughs. ‚ÄúYeah, no, I don‚Äôt think so.‚Äù

Sirius looks at James. ‚ÄúHe thinks we‚Äôre joking.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe must not know what jokes are then.‚Äù

Sirius nods in agreement, turning back to Frank. ‚ÄúGet in the bed Frank. This is not a joke.‚Äù

Frank‚Äôs eyes move from one boy to the other, something between bemusement and shock on his face. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be ridiculous. There‚Äôs not even any room!‚Äù

Rolling his eyes, Sirius sits up, sliding his wand out of his sleeve and casting an extension¬† charm on the bed that causes it to accordion out into the room. The pair of them then look at Frank expectantly but the older boy only shakes his head.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúFrank,‚Äù Sirius cuts him off, sounding very serious, "we‚Äôre sad.‚Äù

Frank looks back at them, trying to hold out, but clearly defeated. Eventually he sighs. ‚ÄúThis really is ridiculous you know,‚Äù he mutters, noxing the light in the corridor and reluctantly climbing into bed with them.

When they were kids and they would lie like this, curtains drawn, talking, it was inevitable that Remus would eventually find his way next to Sirius, that Peter would come, sleepy-eyed and wrapped in a blanket, the four of them falling asleep on top of one another. A many limbed, many headed, monster.

This isn‚Äôt like that exactly. The cruelty of the past, is nothing is ever as it was. But it helps. As James closes his eyes listening to the soft breathing of his two friends, pressing against him on either side, limbs sleep warm and reassuring, James feels his grief loosen. Still ever present. Just a bit less choking.

¬†

¬†

At some point in the night James wakes up. He lies there for a minute, blinking the sleep away, unclear if there‚Äôs a reason for his sudden consciousness or if it‚Äôs just because Sirius has started snoring. He smiles a little at that. He‚Äôs missed the sound. Which is not something he ever thought he would say.

He stays still for a little longer before he feels something start to tug‚Äîon his thoughts, his stomach, the heart in his chest. He slips quietly out of bed, a bit difficult since during the course of the night Sirius has seen fit to throw his arm over James, burying his face in his shoulder. By some miracle, however, James manages to escape. Avoiding the creaky floorboards he‚Äôs had memorized since he was a kid, following the tug down the stairs and into the front hall. Following it all the way to his jacket pocket.

He lights one of the lamps in the sitting room with his wand, dropping onto the sofa, the letter held delicately in his hands. For a long time all he can do is stare at it, thumb tracing along the elegant J on the front. He knows this was written days ago. Weeks even. But it‚Äôll still be the last thing that Regulus ever says to him. And he‚Äôs not sure he‚Äôs ready to face that.

Eventually, fingers shaking, he slides his hand under the wax seal and pulls the pieces of parchment out of the envelope. They glow in the low light.

¬†

Dear J,

¬†

It starts‚Ä¶

¬†

I‚Äôve been thinking about dinner. About which one of us would do the chopping and which one would do the stirring. Which one would set everything on fire. I‚Äôve been thinking about laundry too. Who would put it off the longest (you) who would have a whole system in place for it (me) who would do the folding (you like mind numbing tasks don‚Äôt you?). See what you‚Äôve done to me? I‚Äôve been reduced to fantasizing about household chores.

You described to me once, the life you wanted us to have, that you pictured for us. I didn‚Äôt believe in it then. But I believe in it now. I think about it all the time James. You were right when you said I gave up last time, but I promise I won‚Äôt do it again. Not now. We‚Äôve wasted so much time. I‚Äôve wasted so much time.

I know it must seem like I‚Äôm still wasting time, but once I‚Äôve done what I need to, once I‚Äôve done it you‚Äôll understand. I know it won‚Äôt make up for all the bad, but it‚Äôs a start right? I wanna try this time, I really want to try. Sirius did it after all. It can‚Äôt be impossible.¬†

I love you James. Pathetically and desperately and always. Even when we didn‚Äôt speak. Even when I hated you I still loved you. Wherever you want me. However you‚Äôll have me. I just want to be near you that‚Äôs all. I‚Äôm so tired of you being so far away.

Sorry, it‚Äôs getting late and I‚Äôm feeling overly sentimental. Mostly I just want you to know that I‚Äôll see you soon. That I‚Äôll make things right. I promise.

¬†

Yours, always.

R.¬†

¬†

¬†

PART IV CERCI

¬†

It was Barty Crouch of all people, who told Cerci about Regulus.

He sent her an owl. Brief. To the point.

¬†

Greengrass,

¬†

Figured you should know.

Regulus is dead.

He tried to get out.

There‚Äôs no body.

¬†

Cheers,

B. C

¬†

And of course she hadn‚Äôt believed him. Not for a second. Apparating to Grimmauld Place immediately only to be met by a wall of impenetrable wards. It wasn‚Äôt like it had been last time‚Äîafter the attack on the Ministry‚Äîthese wards didn‚Äôt feel like Regulus at all. Didn‚Äôt feel like his magic.

Because.

Of course.

They weren‚Äôt.

Even now, thinking about that moment, that realization, feels like breaking her ribs. Cerci‚Äôs life is a much lonelier place without Regulus Black. Once she‚Äôd calmed down, she‚Äôd written Barty back. ‚ÄúTried to get out, no body‚Äù was not nearly enough information for her. But he never responded.

She had fully intended to track him down and demand answers. Answers no one, so far, had been able, or willing, to give her. Not Regulus‚Äôs father, who wept when she told him how much Regulus had wanted to visit, how much he had loved him. Or his mother, who recoiled at the mention of her son‚Äôs name. Embarrassed by his death. By his life. She was certain they had to know more than they were saying, but she was also certain, that she was far more likely to crack Barty Crouch than Walburga Black.

She‚Äôd been coming up with a whole plan. Perhaps one involving a little kidnapping and intimidation. But then. Then James Potter had appeared. The last person she ever expected to find outside the Black family crypt. The last person she had ever expected of being Regulus‚Äôs‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶anything. And the shock of it, had jogged loose another memory of James Potter.

Or at least a story.

Of him beating the living daylights out of Lucius Malfoy in the Atrium of the Ministry of Magic.

And suddenly, there was someone else she wanted answers from.

Which is how Cerci Greengrass finds herself outside the gates of Malfoy Manor for the first time since she was nine years old and her parents dragged her along to some sort of Christmas ball. Cerci has a vague memory of eating some bad chicken and vomiting on the Floo ride home. Plus, she‚Äôd been forced to wear a terribly uncomfortable dress‚Äîtoo many bows‚Äîeven just thinking about it makes her nose wrinkle. All in all, not an enjoyable experience.

Still. Here she is.

‚ÄúAnd you are?‚Äù a magical voice demands out of nowhere.

‚ÄúCerci Greengrass.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a moment‚Äôs pause and then. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing in Mr. Malfoy‚Äôs itinerary about a social call from a Cerci Greengrass.‚Äù

No. There wouldn‚Äôt be.

‚ÄúTell him I‚Äôm here to talk about Regulus Black.‚Äù

She had been there, for the week or so after the Ministry attack, when Lucius had relentlessly pushed against Regulus‚Äôs wards. Every day. Without fail. Sometimes multiple times a day. She hadn‚Äôt quite understood it then. Still doesn‚Äôt quite understand it now. But she reckons that that kind of obsession doesn‚Äôt just disappear. In fact, she suspects Lucius Malfoy is dying to talk about Regulus.

There‚Äôs a longer pause this time before the voice returns. ‚ÄúAccess has been granted. Please follow the walkway to the main house. You will find Mr. Malfoy in the first floor sitting room, third door on the left.‚Äù

The grand gates in front of her creak open, revealing an unnecessarily long driveway carved between two lawns which remain green even now at the end of December.

When she makes it to the main house her steps echo through the entryway. She isn‚Äôt sure what she was expecting‚Äîin her memories the mansion is filled with people and music and light. Of course, that had been a ball, but it all feels rather different when it‚Äôs empty. The grey winter sun filtering in through the windows, the grand corridors and high ceilings making everything feel cold and hollow. Cerci shivers at the thought of having to live in a place like this.

‚ÄúThird door on the left,‚Äù she murmurs to herself as she starts walking.

She isn't sure if she‚Äôs meant to knock. After a few seconds of standing outside the room she decides ‚Äúpolite knocking‚Äù is not quite the energy she‚Äôs going for and decides to just push on through.

Lucius Malfoy is sitting in a high-backed chair upholstered in green velvet, looking every inch the villain she‚Äôs sure he thinks he is. He‚Äôs reading something, long black pipe in his free hand. He doesn‚Äôt look up when she comes in.

‚ÄúClose the door,‚Äù he says, sounding bored.

Cerci‚Äôs wand twitches as she lets the door slam behind her. It has the desired effect, Lucius‚Äôs eyes snapping up at the noise, Cerci not bothering to hide her smug smile as she slips her wand back up her sleeve. No reason to put him on high alert just yet.

‚ÄúMiss Greengrass,‚Äù he says, snapping his book closed and leaning back in his seat. ‚ÄúTo what do I owe the pleasure?‚Äù

‚ÄúI want to talk about Regulus.‚Äù

She doesn‚Äôt miss the flash in his eyes. ‚ÄúYes. So you mentioned. Though I‚Äôm not sure why you would wish to do so with me?‚Äù

She arches her brow. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Cerci doesn‚Äôt buy any of it. Not the forced casual tone, not the book, not the pipe, not the confused look on Lucius‚Äôs face which is quickly disappearing. It all feels like an act to her. A piece of theatre.

She takes the chair across from him without being asked, eyes meeting his. She doesn‚Äôt speak‚Äîcontrary to popular belief it is actually possible for her to be quiet. And silence is particularly good at getting people to start saying things they shouldn‚Äôt, just to fill the void, all of us so desperately uncomfortable with the emptiness.

Regulus taught her that.

A few minutes pass before Lucius‚Äôs eyes narrow. ‚ÄúWhat did he tell you then?‚Äù

‚ÄúWas there something to tell?‚Äù Cerci asks mildly, smiling politely at him. ‚ÄúI thought you had no idea why I would want to talk to you?‚Äù

Now Lucius‚Äôs face forms a full blown scowl. He isn‚Äôt old, but when he makes this expression, you can see how he will be one day.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not interested in playing games little girl.‚Äù

But Cerci‚Äôs smile does not diminish. ‚ÄúSure you are, or you wouldn‚Äôt have opened the gate.‚Äù

Lucius appears to have no response to this so he simply scowls harder.

‚ÄúWhy were you trying to break through Regulus‚Äôs wards?‚Äù her voice is calm, level‚Äîeven pleasant. But if you were observant enough, something Lucius certainly is not, you would be able to see the knives in the corners of her mouth. In the centre of her iris‚Äôs. The violence in the set of her shoulders.

Lucius lets out a breath of laughter. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure what you‚Äôre expecting but it‚Äôs nothing spectacular; I wanted to see him, that‚Äôs all. ‚Äù

‚ÄúClearly he didn‚Äôt want to see you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes well,‚Äù Lucius‚Äôs posh accent somehow manages to grow even more condescending as he flicks a bit of lint off his trousers. ‚ÄúRegulus was not a very good judge of what was good for him.‚Äù

Cerci agrees. Though she doubts very much that Lucius and her are thinking of the same things.

‚ÄúAnd you were good for him?‚Äù she asks, same calm tone.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù as though suggesting anything else would be absurd. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been his closest ally since his brother left him.‚Äù

No, Cerci thinks, that isn‚Äôt true. Regulus always kept his allies close, even in school. Even if he didn‚Äôt particularly like them as people. Which means that whatever Regulus saw Lucius as, it wasn‚Äôt that.

‚ÄúYou two didn‚Äôt seem particularly close,‚Äù she says finally.

A twisted smirk curls the corner of Lucius‚Äôs mouth. ‚ÄúOh, I assure you. We were very close.‚Äù

Something about the way he says it makes her skin itch. She isn‚Äôt exactly sure what he‚Äôs implying but she knows she doesn‚Äôt like it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got another question for you.‚Äù

Lucius snorts. ‚ÄúGo on then.‚Äù

She gives him a long look. ‚ÄúWhy did James Potter attack you?‚Äù

There‚Äôs the smallest flicker, a twitch of his lip, and when his words come out next he‚Äôs practically snarling. ‚ÄúBecause he‚Äôs unhinged I imagine. I‚Äôve never experienced anything so uncivilized in my life.‚Äù

Cerci lets that sit between them for a moment. ‚ÄúSo he just went off, unprovoked?‚Äù

‚ÄúAsk anyone who was there,‚Äù Lucius gestures with his pipe. ‚ÄúI did nothing to him.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you do something to someone else.‚Äù

She can feel it. The tensing in his posture. The way he draws himself up a little higher, holds his nose in the air a bit more. Wrapping his superiority around him like a shield.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to have to be more specific, I have done a great many things to a great many people.‚Äù

Cerci is still smiling, though it is beginning to feel a bit strained. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you have,‚Äù she inches her wand slowly towards her palm. ‚ÄúBut what did you do to Regulus Black?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, Cerci can hear the clock on the fireplace mantle ticking, hear the sound of her own pulse pounding in her ears. Then, the older man sneers.

‚ÄúNothing he didn‚Äôt want.‚Äù

Cerci never figured out how to put all the pieces of Regulus together, never quite managed to see the full picture all at once. It‚Äôs one of the many things that breaks her heart‚Äîknowing now she never will. That so much of the boy who was her best friend, her family, will remain a mystery to her. But she does have a very clear memory of Regulus standing in the Slytherin common room, struggling to breathe, to put one foot in front of the other, a boy who couldn‚Äôt be touched.

It would come and go, Regulus‚Äôs aversion to other people‚Äôs hands. It was in the moments when he was at his worst, the moments you wanted to touch him the most, that you had to keep away. She had worked that much out at least.

Looking at Lucius Malfoy now. She thinks she can perhaps work out a bit more.

Cerci doesn‚Äôt know what her face is doing but it makes Lucius roll his eyes. ‚ÄúOh don‚Äôt give me that look,‚Äù he says dismissively. ‚ÄúWhatever Regulus said, it was just him trying to get your attention. Your sympathy. He was always like that, a bit of a worm if you will. I‚Äôm not surprised it got him killed,‚Äù he laughs cruelly. ‚ÄúWhat a meaningless little life he ended up living.‚Äù

Cerci is fairly certain Lucius doesn‚Äôt see the wand slide fully into her hand. He certainly seems surprised, when a second later he‚Äôs being thrown from his chair and into the wall behind him, body hitting with a satisfying ‚Äúthud‚Äù.

‚ÄúBitch,‚Äù he wheezes, the force of the spell knocking the air from his lungs. He reaches for his wand but Cerci is too quick.

‚ÄúExpelliarmus,‚Äù the small piece of wood flicks across the room as she steps towards him.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck do you think you‚Äôre doing? DOBBY! Narcissa!‚Äù

‚ÄúI cast a silencing charm on the room the minute I stepped through the door,‚Äù Cerci says calmly, pressing the tip of her wand to the older man‚Äôs neck. ‚ÄúYou must have missed it, while you were pretending to read your book.‚Äù

Lucius bares his teeth, but he isn‚Äôt able to wipe the fear from his eyes. ‚ÄúThis is a very bad idea little girl.‚Äù

‚ÄúI disagree.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you going to do? Truly? Kill me?‚Äù he sounds like he‚Äôs verging on hysterical. ‚ÄúYou expect me to believe you‚Äôre capable of that?‚Äù

She looks at him thoughtful. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says after a brief pause. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt expect you to believe I‚Äôm capable of anything.‚Äù No one ever does. ‚ÄúCrucio.‚Äù¬†

Lucius screams. She doesn‚Äôt let it go on for too long. Just long enough. His skin shiny with sweat as he collapses back against the wall, shivering.

‚ÄúCunt.‚Äù

Cerci ignores him, lifting her wand again and watching Lucius desperately try to scramble backwards even though he has nowhere to go.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck do you want from me?‚Äù his voice is almost painfully high.

I want you to take it back,

she thinks hopelessly.

I want you take it all back.

All the pain you caused him.

I want you to take his place.

‚ÄúWhat happened to him, really? How did he die?‚Äù she asks.

Lucius shakes his head, the hair that‚Äôs slipped out of his plait whipping around his face. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, honest to Merlin.‚Äù

Lie.

Cerci steps forward.

‚ÄúLook, he went missing for a few days‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYes I was there for that bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one knew where he was, no one, not even the Dark Lord.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd then?‚Äù she prompts.

Lucius swallows‚Äîit‚Äôs a showy swallow, his Adam‚Äôs apple on full display, bobbing up and down in his abnormally long, skinny neck. ‚ÄúAnd then one day the Dark Lord went somewhere on his own. And when he returned he said that Regulus was dead, that he‚Äôd been trying to defect and that there was no body.‚Äù

Cerci considers this for a moment. ‚ÄúNo one else ever saw him, Regulus? Just Voldemort?‚Äù

Lucius cringes at the use of the name. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he answers.

It was the Horcrux.

It had to be.

Regulus found out where it was and went after it.

But why didn‚Äôt he bring me? asks the small voice in the back of her mind.¬†

She notices Lucius attempting to inch towards his wand. She doesn‚Äôt hesitate. ‚ÄúAfflicto,‚Äù wand pointed at his arm. There‚Äôs an instant crack as the bone snaps and the older man begins to howl, clutching the broken limb to his chest. She watches him writhe around for a few more seconds before stepping forward again, wand back at his neck, knocking his chin so that he‚Äôs forced to look at her.

‚ÄúI want you to listen to me,‚Äù she says, gaze steady on his darting eyes. ‚ÄúI want you to hear this. To know it in your bones,‚Äù he whimpers, holding his arm closer. ‚ÄúYou could live for a hundred years. A thousand. But you will never matter the way that he mattered.‚Äù

Finding no escape his eyes reluctantly meet her‚Äôs. She makes sure her stare is relentless.

And then she pulls away.

Walking around the overturned chair, through the door, down the hall.

She makes it all the way to the front gate before the tears start.

¬†

¬†

Cerci writes Albus Dumbledore a letter.

She considers going to see him in person but she can‚Äôt bring herself to. Too afraid maybe. Too tired more likely. Of all these men and their war.

So Cerci Greengrass writes Albus Dumbledore a letter.

She explains it all. The Horcrux, Tom Riddle, Salazar Slytherin, how she thinks Regulus‚Äôs death is connected. She includes their notes. Their research. And at the end, right at the end of all that, she asks that if it turns out to be true, he tells people. Tells people it was Regulus who saw it first. Who tried first.

And then she sends it away.

She doesn‚Äôt expect him to listen.

But for Regulus‚Äôs sake she has to try.

Actually, she has a small list of things she has to try for Regulus.

¬†

¬†

‚ÄúCerci!‚Äù

She looks up as Moira walks through the Leaky Cauldron towards her. Cerci‚Äôs sat at a table by herself currently taking out her anxiety on the napkins.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Cerci smiles, wiping the dozens of shredded pieces of paper quickly onto the floor. She‚Äôll vanish them later.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so good to see you,‚Äù Moira has about the loveliest smile Cerci has ever seen. It‚Äôs just so‚Ä¶warm. It makes her feel safe. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt bring your entourage today.‚Äù

Cerci blinks. ‚ÄúMy‚Äîwhat?‚Äù

Moira motions at the empty booth around her. ‚ÄúThe boys who were with you last time?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Cerci does her best not to wince. Not to look at the spot that Regulus had sat in. Instead she swallows, opening her mouth to say what she came here to say when‚Äî

‚ÄúSo what‚Äôll it be?‚Äù Moira asks, the QuickQuotes Quill standing at attention beside her. ‚ÄúThe usual? Burger and chips?‚Äù

‚ÄúEr‚Äî‚Äú crap. ‚ÄúY-yeah, yes, great.‚Äù This is not going well. Why did she think this would go well? She doesn‚Äôt know how to ask somebody out!

‚ÄúNo whisky this time?‚Äù Moira teases, and Cerci thinks her smile must be strained.

‚ÄúJust pumpkin juice is good thanks.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou got it,‚Äù Moira gives Cerci a wink. ‚ÄúAnything else I can get you?‚Äù

And the thing is, she doesn‚Äôt have to. Ask Moira out that is. No one knows she‚Äôs here. No one even knows she has feelings for someone anymore. Reg was the only person she ever told. She could just walk away. No harm no foul.

Except.

Except she can‚Äôt help thinking about Regulus, who could only ever speak about the boy he loved in bits and pieces. When he was upset. When he had an escape. When he was drunk. Or James Potter, who didn‚Äôt even know that Regulus had managed that much. Who didn‚Äôt think that anyone in Regulus‚Äôs life had any idea about them. And how much it had clearly meant to him, to find out the opposite was true.

So many things were left unsaid between them. So many things that Regulus must have thought he would have time to say one day.¬†

‚ÄúCerci?‚Äù

She blinks, coming back to the present, Moira‚Äôs head cocked to the side, a slightly confused look on her face.

Cerci shakes herself awake. ‚ÄúSorry I‚Äîsorry I was just,‚Äù she takes a deep breath. ‚ÄúI was actually just wondering if maybe you might be interested in going out sometime?‚Äù she says in one big rush, barely leaving any space between her words.

There‚Äôs a pause.

‚ÄúJust in general?‚Äù slightly amused. ‚ÄúOr was there someone specific you were thinking I could go out with?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Cerci laughs nervously, running her hand through her hair, feeling her cheeks heat. ‚ÄúRight, yeah, forgot that bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an important bit,‚Äù and Cerci thinks‚Äîmaybe‚Äîjust maybe‚Äîthere‚Äôs a little blush colouring Moira‚Äôs cheeks too.

‚ÄúWell, um, I was wondering if you‚Äôd want to go on a date with‚Ä¶me?‚Äù

And there comes that smile, the one that makes Cerci feel safe. Comforted.

‚ÄúI would love to,‚Äù Moira says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm off work Saturday.‚Äù

Cerci nearly chokes. ‚ÄúI‚Äîyou‚Äîreally?‚Äù

‚ÄúAm I really off on Saturday? Yes.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo I‚Äîokay, okay great. Yes. Cool. Saturday then. It‚Äôs‚Äîah‚Äîit‚Äôs a date.‚Äù

Moira is still smiling. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a date.‚Äù There‚Äôs a small moment of stillness during which the two of them just smile at one another like idiots. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Moira says eventually, ‚ÄúI guess I should go get your burger then.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Cerci had completely forgotten she ordered anything. ‚ÄúRight.‚Äù

She watches Moira walk towards the kitchen feeling her heart stutter in her chest, hands all clammy and something‚Äîmaybe butterflies‚Äîhumming in her belly.

‚ÄúDid you see that Reg?‚Äù she whispers, unable to keep the smile out of her voice. ‚ÄúI did it.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

Chapter End Notes

Hey! Hi! Hello!

I know it's been a few weeks but here we are, back again!

I hope that at least parts of this felt comforting (and also that it wasn't too long and boring)

I feel like I had more to say but my brain is fried right now so thank you all for your support! The next chapter will be posted along with the epilogue and then this baby is done! Which is wild and crazy and a little sad!

ANYWAY hope you're having a good day / night / morning :)

Chapter 55

Chapter Summary

People make mistakes, but they also make choices.

Chapter Notes

cw / tw: Mild sexual content
tw: Discussions of SA (not graphic)
tw: Major Character Deaths (multiple)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

¬†

PART I REGULUS

¬†

You were‚Ä¶the best part for me. Of being here. Of‚Ä¶being.

¬†

September 1972

¬†

Regulus watches as the train station flies by outside the window. People and buildings blurring together as they pull away from all the things he knows. He can‚Äôt even see Kreacher anymore. Won‚Äôt see him again until Christmas.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù Sirius nudges him lightly with his elbow. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll introduce you to the boys, you‚Äôll love ‚Äòem.‚Äù

Regulus looks up at Sirius and doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs imagining the strain in his smile. Things have been‚Ä¶weird, since he came back from school this summer. Every time they talk it‚Äôs like there‚Äôs something they‚Äôre trying not to say, only Regulus isn‚Äôt sure what it is. Just knows he‚Äôs being careful. Tiptoeing around their conversations.

It doesn‚Äôt help that Sirius has been fighting with their mum more. It‚Äôs Sirius‚Äôs fault for shoving the fact that he‚Äôs a Gryffindor in her face. For bringing up James bloody Potter every five seconds. Even just thinking the name makes Regulus roll his eyes. When Sirius wasn‚Äôt up in his room writing him letters, he was in Regulus‚Äôs room talking about him. It got so annoying that one day Regulus just snapped:

‚ÄúIf you love him so much why don‚Äôt you just go bloody marry him.‚Äù

Sirius had blinked. ‚ÄúJeez Reg, excuse me for having friends.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt know why they can‚Äôt seem to get along anymore. Why hearing about Hogwarts has stopped being fun and started being aggravating. He just wants things to go back to normal. Wants Sirius to stop picking fights with their parents and looking so disappointed when Regulus doesn‚Äôt want to pick them with him.

‚ÄúPretty sure they‚Äôre down here somewhere,‚Äù Sirius mutters as they make their way along the train car, squishing against the wall to allow other students to pass them. Regulus wants desperately to ask Sirius if they can just sit on their own, but he already knows the answer will be ‚Äúno‚Äù and he doesn‚Äôt want to have to endure the pain of hearing it.

‚ÄúAh, yup, that sounds like James‚Äôs laugh.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs stomach lurches. ‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äù¬†

But Sirius is already sliding open the door, letting loose a flurry of young voices.

‚ÄúLads,‚Äù Sirius throws out his arms. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve arrived.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbout bloody time!‚Äù

A boy with wild brown hair gets out of his seat, instantly pulling Sirius into a hug. He‚Äôs wearing a pair of glasses, slightly lopsided on his nose, and his eyes remind Regulus of the colour of the creek near their home in Scotland.

There are two other boys in the compartment, both lighter haired, one with a ghastly scar running across his face. He‚Äôs the first one to make eye contact with Regulus, who is still standing a few feet behind his brother in the open doorway. The scarred boy smiles. Regulus does not smile back.

After a few minutes of Sirius and the bespectacled boy joshing one another back and forth‚Äîlaughing and babbling and pushing and shoving‚ÄîSirius finally seems to remember Regulus is there.

‚ÄúThis is Reg by the way,‚Äù he smiles when he says it, which Regulus thinks is maybe a good sign, slinging his arm around Reg‚Äôs shoulders and squeezing. ‚ÄúReg, these are the boys‚ÄîRemus,‚Äù he nods towards the scarred one who offers Regulus a wave, but Regulus isn‚Äôt sure if it would be odd for him to return it or not so he just keeps his hands in his pockets. ‚ÄúAnd that there‚Äôs Peter.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù Peter says without looking up from the chocolate frog cards in his lap.

‚ÄúAnd James.‚Äù

James.

Regulus has heard that name so much at this point he feels as though it‚Äôs burned into his brain. Every time it‚Äôs said he gets a bitter taste in his mouth. But now, as he turns to the boy in front of him, their eyes meet for the first time.

And Regulus‚Äôs heart hiccups in his chest.

Everything going quiet.

He‚Äôs sure it‚Äôs dislike that‚Äôs making all the softest parts of him flutter.

Sure it‚Äôs bitterness fizzling in his stomach.

Sure it‚Äôs annoyance that makes his hand shake when he extends it to the older boy for no reason he can think of.

‚ÄúHello,‚Äù he says to James Potter, who looks down at him with a bemused smile.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù he half-laughs as he shakes Regulus‚Äôs hand. Regulus doesn‚Äôt understand what‚Äôs funny, but it‚Äôs not‚Ä¶unusual, for him to get things wrong in moments like this. He‚Äôs never had Sirius‚Äôs talent for charming people.

James‚Äôs handshake is solid without being overbearing. His palm warm when it presses against Regulus‚Äôs. And his heart does it again.¬†

Hiccup.

Hiccup.

Hiccup.

‚ÄúRelax Reg, it‚Äôs not a dinner party, no need to be so formal,‚Äù Sirius is saying as James Potter pulls away and they all squish into their seats.

The scarred boy is next to Regulus, his face in a book, the other blond one organizing his cards into meticulous piles. Sirius and James immediately fall into easy conversation. Talking too quickly and using too many inside jokes for Regulus to follow.

James Potter doesn‚Äôt look at him again.

And Regulus hates him.

Hates him.

Hates him.

He flexes the hand he shook. Like he can still feel James‚Äôs touch.

Hates him.

Hates him.

Hates him.¬†

¬†

¬†

September 1975

¬†

It‚Äôs embarrassing enough that Regulus has ended up in this situation‚Äîpinned to a wall by Nicolai fucking Mulciber, a boy who couldn‚Äôt think his way out of a paper bag. But it‚Äôs made even more mortifying when James Potter walks around the corner. Regulus doesn‚Äôt know what he‚Äôs done to piss the universe off, but he wishes it would cut him some slack every once and a while.

Not that Potter even looks at him of course‚Äîhe never does really. The most irritating thing about that, is that Regulus is pretty sure it isn‚Äôt on purpose. Regulus simply doesn‚Äôt register for James Potter. At least not until he does something Potter deems worthy of moral condemnation. He is not sparing with his righteousness.

‚ÄúGot a hot date with the Giant Squid Snivellus?‚Äù

Potter has barely spoken before Mulciber jolts back, letting go of Regulus as he falls to the ground, enchanted ropes wrapping around his arms and legs. Potter looks insufferably smug about it, but then, he rarely looks anything else.

‚ÄúFucking Potter‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúExpelliarmus!‚Äù

Regulus watches the ensuing chaos with mild interest. Irritated with himself for being impressed by Potter‚Äôs ability to take on three opponents at once. Thinking anything positive about Potter always feels like the deepest betrayal of himself. But then, he‚Äôs never been a particularly loyal person.

‚ÄúI just hope I‚Äôm there to see it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSee what?‚Äù

‚ÄúSee them break you.‚Äù

Regulus flinches at that, not that anyone is paying him enough attention to notice. He knows a thing or two about being broken. He watches the confusion play across James Potter‚Äôs frustratingly handsome face and feels the tickle of another traitorous thought‚Äîthat he hopes Snape is wrong. He might find James Potter‚Äôs moral indignation tiresome, but he can‚Äôt quite imagine the messy haired boy without it. A broken James Potter simply feels unnatural.

‚ÄúYou want this?‚Äù Potter holds up Avery‚Äôs wand, twirling it between his fingers.

‚ÄúYou know I do, you twat.‚Äù

Potter nods. ‚ÄúWell alright then,‚Äù he winds his arm back and chucks the wand down to the other end of the corridor.

‚ÄúBastard!‚Äù

‚ÄúGo on doggy, go fetch.‚Äù

Growling, Avery takes off after his wand.

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù Mulciber shouts. ‚ÄúHey wait‚Äîfucking‚ÄîMerlin‚Äôs tits, wait!‚Äù

That‚Äôs when Jame Potter‚Äôs face cracks open, joy lighting up his eyes as he starts to laugh. Regulus drops his gaze. Something about Potter is too bright. Regulus doesn‚Äôt know how to bear it. Far more comfortable in the shadows.

But then‚Äî

‚ÄúRegulus?‚Äù

It‚Äôs an automatic response, looking up, his grey eyes colliding with vivid colour.

James Potter is looking at him.

¬†

¬†

October 1975

¬†

He‚Äôs drunk.

Which is stupid of him.

People do things, and say things, they shouldn‚Äôt when they‚Äôre drunk. And the list of things that Regulus ought not to do or say is longer than most people‚Äôs. He told himself he wasn‚Äôt going to come up to the Astronomy Tower tonight. Told himself to just stay at the fucking party. Told himself that James wouldn‚Äôt even be there‚Äîbecause why would he be?

And yet.

And yet.

Somehow Regulus finds himself climbing the winding steps, pushing open the heavy wooden door, standing a few feet from a beaming James Potter, who looks so beautiful it makes Regulus‚Äôs chest ache.

To be fair, being around James always makes Regulus ache.

He wants nothing more than to touch him. Not even in a sexual way. He just wants to know if he‚Äôs as warm and sturdy as he looks. As soft. He just wants to run his fingers through James‚Äôs hair, down his cheek, along the hills and valleys of each one of his fingers. He wants to worship him.

That probably isn‚Äôt normal.

The things Regulus wants rarely are.

‚ÄúYou gonna sit down or‚Ä¶?‚Äù

Regulus blinks, James‚Äôs voice bringing his drunken thoughts back to the present. ‚ÄúRight,‚Äù he nods to himself. ‚ÄúRight. Yeah.‚Äù

It‚Äôs hard to concentrate, this close to James, even when he isn‚Äôt drunk. His eyes forever dipping down to James‚Äôs mouth, like it has some sort of magnetic pull. Merlin this was such a bad idea. His whole body is buzzing from the adrenaline of the game. The adrenaline of having James Potter‚Äôs undivided attention. He feels out of control.

‚ÄúYou were brilliant today,‚Äù James says, Regulus is practically in his lap, close enough that he can see the small flecks of gold in James‚Äôs eyes.

Stunning.

Every inch of him.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù is all he can say, hoping James doesn‚Äôt notice how breathless he sounds.

‚ÄúThat feint? It was beautiful Reg, I mean it. I‚ÄîGod, watching you I just‚Äîhow did I never notice before? How did I never notice what a fucking star you are?‚Äù

Regulus snorts. ‚ÄúLiterally.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James says without the sarcasm. ‚ÄúYeah, but you are though.‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt deserve this. He knows he doesn‚Äôt. The adoration in James‚Äôs voice, the kindness in his eyes, it isn‚Äôt fair for Regulus to do this. Let James get caught up in the boy Regulus could be, instead of the one he is. Twisted and gnarled and rotten. Bound to let you down. To walk away when you need him most.

But he‚Äôs too selfish and too drunk to do the right thing. James‚Äôs eyes boring holes in his chest.¬†

‚ÄúGuess you weren‚Äôt looking,‚Äù Regulus says eventually.

James pauses, and Regulus wonders if that was a stupid thing to say until; ‚ÄúMaybe. But I‚Äôm looking now.‚Äù

He knows better.

Better than to let his eyes flicker down to James‚Äôs lips again.

Better than to let himself lean forward.

Fourteen years old and Regulus has never kissed a boy.

He‚Äôs been kissed.

But that isn‚Äôt quite the same thing.

Their lips meet and everything inside of him sighs with relief.

Oh yes, oh please, right here. This is where I‚Äôm meant to be. Where I should have been all along. Between his lips. Under his teeth. Oh, please, oh please, oh please.

He‚Äôs drunk.

So it takes him too long to notice that James isn‚Äôt moving.

When he pulls back he swears he sees horror in James‚Äôs eyes and all the good feelings that had fluttered their way to the surface crack open and fall apart. Suddenly he feels dead sober. Scrambling to his feet, his whole body shaking. He‚Äôs gone and fucked it up, of course. He couldn‚Äôt just be happy with what he had‚Äîwith their conversations, their budding friendship. He had to take more.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. Fuck, fuck, I‚Äôm sorry I didn‚Äôt‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt mean it.‚Äù He‚Äôs backing up towards the door, hands held in front of him. Waiting for the anger. For the violence. ‚ÄúI swear I didn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú he chokes, he can feel the tears welling up in his eyes.

He won‚Äôt cry in front of James Potter, he won‚Äôt. Without another word he turns around and runs.

¬†

¬†

November 1975

¬†

‚ÄúMerlin‚Äôs balls‚Äîsorry Professor‚Äîbut James Potter has just stolen the Quaffle!‚Äù

James is on another level today. He always plays well but this game‚Äîthis game is exceptional. It‚Äôs doing terrible things to Regulus‚Äôs heart.

‚ÄúI fucking hate Potter,‚Äù Barty mutters beside him.

‚ÄúYou just hate that he isn‚Äôt in Slytherin,‚Äù Evan is on Regulus‚Äôs other side, leaning forward over the railing. He‚Äôs spent more time ogling the sixth year girls below them than he has watching the game.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a showoff,‚Äù Barty glares at the sky as James speeds across the pitch, pilfered Quaffle in hand. It‚Äôs not that Barty‚Äôs wrong, James is a horrendous show off. But he still manages moves that Regulus has barely seen attempted by professionals.

‚ÄúYou sound bitter Barty dear,‚Äù Evan sings. And then, elbowing Regulus; ‚ÄúYou reckon we could bribe Potter to switch houses? You and him on the same team?‚Äù he lets out a low whistle. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd be fucking unstoppable.‚Äù

Regulus does his best to ignore the things that idea does to his stomach. Too close to the fantasies he barely lets himself acknowledge. ‚ÄúPotter? James Potter? ‚ÄúUgh, fine, guess you‚Äôll just have to win it all on your own then.‚Äù

Regulus smirks.

He fully intends to.

‚ÄúAnother goal for Gryffindor!‚Äù

The stands go wild, their cheers echoing throughout the pitch. And James, being the ridiculous person he is, decides to fly over to them and start giving out high-fives, like some sort of beneficent king.

‚ÄúWhat the hell is that!‚Äù Barty jabs an angry finger in James‚Äôs direction. ‚ÄúThat can‚Äôt be allowed! It‚Äôs a fucking penalty‚Äîpoor sportsmanship!‚Äù

Evan and Regulus both stare at him.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if we should bring him to Quidditch matches anymore,‚Äù Evan says as they watch Barty‚Äôs face turn red with indignation. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs bad for his health‚Äîhey, Barty, breathe okay buddy? It‚Äôs gonna be alright.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs blatant favouritism!‚Äù

‚ÄúMr. Potter,‚Äù McGonagall‚Äôs voice comes over the speakers. ‚ÄúStop showboating and take your position on the field immediately.‚Äù

‚ÄúFucking finally,‚Äù Barty grumbles under his breath.

The game starts up again, Macdonald getting hold of the Quaffle, racing towards the goalposts. At this rate it won‚Äôt even matter if Ravenclaw catches the Snitch.

‚ÄúAnd Gryffindor is in possession again!‚Äù comes the ecstatic voice of the announcer. ‚ÄúPotter and Macdonald are making a joke of Ravenclaw‚Äôs defences this game. And it looks like‚ÄîOh shit.‚Äù

The Bludger comes out of nowhere.

And even though he knows that it can‚Äôt be true, Regulus swears he hears it colliding with James‚Äôs skull. The ‚Äúcrack‚Äù echoing in his chest.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù the name punches out of him involuntarily. Luckily the crowd is loud enough that no one seems to hear.

‚ÄúHoly shit, this game just got interesting,‚Äù Evan says, leaning so far over the railing that Regulus‚Äôs hand shoots out to grab the back of his shirt without even thinking.

‚ÄúFucking serves him right,‚Äù Barty adds from Regulus‚Äôs other side.

Regulus barely hears them. His whole body running cold as he watches James fall. Come on, he thinks, looking around, trying to spot McGonagall. Do something! Save him!

There‚Äôs chaos‚Äîin the crowd, in his head, on the Pitch.

Fuck it.

Regulus reaches for his wand‚Äîhe doesn‚Äôt care how it‚Äôll look, what people will say, he‚Äôs not about to just let James fall. His hand trembling as it wraps around the handle.

‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs Gryffindor Beater, Sirius Black, to the rescue,‚Äù the announcer says as Sirius sweeps James into his arms, barely keeping his own balance. ‚ÄúQuite the heroic gesture, though that hit looked pretty gnarly, Potter does not appear to be conscious.‚Äù

Regulus exhales as he watches Sirius land on the field, Madam Hooch darting out to meet them. But the pressure in his chest only increases as James is levitated off the Pitch, still unconscious. Every inch of Regulus desperate to go with him.

He‚Äôll be okay,

he tells himself.

It‚Äôs James Potter.

He‚Äôs always okay.

He‚Äôs still shaking, still feels like he‚Äôs going to be sick. Like he won‚Äôt be able to breathe until he can touch James. Can make sure he‚Äôs alright.

When did he start caring so much about this fucking moron? A crush is one thing, but this? What the hell is this feeling? He doesn‚Äôt want to think about it too hard, afraid of what he‚Äôll find.

He realizes, suddenly, that he‚Äôs still gripping the handle of his wand and he lets go of it, cheeks flushing with embarrassment even though nobody noticed‚Äîand even if they had they wouldn‚Äôt have known what he was planning to do.

Regulus will never be the one to save James.

To catch him when he falls.

That will always be Sirius.

You‚Äôd think Regulus would have learned their roles by now.

In some twisted way he wonders if this whole mess with Potter has been an exercise in self-flagellation. Getting involved with a boy he knows he cannot keep. A boy who will always belong to his brother. Somehow Regulus has managed to find another way to make himself the spare.

‚ÄúReg? Reg?‚Äù Evan elbows him again and Regulus blinks realizing he‚Äôs just been staring blankly at the last spot he could see James.

Evan looks at him curiously as the players take their places again.

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he clears his throat, trying to sound more confident. ‚ÄúYeah fine.‚Äù

The whistle blows.¬†

¬†

¬†

December 1975

¬†

He‚Äôs been wanting to bring James to the Room for a while, but he‚Äôs been‚Ä¶afraid. Like somehow this makes whatever they‚Äôre doing more real. Escalates things. He wants that, and also wants to run away from it all at the same time. He knows he‚Äôs playing with fire here. He‚Äôs not sure when to pull away to keep from getting burned. Hopes if it all goes up in flames James makes it out okay.

‚ÄúRegulus,‚Äù there‚Äôs warning in James‚Äôs voice.

‚ÄúThe bed is here for a reason Potter,‚Äù he crowds James against it until the mattress cuts him off at the knees, causing him to sit down.

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt mean we have to do anything,‚Äù the look in James‚Äôs eyes says he wants to though. Dark and a little desperate. That look usually curdles Regulus‚Äôs stomach. But on James‚Ä¶on James it does something different.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve made that abundantly clear,‚Äù Regulus straddles James‚Äôs hips, hand on his chest, pushing him down. He pauses then, hovering above him, letting the fear in him spark and fizzle out. He‚Äôs in control, he reminds himself. Everything that happens is up to him.

James is staring at him, biting on his lower lip, looking uncertain.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying yes James,‚Äù his fingers play with the collar of James‚Äôs shirt. ‚ÄúBut there are‚ÄîI have‚Äîrules.‚Äù He tries not to wince, even though he hates the way that sounds. Laying his weaknesses out so explicitly.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James says, like he doesn‚Äôt care. Like it isn‚Äôt something to be ashamed of. ‚ÄúWhatever you want.‚Äù

Regulus‚Äôs chest aches.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú he struggles to swallow, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt touch me.‚Äù

James‚Äôs hands instantly drop away from where they'd been gripping Regulus‚Äôs waist and he almost laughs. Especially at the absolute sincerity on James‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúNot like that, I mean‚Äî‚Äú but his voice cuts itself off without Regulus‚Äôs permission. Incapable of saying it out loud. Of being explicit.

There‚Äôs a pause and then: ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúOkay, of course.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes?‚Äù

James nods. ‚ÄúYes Regulus, yes.‚Äù

Regulus doesn‚Äôt know if he actually likes sex. He‚Äôs not sure that he‚Äôs ever‚Ä¶enjoyed it. It‚Äôs not that he doesn‚Äôt think about it, of course he does. Touching James is different. He wants to kiss every inch of him, wants to pull those breathy little noises out of him. He feels James quiver beneath his hands and something hot shoots through him. He isn‚Äôt used to it. He tries not to be afraid.

He likes it when James starts to lose control. Likes it when he spills into his mouth. Likes knowing that he did that. That he made someone‚Ä¶feel good. He likes that James doesn‚Äôt try to take his trousers off.

‚ÄúWho are they?‚Äù

Regulus blinks, turning towards the ceiling.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Achilles,‚Äù he points to the hero who is dramatically pushing everyone away, ‚Äúand that‚Äôs Patroclus,‚Äù the pale body in his arms.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs dead yeah? Pat-row-what‚Äôs-his-face?‚Äù

Regulus bites the inside of his cheek, trying to hold back a smile at James‚Äôs terrible pronunciation.

‚ÄúPatroclus. And yes. He‚Äôs dead,‚Äù he isn‚Äôt sure why that statement feels so heavy. Like a curse. A bad omen. Patroclus‚Äôs corpse sitting, suddenly, in the bed with them. He refused to burry him at first, and when he finally let them burn the body he made his men promise that when he died they would mix his ashes with Patroclus‚Äôs, so that they could be together.‚Äù

James Potter rarely blushes so it‚Äôs a sight when it happens. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Äîyeah‚Äîyeah a bit. But, I don‚Äôt know. They loved each other. They loved each other more than anything else in the world; more than power, more than glory, more than winning the war. I‚Äôve never seen that in real life‚Äînever seen people love like nothing else matters. It aches but‚Ä¶in a good way, you know?‚Äù

They‚Äôre looking at one another unabashedly now. No one‚Äôs eyes darting away, no one‚Äôs head turning to the side. Regulus rolls forward, closing the gap between them.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James says after a moment, reaching out to tuck a dark curl behind Regulus‚Äôs ear. ‚ÄúYeah I know.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

The next morning, after a brief whirlwind of scrambling and chaos, James pauses at the door on his way out, turning back to Regulus, crease lines from the sheets still clear on his face. Everything about him is so soft that it almost frightens Regulus. He wants to protect him. He wants to keep him.

Stupid.
