‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù James asks, like he really wants to know. The question pulling Regulus out of his thoughts.¬†

‚ÄúYeah James,‚Äù he says slowly, afraid of how much he means it. ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôm okay. I might even be happy, if you can believe it.‚Äù

James‚Äôs smile is so bright it almost hurts to look at. But Regulus does. Tries to burn it into his memory, tries to make sure he will never forget.

‚ÄúMerry Christmas Regulus.‚Äù

‚ÄúMerry Christmas James.‚Äù

I love you, Regulus thinks helplessly, watching the door close.

I love you.

I love you.

I love you.

¬†

¬†

Just‚Äîthe best part.

¬†

¬†

PART II REMUS

¬†

The flat is empty when he gets home.

For a moment he just stands there, crumpling against the door, staring out at the dark rooms. He knows it‚Äôs irrational, the spike of fear that immediately drives through his chest. There‚Äôs no reason for him to expect Sirius to be there. But he can‚Äôt stop the nervous thoughts.

What if something‚Äôs happened?

How would you even know?

Eventually he forces himself to move, body heavy as he starts to unpack‚Äîwhich mainly consists of him dumping the contents of his tiny duffle bag into the dirty clothes hamper in the corner of their room.

The bed is unmade, a half-finished glass of water beside it, Sirius‚Äôs things strewn around the floor. He picks up one of Sirius‚Äôs t-shirts and clutches it to his chest for a period of time he deems sufficiently pathetic, and then goes into the kitchen to make a cup of tea. There are dirty plates in the sink, a nearly empty bottle of firewhisky on the counter. Remus grimaces.

He reaches for the bottle, holding it in his hands, wondering if he should be worried. Which is a stupid question. Because with Sirius the answer is always yes. He closes his eyes briefly, hands squeezing

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he whispers.

It‚Äôs been too long. Too long without seeing him or hearing him or laughing with him. It makes Remus want to tear off his own skin. He looks down at the bottle one last time before placing it back on the counter. He putters around the flat for a little while before eventually forcing himself to sit down on the sofa with a book. It‚Äôs nearly eight, surely Sirius will be back soon?

Remus can wait.

¬†

¬†

It‚Äôs loud voices in the street outside that startle him awake. The book he‚Äôd made a pathetic attempt to read slides off his lap and falls to the floor as Remus jolts upright, back and neck stiff. He blinks against the light streaming in from the window‚Äîhe fell asleep on the sofa. Sirius must have not wanted to wake him.

Or he was too angry to.

Remus pushes that thought away, scrubbing at his face before he gets to his feet and drags himself to the bedroom. He expects to find Sirius, dead to the world, maybe even snoring, but he doesn‚Äôt. His feet stutter as he enters the bedroom and finds it just as he left it‚Äîempty. Dark.

The nervous thoughts are getting louder now.

Something isn‚Äôt right here.

Remus doesn‚Äôt bother trying to fix himself up‚Äîdoesn‚Äôt bother to brush his hair or his teeth, to shower, or change his clothes. He feels lightheaded as he moves through the flat towards the fireplace. Voice shaking when he calls out ‚ÄúGodric‚Äôs Hollow.‚Äù

Surely if something had happened Moody and Dumbledore would have told him? Right? If something had happened to Sirius someone would have told him? They wouldn‚Äôt just leave him with an empty flat? James or Peter or Lily or Marlene or Dorcas or Frank‚Äîsomeone would have told him.

The fireplace in front of him flickers for a few moments, long enough that Remus is worried that no one is going to answer until finally James‚Äôs face appears, eyes growing wide at the sight of him.

‚ÄúRemus!‚Äù he says, surprised.

‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt here,‚Äù Remus blurts out, the least articulate way to phrase what he‚Äôs trying to say. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt come home last night and I don‚Äôt know where he is, there‚Äôs no note or anything, and I‚Äôm not sure how long he‚Äôs been gone but it feels like maybe it‚Äôs been a while and I don‚Äôt even know where to start lo‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWoah, woah,‚Äù James holds his hands up. ‚ÄúSteady on, Sirius is fine. He‚Äôs been staying at mine.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh thank god,‚Äù Remus lets out a breath he wasn‚Äôt aware he‚Äôd been holding, head dropping down for a minute as he tries to get his pulse back to a normal pace.

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù James asks gently.

Remus offers him a weak smile when he‚Äôs finally able to look up. ‚ÄúScared me is all,‚Äù the embarrassment is starting to set in‚Äîthat all it took was one night for Remus to completely lose his cool. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a bit paranoid I guess.‚Äù

James gives him a sympathetic look. ‚ÄúI think we all are, honestly.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is he‚Äî‚Äú Remus takes a minute, trying to force himself to sound less frantic. ‚ÄúWhy is he staying at your's?‚Äù he realizes as soon as he asks the question how stupid it is. He knows it drives Sirius mad being alone in their flat.

Something complicated flickers across James‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúYou should‚Äîuh‚Äîyou should come over Moons,‚Äù there‚Äôs a pause, James‚Äôs mouth opening and closing like he can‚Äôt figure out what to say, eventually he just sighs. ‚ÄúYou two should‚Ä¶talk.‚Äù

Remus nods, hoping the gesture doesn‚Äôt betray how shaky he feels.

‚ÄúAlright, yeah, I‚Äîgive me a few minutes to shower and change and I‚Äôll be right over, okay?‚Äù

James‚Äôs smile doesn‚Äôt reach his eyes. ‚ÄúSounds good mate.‚Äù

Remus tries not to read too much into it.

¬†

¬†

When Remus steps through the fireplace into the little cottage a half-an-hour later he finds James waiting for him. He‚Äôs leaning against his father‚Äôs desk, hands in his trouser pockets. Remus is taken aback by the sight of him. He looks‚Ä¶exhausted. Bags under his eyes, skin ashen, a noticeable slouch in his shoulders.

‚ÄúHey Moons,‚Äù he says, another one of those flickering smiles, like James is a candle about to go out.

Remus stumbles forward. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happened?‚Äù he asks, too scared to care about the crack in his voice.

James grimaces. ‚ÄúC‚Äômon, Pete and Sirius are in the living room,‚Äù and with that he pushes off the desk and starts walking towards the front of the house, Remus powerless to do anything but follow. He thinks this must be a dream, everything feels a little off, a little unreal. He starts counting his fingers.

‚ÄúThat move‚Äôs illegal!‚Äù Peter shouts, him and Sirius sitting on opposite sides of the coffee table, a game of¬†Wizard‚Äôs chess between them.

‚ÄúIs not,‚Äù Sirius says, watching with a smirk as one of Peter‚Äôs pieces is smashed to smithereens by his rook. ‚ÄúI thought you were supposed to be good at this game?‚Äù

Peter glowers. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking this up, there‚Äôs no way that‚Äôs allowed,‚Äù he reaches into the empty box on the floor, pulling out a small pamphlet and immediately flipping through it.

"If it was illegal the pieces wouldn‚Äôt have done it.‚Äù

Peter scoffs. ‚ÄúThey would if they were also dirty cheaters.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat!? Peter! How dare you suggest such a thing! These are some of the most honourable chess pieces around,‚Äù Remus swears he sees Sirius wink at his Queen. It makes his heart flutter, so reminiscent of the boy he grew up with. Fell in love with.

James clears his throat. ‚ÄúGuys,‚Äù he says.

Both of them look up, Sirius‚Äôs eyes meeting Remus‚Äôs and then instantly dropping back to the board.

‚ÄúOh woah, hey Remus! When the fuck did you get back?‚Äù Peter asks.

‚ÄúUh‚Äî‚Äú he stares at Sirius, willing him to look up again, but he doesn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúLast night. Didn‚Äôt realize everyone was here,‚Äù he tries to give Peter a smile but doesn‚Äôt quite manage it.

‚ÄúYeah, we‚Äôve kinda unofficially moved in since‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPete,‚Äù James cuts him off. ‚ÄúWanna help me get lunch ready?‚Äù

Peter blinks. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt we just ordering takeaway like always?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot today.‚Äù

Peter‚Äôs eyes slide from Remus to Sirius and then back to James. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says, quickly dropping the rulebook in his hands and getting to his feet. ‚ÄúRight. Yeah, Okay. Lets go.‚Äù

Remus feels like any minute he‚Äôs going to crumble under the weight of everything going unsaid in this room. James squeezes his shoulder on his way out, Peter chattering at his side about the technicalities of chess.

Remus has no idea what to do, what to say. So he ends up just hovering there, in the middle of the room.

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou have a nice trip?‚Äù Sirius cuts him off, poking at one of his knights. ‚ÄúWherever you went.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt know how to answer that. Things had been good between them, when he left. The best they‚Äôve been in months honestly. After the visit with Charlotte it felt like some of the resentment faded, like they didn‚Äôt have to be so careful with one another. He doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs changed.

‚ÄúIt was‚Ä¶‚Äù he trails off. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. It just was. Sirius please, tell me what‚Äôs happened? I don‚Äôt understand what‚Äôs going on.‚Äù

With the way they‚Äôre standing Remus can only see part of Sirius‚Äôs face. But he can still read the danger in it. Something barely restrained. Sirius keeps playing with the chess pieces in front of him, pushing and shoving them and generally just egging them on.

‚ÄúRegulus is dead.‚Äù

He says it in such a blank voice that Remus almost doesn‚Äôt understand. Going over the words again and again, trying to make sense of them.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Still Sirius doesn‚Äôt look up.

Remus feels like reality is slipping through his fingers. This really must be some sort of dream. He just saw Regulus. Just dragged him out of the Ministry.

An unwelcome image flashes through Remus‚Äôs mind of a little kid standing behind Sirius on the train. He‚Äôd looked so concerned, barely speaking to any of them. Curling in on himself the moment he sat down, like he was afraid of taking up too much space. Now that he thinks about it, James might have been the only one Regulus said a single word to that day. Maybe there was some foreshadowing in that, Remus doesn‚Äôt know.

‚ÄúHow?‚Äù he finally manages to ask.¬†

Sirius flicks over his King, the tiny stone figure sprawling across the board. ‚ÄúHe chickened out. Got caught. Voldemort took care of him. Didn‚Äôt even leave a fucking body when he was finished.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo body?‚Äù Remus feels sick.

A little boy with wide grey eyes and a frowning mouth.

‚ÄúNope.‚Äù

A little boy standing always in his brother‚Äôs shadow.

Remus doesn‚Äôt know what to say. What to do. He wants to move, to get down on the floor with Sirius and pull him into his arms but somehow that doesn‚Äôt feel right. So he stays where he is.

‚ÄúWhen did you find out?‚Äù

‚ÄúAbout a week ago.‚Äù

A week. Remus feels his face drain of colour. Sirius has been sitting with this, dealing with this, for a week. Without him. It‚Äôs like Fleamont all over again.

‚ÄúSirius, I‚Äôm so sor‚Äî‚Äú

Sirius gets up, nearly knocking the chess board off the table. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go see if they need help with lunch,‚Äù he says, hands shoved in the pockets of his trousers as he heads for the door.

‚ÄúSirius‚Äî‚Äù

But he doesn‚Äôt stop, keeps his expression blank as he pushes out of the room, Remus listening to the distant sounds of voices down the corridor.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù he drops onto the sofa, head in his hands. ‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù

This is his fault. Properly his fault. He stayed with Greyback longer than he was meant to because he‚Äôs been getting worried about Gabe. The more time that passes the more Gabe withdraws and Remus doesn‚Äôt know what to do. He wants him to go see Ava and Liam, but he always mutters something about it being too dangerous. Not wanting them to get dragged into this. Remus is still trying to convince Dumbledore to let him bring Gabe to visit Charlotte but he isn‚Äôt having any luck with that either.¬†

So he stayed.

And Regulus died.

And he wasn‚Äôt there.

‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

Remus's head snaps up, finding James standing in the doorway. He sounds almost as tired as he looks.

‚ÄúI probably should have stayed to referee that,‚Äù he goes on, which makes Remus laugh.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre supposed to need a referee.‚Äù

James just shrugs, walking over and sitting down next to him. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs hurting.‚Äù

Remus looks at his knees. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe gets angry when he‚Äôs hurting. Self-preservation and all that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Remus snaps. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm his fucking boyfriend James, I don‚Äôt need you to explain him to me.‚Äù

James goes still beside him, a long pause before he speaks. ‚ÄúSorry, I wasn‚Äôt trying to‚Äî‚Äú he stops, sighing. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like it when you guys fight, that‚Äôs all.‚Äù

The shame is instant.

Remus takes a deep breath, running a hand over his face. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he says finally, knocking their shoulders together. ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt have‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt mean to bite your head off.‚Äù

James gives him a faint smile. ‚ÄúNah, you‚Äôre alright Moons.‚Äù

He‚Äôs more defeated than Remus has ever seen him before. And that‚Äôs what it is really. Defeat. He‚Äôs seen James angry, and sad‚Äîhell, he‚Äôs seen him fucking devastated‚Äîbut he‚Äôs never seen him so close to giving up.

Remus bites on his lower lip, still pressing lightly into James‚Äôs side. ‚ÄúHow are you?‚Äù

James lets out a shaky exhale, looking down at his hands. ‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù he says, dry smile pulling at the corner of his mouth. ‚ÄúFucking awful. But‚Ä¶better with those two assholes around,‚Äù he nods towards the kitchen. ‚ÄúGives me something to do.‚Äù

The guilt is big and heavy in Remus‚Äôs stomach. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he says again.¬†

James only shakes his head. ‚ÄúS‚Äôok, not your fault,‚Äù there‚Äôs a pause and then; ‚ÄúSirius knows that too.‚Äù

Remus swallows with difficulty, unable to muster an answer. Clearly James notices because he keeps going: ‚ÄúHe loves you so fucking much, you know? I think it scares him to be honest. That he needs you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù because he does. There was a time when he thought that being with him would help Sirius. Would show him that things could be different. That people could be good to one another. Hubris, he supposes.¬†

There‚Äôs a long moment of silence between them. Remus can hear the radio in the kitchen, hear Peter and Sirius squabbling over something, maybe the sound of cutlery being dropped, or‚Äîknowing them‚Äîthrown.

It takes him that long to realize that someone is missing.

‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Lily?‚Äù

James‚Äôs face instantly shutters. It‚Äôs such an uncommon expression on him that it actually takes Remus aback. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs at Mary‚Äôs.‚Äù

‚ÄúMary‚Äôs? Why?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs staying there.‚Äù Something‚Äôs wrong with James‚Äôs voice but Remus can‚Äôt quite figure it out.

‚ÄúDid those knobs annoy her out of her own house?‚Äù he asks, but James doesn‚Äôt laugh, doesn‚Äôt crack a smile, just sits back, running a hand over his face and shaking his head. Remus waits for more of an explanation but after a few minutes pass he realizes he isn‚Äôt going to get one.

He nudges James‚Äôs foot. ‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù

James shakes his head again, opening and closing his mouth a few times before he finally manages to speak, voice small. Helpless. ‚ÄúRegulus died.‚Äù

Remus blinks, not understanding, and then‚Äîthen he sees the crumpled look on James‚Äôs face and‚Äî ‚ÄúYou told her?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe knew,‚Äù James laughs wetly before squeezing his eyes shut. ‚ÄúKnew for years apparently.‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs eyes go wide. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîwow‚Äîokay, well, I didn‚Äôt see that coming,‚Äù though he should have. Lily is clever and James is obvious. She probably caught him making heart eyes at Regulus across the Great Hall or something.

‚ÄúBut then‚Ä¶‚Äù Remus scrubs at his face. ‚ÄúWhy is she at Mary‚Äôs?‚Äù

James just looks back at him, eyes sad.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more?‚Äù Remus says finally, speaking slowly, careful with his words.

There‚Äôs a pause and then; ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James croaks. ‚ÄúYeah there‚Äôs more. But I can‚Äôt‚ÄîI can‚Äôt right now Remus. I can‚Äôt do this again‚Äîtalk about this again.‚Äù

Remus nods. Because he‚Äôs not about to push James and because he‚Äôs fairly certain he can fill in some of the blanks for himself.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says finally, ‚Äúokay.‚Äù He reaches out and squeezes James‚Äôs arm, still feeling a little shellshocked.

‚ÄúThe attack on the Ministry,‚Äù he startles himself when he speaks, not having thought it through. ‚ÄúRegulus could have made that much much worse for us,‚Äù he struggles for a moment, to decide what he wants to say. How much he wants to say. ‚ÄúHe could have made things much worse for me specifically. And he didn‚Äôt. He‚Ä¶well, he protected me I guess. So‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know if that matters but‚Ä¶I thought maybe you‚Äôd want to know.‚Äù

James just stares at him for a moment. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the leak?‚Äù he asks eventually. ‚ÄúThe one who tipped Moody off?‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs stomach feels like it‚Äôs tying itself in knots. He can‚Äôt speak so he nods instead.

‚ÄúAnd Regulus kept your secret?‚Äù

They really shouldn‚Äôt be having this conversation, but Remus nods anyway.

James makes another pained face.

Open wound, that‚Äôs the first thing that comes to Remus‚Äôs mind.¬†

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù James says quietly.

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

They sit in silence for a while, both leaning into one another, listening to the distant noises of Sirius and Peter no doubt destroying James‚Äôs kitchen. Remus takes in a deep breath and then exhales. He can still feel it. That undeniable sense of ‚Äúright‚Äù when the four of them are together. Like this is how they were meant to be, always. Wars, love affairs, all of it comes second to this.

To them.

He closes his eyes for a moment, just‚Ä¶feeling it. ‚ÄúYou gonna make things right with Lily?‚Äù he asks eventually.

He feels James stiffen. ‚ÄúYou think I can?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Remus frowns. ‚ÄúBut I think you owe it to her to try.‚Äù

James lets out a weak laugh. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna try,‚Äù he says, as though that was never a question. ‚ÄúOf course I‚Äôm going to try.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúGood. Whatever you did, she didn‚Äôt deserve it.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James sounds about a hundred years old. ‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù

Peter‚Äôs voice comes bellowing from the kitchen.

‚ÄúLunch is ready!‚Äù

Remus turns to James, brow arched. ‚ÄúOut of ten, how inedible is this going to be?‚Äù

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù James punches him playfully. ‚ÄúThe three of us can cook alright?‚Äù

‚ÄúSince when?‚Äù

James smiles and it‚Äôs nice. Makes him look more like himself. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just beans on toast.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh well, in that case.‚Äù

They both get up but Remus slows when they reach the corridor, a sinking feeling filling his stomach as he listens to the voices coming from the Kitchen. ‚ÄúMaybe it‚Äôd be best if I‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo, you‚Äôre staying,‚Äù James says decisively. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my house. Besides,‚Äù he gives Remus a meaningful look, ‚Äúit hasn‚Äôt felt right without you.‚Äù

It hasn‚Äôt felt right without you either, Remus almost says, even though it doesn‚Äôt make any sense. Even though he‚Äôs not sure he could explain how much he feels it. The loss of them. Like he‚Äôs only the faint imprint of himself when they aren‚Äôt with him. But then, he probably wouldn‚Äôt have to explain it. At least not to James.

‚ÄúAh‚Äîfuck,‚Äù Peter drops his toast onto his plate, fanning his mouth while Sirius rolls his eyes next to him.

‚ÄúI told you it was hot,‚Äù he says, blowing on his own food.

‚ÄúI dwidn‚Äôt twink it was thawt hawt,‚Äù Peter says with his tongue half out of his mouth.

The kitchen is an absolute disaster, though Remus reckons that‚Äôs not only because of lunch. Dishes and wrappers and half eaten food are scattered over the counters and piled in the sink.

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù Remus asks, as James hands him a plate. ‚ÄúNot one of you can manage a cleaning spell?‚Äù

James looks around as though only just realizing that there‚Äôs anything to clean. ‚ÄúI suppose it is getting a bit dingy isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

Remus arches his brow, sitting down at the table across from Sirius who still isn‚Äôt making eye contact with him. ‚ÄúA bit dingy?‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright, alright,‚Äù James chews and swallows. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll clean after lunch okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe?‚Äù Peter demands, looking genuinely concerned. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt remember agreeing to that.‚Äù

‚ÄúA little housework isn‚Äôt gonna kill you Peter,‚Äù Remus says flatly.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know that.‚Äù

Sirius snorts. ‚ÄúHe has a point.‚Äù Remus tries to catch his eye.

James glares at the pair of them. ‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôm sorry, is there some other kitchen the two of you have been using that I‚Äôm not aware of?‚Äù both of them remain sullenly quiet. ‚ÄúNo? That‚Äôs what I thought. You helped mess it up, you can help clean.‚Äù

Sirius rolls his eyes, but Peter opens his mouth: ‚ÄúWhy can‚Äôt you just get a new house elf already?‚Äù there‚Äôs a petulant tone to his voice, reminiscent of an unhappy toddler.

Everyone at the table freezes, Remus looking from Peter to James and back again. James‚Äôs face has been wiped of all good humour, Peter realizing his mistake immediately.

‚ÄúNot that‚Äînot that Mimi wasn‚Äôt like, important and stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúFamily, you mean.‚Äù

Something seems to flicker in Peter‚Äôs eyes that Remus can‚Äôt quite figure out, but as soon as it appears it‚Äôs gone. ‚ÄúYeah, right. I‚Äôm not trying to say she‚Äôs replaceable.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust that I should hurry up and replace her?‚Äù James asks coldly, making Peter squirm.

Remus decides to cut this off before it goes too far. ‚ÄúPlenty of people manage to clean their houses without a house elf. I think we‚Äôll survive, yeah?‚Äù

He looks between his two friends, the tension still so thick he can practically taste it.

‚ÄúYeah, definitely,‚Äù it‚Äôs Sirius who eventually speaks, nudging Peter with his elbow. ‚ÄúRight Pete?‚Äù

Peter‚Äôs eyes are still locked on James‚Äôs but eventually he nods, swallowing with some difficulty. ‚ÄúYeah, of course,‚Äù he looks down at his toast.

The rest of the meal is significantly quieter.

¬†

¬†

Peter and Sirius do help clean, and with relatively little complaint. Though Remus catches Peter mumbling curses under his breath a couple times, especially when his water charm ends up spraying him in the face. Still, they manage to get through most of the mess before they lose them; Peter wandering into the living room and, judging by the ensuing noises, promptly taking a nap, and Sirius disappearing into the back garden.

Remus stares at the back door, an ache in his chest. It‚Äôs hard to be away. But it‚Äôs always harder to be back and still not be able to touch him. To see him and still feel the distance between them like an insurmountable wall.

‚ÄúGo on then.‚Äù

Remus starts and then fumbles, struggling not to drop the plate in his hands, looking up to find James staring at him with amusement. The other boy gestures for Remus to hand over the dinnerware.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Remus mutters, reaching for the next dish.

‚ÄúMoons,‚Äù James sounds fond but exasperated, ‚Äúleave the bloody dishes and go fucking talk to him.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. I‚Äôll help you finish,‚Äù he insists stubbornly, earning him a frustrated sigh.

‚ÄúMate, if I have stand here and watch you spend another fifteen minutes drying the same plate I‚ÄôM going to break something.‚Äù

Remus blinks, looking at the plate in James‚Äôs hands and then back up. ‚ÄúOh, sorry I got‚Ä¶‚Äù his eyes slide over to the back door, ‚Äúdistracted.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, I got that,‚Äù he rips the tea towel out of Remus‚Äôs hands.

‚ÄúHey‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJust go,‚Äù James nudges him towards the door. ‚ÄúPlease, for all our sakes.‚Äù

Remus frowns but James has already turned back to the dishes, apparently deciding to ignore him. He considers arguing some more, but, unfortunately, this happens to be one of the the few moments in which James is actually being sensible. After another second of hesitating in front of the door, he slips his boots on and pushes outside.

He instantly casts a warming charm over himself because it‚Äôs fucking cold, even with the sun out in full force. Remus crosses his arms over his chest as he walks down the slope in the Potter‚Äôs back garden towards the Quidditch pitch.

He doesn‚Äôt see Sirius until he‚Äôs almost under him‚Äîflying around the miniature goal posts Fleamont charmed into existence back when James could still barely walk. Remus shields his eyes with his hand as he stares up at Sirius, speeding through the sky, dark hair whipping behind him.

He‚Äôs beautiful when he flies.

Well,

he‚Äôs beautiful all the time.

Remus sits down on the ground, knees bent, waiting.

And waiting.

And waiting.

But Sirius doesn‚Äôt come down, and Remus isn‚Äôt sure if it‚Äôs because he‚Äôs avoiding him or because he really just doesn‚Äôt want to. His teeth bite into his lower lip as he watches Sirius go round and round and round until eventually he can‚Äôt stand it anymore.

Admittedly, this is a terrible idea. He knows it even before he swings his leg over the broom handle, even before he pushes off, clumsily, into the air.

‚ÄúOh fuck, oh fuck, oh fuck.‚Äù He closes his eyes and then, realizing how ridiculously unhelpful that is, forces them to open again.

He hates flying, at least by broom, doesn‚Äôt know how James and Sirius do it. He feels completely unstable and vulnerable. There is absolutely nothing sturdy or comforting about a fucking broom. Of all the household objects wizards could enchant to fly, he‚Äôs not sure why it couldn‚Äôt have been a mattress or an armchair.

He wobbles, hands shaking as they grip the handle. This was a mistake. This was such a mistake. He‚Äôs going to fall to his death before he ever manages to speak to Sirius. God, flying broomsticks are so fucking stupid. So fucking‚Äî

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you doing?‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs head snaps up, causing his broom to bob and him to drop down, pressing his chest to the handle and clinging on for dear life.

‚ÄúTrying to talk to you,‚Äù he says in a strained voice, staring up at Sirius who is floating in front of him, a confused look on his face. He‚Äôs sweaty despite the cold, but Remus supposes flying neurotically around a Quidditch Pitch will do that to you.

‚ÄúYou hate flying,‚Äù Sirius says finally. Which seems a bit redundant to Remus, but given the current state of their relationship he manages to refrain from pointing that out.

‚ÄúI wanted to talk to you,‚Äù he repeats instead.

Sirius watches him for another minute, that same confused look on his face, like he‚Äôs trying to work something out, before eventually he flies forward.

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù he says, reaching over and placing his hand on Remus‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre making this harder than it has to be.‚Äù

‚ÄúWoah, woah,‚Äù Remus says as Sirius starts to try and push him upright again. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre you doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not sitting right.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sitting just fine.‚Äù

Sirius huffs. ‚ÄúJust let me‚ÄîI‚Äôm trying to help. Could you just trust me, please?‚Äù

And for a moment their eyes meet, and Remus can tell by the look on Sirius‚Äôs face that he hadn‚Äôt meant to say those words. Hadn‚Äôt meant to drag up all that baggage. A thousand different meanings suddenly floating in the air between them.

Finally, Remus exhales. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he says, relaxing enough that Sirius is able to gently push him upright again. Keeping one hand on his shoulder and placing the other on Remus‚Äôs lower back, shifting him toward the tail end of his broom.

‚ÄúThere you go,‚Äù Sirius says softly. Remus looks over at him, still terrified, though momentarily distracted by how close Sirius is. By the way his sweaty hair curls at his temples and ears.

‚ÄúAnd then just,‚Äù Sirius lets go of his torso and Remus is surprised to find that he actually does feel more stable, ‚Äúput your hands like this,‚Äù his tongue sticks out between his lips as he carefully adjusts Remus‚Äôs hands, the contact making Remus shiver. And maybe he‚Äôs imagining it. Maybe it‚Äôs wishful thinking. But he swears Sirius holds onto them for several seconds longer than is strictly necessary.

‚ÄúThere,‚Äù he pulls back slowly, ‚Äúbetter?‚Äù

Remus swallows, throat tight. He knows that it‚Äôs the flying and the cold that have put the pink in Sirius‚Äôs cheeks, but he can‚Äôt help staring at it anyway. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he manages finally, voice rough, ‚Äúbetter.‚Äù

Sirius nods and for a long moment they just float there, wind pushing against them, rocking them like ships. Remus does his best not to start hugging his broom handle again.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Sirius finally clears his throat, looking off into the distance, ‚Äúyou wanted to talk?‚Äù

He had. He really had. Except now that he‚Äôs here he has no idea what to say.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to fight,‚Äù is what he decides on finally. Childish? Yes, perhaps. But succinct. Honest. Brutally, painfully honest.

He watches Sirius chew on the inside of his cheek, still staring into the distance. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not fighting,‚Äù he manages finally. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I‚Äôve been‚Äîthat‚Äôs what I‚Äôm trying not to do.‚Äù

And of course, as soon as he says it, Remus can see all the ways it‚Äôs true. Sirius has been walking away from him all day. Walking away when normally he would shout and yell and fume.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still kinda fighting though,‚Äù Remus says eventually. ‚ÄúDifferent maybe but‚Ä¶you‚Äôre punishing me. Aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Sirius sighs, scrubbing at his face. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you want me to do Remus?‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how to not be angry about this.‚Äù

Which is fair.

More than, really.

Remus follows Sirius‚Äôs gaze. The sky is almost cartoonish today‚Äîlight blue, with big, fat, white clouds.

‚ÄúRegulus loved flying,‚Äù Sirius says suddenly, making Remus start.

He opens and then closes his mouth. It‚Äôs not the kind of statement that really requires a response, so instead he watches Sirius, waits for him to say more.

‚ÄúHe was going to go pro,‚Äù Sirius goes on eventually. ‚ÄúYou know there were already scouts looking at him? Back when he was at Hogwarts?‚Äù

Remus hadn‚Äôt‚Äîthough, in fairness, Remus knows very little when it comes to the workings of Quidditch. Still, it surprises him that Sirius knows this. He wonders, suddenly, if there‚Äôs the chance that Sirius has been keeping a closer eye on his little brother all these years than Remus realized.

‚ÄúHe was going to have his pick. He was going to be a fucking star. Probably play in the world series he‚Äî‚Äú Sirius‚Äôs voice breaks and he stops, closing his eyes for a minute, making Remus‚Äôs heart ache. ‚ÄúHow did we get here?‚Äù Sirius whispers, face scrunching. ‚ÄúHow the fuck did we get here?‚Äù

And despite the unbelievable terror it strikes into his heart, Remus lifts one hand off his broom and reaches out, squeezing Sirius‚Äôs arm.

‚ÄúYou know, sometimes,‚Äù Sirius says weakly. ‚ÄúI wonder, if there hadn‚Äôt been a war, would he have left that house with me? Would their hold on him have been weaker, if everything wasn‚Äôt so‚Ä¶scary.‚Äù

Remus doesn‚Äôt know what to say to that, eventually offering up a pathetic; ‚ÄúMaybe.‚Äù

But Sirius only shakes his head. ‚ÄúBut is it the war that made him do what he did? Or was that always in him? Was that person always there? Was he always going to be‚Ä¶like them? Or was it‚Ä¶but he said he regretted it, so I don‚Äôt know. Fuck I don‚Äôt know anymore‚Äù

Remus blinks, surprised. ‚ÄúHe did? He said he regretted joining Voldemort? When?‚Äù

Sirius‚Äôs eyes open. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen did he say he regretted it?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Sirius looks suddenly embarrassed, which doesn‚Äôt make sense to Remus. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt. Never mind. I don‚Äôt know why I said that.‚Äù

Which Remus doesn‚Äôt buy, but he decides to leave it alone. At least for now.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he says instead, finally bringing Sirius‚Äôs eyes back to him.

The other boy gives him a sad smile. ‚ÄúYeah. Aren‚Äôt we all.‚Äù

It‚Äôs like looking at James all over again. Like losing Regulus has severed whatever thin thread of childhood they were both still clinging to. The ghost of that hope, that naivety, that belief in themselves‚Äîthat they were kings, that they could do anything. The spark that made them James Potter and Sirius Black has been snuffed out.

Remus‚Äôs hand slides from Sirius‚Äôs arm to his face, holding it carefully, finger brushing over his cheek.

‚ÄúI love you, you know,‚Äù he says, because it‚Äôs all he has at this point. He can‚Äôt go back and change what‚Äôs happened. Can‚Äôt fix anything. All he has is love. Which the stories and the poets like to make a big fuss about.

All you need is love.

As they say.

It‚Äôs bollocks, of course.

A dying man might be loved but it won‚Äôt put the air back in his lungs.

And that‚Äôs what they are these days, isn‚Äôt it?

Dying men.

Sirius‚Äôs eyes open, the light catching them, making them glow, making Remus‚Äôs breath hitch, snagging on his ribs. After a moment Sirius turns his head and kisses Remus‚Äôs palm.

‚ÄúI love you too.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

PART III JAMES

¬†

James is outside Mary‚Äôs house.

It‚Äôs probably a mistake.

Which is why he‚Äôs still standing in the street two hours after getting there, not quite able to make himself walk up to the front door.

Because this is probably a mistake.

But what else is there?

He paces back and forth, hands running through his hair as his fingers start to go numb from the cold. His thoughts are all jumbled up, nerves making them tangle themselves in knots. He tries to pick them apart, place them in neat rows. Make sense of them. It doesn‚Äôt matter how many times he thinks about what he‚Äôs going to say. What he‚Äôs going to do. He can‚Äôt make himself move any closer.

Being in limbo, not knowing where he and Lily stand, whether or not she‚Äôs going to come back, whether or not they‚Äôll be able to get past this, it‚Äôs torture. Really, it is. It eats him up. But at least it still gives him hope. A chance. Schr√∂dinger‚Äôs relationship. As soon as he knocks on that door he loses that. There will no longer be a reality in which their relationship is both alive and dead. It‚Äôll be one or the other. And he‚Äôll have to live with that.

He‚Äôs almost positive he can‚Äôt.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù James jumps, spinning around to find Mary leaning casually against her front door, ‚Äúpeople are going to start calling the cops if you keep lurking out here.‚Äù

James blinks, trying to keep his anxiety in check. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not lurking.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou look pretty lurky to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just standing.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd pacing.‚Äù

James rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúOkay, yeah, and pacing.‚Äù

‚ÄúOutside my house. For hours.‚Äù

James lets out a sigh, but instead of walking towards her sinks down onto the curb, resting his elbows on his knees and holding his head. He can‚Äôt do this. He can‚Äôt. He has to, but he can‚Äôt.

After a few minutes he feels Mary sit beside him. She‚Äôs cut her hair since he last saw her. He probably wouldn‚Äôt have noticed except he‚Äôs never seen her with short hair before‚Äîa tight, curly afro framing her face. It‚Äôs jarring because it‚Äôs different. Because it‚Äôs new. Because he‚Äôs known Mary since they were both eleven and suddenly she looks like an adult and he doesn‚Äôt understand how that‚Äôs happened. Part of him hates it. Wants things to stay as they were. Wants everyone to stay as they were.

It‚Äôs childish and doesn't make him feel particularly good about himself.¬†

‚ÄúDoes Lily know I‚Äôm out here?‚Äù he asks finally, after a long drawn out pause.

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúIf Lily knew you were out here she would be out here.‚Äù

James turns to look at her, trying and failing to work out her expression. No one hides their feelings quite as well as Mary. Not even Sirius. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Ä¶don‚Äôt want that?‚Äù he asks finally.

‚ÄúYou¬†don‚Äôt want that," she corrects. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why you‚Äôve been creeping up and down the pavement for the entire afternoon.‚Äù

James pouts. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt been creeping.‚Äù

‚ÄúMmhm,‚Äù Mary pulls out a small carton from her back pocket. Placing a cigarette between her fingers before she offers him the box. ‚ÄúWant one?‚Äù

James wrinkles his nose. ‚ÄúHell sticks.‚Äù

‚ÄúPardon moi?‚Äù Mary asks, slightly amused.

He nods at the cigarettes. ‚ÄúFucking hell sticks. You and Lily, I don‚Äôt know how you do it.‚Äù

Mary smirks, sliding her‚Äôs into her mouth and snapping her fingers to light it. ‚ÄúLily isn‚Äôt smoking anything at the moment,‚Äù she says, inhaling deeply and a second later tilting her head back and blowing the smoke up into the sky. ‚ÄúY‚Äôknow, you have real shit timing.‚Äù

James just looks at her, not sure what to make of that, causing Mary to wave her hand impatiently. ‚ÄúDropping this all on her when she‚Äôs pregnant. I mean, there are the obvious reasons it makes you a complete dickhead.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo problem. But then there‚Äôs the fact that she can‚Äôt do any of the things you‚Äôre supposed to do when someone breaks your heart.‚Äù

James winces. He never wanted to break Lily‚Äôs heart. Never thought he could. Always so certain it would be the other way around.

‚ÄúShe can‚Äôt drink, can‚Äôt smoke, can‚Äôt do recreational substances of any kind,‚Äù she takes another drag from her cigarette. ‚ÄúShe could get a haircut I suppose.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that why you cut yours?‚Äù James asks before he can stop himself.

Mary looks at him out of the corner of her eye. ‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt you like to know.‚Äù

There's a moment of silence before eventually James groans, scrubbing at his face and then holding out his hand. ‚ÄúFuck it. Give me one of those.‚Äù

Mary smirks, passing the carton over and watching with increasing amusement as James awkwardly places a cigarette in his mouth.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve gotta inhale alright?‚Äù Mary says as she positions her fingers at the tip.

James rolls his eyes at her. ‚ÄúI know how it works,‚Äù he mumbles around the cigarette. Mary only grins, snapping her fingers and making the tip glow. James breathes in and instantly regrets every decision he‚Äôs made in the last few seconds.

The smoke scorches his throat and lungs, and the scratchy dry heat instantly has him coughing, smoke pouring from his mouth.

Mary laughs. ‚ÄúOh my god, you are tragic.‚Äù

James glares at her through his watering eyes, before leaning over and spitting on the ground. ‚ÄúThese things are vile,‚Äù he says, bringing it back to his lips for some reason and inhaling again. It‚Äôs almost an automatic response. It still feels awful the second time but the coughing is somewhat more sedated. ‚ÄúMerlin, I‚Äôm so glad neither of you showed these to Sirius.‚Äù

Mary snorts. ‚ÄúNever. That wanker would make them his entire personality.‚Äù

James laughs and it feels good, even if he coughs a little bit afterwards.

For a while they just sit there, James very much aware that Mary is waiting for him to speak. To explain himself. He just‚Ä¶doesn‚Äôt know where to start.

‚ÄúHow is she then?‚Äù he finally manages, dreading the answer.

Mary gives him a bemused look. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs who? You‚Äôre pregnant girlfriend whomst you lied to and cheated on?‚Äù Mary lets out a long exhale, smoke easing from the corner of her mouth. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs peachy.‚Äù

‚ÄúMary,‚Äù he says wearily.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù for the first time there‚Äôs the tiniest edge of anger in her tone. Honestly, James is surprised it‚Äôs taken this long to show up. ‚ÄúWhat would you like me to say?‚Äù and when he just continues to stare at her she rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs‚Ä¶she‚Äôs confused mostly, if you want to know the truth. It's like you‚Äôve gone and changed it all. She thought she knew you, thought she knew your relationship, and then suddenly everything is different,‚Äù Mary exhales. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a lot to adjust to.‚Äù

James fidgets with the cigarette in his hand more than he smokes it, rolling it between his fingers, knocking the ash off the end, knee bouncing up and down.

‚ÄúI didn't want to hurt her,‚Äù he cringes at himself. It‚Äôs such a generic phrase it belongs on a greeting card.

Mary lets the silence stretch on for an unnecessarily long time. Lets James sit in his embarrassment. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt want to hurt her,‚Äù she repeats finally. ‚ÄúOr you didn‚Äôt want her to feel hurt?‚Äù

That knocks James sideways. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Mary pauses again, forcing him to meet her stare. ‚ÄúHave you ever had someone apologize to you by saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre upset‚Äù? Not ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry I did it‚Äù not ‚ÄúI was wrong‚Äù but I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre upset? I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre making this a problem‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt what I mean.‚Äù

Mary arches her brow. ‚ÄúYou sure about that?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú but his voice cuts out. Truth is, James isn‚Äôt sure of very much at the moment. He sighs, frustrated, trying to get his thoughts in order for the thousandth time that day.¬† ¬†

‚ÄúI guess maybe I‚Ä¶‚Äù he looks very determinedly at his hands, ‚ÄúMaybe I thought that‚ÄîI hoped that‚Ä¶‚Äù he trails off, laughing without humour. ‚ÄúThat it wouldn‚Äôt hurt her, I guess. That maybe she would understand,‚Äù he briefly squeezes his eyes shut, forcing these vulnerable dreams out into the world. The ones that now taste like ash in his mouth. ‚ÄúI hoped that maybe we were meant to be this way, you know? That I was meant to be with them both. And they would be able to feel that too,‚Äù his next inhale shakes. ‚ÄúI really wanted her to understand. Because it just doesn‚Äôt‚Ä¶feel wrong to me.‚Äù

He can sense Mary scrutinizing him, dark, clever eyes running him over. ‚ÄúBeing with Regulus?‚Äù she asks neutrally, tone unreadable.

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúLoving them both,‚Äù he opens his eyes. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt feel wrong loving them both. I know that it‚Äôs supposed to. But that itch that tells you you‚Äôre doing the wrong thing, it was never there. Or at least never here,‚Äù he taps his chest.

Mary watches him for a moment longer before letting out a heavy sigh. ‚ÄúMerlin, you really are a disaster aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

That surprises James into a laugh, grateful for the break in tension. ‚ÄúYeah, absolutely.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean you‚Äôve fucked this up about as much as you possibly could.‚Äù

‚ÄúI realize that.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I will vehemently deny this if you tell anyone,‚Äù Mary goes on, pulling James‚Äôs attention away from his hands, ‚Äúand if Lily decides she wants to leave you I will be right there with her, cheering her on, boxing up her stuff,‚Äù the image makes James‚Äôs stomach twist painfully. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm still rooting for you James Potter.‚Äù

A slight prickling sensation suddenly materializes behind James‚Äôs eyes that he has to quickly blink away. He wasn‚Äôt expecting that from Mary. Not after‚Ä¶everything. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he says, and then, before he can stop himself; ‚ÄúStill? I wasn‚Äôt aware you were rooting for me in the first place.‚Äù

Mary snorts, knocking his shoulder with her‚Äôs, James returning the gesture. He takes a drag of his cigarette, just to distract himself from the emotions swelling in his stomach and maybe give him an excuse for the wetness in his eyes. Cars drive past along the street, the sound of children playing echoing from somewhere a few houses down.

Something tugs at James‚Äôs chest. A new feeling of guilt‚Äîor perhaps more accurately, an old feeling resurfacing. It‚Äôs been a long time since him and Mary have talked. Properly talked. Something has lodged itself between them, built a wall neither of them seemed willing to acknowledge or climb. But things have changed now. Everything is in the open.

‚ÄúListen, I‚Äôve been meaning to‚Äî‚Äú he stops, grimacing at the business like tone of his voice. He clears his throat and tries to start again, hands shaking so badly he has to drop his cigarette, putting it out with the heel of his trainer. Mary watches him curiously.

‚ÄúWhat happened to you‚Ä¶at school‚Äî‚Äú frustratingly his voice cuts out again, but he sees understanding light up Mary‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúYes, being attacked and then having my memory completely fucked by your boyfriend. Please do go on. I‚Äôm interested to see where this goes.‚Äù

James grimaces. Mary has the uncanny ability to put things in a way that allows you no escape. Like having the lights turned on. The curtains pulled back. The mask torn off. James‚Äôs mouth has suddenly gone dry.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù the limits of the English language have never been more apparent to him than in this moment. Because that isn‚Äôt close to what he means. To how much he means.

Mary‚Äôs face remains unreadable. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to need you to be more specific. What exactly are you sorry for?‚Äù

Regulus is suddenly sitting between them. Maybe he‚Äôs been there the whole time. Maybe he‚Äôs been there for years. The wall they didn‚Äôt want to acknowledge. To climb over.

Eventually James forces himself to speak. ‚ÄúI wanted to be there for you.‚Äù

She nods slowly. ‚ÄúFunny way of showing it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know," James cringes. "I know, it just felt like‚Äî‚Äú he tries to explain. ‚ÄúAt the time, it just felt like so much was happening all at once and it was all so big and so fucking awful and I just‚Ä¶I didn‚Äôt know what to do. I didn‚Äôt know how to handle any of it.‚Äù It isn‚Äôt that he can‚Äôt hear how that sounds. How inadequate. But that doesn‚Äôt stop it from being true. He hadn‚Äôt known what to do.

He‚Äôd only been sixteen.

‚ÄúBut I should have been there for you,‚Äù he‚Äôs saying this all wrong. ‚ÄúI should have‚Ä¶figured it out sooner. What to do. What was right.‚Äù It still isn‚Äôt good enough. Nothing ever will be.¬†

Silence follows. The noise of James‚Äôs own pulse loud in his ears. He‚Äôs sweating despite the cold.

‚ÄúAnd what if I can‚Äôt forgive you?‚Äù Mary asks finally. It isn‚Äôt angry. Isn‚Äôt mean. She looks at him with honest curiosity.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not why I‚Äôm apologizing,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want anything from you Mary. I just‚ÄîI needed you to know. That I‚Äôm sorry. That I haven‚Äôt forgotten. That I‚Äôll never forget." He sounds like a little kid and he can‚Äôt help wondering when that‚Äôll stop. When do adults start sounding like adults?

There‚Äôs silence, but after a few seconds of tension Mary knocks their shoulders together again. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù the words sound awkward and stiff in her mouth. She really is so much like Sirius.

He doesn‚Äôt know how to respond‚Äîhe certainly isn‚Äôt about to say ‚Äúyou‚Äôre welcome.‚Äù Thankfully, Mary saves him the trouble.¬† ¬†

‚ÄúIt never really stopped after then, did it?‚Äù

James can feel his face scrunching in confusion. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

She waves her cigarette in the air. ‚ÄúThings happening all at once. Big things. Awful things. Things none of use knew how to handle. It feels like it started then, started with that, and then it just‚Ä¶‚Äù she trails off, gesturing into the distance.

James waits a moment before nodding. He feels like he hasn‚Äôt been able to catch his breath in ages.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs only four of them now.‚Äù

James looks at her. ‚ÄúFour of who?‚Äù

‚ÄúThem,‚Äù she repeats, staring across the street. And then she holds her hand up and begins ticking names off on her fingers: ‚ÄúSnape, Mulciber, Avery and Crouch,‚Äù there‚Äôs something sharp in her voice. Something that wants to slice and tear and rip things apart. ‚ÄúTwo dead. Four living,‚Äù and now she turns to James. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna outlive them all. Just to fucking spite them. Live until the last one of them takes their finally pathetic breath. Hell,‚Äù the corner of her mouth twitches upward, ‚Äúmaybe I‚Äôll even kill them myself.‚Äù

From anyone else that would be a figure of speech. A bit of drama. But from Mary, it is almost certainly a promise.

Before anymore can be said she‚Äôs dropping her cigarette in the gutter and getting to her feet. ‚ÄúWell, are you ready?‚Äù

‚ÄúReady?‚Äù

‚ÄúTo talk to Lily? You know, the whole reason you‚Äôre here?‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù James‚Äôs stomach instantly drops into the soles of his shoes. ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äîyeah, okay,‚Äù he moves to get up too but Mary waves him off.

‚ÄúNah, stay there. If she decides to murder you I don‚Äôt want blood on my carpet. Real pain to get out that, even with magic.‚Äù

Despite his nerves he can‚Äôt help but snort. ‚ÄúAppreciate the vote of confidence Macdonald.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnytime Potter,‚Äù she calls over her shoulder as she heads back towards the house.

But something isn‚Äôt quite sitting right with James. ‚ÄúHey‚ÄîMary?‚Äù he calls out, stopping her at the door. She turns around with an exasperated look on her face. Probably expecting him to chicken out, but that isn‚Äôt what it is.

‚ÄúWhat I said before, about wishing I could have been there for you,‚Äù he sees the smallest flicker of surprise before she wipes it away. ‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt‚Äîthat isn‚Äôt really what I was trying to say. I mean, it is, but there‚Äôs more than that. I feel like it makes it seem like‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre babbling Potter.‚Äù

He runs a frustrated hand through his hair and tries to get his thoughts in order. ‚ÄúI wish I could have been there for you then, but I also want you to know that I‚Äôm here for you now. If you need to talk. If you need‚Ä¶‚Äù he loses his words. ‚ÄúIf you need anything, okay? I‚Äôm here.‚Äù

Mary just stares at him, expression blank, and after a few seconds James can‚Äôt stop himself from saying more.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the strongest person I know Mary, honestly. Which is saying something, considering the people I know. You can handle it all on your own, I just‚Äîyou shouldn‚Äôt have to.‚Äù

Something flashes in her eyes that he can‚Äôt quite place. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just as the world made me.‚Äù

James flounders. Not knowing what to say. Not even quite knowing what she means. Clearly seeing what a loss he‚Äôs at, Mary takes pity on him.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll let you know if I need anything, alright Potter?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he manages, breathing out a sigh of relief. ‚ÄúYeah alright, deal.‚Äù

She doesn‚Äôt say anything else, turning around and heading back inside.

J ames watches the door, hands rubbing nervously up and down his thighs. He feels like he hasn‚Äôt seen Lily in ages and he fucking misses her. But as more time passes he starts to worry that maybe she isn‚Äôt coming. That she doesn‚Äôt want to speak to him. It was always a possibility, just one he was hoping was really, really unlikely. That might have been optimistic of him.

Then the door opens.

And she‚Äôs there.

James has a visceral memory of the first time he ever saw Lily. He had never felt anything as strongly or as suddenly as he‚Äôd felt the urge to be near her. To get her attention, to make her laugh, smile. Of course, he didn‚Äôt manage much of that in those first years‚Äîthere was a lot more indignation and glaring. Not that it mattered. He had just wanted the chance to orbit around her for a few minutes. Few seconds.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù she says, causing James to come back to the present.

He‚Äôs stood up‚Ä¶for some reason‚Ä¶Lily by the door, like she isn‚Äôt sure if it‚Äôs safe to come any closer. Looking at her still makes him feel the same as it did when he was eleven‚Äîlike he never wants to be anywhere Lily isn‚Äôt ever again. Except that now that feeling is tied up in guilt and sadness and a bunch of fucking pain.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù James finally manages.

Neither of them move. The world suddenly going quiet, like it‚Äôs just them. Lily looks tired, and not entirely pleased to see him, but she isn‚Äôt aiming her wand at him so James figures that‚Äôs at least something.

‚ÄúI thought maybe we should‚Ä¶talk.‚Äù He braces himself for rejection. He‚Äôs had lots of practice being rejected by Lily Evans. If she tells him to go he will. It‚Äôll break his fucking heart but he will.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Lily says eventually, ‚Äúokay.‚Äù James sees her take a deep breath before she starts walking forward.

He‚Äôd thought the hardest thing was not seeing her, but maybe he was wrong. Maybe it‚Äôs harder to see her and know that in some profound way he has lost the privilege of belonging to her. Of having her. Of being had.

He clears his throat. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîwell, I guess maybe we should‚Ä¶‚Äù he gestures to the curb like he‚Äôs pulling out a chair and sees the faintest flicker of a smile on her face.

‚ÄúRight, sure.‚Äù

They both sit down on the cold ground, James quickly casting a warming charm. He sees Lily stiffen the moment he does, eyes closing for a second.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know how he‚Äôs managed to screw this up already. ‚ÄúI can get rid of it if it bothers you, I just thought‚Ä¶because of the cold‚Ä¶‚Äú

Lily shakes her head. ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs fine I‚Ä¶I guess it‚Äôs been a little while since I‚Äôve felt your magic,‚Äù she opens her eyes and gives him a weak smile. ‚ÄúWasn‚Äôt expecting it to‚Ä¶effect me quite so much.‚Äù

James isn‚Äôt sure what to do with that, doesn‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs a good thing or a bad thing. Wishes he could wipe the sadness out of Lily‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúYou wanted to talk?‚Äù she says, after an overly long pause.

‚ÄúOh‚Äîyeah, I‚Äîyeah,‚Äù he sighs, scrubbing at his face. He needs a second, to get his thoughts in order. He‚Äôs thrown off by‚Ä¶by whatever they are right now. There‚Äôs never really been silence between them before. There was anger and passion and friendship and love but never‚Ä¶restraint. Never fear. He thinks that might be what hurts the most. That when she looks at him now, there is fear hidden in the corners of her eyes.

Eventually James reaches into his jacket pocket and pulls out a small vial of clear liquid.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äî‚Äú but Lily stops, and James can practically see the cogs turning in her head. Narrowing down potions by colour, consistency, relevancy. What could James have possibly brought with him here?

‚ÄúVeritaserum?‚Äù she almost whispers, eyes bouncing from the vial to his face and back again.

James nods without really looking up at her, turning the potion over in his hands. ‚ÄúI reckon that you probably don‚Äôt have‚Ä¶the most trust in me right now,‚Äù he grimaces. ‚ÄúWhich is fair. But I don‚Äôt want you to have to wonder whether or not I‚Äôm telling the truth, you know?‚Äù

He looks up and finds her eyes wide‚Äîhe‚Äôs never seen anything quite like them, her eyes. He swears they‚Äôre made of magic.

She‚Äôs so lovely.

His Lily.

It‚Äôs hard to think that and not feel as though he‚Äôs betraying Regulus. But it‚Äôs true. They were always his. Or maybe, more accurately, he was always their‚Äôs. He belonged to them. Both of them.

His grief doesn‚Äôt make him love Lily less.

He simply is‚Ä¶less.

Less without Regulus.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt ask you to do this James,‚Äù she says finally.

Now it‚Äôs his turn to give her a sad smile. ‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt asking. I am. Let me do this Lily‚Äîlet me make this‚Ä¶‚Äù he searches for the right words. ‚ÄúAs easy as it can be.‚Äù

She considers him, green eyes thoughtful as they run him over, and he lets her. James Potter has never been one to hide his feelings. Slowly, Lily nods.

‚ÄúWhat do you want me to ask you?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever you want.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she cautions, because it is quite something to open yourself up completely, to set no boundaries, to place all your inner thoughts and feelings on display, even the ones you didn‚Äôt realize you had. But then, it seems only fair, after everything that‚Äôs happened.

‚ÄúWhatever you want Lils,‚Äù he says again. ‚ÄúI trust you.‚Äù

She bites her lower lip, still looking uncertain. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she says quietly. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt take too much.‚Äù

He smiles at her. ‚ÄúYou got it,‚Äù he pulls the cork out with his teeth, swallowing a mouthful before he can get too nervous. ‚ÄúThat oughta give us, what? An hour?‚Äù

Lily nods. ‚ÄúAbout, yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can always take more if you need me to.‚Äù He puts the cork back in the bottle and slides it into his jacket pocket.¬†

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure an hour will be enough.‚Äù

He can already feel the effects taking hold. The buzzing beneath his skin, the loosening of the dozens of knots tying his truths down, allowing them all to float to the surface.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù James says after a few more minutes, turning to face Lily properly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure we‚Äôre good.‚Äù

She looks at him, Lily‚Äôs always had the ability to pin him to the spot.¬†

‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù she asks finally, which isn‚Äôt what he was expecting at all. He can feel his brows drawing up in surprise while his mouth opens:

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

He can‚Äôt help laughing. Maybe it‚Äôs nerves. Or the desire to avoid the weight of that confession.

Lily only nods, taking it in. ‚ÄúThe day of the attack on the Ministry, was that the only time you saw Regulus after he left school?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù the answer is once again out of him before he has any real time to think, Lily‚Äôs face instantly clouding over. ‚ÄúHe was one of the Death Eaters who broke into the shop me and Marlene were guarding,‚Äù he explains quickly. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the only other time I saw him.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou never went to his house?‚Äù

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúJust that once.‚Äù

‚ÄúNever wrote to him?‚Äù

James swallows, thinking of the letter back at the cottage, the one he‚Äôs been rereading almost every night since he first opened it. ‚ÄúNot after Hogwarts,‚Äù he manages finally.

‚ÄúBut‚Äî‚Äú her voice cuts out and she grits her teeth. ‚ÄúBut you loved him? Until the end?‚Äù

‚ÄúStill,‚Äù James winces. ‚ÄúI still love him.‚Äù

Lily lets out a tragic sounding laugh. Running her hands over her face as she shakes her head, looking away. James has the overwhelming urge to reach out to her, but he keeps his hands balled in his lap.

‚ÄúAsk me if I love you too,‚Äù he says instead.

‚ÄúGod, James‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPlease. Ask me if I love you.‚Äù

She looks back at him, eyes glassy. Angry. Disappointed. It feels like a long time before she speaks. ‚ÄúDo you love me?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the word runs out of his mouth. It hurts when he sees actual surprise on her face. ‚ÄúOf course, I love you.‚Äù¬†

Lily looks down for a minute, clearly struggling with herself.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù she says, after a long pause. ‚ÄúI really didn‚Äôt think that was going to be the answer.‚Äù

‚ÄúLily‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNot under the Veritaserum.‚Äù

"I love you. I promise.‚Äù

Lily blinks a few times, tears spilling over her cheeks that she quickly wipes away. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚ÄîI don‚Äôt really see how that‚Äôs possible James.‚Äù

He hates this.

‚ÄúIt is. I promise it is.‚Äù

More tears make it down her face and she lets out a frustrated noise, tilting her head back and closing her eyes.

‚ÄúI fucking hate crying in fights,‚Äù she says, only barely talking to James. ‚ÄúIt makes me feel so‚Ä¶out of control. So weak.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt weak.‚Äù

She scoffs, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think?‚Äù

And he isn‚Äôt sure what to do with that‚Äîwhat she means by it. Lily opens her eyes again, scrubbing angrily at her face with the sleeve of her jacket.

‚ÄúI want to come home so badly,‚Äù she whispers, not looking at James. ‚ÄúI miss you‚Äîtalking to you, touching you, falling asleep with you. After everything that‚Äôs happened, how can wanting that not make me weak?‚Äù

James swallows with difficulty. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I can answer that question.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lily laughs and sniffles at the same time, wiping her nose. ‚ÄúNo I suppose you can‚Äôt.‚Äù She stares down at her hands, picking them apart for a minute before she speaks again. ‚ÄúDo you‚Äî‚Äú her voice wobbles. ‚ÄúDo you still want this baby?‚Äù

James feels like the air has just been punched out of his lungs. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that the reason you stayed? After you went to Grimmauld? Was it the baby?‚Äù

He shakes his head even though she still isn‚Äôt looking at him. ‚ÄúNo. I love you. I want to be with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs much as you wanted to be with him?‚Äù and finally her eyes flick up, making James's heart do all manner of clumsy things in his chest.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he whispers. She doesn‚Äôt let him go, gaze holding him down.

‚ÄúWas I your second choice? Regulus left school and then we got together, if he had stayed‚Äî‚Äú

James shakes his head. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd already‚Ä¶finished, before he left. He‚Äî‚Äú James has to take a moment, eyes squeezing shut. ‚ÄúI thought I could‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶get him to see things differently. But he‚Äîit all went a bit wonky sixth year. All went a bit‚Ä¶wrong.‚Äù

His chest grows tight at the memories. At how lost and how scared and how overwhelmed he‚Äôd felt. How hard it had been to make sense of the boy he knew and the person who had hurt his friend. Had gotten the Dark Mark branded on his skin.

He hadn‚Äôt wanted to accept it.

Honestly, he still struggles to.

James exhales, forcing his eyes open again, finding Lily watching him carefully.

‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt a replacement or a second choice is what I‚Äôm trying to say,‚Äù he finally manages, before giving her small smile. ‚ÄúI mean, you‚Äôre Lily Evan‚Äôs for Godric‚Äôs sake.‚Äù

Lily lets out a wet laugh, shaking her head. ‚ÄúI still don‚Äôt know what that means.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs because you get to be you all the time. The rest of us have to go without you every once and a while. Have to experience how flat life becomes when you‚Äôre not around.‚Äù

She rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúSounds terrible.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù his voice is more sincere than he intends, maybe it‚Äôs the Veritaserum. For a moment it feels like they‚Äôre both holding their breath.

Eventually Lily shakes her head. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where we go from here.‚Äù

James takes in a shaky breath. ‚ÄúCome home.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNot because everything is fixed,‚Äù he explains quickly. ‚ÄúI know that it isn‚Äôt. And I‚Äôll‚Äîyou know‚ÄîI‚Äôll sleep in Sirius‚Äôs room, whatever you need, to feel comfortable. But come home so we can‚Ä¶try.‚Äù He looks at her imploringly. ‚ÄúI want to try Lily. Don‚Äôt you?‚Äù

He can see her arguing with herself and he does his best not to push anymore. Not to fidget, not to look away, not to let the fear in his gut show on his face. Because what if she doesn‚Äôt? What will he do then?

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she says the word slowly, like she‚Äôs testing out how it feels on her tongue.

James does his best to keep his bouncing heart under control. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot because everything is fixed,‚Äù she repeats his words back to him. ‚ÄúBut because I want to try.‚Äù

James nods his head vigorously. ‚ÄúYes, okay, yes. That‚Äôs‚Äîthank you.‚Äù And suddenly James can‚Äôt help it anymore. ‚ÄúCan I‚Äîcan I hug you?‚Äù

Lily looks surprised for a moment and then her face softens. ‚ÄúYeah James, you can hug me.‚Äù

Less then a second later she‚Äôs in his arms, holding him as close as he holds her. James feels his whole body relax at the contact, burying his face in her hair and breathing her in. Warmth sings through his veins, making him feel‚Ä¶settled. James will never be full again, but at least here, in Lily‚Äôs arms, he doesn‚Äôt feel quite so fucking empty.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she sighs, pulling back much to James‚Äôs dismay. She meets his eyes, her‚Äôs a little red but determined. ‚ÄúLet me get my stuff.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

It isn‚Äôt until the moment that they walk through the front door that James remembers his house is full of Marauders.

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù he says, as loud, belligerent yelling comes from the kitchen. ‚ÄúI forgot they were here.‚Äù Well, he didn‚Äôt forget exactly, he‚Äôs just gotten so used to them being there that he forgot that they aren‚Äôt usually.

‚ÄúYou really think you can beat me? Really?"

‚ÄúOf course I think I can beat you! You don‚Äôt know anything about strategy! You just make things up!‚Äù

‚ÄúBeen working pretty well for me in Chess.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause you‚Äôre cheating!‚Äù

‚ÄúAm not.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre too.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm not!‚Äù

James turns to Lily who, thankfully, instead of looking angry or horrified, is laughing.

‚ÄúI can tell them to go‚ÄîI mean‚ÄîI will tell them to go, obviously,‚Äù he ignores the part of him that desperately doesn‚Äôt want to, even though Lily is here now. It's been nice, the four of them back together these past few days, living with one another, like old times. It‚Äôs been too easy to get used to it. Get comfortable with it. It‚Äôs the only good thing to come out of any of this really.

‚ÄúAre they all here?‚Äù Lily asks.

‚ÄúYeah‚Äîlike I said, I‚Äôll tell them to‚Äî‚Äú

But Lily waves him off. ‚ÄúNo don‚Äôt, I haven‚Äôt seen them in ages.‚Äù She puts her bag down, coat and boots already off, shoving James towards the kitchen.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon lets go see what all the yelling is about.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù James asks nervously. ‚ÄúBecause I swear I‚Äôll throw the dickheads out, right now.‚Äù

Lily lets out a small huff. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure. Go on.‚Äù

He wonders if maybe she feels it too‚Äîthe anxiety about being alone together. About having to try to go back to normal. About how wrong it‚Äôll all feel now, their house, their life, everything changed.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just make up your own rules and pretend you‚Äôre winning!‚Äù Peter‚Äôs face is bright red as he shouts at a considerably less bothered Sirius. Remus appears to be staunchly trying to ignore them both, nose in a book, a cup of tea in his free hand.

‚ÄúAll rules are made up Peter, you do know that don‚Äôt you? They aren‚Äôt naturally occurring phenomena. Some bloke somewhere just decided that this was how things we‚Äôre gonna be. Well, I‚Äôm also some bloke and I decide that things should go differently.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Äîthat‚Äôs not how games work!‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not how anything works,‚Äù Remus adds flatly, not looking up from his book.

But Sirius doesn‚Äôt appear bothered by either of these remarks, shrugging his shoulders, a lazy grin hanging from his mouth. ‚ÄúMaybe not for you lot. But it‚Äôs certainly how it works for me.‚Äù

James can‚Äôt help snorting, bringing both Peter and Sirius‚Äôs attention towards them, Remus, of course, doesn‚Äôt look up from his book.

Well, at least not until Peter says: ‚ÄúLily?‚Äù

‚ÄúLily?‚Äù Remus repeats.

Sirius is already out of his seat, Lily meeting him halfway, the two embracing‚ÄîSirius even lifts her a little bit off the ground. ‚ÄúHey beautiful,‚Äù he says gently, the address lacking its usual cheekiness.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù she says softly, pulling back but not too far, just enough to look at him. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôre you doing? I‚Äôve been thinking about you.‚Äù

Sirius smirks but it doesn‚Äôt quite reach his eyes. ‚ÄúWhat? About little old me?‚Äù and when Lily doesn‚Äôt let go; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm alright Evans. You know‚Ä¶what about you?‚Äù

Her mouth twitches. ‚ÄúYou know.‚Äù That makes Sirius laugh.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Remus comes up beside James, pulling his attention away from the other couple. ‚ÄúDo you want us to get out of here?‚Äù he asks in a quiet voice.

James looks back at Lily, her and Sirius speaking in low tones he can‚Äôt quite make out. He realizes he‚Äôs a little jealous, though he isn‚Äôt exactly sure of who. After a moment he shakes his head.

‚ÄúNo, Lily said she wanted you to stay,‚Äù and when Remus looks skeptical; ‚ÄúI want you to stay too.‚Äù

It's hard to explain, how it feels to have them here. His boys. Together. How much he needs it. How much it‚Äôs holding him together right now. He wonders if they feel the same. None of them have questioned it, the way they‚Äôve all just started living together. Peter still goes to work, Sirius occasionally called away on Order business‚ÄîJames hasn‚Äôt been asked to do anything recently, and he suspects that‚Äôs Frank‚Äôs doing‚Äîbut none of them have even hinted that they need to go home. And he‚Äôs grateful.

‚ÄúWhat do you say Wormtail?‚Äù Sirius's voice pulls James out of his thoughts. ‚ÄúYou ready for that game of Exploding Snap?‚Äù

‚ÄúBest two out of three?‚Äù Peter asks as he gets out of his seat.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre on.‚Äù

‚ÄúI call playing the winner!‚Äù Lily sings, Sirius herding her towards the living room. She meets James‚Äôs eye on her way out and he thinks he sees her smile grow a little tight. He tries not to let it get to him.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Remus nudges him after the others have left, Pete and Sirius arguing about who draws first as they shuffle down the hall. ‚ÄúYou alright?‚Äù

James tries to smile. ‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

Remus gives him a skeptical look but all James can do is shrug.

‚ÄúShe came back,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I can ask for more than that right now.‚Äù

Remus reaches out, squeezing his arm.

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù Peter‚Äôs voice carries from the living room. ‚ÄúWhat do you think you‚Äôre doing!‚Äù

‚ÄúShuffling,‚Äù Sirius responds.

‚ÄúThe hell you are, I don‚Äôt fucking trust you‚Äîgive me those, I‚Äôm shuffling.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell who says I trust you?‚Äù

‚ÄúBoys, boys,‚Äù Lily cuts in. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll shuffle.‚Äù

Remus gives James a small smile, ‚ÄúC‚Äômon,‚Äù he says, nodding his head towards the front of the house. ‚ÄúLets go make sure they don‚Äôt kill each other, yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust like old times isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù James says, doing his best to ignore the ache in his chest.

The desire to go back and do it all differently.

¬†

¬†

In the end Peter beats Sirius.

And Lily beats Peter.

And Remus.

By which point they‚Äôre all half-asleep. Too tired to even make it upstairs. Carpets and sofas are transfigured into mattresses until eventually the whole living room is nothing but beds and blankets. Peter is snoring before James has even flicked off the lights, Sirius and Remus lying close to one another, James and Lily on either side of them. For a brief moment their eyes meet.

Good night

Lily mouths, making James‚Äôs breath hitch. He resists the urge to crawl over to her.

Good night

He eventually mouths back.

It takes him a while to fall asleep.

¬†

¬†

‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt understand why we can‚Äôt help,‚Äù Sirius says the next morning, unable to keep an entirely straight face as him and James tease Remus who is currently attempting to make them breakfast.

‚ÄúYeah, me and Padfoot are well good cooks,‚Äù James adds from his place on the counter, feet banging into the cupboards below. Peter is slumped over the table still half-asleep, Lily on the otherside of Remus chopping fruit.

‚ÄúLily gets to help,‚Äù Sirius point out petulantly.

‚ÄúYes well,‚Äù the pan Remus is standing over begins to sizzle, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs because I can trust Lily not to cut off her own fingers,‚Äù and then, with a significant look at Sirius, ‚Äúor anyone else‚Äôs.‚Äù

Sirius lets out a dramatic gasp. ‚ÄúProngs did you hear that?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure did, sounds like he‚Äôs questioning your knife skills.‚Äù

‚ÄúAn affront to my honour!‚Äù

Remus shakes his head, carefully pouring batter into the pan, tilting it gently this way and that until the whole surface area is covered. It‚Äôs honestly fascinating to watch.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm French after all,‚Äù Sirius goes on.

‚ÄúWhat does that have to do with anything?‚Äù Lily asks, popping a strawberry into her mouth. James tries not to notice the way the juices turn her lips red, looking down at his knuckles instead.

‚ÄúUm, he‚Äôs making cr√™pes,‚Äù Sirius says. ‚ÄúThe food of my people.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe food of your people,‚Äù Remus mutters, hip checking Sirius out of the way and sliding the newly made cr√™pe onto a plate with the rest of them before starting the whole process over again.

Sirius looks like he‚Äôs gearing up for a big speech when there‚Äôs tapping on the window. All of them turn to see the little brown owl waiting impatiently with the Prophet in its beak.

Remus gives Sirius another shove. ‚ÄúThere, you want to be helpful? Go get the paper.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut I‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúGo on, get!‚Äù

Rolling his eyes Sirius heads towards the window, muttering something like ‚Äúmy talents wasted‚Äù as he goes.

‚ÄúLily, did we remember the blackberries?‚Äù Remus asks, not taking his eyes off the pan in front of him.

‚ÄúUh‚Äîyeah, they must be around here somewhere,‚Äù she starts spinning about herself, eyes roaming over the chaos of groceries on the counter. James is pretty sure they bought out the whole supermarket.¬†

‚ÄúOn your left.‚Äù

Her eyes flick up to his and for a moment the pair freezes. He can‚Äôt tell anymore, if the electricity between them is a good thing or a bad thing.

James clears his throat. ‚ÄúThe blackberries. They‚Äôre on your left,‚Äù he points with his finger.

Lily blinks. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù she pushes a few things aside to get to them, ‚Äú‚Ä¶thanks.‚Äù

James is about to say ‚Äúyou‚Äôre welcome‚Äù or something equally stiff and boring, when Peter interrupts:

‚ÄúSirius are you okay?‚Äù

They all turn their heads, even Remus, who had previously been very reluctant to look away from his cr√™pes. Sirius is standing at the window, newspaper in hand, owl long gone, just staring at the front page.¬†

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù James asks, slipping off the counter, but it‚Äôs Remus who walks across the room towards him, Lily waving her wand to turn the heat off the food before it burns.

Sirius doesn‚Äôt look up or give any indication that he‚Äôs heard anything, just keeps standing there, completely frozen. James feels something heavy forming in the pit of his stomach.¬† ¬†

‚ÄúSirius?‚Äù Remus asks again, now at his side, hand brushing against Sirius‚Äôs lower back.

Sirius starts, lifting his head so that James can appreciate how pale he‚Äôs gotten. ‚ÄúShit, sorry, zoned out,‚Äù he says in a falsely cheery voice, tossing the paper off to the side and walking back towards the food. ‚ÄúSo, are we done? I‚Äôm fucking starving.‚Äù

He grabs the plate of finished cr√™pes, flicking his wand so that the fruit follows him as he sits down at the table with a very startled looking Peter. Lily has to scramble to grab hold of the precariously placed knife on the cutting board now following Sirius across the room.

‚ÄúFuck this looks good,‚Äù Sirius says, starting to somewhat manically fill his plate. ‚ÄúWell, go on Pete, dig in.‚Äù

Peter looks surprised to have been acknowledged and then quickly turns to James with a clear ‚Äúwhat do I do?‚Äù look on his face. James just nods, and so, warily, Peter starts to eat.

Remus has now taken Sirius‚Äôs place, standing by the window, staring wide eyed at the front page of the paper.

‚ÄúMoons?‚Äù James finally asks. Remus looks up, eyes drifting to Sirius and then back to James, who arches his brow in question.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Orion,‚Äù Remus says finally, voice strained as he turns the paper around so they can see the giant moving photo of Orion Black‚Äîsurely taken several years ago at some Ministry function. He‚Äôs dressed in fancy robes and grinning in a way that twists James‚Äôs stomach‚Äîreminding him too much of Regulus. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs dead.‚Äù

That information really shouldn‚Äôt be so shocking, considering the shape he‚Äôd been in the last time James saw him. But for some reason he still feels his heart catching.

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù Peter looks across the table at Sirius who has not put down his fork, not lifted his head to look at anyone, eyes focused intently on his plate. Remus drops into the seat next to him, James and Lily still frozen in place. None of them really knowing what to say or do.

Sirius seems to swallow with some difficulty, letting the silence stretch on for a good long while before he finally speaks.

‚ÄúBad time to be a Black, huh?‚Äù

His laughter doesn‚Äôt reach his eyes.

¬†

¬†

The boys stay for a few more days after that. Though no one talks about why, especially Sirius. He doesn‚Äôt mention his father‚Äôs name once and when anyone tries to bring it up he becomes intensely focused on some task or another‚Äîhoovering or looking through Lily‚Äôs records or broom polishing. But eventually, they do have to leave.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll come by a couple times after work maybe?‚Äù Peter says as he pulls away from a hug with Lily.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôd be nice Pete,‚Äù she says, smiling.

‚ÄúThanks Wormtail,‚Äù James wraps his arms around him. Peter was shorter than him when they were kids but they‚Äôre practically the same height now, a fact James always forgets until moments like this. ‚ÄúFor‚Ä¶you know.‚Äù

He can feel Peter nod against his shoulder. ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a bit harder, letting Remus and Sirius go.

James isn‚Äôt sure how long Sirius and him stand at the front door hugging one another. Probably an embarrassingly long time but he doubts either Lily or Remus are surprised.

‚ÄúYou can come back, if you need,‚Äù James says, feeling Sirius nod.

‚ÄúYeah I know. Always welcome right?‚Äù

James squeezes him tighter. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll even make you your disgusting tea.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck off Potter.‚Äù

James laughs, turning his head and kissing Sirius‚Äôs temple, feeling the other boy sag into him a little more. ‚ÄúWe can still be happy,‚Äù he whispers.

This time it‚Äôs Sirius who squeezes, before reluctantly pulling back. ‚ÄúI believe you,‚Äù he gives James a half-hearted grin.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll take care of him,‚Äù Remus says, when it‚Äôs his turn.

‚ÄúTake care of you too, okay?‚Äù

Remus lets out a huff. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll try.‚Äù

And then they‚Äôre gone. Leaving James and Lily alone in an empty house.

¬†

¬†

Things are tense.

They don‚Äôt‚Ä¶fight, but they don‚Äôt‚Ä¶talk much either. James moves into Sirius‚Äôs bedroom, starts going into the Ministry again, helping Frank train the Aurors in flying combat. Lily has her own jobs, though, of course, James has no idea what they are. So avoiding one another is fairly easy. And that is what they‚Äôre doing, as much as James doesn‚Äôt want to admit it.

For the first time James thinks he really understands the term ‚Äúsmall talk‚Äù because every time they speak it all feels tiny. Little words, with little meanings.

Hi.

Good morning.

Nice out today.

We need more milk.

The smaller the words get the tighter his chest feels. Like he‚Äôs shrinking himself, trying to take up less space, apologizing for being there. For being in her life. A form of penance. James Potter, the loudest and biggest and brightest, shoving himself in a corner. Because maybe if he hadn‚Äôt been so loud and big and bright he would have been able to see beyond himself. Maybe he would have been able to stop everything from going so wrong.

Weeks pass.

A new year begins that no one seems particularly enthused about.

Time drags on.

James said he would fix this. Said they could still be happy.

He wants to make good on those promises, but sometimes the weight in his chest is too much. The grief. The loss. Sometimes he thinks he‚Äôs mourning Lily as much as Regulus.

Then, one day, he comes home and finds her sitting at the kitchen table.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he stops in the doorway. ‚ÄúHi.‚Äù

By and large the two of them have been spending very little time in common areas, both preferring to hide in their rooms.

She gives him a weak smile. ‚ÄúHi,‚Äù and then, clearing her throat. ‚ÄúSit?‚Äù

James‚Äôs heart drops into the pit of his stomach as he sinks into the seat across from her. He doesn‚Äôt like where this is going at all, knee bouncing nervously up and down under the table.

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLook,‚Äù he cuts in, leaning forward. ‚ÄúI know I haven‚Äôt been doing this right, that I said I wanted you to come back so that we could try and then I‚Äôve just been‚Ä¶staying out of your way.‚Äù

‚ÄúJames‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs only because I don‚Äôt know how to‚Äîto start I guess? And I don‚Äôt want to push too hard. I want to give you time and space and, y‚Äôknow,‚Äù he runs a frustrated hand through his hair. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôve let this go on for too long and it probably feels like I‚Äôm not putting any effort in at all. But I swear I am‚Äîor, I want to be. I just‚Äîjust need to figure out‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù she speaks loud enough to shut-up the spiralling thoughts in his head, causing his eyes to snap up and meet her‚Äôs. She doesn‚Äôt look angry, just a little exasperated, and if he‚Äôs feeling generous, there might even be some fondness there.

‚ÄúThis doesn‚Äôt all fall on you,‚Äù she says finally.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the one who fucked it up though.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúMaybe, but I agreed to come back. Which means we‚Äôre both responsible for making this work. And I haven‚Äôt‚Ä¶haven‚Äôt exactly been pulling my weight either,‚Äù she chews on her bottom lip for a moment before confessing: ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm scared, to be honest with you.‚Äù

James gives her a weak smile. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he croaks, ‚Äúme too.‚Äù
