‚ÄúI‚Äôve been talking to Alice,‚Äù she says eventually. ‚ÄúAnd she thinks it might be good for us to‚Ä¶see someone.‚Äù

James blinks, forehead scrunching in confusion. ‚ÄúSee someone?‚Äù

Lily has started picking at her fingers the way she often does when she‚Äôs nervous. Chewing on her words before she says them. ‚ÄúYeah, like a‚Ä¶you know, a Mind Healer.‚Äù

That word sits in the middle of the table. It‚Äôs big and obtrusive and James can‚Äôt see around it as much as he would like to.

‚ÄúYou think we need to go to therapy?‚Äù he doesn‚Äôt know why that idea bothers him so much, except that somehow it feels like admitting defeat. That he failed in some way. That the two of them are‚Ä¶not strong enough to solve this themselves. His parents, after all, never needed to go to therapy.

Lily sighs. ‚ÄúI think‚Ä¶I think I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing,‚Äù she admits finally, looking up at him. ‚ÄúThis‚Ä¶thing‚Ä¶between us, I don‚Äôt know how to approach it. I don‚Äôt know how to talk about it. It‚Äôs too big.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can handle it,‚Äù James says. ‚ÄúWe can get past this, I know we can.‚Äù

Lily looks at him sadly. ‚ÄúI hope so. But not on our own I don‚Äôt think.‚Äù And when James continues to stare at her, fighting his own internal battles, she eventually goes on. ‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù her voice is raw. ‚ÄúI think we need help. I need help.‚Äù

I want to help. Let me.

But he swallows that thought, because despite all his inner protests, he knows she isn‚Äôt wrong. Knows he‚Äôs so far out of his depths right now that he can‚Äôt tell which way is up or down.¬†

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù even though it kills him to say it. ‚ÄúLets‚Ä¶find a Mind Healer.‚Äù

The look of relief on her face almost makes it worth it.

¬†

¬†

Their Mind Healer is a woman in her fifties named Katherine‚Äîshe insists they use her first name. She has large, thick, purple rimmed glasses, that hang on a chain around her neck, shockingly white hair for someone who isn‚Äôt that old, and a tendency to wear very chunky and colourful jumpers.

She‚Äôs nice.

Though James doesn‚Äôt think she necessarily likes him very much. Not that she‚Äôs ever rude but often, when he answers a question, she‚Äôll tilt her head to the side and give him a patronizing smile that suggests she doesn‚Äôt quite believe him.

James doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs lying. Exactly. But he‚Äôs maybe‚Ä¶not being completely open. Trying to find the answers to her questions that he thinks she wants. That he‚Äôs supposed to have. He‚Äôs pretty good at reading people, at figuring out what‚Äôs expected of him, he always has been. Except that every time he thinks he has the right answer he gets one of those looks, and an increasingly frustrated noise from Lily.

Personally, James feels like therapy is not at all what it‚Äôs cracked up to be. Sure, things were tense before, the pair of them tiptoeing around one another. But at least they weren‚Äôt fighting. Now though? Well‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand why you‚Äôre so pissed at me,‚Äù James snaps. They‚Äôve come home from their third session and Lily is stomping around the house, slamming cupboard doors.

‚ÄúBecause that was a colossal waste of our time, again!‚Äù she reaches for a bottle of beer and then, realizing the minute she has it in her hand that she can‚Äôt actually drink it, glares viciously at it. Like its just greatly offended her.¬† ¬†

‚ÄúWell I don‚Äôt see why that‚Äôs my fault,‚Äù James shoots back. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one who wanted to go to therapy not me!‚Äù

‚ÄúTo try to help us fix this,‚Äù she slams the bottle so hard on the counter that James is honestly impressed it doesn‚Äôt crack.

‚ÄúWell it‚Äôs not my fault it isn‚Äôt working!‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not even trying!‚Äù

Which James thinks is entirely unfair. ‚ÄúYes I am!‚Äù

‚ÄúBullshit James, that‚Äôs bullshit! You sit there like you‚Äôre a politician giving fucking press releases!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat the fuck does that mean?‚Äù James‚Äôs hands have curled into fists. Lily rolls her eyes which only infuriates him more. ‚ÄúNo, really Lily, what the fuck does that mean? What the fuck do you want from me? You wanted to run away to Mary‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRun away?‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I let you go‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOh how fucking gracious of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou wanted to go to therapy, I‚Äôm going to therapy. I‚Äôm sitting in a room with some lady that we don‚Äôt even know and I‚Äôm‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDoing nothing!‚Äù Lily cuts him off. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre doing nothing. You‚Äôre giving nothing‚Äîtherapy is work James. You have to be willing to do the work, to look at yourself, to be honest. I swear to god we sit in that room and I feel like we‚Äôve gone back to being thirteen years old with you acting like some pompous dickhead.‚Äù

James throws up his arms up in frustration. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre talking about!‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre putting on an act!‚Äù she shouts back. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre putting on an act James, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm talking about and it‚Äôs not goddamn helpful. It‚Äôs the fucking reason we‚Äôre here in the first place. You keep trying so hard to be this perfect person‚Äîthis person you think people want and you end up hiding all this shit from everyone. It‚Äôs not healthy and we can‚Äôt‚ÄîI can‚Äôt do this if I don‚Äôt even know who the fuck I‚Äôm doing it with.‚Äù

Her face is flush, hair falling out of the bun at the back of her head.

‚ÄúI mean, who are you James? Do you even know?‚Äù

That strikes a nerve, one that cuts right through him, hot and sharp. Which should maybe make him pause, make him take a deep breath. But James is too fired up to do anything but be on the defensive.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a stupid question‚Äîyou‚Äôre being ridiculous.‚Äù

She shakes her head, running a hand over her face before pushing past him and heading for the door.

‚ÄúOh great, are you leaving again? Real helpful Lils! Go on then, go talk shit with Mary.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck you Potter!‚Äù she shouts as he follows her into the front hall.

‚ÄúYeah fuck you right back!‚Äù he snaps, the door slamming in his face.

Before he can stop himself he drives his fist into the wood in front of him, leaving behind a dent. Pain vibrates from his knuckles all the way up to his elbow, the splintered wood scratching up his hand, leaving it red and dotted with blood, already starting to swell. He could fix it in a second but he doesn‚Äôt, preferring the ache to the emptiness he knows he‚Äôll feel when it‚Äôs gone.

He does fix the door though, before grabbing his jacket and Apparating to Sirius and Remus‚Äôs flat. It‚Äôs a bit rude, admittedly, turning up unannounced, but he just can‚Äôt stand it. Being in that house. If they‚Äôre not home he‚Äôll go to Pete‚Äôs. Or fucking Frank‚Äôs. Anywhere.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Remus says when he opens the door, blinking at James several times before stepping aside and gesturing him in. ‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù

James immediately starts to pace, hands running through his hair.

‚ÄúSorry, Sirius is out doing‚Äîwell, I don‚Äôt actually know what, presumably something for the Or‚ÄîJames your hand!‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù James mutters, still pacing.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs bleeding.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh, okay, I‚Äôm going to need you to sit down,‚Äù Remus takes James firmly by the arm, and while he considers fighting him he ultimately allows himself to be dragged over to the sofa. Remus sits on the coffee table across from him, taking James‚Äôs hand gently in his, he looks at it for a moment before his concerned eyes flick up to James.

‚ÄúWho did you punch?‚Äù

James looks away. ‚ÄúMy front door.‚Äù

Remus hums. ‚ÄúWell, I mean, it could certainly have been worse.‚Äù He pulls out his wand, James hissing at the sting of his healing spells. ‚ÄúOh come on you big baby, it doesn‚Äôt hurt that bad,‚Äù Remus nudges his foot good-naturedly.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù he lets James have his hand back, putting his wand down on the table, ‚Äúyou wanna tell me why you punched a door?‚Äù

James sits back, crossing his arms over his chest and glaring at the floor. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm losing at therapy,‚Äù he says eventually, causing Remus‚Äôs eyes to widen.

‚ÄúOkay, jeez, lots to unpack there,‚Äù he lets out a breath. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in therapy?‚Äù

‚ÄúLily thought it would be a good idea,‚Äù he kicks at the table leg. ‚ÄúShe was fucking wrong.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause you‚Äôre losing at it?‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly.‚Äù

Remus is quiet for a minute, watching James. ‚ÄúHas it occurred to you that therapy isn‚Äôt something you win or lose?‚Äù

James scoffs. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, that might be your first problem.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh there‚Äôs more than one? Goody.‚Äù

Remus smiles dryly. ‚ÄúTell me James, how exactly does one win at therapy?‚Äù

James shifts his glare from the floor to his mate, who laughs, holding his hands up in surrender.

‚ÄúListen, you said it, I‚Äôm just asking. Cause honestly, I have no idea.‚Äù

James grumbles, trying to figure out exactly what it is that stops him from being‚Ä¶a hundred percent honest in these sessions. That makes him recoil at the idea of telling Katherine exactly how he feels, exactly what he‚Äôs done.

‚ÄúYou‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know, you show them that you‚Äôre not‚Ä¶broken. That they can‚Äôt fix you. That you can do it yourself.‚Äù James stares resolutely out the window, not willing to look at Remus, not willing to admit that he knows how ridiculous that sounds. Eventually he sighs.

‚ÄúYou know, my parents? They never fought. Not once. They were never mean to one another, never hurt one another, they never did anything worth fighting about. They were just‚Ä¶disgustingly in love. I think it might have fucked me up a bit honestly, seeing two people love that perfectly,‚Äù he blows out a breath, aware of Remus‚Äôs eyes on him, of the way he‚Äôs listening intently. Remus has always been a good listener.

‚ÄúI want to be like that, you know? But it feels like the way that I love is just‚Ä¶all it does is make everyone‚Äôs lives harder. It‚Äôs too much. It‚Äôs too loud. Too overwhelming. I can‚Äôt seem to rein it in. I do it all wrong. I love people all wrong. Or something‚Äîfuck‚Äîignore me, I‚Äôm talking rubbish,‚Äù he mutters, shaking his head.¬†

Remus keeps watching him, long enough that James starts to fidget. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know what they didn‚Äôt tell you James,‚Äù he says gently. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know what their marriage was like behind closed doors. I don‚Äôt think‚Äî‚Äù he cuts himself off, biting his lower lip. ‚ÄúI mean, I‚Äôm no expert, but I don‚Äôt think anyone loves perfectly. Fuck, I don‚Äôt think anything that actually exists in real life is perfect.‚Äù¬†

James frowns. ‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù but he‚Äôs not sure he agrees.

There‚Äôs something sad in Remus‚Äôs eyes that James can‚Äôt stand, so he drops his gaze back down to the floor.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù Remus says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay to be broken sometimes. After everything we‚Äôve been through‚Ä¶I think we get to be a little broken.‚Äù

James doesn‚Äôt bother pointing out that he and Remus have not been through the same things. That Remus‚Äôs life has been, by any measurement, far more difficult.

‚ÄúWhat if‚Äî‚Äú he stops himself, taking a deep breath. ‚ÄúWhat if I can‚Äôt be me and be broken?‚Äù

Remus‚Äôs eyes widen but he still takes his time before he speaks. ‚ÄúWhat if that‚Äôs the only way you can be you?‚Äù

James huffs out a laugh. ‚ÄúMerlin, this is getting too fucking philosophical.‚Äù

Remus grins. ‚ÄúA bit yeah,‚Äù and then, more sincerely. ‚ÄúNeeding therapy doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôve lost James. Doesn‚Äôt mean you love any worse than anyone else. So just, y‚Äôknow, maybe let your guard down a little yeah? It might actually help.‚Äù

James sighs, dropping his head back against the sofa. ‚ÄúFine. I‚Äôll‚Ä¶try.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood boy.‚Äù

He rolls his eyes, kicking Remus who kicks him back.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôre you and Pads doing then? Things‚Ä¶better?‚Äù

Remus grimaces, tilting his head from side to side. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know. I get the feeling he‚Äôs holding himself back. Which‚Ä¶is fair I guess. No use getting comfortable with someone who‚Äôs constantly disappearing for weeks at a time. But‚Ä¶‚Äù

"You hate it?‚Äù

Remus laughs without much humour. ‚ÄúI fucking hate it. Makes me want to break things most days,‚Äù he lets out a weary breath, pinching the bridge of his nose. ‚ÄúI just keep thinking‚Äîwhen this war is over, we‚Äôll be okay. We just have to make it out of this. We just have to survive that long. Because I know we‚Äôre meant to be together, I just fucking do. But not‚Ä¶like this. So if we can just hold our breath a little longer‚Ä¶except it‚Äôs hard to see an end these days isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

He looks up at James who feels his chest grow tight. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt feels like we‚Äôre just gonna be trapped like this forever.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat,‚Äù James agrees, ‚Äúor we‚Äôll, you know, die.‚Äù

Remus lets out a startled laugh. ‚ÄúFuck me, that‚Äôs morbid. You really do need therapy.‚Äù

‚ÄúOi!‚Äù James smacks Remus with one of the sofa pillows, which Remus promptly rips out of his hands and hits him back with.

¬†

¬†

When James gets home he can hear the sound of Lily‚Äôs record player. He stands at the bottom of the stairs for a minute, taking a deep breath and trying to gather his courage. It‚Äôs dark out, most of the lights in the house off, though as he climbs up to the second floor he can see the warm glow spilling out from under their bedroom door. Or, at least, what used to be their bedroom.

He knocks. ‚ÄúCan I come in?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a pause, and he wonders if maybe she didn‚Äôt hear him, but then:

‚ÄúYeah, you can come in.‚Äù

Lily sounds almost as tired as James feels.

He finds her lying on her back on the floor, only the softest lamps in the room lit, giving the space an undeniably safe feeling. The song playing is by a Muggle band, James can‚Äôt remember the name but he‚Äôs heard them before. One of Lily‚Äôs favourites.

¬†

Well, I've been afraid of changin'

'Cause I've built my life around you

¬†

The haunting voice fills the room, aching with nostalgia.

¬†

But time makes you bolder

Even children get older

And I'm getting older too

¬†

James forces his feet to move, walking over to Lily and lying next to her on the carpet. They‚Äôre close but not touching, both staring up at the ceiling, the lyrics washing over them.

‚ÄúYou were right,‚Äù James exhales. He feels her turn her head but keeps his own eyes on the ceiling.

‚ÄúI was right?‚Äù she repeats slowly.

James nods. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been‚Äî‚Äú he struggles for a moment, a part of him desperate not to give up this truth, this ugly insecurity, ‚Äútrying to prove to myself‚Äîto you, to Katherine‚Äîthat I don‚Äôt need therapy. That we don‚Äôt need therapy. And that isn‚Äôt fair,‚Äù he sighs, finally forcing himself to look at her. ‚ÄúI told you I would go, I told you I would try. I want to. I‚Äôm going to‚Ä¶be better. I promise.‚Äù

She studies him for a moment, James unsure if the silence is a good thing or a bad thing until he feels her hand slipping into his. They touch so rarely these days that the contact sends electricity shooting through James‚Äôs arm, his eyes dropping down to the place where they meet. Marvelling at them.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Lily says finally. And then; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not just going to leave again you know,‚Äù and when James looks at her confused; ‚ÄúI walked away today because I needed space. But I don‚Äôt want you to worry that every time I‚Äôm upset now I‚Äôm just going to disappear for a few weeks. I made the decision to come back. So I‚Äôm here, a hundred percent. I‚Äôm not going anywhere okay?‚Äù

James finds himself squeezing her hand without even meaning to. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he whispers.

They don‚Äôt talk too much after that, just listening to the music, lying beside one another. When James wakes up in the morning, the sun slipping through the window, and finds himself still on the floor, hand still wrapped up in Lily‚Äôs, he can‚Äôt help but think that this is the first time they‚Äôve slept in the same room in months.

And something like hope starts to bloom in his chest.¬†

¬†

¬†

PART IV LILY

¬†

Lily never thought much about being pregnant.

She thought a little about getting pregnant.

About giving birth.

About being a mum.

But the actual being pregnant bit she never spared much thought for. It isn‚Äôt quite as exciting a daydream she supposes. It‚Äôs only now that it‚Äôs happening that she realizes what a mistake that was. That apparently there are lots of rules about being pregnant that everyone seems to know except her.

It‚Äôs because all those people have mother‚Äôs, whispers the cruel voice in the back of her head.¬†

There are lists of things she can‚Äôt eat or drink or do, and at least three potions she‚Äôs never heard of that she‚Äôs now drinking everyday. One of them is an anti-nausea potion and thank Merlin for that, because the term ‚Äúmorning sickness‚Äù is entirely inaccurate and, as far as Lily is concerned, far too cutesy for a condition that involves being hit with the overwhelming need to vomit at random moments throughout the day.

She feels completely ill-equipped to deal with being pregnant‚Äîthis thing that is supposedly natural. Maybe that bodes poorly for her as a mother. Like if she had a proper maternal instinct she would know how to do all this already. Honestly, Lily has no idea. She never asked her mum what it was like being pregnant. She thought she would have more time.

At least she has Alice.

‚ÄúThis is it?‚Äù Lily asks warily as they stop outside a shop in Diagon Alley with painted pink bricks and white shutters. An enchanted baby doll is sitting on the sign laughing and giggling.

‚ÄúYup,‚Äù Alice says, frowning slightly. ‚ÄúBit‚Ä¶much, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

‚ÄúA bit, yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want to turn around and go back to mine and eat crisps and gossip?‚Äù

Lily laughs. ‚ÄúYes, but I should probably get like‚Ä¶a crib at least? I hear those are important.‚Äù

‚ÄúMm,‚Äù Alice agrees. ‚ÄúAlright then, lets give it a go shall we?‚Äù she smiles at Lily as she links their arms. ‚ÄúMaybe the inside won‚Äôt be so‚Ä¶‚Äù she gestures at the giggling baby and Lily snorts.

Unfortunately, the inside very much is still so‚Ä¶

‚ÄúPink,‚Äù Alice says, a little dumbfounded.

‚ÄúAnd blue,‚Äù Lily adds. It‚Äôs like there‚Äôs a wall dividing the store in two.

Alice walks over to a shelf with baby bottles made to look like tiny butterbeers and a onesie that says ‚ÄúDaddy‚Äôs drinking buddy‚Äù on it. She scrunches her nose. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

On the other side of the aisle, there appears to be something with a tutu attached that says, in sparkling letters, ‚Äúheartbreaker‚Äù.

Lily can feel her anxiety mounting as she looks around the store. Whatever this is‚Äîshe hates it. But what does that mean? Shouldn‚Äôt she be excited to buy things for her baby? Isn‚Äôt that a whole thing? Why does she suddenly feel like she can‚Äôt breathe?

‚ÄúWhere did you get your stuff?‚Äù she asks Alice as they start cautiously making their way further into the store.

‚ÄúFrank‚Äôs mum mostly,‚Äù she shrugs, squeezing some teddybears as they walk by who growl playfully at them. ‚ÄúShe kept all his baby stuff so we‚Äôre basically set.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Lily hadn‚Äôt even thought about that.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure James will have a bunch of stuff, I can‚Äôt imagine his parents throwing out anything he ever touched honestly,‚Äù she smiles and Lily does her best to smile back, though she doesn‚Äôt think she quite manages it. Alice‚Äôs expression quickly dims. ‚ÄúHey? What is it?‚Äù

Lily shakes her head, looking away for a minute, allowing her fingers to trail over a row of tiny baby towels they‚Äôre walking by. ‚ÄúI just‚Äî‚Äú she isn‚Äôt sure how to explain. ‚ÄúI really miss our flat.‚Äù

Alice looks at her, a slightly confused expression on her face. ‚ÄúYour flat?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know it wasn‚Äôt anything special,‚Äù certainly nothing like the Potter‚Äôs cottage, ‚Äúbut it was‚Ä¶ours, you know? We went and saw it together, decided to rent it, filled it with all our crappy furniture and our tacky posters that didn‚Äôt even have frames. And it was, you know, a complete disaster of course. But every inch of that place was ours. The two of us. The life we were building together.‚Äù

She pauses, expecting Alice to speak, but she doesn‚Äôt. Somehow knowing Lily has more to say.

‚ÄúNow we live in his house,‚Äù she goes on. ‚ÄúSurrounded by his stuff, his childhood, his family. We sleep in his room. And I‚Äôm just slotting myself in. Forcing myself into a space where I don‚Äôt even know if I belong‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLily,‚Äù Alice says sadly, but she waves her off.

‚ÄúEverything is his. But I want this baby to be ours, you know? I want to look at this kid and see myself too, and not just the next Potter heir,‚Äù she sighs. ‚ÄúDoes that sound mad?‚Äù

Alice shakes her head. ‚ÄúNo. Not at all.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood, because I do feel a bit mad sometimes.‚Äù They come to a stop in some random aisle.

‚ÄúDo you have any of your stuff you could use?‚Äù Alice asks. ‚ÄúOld baby stuff I mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúDunno.‚Äù She has vague memories of cleaning out her childhood home with Petunia after their mother died, but honestly it‚Äôs all such a blur. She can‚Äôt remember what they kept and what they threw away. ‚ÄúMy sister would probably know.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou should ask her,‚Äù Alice says, not fully understanding how complicated that would actually be. ‚ÄúIt might help for you to have some of your stuff around, you know? Some of your life?‚Äù

Lily makes a noncommittal noise, stepping a little too close to a shelf of pacifiers which all the sudden start making very suggestive sucking noises.

‚ÄúJesus,‚Äù Lily jumps back. ‚ÄúLiterally what the fuck?!‚Äù

Alice is laughing and somewhere by the cash Lily swears she hears someone muttering unhappily‚Äîno doubt the shop owner coming to tell them off.

‚ÄúOkay, that‚Äôs it, can we get out of here?‚Äù she grabs hold of a still giggling Alice, dragging her towards the exit.

‚ÄúYour face!‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, yeah," she pulls out of the aisle and almost runs right into a woman in what looks like an old candy striper outfit‚Äîpink pinafore, white collared shirt underneath. Cleary the shop owner.

‚ÄúOh, sorry,‚Äù Lily says startled, stumbling back as Alice attempts to get herself under control.

The woman surveys them with an unhappy expression. ‚ÄúCan I help you girls with anything?‚Äù

‚ÄúActually my friend was really interested in those pacifiers‚Äîow,‚Äù Lily stomps on Alice‚Äôs foot, giving the shopkeeper a forced smile.

‚ÄúNo, nothing, thank you. I think we‚Äôre done looking.‚Äù

The woman doesn‚Äôt move at first, eyes running them up and down. ‚ÄúThis is an adult store you know, the sweet shop is another block over.‚Äù

With that she sniffs, head held high as she steps out of their way. For a moment Lily is too thrown to move. Neither Alice nor her are really showing yet, they‚Äôve put on some weight, but they‚Äôre wearing coats, and if you hadn‚Äôt known them before than you might not notice their bellies. It‚Äôs clear that when the shopkeeper looks at them she doesn‚Äôt see two expecting mothers. She sees children. The idea that they‚Äôre having babies probably seems ridiculous to her. Honestly, it seems a bit ridiculous to Lily too most days.¬†

‚ÄúC‚Äômon Lily,‚Äù Alice takes the lead, pulling Lily towards the door and back out onto the street.

It‚Äôs snowing now, Alice tugging her hat down over her ears as Lily follows her along the road. She wonders what it‚Äôll be like when everyone can tell‚Äîwonders if every time a stranger sees her in public the first thing they‚Äôll think is ‚Äúwhat kind of a girl gets herself in a position like that?‚Äù She supposes she should have had these thoughts before it‚Äôs just‚Ä¶everything‚Äôs happened so fast. But now she can‚Äôt help looking at the faces she passes. Can‚Äôt help wondering what they think of her.

Can‚Äôt help wondering what she thinks of her.¬†

‚ÄúThat woman was such a cunt.‚Äù

Lily is startled out of her spiral, unable to stop herself from laughing. ‚ÄúAlice!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Alice asks, grabbing hold of Lily‚Äôs arm as they keep walking down the street. ‚ÄúShe was!‚Äù and then, casual as anything, as though nothing‚Äôs happened‚Äîwhich Lily supposes, in the grand scheme of things, it hasn‚Äôt‚Äîshe goes on; ‚ÄúLets go to the Leaky, yeah? I‚Äôm starving. Plus I really have to pee.‚Äù

Lily laughs.

¬†

¬†

It takes her a few days, but eventually she does call Petunia. Asks to meet for lunch. Well, actually, she asks to come over but Petunia insists they eat out. Lily expects that has something to do with her not wanting Lily around Vernon. Considering what an unimpressive person he is, her sister is constantly afraid of somehow falling short of his standards.

It‚Äôs been a long time since they‚Äôve spoken, and Lily finds that she‚Äôs nervous as she walks up to the small restaurant in a suburb just outside of London. Hands fiddling with her sleeves.¬†

Petunia, of course, is early. So Lily gets to enjoy the distinctly uncomfortable sensation of feeling her sister‚Äôs critical gaze on her as she is lead to the table by the hostess.

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù she says to the woman as she sits clumsily in her chair, a menu placed in front of her.

She always feels big and loud and awkward around Petunia, who is none of those things. If the word ‚Äúdainty‚Äù was a person it would be Lily‚Äôs sister.

‚ÄúYou made it,‚Äù Petunia says flatly.

‚ÄúOf course I made it,‚Äù Lily tries to smile but it doesn‚Äôt feel quite right on her face, and Petunia certainly doesn‚Äôt return it, if anything she looks suspicious. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Lily isn‚Äôt sure why she sounds so out of breath or why her cheeks are so hot. ‚ÄúThis place is nice. Have‚Äîer‚Äîyou been here before?‚Äù

‚ÄúMe and the girls come here for lunch every other Tuesday.‚Äù

The ‚Äúgirls‚Äù is a group of women Petunia has been friends with since primary school. Lily has never much got on with them. To be honest, she‚Äôs not entirely convinced that Petunia gets on with them either but they certainly‚Ä¶look the way that Petunia wants to. The way they dress and the places they go and the families they come from. Lily is almost positive that‚Äôs the only reason they‚Äôre friends, because otherwise she can‚Äôt think of a single thing they all have in common.

But then, it‚Äôs not as though she knows much about her sister these days.

‚ÄúGreat,‚Äù Lily manages, maintaining her false cheer. ‚ÄúThen you can tell me what‚Äôs good.‚Äù

Petunia gives her a long look before dropping her eyes down to the menu. ‚ÄúTheir salads are lovely.‚Äù

Lily does her best not to cringe.

In the end, she gets the chicken parmesan, because she likes it and can‚Äôt ever seem to figure out how to make it right on her own‚Äîshe‚Äôs still looking for a spell. Petunia does, indeed, order a salad.

‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶‚Äù Lily starts awkwardly, once the waitress has left them.

Petunia arches her brow. ‚ÄúSo?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow are you? How are things?‚Äù

Her brow does not lower. ‚ÄúReally? This is what you wanted to talk about?‚Äù

Lily shifts uncomfortably in her seat, suddenly worried she didn‚Äôt dress well enough‚Äîit‚Äôs not that this place is fancy but it‚Äôs certainly nice, and she‚Äôs only in a pair of stretchy black trousers and an oversized jumper.

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that what people ask each other?‚Äù she says hopefully.

Petunia‚Äôs eyes narrow. ‚ÄúPeople, maybe. But not you. You never ask how I am. I‚Äôve barely heard from you since we finished dealing with mum‚Äôs stuff.‚Äù

Lily winces, knowing it‚Äôs true. ‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs not like you‚Äôve called me either.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have a phone,‚Äù Petunia points out flatly.

Right.

‚ÄúWritten me then.‚Äù

Petunia stares at her. ‚ÄúAnd how would I send this letter exactly? By raven? Badger? Or is there some other creature you‚Äôre using these days?‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúYou can send me letters using the Muggle post.‚Äù

‚ÄúMuggle,‚Äù she repeats the word with intense dislike and Lily sighs, because she really should have known better than to say that.

‚ÄúOkay, look, I‚Äôm sorry I haven‚Äôt‚Ä¶been around. Things are‚Ä¶‚Äù how to even explain. ‚ÄúA bit dangerous in my world right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh you have your own world do you? How nice.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that the only part of what I just said that you heard?‚Äù

Petunia glares. ‚ÄúJust eat your pasta Lily.‚Äù She herself makes an angry stab at the lettuce in front of her. Lily vehemently refuses to touch her food out of principal. She‚Äôs a grown-up after all and Petunia doesn‚Äôt get to tell her what to do. However, after a few minutes of Petunia ignoring her, and Lily‚Äôs stomach grumbling, she eventually gives in.

They eat in silence for the most part, Lily letting the tension simmer down as she tries to work up the courage to ask what she came here to ask.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù she tries again, taking a gulp of her water, hands a little shaky when she sets it down, ‚Äúdo you know what happened to our baby stuff?‚Äù

Petunia stiffens. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù she asks tightly, as she sits back, dabbing at the corners of her mouth with her napkin.

Lily is starting to feel a little too hot again, tugging at her collar. ‚ÄúWell I just can‚Äôt remember what we did with it when we cleaned out the house and‚ÄîI mean, it would be nice to have, for, you know‚Ä¶our kids.‚Äù

Petunia keeps staring at her and Lily can feel herself shrinking under her hard gaze, the restaurant suddenly too full and too small, the clinking of cutlery making her wince.

‚ÄúI have it,‚Äù Petunia finally says.

Lily blinks. ‚ÄúYou‚Ä¶have it?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe baby stuff, yes, I have it.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù There‚Äôs something about the way that her sister says it, like a challenge, it‚Äôs not that that‚Äôs unusual for Petunia exactly, but Lily is getting the sense that this is something she‚Äôs going to have to ask for delicately. Petunia is never a fan of giving things to Lily, hasn‚Äôt been since the day Lily got her Hogwarts letter.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs great,‚Äù she goes on, smiling again. ‚ÄúWould‚ÄîI mean‚Äîwould you mind if I took a look at it? Maybe took some of my things?‚Äù

‚ÄúNone of them are yours.‚Äù

That startles Lily. ‚ÄúSome of it must be.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Petunia says pointedly. ‚ÄúEverything you had was mine first. So all of it, is technically, mine.‚Äù

Lily grits her teeth, doing her best not to lose her patience. ‚ÄúOkay, well, would you mind if I took some of it anyway?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes I would mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Lily demands. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like you‚Äôre using it.‚Äù

Petunia doesn‚Äôt say anything, and after a long uncomfortable moment of silence reaches for her water and takes a sip. Lily feels something itch in her chest.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not using it?‚Äù she repeats, getting the same blank stare. ‚ÄúRight?‚Äù

Petunia clears her throat. ‚ÄúI am actually.‚Äù

It takes several moments of stunned silence for Lily to process that statement. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre pregnant?‚Äù Her eyes go automatically to her sister‚Äôs stomach which is, of course, largely covered by the table. ‚ÄúHow far along?‚Äù

‚ÄúAlmost five months now,‚Äù Petunia actually smiles when she says that, placing her hands on her belly and now Lily can see it‚Äîthe roundness. Subtle, but there.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs,‚Äù Lily swallows, not sure why this is making her emotional. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs really‚Äîthat‚Äôs really great Tuni, I‚Äôm so happy for you, wow.‚Äù

Her sister looks up at her, beaming. Actually beaming. ‚ÄúSo you see, I‚Äôm going to be needing the baby stuff.‚Äù

Something tugs in Lily‚Äôs chest, her nerves returning. This whole conversation is so surreal. It feels like barely anytime has passed between the two of them playing in the park at the end of the street and now. Sitting here. Both pregnant. Barely anytime. Or maybe lifetimes. It‚Äôs hard to tell which.

‚ÄúYeah of course,‚Äù Lily finally manages, voice a little rough. ‚ÄúBut‚Äîum‚Äîbut do you think there‚Äôs anyway we could share?‚Äù

Petunia‚Äôs expression instantly shutters. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù she asks sharply, and then her eyes drop down to Lily‚Äôs stomach, which isn‚Äôt showing much, but enough that once it‚Äôs pointed out‚Ä¶ Petunia‚Äôs gaze snaps back up. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre pregnant?‚Äù an accusation.

Lily gives her a wavering smile. ‚ÄúSurprise?‚Äù

For a second it feels like Petunia stops moving completely, frozen in place, and then: ‚ÄúYou got married?‚Äù

Does she sound hurt?

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lily falters. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîno‚Äîit wasn‚Äôt exactly planned.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ Lily. With who?‚Äù

‚ÄúMy boyfriend, who do you think?‚Äù she bristles. ‚ÄúYou met him at the funeral.‚Äù

Petunia makes a face. ‚ÄúThe one with the horrible hair?‚Äù

Lily barely refrains from pointing out that Petunia is hardly in a position to be disparaging the looks of anyone‚Äôs significant other.

‚ÄúYes, that‚Äôs the one,‚Äù she says tightly. ‚ÄúSo I was hoping that‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHoping that what?‚Äù Petunia demands. ‚ÄúHoping you could swoop in and steal the spotlight?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe spotlight?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust take whatever you want and disappear back into your own little world, leaving the rest of us behind without a second thought?‚Äù

Lily makes a frustrated noise. ‚ÄúThat isn't fair.‚Äù

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she runs a flustered hand through her hair. ‚ÄúI think about you‚Äî‚Äú Petunia scoffs. ‚ÄúI do! But you don‚Äôt want me here Tuni, you‚Äôve made that abundantly clear, so what do you want me to do? Just come around every few weeks and let you use me as some sort of punching bag?‚Äù

Petunia shakes her head. ‚ÄúForget it.‚Äù

But Lily can‚Äôt. She leans forward, halfway across the table, trying to get closer to her sister. ‚ÄúI miss them too.‚Äù

‚ÄúShut up.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm sorry I wasn‚Äôt there when dad died, and I‚Äôm sorry you had to take on so much of the work when Mum got ill.‚Äù

‚ÄúI said shut up,‚Äù Petunia‚Äôs voice quivers.

‚ÄúBut I swear I tried! I did my best. I was just a kid‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAnd what was I?‚Äù Petunia doesn‚Äôt shout exactly, but her voice certainly raises enough to get the attention of the surrounding tables. Lily couldn‚Äôt care less but she instantly sees her sister‚Äôs shoulders pull back, her chin lifting.

‚ÄúPetunia‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThis conversation is finished,‚Äù she fishes around in her purse before pulling out her wallet and dropping a few bills on the table. ‚ÄúThat ought to cover lunch,‚Äù she says as she rises to her feet.

‚ÄúTuni‚Äî‚Äù Lily feels very small all of the sudden. And very young. And very very alone.

Her sister fixes her with a cold look. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt call me again.‚Äù

Lily watches Petunia walk away.

The last words her sister will ever say to her ringing in her ears.

¬†

¬†

Lily doesn‚Äôt go home.

Isn‚Äôt sure she quite knows where that is anymore.

She ends up sitting in front of her mum‚Äôs grave. She was always going to visit, of course. But somehow visiting has turned into hours of sitting, talking, thinking. This, Lily realizes, is the closest thing she has to an anchor. To her childhood. To belonging. Her eyes trace over the words carved in front of her for the dozenth time, finding no more comfort in them now than before.

She lets out a shaky breath, closing her eyes. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do,‚Äù she whispers, even that feeling loud in the empty space around her, the sky overhead turning navy blue as evening creeps in. ‚ÄúMum I don‚Äôt know what to do. I really need you to tell me.‚Äù She sniffles, wiping at her face. ‚ÄúAm I making a mistake?‚Äù she laughs wetly. ‚ÄúHave I made any choices recently that aren‚Äôt mistakes?‚Äù

Lily can feel the cold biting at her cheeks, she needs to refresh her warming charm but she doesn‚Äôt reach for her wand. Listening instead to the sound of the wind, to the distant noise of traffic a little further off. Listening for her mum.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù comes a quiet voice behind her.

Lily jumps, eyes flying open as she turns around to find James standing on the path a few feet away, looking a little sheepish in the lamp light.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù she blinks. ‚ÄúEr‚Äîwhat are you doing here?‚Äù It‚Äôs then that she sees the flowers in his hands‚Äîyellow daffodils, her mother's favourite. ‚ÄúYou remembered,‚Äù she says, before he can answer.

James looks confused for a moment before he follows Lily‚Äôs gaze. ‚ÄúOh‚Äîyeah. Yeah well, we were getting them a lot once she was in the hospital and I‚ÄîI mean I know we can conjure them but it feels better when they‚Äôre real. Anyway, sorry, I‚Äôm babbling.‚Äù

He hasn‚Äôt moved, hasn‚Äôt left the path, like he‚Äôs waiting to be dismissed.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing here?‚Äù she asks again.

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù James rubs nervously at the back of his neck. ‚ÄúYou said you were having lunch with your sister, but as long as I‚Äôve known you you‚Äôve never willingly spent more than an hour with her,‚Äù Lily snorts, even though, all things considered, it isn‚Äôt really funny. ‚ÄúSo when you didn‚Äôt come home I figured you probably came here. And when you still didn‚Äôt come home I figured‚Ä¶maybe lunch was, y‚Äôknow, hard. And maybe you might need some company?‚Äù

When all Lily does is stare back at him he quickly goes on.

‚ÄúBut I completely understand if you wanna just tell me to fuck off.‚Äù

She laughs a little, rubbing at her nose. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she says finally. ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs‚Äîthanks.‚Äù

James relaxes. ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù But he still doesn‚Äôt move.

‚ÄúWell?‚Äù Lily arches her brow. ‚ÄúAre you just gonna stand there or are you going to give her her flowers?‚Äù she nods towards the headstone.

‚ÄúRight‚Äîyeah,‚Äù James starts forward, placing the bouquet gently at the base of the stone before sliding off his backpack and Jacket, transforming the latter into a blanket. ‚ÄúHere,‚Äù he says, and Lily gratefully slides onto the soft material.

‚ÄúThanks, I should have thought of that but‚Ä¶‚Äù she trails off and James only nods, sitting next to her, not needing her to explain. She notices the purposeful space he leaves between them. He‚Äôs been good at that, since she‚Äôs come back. Somehow knowing instinctually that intimacy‚Äîall intimacy honestly‚Äîwould be hard after what happened. Letting her take the lead. Never initiating anything.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs in the bag?‚Äù she asks finally.

‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù

She nods at the backpack he dropped next to them.

‚ÄúOh!‚Äù James perks up. ‚ÄúRight, look at this,‚Äù he unzips it and pulls out a bottle, handing it over to Lily.

‚ÄúNow this just seems cruel,‚Äù she says as she stares down at the beer.

‚ÄúNo, no, look!‚Äù he points to the label, and Lily squints through the darkness to see the small words printed at the bottom.

¬†

Alcohol free

¬†

She stares at it for a minute and then up at James‚Äôs hopeful face. ‚ÄúYou‚Ä¶got me alcohol free beer?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna get rid of the other stuff when we get home,‚Äù he says, grabbing his own bottle and twisting off the top. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt drink, I can‚Äôt drink, only seems fair yeah?‚Äù he holds out his bottle and Lily taps her‚Äôs against it without even thinking. She watches with bemusement as he takes a sip.

‚ÄúAny good?‚Äù

James seems to consider it. ‚ÄúWell, as you know, I have a very refined palate.‚Äù

Lily snorts. ‚ÄúYes, very refined. What was it you and Sirius we‚Äôre eating the other day?‚Äù

‚ÄúPickle sandwiches.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the one.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike I said,‚Äù he shoots her a grin, ‚ÄúRefined palate.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh-huh, and what does your refined palate say about the non-alcoholic alcohol?‚Äù

James smacks his lips. ‚ÄúA good vintage‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOh fuck off.‚Äù

‚ÄúHints of oak and cherry.‚Äù

‚ÄúForget I asked.‚Äù

He smiles holding his open bottle out to her. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good, try it.‚Äù And even though she has her own she takes it.

‚ÄúWell?‚Äù he asks, eyebrow arched as she hands it back.

Lily wobbles her head from side to side. ‚ÄúNot bad,‚Äù looking down at the bottle in her hands she sighs. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait until I can get properly drunk again though.‚Äù

James laughs, the noise bouncing around them. ‚ÄúOne day huh?‚Äù his eyes drop to her belly before looking away.

After a few moments of silence she lies back on the blanket, looking up at the sky as the stars start to fade slowly into view. It‚Äôs peaceful and she lets out a big breath, trying to release some of the stress and anxiety that‚Äôs been building up in her all day. It only takes a minute or so before James is lying down beside her.

‚ÄúDo you remember,‚Äù she asks, still looking up at the sky, ‚Äúthat night I found you drunk in the back garden at Mary‚Äôs party?‚Äù

James snorts. ‚ÄúYeah, bit fuzzy, but yeah.‚Äù

Lily pauses and then; ‚ÄúYou were looking at the stars.‚Äù

She can feel the slight shift in him. The tensing.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he says finally.

Lily brings her hand up, rubbing her sternum, trying to ease some of the pressure building in her chest. ‚ÄúI thought it was Sirius who‚Äôd told you about them. But you said it wasn‚Äôt,‚Äù she swallows with difficulty. ‚ÄúIt was him, wasn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

James stays silent for a minute and then: ‚ÄúYeah, it was him.‚Äù

She already knew the answer so she doesn‚Äôt know why it still feels so sharp. Her hands gripping the blanket underneath her, eyes squeezing shut. She feels embarrassingly close to tears which she is blaming entirely on being pregnant.

‚ÄúThat night,‚Äù she manages, when she can finally trust her voice not to wobble, ‚Äúyou told me I was a force,‚Äù she feels James turn his head towards her but doesn‚Äôt look. ‚ÄúThat that was what you liked about me, not that I was beautiful, but that I was‚Ä¶god what did you say again? ‚Äî a storm.‚Äù She laughs a little wetly. ‚ÄúThat,‚Äù her voice thicker than she would like it to be. ‚ÄúThat meant a lot to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúLily,‚Äù he says softly, but she shakes her head.

‚ÄúNow when I look back it‚Äôs like‚Äîhe was always there, you know? In all these moments that I thought were about us, there was this other person there and I didn‚Äôt even know it.‚Äù

Silence follows those words, of course. Lily doesn‚Äôt even know what she expects him to say. But she can practically feel him thinking next to her.

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù his voice a little wrecked when he finally does speak. ‚ÄúI think he kinda felt the same way about you.‚Äù

That‚Äôs enough to get Lily to open her eyes, to look at him. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe always felt like you were the person I was supposed to be with. And I‚Äî‚Äú James stops, chewing on his lower lip for a moment, brow furrowing. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt see it that way. Not once. But I never stopped having feelings for you. Even if I tried not to think about it. I‚Äôm not sure that there‚Äôs ever really been a moment, regardless of who I was with, that I didn‚Äôt want you both.‚Äù

Lily doesn‚Äôt need Veritaserum to know that James means that. Now it‚Äôs his turn to shut his eyes, face crumpling.

‚ÄúGod, I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù Lily asks.

James lets out a shaky exhale. ‚ÄúI never wanted either of you to feel that way.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat way?‚Äù

‚ÄúLike you didn‚Äôt mean everything to me.‚Äù

Lily doesn‚Äôt know why her breath catches in her chest. They‚Äôre quiet for a moment. James still with his eyes closed, Lily‚Äôs gaze running over the planes of his face; the bruises under his eyes, the small curls of dark hair at his temples, the smudges on his glasses.

‚ÄúJames?‚Äù she says finally.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

She takes a breath, steeling herself. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think Regulus was a very good person,‚Äù because she has to say it, because she‚Äôs worried that sometimes that gets lost. And it can‚Äôt. It‚Äôs important to her that it doesn‚Äôt.

James‚Äôs face grows sad again, and Merlin does it hurt, watching his lovely mouth turn down, his eyes squeezing themselves more tightly closed.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù James finally manages, ‚Äúmaybe he wasn‚Äôt. But he really fucking wanted to be,‚Äù when James‚Äôs eyes open they‚Äôre damp and Lily can‚Äôt stop herself from reaching out and wiping the tears off his cheeks. ‚ÄúAnd that has to count for something right?‚Äù

She keeps her hand on his face, gentle, holding. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she manages, even though she doesn‚Äôt know if she believes it. ‚ÄúYeah it counts for something.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

They lie there for so long that Lily eventually falls asleep. Only partially waking up when James scoops her into his arms. She makes a sort of grumbling noise, not quite awake enough to form actual words.

‚ÄúShh,‚Äù James says softly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just gonna Apparate us home okay?‚Äù

Lily hums, burying her face in his chest as she feels the familiar dizzying sensation of Apparation. She‚Äôd forgotten what it was like‚Äîbeing held by James. The warmth. The strength. She really does love him a horrible, horrible amount.

‚ÄúAlmost there,‚Äù he whispers. Lily can feel him moving under her but she doesn‚Äôt open her eyes. ‚ÄúHere you are,‚Äù he gently lowers her down, Lily groaning and rolling over. She can hear the sound of James laughing softly.

‚ÄúLet me get your boots off would you?‚Äù

She feels him take off her shoes and jacket, feels the blanket being pulled back and then wrapped around her. Everything is vague‚Äîimpressions‚Äîdisembodied noises and sensations that her brain doesn‚Äôt quite process.

‚ÄúAlright, good night you nutter,‚Äù she feels him pull away and before she has time to think she‚Äôs blinking her eyes open.

‚ÄúJames,‚Äù her voice heavy with sleep.

‚ÄúWell look at that, she speaks,‚Äù he says lightly, pausing in the doorway.

‚ÄúCome back.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a beat.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Lily pats the bed next to her. ‚ÄúStay. Please?‚Äù

James hesitates, and even in the dark and her half-conscious state she can see the concern in his eyes. ‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm tired James, not drunk.‚Äù

He laughs at that.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure,‚Äù she tries to make her words as sturdy as possible. ‚ÄúWould you just‚Äîjust come here?‚Äù

That seems to be enough for him, she watches through the shadows as he takes of his own clothes‚Äîjacket and boots falling to the ground before he crawls into bed, leaving space between them as he always does. Lily lets out a little huff before reaching over and arranging him how she wants him.

James laughs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the big spoon huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúAlways,‚Äù Lily yawns, burying her face between his shoulder blades.

Enough time passes that Lily is almost properly asleep again before she hears him whisper the words:

‚ÄúI‚Äôve missed you,‚Äù into the dark.

She wants to tell him that she‚Äôs missed him too but she‚Äôs too tired, so instead she just squeezes him really, really tight.¬†

¬†

¬†

Gideon and Fabian are the first Order deaths that really hit Lily. All death is awful, of course. But she‚Äôd known Gideon and Fabian. Worked alongside them. Gone to the pub with them. Danced at Alice‚Äôs wedding with them. They were only a few years older than her.

And now they‚Äôre dead.

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù Sirius hisses under his breath as they watch the caskets being lowered into the ground.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James says beside him.

It‚Äôs wet and miserable and grey. Lily‚Äôs stomach too big for her to do up her coat, which makes her feel ridiculous. Marlene shuffles over, taking her arm and placing her head on Lily‚Äôs shoulder, sniffling.

‚ÄúThis is so fucked up.‚Äù

Lily nods, watching as the family walks up one by one, dropping handfuls of soil into the graves. She sees Molly Weasley, her eyes red, ginger hair pulled back as she carries a baby and a handful of dirt, whispering something when she reaches the graves that Lily can‚Äôt hear. Tears dripping down her face as she turns away.

Alice is one of the last people to walk up. She has none of the obvious signs of grief‚Äîface clean, robes orderly. But it‚Äôs that stiffness, that formality, that gives her away. Alice who is usually so open and loose, today is cold and tightly held. An Auror through and through. She‚Äôs one of the people who found their bodies‚ÄîGideon and Fabian. Sent after them when the brothers didn‚Äôt return. They think it took quite a few Death Eaters to take them down, they certainly killed enough in the process. Moody talked at the service about how impressive that is.

But Lily doesn‚Äôt think the Prewetts are much concerned with how impressive their sons were at the moment.

She reckons they would rather them have been mediocre and alive.¬†

When Alice is done and the graves start to be filled in properly, she comes over to them. Mary is immediately at her side, arm around her back, and that‚Äôs when Lily notices how pale Alice looks, like she‚Äôs ready to collapse.

‚ÄúHello darlings,‚Äù she says with a half-hearted smile.

‚ÄúWhat do you need Alice?‚Äù Sirius asks, face as sober as Lily has ever seen it. Him and Remus look like they‚Äôre leaning pretty heavily on one another. Each holding the other up.

Alice lets out a breath, her smile wobbling as she blinks the wetness out of her eyes. Lily wants to tell her it‚Äôs okay to cry but she knows Alice. Knows how much she‚Äôd rather take care of everyone else than be taken care of herself.

‚ÄúWill you lot come over then? For supper? Drinks?‚Äù

Frank isn‚Äôt there. As Moody put it, he couldn't give everyone in the department the day off. Frank wasn't happy, but he also isn‚Äôt one to go against a direct order.

‚ÄúYeah, ‚Äòcourse we will,‚Äù James says, returning her smile. ‚ÄúMe and the boys will even cook. We make a mean beans on toast, isn‚Äôt that right Moony?‚Äù

Remus rolls his eyes but Alice laughs. It isn‚Äôt quite the noise it usually is.

‚ÄúYeah, no, we‚Äôre getting takeaway,‚Äù Mary says.

‚ÄúI second that,‚Äù Dorcas pipes up.

Sirius turns to her, mock indignation on his face as he clutches his chest. ‚ÄúEt tu, Brute?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah okay, simmer down there Black.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a tension that runs under the conversation, threatening to crack the thin mask of normalcy they‚Äôre attempting to maintain. Each one of them looks delicate. Their brevity, their good humour, all breakable.

‚ÄúAlright, well, lets say our goodbyes and head out of here yeah?‚Äù Alice leans a little bit more into Mary when she speaks.

There‚Äôs mumbled agreements, some of them filtering off towards the family, the rest drifting down the small slope towards the front gates. As Marlene peels off to walk down with Dorcas, James and Sirius talking quietly already ahead of them, Lily notices someone hanging back by the graves.

‚ÄúYou alright Pete?‚Äù

He doesn‚Äôt look up, staring intently at the fresh earth like he‚Äôs trying to work out some sort of riddle. The wind whistles through the tombstones around them, blowing Peter‚Äôs hair into his eyes‚Äîit‚Äôs grown longer recently, longer than Lily has ever seen it before. She resists the urge to reach over and brush it out of his face. It‚Äôs difficult not to want to take care of Peter. It always feels like he needs it more than the others. Like without a little help he might easily lose his way.¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†

‚ÄúIf they hadn‚Äôt fought,‚Äù Peter says finally, still looking down at the graves, ‚Äúthey would still be alive.‚Äù

Lily blinks. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù

‚ÄúPrewett, it‚Äôs an old pureblood family. If they hadn‚Äôt fought, Voldemort wouldn‚Äôt have killed them. They‚Äôd still be alive.‚Äù

Lily isn‚Äôt sure what to do with that. After a few moments of silence she finally manages to work some words into her mouth. ‚ÄúYes, but then other people would be dead.‚Äù

Peter finally looks at her, brow furrowed. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúSomewhere out there, people are alive because Fabian and Gideon chose to fight.‚Äù

Peter considers this for a moment, before his eyes slide back to the graves in front of them. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know those other people,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúBut I knew Gideon and Fabian. Have since I was little,‚Äù Peter sniffles. ‚ÄúGideon wanted to open a pet shop, he was wicked good with animals. And Fabian wanted to paint portraits,‚Äù his voice cracks and Lily reaches out, squeezing his arm.

‚ÄúI wish they hadn‚Äôt fought,‚Äù he says finally, voice small. ‚ÄúI wish they were still alive.‚Äù

Lily doesn‚Äôt fault him for any of this. She knows well enough how careless grief can make you. Besides, who hasn‚Äôt wished something terrible at the deathbed of a loved one? Hasn‚Äôt wished that it was anyone else there besides them. Someone else‚Äôs mother or father or brother. Let someone else feel this pain, anyone but me.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù she says eventually, sliding her arm through his and linking them together. ‚ÄúLets go join the others huh?‚Äù

Peter gives her a small smile, though it doesn‚Äôt quite reach his eyes. ‚ÄúYeah. Yeah alright.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

It doesn't feel like they're trying to win a war anymore.

It just feels like they‚Äôre trying to survive one.

The difference is subtle maybe, but important. They don‚Äôt talk much about defeating. Just don‚Äôt die. That‚Äôs the Order‚Äôs new motto.

Don‚Äôt die.

Don‚Äôt die.

Don‚Äôt die.

It‚Äôs what they repeat over and over again the night Sirius shows up on their doorstep, Remus in his arms, bleeding. Unconscious.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt make it stop,‚Äù Sirius is pale, teeth chattering as James pulls him inside. ‚ÄúHe just showed up like this and I tried everything but I can‚Äôt make it stop‚ÄîI can‚Äôt make it stop‚ÄîI can‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúOkay Pads, it‚Äôs okay,‚Äù James says calmly, even though his eyes are full of fear.

‚ÄúThe kitchen,‚Äù Lily‚Äôs already moving down the hall. ‚ÄúPut him on the table.‚Äù

The boys follow behind her, Sirius shaking so badly Lily is surprised he hasn‚Äôt dropped Remus. But when he lies him down he does it with so much care you‚Äôd think Remus was made of glass.

Lily quickly steps forward. Remus‚Äôs shirt is covered in blood but it isn‚Äôt ripped. No entry point‚Äîno place where he was stabbed or shot or clawed. She waves her wand and his shirt is gone, revealing a clean gash cutting him open from his hip to his ribs. For a moment Lily is struck dumb by it, by seeing Remus revealed in this way. Peeled open like fruit.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Sirius sobs behind her, bringing her back to the present.

‚ÄúYou tried Episkey? Ferula?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúDittany?"

‚ÄúYes‚Äîfuck, I tried all of that shit James.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, okay sorry I just‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a cursed wound,‚Äù Lily cuts them off, eyes trailing around the smooth edges of the gash. ‚ÄúLike the one Frank had after your fight with the Bulgarians, you remember?‚Äù

‚ÄúShit.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do we do?‚Äù Sirius steps forward, eyes pleading, panicked. Lily doesn‚Äôt think she‚Äôs ever seen him look so young.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll have to brew a potion, and you,‚Äù she summons a towel from the cupboard and presses it into Sirius‚Äôs hands. ‚ÄúAre going to hold this against the wound. It needs pressure to slow down the blood flow.‚Äù Sirius is already moving to Remus‚Äôs side.

Lily turns to James. ‚ÄúGet me my cauldron and the potions book in your father‚Äôs study‚Äîthe green one with the purple spine.‚Äù

James nods, hand pressing reassuringly to her lower back before he goes. Lily quickly starts rummaging through the cabinets and drawers, pulling out ingredients‚Äîanything she thinks she might need.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt die okay?‚Äù whispers a small voice behind her. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt die Rem. I don‚Äôt want any of this without you. So just‚Äîplease don‚Äôt die.‚Äù

¬†

¬†

They say it too, when James and Marlene disappear for days, Moody unwilling to tell them where they are or what they're doing or when they'll be home.

Don‚Äôt die.

Don‚Äôt die.

Don‚Äôt die.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôll come back Lils,‚Äù Sirius reassures her. ‚ÄúHe always comes back.‚Äù

Don‚Äôt die.

Don‚Äôt die.

Please don‚Äôt die.

¬†

¬†

Or when Lily wakes up one morning with blood in her knickers. Hands clutching her belly.

Don‚Äôt die.

Don‚Äôt die.

Don‚Äôt die.

‚ÄúThere, you see it?‚Äù the Healer asks, smiling with her wand held over Lily‚Äôs stomach, the blurry image of a baby projected in front of them. ‚ÄúStrong heartbeat and everything. It was just a scare, probably caused by stress.‚Äù

Lily still isn‚Äôt breathing properly, eyes unable to look away from the image in front of her.

‚ÄúGod he‚Äôs getting big,‚Äù James whispers, their hands twinning together.

‚ÄúSure is,‚Äù the Healer smiles. ‚ÄúLooks like you‚Äôre gonna have a very hearty baby.‚Äù

Lily feels something tug on her chest. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure he‚Äôs okay though? Positive? There aren‚Äôt any other tests you need to run?‚Äù

The woman gives her a patient look. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve done a full workup on the pair of you, you‚Äôre both in perfect health.‚Äù

Lily nods, trying to get herself to relax. To believe her. ‚ÄúOkay. Thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù the woman‚Äôs eyes bounce between Lily and James before she says; ‚ÄúI‚Äôll leave the three of you alone for a minute shall I?‚Äù

Lily gives her a small smile, eyes going back to the projection of her baby. James collapses into the chair next to her, dropping his forehead onto Lily‚Äôs shoulder and letting out a heavy sigh.

‚ÄúLets not do this again, yeah?‚Äù

Lily can‚Äôt help but laugh, though it ends up sounding a bit more like a sob, causing James‚Äôs head to pop up.

‚ÄúOh hey,‚Äù he says softly, running a comfortingly hand through her hair. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay. He‚Äôs okay. Everything is fine.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù she hiccups. ‚ÄúI really do. I was just worried there for a moment that‚Äî‚Äú her voice cuts out.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù James says, squeezing her hand. ‚ÄúBut look at him,‚Äù he nods towards the image. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre taking such good care of him. He‚Äôs going to be okay.‚Äù

I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing, she almost says.

What if I‚Äôm screwing it up?

What if I never get better?

What if I always feel this scared?

She doesn‚Äôt say any of that, of course. Instead what comes out of her is; ‚ÄúHow can you love someone you‚Äôve never met this much?‚Äù which in the end is maybe the same thing.

James just shrugs. ‚ÄúBecause he‚Äôs ours,‚Äù as though that explains everything.

‚ÄúOurs,‚Äù Lily repeats, looking back down at her belly, free hand resting protectively on top.

Don‚Äôt die.

Don‚Äôt die.

Don‚Äôt die.

¬†

¬†

Sometimes, Lily will catch James staring off into space, eyes out of focus, expression sober. Sometimes she‚Äôll catch sight of a little red ball passing back and forth between his hands.

She‚Äôs never sure whose heart is breaking more in those moments.

¬†

¬†

It‚Äôs a month after the hospital visit that Lily is reading in the living room when a glowing white stallion bursts through the front door.

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù she drops her book, hand clutching at her chest as the Patronus gallops into the centre of the room.¬†

‚ÄúLily?‚Äù comes James‚Äôs worried voice from upstairs.

She‚Äôs about to answer but the horse speaks first;

‚ÄúAlice has had the baby,‚Äù Frank‚Äôs voice fills the room, Lily can hear James coming down the stairs. ‚ÄúIt happened fast, don't ask me how she managed that, but‚Äîyeah‚Äîhe‚ÄîI have a son,‚Äù Lily can practically hear the smile in Frank‚Äôs voice and she feels her eyes filling with tears because being pregnant makes her cry at everything. Not that she minds much this time.

‚ÄúHis name‚Äôs Neville,‚Äù Frank is saying as James comes into the room, eyes going wide at the sight of the horse. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs healthy‚Äîthey‚Äôre both healthy, both beautiful,‚Äù Lily thinks maybe she isn‚Äôt the only one getting weepy over this. ‚ÄúOkay, okay, I have to go,‚Äù Frank laughs. ‚ÄúAlice wants you to come see him though‚Äîtomorrow? Everyone will be here I expect. A proper Birthday party. Okay, okay, I really do have to go. See you soon though.‚Äù

The horse shakes his mane before dissolving into mist, leaving James and Lily staring at one another across the room, Lily sniffling and wiping her eyes.

‚ÄúThey had their baby?‚Äù James asks.

Lily nods. ‚ÄúMerlin he sounded so happy,‚Äù laughing a little. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt heard Frank that excited about anything since Quidditch.‚Äù

James smiles as he sits down next to her on the sofa. ‚ÄúSurprised he didn‚Äôt name the kid Quaffle honestly.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlice would never let him.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt underestimate Alice. She‚Äôs been known to go off the rails every once and a while.‚Äù

Lily looks over at him, eyebrow raised. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? It‚Äôs a compliment. Honestly, I don‚Äôt think Sirius has ever actually been on the rails.‚Äù

Lily laughs again, shaking her head and leaning into him. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre ridiculous.‚Äù

For some reason that makes James stiffen. Lily tries to move away but he quickly wraps his arm around her, pulling her back against him. She can feel him forcing himself to relax‚Äîbreaths controlled, like he‚Äôs trying to calm himself down. She wonders what she could have possibly said to set him off.¬† And she has no idea how to ask without making it worse.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have a name,‚Äù James says finally. It‚Äôs so not what Lily was expecting that it takes her a few minutes to really understand him.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù she says when it finally hits her. ‚ÄúRight, yeah‚Ä¶forgot about that.‚Äù

That makes James laugh, easing the tension out of his shoulders. ‚ÄúWe could just call it baby?‚Äù

Lily snorts. ‚ÄúNo we absolutely could not.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat about kid? Kid is a great name!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy do I feel like I‚Äôm going to have to explain to you the difference between naming and labeling? Also in what world is kid a great name?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh come on! ‚ÄòHey kid! Over here kid! What‚Äôre you doing kid?‚Äô rolls right off the tongue. Very catchy. Very versatile.‚Äù

Lily shakes her head, punching him lightly in the chest. ‚ÄúWe need to come up with a proper name for him.‚Äù

‚ÄúUgh, proper, that sounds terrible.‚Äù

‚ÄúSays James Potter, that‚Äôs the most proper English name I‚Äôve ever heard.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh sorry Lily Evans, if only my parents had gone with something more adventurous like naming me after a flower.‚Äù

She pinches his side and he messes up her hair, the pair wrestling on the sofa until Lily eventually finds herself on top.

‚ÄúAlright, alright, cease fire,‚Äù she pins his arms over his head, James‚Äôs bright eyes staring up at her, all earlier awkwardness forgotten. Before she can help herself she dips down and kisses his mouth. Quick. Chaste. Still, when she pulls back he smiles dopily at her.

‚ÄúOur son needs a real name.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre very picky for someone who didn‚Äôt even remember naming was a thing until five minutes ago.‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes, sitting back and blowing a strand of hair out of her face. ‚ÄúWhat about Fleamont?‚Äù

James pauses, expression growing serious as he straightens out his glasses.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôd‚Ä¶want that,‚Äù he says finally. ‚ÄúFleamont will always be my dad, you know?‚Äù

Lily nods, because she does know. ‚ÄúI feel the same way about my father‚Äôs name,‚Äù she sighs, running a hand through her hair and looking out at the room. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want him to spend his whole life being compared to a ghost.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù James agrees. ‚ÄúYeah, totally.‚Äù

James‚Äôs stomach interrupts the moment with an absurdly loud growl.

‚ÄúOof, okay,‚Äù he gets off the sofa and offers Lily his hand. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt think on an empty stomach. We can brainstorm names after we eat. You good with spaghetti?‚Äù

Lily smiles. ‚ÄúYeah, alright. I‚Äôm gonna put on some music.‚Äù

James taps his nose. ‚ÄúGood thinking, that‚Äôs bound to give us tons of baby names,‚Äù Lily shakes her head as he starts walking towards the kitchen. ‚ÄúOi! What‚Äôs that Muggle singer you like? The one who dances like a possessed scarecrow?‚Äù

Lily snorts. ‚ÄúMick Jagger?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the one!‚Äù James shouts from the other room. ‚ÄúJagger‚Äôs not a bad name.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely not!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?! Who wouldn‚Äôt want to be friends with Jagger Potter!‚Äù

Lily rolls her eyes as she walks up to their bedroom. She never bothers moving the record player, not when she can just magic the sound into any room she wants it in. She bends over to start flipping through her albums when an ache radiates through her lower back.

‚ÄúUgh,‚Äù she pauses, hand resting on the wall as she breathes through it. She‚Äôs so big at this point that just walking up the stairs does her in. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt take this the wrong way,‚Äù she whispers, looking down at her belly. ‚ÄúBut you really suck sometimes.‚Äù

As if in response, she feels a small kick somewhere far too close to her bladder. ‚ÄúCheeky,‚Äù she murmurs, reaching for her records again. She skips over the Stones, not wanting to encourage James, looking for something slower‚ÄîElla Fitzgerald or Peggy Lee or Otis Redding.

‚ÄúAh ha!‚Äù she pulls out her copy of At Last! accidentally grabbing the record behind it as well, which she proceeds to drop on the floor.

Lily groans. The floor has become enemy number one. Nothing is quite so bothersome these days as having to pick things up. She considers just leaving the record for James to get later but then it registers with her what it is.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù she stops, staring at it for a moment before clumsily bending down and picking it up. It‚Äôs older and rougher looking than most of her collection. ‚ÄúHello,‚Äù she runs her hand over the cover.

Lily very much believes in fate when it comes to music. That every once and a while a song plays at just the right time, in just the right place, for just the right people, because it was meant to. Because they needed to hear it. To mend hearts or break hearts or topple empires. Music, as far as she‚Äôs concerned, is the purest form of magic.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs this one?‚Äù James asks when she comes into the kitchen, groaning when she sits down at the table. Her lower back is being a right little bastard. A gentle pulsing pain pushing against her spine.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve heard it before,‚Äù James continues, waving his wand just in time to stop the pot of water from boiling over on the stovetop.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my dad‚Äôs, I got it when we were cleaning out my parents house,‚Äù she closes her eyes for a moment, listening to the song‚Äîthe big band sound, the intricate trumpet. It reminds her so much of her childhood she can practically taste it.

‚ÄúSounds kind of sad,‚Äù James says, causing Lily to open her eyes. Her hand goes to her stomach, rubbing slow, comforting circles.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not. Actually, it‚Äôs rather happy.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh yeah?‚Äù James places the pasta in the water before turning to face her, leaning against the counter and giving her a look clearly meant to indicate that he‚Äôs listening. Ready for more.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs supposed to be someone welcoming their lover home after the war. It‚Äôs about all the time they have now‚Äîto talk, to kiss, to be together. About how much they‚Äôve missed one another, but the waiting is over. They‚Äôve made it through. They can finally be together. Be happy,‚Äù her voice gets unnecessarily choked up at the end and she coughs, trying to hide it, unable to hold James‚Äôs stare.

It‚Äôs all any of them ever think about anymore‚Äîwhat it‚Äôll be like, when the war is over. Honestly it feels pornographic, her daydreams of domesticity, of an average life. Lily blushes just thinking about it.

‚ÄúMy dad loved this song,‚Äù she pushes on when neither of them speaks. ‚ÄúHe used to play it when he was in a good mood and force my mum to dance with him,‚Äù Lily smiles at the memories. ‚ÄúOr if she was busy sometimes he‚Äôd dance with me and Tuni, we‚Äôd stand on his feet, waltzing around like idiots.‚Äù

Lily remembers her and Petunia watching their parents dance. Remembers giggling and thinking how silly it was. What she wouldn‚Äôt give to go back. To watch them one more time.

James pushes off the counter and steps towards her, hand outstretched. She looks at the hand and then up at his smirking face.

‚ÄúDance with me,‚Äù he asks‚Äîwell, asks might be a bit generous. There doesn‚Äôt sound like there‚Äôs much room for refusal. Lily still tries though.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be ridiculous‚ÄîJames, I‚Äôm a whale, I can‚Äôt dance.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre perfect,‚Äù he says without missing a beat. ‚ÄúDance with me.‚Äù

Despite everything they‚Äôve been through, Lily still feels herself blush at that‚Äîthe honest and sincere way he says it. She slips her hand into his and lets him pull her to her feet, the pair of them starting to sway. And yes, it feels a little silly, but it also feels very, very important. And Lily doesn‚Äôt know how to explain that.

‚ÄúWho is it?‚Äù James asks eventually.

Lily blinks, lifting her head off his shoulder. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs who?‚Äù

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs the song by?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù it takes her a minute to drag the name out of her sleepy mind. ‚ÄúHarry James.‚Äù

He looks at her. ‚ÄúHarry James?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

Something comes over his face, it reminds her of being at Hogwarts, the way he would look right before he was about to pull some ridiculous stunt or just do something absurdly James Potter-like.

‚ÄúHarry James,‚Äù he repeats again. ‚ÄúYou know, my grandfather‚Äôs name was Harry.‚Äù

Lily has no idea where that‚Äôs come from. ‚ÄúWas it?‚Äù but James is barely listening to her.¬†

‚ÄúHarry James,‚Äù he keeps mumbling. ‚ÄúHas a nice ring to it, don‚Äôt you think?‚Äù and then, cheeky grin on full display; ‚ÄúHarry James Potter.‚Äù¬†

There‚Äôs a beat of silence. And then, for whatever reason, Lily finds herself laughing.

‚ÄúWhat? Why is that funny?‚Äù James asks indignantly, the pair of them coming to a stop in the middle of the kitchen. ‚ÄúWhat problem could you possibly have with that name?‚Äù

Lily only shakes her head. ‚ÄúNo, none. It‚Äôs perfect.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äîwait, really?‚Äù

She smiles, going up on her tiptoes so that she can reach his mouth. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she says against his lips. ‚ÄúA bit of me and a bit of you. I love it.‚Äù

James kisses her back before smiling smugly. ‚ÄúWell, obviously, I came up with it.‚Äù

Lily is about to quip back when a sharp pain shoots through her lower body. ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù she hisses, grabbing her back and hunching over. The joy is instantly wiped from James‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúLily? Hey, are you alright?‚Äù

She gives him a tight smile. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she exhales, James helping her sit back down. ‚ÄúFine, just back pain, cramps.‚Äù

‚ÄúShould we go to St Mungo‚Äôs? Do you need me to call a Healer?‚Äù

But she shakes her head, those are the last two things she wants. ‚ÄúNo, really James, it‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

He kneels down in front of her, hands on her knees, looking at her with concern. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù

She smiles again, this time a bit more reassuringly. ‚ÄúPositive,‚Äù her eyes flick over his shoulder to the steaming pot behind him ‚ÄúNow go check on the pasta will you? I‚Äôm starving.‚Äù

James waits for another minute before squeezing her knees and going back to the food. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll tell me if it gets worse yeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù her hand is on her stomach again, making those slow circles. The last notes of the song floating through the room.

¬†

You‚Äôll never know how many dreams

I‚Äôve dreamed about you

Or just how empty they all seemed without you
